column2: MONTREAL, May 1 (AP) -- The resignation of Sir Edward Beatty as president of the Canadian Pacific Railway because of ill health was announced today. He becomes chairman of the board and is succeeded by D.C. Coleman, vice president, as president, effective immediately.
MOSCOW, May 1 (From Russian broadcasts recorded by the Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

The Federal Reserve Board, after weeks of study and preparation, is about ready to announce a further tightening of installment credit through amendments of Regulation W. For example, it is planned that department stores' charge accounts shall be paid up every forty days.

Joseph M. Schenck, the motion-picture executive and pioneer who was convicted a year ago of cheating in his income tax returns, will go to prison today, but his term will not be the three-year penalty originally imposed. United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa revealed yesterday that Schenck's cooperation and secret testimony had made possible the prosecution and conviction of Willie Bioff, movie union leader, and others.

FORT WORTH, May 1 -- Volunteering of clubwomen for war work was praised today by Mrs. Gustav Ketterer of Philadelphia, chairman of the war service department, who said that voluntary action was a factor in President Roosevelt's decision to call off compulsory registration of women.

PITTSBURGH, May 1 -- An explosion wrecked the plant of the Central Railways Signal Company at suburban Versailles this afternoon and killed eight young women, injuring eleven other employes. The plant was engaged in the manufacture of railroad signal torpedoes and flares.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Delegates of the National League of Women Voters ended their four-day biennial convention today with the adoption of a resolution which demanded that only public officials of high caliber be sent next Fall to the Congress that must determine the prosecution of the war effort.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The War Department is prepared to enroll 150,000 women in active noncombatant service immediately, it was reported today by the Senate Military Affairs Committee.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 1 -- A program of ballets and dances tonight ended the Eastman School's Music Festival. Works presented were "Juke Box" by Alex Wilder, "Night Clouds" by Wynn York, "Night Piece" by Kent Kennan, "The Winter's Passed" by Wayne Barlow, "Dance" by La Vahn Maesch, "Gold and Senor Commandante" by William Bergsma, "Step Into My Parlor" by Burrill Phillips and a suite from "Merry Mount" by Howard Hanson.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Disregarding the recommendations of Secretary Morgenthau and the anti-inflation program submitted to Congress by President Roosevelt last week, the Ways and Means Committee today voted to impose a 40 per cent income tax upon corporations reporting a net profit of over $25,000 instead of the 55 per cent requested by the Treasury.
BERNE, Switzerland, May 1 -Sprigs of lilies of the valley are still worn in the lapel on May Day in Western Europe as an augury of good luck, but the day has lost all significance since the war.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Indians stretched their winning streak to twelve games today by routing the Senators, 13 to 6, and took a lead of two and one-half games. Cleveland hammered four pitchers for sixteen hits, including four doubles, four triples and a home run.

While free trade is "perhaps a dream of the future," there can be a more logical trade relationship now between North and South America which will benefit both continents, David Dasso, Peruvian Minister of Finance and Commerce, declared yesterday.

LONDON, Saturday, May 2 (U.P.) -- Clear aerial photographs of Rostock, the German Baltic port that British bombs devastated four nights in a row, made it evident that no warplanes would leave the huge Heinkel works there for many months, the Air Ministry announced early today.

The right to the "pursuit of happiness'' asserted in the Declaration of Independence permits any American to "forsake his original name for another," even if the new name be that of a distinguished family whose colonial forebears helped to enforce and win that right, Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan ruled yesterday in denying the petition of four attorneys of colonial descent to prevent another attorney from assuming their name.

The nation is being deprived of needed skills in the war program because of barriers against loyal aliens, speakers declared yesterday at the annual conference of the National Council on Naturalization and Citizenship in the Hotel Astor.

Fishing tournaments are not expected to form a prolific part of the news this season, since there are not too many remaining on the schedule. However, Governor Edison's New Jersey competition apparently is meeting with success, for not only do reports received from the State reflect satisfactory results by trout anglers thus far, but the entries in the fishing contest reflect the policy that is being followed of heavily stocking the streams.
The report of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., for the quarter ended March 31 shows a net profit of $995,658 after provision of $3,950,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes.
For the first time in thirty years the Dutch Treat Club failed to stage its famous annual show when it gave its "Wartime Dinner" last night at the Park Lane, 299 Park Avenue.
Manhattan's Thursday night total blackout from Greenwich Village to lower Harlem won warm praise yesterday from municipal and Army authorities.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- With hot weather just setting in, the war caught up with the ice cream industry today.

MEXICO CITY, May 1 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho espoused the cause of the democracies and lauded former President Lazaro Cardenas's oil expropriation as a "patriotic" act in addressing about 100,000 workers at the Zocalo this afternoon in commemoration of the country's Labor Day.

LONDON, May 1 -- Business on the Stock Exchange was very quiet today but a steady tone was maintained. A further rise of 10s in Cable Wireless ordinary stock to 55 brought the total rise this week to 410s. The stock is now 9 above the low level touched in March.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Senate's drive for practical economy in nonwar expenditures bogged down today as consideration of the $2,125,000,000 appropriation bill for the Independent Offices and Agencies developed into a major fight over the Tennessee Valley Authority.

The hit-and-run auto killing of Miss Dorothy Brady, 16 years old, a secretary, of 193 King Street, Great Kills, S.I., and serious injury to her 19-year-old sister, Mrs. Eleanor Cannon of the same address, was believed by the police to have been solved yesterday when they arrested Michael Schiavone, 19, a chauffeur, of 570 Caswell Avenue, Graniteville, as the operator of the car.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Plans to register women for war service have been abandoned temporarily, President Roosevelt said today. He cited a report from Paul V. McNutt, director of the War Manpower Commission, that there was no present need for such a mobilization.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 2 -- Victorious over Harry M. Jones of Homestead, Pa., in a shoot-off, Wilbert C. Saunders of Woodbury, N.J., today won the amateur championship of America at sixteen-yard clay targets to highlight the annual title meet at the New York A.C. Travers Island traps.

Here are two amusing picture books that both children and adults will cordially welcome not only for their gay colors, the liveliness of the creatures depicted and the brisk little text but because they provide something for chfidren to do, and that without the need for scissors or paste.

Since vacations promise to be severely limited this year, stay-at-homes are planning to make the most of their terraces and backyard gardens. Even the smallest outdoor space has unrealized possibilities. Furniture for porch and terrace, for example, is now as comfortable as indoor chairs and sofas.

A TWO-YEAR-OLD loves to turn the pages of a magazine, to gaze at pictures, identifying "car," "airplane," "doggie," according to his own particular enthusiasm of the moment. And he goes on from here, looking at his own picture books, learning rhymes and jingles, lining his alphabet blocks right side up, and recognizing letters and words.

GRACE ZARING STONE, a very spirited writer, answered a comment that her novel "Escape" -- the authorship of which was so long secret -- had been rather "slickly" written, which was to say as though to meet the requirements of a magazine.

The tenth annual Campus Day will be held today at Manhattan College in Riverdale, it was announced by Joseph J. Egan and Francis S. Myers, co-chairmen of the affair. The event, one of the most colorful of the school year, usually attracts more than 2,500 parents and friends of undergraduates.

More than 200 men with seafaring experience on local WPA rolls have been placed to date on merchant vessels by the WPA Division of Training and Re-employment as one phase of a program which is supplying trained men to build and to operate ships during the war, it was announced yesterday by Major Irving V.A. Huie, WPA Administrator for New York City.

A couple of torpedoes hitting a ship from Jamaica bound for England throw Janice and Terry into each other's arms, and a bomb over a country lane some months later throws Janice into John's arms. John and Terry are brothers and both love Janice, who has her own definite preference.
ALLAHABAD, India, May 2 (U.P.) -- A partial text of the resolution adopted by the working committee of the All-India Congress party:

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 2 -- Without good management and good labor, the vast volume of raw materials of our nation will be of no more use to us in armed struggle than sheer raw courage, William L. Batt, director of materials of the War Production Board, told graduates, faculty and guests at the seventieth annual commencement of Stevens Institute of Technology held here today in the William Hall Walker Gymnasium on the campus.

HENRY J. TAYLOR -- correspondent, economist, business man -- set out for a tour of Europe in the Autumn of 1941, and returned by clipper from Lisbon a few hours after Hitler declared war on the United States.

Spain is on the verge of sending a million men to the Russian front to fight at the side of Adolf Hitler's hard-pressed forces, it was asserted here yesterday by Don Manuel de Agustin, Marques de Aguiar, representative in this country for the Spanish Royalist (democratic) and Catholic Parties.
BERLIN, May 2 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Today's German communique follows:

The fall of Lashio and with it, sooner or later, the whole of Burma is a bitter blow, but its significance should not be exaggerated. It makes for retardation, not decision. Lashio is the western terminus of the Burma Road, but that road had all but lost its real efficacy with the fall of Rangoon, port of entry for the supplies that flowed into China from abroad through Burma and into Yunnan to Chungking.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Even in wartime, when he is bowed down with major problems, citizens feel free to write to the President of the United States, and the White House mail, which at times hits 10,000 letters a day, seldom goes below 2,000 or 3,000 missives daily.

BY vivid on-the-spot reporting and by effective dramatization of the war's problems and issues, radio broadcasting has been establishing new levels of achievement. But I wonder if, in one respect, radio is not failing in its job -- to wit, in its handling of regular news programs.

Clarifying some of the fundamental questions involved in sugar rationing the Office for Emergency Management has just made public the answers to numerous inquiries received daily by the Field Offices of the War Production Board, the Office of Price Administration and other Office for Emergency Management agencies.

If it is still true that "a penny saved is a penny earned," then the two-billion-dollar economy proposal of Senator Byrd would, if adopted by Congress and approved by the President, amount to a gift of $23.20 for every man and woman in the United States 21 or older.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 2 -- Hammering four Princeton pitchers for twelve hits, the Fort Dix baseball team scored an easy 10-3 triumph on University Field today.

Nothing brings more interest and diversity to the small garden than a well-placed wall fountain. If this drips into a bowl, which in turn overflows into a pool, the effect is greatly increased. Water in motion adds life and charm to any garden.

GENERAL MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, Australia, May 2 (U.P.) -- Japanese airplanes and long-range guns are continuing a ferocious, almost continuous attack on Corregidor fortress in Manila Bay. General Douglas MacArthur said today in his general headquarters communique.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 2 -- The railroads and trucking companies so far have done a far better job than in the last war when the government was forced to step in to improve operations, Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, said here tonight.

The Continental Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, valued yesterday the collateral back of the 5 per cent bonds, due 1942, of the Alleghany Corporation at $22,212,109, including $63 in cash. This is equivalent to 102.5 per cent of the $21,661,000 principal amount of this issue outstanding and compares with 127.1 per cent on Feb. 1, the previous quarterly appraisal date.

RICHMOND, Va., May 2 -- Dr. Peter Kapitza of Moscow, one of the U.S.S.R.'s greatest scientists, has just won a patent (No. 2,280,585) here for an apparatus for cooling gases to extremly low temperatures which eliminates the need of compressors in cooling and liquefying gases.

The most important years for growth of mind and character as well as for physical development are the ages under 5, the 550 delegates of the New York State Association for Nursery Education were told at their annual conference, which closed yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

What you do with your windows in Summer makes a huge difference in the livability of your rooms, especially if you live in town. One good stunt is to take down the curtains, leaving the walls bare and clean and cool looking, and to hang up rustic wood-slat shades.

As a tribute to the officers and men of the United States Navy, a dinner dance and entertainment will be given Thursday in the Hotel Ambassador Gardens under the auspices of the canteen division of the New York Women's Council of the Navy League.

Support for the cause of the United Nations in the war was pledged, with the hope expressed that those nations will accept their obligations to establish a just peace, in a report adopted yesterday by delegates to the New York annual conference of the Methodist Church at the Washington Square Methodist Church, 133 West Fourth Street.

PITTSBURGH, May 2 -- President Ford Frick of the National League fined Manager Frankie Frisch $50 for his part in yesterday's extraordinary demonstration in Forbes Field, but Onkel Franz must have written and mailed the check cheerfully after what his Pirates did today to the league-leading Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Office of Price Administration today issued three cardinal "Do's and Don't's" to the estimated 2,000,000 retailers in the nation to guide them in following the recent general price "freezing" order. Another OPA announcement issued today said that OPA would not "tolerate wholesale eviction of workers" from war industry areas in the hope of evading maximum rent regulations in the recent general price "freeze" order.

Since the War Production Board has restricted the civilian use of sponges from the luffa gourd, which have long been imported from Japan, the largest commercial producer, and since the WPB has also suggested growing them commercially in the United States, Central and South America, considerable interest is being evinced by local horticulturists.

This is a most inconvenient murder. In the first place, Lieutenant Bill Weigand and Dorian Hunt have just decided to be married immediately and are about to start hunting for a minister, when Bill is directed to proceed at once to the West Forty-fifth Street Theatre, where there is work for the Homicide Squad.

EVEN before we decided to arm ourselves to the teeth, we knew that all was not well with the American diet. A mild popular interest in vitamins which began twenty years ago has developed into a wave of nutritional reform. The health of the nation of the armed forces, of the workers in munitions plants depends on them.

HOLLAND, Mich. -- Despite the fact that the former source of supply of imported bulbs is closed, the annual Tulip Time will be held here as usual May 16 to 23, with domestic flowers providing all the color. The event will open with the traditional street-scrubbing ceremony by the residents in costume.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from Benjamin M. Anderson, Professor of Economics at the University of California, which makes substantially the same criticisms of the Administration's so-called "antiinflation" policy as this newspaper has made.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., May 2 -- A program of war sacrifice unequalled by any other British Dominion and by few other nations at war will be instituted in New Zealand with the passage and application of the new war budget, introduced by Prime Minister Peter Fraser in the House of Representatives this week.

SOMEWHERE in these embattled islands is the secret headquarters where high officers of the army, navy and air force plan and direct those recurrent sorties against the enemy-held coast of Europe which have come to be known as "Commando raids" and are causing much consternation among Hitler's generals.
BEAR MOUNTAIN PARK -- Without any appreciable lapse from your war duties, you can still have a very healthful -- and enjoyable -- day or two off up here in the heart of the Hudson Highlands.

Doing their part to relieve the national shortage of farm labor, eighteen city-bred Hunter College girls have registered for Summer work in the Volunteer Land Corps, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Dean S. Schloss, director of the college placement bureau.

TWO comedians in Berlin's popular Kabaret der Komiker tried out a new version of an old joke on their audience recently. It ran something like this: "Do you know that Herr General Field Marshal von Brauchitsch is writing a book?" "No, what is he going to call it?" "Six Months of Blitzkrieg Against Russia."

WITH THE ROYAL AIR FORCE, in Libya, May 2 (Reuter) -- Six R.A.F. squadrons returned to their bases in the Western Desert by the first light of dawn yesterday after the biggest night-out of the year for medium-heavy bombers of the Middle East Command.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 2 -- A feeling of relief has characterized this region's attitude toward the announcement of President Roosevelt that an all-out effort will be made to control prices, profits and wages. Worry over possible inflation and a runaway buying spree has existed here for many months.
Two member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, DeCoppet Berdan and Grant Keehn Co., were dissolved Thursday. On the same day S.R. Livingstone Co. retired as a member firm.

THE men and women of France crouch in cellars or hide in their barns, listening secretly to short-wave broadcasts from the United States. Many have built their radio sets inside the steps of their staircases or half way up their chimneys. At the risk of prison sentences or death penalties they are getting the news their Nazi masters, aided by Nazi sympathizers in France, are trying to suppress.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Irving Lipkowitz of the Justice Department's anti-trust division told the Senate Patents Committee today that officials of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) did not dare appear before the committee to answer his charges that their agreement with I.G. Farbenindustrie, German trust, had retarded synthetic production of acetic acid in the United States.

I HAVE been interested in the correspondence that has recently appeared in your columns about the value of prize contests for operas by Americans. Possibly a slightly different point of view may be of interest to your readers.

A free lecture, "Flowering Shrubs of the New York Botanical Garden," will be given by Howard R. Sebold of Columbia University at 3 P.M. on Saturday at the New York Botanical Garden. The discussion will be of value to all interested in making use of flowering shrubs in home ground plantings.

LONDON, May 2 (AP) -- Red Army tanks, smashing forward on firming ground against a Nazi Army that has not yet been able to get an offensive under way, are driving deeper wedges between the German "hedghog" positions of Bryansk. Orel and Kursk, dispatches from Stockholm said today.

Despite the repeated predictions that many small companies would be forced out of business because of shortages of materials, business failures continue to run well below those of last year, with the total to date 15.8 per cent lower than the like 1941 period, credit men pointed out yesterday.

Miss Helene Rains of the Women's Swimming Association of New York not only made a successful defense of her national A.A.U. 300-yard individual medley championship last night but broke the American record in the process at the start of a two-day meet in the London Terrace pool.

LONDON, May 2 -- As recently as February an official Nazi spokesman declared the bombing of British towns was not worth while; that the Luftwaffe would never again be wasted on that method of warfare. No amount of bombing of German cities by the British Royal Air Force, he said, would lead to German reprisals.

OTTAWA, May 2 -- Five months' experience of price control in Canada has proved that, as in every other battle, success depends upon the intelligence and force of the commanders and the spirit and discipline of the troops. And in these Canada has been fortunate.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Army service will start next month for some of the men who enrolled in the registration of Feb. 16. State draft directors received instructions from Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national director, today to include men of the 20-21 and 36-44 age groups in the June calls.

BOSTON, May 2 -- The prevailing sentiment in New England with respect to the President's message to Congress and his broadcast to the nation, and to the price-control regulations issued by the OPA, is that we are in the war and the sooner and the more completely we go all-out for victory the better.

After having tried for several seasons to grow Thalictrum dipterocarpum, with unsatisfactory results, I experimented, increasing their original requirement of "fairly fertile" garden loam to one very rich in organic matter, deeply dug, and well drained.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 2 -- The heavily favored Harvard crew won the varsity race against Princeton, Syracuse and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the Compton Cup regatta on Lake Carnegie today. The victory marked a perfect day for the Crimson, for the freshman and junior varsity events also went to the Cantabs.

Although transportation facilities have been listed as the chief bottleneck in supplying petroleum products to the Atlantic Coast area, the level at which the Office of Price Administration permits the oil companies to sell their products may be equally important as far as supplies are concerned.

With 8,000 elevator operators and service workers back at work in 800 Manhattan buildings after a thirteen-hour strike, the Realty Advisory Board announced yesterday that it would make any wage increase ordered by the National War Labor Board retroactive to April 20, the expiration date of the old three-year contract between the owners and Local 32B of the Building Service Employes International Union, American Federation of Labor.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 2 (U.P.) -- An announcement from German-held Belgrade said tonight that an undetermined number of high Yugoslav officials and British experts had dropped by parachute in the vicinity of Sarajevo, Yugoslavia. Two Britons and several Yugoslavs were said to have been arrested.

TOKYO, May 2 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Tokyo radio declared today that the 4,761-ton Russian merchant ship Angristroi was torpedoed last night by a United States submarine or one of its allies and left in a sinking condition off the southwest coast of Kyushu, southernmost of the main Japanese islands.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 2 (AP) -- United States service troops in steadily increasing numbers are in positions supporting the main British desert army and air forces ranged against the threatening German African Corps of Field Marshal Erwin Rommel.

For the first fifty years -- and color photography is that old and older -- the workers in color bent their energies toward the most accurate rendition of color as it occurs in nature. In their older forms, Lumiere, Finlaycolor, the early bi-packs and tri-packs were difficult and unpredictable at best.

The Foreign Trade Zone Board in Washington intends to license a second "free port" in the Gulf of Mexico to increase and expedite the flow of commerce through the Gulf area, according to Representative Emmanuel Celler. Mr. Celler, who wrote the Foreign Trade Zone Bill that resulted in the establishment of the country's first "free port" on Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- It is well recognized officially in Washington that the Free French movement headed by General Charles de Gaulle is primarily a military and not a political movement. There is no disposition on the part of the State Department to interfere in the internal concerns of this movement.

This is the story of Jethro Cobb and of the people whom he chooses as subjects for a psychological experiment. The time is the beginning of the present war. An ancient castle on the Irish coast is the place selected for the experiment, and to this place Cobb brings his human guinea pigs.

Increasing in number in this time of war are seals, labels and poster stamps to meet all purposes, chiefly serving the cause of propaganda and charities. Collecting them is the hobby of thousands of persons in this country -- a hobby closely akin to philately because the mails are used to spread the "word" and perhaps also because the seals resemble stamps.

ONE of the most diverse group shows the season has brought forth is current at the Lilienfeld Galleries. Seven American artists are represented. Most widely known of the exhibitors is Lyonel Feininger, whose recent canvases reflect a shift in his approach from the former planes of light to a semi-abstraction in which more diffused and heightened color and a more lyric feeling are evident.

Records held no awe for the schoolboy athletes competing in the second annual Public Schools Athletic League Relay Carnival staged at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday. Seven new standards were established in the senior high relay tests, three of them in the open division and two each in the tests closed to public high and Catholic high youths.

NORFOLK, Va., May 2 -- An eight-man Navy gun crew was aboard an American cargo ship torpedoed recently on the Atlantic, the Fifth Naval District disclosed today in announcing that all but two of the blasted ship's complement of forty-seven were saved.

A new design for living was unfolded last week for the 132,000,000 people of the United States. The design provided for a planned economy, war-induced, and would affect every American home. From now on American life was to be molded to the needs of a government engaged in a war extending from America's shores to the far corners of the globe.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Immediate readjustment of refinery operations in the East and Middle West to increase industrial fuel oil output -- which would mean a reduction in gasoline production -- was called for today by the Office of Petroleum Coordination in a new move to relieve the heavy oil-supply situation along the Atlantic seaboard.

General Henri Honore Giraud, French hero of two wars, who escaped from a German prison camp last month after his capture two years ago while in command of the French Ninth Army, was reported in private advices to THE NEW YORK TIMES last night to have been handed back to the Germans and then returned in custody to the outskirts of Vichy.

BOSTON, May 2 (AP) -- Coming from behind twice and aided by Ted Williams's fifth home run of the season in the ninth inning, the Boston Red Sex slugged their way to an 11-10 decision over the St. Louis Browns today to gain a split in their two-game series.

Despite the confusion created by issuance of the official over-all price-ceiling order, most markets were active, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

THE outbreak of war, like a sudden flash of light from a terrific explosion, has thrown illumination on a number of subjects previously ignored. It has shaken us out of old complacencies. One of the primary questions which it has raised concerns the patriotism and unity of the country.

With traditional ceremony, but in a setting less lavish than ever before, delegates of the Daughters of the American Revolution are assembling today for their Continental Congress in Chicago, the first to be held outside the national capital in its fifty-one year history.

LONDON, May 2 -- Mandalay, old capital of Burma, has been occupied by Japanese troops, according to a communique of Tokyo Imperial Headquarters broadcast today and inferentially confirmed by the British communique. The invaders, however, were said by Chungking to have been checked in their headlong rush over the Burma Road northeastward from Lashio. The Chinese reported inflicting heavy casualties on the foe at a point north of Hsenwi.

Under a decree signed by President Batista of Cuba, the island republic, one of the United Nations in the war against the Axis powers, is planning two series of stamps -- one bearing vignettes and inscriptions selected to direct the people's attention to the menace of fifth column activities, and the other to represent graphically President Roosevelt's Four Freedoms.

Filled with quaint characters who give hoots of glee or scornful snorts, according to the mood of the moment, this is a story of Cape Cod to match the author's "Clear Before Leven." Its heroine is Jerusha Ware, known to friends as Jerry.

Main floors were active in retail trade last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Dress, coat and suit volume was good, and activity was brisk in basement departments.

The numerous campaigns for the conservation of paper now sweeping the country have backfired as far as the industry is concerned and the decline in orders has been so steady in recent months that within a short while the manufacturing rate will fall below that of a year ago, reports in the trade indicated last week.

HONOLULU, May 2 -- Last Fall a ship left New York Harbor with 8,621 huge boxes, a group of Navy technical men and a few Navy physicians aboard. Some of the physicians were distinguished specialists who had only recently donned uniforms.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 2 -- The Northwest is taking all-out war, and all that it involves, in stride. To judge by the public response to the successive measures being put into effect from Washington these necessities were discounted in advance and are being taken as a matter of course by practically every one.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 (AP) -- Hal Wagner, who apparently has ousted Frankie Hayes for the Athletics' No. 1 catching assignment, took a stronger hold on the job today when he blasted a single with two out in the ninth inning to give the Mackmen a 7-6 triumph over the White Sox.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Roosevelt announced today that United States lease-lend aid would be extended to Iran and Iraq, key Middle Eastern countries, as an increasing number of unverified reports that the German Spring campaign might be launched within seventy-two hours poured in on Washington.
WEST POINT, N.Y. May 2 -- Army defeated Nebraska and Columbia in a triangular track meet today, scoring 78 1/2 points to Nebraska's 77 1/2 and Columbia's 7.
DALLAS, Texas, May 2 -- Federal price control and other parts of the all-out war program as announced this week have been received with approval by business and the public alike in the Southwest.

THIS intelligent and totally unpretentious novel contains, so far as the knowledge of the present reviewer runs, the first full-length portrait in fiction of Davy Crockett. "Wave High the Banner" is a novel, in the sense that fact and invention are discreetly combined to suit the purposes of the story teller.

Four youths, the youngest 10 years old and the eldest 17, stole an automobile at the Jamaica Race Track yesterday afternoon and a little later struck and killed an 8-year-old Negro girl. The body became wedged in the bumper and was dragged for three blocks.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Accused by Lowell Mellett, director of the Office of Government Reports, of "willful disregard of the truth" in classifying the OGR as a publicity medium. Senator Byrd asked today whether the Federal agency headed by Mr. Mellett, a Presidential executive assistant, was in fact, dispensing publicity, information or propaganda.

A year ago shad fishing by rod and reel in the Connecticut River came into prominence for the first time. By the time the run had been completed some 6,000 shad (by official count) had been taken by 3,000 fishermen.

Exporters, while generally pleased over what they described as the "liberal" provisions of the new price-control order affecting their trade, last week expressed confusion over the specific application of certain of its terms. Principal criticism of the order was that it appeared to have been written in the belief that export commission houses, export merchants and similar traders in the New York area handle most of American manufactured exports.

A HANDBOOK for city farmers, the subtitle calls this volume. The author, a farm consultant (and, among other things, secretary of the New York Farm Club), states a different aim for his work: "to disabuse the city man of many popular misconceptions about farm life."

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that the correct 1942 agricultural conservation payment rate for wheat was 9.9 cents a bushel. Such payments are made to farmers who comply with the department's crop-control program.
CINCINNATI, May 2 (AP) -- The Reds defeated the Phils in a dull ball game today, 4 -- 3, on Johnny Vander Meer's effective pitching.

Considering its members in the likeliest age group for conscription in wartime industry, the National Council of Business Girls of the Young Women's Christian Association is setting out to determine how its 60,000 working girls throughout the country feel about registration of women.
Americans were urged to rally to President Roosevelt's call for self-denial on the home front, as the price of victory on the war front, in sermons by rabbis here yesterday.

How a practical joke begun several weeks ago by a group of grease-spattered mechanics in a tiny garage in Red Bank, N.J., led the New Jersey Legislature to adopt a resolution congratulating a 58-year-old father for having all of his "eleven" children in the Army or in war work was disclosed last night in all its serio-comic aspects.
The fall of Lashio, gateway to the Burma Road, brought to tragic climax last week another campaign of the "too little and too late" class.

LONDON, May 2 -- Following an unprecedented meeting in which operating officers of the Royal Navy and flying officers of the Royal Air Force Coastal Command exchanged experiences, a scheme has been arranged whereby men of the cockpits and quarterdecks will change positions to acquire a knowledge of each other's problems in combating submarine enemies in the Atlantic battle, it was revealed today.

Leading for nearly every foot of the six furlongs, George D. Widener's chestnut gelding Overdrawn pleased the form players in the crowd of 31,315 that bet $1,621,125 at Jamaica yesterday, when he staved off the closing rush of Neil S. McCarthy's Augury to take the $5,000 added Jamaica Handicap by a head.
LONDON, May 2 -- At every ticket window in every railroad station in Britain today there is a large placard asking travelers: "Is your journey really necessary?"

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J. -- Sectional qualifying rounds will be held in twenty-eight cities throughout the country on Friday to select those who will come to Atlantic City for the national championship tournament of the Professional Golfers Association, at the Seaview Country Club from May 25 to 31.

A large but undisclosed number of plywood planes for training multi-engine combat crews for the Army has been ordered by the U. S. Army Air Force, according to an announcement authorized recently by the War Department.

LONDON, May 2 (U.P.) -- Moscow reported today that Soviet fighter planes had "harassed" Finnish defense lines and from Helsinki came word over the Berlin radio, that Soviet artillery on the island fortress of Kronstadt, in the Gulf of Finland, was "livelier than usual."

A 7,073-ton freighter, recently completed in an English shipyard and turned over to the Norwegian Shipping and Trade Mission for operation in the United Nations cause, reached an East Coast port last week in command of Captain Carl Iver Jensen, who at 31 is one of the youngest masters in the Norwegian merchant marine.

The boxes are coffins, and the three ladies who are destined to be placed in them are all exquisitely beautiful, each in her own peculiar way. They are dining at the Riverdale home of Senor Corrijo, a wealthy Argentinian, when a gypsy palmist prophesies that all three will be murdered within a week, but they are spared the suspense of waiting so long, for all three die the very next day.

ALEXANDER KORDA, who took a most direct route to London via a lend-lease bomber two months ago, is back in town after a round-about return flight via commercial airlines that totaled approximately 19,000 miles. Mr. Korda's presence in the bomber must be due to his friendship with British officials from Winston Churchill down, for the producer claims his only reason for going over was to settle personal business.

LONDON, May 2 (U.P.) -- The big British Lancaster bombers, in their daylight raid on Augsburg, South Germany, on April 17, upset Adolf Hitler's plans to increase his fleet of submarines for the Spring and Summer sea war by wrecking the Reich's largest U-boat engine factory, the Air Ministry said tonight.

Your editorials of yesterday and this morning express perfectly my own feelings regarding the policies set forth in the President's anti-inflation message to Congress and to the nation. If these policies are to prevail it will be difficult, if not impossible, for us to win the war.

THE Congress of the United States is unhappy. It was chosen by a people at peace who were divided sharply on foreign and domestic issues. Now the nation is at war and united sincerely in the desire and determination to win. Congress is harassed, jumped upon and blamed for things it has done and has not done, and for things over which it has no direct control, until it is in a state of jitters.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 2 -- An exhibition of American antiques and memorabilia, known as "Heirlooms of America," will open here on Monday in the Little Theatre of the County Center for the benefit of the War Fund of the American Red Cross.
LONDON, May 2 (Reuter) -- Results of today's soccer games in Britain:

THIS is an air war. The statement has been made several times and with varying degrees of emphasis; and it is both the defect and the virtue of what is probably the most brilliant book yet to appear on the war that Major de Seversky really believes it. No one has produced a more intelligent and comprehensive analysis of any feature of the world struggle.

Combined earnings of 203 companies in the construction, home-equipment and electrical-manufacturing fields in 1941 amounted to $316,287,834, compared with $264, 864,375 in 1940, a gain of 19.42 per cent, while construction activities rose 50 per cent to a level equaling the records attained in 1926 and 1927.

An apple orchard is a magnificent sight in early May, breath-taking in its expanse of blossom and awesome in its symmetry. Downwind, you can catch its fragrance half a mile away. When you see a whole orchard in full bloom against a hillside, you think that nothing can excel it.

The government is making better use of the American liberal arts colleges than it did in the first World War. While this fact is generally appreciated among educators it deserves wider recognition on the part of the public.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 2 -- With the announcement of the second Summer program in introduction to engineering for training workers for war industries, Rutgers University today issued a statement that 95 per cent of those who took this course last Summer had been employed in war industries in New Jersey.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 2 -- Four years of exposure to a Williams education have had a significant effect on the knowledge, opinions, and self-attitude of Williams seniors, according to a survey just completed there.

Geraldine Cashman is one of those jewels found among trash, a lovely, instinctively honest girl with an impossible family and associates. Just vaguely discontented with her job in a grocery, her home on the muddy side of the tracks, her coarse friends, she gets a glimpse of another world when she meets rich, young Holland, first name Vere, and very Vere de Vere.
STORY: Adolf Hitler's latest speech reminded Representative Wilbur Cartwright, Oklahoma Democrat, of a story. In his regular letter to the folks back home the Congressman told it last week, thus:

The State Charities Aid Association, founded on May 11, 1872, by Louisa Lee Schuyler, great granddaughter of Alexander Hamilton, will celebrate its seventieth anniversary at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore tomorrow. Members and friends of the association from all parts of the State will attend.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 -- The second string to the Greentree bow proved best at Churchill Downs today when Mrs. Payne Whitney's Shut Out drove home a two-and-one-quarter-length winner of the sixty-eighth Kentucky Derby to earn $64,225, the largest purse ever given in this old mile-and-a-quarter test which stretches back through Bluegrass tradition to 1875.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Just when Master Melvin Ott was beginning to wonder what he would have to do to strike up acquaintance with somebody who might do a reasonable job of pitching for his Giants, long Cliff Melton stepped out on the rubber today and turned in a gilt-edged performance to blank the Cubs, 1 to 0.

DERBY, Conn., May 2 -- The Yale varsity eight launched its season today with a beautifully rowed race to win handsomely from Pennsylvania and Columbia in the Blackwell Cup regatta over the two-mile course on the Housatonic.

CHICAGO May 2 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady today at the close of a wreck of sharp declines in the hog and cattle departments that followed announcement of blanket ceilings on wholesale and retail meals, except lamb and mutton. Lambs advanced during the week.

While the OPA price control order as issued last week made no specific provision for seasonal goods not on sale during the March base period and thus left both retailers and manufacturers here confused, it was pointed out that Canada last month issued revised regulations under the Dominion's price control plan which solved this question.

Fears that the distilled spirits industry, in undertaking to aid the war effort, would close out white sections of the industry were expressed in some sections of the trade last week. Despite an official assurance that only a few days of the weekly run of so-called "high wine" stills would be required to meet the government's alcohol needs, possibility that the estimate would receive considerable upward, revision was being discussed in the industry.

NORWALK, Conn., May 2 -- Gosuke Kwan, Japanese butler in the home of Dr. J.H. McHenry, was ordered today by City Judge Paul R. Connery to invest $75 of his monthly salary of $100 in war bonds every month that the war lasts because of his part in a fight with Eugene Nagy, Hungarian-born gardener on the McHenry estate.

Primarily this is the story of two brothers, Fred and Stephen Yates. Fred, the elder, is strong, handsome and gifted. Stephen is a cripple as the result of infantile paralysis and is embittered by his helplessness. He has a good mind, but has done little to develop the capabilities that lie within him, and he is given to caustic comments which are not calculated to endear him to others.

IN his sixties a poet's lyrical days are supposed to be over; that is, his verse is no longer the thing on wings that lyric poetry is. But here in "The Witness Tree" by Robert Frost is the lyric in all its intensity, indeed, with a greater intensity than the lyrics the poet wrote when he was young.
KUIBYSHEV, May 2 -- If the democracies owe a debt to the Red Army, a large part is due to those conscientious, clear-sighted and soldierly men, the political commissars.

Thousands of teen-aged boys and girls throughout the country, their patriotic feelings awakened by Secretary Knox's plea for 500,000 model airplanes, have been hard at work for the past two months building the world's military aircraft in miniature.

OMAHA, Neb., May 2 -- The war has been coming steadily closer to the Corn Belt. This week there was the forecast of a still closer association with the war effort in the President's seven-point program, announcement of Mr. Henderson's price list, and plans for putting the sugar ration into effect.
My only garden space faces a side street, where it is constantly on display. To make it ornamental as well as useful, last year I "landscaped" it with vegetables.

RICHARD W. KRAKEUR, one of the "F.S.K." incorporators, has purchased a couple of plays for that combine. In behalf of "F" (Vinton Freedley) and "S" (W. Horace Schmidlapp) he selected "What Would You, Ladies?," by Harry Timothy Madden, and "This Little Hand," by Wilfred H. Pettitt.

LONDON, May 2 -- Forced by bad weather to curtail its mass raids against enemy objectives, the Royal Air Force made comparatively minor sorties last night across the North sea and over them French coast. British bomber crews smashed a Nazi destroyer off the Norwegian coast and plowed up landing fields at various German air bases in Northern France.

THE lady who is haunted is Mrs. Eliza Fairbanks. She is an old lady and she does not like bats or rats, especially when they come into her bedroom. When she complains to the police, Inspector Fuller sends Hilda Adams to the house to see what she can learn.

At a recent tennis match on a bright, warm day here in Chapel Hill I was greatly impressed by the difference in the quantity of clothing worn by a young woman among the spectators compared to that worn by her escort, a young Army lieutenant all done up in olive drab and brass buttons.
CHICAGO, May 2 -- The Washington edict freezing prices as the newest step in the total war effort seems to have met with an initial welcome in Illinois and neighboring States.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 -- The dominant popular reaction in the Northern California sector to this week's price fixing and all-out war effort program can be stated substantially thus:
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Total casualties of the United States naval forces, which include the Navy, the Marine Corps and the Coast Guard, numbered 6.393 from Dec. 7 to April 15.

For thirty-six of the fifty-seven years the American Fox Terrier Club has been in existence it has been served as president by Winthrop Rutherfurd. It is fitting, therefore, that the sixty-ninth specialty show of this organization will be given in honor of its veteran breeder, exhibitor and leader in foxterrier affairs in America.

On the military calendar, in the Northern Hemisphere, Spring arrives with the first week of May. The season of greatest beauty, when the ecstasy of life runs through all animate creation, is a good time for generals to make their plans. Hitler and his generals have about six months in which to win this war.

While the factories of the land are coping with vast technical and administrative problems involved in the switchover from peacetime to wartime production, Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the new Man Power Commission, is faced with a gigantic task of human conversion.

WITH all the current emphasis on physical fitness, sleep or the lack of it. always a subject of wide interest, comes in for even more attention. Sleep and lots of it is doubly important now, we are told, so that one's nerves will be in a good shape and one's thinking as clear as possible.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt expressed doubt yesterday that the country needed more flag-waving or martial music to bolster the morale of young men going into the armed forces or to fire the civilian population with a determination to win the war.
Whether you read Mr. Garth's novels for the adventure, the mystery or the love story, they may be trusted to carry interest along all three lines. In this one the Nazi plot is the most exciting.

MOSCOW, May 2 (U.P.) -- This capital of warring Russia was ablaze today with banners inscribed "The War Must Be Decided in 1942!" when foreign correspondents returned to it from Kuibyshew after an absence of four months.

Gardenias are far from ideal house plants, yet their great beauty has long made them window garden favorites. Despite the gardenias' exacting demands, the amateur somehow has found ways to please them with the result that they not only endure but actually thrive under conditions only approximating those halcyon ones of the greenhouse.

LONDON, May 2 (Reuter) -- General Charles de Gaulle's entourage does not understand reports from Washington and New York of the "concern" shown by the United States Government over the political aspect of the Free French movement as a result of talks now in progress between the Free French National Committee's delegate in America, Adrien Tixier, and Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

Measuring the expansion of metal and glass during heat treatment is essential in the development of precision optical products. With the aid of the devenard dilatometer, an extremely versatile laboratory test instrument, W.J. Wrighton, chief metallurgist of the American Optical Company, is here shown measuring the expansion of metals caused by heat.

THE exhibition, "The American Way in Art," current at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts through May 30, was arranged to complement the special series of lectures now being given for members. The material for the exhibition has been assembled from the Institute's collection and from private collections in Minneapolis.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- In a debate today at the annual meeting of the American Council on Education Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of Chicago University, was criticized for his new "two-year plan" for conferring the bachelor's degree at the end of the sophomore year.

PITTSBURGH, May 2 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, stood before 200 members of his home local of the United Mine Workers of America near Bentleyville today and denounced John L. Lewis and other "enemies" who he said were attempting to force him out of the union.

Shares on the New York Stock Exchange extended their gains yesterday in irregular fashion and closed at the best levels of the recovery movement. The market, however, was the third dullest Saturday of the year.

TORONTO, May 2 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs and Jersey City Giants divided a double-header today, Jersey City winning the opener, 2 -- 0, behind the three-hit pitching of Johnny Wittig and Toronto taking the seven-inning nightcap, 8 -- 2.

The Army Emergency Relief Fund will be the beneficiary of an entertainment known as a Pan-American Coffee Festival to be held on Thursday afternoon at the Copacabana. There will be divertissements by stars of the theatrical and motion picture worlds, an auction, general dancing and a fashion revue.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- After a careful check of wholesale and retail prices the National Association of Retail Druggists hailed the fair-trade acts operating in forty-five different States as softening the impact of the price-freezing order for its membership.

An "individualized" physical education program designed to encourage the interest of America's young men in their personal physical fitness was suggested yesterday by Dr. George Gloss of Louisiana State University and visiting scholar at Teachers College of Columbia University.

Kresge Department Stores, Inc., reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 a net profit of $169,696 after depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges, or 45 cents each on 250,864 shares of common stock after dividends on the 4 per cent cumulative convertible first preferred stock. For the year to Jan. 31, 1941, net income was $149,431, or 37 cents a common share.

A relatively unknown N.Y.U. sophomore javelin thrower, Bill Waite, tossed the spear a relatively inconsequential distance at Ohio Field yesterday, but his 3 points provided the Violet with its winning margin in its annual track and field meet with Fordham, its twelfth straight dual engagement victory in the past four years.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 2 (AP) -- The league-leading Newark Bears went on a batting rampage against Buffalo for the second straight time today to notch a 13-0 triumph.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., May 2 -- Controversy over the place that the traditional history courses are to occupy in the schools during wartime has been brought into the open in Indiana where extensive curriculum revisions are being made.

VICHY, France, May 2 (U.P.) -- Pierre Laval, the chief of government, was reported conferring tonight with German authorities at Moulins over Nazi demands resulting from spreading outbreaks of anti-Nazi terrorism and sabotage over large areas of occupied France.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Attorney General Biddle's refusal to permit Thurman Arnold, head of the Justice Department's anti-trust division, to testify before a House committee on a bill involving questions of alleged labor "racketeering" was described by Senator Wheeler of Montana today as an infringement on the rights of free speech.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 2 -- Despite the bitterness that has marked the Presidential campaign that culminates with the voting tomorrow it is expected that the balloting will take place without disorders, it was said here today.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 2 -- The 110-foot submarine chaser, the PC-672, was launched today at the Walter E. Abrams Shipyard, Inc., of Halesite, the first submarine combat vessel to be sent down the ways from this yard.

STATED briefly, the idea behind the concert "Music At Work" was to have American composers, or rather, composers in America, shown doing their stuff, and aiming their performance at Russian War Relief as their tribute to the valiant fighters of the USSR.

In order to establish a basis for any adjustments that may be made in price ceilings from time to time, the Office of Price Administration has set up a reporting program which will require about 25,000 companies to file periodic statements of their financial condition, it was announced yesterday.

THE Metropolitan Opera's first visit to a university was such a success that the particular university visited -- the University of Indiana -- is already talking about having the company give three shows during its Spring tour next year.

Moving swiftly on the heels of Army complaints that dimout regulations were being disregarded, Police Commissioner Valentine directed last night that every air warden and the entire patrol force advise violators that they face a $1,000 fine, a year in the Federal penitentiary, or both.

From some point in the Eastern coastal belt of Australia General MacArthur looks at maps and surveys his problem of "organizing an American offensive against Japan" from the base of Australia. But before the offensive can begin material must be accumulated and the base secured against attack.

Statisticians sharpened their pencils yesterday, and with slide rule in hand began to figure what effect the proposed new tax rates on corporate and excess profits would have had on some of the corporate earnings of 1941.

Federated clubs in the first and second judicial districts will hold annual meetings this week, with Mrs. Guy W. Cheney, president of the State Federation of Women's Clubs, scheduled to address both gatherings. Delegates from the second district will assemble on Tuesday at the Nassau Athletic Club, Floral Park, to hear reports from Kings, Queens, Nassau, Suffolk and Richmond Counties.

New York's two club bridge leagues have completed their 1941-42 seasons and have announced the winners of their various contests. In these leagues, as in the several industrial and business leagues which play annual schedules, there are matches between teams representing the clubs and further contests for the best pair and individual records.

LONDON, May 2 (Canadian Press) -- Before a crowd of 41,000, one of the biggest since the war started, Arsenal and Brentford played a scoreless draw today in the semi-final round of the London War Cup competition.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 2 -- At least four new forest fires broke out in Western Rhode Island today and a resurgent old one threatened to bring about the evacuation of fifty to 150 families in the township of Coventry, name of tragic associations.

Driven from the mound in the first inning of the opener, when Penn counted seven times, Sophomore Bud O'Brien, Columbia right-hander, tried again in the nightcap and this time made good as the Lions split a double-header at Baker Field yesterday.

IN 1938 a story of Maureen Daly's, "Sixteen," was selected by Harry Hansen for inclusion in the O. Henry Memorial prize volume for that year. It was a very brief, very tenuous story -- barely more than a sketch -- but it had a quality of freshness and first-hand emotion which was only partly explained by the circumstance that the author herself was a 16-year-old girl.

UNDOUBTEDLY the news of the week along Radio Row was the disclosure that the War Department and the General Motors Corporation will launch a one-hour program over the Columbia network on June 2 -- a show to be called "Cheers From the Camps," consisting of amateur soldier talent in training centers in this country and abroad.

THE subject with which Mr. Downes's article in last Sunday's TIMES dealt has been the most vital one for me ever since I left the Juilliard Graduate School several years ago -- the subject of the young American conductor trying to find a place for himself in the musical life of America.

WITH today's performances at the National Theatre, Eugene Loring's new company, Dance Players, closes the first chapter of its career, and invites accordingly some sort of appraisal. Not at all a conventional ballet, although it makes use of the academic technique as its basis of movement, it devotes itself to the presentation of theatre pieces, with the accent on dancing rather than on production.

UTICA, N.Y., May 2 -- Thomas E. Dewey was assailed as "the Charlie McCarthy of the milk trust" in an address by Ray Thomason, regional director of the United Dairy Farmers, at a meeting of up-State organizers here this afternoon.

Dr. Carleton J.H. Hayes, newly appointed United States Ambassador to Spain and former Seth Low Professor of History at Columbia University, will receive the annual award of the Association of Teachers of the Social Studies of New York City for "distinctive work" in social studies, it was announced yesterday at the organization's seventh annual luncheon in the Hotel New Yorker.

INVENTORS' SHOW -- Erwin M. Frey, president of the American Hobby Federation, 330 West Forty-second Street, New York, is organizing an Inventors' Exposition to be held in New York from June 1 to 18 at the Sachs Auditorium, Thirty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue.

CHARLES KINGSLEY was a thoroughly stimulating teacher and he had the rare gift of inciting others to think for themselves. Having wide and various information and feeling a deep interest in the welfare of those around him, he became one of the most prominent men of his day.

The gardener who grew parsley, chives, and mint last season is probably planning a much larger herb bed this Summer. For herb gardening is a cumulative enthusiasm which increases from year to year. In the long run most herb enthusiasts reach the stage where they become collectors of rare items.

In a flurry of rehearsals, members of the Girls Service Club are making final preparations this week to give one of their many contributions to welfare work which is part of the year's program. The performance will be of a comedy written by members of the crafts class under the title "Shadow From Broadway." Proceeds will be divided between the Greater New York Fund and organizations doing welfare work with the armed forces.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- Prancer of Barlynn, Doberman pinscher owned by Cecil MacCoy of Chappaqua, N.Y., took the best-in-show prize at the twenty-second annual fixture of the Bryn Mawr Kennel Club, held at the Philadelphia Country Club today.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 2 -- Although it has turned over to the British the job of instructing the men who operate and maintain United States-made equipment, the United States military mission under Major Gen. Russell L. Maxwell is still carrying on its own projects and is making rapid progress.

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., May 2 -- Soldiers guarding restricted areas and big-gun emplacements on Fort Hancock were accompanied tonight by dogs that have been trained especially for sentry duty. The dogs were turned over to post authorities this afternoon by Mrs. Milton Erlanger of Elberon.

WASHINGTON. -- A twofold assignment to meet wartime realities faces the Eighth Pan-American Child Congress now assembled here. It embraces the safety of children throughout the Western Hemisphere during the war period and their continuing welfare in the era of profound adjustment which will in all likelihood follow the present war.

LONDON, May 2 -- The working committee of the All-India Congress party insisted today at its meeting at Allahabad, India, that invasion of India could be met only through "non-violent non-cooperation."

WASHINGTON, May 2 (U.P.) -- Representative Albert Gore, of Tennessee, said today that he would introduce a bill next week to "freeze" wages at current levels and to impose "ceilings" on farm prices at parity, instead of the present 110 per cent of parity.

Charlotte T. Muret, 146 East Thirty-ninth Street, New York City, is writing a book on the mining towns of Colorado and is anxious to find any unpublished material -- letters, diaries, references, stories -- relating to them. The towns which interest Mrs. Muret are Fairplay, Breckenridge, Silverton, Creede, Rosita, Silver Cliff, Aspen, Gothic, Crystala.

CHUNGKLNG, China, May 2 (U.P.) -- A Japanese advance through the Lashio sector of Burma toward the Chinese frontier was repulsed with heavy losses, a communique said tonight, and Chinese troops in the Taunggyi-Loilem sector have killed 1,350 troops in a struggle to cut off reinforcements.

ELIZABETH GOUDGE'S new novel is one more indication of the effects of today's upheaval. The bubbling happiness, the joy in life -- of nature no less than of the spirit -- that distinguished all her writing have gone.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Five temporary maximum price regulations covering canned fruits and vegetables, used typewriters, bedding, metal beds, mattresses, springs and studio couches, novelty floor coverings and sisal pads will be superseded by the provisions of the general maximum price regulation, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

The Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria will be formally opened for the season on the night of May 18 with a supper dance for the benefit of the Metropolitan Division of Bundles for America, Inc., which operates branches in this city and the suburban area.
Fordham's baseball victory skem, which had reached the impressive mark of ten straight, was snapped yesterday on Rose Hill when the Rams were upset. 10 -- 4, by Villanova.
GRANT RICHARDS was not the first publisher of A.E. Housman, but he was the liveliest and best known, and since he is a writer on his own account he makes an uncommonly interesting book about Housman.

A children's health service that has been a moving factor in child welfare here for the last several decades will be materially aided through the proceeds from a mid-Spring entertainment now enlisting the support and cooperation of many members of society.

FROM a price economy the country goes over in another two weeks to a war economy. On May 11 all manufacturers and wholesalers can sell at no higher than their highest March prices and on May 18 the same rule applies to all retailers.

Allan Nevins has a startling phrase in his article about American history in the high schools and colleges in our Magazine today. For that matter his whole message is startling. He finds the teaching of American history sadly inadequate.

THE portly Ed Burns, Chicago Tribune correspondent currently on interrupted tour with the White Sox, is moodily furnishing the baseball world with the laugh of the year. It isn't often that the players, managers and club owners have the laugh on one of their best friends and severest critics and they are making this a long laugh, with rolls and flourishes.

Murder and a disappearing corpse -- that is enough to begin with, although the story does not actually begin that way. Honey Stapleton (Mrs. Weaver Stapleton) discovers the corpse in a stateroom of the cruise ship on which she and her husband have embarked for the West Indies, but when she returns to the stateroom with a man to whom she has confided her discovery the body is no longer there.

ELINOR PRYOR is a newcomer in the field of American fiction. She makes a notable entrance with her historical romance "And Never Yield," a story of the turbulent decade in the history of the Mormon Church when its members were fleeing persecution in Missouri and Illinois.

PAWHUSKA, Okla., May 2 (AP) -- Tornadoes battered communities and rural areas in several parts of Northeast Oklahoma and Eastern Kansas today, leaving twenty-one persons dead or missing, injuring scores of others and causing heavy property damage.

A group of members of the American Women's Voluntary Services, organized as War Savings Volunteers to aid the New York War Savings Staff of the United States Treasury Department, has planned a series of "Victory Forum Luncheons" to be held in the grand ballroom of the Pierre on May 11, 18 and 25.

"CEBU CITY, in the island of Cebu, is in Japanese hands," reads a newspaper headline, and we pause a moment as we try to recollect Cebu's place among those islands of the Pacific which have recently sprung to prominence in the news.

MOYOCK, N.C., May 2 -- The Rev. and Mrs. Louis Thompson Singleton of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Lawrence Singleton of Moyock and New York, to William Daniel Ligon Jr. of New York and Virginia, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ligon.

A fortnight from today, when another speed boat racing season is launched in the metropolitan area, untold thousands of Sunday morning spectators in Riverside Drive Park may see new records established in the annual May-time marathon down the Hudson from Albany.

A SCULPTOR and a painter are currently exhibiting at Wildenstein's. It was a wise decision not to hang Johannes Schieffer's canvases in both rooms and distribute Guitou Knoop's sculpture. Mr. Schieffer's paintings are large and exclamatory.

The selection of Richardson Wright, editor of House and Garden, as the 1942 recipient of the Arthur Hoyt Scott Garden and Horticulture Award has been announced by President John W. Nason of Swarthmore College. The award of $1,000, together with a gold medal, is given "to that individual, organization or agency which, in the opinion of the committee, has made an outstanding contribution to the science and art of gardening."

Today is Poland's national holiday. It marks the 151st anniversary of the adoption of the Polish Constitution. This year it will be celebrated with the cooperation of our own Government throughout the United States. The commemoration gains a special significance now that the United Nations are joined in a great war for the liberation of all peoples.

THE production of "Watch on the Rhine" at the Aldwych Theatre last week and its instant welcome by the play-going public is one more heartening piece of evidence that the serious theatre isn't likely to suffer during this war as it did in the last.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- One of the primary objectives of the United Nations in this war is to guarantee for coming generations "a legacy of peace and brotherhood untrammeled by the threats and fears of greed and brute force," Breckinridge Long, Assistant Secretary of State, declared in opening the eighth Pan-American Child Congress today.

The massive Rudy York spoiled Marius Russo's 1942 debut yesterday at the Stadium and gave the Yankees, struggling to keep near the top in the American League standing, an unexpected push in the wrong direction.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- With the opening of the tennis season near at hand, the courts of the leading hotels here are being made ready. The eight clay courts at Buck Hill Falls are being put in condition, Pocono Manor's five courts are being resurfaced and the four stone-dust courts at the Skytop Club are also being spruced up.
PIMLICO, Md., May 2 -- Belair Stud's Vagrancy raced to a narrow victory in the nineteenth running of the $10,000-added Pimlico Oaks before some 22,000 fans today.

SINCE even the radio cannot concoct a new wonderwork at will, it becomes necessary on occasion to pour a spot of more or less new wine into a slightly used bottle -- or, as the program-makers say, change the format a little.

Senator Robert A. Taft, Ohio Republican, demanded last night a curtailment of what he called huge government expenditures for "propaganda pure and unadulterated." "We can't defeat Hitler with words," he said.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 2 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler, acknowledging a message of greeting from the Reich Labor Office in a deferred May Day session in Berlin today, telegraphed the following to Dr. Robert Ley, head of the German Labor Front:

A check for $45,000 to be applied to the cost of construction of a Navy bomber will be presented tomorrow by the workers of the Robins Dry Dock and Repair Company to Rear Admiral E.J. Marquart, commandant of the Third Naval District, it was announced yesterday.

NEW HOPE, Pa. -- Open House Day, held each year for the benefit of the New Hope Public Health Association, is scheduled for Saturday -- earlier than usual this year because of impending gasoline rationing. There will be ten houses open to the public.

AND now Ernest Bloch is to be received into the bosom of the American Academy of Arts and Letters. It is an honor that reflects further distinction upon the Academy, and the soundness and liberalism of its invitation.

TRENTON, N.J., May 2 -- New Jersey's smaller railroads awaited today Governor Charles Edison's signature upon a bill, passed yesterday by both houses of the Legislature, which sets up a new formula for levying taxes on their earnings.

If it is true that inflation results not from increased purchasing power but from the use of that power, it should be possible to control prices and prevent inflated values by encouraging saving in itself and by encouraging the non-spending of earnings and the non-spending of reserves.

MY mother's friend, Miss Birdling, has a horror of rumors, especially in wartime. She says -- with perfect truth but perhaps not a great deal of originality -- that rumor mongers are playing Hitler's game for him. So nothing she says herself ever is rumor: It's a fact.

Governorship of the State of New York has traditionally been regarded as a stepping-stone toward, if not the Presidency, at least Presidential candidacy. Since the Civil War three men -- Grover Cleveland, Theodore Roosevelt and Franklin D. Roosevelt -- have moved from the Governor's Victorian mansion in Albany to the White House in Washington.

IN New York, it has been said, if one waits long enough, the world passes in review. The other day additional significance was given to that saying. For instance, it was learned that Manhattan has a one-man radio school and that beginning this week it will double its Morse-code and radio-fundamentals teaching capacity to equip more American women and men for the vast new war needs of Uncle Sam.

Officers of the Army Air Corps conferred with 1,300 students at City College, New York University land Fordham University last week concerning deferred service enlistment and a large rally is scheduled tomorrow at Columbia University, officers of the First Air Force announced last night.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, an affiliate of the C.I.O., announced last week that he had written a letter to Admiral Emory S. Land, head of the Maritime Commission and the War Shipping Administration, accusing shipping companies of "hoarding" seamen.

JUDGE CAMILLE KELLEY of the Juvenile Court of Memphis, Tenn., reached the judicial bench by way of the Parent-Teacher Association, her own county organization which she helped to found. And she reached the Parent-Teacher Association through her natural following of her own children's experience, from the day when her 6-year-old son first started to school.

The Free World Association will hold an international conference at the Hotel Commodore next Friday, at which 200 Free World leaders from the four quarters of the globe will attend for the purpose of spreading its counter-campaign against fascism and nazism throughout the world.

Mayor La Guardia, speaking to 1,700 persons who attended a $25 dinner last night at the Hotel Astor to raise $59,000 to pay a deficit of his 1941 campaign, declared that "I don't hate any one in these times except Mussolini, Hitler and the Mikado" and pleaded for the "understanding and support of the people of the city."

THIS department has already set down its convictions regarding the rewards to be had from a reading of Tolstoy's "War and Peace," which are greater, perhaps, than those to be obtained from the reading of any other novel.

THIS week we queue up for the first Federal ration books that Americans have ever possessed -- somewhat ominously entitled War Ration Book No. 1. As we gingerly apportion the half pound of sugar a week to which they entitle us, questions as to what other effects the war will have on the kitchen front will inevitably arise.

LET it be said at the outset that the dozen sketches provided here by Max Eastman of "twelve who lived great lives" make instructive and delightful reading. But there is such a thing as letting well enough alone.

Likening the war front in Burma to a fog because it "is all around you," Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce asserted yesterday that the Chinese would not be able to arrive in great numbers in Burma because they lacked transportation. She arrived at La Guardia Field early in the morning by Pan American Airways Clipper after a three-month visit to Egypt and the Far East.

City College will celebrate this week its ninety-fifth anniversary with ceremonies in all divisions. The observance will reach its climax on Thursday with Charter Day exercises in the Great Hall of the main building, where Dr. Edmund E. Day, president of Cornell University, will deliver the principal address.

PARTICIPANTS in the Major Concert Series of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences to be held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music next season, are Alee Templeton, Nov. 10; Carmen Amaya and her Dance Troupe, Dec. 15; Vladimir Horowitz, Jan. 5; Yehudi Menuhin, Jan. 19; General Platoff Don Cossack Chorus, Feb. 2; Jan Peerce, Feb. 16; Efrem Zimbalist, March 2; Anne Brown and the Eva Jessye Choir, March 16, and Artur Rubinstein, March 30.

The cotton futures market moved irregularly yesterday in quiet trading. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed near the best levels of the session, 2 points higher to 4 points lower than Friday's final prices.

THERE are few absolute certainties in a global war that has been packed full of surprises. But there would seem to be a considerable balance of probability in favor of the proposition that Japan and the Soviet Union will come into conflict before the present war is ended.

A long-range program of vocational guidance and school training for the millions of men and women in this country who will face new problems when peace comes is being formulated by a commission of thirty-five nationally recognized educators and industrialists, organized last week.

A number of Westchester clubs whose officers have completed their terms, are electing new slates this month in preparation for another season of activity as crowded as the last one. Others, however, finding their desire to continue under their present leadership conflicting with club regulations as to the length of term permitted, have resorted to unusual procedures or an emergency provision in their by-laws.

The thirty-five persons chosen by Mayor La Guardia for service on his proposed duplex board for study and report on the city's fiscal problems will get no official notice of their appointments until tomorrow afternoon or Tuesday morning.

CONNOISSEURS of chamber music have treasured Schubert's Quintet in C, Op. 163, as one of the finest works of its kind. Of course, most chamber music is not commercial in the sense that it commands the attention of the general public, and this quintet is perhaps less played at concerts than other compositions for small ensemble.
Dr. John W. Cunliffe, director emeritus of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, disclosed yesterday that he was retiring from teaching at the close of the present semester.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Restrictions on passenger travel are imminent, Joseph B. Eastman, director of Defense Transportation, said today.

To the Summer's styles comes beauty from exotic climes. The vibrant tones the mingle on the Latin American palette have been brought to life for North American women by Luza the Peruvian artist who has developed unusual color schemes for New York designers.

AS far as I know, this is the first novel to choose its principal characters from among the Veddas of Ceylon. These denizens of the island's remotest jungles, a fast-disappearing people whose very existence is "little more than a tradition" to its cultured inhabitants, are prototypes of earth's early human inhabitants, difficult for a white man to see, still more difficult to know.

THERE is nothing especially penetrating or brilliant in the writing of this book, yet its four principal characters seem extraordinarily real -- poor, blundering creatures -- and their motives clearly illuminated.
