The story too is ordinary, but is detailed and personalized enough to keep one going on with interest to the end.

Former Secretary of State Bainbridge Colby, who was a member of the United States Shipping Board, vice president of the Emergency Fleet Corporation and shipping member of the American Mission to the Inter-Allied War Conference in the last war, called upon America last night to make the same "mass effort" for the mass production of ships that defeated the submarine threat in 1917-18.

OTTAWA, May 2 -- Although the people who voted "yes" and the people who voted "no" in last Monday's plebiscite expected that conscription for overseas service would be the result, there has been no hint as yet by the government as to the course it intends to follow.

ITHACA. N.Y., May 2 -- Yale's baseball team defeated Cornell. 2 -- 1, in the first half of an Eastern Intercollegiate League doubleheader today, then lost 6-1, against the four-hit pitching of Phil Smith.

INDIA has some very urgent matters to attend to at the moment, but the BBC has wisely decided that a political and military crisis is not a sufficient reason for suspending its talks on literary subjects to listeners in that country.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 2 -- A majority of American voters are ready to accept a 2 per cent Federal sales tax. If submitted to the 60,000,000 eligible voters in a national plebiscite, such a tax plan would be favored by approximately 30,600,000, opposed by approximately 25,800,000, with the remaining 3,600,000 undecided or having no definite opinion and therefore not likely to vote.

HALLETT ABEND is no stranger to the Far East or to readers of this newspaper. Fourteen and a half years in China gave him an insight into conditions which most of us find it hard to understand. As the years passed on he learned to measure the growing strength of China and the growing menace of Japan.

THE title page explains that this book is "the story of an expedition to Ungava and the Belcher Islands"; and it is one of the expedition's factors of interest that for ninety-nine readers out of a hundred the explanation itself will have to be explained.
ST. LOUIS, May 2 (AP) -- Sibby Sisti got his first home run of the year today to give the Braves a 1-to-0 victory over the Cardinals in a game curtailed to six innings.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 2 -- Despite the military reverses which the allied nations have suffered, the confidence of the Southeast in President Roosevelt's leadership of the war effort has taken on additional strength in recent weeks. The impression seems to have grown that in matters which were controversial the President's prevision was keener and his judgment sounder than those of his critics.

French scholars in the United States must keep alive the culture of France until victory is won by the Allies and the forces of General De Gaulle, it was asserted yesterday by General Adolphe Eugene-Marie Sice, High Commissioner for Free French Africa.

RUTH SAWYER'S latest book is as invigorating as a wind blowing over the Spring meadows. She has chosen her title well, for the story-telling of which she speaks is not the here learning and retelling of tales.

Beset by the problems of abnormally high taxation and depressed market values, the management of public utility holding companies are in a quandary as to the solution of the integration, or "death sentence," provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the Department of Agriculture reported that but little opposition was apparent in today's farmer referendum on the question of continuing a rigid Federal control over production and marketing of wheat.

How to translate the over-all price ceiling into specific terms of satisfactory costs and operating margins was the intricate problem facing retailers and manufacturers yesterday at the end of what was described as one of the most confused weeks in American business since the NRA.

Men of the East and of the West --Irishmen, Scots, Yorkshiremen, Britons, Americans, Punjabis, Sikhs, Garwallis, Ghurkas, Kachins, Chins, Chinese -- fought, cursed in their several tongues and died on the dusty river bottoms and along the slopes of the Shah massif in Burma all last week.

Retail trade here was fair last week. Department store executives estimated an increase of about 5 to 6 per cent over the corresponding period a year ago. A gain of this amount would indicate a substantial falling off in units due to the higher price level compared with 1941.

The People's Chorus of New York, of which Mrs. John Henry Hammond is chairman, will present its Spring Song Festival and dance on the right of May 15 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event this year will be a benefit for the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.

NEW DELHI, India, May 2 (U.P.) -- British forces in Burma, according to today's communique, have been fighting in and around Monywa to protect the United Nations' flank and halt a Japanese encirclement thrust northwest of Mandalay, while the situation along the adjacent Irrawaddy sector was reported unchanged.

Registration of New York City's family units and individuals for sugar rationing will begin tomorrow and continue daily through Thursday as part of the nationwide enrollment for the first food item to be rationed as a wartime necessity.

BY one of the many ironies of the theatre, the finest achievement of the year is a production put on for the benefit of Army and Navy relief for only a few special performances. It is the Katharine Cornell revival of Bernard Shaw's "Candida," which gave four matinees last week, will play tonight and, by furious demand, will give four more matinees this week and a final performance next Sunday evening.

Selective service men engaged in studying photography when called into service are being deferred by draft boards in the metropolitan area until they have finished their courses, according to information received by the School of Modern Photography.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., May 2 -- At a recent meeting of the trustees of Skidmore College, held here, the board unanimously endorsed the recommendation of the faculty that no general acceleration program should be planned now.
LONDON, May 2 -- The British Government announced today that efforts to aid prisoners of war in Hong Kong and other places in the Far East were being held up by the lack of Japanese cooperation.

IN addition to the usual sports and crafts, children who go to camp this Summer will learn, for a treat, some of those chores that, to hear their elders tell it, made an earlier generation what it is today; hoeing potatoes, clearing trails, helping to spot forest fires are some of the jobs on near-by farms and in forests scheduled by many camps, according to the American Camping Association.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The United States opened an all-out war upon inflation here this week, using as its first salvo an order invoking overall control of retail prices. Beginning May 18, thousands of items entering into the average citizen's living costs, from bread to cigarettes, go under stringent control of the Office of Price Administration.

In "Primrose Day" the author, whose earlier books about a little girl ("B is for Betsy", "Betsy and Billy" and "Two and Two Are Four") are well loved by the 6 to 8 years old, has now written a spontaneous, unsentimental little story about a little English girl, named Merry Primrose Ramsay, who was sent to this country because of the war.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 2 -- Alumni of Cornell University this year will increase their already large war effort by foregoing the usual campus pageantry in favor of an informal and decentralized series of reunions in 151 communities from coast to coast.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The nearly 29,000 donors from all walks of life who have poured into the Treasury unrequested cash gifts totaling $614,670.57 to help finance the war effort were cited today by Secretary Morgenthau as symbols of the voluntary principle to which the government has turned, in preference to compulsion, for the mass purchase of $1,000,000,000 of War Savings Bonds each month.

LONDON, May 2 (U.P.) -- An announcement by the Rome radio that additional Italian troops would be sent to the Russian front convinced United Nations diplomats tonight that a serious shortage of Axis man power was one of the chief topics of the Salzburg conference of Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Premier Mussolini.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, May 2 -- Viewing the staggering tax load laid upon New Zealanders by the new war budget, the press concedes that the government deserves praise for its courage. The major complaint is that more sacrifices were not demanded.

The Institute on Educational Reconstruction, which met at New York University last week, represents "a historic step toward achieving a world-wide democracy," Dr. Reinhold Schairer, visiting Professor of Education at New York University and director of the United States Committee of Educational Reconstruction, said yesterday.

THIS department always gets a strange sensation, toward the end of a week such as the past, of being a frantic participant in a game of musical chairs. With three and four new films opening daily by wretched coincidence, one suddenly finds one's self describing mad circles in the midtown New York streets and popping in and out of picture theatres as though stuck in a revolving door.

UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, May 3 (AP) -- Allied planes scored a direct hit on a Japanese transport, damaged another, capsized a tender, destroyed six Japanese planes and damaged six more in fierce new action over New Britain and New Guinea yesterday, General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced.

Fate, in the form of sea warfare against oil tankers, has designated the East Coast to a line roughly 300 miles inland as the area for testing the loyalty of car owners in a time of crisis for the world and the nation. So far, the results are not good.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Navy Yard, which more than eighty years ago built a warship that routed four Japanese vessels bent on the destruction of an American packet, received the Navy's "E" pennant today for its work in the present war.

One of the most interesting objects to watch for in the evening skies of May will be the planet Mercury. This elusive neighbor world of ours reaches its greatest eastern elongation on Monday, the eighteenth. It will then be about 22 degrees east of the sun and will appear as a brilliant reddish object in the northwestern sky, setting about an hour and a half after sunset.

That is sufficient reason for desperate attempts to find it.

ICELAND CHIEF: The appointment last week of an American as commander in chief in bleak, fog-shrouded Iceland revealed that American troops had virtually completed the relief of their British comrades for action elsewhere, had taken over protection of the treeless island that controls vital northern sea routes.

THE theory that a man who has cracked up before the problems the world presents may find new strength and joy in rejuvenating a broken-down farm is one which a great many people enjoy brooding on, if not actually putting into practice.
Mrs. Julius Ley, who had been in Washington, has returned to her home at 115 East Sixty-seventh Street.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 2 -- The Naval Academy varsity crew, victorious over Princeton and Columbia, today added Cornell as its third victim, defeating the Big Red boat on the Severn River in a grueling race by one-eighth of a length.

THE BOMBERS who have flown over Japan have looked down on one of the most astonishing archipelagoes in the world. The islands of the empire proper stretch more than 2,000 miles from north to south. In the group known as Old Japan, centering on Honshu, are eight principal islands; actually, however, this group consists of 400 habitable bits of land.

Despite its new-gained stature as capital of the freedom-loving world, wartime Washington, to the thousands upon thousands of government workers who toil in its old marble palaces and new plaster buildings, is a jangling symphony in which the principal themes are hustle, shove and stand-in-line. Its population is swollen like an overblown balloon -- but still the war workers come.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters will hold a Spring festival next Friday afternoon at which new members will be inducted, medals and awards will be presented, and the first comprehensive exhibition of work by about 250 members will be opened.

The past week's arrivals of new issues include Liberia's 1938 airmail series overprinted for use when regular aerial mail service was inaugurated between the African republic and the United States in February. The service was to have been begun last year, and "First Flight Liberia -- U.S. 1941" was overprinted on each of the ten stamps; but, as now released, two black bars pass through the 1941.

A recent Gallup poll indicated that only a fraction of the public knows or cares what block-booking is. For that reason, the current agitation to scuttle the government's consent decree, which outlawed block-booking last September, has meant little to the people it will ultimately affect -- the theatre patrons.

THE formula is pat. With Bing Crosby you kid about his bad horses. With Eddie Cantor you complain about your pay check or, if you are a lady, go into the patter about his being your leading man. With Jack Benny you must mention the toupee and also the pay check routine.

After reaching the lowest since Spring of 1933 -- having fallen 13 3/8 points between the beginning of February and the middle of last week -- stock market averages recovered 2 points or more. Bonds held firm throughout the week. Wheat and cotton declined, then regained their early losses.

LONDON, May 3 -- Herr Hitler's speech a week ago was a tonic to financial London. So-called logic failed to modify the City's impression that his oration was that of a tyrant who knows that defeat is inevitable and possibly imminent. Observers who had been awaiting such signs see them in the hysterical outbursts of the German press that accompanied the bombing of Britain's historic cities.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 3 -- With at least three forest fires still burning, although the worst was believed definitely over, Rhode Island State police recorded today for the first time their conviction that the outbreaks, which have spread damage in a sixty-square-mile area since Thursday, were incendiary.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (U.P.) -- The nation's officially announced toll of dead in the war rose to 3,395 tonight as the War Department issued its first list of soldiers who were killed in action or died of wounds in the Philippines.

Total shipments of all types of hosiery during March amounted to 13,506,290 dozen pairs, a gain of 1,010,936 dozen pairs over the same month a year ago, according to the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. The increase over a year ago was said to be based on gains recorded by the seamless branch, both women's and men's.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Office of Price Administration is prepared to offer subsidies to manufacturers rather than permit the puncturing of the price ceiling for any article, it was revealed today.

Wednesday will find War Ration Book No. 1 in active use. This prerequisite to purchasing will entitle shoppers to a choice of five sorts of sugar -- granulated, lump, confectioner's, powdered or brown. Show no dismay -- certain wholesalers and retailers warn -- if not all of these are immediately available in your favorite grocery.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 3 -- Dalchoolin, the big brown imported gelding owned by Mrs. Elizabeth Correll of Scarsdale, and shown by Gordon Wright of White Plains, today captured his third successive hunter championship, winning at the seventh annual Hutchinson horse show at Hutchinson Farms.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- American eyes have been focused upon Japan's military machine in action, but the government in Washington has been watching carefully Japan's attempts to propagandize herself in Asia as a nation involved in liberating the Asiatics from "white domination."

With God as an ally it will be possible to re-educate millions of Nazi-poisoned German youth after the war, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Candidates for two Senatorial, two Gubernatorial, and twenty-eight House seats will be chosen in four State primaries Tuesday following wartime campaigns marked by canned speech-making and lack of opposition to many incumbents.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Father, mother and maybe granddad will join the youngsters in trudging to neighborhood schools tomorrow as the government begins its four-day registration of consumers for the sugar rationing program.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., May 3 -- A medium-sized United States freighter, which had been damaged in collision with another vessel off Sandy Hook, at the entrance to New York Harbor, was grounded about 9 A.M. today on a sandbar 250 yards of the Seabright Coast Guard Station here.

The New York Zoological Society "progressed upstream against the down-current of world catastrophe" in 1941, according to the forty-sixth annual report of the society for the last year, made public yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 3 -- Nests of Axis air and undersea raiders that are menaces to British shipping in the eastern Mediterranean and, possibly, to ports of Egypt were targets of Friday-night raids by bombers of the Royal Air Force's Middle East Command.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 -- Longshore gangs working under rules drafted by the recently established Pacific Coast Maritime Industry Board have turned in commendable performances in unloading ships when wartime needs dictated a speedy "turn-around" in West Coast harbors.

Otis R. Rice, chaplain of St. Luke's Hospital, said yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, May 3 -- The Japanese are reported to be continuing to concentrate naval and air forces in the Southwest Pacific and informed quarters here believe that in the next few weeks the Japanese may launch major new offensive operations, either in the direction of Australia or southeastward against United Nations island bases in the South Pacific.

Registration for sugar rationing starts today at 9 A.M. in 1,036 elementary, parochial and private schools where 80,000 assistants will be on hand to speed the task of enrolling an estimated total of 1,500,000 New Yorkers as individuals and for family units.

LONDON, May 3 -- After a daylight respite yesterday because of bad weather the Royal Air Force resumed today its large-scale sweeps over the German-occupied French coast. The attackers were challenged once by a flight of fifteen Focke-Wulf 190s; Free French pilots shot down three of the foe and routed the rest.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Southpaw Al Hollingsworth hurled effectively in the pinches to give St. Louis a 5-1 victory over Washington in the second game today after the Browns had dropped the opener, 9 -- 8.

George Payne, dean of the School of Education of New York University, asserted yesterday that "immediate organization of an educational system" was needed "to guarantee a peace that will make impossible the discrimination and persecution of the Jews that has characterized civilization of the past."

NEW ORLEANS, May 3 -- The President's idea on how to keep down the cost of living took precedence over everything else in the cotton futures market here last week.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- A board of Army, Navy and Marine officers, headed by Brig. Gen. Guy V. Henry, United States Army, will leave Washington tomorrow for Canada to effect the transfer of a number of American citizens and former citizens from the Canadian to the United States armed forces, the War Department said today.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 3 -- Breaking 94 of 100 targets from the twenty-five-yard or scratch mark, J.R. Johnston Jr. of Hartford-City, Ind., triumphed today in the distance handicap contest, concluding event of the thirty-seventh annual amateur trapshooting championships of America at the New York A.C.'s Travers Island layout.

In the western part of New York, not far from Lake Erie, anglers are more likely to discuss muskellunge fishing than they are here in the East, for Chautauqua Lake, near Jamestown, is the largest 'lunge fishing grounds in the State.
VICHY, France, May 3 -- On their way back from Spain, Japanese members of the Axis Mixed Commission were received and entertained here today by the chiefs of the French Government.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- A good shipping demand for cash oats prevailed here last week, but prices of that grain for future delivery averaged lower on the Board of Trade in sympathy with other grains. There was no material pressure on the market except for liquidating longs.

At the tenth annual Campus Day exercises at Manhattan College yesterday, it was announced that the names of 477 graduates and former students now serving in the armed forces, as well as the sixty-four members of the student body who have enlisted but have been permitted to continue their studies temporarily, will be inscribed on a plaque in the Chapel of St. John Baptist de la Salle on the campus.

LONDON, May 3 -- In a speech that was mainly a call for elimination of economic inequalities in the post-war world, Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal, declared tonight that "the moment to strike is approaching."

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Rationing of lard is regarded here as inevitable if the government's buying of that commodity for lease-lend operations continues on its recent scale. Stocks in cold storage here decreased 47,000,000 pounds last month, the largest reduction for a like period on record.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 3 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayor has revived its plans for a new screen version of "Quo Vadis?," Henryk Sienkiewicz's 1893 novel about Roman decadence under Nero, and has announced that Arthur Hornblow will produce the picture as his first venture under his new Metro contract.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Senator Bankhead of Alabama said today a poll of Senate sentiment indicated that President Roosevelt would not win a requested revision of farm price formula under the Price Control Act.

"A pocket edition of a cold shower" is one woman's description for a mint-green skin freshener that can perform the function of a cool oasis in a sweltering afternoon. It is an antidote for that sticky, 4 o'clock feeling.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Liquidation of contracts for future deliveries of corn was on last week on the Board of Trade here, and prices of that grain dropped to the lowest levels since early in the year in the face of relatively small country offerings and a record farm consumption of the grain.

Public education on international relations to avoid concessions to ignorance that have so often ruined the peace movement in the past was urged by Dr. James T. Shotwell yesterday in his report to trustees of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace as director of the division of economics and history.

PITTSBURGH, May 3 (AP) -- The Pirates ran a winning streak to three straight games today by beating the Braves, 6 -- 2, in the opener of a double-header, but the roof fell in on them in the second game as Boston gained a 12-3 victory before 29,030 fans.
A final service yesterday at the Washington Heights Methodist Church, 153d Street and Amsterdam Avenue, marked the merger of that church with the Broadway Temple Methodist Church at 174th Street.
Substantial improvement in earnings in the first quarter of this year over the corresponding period last year was disclosed in the reports of two oil companies, announced for publication today.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- There is "no evidence" to indicate that the serious problem of transporting oil and gasoline to the Eastern Seaboard can be "expected to improve substantially in the immediate future," Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, said today.

LONDON, May 3 -- Whitehall and its environs, wherein are situated so many government buildings that it is sometimes called "the heart of the Empire," was subjected to an eighteen-hour simulated attack by "parachute troops" from Army units last night and today.
As the Japanese all but completed the conquest of Burma last week another major defeat was added to the long list of battles lost by the United Nations.

A move to reorganize the government of Spain, to include conservative elements opposed to greater collaboration with Germany and Italy, is under way in Madrid, and already has produced a series of anti-Axis demonstrations and one attempt to assassinate the pro-Axis Minister of Labor, according to private advices reaching New York last night.

The city of gilded pagodas that was Mandalay is now a heap of ashes patrolled by Japanese troops. Its fall means nothing less than the conquest of Burma, for it was the strategic heart of the country. Fighting may continue a while in the north and below the Chinese border, but with Lashio and Mandalay both held by the enemy organized resistance to save the rest of Burma must collapse.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., May 3 -- Goldie, the 500-pound brown bear at the Bear Mountain Zoo, and her entourage of three cubs, went visiting early this morning and it took park attendants and policemen more than six hours to get them where they wanted them -- Goldie back in the bear pit and the cubs in the Trailside Museum.

Recently Paul V. McNutt proposed. that there be group deferments of labor. This is an excellent idea if applied only where needed. It might even be necessary in order to prevent laboring men from enlisting voluntarily, because there is no person in the country more patriotic than the individual laboring man if he is let alone instead of being upset and misled by some conniving and self-seeking union "leader," agitator or demagogue.

VICHY, France, May 3 (U.P.) -- The execution of fifty-five French hostages at Lille and two new attacks on German troop trains were announced today a few hours after a conference of high Nazi and Vichy officials on the resurgence of "terrorism" in France.

Although seasonal types of apparel continued fairly active, reflecting unusually warm weather, the confusion created by publication of the price ceiling order had its greatest effect upon further selling of Fall and Winter items, according to a summary of last week's business prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident offices.

New Deal supporters of President Roosevelt, having found in a survey that Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., whom they oppose, is a much stronger candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor than they expected, are contemplating a movement for the renomination of Governor Lehman, it was learned yesterday.

An appeal to the Irish in this country to take the leadership in a movement to obtain use of Ireland's submarine bases by the United Nations was applauded yesterday at the communion breakfast of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, New York Guard, which replaced the 165th Infantry, successor to the "Fighting Sixty-ninth."

Unless we are on the alert as Christians, the contending forces of pride, prejudice and inertia in our natures will tend to crowd God out of our lives, the Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig declared yesterday in his sermon at the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street.

A simple six-word statement, "O God, Thou art my God," was analyzed by the Rev. Dr. William Pierson Merrill in his sermon yesterday morning as expressing the essence of religion. He added that many individuals, groups and nations misinterpret its meaning.

Tonight's scheduled premiere of "The Walking Gentleman" at the Belasco has been postponed to Thursday evening. The "psychological thriller" by Mr. and Mrs. Fulton Oursler, whose central character is a psychopathic murderer, gave three performances in Wilmington (April 24-25) and two previews here on Friday and Saturday nights.
LONDON, May 3 -- The women of Britain, who are sharing equally with the men the burdens of war, are not going to sit by silently when peace comes and let men alone reorganize the country.

The Great Bambino on his return from the West Coast offered the perfect example of the average man who has just been delivered miraculously from a critical illness. "I'm smoking my usual quota," he told reporters.

LONDON, May 3 -- Heavy fighting continued today in a number of widely separated sectors on the Burma front, with the fall of Mandalay acknowledged by the United Nations, while there were indications of a further Japanese advance near Kutkai on the Burma Road about forty miles north of Lashio.

Jimmy Dykes couldn't restrain himself yesterday at the Stadium, where baseball's largest crowd of the year was watching the Yankees and the White Sox battle through the first double-header of the campaign in the Bronx.

PITTSBURGH, May 3 -- The steel industry last week reached an all-time high in the production of steel ingots with operations reaching 99.5 per cent of rated capacity, up 1 point from the level of the week before. According to steel observers, this experience is al the more exceptional because of the pressure placed on primary steel equipment for the past year or more.

BOSTON, May 3 (AP) -- The Red Sox, aided by the Tribe's jittery fielding, snapped the Indians' thirteen-game winning streak today, defeating the American League leaders, 8 -- 4, for Charlie Wagner's third straight victory.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 3 -- Yugoslavia is in chaos on the eve of Germany's expected Spring offensives and the anticipated general attack on the Axis occupying forces there by General Draja Mikhailovitch's Yugoslav troops, according to information given the writer today by a special agent who escaped from Yugoslavia last week.

A novel party entitled "The Round-Up" and planned as an indoor prairie fiesta will be given on the night of May 26 at the Park Lane as a benefit for the Madison Square Boys Club. The proceeds will be used to provide medical care for 200 of the young club members who are in need of this service.

TOKYO, May 3 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press in New York) -- Mandalay, Burma's second largest city, was a wide expanse of smoldering ruins and without a glimmer of life when Japanese troops marched into it Friday, a Domei news agency front correspondent reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Controversy over terms of legislation to create female branches of the Army, Navy and Marines developed today with a demand by Chairman Walsh of the Senate Naval Affairs Committee for an amendment to eliminate from a House-approved bill the possibility that women might be called for combat duty.

PITTSBURGH, May 3 -- Both wings of the labor movement in this country are "unalterably opposed" to any system of wage-freezing, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared here tonight.

Asserting that the inflationary tendency is growing steadily and that more effective measures are needed to keep it under control, the National City Bank of New York in its monthly bulletin declares that the chief criticism of the government has been against the lack of a complete and rounded policy to accomplish these purposes.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period April 25 to 30 are given in the appended tabulation:

Maintaining that neither tyranny nor lust for power or conquest can "devalue" mankind, the Rev. Dr. George Caleb Moor, pastor of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church at Thirty-first Street, assured his congregation in a sermon yesterday morning that the Cross of Christ had given man true supremacy and that its presence could not be "pushed aside."

MADRID, May 3 (Reuter) -- Six hundred persons were reported here today to have been arrested in Paris following food-queue scenes caused by the distribution of over 100,000 bogus circulars announcing an extra bread ration.
CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) -- The Cubs and Phils divided honors today before 19,880, Chicago winning the first game, 9 to 1, and losing the second, 8 to 1.

The Hale Tool Company, manufacturer of machine tools, leased the building at 113 Edison Place, Newark, N.J., from Mary E. Jackson through Louis Schlesinger, broker, who also leased the bottling plant formerly used by the Wiedenmayer brewery at 604-08 Market Street, southeast corner of Chambers Street, Newark, to Andrews-Steib, Inc., for the warehousing and distribution of brass, copper and kindred products.

The Women's Swimming Association of New York kept the 300-yard medley relay title in near-record time, while Miss Helene Rains of that club and Miss Betty Bemis of Indianapolis became the breast-stroke and free-style rulers at 220 yards at the end of the women's national A.A.U. championship meet in the London Terrace pool yesterday.

Many thousands of men who know that they will be drafted within the next three to six months are wondering and worrying about what life in the Army will be like. Many of us are thinking that our spare time could be devoted to a sort of pre-induction training.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Treasury today invited cash subscriptions at par and accrued interest for $1,250,000,000, or there-abouts, of 2 per cent Treasury bonds of 1949-51 and for an unspecified amount of 2 1/2 per cent Treasury bonds of 1962-67.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, May 3 -- Practice of democracy in daily living constitutes the most important wartime job of parents and teachers, Howard V. Funk, principal of the Bronxville (N.Y.) Junior High School, declared here today in opening the forty-sixth annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers.

ADVANCED UNITED NATIONS BASE, Southwest Pacific, May 2 (Delayed) -- The Japanese have made another incursion into the Markham Valley, in Northeast New Guinea, and have reached the high mark of a previous advance, which ended six weeks ago when floods forced a withdrawal to the coast. This was announced today by an Australian military spokesman.

Arthur R. Vinton, stage, screen and radio actor, who successfully operates a 136-acre dairy farm in the town of New Windsor, Orange County, announced yesterday his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Representative in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District.

Partly because of the early Easter, advertising linage in eight New York newspapers showed a sharp drop last month, according to a compilation based on Media Records reports. The decrease was 13.1 per cent from the corresponding 1941 month, with all newspapers showing a decline.

Arturo Toscanini concluded his historic series of Beethoven programs with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall with performances of the Eighth and Ninth symphonies. It is not necessary to dilate here upon incidents, more or less customary at a Toscanini concert, of what would be with another leader a spectacular triumph.

The American book trade's obligation in the war is the theme of the three-day convention of booksellers opening today at the Hotel Astor. Three hundred members of the American Booksellers Association, faced with new problems of supply and marketing and with new responsibilities, will hear forecasts of the war's impact on their business.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The War Department issued the following communique:

ALBANY, May 3 -- Legislative approval of the demolition of the Second Avenue elevated structure in Manhattan became final today, as Governor Lehman signed the Jarema bill, passed in the closing hours of the recent session. The bill speeds the demolition of the structure by permitting one-third of the cost to be assessed on the local area, one-third on the Borough of Manhattan, and one-third on the city at large.
MONTREAL, May 3 (AP) -- Montreal downed Jersey City, 5 -- 2, in the seven-inning second game today after the Little Giants had taken the first, 4 -- 1.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 3 (Reuter) -- The newspaper Svenska Dagbladet reports that bombs were dropped when an aircraft flew over Copenhagen last night.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Wheat futures sold last week at the lowest prices since late November on the Board of Trade here, and while there was some recovery from the bottom the rally was not impressive and was caused mainly by short covering, combined with a little buying by mills.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., May 3 -- Today, officially proclaimed Brazilian day, citizens of New Bedford, including more than 40,000 Americans of Portuguese descent, joined in celebrating the discovery of Brazil 442 years ago by Pedro Alvarez Cabrul. Portuguese, the official language of America's largest republic, is spoken by almost a third of the town, the people constituting the largest Portuguese-speaking group in the United States.
VICHY, May 3 -- The monthly statements of condition of three main banks as of Feb. 28 show a slowing down in deposits, which had been increasing rapidly since the war began.

Wartime civilian rationing, with its universal registration of consumers, its ration books and coupons, will begin in the United States today. We have had rationing of a sort for some months. New automobiles, tires, bicycles and a long list of critical and strategic materials have been "rationed," as have fuel oil and gasoline.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- For the second time since the Japanese began their siege of our island fortress Corregidor, in the Philippines, the American flag was a casualty for a short time, the War Department revealed today. But as in the first instance on April 18 gallant American soldiers braved the fury of the enemy fire to restore the Stars and Stripes to the top of the flagpole.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 3 (AP) -- The Newark Bears took both ends of a double-header from the Rochester Red Wings today, 11-7 and 6-3.

CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) -- Early arriving delegates to the fifty-first Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution today honored 2,390 of their sisters who have died during the past year at a special memorial service.

The National Institute of Social Sciences yesterday announced that its 1942 gold medal awards "for distinguished services to humanity," would be presented to Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board; Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and Dr. Fufus B. von Kleinsmid, president of the University of Southern California.

Leopold Stokowski led the New York City WPA Symphony Orchestra early yesterday evening at the Cosmopolitan Opera House in the first of a series of five concerts sponsored by Mayor La Guardia on behalf of the Treasury Department.

JERUSALEM, May 3 -- Three recent abortive land-mine outrages have drawn attention again to the activities of the irreconcilable political terrorist group known here as the "Stern Gang," after their leader, Abraham Stern, who was shot two months ago in a police raid on his hideout on the fringe of the city of Tel Aviv.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 3 -- The first demonstration of wartime fire fighting in this area was presented on the drill grounds of the Stamford Fire Department this morning by regular members of the department and thirty-seven graduates of a civilian auxiliary fire department school.

The American Automobile Association has undertaken to collect and conserve the immense quantities of scrap rubber now serving no good purpose in garages, back yards and out-of-the-way corners the country over. It estimates that discarded tires alone will build a stock pile of at least 1,500,000 tons.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 3 -- Declaring that farmers and labor had nothing in common, William Rich, master of the New York State Grange, said today that his opposition to attempted unionization of dairy farmers stemmed from this and not from the leadership of John L. Lewis in the union movement.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose slightly from 106.3 to 106.5. The foodstuffs index went up 0.5 per cent due to rises in butter, egg and beef steer prices, which outweighed declines in oranges and potatoes.

MOSCOW, May 3 (AP) -- Red Army forces all along the 2,000-mile front took oaths today to carry out Premier Joseph Stalin's order to make 1942 the year of final defeat for the Germans, and there were indications that the Russians were planning their own Spring offensive.

General Henri Honore Giraud, fugitive from the Saxon fortress of Koenigstein, has not been delivered by the French Government to the Germans, who claimed him, according to private advices reaching THE NEW YORK TIMES.

President Roosevelt's conference on May 5, 6 and 7 in Washington, between Federal and State representatives, to consider the elimination of shipping restrictions encountered at State lines, and other trade barriers which hamper our war efforts, must recommend the free flow of goods in interstate commerce.

LONDON, May 3 -- A joint Admiralty and Air Ministry communique tonight gave the first definite reports on the whereabouts and condition of the German battleships Scharnhorst and Gneisenau and the heavy cruiser Prinz Eugen since their sensational escape from Brest, France, on Feb. 11.

NEW DELHI, India, May 3 (AP) -- Major Gen. Lewis H. Brereton, commander of the United States air force in India, said in an Army Hour broadcast to the United States tonight that "we stand ready to defend the shores of India."

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 3 -- Three Hempstead patrolmen and one civilian were injured and two police cars badly damaged by bricks and other missiles hurled by Negro civilians in the Negro section here last night and early this morning.

WHY anybody keeps track of such things it's hard to know, but last Friday, when the Western clubs scored a sweep over the Eastern clubs in the National and American Leagues, interested parties popped up in all corners to point out that this had occurred at least once before in big league annals, and the date, carefully wrapped in the convolutions of their brains all these years, was May 15, 1929.
KEARNY, N.J., May 3 -- Four destroyers for the Navy were launched within an hour here today, a record for one day at one yard.

Inspired by the belief that a singing citizenry can more easily defeat the Axis, music students of the New York University School of Education will conduct a series of community sings in the Washington Square Park beginning Friday, in the hope of popularizing the idea of singing to relieve the tension caused by the war.

A 1,200-acre property consisting of woodland and fields at Mastic, L.I., in Suffolk County, has been sold by Floyd Properties, Inc., and the heirs of Dr. Rolfe Floyd to John B. Dawson, a New York attorney. It includes a twenty-room house and many outbuildings and was held in the Floyd family since colonial days.

Dr. Felix Pinner, 62 years old, economist and former editor of the Berlin Tageblatt, and his wife, Gertrude, 56, committed suicide yesterday in their apartment at 88-04 Sixty-third Drive, Princeton Gardens, Rego Park, Queens.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 3 -- In the closing session today of six months of dinghy sailing at the Larchmont Yacht Club, Jack Sutphen, with his boat Rum Rum, led fifteen other Class B craft, with 93 points to 83 for Arthur Knapp and his Prissy.
PENDLETON, Ore., May 3 (AP) -- A Flying Fortress bomber crashed into the wooded Blue Mountains here today, killing six of the eight Army fliers aboard.
PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (AP) -- After winning the first game, 8 to 7, the Tigers made only two hits off Phil Marchildon and lost the second half of a double-header today to the Athletics, 1 to 0.
LONDON, May 3 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

A continuance of the demand for loft properties in good locations in Manhattan was indicated by a purchase reported over the week-end in which a syndicate of investors bought the ten-story building at 296 Broadway from the United States Trust Company.

In the absence from the city of Mayor La Guardia, four of his aides in the civilian defense program yesterday used the radio time ordinarily devoted to his "Talk to the People" to present concise, factual and informative summaries of progress made to date in the activities under their control.

Robert Nathan has been re-elected president of the American center of the P.E.N., the international writers' organization. Inez Haynes Irwin was re-elected vice president for the next year. John L.B. Williams has become the new secretary and Mary Day Winn the new treasurer.

Historic St. Paul's Church, in Eastchester, Mount Vernon, N.Y., was hailed as the American Shrine of Freedom of the Press and the Bill of Rights by President Roosevelt and spokesmen for the nation's publishers yesterday morning when the restored edifice was formally rededicated.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 -- It appeared today that both Greentree Stable horses, Shut Out and Devil Diver, would go in the Preakhess Stakes at Pimlico next Saturday and that Eddie Arcaro again would ride Devil Diver. Major L.A. Beard, manager of the Whitney racing interests, said:

Frederick E. Hasler, chairman of the Continental Bank and Trust Company, has been nominated for president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York to succeed Percy H. Johnston, who has served two terms and is ineligible for re-election.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Roosevelt is expected to send to Congress this week the 1943 Army Appropriation Bill and the VPA Appropriation Bill. The former will be one of the largest if not the largest single money bill of the war and will provide for the rapidly expanding United States Army.
In his last Reichstag speech Hitler passed the following judgment:

"Cash and carry" is a phrase with a new meaning now. The accent is on the toting of the family groceries, since the rubber tire situation makes it no longer merely a matter of lugging the viands out to the curb and stacking them in the car for a quick trip home.

ST. LOUIS, May 3 -- With both teams minus their managers for a greater part of the afternoon, a season's record crowd at Sportsman's Park of 23,871 today saw the National League champion Dodgers transformed into chumps by losing both ends of a double-header to the Cardinals, the first by 14 -- 10 and the nightcap, called at the end of five and one-half innings because daylight ran out, by 4 -- 2.

HONOLULU, May 3 -- A warning that Hawaii may expect to be bombed again before this war is over came today from Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons, commanding the Hawaiian Department and military governor of the territory.

In May, 1872, the State Charities Aid Association was founded in this city by Miss Louisa Lee Schuyler, a name that was to become revered. The purpose of this society was to keep an eye on charitable institutions and to improve them. Within two years conditions were discovered in Bellevue Hospital that led to the establishment there of the first American training school for nurses.

CINCINNATI, May 3 -- Bucky Walters, who for a couple of years was the National League's reigning pitcher, doesn't seem to have what it takes any more and it took the Giants only a few minutes to find that out today.
CAIRO, May 3 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued this communique today:

Of the written word of today the largest part flows into Government reports. Knute Hill, a State of Washington Representative, has put into the Congressional Record a summary of the "ten major faults" in the writing of Government officials. For five years the public-relations faculty of the American University under the direction of Professor William Dow-Bout-well has been studying this gigantic literature.

LONDON, May 3 -- The stock markets here as a whole continue to reflect the tension created by the impression of pending big events. If any confirmation were needed that the struggle is about to reach its peak, it could be found in the impressive spirit of offensive now displayed in the air war, in Hitler's Reichstag speech and in the Salzburg meeting of the dictators.

The Cornwall Hospital of Cornwall, N.Y., has sold the two-story Spanish-type dwelling at 80 Ellwood Avenue, in Mount Vernon, to Harold B. Seligman through the Realty Mortgagee Corporation. The buyer was represented by Harriet Portman. The property is assessed at $16,000.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Fifty-six fellowships, totaling $90,000, and sixteen scholarships, worth $10,000 in all, have been awarded by the Julius Rosenwald Fund, Edwin R. Embree, president of the fund, announced today.

ADVANCED UNITED NATIONS BASE, Southwest Pacific, May 3 (AP) -- Telling of a raid that he led last Friday, 25-year-old Lieut. Col. Boyd (Buzz) Wagner of Johnstown, Pa., said today that he and his mates had engaged in "the most terrific dogfight I've ever seen -- rolling like tumbleweed up and down thirty miles of coastline of New Guinea."

NORWALK, Conn., May 3 -- Dr. J.H. McHenry sat in judgment today on his Japanese chauffeur and Hungarian-born gardner and decided that the gardner was to blame for the fisticuffs between the two men last Monday. He discharged the gardner.

Five new films are scheduled for this week, including today's entry, "The Mystery of Marie Roget," an adaptation of the Edgar Allan Poe story, at the Rialto. Patric Knowles, Maria Montez, John Litel, Maria Ouspenskaya and Lloyd Corrigan head the cast of the Universal melodrama.

The report for 1941 of the Pan American Airways System, for publication today, shows a net income of $3,361,251 after charges, taxes and reserves, but including a net gain of $891,654 from sales of building and equipment. The net was equal to $1.73 each on the 1,937,355 shares of capital stock outstanding.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, May 3 -- The Americans at an advanced flying base have just about all the comforts of home -- plus parrots and a Dutch oven burned out of an ant hill.

Divided India spoke with the voices both of Gandhi the pacifist and Nehru the militant nationalist in the resolution adopted on Sunday by the working committee of the All-India Congress. The pacifism was in the statement that resistance to invasion "can only take the form of non-violent non-cooperation."

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 29: decreases of $143,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans and $274,000,000 in United States Government deposits and an increase of $213,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.

MADISON, Wis., April 4 -- A poll by the School of Journalism of the University of Wisconsin of the editors and publishers of 500 daily newspapers throughout the country has resulted in the selection of THE NEW YORK TIMES as "the greatest newspaper in the world."

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 -- Continuing a wartime policy of undiminished enforcement of Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, the Securities and Exchange Commission instituted today proceedings against the Cities Service Company and four of its direct or indirect subsidiaries.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 4 (AP) -- For the first time in its history, American radio is meeting the challenge of a world war, according to a report by the committee on awards today at the thirteenth annual Institute for Education by Radio.

South African authorities have tightened import restrictions and foreign exchange rules pertaining thereto, according to cabled advices received yesterday by the New York agency of Barclays Bank. The new rules, which were distributed to the market by the Bankers Foreign Exchange Committee, were as follows:
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, May 4 -- President Roosevelt called today upon parents and teachers to help surround the children of America with all possible safeguards.

Your leading editorials of April 28 and 29 stress the important fact that wages in war industries are tending to increase, while the volume of goods which those wages can buy is being reduced. Unless the surplus wages can be immobilized, the inevitable result is a rise in prices which will prompt further rises in wages.

Five hundred delegates of the ministry and laity and members of their families attended yesterday the final session of the 143d New York Annual Conference of the Methodist Church, which began last Thursday. The conference was held in the Washington Square Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street, of which the Rev. C. Lloyd Lee is pastor.
LONDON, Tuesday, May 5 -- British bombers and fighters roared back and forth across the Channel in attacks on enemy strongholds in occupied France during the daylight hours yesterday.

As a result of a Circuit Court of Appeals decision that income taxes have priority over dividends declared by certain subsidiaries of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, stockholders of the Warren Railroad, one of these subsidiaries, are to hold a special meeting in Hoboken on May 27 to elect a new board of directors.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (AP) -- Al Simmons was banished from the coaching lines, and a fan, returning a foul ball hit into the stands, aimed it at Umpire Art Passarella as the Tigers defeated the Athletics today, 6 -- 4.

Dr. Julius L. Seligsohn, news of whose death has just been received in this country, did not fall as a soldier does in the anesthetizing excitement of battle. He did not die once, but daily, over many months. He is one name out of the many nameless who gave up their lives like heroes in the German concentration camps.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 4 -- It is estimated that United Nations air forces fighting over New Guinea have a three-to-one margin over the Japanese in the number of planes shot down in combat. But despite their heavy losses the Japanese forces continue to increase.

The Whitney Museum of American Art receives $2,500,000 under the will of its founder, Mrs. Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, who directed that the rest of her fortune, except for real estate and personal effects, be used for charitable and educational purposes and for the encouragement of art.

The American Car and Foundry Company has more business than at any previous time in its history, Charles J. Hardy, president, said in a statement to stockholders yesterday. He said that sales billed in the year ended April 30 were almost $200,000,000 and that the present total of billings exceeds that figure.

A nation-wide campaign to "Buy a Bond for Mother's Day" under the auspices of Saks Thirty-fourth Street, in cooperation with the American Women's Volunteer Services, was opened yesterday in the department store by Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 4 -- Hungary is in the grip of a new "White Terror," according to reports reaching foreign military intelligence sources here tonight, and is under a virtual military dictatorship established by the General Staff, headed by Lieut. Field Marshal Franz Szombathelyi, and semi-official military organizations.

LONDON, May 4 -- Anticipation gave way to chagrin when employes of the United States Embassy opened two crates containing "a little gift" brought by General George C. Marshall and Harry Hopkins on their most recent visit here.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- United States exports for March had a total value of $608,570,000 and imports amounted to $272,287,000, the Department of Commerce announced today. For the first three months of this year exports reached a total of $1,566,581,000, an increase of 59 per cent compared with the corresponding period last year.

One of the by-products of the Victory Book Campaign, it has been learned, will be the distribution of books to large war production areas that are not served by libraries or book stores. Although the book drive has sought contributions for the Army, Navy and merchant marine, it has been found in the sorting of donations that there are many volumes, such as juveniles, that are unsuitable for the services.
CHICAGO, May 4 -- With "courage'' as its announced keynote, the Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution opened its convention tonight in the Medinah Temple.

Francis I. du Pont Co. and Chisholm Chapman will open tomorrow a new midtown office at 342 Madison Avenue under the co-managership of Geoffrey C. Ettlesen, Thomas B. Meek, J.C. Bennett and Lester Robins. Mr. Meek is president of the Association of Customers Brokers, Arthur J. Hansen, Jerome J. Seitz and Samson Gordon, all formerly with Orvis Brothers, are at the new du Pont office.

PITTSBURGH, May 4 -- A new step forward in harmonious relations between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations will be taken this week as a result of decisions of the Pennsylvania Federation of Labor and the Pennsylvania Industrial Union Council to send fraternal delegates to one another's annual conventions.
Ethel Wilkinson, in 205 E 78th St; Gerald F. Fitzgerald, Irma Berger, in 311 E 72d St; Mrs. Irving Ruland, in 157 E 72d St -- Pease Elliman, Inc, brokers.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Thomas F. Meaney, the candidate of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, was nominated by President Roosevelt today for fifth United States judge for the New Jersey district.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The State Department tonight officially informed the French Ambassador, Gaston Henry-Haye, that British forces acting with the approval of the United States Goverment had occupied the island of Madagascar.

Paul van Zeeland, former Belgian premier, reported yesterday on his arrival from England by clipper that British morale and confidence in ultimate victory of the United Nations remained unshaken and that any dissatisfaction in England was solely from the desire of the people to "get on with the war" more speedily and effectively.
GREAT NECK, L.I., May 4 -Al Ciuci and Barney Bernard of Fresh Meadow each posted a 65 to capture the opening pro-amateur tournament of the Long Island P.G.A. today over the Sound View course.

TOKYO, May 4 (from Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Japanese forces have made two fresh landings on the northwest coast of Mindanao, the Tokyo radio announced today. The landings, the announcement said, were made at Cagayan on Macajalar Bay and at Tagoloan, about twenty miles to the northwest.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- President Roosevelt, in a telegram to the War Production Board's shipbuilding stabilization conference here, warned that full wage increases now due to part of the nation's shipyard workers under union contracts, which provide periodic adjustments on the basis of living costs, are "irreconcilable with the national policy to control the cost of living."

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The island defenses of Manila Bay clustering around Corregidor experienced today the third day of intensive bombardment in the most recent Japanese onslaught, the War Department reported.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The essential need of children is freedom to develop the capacity to meet and participate in the realities, even the dangerous realities, of life, Dr. Frederick H. Allen of Philadelphia told the eighth PanAmerican Child Congress at its opening session here today.

When Spring becomes Summer, as it has this last week, New Yorkers start to think of hot-weather protection. Electric fans and linen slip covers and rugless floors all come to mind. So do salads and jellied soups and -- most of all, perhaps -- ice-cold beverages.

Arrangements for conversion of 4,000 tapestry looms and 1,000 plush looms to the production of osnaburgs and cotton duck, two critical war materials, have been virtually completed. This equipment, said to represent the major portion of the industry's facilities, will be used to provide 200,000,000 yards of osnaburg and 40,000,000 yards of cotton duck.

NEW DELHI, India, May 4 -- A promise to continue his work for a national front and national party to meet the Japanese threats was made today by Chakravarthi Rajagopalachari, leader of the Madras Congress party.
Soldiers and sailors of the United Nations who have seen service on widespread fronts helped the Museum of Modern Art last night open an art sale for its war program.

Mill buying in the distant months, presumably against govermnent orders for 1943, and liquidation in the near months combined to produce widening differences in the cotton market yesterday. This dual activity caused active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange to close unchanged to 8 points higher than Saturday's final prices.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Postmaster General Frank C. Walker revoked today the second-class mail license of the Social Justice Publishing Company of Royal Oak, Mich., after representatives of the paper failed to appear to show cause why Social Justice should not be banned from the mails for sedition.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 6 per cent last week, in comparison with the same week last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The figure is unchanged from the percentage of gain shown in the preceding week.

CHUNGKING, China, May 1 (Delayed) -- Unsung heroes in China's five-year struggle against aggression are her wartime postmen. Homeless, underpaid -- as are nearly all government workers -- yet unhesitatingly loyal and responsible, these postmen daily brave bullets and bombs to carry the mails up to and through the front lines, keeping the soldiers and civilians in occupied and unoccupied areas in contact with the rest of the world.

Registration to provide a general census of women in New York City who are available for voluntary service in the Civilian Defense program was advocated yesterday by Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, chairman of the Manhattan Office of Civilian Defense.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, said today that recommendations on the degree of gasoline curtailment deemed necessary for the East Coast would be made by his office tomorrow. He was testifying before a House Interstate and Foreign Commerce subcommittee which is investigating the oil situation.

Even a change in date and site may not be enough to keep the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta, known more familiarly as the Poughkeepsie, on the 1942 sports calendar, a survey by The Associated Press showed last night.

The pricing and showing to buyers of Fall lines of women's and children's apparel were delayed here yesterday pending clarification of seasonal pricing of merchandise under the General Maximum Price Regulations of the OPA.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 4 (AP) -- Nicotine, that much-abused component of tobacco that has been blamed for so many things, was today tentatively exonerated of one charge commonly made against it.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 4 -- Undeterred by the refusal of Westchester County to preserve the historic Boscobel mansion at Crugers-on-Hudson, a group of historians and civic leaders organized under the name of Boscobel, Inc., began a campaign here today to save the structure from wreckers' hammers.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (AP) -- William W. Bodine, president of the United Gas Improvement Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting today that the concern was retaining a major portion of cash resources pending completion of proceedings to comply with the Holding Company Act.

TRENTON, May 4 -- Using seven pens, which were given to interested onlookers, Governor Charles Edison signed today a bill providing stiff penalties for war or public works contractors who refuse to employ a person because of race, color or creed.

CHICAGO, May 4 (AP) -- The American retail family, which includes a total of 8,000,000 persons, enlisted for the duration of the war today -- in a campaign to sell $1,000,000,000 worth of war stamps and bonds in 1942.

HALIFAX, N.S., May 4 (Canadian Press) -- After spending twenty-two days on a liferaft, Robert William Hilcken, 17-year-old United States Navy gunner, sat on his hospital bed here today and grinned as he read that two memorial masses had nearly been sung for him in Fairview, N.J., where his family gave him up as dead after his merchant ship was torpedoed in the Western Atlantic.
YONKERS, N.Y., May 4 -- Dan Galgano, youthful Woodway pro, and Charlie McAdam of Tamarack led in a field of twenty-one proamateur teams at Dunwoodie today in the Westchester golf opener.

Manufacturers and retailers of men's wear, attending a luncheon sponsored by Affiliateed Clothiers, Inc., resident buying office, at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday, agreed that while the price ceilings would cause some temporary hardship, they would eventually work out to the best interests of all concerned.

A realignment of the advertising, publicity and exploitation services of Twentieth Century-Fox was announced yesterday coincident with the appointment of Hal Horne as director of advertising and publicity. Mr. Horne will take up his new duties immediately and his predecessor, A.M. Botsford, who was appointed to the post last Fall, will return to Hollywood next month as special studio representative fore distribution.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has authorized the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and the Pennsylvania Company to acquire control of the Wabash Railroad Company through ownership of its capital stock.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The President, as he demonstrated today in his telegram to the shipyards' wage negotiators at Chicago, fully realizes that the settlement reached at that conference, or after reference of the issue to the War Labor Board, will set the pattern of a stabilized national war-wage policy or start a spiral of increases throughout industry.

LOS ANGELES, May 4 -- The Los Angeles Times fought for three and one-half years to confirm the right of the nation's press to comment on judicial cases in which verdicts have been rendered. Its struggle was rewarded today with the announcement that the publication had received the Pulitzer Prize for the most disinterested public service of an American newspaper in 1941.

The decks were cleared yesterday for the Navy Relief Society meeting of the Giants and Dodgers in Ebbets Field Friday, a struggle that will start at 4:45 P.M. and provide the first major league twilight baseball game in local history.

In the vast complex development of our war program the solution of one problem inevitably gives rise to another. Now that the output of war materials is beginning to roll in ever-increasing volume, the job of moving that production becomes increasingly acute.

Reporting yesterday on operations in the fiscal year ending with February, Martin L. Straus, president of Eversharp, Inc., informed stockholders that the volume of sales reached a new high record of more than 100 per cent over the previous year.
LONDON, May 4 -- Business on the stock markets was quiet today and prices closed higher in many cases. Gilt-edge issues were easier but the home rails gained fractionally.

MEXICO CITY, May 4 -- A recent speech in which Vicente Lombardo Toledano, head of the Mexican Confederation of Labor, attacked several members of the Cabinet, including Communications Minister Maximino Avila Camacho, the President's brother, has caused a stir in political circles here and brought a retort today from Maximino Avila Camacho.

A thorough but mildly phrased denial of recent War Production Board charges that United States Steel Corporation's principal producing subsidiary had violated repeatedly and still was deliberately violating priority regulations was given to stockholders of the country's largest steel company at their forty-first annual meeting at Hoboken, N.J., yesterday forenoon, by Irving S. Olds, chairman of the board.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 5 -- To forestall a Japanese move against the French naval base of Diego Suarez, on Madagascar Island, "a combined British naval and military force arrived off the island at dawn this morning," according to a joint communique issued by the British Admiralty and War Office early today.

BOSTON, May 4 (AP) -- Bobby Doerr, the American League's leading hitter, had a perfect day at the plate today while pacing the Red Sox to an 11-8 victory over the Indians. Doerr, who has hit safely in ten straight games, collected two singles and a double with the bases loaded to boost his average to 467.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 4 -- Dr. Benjamin F. Barnes, Mayor of Yonkers, was criticized this afternoon at a meeting of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors for "refusal to cooperate" with the new Westchester County War Council.
As Maine attracts anglers by the thousands each year there is a reason for the interest shown in the bulletins that are received almost daily regarding the early fishing there.
With neatness and dispatch, the Yankees submerged the White Sox yesterday at the Stadium to bag their third straight victory, all at the expense of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to extend the Civilian Conservation Corps and the National Youth Administration for another year and to appropriate $102,150,000 for the two agencies for the fiscal year 1943.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 4 -- Terminating an association which began last December, William Saroyan, playwright and novelist, has left Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer reportedly because the studio would not let him produce and direct his photoplay, "The Human Comedy," which the studio bought from him for $60,000 as a vehicle for Mickey Rooney.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Passage of the $2,125,000,000 Independent Offices Appropriation Bill was delayed another day today while members of the Senate argued over an amendment by Senator McKellar which would require the Tennessee Valley Authority to turn over all its revenues from sale of light and power to the Federal Treasury.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- In a six-to-three decision the Supreme Court supported today the action of the Interstate Commerce Commission in refusing to grant Chicago packing houses free egress for livestock shipments from the Chicago Union Stockyards.

The annual award of the prizes in journalism and letters, established in 1917 under the will of Joseph Pulitzer, was announced yesterday afternoon by the trustees of Columbia University after they had acted on the recommendations of the Advisory Board of the Graduate School of Journalism.

The story is told of a fine middle-class American family in the moderate brackets which found itself at the end of the year $5,000 in debt as the result of a great deal of illness, a fire in the house and lesser mishaps.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Roosevelt issued an order giving the Office of Defense Transportation power to set policies for wartime control of passenger cars, buses, taxicabs and trucks; nominated Rear Admirals Adolphus Andrews and John W. Greenslade to be vice admirals; nominated Thomas F. Meaney to be United States judge for the District of New Jersey.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 4 -- The Socialist Labor party outlined today the resolutions of the third general congress of the members, drawn from all points in Chile, which closed yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, May 4 -- Manager Leo Durocher not only was pained yesterday by the loss of two games to the Cardinals but he and three other Dodgers, Captain Dolph Camilli, Freddy Fitzsimmons and Chet Kehn, were hit today where it hurt the most -- in their pocketbooks.
The nine-story apartment building at 13-19 West Eleventh Street has been acquired by the Ralph Lloyd Corporation from the Union Dime Savings Bank for cash above a mortgage of $300,000.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Denying Department of Justice charges that inability to deliver his patented "cowl fastener," coupled with unwillingness to allow other concerns to manufacture them under license, had been causing a serious delay in construction of fighting planes, William Dzus told the Senate Patents Committee today that he had tried to enlarge his factory but had been blocked by the Office of Production Management.

The approach of another Mother's Day leads me to some reflections on its proper observance. I have known intimately two mothers in my own life and I have memories of both that cause me to have opinions on the subject that may be shared with others.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a plan for the merger of the Northwestern Ohio Natural Gas Company into the Ohio Fuel Gas Company. Both are subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Recommendation for a rise from 6 to 10 per cent in the surtax on corporations earning less than $25,000 a year was voted today by the Ways and Means Committee. Last week the committee proposed that rates for larger corporations should be increased from 7 to 16 per cent.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 4 -- British Commando troops, aided by enthusiastic Bretons, captured the German field headquarters in Saint-Nazaire and held it for forty-eight hours before being dislodged by superior numbers, according to a person now in Stockholm who visited the French port after the raid.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 4 -- A $1,000,000 packet of diamonds, lost when a plane flying from Java was shot down by the Japanese off the Australian coast, was found by an unidentified beachcomber after official searches failed, it was announced today.

The report of the Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income for the period, after expenses and charges, of $4,565,011. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.21 a share on the outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $5,049,449, or $1.45 a common share, in twelve months to March 31, 1941.

LONDON, May 4 -- An unofficial stay-in strike of workers -- most of them women -- at a Midlands factory and a strike of over fifteen hundred men and boys employed at the Whitburn Colliery in County Durham threatens to delay Britain's war effort in two of its most vital aspects, it was revealed today.

Human beings are far more rational than their conduct generally indicates. When fundamentals are involved, as in war -- when a philosophy of life, a way of living, is at stake -- they are extremely rational. They want to know the reason why.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, May 5 (U.P.) -- Russian troops swung into the offensive against the Germans in several sectors of the water-logged front yesterday, the High Command reported today. A late communique announced that the Red Army had improved its positions in offensive battles at several points.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The War Department communique based on reports received here up to 9:30 A.M. said:

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 4 -Bill Urban of the Aldecress Golf Club led a field of twenty-eight players at the hilly Plainfield Country Club course today in the New Jersey sectional qualifying round for the Professional Golfers Association national tournament at Seaview, N.J., May 25-31.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Japanese landing on Mindanao reported today was the fourth invasion of that island, the second in size in the Philippines, which often has been termed the Philippine "Wild West" because its resources have been relatively little tapped.

On April 4 the body of John P. Broff, 40 years old, of 655 Leonard Street, Brooklyn, an employee of the Consolidated Edison Company, was found at 3 A.M. on the steps of 136 West 117th Street. He had been fatally stabbed and robbed of $51.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, reported to the Mayor yesterday that he had found no substantiation for charges made by Paul J. Kern, former president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, that a Bronx garage foreman employed by the city had used city material to improve his Summer home and had acquired furniture in an improper manner.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- A charge that officers' commissions were being dealt out with an eye to creating pressure for a separate air corps was made today by Representative Faddis of Pennsyl vania, who is critical of all commissions given to civilians without military training.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The British occupation of Madagascar, announced tonight, came after weeks of anxious speculation hinging on the advance of Japanese forces in the eastern regions of the Indian Ocean. This was complicated by the known presence in Madagascar of a number of Nazi "technicians," who had been sent ostensibly to "cooperate" with the French officials there.

A fresh wave of German terrorism is sweeping across the Continent as the time nears for Hitler's long-heralded Spring offensive. Yesterday's dispatches brought news of the execution of seventy-two Dutch citizens accused of "favoring the enemy." This is the common crime of every subject people from one end of Europe to the other.

For two hours yesterday morning 15,000 youngsters lifted their voices in joyous and sustained acclaim. Laughter and cheers mingled with staccato "ohs" and long "oohs" throughout Madison Square Garden.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 4 -- George Turner of Somers Township, dean of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors until his recent resignation, was sentenced today by County Judge Frank H. Coyne to serve one year in the county penitentiary and pay a $250 fine for having misapproriated Somers Township funds.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Midwest and Far West are matching New York as important factors as money markets for the Treasury Department, officials here said tonight as they awaited returns from those regions before announcing that the books had been closed for subscriptions to the Treasury's $1,250,000,000 of 2 per cent bonds maturing in 1951.
CAIRO, May 4 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Middle East Command issued this communique today:
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The War Production Board, in one of the broadest conservation orders it has ever issued, today forbade the use of iron and steel in more than 400 common civilian products.

ALBANY, May 4 -- At the request of Mayor La Guardia, Governor Lehman vetoed today the Johnson bill providing for free transportation of all men in the uniforms of the fighting forces of the United Nations on the New York City rapid transit and ferry lines.

LONDON, May 4 (U.P.) -- An army of Rumanian guerrillas has risen in the Balkans, wrecked a German troop train, set an oil train on fire and raided a German barracks, forcing Adolf Hitler to dispatch additional troops to the country to guard the rear of his armies in Russia, it was reported here tonight.

Despite the fact that the Treasury withdrew $266,248,000 from commercial bank depositaries throughout the nation yesterday, of which $142,842,000 was taken from the New York District, the Treasury announced yesterday that it would withdraw $212,087,000 on Thursday from these banks, of which the New York commercial bank depositaries will give up half.

With imminent price ceilings putting an effective damper on the desire of shoe manufacturers to get advances of 25 to 50 cents a pair on Fall styles, the organized openings yesterday met indifference on the part of buyers. As a matter of fact, some exhibitors canceled their showings yesterday and returned to their home.

PITTSBURGH, May 4 -- Elbie Fletcher's only hit of the game, a sharp ninth-inning single, gave the Pirates a 2-1 victory over the Braves today and the Bucs advanced to within a half-game of the National League-leading Dodgers, who did not play.
