The nation's determination to face difficulties cheerfully to win the war was exemplified by the first day of sugar rationing yesterday when household consumers of the nation applied for and obtained their war ration books. At the close of the day a total of 2,551,282 books for roughly one-third of New York City's population had been issued.

Reassuring publishers and printers that the WPB is allowing the industry the unrestricted use of its paper and other materials once war needs have been met, E. W. Palmer, assistant chief of the printing and publishing branch of the WPB, yesterday cautioned publishers against waste and declared that self-regulation could put off the day when allocations and priorities would be imposed.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 4 -- Air Minister Arthur S. Drakeford and General Douglas MacArthur, Allied Commander in Chief, traveled today from Australian headquarters to attend the funeral of Brig. Gen. Harold H. George, who was killed in an air accident last week.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., May 4 (U.P.) -- The Great Lakes Naval Training Station baseball team, led by Lieutenant Gordon (Mickey) Cochrane, bowed to the Cubs, 6 to 3, today in a renewal of a "series" started twenty-four years ago. The Great Lakes team of World War I dropped a 5-0 decision to the Cubs.
BERLIN, May 4 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The text of the German communique:

Every one not engaged in emergency activities must remain indoors during tonight's practice blackout in Northern Queens, it was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine. This is the first time this drastic step is being taken and is believed to be the result of Mayor La Guardia's indignation over the presence of crowds in Times Square during last week's blackout.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 4 -- While the Federal Government remains uncertain about the need for or advisability of a nation-wide registration of women, either on a voluntary or compulsory basis, Connecticut went ahead today with its State-wide voluntary mobilization of woman power to meet what one official called "a present need" in this highly industrialized State.

The Army Air Corps new enlistment program, which will permit college students to enlist and continue their college education, was explained to 600 Columbia University students yesterday by Colonel H.G. Woodward of the Army aviation enlistment board at a special meeting at the Harkness Theatre on the campus.
The sale of a large loft building on East End Avenue and two deals in East Fifty-fourth Street were listed among the East Side transactions reported by Manhattan brokers yesterday.

The sinking of the 6,692-ton Brazilian freighter Parnahyba and of a medium-sized British merchant ship were officially announced yesterday, while an unconfirmed report was relayed here by The United Press that a large United States merchant ship had been torpedoed and sunk off the eastern coast of Venezuela.

LOS ANGELES, May 4 -- Secretary Knox said today that the United States' stake in the war is "all we have and all we are" and when victory comes "we will all share in the awful responsibilities and the stirring opportunity it will bring."

Slackening of demand combined with light selling to produce a mixed closing yesterday on the Stock Exchange after the early trading in stocks had extended the recovery of last week. Best additions centered in the public utilities, but even here the high levels of the day were not maintained, although a few specialties managed to keep ahead of the trend.

Operations of the City Stores Company and its subsidiaries in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, resulted in the second largest sales volume in the history of the company, according to the annual report signed by Albert M. Greenfield, chairman of the board, and Saul Cohn, president.

BALTIMORE, May 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Payne Whitney's Shut Out arrived today at Pimlico, where he will try Saturday to pick up another rich purse in the Preakness Stakes. Shut Out came to town from Louisville with much less ado than usually attends the arrival of a Kentucky Derby winner, but he looked fit as a horse can be.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 4 -- German submarine activity along the United States and Canadian coasts interests neutral naval observers in various European capitals. German official quarters abstain from discussing conditions under which these operations have been made possible.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The chartered Swedish liner Drottningholm will sail for Lisbon from New York on Thursday with Axis officials and nationals, according to present plans.

The realty firm of J. Halperin Co. of Jamaica, L.I., announces that since it opened offices in Norfolk, Va., Oct. 27 last, for the placing of mortgage loans, commitments have been obtained from the FHA during the six-month period totaling $6,149,560 for 1,713 dwelling units.

The Treasury's huge financing plan published on Monday, involving offering of $1,250,000,000 of regular open-market 2 per cent bonds due in 1949-51 and 2 1/2 per cent bonds due in 1962-67 in an unspecified amount, got off yesterday to a "flying start," according to reports in Wall Street.

Play schools maintained by the Play Schools Association and attended by children whose parents are working in war plants are "a very important project," Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the Port of New York Authority, declared yesterday.

Again Morningside awards the laurels. The Los Angeles Times defender of the freedom of the press against judicial arrogance, is justly honored for assertion of a right that in time of war is most open to attack. Geoffrey Parsons of our neighbor, The Herald Tribune, receives an accolade owed to his long distinction in his profession, emphasized by the steady wisdom of his writings before the war and since it began.

There will be a feeling of immense relief in every one of the United Nations over the fact that at last we have beaten the Axis to an important move. The British occupation of the island of Madagascar takes the initiative away from Japan in the great battle which will soon begin for the command of the Indian Ocean.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Roosevelt today gave the Office of Defense Transportation, headed by Joseph B. Eastman, power to set policies for wartime control of passenger cars, buses, taxicabs and trucks, including the authority to limit the use of these for "non-essential civilian activities."

William J. Scheirer, 36-year-old American survivor of a recent torpedoing of a Swedish vessel off the Atlantic Coast, declared yesterday that although the submarine that sank the freighter on which he served was Italian, its commander was unmistakably a German.
LONDON, May 4 (AP) -- A joint communique of the Air and Home Security Ministries said today:

LONDON, May 4 -- Admiral Harold R. Stark cited today a remark of Admiral William S. Sims, his former chief and his predecessor in the job of commanding United States naval forces on this side of the Atlantic, to show that the campaign against German submarines was one of the vital issues of the war.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The names of 2,991 officers and men of the Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard who gave their lives for their country in the first four months of war, were made public tonight by the Navy Department.

The Mayor, the City Council, the Legislature, the Governor and the War Production Board have all spoken or acted in favor of taking down what is left of the Second Avenue elevated line -- that is, the section between Sixtieth Street and Chatham Square. In a negative way the line is ugly, out-of-date, and has long been losing trade.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 4 -- Between 7,000 and 8,000 persons were killed in the Royal Air Force's bombing of Rostock over four nights and more than 30,000 are homeless, according to estimates of reliable persons recently arrived here from Berlin.

CHUNGKING, China, May 4 -- Three powerful Japanese columns had pushed the United Nations armies back within 150 miles of India and within twenty-five miles of China tonight in swift offensives that threatened to develop into invasions of both those vast countries and to overrun the still unconquered part of Burma.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Beverage alcohol distilleries must devote seventy-five days' output of high wines for the remainder of this year to the production of alcohol to meet war requirements, the War Production Board announced today.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association petitioned Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, yesterday for modification of ODT orders affecting newspaper delivery, and submitted a six-point plan designed to reduce mileage more than ODT orders contemplate without curtailing deliveries drastically.

LONDON, May 4 -- The British Admiralty had nothing to say tonight on German claims that one of Britain's 10,000-ton cruisers had been sunk by a submarine during a running attack by German submarines and light surface forces on an Arctic convoy.

More than half of the 587,040 New Yorkers who enrolled in the third Selective Service registration last February have received their occupational questionnaires, it was announced yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, draft director here.

Each New Yorker was asked yesterday to be his own "water warden" by Patrick Quilty, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, who said the conservation of water now was a patriotic duty for every one. Mr. Quilty said the city's up-State reservoirs held 20,000,000,000 gallons less than the amount of water in storage at this time last year.
NORWICH, England, May 4 -- The first mass burial of those who were killed in Norwich in last week's sharp air raids was held today.

Miss Helen Thompson, 26 years old, was about to be called yesterday as an important prosecution witness in the General Sessions trial of two men for thefts totaling $1,200,000 in five years from the Tide Water Associated Oil Company, at 17 Battery Place, when both defendants pleaded guilty.

CINCINNATI, May 4 -- Incredible as it may seem, the Giants ran into a blackout in broad daylight today. At least, everything went black for Master Melvin Ott as his cohorts split wide open, fell all over themselves and allowed the Reds to pour twelve runs across in the fourth inning.

A pair of 3-year-olds bred on opposite sides of the Atlantic but handled yesterday at Jamaica by the same jockey each won at a mile and a sixteenth with a full second's difference in the time. In the Meridian Handicap, Ship's Run scored for Ogden Phipps in 1:45 1-5, with Jack Westrope driving his best to keep a tired horse going.
Biographical sketches of winners of Pulitzer Prizes in letters and journalism follow:

LONDON, May 4 -- The German radio today broadcast the news that seventy-two Netherlanders had been shot and seven sentenced to life imprisonment for aiding the United Nations secret service, for being in possession of arms and explosives and "in some cases for breaking their word of honor as officers." The report of the executions was confirmed in Netherland official circles in London tonight.
MONTREAL, May 4 -- Leon Henderson, United States Price Administrator, speaking at a Canadian Club luncheon here today, said that American production was no longer a problem -- "we've got it licked."

The five-story house containing sixty-seven apartments at 6049-55 Boulevard East, West New York, N.J., has been sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company, trustee, to the Boulevard East Realty Corporation of Hoboken, Felix Neumann, president.

Changes in the last quarter century in the structure and functioning of government in the State and City of New York "may constitute a serious threat to the ability of the social service departments to actually deliver social service," Homer Folks, secretary of the State Charities Aid Association, declared yesterday.

Captain Silvio Magalhaes Padilha, director general of the Department of Physical Education and Sports of the State of Sao Paulo, Brazil, who has completed a forty-day tour of this country, expressed the hope yesterday on his arrival here that athletic teams of the United States soon would be sent to Brazil.

BERLIN, May 4 (From German broadcast) -- In an Arctic Ocean battle that lasted several days despite "stormy weather and heavy seas," German surface and undersea warships and bombers sank a 10,000-ton cruiser and six freighters totaling 37,500 tons from a convoy, the German communique declared today.

VICHY, France, May 4 (U.P.) -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain today received Admiral Naokuni Nomura and Rear Admiral Katsuo Abe, special Japanese envoys to Berlin and Rome, respectively, who are completing their round of conferences and entertainment in Vichy.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended April 29 aggregated $11,141,000, 000.

The season wanes, but there are still life-like signs on and off Broadway and the week of May 17 promises to be a busy one as things now stand. Two Broadway openings are listed for May 19 and one for the next evening.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 4 -- The war is almost entirely static from Gibraltar to the Dardanelles, excepting Malta, and viewed from here the situation presents no visible prospects of immediate change.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 4 -- General Sefik Cakmak, chief of the Turkish air staff, and a party of Turkish air staff and tank officers have just completed an inspection of the Middle Eastern front and of American and British planes, tanks and other equipment now in use in Cyrenaica.

E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc., and Glover MacGregor, Inc., received yesterday the award of an issue of $250,000 of refunding bonds of Cambria County, Pa., on their bid of 100.66 for 13/4s. The bonds, dated May 15, 1942, will mature on May 15, 1944 to 1952.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt presided at a ceremony yesterday morning at the offices of the Treasury War Savings Staff, 1270 Sixth Avenue, marking the official opening in New York State of the campaign to get buyers to take part of their change in war savings stamps.

Michael J. Kennedy, leader of Tammany Hall, announced yesterday that he had called a meeting of the New York County Democratic Executive Committee for May 14 to hear a report on plans for reorganization. The committee is expected also to elect a new chairman.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The probability that the Senate Military Affairs Committee will approve the Rogers bill to create a Women's Army Auxiliary Corps was mentioned today by Senator Reynolds, chairman of the committee.

AT AN ADVANCED ALLIED BASE, Southwest Pacific, May 4 (U.P.) -- All the enchantments of the South Sea Islands, plus a dash of old France, greeted American soldiers when they landed here among the Javanese, French, Indo-Chinese and fuzzy-haired natives of Free French New Caledonia, it was revealed today.

The recovery movement in the stock market was extended yesterday for the sixth consecutive session with the over-all average advance at a point, although some key groups tended to back water. Except for the British landing on Madagascar, an initiative which brokers held created a better feeling among investors, the news was not of a character to bring out any added activity.

Young farmers and farmerettes picked up their hoes, shovels and water pails yesterday and began their Spring planting of vegetables on their own individual "farms" at York Avenue, between Sixty-fourth and Sixty-seventh Streets.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Frank E. Mullen, vice president and general manager of the National Broadcasting Company, told the House Interstate Commerce Committee today that any revision of the law governing radio should aim to preserve "the American system of broadcasting," and that "a free radio supported by private enterprise, free from government subsidy or ownership, is one of our democratic bulwarks."

In denying a claim for triple damages for alleged discrimination under the Robinson-Patman act, a jury in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York has upheld the right of a seller to charge varying prices on similar goods to the same class of customers, where the variations merely reflect rapid market changes.

LONDON, May 5 -- Small units of British Commandos and regular troops won a bridgehead at Courier Bay in the action against Madagascar and were reported tonight to be fighting their way across a ten-mile-wide isthmus toward the important naval base of Diego Suarez.

A vast army of volunteer price-control wardens, without legal powers of any kind, will be established through an expanded number of local rationing boards, which will be the point of contact for the public in the administration of the over-all price ceilings that go into effect for retailers on May 18.
Mrs. Wainwright Abbott has arrived from Suva, Fiji Islands, and is at Mayfair House.

Helen Keller, deaf and blind author, in behalf of the board of trustees of the American Foundation for the Blind, presented to Senator Robert F. Wagner an engrossed scroll commemorating his support of legislation benefiting the blind of America, at the foundation's headquarters, 15 West Sixteenth Street, yesterday afternoon.

NEWARK, N.J., May 5 -- John H. Vogel, 54 years old, of Belmar, N.J., the trainmaster who dispatched the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad train that was wrecked in the Exchange Place station, Jersey City, on April 26, attempted suicide by slashing his throat and wrists in Weequahic Park here today, according to the Newark police.

Plans for the registration of motorists for gasoline rationing next week were mapped by Federal and City officials yesterday as registration for sugar rationing continued for the second day. Gasoline registration will cover the three-day period from Tuesday to Thursday inclusive.
Both the east and west sides of the midtown section shared in the residential leasing activity reported yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia's opposition to free transit rides for service men was denounced yesterday by Vice Chairman Joseph T. Sharkey, leader of the Democratic majority in the City Council, who said that the Mayor's attitude conflicted directly with the wish of the people of the city to do everything possible for men in the armed forces.

Moving up steadily on the outside at the head of the stretch, Louis B. Mayer's 3-to-4 favorite, Painted Veil, under an easy ride by Jack Westrope, took the Maud Muller Handicap at Jamaica yesterday by a neck from the Brookmeade Stable's Pomayya, the leader for most of the mile and a sixteenth.

The 1941 annual report of the American Cable and Radio Corporation, issued yesterday by John L. Merrill, chairman, shows a consolidated net income after expenses and charges of $556,623 for the year, compared with a net of $546,150 in 1940.

In the publishing season of the year 1947 the runaway best-seller on the non-fiction list was a small book called "Civilization's Debt to the Banker." The title is enough to explain the sensation which the book created.

Sending of advertising mats and proofs to all retail accounts instead of to those who asked for them has brought a fourfold increase in local advertising of Pyrex ware by stores, Robert A. Whitney, sales promotion manager of the Corning Glass Works, reported yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- Grain traders hesitated today to take the buying side of wheat on the Board of Trade as the result of a five-day advance. Prices eased early on scattered selling, but later, when shorts tried to cover, they found offerings light and the market rallied around 3/4 cent a bushel from the low level with the close at the top with gains of 1/8 cent.

BOSTON, May 5 (AP) -- The Red Sox bombarded a trio of pitchers for eighteen hits and a total of twenty-eight bases today while sweeping their three-games series with the league-leading Indians with a 13-3 triumph. The victory advanced the Red Sox from fourth to third place.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A recommendation that the Erie Railroad be denied permission to abandon parts of its line in Steuben and Livingston Counties, New York, was submitted today to the Interstate Commerce Commission by J.S. Prichard, examiner.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, May 5 (U.P.) -- United Nations' planes, one flight of them led by 52-year-old Brig. Gen. Martin F. Scanlon of Scranton, Pa., have damaged or destroyed more Japanese planes and spread fiery destruction among two of Japan's largest invasion bases, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt said today that the United States Committee for the Care of European Children was considering how it can help some of these young people without subjecting them to the hazards of an ocean voyage to this country.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 5 United Nations planes again raided the airdrome at Lae, New Guinea, yesterday, and grounded aircraft, it was announced today. The airdrome at Rabaul, New Britain, also was attacked. Three enemy planes were hit.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 5 -- Jean Renoir, French film director, and Dudley Nichols, scenarist, have closed a deal with RKO for the production of a film about the German occupation of Belgium, with Charles Laughton in the leading role.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (AP) -- Rookie Russ Christopher, drafted from a Yankee farm, pitched a three-hitter in his first major league start today to give the Athletics a 2-1 victory over the Tigers, who dropped from second to fourth place in the standing.

The Bronx County grand jury that has been hearing evidence on the paving with city materials and labor of a courtyard on the Lake Mahopac estate of Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, as well as other irregularities in the Bronx, handed up a seventeen-page presentment yesterday, finding that Bronx County is "singularly free of fraud and corruption," but that many irregularities are prevalent.

BALBOA, C.Z., May 5 -- President Prado of Peru will leave tomorrow morning in a chartered plane. He spent last night and tonight here as guest of Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews, commanding the Caribbean defense, who piloted the plane which brought President Prado from Peru.

PITTSBURGH, May 5 (AP) -- Jimmy Wallace, a tiny, apple-cheeked boy with a winning smile and a pretzel curve, made his bow as a big league hurler for the Braves today -- and did a man-sized chore of throttling the Pirates, 7 -- 1, on six widely scattered hits.

A difficult situation faces the 116 institutions affiliated with the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies despite impending price ceiling orders, it was said yesterday by George Z. Medalie, president of the federation.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- A direct tie-up between crooked policemen and ambulance-chasing lawyers was charged by the Philadelphia Bar Association in a report to the board of judges of the Court of Common Pleas.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- Delegates to the congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution pledged themselves today to buy $106,000 in war bonds. Of this amount $24,000 was pledged for the national society by Mrs. Samuel James Campbell, treasurer general, to complete a quota of $50,000 for the calendar year.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Seeking to force a House vote on a bill which would repeal the granting of pensions to an estimated 250,000 government officials and employes, some of them in the $10,000-a-year class and entitled to annuities of about $5,000, Representative Smith of Ohio today resorted to a petition of discharge to get the measure to the floor.

Descending on Harlem vice dens early yesterday morning, thirty-four plainclothes men and forty-two detectives visited bars, apartments and other places and arrested fifty-three men and thirty-three woman on charges of vagrancy.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., May 5 (U.P.) -- The Missouri Supreme Court suppressed today as "scandalous, impertinent and scurrilous" opinions of its chief justice, Ernest S. Gantt, and Judge Ernest M. Tipton in a case arising from fire insurance rate litigation that began twenty years ago.
BERNE, Switzerland, May 5 -- With Washington supporting British action in Madagascar, Europe fully realized today that "the American phase of the war" had begun in earnest.

As the seriousness of whooping cough, both as to incidence and mortality, among New York children increased last week, Health Commissioner John L. Rice warned yesterday against unnecessary exposure of children to contagion. In the week ended Saturday there were 284 new cases and three deaths.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Roosevelt held one of the shortest press conferences on record today and revealed so little news that when a correspondent broke up the session with the customary "Thank you, Mr. President," the Chief Executive laughed heartily and inquired:

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The officers and crew of a Navy patrol bomber received today special honors for landing their ship in rough seas and rescuing sixteen men and one woman who had survived the torpedoing of a merchant ship near San Juan, P.R., on last March 9.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Five witnesses who recently testified before the special grand jury regarding the magazine Social Justice have been recalled and another has been subpoenaed, the Department of Justice disclosed today.
HOLLEY, N.Y., May 5 -- Caesar, 175-pound golden-brindle Great Dane, convicted as "dangerous" and ordered "securely confined," will be released Sunday at the expiration of his one-year sentence.

Bishop William T. Manning urged a redoubling of effort "to strengthen the church for its great missions" in this time of crisis, in addressing yesterday the annual meeting of the Women's Auxiliary to the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

Experts are of the opinion that steel frames in buildings afford greater protection to people within them during bombing raids than any other form of available refuge. To the warships -- particularly the huge ones of 35,000 tons -- might be given the palm for being the least safe steel containers for human beings.

A two-year contract between the Screen Publicists Guild of New York and six major motion picture companies was signed yesterday after eight months of negotiations. Wage increases totaling $79,000, plus retroactive pay amounting to $31,000, for 169 employes of Columbia, RKO, Loew's-Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Universal, Twentieth Century-Fox and Paramount, are contained in the contract.

Still groping for a clarification of the price-control policies that the Administration will soon initiate for agricultural products, the cotton market became quiet yesterday as traders sought to defer negotiating contracts until the outcome of tomorrow's farm bloc meeting in Washington is known.

A Federal official began yesterday an investigation into conditions in a Brooklyn shipyard that have become a source of amazement and some indignation to Federal Judge Murray Hulbert. The situation was uncovered when Judge Hulbert found that an alien Italian, who had come before him for sentencing on a narcotic charge, had obtained frequent access to the shipyard.

The first annual meeting of Standard Brands, Inc., to be held at the company's offices here attracted 250 shareholders yesterday and developed into a protracted "hammer-and-tongs" meeting. Previous meetings were held at Dover, Del.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Child victims of the second World War got attention today at the White House and at the British Embassy.

Cotton fashions for a round-the-clock Summer wardobe were featured yesterday in De Pinna's showing in the Oval Room of the Ritz Carlton. Ine one of the newer uses of washables, men's wear cotton suitings in women's two-piece "tailor-mades" were emphasized.

Several hundred representatives of the nation's mutual savings banks are expected to attend the three-day annual meeting of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks which will open today at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

This was a planned war that is not proceeding according to anybody's plan. No military enterprises in history were so carefully blueprinted and thoroughly prepared in advance as Germany's and Japan's campaigns of conquest. Yet when they converged yesterday, for the confused fighting in Madagascar was a shadowy point of contact between the aggressor of Europe and the aggressor of Asia, the encounter brought into startling focus all the unexpected developments of this struggle.

Almost 2,000 foreign traders took time out yesterday at two separate meetings to hear an official explanation and clarification of the export price ceiling order by government spokesmen, and left the gatherings with but two definite assurances -- that the Office of Price Administration and the Bureau of Economic Warfare were sympathetic toward their problems, and that the situation was being given "further study."
CINCINNATI, May 5 -- The swan gong the boys were singing over the supposedly faded greatness of Bucky Walters, it now develops, was not only slightly off key but wholly premature.
TORONTO, May 5 (AP) -- The Newark Bears extended their first place margin in the International League today with a 10-to-9 triumph over Toronto.

The twenty-family house at 170 East Thirty-second Street, Paterson, N.J., has been sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company, trustee, to William Givone for investment. J.I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker. Title will be insured by the New Jersey Realty Title Insurance Company.

The decisions just completed by the House Ways and Means Committee with respect to corporation tax rates for this year represent, as a whole, a distinct improvement over the proposals made by the Treasury. They strengthen the favorable impression of the committee's ability and good sense which has been growing during the past two months of hearings before it.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed issuance and sale through competitive bidding of $15,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds, 3 per cent series, due in 1972.

CHUNGKING, China, May 5 -- Consternation is sweeping Japanese occupied cities, including Shanghai, Nanking, Hangchow, Nanchang, Ningpo, Wuhu, Amoy and Soochow as the result of damaging raids carried out by Chinese forces, according to information reaching Chungking late tonight.

" Only if America is victorious, and the ideals of Lincoln shall once and for all replace the ruthlessness of the totalitarian countries, only then can we hope for a successful Palestine, a successful Czechoslovakia, a successful Europe and a successful world," Dr. Jan Masaryk, Vice Premier and Foreign Minister of the Czechoslovak government-in-exile, declared yesterday.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., May 5 -- Four buildings in a half block of the Main Street business district here were destroyed by fire tonight as volunteer fire fighters from eight surrounding communities fought the blaze. The three-story Peoples National Bank Building was razed and Cooke's Department Store, adjoining the bank, was destroyed with all its merchandise.

LONDON, May 5 -- A frank warning that many people here and in the United States still commit the "suicidal heresy" of underestimating Japan was given by Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Minister for External Affairs, at a press conference here today.

MOSCOW, May 5 -- Stealing the jump on Reichsfuehrer Hitler, hundreds of thousands of Russian soldiers, tanks and planes smashed head-on today at three key German bases from which it was believed the Nazi leader was planning his Spring or Summer drive.

ALBANY, May 5 -- Automobile accidents due to defective tires increased from 17 in March, 1941, to 36 this year, Carroll E. Mealey, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, revealed today. Total accidents in March increased from 5,007 to 6,110 and injuries from 6,459 to 7,769.

Yervant Cavanoz, a Turk, a member of the firm of Cavanoz Charlier, diamond cutters and jewelers, of 515 Madison Avenue, waived examination yesterday for action by the grand jury before Magistrate Ramsgate in the Felony Court. He is charged with a series of jewelry thefts on memoranda running up to $125,000 in what Assistant District Attorney Harold X. McGowan described as "a robbing Peter to pay Paul stunt."

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Three classifications of factory jobs which women can fill in war industry plants, as compiled by the experts of the Women's Bureau in the Department of Labor, were released today "for the easy reference of employers and women who are or may be in the labor force."

ST. LOUIS, May 5 -- In one of the finest performances of his long career, the veteran Larry French today pitched and batted the Dodgers to an eleven-inning 3-triumph over the Cardinals and sent the National League champions happily away to Chicago tonight three and one-half games ahead of the team that many have picked to win the pennant.

Nine years ago this Sunday in the University towns throughout Germany students were consigning books, both German and foreign, to huge bonfires. In Berlin the pyre was made up of 20,000 volumes and Dr. Goebbels made a speech about the purity of German literature.

LONDON, May 5 (Reuter) -- It is possible that the widespread Chinese attacks have been launched as part of general Allied strategy in the Far East. Coming at a time when the Japanese, advancing up the northeastern side of Burma, are now at China's back door, they are well calculated to counter this threat.
With colonial-type houses appearing to be in favor with most buyers, the Scarsdale section led trading in Westchester yesterday.

For all that they boast a distinguished foreign ancestry, the crunchy cookies that the United China Relief is now selling are reminiscent of those that used to be made right here in this country in early American kitchens. They are round and spreading, rather sugary on the surface, old-fashioned in savor and appearance, the sort that our grandmothers might have cut out and baked in a fragrant oven to a delicate shade of brown.

The thirteenth annual benefit of the School Nature League was begun yesterday with the first of a series of tours of private penthouse terraces and backyard gardens opened to the public by their 'owners between 2:30 and 5:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on April 18 amounted to 257,563,000 barrels, according to data reported to the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the preceding week, there was a decrease of 879,000 barrels, comprising declines of 530,000 and 349,000 barrels in stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum respectively.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 5 -- Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor and a member of the War Production Board, charged here today that "certain employing interests" were resorting to "war legislation" in an effort to strike at organized labor.

PITTSBURGH, May 5 -- Accusing John L. Lewis of failure to give him promised cooperation, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, called today for an end to "back-stabbing" tactics so that the C.I.O. could concentrate all its energies on winning the war.

Indications that New York banks and other institutions are making steady progress in disposing of their real estate were found in the reports of Manhattan deals yesterday. In most of the transactions banks were listed as the sellers.
LONDON, May 5 (AP) -- A joint Admiralty and War Office communique stated:

The Federal Government is planning to take over from the States the direct administration of the rationing of all commodities now rationed or to be rationed, it was learned yesterday. A second step, and one on which no final decision has been reached, would be the "federalization" of the present local volunteer rationing boards.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Restrictive city and State legislation enacted in peace times frequently at the behest of pressure groups have become mortally dangerous to the country's war effort and must be abolished, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the, War Production Board, said here today.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Bob Harris limited Washington to five hits today but his fellow Browns supported him feebly and the Senators captured a 5-3 decision as Early Wynn checked the visitors with eight hits.

As a newspaper man who worked with W.F. Bullock for several years, I should like to pay tribute to his memory. I never knew Lord Northcliffe, but I always think of Bullock as one of the giants of his regime. From his post in New York, Bullock aided in building the reputation of The Daily Mail while it was introducing a new strength into journalism.

ALBANY, May 5 -- Appointment of Major Gen. William N. Haskell as Director of Civilian Protection for the State was announced today by Governor Lehman. General Haskell succeeds Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, who held the comparable post of Director of Civilian Defense under the old Defense Act which expired May 1.

LOS ANGELES, May 5 -- "This country will be confronted with the greatest labor shortage in its history about next September and the government will have to 'freeze' employes to their jobs," Richard T. Frankensteen, a national C.I.O. leader, predicted today.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora yesterday upheld a ruling of the Municipal Civil Service Commission under the presidency of Paul J. Kern, since removed, which disqualified from any city employment Sidney Z. Searles an assistant to Emil K. Ellis as counsel to the City Council committee that investigated the Kern regime.

CHUNGKING, China, May 5 -- An ominous note was sounded today in the accusation made by a Japanese military spokesman in Burma that the United Nations forces had used poison gas in Burma and that the gas attacks took place shortly after Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's conference with Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stillwel and General Harold R.L.G. Alexander in Burma, inferring thereby that the use of gas was discussed at this meeting.

The many opportunist books on Latin America based on inadequate reporting and research have worked a two-way harm to inter-American relations, Hubert Herring, director of the Committee on Cultural Relations with Latin America, told booksellers yesterday at their annual convention.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 5 -- Ted Harrison, strikeout king of the Eastern Intercollegiate League two seasons ago, regained top form today to defeat Charlie Blazek of Columbia and give Yale a 2-1 decision over the Lions in a circuit contest.

LONDON May 5 -- Renewed demands for reformation of the British war machinery at the top to provide unified command of the Army, Air Force and Navy, were made in a long debate in the House of Lords today.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- In the first decision made since President Roosevelt announced his wage stabilization policy, a board of arbitration of the War Production Board today granted increases to ten of the twenty-four crafts belonging to the Detroit Building Trades Council, and denied increases to the other fourteen.
BERLIN, May 5 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

By his telegram to the shipyard's wage negotiators, the President has shown that he is in earnest about his "anti-inflation" program. Part of the nation's shipyard workers have union contracts which provide for periodic adjustments in wages on the basis of rises in living costs.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (U.P.) -- A stirring new chapter in the story of American fighting men -- a chapter this time of men armed chiefly with courage and devotion to duty -- was unfolded tonight as the War Department cited units of the United States-Phillippine forces on Luzon for their "magnificent defense of the island against overwhelming odds."

James B. Schafer, 41 years old, the self-styled "master metaphysician" who pleaded guilty to the theft of $9,000 from one of the women "students" of his "Church of the Royal Fraternity of Metaphysicians," was sentenced in General Sessions yesterday to a Sing Sing term of two and one-half to five years.

ALBANY, May 5 -- Governor Lehman approved today the Ives bill increasing unemployment insurance benefits. He noted that more men are being laid off from jobs because of the effect of war on our domestic economy. The nature of New York's commerce and industry requires a greater economic sacrifice than elsewhere, the Governor declared.

BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP) -- Major Gen. Milton A. Reckord, commanding general of the Third Corps Area, said tonight he had been advised that the amateur status of Private Marty Passaglia has been restored by the Amateur Athletic Union.

Events today: Concert by the Department of Music Education, New York University, for the benefit of the Lowell Mason Scholarship Fund, Town Hall, 8:30 P.M.; David Prentiss, song recital, Carnegie Chamber Music, 8:30; Westchester County and Philadelphia Chapters of the National Foundation of Musical Therapy, free concert, Studio 704, Steinway Hall, 3; Charles O. Banks, organ recital, St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Congressional investigation into war-production costs and profits has saved the Federal Government $507,208,277 to date, with more to come, Representative Vinson, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee, told the House today.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Before Admiral William D. Leahy, the United States Ambassador to Vichy, arrives in New York, as he is expected to do very soon, the consequences of the British occupation of Madagascar may have demolished the whole structure of this government's French policy, which the Ambassador has done much to interpret and keep in being.

David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, declared yesterday, in commenting on the current patent investigation by the Federal Government, that RCA has assured the government of its readiness to grant licenses under its patents to any supplier engaged in war production.

Brig. Gen. Cornelius Vanderbilt, who died on March 1, left his entire estate to his family. In his will, filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday, he also exercised a power of appointment for the benefit of his son and daughter over trust of the residuary estate of his mother, Mrs. Alice Gwynne Vanderbilt, from which he received a life income.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, May 6 -- The American fortress of Corregidor and the other fortified islands in the entrance to Manila Bay surrendered today, it was officially announced here.

DETROIT, Mich., May 5 -- On the eve of the start of negotiations before a panel of the National War Labor Board between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., C.E. Wilson, president of the corporation, revealed today that it had defied the board on the issue of double-time pay for Sunday and holiday work.

Bringing retail charge accounts under control for the first time and ruling that installment purchases must be liquidated in twelve months the Federal Reserve Board promulgated yesterday amendment No. 4 to its consumer credit regulation W, carrying into effect the seventh point in President Roosevelt's anti-inflation program.
ANNAPOLIS, May 5 -- The Navy commissioned today 574 reserve midshipmen, who completed a four months' course of training at the Naval Academy as reserve ensigns and sent them on active duty.
UNITED STATES HEADQUARTERS, NEW DELHI, India, May 5 (AP) -- A communique from the Burma front follows:

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Roosevelt conferred with legislative leaders from the Capitol, with the Pacific War Council and held his press conference; his visitors included Governor O'Conor of Maryland, the Netherlands Minister and General L. Van Oyen, chief of the Dutch East Indies Air Force, and Viscount Halifax.

LONDON, May 5 -- Candy will be rationed as from July 27, it was announced today by Food Minister Lord Woolton, who said he had received many appeals both from public and from traders for the use of a ration book for the sale of candies.

Life insurance companies, as expected, will be the principal buyers of the Treasury's new offering of 2 1/2 per cent bonds of 1967, callable in 1962, it was indicated yesterday as distribution of the new type of limited-market government obligation continued.

Sixteen portrait sketches in sculpture of "Women at War," by John Hovannes, have been placed on view in the Lady Hamilton Room at Gimbel's, for the benefit of the American Women's Voluntary Services. The exhibition will open with an invitation preview and reception tomorrow afternoon and will be open to the public thereafter through May 16.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Gasoline consumption in the East will be slashed 50 per cent below normal starting May 16, the War Production Board said tonight. This means that many of the area's 10,000,000 motorists probably will have to get along with as little as five or six gallons a week.

TRENTON, May 5 -- The all-Republican State Senate committee investigating expenditures at the Sea Girt executive cottage last Summer during occupancy by Governor Charles Edison, Democrat, heard testimony today by Miss Dorothy W. Van Ness, Mrs. Edison's personal secretary, contradicting that given previously by George Milligan, the family's butler, as to the number of week-end guests entertained.
The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday in a statement covering the first three months of this year, net profit of $5,458,952 after Federal income tax provision of $2,750,000.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Acting after direct pleas from the War Department, the House Military Affairs Committee modified materially today restrictions it had approved on the granting of Army commissions to civilians who lack specified military service or training.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 5 -- Dr. Walter Damrosch, world-famous orchestra conductor for sixty-one years, drew high praise from representatives of government, music, radio and education at a testimonial dinner held for him at the Neil House here as a feature of the thirteenth annual Institute for Education by Radio.
The British landing on the Vichy-controlled island of Madagascar in the Indian Ocean relieves a potential enemy threat to our supply lines to the Middle East and India.

A $5,000,000 gate for a single showing of a motion picture -- that is the goal of the War Savings Bond Committee that is sponsoring a world premiere of Warner Brothers' "Yankee Doodle Dandy" at the Hollywood Theatre, Broadway and Fifty-first Street, on May 29.

OTTAWA, May 5 -- More than four out of every five soldiers, sailors and airmen in the Canadian service voted "yes" in the recent plebiscite for the release of the government from its no-conscription pledge.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Office of Defense Transportation today set up a Section of Tank Car Service which will start a system of a nation-wide tank-car control on May 15. On and after that date no railroad will be allowed to accept for transport any loaded tank car without special or general permission of the section except cars specifically exempted by the order.

In a dispatch from Chungking printed in this newspaper yesterday, Chinese worthies hitherto unsung stood out with the qualities of their nation, resourceful, intelligent, calmly brave. Chinese postmen are delivering mail, keeping up the service between occupied and unoccupied China, just as if everything was as quiet as a postage stamp.

A loan exhibition of work by nineteenth-century French masters opened to the public yesterday at the Paul Rosenberg Gallery, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street. It was organized as a benefit for the Navy Relief Society, of which President Roosevelt is the honorary president.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The War Department communique based on reports received in Washington up to 5 P.M. said:

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Ways and Means Committee decided today to begin consideration tomorrow of individual income taxes, laying aside several important phases of the corporation taxation program for further study.

Sharp criticism of the President's seven-point anti-inflation program was expressed by Professor Benjamin M. Anderson in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES published May 3. Elsewhere on the same page the letter received an editorial nod of approval.

While Hank Borowy was saving a noble pitching experiment from going on the rocks at the Stadium yesterday Joe DiMaggio was clubbing the Yankees to their fourth straight triumph over the forlorn White Sox and hammering the world champions into second place, hard on the heels of the tottering Indians.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 5 -- John L. Lewis's plan to organize farmers into his United Mine Workers does not strike a very sympathetic chord with the dirt farmers of America. Of all groups, farmers are the least sympathetic to the labor-union movement.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., in its annual statement for the year ended on Jan. 31, issued to stockholders yesterday by Lincoln Filene, chairman, shows combined net sales of the company's subsidiaries rose 14.63 per cent to the record total of $131,427,879 from the $114,657,245 sales reported the year before.

A mock raid by fifth columnists on La Guardia Field, with a special foray intended to capture the Pan-American seaplane base, featured last night's blackout of Northern Queens and gave a fast-moving force of rifle-bearing patrolmen a chance to show how they would rout any such intruders.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Rear Admiral S.C. Hooper, speaking for the Navy Department, asked Congress today to give the armed forces a veto power over any communications merger, contending that the Communications Commission had "so little knowledge of the military requirements and principles involved."

PEARL HARBOR, May 5 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, recently visited the Midway Islands and personally decorated Marine Corps fliers and Navy personnel there who repelled five Japanese attacks from air and sea, the last of them on March 10.

Billows of white smoke described as an "artificial fog" spurted from the exhausts of a dozen automobiles lined up in the barren Castle Hill area of the Bronx yesterday after a demonstration planned for Army and Navy officials at Long Island City had been banned by Mayor La-Guardia.

CHUNGKING, China, May 4 (Delayed) -- A five-year industrialization plan for post-war China is being prepared by experts of the National Resources Commission of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, according to Chien Chang-chao, the commission's Oxford-educated vice director.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 5 -- Four men of the Royal Air Force and eight of the Royal Australian Air Force have reached Australia after a voyage from Java in a 30-foot engineless lifeboat across 1,500 miles of ocean in forty-four days, it was revealed here today.

VICHY, France, May 5 -- There is little information here as to how the defense of Madagascar is going. Although the foreign radio has been giving details of the operations and of diplomatic exchanges, nothing was issued here until Pierre Laval summoned the press at 7:30 P.M. today.

Mrs. Frank Stearn of 105 Haven Avenue and her 2 1/2-year-old son Kenneth were taken to the Wadsworth Avenue station yesterday in a patrol wagon after Mrs. Stearn had refused a summons for allowing the baby to dig in J. Hood Wright Park at 174th Street and Fort Washington Avenue.

Bus and trolley companies represented at the conference held Monday by the Transit Commission expressed a complete willingness to comply as fully as possible with the proposals of Joseph B. Eastman, Director of Defense Transportation, for increasing the efficiency of mass transportation and conserving tires and gasoline, Victor McQuistion, secretary of the Third Avenue Railway System, said yesterday.

Authoritative military sources have warned "that we in New York may expect an attack by the enemy from the air at any moment," James G. Blaine, chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, said last night in an address over WNYC, the municipal radio station.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Workers engaged in coal production and railroad transportation may be considered for deferment from military service as "necessary men," Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, advised State directors today.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The fortified island of Corregidor in Manila Bay, last bastion of the American defenders of the Philippine Island, Luzon, was fighting a landing attack by Japanese troops today.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 5 -- Siravo and Petrucci's Marion Collins won the Valley Falls claiming purse at Narragansett Park today.

CHUNGKING, China, May 5 -- According to the Chinese military spokesman today, a Japanese column is at present attacking Chukok on the Burma side of the Chinese-Burma border, and Wangting, on the Chinese side of the border, and is expected to swing westward via the Nam Mao River toward Bhamo, thence striking north along both the Irrawaddy River and the Mandalay Railroad.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 711, which compared with 753 in the preceding week and 533 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 344, as against 273 for last Tuesday.

LONDON, May 5 -- The stock markets were quiet and firm again today. There was little movement in gilt-edge issues and the home rails were quiet. Business in the foreign section was restricted to Brazilian issues, which improved.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., May 5 -- This is the sequel to the story of Goldie and the three bears -- Goldie's own little bear cubs, it may be remembered by those who read about their tantrums as recorded yesterday morning.

An Associated Press report from Atlantic City quoted Dr. Willis F. Evans and Dr. Harold J. Stewart of the New York Hospital as having reported before the meeting of the American Society of Clinical Investigation that smoking cigarettes, even those from which the nicotine has been removed, was followed by "a drop in the blood pressure."

Spring weather this year has been a delight to the city dweller; but the suburbanite, noting the slow progress of his lawn and the dusty dryness of his garden beds, has realized that day after day of bright sunlight and nights full of stars bring their penalties. The farmer, busy at his Spring plowing, is deeply worried by the early drought.

When the New York Stock Exchange was 100 years old -- according to its own calculations -- there was no celebration of the event and it passed almost unnoticed in Wall Street. One New York paper devoted a half column to the date and three-quarters of a column to a letter from an outraged reader complaining that the Exchange was celebrating a mere seventy-fifth birthday.

There is an unmistakable threat of things to come in Vichy's reply to the declaration of our Government's "full approval and support" for the British attempt to occupy Madagascar. The note sent yesterday by Laval asserts that Vichy "cannot but leave to President Roosevelt the part of the responsibility which will fall on him in the consequences which will result from this aggression."

LONDON, May 5 -- The Japanese have entered Yunnan Province in China via the Burma Road, it was announced today. Their vanguards reached the suburbs of Wangting, which is on a small river dividing Burma and China, and Chungking said the Japanese were being engaged by Chinese troops in the hills. The main enemy column was waiting within Burma at Chukok, near by.

Detailed arrangements were announced by the Dodgers yesterday for their contest with the Giants at Ebbets Field Friday that will open a two-game home-and-home series between the teams for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society and the Army Emergency Relief.

The prospects for a second extension of the special "Candida" engagement, in which Katharine Cornell, Raymond Massey, Burgess Meredith, Dudley Digges, Mildred Natwick and Stanley Bell are donating their services for the equal benefit of Army and Navy relief, are not considered remote, it was acknowledged yesterday by an authoritative source.

THE National League managers are moaning over President Ford Frick's new rules designed to keep law and order on the field during the playing of ball games. It's the notion in this corner that Mr. Frick has been quite liberal in the matter of permitting riotous assemblies on the diamond.

The scope of consumer information and where to find it were discussed yesterday by Mrs. Elizabeth Bussing, chairman of the consumer committee of the Brooklyn Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, in the eighth of a series of lectures in 60 Clinton Street, Brooklyn.

Senator William J. Billow, who criticized Administration measures in the international field before Pearl Harbor but has supported the war effort, trailed former Governor Tom Berry in early returns from South Dakota's Democratic Senatorial primary last night.

In previous years when mid-May rolled around, it was the custom for salt water anglers in the metropolitan area to toss a rod into the car and motor to Peconic Bay. The weakfish, of course, provided the attraction and helped to make the east end of Long Island one of the best known fishing grounds along the coast.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the National War Labor Board, said tonight that he did not construe General Motor's latest answer as a refusal to comply with an NWLB temporary order on double pay for Sunday time, and expressed confidence that the dispute would be ironed out at hearings beginning here tomorrow.

BALTIMORE, May 5 -- Whirlaway, Challedon and Mioland -- three of turfdom's greatest campaigners -- were named today to start for the first time in the same race in old Pimlico's $20,000-added Dixie Handicap tomorrow.

The two six-family apartment houses at 24-52-54 Twenty-seventh Street, Astoria, L. I., have been each sold for cash above first mortgages of $13,370, held by the New York Life Insurance Company, to Graziosa Partemi through IVIrs. iVfary Deller, broker. The Tri-Boro I Gardens, Inc., represented by A. G. !Walker and Associates, administrators, was the seller.

According to the most accurate statistical calculations available to this department, there are at the present moment 34,861,625 mothers in the United States and possessions. Each one is different from every other. And yet, in one respect, each resembles the 34,861,624 others -- she is, inevitably, a woman with a thousand worries, and she has the occasional right to be soundly spoiled.

SAN ANTONIO, May 5 -- High schools of the nation were urged today by Dr. Edwin A. Lee, dean of the School of Education at the University of California, to train all students for direct participation in the war effort.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Retail trade association representatives representing something more than 700,000 establishments that deal directly with the buying public, today received a detailed explanation of the general maximum price regulation as it applies to retailers at an all-day meeting with officials of the Office of Price Administration.
Many of the commercial leases reported yesterday by brokers involved contracts for retail store space.

The St. Regis Roof was formally opened for the late Spring and Summer season last night with a dinner dance and entertainment in aid of the Musicians Emergency Fund, beneficiary each year of the seasonal openings of both the roof garden and the Iridium Room of the hotel.

SCRANTON, Pa., May 5 (U.P.) -- Attorney General Biddle warned labor today that it must "clean house" and win public confidence to protect its social legislation gains against wartime and postwar pressures for repeal of those benefits.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The United States will adhere to its policy of supporting the British in occupying Madagascar, regardless of the note of Pierre Laval rejecting the warning of President Roosevelt that "any warlike act" against Britain or the United States would be regarded as an attack upon the United Nations as a whole.

LONDON, May 5 -- Stuttgart, Germany and the Skoda works at Pilsen, Czecho-Slovakia, two of the most tempting targets in Europe, were heavily bombed by some of Britain's most powerful aircraft last night.

LOS ANGELES, May 5 -- Wage disputes involving tens of thousands of workers, several hundred employers and a number of unions in three industries are developing in this city, a survey disclosed today. The trouble may have to go to the War Labor Board for settlement.

Enemy submarines have sunk three more ships in our East Coast waters, with the loss of twenty-three lives, it was disclosed yesterday by the Navy. The victims were a small Norwegian freighter, a medium-sized British merchant ship and a medium-sized vessel identified only as of United Nations registry.

The one-story house on a plot 75 by 100 feet with an adjoining vacant plot 120 by 100 feet on the southeast corner of Meeker and Porter Avenues, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Bedford Holding Corporation to an investing client of Frank R. Fischer, broker.
MONTREAL, May 5 (AP) -- Al Sherer pitched the Royals into a tie for second place in the International League today by stopping the Jersey City Giants, 3 -- 1, with five-hit pitching.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a proposal by the Pacific Power and Light Company to surrender for cancellation to the Inland Power and Light Company, a wholly owned subsidiary, of a $7,560,000 note as a preliminary step to dissolution of the latter concern.

LONDON, May 5 (AP) -- A group of Adolf Hitler's generals, headed by General Field Marshal Walther von Brauchitsch was reported today to have told Herr Hitler bluntly that if his 1942 campaign in Russia failed they will try to institute for Germany an alternate plan of their own calling for "abolition of the Nazi system."

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Some members of the House Appropriations Committee asserted today that they were determined to write into all future supply bills a provision prohibiting Federal administrative officials from accepting employment outside the government.

A priority system for the sale and delivery of fuel oils is almost ready for promulgation in Washington, it was reported yesterday as governmental and industry authorities talked of the fuel oil and gasoline situation in increasingly somber tones.

City College, after nearly a century of emphasis on the liberal arts aspect of higher education, is gradually reorganizing its curriculum with a view to a closer relai tionship of the acadefnic program to the neels of government, Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, predicted today that although people have enough money for the highest standard of living in history, the national level will be forced down in the next twelve to fifteen months to the low standard of 1932.

Distribution of sugar ration books, which has been under way here since Monday, ends today. Consumers who fail to register and get their books within that time must wait until May 21, they were reminded yesterday by Lee S. Buckingham, acting Federal Rationing Administrator for New York City.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- In his press conference Clarence B. Randall emphasized that Inland Steel's appearance before the NWLB did not constitute an acknowledgment of the board's jurisdiction to arbitrate the union shop issue.

The bolstering of social services to meet family and child problems resulting from the war was urged yesterday by psychologists and social workers before the Vassar Club of New York as a keystone of wartime morale and an indispensable prelude to successful post-war reconstruction.

CHICAGO, May 6 (U.P.) -- Spokesmen for the War Production Board indicated tonight that conferees assembled here to formulate wage scales for the nation's shipyards -including representatives of organized labor -- were agreed on the necessity of reducing certain pay increases to which shipyard workers are legally entitled.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Victory in war and a brighter future in the peace to follow it were predicted at tonight's White House session of the Pan-American Child Congress by Dr. Enrique Saladrigas, chairman of the Cuban delegation, in his opening address to the delegates following their reception by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The $2,125,000,000 Independent Offices Appropriation Bill was approved by the Senate this afternoon after conservative members of both parties had joined in adopting an administration-opposed amendment which would abolish the Tennessee Valley Authority's revolving fund and would require Congressional approval for every penny spent in the future by the TVA.

With buying interest depressed by a combination of domestic and war front developments, the recovery movement in the stock market was checked yesterday. Sales on the Stock Exchange were 267,890 shares against 272,900 on Tuesday.

An appeal for 500 men to volunteer as telephone clerks for the Fire Department was made yesterday by James G. Blaine, chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office. The men are needed to man the thirty-three existing fire-alarm posts in the five boroughs on a twenty-four-hour-aday basis, Mr. Blaine said, and are to rotate on four-hour shifts, each volunteer working three shifts a week.

Chalky Wright, recognized in New York State as the world featherweight champion, rules a 5-9 favorite to vanquish Lulu Costantino, East Side sensation, in their scheduled eight-round non-title bout tonight at the St. Nicholas Palace.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., May 6 (U.P.) -- Christy Mathewson has been promoted to the rank of active captain in the Army Air Corps -- and thereby hangs a tale of courage. The story was told today by his mother, Mrs. Mathewson, widow of the baseball immortal, young Christy's father.
Corregidor has gone and the campaign of the Philippines is ending.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 -- Several hundred employes in the pneumatics department of the Cramp Shipbuilding Company remained idle for more than two hours today in a controversy over rates of pay for piece work.

NEW DELHI, India, May 6 (AP) -- Awards of the Order of the Purple Heart today disclosed the deaths of nine United States Army airmen in a crash in India April 2 as they were taking off to attack the Japanese Navy. Those on whom the medal was bestowed posthumously for "extraordinary fidelity and essential service" were:

BERNE, Switzerland, May 6 -- General Henri Honore Giraud remains in safety in unoccupied France, but his escape apparently has led to reminders in Germany that aid to captives may be punished severely, even with death.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- I.G. Farbenindustrie, by a cartel agreement with Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, held up one phase of American explosives manufacture by blocking the use of an ultra-efficient method of producing synthetic ammonia, the Senate Patents Committee was told today by John R. Jacobs Jr., a special assistant to the Attorney General.

Governors of the New York Curb Exchange submitted to the membership yesterday constitutional amendments increasing commissions to non-members by 20 to 21 per cent and authorizing a system of special offerings similar to that adopted by the New York Stock Exchange.

Tonight at 8:30 "The Walking Gentleman" will stroll into the Belasco Theatre. Heading the cast of this mystery play by Grace Perkins and Fulton Oursler are Victor Francen, Arlene Francis and Richard Gaines. Mr. Francen has the title role.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Two pairs of brothers are with the Fourth Marine Regiment which fought to the end alongside soldiers and sailors in the defense of Corregidor.

Hedging on Commodity Credit Corporation cotton that was met by sufficient trade demand tended to hold a hesitant cotton market within a narrow range yesterday. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed near the day's lows at net losses of 1 to 3 points from the final quotations of the preceding day.

VICHY, France, May 6 -- A communique issued tonight said that the French troops and their leaders at Madagascar; despite numerical inferiority, were resisting in a manner "worthy of our most glorious military traditions."

That novel by Katherine Anne Porter, her first, which is heard about each literary season, looks certain for Fall, according to Donald Brace of Harcourt, Brace, who said yesterday that he had seen two-thirds of the manuscript and expected to have it all in his hands by June.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The House Ways and Means Committee was told today by its experts that a 94 per cent excess profits tax on corporations would hamper the war effort unless an incentive toward efficiency was provided through a post-war tax credit.

The preservation of the democratic spirit at home and abroad is necessary to the winning of the war, Crown Prince Olav of Norway declared yesterday at the second progress luncheon of the Greater New York Fund, which was held in the Hotel Biltmore.

The Bronx County grand jury, having sat on the 8,000 second-hand city paving blocks which were removed last November from a city storage yard and placed within the Lake Mahopac estate of National Democratic Chairman Edward J. Flynn, has hatched out some mild and thoughtful conclusions.

Following the survey begun April 8 with the issuance by the Board of Economic Warfare of an order requiring specific information in applications for export licenses of the location and condition of goods for export, a system of shipping priorities was jointly announced yesterday by the board, the State Department and the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.

ALBANY, May 6 -- Governor Lehman gave his approval today to the Ives bill creating a commission to draft plans for post-war public works, to be undertaken by the State and its localities in the event of a slump in employment.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -Big Buck Newsom set down his old team-mates, the Tigers, with one hit as Washington pounded out a 7-0 victory today.

Twenty of the men who composed the "Di Fiore bootleg syndicate'' that operated from 1932 to 1941 received their sentences in Federal court yesterday from Judge Grover M. Moscowitz. The penalties ranged from suspended sentences for two of the group to a four-year term.

With the war drums of the prohibitionists beginning to roll faintly in the distance, leaders of the old (and successful) repeal movement threatened last night to reorganize their forces and "spring into action" if the "drys" should try to "bring back the bootlegger and his blinding booze."

LONDON, May 6 -- According to news reaching Chungking quoted by Reuter, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, United States commander of the Chinese forces in Burma, and several senior Chinese commanders have safely arrived at an undisclosed base in Burma from which they will continue to direct operations.

With the so-called "big five" life insurance companies having taken $410,000,000 of the new Treasury 2 1/2s, interest now centers on the results to be shown from the vast coverage of potential buyers being made by the thousands of investment and brokerage firms throughout the country.
BERLIN, May 6 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

Various proposals for a paid government advertising campaign to further the war effort were sharply criticized yesterday by Walter Weir Jr., vice president of Lord Thomas, who asserted that such a campaign would prove "advertising one of the greatest economic wastes ever invented."

Likening the "philosophy of distribution" of the book trade during the last two decades to that of the motion pictures, in that merchandise has been sold without responsibility for the contents of the packages, Archibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress and director of the Office of Facts and Figures, last night urged that the book trade return to the position of "high responsibility and profound authority it once occupied."

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, May 6 -- American life is being blasted far more by the dislocation of populations owing to war industries than from any enemy aggression, Paul Kellogg, editor of Survey Graphic, told the annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers today.

Two veteran members of Congress, both described by their opponents as "pre-war isolationists," were defeated in primary elections Tuesday, according to unofficial but apparently decisive returns from four States last night.

Joe Bonacorsa, star of the N.Y.U. freshman football team last Fall, had a great day with the stick yesterday and the Violet defeated the City College nine on Ohio Field for the second time this season, 8 to 2. The victory enabled N.Y.U. to tighten its hold on third place in the Metropolitan Conference.

CINCINNATI, May 6 -- Canadian retail business does not resent or regret the Dominion's control of credit practices, believing they are improvements which should not disappear when the war is over, G. Don Smith, credit manager of Henry Morgan Co., Ltd., Montreal, said here today at the ninth annual convention of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Gibson.

Miss Edith Fox, 33 years old, X-ray technician and assistant to Dr. Arthur S. Unger, director of the division of roentgenology at Sydenham Hospital, 123d Street and Manhattan Avenue, suffered a fatal electric shock yesterday afternoon shortly after she had started to demonstrate an X-ray machine to a class of three technician students at the hospital.
MOSCOW, May 6 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) ciated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau communique today said:

President Ford Frick of the National League took the offensive yesterday, despite the circuit-wide debate over his new anti-squawk rule, and warned that managers, coaches or players who continue to violate the regulation will be suspended instead of merely fined.

VICHY, France, May 6 -- Darquier de Pellepoix, a leading anti-Semite, has been appointed General Commissioner for Jewish Questions, according to the Paris press. If the appointment is confirmed he will succeed Xavier Vallat.

Confronted with the prospect of the most serious post-war unemployment problem in the country's history, the City Planning Commission made public yesterday a program of public works aggregating $628,005,182 to be built after the war and set next Wednesday as the date for a public hearing in City Hall on the individual projects.

The humble yellow-tail or dab, a species of small flounder presented proudly by many a waiter as a filet of sole, is the main reason for the presence here of a Massachusetts special commission on transportation of fish and other foodstuff.

Holgar J. Johnson, president of the Institute of Life Insurance, yesterday called on the life insurance companies to back up the government's fight on inflation by sponsoring the greatest thrift campaign in history, in a threefold program.

Mayor La Guardia has directed the Board of Transportation to take steps to see that subway entrance and exit lights are blacked out as far as practicable during blackout drills and that all but the pilot lights on elevated trains and subway trains moving above the surface are extinguished, it was disclosed yesterday.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. "Saboteur," a Universal release directed by Alfred Hitchcock, will be the new attraction at Radio City Music Hall. Robert Cummings and Priscilla Lane head the cast of the melodrama, while supporting roles are played by Otto Kruger, Alan Baxter, Clem Bevans, Alma Kruger, Dorothy Peterson and Vaughn Glazier. . . . Metro's remake of the musical, "Rio Rita," will be the newcomer at the Capitol.
LONDON, May 6 -- The stock market continued today to show a firm appearance, but the volume of trading was small. Gilt-edge issues improved 1-16 to point, and home rails were brighter.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 6 -- The Germans have launched a Spring offensive -- but behind their own lines against the Russian guerrillas. A report from Berlin today says that "the Germans have started cleaning-up operations against Russian partisans of such an extent that it is possible to speak without exaggeration of an offensive behind their own lines."

Nicaragua is solidly behind the war policy of the United States and is seeking to increase production of rubber and other war materials, Dr. Mariano Arguello, Nicaraguan Minister of Foreign Affairs, said in an interview yesterday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
LOS ANGELES, May 6 (AP) -- The body of Mrs. Rose M. Whitmore, formerly of New York City, was found in her recently bought house last night, her head battered with a car jack handle.,

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 6 -The opening tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association attracted thirty-six starters to the Piping Rock course today and produced $67 in donations for the American Red Cross.

The four-story industrial building on a plot 435 by 93 feet at 11-39 Wilkinson Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold by the Eureka Properties, Inc., Charles J. Smith, president, to Eureka Lofts, Inc., of Hoboken. Sale was for $18,000 above a $35,000 mortgage held by the United States Rubber Company.

The lower courts have a duty, when the United States Supreme Court exhibits a new "doctrinal trend" in its decisions, to follow that trend, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals declared yesterday in a ruling upholding subpoenas issued by Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins to the Endicott Johnson Corporation.

Ninety-five years ago the people of this city voted to establish a municipal Free Academy. That institution later became the College of the City of New York. Its name hardly does justice to its size, its organization, its activities. Actually the college is a university composed of various schools, with 27,000 students who have been carefully selected for their later intellectual promise and who come from families of modest means.

BOSTON, May 6 -- Four hundred retailers -- members of the Boston Retail Trade Board and the Massachusetts Council of Retail Merchants -- were advised by an OPA executive today temporarily to make their own decisions as to how best to adapt to their businesses the provisions of the government's maximum price regulation.

The entire BMT division of the city transit system in Brooklyn and Southern Queens was halted at 7:27 o'clock last night by a power failure caused by a short circuit in a trunk line leading from the main power plant at Kent and Division Avenues, near the Navy Yard.
A plea for more war contracts for the New York area was made by speakers at the luncheon meeting and annual election of the New York Building Congress yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

AT AN ADVANCED UNITED NATIONS AIR BASE, Southwest Pacific, May 5 (Delayed) -- The tempo of the air war in this area is rising. On eight of the last twelve days the Japanese raided Port Moresby, using a total of fifty-four bombers and ninety-two Zeros. On last Wednesday there were three raids.

Retailers are beginning to complain vigorously about price advances on men's pajamas, which, it is estimated, have shown a sharper rise than practically any other item of men's furnishings. Unbranded goods which sold a year ago at $1 have been coming out for Fall recently at a basis requiring a retail price of $1.79 to $1.95.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Clarence B.
