Randall, vice president of the Inland Steel Company, suggested today that the company may take the unusual action of polling its 8,500 stockholders before deciding whether to comply with an expected decision by the National War Labor Board requiring a "maintenance of membership" clause for the C.I.O.'s Steel Workers Organizing Committee.

MIAMI, Fla., May 6 (AP) -- President Manuel Prado of Peru, a leading exponent of the Pan American good-neighbor policy, arrived here today on his way to visit President Roosevelt and study the United States armament effort.

Following the failure of the Bronx County grand jury last Tuesday to return indictments against any of the persons involved in the paving charges against Edward J. Flynn, the Citizens Union joined yesterday with Paul J. Kern, author of the charges, in labeling the action a "whitewash."

Investigation by the executive committee of the New York Bar Association of the personal as well as official conduct of Magistrate Alex Pisciotta while Mr. Pisciotta, now a captain in the Army, was director of the Bureau of Weights and Measures of the Department of Markets ended abruptly last night because of the association's lack of jurisdiction.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Predicting mass migrations of labor across community and State lines to man the nation's war industries, Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, told the Federal-State Conference on War Restrictions, convened here on the invitation of President Roosevelt, that the United States faces "a supreme test" in mobilizing an additional 10,500,000 workers to more than double the war industry labor supply before the end of 1942.

VICHY, France, May 6 (AP) -- Sources usually well informed on German-French relations said today that any question of turning General Henri Honore Giraud back to the Germans had been settled, and that the general would remain in France.
LONDON, May 6 (AP) -- The joint Admiralty-War Office communique said:

LONDON, May 6 -- Planes of the Royal Air Force bombed Stuttgart last night for the second straight night, dropping heavy explosives on factories that are making electrical equipment for German planes. Then, in daylight, fighters and bombers carried out sweeps over Northern France.

A women's land army in New York State will be recruited systematically through the offices of the United States Employment Service, according to Miss Henrietta Rothstein, farm coordinator for New York City. Miss Rothstein announced yesterday the beginning of a drive to enlist 3,000 women and girls over 16 years old to meet a large demand for harvest hands up-State and in neighboring States.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $1,394,976,846 last month, according to a compilation issued by the Exchange Average price a share of all listed stocks on April 30 was $21.41, compared with $22.36 at the end of March.
TORONTO, May 6 -- Two escaped Nazi prisoners of war stole an airplane from Barker Field, near Toronto, this morning, but crashed a few minutes after taking off. They are still at large.
One and two family houses made up the bulk of the trading in the Bronx reported by brokers yesterday.

ALBANY, May 6 -- State personal income-tax returns exceeded a total of 1,000,000 for the first time in the April 15 collection, this year, with remittances indicating that Governor Lehman's $74,000,000 revenue estimate for this fiscal year will be surpassed.

MONTREAL, May 6 (AP) -- Johnny Wittig threw a ball game away today when he pegged a high throw, supposed to go to third base, into the grandstand to permit the winning run to score and give Montreal a 3-to-2 victory over Jersey City in the tenth inning.

MOSCOW, May 6 (AP) -- Red Star, the army newspaper, said today that Allied aviation in the Pacific was taking the offensive and that "despite the tremendous distance separating Japan from the main Anglo-American bases any of the main military, industrial and strategic centers of Japan may be exposed to raids from modern American bombers.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -Confirmation of the promotion of Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews to the rank of vice admiral was held up by the Senate Naval Affairs Committee today after Senator Brewster of Maine raised the question of placing responsibility for the fire which caused the former French liner Normandie to turn over at her New York berth.

Special honors were given to twenty-one young artists last night at the annual distribution of awards of merit at the art school of the National Academy of De-i sign, _Amsterdam Avenue and 109th Street. Hobart Nichols, president of the academy, presented the three cash awards, sixteen medals, and fourteen honorablemention citations,
In one specific sense this is a war for democracy. We are learning to register.
ST. LOUIS, May 6 (AP) -- The Cardinals bore down on the last-place Phils today and pushed them deeper into the cellar with a 14-hit barrage that brought an 11-to-2 victory.

BALTIMORE, May 6 (AP) -- Sun Again, the Calumet meteor who didn't get a chance to run in the Kentucky Derby last Saturday, today was accorded a "better than even chance" by Trainer Ben Jones of starting next Saturday at Pimlico against nine other 3-year-olds in what may be the richest Preakness Stakes of them all.

A call to Czechoslovaks at home to "cease passive resistance" and organize for an immediate "armed struggle against the German invaders" was issued by prominent Czech emigres and broadcast by the Moscow radio last night, the Columbia Broadcasting System's short wave-listening station reported.

Now that the over-all price ceiling order has been issued, the main problem of the Office of Price Administration is to allow the retailer to live under his frozen price without bearing all of the burden, although he should not come out any better than the manufacturer or wholesaler.

No matter what happen from now on in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference Fordham will finish no lower than a tie for first place. This became definite yesterday at Dexter Park, where Jack Coffey's Rams turned back St. John's, 4 -- 2, for their seventh consecutive triumph in the league.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- House Appropriations Committeemen, disclosing today that Mrs. Anna Rosenberg, $7,500-a-year Social Security Board director in New York City, had a $28,500 income as adviser for three private groups, announced they would seek to prohibit Federal administrative employes from holding "outside positions."

Residents of this city may be compelled to hire horses or take to bicycles, but the fact remains that neither gasoline nor tire shortages will keep them staidly at home. When warm weather arrives, the desire to disport one's self in a green-growing field may not be denied, especially by persons who have attained the age of 13 or 14 years.

LONDON, May 6 (AP) -- Vichy broadcasts today said that Governor General Amand Annet of Madagascar had notified the Vichy Government that his position was critical and that twenty-three British ships, large and small, were in Courrier Bay ready to land fresh troops against his fagged defenders.

"Victory by Savings" was the keynote of speakers at the twenty-second annual conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks which opened yesterday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. They urged greater effort in the sales campaign for war savings bonds and greater public thrift so that savings deposits might be increased, thus enabling savings institutions to increase their direct purchases of government bonds.
CANBERRA, Australia, May 6 -- Prime Minister John Curtin, commenting on the fall of Corregidor, said pride and admiration rather than dismay would be Australia's feeling and added:

All nineteen of the vessels owned by the United States Lines Company have been requisitioned by and chartered to the government, and the company is now operating about fifty vessels, owned or chartered by the government, and assigned to the company for operation under a service agreement, according to the annual report of the International Mercantile Marine Company for 1941.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Organized resistance to the Japanese in the Philippine Islands ended today with the surrender of a starving force of not more than 10,000 Americans and Filipinos on Corregidor and the satellite island forts named Hughes, Drum and Frank.

NOW for a real record in big league baseball. There's a chance to make it the finest record in the history of the century-old national pastime. Here's where the fans, players, club owners and league officials can come to bat together and make eighteen straight hits, good ringing blows the echoes of which may be heard as far off as Tokyo or Berlin.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 6 -- Ann Sheridan and Humphrey Bogart will play the leads in Warner Brothers' "Edge of Darkness," which Robert Rosson is adapting from a novel by William Woods, the studio announced today. Lewis Milestone will direct the film, and Henry Blanke will produce.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Shipment was announced today by the American Red Cross of 598,000 "requested" articles, hand-knitted by volunteers for the nation's armed forces, they included 317,890 sweaters, 97,990 socks, 53,353 mufflers, 43,461 helmets and lesser quantities of sea boots, beanies, watch caps, scarfs, mittens, gloves, wristlets and rifle mitts.

James Kalish, 20 years old, who, while under parole on a fifteenyear sentence for one Hoboken holdup and under suspicion in another, held up Dr. Ansel Steinman last December and took $40 in his offices at 897 Eighth Avenue, was sentenced to ten to twenty years by Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions yesterday.
DETROIT, May 6 -- War workers in the automatic screw department of the Packard Motor Car Company have voluntarily given up their half-hour lunch period as their part in the "win-the-war" program.

Local retailers yesterday revised their credit practices to conform with Amendment No. 4 of Regulation W of the Federal Reserve Board affecting both charge accounts and installment sales. The chief change was to regard any account running more than forty days as being in the installment category, with the result that down payments of one-third were requested in line with the board's order.

War work through classes in first aid, home nursing, nutrition, child care, motor mechanics and !kindred subjects has become the primary consideration of Young Women's Christian Associations, according to the annual report of Mrs. Henry A. Ingraham of Brooklyn, president of the national board.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Warned by government officials that the rubber situation has reached a "perilous" stage, from a military standpoint, the Senate Military Affairs Committee indicated today that it would approve legislation giving the President authority to seize automobile tires from private owners, and the cars, too, if necessary, to conserve this vital commodity for actual war use.
PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) -The Browns turned back the Athletics, 7 -- 2, behind the seven-hit pitching of Elden Auker today.

An old four-stack destroyer's searchlight flashed through the darkness; a burst of machine-gun fire swept across the decks of a surfaced submarine, forcing many of her crew to jump into the water, and then at point-blank range a four-inch gun tore a gaping hole in the side of the U-boat, which slowly rolled over and plunged from sight.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 6 -- One of the highest honors in the medical profession, the George M. Kober Medal, was awarded today to Dr. Donald D. Van Slyke, chief chemist at the Rockefeller Institute Hospital in New York for twenty-two years.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 6 -German reaction to the move in Madagascar continues to be reserved and even noncommittal, especially concerning the attitude of the United States. For the present the tendency in Berlin seems to be to let the French act as they see fit in defense of their empire.
I should like to state the position of The Otthon, Hungarian weekly, in the controversial debate of "Patriotism Versus Journalism."

TEANECK, N.J., May 6 -- Nine Teaneck High School seniors, none more than 18 years old, have replaced adult firemen called to military duty, Chief Francis A. Murray of the paid Fire Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President Roosevelt's callers were Vice President Wallace and Wayne Coy and the South African Minister and John Martin, purchasing commissioner in this country for the South African Government.

The Vichy Government insists that it has had no negotiations with Japan regarding Madagascar and that there was accordingly no danger that this island would be used against the United Nations. But the Vichy Government, even before it was dominated by a man who has staked his future on a quick Axis victory, showed that it could not be counted upon to resist pressure from Japan.

At a rally of the National Security Women's Corps held last night in the ballroom of the Hotel Edison, 228 West Forty-seventh Street, Mrs. Vincent De Leo of Jersey City was selected as the "typical N.S.W.C. girl," to have her portrait painted for the emblem poster of the organization. Howard Chandler Christy, who attended the rally, and Sidney E. Dickenson, previously had chosen Darrell Brown as the artist to do the portrait.

BOSTON, May 6 (AP) -- Even a masterful pitching performance by ancient Ted Lyons couldn't cool off the blazing bat of Bobby Doerr today and two home runs by the Boston Red Sox second baseman gave his team a 3-1 ten-inning decision over the Chicago White Sox.
With many questions relating to salt water angling gradually being clarified as the season approaches, additional light on Peconic Bay weakfishing was supplied yesterday.

The 1Vfarie Harriman Gallery, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street, will close on July 1 for the duration of the war. VLrs. Harriman will devote her time to war work. Watercolors and drawings by seven artists who have been associated with the activities of the gallery since its opening in 1930 will be represented in a farewell exhibition opening on Monday.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A War Department communique on the military situation as of 4:15 P.M. said:

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., May 6 -- City, county, State and Federal sugar rationing machinery was set in motion today to consider the problem of Joseph Budesa, 41 years old, who admitted when registering for sugar rations yesterday that he had 15,500 pounds of the commodity.

CHICAGO, May 6 (U.P.) -- Kathy Ann Johnson, 7 weeks old, who was abandoned by her young parents in a New York department store April 2 and was won back after a contest with welfare authorities, died today, evidently of malnutrition.

Your editorial suggestion that the government lay a 100 per cent tax on corporate excess profits, but promise to remit 25 per cent of this when the war ends, is based on two fiscal premises, neither of which appears to me sound.

A few days-ago my brother, a 19-year-old college sophomore, received from a friend a letter urging him to go to Detroit to work in a defense plant. He would receive $1.25 an hour for ten hours of work. Thus, at a job for which he had no training or skill, my brother would earn a weekly salary far beyond his most optimistic dreams.

In Mr. Brigham's report in today's issue of your paper about the meeting of Hitler and Mussolini on Wednesday and Thursday in the castle of Fueschl the official German news agency, D.N.B., is mentioned as "giving out the information that the meeting had been attended by Reich Foreign Minister von Ribbentrop, who acted as host -- it was in his father's castle that the meeting took place."

PITTSBURGH, May 6 -- With relations between Philip Murray and John L. Lewis near the breaking point, it was made known today that Mr. Murray's Steel Workers Organizing Committee had paid off all its $601,000 debt to Mr. Lewis's United Mine Workers for financial aid extended to the steel union in its formative years.

Pricing of seasonal goods under the general maximum price regulation is likely to be decided by the OPA within the next few days, Dr. William Ehrlich of the office of Dr. Merle Fainsod, chief of the retail trade and services division of the OPA, said yesterday at a special meeting attended by some 200 local retailers in the OPA headquarters in the Empire State Building.

PITTSBURGH, May 6 -- Although balked in their efforts to get their two-game series started l today, the Giants and the Pirates decided they would lose no time in getting this brief set out of the way and announced they would play a double-header tomorrow.

Details of the two programs to be held at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, next Tuesday and Wednesday evenings under the sponsorship of the Council on Books in Wartime, were made known yesterday. The council, a group representing educational, library, publishing and authors' organizations, is furthering the concept of "books as weapons in the war of ideas."

Gasoline rationing and possible restrictions on other forms of transportation may put a dent in certain types of Summer advertising this year, which, however, may be offset partly by continued advertising of products normally slow during the warm weather, according to agencies.

The twenty-room house with an acre and a half of land, formerly owned by Mrs. John E. Searle at Hewlett Neck, L.I., has been purchased by Mrs. Martin Goodman for occupancy. The property adjoins the Hunting Club polo field. Burr McAuley, Inc., were the brokers.

The new Federal Reserve regulations governing charge accounts and installment sales are intended to carry out the seventh point of the President's anti-inflation program -- "We must discourage credit and installment buying and encourage the paying off of debts." The limits put on charge accounts are a logical sequence of the Federal Reserve regulations of last Sept. 1, restricting installment buying.

There exists in the Army a branch of the Surgeon General's office known as the Medical Administrative Corps. Its personnel consists of commissioned officers, better known in the service as the M.A.C.'s, and called the stepchildren of the Army. Why? Because in no other branch of the military service is a commissioned officer restrained by law from rising above the rank of captain.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Norwegian Government is negotiating with the United States for supplies that will be necessary when and if the United Nations invade Norway, Johann Nygaardsvold, Prime Minister of Norway, said at a press conference today.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A depressing charge of politics as usual comes from New Jersey on the day of the fall of Corregidor. Though only a patronage deal is involved, typical of many Administrations, such arrangements project the shadow of cynical politics into a time when the human spirit and character are being urged to the highest planes of idealism.
For the third time in a row the good-looking chestnut gelding Red Sonnet flared into brilliance at Jamaica yesterday as he captured the $5,000-added Youthful Stakes by a head from Joe Burger.

The nation's gasoline stocks at the close of last week were 101,376,000 barrels, a decrease of 1,521,000 from the 102,897,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago these stocks amounted to 95,823,000 barrels.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., May 6 -What union officials described as "an unauthorized strike" completely tied up production at the local plant of the Bethlehem Steel Company today.

VICHY, France, May 6 -- The Cabinet discussed the British attack on Madagascar today while Pierre Laval, Chief of Government, began a series of conferences on the same subject with German and Japanese diplomats and other officials.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- All really necessary materials and equipment for home canning are assured for this year, the Consumer Division of the Office of Price Administration reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Semimilitary uniforms and non-military pay rates were stipulated among a series of regulations issued today by the War Department to govern operations of the Army Specialist Corps, organized by authority of an executive order signed by President Roosevelt in February.

CHUNGKING, China, May 6 -- Japanese vanguards, driving ahead in spite of United States Army air attacks that have knocked out seventy-four of their supporting planes this week, have pushed fifty miles into China's Yunnan Province along the Burma Road, and a major battle now looms where the highway crosses the upper Salween River, war dispatches said tonight.

The two-story and basement factory building at 1755 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Kneeland Holding Corporation to the Pecorella Manufacturing Company, manufacturer of thermometers. The Brevoort Management Company was the broker.

VICHY, France, May 6 (U.P.) -- The German authorities have shot forty more French civilians and ten others face death tomorrow, but terrorism persists in the occupied zone and another German munitions train has been wrecked, killing twenty-one Frenchmen who had been forced aboard as hostages, it was announced tonight.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, May 7 -- The story of "Wainwright's Rock" -- Corregidor -- is the story of men who held on and fought until their endurance was stretched beyond human limits by a merciless blasting from the air and from massed artillery.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Yesterday's action by the Federal Reserve Board in strengthening controls of consumer credit through amendment of its regulations will be of great importance in supporting other measures being taken by the Office of Price Administration, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, said today.
Leases of several large apartments, including duplexes or two-floor suites, were reported in Manhattan yesterday.

While a mother was appearing before Magistrate Leonard McGee in Washinghton Heights Court yesterday for permitting her child to dig in a park, Park Commissioner Robert Moses criticized parents who fail to curb destructive tendencies of their children and said: "There are some people nothing but an arrest has any effect on."

WASHINGTON, May 6 (U.P.) -Representatives of the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company asked the House Interstate Commerce Committee today to limit Federal regulation of radio broadcasting to matters of a strictly technical nature.

CALCUTTA., India, May 5 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Five American oil drillers who arrived in Calcutta today after carrying out a "scorched earth" destruction of the Yenangyaung and Chauk oil fields in Burma said it would be months before the Japanese could provide Burmese oil for their war machine.

TOKYO, May 6 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Schichiji Ito, military commentator, said in the May issue of the monthly magazine Gendai today that the season of melting ice in the Northern Pacific had brought to the fore the possibility of an American offensive against Japan from Alaska and the Aleutian Islands.
Thirteen private city gardens and penthouse terraces were visited yesterday afternoon by the subscribers to two tours sponsored by philanthropic groups.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Canadians resident in this country who are qualified for military service have the option of joining Canadian forces or if induction into those of the United States, Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of Selective Service, stated today.

The directors of the Canadian Pacific Railway must consider debts maturing in the next few years and the impossibility of predicting future conditions in deciding upon the payment of dividends, D.G. Coleman, newly elected president of the company, said at the annual meeting in Montreal yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Some indication of the amount of gasoline motorists may obtain under the new rationing system and what qualifications they must have to get it were revealed today in an Office of Price Administration pamphlet designed to instruct registrars in the application of the system in seventeen Eastern States, the District of Columbia and Oregon and Washington.

Being money players who always can be relied on to rake in the chips when the pile is at its largest, the Yankees vanquished Jim Bagby and the Indians before 18,916 at the Stadium yesterday, 3 to 0, and thus vaulted over the Tribe into first place.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 6 (AP) -- An eye operation that could have a profound political effect throughout Argentina and in other countries of the Western Hemisphere may be performed next week on Argentina's ailing President Roberto M. Ortiz, it was reported tonight.
TRENTON, May 6 (AP) -- Governor Charles Edison vetoed today five legislative bills, among them one to raise from 62 to 65 the age at which a local board of education could force a teacher to retire.

BALTIMORE, May 6 -- They threw a million-dollar field of handicap horses at Whirlaway today and "little long tail" made his rivals look like selling platers as he boomed along the road toward Seabiscuit's all-time money winning record.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Zonite Products Corporation, New York, maker of Zonite Liquid and Zonitors, feminine hygiene products, has been charged by the Federal Trade Commission with allegedly false and deceptive advertising concerning its products' effectiveness in destroying germs and bacteria, harmlessness of use and other qualities.

Capturing eight of the fourteen first places, City College's track and field forces vanquished Brooklyn College, 70 -- 56, yesterday on the loser's field. It remained, however, for two of the home team's athletes, Clifford Daire, versatile sophomore, and Charles Setzer to provide the features of the day.

LONDON, Thursday, May 7 -- Bloody fighting in the streets of Diego Suarez was reported today as British besiegers and French defenders battled for the Madagascar naval base, which had been under a pulverizing bombardment from land, sea and air all day yesterday and far into the night.
CLEVELAND, May 6 -- Rents of government housing projects for low-income families in two Ohio cities were raised today, and in one community about 300 families were ordered to move out.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The award of the Distinguished Flying Cross to eight officers and enlisted men of the Air Corps for a hazardous and technically difficult flight "on an urgent and vital mission" to the Netherlands Indies was announced today by the War Department.

Another of the old Lepke-Gurrah gang of gunmen, who terrorized the baking, garment and other industries in this city up to five years ago through domination of labor unions, was sentenced to State prison yesterday. He is Sam (the Dove) Turtletaub, 30 years old, on whom Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions imposed a terra of twenty years to life on his recent conviction by a jury of second -degree murder.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 6 -- Today's United Nations communique reports a further Allied attack on the Lae airdrome with grounded enemy bombers again hit. There also was a raid on Rabaul and hits were scored in the target area.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 6 (AP) -- The British Middle East general headquarters communique said today:

LONDON, May 6 -- No matter how favorable the weather may be from now on, Germany and the occupied countries of Europe cannot hope this year to make up their losses on the food front, the Ministry of Economic Warfare said today.

A property in Harlem that was modernized recently has passed to new control in the sale by the Arkro Holding Corporation to an investor of the building containing four stores and fifty-six rooms at 1734 Madison Avenue, northwest corner of 114th Street.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- The Daughters of the American Revolution endorsed today the work of the Dies Committee in its investigation of un-American activities and went on record as opposing the proposed Joint Income Tax Return Bill before Congress.
LONDON, May 6 (AP) -- A communique broadcast by the Vichy radio today said:

The report of the Bendix Aviation Corporation and its domestic subsidiaries, announced yesterday, shows a net profit for the six months ended on March 31 of $8,122,679 after all charges and reserve of $36,261,381 for Federal income and excess profits taxes.

VICHY, France, May 7 -- Diego Suarez, the principal naval establishment of Madagascar, today surrendered to the British, but the defense of the rest of the island continues, according to an official announcement here tonight.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 7 -- Finance Minister Arthur de Sousa Costa has released a long-awaited statement setting forth the basis of Brazil's agreement with the United States on price control and rubber supply.
BERLIN, May 7 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
GAINESVILLE, Fla., May 7 -- Florida Agricultural Experiment Station scientists tell how to make rationed sugar stretch further:

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Roosevelt greeted today President Manuel Prado y Ugarteche of Peru, the first South American President ever to visit the United States, at Bolling Field and drove with him to the White House through streets lined with saluting troops and bands.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- An elderly master sergeant who fooled the Army about his age when he enlisted in 1922 and sixteen officers of the Army Air Force have received citations for heroism from Lieut. Gen. George H. Brett, Deputy Commander in Chief in the Southwest Pacific, the War Department announced today.

LONDON, May 7 (AP) -- Note circulation at the Bank of England continued its uninterrupted advance for the eleventh consecutive week to a record high of 776,950,000. The total represents an increase of more than 150,000,000 compared with the same date a year ago.

Allocation of domestic hides and calfskins by the middle of the year and an eventual decline in shoe production to the 1932 level were predicted yesterday by speakers at the Spring meeting of the Tanners Council of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The Star Theatre property, formerly known as Hurtig Seamon's Music Hall, at 389-397 Jay Street and 50-52 Willoughby Street, in Fulton Street section of Brooklyn, has been acquired by Charles F. Noyes, who announced yesterday that he had purchased it for his own account from the Thames Realty Corporation.

The third and final phase of the Treasury's May program for raising cash in the open market to finance the war will be announced officially today in the invitation to submit bids up to 2 P. M. on Monday for $250,000,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury discount bills, maturing on Aug. 12.

Upon receipt of the news that Governor Lehman had announced that he would not be a candidate for renomination, friends of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. expressed confidence yesterday that Mr. Bennett would be the next Democratic nominee for Governor.
VICHY, May 7 (UP) -- The following communique, from Governor General Armand L. Annet of Madagascar, was issued here today:

New air supply routes to China, requiring "thousands of planes," may have to be established either "across Alaska, Siberia and Mongolia, or from Russia across Sinkiang and the deserts of Central Asia" to maintain the flow of China's war supplies, it was declared here yesterday by Vice Admiral Harry E. Yarnell, retired, former commander of the Asiatic Fleet.

Baseball's first benefit-game contribution to the war effort will be made at Ebbets Field late this afternoon when those ancient rivals, the Dodgers and Giants, collide at 4:45 P.M. in a regular season contest whose entire proceeds will go to the Navy Relief Society.

Presidents and executive officers of real estate boards and State realty associations of the New England and Central Atlantic districts will hold a conference at the Hotel Biltmore today and tomorrow to discuss problems arising out of emergency rent control, now being instituted by the Federal Government in various parts of the country.

MEXICO CITY, May 7 -- It was learned from an official source today that the American Rolling Mills had already received $1,500,000 from the Export-Import Bank as the first portion of a $6,000,000 loan for the construction of a plating mill in Northern Mexico, probably in San Luis Potosi.

UTICA, N.Y., May 7 -- We have learned in England that calories alone will not properly feed a person, E.M.H. Lloyd, economic adviser to the British Ministry of Food at Washington, D.C., said today in addressing the New York State Dietetic Association.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- An agreement for "immediate surrender" of scattered American and Filipino troops operating on various islands in the Philippines has been accepted by Lieut. Gen. Jonathan H. Wainwright, according to a broadcast from a Japanese-controlled Manila radio station, the War Department announced tonight.

PITTSBURGH, May 7 -- The Giants and Pirates fought each other tooth and nail today, but when a long afternoon had finally run its course there seemed to be nothing left to divide except teeth and nails.

TRENTON, May 7 -- Governor Charles Edison set the stage today for what may develop into the prelude to a show-down between him and Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City in their struggle for control of the Democratic party in New Jersey when he summoned members of the Hague-dominated Hudson County Tax Board to appear before him for a hearing beginning June 1, on removal charges filed by the City Affairs Committee of Jersey City.

Volunteers are still needed to fill posts in the war program in most communities in New York State, Mrs. Oswald B. Lord, assistant regional director of the OCD, said at an informal forum held yesterday afternoon in the meeting room at Coty, 612 Fifth Avenue.

CANBERRA, Australia, May 7 -- Reports that Prime Minister John Curtin has received from a source that the government considers accurately informed and reliable are that in the treatment of prisoners in the Hong Kong area marked discrimination is being shown against Europeans.

A pre-opening dinner dance was given last night in the Gardens of the Ambassador as a benefit for the recently organized canteen division of the women's council of the Navy League. The Gardens will be opened tonight for the season.
VALLETTA, Malta, May 7 (AP) -- The government tonight issued this communique:

PRINCETON, N.J., May 7 -- The marriage of Miss Alison Stuart, daughter of Mrs. Duane Reed Stuart and the late Professor Stuart of Princeton, to Ensign Paul Foote Norton, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Foote Norton of Kalamazoo, Mich., took place here at noon today at the home of the bride's mother.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Congressional authorization for the speedy construction of "more than 100" additional submarines, to about double the existing strength of this naval arm, was completed today by the Senate.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission gave notice today that the North American Light Power Company had filed two applications in connection with its contemplated liquidation, one calling for the dissolution of Power and Light Securities Company, a wholly owned subsidiary, and the other proposing redemption of $3,376,500 of debentures on July 1.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 7 -- The care of children in wartime requires extra vigilance by citizens' organizations, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Miss Katherine Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau of the United States Department of Labor, said today in messages delivered here by electrical transcription at a Children's Week radio program sponsored by the Westchester County Children's Association.

The fine news of the sinking of seven Japanese warships by our Navy in the vicinity of the Solomon Islands must be read in connection with the report from General MacArthur's headquarters, also issued yesterday, to the effect that Japanese ships have been massing northeast of Australia, "apparently for a major offensive."

TOKYO, May 7 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Japanese forces completed occupation of Corregidor and the three other fortified islands at the entrance of Manila Bay at 8 A.M. today, about thirty-three hours after the first successful landing on Corregidor Tuesday night, an Imperial Headquarters communique said today.

A dinner dance under the auspices of the recently-organized Salvage Committee of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association will be held on May 29 at the formal opening of the Casino-on-the-Park. Mrs. A. Pierson Riker, chairman of the beneficiary, and Mrs. H. Graves Terwilliger, vice chairman, head the group in charge of the arrangements for the dance.

Three jockeys were unseated at Jamaica yesterday as 10,293 persons watched the races run through deep and sloppy footing. Examinations at the track emergency hospital revealed a dislocation, a sprain and a shaking up, but no broken bones.

Judge John J. Sullivan in General Sessions denied a motion yesterday of counsel for Miss Madeline Webb, former showgirl, for the surrender of her diary, uncovered by the District Attorney's office before she and three men were indicted for first-degree murder in the suffocating and robbery of Mrs. Susan Flora Reich, 52 years old, a refugee.
If Mrs. William N. Berry, "the American mother for 1942," had her way, every mother of America's fighting men would be nursing writer's cramp these days.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A proposal that $1,100,000,000 be raised in addition to the $7,600,000,000 already requested by the Administration for new war revenue was presented today to the Ways and Means Committee by Secretary Morgenthau.

Declaring that retention of a forty-hour week and overtime pay jeopardizes success in the war, the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at its 174th annual meeting yesterday urged Congress to enact legislation establishing forty-eight hours as the minimum measure of a week's work.

Nearly every one derives more pleasure from "The Walking Gentleman'' than the audience that sits silently before it. Grace Perkins and Fulton 0ursler, who are Mr. and Mrs. Oursler at home, have had the pleasure of writing an esoteric crime play with a good many quotations from Shakespeare and some psychiatric overtones.

Governor Lehman's announcement yesterday that he is not a candidate for re-election and will not accept the nomination was not a surprise. As James C. Hagerty stated in a dispatch to this newspaper published on April 11, it has been believed on good authority that President Roosevelt is planning to call the Governor to Washington "to assume a high position in the national war effort."

Bank clearings for twenty-four leading cities of the country for the week ended last Wednesday were $7,411,603,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This represented a rise of $617,007,000, or 9.1 per cent over the previous week and a gain of 13.6 per cent over the $6,526,581,000 for the similar week last year.

Members of the Board of Estimate concurred yesterday on a local law adopted by the City Council that would permit the executive committee of a political party to designate candidates for the City Council, after Council President Newbold Morris had denounced the bill as a "back-room politics" measure.

The five-story apartment building containing twenty-eight suites on a plot 75 by 98 feet at 56 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Cahn Cahn, operators, to an investor. Sale was for cash above a first mortgage of $87,000, recently extended for five years.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The Labor Department's commodity price index rose 0.1 per cent last week to 98.7 per cent of the 1926 average, the highest level since late in 1926. The index has risen 0.8 per cent since early in April and is now 18.6 per cent higher than at this time last year.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Charges that manufacture and distribution of tungsten carbide, an alloy vital to the making of machine tools and dies for war production, had been restricted by exorbitant prices controlled by the General Electric Company through a cartel agreement with the Krupp Works of Germany, were entered into the record of the Senate Patents Committee today.

ST. LOUIS, May 7 (AP) -- The Professional Golfers Association and its members will conduct a huge war relief program of exhibition tours and tournaments, with the proceeds to go to the Army, Navy, USO and Red Cross, Fred Corcoran, P.G.A. tournament manager, said today.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The War Department announced today that commissions as majors had been given to two outstanding heroes of the last war, Sergeants Alvin C. York and Samuel Woodfill.

Production of steel ingots and castings in April totaled 7,122,313 net tons, the highest on record for that month and 5.5 per cent above the 6,754,179 tons produced in the same month of 1941, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

In "The New Order in Poland," which Knopf will publish Monday, Simon Segal has written a report on the Nazi New Order in operation. His material covers the organization of the regime, population transfers, religious and cultural life, economics, labor, food, the underground movement and Poland in exile.

BRIDGETON, N.J., May 7 -- Broken-hearted South Jersey farmers, their women folk and their children labored ceaselessly in their asparagus beds in Cumberland and adjoining counties tonight, as they have all nights since May 1, trying to save their crops from rotting and going to seed.
The sun still shines on Mr. Reilly's victory garden.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange on April 30 was 530,636 shares, against 513,546 on March 31, exclusive of the odd-lot short positions of odd-lot dealers, which were 66,323 against 71,578 shares.

While openings of women's Fall coats, based on the L-85 style restrictions of the WPB, were scheduled to be made this week, the showings were not held because of price uncertainty. It is expected, however, that issuance of the expected supplementary ruling of the OPA will be issued within the next few days and this may result in figuring costs in time for showings some time next week.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The public attempt this week by a number of war administrators to get from Congress explicit power to commandeer private automobiles, while at the same time urging on car owners the utmost conservation of their vehicles, constitutes one of those unwitting lapses from sound psychology that have been so numerous under the New Deal.

Joseph E. Davies, former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, warned last night against "sixth columnists and stooges of Hitler" in this country who are attempting to discourage American aid to Russia in her fight against Nazi Germany.

Peonies, the first of the flowers that bloom in the Summer, receive top billing in this week's garden revue by the New York Department of Agriculture. Its flower scout reports the almost unprecedented number, for this time of year, of nearly 14,000 bunches from points South.

Two dozen of the smartest Spring fashions, notable for their simplicity of design, were employed as "stage props" yesterday in a revue of diamonds and orchids. Ornamentation, in its costliest forms was featured during luncheon in the Hotel Pierre as a benefit for the Nearly New Shop.

Taxicabs and trucks, if they are clearly recognizable as such, will not need rationing cards to get all the gasoline they require, according to instructions for local rationing officials sent here yesterday from Washington. The instructions are being distributed to school teachers and other volunteers who are to distribute gasoline rationing cards starting next Tuesday.
The consolidated net profit of Stern Brothers after Federal income taxes and other charges, was $153,650 for the year ended on Jan. 31, 1942. It compares with $132,103 earned in the preceding year.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, May 8 -- United States and Japanese warships and planes were locked in "a great naval and air action" in the Southwest Pacific today, it was announced officially, after eight Japanese ships had been sunk in the initial clash Monday.

ALBANY, May 7 -- Governor Lehman announced today that his tenure as the State's Chief Executive, now of ten years' duration, was nearing an end. In three short sentences he took himself completely out of the picture as a possible candidate for a fifth term, and left in doubt only the exact date when he will vacate the Executive Mansion and move into an important spot in the war effort, in Washington or elsewhere.

An all-sports carnival for the benefit of the Army Emergency Fund and the Navy Relief Society will be held at the Polo Grounds on Sunday, June 14, it was announced yesterday by Major Gen. Thomas A. Terry, Commanding Second Corps Area; Lieutenant W.L. Huggins Jr., representing the Navy Relief Society; Stanton Griffis, Bert Bacharach and Horace Stoneham.
On the first day of Spring in France every ancient wood once resounded with the voices of a thousand lads who gathered lilies of the valley for the demoiselles of of their choice.

Regional committees composed of paper manufacturers, wholesalers and dealers will be set up to work with the regional officers of the Office of Price Administration, Martin D. Schwartz of the OPA said yesterday at a meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt, in which the over-all price ceiling was discussed.

Stocks returned yesterday to the high marks of the recovery attained on Tuesday, as the movement, after a one-day interruption, was resumed with spirit. News to affect the market was not important, except in isolated cases, and the fall of Corregidor, which had had a sentimental reaction on the previous day, did not act again as a brake on business.

Discussion of reductions in the $777,911,106 city budget centered yesterday on educational appropriations, as the Citizens Budget Commission asked the City Council finance committee to reduce the Board of Education budget by $4,141,718 in addition to the cuts already made.

A banking syndicate headed by Shields Co., and including Hemphill, Noyes Co., Hornblower Weeks and others was the successful bidder yesterday for $3,162,000 of Series A refunding bonds of the Syracuse (N.Y.) Housing Authority.

Yale's long search for a football coach to succeed Emerson (Spike) Nelson finally has borne fruit in the person of one of the youngest and least experienced men ever called to the helm of a major college eleven.

The importance of college training for careers rather than for short-time emergency posts was stressed yesterday at a conference on job opportunities for women held at Hunter College. The government needs "fully trained minds" and not people whose education is partial or incomplete, it was pointed out to 200 Hunter students by spokesmen representing business, aviation, the Federal Government and the Campus Committee on Defense Courses.

PITTSBURGH, May 7 -- By a vote of 225 to 145 supporters of John L. Lewis in the Pennsylvania Industrial Union Council succeeded today in defeating a resolution calling upon the national executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations "to expose disrupters of the labor movement as agents of the Axis powers."

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Rationing of passenger space on railroads and overland buses is "definitely in prospect" within the next few months, officials of the Office of Defense Transportation said today.

There is no prospect that the government will take over the nation's railroads, as it did in the first World War, John W. Barriger 3d, associate director of the Division of Railway Transport of the Office of Defense Transportation, told savings banks officials yesterday at the second day's meeting of the three-day economic conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The public does not believe advertising should be eliminated in wartime, but it is interested in copy telling how to make products last longer, according to a nationwide survey prepared by Dr. Henry Link for the Association of National Advertisers.

LONDON, May 7 -- Japanese troops have crossed the border into India in the vicinity of the Burmese town of Paletwa, according to statements made over the Paris radio, credited to a German source. This is not confirmed here, however.

President Roosevelt's proposal of a $25,000 maximum income raises one question which seems to me of permanent importance in the working of our democratic institutions. It is that of contributions to political parties and organizations. At present such contributions cannot be included in the 15 per cent of income deductible for charitable gifts.

CHICAGO, May 7 (AP) -- Grain men, seeking to avoid possible railroad embargo regulations on shipments to this market when the new wheat crop begins to move, decided today to postpone action until they had heard recommendations of government authorities.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 -- Lieutenant John D. Bulkeley of Long Island City, whose mosquito boat squadron while harrying the Japanese Navy wrote one of the most spectacular chapters in the history of the Philippines engagement, arrived today with three fellow-officers.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- Grain markets were on the upgrade today and went into new high ground on the current movement on fairly general buying of futures attributed to commission houses and professional operators. Soy beans led the advance and closed 1 1/8 to 2 3/4 cents a bushel higher.

ALBANY, May 7 -- Two measures extending the State's laws against racial discrimination were signed by Governor Lehman today. The first was the Washburn bill in relation to discrimination in defense industries; the second, the Schwartzwald bill giving the State Industrial Commissioner the right to investigate charges of discrimination.

Peter F. Curran, Pola Jaludsky, in 640 Riverside Dr; G. Greifenstein, in 501 W 156th St; M. Henry, in 875 W 181st St; S. Rossmer, in 106 Cabrini Blvd; O. West, in 4761 Broadway; J. Titolo, in 106 Cabrini Blvd -- Wood, Dolson Co., brokers.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The building and use of small sailing ships for Latin-American service, to meet the problem created by sinkings of some of the larger vessels in this trade and the withdrawal of others for necessary service elsewhere, is under government consideration.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Navy Department issued the following communique, based on reports received up to 3 P.M., today:

BERNE, Switzerland, May 7 -- Speaking to the General Budgetary Commission of the Chamber of Fasces and Corporations, Raffaelo Riccardi, Italian Minister of Exchanges and Trade, said that "even after the Axis victory it must not be expected that the [food and raw-material] situations will rapidly improve. * * *

LONDON, May 7 -- Four days of air and sea attack in the Arctic on two convoys in the service supplying Russia, in which the British lost the 10,000-ton cruiser Edinburgh and four merchant ships of undisclosed tonnage, were reported today by the Admiralty.

Chalky Wright, featherweight champion of the world, snapped Charley (Lulu) Costantino's string of successes at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. Undefeated in fifty-six fights as a professional and winner of fifty-two of these contests, Costantino was out-pointed by the titleholder in a close, bitterly fought eight-round non-title bout that was witnessed by a crowd of 5,500.

LOS ANGELES, May 7 -- Through the perseverance of a father who had vowed to devote the rest of his days, if necessary, to finding his pilot son's body, an Army transport plane missing since Dec. 12 was found today in melting snows 11,000 feet up Kidd Mountain, southwest of Big Pine, Calif., in the Sierras.

The trend of earnings of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company so far this year has been downward, month by month, W.F. Humphrey, president of the company, told stockholders at their annual meeting held here yesterday. The decrease in earnings, he said, resulted from increases in costs of operations.

Secretary Morgenthau proposed yesterday that personal income tax exemptions, which now stand at $750 for single persons, $1,500 for married couples and a $400 credit for each dependent, be lowered to $600, $1,200 and $300 respectively. Mr. Morgenthau must have come to this decision with reluctance.

FORT, LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 7 (AP) -- A small Nicaraguan merchant ship was blasted in two by an enemy torpedo off the Atlantic Coast, the Navy announced today. The decks became smeared with bananas, creating a slippery hazard as survivors abandoned the vessel.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation and holdings of United States Government securities to be at the highest of the year to date, the latter showing an increase of $86,012,000 for the week.

Leases for long terms of stores in 417 Fifth Avenue have been taken by two Paris concerns. The deals complete the renting of the shops in the building near Thirty-eighth Street formerly occupied by Bonwit Teller and were arranged by Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker.
The Police Department's "Father Time" is dead. He died yesterday at Manhattan General Hospital at 11:30 A.M.

On the morning of March 11, 1872, when New York City had a population of about 1,000,000 and most of the world was at peace, when President Grant was in the White House and the wounds of our Civil War were slowing healing, a tall, smiling, apple-cheeked Irish-American lass, her sandy hair neatly combed, went to work for the family of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Harrison at 214 East Fifty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- United States naval forces have delivered a smashing blow to the Japanese Navy in a battle off the Solomon Islands by sinking seven warships and a supply vessel and severely damaging two large warships and two other ships, the Navy Department reported tonight.

LONDON, May 7 -- Diego Suarez and Antsirana, the most important naval bases in Vichy-governed Madagascar, surrendered today to British forces after a hard but short-lived campaign, and the British Fleet sailed in this afternoon and hoisted the Union Jack where the Tricolor had flown and where it was feared the flag of Japan might fly if the United Nations had hesitated.

A campaign to raise $75,000 for the relief of French prisoners of war and starving French children to be launched today by the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, 451 Madison Avenue, has been designated the Jeanne d'Arc drive.

" Lamb remains the best value," is the bulletin issued for this weekend by the Consumer's Service Bureau of the Department of Markets. Breast, the outstandingly economical cut, ranges from 12 to 19 cents, averages 14 a pound and is 2 cents below the approximate price of last Friday.

The government has requested individuals to order and take delivery of the Winter's coal supply during certain specified periods in order to relieve the transportation systems for military requirements. It is apparent that few will follow this sensible method voluntarily, and a very large proportion will be unable for financial reasons to comply.

With such masters as Byron Nelson, Ben Hogan, Craig Wood, Bobby Jones and many others already entered and more coming in every day, the Hale America national open golf tournament not only will positively be held June 18-21 at Chicago, but it promises to be a glowing success, the United States Golf Association stated yesterday through The Associated Press.

Trophies that athletes won on many fields of sport during peaceful years began flowing into the war effort yesterday when a campaign was launched as part of the general salvage program by the New York City Salvage Committee, 122 East Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- General Motors Corporation accepted today without qualification the National War Labor Board's interim order respecting payment of overtime from April 28 to May 18 which it had previously rejected. The corporation also retracted its charge that the order had been made after "ex-parte" consideration by the board.

LONDON, May 7 (U.P.) -- The Yugoslav Government in Exile sent a memorandum to the United States and other Allied governments today charging that Axis occupation forces had executed more than 465,000 persons in Yugoslavia.

All of Northern Manhattan, with a population of 750,000 persons, was darkened between 9:30 and 9:50 o'clock last night in a practice blackout that covered the entire island north of a line starting at the Hudson River and running through 123d Street, Nathan Davis Place, 120th Street, Madison Avenue and 121st Street to the East River.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 7 -- Paramount announced today the purchase of the late Rachel Field's last novel, "And Now Tomorrow," for $75,000, having outbid Warner Brothers and David O. Selznick for the property. The story, which tells of two sisters who own a New England spinning mill, is now appearing as a magazine serial and will be published in book form this month.

War ration books have been distributed to more than 7,000,000 residents of New York City, Lee S. Buckingham, acting Federal rationing administrator, announced last night as the most complete registration of consumers ever undertaken was brought to a close after four days.

Renewed affirmation of loyalty to fundamental American ideals is necessary if we are to "pay off" the Axis "stab in the back" and win an enduring peace, Dr. Edmund E. Day, president of Cornell University, told 2,500 students, faculty members and alumni of City College yesterday at Charter Day exercises commemorating the ninety-fifth anniversary of the institution.

A plea by Sidney Sugarman, an attorney, in behalf of a widow and eleven of her sixteen children who were on the verge of losing their home, fell on friendly ears yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court when Justice Aaron J. Levy stayed an order to foreclose and sell their two-family frame home.
By air and by sea we have struck again in the Pacific.

More than 35,000 teachers and other employes of the New York City school system will participate in a program of war training to be conducted at the city's schools during the ten-week vacation period and will remain within twenty-four hours' traveling distance of the city in case of a war emergency, it was announced yesterday.

It is being charged in Washington that Standard Oil, by reason of its cartel relations with German business interests, has done harm to America's war effort; as when patent rights and royalties were allowed to hold up the development of American explosives manufacture.

MEXICO CITY, May 7 -- The publication last week -- in a journal hostile to the Mexican labor leader -- of a speech attributed to Vicente Lombardo Toledano, secretary general of the Mexican Labor Confederation, but which Senior Lombardo Toledano denies having made, has created a political mystery here with potential international repercussions.

The four-story factory building occupying the entire blockfront on Hudson Avenue between Sixty-second and Sixty-third Streets, West New York, N.J., has been sold by the Catoir Silk Company to Ely Pollack, owner of the Dalesta Company, manufacturer of ladies' blouses and neckwear.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Far from being willing to accept 100 per cent of parity prices for their products, as recommended by President Roosevelt, the nation's farmers do not think the present basic 110 per cent price ceiling is high enough, representatives of the American Bureau Federation, the National Grange, the National Farmers Union and the United States Live Stock Association declared today.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Legislation authorizing a 27 per cent increase in the strength of the Corps of Cadets at the United States Military Academy, from the present 1,960 to 2,496, and providing for maximum use of officer training facilities was passed without contest by the Senate today and sent to the House for early action.

Dr. Manuel Prado, President of Peru, arrived in Washington yesterday in gracious response to Mr. Roosevelt's invitation. In sober fact and not for the sake of compliment, it can be said that he is also the honored guest of the American people. Inaugurated in December, 1939, he was the first civilian President for some years.

Despite a substantial amount of hedging, principally against cotton from the Commodity Credit Corporation, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 8 to 15 points above the previous day's final levels. Strong buying support from mills and New Orleans operators aided the rise.

The report of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $7,377,783, after operating expenses, taxes and other charges, compared with $9,418,873 in the twelve months to March 31, 1941.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The legation of the Netherlands was elevated to the status of an embassy and Dr. Alexander Loudon, the Minister, was promoted to the rank of Ambassador today as a tribute to the Dutch people on the second anniversary of the German invasion of their country.

The circulation department of the New York Public Library is an important agency of propaganda for the American way among our foreign-born citizens and non-citizens, many of whom are as yet unable to read English and are dependent for their information on foreign language books, magazines and newspapers.

Support of Russia as the "spearhead" of the United Nations to hold Germany in bounds in post-war Europe and of China to restrain Japan in Asia was proposed last night by Albert G. Milbank, noted attorney and president of the Milbank Memorial Fund, as the "more realistic" alternative to a League of Nations for keeping "the two notorious troublemakers among the nations" from again plunging the world into war.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Plans are being formulated whereby "extra" tires will be purchased by the government from private automobile owners on a voluntary basis, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, said today. Extra tires were defined by Mr. Patterson as all those in excess of five per automobile.

PITTSBURGH, May 7 -- Despite decreases in freight shipments and in the volume of trade, business in the Pittsburgh district last week held near the high levels reported since the middle of March, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 7 -- A blackout should be a symbol of our national peril, Colonel Frederick L. Devereux, Westchester County Director of Civilian Protection, declared today in urging the county's 575,000 residents to join in a "spiritual alert" by praying en masse for five minutes during next week's surprise blackout and mobilization.

A victory in the "battle of the factories" that may be reflected on the field of action by superior performance of American planes was revealed here yesterday with the announcement by the Wright Aeronautical Corporation that it had perfected a manufacturing technique for the high-speed mass output of forged cylinder heads for aircraft engines.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Governors of every State will be asked to meet within the next two weeks to determine what specific emergency action they can take to wipe out interstate trade laws which impede the war effort.

LONDON, May 7 -- The stock markets today were cheerful. Prime Minister Churchill's statement on Madagascar helped sentiment. Gilt-edge issues improved further 1/16 to 1/8 point and home rails were firm.

LONDON, May 7 -- Above all, this is a war in the air. It will be won by such swift and daring raids as that of Brig. Gen. Ralph Royce's bombers against the Philippines. It will be won by the heavy and continuous Royal Air Force assaults that are keeping more than 60 per cent of the German Air Force on the defensive in France, Germany, Sicily and Libya.

Reflecting the large Treasury withdrawals from commercial bank depositories throughout the country, withdrawals which were heaviest in this district, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System fell $140,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $535,000,000, lowest since March 9, 1938.

LONDON, May 7 -- In a debate on fuel rationing in the House of Commons today Hugh Dalton, president of the Board of Trade, suggested that in certain contingencies Britain must be prepared for substantial increases in coal exports in "certain unexpected directions."

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission amended today its rules to allow manufacturing plants with their own generating systems to sell their excess electricity for war-emergency purposes without coming within the purview of the commission under the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

CHUNGKING, China, May 7 (U.P.) -- Chinese guerrilla forces, which have opened a "second front" in Eastern China, were reported tonight to have carried out a series of attacks inside the city of Canton, killing 500 Japanese troops in street fighting and blowing up many buildings.

Moscow, May 7 -- Smashing their way through somber pine forests and tawny swamps, Red Army units on the Leningrad front have ousted German forces from lines they had held throughout the Winter, divided them by seizing a communication road, surrounded units of unspecified strength and pounded convoys of German rafts and boats seeking to relieve garrisons marooned by rising flood waters, according to Russian advices released here today.

Substantial increases in the activities of all the voluntary arbitration tribunals of the American Arbitration Association, with the Industrial Tribunal showing the greatest increase, were reported to the board of directors of the association at its annual meeting here yesterday.

" In This Our Life," the Warners' picturization of the Ellen Glasgow novel, which has just received the Pulitzer Prize, will open at the Strand this morning. Bette Davis, Olivia de Havilland, George Brent and Dennis Morgan share the stellar roles of the drama, which was directed by John Huston. Charles Coburn, Frank Craven, Billie Burke, Lee Patrick and Hattie McDaniel are among the supporting players.

Maurice Evans and Judith Anderson will experiment on the reaction of the American soldiery to Shakespeare early in June when they will take their present production of "Macbeth" to Fort Meade, Maryland, for three performances.

The growing popularity of long-term series A bonds of local housing authorities was demonstrated again yesterday in the sale of $3,162,000 of these bonds by the Syracuse (N.Y.) Housing Authority to a group headed by Shields Co. at a net interest cost of 2.042 per cent.

While the residents of every community on Long Island within the city limits are striving in every way to comply with regulations governing lights under the air raid precautions, and the orders of the Army for the protection of shipping, there seems to he some one in authority who has misinterpreted what the military is trying to accomplish.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- With every last workman who can be hired, trained or recalled from retirement straining for top results, production of medium tanks at a near-by war factory already is three and one-half times ahead of "the ultimate capacity" which the Army had hoped for one year ago and the present output will be "trebled" before the year is up, an Army major told newspaper correspondents yesterday.

Net sales of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc. for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 amounted to $28,925,180, the largest annual volume in the history of the store, and an increase of 11.05 per cent from the previous high of $26,047,123 recorded in the preceding fiscal year, according to the annual report of Michael Schaap, president, mailed yesterday to stockholders.

For the first time since the founding of the Stadium Concerts all tables for the opening night have been sold out six weeks in advance, it was announced yesterday. But orders for reserved seats are being taken, with the Federal tax of 10 per cent added to the usual price.
CHICAGO, May 7 -- Daughters of the American Revolution closed its congress today with a session devoted mainly to youth projects for the safeguarding of democracy.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Income payments to individuals, including wages, dividends and other expenditures, were running at the end of March at the rate of $106,000,000,000 annually, the highest total ever recorded for the country, the Department of Commerce said today.

" Although governmental restriction on coastal fishing waters has kept the number of entries below those of other years," says George Ruppert in announcing developments in his fishing tournament, "there is still every evidence that the contest will draw an interesting group of competitors before the year is over."
LOUISVILLE, May 7 (AP) -- Harry Saladin saddled his first winner for the Arcturus Stable when Bird High, a daughter of Jack High and Falco, accounted for today's fifth dash at Churchill Downs.

Projects connected with the war lifted the volume of engineering awards for the current week to the highest level in history. The total was $434,955,000, an increase of about 45 per cent over the former high of $298,718,000, established during the week of July 10, 1941.

The two-room apartment on the fifteenth floor of the Hotel Piccadilly yesterday was well littered with dated releases. Roland Butler, the Big Show's general press representative, was getting a last whack at the daily correspondence, in between directing aides Edward Callahan, Allen Lester and Gardner Wilson at packing a ton of press material, and answering the telephone.

JERUSALEM, May 7 -- Archaeology in the Holy Land was unexpectedly enriched this week by the chance discovery of remarkable remains of the second Temple period dating back 2,100 years. The discovery was made through workers reparing sidewalks and it sheds further light on life in ancient times.

TRENTON, May 7 -- Career men should make a clean break from their protected posts if they aspire for public office, Governor Edison said today in vetoing a measure that would permit a civil service employe to take a leave of absence to campaign for Sheriff or some other elective office.

An exhibition of sculptured sketches by John Hovannes called "Women at War" was opened yesterday afternoon with a cocktail party in the Lady Hamilton Room at Gimbel Brothers under the auspices of the American Women's Voluntary Services, Inc.
LONDON, May 7 -- For the third night in succession big bombers of the Royal Air Force droned last night over France and into Southern Germany, where they bombed the industrial city of Stuttgart.

Dr. John K. Galbraith, deputy administrator of the OPA, yesterday told a special meeting of coat and suit manufacturers at the Hotel Astor that recent increases in labor costs cannot be added to the March ceilings of the General Maximum Price Regulation.

A $30-a-week former Wall Street bookkeeper, whose after-hour activities included the secretaryship of a German-American aviation club and the juggling of the funds of some 400 Yorkville neighbors, whom he is accused of having mulcted of at least $100,000 in a get-rich-quick scheme, was held in $10,000 bail on a grand larceny charge yesterday afternoon.

America's need for young men to care for and fly planes of the country's aviation forces makes imperative the introduction of a preflight aviation training system in the 28,000 secondary schools of the nation, John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, has advised school supervisors throughout the country, it was disclosed yesterday.

The United States Gypsum Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on March 31, net profit of $1,141,894 after Federal income taxes based on anticipated increased rates, and other deductions.

NEW DELHI, India, May 7 (AP) -- The Government of India launched a vigorous campaign today to create a fighting spirit in this country, whose major political group -- the Congress Party -- decided a week ago that the only way to oppose a threatened Japanese invasion would be by "non-violent non-cooperation."

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, May 7 -- Proposals for speeding up the wartime educational program and findings pertaining to controversial school problems were put into resolutions adopted today at the final session of the annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers.
BERNE, Switzerland, May 7 -- The Turkish Government is reported to have taken during the last forty-eight hours a number of measures that Axis circles are playing up as directed against the British.

BALTIMORE, May 7 -- Three Preakness candidates -- Albert Sabath's Alsab, Emerson F. Woodward's Valdina Orphan and R. Sterling Clark's Colchis -- took one-mile workouts over a slow track at Pimlico today while eight other probable starters in Saturday's $50,000 added race took easy gallops around the track.

CHUNGKING, China, May 7 (AP) -- The Japanese armies that have raced into China proper on the Burma Road brought up artillery today in a savage attempt to break the Chinese defense lines, amid ominous indications of a general offensive against Free China.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- Former President Herbert C. Hoover and Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, in speeches tonight joined in tributes to the Boys Clubs of America at the organization's annual dinner.

THE distinguished University of Illinois alumnus, Lou Boudreau, who has finally attained big league managerial rank at the ripe old age of 24, not only has established harmony in the Cleveland clubhouse but apparently is trying to spread it all over the American League. He's a booster for all American League clubs and players.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The War Production Board today prohibited the use of copper and its alloys, including brass and bronze, in an additional 100-odd civilian products, curtailed other uses after June 15, and issued other restrictions designed to conserve copper and copper-alloy supplies.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and Peru, signed at the State Department today, provided for tariff reductions on some items, binding of other tariff rates and free duties for some commodities.

The following release was issued yesterday by the State Department covering the departure of the Drottningholm with Axis diplomats. The department requested that no further information of the sailing, gathered locally or elsewhere, be added.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 7 (AP) -- The Tall Trees Stable's Ball Player scored by seven and one-half lengths at Narragansett Park today to win the mile and one-sixteenth Point Judith Purse in 1:46 1-5. S.A. Nielsen's Fancy Free was second, a length in front of B.A. Dario's Master Key.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- Reaffirming its order of April 15, 1941, the Securities and Exchange Commission directed today that the United Gas Improvement Company strip itself of all connection with nine of its subsidiaries not in the Pennsylvania-Maryland-Delaware area.

CHICAGO, May 7 (AP) -- Hogs backed down 5 to 15 cents a hundred weight today, erasing all of yesterday's advance, as a moderately large supply entered the market. The top was $14.15 and most sales were at $13.85 to $14.10. Livestock men said ceilings on dressed pork served to set a resistance area over any advances, while the great demand for pork and lard acted to halt any severe decline.

It is difficult to believe that Japan seriously intends to attack China from Burma. Even on the assumption that it is wisest to finish off China before attempting the grand coup of planting the Japanese flag from Sydney to Bombay, it is difficult to see why Japan should attempt to do so the hardest way.

For many years the San Carlo Opera Company, founded and operated by Fortune Gallo, has been trouping through America, bringing a respectable brand of lyric theatre to communities that would not otherwise see and hear it. The San Carlo Company does not depend on New York for its existence, which is good, but occasionally it pays a brief call here to show that moderate-priced opera can be agreeable opera.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Although usually increasing at this time of the year, the value of department store sales declined somewhat in April, with the adjusted index of the Federal Reserve Board based on the 1923-25 average, dropping to 117 from the March figure of 124.

A total of 527 golf clubs, public courses and associations had sent word to the United States Golf Association up to May 1 that they were planning tournaments among members for the benefit of the American Red Cross War Fund, it was announced by the U.S.G.A. yesterday.

VICHY, France, May 7 (U.P.) -- Major-General Oberg, a brigade leader of Adolf Hitler's Elite Guard, took over full responsibility for repression of terrorism in occupied France today with the title of "Police Leader."

Pictures of women in the ammunition factories manipulating the welding torches and the accuracy gauges are now common. They will become much more familiar. They make one wonder if the permanent post-war effect will be to break down a taboo against women in the mechanical industries.

PITTSBURGH, May 8 -- Bernard M. Baruch, chairman of the War Industries Board in the first World War, said tonight that price control alone is not enough to curb inflation and there is need for a unified program.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- In an endeavor to reduce loss of life when merchant ships are sunk through enemy action, all mechanically propelled American ocean and coastwise vessels of more than 1,000 gross tons soon will be required to carry at least one portable radio installation for use in lifeboats.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 8 -- Because of financial strain resulting from decreased enrollment and the war program, the privately endowed colleges, schools and denominational institutions are in danger of closing, Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio said today at the annual convention of the American College Publicity Association.

A list of recommended substitute materials and supplies for use in the cosmetic field has been issued by the Toilet Goods Association, based on a survey by its scientific advisory committee of alternate materials for those appearing upon the list of scarce or critical materials recently published by the War Production Board.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission directed today that hearings be held under the "death sentence" and corporate recapitalization clauses of the Public Utility Holding Company Act in the matter of the Republic Service Corporation and its fifteen subsidiaries.

A resolution suggesting that a uniform date for the country as a whole be fixed for rent-stabilization purposes, and that the date be March 1, 1942, was adopted at a conference of executives of realty boards and State associations of the New England and Central Atlantic regions held yesterday in the Hotel Biltmore.

UTICA, N.Y., May 8 -- To safeguard the State's milk supply from sabotage, Walter Von Dohlen Tiedeman of Albany, long a member of the State Department of Health and recently appointed State Director of Emergency Milk Supplies, told the New York State Dietetic Association today that all employes of milk plants were to be fingerprinted and listed.
