LONDON, May 8 (U.P.) -- Axis occupation forces have launched a general offensive against the Army of General Draja Mikhailovitch, Yugoslav War Minister, in an effort to crush Balkan guerrilla resistance before the start of Adolf Hitler's Spring campaign, it was reported tonight.
The Swedish Industries Fund, Inc., organized to promote cultural and business relations between Sweden and other countries, has leased offices in the International Building of Rockefeller Center.

At a joint ceremony yesterday afternoon the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters made fourteen cash awards totaling $12,500, presented medals and inducted new members. The program was held in the Academy Auditorium, 632 West 156th Street.

AT ADVANCED UNITED NATIONS AIRBASE, Southwest Pacific, May 8 -- An Attempted Japanese attack on one of the airdromes at Port Moresby, New Guinea, yesterday was thwarted by American fighter planes, it was revealed today by a United Nations military spokesman.

As has been the case in England, the literary output in this country stands to be "gravely affected" by the war, Warder W. Norton, president of W.W. Norton Co., told the booksellers' convention at one of their panels this week. The shortage of good manuscripts in England has been seriously felt, he said.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York issued a warning yesterday to retailers and others concerned with installment loans and charge accounts that opening of new charge accounts with intent to later convert into installment loans, or for a retailer who never employed the charge account system but only installment selling now to permit charge accounts, will violate the law.

LONDON, May 8 -- Adolf Hitler, in the opinion of General Wladyslaw Anders, Commander in Chief of the Polish forces in Russia, who is now in London, must risk an offensive in Russia soon. From what he saw and learned from contacts with Russian commanders, General Anders concluded that the much-heralded German Spring offensive had been delayed mainly by the tremendous German losses during the Winter.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 8 -- Michael Cardinal von Faulhaber, militant leader of the religious opposition in the Reich, has just sent an eleven-point indictment of the church situation in Germany to the Holy See. Intimations from Vatican sources received here tonight indicate that the Vatican Secretariat of State is taking a serious view of the situation.

In fixing rates for wartime excess profits taxes the problem is to find a point at which the maximum of war profits can be recaptured while still leaving industry some incentive for efficiency and some opportunity to prepare for post-war strains. It is not a new problem.

LONDON, May 8 -- The manner in which a group of youthful Norwegians who wanted to flee Nazi rule in their country seized a ship at pistol point and steered it safely to England, with its kidnapped officers, crew and passengers still aboard, was told here today.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Chairman William H. Davis of the War Labor Board telegraphed the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company today his appreciation of the company's acceptance of the board's order. Mr. Davis's message to L. H. Korndorff, company president, said:

Six swords awarded for honors to recent college graduates who are completing a special four-month course on the naval training vessel Prairie State, anchored at 136th Street and the Hudson River, were presented by high Navy officials yesterday in ceremonies at the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Realism bowed to diplomacy in today's business session of the Pan-American Child Congress, yielding only, however, the technical ponit involved and carrying off the final honors.
1Vfrs. Carlos iV[artins, wife of the Brazilian Ambassador, has come to the St. Regis from Washington.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- Five new members were elected to the board of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad today at the annual meeting here. They were Victor V. Boatner, Washington; Robert F. Carr, Chicago; J. Travis Fleishel, St. Louis; Henry E. Perry, New York, and Bryan S. Reid, Chicago.

LONDON, May 8 (AP) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said in a speech at Edinburgh today that the United States, Britain, China and Soviet Russia must police the post-war world to prevent "highway robbery and gangster methods."

While Hitler prepares to loose new fire and destruction over Russia, the grass behind him springs into flame. Organized guerrilla warfare is no longer confined to the conquered steppes. The blaze that General Mikhailovitch has kept burning for a year in Yugoslavia has now spread to Croatia and Rumania.

LONDON, Saturday, May 9 -- United States-built Lockheed Hudson bombers of the Royal Air Force Coastal Command had a big night after dark Thursday with a German convoy of twelve supply ships off the Netherland coast. Pilots of a Canadian squadron, including a New York State man, made direct hits on seven of the enemy's ships and a Dutch flier in an another squadron blasted an eighth cargo vessel.

Continued shipments of United States currency to Cuba in bills of large denominations, presumably for hoarding purposes, was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly summary of exports and imports of currency. The figures, covering April, show a diminution of the flow to Cuba, although the amount is still sizable.
CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- The Pirates beat the Cubs, 6-4, today to tighten their grip on second place.

ALBANY, May 8 -- New York State soldiers serving abroad were given today an extension of the time in which to pay their State income taxes until six months after the end of the war. Governor Lehman signed the Rules Committee bill accomplishing that purpose.

BALTIMORE, May 8 -- Ten, including Shut Out and Devil Diver, have been named for the Preakness, Maryland's greatest horse race, to be run at Pimlico here tomorrow. With Baltimore filling up for this fifty-second running of the $50,000-added test at a mile and three-sixteenths, there is no unanimity of opinion that the Kentucky Derby winner, Shut Out, can repeat here tomorrow.

Joint Federal and State fiscal action is necessary for the control of inflation, increased war production and proper preparation for the return to a peacetime economy, Harold D. Smith, Federal Director of the Budget, declared yesterday in an address before the Regional Conference on Emergency Fiscal Problems in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Yesterday at Ebbets Field was a great day for the Navy Relief Society and for the thousands of fans who packed the bunting-covered stands. But it was a greater day for President Larry MacPhail of the Dodgers, originator of the idea of playing such a benefit game.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- How airplane trainers and bomb fuses are coming out of factories where once the finished goods consisted of office desks or card tables is the substance of the story told today by the War Production Board of the manner in which the $1,000, 000,000 furniture industry has been converted to war production.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 8 -- Miss Barbara L. Taylor, who has been in court seventeen times in the last six years on charges of violating the motor vehicle laws, will make her eighteenth appearance on May 18 as the result of a meeting this morning with Sergeant Stephan Vandewater, a radio-car patrolman.
MOSOOW, lIay S (Fro.7 lessian broadcasts recorded by tte Associated Press) -- The oviet ln/orvation Bureau issued this communiqu today:

I was very much interested in John Kieran's column entitled "An Extra Man in Baseball Riots." He states that there must be some legal rule or precedent to invoke against flaunting of the law by managers and players.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The steel plate problem, which has been one of the chief headaches of the War Production Board and the Maritime Commission, is being eased slightly by increasing production; particularly from strip mills, it was announced today by C.E. Adams, chief of the Iron and Steel Branch of WPB.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Navy has undertaken an aircraft carrier building program greatly in excess of that already announced, it was learned today as American and Japanese communiques on the progress of the sea battle still continuing in the South Pacific emphasized the fact that carriers were playing an important part in the action.

Pearl L. Bergoff, 68 years old, the former operator of a strike-breaking private detective agency, went to trial in Special Sessions yesterday with his daughter, his son, his brother and three other men after two of the latter had pleaded guilty to the "information" that they had conspired to violate the State General Business Law by operating a private detective business without a license.

Equal opportunity for all races, rather than the exploitation of other races by one that mistakenly considers itself superior, was the keynote of the opening session last night of the annual Spring conference of the League for Industrial Democracy at the Hotel Roosevelt.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 8 -- The visit of President Prado of Peru to the United States is drawing the attention of Chileans, Leftist circles in particular attaching importance to the visit as a significant step in favor of democracy and an effective tie-up between the United States and Chile's northern neighbor.

OTTAWA, May 8 (Canadian Press) -- The strongest force for victory and post-war reconstruction lies in the hands of women if they will cooperate in a single cause, Mrs. Frederic Beggs, chairman of the American National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War, declared today at a joint meeting of her organization and the Canadian Committee on International Relations.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- Hogs sold today at steady prices with the bulk of offerings bringing $13.90 to $14.10 a hundredweight and a few choice kinds $14.15. Dressed pork remained unchanged at ceiling levels.

LONDON, May S (;P) -- An .4dmiralty oommuniqu6 gaid today: The Admiralty announced there is no truth whatever in the Japanese suggestion that H. M. S. Warspite or any other British battleship had been sunk or damaged in action which now is reported to be proceeding in the Coral Sea.

The six-story Carlyle Apartments at 108-24 Seventy-first Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, has been sold by Joseph G. Haft and Henry M. Weitsner. The structure is on a plot 175 by 100 feet and was erected by the sellers in 1939. There are sixty-six apartments in the building, which has a gross rental of about $55,000.

Officials of the Middle Atlantic Outboard Association in an emergency meeting yesterday canceled the fifteenth annual motor boat marathon down the Hudson from Albany that was scheduled for Sunday, May 17. Commodore Harry Birdsall Sr. sent messages to the drivers and officials explaining that the government's new gasoline regulation was the reason.

General Motors' Credit The $150,000,000 line of credit arranged with numerous banks by the General Motors Corporation, like the $100,000,000 program of Chrysler Corporation some weeks ago, marks the venture of the automobile industry into the production of aircraft, tanks, machine guns and other implements of war.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 8 -- Private Francis Shaughnessy, 17 years old, of 291 Monmouth Street, a fugitive from the guardhouse at Fort Dix, was captured here today and held for Army authorities, who said, according to Police Chief Harry W. Walsh, that he had critically injured a guard by hitting him over the head with a shovel in his escape yesterday.

Patricia Dillon, 12 years old, of 237 East 163d Street, the Bronx, walked down the block Tuesday with two pennies in her hand. At 225 East 163d Street she entered Mrs. Pauline Hirschman's candy store.

MONTREAL, May 8 (AP) -- Joe Hatten, Montreal Royals' rookie southpaw, pitched his second straight three-hit victory today to stop the league-leading Newark Bears, 6-1, and extend Montreal's current winning streak to four games.

The Navy Department announced in Washington yesterday that three medium-sized United States merchant vessels had been torpedoed in the Caribbean area and that their survivors had been landed at an East Coast port.

LONDON, May 8 -- Japanese forces today continued fighting along the Burma Road in Yunnan, with imperial headquarters in Tokyo claiming that Lungling, fifty miles inside the border, had been occupied, but Chungking reports said the Chinese forces were counter-attacking at Chefang, twenty miles from the border.

Mother's Day sermons will be preached tomorrow in churches throughout the city. Pastors will pay tribute to Gold Star Mothers of the present war and will advocate also a little more kindness to the mothers who have boys in the armed forces.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 8 -- Sixty passengers on a three-car eastbound tube train of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad were shakened and eastbound traffic between Journal Square and uptown New York and Hoboken to Cortlandt Street was suspended more than seven hours today as a result of the second derailment of the railroad's trains since April 26. In the earlier accident at the Exchange Place Station here five passengers died and 222 were injured.

OTTAWA, May 8 -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King announced in the House of Commons this afternoon that a bill to amend the National Mobilization Act would be available for introduction on Monday, but he refused to divulge what its contents would be.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- Prices of wheat advanced around 1/2 cent a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade today and went into new high ground on the current upturn, but the demand flattened out later and profit taking and professional pressure carried prices down around 1 cent from the early top and the finish was 1/4 to 3/4 cent lower.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, May 9 -- The titanic air and naval battle between United Nations and Japanese forces, raging since Monday over thousands of miles of the Coral Sea off Northeastern Australia, has "temporarily ceased" and the "enemy has been repulsed," it was announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 -- Proud that his countrymen stood by the United States until the fall of Corregidor, Manuel Quezon, refugee President of the Philippines Commonwealth, has arrived here on the way to Washington to establish the first government-in-exile in this country.

There is a serious danger that the shift from civilian to war production, together with the development of production plants in new locations, will leave New York City with a large group of idle workers, many of them middle-aged and having skills not readily adaptable to war work, the Regional Plan Association, Inc., said yesterday in a report to its members.

Success in rationing will depend very much upon public cooperation with the program. This is especially true of those items where rationing cannot be carried out on the elementary basis of dividing up what is available among every one. In the case of sugar it is possible to treat every one alike and give each applicant an identical ration card.

It is up to the shopper to see to it that manufacturers do not circumvent price controls by cheapening the quality of their product Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told an audience of 500 persons at a win-the-war rally of the Twelfth Assembly District American Labor Party Club last night at 162 East Twenty-third Street.

One hundred and fifty-four companies with securities traded on the New York Curb Exchange have paid dividends in every year for ten years or more, the institution revealed yesterday in a published tabulation. Eighty-five concerns have paid for twenty years or more, fifty-two for thirty years or more, twenty-three for forty years or more and thirteen for fifty years or more.

VICHY, France, May 8 (AP) --General Henri Honore Giraud, who recently escaped from a German prison, has refused to agree not to take up arms against Germany, although he has signed a declaration of fidelity to the Chief of State, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, pledging that he will not join General Charles de Gaulle.

New bond financing materializing in this market continued in relatively light volume this week and was again restricted to the tax-exempt field. Four individual loans were formally offered for public subscription in the aggregate amount of $9,720,337, compared with $10,286,000 last week.

The seventeen-story loft building at 263-71 West Thirty-eighth Street in the heart of the Garment Center has been sold by John F. Dailey Jr. trustee in reorganization proceedings of the 263 West Thirty-eight Street Corporation, to Joseph P. Schwartz and Max Rosenfeld, who made the purchase as an investment.

A battle between three policemen and two deaf-mutes who mistook the police for burglars wound up early yesterday morning with John Hovanec Jr., 35 years old, one of the mutes, in Queens General Hospital with a bullet wound in his thigh. His condition is not serious.
CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- The medical profession, its ranks being thinned by the war, asked the public today to curtail its aches and pains for the duration.

Herbert Zander Co. of Venezuela has given blanket authorization to the Arco Company, paint manufacturers of Cleveland, to pay to the American Red Cross or other war-relief organizations 10 per cent of all commissions earned since Pearl Harbor, as "material proof of the enthusiasm with which South American business is supporting our war effort."

I am glad to see that the Amateur Athletic Union has appended to the listed world records in its 1942 track and field guide the unofficial world records and other record-breaking performances that have not yet been approved.

Fragmentary reports of the great naval battle northeast of Australia, from which the implication of advantages for the United Nations was drawn, allowed the stock market to push forward again yesterday in its recovery. Precautionary trading entered the picture in the afternoon, however, and suggested that operators were inclined to await more definite news of the outcome of the engagement.

CANBERRA, May 8 -- Speaking to the House of Representatives today, Prime Minister Curtin said that the naval battle going on off Australia was of "crucial importance to the whole conduct of the war in this theatre" and he solemnly called on all Australians for their "maximum support" of the war effort.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- President Roosevelt praised highly the courage of the Hollanders in resisting German and Japanese aggression in a letter to Queen Wilhelmina transmitted through Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr. in London today.

The President has expressed the feelings of all Americans in raising the Netherlands Legation to the rank of an embassy. In becoming the first Ambassador of his country to the United States, Dr. Alexander Loudon is honored for his own unfaltering courage in time of trial.
Including in his statement praise for Governor Lehman, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. announced yesterday his willingness to run for Governor on the Democratic ticket.
CINCINNATI, May 8 (AP) -- Billy Southworth's Cardinals said it with home runs today, sixth-inning circuit blows by Enos Slaughter and Ray Sanders helping them to a 5-2 victory over Cincinnati.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Transportation difficulties have cut down imports to such an extent that the War Production Board is expected to act early next week to limit the processing of cocoa beans, thereby curtailing the amount of cocoa available for manufacture into consumer products.

LONDON, May 8 -- Two British Cabinet members, Sir Archibald Sinclair, Secretary for Air, and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, joined today in indicating that the present British air attack against the Germans was the forerunner of an eventual United Nations invasion of the Continent.
Ably supported in the field, Ed Alex turned in one of his top pitching performances yesterday as he twirled Fordham University's nine to a 5-to-0 decision over Temple at Fordham Field.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- To prevent further interruption in deliveries of finished piece goods whose price ceilings are established by the finished piece goods maximum price regulation, the Office of Price Administration today outlined conditions under which such deliveries may be made pending the determination of cost elements required by the order.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- An individual income tax plan calculated to increase surtax rates by about 20 per cent was placed before the Ways and Means committee today by experts of the joint committee on Internal Revenue Taxation. The experts, headed by Colin F. Stam, are to continue their discussion of the plan before the committee Monday.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 8 -- Princeton's nine strengthened its hold on first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League race by turning back Cornell, 4 -- 2, in a hotly contested game on University Field today.

Too many persons, including military strategists, have yet to overcome the habit of thinking about this war according to tradition rather than according to immediate military realities, Major Alexander P. de Seversky told 3,000 men and women yesterday at a rally sponsored by Freedom House at the Hotel Waldorf Astoria.
With night baseball likely to be abandoned or curtailed in the coastal cities as a precautionary war measure, the time seems ripe for major league baseball to give twilight games a thorough trial.

The management of "Johnny 2x4" decided yesterday to close the run of the attraction after tonight's performance. Thus, with the scheduled closing of "Jason," there are two departures from Broadway this evening. The Rowland Brown play will have registered sixty-four performances, while "Jason" terminates its engagement after 125 showings.

"The Gold Rush" today enters its fourth week at the Globe Theatre. . . . "How Green Was My Valley" will begin a week's engagement today at the Little Carnegie Playhouse. . . . "The Art of Love" and "Bedroom Diplomat" will be held over for a sixth week beginning today at the Fifth Avenue Playhouse.

TOKYO, May 8 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Domei reported today from the Philippines that American forces still were resisting obstinately in the Visia archipelago and on Mindanao Island.

The Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton will preside tomorrow at the 11 A.M. service for the first time as pastor of the Broadway Temple-Washington Heights Methodist Church, in what was formerly the Broadway Temple, at 174th Street, and which beginning tomorrow will be the place of worship of the two merged congregations.

If your observation of tomorrow's fete centers around a mother who, war or peace, rain or shine, prepares her family's meals with a faithful and clocklike regularity, there is one present she would be sure to enjoy. In fact, we think it would be a good one for her to suggest herself (if asked) -- in a last-minute flurry -- what she really wants.

Those drivers of "pleasure" automobiles who still can get the gasoline to drive on the network of parkways in and, around New York City will welcome the announcement by the Triborough Bridge Authority that the northern section of the new Gowanus Elevated Parkway in Brooklyn, unfinished when the Third Avenue portion was opened last Fall, has been completed and is now in use.

Brooklyn went all out yesterday to make a glittering triumph of professional baseball's Navy Day, and the Dodgers, not to be 'outstripped by the community in which they stand so high, went even a stride farther.
BOSTON, May 8 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Motorists of the Eastern seaboard States doing nonessential driving will receive between two and three gallons of gasoline a week, probably about two, under gasoline rationing starting May 15, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, stated today.

Verdi's "Rigoletto" was presented last night as the second offering of the San Carlo Opera Company's season at the Center Theatre. The performance moved smoothly and with plenty of spirit, but the vocalism was not on a par with that heard from the organization in the work during previous seasons in the same surroundings.

Not Russia, not the Mediterranean, not the bristling, coasts of Northern Europe, but the Coral Sea is the scene of the thunderous opening of the Spring campaign. The chief protagonists in this crashing curtain raiser are not Germans or Russians or even Britons, although units of the Royal Navy and the Australian fleet are engaged in the action.

The report of the Electrolux Corporation, announced yesterday for the quarter ended with March, shows a profit of $483,677 before providing for Federal income taxes of $241,900 and a reserve of $50,000 for contingencies.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- President Manuel Prado of Peru emphasized today that the navies of the United States and his country were "united" in fighting for the democratic ideal of "keeping open the frontiers of justice and of law."

Despite a continuing belief in the unsoundness of any contract provision requiring workers to belong to a union as a condition of employment, the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, agreed last night to abide by a National War Labor Board decision directing it to grant the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C.I.O., a "maintenance of membership" clause at the company's shipyard at Kearny, N.J.

CHUNGKING, China, May 8 -- Without minimizing the importance of the increasing guerrilla activities, which are still going on, they must not be construed as signalling the long-expected Allied counteroffensive.

ON Tuesday and Wednesday evenings of the coming week there will be some good talk at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, on books and the war. Clifton Fadiman, the adroit lion tamer of Information Please, will preside at the Wednesday meeting. Since Kip Fadiman has one of the sharpest minds now extant in New York literary circles, he'll make the boys look up.

The new high altar in St. Patrick's Cathedral will be consecrated this morning at 9 o'clock by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman in the presence of priests and nuns of the Archdiocese of New York. Immediately after the consecration the Archbishop will celebrate the first mass on the Altar. It will be a low mass.

Three five-story apartment houses at 90-92 Greenwich Street and 17 Rector Street have been sold by Harry Ruhlander to Henry Goelet, operator, for cash over a first mortgage of $77,500. They are at the southwest corner of the two streets and are assessed at $166,000.

The Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies opened yesterday its Jeanne d'Arc drive for $75,000 to aid French prisoners of war, starving French children and American prisoners and those interned in Europe. The campaign was started at a luncheon held at the council's headquarters, 451 Madison Avenue.

Original designs presented last night at a fashion show of the Children's Aid Society's Lower West Side Center indicated what the younger generation can do in this field. One hundred and twenty-five girls between the ages of 7 and 14 exhibited dresses designed and made in the children's sewing classes at the Center, 209 Sullivan Street.

A week ago New York University beat Fordham by a scant 3 points in their annual dual track and field meet. Today at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island these two old rivals figure to wage just as tight a battle for the metropolitan intercollegiate championship.
BEILI1V, May 8 (From German broadcasts 'ecorded by The Hssociated Press) -- TIe German High Command issued this eommuniqu tday:

Richard A. Knight, attorney, of 32 Broadway, was disbarred yesterday by the Appellate Division in an unanimous ruling holding him "guilty of gross moral turpitude" and "unfit to remain a member of the bar." The court found that six communications widely circulated by Mr. Knight and containing wholesale charges against many members of the bench and bar were aimed at "a scandalizing of the courts in an attempt to bring them into public disrepute."
Although visibility was almost perfect at this stage of the struggle, the Giants seemed to be contending with an invisible ball in the third and fourth rounds.
Kirk Test, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, was dissolved on April 30 it was announced by the Exchange.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- The War Department announced today a new coffee-purchasing policy by which Colombian, Guatemalan, Salvadorean and Costa Rican coffees as well as Brazilian will be provided for United States troops at home and abroad.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Secretary Wickard today threw his influence behind demands from farm-minded lawmakers that large quantities of surplus wheat, corn and other agricultural commodities be converted into synthetic rubber.
Connecticut has lifted the ban on fresh-water angling imposed a week ago and the trout season is open again for streams as well as lakes and ponds.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 8 (AP) -- Speedy on the heavy track, Benjamin F. Lister's Silver Tower won the featured Kent Purse at Narragansett Park today by a length and a half from Harold Simmons's Siganar.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 8 (AP) -- Bobby Coombs scattered seven hits as the Jersey City Giants blanked the Red Wings, 3 to 0, in the opening game of the series today. Three of the Rochester hits were made by Dusty Cooke, a former teammate of Coombs at Jersey City.

There was a Marblehead in the United States Navy during the Civil War; another during our war with Spain, in 1898, later converted to do honorable service as a schoolship; and there is, as every one was reminded yesterday, a cruiser Marblehead in this war. The Japanese did their very best to alter this situation.

LONDON, May 8 (AP) -- The Reuter news agency reported today that the Japanese were rushing troops into Manchuria, according to information in Chungking. The Japanese North China garrisons were reported being filled with troops of the Wang Ching-wei Chinese puppet regime.

Lewis H. Brown, president of the Johns-Manville Corporation, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday that Government tax proposals and policies were such that all corporations will be obliged to reduce dividend rates, sooner or later. He estimated that the corporation's income taxes this year would be around $15,000,000, against $11,500,000 last year, but gave no hint as to what action the company's board might take at their dividend meeting later this month.

UNION CITY, N.J., Saturday, May 9 -- An elderly man was burned slightly, several persons were overcome by smoke and more than a score of women and children were assisted down ladders by policemen and firemen early today when a fire, fought by firemen from this and neighboring communities summoned on a general alarm, swept a five-story apartment house at 4523 Bergenline Avenue here.

Army officers, Selective Service officials, Local Board members and other responsible citizens interested in Selective Service procedure yesterday added their emphatic protests to the common outcry against "screen test" or cursory examination methods of accepting registrants for military duty.

Robert L. Moran, Bronx Commissioner of Public Works, who was under fire in the Flynn paving job investigation and was severely criticized for the deplorable condition of his department's records by the Bronx County grand jury that handed up a presentment last Tuesday, has put in his application for retirement, it was learned yesterday.

BALTIMORE, May 8 -- In a way, it was too bad that any wishful thinkers in the Axis camp, who would like to regard American manufacturers as complacent, could not have visited two war plants in the Baltimore area yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 (AP) -Behind the five-hit pitching of Phil Marchildon today, the Athletics beat the Red Sox, 2 to 1, for the first time this year. The setback dropped the Sox to third, a game behind the Yanks and one-half game behind Cleveland, and ended Charley Wagner's string of nine consecutive victories over the Athletics.

With a record of service -- forty-three years -- that goes back almost to the time when his home borough of Queens became a part of the Greater City, Charles Underhill Powell, chief engineer of the Queens Topographical Bureau has announced his intention to retire.
LONDON, May 8 -- The capture of Madagascar had a good effect on prices on the Stock Exchange today, although business was at a minimum due to the week-end.

LONDON, May 8 -- Ever since the war broke out there has been conflict here between mothers' instincts to keep children at home and the government advice to send them to the country to so-called safe areas.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Conservation of carpets is another of the manifold wartime activities the housewife must fit into her schedule, the consumer division of the Office of Price Administration said today.

MOSCOW, May 8 -- Three German columns attempting to invade Soviet Karelia from Finland have been driven off Russian soil, it was announced here today. At the same time it was reported that German air units in the far north had been forced to withdraw to more remote bases by increasing counter-action by Russian fliers against the Axis air threat to the Murmansk sea and rail supply route.

Lieutenant John D. Bulkeley, who returned yesterday to his family in Long Island City after having made the mosquito boat a symbol of lightning-quick destruction to the Japanese, said he would like to be left alone for a few days with the wife and 19-months-old daughter he had not seen since last August, to say nothing of the son born in his absence and "mom's cooking."

The Childs Company addressed yesterday to holders of $4,943,000 of fifteen-year 5 per cent debentures due on April 1, 1943, a plan under which new 5 per cent debentures due in 1957 are offered in exchange for the present issue. Holders of more than $1,000,000 have indicated a favorable attitude toward the plan, the announcement said.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- United States exports this year will reach a total of $7,000,000,000, the Department of Commerce estimated today in a release giving in general outline the trends of exports and imports. The expected export total compares with $5,146,000,000 last year and "will represent a major accomplishment of supply and transport," the Commerce Department added.

Teachers and lay groups interested in the public schools expressed approval yesterday of the Board of Education's plan which will require teachers to give up part of their Summer vacations to be available for service in case of emergency.
Vice President Henry A. Wallace, in an address here last night, forecast a Japanese attack on Alaska and the Pacific Northwest timed to coincide with German-led uprising in Latin America.

Today's events: "The Secret of Suzanne" and "Martha," afternoon, and "Aida," evening, San Carlo Opera Company, Center Theatre; Victory Concert for service men, with James Friskin, piano, and Jacques Gordon, violin, as the participants, New York Public Library, 5 P.M.; Ethel Elfenbein, piano; Jean Spitzer, violin; Henri Mondi, baritone, and the Rolland Choral Singers, under Anton Rolland, Russian War Relief concert, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall 8:30.

A two-day forum at which prominent speakers will discuss suggestions for the future world order and the part Americans must take in maintaining it will be held next Monday and Tuesday at the Hotel Plaza under the auspices of a group of men and women representing all branches of public life.

Real estate mortgages will remain in the front rank of desirable investments for individuals, trustees and financial institutions, despite the many changes that have taken place and are likely to take place, George S. Van Schaick, vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company, told delegates at the final session yesterday of the three-day conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The controversy over the establishment of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps moved closer to final solution today when the Senate Military Affairs Committee reported favorably the House version of the legislation to create a women's corps to serve with the Army but not as an integral part of the military arm.

With seventeen named, fifteen being probable starters, the $15,000 added Grey Lag Handicap features the closing day of Jamaica's Spring meeting this afternoon. Of those listed, Welcome Pass and Devil's Crag are also in the Dr. Gardner Handicap and may go in that instead, but among the probable starters for the Grey Lag are many of the most interesting horses in training.

The store and apartment property at 538 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., has been purchased by the Five-Thirty-Eight Washington Street Company from the City of Hoboken through J.I. Kislak, Inc., broker.

Statements that the present "black market" in hides would be extended to leather within six months, unless the government makes stringent efforts to remedy the situation, were voiced yesterday by tanners at a round-table discussion on price ceilings at the Spring meeting of the Tanners Council of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Prison- made war goods intended for the United States or the United Nations under the lease-land program can be transported in interstate commerce without violating Federal laws, Attorney General Biddle ruled today.

In preparation for next week's registration of motor car owners and the distribution of gasoline rationing cards, school teachers who will serve again as registrars received instructions yesterday in the procedures they are to follow.

LONDON, May 8 -- Britain poured strong reinforcements today into the newly-occupied Diego Suarez naval base on Madagascar and into the Island of Ceylon, off Southern India, tightening the United Nations grip on a 2,100 mile line dominating the vital western half of the Japanese-menaced Indian Ocean.

Dr. Charles N. Frey, director of research of the Fleischmann Laboratory of Standard Brands, Inc., was elected chairman of the New York section of the American Chemical Society at its annual meeting last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Professor Vincent du Vigneaud, head of the department of biochemistry, Cornell University Medical School, was named chairman-elect to take office in 1943.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Committees of the National Canners Association, the Department of Agriculture and the Office of Price Administration were in joint session here tonight endeavoring to find a solution to cost problems raised for canners by the governments over-all price ceiling effective May 11.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, asked Congress today to grant $5,000,000,000 of additional borrowing authority to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation so that it might carry on a vast program of war plant expansion, purchase of vital materials and the financing of many other war activities.

BOSTON, May 8 (AP) -- The Navy and Marines have seldom put on a better street corner brawl than did Private First Class Garvey Young, U.S.M.C., and Boatswain's Mate Freddie (Red) Cochrane, world welterweight champion, in a ten-round nontitle bout tonight at the Boston Garden for the Navy Relief Society.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- United States, British and Australian sea and air forces, engaged tonight in a great naval battle in the Southwest Pacific, have sunk a Japanese aircraft carrier, heavy cruiser and transport or cargo vessel and se- verely damaged an aircraft carrier and heavy cruiser in addition to losses previously announced.
Olga Giddy, in 146 W 10th St, through Duross Co, broker.

Heartened by the farm bloc's recommendation of higher parity prices on cotton and a one-year extension on Commodity Credit Corporation loans, the cotton market yesterday continued its upward movement, approaching the levels made in the recent thirteen-year highs.

Senator O'Mahoney has introduced for himself, Mr. Bone and Mr. La Follette a bill (S. 2491) which is intended to prevent the suppression of inventions. If a patentee fails for a period of three years after the issuance of the patent to make, use and vend his invention or discovery without reasonable justification, the Commissioner of Patents would be empowered to grant licenses to others

Gifts and bequests from individuals which in the past have been a principal source of funds for hospital construction and expansion, are now diminishing. Must voluntary hospitals hereafter look to the government alone for capital funds? I do not believe so.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A plan for bolstering the economies of Latin America which have been hit heavily by submarine raids on shipping routes to the United States is being worked out by the government, it was learned tonight.

A candlelight dinner dance was given last night on the Pierre Roof by the Republican Committee of One Hundred for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York. There were many dinner parties.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 8 -- Negotiations by Samuel Goldwyn to sign Danny Kaye, star of Broadway's "Let's Face It" and of last season's "Lady In the Dark," are in the final stages, it was learned today. The deal is for one picture to be made next year, with Kaye receiving $100,000.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., May 8 -- A unique handicap tournament, featuring match play against par, brought out fifty-two contestants for the second one-day event of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Ridgewood Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Corrington Gill, Deputy Director of the Office of Civilian Defense, in charge of operations, and his assistant, Burton Palmer, have resigned. It is not expected that a successor to Mr. Gill will be appointed, and most of the members of his staff will be reallocated to other positions in 0CD.

Early last year when the threat of curtailment in the consumer durable goods industry was just beginning to emerge, industry was interested in the possibility of establishing some sort of plan which would build up a reservoir of buying power for the purchase of specific durable goods after the war.
TAMPA, Fla., May 8 (AP) -- A heavy bomber with ten Army men aboard, two of them passengers, was listed as missing today by MacDill Field officials.

Retail trade here this week continued at about previous levels, with department store executives estimating gains of 5 to 7 per cent over a year ago. While opinions differed on the extent to which customers were delaying buying in anticipation of the retail price ceilings on May 18, reports agreed that registration for, sugar rationing had tended to cut down attendance of customers in many stores during the early part of the week.
The future course of the war in the Pacific -- and in the world -- may be hanging in the balance, shrouded by the miles of distance and the smoke of gunfire in the Coral Sea.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Bill Lee, veteran right-hander, scored his fourth victory of the season by limiting the Pirates to six hits today while the Cubs fashioned a 3-to-1 victory over the second-place Bucs. Pittsburgh fell another halfgame behind the idle Dodgers, whose lead now is two lengths. Stanley Hack drove in two Chicago runs. He nit a double in the Continued on Page Four
BOSTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Braves showed some power at the plate today for their hard-luck Jim Tobin and he coasted to his fourth victory, 6 to 2, by setting down the Phils with six hits.
HONOLULU, May 9 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, using the facilities of the Columbia Broadcasting System, spoke to the "Mothers of America" from Honolulu today.

Members of the Class of 1942 and a delegation of members of the Manhattan College Alumni Society will attend the yearly memorial mass for the graduates of the college today to mark Manhattan College's eighty-ninth annual commencement week program.

When Franklin D. Roosevelt was finishing his second term in 1932 as Governor of New York State, he was asked whether Lieutenant Governor Herbert H. Lehman would be his choice for the next Governor. "What do you expect me to do," said the future President, "cut off my good right arm?"

Since Pearl Harbor the aircraft manufacturers of the United States have done a remarkable job. Colonel John H. Jouett, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, Inc., stated recently that production of military planes has almost doubled in number since Dec. 7.

The medical advisory committees of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis have recommended research grants amounting to $189,525 for further investigation into the causes and cures of the disease, Basil O'Connor, president of the foundation, announced yesterday.

Industrial shares climbed yesterday to their highest points of the present recovery movement on the New York Stock Exchange, and the whole list closed irregularly higher on the day but dull. Stocks generally were higher for the second consecutive week, with industrials at the best levels since April.

FOR THE COMING WEEK -- Dahlia cuttings, from new growth of tubers that have been started indoors, root quickly in sand and peatmoss and make strong plants. The tubers remain just as good for setting out. . . . . Dandelions in the lawn, easily spotted now by their blooms, can be removed readily with an asparagus knife; left until later, they will prove much more difficult.

AFTER a few months of envious comment upon the fact that the Army camps near New York and Hollywood were the nearly sole recipients of the entertainment industry's beneficence, we here in Kansas adopted a "sour grapes" attitude which has been working overtime to our advantage.

Too many suspects and too few clues combine to make it difficult for Sheriff Jess Roden to solve the mystery of the death of Vivian Beck. Of one thing Roden is certain: Mrs. Beck was not killed by the pack of dogs which roams the countryside at night. The evidence is meant to point in that direction, but Roden knows too much about dogs to be deceived.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Rationing became an integral part of every American's life this week when the nation went through the formalities of registering for the books of stamps which now are required for the purchase of sugar anywhere in the country.

BERLIN, May 9 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Japanese Government has decided to introduce compulsory military service in Korea in 1944, dispatches from Tokyo said today.

The loss of a medium-sized merchant vessel and a small freighter to Axis submarines in the Gulf of Mexico was announced yesterday by the Eighth Naval District at New Orleans. This was the first time enemy submarines had been reported operating in the Gulf.

THE newly organized Council of Books in Wartime, with the cooperation of THE YORK TIMES, has arranged a series of discussion meetings on the theme of "Books as Weapons in the War of Ideas." They will be held on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday evenings of this week in Times Hall, formerly the Little Theatre.

The fourteenth annual Block F dinner, at which Fordham's athletes were honored, attracted 400 persons to Keating Hall last night. The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, S.J., president of the university; Lieut. Comdr. Jim Crowley, who received a leave of absence from his head football coaching duties to join the Navy, and Earl Walsh, acting head gridiron mentor at Fordham, were among the speakers.
MOSCOW, May 9 -- In a dispatch from the North Caucasian city of Krasnodar, the official Tass news agency declared today that the Germans were using poison gas mines in their Crimean operations.

RANQUILLA, Colombia, May 9 (U.P.) -- Survivors of a United States merchant vessel sunk last Monday by a German submarine said today a United States bomber dropped depth charges over the U-boat and sank it.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Three New York State men are among 176 members of the Fourth Regiment, U.S.M.C., and eight members of the Navy Medical Department attached to the famous Leatherneck regiment who have received Army decorations for heroism in the Battle of the Philippines, the Navy Department announced tonight.

Cotton have burst into full bloom for Summer. The fluffy boll, transformed into cobweb thread, has been woven into fine materials that will go to the best of the Summer's parties. America's greatest designers have put a swish and swirl into muslins and dimities that would have charmed a Scarlet O'Hara. To pique they have given a sophisticated finish.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 9 -- Although its captain, Edward Beetem, scored 18 points in four field events, Pennsylvania lost its annual dual track meet with Cornell today, 71 -- 64.

SO far as Susie Smith or Joe Doakes are concerned the local movie palace brings in a new double-bill every Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday. That, so far as the exhibitor is concerned, is all that the public knows or needs to know.

RETURNED: On May 7 the S. S. Drottningholm sailed for Lisbon. Aboard her were 867 officials, the preDec. 7 representatives to the United States of Germany, Italy, Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria. Also sailing were about 100 non-official nationals of these countries.

Two years ago this morning Hitler unleashed his total war. On May 10, 1940, the German armies launched their wanton attack on Holland, Luxembourg and Belgium. In the days that have passed since those fateful blows were struck, the war has widened immeasurably.

THE end of the WPA Music Project as it has functioned in the past is signalized for this locality by the resignation of Horace Johnson, New York's regional director, effective as of May 1. Mr. Johnson's departure does not mean that the Music Project has ceased to exist, but it does mean that this project has been absorbed, its funds curtailed, and its machinery used for purposes of war work.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has made the first purchase for its permanent collection of a work of sculpture by a South American. This is an over life-size portrayal of St. Francis, carved by Mme. Maria Martins, wife of the Brazilian Ambassador to the United States.

LONDON, May 9 (U.P.) -- German firing squads killed scores of civilians throughout occupied Europe today, fifty of them in Paris, while Reinhard Heydrich of the Gestapo extended his ruthless campaign of reprisals to stamp out anti-Nazi disorders, according to advices reaching London.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 9 -- Awards for distinguished service in educational fields were presented here today to six individuals at the closing session of the twenty-fifth annual convention of the American College Publicity Association.

EVELYN BOLSTER'S first novel, "Morning Shows the Day," was a story of three children who grew up the hard way, having no one but a somewhat erratic father to depend upon. Fresh, amusing, poignant, and almost startlingly veracious, it was as good a book about children as has appeared in many years, and had a flavor that was wholly individual

THE April 18 issue of News From Belgium, issued by the Belgian Information Center, 630 Fifth Avenue, New York City, registers a protest against John Steinbeck's story, told in "The Moon Is Down," of the little old Belgian woman who killed twelve Nazis with a long, black hatpin.

Like Hardie Gramatky's picture books, this one proves that the machine age is no detriment to fantasy. Its succinct rhymes and vigorous pictures concern one Timothy Timpkins, a small boy who entertains himself in those boring moments between bedtime and sleep with visions of things he likes -- boats, trains, horses, ice cream, dinners, but mostly trucks.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Looking forward to the day when "all ideologies of force and despotism shall be outlawed," Dr. Manuel Prado, president of Peru, said today that the New World will then be united "in a state of general well-being" as it is today, by danger.

The report of Parke, Davis Co. for the quarter ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $1,449,234 after depreciation, a provision of $2,345,000 for United States and foreign income and excess profits taxes and other charges.

With practice blackouts in huge sections of New York occurring frequently, this town is taking the possibility of air raids more seriously than it once did. In an actual air raid flying glass is one of the worst menaces. There is a safeguard against this danger that has stood the test of war conditions in England and is now being sold in stores here.

Marking the second anniversary of the invasion of Holland, a salute to the flag of the Netherlands will be held this afternoon aboard a United States battleship in an Atlantic port, according to an announcement yesterday from the Netherlands Information Bureau.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 9 -- Cornell crews swept their regatta with Syracuse on Cayuga Lake today, with the Orange furnishing opposition only in the varsity race.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Senator Prentiss M. Brown of Michigan announced today his candidacy for re-election to the seat he has held in the upper house for six years, and for which a bid is being made, on the Republican ticket, by Gerald L.K. Smith, preacher and leader, or follower, in many nation-wide movements during the last decade.

Saying that no man was wise enough to draw a blueprint for the future, Thomas E. Dewey, former District Attorney and prospective Republican nominee for Governor, declared yesterday there was no doubt that the United States must recognize its responsibility and power in the family of nations after prosecution of the war to complete victory.

CHUNGKING, China, May 9 -- To the patient, five-year-suffering Chinese the loss of Burma is considered but another phase of Genaralissimo Chiang Kai-shek's magnetic war strategy of trading space for time -- the time when China, aided by her new allies in full war production, will be able to seize the initiative from the enemy.

OTTAWA (Canadian Press) May 9 -- Canadian beef cattle shipped to the United States from Jan. 1 to May 7 numbered 94,859 head, against 35,986 for the same period last year, the Agriculture Department reported today. From April 1, the date on which Canada started filling a quota of 51,720 head for the second quarter of the year, 47,269 head were shipped to May 7.

OTTAWA, May 9 -- Every Canadian who goes to the United States must obtain a passport issued by his own government, with a United States visa or a renewable border-crossing card if he goes for less than twenty-nine days.

LONDON, May 9 -- Lieutenant John Wrait of the British Navy, who wears the D.S.O. and D.S.C., put his submarine, the Upright, into an English port today. Covered with barnacles and seaweed, the Upright is the only submarine in British service that can claim the downing of an enemy plane and the sinking of an enemy floating dock.

A Piccadilly Milk Bar will be opened tomorrow at noontime in the British War Relief Society's shop at 6 East Fifty-seventh Street as a new fund-raising venture to aid in the purchase of clothing for British children in the bombed cathedral towns.

SAWDUST HOUSES -- Softwood sawdust, chalk, flour and cement, plus certain undisclosed ingredients, are used in the prefabrication of a type of residential unit in the United Kingdom where housing facilities are urgently needed. The mixture is poured into a reinforced mold and the resulting panels or units are screwed or nailed together.

TWENTY bomber pilots and navigators were assembled in a room in the operations building of one of the advanced air bases. Some wore Australian shorts and short-sleeved shirts; some wore coveralls, with huge pockets and pantlegs, over their shirts; some wore the regulation khaki shirt and long trousers of the American Army.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 9 -- Brownell Combs's Miss Dogwood, a fleet daughter of Bull Dog and Myrtlewood, galloped to a hollow victory in the sixty-eighth running of the Kentucky Oaks before 18,000 racegoers at Churchill Downs today.

Ever since this country became involved in this war much time has been taken up on the radio and space in newspapers by critics of those in authority at home and of those at the danger points far away. Proposals for the complete reorganization of college instruction in art have been drafted by the Department of Art at Brooklyn College. Serge I. Chermayeff, new chairman of the department, who was appointed on Feb. 1, directed the plans for the new curriculum.

ARCHIBALD MacLEISH said, "I knew what I wanted to do from the beginning of knowing, from the time I was first sure about anything -- to write, and by writing, I mean poetry. And never anything but poetry.

GANANOQUE, Ont. -- Here in Gananoque, "the place where water runs over stones," as the Indian name means, the residents are jubilant over their role as gatekeepers on the friendliest border in the world. Despite the wartime restrictions on tourist trade, the nearness of these resorts to large population centers leads to the expectation that they will be more visited than ever before this year.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 9 -- Brown scored twice in the fifth inning without getting the ball out of the infield and defeated West Point today, 2 to 1, in a game halted after seven innings because of the weather.

Una E. Johnson, curator of prints at the Brooklyn Museum, is completing a catalogue and check-list of the books, prints and bronzes edited by the late Ambroise Vollard, Paris, from 1895 to 1939. She would be interested in hearing from persons owning any of the Vollard editions or having any Vollard letters or documents, as she is attempting to note in her catalogue as many of the names of Vollard collectors as possible.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Styles of women's lingerie were ordered simplified by the War Production Board today. In an effort to conserve cloth the order prohibits ruffles, all-over pleating or tucking, full sleeves and excessive length of sweep in night gowns, slips, petticoats and pajamas.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 9 -- Dispatches from Rome make much of the celebration in Italy of the sixth anniversary of the foundation of the "Italian Empire." One says that an Italian airplane flew over Asmara and other areas of the empire and dropped "warm messages of salutation" intended for the Italian and native populations.

Reflecting the efficiency of the postal censors in coordinating the handling of mail immediately after Dec. 7 is a printed form dated Dec. 12, 1941, found by Eugene Hoffmann of New York in a cover recently delivered from Argentina.

SIR THOMAS BEECHAM'S performance of Bach's "Phoebus and Pan" was received with mingled emotions. The magic name of the composer and the reputation of the conductor tended to blunt any criticism; but the critics were not misled and very properly pronounced the cantata -- nothing more than a little piece de circonstance -- a rather puzzling venture for the Metropolitan.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Japan, at the high tide of its success at arms, which many observers believe must end after 1942, sought this week to interrupt United States communications with Australia-after forcing the Manila Bay forts and advancing from Burma into China -- and ran disastrously into what may be termed accurately an outpost of American air and sea power.

Recent discussions of the problem of price control, including those by Government officials, have stressed the point that price-fixing alone cannot prevent inflation so long as there remains an "inflationary gap" between the spendable income in the hands of the public and the supply of civilian goods upon which this income can be spent.

ALBANY, May 9 -- Governor Lehman gave his approval today to a flat $100 bonus to 15,000 State employes receiving less than $1,500 a year. The increase is for this year only, and is designed to meet a rise in the cost of living for the State's lowest-paid employes -- those working in mental hygiene, health and correctional institutions.

AT harvest time, in 1929, Hermann Rauschning and his family moved to the big farm they had just bought near Danzig. It was a financial venture, for they planned to breed prize-winning stock as well as to raise sustenance crops on their fertile acres; but for them all, immediately and supremely, the farm was home.

It is a tale of devotion to duty, unhonored unsung, that shows the common man lifted above himself by sacrifice.

A second class of 443 men was graduated on Friday at the United States Maritime Service Training Station at Fort Trumbull, New London, to take posts in the country's merchant marine as third mates or third assistant engineers.

ST. LOUIS, May 9 (AP) -- The desperate White Sox broke a six-game losing streak and almost broke Johnny Niggeling's heart as they made three hits, all in the first inning, good for a 2-to-1 victory over the Browns today.

THE time is almost here, according to scientists, when astronomers in dressing gowns and slippers may sit by their radios, listen to the music of the stars, and learn more about space than if they gazed through telescopes.

The Babies Hospital will be the beneficiary of the annual Spring production of the English Dramatic Club of Miss Hewitt's Classes to be presented on Thursday night at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre. The school supports a bed at the hospital.

Mother's Day, assuming a deeper significance this year because of the war, will be observed today with many exercises and services at which special tributes will be paid to the mothers of the men in the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The United States has entered into negotiation with French local authorities at Martinique for positive and effective guarantees against the use of French New World possessions by the Axis. These include Martinique, Guadeloupe and French Guiana. A State Department official refused tonight to state what action this government would take in case these negotiations failed.

A definite challenge to exhibitors of pure-bred dogs in this part of the country lies been issued by the Greenwich Kennel Club, which will hold its thirteenth annual all-breed show Sunday, May 24, on the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club in Port Chester, N.Y.

Endeavoring to bring more light and laughter into the lives of handicapped children and to lift them out of their darkness into a normal world, 5,000 Campfire Girls throughout the country are engaged this Spring in numerous projects from which these youngsters are benefiting.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 9 (AP) -- Penn State's golfers lengthened their lead in the Middle Atlantic division of the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association with a 6-to-3 victory over the University of Pennsylvania on the Springdale course today.

A smooth-stroking, revamped Pennsylvania varsity eight staved off Princeton's desperate late challenge on the Harlem yesterday and triumphed by a margin of about four feet to highlight the thirty-eighth edition of the historic Childs Cup rowing regatta.

LONDON, May 9 -- An embarrassing problem for Great Britain involving deals with neutral countries that do not have lease-lend agreements is now gradually coming to have a more serious aspect. These nations are showing irritation because neither can they get goods in return for their exports to Britain nor are they permitted to draw on their sterling balances that are accruing here.

After two days of fairly active trading, the cotton futures market returned yesterday to the irregular movements that have characterized it for three weeks. On the New York Cotton Exchange closing prices on active months were 3 points lower to 1 point higher than on Friday.

HAMMONTON, N.J., May 9 -- The bodies of Russell Richardson Jr., 34 years old, chief statistician of Buckley Brothers, Philadelphia investment house; his wife, the former Elizabeth Greenwood, 26, and David Greenwood Richardson, 7, her son by a previous marriage, were found at 6:30 A.M. today in the ruins of their four-room cottage at Atsion Lake, near here.

SANTA FE, N.M. -- Santa Fe promises to be a happy haven for visitors this Summer. They will not be the former overnight motorists, but families who come to stay for several months. An ideal Summer climate, always cool at night in the 7,000-foot altitude, and a quiet peacefulness rarely found in this year's world, have attracted many people from hectic, crowded cities.
