MOSCOW, May 9 (U.P.) -- The Russian Academy of Sciences has elected to honorary memberships three Americans and two Britons, the first foreigners to be so honored since the revolution, it was announced today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 9 -- Yale and Dartmouth abandoned plans to stage a double-header today and played to a 1-1 tie in a game limited to six innings because of the weather.

KINGSTON -- The Hudson Valley's fifth annual Apple Blossom Festival, which in traditional neighborliness has been compounded of river lore, muted Mohawk drums and a touch of "Genesee Fever," will be held in this city starting on Friday and lasting through the following Monday.

Esthetics has always been a trouble zone, where, so to speak, one man's meat becomes another man's poison. Peculiar difficulties attach to the subject, which seems to thrive best in a more or less murky atmosphere. Sometimes, in a mood of despair, one may be led to speculate as to whether absolute and unadulterated clarity exists anywhere save in the mind of the scholar responsible for a given parcel of theories.

The Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus will close tonight its engagement of thirty-one and one-half days at Madison Square Garden, leaving behind a new record to shoot at next season. Roland Butler, the general press representative, announced yesterday that with tonight's performance 750,000 persons will have witnessed the sixty-three shows.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The effect of the impact of war on American labor has been to unleash its energies by accelerating methods whereby production of war goods may be speeded through systematic consultation with employers on joint labor-management committees.

DETROIT, May 9 -- Al Benton, top 1941 Detroit Tiger pitcher, who had gone without victory in five starts despite reasonably good performances this season, today notched his first triumph by blanking the Indians, 1 to 0. The contest was called in the Detroit half of the sixth.

Marriage, elderly gelding now owned by Roy A. Coward, added $13,600 to his earnings yesterday as Johnny Longden piloted him home first in the $18,600 Grey Lag Handicap on the final program of the twenty-seven-day Jamaica meeting.

A committee under the chairmanship of Mrs. Kenneth A. Ives has arranged a cabaret party to be given on the night of May 26 at the clubhouse of the Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street, in conjunction with the league's benefit theatre party that night.

ABOUT that experiment which will find Mark Van Doren reading "The Scarlet Letter" in fifteen-minute daily installments on WABC, Monday through Friday at 9:15 A. M., beginning tomorrow: Mr. Van Doren was saying last week that he figured on reading 2,000 words a day, at which rate it would take him about six or seven weeks to finish the Hawthorne novel, which will not be abridged for the air.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 9 -- Harvard's powerful varsity 150-pound crew triumphed by a length and a quarter over Princeton to retain possession of the Goldthwaite Cup for the fifth straight year on Lake Carnegie today. Yale finished a length and a half behind the Tigers, in third place.

Few of the people of Castle-Dinas seem inclined to make any great to-do about the murder of Anthony Beresford, an outsider who had been making desperate efforts to crash the portals of the best society there. But the police have their duties and are not permitted to be swayed by the public's desire to let well enough alone in a case like this.

The Commissioner of Education, John W. Studebaker, has urged school supervisors throughout the country to initiate a program of pre-flight aviation training in the 28,000 secondary schools. It is suggested that small schools with relatively few students pool their resources and offer aeronautics as a course in a single school in a local area.

COLONEL BRITTON, commander of the Continental "V Army," is broadcasting regularly to his outlaw bands in Europe. Three times week short waves carry the colonel's calm, minute instructions. Information about new enemy factories and munitions plants is flashed to the eager ears of restless saboteurs.

WHERE humble homes that had sheltered generations of Washingtonians once stood there is now a squat gray building that is the headquarters of the new Mother Hubbard who holds the keys to all the country's cupboards. It is as ugly as sin and busy as the devil.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Immensely stirred by the battle of the Coral Sea, Washingtonians regarded it today as vivid proof of President Roosevelt's recent statement that enough men and materials had been poured into the Australian area to check the southward drive of the Japanese.

In an address delivered by Senator Robert Taft in New York before the American Irish Historical Society he fired a broadside of caustic criticism against the government's use of publicity as an aid to winning the war. He took the Administration to task for spending more than thirty million dollars annually on public information agencies and would have us believe that this is money wasted on an unnecessary and useless service.

First prize of $300 in the $1,000 Mercury Photo Contest conducted by the Universal Camera Corporation has been awarded to H. Francis Jackson of Everett, Wash., for his picture "War Worker." In all, there were 2,433 entrants, of whom sixty-eight received awards.

That there is a real problem involved in trying to find satisfactory substitute merchandise for sales and dealer outlets to handle was revealed here last week by a canvass of sales managers of industrial concerns. This, however, was said to be affording companies which make such substitute products a rare opportunity to widen their distribution.

A new agreement covering thousands of Chinese seamen employed in the British merchant marine has been signed in London as a result of long-standing demands by the Chinese for an equal footing with death of a seaman.

The bonds of culture and the similar political philosophies that have linked the governments of France and the United States in the past will continue to exist so long as true French culture survives in the United States, Count Charles de Fontnouvelle, head of the Lycee Francais de New York, the first French secondary school ever established in the United States, asserted yesterday.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 9 -- Designed to meet the nation's wartime need for translators and interpreters of foreign languages, special courses in Japanese, Russian, modern Greek, Malay and possibly Arabic will be presented during the University of Michigan's new Summer term.

Final plans have been completed for "Carnival Street," an elaborate entertainment to be given Tuesday night in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society. The net proceeds will aid families of men serving in the United States Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard.

Budget dress promotions drew good consumer response last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

JOHN QUINCY ADAMS was in St. Petersburg in November, 1812, and he wrote to mother -- Abigail Adams -- about what was happening to the man who for almost twenty years had been a conqueror. Napoleon "appears really to have concluded that all he had to do was to reach Moscow," the American statesman commented, "and the Russian Empire would be prostrate at his feet.

Until the middle of the last century the Yosemite Valley was exclusively inhabited by a tribe of Indians. In fact, it was in pursuit of a marauding band of Indians that the government troops first discovered this valley. At that time gold deposits had been found a hundred miles farther down the stream and an expedition formed to pan it.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9 -- Southpaw Morton Waldstein pitched Harvard to an 11-1 victory over Columbia at Soldiers Field today in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game. It was Harvard's third league triumph this season and its first league contest on the home field.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 9 -- The only dog of the six in the ring with no previous best-in-show record triumphed in the final judging at the ninth annual Orange Kennel Club all-breed fixture on the grounds of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.

MOSCOW, May 9 -- The builders of Leningrad's Winter lifeline across Lake Ladoga's ice were honored in a long list of awards published today. Engineers, workers, chauffeurs and members of the Red Army's supply corps were singled out for special praise.

Civilian purchasing staffs are now being set up in a number of key cities to acquire canned foods, under the recently announced program by which all such buying for wartime agencies will be handled by the War Department, it was learned last week.

WINDOW ROOK, Ariz. -- Within our borders is a land one-half the size of the State of New York whose citizens -- and none have a prior claim to citizenship -- realize the country is at war and are doing something about it. They are not hysterical or confused over the issue, the outcome, or what it takes to win a war, for they know what war means.

THE report of new jobs and new duties for girls and women has rushed like the wind over the country. On the face of the situation, with armed forces of 5,000,000 men in prospect, and with production speeded up to unprecedented highs, women will have to take over an enormous amount of work.

Humor in photography either is or it isn't. Everybody is agreed on that. Whether whimsy, ridicule or slapstick is employed, the picture must stir laughter or a smile instinctively and promptly. If the observer has to stop to think about it the picture is a failure.

THIS is the second novel to be published within a couple of weeks which has as its background the early chapters in the history of the Mormon Church. The first, "And Never Yield," by Elinor Pryor, went back to the massacre at Haun's Mill and ended with the exodus from Nauvoo, the city the Latter Day Saints had built in Illinois after being hounded out of Missouri.

For some reason the nemesia remains a stranger to the average garden. This South African annual, related to the figworts, is half-hardy, it is true, but the close bedding of these flowers has been called a "mosaic of jewels," and the description is apt.

The accidental discovery of an old diary is the starting point of Mrs. Bradley's investigation of a murder mystery which the authorities have long since written off their books. The diary makes no startling revelations, but Mrs. Bradley reads between the lines that there is something still to be learned about two sudden deaths which occurred six years earlier and about a woman who was tried for murder and acquitted.
Lafayette, Conn., steeped in Revolutionary lore, is a long way from the Des Moines River and the Iowa frontier, but the boys

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- "It will not do to say to one American citizen, 'You may not have the benefits of an improved method of education because of your race,' when at the same time other citizens in the same school district are being accorded those benefits."

Wherever anglers gather and discuss methods there is likely to be a difference of opinion. Even in a recently received issue of The Fishing Gazette, an English weekly published near London, one can find a controversy raging.

ANTI-ENEI%I ALFF, N: A Cffth-floor studio on lVJ[anhattan's Fourteenth Street is the workshop of Yasuu I, the Japanese artist who lias made his home in America since 1906, when, as a boy of 13, he came from over the Pacific to "make a fortune."

THE WINGS OVER JORDAN CHOIR was organized some years ago in Cleveland by the Rev. Glenn T. Settle, pastor of the Gethsemane Baptist Church there. It appeared on a local radio station, went on to achieve a network of more than a hundred stations of the Columbia Broadcasting System and gave concerts on tour from coast to coast.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (U.P.) -- The United States is sending a special mission to the Union of South Africa to seek means of developing vast natural resources for the United Nations' war effort, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Restrictions of the jute limitation order were relaxed by telegrams sent today by the War Production Board to rug and carpet manufacturers. The telegrams gave the floor-coverings producers permission to use jute yarns on hand in the manufacture of rugs and carpets beyond the shut-off date which had been set previously as May 11.

Because his diplomatic career has been cut short by an accident which resulted in the loss of his sight, Henry Morton Wardlaw turns his keen intellectual powers to other uses. Sitting alone in his penthouse, he listens to police radio broadcasts until he hears of a crime that seems to present enough difficulties to make it interesting.

In an effort to spur a greater understanding of the issues, aims and progress of the present war in boys and girls of high school age, Samuel J. Tilden High School in New York City will set up two elective courses in contemporary American problems and Latin-American civilization next semester, it was announced yesterday.

The new pattern of life laid out for Americans by the necessities of total war was becoming clearer last week. Regulations set up in Washington found their way to cities, towns, villages, hamlets, homesteads in the forty-eight States. Housewives, their sugar books in hand, had their first experience of rationing.
Loyola University of Baltimore defeated City College, 13 -- 1, in lacrosse yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The first contingent of the Atlantic City Beach Patrol will go on duty on Saturday, two weeks ahead of schedule.

There are many new books on home vegetable gardening inspired by the need for producing foodstuffs this year. Many of these are good, some hastily thrown together, but often the fruits of years of practical experience. After reading and reviewing these for months, it seems to this reviewer that no other is quite so informative, comprehensive, succinct and authoritative as "Home Vegetable Gardening."
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 9 (AP) -- Outfielder Jimmy Ripple, onetime world series hero, blasted two homers and drove in five runs as Rochester turned back Jersey City, 8 -- 6, today.

General Henri Honore Giraud, who escaped from the German fortress at Koenigstein in April, was arrested yesterday in Geneva, Switzerland, for traveling with false papers, according to private advices to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

An important Zionist gathering, attended by delegates from all parts of the country and by leaders from abroad, opened at the Biltmore last night with an address by Dr. Chaim Weizmann in which the essential role of Palestine in the solution of the post-war Jewish problem was stressed.

FUNDAMENTAL shifts in economic and social power have taken place in the last two decades that are giving rise to revolutionary changes in public policy. Labor is aggressively insisting on its right to participate in the formulation of all policies that affect production.

READERS of Valtin's "Out of the Night" who may have questioned that a young German sailor whose adolescent schooling had been that of the forecastle, with a finishing course in California's State prison, could have written a best-seller in English without benefit of a collaborator will here find convincing evidence to dispel their doubts.

THE end of William Saroyan's idyllic five-month association with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer came suddenly this week when the playwright walked out of the studio and wrote a byline story for The Daily Variety, a Hollywood trade paper, under the heading "Why I Am No Longer at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, or The California Shore-Bird in Its Native Habitat, or Brahms' Double Concerto in A Minor."

While final plans for the registration of New York City's 900,000 automobile owners for gasoline rationing were perfected yesterday, it was announced in Washington by the Office of Price Administration that the maximum weekly allotment for motorists along the Eastern seaboard engaged in nonessential driving would be three gallons after next Friday.

Business, professional and labor groups in the past week have adopted quotas totaling $213,000 in the Greater New York Fund Campaign, it was announced yesterday by John W. Hanes, campaign chairman, from the Fund headquarters, 52 Wall Street.

AT ADVANCED UNITED NATIONS AIR BASE, Southwest Pacific, May 9 -- Intermittent naval and air action since Monday has broken up one Japanese threat to push farther south in the Pacific, but the danger is by no means over.

The Treasury's program for 1942 tax legislation called for additional corporate taxes of $3,000,000,000. It appears now to be agreed by the President and the Treasury that, whether or not this amount can be reached by way of new taxes on corporations, the added burden shall not be such as to impair production.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation announced yesterday that it would set up a training program in its Brooklyn repair yard to develop a reservoir of skilled labor and keep pace with the demands for such labor created by the war.

LAWRENCE, Kan., May 9 -- Drafted after investigations had disclosed a great need in Eastern industrial centers for technicians, a new program to prepare skilled craftsmen for war industries will go into operation next Fall at the University of Kansas.

This business of sixth columnists and Hitler stooges is being dreadfully overdone. This business of trying to frighten people into silence by reminding them that their remarks here in America will be read with pleasure by Hitler and the Mikado -- it is as futile as it is impertinent.

Sing hymns to the sun and contrive odes to the south wind if you will, but the man with a garden -- or a farm -- will swap them all to the sound of rain on the roof. Particularly when bright skies and a beaming sun have greeted him day after day for a worrisome month when seeds should be sprouting and plants should be thrusting their roots down deep for Summer strength.

FOR more than a decade the authors of "American Glass" have been compiling this gargantuan study, now a definitive source. Dilettanti and corner shop collectors with a fondness for facts relieved by romantic presentation will find the volume, with its thousands of illustrations, bibliography, glossary, chronological tables and detailed pattern charts, an overwhelming dose.
The great Battle of the Coral Sea is the opening engagement in the decisive phase of the Battle for the World.

Justice Hugo L. Black of the United States Supreme Court will be the principal speaker at the "I Am an American Day" exercises in Central Park next Sunday, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday. At the same time the Mayor made public the roster of the general committee, headed by Grover A. Whalen, in charge of the celebration.

THE inside of Alfred Hitchcock's noggin must be a truly fearful spot. Vaguely one has the picture of a Stygian vaulted dome within which a prodigious army of cerebral molecules is forever feverishly employed in the production of diabolic schemes.

Nine years ago today the Nazified students of the German universities were burning thousands of "un-German" books. This "purification" of the libraries seemed unnatural in the country where printing was invented. As we look back to that day we remember how strange, unreal, incredible such a revival of obscurantism seemed in a nation so long famous for scholarship, philosophy, literature and the free teaching of every knowledge and science.

A campaign has been begun by many banks in various parts of the country to urge the public to search for "hidden treasure" in the form of old Liberty bonds and other government securities which matured long ago and have never been presented for payment.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 9 (AP) -- Richard H. Simons, chief of the Connecticut office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced today that his agents had searched the Thompson estate of Anastase A. Vonsiatsky, leader of the International Russian Fascist party.

MEXICO CITY, May 9 -- Though the steamship Drottningholm has departed on her first voyage without taking those Nazi agents in Mexico whom Mexican officials had said would be sent to Germany on this ship, it is still said here that they will go.
MOSCOW, May 9 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

In a review of racial problems throughout the world, the League for Industrial Democracy, Inc., heard yesterday the charge that present conditions "are building up for a Third World War on racial lines, very likely with the Germans on the side of the Anglo-Saxons" against the vast yellow and black populations.

A new high altar of gray-white Italian marble simply carved, set under a bronze baldachin, or canopy, of soaring Gothic grace, was consecrated at St. Patrick's Cathedral by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Delegates to the eighth Pan-American Child Congress adopted today a decalration of opportunity for children which summarized the program formulated at the sessions which opened last week.

With indications multiplying that the OPA is moving to administer the general maximum price regulation "equitably and reasonably" among the branches of production and distribution, the consensus in trade circles here at the week-end was that "the fog is beginning to lift."

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Floral time in the Poconos, with dogwood, wild azalea, arbutus and apple blossoms now at the height of their flowering beauty, is attracting many to the mountains, and guests at each of the resorts are enjoying golf, horseback riding, lawn bowling, tennis and hiking.

The second game of their series postponed, the Giants and Dodgers yesterday decided to stake everything on a single game today at Ebbets Field to recoup some of the loss of a Saturday date in Brooklyn. The engagement will get under way at 2:30 o'clock.

NORTHFIELD, Mass. -- Eight trips have been announced by the American Youth Hostels, Inc., of Northfield, Mass., for the coming travel season. Groups will travel by bike and prepare their own meals to reduce travel costs. Excursions to Canada and Latin America will provide opportunities for those interested in foreign travel as well as those who want to further inter-American ties.

"A PRODUCTION on the grand scale" in the movies is promised this ambitious story. With a red-haired actress for the Governor's wife and an actor with a bulldog chin to play the part of the newspaper man it will likely turn out an effective picture.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 9 -- A new cooperative arrangement between the University of Buffalo and the Buffalo School of Fine Arts, for the preparation of teachers of art for elementary and secondary schools, was announced jointly today by Chancellor Samuel P. Capen of the university and Philip C. Elliott, director of the art school.

CINCINNATI, May 9 -- Johnny Vander Meer, pitching nine innings without issuing a walk for the first time in his career, gave the Reds their first 1942 victory over the Cardinals today. The score was 5 to 2.

IT is an amusing story of Regency days, told with humor and sharp appreciation of the likeness of people then to those today. Miss Deborah Grantham and her titled aunt had started a professional gaming business in Lady Bel's charming London house much as a couple of New York suburbanites might get involved in the chicken business in their backyard.

A VOLUME to be treasured at any time, the appearance of this one now is an affirmation of one of the principles for which we are fighting, for this is a war to preserve culture as well as political ideals, and now more than ever do we need to know and appreciate our heritage of art.

LONDON, May 9 -- Rationing of fuel, which appears to be certain following the debate in Parliament, will not solve Britain's coal problem, which is essentially one of production. The government plans to find a solution of the difficulties of coal production next Summer among several schemes which are being examined.

The twenty-seven-day wartime Jamaica race meeting, which ended yesterday, was the most successful in the track's history and far eclipsed the figures for the corresponding session of 1941, which was a twenty-five-day meeting.

To the many garden lovers who will visit Washington this Spring and Summer one of the most fascinating points of interest will be Mount St. Alban, the famous "garden out of a dump heap" -- a remarkable collection of ancient yews, boxwood from old colonial mansion gardens, centuries-old sculpture brought from quiet monastery gardens of Europe and an ancient wisteria vine.

Fortified with the support of the New York County Medical Society, organized women physicians are turning to leaders of national women's groups for help in their campaign to remove barriers against their serving with the armed forces.

Walks of cement seem decidedly incongruous in a garden. Even brick paths, though they may look well enough, have their faults. And the stepping stones, sometimes introduced on the theory that they are particularly gardenesque, are found in practice to be particularly pernicious, as any one discovers who tries to run the lawn mower over them or to keep the weeds pulled out of the cracks.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 -- Never has the West Coast felt more certain than it does today that some time before the war ends Japanese aircraft will drop at least a load or two of bombs on the mainland. This belief has been strengthened, rather than dispelled, by our own aerial attack on Tokyo, and it has grown in the face of the precautionary evacuation of Japanese from a great coastal area.

IT might have been interesting to ask some of the wise persons on some information program who John Woolman was, and what he did to be remembered for. An answer might be that he wrote a journal celebrated for its gentle revelation of a man's inner life.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 9 -- A new "death cargo" of 160 elderly and sick Norwegian teachers was sent from Trondlheim to the extreme north of Norway on May 1, it is reported tonight in Stockholm, where it is also learned that the German military have compelled Premier Vidkun Quisling to abandon or postpone his plans for a "complete new ordering" of Norwegian workers.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- There are a lot of problems to be solved and "kinks" to be straightened out in the application of the forthcoming government price-control program, Price Administrator Leon Henderson conceded today. He added, however, that the greatest part of the price work could be handled easily and swiftly.

VICHY, France, lViay 9 (U2PJ-The death of Captain Jean Assolant, who flew the Atlantic in 1929, was reported unofficially today from 1Vfadagascar. The report, however, was not confirmed. It wa, believed that Captain Assolant had been shot down in action against the British, although dispatches said that he might have escaped to another part of the island.

NOW that both our countries are drawn into this war and there is considerable talk of preserving our joint cultural heritages, may I draw the attention of your readers to a subject which is very apt to be submerged by the immediate needs of strategy but is in the long run equally important, namely, the actual struggles to keep that culture alive?
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- At 12:01 A.M., local time, Monday, government controls will be clamped on the prices charged by virtually every manufacturer and wholesaler in the United States.

This very attractively bound and printed book deals specifically with Paul Klee's paintings and water-colors produced between 1913 and 1939 (he died in 1940). But Mr. Nierendorf has fitted together a biographical record covering the Swiss artist's whole life, while Mr. Sweeney takes up the task of analyzing and of trying to clarify the basic aims that have made Paul Klee's hauntingly strange pictorial expression what it is.

A new speech major for undergraduates studying in the English Department of Barnard College was announced this week. Courses required of speech majors will stress a sound understanding of English literature as well as the mechanics of speech.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 9 (AP) -- Shipments of petroleum products on New York's Barge Canal system have dropped 35 per cent this year due to a shortage of ocean tankers which normally supply the barges, a State official said today.

Mrs. William N. Berry, who has raised thirteen children, has been elected "American Mother of 1942" by the Golden Rule Foundation. Ever since her marriage, says her husband, she has kept house, done the marketing and carried her part of the family business. "As more babies came," says Mr. Berry, "the older children looked after them while their mother and I worked."

RETAILERS will have a fair test of the influence of war news this week when response to the Pacific naval victory is measured. Many of them are willing to concede that the public seems to have lost interest in buying.

Citations for intellectual achievement and distinguished public service will be awarded to each of the ten new founding members just elected to the Phi Beta Kappa Associates, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Prices of wheat held within narrow limits today on the Board of Trade with professional operators inclined to go slowly on either side pending developments, especially in the Far East. The market was influenced easily.

PORTLAND, Me. -- No State in the Union is more concerned about the coming Summer vacation season than the State of Maine, which has a $100,000,000 stake in the relatively young business of catering to the roving tourist.

THE political historian is one who lives dangerously, for his road is beset by occupational hazards and the continually haunting specter of new evidence. His work, like woman's, is never done, for there is no such thing as a definitive history.

WHEN the first asparagus of the season made its somewhat dramatic appearance in January it was priced at $3 a bunch. Since then most of the devotees have bided their time, watching the price slowly spiral down out of the upper brackets. Now the tender stalks, growing in nearby gardens, are within reach of all.
CAIRO, May 9 -- There is comparative inactivity in the Mediterranean and Middle East war theatres today, but it is a question of whether this is a breather of some duration or a lull before a storm.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Vermonters who have developed a big Summer vacation business in recent years, and who depend upon it for a considerable part of their cash income, are awaiting with keen interest the outcome of plans for rationing of gasoline in the eastern part of the United States.

HAMILTON, N.Y., May 9 -- Belief that the college senior of 1942 is less cynical, less pessimistic and less confused than was his prototype of 1941 was expressed by Dr. Carl A. Kallgren, Colgate University's dean of students, today as a result of a survey made among the 180 men who will be graduated tomorrow at Colgate's 121st commencement exercises.

If the voluntary war stamp and bond drive fails, a compulsory savings plan is the only alternative, Representative Richard M. Duncan, Missouri Democrat and member of the House Ways and Means Committee, declared yesterday at the closing session of a two-day conference on emergency fiscal problems in the Hotel Roosevelt.

NEW HAVEN -- War this week brought drastic regulations for activities after dark in the vacationland along Connecticut's eastern shore; but the same regulations have lifted restrictions upon most of Fairfield County's shore resorts, which had been dimmed out for eight days.

LONDON, May 9 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill will broadcast to the world Sunday night [3 P.M. Eastern war time] to explain the latest developments in the British Empire's fight for survival and victory on the second anniversary of his selection as Prime Minister and the start of the Nazi conquest of the Low Countries and France.

Attorney General Francis Biddle, who attended yesterday a regional conference of United States Attorneys at which wartime problems were discussed, said in an interview that the weeding out of enemy aliens has been virtually completed and that no plans were under consideration at this time for their large scale evacuation from the New York area.

Though not much came out of the effort in the last war to tap the country's inventive ability, we still think so highly of our unknown Morses and Edisons that as early as August, 1940, we created a National Inventors Council to serve as a clearing house for inventions which could be used by the Army and Navy.
BOSTON, May 9 (AP) -- The powerful Rutgers crew, undefeated in the three previous Dad Vail competitions, swept its way to a one-length victory today in the race on the Charles River Basin.

LOS ANGELES, May 9 (AP) -- Capturing twelve first places as well as the relay and sweeping three events, the champion University of Southern California track and field team rolled over Stanford in a Pacific Coast Conference dual meet today with a point score of 94 1-3 to 36 2-3.

The City Club of New York, for the last half century a militant force in the cause of good municipal government, will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary on May 22 with a dinner at its quarters at 55 West Forty-fourth Street. Mayor La Guardia, Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti, former Governor Alfred E. Smith and Richard S. Childs will be the speakers.

To many persons a school teacher is an impractical, dreamy-eyed individual who sits in the classroom and hides behind books. She has been portrayed in song and poem as a befuddled thing without any awareness of life beyond the blackboard or the college campus.

THE Summer theatres this year are facing dubious days. In addition to thinning tires and the rationing of gasoline -- with its uncertain quantity -- they are encountering dim-outs along the coast as well as the whole unknown matter about where America will be spending its vacation come August.

LONDON, May 9 -- A "powerful force" of the biggest British bombers returned to the Rostock area last night and pounded anew the Germans' Baltic port works and airplane plants there, the Air Ministry reported today.

LONDON, May 9 -- Not quite a year ago London was rocking under one of the worst air attacks it had ever suffered. While fires raged, while anti-aircraft guns barked, while bombs came whistling down in London a curious thing was happening far to the northward.

WOODS HOLE, Mass. -- These wartime days find sea-going Cape Cod uneasy of mind. The Cape has good reason to know that for more than 400 years explorers from Europe could scarcely miss one of the most exposed strips of land along the North Atlantic coast line.

DETROIT, May 9 (U.P.) -- Richard T. Leonard, director of the Ford division of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., proposed today that employes demand $1-a-day wage increase when they open negotiations for renewal of the contract which expires June 20.

GERMAN-OCCUPIED Belgium -- specifically Antwerp -- is the scene of this novel of espionage, counter-espionage and underground resistance to Nazi domination. Peter Stanleigh of British Military intelligence is sent to Antwerp to learn what he can of the Nazi spy ring which has its headquarters there.

Wolf-Ferrari's "The Secret of Suzanne" and Flotow's "Martha" formed the double bill presented by the San Carlo Opera Company yesterday afternoon at the Center Theatre. The operas, given in English, were each laudably sung, but special interest was aroused by the Wolf-Ferrari one-act "intermezzo," which had not been heard for a number of years in this city.

New personalities are coming to the front in a number of Long Island women's clubs a election returns are tallied at final Spring meetings. The largest organization in the area, the Community Club of Garden City and Hempstead, with 1,000 members, has already selected Mrs. Joseph Burton Back, formerly first vice president, to direct its activities next season.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Indications that Argentine-American relations had been somewhat improved as the result of the action of this government in waiving salvage claims on the Axis-torpedoed Argentine tanker Victoria grew to day as the State Department made public exchanges with the owners.

ROBERT M. McBRIDE CO. have published "Highroad to Adventure," an anthology made up of the accounts of more than twenty tense, exciting moments. The sources range from William H. Prescott's "Conquest of Peru" to the story of his hair-raising escape from Devil's Island by Rene Belbenoit.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col. -- It is time to arise and go now to the tall and wide country where the four-leaf clovers are as big as your hand, the trees as high as insurance buildings and the boys and girls at least six feet long -- and beautiful besides.

LEW AYREE, the movie actor, must have been known to about 100,000,000 Americans as the hero of the popular Dr. Kildare series. The Kildare stories were hardly profound but the hero of them had established a screen picture for serious and idealistic youth. Ayres's decision to destroy his career by registering as a conscientious objector aroused curiosity and some worry.

The seven chamber music works which will be played at the Music Critics' Circle concert at Town Hall on Tuesday afternoon will be performed as far as possible by the groups that introduced them, it was announced yesterday.
Confirmation of the appointment of Howard Odell as Yale's new head football coach was made at New Haven by Ogden D. Miller, director of athletics, yesterday following action by the Yale Corporation.

Keuka College has adopted a new semester plan designed to utilize vacation periods for first-hand work experience. With an early start on Sept. 2, the period of residence on the campus will end on Dec. 8 and each student during the interval until Jan. 18 will undertake an independent assignment in what might be caned the laboratory of life.
HEREWITH the biennium report from Allentown, one of those places for which old timers sigh and say, "That always was a good show town."

LOS ANGELES, Calif. -- Being on the front line of defense does not interfere with California's maintaining its place on the front line of vacation travel. During Winter and Spring war alarms upset the migration of visitors west-ward far less than expected, and the falling off was only about one-third from normal.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- United States naval losses in the five-day battle of the Coral Sea, fought to a magnificent victory south of the Bismarck Archipelago in the Southwest Pacific between Monday and Friday, were remarkably slight in comparison with the crushing blows dealt to the Japanese Navy, judging from a Navy Department communique issued here this afternoon.

FARGO, N.D., May 9 -- The science of paint chemistry has evolved as a successful course of study at North Dakota Agricultural College. The industrial chemistry course in protective coatings at North Dakota's land grant college had its inception in 1905.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9 -- With Skipper Lennie Romagna setting the pace in the Intercollegiate Y.R.A. national dinghy championships for the Henry A. Morss Trophy, Brown took the lead today in the first session of the two-day regatta.

INCREASINGLY in the past year there seems to have been a renewed interest in parlor games and all inexpensive kinds of entertainment. It is not only that people are spending more time at home; it is also a change of mood and pace. No one seems very interested in formal entertainment, in dressing up, or even in planning anything very far ahead.

IF the American people do not come eventually to a complete understanding of the strange and perpetually intriguing part of the United States known as The South, it will not be for want of willing and eager students and interpreters, both from within and without.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ATLANTIC FLEET (undated) (U.P.) -- American fighting craft, escorting a major Allied convoy, wheeled into action twice within forty-eight hours, fighting off one possible submarine threat with a barrage of depth bombs.

As the war continues to eat up military man power the problem of pilots and other airmen making up war plane crews becomes an ever-increasing concern of the fighting nations. The quality of English pilots in military service can hardly be as good now as it was when the war started, and the same goes for Germany, Russia, Italy and Japan as well.

MR. ATKINSON'S notion that the past theatrical season has been barren because of the present world chaos is inadequate. That is a feeble alibi which playwriting does not need and could never permit itself to enjoy.

ONCE, and not so long ago, it was a sort of stepchild in the radio's complex family, as even the radio's more ardent admirers would have admitted -- and tacitly did. Now short-wave broadcasting is not only grown to full stature; it has become radio's most potent contributor toward victory and the ultimate settlement of a disordered world.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, speaking on "Citizen Responsibility for the Peace," will open a forum on "The Future World Order" at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow in the Hotel Plaza. The forum will close Tuesday night.

A new club for service men of the Allied armies and navies and men of the merchant marine is affording a midtown center of hospitality through the efforts of an organization of Canadian-American women. Called the Maple Leaf Snack Bar, it offers free refreshments daily from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M. in its rooms at 601 Fifth Avenue.

LONDON, May 9 -- The British Government is considering a plan for control of the coal mining industry that provides for a Coal Board on which would sit equal numbers of representatives of the government, the owners and the miners, David Rhys Grenfell, the Minister for Mines, said yesterday.

A tour of "Little Gardens in Old New York" will be conducted on the afternoons of May 20 and 21 by the Little Gardens Club of this city, to assist that organization's Garden Center and the Greenwich Village unit of the American Women's Voluntary Services. Several notable residences are included in the pilgrimage.

IN honor of the twentieth anniversary of the League of Composers, next season, a celebration will be held by symphony orchestras throughout the country, each of which will play one of the league's commissioned American works.

Senator Norris has one besetting sin, though it besets him only periodically. Every four or five years he is homesick; he longs to be done with Washington and go back to his old Ioway home. Not long ago he relapsed into this weakness. Now his good angel has fired his bad one out.

A suggestion that the American soldier today be equipped with some form of body armor has been made by Stephen V. Grancsay, curator of arms and armor at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. This idea has been advanced in connection with the announcement of the acquisition by the museum of several elements of a Renaissance brigandine, or armored jacket.

AMONG the newly opened exhibitions, two of drawings and prints should prove of special interest. In "Aspects of Modern Drawing," at the Buchholz Gallery, Curt Valentin has brought together nearly a hundred highly diverse examples of work in black-and-white by European and American painters and sculptors.

MOSCOW, May 9 (U.P.) -- The Red Army was reported tonight to be hacking methodically into German lines around Leningrad and, with the aid of guerrillas, maintaining strong offensive actions all along the front in local battles that had cost the enemy about 4,000 dead in forty-eight hours.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra recently had to cancel one of its out-of-town concerts because it found it could not get transportation back to its home city in time to fulfill a local engagement. That is a portent of things to come; orchestras are likely to find touring difficult.

All those who are concerned with the present and future of democratic France are naturally gratified to learn of the increased cordiality recently shown by the State Department in dealing with the Free French. At the same time it requires some forbearance not to be impatient in face of the doubts and reservations still expressed.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Because the Berkshire Hills of Western Massachusetts are less than 150 miles from Times Square, transportation problems do not figure largely in the season's prospects. At the office of the Berkshire Hills Conference in the court house, Pittsfield, it was said that inquiries from persons seeking a quiet vacation retreat in a small town exceed those of normal years.

Under stress of shortages, the easy-going habits of the American housewife are rapidly changing. Extra care of fine household furnishings is now given as a matter of course: wool rugs, for example, properly cleaned and mothproofed, are carefully put away for the Summer to escape the dust from open windows and the depredations of the moth when apartment or house is closed for vacation time.

Sales of leading mail-order and chain-store companies recorded an average increase of 11.7 per cent in April over the same month last year, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The increases were not general and several important classifications, including the mail-order companies, showed declines.

FORSYTHIA has been at its grandest this year. When Robert Fortune sent the first bush of it home to his Western World, more than a century ago, he did a fine thing for the human race. By now forsythia -- which Fortune named for William Forsyth, a British botanist and horticulturist -- has become so much a part of the American scene that it passes for an old-fashioned native plant.

THE American Opera Company has selected six young American singers for roles in the productions of its season starting Nov. 3 at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre. Four of these vocalists have not appeared before with the company.

Conversion of industry to war work has been greatly speeded since the middle of March, but there are still cases in which this process is delayed or thwarted by War Production Board officials, according to Robert R. Guthrie, whose resignation from the WPB in March brought charges of "business as usual" among some of the agency's officials.

Price Administrator Henderson dropped a remark at a recent press conference which went far beyond even the tremendous subject of price control. The price control orders, Mr. Henderson said, "are of such magnitude that even we who have been busy framing them for the last few weeks cannot fully visualize their ramifications."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 9 -- Republican leaders in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District, faced with the possibility that Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. may be successful in his fight to win renomination in the coming party primaries in August, have been holding a series of conferences in an attempt to unite the anti-Fish forces behind a single "united" candidate, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Politicians agree on only one thing in looking for trends in the 1942 primary elections held thus far in five States. That is, that the people are too preoccupied with the war to show the normal off-year interest in politics.

THESE three monographs are all recent additions to the growing shelf of works of this nature contributed by the Hyperion Press. In each instance the text is interesting, and the several approaches are quite dissimilar.

ADIRONDACK MOUNTAINS -- Judging by the large-scale rentals of Summer cottages and hotel reservations which have thus far been received, the Adirondack vacation scene, despite the gloomy outlook on travel, will not be shorn of its legion of vacationists this Summer.

The board of trustees, the governing committee and the Woman's Auxiliary of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden are in charge of the twenty-eighth annual tour of the Botanic Garden and several exhibits which will be shown in the Laboratory Building from 2:30 to 3:45 Tuesday.
BERNE, Switzerland, May 9 -- "Implacable violence" is to be the repression in Europe for those who refuse to accept Adolf Hitler's "New Order."

BILLINGS, Mont. -- It is out here where the open lands spread blanketlike and the Rocky Mountains wave snowy fingers at the sky one will find the dude-ranch country. These ranches are genuine ranches where genuine cowboys punch genuine cattle and the "dudes" are not of absolute necessity dandified dilettantes.

PARENTS have reason to know that children are ardently contemporary. They live right this minute. There's little use telling them that "some day" they'll be sorry that they didn't practice longer or study harder. Children know later they forget and have to learn over again that there is no future; there is only now.

HARRISBURG, Pa. -- Despite the war and its concomitant restrictions on travel, Pennsylvania is polishing up its door knobs, dusting off its vast collection of historical treasures, trimming and nurturing its colorful gardens and rich farmlands and preparing in many other ways to play host to thousands of Summer tourists and vacationists.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Public resentment against the proposed granting of power to the government to confiscate the automobiles of drivers who exceed a national speed limit appeared to have reached a stage today where this and other recently projected drastic measures for conservation of rubber were due for distinct modification before bringing them to Congressional test.

THE munificent radio business has not yet got to the point of giving a prize to just any one who turns a dial -- the listener is usually asked to send in a couple of box tops by way of proving his enthusiasm -- but with one commodity it is generous beyond a doubt.

The board of trustees of Washington and Lee University has recently established the Robert E. Lee Archives as a division of the new Cyrus Hall McCormick Library. It is proposed to make the school which Washington endowed and to which Lee gave the last five years of his life a national repository of source material concerning the entire life of Robert E. Lee.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col. -- The Pikes Peak region was born as a vacationland in the era of stagecoaches and wagon trains and the wartime tourist is assured of uninterrupted sight-seeing even if he alights from his train without even so much as a pair of roller-skates, a transportation survey discloses.

Something new in the way of a creative hobby are these cotton sculpture caricatures by an artist named Elsie Shaver. One day she needed some flowers for a vase but had none; fiddling around her studio it occurred to her to see what she could do with bits of cotton.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., May 9 -- In a mighty shipyard now devoted to the building of war vessels a rear admiral retorted yesterday to contentions that the battleship was "obsolete," and one of the nation's foremost shipbuilders asserted that American shipyards would win their part of the battle of production.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 9 -- Robert W. Collins's Sweet Willow, making her first start since the Florida season, captured the $5,000 added Blackstone Valley Handicap today before a closing day crowd of 26,000 at Narragansett Park.

GERRIE THIELENS'S second novel is a light but well-written story of an Anglo-American marriage that finds itself under the stress of the beginning of the war in England. As a story of a man and a woman it is excellent. The fact that she is American and he is English is incidental.

ALBANY, May 9 -- The reappointment to the Supreme Court bench in New York County of Lloyd Church was announced today by Governor Lehman. Justice Church, who resigned from the bench last Fall to run for controller on the Democratic ticket, succeeds Justice James O'Malley, whose retirement became effective on May 1.

Wholesale business slowed down and a great many orders were being held up, pending clarification of the terms of the price-freezing order, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

DETROIT -- Scrapping of 1942 model automobile dies to reclaim nickel alloy steel, as considered by the War Production Board's salvage section, would delay for perhaps nine months resumption of new-car production when peace comes, automotive experts declare.
Girls and men in uniform at an airdrome in England do not spend every moment actively in service. In this novel they find time to fall in and out of love and to live on gossip.

OTTAWA -- Canada is only a night trip by rail from New York and America's greatest center of population. But between the seething world of Broadway and the woods and lakes of Ontario and Quebec there is the difference between a battle and reposeful sleep.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 9 -- Miss Jean Larkin of Kingston, N.Y., a senior, was crowned "Victory Queen" this afternoon as the climax to the annual Mission Day program at the College of New Rochelle, largest Catholic girls' college in the country.

Proud of the fact that so many of its members have done deep water ocean cruising and navigating, the Coast Guard flotilla No. 602 has become one of the most energetic of the many metropolitan area units mow training for service in the war effort.

DEADWOOD, S.D. -- The Black Hills of South Dakota are aptly called "the Mountain Paradise of the Middle West," for there are cool waters, canyons and caves as well as pine-clad peaks, the chief of these crowned by Gutzon Borglum's "Shrine of Democracy" on Mount Rushmore.

The movement of coal by rail from Hampton Roads, Va., to the Port of New York and its transfer here to colliers and barges for shipment to New England has reached tremendous proportions in recent weeks. Nothing like it has been attempted before, but men in the coal trade say that this feat of transport is a splendid performance, both in road movement and terminal transfer.

Free French Africa under the administration of the de Gaulle forces has made more economic progress during the last year than "in one hundred previous years," said Andre Dulin in an interview at the Hotel New Weston last week.

IT is appropriate that the first comprehensive work in English on the Roman Imperial Navy should appear at a time when the Mediterranean is again a key to the mastery of the world. Particularly suggestive for our own future policy is the seeming paradox that during its entire existence, from Augustus to Constantine, the Imperial Navy fought no major engagement.

IN this book Mr. Wertenbaker, whose long service at Princeton has left un-faded a background that belongs to the University of Virginia, traces to their beginnings the influences which created the pattern of civilization in our Southern States. It is a pattern definitely regional.

THAT Mr. Lania has long admired and is thoroughly at home in the American school of journalism is once again evident in his published "personal history." The quantity of experience of this brilliant journalist, novelist, playwright and motion-picture producer is impressive.

SO you think the dance season is over. Well, the ballet companies seem to have departed, at least until the Stadium gets under way, and most of the recitalists have gone into whatever the Summer equivalent of hibernation is called.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has made a pre-campaign gift of $200,000 to the Greater New York-USO Joint War Fund, which is to open officially tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by Henry C. Brunie, campaign chairman for the United Service Organizations.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 9 -- Twice in a row have world wars interfered with anniversary ceremonies and projected festivities at the University of Illinois. The university was opened to students March 2, 1868, hence was fifty years old during World War I. All thought of any commemoration of the event was canceled by trustees.

Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh asked yesterday for the immediate enlistment of at least 40,000 more men, between the ages of 18 and 55, to serve as auxiliary firemen in the five boroughs. His appeal, made through the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office at City Hall, was coupled with the warning that "it will be too late to start training when the fire bombs fall."

SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 -- On arid wastes in the shadow of the Sierra Nevadas, where sagebrush flourished seven weeks ago, water flowed today through newly dug irrigation ditches as Japanese evacuees from the Pacific coastal regions began planting crops to help feed the rapidly mounting population of the Owens Valley reception center.

Planning the Summer vacation trip, ordinarily an extremely pleasant chore, will this year bring plenty of problems to those looking forward to the usual two-weeks-with-pay. The war effort has brought new complications to the annual questions: Where shall we go? and, How shall we get there?
The Union for Democratic Action, under the leadership of Dr. Frank Kingdon, announced plans yesterday for a national political drive to oust "obstructionists" from Congress.

LONDON, May 9 (Canadian Press) -- Wales conquered England by 1-0 in a hard-fought international soccer match at Cardiff before a crowd of 35,000, avenging a defeat last Fall. The game brought the international season to a finish.

ARCHITECTURALLY Harriet Ball's novel presents a compact and interesting scheme. It shows a three-generation American family under a double set of strains and stresses during the week-end when England and France declared war on Germany in 1939. The Victor family shared the general nervous tension that swept the entire country.

A total of 116 visiting professors from forty-eight colleges and sixteen officials of governmental and private agencies will conduct courses in the expanded wartime curriculum of Columbia University's Summer session, Dr. Harry Morgan Ayres, the director, announced yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, May 9 -- After five years of struggle in the face of the most difficult war conditions, with ever tightening blockades cutting off imports, machinery and necessary war materials, China has succeeded in building up a major industry in the hinterland that makes her self-sufficient in everything necessary for the war with the possible exception of high-grade steel.

RADIO being a young industry barely 21 years old, it's not surprising that Ed Byron, who has spent fifteen of his thirty-six years in it, knows the business inside out. Mr. Byron has been announcer, sound-effects man, engineer, actor, writer, director and producer.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 9 -- Yale today won its varsity track meet with Princeton, 82 1-3 to 52 2-3, and the freshman competition by 101 to 34. The meet was the thirty-ninth in the Eli-Tiger series.

A luncheon in behalf of Junior Programs, Inc., a non-profit organization which produces musical plays for children from coast to coast, will be held on May 20 in the Roof Garden of the Pierre. Miss Katherine Cornell will be the guest of honor.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 3 -- Production of petroleum in Venezuela in 1941 exceeded that of any previous year in the country's history, soaring to more than thirty-three million metric tons and placing the country second among the world's oil-producing nations, it is revealed in the annual report of the Ministry of Development.

The Reich propaganda machine in Norway, which has directed much of its efforts since the invasion toward the "free" Norwegian merchant marine, recently broadcast a list of "further" losses of Norwegian merchant vessels, mentioning twenty-nine ships but giving no dates for the reported sinkings.

War production industries are beginning to consume materials so rapidly that it will be impossible to convert all of the country's plants to war work, and those which do not immediately get into some kind of essential output will soon find it impossible to do so, George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, said yesterday.

RIO DE JA1NEIR0, Brazil, May 9 -- The Brazilian-American rubber agreement, by which Brazil agrees to sell and the United States to purchase all surplus rubber after domestic needs are filled, has been widely applauded here. The press urges Brazilians engaged in the rubber industry to work harder than ever to help the United States win the war.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Bituminous coal must be moved over railroads into New England at a weekly rate of 310,000 tons for the remaining thirty-four weeks of this year to maintain the "off-peak" tonnage spread and help to forestall any possibility of a shortage of fuel in the Noreseastern States, Joseph B. Eastman, Director of Defense Transportation, said here today.

A premiere showing of the new film, "Ships With Wings," will be given at the Normandie Theatre on the night of May 19 under the sponsorship of members of the English-Speaking Union and the Union Jack Club of the British War Relief Society.

Inspired by the fact that this is the season when hundreds of persons telephone to the Bronx Zoo and inquire what should be done about "a poor little baby bird that's just fallen out of its nest," Lee S. Crandall, curator of birds at the Zoo, made yesterday some helpful suggestions on the care and feeding of the unfortunates.

In many clubs where bridge is played the members wish to play for a short period, usually one hour, after luncheon or in the afternoon, when they leave their offices. This gives them time for only two rubbers, and if the first rubber drags out they can hardly finish the second.

His appeal, made through the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office at City Hall, was coupled with the warning that "it will be too late to start training when the fire bombs fall."

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Although reports from General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters indicated that merely the first phase of the great naval engagement might have been completed, officials of the United States armed forces here did not attempt to conceal their satisfaction again today relative to the outcome of the action.

LONDON, May 9 (Canadian Press) -- Wales conquered England by 1-0 in a hard-fought international soccer match at Cardiff before a crowd of 35,000, avenging a defeat last Fall. The game brought the international season to a finish.

The Victor family shared the general nervous tension that swept the entire country.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Although reports from General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters indicated that merely the first phase of the great naval engagement might have been completed, officials of the United States armed forces here did not attempt to conceal their satisfaction again today relative to the outcome of the action.
The Navy "E" award for production achievement was presented to the Staten Island yard of the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipbuilding division at Mariners Harbor in ceremonies yesterday afternoon.

NOT so many years ago propaganda plays were regarded with suspicion and contempt as perversions of truth and travesties on art. Do you remember the time when special pleading in a play was looked upon as sinister tomfoolery? Now the shoe is on the other foot, where the fit, incidentally, is no better.
Your recent editorial, "The Need for Patent Reform," suggests some comments from my experience as an engineer, for more than reform is needed.

TOKYO, May 9 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Domei broadcast said today that Myitkyina, northern terminus of the railroad from Mandalay, was occupied yesterday "without bloodshed" by a Japanese column pushing northward in Burma.

ALTHOUGH sugar and spice are increasingly hard to come by, American meals need not sink into the doldrums for the duration. Herbs, which most of us overlooked in more bountiful days, still abound to make dinnertime interesting.

Car owners today express doubt about taking Spring or Summer vacations on the road. Conditions are acute in the gasoline-rationed East, where drivers seek advice before making plans. The problem has no cut-and-dried answer, for the government, controlling automobile destinies, has avoided dictates on vacation driving.

WASHINGTON. May 9 -- Three gallons of gasoline a week was formally established today as the maximum to be allowed by the Office of Price-Administration after May 15 to motorists along the Eastern seaboard engaged in nonessential driving.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., May 9 -- A concert by the Random Choristers, a group of singers from Mount Kisco, Bedford and Katonah, will be given here on the night of May 22 at Penwood, the country place of Mr. and Mrs. Carll Tucker, for the benefit of the Boys Club of Mount Kisco and the Westchester County Children's Association.

IT used to be that the connotations of life in Philadelphia centered, for outlanders, about Rittenhouse Square and a strange, stern dictum that "nobody" lived North of Market Street; but that time had well gone by before Kitty Foyle came out of Frankford (even though Mr. Morley could not resist naming most of his other actors for the city's more aristocratic suburbs).

TORONTO, Ont., May 9 -- Denying that there was any shortage of woodpulp in its territory, G.T. Clarkson, receiver and manager of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, today attributed the reduced output of his company's mills to lack of demand for newsprint.

WHEN a book has had a sale of 100,000,000 copies, and when that sale has stretched over a period of nearly a century and a quarter, it is obvious that it has a claim to attention irrespective of its merits and that it must rank as one of the great best sellers of all time.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., May 9. -- America's call for thousands of nurses for military and civilian services will be answered in Pittsburgh as a result of a grant of $20,000 by the A.W. Mellon Educational and Charitable Trust to the University of Pittsburgh School of Nursing.

The labor press can play a vital part in helping the United States reach the goal of non-stop production, William H. Davis, chairman of the National War Labor Board, told a dinner conference of labor editors last night at the Men's Faculty Club, Columbia University, 400 West 117th Street.

With a month of pressing tasks just finished, gardeners turn with pleasure to plants which did not require action during the thick of this recent fray, but can be safely set out only after the soil is really warm and all danger of frost past. Such are the tender bulbs of Summer time; the canna, dahlia and gladiolus of long familiarity, and the Cape hyacinth, montbretia, Peruvian Daffodil, Fairy-lily and many other almost unknowns.

Belmont Park, on Long Island, will draw a large throng of members of society tomorrow for the opening of a four-week Spring racing season to be held under the auspices of the Westchester Racing Association. Several innovations are noted in plans for this meeting, during which the war effort will be aided by a war fund drive, a series of benefit luncheons and fashion shows and various between-race features.

Men and women who have played a historic part in American life are subjects of fifty paintings and sculptures by early and contemporary American masters, which will be shown in a benefit "Parade of Patriots" loan exhibition on May 25 at the Gotham branch of the Grand Central Art Galleries, 2 West Fifty-fifth Street.

The announced method for rationing gasoline to private cars in the East is virtually an "honor system" to be upheld by every driver voluntarily. Starting May 15, it cannot prevent collusive dishonesty between a driver seeking fuel to which he is not entitled and a service station operator willing to cheat for the sake of a friend, a steady customer or a bribe.
Tributes to the mothers of America for their heroism and spirit of sacrifice in this war were paid by rabbis here in sermons yesterday, preceding Mother's Day.

BETHLEHEM, Pa. -- On May 16 visitors will stream into this city, home of a famous steel company. They come not to look upon the fiery clang and bang of molten steel being prepared for war but for spiritual refreshment through music -- the music of Johann Sebastian Bach, as presented each year by the Bach Choir.

The public is becoming conscious of a comparative newcomer in the Civilian Defense set-up. She is the volunteer nurses' aide. Ten thousand of these volunteer hospital workers are needed in New York City alone; the national quota is 100,000.

In the heaving Pacific waters off Australia's northeastern reefs air-and-sea fleets of Japan and the United Nations locked last week in a mighty encounter. The battle, hailed as the greatest of its kind since Jutland, harbored decisive implications for the future course of the Far Eastern War.

RICHMOND, Va., May 9 -- A pinch of ordinary starch may speed the recovery of aluminum from its ores and increase the efficiency of the recovery process, according to a patent (No. 2,280,998) granted to Ralph W. Brown of East St. Louis, Ill., and assigned to the Aluminum Company of America, Pittsburgh, Pa.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Justice and equality for women, with world recognition of their right and responsibility to participate equally with men in national and international councils, was demanded by the representatives of ten nations, who met here today for the first council meeting in this country of the World Woman's Party.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 9 -- One weapon the Church in Germany is reported to be using liberally to resist the "veritable war against Christianity" cited in Michael Cardinal yon Faulhaber's report to the Holy See, outlined in these dispatches yesterday, is a list of ten commandments distributed to the faithful in churches throughout the Reich.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 9 (U.P.) -- Dispatches from Berlin tonight hinted strongly that Germany expected new and drastic pro-Axis moves by Pierre Laval's collaborationist Vichy government within the next few days.

United States oil companies whose properties in Mexico were seized more than four years ago do not consider the agreement reached recently by the experts appointed by the United States and Mexican Governments as a clear-cut settlement, largely because they still must defend themselves against both private and government claims brought in Mexican courts.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 9 -- The Times Printing Company, publishers of The Chattanooga Daily, Evening and Sunday Times, and the Chattanooga News-Free Press Company, publishers of The Chattanooga News-Free Press, afternoon and Sunday editions, announced here tonight that an agreement had been closed to form a new agency company for the joint distribution of the newspapers and the direction of advertising and circulation.

ESTES PARK, Col. -- Manhattanites who make their way this Summer to the high country of the West by train and plane instead of automobile will enjoy new experiences, including, it may be, a lot more fun than they anticipate. This, at least, is the prediction of old-timers native to these parts.

PERHAPS children might get silly notions of seeing dream ladies, Louise Soubirous tried to reason, just because they never had quite enough to eat. Or perhaps the sight of something that didn't exist might be an illusion of any 14-year-old.

TORONTO -- With highway officials promising the opening about the middle of July -- depending on what the weather man does in the next few weeks -- Ontario's last link of the great Transcanada Highway now nears completion, and foretells the day when motorists can drive from the eastern coast of Canada more than 4,161 miles to the west coast on one great highway.

The women's national lacrosse championship, originally scheduled for May 22 to 24 at the Merion Cricket Club, Philadelphia, has been advanced to the coming weekend at the same place. The change is due to the gas rationing that will apply after May 15, since many of the contestants must travel thousands of miles to compete.

MONTREAL, May 9 (AP) -- Unlimbering some of their proverbial power, the Bears collected a dozen hits to ride over the Royals, 12 -- 3, today. The victory gave the Bears an even break in the two-game series and restored their margin of leadership in the International League to three games over Montreal, the runner-up.

The Navy is intensifying its search for "Seabees," men who are skilled in mechanics, electricity, carpentry, drilling, diving and other construction trades, to go to overseas naval bases to build vital facilities for the fleet's ships and personnel and, if necessary, to interrupt their construction activities long enough to fight off any enemy attack that may be leveled against the site, it was announced here yesterday.

The Navy is intensifying its search for "Seabees," men who are skilled in mechanics, electricity, carpentry, drilling, diving and other construction trades, to go to overseas naval bases to build vital facilities for the fleet's ships and personnel and, if necessary, to interrupt their construction activities long enough to fight off any enemy attack that may be leveled against the site, it was announced here yesterday.

TOKYO, May 9 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Imperial headquarters announced today that a "small-sized Japanese aircraft carrier converted from a tanker" had been sunk in the Coral Sea naval battle and acknowledged the loss of thirty-one planes.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. -- The spirit of the Spanish Southwest, which survives so authentically in New Mexico, asserts itself with a typical combination of religious solemnity and all-out hilarity during the annual Fiesta of San Felipe de Neri in old Albuquerque from May 26 to June 1.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- President Roosevelt today called on the American people to honor not only the Stars and Stripes but also flags of all the twenty-six United Nations in proclaiming June 14 as Flag Day. He asked, too, that the American people pay special tribute to "the nation's mothers and their valiant sons in the service" by displaying flags.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and twenty-four wives of heads of government departments and agencies today made recommendations for improvement of housing for women government workers in Washington, charging that the present situation is extremely bad because of profiteering, lack of sanitation and overcrowding.

WITH an optimism that tends to refute reports that Hollywood expects to have to curtail its annual output of pictures because of material shortages, Twentieth Century-Fox the other day revealed that it contemplates making fifty-two feature films next season.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on May 2 totaled 259,145,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, United States Department of the Interior. This represented an increase of 2,072,000 barrels in the week, comprising increases of 2,003,000 and 69,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.

THE literature on librarianship in this country abounds in excellent technical and scientific treatises which mean much to the specialist but little to the general public. If the educated layman wants to get an answer to the question, What is the place of the American library in the world of today? he will find few books to his liking.

THE literature on librarianship in this country abounds in excellent technical and scientific treatises which mean much to the specialist but little to the general public. If the educated layman wants to get an answer to the question, What is the place of the American library in the world of today? he will find few books to his liking.

THOSE who accept the principle that in realistic fiction everything under the sun is subject for the novelist -- as also for the painter, photographer and poet -- need have no hesitation in accepting this first novel by a short-story writer and poet whose name is not unfamiliar.

BABYLON, L.I., May 10 -- A Labrador retriever by the name of Marvadel Cinders was the winner tonight of the open all-age stake of the Spring field trial meeting of the Women's Field Trial Club held on the Wagstaff estate.

LONDON, May 10 -- On the site of a bombed Dutch church in London today members of the exiled Netherland Government commemorated the second anniversary of the invasion of their country. Those who lost their lives and those who "live under the heel of the oppressor" were equally remembered.

War is fought on the basis of a twenty-four-hour day, of course, and a good many civilians have been discovering that life at home has to change accordingly. An Associated Press dispatch from Albany tells of what has happened to the Patrie family.
ST. LOUIS, May 10 (AP) -- Joey Kuhel's seventh-inning home run with one aboard gave the White Sox a 9-to-7 nightcap victory over the Browns today after St. Louis took the opener, 5 to 2.

A dramatic reverse in the three-month Battle of Burma seems suddenly to have imperiled the sweeping Japanese victory in the entire northern area. The enemy spearhead thrust into China has been broken, according to Chungking, and the Japanese are now in flight down the Burma Road, with their retreat cut off by a "lost" Chinese Army which has not only retaken Maymyo but is already in the outskirts of Mandalay and astride the Mandalay-Lashio railway.

LONDON, Monday, May 11 (U.P.) -- Military experts predicted today that if Adolf Hitler decided to use poison gas against Russia this would lead to indiscriminate chemical warfare throughout the world, making all countries, including the United States, liable to gas attack.

Wartime restrictions are holding up public housing projects, construction of a produce terminal market and channel improvements in the port area, the Regional Plan Association declared in a report made public yesterday.

LONDON, May 10 -- One year to the day since the last heavy raid battered London, more than 1,000 men and women, enrolled in the national fire service organized since that attack, staged today an impressive demonstration of their new technique in fighting flames.
ROME, May 10 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

CINCINNATI, May 10 (AP) -- The Reds today blanked the Cardinals in both games of the season's first double-header at Crosley Field, 1 -- 0 and 3 -- 0, before a crowd of 20,232 -- biggest since opening day.

Two hundred war plants throughout Brooklyn, Queens and lower Manhattan will circularize their employes next week to inform them of their opportunity to obtain modern low-rent apartments in Fort Greene Houses, the 3,500-apartment State-aided public housing development being built adjacent to Fort Greene Park in downtown Brooklyn by the New York City Housing Authority.

NEWARK, N.J., May 10 -- A non-profit organization describing itself as a "service for sociability" backed by Essex County civic leaders, clergymen and educators will open quarters tomorrow in the Raymond Commerce Building here.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 10 -- Rutgers University conferred 343 bachelor degrees, fifty-one advanced degrees and ten honorary degrees at the 176th anniversary exercises of the university in the Rutgers Gymnasium here this afternoon.

DETROIT, May 10 -- The Ford Motor Company demanded today freezing of wages of all Ford workers for the duration of the war. The demand was in reply to the 13-point program, including a flat $1 a day increase, proposed by the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., preliminary to negotiations for renewal of the contract which expires June 20.
