LONDON, May 10 (U.P.) -- Formations of Royal Air Force fighters and bombers, extending fifteen miles in width across the sky, sped over the Channel and pounded and seared German objectives inland from the Boulogne area of the French coast this afternoon in one of the war's heaviest daylight raids.
CHICAGO, May 10 -- Trading in lard futures on the Board of Trade continues relatively slow, with a considerable part of the business in the way of changing over from May to July.

VICHY, France, May 10 -- While the situation in Madagascar remained uncertain new empire problems were raised for France today by the United States propositions concerning Martinique and Guadeloupe. The communique issued here tonight threw no light on the nature of the United States proposals.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., May 10 -- Horton Smith and Jimmy Thomson of Chicopee Falls, Mass., defeated Clarence Doser of the host club and Craig Wood of Winged Foot, 4 and 2, in a best-ball exhibition match at the Scarsdale Golf Club for the benefit of the American Red Cross War Fund today.

A warning that our victory in the present world conflict must be spiritual as well as material was voiced yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine by Bishop Robert E. Campbell, retired Bishop of Liberia, who preached at the 11 o'clock communion service.

VICHY, France, May 10 (U.P.) -- Official reports from Madagascar today said the Diego Suarez naval base fell last week after two British tank columns had battered through three lines of permanent fortifications built by Marshal Joffre in 1900 when he did a tour of duty there.

Increasing its production schedule by four films over the current season, Republic Pictures will produce sixty-six feature-length pictures and four serials during the 1942-43 season, according to an announcement yesterday from James R. Grainger, the president.

The recently announced plans of Park Commissioner Robert Moses for reconstruction of Battery Park are "inadequate as to both architectural and landscape treatment," James C. Mackenzie, president of the Fine Arts Federation of New York, declared yesterday.

"Arsenic and Old Lace," that strangely genteel tale of murder in a Brooklyn mansion, was silently acted on the stage of the Fulton Theatre last night to a duly appreciative audience. Actors from the dramatic club of Gallaudet College of Washington, D.C., the only college for the deaf in the United States, presented the arsenous comedy in sign language, the first such presentation of a play in the history of Broadway.

HAVANA, May 10 -- It is imperative that the United States advise Cuba of the exact requirements of sugar for the American market for 1943, Gaston Godoy, president of the National Sugar Institute, said in a statement to Cuba's sugar producers which was made public today.

In keeping with the accelerated program of study, Manhattan College held combined Class Day and baccalaureate services yesterday on the campus. Nine hundred friends and relatives of the graduating class attended. The baccalaureate address was by Mgr. Thomas J. Doyle, rector of St. Margaret's Church, Riverdale.

MOSCOW, May 10 -- The determination of Soviet women to fulfill Premier Joseph Stalin's May Day order designating 1942 as the year of German defeat was expressed this evening at a meeting in Moscow's Hall of Columns of the Anti-Fascist Committee of Soviet Women.

Total war first appeared in peaceable people's minds as total horror. It is that. We begin to see, however, that the old laws still operate. New kinds of attack produce new methods of defense. Attack on civilians produces civilian defense, which in Britain has become a distinct division of the art or science of war, and may become so here.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- An active shipping demand for cash oats and a somewhat unfavorable outlook for the new crop brought about higher prices for that grain last week. Choice quality cash oats were wanted at a premium of 1 to 2 cents a bushel over the May, with the trade looking for a liberal reduction to be shown in the visible supply before the end of the month.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Gaston Henry-Haye, the French Ambassador, is expected to take up with the State Department early this week his government's views, on instruction of Pierre Laval, of the agreement that the United States is seeking to reach with Admiral Georges Robert, French High Commissioner in Martinique, concerning a new status for that island, Guadeloupe and French Guiana.

CINCINNATI, May 10 (AP) -- William Mihalo, Detroit defense worker, won the National A.A.U. 50,000-meter walking championship today, recording the third fastest time in the history of the event -- 5 hours 6 minutes 45 seconds.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 10 -- Five hundred relatives and friends of the students of Marymount College saw Miss Muriel Regina Fullen, daughter of Transit Commissioner and Mrs. William G. Fullen of New York City, crowned queen of the May by Miss Betty Connor, New Haven, Conn., president of the senior class, this afternoon.

TOKYO, May 10 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Nichi Nichi's correspondent today gave the following "eye-witness account" of the surrender of United States Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright at Corregidor:

The Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, announced yesterday the formation, in cooperation with leading American museums, of the American Art Research Council. The new council will be an agency for research in American art, with particular relation to problems of authenticity.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 10 (U.P.) -- Meet records in four events fell today in the eighth annual Cotton Carnival track and field games. Cornelius Warmerdam, California's pole-vaulting star, thrilled a crowd of 3,000 with a vault of 15 feet 1 1/2 inches -- the first 15-foot leap ever made in the South.

LONDON, Monday, May 11 -- The British Air Ministry in a report issued today added up the score of R.A.F. raids over Germany in the last two months, as illustrated in photographs taken by reconnaissance planes. These showed extensive damage done military targets in Kiel, Cologne and the Ruhr.
Following is the test of Prime Minister Wilton Churchill's broadcast from England yesterday as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Exactly nine years ago -- on the morning of May 11, 1933 -- Americans read in their newspapers of the ceremonious burning by the Nazis, in most of the German university towns, of the books of numerous authors. Of these authors there are at least three who live here in Los Angeles -- Erich Maria Remarque, the poet Bertolt Brecht, of whom Archibald MacLeish, for example, spoke with the highest praise, and myself.
Sales by savings banks of several repossessed properties in Manhattan were announced over the week-end. Most of the parcels were acquired by investors.

ALBANY, May 10 -- Governor Lehman signed today the three Olliffe bills designed to prevent the otherwise mandatory discharge of teachers from the New York City school system whose positions are being abolished because of the decline in school population.

In happier days Spring in Paris was the season of beauty and joy, of unfolding blossoms and gay flower marts. This year it is marked by the arrival of Reinhard Heydrich, "Der Henker," and the dark unfolding of crepe in memory of murdered hostages.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The War Department communique said:

CLEVELAND, May 10 (AP) -- The Indians absorbed their sixth straight defeat today as the Tigers took the first game of a double- header, 5 to 1, on the five-hit hurling of Tommy Bridges, but the Tribe rallied late to take the teninning nightcap, 6 to 5, and gain undisputed possession of second place.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 10 -- Placing in all four of the division's full-course classes, the gray gelding Our Blue Moon, owned by Lieutenant and Mrs. John W. Morris of Staten Island, capped his 1942 competitive debut today by capturing the jumper championship at the twelfth annual Harrison Charity Horse Show.
LONDON, May 10 -- Lieut. Gen. Sir William Dobbie, accompanied by his wife and his daughter, Sybil, arrived in London today by air. They had come by way of Gibraltar.
LONDON, May 10 (AP) -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, French Chief of State, appealed today to the French people to apply the example set by Joan of Arc in overcoming their present difficulties.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 10 -- Brian Ahern has been named by Columbia to play Robert Baker, the leading male character in "My Sister Eileen," which will go before the cameras this week with Alexander Hall directing. Rosalind Russell has already been announced for the role of Ruth Sherwood, and Miss Jeff Donnell, a recruit from the Summer theatres, has been engaged to play in the film.
The flag of the Netherlands at half staff in Rockefeller Plaza, began inching upward late yesterday afternoon while a band played the Wilhelmus and a silent crowd of 800 persons watched.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The American people were warned today by Donald M. Nelson that rationing of coal might be necessary unless consumers put in reserve supplies "at once to the limit of storage capacity."

ST. LOUIS, May 10 (AP) -- A monthly bonus of 10 per cent, ranging from $15 to $40, will be awarded to all employes in the production departments of the Century Electrical Company who report for work on time each working day.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The British have started a war of nerves against the German people designed to produce a revolt against Reichsfuehrer Hitler and the Nazi regime. This is Washington's unofficial interpretation of today's speech by Prime Min ister Churchill, which is being hailed here as the start of an intensive political warfare campaign against the Axis.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- Weather conditions were generally favorable for the new crops last week, and corn planting is becoming fairly general in the more southern sections of the main producing area. and will get well under way in the more northern areas this week if weather conditions are favorable.

The graceful new span of simple lines across the Niagara River at Niagara Falls has won the award as the most beautiful steel bridge of monumental size erected in this country in 1941, in the annual competition of the American Institute of Steel Construction.

OTTAWA, May 10 -- Reports are current today and not denied that the amendment of the mobilization act, which will be available for introduction in Parliament tomorrow, may cause at least one resignation from the Cabinet.

Marian Anderson, Negro contralto, brought her activities of the 1941-42 music season to a close last night with her third and final New York recital at Carnegie Hall. Like most of her appearances here, it attracted a capacity audience that remained applauding her long after the house lights had been turned up.

Mrs. William N. Berry of Greensboro, N.C., made her "inaugural" address to the nation yesterday as "the American mother for 1942." She was heard on the Golden Rule Foundation's annual Mother's Day program, broadcast from 12:15 to 12:30 P.M. over WABC.

Dean Dixon, 27-year-old Negro conductor, led the New York Chamber Orchestra, composed oil thirty white players, in a concert last night at Town Hall, at which he presented four young American artists as soloists. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who was the guest of honor, made a brief address stressing the importance of music in the present international crisis.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The National Selective Service headquarters will advise State and local boards tomorrow that ship construction and coastal, inter-coastal and off-shore water transportation are vital to this nation's war program, and the boards will be instructed, accordingly, to give careful consideration to deferment from military service of individual registrants engaged in these activities.

With Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presiding in the sanctuary, the Rev. William J.B. Daly, pastor of Sacred Heart Church, Dobbs Ferry, celebrated yesterday the first public solemn mass at the new marble high altar in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The United States must lead the way in establishing after this war a new world order based on "God's Ten Commandments" and use force, if necessary, to compel other nations to follow her example, Mgr. Francis W. Walsh, vicar delegate to the armed forces, declared yesterday at the annual communion breakfast of the Holy Name Society of the Department of Sanitation in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond at the Hotel Astor.

The American Bible Society in 1941 distributed 8,096,977 volumes of Scripture, the largest total of any year since 1931, according to the 126th annual report of its board of managers, made public yesterday.

BOSTON, May 10 (AP) -- Ernie Koy's three-run homer in the fifth inning of the nightcap gave the Phils a 4-3 decision and a split in today's double-header with the Braves. Al Javery's four-hit hurling won the opener for Boston, 5 -- 1.

We have been accustomed to read much in the newspapers lately about the curtailment, attributable to the war, of public and private services of all kinds. The Regional Plan Association, in its new progress report on transportation and public projects of the past four years, finds that under the pressure of urgent military requirements the airport system of the New York Region is being built up now on a scale "which dwarfs earlier accomplishments."

Following his recent purchase of the Garden Apartments, a large development in the block bounded by Broadway, Avenue E, and East Eleventh and Twelfth Streets, in Bayonne, N.J., from the Rockefeller estate and other industrial interests in the area, John Avrutis has bought from the same sellers thirty-nine lots on two blocks adjacent to the housing project.

The danger that wartime mass emotion may "submerge whatever is distinctively Christian in us" was emphasized in a sermon yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in the Riverside Church, at 122d Street.

G.P. Putnam's has acquired the rights to a long list of the works of Theodore Dreiser, and it is learned in connection with this transfer that a new novel, called "The Bulwark," is expected for the Fall of this year. Simon Schuster had held the rights in recent years to many Dreiser titles, having got them from Liveright.

For the first time in many weeks the stock market was governed last week by war news, and the news was of varied character. On Wednesday, when the surrender of Corregidor was announced and with it the downfall of American power in the Philippines, stocks were distinctly weak.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Brookings Institution will publish tomorrow a study by Dr. Arthur C. Millspaugh entitled "Democracy, Efficiency and Stability," in which the prospects for democracy in the United States are appraised in the light of evolution and experience, with particular reference to recent political, social and economic trends.

In an all-cash transaction, the six-story apartment building at the northwest corner of Southern Boulevard and Leggett Avenue, in the Bronx, was sold by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, as liquidator of the Lawyers Title Company.

LONDON, May 10 -- Japanese units were deliberately allowed to extend themselves in the invasion of Yunnan, according to the Chungking communique received here today that announced rout of the foe along the Burma Road.

MOSCOW, May 10 -- With desperate guerrilla fighting continuing on a bigger scale than at any other time since the war began, the Red Army's main operations still appear to be confined to sectors on the right wing and in the center.

Asserting that it has gone about "its war job in the conviction that action and not talk is what is needed," the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey says in the current issue of its house magazine, The Lamp, that it is spending $60,000,000 to expand the production of 100-octane fuel.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 10 (AP) -- Rochester and Jersey City divided a double-header today, the visitors winning the first, 3 -- 2, with the Red Wings taking the nightcap, 7 -- 2.

Rumbling along well enough on their own power at such times when their distinguished adversaries from upper New York weren't making matters easier with another odd assortment of glaring blunders, the Dodgers regaled a gathering of 26,020 at Ebbets Field yesterday by flattening the Giants once again, 5 to 3.
The strain imposed on the family by the war, and particularly the cross that mothers are now called upon to bear, were the themes of a number of Mother's Day sermons yesterday throughout the city.

Dollar sales volume of $151,808,858 for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 was the highest in the history of the Allied Stores Corporation, and was 25.2 per cent greater than in the preceding year, when sales were $121,270,682. The number of items of merchandise sold, based on the number of sales transactions -- 78,500,000 -- was also the highest in the company's history.

The American Women's Voluntary Services staged a Mother's Day rally yesterday afternoon that held the attention of 3,000 persons for two hours. Arranged as a tribute to mothers of the 4,000 lower East Side men who are in the armed forces, the event had for its setting a large temporary platform on Straus Square, East Broadway and Rutgers Street.

ALBANY, May 10 -- The volunteer community service for non-citizens was started here today by a group of public-minded citizens to provide an organized program of education, information and aid to the foreign-born citizens and aliens.

Today the USO opens a campaign to raise at least $32,000,000 in the United States, at least $4,500,000 in Greater New York, to provide recreation, entertainment and comforts for the men in the armed services. The need is several times what it was last year, because more men are in service.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices dropped from 106.5 to 106.3. Although this was only a 0.2 per cent change, in sub-groups there were appreciable rises and declines which canceled each other. The major raw materials index dropped 0.6 per cent, reflecting price declines in livestock, shearling, fruit and eggs, which outweighed rises in grain, cotton, lamb and potato prices.

TRENTON, N.J., May 10 -- Champion Che Le of Matson's Catawba, imported Pekingese owned by Mrs. James M. Austin of Westbury, L.I., and shown by Ruth Sayres, was named for the chief prize at the annual Trenton Kennel Club fixture today.

CHUNGKING, China, May 10 -- A communique tonight reported that 3,000 Japanese troops of a mechanized column pushing up the Burma Road were annihilated by Chinese artillerymen in the vicinity of Chefang, twenty-five miles inside Yunnan Province, last night.

"When destructive forces are operating on a scale never before known, I rejoice to discover humanity is aflame with an ineradicable impulse to make things better," the Rev. Dr. John Howland Lathrop pastor of the Unitarian Church of the Saviour, Brooklyn, said in a sermon yesterday in the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

The Yiddish Culture Chorus, under Vladimir Heifetz, gave a concert yesterday afternoon at Town Hall with Moshe Rudinov, baritone, and Arnold Eidus, violin, as assisting artists. With the exception of the prefatory national anthem all of the choral offerings were sung in Yiddish, including the featured cantata, "I Hear America Singing,'' by Kleinsinger, based on Poems of Walt Whitman.

Thirty thousand members of the Knights of Pythias in the metropolitan area are expected to attend the dedication exercises of the new Pythian Camp in Sullivan County on Decoration Day, it was announced yesterday by David M. Engelson, secretary, at his headquarters in 415 Lexington Avenue.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 10 -- The notable reception given President Prado of Peru in the United States and the possible consequences of his visit for South America in general and Peru in particular continue to draw attention from Chileans of all circles.

LONDON, May 10 -- The stock markets here closed last week without having a full report of the result of the battle of the United Nations' fleet in the Pacific with the Japanese, hut was sufficiently known to create an undercurrent of cheerfulness such as they had not experienced in many a long day.

The article in Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES by James C. Hagerty on my candidacy for re-election to Congress, although otherwise eminently fair, repeats an absolute falsehood circulated by an independent committee opposed to me that I was a friend and associate of Frederick Auhagen, registered Nazi agent now in jail.

With twelve named for the Toboggan Handicap, the Spring meeting of the Westchester Racing Association will begin at Belmont Park today with George D. Widener as president and with bright prospects, despite wartime conditions.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Legislation to force the people of the nation to buy war stamps and bonds and to freeze wages, profits and parity farm prices will be introduced in the House tomorrow by Representative Gore of Tennessee.

NEW ORLEANS, May 10 -- Looking beyond its immediate war service and the day-by-day activities of its program, the National Conference of Social Work, through its president, Shelby M. Harrison, pictured tonight its part in "the world the democracies are striving to bring into being."

In a drive to continue and expand service to the armed forces at a pace equal to the nation's war moves, the United Service Organizations, Inc., will open today a $32,000,000 War Fund campaign. The USO plans to have 900 clubhouses and smaller units in operation by the end of the year.

The war added a somber note to the annual observance of Mother's Day yesterday as the metropolitan area paid honor to the mothers of the men in the armed services and especially to the Gold Star mothers whose sons will not return from the battlefields.
PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (AP) -- With Bob Johnson accounting for two home runs and driving in five runs, the Athletics turned back the Red Sox today, 4 -- 2 and 6 -- 5.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 10 (AP) -- Syracuse split a double-header with league-leading Newark today, winning the nightcap, 6 to 4, after the Bears had taken the opener, 4 to 3.

The Brookhattan soccer team won the Lewis Cup, emblematic of the professional championship of the United States, by defeating the Irish Americans, 2 to 1, in the second game of the final round at Starlight Park yesterday before a crowd of 4,500.

Most apparel markets experienced a normal amount of business, one notable exception being coats and suits, where selling came to a standstill while producers awaited clarification of the general ceiling order, according to a summary of last week's business prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident offices.

LONDON, May 10 -- It was not disclosed here tonight in just what form the Russians had communicated to the British Government their fears that Germany was planning to use poison gas against them. However, it was the belief in diplomatic circles here that matters must have gone far for Prime Minister Winston Churchill to have uttered his grim, forthright warning.

Cotton prices moved slightly higher last week as sentiment improved on reports of strong opposition to proposals that ceilings on agricultural products be placed at parity levels. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts closed the week with net gains of 17 to 27 points.

MEXICO CITY, May 10 (AP) -- Despite a frantic last-chukker drive that netted the losers three goals, the United States polo team defeated Argentina today, 9 to 6, and annexed the title in the America international tourney.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The United States' spending program for World War II is greater than all the Treasury money spent for all purposes from the time George Washington was inaugurated until Pearl Harbor.

Five new films will open in Broadway theatres this week. The first arrival is "Native Land," a documentary based in part on the report of the Senate Civil Liberties Committee, which has its premiere tonight at the World Theatre. The film has been more than two years in the making and was directed and photographed by Leo Hurwitz and Paul Strand.

"The people with the soundest philosophy of life and the surest faith in God will win the ultimate victory in the present world revolution," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman asserted yesterday morning in his sermon at the Christ Church. Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, of which he is the pastor.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- Continued heavy farm and industrial consumption of corn is regarded as the main influence sustaining the corn market and sufficient speculative demand developed last week to bring about a higher range of prices, with the close on the Board of Trade yesterday showing gains of 1 1/3 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel.

Creation of a Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences in America, composed of members of the original Polish Academy of Arts and Sciences who are now in this country, was announced yesterday. The new institute, with headquarters at 37 East Thirty-sixth Street, has been formed to "insure continuity of Polish cultural life which the Nazis seek to exterminate."

CHICAGO, May 10 -- Grain markets developed a much firmer undertone last week following a letup in liquidation by holders of May contracts. At the top wheat on the Board of Trade showed a rally of around 5 cents a bushel from the recent low, reaching the highest ground in about three weeks. The new-crop months were in the lead.

The American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., charged off its direct investment of $2,493,000 in Shanghai Power Company against surplus in December, following Japanese occupation of that city, and wrote off the earned surplus of the Shanghai subsidiaries in the same manner, or a further charge to surplus of $3,060,000, according to the annual report for 1941.

Three principles to guide Jewish and general public opinion "toward a Zionist solution of the Jewish problem and the problem of Palestine," were laid down yesterday by David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the World Zionist Executive, at the conference sponsored by the American Emergency Committee for Zionist Affairs at the Hotel Biltmore.
BERLIN, May 10 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

The Brooklyn Civilian Defense Volunteer Office is coming to the aid of householders who are struggling with a ration booklet, a curtailed market, and a bond-conscious budget, and are seeking to live up to their responsibilities as constructive consumers.

The annual report of the United Gas Corporation, made public yesterday by J.H. Gill, president, shows a consolidated net income for 1941 of $6,449,118, after all expenses, taxes and other charges. This compares with a net of $5,519,599 in 1940. Net income of the corporation alone, as parent concern, totaled $5,022,666 last year, against $4,125,036 the year before.

Plans for further "streamlining" of the city's air raid warden service, including the uniforming of the force of 280,000 men and women and the mobilization of the city's taxicabs and their drivers into an emergency transportation corps, were disclosed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in his weekly "Talk to the People," broadcast from City Hall through WNYC, the municipal radio station.
There appears to be much confusion of "equality" with "justice," as evidenced by recent letters published in THE TIMES.
Much has been said lately on the subject of marriage during wartime, but I've unearthed at least one fact which is making for happier marriages these days.

May issues of monthly magazines are beginning to reflect the involvement of this country in the war, with linage running about 18 per cent below the like 1941 month. Because of the need for placing copy in advance in monthlies, the retrenchment which advertisers started in December was not apparent until the May issues came out.

Events today: Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff," Michael Fiveisky conducting, Town Hall, 8:15 P.M.; Dessoff Choirs, Paul Boepple conducting, William Gephart, baritone, soloist, New York Times Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Matthew Carnan, baritone, song recital, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Bach Prelude and Fugues, students of the Juilliard Graduate School, Recital Hall, 120 Claremont Avenue, 4:30 P.M.

LONDON, May 10 -- Many special services have been held in Britain this week end for the Netherlands and to honor Queen Wilhelmina, who, after two years of exile in this country, remains as unapproachable, aloof and regal as she was at home.

While reading your editorial of May 4 "Federal Style," based on the American University's five-year study of ten major faults in the writing of government reports, it occurred to me that a more worth-while project would have concerned itself with the matter of accuracy in some of those documents.

By the coming week-end, saltwater fishing in this area will have started on another phase. The weakfish have been arriving in Peconic Bay on schedule this Spring, according to reports from this famous fishing grounds on the east end of Long Island.
President Ed Barrow of the Yankees couldn't have had a better seventy-fourth birthday if he had stage-managed it himself.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The proposal for a 1,500-mile pipeline from Texas to the New York-Philadelphia area was again brought forward today with the contention it offered the principal hope for lifting Eastern motorists from extremely short rations of gasoline and for assuring adequate oil for heating homes.

TOKYO, May 10 (From Japanese broadcast, recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Japanese in Burma have cut United Nations lines of retreat to the India Province of Assam by seizing all important points on the Burmese-Indian frontier and are steadily tightening their encirclement of British and Chinese troops, Domei reported today in a dispatch from the Burma front.
WHEN an ex-sergeant receives a letter from a lieutenant colonel the impulse is to jump to attention and answer in a military manner. The letter from Camp Croft, S.C., ran as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- To meet wartime needs for labor millions of young married women will be called upon to take the places of men in industry, according to figures released today by the Bureau of the Census.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, May 11 -- United Nations bombers aiding American and Australian warships in a death hunt for the battered remnants of a Japanese fleet repulsed at the gates of Australia have sunk or damaged two submarines to run up the toll of Japanese ships in the Coral Sea fighting to at least twenty-one, it was announced today.
CHUNGKING, China, May 10 (Reuter) -- Tonight's Chinese communique said:

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, May 11 -- United Nations bombers aiding American and Australian warships in a death hunt for the battered remnants of a Japanese fleet repulsed at the gates of Australia have sunk or damaged two submarines to run up the toll of Japanese ships in the Coral Sea fighting to at least twenty-one, it was announced today.
CHUNGKING, China, May 10 (Reuter) -- Tonight's Chinese communique said:

CHICAGO, May 10 -- May 15 officially ends all production of household washers and ironers for the duration of the war and leaves an industry that in 1941 produced some 2,400,000 washers and ironers entirely dependent upon war production for its survival.

VICHY, May 10 -- The French Government, which, like the governments of other countries, is concerned with preventing inflation of its currency, has just taken a new measure which aims to render unavailable a part of the funds put in circulation through State expenditures. For this purpose, however, it did not have recourse to compulsion.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The National Negro Congress said today that Secretary Knox had disapproved legislation to award a Congressional Medal of Honor to Dorie Miller of Waco, Tex., Negro mess attendant, who won distinction in the Pearl Harbor attack.

The food and clothing industries made substantial improvement in their earnings last year despite increased taxes and costs, although this favorable trend was not shared by all components of these groups. Textile and leather companies, suppliers to the apparel field, also showed marked improvement. Drugs and cosmetics gained moderately, but tobacco companies had the poorest results in several years.

Although Spain is "still in the chaos of economic difficulties" because of her recent civil war, an attempted Nazi invasion of the Iberian Peninsula would be resisted, "even by the Franco adherents," Wyndham Eric White, first secretary of the British Embassy in Washington, declared yesterday.

In an economy of price ceilings and sugar rationing, where one feels like a second Columbus if he happens on a tiny tin of Strassburg pate de foie gras or a homely crock of British marmalade, it is pleasant to know that at least one of life's little luxuries is still available.
A duplex apartment of twelve rooms in the building at 775 Park Avenue has been leased by James Wood Johnson through Frances R. Jaffin, broker, and Douglas L. Elliman Co., agents.

When New York City's 900,000 motorists register for gasoline rationing tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday, they will find it useless to plead for higher quotas on the ground that they must use their cars for "convenience" as well as for pleasure.

Special efforts must be made in these days to guard against adverse effects upon home life created by the war, because the home is the basic unit of our spiritual life, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo declared yesterday morning in his sermon in the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Forty-eighth Street and Fifth Avenue.

LONDON, May 10 -- Warning the German people tonight that a combined British-American bombing offensive of growing intensity is about to be opened against them, Prime Minister Winston Churchill sent chills and shivers chasing up and down the spines of his listeners by leaving it to Adolf Hitler to choose whether the horror of gas warfare is to be added to the miseries of Europe's suffering millions.
CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- The Cubs and the Pirates divided a double-header today, with Chicago winning the first game, 4 to 2, and losing the second, 3 to 2.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The planes that carried the war to the heart of Japan for the first time on Saturday, April 18, and dropped demolition and incendiary bombs on objectives in Tokyo, Yokohama, Nagoya and other localities were United States Army bombers, the War Department revealed today.

The League of New York Theatres, after three months of discussion with the Theatrical Protective Union, Local 1, has agreed to raise the wages of stagehands, effective today, it was announced last night by a union official. The union's demand for seven men to operate a one-set show, which brought about vehement protests from the producers, was dropped.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Freedom and equality now for the women of the United Nations is demanded in a special message drawn up and formally approved at today's closing session of the two-day council meeting of the World Woman's Party.

PITTSBURGH, May 10 -- With an increase in orders for ship plates, munition steel and lease-lend requirements, all of which are controlled either by allocations or exceptionally high priority ratings, most steel companies last week found their rolling schedules involving material which carried ratings no lower than A-1-k.
Skepticism regarding the success of President Roosevelt's anti-inflation program is expressed in the current issue of The United Mine Workers Journal, official organ of John L. Lewis's own union.

"Blossom Time" will begin the last week of its transcontinental tour at the Brooklyn Academy of Music tonight. Portraying Franz Schubert, Everett Marshall will have the star role in the operetta. The featured players include Charlotte Lansing, Frank Hornaday, Agnes Cassidy, Detmar Poppen, Harry K. Morton and Zella Russell. Prices range from $1.65 top to 55 cents at night with a matinee high of $1.10.

Those poetic "silver threads" of song and story have a distressing way of sprouting almost overnight, and upsetting the whole, studied color-scheme of one's facial makeup. Suddenly, beneath such muted halo, rouge appears bright and garishly theatrical on the cheeks, and the rest of the face seems pale and ghostly.
MOSCOW, May 10 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

BALDWIN, L.I., May 11 -- Jack Father, paired with Walter Scheiber of the home club, and the team of Mel Galletta and Ralph Leaf of North Hills hung up 68s today to tie for first place in the Long Island P.G.A. pro-amateur best-ball handicap tournament at the Milburn G.C.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -- Chester T. Lane, general counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, said in a formal opinion today that an investment adviser for a registered investment company cannot legally sell his contract to another adviser for a profit.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The strained relations between the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the United Mine Workers will be taken up for discussion at the forthcoming meeting of the miners' executive board on May 26 or May 27, it was reported here today.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Officials of the Office of Defense Transportation held another round of conferences with newspaper publishers today on an ODT order limiting motor deliveries by any one companay to one a day, beginning Friday.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The use of the patent laws to promote price fixing and monopoly was denounced by the Supreme Court today in holding that ten building material manufacturers and a producer of eyeglass lenses had violated the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

Settlement of a National Labor Relations Board complaint charging the Curtiss-Wright Corporation with unfair labor practices was believed probable yesterday after Frank A. Mouritsen, trial examiner, adjourned hearings in the case until Thursday to enable attorneys for the company and Lodge 703 of the International Association of Machinists to reach some basis for agreement.
ALBANY, May 11 (AP) -- Governor Lehman today signed a bill strengthening the State's system of collecting for the maintenance of inmates at eighteen State mental hygiene institutions.

VICHY France, May 11 -- Saboteurs struck twice in occupied France today, silencing Radio Paris, radio outlet for German propaganda, by dynamiting its aerial masts near Bourges, 130 miles south of Paris, and derailing a freight train near Parthenay, 180 miles southwest.
VICHY, France, May 11 -- In an interview published here today Darquier de Pellepoix, the new Commissioner for Jewish Problems, declared that his aim was not persecution of the Jews.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 11 -- Dean James M. Landis, director of the Office of Civilian Defense, declared here tonight at the annual convention of the National Fire Protection Association that "too many" cities in the country were "highly susceptible" to incendiary bombs and that fire protection was far from adequate.
LONDON, May 11 -- The defense plan for India has been streamlined, it was announced today in New Delhi.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 11 -- The Army Air Corps today gave commissions as second lieutenants to 500 picked enlisted men, the first graduates from its only non-flying officer candidate school.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 11 -- Dr. Ramon Castroviejo of the staff of the Institute of Opthalmology at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York, from whom a considerable part of the Argentine population expects the "miracle" of restoring the eyesight to President Roberto M. Ortiz, thus enabling him to wrest active management of Argentina's affairs from Acting President Ramon S. Costillo, arrived here by plane this afternoon.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 11 -Three men were arrested today in connection wtih systematic thefts of dental cream from the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company here. Officials of the company said the thefts, committed in a storage house of the American Sugar Refining Company, amounted to $25,00 or $30,000.

Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff" is so great an opera that one is thankful to hear it in concert form, even in a truncated version. Under the authoritative direction of Michael Fiveisky most of the opera was presented last night at the Town Hall with a group of singers who were almost all Russian, and the magnificence of the score held one as if there were scenery, action, a full orchestra and a large chorus.

Class I railroads operating in New York submitted testimony yesterday to the Public Service Commission in support of a petition to have the commission declare reasonable and lawful the 10 per cent increase in intrastate basic passenger rates which went into effect on Feb. 10.

CHUNGKING, China, May 11 -- Chinese for centuries have lived close to the soil, with imported foods in the category of luxuries. Therefore the tightening blockade will have little if any effect on China's food outlook, at least so long as the crops remain normal.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Legislation doubling the base pay of men in service who receive $21 a month at present, and increasing the base pay of other grades of enlisted men of the armed services, will come up for a vote in the House tomorrow. The Rules Committee today, ordered the vote and allowed two hours of debate to precede it.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 11 -- A Swedish-Finnish commercial agreement, including a 35,000,000-kronor credit and a two-year commercial credit of an unspecified amount to Finland, was signed today in Stockholm. This agreement, highly advantageous for Finland. was concluded one day after the Finnish Minister of Commerce and Industry, V.A. Tanner, declared that although hoping for peace this Summer, Finland was not prepared to conclude any separate peace with Russia.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The War Department today raised the Capital City to the rating of a military district for the purpose of administration of defense operations. Washington previously has contained the technical organization of a provisional brigade.

It may be well, in the interest of a proper understanding as well as of avoiding wholly inadvisable financial operations, to examine Point No. 7 proposed by President Roosevelt in his message to Congress as "our present national economic policy" aiming to curb the rising cost of living.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 6: Decreases of $77,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $256,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $504,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and $113,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and an increase of $205,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

With the largest entry in the history of the tournament, the twenty-seventh annual tennis championship of the Athletic Association of Private Schools started yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 11 -- Wage scales, which up to now have been the primary basis for computing rents in Federal housing projects, will be abandoned and the rents will be based upon the value of the property and the cost of maintenance, Lee F. Johnson, assistant commissioner for management, Federal Public Housing Authority, said here today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 11 -- There were extraordinary buying rushes throughout Australia again today because of imminence of rationing of clothing. Many stores sold the day's quota in two or three hours after opening, and closed various departments.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, instructed the oil industry today to adopt a "far reaching program" to further the movement of industrial fuel oil to the Eastern States by tank car "at the expense of gasoline" and thereby disclosed another reason for the rationing of gasoline on the Eastern seaboard, for which registration begins tomorrow.

AN AUSTRALIAN PORT, May 8 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Two United States Navy fliers, Lieut. Comdr. Edward N. Parker of Lexington, Ky., and Lieut. John N. Hughes of Des Moines, Iowa, received the Navy Cross today for bringing their giant seaplane safely back to base after it had been forced down in high seas during a gale.

Major Gen. Thomas A. Terry, new commanding general of the Second Corps Area, gave warning yesterday that Federal authorities would take over the task of eliminating prostitution from districts adjacent to military establishments unless the local health and police agencies took immediate steps to correct existing conditions.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The "Guthrie incident," which started inquiries by House and Senate committees in March into the War Production Board's methods, was echoed in the House here today.

With regard to the article in THE TIMES of May 8 about the farmers in New Jersey facing ruin, the city facing possible food shortage from loss of vegetables, it seems to me that, with or without the help of governmental agencies, something very definite could be done about this situation.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The highest yield an acre and the smallest abandonment of Winter wheat in the last ten years are indicated by May 1 conditions, the Department of Agriculture reported today in estimating the crop would be 646,875,000 bushels.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -- Pennsylvania took both ends of an Eastern Intercollegiate League double-header from Cornell on River Field today, 5 -- 4 and 2 -- 0, to gain undisputed possession of third place.
It will mean starting from scratch in more ways than one if the members of the Boys Brotherhood Republic, 290 East Third Street, are to make a Victory garden out of a vacant lot three doors away.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 -- Because of the "accentuated submarine menace created by the shoreline silhouetting of American ships," the Ninth Regional Office of Civilian Defense today ordered for the duration of the war a dim-out of the California coast within the Twelfth Naval District.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's centennial season was financially its most successful season in its history, Marshall Field, president and chairman of the board of directors of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, reported at the society's annual meeting yesterday afternoon at Steinway Hall.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., May 11 -- The following is the text of the address of Wendell L. Willkie, delivered today at the 147th commencement of Union College, here, of which he is honorary chancellor:

William Gaxton and Victor Moore will leave "Keep 'Em Laughing" after the performance of Thursday evening, May 28. Mr. Gaxton has a date with Harry Goetz of the movies and Mr. Moore has one with Paramount, both on the Coast, which means the Messrs. Gaxton and Moore will be away from town throughout the Summer.

A total of 47,809 mothers, children and babies were carried aboard the Floating Hospital of St. John's Guild in local waters last Summer, according to the annual report of the guild's president, Richmond Weed, made public yesterday. The ship carries ill and crippled children.

The Dessoff Choirs, conducted by Paul Boepple, presented a program of choral music by Schubert, Mendelssohn, Brahms and Schumann last night at THE NEW YORK TIMES Hall. The assisting artist was William Gephart, bari tone, who sang the sixteen songs of Schumann's "Dichterliebe."

In the rationed days ahead of us we shall get back not only to a simpler and sturdier life but to simpler and sturdier words. Thus it will be noticed that the government has placed restrictions on the old-fashioned form of credit known as installment buying.

Robert L. Stott was re-elected yesterday chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange for a second successive term of one year. The remainder of the slate chosen by the nominating committee for 1942 also was elected.

A new regional chain of seven radio stations, in most of which Arde Bulova has an interest, will begin operations on June 15 under the name of the Atlantic Coast Network, it was said yesterday by Harold A. Lafount, former Federal Radio Commissioner, now in charge of the Bulova radio interests.

LONDON, May 11 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 110.6 on April 28. This compares with 110.3 a fortnight before -- at which figure it has stood since March 3 -- 104.6 a year before and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

The Union Electric Company of Missouri, one of the country's largest operating utilities, completed yesterday arrangements for the outright purchase of all physical properties of the Laclede Power and Light Company for $8,600,000. The deal will bring about complete integration of electric facilities in the St. Louis area under single ownership.

The first restrictive order to be issued by the War Production Board putting quotas on sales of spices by packers and wholesalers was formally presented to the trade yesterday by R. Barclay Scull, administrator of the Tea, Coffee and Spice Conservation Section, at the annual convention of the American Spice Trade Association, at the Hotel Astor.

The new air raid warden uniform for our town is to be "a navy blue cover-all, or raid suit, trimmed with belt and epaulets of orange," with the letters NYC in orange "worn on the left sleeve at the shoulder." A matching overseas cap, with orange piping, "will complete the ensemble."

Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, will be the principal speaker at a conference on nutrition in relation to the nation's war program, to be held next Tuesday at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., May 11 -- Overpowering two attendants, four New York City inmates of the Rockland State Hospital here escaped last night, but were recaptured several hours later without trouble after a general police alarm had aroused the community.

VALLETTA, Malta, May 11 (U.P.) -- Tremendously reinforced British air fighters, together with anti-aircraft batteries, have destroyed or damaged 101 Axis planes over Malta during the last seventy-two hours, sixty-three of them in one day, it was announced tonight.

Color was on a rampage at Belmont Park yesterday afternoon. The beautiful race course was at its Spring best. Pink hydrangeas and scarlet geraniums were in full bloom. Not to be outdone by such an outburst, society donned its gayest bonnets for the occasion.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, May 12 -- Shortly after sundown yesterday a German army of 2,000,000 men went into action on the southern front in Russia in what may be the initial phase of Adolf Hitler's long-heralded Spring offensive.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES recently the teaching of American history was subjected to critical discussion both on the editorial page and in the magazine section. I have no quarrel with the men who deplore the inadequate results of history teaching, but I submit that such teaching is encouragingly better than it was twenty-five or fifty years ago.

Danger of Southern New Jersey's asparagus crop going to waste because of a labor shortage was reported relieved yesterday by the local farm coordinator for the New York metropolitan area. Eighty field hands were recruited at the United Stated Employment Service at 124 East Twenty-eighth Street on Saturday and Sunday and sent to New Jersey farms.

CLEVELAND, May 11 -- Use of comomn sense in broadcasting news was stressed today by Byron Price, director of the Office of Censorship, at the opening session of the annual convention of the National Association of Broadcasters. About 1,200 to 1,300 delegates were present.

PEMBROKE, Ont., May 11 (AP) -- Corporal E.V. McNeill of the Ontario Provincial Police said tonight he had been informed by the Ontario forestry branch that two American tourists -- Charles T. Wiggins of Westchester County, N.Y., and Wesley W. Garver of New York -- are believed to have drowned Sunday at Cedar Lake, eighty miles northwest of here.

Gail E. Spain, general sales manager since November, 1940, of the Caterpillar Tractor Company, has been appointed vice president, succeeding the late D.G. Sherwin. He will move to the company's office in San Leandro, Calif., to direct activities there and coordinate operations with those in Peoria, Ill.
The annual golf tournament of the Realty Brokers Of Bay Ridge, Inc., will be held on Thursday at the Rockville Center Country Club. John W. Lake is chairman of the committee.

As the country's vast manufacturing and distributing facilities went under the first price regimentation in the nation's history yesterday, manufacturers in several lines of industry delayed necessary price readjustments in the hope that relief would be forthcoming this week from the Office of Price Administration in the form of supplemental orders.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- The 1942 American Legion National Convention, a mild, streamlined version that its lusty predecessors would not recognize, will be held Sept. 19-21 at national headquarters at Indianapolis.

The entire borough of the Bronx from the Hudson-River to Long Island Sound and from the Harlem to Westchester, an area with a population of 1,800,000, was successfully blacked out from 9:30 o'clock to 9:50 o'clock last night. The Bronx was the first of the five city boroughs to try such a drill.

Four jurors were chosen in General Sessions yesterday of the fourteen who are to hear the evidence in the first-degree murder trial of Miss Madeline Webb, model and novice motion-picture actress; Eli Shonbrun, ex-convict, and John D. Cullen in the death of Mrs. Susie Flora Reich, 52 years old, a Polish refugee, last March 4 in a suite in the Hotel Sutton, in East Fifty-sixth Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 11 -- A suit brought on behalf of John W. Austin, disbarred lawyer, to retrieve $193,620 horse-race bets from Frank Erickson, who has been in numerous difficulties with the New York authorities, was settled outside of court today for $42,500, Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis was told by attorneys.

The Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibition will open on Friday its tenth annual Spring show, which will continue through May 24. This open-air market is under the patronage of the Washington Square Association. Each artist is allotted eight feet of exhibition space in the space along the west and south sides of the square or along Waverly Place, Sullivan and Macdougal Streets, adjoining the square.

The fourteen two-family houses on a plot 462 by 110 feet at 1455-1603 Seventy-sixth Street and the two two-family houses at 1451 and 1609 Seventy-sixth Street, North Bergen, N.J., have been sold by the Embee Realty Company, Loretta Chubatovsky, president, to Pearl Baum of Newark.
A 25-year-old woman died yesterday and her three children were overcome, apparently by gas, in their three-room bungalow at 24 Mesereau Court, in the Gerrittsen Beach section of Brooklyn.

The award of eleven scholarships to students of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism was announced yesterday by Dean Carl W. Ackerman at the School's annual Press Club luncheon in the Journalism building.

IT is to be hoped that Mr. Nelson A. Rockefeller, the coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, can spare Professor Moe Berg from his staff to settle a little problem in baseball that is endangering the good neighbor policy. All the important persons in Washington should be interested in that, and particularly Clark Calvin Griffith, also called the Fox.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Leon Henderson, after discussions behind closed doors with the Ways and Means Committee today, told newspaper men that he had endorsed Secretary Morgenthau's proposals for cuts in income tax exemptions.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- General Sharp went to the Philippines more than a year ago for duty with the field artillery, it was said at the War Department today. Then a colonel, he has been promoted twice since the war began -- to brigadier general last Dec. 18 and to major general on April 2.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 11 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today assigned George Montgomery to the male lead opposite Gene Tierney in "China Girl," replacing Victor Mature, who will be engaged in another film. Ben Hecht is writing "China Girl" and will produce the film in June with Henry Hathaway directing.
The American mother for 1942, Mrs. William N. Berry, broke a precedent yesterday. She was late.

MEXICO CITY, May 11 -- The article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of yesterday saying that the affected United States oil companies regarded the indemnity agreement on their expropriated Mexican properties as obscure, because it left them open to claims in the Mexican courts, was republished here today by the conservative newspaper Excelsior.

Mayor La Guardia's retirement policy for members of the Police Department is expected to be a main issue today when 287 delegates representing 13,500 members of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, numerically the largest of the department's line organizations, meet at 10 A.M. in the Hotel Commodore to ballot in the annual election of officers.
CLEVELAND, May 11 (AP) -- Les Fleming's three-run homer in the ninth inning today won an uphill battle for the Indians as they beat the Tigers, 8 to 5.

The radio, film, theatre and arts division of Russian War Relief will hold its first organizational dinner next Monday nigh at the Waldorf-Astoria. The funds raised will be used to purchase medical supplies for Russia.
LONDON, May 11 (U.P.) -- Spitfire patrols of the Royal Air Force flew through fog and mist today to attack targets in occupied France. Weather prevented long-range attacks.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday was the quietest in several weeks. Traders were awaiting Congressional action on ceilings for farm products. The list closed with losses of 6 to 7 points, compared with Saturday's prices.
BOSTON, May 11 (AP) -- The Braves, just about the hottest team in the National League at present, chalked up their eleventh triumph in fifteen games with a 3-to-2 victory over the Phils today.

MOSCOW, May 11 -- Friction between the German Army High Command and Heinrich Himmler, head of the Gestapo, has resulted from Army demands that Elite Guards be sent to the front, and German youths of 15 and 16 are being drafted for home front police duties, Tass, Soviet news agency, reported today.

BERLIN, May 11 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Berlin broadcasts, commenting today on Prime Minister Churchill's speech yesterday, denied that German troops had used poison gas, as charged by Russia, and recalled pledges by Adolf Hitler that Germany would refrain from using it.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Roosevelt signed several minor bills and nominated Representative William P. Cole to be a judge of the United States Customs Court; he had no engagements.

THOMPSON, Conn., May 11 (AP) -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today removed a truckload of documents from the isolated estate of Anastase A. Vonsiatsky, leader of the Russian National Revolutionary Party, and took them to Hartford where a grand jury was scheduled to convene tomorrow.

A novel of the Canadian West entitled "Little Man," by G. Herbert Sallans, has been chosen for the first annual $500 Ryerson fiction prize in Canada, according to the United Press. The author is general news manager of the British United Press.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- Corn was the leader in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today on a report that a processor had bought an important quantity of cash grain from another processor. Removal of hedges against the grain gave the market a firm undertone from the start, with the close at gains of 3/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Orders permitting several steel companies to pass on to some customers various heavier freight costs described as caused by war business were announced by the Office of Price Administration today.
Increased business resulting from wartime demands in many lines of trade was reflected in some of the commercial rentals reported in Manhattan yesterday.

Steel production this week will set a new high mark of 1,691,800 net tons of ingots and castings, according to mill schedules furnished yesterday to the American Iron and Steel Institute, eclipsing the present record of 1,681,600 tons made in the week of March 23 by more than 10,000 tons.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, May 12 (AP) -- United Nations bombers struck two more Japanese transports and straddled a large tanker with explosives in the islands above Australia yesterday, General Douglas MacArthur announced today.

LONDON, May 11 -- Any Germans who attempt to invade Malta "will get the shock of their young lives," a press conference was informed today by Lieut. Gen. Sir William G.S. Dobbie, who has just relinquished the posts of Governor and Commander in Chief of Malta.

AT ADVANCED UNITED NATIONS AIR BASE, Southwest Pacific, May 11 -- Japanese fliers are less afraid of death than they are of what their government may do to their families if they are captured, according to evidence brought here today by an American cameraman, Earle Crotchett of Universal Newsreel, who has recently returned from Port Moresby.

NEW ORLEANS, La., May 11 -- Concentration of war production in particular areas has caused unplanned and unnecessary migration and is building up a "class of Stateless people in our midst," Representative John J. Sparkman of Alabama told the National Conference of Social Work today.

The United Service Organizations, described as a medium through which the American people can show they are "behind the men behind the guns," opened yesterday a $32,000,000 War Fund campaign with luncheons, meetings of committee workers and well-attended dinners in cities throughout the country.

Arthur Goldschmid, formerly with Leopold Spingarn Co., has been appointed associate manager of an office of Ira Haupt Co. at 501 Seventh Avenue. Samuel E. Sweedler and Emanuel E. Dunn, co-managers there, continue as such.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 5 per cent last week over the corresponding week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. In the previous week the bank reported an increase of the same amount.

Two exhibitions of anti-hoarding posters by New York City school children will be opened tomorrow at the Museum of lVEodern -Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, and at the Women's City Club, 55 West Fortyfourth Street. The two organizations jointly sponsored the project, in which children from 6 to 18 years 0.f age were invited to contribue.

Belmont Park yesterday opened the race meeting which seems certain to be the greatest this year. With 19,783 persons present to see Omission take the forty-ninth Toboggan Handicap and Pomrose the forty-fourth Fashion Stakes, $1,115,645 clicked through the giant totalizator.

OTTAWA, May 11 -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King Introduced in the House of Commons today his bill to remove from Canadian law the bar to conscription for overseas service and announced at the same time that one of his Cabinet members, P.J.A. Cardin of Quebec, had resigned in protest.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, told the House Ways and Means Committee today that freezing of wages as well as prices was necessary to control a situation which, he said, threatened a serious inflation, according to some committee members.

In his Sunday broadcast Mr. Churchill attributed to the Soviet Government "the view that the Germans in the desperation of their assault may make use of poison gas against the armies and people of Russia," and left to Hitler the decision whether or not this "additional horror" was to be added to the many horrors chalked against the progress of aerial warfare.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Navy Cross was awarded by President Roosevelt today to Doris Miller of Waco, Texas, a Negro mess attendant, for "distinguished devotion to duty, extraordinary courage and disregard for his personal safety" during the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (AP) -- The Army today increased its bill for woolen and worsted goods to about $300,000,000 with announcement of awarding of contracts for about 85,000,000 yards of the material. The announcement also said that negotiations have been completed for about 10,000,000 olive drab wool blankets and for a number of woolen and worsted items for special troops.

LONDON, May 11 (AP) -- Leningrad's roof-top spotters have reported sighting Germans working waist-deep in chilly water to prepare assault trenches, Soviet dispatches said today, and the belief was expressed that the Germans might be planning an all-out attack on the city, whose outskirts still are under German artillery fire.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Establishment of a finance section to work with banks in financing war production was announced today by the Navy. The section is to be headed by Sidney A. Mitchell, formerly of Bonbright Co. of New York.

The Museum of Modern Art announced yesterday its schedule of coming exhibitions. On May 21 a show will be opened called "Road to Victory," composed of photographs of the nation at war, directed by Lieut. Comdr. Edward Steichen, U.S.N., with text by Carl Sandburg.

BELMONT PARK, L.I., May 11 -- Society from New York, Philadelphia, New Jersey, Westchester, the Summer colonies of the North and South Shores of Long Island and other parts of the East attended the opening program of the twenty-four-day Spring meeting of the Westchester Racing Association at Belmont Park this afternoon.

DETROIT, May 11 (AP) -- Management was told today by Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national selective service director, to begin now the replacement with older men and women of youth needed for combat service.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- As a result of an hour's conference held by Gaston Henry-Haye, the French Ambassador, with Secretary of State Cordell Hull today, the negotiations concerning the status of French possessions in the West Indies remained centered in Martinique, where they are being conducted with Admiral Georges Robert, the French High Commissioner.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 11 -- Jerry De Sio of Green Valley and his amateur partner, Mike Tartaglia, posted a five under par 34, 32 -- 66 to take the honors in the Westchester P.G.A. pro-amateur best ball tournament at Bonnie Briar today.
Soldiers the world over are fighting for the same objective and if economic security is not assured them when the war ends there will be no peace, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- Safe delivery of machinery required for production of implements of war is a little-known but vital function of the railroads, Edward Dahill of New York City, chief engineer of the freight container bureau of the Association of American Railroads, told transportation inspectors of thirty railroads at a meeting in the Hotel Sherman here today.

LONDON, May 11 -- The stock markets opened higher today, nearly all sections responding to the cheering influence of Prime Minister Churchill's speech. Gilt edge issues saw rises of 1/16 to 1/8 point with the 3 1/2 per cent war loan at 104 3/4 and the conversion 3 1/2 per cent loan at 106 3/4.

LONDON, May 11 -- If Londoners were disturbed by Prime Minister Churchill's warning that gas warfare might come upon them at any time now, they failed to show it today. Only a few more persons than usual were carrying gas masks and that is only a tiny fraction of London's millions.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 11 -- British parachute troops have surreptitiously landed in Norway and blown up the electrical transformer station of Bordshaug, on the Thamshavn railway line, south of Trondheim, paralyzing traffic on Norway's only electrified railroad, it was reported here today.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- War Production Board orders officially setting up thirteen regional WPB offices and vesting broad authority in the regional directors were issued today. The decentralization, for which preliminary steps were taken recently, is expected to be of great help to production and to industrialists engaged or hoping to be engaged in the war effort.
Detective A. O'Neill, known as Buck in the midtown area, yesterday applied for retirement after twenty years' service. He is attached to the main office squad in police headquarters. He is 45.
BERLIN, May 11 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press)

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 11 -After the dramatic spectacles of bombing planes, tanks and liberty ships in mass production, the process of wresting elemental phosphorus from the rich soil of a section of Tennessee that calls itself "the dimple of the universe" seemed prosaic enough.

Three more ships have been torpedoed by enemy submarines off the Atlantic coast, the Navy announced yesterday. All were described officially as medium-size vessels, two of United States registry and the third British. Five lives were lost.

Questions that may puzzle the 900,000 motorists of New York City as they and others throughout the seventeen Eastern States ration area begin registering today for gasoline cards have been answered on the basis of hundreds presented daily to the field offices of the War Production Board, the Office of Price Administration, and other Office for Emergency Management agencies.

The Navy will commission 100 graduate students of engineering schools as officers for instruction duty in one of the three midshipmen training schools, it was announced here yesterday. The Navy's need for capable engineering instructors was said to be "critical."

SAO PAULO, Brazil, May 11 -Subversive operations of Bratac, the Japanese commercial monopoly in Brazil said to be controlled by the Mitsui family, jointly with the Japanese Black Dragon society were indicated in the arrest here today of three Japanese on charges of espionage.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 11 (AP) -- Howard Wells's Equifox, a stake performer with the best last season, returned to form today with a smart victory in the Perryville Purse at Churchill Downs.

The medical advisory committees of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis have recommended research grants totaling $189,525, Basil O'Connor, president of the foundation, announced yesterday. The committees are composed of scientists who advise on the research activities of the foundation, which is supported by the funds raised through the annual celebration of the President's birthday.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- A rubber substitute material for retreading automobile tires, developed by Dr. Glenn L. Casto, a dentist of Spencer, W. Va., and using principally natural gas, coal, wood and grain, will soon be produced in sufficient quantity by a test plant to permit the product on commercial vehicles.

" This Above All," Twentieth Century-Fox's picturization of the Eric Knight novel of England during the present war, will have its world premiere tonight at the Astor Theatre. Directed by Anatole Litvak and produced by Daryl F. Zanuck, the romantic drama stars Tyrone Power and Joan Fontaine.

Any one who is anxious to enjoy a day of weakfishing, even before the surface fishing starts, may leave immediately for Peconic Bay. The rather optimistic reports that came as a prelude to the news of the first fish being taken there last week have been substantiated by Sunday's results.

The city of Akron, Ohio, will be in the market on June 1 with a new issue of $964,000 of refunding bonds, for which bidders are requested to specify a rate of interest not exceeding 3 per cent. The bonds, dated June 1, 1942, will mature serially from Oct. 1, 1943 to 1952.

Thirty-two miles from Times Square the Ramapo Hills rise sharply to dominate Rockland County. And nestling in the valley to the south is a small estate on which a celebrated physician and his wife have seen a hobby grow into a fledgling business.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 11 -- Gasoline ration cards were distributed today to the sixteen ration boards in Westchester County that will begin issuing them tomorrow to owners of the 139,000 pleasure cars in the county. The boards, which will operate registration desks in 100 schools and other public buildings, have the following headquarters:

CLEVELAND, May 11 (AP) -America is self-sufficient in manganese, an essential ingredient of steel which was scarce in the last world war, the official journal of the American Society for Metals declared today.
Eventual recapture by the government through new tax legislation of nearly all profits resulting from war contracts was predicted here last night by Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma.

Inability to settle on a suitable date foreshadows the cancellation of the annual regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association, Asa S. Bushnell, executive director of the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics, disclosed yesterday.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the first quarter of this year, issued yesterday by A. N. Williams, president, shows a net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $1,313,570. This is equal to $1.25 a share on the company's 1,045,277 shares of capital stock outstanding, and compares with a net of $1,288,552 or $1.23 a capital share in the March quarter of 1941.

The National Collegiate A.A. committee on swimming records has approved for registration fifteen record performances achieved in collegiate and scholastic competition this year, it was revealed yesterday by Philip S. Harburger, chairman of the committee.

HOUSTON, Texas, May 11 (AP) -- The Humble Oil and Refining Company had a consolidated net income of $35,356,668 in 1941, compared with $28,107,503 in 1940, the annual report of its president, Harry C. Wiess, showed today. These earnings were equivalent to $3.93 a share, compared with $3.13.

Further stories of how New York boys in the Navy struck back at the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor Dec. 7 were revealed yesterday with the publication of Navy Casualty List No. 2 of men who were wounded. Some of them still are in hospitals and some are now back in active service.
Mr. and Mrs. Ashley Chanler gave a large dinner last night at their home, 141 East Nineteenth Street, followed by a showing of the United China Relief documentary film, "The Western Front."

ALBANY, May 11 -- Governor Lehman vetoed today the Williamson bill which would have put members of the Board of Supervisors of Westchester County under a "weighted-vote" plan, according to each Supervisor voting strength in proportion to the number of citizens he represents.

The officers and directors of the Woodrow Wilson Foundation recorded their conviction yesterday at the close of their twentieth annual board meeting, that "two deep currents have recently taken form in American public opinion."

MOSCOW, May 11 (AP) -- Heavy fighting has erupted in the Kerch Peninsula, the narrow neck of land leading from the Eastern Crimea toward the Caucasus, and the Red Army is fighting stubbornly there against a new German offensive, the Russians announced officially tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The verage daily rate of expenditure for war purposes in April increased to $131,600,000, as compared with $114,900,000 in March, Donald -- M. Nelson, War Production Board chief, reported today.

Decision of the Blue Network to follow the lead of the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System in accepting the principle of the cash discount will be welcomed by advertising agencies as "a constructive move to strengthen the advertising financial structure and provide a stimulus for the prompt collection of radio bills," Frederic R. Gamble, managing director of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Navy released today its Casualty List No. 2, naming officers and enlisted men of the Navy and Marine Corps wounded in the period from Dec. 7, 1941, to April 15, 1942, inclusive. The places of action were not stated. The wounded, with the next of kin, included:

Billy Conn, the Pittsburgh heavyweight title contender, who was stopped by Champion Joe Louis last year in the thirteenths round, but not before he had come close to relieving Louis of the crown, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday with his left hand in a heavy cast.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 11 -- To make sure this war is not "just another season of blood-letting," Wendell L. Willkie implored Union College graduates today to "defend your country not only with your guns but by your votes."

Once upon a time you told me you wished you could get out of Washington and settle down permanently in New York. You said you preferred prizefighters to politicians, Broadway to bureaucracy. But now, to judge by occasional date lines over your column on the editorial page of this newspaper, I see you're going the other way, toward your native State of Kentucky.

Owners of automobiles, motorcycles, motorbikes and inboard motorboats, or their agents, may obtain A cards at the gasoline rationing registration beginning today by presenting the vehicle's registration card, and may fill out an application for a B or an X card, but for larger rations than can be obtained under a B card they will have to apply to their gasoline rationing board.

With a declaration embodying much of what had been laid down previously by Dr. Chaim Weizmann and David Ben-Gurion, the conference sponsored by the American Emergency Committee for Zionist Affairs closed last night at the Hotel Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Full cooperation of Peru with the United States until victory is won was pledged today by President Manuel Prado in an address before the Senate. The President was received by the House and also received such an ovation that he repeated his address there.

ALBANY, May 11 -- Establishment of a semi-public health research institute in New York City, with a budgetary guarantee of $100,000 a year from the municipal government, to carry on work in the development of serums and other health work was assured today.

TOKYO, May 11 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Domei declared in a French-language broadcast tonight that "the conquest of all the islands of the Philippines by the Japanese forces now has been completely achieved."

Problems in maintaining the present standard of living under war conditions were discussed yesterday afternoon at a meeting of West Side residents held in the Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at Seventy-ninth Street.

Myer went last July, now Mike is gone. They were warm, vital figures of New York. In their way they were creators. What they saw and heard on the East Side when the Bowery was a street of theatres, "museums," dance halls, saloons, divans and dives they made into scenes full of a drollery not now to be appreciated in its entirety.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 11 -- "Divert as much of your facilities as possible to war work if you would hold your business together," was the advice given to the Luggage and Leather Goods Manufacturers of America at their annual convention here today.

The symbolism of good neighborliness involved in the visit of President Prado of Peru almost obscured the substance contained in the new reciprocal trade agreement which was signed a few hours before his arrival.
