The agreement provides for tariff concessions by Peru and the United States on about one-fourth of the items comprising the $41,000,000 of trade between them in 1940.
CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were mostly steady today but hogs and cattle had an upward tendency as the market settled down with an undertone of stability.
SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, May 11 -- Among the American soldiers in Australia a new catch phrase has taken root and begun to sprout -- "Hot stuff coming!"

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 11 -- Forty Hudson County motorists who have changed their motor vehicle registration from pleasure to commercial classification but have not had their names and addresses painted on the sides of the vehicle, as required by law, have been summoned to appear here in Hudson County Traffic Court tomorrow and Thursday nights.

LONDON, May 11 -- Heavy fighting was continuing tonight between Japanese and Chinese forces on the Chinese side of the Burma border, but conflicting reports and the fact that the enemy was receiving reinforcements caused responsible quarters here to withhold optimism regarding the outcome.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith criticized yesterday the law in the New York State Constitution that required judges to retire from the bench when they reached the age limit of seventy years. He spoke at the unveiling in the Surrogate's court in Brooklyn, of an oil painting of former Surrogate George Albert Wingate.

A rapidly spreading fire swept through the five floors of the Hotel Marietta, 121st Street and Seventh Avenue, Harlem, last night, trapping twenty-five guests who were rescued by firemen and causing the death of one unidentified Negro. Four firemen and two guests were injured.

VICHY, France, May 11 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, who has been taking a short rest at Villeneuve-Loubet, on the Riviera, returned to Vichy today "because of the importance of events."

Underwriters and investment dealers, who are spending more and more time these days "working for the government" in distributing war bonds and other Treasury obligations, will give a little attention this week to their primary business -- corporate financing.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 11 -- Substantial aid must reach Russia in 1942 if the year is to mark "the beginning of the end for Hitler," an audience of 3,000 persons in the County Center here was told tonight by Joseph E. Davies, former Ambassador to Moscow.

After a period of hesitancy in the morning, the stock market undertook yesterday to extend its recovery to new high levels. Trading was centered in issues of good quality and a few of the recent favorites were able to rise more than a point, although the general advance was by major fractions.

The New York group or committee of the National Committee of Securities Industry for War Financing has made more than 22,750 calls, either in person or by telephone, on eligible purchasers of the Treasury's new 2 1/2 per cent "tap" bonds, it was disclosed yesterday by Perry E. Hall, chairman of the New York committee.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 11 -- There is not the slightest disposition in newspaper and other comments on the Battle of the Coral Sea to regard the action as a conclusive success. It is considered as a repulse of the enemy rather than a defeat.

DETROIT, May 11 (AP) -- A "specific agreement" against strikes or other work stoppages for the war's duration and establishment of "swing" shifts to expedite armament production was proposed tonight by the national Ford council of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O.

Several hundred members of the League of Women Voters took a three-hour "trip to the country" yesterday afternoon without at any time being more than a mile distant from Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- An analysis of official American communiques dealing with the war in the Far East discloses that the damage being done to the Japanese at sea has been inflicted by war planes, submarines, cruisers, destroyers and other craft of tonnage inferior to the battleship.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- By a vote of 9 to 3, the Senate Judiciary Committee approved the proposed constitutional amendment providing "that men and women shall have equal rights throughout the United States and every place subject to its jurisdiction."

Governor Lehman was requested yesterday to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the use of city material, labor and equipment in the paving of a courtyard at the Lake Mahopac estate of Edward J. Flynn, in a telegram signed by Professor Herman A. Gray of New York University Law School and Sydney S. Baron, publicity man, of 277 Broadway.

In the French island of Martinique our Government is seeking certain additional assurances which have become necessary because Hitler's man Laval is now in command at Vichy. Martinique is one of the Windward Island group. It lies almost due east of the Panama Canal and offers a fine potential base for hostile submarine action against traffic north and south as well as east and west.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- United States submarines have sunk another Japanese destroyer, the twenty-seventh enemy ship of this type reported sunk or badly damaged in the Far East, the Navy Department announced today. The sinking of the destroyer was reported in a communique that also listed a Japanese naval cargo ship and a medium-sized cargo ship as victims of American undersea boats.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 11 -- War workers must get preference over other workers and even school children in bus transportation, John F. Fitzgerald, supervisor of motor transportation for the Public Service Commission, said today at a conference of Nassau and Suffolk County bus operators in the new court house here.

MOSCOW, May 11 -- Now it is possible to picture Russian troops moving to the front -- in trucks (this year there are Ford and Morris trucks among the convoys), in freight cars, on the march, astride the short-legged horses of the steppes. Millions are moving forward to take their places on a board set with rare skill and precision.

KANSAS CITY, May 11 (AP) -- "Not a grain" of the wheat crop will be wasted, a spokesman for the railroads said today, if those involved approach the difficult problems of storage and transportation cooperatively.

For the Japanese the Burma Road has proved easy to cut but hard to follow. The events of the past seven days, in Burma itself and over the border in China, took place in a land whose place names are strange to Americans. But the strategy of the defenders has a classical simplicity.

Mrs. Ruth Ballenberg, 26 years old, was found slain yesterday, apparently by strangulation, in the bedroom of her apartment at 42 Thayer Street, in the Inwood section of Manhattan, by women friends who called shortly after 2 P.M. to inquire why she had not kept an appointment.

Activities relating to the war take up 48 per cent of the broadcasting time of WNYC, the city station, according to Morris S. Novik, station director, who testified yesterday before the Council finance committee at a hearing on the city budget in City Hall.

The impression Kenneth Snyder made on one of his fellow-soldiers in the Army nearly fifteen years ago was credited yesterday with causing Snyder's arrest on charges of wearing a Navy uniform without authorization. When he was in the Army Snyder was court-martialed and dishonorably discharged after two months, and he has never been in the Navy, according to E.E. Conroy, head of the local FBI office.

Motorists throughout seventeen Eastern States, including New York City's estimated 900,000 automobile owners, will begin registering today for gasoline rationing. They were urged yesterday by Federal authorities to be moderate in their applications and tourists in the ration area were advised to hurry home before rationing begins Friday.

CALCUTTA, India, May 11 -The last white woman out of Lashio and one of the last to escape from Burma, Miss Mavis Gully of Melbourne, Australia, a member of the staff of the British Ministry of Information, has arrived in Calcutta after a nightmare experience that involved in the short space of a half-hour a bombing, a plane crash and the machine-gunning of a plane in which she and wounded Indian soldiers were passengers.

BOSTON, May 11 -- William M. Rand, vice president of the Monsanto Chemical Company, declared in a speech to the American Institute of Chemical Engineers today that anti-trust action against industry should be postponed until after the war unless war production was directly affected.
MOSCOW, May 11 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:

A mass demonstration and sidewalk rally of blood donors, sponsored by the Red Cross and Hearn's Volunteer National Defense Corps, was held yesterday morning at 9:15 in front of Hearn's Department Store, Fourteenth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

Still seen only in dim outline, the Battle of the Coral Sea can best be estimated in General MacArthur's phrase as a "repulse" for the enemy. But it is only an initial repulse. The Japanese are engaged in a great southward movement of men and ships. They will probably not be deterred by their present losses, costly as they were, and they cannot afford to wait.

Arranged as a benefit for United China Relief, of which Mrs. Robert Low Bacon and Frederick H. Wood are co-chairman, an exhibition of paintings by Professor Chang Shu-Chi and Mme. Tee Ping Shen Hsu opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the Ferargil Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Government officials entrusted with developing facilities for the production of synthetic rubber have displayed "a remarkable lack of interest" in processes in which domestic farm products are the basic raw materials used, members of a Senate Agriculture Subcommittee complained today.

Six men were arrested here yesterday in possession of 210,000 counterfeit defense stamps of 25-cent denomination, together with the plates from which more could be printed. Three months ago they thought they saw an opportunity, they confessed yesterday, because the defense stamps were easier to copy than the currency.

BERLIN, May 12 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Germans were informed tonight by every available means that their Army and Air Force had begun their first major offensive action against Russia since the long Winter campaign of defense.

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard yesterday rejected a legal theory that, he said, would have enabled the Nazis to force this country to set free all the German citizens who have been rounded up as inimical to the security of the United States.

Four hundred and fifty-eight midshipmen received commissions as Naval Reserve ensigns yesterday at the graduation exercises of the sixth and largest class to complete the new four-month officer-training course aboard the old battleship Prairie State at 136th Street and the Hudson River.

In your recent notice of the death of William Warren Orcutt, petroleum geologist and former executive of Union Oil Company of California, I note your statement that Mr. Orcutt "was instrumental in developing interest in the La Brea pits as a source of the study of fossil remains."

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A lowering of exemptions on individual income taxes to $1,000 for married persons and $500 for single persons, with a rise in the normal tax rate from 4 to 6 per cent and the imposition of new surtaxes ranging from 11 to 80 per cent, were proposed to the Ways and Means Committee today by its chief expert, Colin F. Stam.

A resolution urging this country to commit itself to a new world order to prevent aggression and promote the welfare of the peoples of the entire world after the war was adopted by a standing vote last night at the closing session of the two-day meeting of the Forum of the Future World Order at the Hotel Plaza.
CINCINNATI, May 12 -- Good news on the war production front in the Cincinnati area was reported here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -- The average annual net income from 1935 to 1939 of 1,495 listed corporations in the United States amounted to $2,687,000,000, equivalent to 7 per cent of the stockholders' equity at book value, according to the report of a survey made by the Works Project Administration under the sponsorship of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, May 12 -- New Zealand forces completed their first large-scale guerrilla exercises today with a view to sharpening the fighting power of the new army for effective action against the Japanese if the invasion threat should mature.

On May 5 THE TIMES printed a letter from "Disgusted" protesting the President's approval of a $194,109 WPA project for development of parks and recreational grounds in Perth Amboy, N.J. The writer asked how the people could be expected to make financial sacrifices and show enthusiasm in an all-out effort to win the war "when Federal funds are still being lavishly distributed for such nonessentials."

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Congressmen signed up in large numbers at the Capitol today for "X" gasoline ration cards, entitling them to unlimited quantities, but an official of the Price Administration said tonight that their position did not automatically qualify them for such preferential treatment.

LONDON, May 12 -- In the London office building that is the seat of the Netherland Government in exile, tonight a grim-faced man laid down on his desk a piece of paper on which was typed a news report telling of the execution of twenty-four more Netherlanders and the imprisonment for life of three others for what the Germans called "espionage, favoring the enemy and being in possession of arms."

FORT DIX, N.J., May 12 -- Harold G. Hoffman, chairman of the New Jersey Unemployment Compensation Commission and former Governor of the State, reported at the Fort Dix Station Hospital this afternoon for a physical examination to determine whether he is physically fit for active duty with the Army.

A widespread system of military scholarships was urged on the government in a speech here last night by Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, in order that young high school graduates fit to be officers may be educated on their merits with government funds in colleges throughout the country.

Bishop Loughlin Memorial High won the senior trophy with 23 points and Bronx Vocational took the vocational team trophy with 39 1/2 at the fourth annual Brooklyn High School of Automotive Trades track and field meet at McCarren Park, Brooklyn, yesterday.

MOSCOW, May 12 -- The Crimean offensive of Col. Gen. von Mannstein's Eleventh Germany Army marks the third time the ochre-colored earth of the Kerch Peninsula has been fought over in this war. It is one way to the Caucasus oil fields, and it is believed in Russia that Germany is short of oil.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, May 13 -- Adolf Hitler's "first installment of the Spring offensive" continued to develop yesterday as fierce battles raged along the northern shore of the Kerch Peninsula and in mainland regions north of the Sea of Azov in the Donets Basin.

Steeplechasing had its first stake of the New York season yesterday and a familiar pair, George H. (Pete) Bostwick and his big bay gelding Cottesmore, upheld the faith of those who had installed the combination as the 7-to-5 favorite for the $4,350 International Steeplechase Handicap.

Evidence began to accumulate yesterday that the Office of Price Administration was adopting a "hard-boiled" attitude on the matter of relief from the onerous provisions of the price-ceiling regulations and that such relief, when forthcoming, would be "grudging and slow."

A collection of favorite recipes from Columbia University faculty kitchens has just been brought out by the Columbia University Press as "What's Cooking at Columbia." The sponsor and recipient of all proceeds is the university's committee for war relief.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Construction of "monumental" hospitals will not be approved for the duration, Philip B. Fleming, Administrator of the Federal Works Agency, warned tonight in a National Hospital Day broadcast over the Blue Network.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 12 -- A Nazi submarine sank a freighter in the St. Lawrence River yesterday in the first attack within the gulf, Naval Minister Angus L. Macdonald announced today. The exact place where the attack occurred, the nationality of the freighter and other details of the sinking were not made public.

Chief City Magistrate Henry H. Curran chided Mayor La Guardia gently yesterday after the Mayor had complained that the magistrates were too lenient with violators of the ban on smoking on piers and in warehouses.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Roosevelt nominated Anthony J. Biddle to be Ambassador to The Netherlands and the Norwegian governments in exile; he had no engagements.

Wall Street will stage its greatest patriotic rally since the first World War next Monday, when it will celebrate the 150th anniversary of the founding of the New York Stock Exchange on May 17, 1792, with a monster drive to sell war bonds.

Three performances of former French Ambassador Paul Claudel's medieval allegorical play, "L'Annonce Faite A Marie," will be given at the Barbizon Plaza Theatre on May 20, 21 and 23 to augment the scholarship fund of the Lycee Francais de New York.

Seeking to relax Mayor La Guardia's order of a six-day week for city employes, Vice Chairman Joseph T. Sharkey proposed yesterday that the five-day week be restored for all employes who could show that they devoted part of their time to war work.

For the third time Spring in Europe brings a new offensive by the German armies. In 1940 and 1941 Hitler's path was made relatively easy by unsuspecting neutrals and ill-prepared opponents. This year he has the Russian bear by the tail, and the problem of what to do and where to go is not so simple.

When Hitler said "There are no islands any more" he overlooked Malta. As an island Malta is insignificant and, except for its strategic position in the Mediterranean, might easily be overlooked. With its smaller neighbor Gozo it covers only 122 square miles. But this rock in the sea has had more bombs dropped on it than any comparable area in the world.

That baseball rarity, a triple play, left Frank Frisch and his Pirates with dazed, bewildered looks at the Polo Grounds yesterday as the Giants whisked off with a 7-3 victory that left the Bucs still two and a half games behind the Dodgers.

The jury was completed in General Sessions yesterday for the trial of Madeline Webb, 28 years old, the former model and aspiring motion-picture actress; Eli Shonbrun, 33, an exconvict, and John D. Cullen, 40, charged with first-degree murder as the slayers of Mrs. Susie Flora Reich, 52, a Polish refugee, found dead on March 4 in a suite in the Hotel Sutton, in East Fifty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Secretary Morgenthau announced today

VICHY, France, May 12 -- The German Military Command in occupied France issued today a sweeping decree, taking to itself powers to increase working hours in French enterprises and ordering employers to report immediately the number and categories of workmen made available for other work as a result of longer hours.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, May 12 (AP) -- Thirteen American airmen whose planes crashed in the New Guinea area have arrived in Australia to pick up new planes and continue the fight against the Japanese.

Bishop Manning, addressing the annual convention of the clergy and laymen of the Protestant Episcopal Church over which he presides, renewed yesterday his plea for successful prosecution of the war and asked for "a peace not based on vengeance but upon justice and good-will alike to the victors and the vanquished."
CAIRO, Egypt, May 12 (AP) -- An R.A.F. communique issued today:
There will be no Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta this year. With much regret, Asa S. Bushnell, secretary-treasurer of the board of stewards, announced the cancellation last night.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 12 -- Despite reports from London today that Pierre Laval has met Hermann Goering at Moulins on the line of demarcation between the occupied and unoccupied zones of France, information from trustworthy sources identifies the Ger man party to the conversations as Otto Abetz, representative of the Reich in Paris. But whoever may have been the French Premier's iiterlocutor the importance of the occasion remains.

BOSTON, May 12 (AP) -- The liberality of Braves' pitchers, who issued seven bases on balls, and three infield errors enabled the Cubs to win, 9 -- 8, today, although the Boston team came within a tally of deadlocking the game with a five-run eighth inning uprising.
MILES CITY, Mont., May 12 (AP) -- A quick-thinking Army sergeant saved his own and ten other lives today in the crash of a Northwest Airlines transport which fatally injured three airline pilots.

In cooperation with the National Association of Day Nurseries, Bundles for America will provide care and protection for the children of women serving in war industries throughout the country, it was announced yesterday by the national war relief agency's president, Mrs. Wales Latham, from her headquarters, 475 Fifth Avenue.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 12 -- Despite American military reverses in the Philippines, the personal popularity of President Roosevelt continues at a high-level throughout the United States. Approximately eight voters in every ten approve, in general, of the way he is handling his job as President in these crucial days of war emergency.

Mrs. Edmund Summers Hawley gave a luncheon yesterday in her home at 1150 Fifth Avenue for aides of her division in the United China Relief New York City campaign. Before luncheon the guests were shown the United China Relief documentary film, "The Western Front."

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The struggle of the battleship versus the airplane, which has rocked the Navy Department internally for months, is likely to lead to a movement in Congress to limit, if not eliminate, the construction of capital ships.

It is a great shock to millions of motorists to find that they will not be able to use their cars to any extent. This, however, instead of being a hardship, may be turned into a happy blessing in- stead.

The merger of two of New York City's oldest savings banks, the Manhattan Savings Institution and the Metropolitan Savings Bank, was announced yesterday. The combined institution will take the name of the Manhattan Savings Institution, while the president of the Metropolitan, Willard K. Denton, will be the president of the consolidated banks.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Admiral Georges Robert, High Commissioner for French possessions in the Western Hemisphere and the Atlantic, hag been delaying his final reply to the American proposals for neutralizing under the protection of the United States the islands of Martinique and Guadeloupe and French Gulnia until he receives word from Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, French Chief of State.

All signs point toward important news from France. The German radio announces that decisions of "extreme political interest" are expected to be made at today's meeting of the Council of Ministers in Vichy. There are unconfirmed reports that Laval has met and talked secretly with Goering.

Danny Bartfield, 137, East Side lightweight, triumphed over Morris Reif, 144, of Brownsville, in the main eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. A crowd of 3,500 persons saw Bartfield floor the loser for a count of nine in the second.

A MIDWEST MUNITIONS PLANT, May 12 (U.P.) -- Women soon will have 55 per cent, or more, of the jobs in shell-production plants of the Chicago ordnance district, and an increasing number of jobs in the manufacture of tanks, artillery and other implements of war, Army Ordnance spokesmen said today.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A preface to large-scale operations is being written in the skies of Europe and the Far East as intensive air combats precede the offensives, soon to start.
GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 12 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association opened its season today with a field of forty-seven competing at the North Shore Country Club.
LONDON, May 12 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following oommunique today:
LONDON, May 12 -- About 3,750,000 meals are eaten in restaurants by Londoners weekly. Some of these dine cheaply, some expensively, but all dine badly.

WASHINGTON, May l2 -- Senator Tydings, chairman of an appropriation subcommittee which is seeking to determine how much unneeded space, personnel and equipment Federal departments handling civilian affairs should turn over to war agencies, said today that "hundreds" of duplicating machines and much photographic apparatus were not being fully utilized or "apparently" were not being used for work essential to the war effort.
A dog show staged yesterday afternoon by the girls of the Lenox School at 170 East Seventieth Street brought $50 for United China Relief.
BERLIN, May 12 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 -- Plans for resumption of British production by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer were disclosed today with the announcement that Irving Asher would go to England next month to film there "Sabotage Agent," with Robert Donat.

The announcement yesterday by the Prudential Insurance Company that it had purchased an additional $50,000,000 of the new Treasury 2 1/2s led to a quick revision by observers of their estimates as to the probable total subscriptions to this issue.

Sales of the Treasury's new 2 1/2 per cent "tap" issue due in 1967 took an unexpected and sharp jump yesterday and brought the aggregate to more than $750,000,000, assuming that purchases announced yesterday were not included in the sales figure in the Treasury's daily financial statement for Saturday.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 12 -- Governor Lehman declined today to yield to requests from the Citizens Union and other civic groups that he set aside the findings of the Bronx County grand jury in the Flynn paving blocks case and order a special prosecutor to supersede Bronx District Attorney Samuel J. Foley in the investigation.

At the close of the last century this newspaper had on its reportorial staff a young man who had just graduated from school and who was so fascinated by snakes that he carried them around in a satchel which his fellow-reporters were warned not to touch. The result was an order from the assistant night city editor first to keep the satchel under lock and key and then to remove it entirely.

A substantial increase in the number of standees in buses and revision of operating schedules to effect economies in the use of buses, tires and gasoline are provided in wartime regulations announced yesterday by the Transit Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Roosevelt is working night and day on the main war problem that faces the country -- the transportation of munitions from our factories to the major battlefields of the world. He has before him a proposal to expedite shipments by giving one man authority over both inland and ocean transportation.

Definitive bonds of the issue of $32,000,000 New York City 2 1/2 per cents, due from 1943 to 1972, and $18,000,000 of 2 1/4 per cent assessment bonds, due from 1943 to 1952, will be ready on and after next Monday at the City Controller's office in exchange for the outstanding temporary bonds, it was announced yesterday.

Ellsworth B. Buck, Staten Island business man, was elected president of the Board of Education by unanimous vote at the board's annual meeting yesterday at its offices, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn. He Succeeds James Marshall of Manhattan, who refused another term on the plea that the office should be rotated, but who remains a member of the board.

FIRST, give to the USO. After that, take note that the usually astute Uncle Mike Jacobs missed a trick when he didn't rush out to Pittsburgh and sign Jimmy Smith to fight Joe Louis. Jimmy eliminated Billy Conn, the outstanding challenger, didn't he?

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 12 -- Rallying for three runs in the ninth, Seton Hall defeated Fordham's nine, 6 -- 5, at Setonia Field today for its sixth victory in as many starts and avenged a setback that spoiled its 1941 record.

PATERSON, N.J., May 12 -- Three members of the Paterson Board of Aldermen and one former member were convicted here today on charges of conspiracy involving the acceptance of bribes to favor certain junk-yard dealers in the enactment and enforcement of ordinances regulating junk yards.

New York City's 900,000 automobile owners and 7,600,000 other motorists of seventeen Eastern States began registering yesterday for gasoline rationing. Meanwhile, public resentment at the so-called "discrimination" against the Atlantic seaboard increased as members of Congress moved for additional exempt areas and for inland water transportation to ease the gasoline shortage, and as Canada tightened restrictions on tourists following protests by motorists south of her border.

The National Power and Light Company, important subholding unit in the Electric Bond and Share Company system, soon will file with the Securities and Exchange Commission a revised plan for liquidation in conformance with the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, it was disclosed yesterday by P.B. Sawyer, president, in his annual report to stockholders.

John Penn of McBurney, the topseeded favorite, scored a crushing victory over John Putnam of Bishop Loughlin yesterday in the quarter-finals of the championship tennis tournament of the Athletic Association of Private Schools at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

Forty-six policemen were rushed to Harlem Hospital shortly before 9 o'clock last night to disperse an angry crowd of seventy-five Negroes who gathered at the entrance to the emergency ward to protest the shooting of a Negro in an altercation with a policeman.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A Senate Appropriations subcommittee completed tonight consideration of the Agricultural Appropriation Bill, retaining with some modifications a House ban upon the sale of farm products by the Commodity Credit Corporation at less than parity prices.

LONDON, May 12 -- The Japanese forces invading Yunnan Province of China over the Burma Road are now reported by Chungking to have recoiled to Wangting on the frontier. Far to the west, weary British troops falling back along the Chindwin River made a stand at Kalewa, near the Indian border, pushing back a pursuing column some five miles.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Some members of the House Ways and Means Committee were certain yesterday that Leon Henderson, the Price Administrator, advocated before them that wages be frozen along with prices, and such was the report they made to the press.

Registration for gasoline rationing throughout the seventeen Eastern States yesterday was marked by many incidents. Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, who motors extensively, explained in Boston that she did not find gasoline rationing too great a worry.

The start of the Nazi move in the Crimea caused many traders in stocks to take to the sidelines yesterday and as a result stocks closed moderately lower. This inactivity dropped sales on the Stock Exchange to 249,200 shares, against the Monday turnover of 290,650.

It will be a long time before Junior Thompson, the Cincinnati right-hander, forgets Lew Riggs, his former team-mate, now with the Dodgers. For yesterday at Ebbets Field before 11,893 fans, Riggs -- and Riggs alone -- prevented Thompson from achieving a no-hit game as the Reds handed the Brooks a 5-1 setback.

ADVANCED UNITED NATIONS AIR BASE, Southwest Pacific, May 12 -- Japanese naval activity in this area is lessening, but enemy action by land-based planes against the most advanced United Nations bases is being stepped up. The Japanese fleet routed in the Battle of the Coral Sea is continuing its retirement, it was said today by an authoritative source.
Private Billy Conn apparently fared better with a military medical board at Fort Wadsworth yesterday than he did with his father-in-law at Pittsburgh Sunday night, the United Press reported.

Now that the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission has become a reality, it is expected that all those interested in the many phases of salt-water fishing will watch the development and functioning of this body with much attention.

A new destroyer, the U.S.S. Lardner, was delivered to the Navy Yard in Brooklyn yesterday morning by the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, Kearny, N.J., marking the ship's completion six months ahead of schedule.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Treasury announced tonight that it disapproved the use of war bonds or stamps as prizes or rewards in lotteries or for punch-board prizes or in pin-ball games or "other games of chance where an element of personal profit is involved either directly or indirectly."

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Anthony Drexel Biddle Jr. today became the first United States Ambassador to four separate governments when it was disclosed that relations with the refugee Norwegian Government in London were being raised to ambassadorial status.

"The Walking Gentleman" gave its sixth and final performance last night at the Belasco. Early in the week it had been reported that the play would be taken off soon, but the decision was not reached until the backers met yesterday afternoon.

OSAGE, W. Va., May 12 -- A terrific blast deep in a big West Virginia coal mine apparently took fifty-three lives today, with three bodies recovered, eleven more found and the word of rescue workers there was almost no hope for thirty-nine others trapped underground.

VICHY, France, May 12 (U.P.) -- German and French police have isolated large sections of downtown Paris and blocked subway traffic in a hunt for terrorists who bombed five hotels and a restaurant patronized by the German Army, dispatches from the city said today.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Grain markets, with the exception of oats, showed a heavy undertone on the Board of Trade today. Wheat at one time was off around 1 cent a bushel on selling induced by a bearish construction placed on a Department of Agriculture crop report issued late yesterday and in sympathy with cotton and securities.

NEW ORLEANS, May 12 -- Liberation of Germany, Japan and Italy from the yoke of military dominance as well as maintenance of the freedom of the democracies was included in a seven-point program for post-war reconstruction presented tonight to the National Conference of Social Work.

NEWARK, N.J., May 12 -- Dismissal of the War Production Board charges of "repeated, deliberate violations of priority regulations" made in Washington on April 19 against the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh was sought today in an answer to the charges filed with the United States District Court, here.

Renomination by all parties of Justice Peter Schmuck of the Supreme Court was urged last night by The Association of the Bar of the City of New York at its annual meeting at 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

When the Ringling Brothers-Barnum and Bailey Circus opened yesterday in Boston, Gargantua the gorilla sulked no more than usual. But he might have, for his trainer, Richard (Dick) Kroener, died in Polyclinic Hospital here Monday and was cremated in New Jersey yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- By a margin of more than two to one in a surprise move, the House of Representatives voted tentatively today to increase the base pay of the Army and Marine Corps private and the Navy and Coast Guard apprentice seamen to $50 a month and that of private first class and seaman second class to $54.

Salvage. is an important word today. We are busy saving old newspapers, worn-out overshoes and empty tin cans. We urge people, by poster and slogan, to repair the old and not to buy the new because we know that we must stretch our material goods as far as we can.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -Philip Morris Co., Ltd., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement, disclosing that the proposed offering of 40,666 shares of cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value would bear an annual dividend rate of 4 1/2 per cent.

The grand ballroom and adjoining ballroom suites of the Waldorf-Astoria took on carnival guise last night for a gala jamboree entitled "Carnival Street," which was given to raise funds for the welfare activities of the Navy Relief Society.

Concern over impending Congressional legislation that might affect ceilings on agricultural products continues to dominate trading in cotton futures. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts fluctuated yesterday within a narrow range and closed near the day's lows at net losses of 8 to 11 points.
A drop of ten full points in the infant mortality rate in New York City last week was reported yesterday by City Health Commissioner John L. Rice.

John, the 8-year-old son of Major James P.S. Devereaux, heroic Marine commander of Wake Island, unveiled yesterday the first of several thousand posters that will be used by the United Service Organizations to promote the $32,000,000 War Fund campaign being conducted throughout the country to provide recreation centers for the armed forces.

The City College Administrative Committee of the Board of Higher Education has recommended the appointment of Dr. Harry W. Laidler, former City Councilman from Brooklyn, and Dr. Abram Harris, noted Negro educator and chairman of economics department of Howard University, as guest lectures in economics at the Summer session of City College, it was learned yesterday.

Manufacturers engaged in war production were told yesterday by government officials that the progress and growing needs of the nation's war program had reached a point where the need for iron and steel has become so great as to necessitate the utilization of every bit of steel that industry can produce.

Mayor La Guardia, in his best thespian fashion, last night acted out scornfully a "canned" speech that he said had been sent by "some schlemeel" officially connected with the government's program to conserve gasoline and rubber.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 12 -- Sixteen Hungarian officers attached to the Northwest Hungarian Army Command at Gyor were shot to death last week by a firing squad following conviction of membership in a secret organization that planned elimination of pro-German officers and an attack against Rumania, it was said tonight by foreign military intelligence sources in Istanbul.

Mayor La Guardia gave a $25 war bond to each of the five winners in a school essay contest on "What It Means To Me To Be An American" before a large crowd of parents and teachers at City Hall yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP) -- One rally of four straight singles in the third inning was enough to chase Max Lanier from the mound and give the Phils a 3-2 triumph over the Cardinals today that dropped St. Louis from fourth to fifth place, back of the Reds.

The agreement for the settlement of the claims arising out of Mexico's confiscation four years ago of American- owned oil properties provides ostensibly for the payment by Mexico to the American companies of $24,000,000. This is a sum far short of the value placed by the companies upon their properties.

BUENOS AIRES, May 12 -- Dr. Ramon Castroviejo, New York ophthalmologist, through whose surgical skill it is hoped President Roberto M. Ortiz may recover his eyesight, called on his patient for the first time this afternoon and remained with him about forty-five minutes.

CALCUTTA, India, May 12 -- Drunk with weariness, slogging afoot in both desert dust and the oozy slime of dank teak forests, and swimming muddy, swollen streams, the last companies of the British and Indian armies of Burma are fighting on toward the mountains of Assam in the toughest withdrawal of t..is war.

PATERSON, N.J., May 12 -- A 6-week-old infant, the son of a Bloomingdale, N.J., soldier home on a Mother's Day furlough, died this morning at St. Joseph's Hospital here of injuries which, according to State police reports, were inflicted by the 3-year-old child of a neighboring family.

Hollywood's designers have rolled up their sleeves and set to work designing for the wholesale market of New York. A group of eleven has brought a collection of more than seventy models to this city to be viewed by designers and manufacturers with the thought of giving them inspiration for the Fall mode.

CHUNGKING, China, May 12 (AP) -- The Chinese forces that had been by-passed in Central Burma and last week recaptured Maymo were continuing to exert pressure on the Japanese from the rear, a military spokesman said today. He said the Chinese now were seeking to encircle the Japanese and the Japanese were trying to encircle the Chinese.

An underwriting group headed by Glore, Forgan Co. and Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., will offer to the public today an issue of $15,000,000 of National Distillers Products Corporation seven-year 3 1/4 per cent debentures, due in 1949.

Four seamen, members of the crew of a Swedish ship torpedoed in April off the Atlantic Coast, arrived at La Guardia Field last night aboard a Pan American Airways Clipper commanded by Captain Haakon Dulbran Dulbranson with confirmation of earlier reports that their vessel had been torpedoed by an Italian submarine.

One big inning was all the St. John's University baseball team needed to subdue the New York University nine in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference contest at Dexter Park yesterday. In a game that was fairly evenly contested the rest of the time, the Violet ball tossers fell down in the fifth, committed enough fielding lapses to enable their opponents to score five runs, and the outburst gave the Redmen an 8-3 victory.
The advent of warm days is all too likely to bring in its wake a weary look on the part of city dwellers and commuters.

MOSCOW, May 12 -- German engines of war are lubricated with olive oil, indicating that the Nazis are running low on vital raw materials, Eugene Varga, the Soviet's foremost economist, said in today's edition of the Communist party newspaper Pravda.

BERLIN, May 12 (From German broadcast recorded by Reuter) -- The German news agency, quoting the German High Command, today issued the following account of the sinking of three British destroyers south of Crete yesterday:

A bittel campaign for presidency of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association over the question of retirements and pensions was predicted yesterday as complete slates were drawn up for the election of officers on the second Tuesday in June.
A Japanese naval spokesman in Shanghai asserted yesterday that "bad weather and nothing else" had prevented the Japanese Fleet from achieving a knockout victory in the Battle of the Coral Sea.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 12 -- Major Vidkun Quisling, the Norwegian Nazi-appointed Premier, has been sent to the Eastern Front for an indefinite stay, the Svenska Dagbladet of Stockholm will say tomorrow from Berlin. If this is true it should mean that the German Army has finally won its longstanding fight against the Nazi party to have Premier Quisling removed in order to achieve at least a temporary pacification in Norway.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 12 -- An official spokesman explained today that the Japanese had landed stores and equipment from seaplane tenders on certain islands in the Louisiade Archipelago, but said that thus far that was the extent of their occupation of the archipelago.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The War Production Board today announced adoption of a revised form of application for priority assistance for use in the third quarter of this year which will permit applicants for preference ratings under the Production Requirements Plan to omit a considerable part of the information now required.

LONDON, May 12 -- Malta did not have one airplane when Italy declared war, Air Chief Marshal Sir Arthur Longmore, who commanded the R.A.F. in the Middle East in 1940-41 told the Royal Empire Society in London today.

An exhibition of Canadian pastels by George Wright opened yesterday at the Grand Central (Terminal) Galleries, to remain until May 22. Half of the proceeds from sales will be given to the Maple Leaf Fund -- the same fund that benefited from the recent large Canadian show.

Differing from the plan finally adopted in Canada, furs come within the scope of the general maximum price regulations and the industry here has been practically at a standstill awaiting clarifying rulings from the OPA, particularly the issuance of a supplementary order on seasonal goods not subject to pricing during the March base period, leaders in the industry reported yesterday.

Registrations of out-of-town buyers in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 604, as against 711 in the preceding week and 775 in the like period of 1941, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 227, which compared with 344 for last Tuesday.

Because of the technical information involved, the Army Quartermaster Corps believes that engineering and production staffs rather than salesmen should solicit war orders, although technically competent salesmen, thoroughly familiar with their product, frequently can fill the bill.

The city will save $200,000 a year because of dimouts required by the Army, Patrick Quilty, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, said yesterday. A twenty-minute blackout for all five boroughs will save the city $300 on street, fire-alarm-box and one-way arrow lights.

The maturity of $49,000,000 of bonds next May 1 is an obstacle to the declaration of dividends by the Delaware Hudson Company, J.H. Nuelle, president, said at the annual meeting yesterday. The method of meeting the maturity has to be determined, he added.
The first in a series of clinics on price problems was held for wholesalers yesterday by officials of the Office of Price Administration in the agency's headquarters in the Empire State Building.

LONDON, May 12 -- Business was on a small scale on the Stock Exchange today. The chief feature was a further sharp rise in Argentine rail shares. Dealers found an increasing demand as prices moved up throughout the list. Central Argentine 4 per cent debentures rose 35s to 35 3/4, Buenos Ayres Great Southern 6 per cent 1 to 18 and the ordinary 5s to 8 1/2.

NEWARK, N.J., May 12 -- The first steps in a government effort to bring about the revocation of the naturalization of eight New Jersey residents charged with subversive activities were taken late today by the office of United States District Attorney Charles M. Phillips and the Federal Bureau of Investigation acting under Section 338 of the Naturalization Act of 1940.

The Greater New York War Fund drive of the United Service Organizations seeks $4,450,000 as the community's share of the national campaign for $32,000,000 to provide off-duty social and recreational services to the nation's armed forces.

Everybody knows somebody who once spent a vacation in New Orleans. This vacation may have lasted a day or a month, it may have happened five or fifty years ago -- such details are of no consequence to the former visitor. His memories are multitudinous, and he is willing to give them eloquent expression at any and all times.

TRENTON, N.J., May 12 (AP) -- A forty-nine-day horse-racing season, starting July 18 at the new track of the Garden State Racing Association near Camden, was approved today by the New Jersey Racing Commission.

The German flare-up in South Russia, whether or not it starts the Spring offensive, is the move everybody has been looking for. This is the sector of the eastern front where the Germans gave least ground during their disastrous Winter. On the Crimean peninsula, stepping stone to the Caucasus, they are practically in the same positions they occupied when they were stopped last December.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Reflecting shipment of large quantities to Great Britain and Russia, [cold storage stocks of frozen and cured meats declined 154,700,000 pounds in the last twelve months.

Selective service registrants no longer will need upper teeth to get into the Army and only a sufficient number of lower ones to support a denture, it was disclosed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Dental Society of the State of New York at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LONDON, May 12 -- Three of a group of four British destroyers were sunk by German bombers in the Eastern Mediterranean yesterday afternoon, the Admiralty announced today. They were the Lively of the Lightning class -- one of the largest destroyers afloat - - and the Jackal and Kipling of the Javelin class. All were comparatively new ships, the Lively having been completed in 1940, and two others in 1939.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Retail clothing merchants intend to concentrate more on selling the cuff-less trouser idea than on the usual seasonal and Summer sales of merchandise at lower prices, the monthly survey of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers indicated today.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Price Administrator Leon Henderson today issued an order instructing retailers in methods by which they can establish their ceiling prices for a restricted list of Summer apparel, furniture and certain other warm weather merchandise that was not sold generally in March.

A further decline in the volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly survey of this market. The bank said that in April the volume decreased $5,382,000 to $177,293,000, which is the lowest since last December.

Municipal elections were held in a number of New Jersey communities yesterday. The final tabulations indicated that the voting was light even in municipalities where spirited contests had been expected. Preoccupation of the voters with civilian war duties was reported as the major cause for the voters' apparent lack of interest in this year's contests.

LONDON, May 12 (U.P.) -- An American-made Hudson bomber of the Royal Air Force Coastal Command attacked a German convoy within 200 yards of the Norwegian coast today and left a 10,000-ton ship ablaze and at a standstill after peppering it at low level with bombs and machine guns:
MOSCOW, May 12 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:

Despite possible delays due to priorities, the American Institute of Steel Construction expects to follow custom this year in affixing stainless steel plaques to bridges winning its 1941 awards as the most beautiful spans built of steel in this country.

Reviving traditional dances of the village green, 2,000 girls, chiefly from the Manhattan public schools, presented a program of folk dances yesterday afternoon in the sheep meadow of Central Park in the first of a series of park fetes sponsored by the girls' branch of the Public Schools Athletic League.

LITERARY and publishing coincidences are a frequent occurrence (two biographies of the same person or two travel books about the same remote jungle in one season), but surely never before did two books published within a few weeks of each other ever bear so many striking similarities as Virginia Sorensen's "A Little Lower Than the Angels"* and Elinor Pryor's "And Never Yield."

Coverdale Colpitts, reorganization managers for the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad, announced yesterday that committees for several securities of the company had approved a plan for its reorganization.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The government made available tonight $150,000,000 for the purchase of new and used tires or tubes held by American automobile owners. Secretary Jesse Jones said the money would be provided through the Defense Supplies Corporation, and would supplement the plan already announced to finance to the extent of $75,000,000 the frozen stocks of new passenger tires and tubes held by manufacturers, mass distributors, jobbers and dealers.

LONDON, May 12 -- On the eve of the third year of the formation of Great Britain's Home Guard, Prime Minister Winston Churchill inspected the Westminster Palace section in Speakers' Court. He told them how great was the value of the work they and thousands of others were doing.

While several departments of the government appear to be hostile to advertising, it is regarded as an important adjunct to the sale of goods at Army Post Exchanges, it was stated here yesterday by Major Frank K. Duffy of the New York Quartermaster Corps.

Thirty-five varsity letters and six special medals for outstanding accomplishment were presented to members of New York University's co-ed field hockey, basketball, swimming and fencing teams at a dinner held last night in the Green Room of the university's East Building.

NEWARK, N.J., May 12 -- Louis A. Vierbuchen, motorman of a Hudson Manhattan train that was wrecked in Jersey City on April 26, was pictured here today as having been in a distraught frame of mind before he made the run that culminated in the accident.

Among drivers willing to "ride together" to conserve tires, cars and gasoline, the Automobile Club of New York, Inc., Hotel Pennsylvania, offered yesterday to act without fee as a clearing house in its area for a new "share-the-car" information service.

Eighteen persons have filed claims of kinship to Alexander H. (Uncle Alex) Alexanderoff, "one-man advisory bureau" of the lower East Side, who died on Dec. 12, 1940, and are asserting their rights to share in his estate of $33,433.

At the same time that 8,500,000 motorists of the seventeen Eastern States, including New York City's 900,000, began registering for gasoline rationing yesterday, the Canadian Legation in Washington announced that Canada would reduce the gasoline ration for American tourists entering that country as of Friday when rationing begins here.

ST. LOUIS, May 12 (AP) -- Opening their first Western invasion of the season, the Athletics defeated the Browns today, 5 to 4, with a combination of timely hitting and brilliant pitching in the pinch.
The city of Rochester, N.Y., will be in the market on Friday with an issue of $1,100,000 of notes. The obligations, dated May 20, 1942, will become payable on Jan. 20, 1943.

VICHY, France, May 12 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain on his return from the Riviera today went immediately into conference with Pierre Laval, Chief of Government, reviewing the whole political situation.
BERNE, Switzerland, May 12 (AP) -- The nations that Germany occupies and her satellites provided new turmoil tonight for the Axis architects of the "new order in Europe."

Plans to raise funds for the continuance of the Wiltwyck School for Boys, near Kingston, N.Y., the only institution in the metropolitan area for the treatment of delinquent Negro Protestant boys between the ages of 8 and 12, were drafted yesterday afternoon at a meeting in St. Nicholas Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. "This Gun for Hire," a Paramount melodrama, will be the newcomer at the Paramount. Veronica Lake, Robert Preston, Laird Cregar and Alan Ladd head the film's cast. Albert Maltz and W.R. Burnett wrote the screen play from the novel by Graham Greene.

Reflecting increased sales, which in the first quarter this year rose to $17,428,310 from $13,715,336 in the corresponding period of 1941, the net profit reported yesterday by the Ohio Oil Company and its subsidiaries was more than $1,000,000 ahead of last year.

Reduction in dividend rates yesterday by the directors of a number of prominent companies, and the passing of a dividend by another corporation, were regarded in financial circles as further tokens of what stockholders must expect as a result of the war.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. "This Gun for Hire," a Paramount melodrama, will be the newcomer at the Paramount. Veronica Lake, Robert Preston, Laird Cregar and Alan Ladd head the film's cast. Albert Maltz and W.R. Burnett wrote the screen play from the novel by Graham Greene.

Reflecting increased sales, which in the first quarter this year rose to $17,428,310 from $13,715,336 in the corresponding period of 1941, the net profit reported yesterday by the Ohio Oil Company and its subsidiaries was more than $1,000,000 ahead of last year.

Reduction in dividend rates yesterday by the directors of a number of prominent companies, and the passing of a dividend by another corporation, were regarded in financial circles as further tokens of what stockholders must expect as a result of the war.

Production and shipments of steel by the Granite City Steel Company in the first quarter were affected by a scrap shortage and at one time open-hearth operations were below 50 per cent of capacity, it was disclosed yesterday at the annual meeting of the company in Granite City, Ill., by Hayward Niedringhaus, president.
CHUNGKING, May 12 (U.P.) -- Colonel Claire L. Chennault's "Flying Tigers" were reported strewing destruction through the Japanese columns.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Senate passed by eleven votes today the House-approved Rogers bill to form a woman's Army auxiliary corps for service with the Army. The measure now goes to the White House.

Severe penalties for motorists who make false claims to obtain gasoline ration cards permitting them to buy more gasoline than they merit were threatened yesterday as the distribution of cards continued in the States along the Atlantic seaboard, with increasing indications of public resentment against the rationing system and alleged "discrimination" against the coastal area.

CLEVELAND, May 13 (AP) -- A wartime code requiring the fingerprinting and questioning of all personnel producing and broadcasting foreign language programs was adopted today by the War Committee of the National Association of Broadcasters.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 13 -- The present lull in the Southwest Pacific area is not expected to last long. Japanese naval units that participated in the Battle of the Coral Sea have retired to islands north of Australia, apparently to await reinforcements in warships, aircraft carriers and planes from other theatres of war.
HAVANA, May 13 -- The Senate this afternoon approved a motion requesting that the government give that body complete information concerning political refugees who have entered Cuba in 1941 and 1942.

ST. LOUIS, May 13 (AP) -- The Athletics moved into fifth place in the American League today by defeating the Browns, 10 to 9, in a struggle featuring twenty-eight hits and seven errors. Ten pitchers paraded to the mound, six for St. Louis and four for Philadelphia.

"France will be drawn by opportunist Laval into combatant warfare against the Allies unless the United States finds some way to bring aid and moral support to the organized workers of France, who form the strongest opposition to Fascist control of that country," Pierre Cot, former Air Minister of France, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Roosevelt today mixed good news on the battle of the Coral Sea and mounting United States war production figures with a stern lecture to members of the Pacific War Council against "loose talk" that is providing "information of real value to the enemy."

"Sing Your Worries Away," which arrives at the Palace, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The RKO comedy with music includes Bert Lahr, Buddy Ebsen, June Havoc, Dorothy Lovett, Sam Levene and Patsy Kelly in its cast. "To the Shores of Tripoli" is the associate picture on the double-feature program.

New York City's Law Department, often called the world's largest law office, was operated last year at $600,000 less than its 1932 budget, Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler told the city Council Finance Committee at City Hall yesterday.

TRENTON, May 13 -- Retail prices of foods in New Jersey last month rose 4.99 per cent over March, according to the monthly summary of the State Department of Agriculture issued today. The increase was the largest reported in two consecutive months since the wave of buying at the outbreak of the war in Europe in September, 1939.
CHICAGO, May, 13 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis today notified the American and National Leagues that the player limit deadline has been extended to May 25 as a war measure.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 13 -- Foreign Minister Ernesto Barros Jarpa attended a secret session of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee this evening to explain "new points of view of the Chilean Foreign Office."

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Housewife "nutrition wardens" with the war-time task of telling their neighbors about coming "Victory food specials" was the solution for the problem of scattered food surpluses agreed upon today by nearly one hundred food trade representatives meeting under the auspices of the Department of Agriculture.

The bay colt Bright Willie, who came to fame in Florida, was a decisive winner yesterday after being made a 7-to-10 favorite by 15,067 racegoers at Belmont Park. In the forty-second Swift Stakes, grossing $8,575 and netting Mrs. Ralph McIlvain $6,825, the 3-year-old son of Brilliant and Sweet Face had two lengths to spare at the end of the seven furlongs run in 1:24 flat over a fast track.

The cotton futures market made slight gains yesterday on light trade buying. Active months on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 1 to 4 points above Tuesday's final prices. Trading was thin and hesitant as Congressional action on agricultural price ceilings is awaited.
CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- Myril Hoag's tenth inning single today scored Joe Kuhel and gave the White Sox a 2-to-1 victory over the Red Sox.

Ignoring Mayor La Guardia's feud with the press at City Hall, the Municipal Civil Service Commission appealed to the newspapers yesterday to give publicity to its acute need for candidates for the forthcoming patrolmen's examination because the number of applicants is smaller than at any time in the last twenty years.

A BRITISH PORT, Thursday, May 14 (AP) -- Thousands of reinforcements for Canada's land and air forces overseas have arrived safely in Britain to join the United Nations military machine being assembled for an offensive against the Axis.

The report of the American Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses, taxes and other charges, of $8,813,689, compared with $11,524,426 in the twelve months to Feb. 28, 1941.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Recruiting for the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps may get started "within a few weeks," it was indicated today by Representative Edith Nourse Rogers, sponsor of the legislative measure to establish the corps, which passed the Senate yesterday, and now is awaiting Presidential signature.

NEW ORLEANS, May 13 -- National policy and exploitation were held to account for "the economic condition and backwardness of the South" in an address before the National Conference of Social Work tonight by Mark Ethridge, vice president and general manager of The Louisville Courier-Journal, who said a united nation "must be a democracy based on economic justice as well as civil rights."

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Members of the Senate Banking Committee disclosed today that they had recommended that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation be empowered to subsidize businesses which might be caught in a "squeeze" between price ceilings and rising costs.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- While many private citizens in the Eastern States continued to argue with ration boards today for the issuance of X cards entitling them to unlimited quantities of gasoline, members of Congress pushed their own claims to them in a series of resentful speeches on the floor of the House.

Voting at the same time that Senators in Washington were passing a bill to enlist women in the Army, undergraduates at Hunter College declared yesterday in favor of compulsory military service for women. Six hundred and sixty-four girls cast ballots in a poll of all four classes at both day and evening sessions.

Dissatisfaction with the manner in which the War Shipping Administration is handling the freight forwarding industry, despite passage of the Bland act guaranteeing its participation in the movement of lease-lend and other government cargoes, was evidenced yesterday with the disclosure that the New York Foreign Freight Forwarders and Brokers Association has sent a letter of protest to M.L. Wilcox, the administration's director of operations.

NEWARK, N.J., May 13 -- The proportion of A ration cards being distributed to nonessential motorists in Northern New Jersey counties is short of the 33 to 44 per cent estimated by the Office of Price Administration, it was indicated in a survey made here this evening by Eugene Colgan, State representative of the Fuel Rationing Section of the OPA.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters in Manhattan was William F. Zimmerli, vice president of the General Aniline and Film Company, who leased an apartment in 290 Park Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.

Roy Talcott, Princeton's and the Eastern Intercollegiate League's leading pitcher, now owns six victories and one defeat in league competition, but he watched the end of yesterday's game with Columbia at Baker Field from the bench.

NEWARK, N.J., May 13 -- Conflicting testimony on the sobriety of Louis A. Vierbuchen, motorman of the Hudson Manhattan train that was wrecked April 26 in Jersey City, was presented here today at the final session of a hearing before the State Board of Public Utilities Commissioners.

Mrs. Pasquale di Cicco, the former Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, applied through Thomas B. Gilchrist, her general guardian, to Surrogate James A. Foley yesterday for permission to withdraw from her estate $1,500 to pay extraordinary expenses incurred in establishing a home in Manhattan, Kan.

Sydney Hogerton, district manager, priorities field service of OPA, will analyze Order M-126, forcing ultimate shutdown in production of some 400 iron and steel products, next Wednesday in the assembly room of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

HAVANA, May 13 (AP) -- Sugar money -- more than $150,000,000 of it -- began flowing today to mill owners as funds were advanced by the Defense Supplies Corporation of the United States for sugar now in warehouses.

In Fort Worth, Texas, women are busily breaking eggs by the dozens. Not only are they getting paid for it, but the wholesale carnage is considered a contribution to the war program. At the Fort Worth Poultry and Egg Company 200 women are engaged in the various processes of egg dehydration.

The prosecution of modern warfare imposes ever-increasing hardships on most individuals. This is so generally recognized that I think the public is accepting inevitable privations in very good spirit.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- After omitting the January-February bargain "flyer" because of shortages and rising merchandise prices, Montgomery Ward Co. has returned in earnest to the mail order custom of seasonal sales, examination of the 164-page "Summer book" of the house showed today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 13 -- Kenneth W. Morgan, who says he is a disciple of Gandhi and that he lived in India as a Hindu priest, was en route today to New Hampshire where he will become director of a Quaker work camp for conscientious objectors.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The House of Representatives today approved the addition of 536 appointees to the Corps of Cadets at the Military Academy at West Point, but not until it had made its control over the new appointments secure.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- An impression prevailed here today that the diplomatic communication sent to the American Government by Pierre Laval in regard to the American proposals for altering the status of Martinique, Guadeloupe and French Guiana might foreshadow an agreement through negotiation with Admiral Georges Robert, French High Commissioner at Martinique.

A total of 8,096,977 Bibles, Testaments and books of the Bible were distributed by the American Bible Society in 1941, according to its 126th annual report, to be given at 3 P.M. today at the annual meeting at Bible House, Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street.

Referring to the letter of P.T. Fisher suggesting that the Public Library should not circulate contemporary German literature, I bring to your attention some examples of the great service which the Public Library does to the war effort.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., May 13 -- Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. was endorsed for renomination by thirty of the forty members of the Newburgh Republican City Committee at its convention tonight at the Newburgh Court House. Nine votes were cast for Augustus W. Bennet, Newburgh attorney, and one member of the committee was absent.

While the ticket sale for their fifteen-round title bout in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night continued at a brisk clip, Allie Stolz and the world lightweight champion, Sammy Angott, concluded their training yesterday.

The maximum penalty for violation of a Park Department regulation was imposed yesterday by Magistrate Robert Levis in Bronx Magistrates Court when he fined two 18-year-old girls $50 or ten days in jail for picking tulips from the vast bed surrounding the Pelham War Memorial Monument in Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx.

BOSTON, May 13 -- Jim Tobin, the veteran right-hander, set a new major league home-run record for pitchers today by blasting three consecutive circuit drives that accounted for four runs while hurling the Braves to a 6-5 victory over the Cubs.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 13 -- Doubling up on transportation to and from the club in deference to gas and tire rationing, twenty-nine women of the Long Island Golf Association competed over the well-groomed links bordering Lake Success on the Deepdale course today.

The current Selective Service plan, whereby men are called for induction after superficial medical scrutiny at local boards and then are sent to Army posts for physical examination, has not speeded delivery of recruits. It gives registrants no time to settle home and business matters.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The heroic handling of a little minesweeper from the outbreak of the war in the Philippines until the fall of Corregidor early this month was recounted by the Navy today in connection with the award of a Navy Cross to its commander, now presumably a prisoner, with his crew, of the Japanese.

CANBERRA, Australia, May 13 -- Leader of the Opposition A.W. Fadden today moved that the House of Representatives discuss the "premature disclosure of the government's policy of rationing clothing." The motion claimed that the government failed to protect the interests of the public and trading community and that its action adversely affected wartime finance.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 13 (AP) -- The Chicago Budweisers won the five-man title and Ed Nowicki and George Baier of Milwaukee took the doubles laurels of the 1942 American bowling congress tournament. The seventy-two-day event ended tonight.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 13 -- Your correspondent has been with the Free French in the Near East for many days. He has fed at their messes, has been among their personnel, both officers and men, in camps and aboard warships, and has found as before the same spirited determination to fight until an Allied victory rids the homeland of the hated "boche."
HANOVER, N.H., May 13 -- Dartmouth had two high-scoring innings today and routed the University of Pennsylvania, 9 -- 4, in an Eastern League contest.

Three white men, whom he knew only as "Fats," "Chink," and "Jimmy," ordered the assassination nearly ten years ago of Patrolman Michael J. Moroso, shot and killed Dec. 8, 1932, while he was walking his post in Harlem, a witness testified yesterday at the General Sessions trial of two Negroes accused of the murder.

FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT, Winter resident of Warn Springs, said he liked Georgia because it was not a finished State. And Hal Steed, an irreverent and most unprofessional Southerner, has made use of the Presidential description in titling his "Georgia: Unfinished State,"* which is as delightful and juicy a contribution to the newer regionalism as any we have had.

Frankie Frisch tried to pry an extra run loose from Umpire Beans Reardon during a three-run Pirate uprising in the seventh inning of the fray with the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday. However, the conversational approach of the Flash was hardly a model of diplomacy. So he lost the debate and the run -- but not the ball game.

In a setting of medieval splendor, the first solemn pontifical mass before the new liturgical altar was celebrated yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral. It marked the silver jubilee of the episcopal consecration of Pope Pius XII by Pope Benedict XV on May 13, 1917.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Assistant Attorney General Thurman Arnold told the Senate Patents Committee today that the Department of Justice had bowed to the War Department in agreeing to postpone trial of two anti-trust suits against the General Electric Company.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday that it had written to Mayor La Guardia and Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, asking further action in the case involving use of city paving blocks and labor, subsequently paid for, on the country estate of Edward J. Flynn, National Democratic Chairman.

The nine-room Georgian colonial style home at 27 Earlwood Drive, White Plains, Westchester County, has been sold by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., to Rudolf Goldschmidt through Howard L. Auerbach, Inc., and Prince Ripley, Inc., agents.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today reported to the members of the federation's executive council that figures on war production, as supplied by governmental agencies and labor unions, revealed "amazing increases in the output of planes, ships, guns, tanks and ammunition since Dec. 7."

The five-story apartment, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, containing twenty apartments at 987 Trinity Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the 987 Trinity Avenue Corporation to a client of Williamson Bryan, brokers, for cash above a first mortgage of $36,400.

TRENTON, May 13 -- The seven-man Commission on Revision of the New Jersey Constitution, which was appointed last November, announced today it would make a unanimous report to the Governor and Legislature next Monday, recommending a new Constitution with a "comprehensive and complete" rewriting of the State's 98-year-old basic law.

The eleven prize-winning paintings and drawings from Life's art competition for men of the armed forces will have their first public showing at the National Gallery of Art in Washington on July 3. They will remain on view for three weeks. The competition was announced in March and closed on May 4.

CLEVELAND, May 13 -- Because the Indians developed a penchant for banging drives just short of their reach or bouncing them over their heads, the Yankees had their winning streak snapped today at League Park after seven in a row. Lou Boudreau's second-place squad crept to within half a game of the world champions.

Compulsory State-wide registration of girls and women between the ages of 16 and 30 and boys between 16 and 20, for home-front war work, was urged yesterday by Dorothy Thompson, chairman of United Youth for Victory.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 13 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force announced today that British fighters had shot down thirteen Junkers planes of the troop-carrying type, along with two escorting Messerschmitt craft.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Approval by the Senate Appropriations Committee of a measure which would permit the sale of 125,000,000 bushels of cash wheat for feed or industrial purposes below parity prices threw the grain markets into confusion on the Board of Trade today, as well as having a weakening effect on the high-protein feed markets.

Five persons were hurt and several hundred persons were driven from near-by offices and factories when a fire swept the two upper floors of a seven-story building at 133 West Twenty-fourth Street yesterday afternoon. The injured were two firemen and three auxiliary firemen.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Joseph B. Eastman, transportation director, announced today that railroad labor and management had agreed to use all available railroad shop facilities in production of war materials, with labor working a forty-eight-hour week at basic railroad shop pay.

Boys and girls of the Children's Aid Society donned overalls and straw hats, shouldered hoes, rakes and shovels and marched up to the roof of the society's West Side Center at 419 West Thirty-eighth Street yesterday morning. They were supposed to be the vanguard of a small army of gardeners bent on planting only vegetable seeds to help swell the city's food supply.

LONDON, May 13 -- Germany would be ill-prepared to cope with a gas attack launched by the British and may, therefore, ponder a long time before setting the precedent for this kind of warfare, according to opinion here.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 -- A wage scale ranging from $8 a month for unskilled labor to $16 for professional persons was established today for Japanese evacuees from the Far West's military area No. 1, who are being moved into assembly, reception and resettlement centers.

The gratitude felt by many torpedoed seamen, members of the National Maritime Union, for the treatment they have received from the crews of British ships that picked them up was expressed yesterday by Joseph Curran, president of the N.M.U., in a letter to Sir Ashley Sparks, United States representative of the British Ministry of War Transport.

Arthur L. Garniss, executive vice president of the New York Council on Retail Trade Diversion, said yesterday that New York City consumers are losing $25,000,000 a year because of deceptive or misleading practices in trade diversion.
Arthur Woods did admirably whatever he did, in business or in his various public service. He bad rare gifts, a fine and friendly nature.
ROCHESTER, May 13 (AP) -- The Newark Bears scored their sixth consecutive victory of the season over the Rochester Red Wings tonight, 10 to 4.

The Japanese are still claiming victory in the Coral Sea battle and their Emperor formally congratulates the navy on its glorious feat. There is no occasion for wonder. It is consistent with Japanese practice. In the first two years of the war with China, Japan announced the complete annihilation of the Chinese armies more often than Hitler did Russia's last Autumn.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 13 -- Westchester County motorists who made false statements to ration boards in obtaining Class X gasoline ration cards will be detected through investigations of their sworn statements and the guilty motorists will be made to "walk the plank" in criminal prosecutions, Leslie V. Bateman, county rationing administrator, said today.

All things considered, bookings for Peconic Bay weakfishing parties on Saturday and Sunday are good. The boat captains, of course, have not been swamped with requests and there does not appear to be any danger that they will be unable to handle all business.
