OTTAWA, May 13 -- A second ship was torpedoed and sunk in the St. Lawrence River on Monday at about the some time and same locality as the one announced yesterday, Navy Minister Angus L. Macdonald declared in Parliament this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Thomas F. Meaney, whose appointment as a United States district judge in Jersey City had been assailed on the ground that he was "only a cog" in the Hague machine and would be "a puppet judge," told a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today that in sixteen years on the bench no charge of favoritism had ever been brought against him.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The War Production Board today put into effect its first example of what it called "concentration of production" by ordering an end to the manufacture of domestic cooking and heating appliances by all large manufacturers, effective July 31, and permitting the production of a limited number of simplified and lightweight models by smaller companies for civilian use.
MOSCOW, May 13 -- Tonight's reports of the operations on the Kerch Peninsula indicate that the battle for the side door to the Caucasus is developing.

BERLIN, May 13 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- German and Rumanian troops have broken a fortified Soviet line across the neck of the Kerch peninsula in the Crimea, capturing 40,000 prisoners and annihilating encircled groups of Red Army soldiers, the Germans announced tonight.

DETROIT, May 13 (AP) -- The Tigers squared accounts with their former teammate, Bobo Newsom, by blasting him today for nine hits in seven innings that led to a 6-to-2 victory over the Senators. Hal Newhouser yielded three hits.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, May 14 -- United Nations bombers or a 1,300-mile round-trip above Austraha last night sank a Japanese ship and set a fire two others in an attack on Amboina Island, site of a Netherlands Indiesnavali base now in Japanese hands.
LONDON, May 13 -- For the second day in succession South American rails were the best feature in the stock market. There were further rises of 5s to 15s in Argentine debenture and preference stocks.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has sold to the Dasosa Investment Corporation of Jersey City the four-story flat with a store at 4206 New York Avenue, Union City, and the six-family flat at 76 Arlington Avenue, Jersey City, to John Shpunder.
Appointment of Dr. Homer W. Davis, president of Athens College in Greece, as executive director of the Greek War Relief Association was announced yesterday at its office in 730 Fifth Avenue.
MOSCOW, Thursday, May 14 (AP) -- The midnight Soviet communique follows:

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Manuel Quezon, refugee President of the Philippines, arrived in Washington today to establish a provisional commonwealth government and was greeted by President Roosevelt, Secretary Hull and five former Governors General or High Commissioners of the Philippines.

ALBANY, May 13 -- Dr. Maurice F. Neufeld, State director of ra tioning, is expected to be appointed soon as executive assistant to Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti in the State War Council. Lieut. Gov. Poletti is State Coordinator of Defense Activities and vice chairman of the War Council.
Mussolini, who used to figure as a jackal and other displeasing characters in earlier Winston Churchill speeches, became, in the Prime Minister's latest compliments, merely an Italian miscalculator.

Hitler moves at last in the direction in which he is forced to move. As the Spring developed, a variety of reasons may have held the German armies in a state of suspended motion -- the weather, increasing difficulties in filling the ranks and gathering supplies, the old stratagem of keeping the world guessing.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The Office of Petroleum Coordinator declined today to recommend inclusion of Central New York in the area exempt from gasoline rationing. At the same time the office served notice that the exempt area, in five Eastern States, may be reduced within a short time.

More general recognition was accorded yesterday to the increasing number of cuts in dividends, to the tightening domestic economic restrictions and to the cloudy war news, with the result that stocks were sold in sufficient quantities to cause losses of as much as 2 points.

A plan for drastic recapitalization of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company, a subsidiary of the Engineers Public Service Company, involving over-all corporate simplification, redistribution of voting rights and a large refunding operation, was announced last night by D.C. Barnes, president of Engineers Public Service.

The first night baseball game in the metropolitan area since talk of banning nocturnal play arose will be played at Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City at 8:45 tonight when the Little Giants clash with the Baltimore Orioles.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 13 -- Gasoline stocks in Hudson County are threatened with exhaustion before the introduction of rationing, it was disclosed today by Perry Weinstein, president of the Hudson County Gasoline Dealers Association and a special assistant deputy to James B. Clark, County Rationing Administrator.

LONDON, May 13 -- A reinforced Japanese Army moving eastward over the Burma Road is reported by Chungking to be striking toward Yungchang with Lungling, some fifty miles inside China, as the operations base.
BERLIN, May 13 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Adolf Hitler's headquarters issued the following communique today:

Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan denied yesterday a motion by stockholders of Paramount Pictures, Inc., for an inspection of the books and records of the corporation in connection with the stockholders' accounting suit for recovery from directors of moneys paid by the corporation to George Browne and William Bioff, former officers of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The House by a 331-28 record vote today stood by its decision to increase the pay of Army and Marine Corps privates and Navy and Coast Guard apprentice seamen to $50 a month, and that of first class privates and second class seamen to $54, the rate now received by corporals and seamen, first class.

Retailers in most cases will be able to obtain last year's mark-up on the average cost of Summer merchandise, but face a mark-up "squeeze" on replacement purchases of seasonal goods, according to interpretations yesterday of the seasonal order governing retailers issued by the OPA.
KUNMING, China, May 13 (U.P.) -- Two young American aviators were credited today with helping break a Japanese offensive against Yunnan Province by a daring attack May 8 on an enemy truck column.

A sparkling two-hit pitching performance by the veteran Curt Davis, who faced only thirty-one batters, paced the Dodgers to a 4-0 triumph over the Reds at Ebbets Field yesterday. With his side-arm curves baffling the opposition, the long and lean right-hander retired the last nineteen men in order and, except for one inning, was never threatened.

Miss Smitty White, 29 years old, whose male companion was shot and killed by a policeman as they were standing in a doorway next to an automobile school they allegedly had attempted to hold-up, went on trial yesterday in Kings County Court before Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz on charges of assault and attempted robbery.

Motorists who are planning to carry an extra supply of gasoline on long trips as insurance against becoming stranded in an area where they can buy no gasoline were cautioned yesterday by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh and W.E. Mallalieu of the National Board of Fire Underwriters that they may be courting disaster.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- An annual farm fund measure, carrying some $865,000,000 of cash and loans, emerged from the Senate Appropriation Committee today and headed for a series of disputes on the Senate floor, probably starting tomorrow.

Seven of the foremost American authors now writing books of wartime interest were assembled last night on the stage of the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, for an open panel discussion of the thesis of the Council on Books in Wartime: "that books, are weapons in the war of ideas."
MOSCOW, May 13 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique:

The Office of Price Administration is contemplating a delay until June 15 of application of the general maximum price regulations to government contracts, scheduled to become effective on Monday, it was reported yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel Commodore, attended by manufacturers and distributors in the industrial machinery, agricultural machinery, transportation equipment and electrical product industries.

Failure of the Federal Government to keep the public informed on national problems and policies through its publications is charged by Dr. LeRoy C. Merritt, member of the public documents committee of the American Library Association, in a study entitled "The United States Government as Publisher" (American Council on Public Affairs).

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The electric power industry will spend $1,069,309,387 in 1942 on the expansion of its facilities -- $200,000,000, or 23 per cent, more than in 1941 -- it was reported today by the Federal Power Commission.

As the small electrical appliance industry approaches its manufacturing wind-up at the end of this month, sales by distributors continue to show substantial gains over last year. Figures now coming in reveal that April continued to be an excellent month with dollar volume in many cases running as much as 50 per cent over the like 1941 month.

Eighteen thousand bottles of rare wines, liquors, beers and mineral waters that once formed part of the transatlantic stores of the liner Normandie will be offered at a public auction on May 26 at the United States Appraiser's Stores, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Ways and Means Committee voted entatively today to lower income tax exemptions for married couples from $1,500 to $1,200, and for single persons from $750 to $500. No change was made in the $400 exemption for dependents. The committee was reported to have voted 17 to 7.

The greatest medical, dental and surgical rehabilitation program in our history, which will vastly increase the fighting forces of the Army of Democracy will get into swing throughout the country by Summer, it was revealed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Dental Society of the State of New York at the Hotel Pennsylvania by Commander C. Raymond Wells, U.S.N., chief dental officer, medical division of the Selective Service System, Washington.

Independent gasoline dealers of New York and Long Island, meeting last night at the Hotel New Yorker for a discussion out of which it had been reported that a strike against rationing might develop, contended themselves instead with adopting a resolution protesting certain features of the government curtailment program.

OSAGE, W. Va., May 13 (AP) -- With the bodies of forty-five explosion victims recovered and eleven still to be found, rescue workers toiled tonight clearing away debris hiding the remaining men believed to have been trapped in the Christopher Coal Company's big No. 3 mine.

The reaction of some car owners to gasoline rationing is anything but creditable to them. They are said to be testifying falsely in order to obtain preference rations above the three-gallon weekly minimum. There has also been a good deal of reckless waste of existing supplies.
VICHY, France, May 13 -- Pierre Laval today addressed to the United States Government the French reply to American demands on the status of the French West Indies, it was announced here today.

NEW DELHI, India, Thursday, May 14 (U.P.) -- American and British fliers, ranging over a 1,000-mile front from Eastern Burma to French Indo-China, have blasted huge craters in runways and wrecked upwards of fifty aircraft in raids on three of Japan's principal airdromes in Southern Asia, United Nations communiques revealed today.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 13 -- "Whatever may be the issue of the war, everything tends to show that the United States will come out of it in full possession of its power." This sentence in an editorial in the Gazette de Lausanne this morning is considered by competent observers to hold the key to the situation in Europe today, all propaganda to the contrary notwithstanding.

None of us is wise enough to know exactly what problems we shall face when the need for war production ends. But it is certain that whether we face contraction or expansion, we shall meet the test more successfully if we have utilized a portion of our wartime income to reduce private debt.

Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline in the United States at the close of last week amounted to 100,650,000 barrels, a decrease of 726,000 from the 101,376,000 reported a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago these stocks amounted to 95,150,000 barrels.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 13 (AP) -- Royal Air Force Middle East Headquarters issued the following communique today:

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 13 (AP) -- The Bisons today notched their sixth triumph in seven starts at home as they trounced Jersey City, 17 -- 5. Ed Kobesky drove in six Buffalo tallies on a homer and two singles and drew two walks.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 13 -- Out here in the breezy, prosperous Middle West, the factories have done an impressive job in converting from production of the commonplace articles of peacetime into feeders for the arsenal of democracy.
LONDON, May 13 (AP) -- The Free French will assist the British in administering Madagascar, the Foreign Office announced tonight.

The entire face of the teeming borough of Brooklyn, with its pronounced "chin" jutting into the Atlantic like a challenge to sea-borne invaders, went dark between 9:30 and 9:50 o'clock last night in one of the most important blackout demonstrations here so far.

Eleven octogenarians, members of the Columbia College class of '82, were guests last night of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, who turned 80 last month. The occasion was their sixtieth anniversary dinner, held in Dr. Butler's home at 60 Morningside Drive.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, announced late today that he had accepted an offer by the banking and securities business to make a coordinated effort to distribute war securities. As a result, "Victory Fund Committees" will be set up in each Federal Reserve district, composed of bankers and securities dealers.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 13 -- Holy Cross defeated Yale, 14 to 4, at baseball today. The Crusaders amassed sixteen hits off two Eli twirlers, Neville and Hart. Kev Mulcahy led the attack with a home run and three singles.

Twelve men, comprising one of several groups sent to "war college" at Amherst, Mass., have completed their intensive ten-day course in civilian defense work and will soon conduct classes for local groups, it was announced yesterday by the office of the Second Civilian Defense Corps Region at 111 Eighth Avenue.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, May 14 -- Admitting that the first round of Adolf Hitler's Spring offensive had gone to the adversary, the Russian High Command announced early this morning that Soviet troops, "opposing numerically superior forces" on the Kerch Peninsula in the Crimea, had fallen back to new positions, from which they were fighting an intensive rear-guard action.

The WPA central kitchen that will figure in the mass-feeding of New Yorkers in case of a war emergency, according to a recent announcement in Washington by F.H. Dryden, acting commissioner of work projects, is in a three-story former candy factory at 40-24 Twenty-fourth Street, Long Island City.

Oscar of the Waldorf, now in his forty-ninth year as host at the hotel, was guest of honor at a testimonial dinner given in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night and attended by men and women prominent in civic and social fields.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- If the Ways and Means Committee's decision to slash individual income tax exemptions becomes law, millions of new taxpayers will go to the collection windows -- starting with the single man who earns about $10 a week.

The cost of the war must be paid for out of the American standard of living or the country will be faced with the "most terrific inflation of currency the world has ever seen," Thomas E. Dewey said yesterday in addressing clerical and lay delegates to the 159th annual diocesan convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 13 -- Augusta B. Weller, Nassau County Rationing Administrator, said today at his office in Merrick that he had receeived reports that numerous misstatements have been discovered in the applications for gasoline rationing cards that had been filed in the county yesterday.

PAUSING between jumps on the golf tournament and exhibition circuit, Fred Corcoran, the genial P.G.A. tournament manager, remarked that golf probably would produce more revenue for the various war fund chests than any other sport. Apparently he hadn't heard that racing had promised to deliver $2,000,000 this year.

The relation between men and management is the most important factor susceptible of improvement or deterioration in the drive to produce more and still more war goods, Eli L. Oliver, chief of the labor relations branch of the War Production Board's labor division, declared yesterday.

A ST. LAWRENCE RIVER PORT, Canada, May 13 (AP) -Fourteen crew members from one of the two ships sunk by torpedoes from enemy submarines in the St. Lawrence River were reported dead or missing tonight.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 13 -- Governor Rexford G. Tugwell of Puerto Rico signed today the recently passed legislative bill making the tax on re-exported petroleum products retroactive twelve years. The new law will end losses to the insular treasury from the making of refunds to oil companies on products re-exported from Puerto Rico for consumption elsewhere.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 13 -- An article in the Berner Tagblatt attributed to a volunteer in the "French Legion Against Bolshevism" describes this anti-Soviet force as composed of 70 per cent mere tramps with nothing better to do and 20 per cent professional soldiers, while the remainder are "idealists" who had gone through the Spanish campaign against the Republicans.

Now that the repertoire of food-in-tins is becoming a bit on the limited side, we hear that a back-to-the-kitchen movement has started. American women, rumor has it, are gradually modifying their technique. Can openers are beginning to give way to all sorts of old-fashioned devices -- rolling pins and pastry boards, mixing bowls and huge wooden spoons.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Army indicated today that it proposed to enlist college students 18 years of age and over, but to permit them to remain in school until graduation or their service in the Army was necessary.

There is no shortage of paper now and none is impending, Richard J. Cullen, president of International Paper Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders at 220 East Forty-second Street yesterday morning, the first to be held in this city in the history of this company and its predecessors.

Miss Madeline Webb, the former model on trial with two men for the murder of Mrs. Susie Flora Reich, was identified yesterday by a woman witness as the person who three or four days before the killing put in a telephone call to the victim.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Germany is carrying on her submarine campaign in the Western Atlantic with undersea craft having a cruising range of more than 15,000 miles and capable of two-month cruiises. This was reported in reliable circles today as the second sinking in the St. Lawrence River led to concern in official circles that a new general German attack on North Atlantic supply routes might be getting under way.

Not a single transaction in government bonds was made yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. While this development is not so startling as it might seem to be when it is realized that the sale of government issues on the Exchange of late had been exceedingly light, sometimes dwindling to a turnover of one bond, it did, nevertheless, set statisticians to work delving into the records to find a precedent.

Anastase A. Vonsiatsky was cited by a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent yesterday as the founder of a Russian National Revolutionary party that allegedly has for its purpose the organizing of "a military expedition in conjunction with the Japanese and German Governments against the present Russian Government."
In an editorial entitled "Revolt in the Balkans." in the May 9 issue of THE TIMES, Finland was mentioned among the European nations in which "unrest is stirring."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 13 -- Ballots for the election of officers of the Westchester League of Women Voters, with Mrs. William J. Kelley of Scarsdale as nominee for president, were distributed to league members today by the nominating committee of the organization.
A loft building, apartment houses and a warehouse were among properties that figured in realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.

The Girl Scout Council of Greater New York announced yesterday that non-members of Scout ages would be received at its regular Summer camps this year "in furtherance of the announced purpose to permit others outside its membership to make use of its Summer camping facilities."

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- Securities of an aggregate value of $230,027,000 were underwritten by 144 investment banking firms in the first quarter of 1942, according to an analysis made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 13 -- After two years and a half of occupation, characterized by repression by German troops and five kinds of police, the situation in Poland has apparently become so tense for the Germans that a decree has ordered the immediate arming of all German civilians between the ages of 16 and 65.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries has in the three months ended with March a net profit of $8,071,966 after all charges, according to a report yesterday by Robert C. Stanley, chairman and president.
PHILADELPHIA, May 13 (AP) -- Held scoreless in twenty of their previous twenty-nine innings, the Cardinals slammed fifteen hits today to wallop the Phils, 9 to 1, and end a four-game losing streak.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Governor Lehman has some logic on his side in his refusal to supersede Bronx County District Attorney Foley in the famous paving-block case. He points out, with reason, that Mr. Foley gave the grand jury all the evidence it needed. There were 1,500 pages of this evidence, and one has only to read the presentment to feel sure that the jury knew exactly what had been going on.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Forced mass evacuations of aliens from the Eastern seaboard, resulting in economic dislocations, confusion and injustices to many thousands, are imminent unless President Roosevelt reviews "immediately" his authorization prescribing military areas.

Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the trust division of the Department of Justice, was challenged to proceed with an anti-trust action he instituted against Pullman, Inc., in a statement issued yesterday by D.A. Crawford, president of the company.

Beginning today, stars of all the plays and musical shows performing on and off Broadway will make appeals during intermissions for contributions to Army and Navy Emergency Relief, and ushers will take up collections. These funds, of course, will go to families of soldiers and sailors killed or disabled in action.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Chairman Vinson of the House Naval Committee today demanded an inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into subcontract bidding practices relative to work at the Cramp Shipbuilding Yard in Philadelphia "to see whether a conspiracy exists."

Declaring that housing conditions in a large part of Harlem were "a public disgrace," Justice Stephen S. Jackson of the Domestic Relations Court asked the City Planning Commission yesterday to provide new housing in that section as part of its $628,000,000 program of post-war construction.

The two-story dwelling at 69-11 Seventy-fifth Street, Middle Village, Queens, has been sold by John Klein to Anita Breiter and Sally Cipkin. This structure is on a plot 25 by 100 feet. Paul Rubin was the broker. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

Mayor La Guardia, attending ceremonies in the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn, 555 Prospect Place, honoring sixty-eight members of the hospital staff now serving with the armed forces, said yesterday that the United States had entered this war better prepared medically than it did the last World War.
VATICAN CITY, May 13 (From Vatican broadcast) -- Excerpts from the official English translation of today's address by Pope Pius XII follow:

New York State has exceeded the quota in war savings bonds and stamps assigned by the Federal Reserve System for the current campaign and will remain at the advanced figure of 20 per cent of nation-wide sales, Colonel Richard C. Patterson, chairman of the Defense Savings Committee for New York, declared yesterday.

A cooperative effort to emphasize the advantages of living in Manhattan will be sponsored by an organization to be known as the Live in Manhattan Committee, which has been formed by real estate interests and has opened offices at 136 East Fifty-seventh Street.

LONDON, May 13 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal and Leader of the House of Commons, announced in the Commons today that a decision on fuel rationing, which involves further debate, had been postponed until after May 24, but made a suggestion, disturbing to some elements, that the whole question of production would then be considered.

New York State has exceeded the quota in war savings bonds and stamps assigned by the Federal Reserve System for the current campaign and will remain at the advanced figure of 20 per cent of nation-wide sales, Colonel Richard C. Patterson, chairman of the Defense Savings Committee for New York, declared yesterday.

A cooperative effort to emphasize the advantages of living in Manhattan will be sponsored by an organization to be known as the Live in Manhattan Committee, which has been formed by real estate interests and has opened offices at 136 East Fifty-seventh Street.

LONDON, May 13 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal and Leader of the House of Commons, announced in the Commons today that a decision on fuel rationing, which involves further debate, had been postponed until after May 24, but made a suggestion, disturbing to some elements, that the whole question of production would then be considered.

The $4,500,000 aluminum reducing plant to be built in Maspeth for the Aluminum Corporation of America, with funds made available by the Defense Plant Corporation, will cover ninety acres bounded by Grand Avenue, Page Place, Fifty-sixth Road and Maspeth Creek, according to building plans filed yesterday at the Queens Borough Hall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 13 -- Bette Davis will play the feminine lead in the screen version of Lillian Hellman's "Watch on the Rhine," Warner Brothers announced today. Ann Harding previously had been mentioned for the assignment. Dashiell Hammett and Miss Hellman are now adapting the anti-Nazi drama to the screen, and Herman Shumlin, who staged the play in New York, will direct the film with Paul Lukas repeating his Broadway performance as Kurt Mueller.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The unity of purpose of Norway and the United States was emphasized by President Roosevelt and King Haakon today when Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr. presented his credentials in London as American Ambassador and Wilhelm von Munthe af Morgenstierne, the Norwegian Minister here, submitted his credentials as Ambassador.

We can realize how long France has stood at the crossroads of a fateful choice when we remember that precisely a year ago today President Roosevelt addressed to the French Government and the French people what even then was described as "a last-minute appeal" not to collaborate with Germany.

The report for 1941 of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $140,572,419 after taxes, charges and reserves, including a deduction of $30,000,000 for losses on foreign investments, equal to $5.15 each on the 27,283,587 capital shares outstanding.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has offered to the United States Government the free use of all its patents and those of its subsidiaries, both here and abroad, for the duration of the war and six months thereafter, Colonel Sosthenes Behn, president, disclosed yesterday.

IT is alleged that Sammy Angott, the world's lightweight champion, will be defending his title at Madison Square Garden tonight against the attack of a bookworm. The alleged bookworm is Allie Stolz, a native of Newark, in which city there is a notable public library.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Eli Oliver, chief of the War Production Board's labor relations branch and a principal aide to Sidney Hillman, former WPB labor director, resigned today, declaring that "there's no job left for me to do."

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Aroused by assertions that members of Congress should not be allowed unlimited gasoline cards, the Senate took up the challenge tonight and arranged to vote tomorrow on a resolution which would bind Senators to renounce all "rights, perquisites or exemptions" and to "consider themselves bound by honor to the acceptance of the common rule."

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Ensign Edwin Denby Jr., son of President Harding's Secretary of the Navy, and Lieutenant (Junior Grade) William Oscar Spears Jr., son of a rear admiral, were among 2,495 officers and men reported by the Navy tonight to be missing.

Fordham's baseball team became the first champion of the new Metropolitan Collegiate Conference yesterday by beating Manhattan, 7 -- 2, on Fordham Field. It was the eighth straight league triumph for the Rams. Even if they lose their last game with N.Y.U. second-place St. John's cannot overhaul them.

Civilian defense flags and certificates of appointment were given by Mayor La Guardia yesterday to fifty-eight men and women who have offered their services to recruit volunteers for the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

Rationing of gasoline along the Eastern seaboard became effective at midnight last night for most motorists, but card-holders faced difficulty in buying gasoline today because many filling stations had sold their entire quota for the first two-thirds of the month and will not be able to replenish their stocks until next week.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumed during April totaled 998,754 bales of lint and 132,106 bales of linters, compared with 966,631 bales of lint and 131,187 of linters during March this year and 920,950 bales of lint and 120,008 of linters consumed during April last year.
LONDON, May 14 -- King George VI had his first experience today of the British Army's realistic battle training with live ammunition during a visit he made to a division of the Southeastern Command.
DETROIT, May 14 -- The Yanks and Tigers, held idle today, agreed upon a double-header for Saturday, when a single game originally was scheduled.

Fraudulent wholesaling is not confined to New York, even if our people do lose $25,000,000 annually when they set out to get things wholesale. We can think of one public many times larger than New York which stands to lose vastly greater amounts by the operations of a certain man who is without a rival among the world's fake wholesalers.

King's Crown awards, highest recognition accorded at Columbia College for non-athletic extracurricular activities, have been made to eighty-two students by the Advisory Committee on King's Crown, bringing the total for the academic year to 147, Benjamin A. Hubbard director of King's Crown activities, announced yesterday.

To mark the opening of a one-week drive in the 15,000 theatres of the country to collect $3,000,000 for Army and Navy Emergency Relief, three of me outstanding naval heroes of the Philippine engagement were welcomed to Broadway yesterday noon by Mayor La Guardia after a parade in which they rode and before an outdoor variety show which they did not wait to see.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 14 -- The buying rush for clothing continued unabated today. Shops close daily after a few hours of trading and after exhausting the day's selling quota. Some have had to close departments for several days.

The Dodgers yesterday moved another length ahead of the second-place Pirates by beating them, 7 -- 4, before an Ebbets Field crowd of 18,126, including 875 men in uniform. This feat was performed without Onkel Franz Frisch so much as sticking his head out of the Bucco dugout. Brooklyn's lead over the second-place Corsairs now is three and a half games.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 14 -- Although many persons have obtained Class X gasoline ration cards without being entitled to them, the key workers of the Westchester County War Council have received A cards and cannot carry on their work, Colonel Frederick L. Devereux, County Director of Civilian Protection, said this afternoon.

WRIGHTSTOWN, N.J., May 14 -- His chair slumped against the wall in USO headquarters here, a soldier slept soundly today. It might have been the result of the warm sun that hit with a vengeance on the dusty territory near Fort Dix, which is ten minutes' walk from the clubhouse.

MOSCOW, Friday, May 15 (U.P.) -- Russian troops, pouring through a breach in the first German defense line around Kharkov, are boring in toward the heart of the city and on the Kerch Peninsula are battling strongly against superior Axis forces after a further withdrawal, the Red Army announced today.

LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- Note circulation of the Bank of England increased last week 3,227,000 to advance to the high record of 780,177,000, the weekly condition statement showed today. It was the twelfth consecutive weekly rise.

BERLIN, May 14 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A German High Command spokesman asserted tonight that the Russian forces embattled at Kerch had begun counter-attacking on a line thirteen miles west of that important Eastern Crimean town, and northward on the Donets front.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 -- A plan of the New York Curb Exchange for special offerings, similar in detail to other plans recently declared effective for the New York Stock Exchange and the San Francisco Stock Exchange, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Members of the Babylon Tuna Club are meeting tonight to decide whether they should continue activities for the duration. Secretary Chet Brown's letter to his colleagues says in part:

NEWARK, N.J., May 14 -- Charges of sabotage were filed here today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation against the operator of a power press in the electrical shop of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company in Kearny, N.J., who was accused of having deliberately ruined six dies and eight punches during the last six weeks.

OTTAWA, May 14 -- From practically nothing in 1939, Canada had established a $4,000,000,000 war industry that was still growing, Munitions Minister C. D. Howe told the House of Commons today when presenting the estimates of his department.
BERLIN, May 14 (From German broadcasts recorded by the Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Federal Trade Commission will conduct an investigation into the manner in which bids covering contracts for the rehabilitation of the yards of the William Cramp Sons Ship and Engine Company at Philadelphia were submitted and handled, the House Naval Affairs Committee said today.

As a teacher in the New York public sehool system I am in daily contact with hundreds of youngsters. There is no better way of judging the degree and scope of the effects of the war upon the mind and soul of our population than through the observation and study of our school children.

In a very literal sense Joe Jackson died with his boots on. They were enormous, ramshackle boots that he had picked out of an ashcan in New Jersey before the last World War. They humorously concluded a messy and tattered costume that still contained a patch of the original pants from forty years or so ago, and the whole bedraggled get-up, crowned with a battered hat, clothed a classic vaudeville turn.

Sufficient buying re-entered the stock market yesterday to make possible a slight recovery but only after the share list had been beaten down in the morning to a new low level. Traders who drifted to the sidelines appeared to take heart in the afternoon on the more favorable news from the Russo-Nazi front.

NEW ORLEANS, May 14 -- Assurance of family protection and child security, as an objective of the war, was proclaimed before the National Conference of Social Work tonight by Paul V. McNutt, Federal security administrator.

ALBANY, May 14 -- Results of the examinations for admission to the bar conducted March 19 and 20 were made public today. A total of 1,143 took the examinations and of this number 690 passed. However, only 342 names will be certified to the four Appellate Divisions of the State at this time, and the remaining 348 applicants will be certified as soon as they have complied with Court of Appeals requirements.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 14 (U.P.) -- Arno Lieckfield, described as a German naval officer operating as a spy, is under arrest at Joinville in the Southern State of Santa Catharina, where there are large German colonies, the newspaper Globo reported today.

LONDON, May 14 -- The Chancellor of the Exchequer announced today in Commons that he had given permission to private companies to convert stocks bearing fixed interest of more than 4 per cent to lower interest rates.

The index of retail prices advanced another 0.8 per cent in April, Fairchild Publications announced yesterday. This gain, which compared with an increase of 0.5 per cent in March, put the index at 113.4, or 18.7 per cent above a year ago.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 14 -- Governor Lehman today designated Sunday, May 17, as "I Am an American Day."
SYDNEY, Australia, Friday, May 15 (AP) -- The men who fought the Battle of the Coral Sea for the United Nations have landed unheralded at an Australian port.

The Russian offensive against Kharkov must be studied in the light of one determining fact. This is that Hitler cannot win in the East without breaking up the Russian Army, and that he cannot break up the Russian Army as long as it retains the spirit and possesses the materials to launch a full-dress attack.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- An oversold condition developed in the grain markets today and while there was nothing in the general run of the news to account for it, good buying made its appearance on an early decline and all grains, except oats, rallied quickly.

The High School of Music and Art (Convent Avenue and 135th Street), established in 1936 by Mayor La Guardia, opened yesterday its thirteenth semi-annual exhibition of work in arts and crafts. This opening followed a concert at 3:30 P.M., given in the school auditorium.

The New York Central Railroad in 1941 charged a loss of $26,842,000 to its investment in stock of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, F.E. Williamson, president of the trunk line, disclosed in his annual report issued yesterday.

LONDON, May 14 -- J. Christmas Moeller, a former Danish Cabinet Minister, was disclosed today to be one of those who had escaped Nazi-occupied Denmark. He has landed in England with his wife and son. As is usual, his method of escape was kept secret.

Among the twenty-one defendants before Magistrate Peter Abeles in Yorkville Court yesterday accused of violating Park Department regulations was Mrs. Shirley Gurly, 26 years old, of 9 West Eighty-fourth Street, who had been served with a summons for pulling weeds and grass in Central Park.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- United States Vice Consul John M. Slaughter and Mrs. Slaughter of South Bend, Ind., who were killed in the earthquake at Guayaquil, were serving their first tour of foreign service, having gone to that post only recently.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 14 -- Two veteran stars of action films, Richard Dix and Jack Holt, were signed today by RKO to play the leads in "Grand Canyon," which the studio has scheduled for production next Fall. James Craig has been assigned to the juvenile lead and extensive location filmings at the Grand Canyon are planned by the studio.
PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP) -- Bill Lee racked up his fifth victory in six tries by pitching the Cubs to a 5-to-3 triumph over the Phils today. Lee gave seven hits, five in the last three innings.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Aluminum Company of America has agreed to make substantial reductions in the prices of fabricated aluminum products, beginning June 15, the Office of Price Administration announced today. According to Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, the reductions will effect substantial savings to the government in its purchases of planes and other war materials.

William J. Ahearn, Democratic leader of the Fourth Assembly District, Manhattan, collapsed yesterday afternoon at Tammany Hall, 100 East 17th Street, where he was attending a meeting of the Democratic County Executive Committee.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 -- Contrary to earlier belief, thousands of Japanese evacuees from the West Coast Military Area No. 1 will have the opportunity this season to work on farms outside resettlement projects now being set up. For this work they will receive "prevailing wages."

The American Institute of Graphic Arts gave its highest honor, the Institute Medal of Award, last night to Edwin and Robert Grabhorn, designer-printer brothers, whose Grabhorn Press in San Francisco is widely known for distinguished printing.

In an otherwise hesitant market, buying by mills and New Orleans operators combined yesterday to hold cotton prices near the closing levels of the preceding day. At the end of trading, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 2 points higher than Wednesday's final quotations.

Fashions for office workers and business women were shown yesterday by Hearn's, Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Street, in a style review in the store's auditorium. Models for the show, which was sponsored by The Civil Service Leader, were Civil Service workers from New York offices.

Tallying seven runs in the sixth inning and six in the eighth, St. John's University's baseball team beat Brooklyn College, 14 -- 0, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference test at Brooklyn College Field yesterday. The victory was the sixth in the league for the Redmen.

CHICAGO, May 14 (AP) -- Led by Outfielder Myril Hoag, who drove in four runs with three singles, the last-place White Sox won today, 9 to 4, and ended the Athletics' five-game victory string. It was the third straight triumph for the Chicagoans, who, until yesterday, hadn't won two games in a row.

Eli Shonbrun, the ex-convict who is being tried in General Sessions with Madeline Webb, former model, and John D. Cullen, a minor police character, for the murder of Mrs. Susie Flora Reich, a refugee, in a $2,000 jewel robbery in the Hotel Sutton last March 4, threw the courtroom into an uproar yesterday when he interrupted the testimony of a girl witness to denounce her as "a contemptible, vicious'' liar.

A simple mechanical device, a tire lock, was the downfall yesterday of five tire thieves who were arrested by the police as they struggled with chisel and hammer to break the lock on a car parked at Stillwell Avenue and Pelham Parkway, the Bronx.

VICHY, France, May 14 -- Although at various intervals throughout the day it was reported that the government would make an announcement concerning negotiations with the United States, there was no communication of any kind today.

Representative Michael J. Kennedy, new leader of Tammany Hall, announced yesterday afternoon that the "differences" that had existed previously between the local Democratic organization and the national and State administrations in Washington and Albany had been ironed out and that "today complete harmony prevails."

A new high record in the value of the monthly milk pool for the New York milkshed was for the April, N.J. Cladakis, Federal-State Market Administrator, reported yesterday. This was the first month of operation of amended marketing orders with new diversion payments intended to increase milk production generally and lease-lend foods such as milk concentrates and cheese particularly.

The State Executive Committee of the American Labor party, through Luigi Antonini, chairman, and Alex Rose, secretary, announced yesterday that in the coming primaries the A.L.P. would support candidates "who have been loyal, consistent and unwavering supporters of the fundamental course of the New Deal, foreign and domestic, under the leadership of President Roosevelt."
Following is an excerpt from a short-wave broadcast by Transocean Wireless, official German agency, from Berlin recorded at THE NEW YORK TIMES last night:
Six professors of the New York University School of Education, having reached the mandatory age of retirement, will withdraw from the faculty before the close of the current school year.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- You won't have to give the government the shirt off your back to help win the war, but you're going to lose some of the shirt tail.

Friends of President Theodore Roosevelt will visit his grave and home in Oyster Bay, L.I., today, according to an announcement yesterday from the Roosevelt Memorial Association. The pilgrimage has been made annually since Mr. Roosevelt's death in 1919 but until this year it has been made on Jan. 6, the anniversary of his death.

ST. LOUIS, May 14 -- The all-out scope of this country's entrance into the war was hammered home yesterday by a visit to the St. Louis Ordnance Plant, where millions upon millions of cartridges for small arms are being turned out in the most rapid, precision-like manner that modern engineers can devise.

Expressing the opinion that fair trade contracts in effect before April 1 are valid and enforceable and, are not affected by the Federal price ceiling order, Eric Calamia, president of the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America, said last night that "issuance of fair trade contracts in the future is a matter of much concern."

Gasoline rationing will probably shake down into something like a system as soon as the majority of motorists are convinced, by evidence which one trusts will be forthcoming, that no undue favoritism has been shown. Meanwhile a few drivers are trying to beat the game.

AS an institution virtually coeval with the United States of America, and surely a significant part of our Republic during its historic formation and epic development, the New York Stock Exchange merits something better than a routine salutation on its 150th birthday anniversary this coming Sunday.

Government rationing of man power in industry now looms and will compel the elimination of practices inimical to full war production, particularly labor hoarding and pirating of employes by one concern from another, it was stated yesterday by Richard C. Brockway, director for New York of the United States Employment Service.

At the meeting of the Music Critics' Circle of New York held yesterday afternoon at the Blue Ribbon Restaurant, William Schuman won the organization's first annual award for the best new American orchestral work performed in this city during the season.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today a procedure by which retailers in exceptional circumstances may apply for adjustment of an abnormally low maximum price under the provisions of the general maximum price regulation.

After an interval of two weeks, the United States Treasury yesterday notified commercial bank depositaries that it will withdraw funds on Monday. The call for the entire country will amount to $115,211,000, of which $60,168,000 will be withdrawn from the banks in this district.

Some thirty-five local stores are considering running a joint advertisement in New York newspapers on Sunday announcing their adherence to the OPA price ceilings, it was learned yesterday. Decision will be made today. The ad is expected to be full-page size and will be limited to copy reading about as follows: "As of tomorrow (Monday) the undersigned signify that their prices will be at or under the ceilings fixed by OPA."

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Sharp declines in prices for certain farm products and foods, particularly livestock and fruits and vegetables brought about last week the first drop in the general level of wholesale prices since early in February, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses and his staff walked out of City Hall in an angry mood yesterday after a flareup between Mr. Moses and Chairman Joseph E. Kinsley of the Council finance committee, in which the park head accused the Councilman of insulting him.

OTTAWA, May 14 (Canadian Press) -- Dominion government deposits decreased $17,015,000 to $110,352,000 in the week ended yesterday the Bank of Canada reported today in its weekly statement. Notes in circulation increased $1,495,000 to $521,665,000.

LONDON, May 14 (U.P.) -- Widespread sabotage and anti-Nazi demonstrations forced the Germans to cancel celebrations observing the second anniversary of the invasion of the Netherlands last Sunday, according to reports reaching the Aneta news agency today via Switzerland.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 14 -- The Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association officially opened its season today over the Wykagyl Country Club course. Mrs. Frank J. Holleran of Round Hill led a field of forty-six players to captture low-gross laurels with a 46, 44 -- 90.

Due mainly to heavy Treasury disbursements in excess of Treasury receipts, the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City and for the nation as a whole recovered sharply in the week ended on Wednesday, following the previous week's setback, it was disclosed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman yesterday afternoon dedicated the $200,000 Brady Memorial Library on the campus of the Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart, 133d Street and Convent Avenue. Begun in January, 1941, the library was made possible by a legacy from the estate of Mrs. William J. B. Macaulay, formerly Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady.

LONDON, May 14 -- The Battle of Burma seems to be rapidly turning into a campaign for Kunming, capital of China's Yunnan Province. While there continues to be a dearth of official news from the fighting front, today brought forth a number of reports of impressive Japanese gains.

A fresh new fragrance bursts upon the Summer scene. It is a warm, sun-drenched scent designed to awaken sharp nostalgia for a Summer filled with scudding sailboats, wind-blown meadow grass and dancing under the stars. It's just the thing to tuck in a weekend kit.

LONDON, May 14 -- The problem of rationing coal, which has stirred the British people more than any recent domestic proposal of the war, was aired anew today with publication of an exchange of letters between Sir William Beveridge, the economist who first drew up the fuel-rationing scheme, and Dr. Hugh Dalton, President of the Board of Trade, who offered it in Parliament.

Between 125 and 150 members of the American Women's Voluntary Services received X gasoline rationing cards, entitling them to buy motor fuel in unlimited amounts, at a special registration board set up yesterday in the regional headquarters of the Office of Price Administration in the Empire State Building.

Yankee Dandy, by Son o' Battle, was too much for all the others in the featured Elmont Purse at Belmont Park yesterday when he drove through the stretch to score at $39.70 before 15,943 persons who wagered $1,038,895 on the eight-race program.

TAPPAN, N.Y., May 14 -- A dappled gray work horse that trampled a woman to death was trapped and killed early today by an automobile posse of 200 men after a night of wild excitement in the Tappan-Sparkhill area of Rockland County.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 14 -- A correspondent in Athens has sent the Journal de Geneve a pathetic account of hungry Greek children lining up outside soup kitchens. At one kitchen alone 1,200 come each day. Their ages range from 3 years to 18 years.

Joe Jackson, beloved comedian and distinguished throughout the theatrical realm for his "tramp" bicycle act for more than forty years, stood in the wings of the Roxy Theatre at 1:34 P.M. yesterday. An audience of 3,509 youngsters and adults were cheering and applauding.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 14 -- Yale's football hopes took a big leap today, when Howie Odell, head coach, came here and announced himself eager to start the job of reversing the depressing trend of affairs that has seen the Elis underdogs the last two years.

The family of Ensign John F. Connery, consisting of his father, Thomas, 79 years old, and a sister, Annette, said last night at their home at 80 Crescent Avenue, New Brighton, S.I., that although the Navy listed the ensign as missing, they felt confident he was all right, because they received a cablegram from him only on Monday.

The report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday by Edward Reynolds, president, shows a consolidated net income after expenses, taxes and other charges of $7,544,469.

Sammy Angott of Washington, Pa., will defend his world lightweight championship against Allie Stolz of Newark in the main bout of fifteen rounds at Madison Square Gardon tonight. Because the clash will head the first Garden card in six weeks and in view of the championship involved, it is expected that a crowd of more than 12,000 fans will witness the proceedings.

MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, May 14 (AP) -- Charles R. Hook, president of the American Rolling Mill Company, in a statement, which he said was to clarify his stand on the "closed shop" issue, declared today that establishment of a national wartime labor policy would foster greater war production.

JERSEY CITY, May 14 (AP) -- Joe Orengo's single with the bases full in the ninth broke a 4-4 deadlock and gave Jersey City a 5-to-4 victory over Baltimore tonight in the first night baseball game in the metropolitan area since talk of a ban on dimout ball six weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, wife of the former Governor of Texas and at present a publicity executive for the War Department, has been asked to assume the directorship of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 14 -- Carl O. Dunbar, Professor of Paleontology and Stratigraphy at Yale University, has been named director of the Peabody Museum, it was announced today by President Charles Seymour. He will replace Albert E. Parr, who has been called to head the American Museum of Natural History in New York.

"Mrs. Miniver," Metro's screen version of the book by Jan Struther, has been booked to follow "Tortilla Flat" at the Radio City Music Hall. The latter film, which is scheduled to open at the theatre next Thursday, was directed by William Wyler and stars Greer Garson and Walter Pidgeon.
ALBANY, May 14 -- Appointment of a State War Transportation Committee by the State War Council was announced today by Governor Lehman.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Roosevelt sent to Congress the United States-Mexico agreement for settlement of agrarian claims, signed a bill suspending overtime provisions of the Walsh-Healey Act in certain circumstances, sent to the Senate the nomination of Spencer C. Young to be United States Marshal for the eastern district of New York, and gave a luncheon for President Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The long-standing dispute between the marine workers unions and the government maritime agencies has been settled by an agreement between the War Shipping Administration and the unions.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, May 15 -- Though admitting further withdrawals on the Kerch Peninsula, a Russian communique issued early today claimed specific gains on the Kharkov front, where the fighting was becoming more and more intense.

Scoring in ten of the eleven events, the Mount St. Michael High charges of Coach Ernie Hjertberg captured the senior team title with 51 points at the fifteenth annual Manhattan-Bronx - Westchester C. H. S. A. A. track and field championships at Macombs Dam Park yesterday.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, May 15 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur's Headquarters announced today that United Nations planes had attacked Japanese shipping yesterday at Rabaul, New Britain, damaging a transport and shooting down seven of seventeen enemy fighters that tried to intercept them.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, May 14 -- The death toll is expected to reach 100 in the worst earthquake in the history of Guayaquil, which shook the city for two terrifying minutes last night. The number of persons injured is placed at several hundred and many hundreds more are homeless as a result of the destruction of many buildings, including a number of new apartment houses.

The 1,250 cadets and cadet officers of the New York University Reserve Officers Training Corps, largest unit in the history of the university, were reviewed yesterday afternoon on Ohio Field in the twenty-fourth annual military field day. Four thousand spectators were in the stands.

The only encouraging feature in April newspaper advertising linage in fifty-two cities, measured by Media Records, was a gain of 1.1 per cent in national advertising over April of last year. Total advertising declined 10.2 per cent, bringing the loss for the four-month period to 7 per cent.

Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, revealed last night that the American Government spent at the rate of $41,000,000,000 a year on its war program in the month of April and predicted that it will be spending at the rate of $60,000,000,000 a year by November and December.

The phenomenal escape of a medium-sized United States merchant ship from an enemy submarine that struck it with three torpedoes and subsequently shelled it and the sinking of a Panamanian ship with the probable loss of thirteen members of its crew were revealed yesterday by the Navy Department.
Herbert C. Gerlach, county executive, sent a telegram containing a similar plea to Governor Lehman.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., May 14 -- A member-guest field of fifty-four competed in the opening monthly tournament of the New York Athletic Club over the west course at the Winged Foot Golf Club today. Thirteen individual flights of four were played.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Formation of a government agency to supervise the pooling and production of transocean commercial air transport facilities, similar to the Maritime Commission's control over the merchant marine, has been proposed as a war measure and is being considered by the Administration, it was understood today.

With flying weather improving each day as the Summer approaches, it is more important than ever to trace the movements of all planes flying over the northeast section of the country twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week, Brig. Gen. John K. Cannon, commander of the First Interceptor Command, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- After a brief question-and-answer period concerning the $13,000,000,000 of commitments made thus far by the Reconstructive Finance Corporation, the House today passed unanimously an Administration measure increasing the corporation's borrowing power by $5,000,000,000 for further vast-scale lending operations for expansion of war production and acquisition of raw materials.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission upheld today a trial examiner and denied Samuel Okin of New York, holder of 7,000 common shares of the Electric Bond and Share Company, the right to intervene in company proceedings before the commission.

In the matter of gasoline rationing most of us are satisfied with A cards or B-1 or B-2 or B-3, appropriately named, since they remind us of the vitamins of victory that had previously been driving our nervous systems instead of our cars. But Congressmen can, if they wish, get cards marked X -- and X, as every schoolboy knows, means an unknown quantity.

LONDON, May 14 -- Discussing the United States naval program, the 1941 edition of Jane's Fighting Ships, the authoritative annual of the world's navies, made public today, asserts that "never before has such a quantity of capital ships been under construction at the same time for any country."
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 14 (AP) -- Pounding three Syracuse pitchers almost at will, Newark opened the arc-light season here tonight with a 14-to-3 victory over Syracuse.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 -- An eight-point charter for industrial harmony was offered to the nation tonight by William P. Witherow, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, as "a domestic companion to the famed Atlantic charter."

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Eight corporations, including E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation and the American Cyanamid Company, and twenty of their officers and directors were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Trenton, N.J., today, accused of a world-wide conspiracy to suppress competition in and to monopolize the manufacture and sale of dyestuffs here and abroad.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of an issue of $300,000 of relief bonds of New Bedford, Mass., on a bid of 100.683 for 1 1/2s. The bonds, dated May 14, 1942, and maturing on May 1, 1943 to 1952, were reoffered to yield 0.50 to 1.40 per cent, according to maturity.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Charging that the Agriculture Depart ment has been "asleep at the switch for years," Senator Wheeler of Montana asserted today that by failing to develop the country's resources the department was responsible for the shortages of gasoline, rubber and alcohol.

Four members of the Press and Propaganda Department of the Brazilian Government were honored yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Roosevelt and heard Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia School of Journalism plead for "a less superior attitude on the part of my countrymen in hemispheric relations."

The period between the wars was one which constantly demanded of business leaders a higher standard of training, education and understanding. In meeting this need the Harvard Graduate School of Business, under Dean Wallace Brett Donham, has made a notable contribution to the business life of the country.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The war may clip the wings of America's most prominent traveler, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, but she says she is ready to take whatever may come.

Turn about is fair play. A little more than a week ago the Reds staggered the Giants with a twelve-run inning. Yesterday at the Polo Grounds the New Yorkers paid back the Cincinnatians in kind by slashing out ten runs in a hilarious eighth frame to beat Deacon Bill McKechine's operatives, 12 to 6.

Bank clearings in twenty-four major cities of the country for the week ended Wednesday increased 15.9 per cent to $6,553,742,000 from $5,653,686,000 recorded in the corresponding week last year, but declined 11.6 per cent from the total of the previous week, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 14 (AP) -- Fowler McCormick, president of the International Harvester Company, said today that production restrictions might lower sales of regular products in the next six months but that this situation might be offset by increased deliveries of armament products.

A ST. LAWRENCE RIVER PORT, May 14 (U.P.) -- Survivors of the second ship torpedoed by an enemy submarine in the St. Lawrence River said today that most of the twelve who perished were caught below decks and probably were scalded to death by escaping steam.

The conflict between John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, and his left-wing opponents in the C.I.O. was accentuated yesterday with the filing of charges by Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, at the national office of the C.I.O. in Washington alleging that Mr. Lewis and three other mine union officials were conducting a dual union movement against the New York local of the T.W.U.

Joy Hodges win succeed Rosemary Lane in the leading feminine role in "Best Foot Forward." Miss Lane is going back whence she came -- Hollywood -- and later on will act her role in the screen version of the musical. The change will take place Sunday afternoon, May 31.

Mayor La Guardia told 2,000 parochial and public school children yesterday that they constituted the most important delegation ever to visit City Hall, as they gave him more than 5,000,000 signatures pledging support of "I Am An American Day" on Sunday afternoon at the Central Park Mall.

RICHMOND, Va., May 14 (AP) -- Trustees of the Central States Electric Corporation filed today their fifth report with Judge Robert N. Pollard, United States District Court, who entered orders in accordance with it.

BOWMANVILLE, Ont., May 14 (AP) -- Two German Air Force lieutenants, Frederick Oeser and Everhardt Wildermutch, escaped today from the officers' prison camp here apparently by hiding in clothing crates being sent to another camp.

MEXICO CITY, May 14 -- The first Mexican ship to be sunk by an Axis submarine, a 6,132-ton tanker, went down last night off the coast of Florida with the probable loss of thirteen of her crew of thirty-five, the Mexican Foreign Office announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (U.P.) -- Major General Lewis B. Hershey told Congress today the Selective Service was "going slow" in calling up men with dependents, but that men whose wives are working will be inducted "soon."
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, May 14 (AP) -- A communique issued here today said:

Announcing Summer publication plans Little, Brown points up a novel entitled "Signed With Honour," by James Aldridge, North American Newspaper Alliance correspondent. It is a novel of air warfare in which the chief character is a flying officer.

An army of 200,000 "minute men" and "minute women" will be enlisted and trained to carry the war-bond sales campaign into every one of the 2,000,000 homes in Greater New York, it was announced yesterday by John T. Madden, chairman of the United States Treasury's Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Continuing to show improvement over the corresponding periods of 1941, department store sales in the week ended May 9 were 6 per cent larger than a year ago, following a gain of 8 per cent in the preceding week, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Treasury is studying a proposal to impose a nominal head tax of $5 on every one who files an income tax return -- whether he is liable to pay income tax or not -- and will recommend it to Congress if it is not unconstitutional, Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today.
The disparity between German and Soviet official claims on the fighting in Russia was illustrated in figures issued yesterday on the opposing forces' air losses.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- More than 2,000 persons comprise a special staff which, under direction of the Office of Censorship, scans the foreign mails at New York as an important phase of the war effort.

Gasoline rationing for some 9,000,000 motorists along the Atlantic seaboard will become a reality today. How long this novel experience will last for these motorists, living in a nation having 65 per cent of the world's oil production on a restricted basis, depends on how rapidly alternate methods of transportation are put into use.

ALBANY, May 14 -- The Murray-Olliffe Bill, setting up the machinery for "pre-flight" training courses in the State's high schools, as part of a junior aviation program, was signed today by Governor Lehman. It carries an appropriation of $150,000 for equipment.

The ninth annual Summer series of one-man shows at the offices of Theodore A. Kohn Son, jewelers, 608 Fifth Avenue, opens on May 25 with an exhibition of paintings in gouache by Lucy Aurino. Robert Bauer will show oils and Robert Becker, abstractions in gouache, from June 22 to July 17.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, May 14 (AP) -- Among the missing in last night's earthquake is Dr. Modesto Arreaga Gomez, director of a large clinic that was shaken to the ground.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The end of all civilian air travel except that considered vital to the war effort appeared near today with announcement in part by the War Department of a program to control operations of the airlines.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP) -- R.H. Macy Co., Inc., of New York City, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration covering a proposed issue of $12,000,000 of 2 1/2 per cent ten-year sinking fund debentures due on May 1, 1952.

During the Japanese attack on the rubber-growing countries so vitally important to the manufacturing industries of the United States a great deal was said about the scorched-earth policy, and the fact became known to the general public that rubber trees cannot be burned out wholesale like other trees in dry lands.

TOKYO, May 14 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- A large Japanese merchant vessel has been torpedoed and sunk in the eastern part of the South China Sea by an enemy submarine, but the submarine itself is believed to have been sunk, an official announcement said today.

The Bronx Savings Bank, which was temporarily halted last Friday by an order in Bronx Supreme Court from foreclosing and selling the home of a widow who lives with eleven of her sixteen children at 2184 Parsifal Place, the Bronx, served notice yesterday through their attorney, George K. Shields, that they wanted Justice Aaron J. Levy to disqualify himself from the case because they contend he was prejudiced and biased.

CHICAGO, May 14 (AP) -- Advancing 25 to 35 cents a hundred pounds, wooled lambs hit today the highest price since 1929 at $15.40 in active trading. Shorn lambs and fat sheep shared in the upturn. Livestock men said the absence of ceilings on wholesale or retail lamb quotations, similar to those in effect upon pork and beef, was primarily responsible for the rise.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 14 -- Firing rifles and tommy guns through the windows of the Junkers-52 planes in which they were soaring over the Mediterranean, German troops tried in vain to beat off the attack of Royal Air Force fighter aircraft that sent thirteen of the German air transports plunging into the sea Tuesday.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 14 -- German-Turkish relations and Turkey's attitude on the present war are commanding increased attention in the German press. In an article contributed to a German "front" newspaper, Franz von Papen, the German Ambassador to Turkey, discusses the subject of neutrality.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Further steps toward decentralizing the War Production Board were made today when Donald M. Nelson, WPB chief, announced the appointment of Dr. Luther Gulick to direct a permanent office of organizational planning, which will advise Mr. Nelson on administrative operations.

Enemy submarines torpedoing freighters both in the St. Lawrence River and the Gulf of Mexico emphasize the increasing boldness of these marauders and the wide range of their operations. Meantime, sinkings continue in our coastal waters nearer home.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Army manoeuvres planned for the coming Summer have been designed to train relatively small, hard-hitting combat teams in every type of specialized unit warfare from deserts to jungles, and particularly in night fighting.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Roosevelt nominated today Spencer C. Young of St. Albans, L.I., to be United States Marshal for the Eastern District of New York, succeeding Arthur G. Jaeger.

E.R., Squibb Sons and domestic and Canadian subsidiaries had a net profit for the nine months ended on March 31 of $1,801,516 after Federal income taxes and extraordinary reserves of $207,457, according to a report issued yesterday.

HAVANA, May 14 -- The Cuban Government has refused to permit the Spanish charge d'affaires to visit German, Italian and Japanese citizens interned on the Isle of Pines, Prime Minister Carlos Saladrigas said tonight. These persons are being held incomunicado, and the government believes the Spanish Legation can obtain the information necessary to look after their interests through regular official channels.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 14 (AP) -- British headquarters issued this communique today on the Libyan fighting:

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Census figures for 1940 show that the number of women in the country is almost equal to the number of men, it was stated today by the Bureau of the Census. This means a decline in the proportion of 102.7 men for every 100 women in 1930 to 100.7 men for every 100 women today.

CHUNGKING, China, May 14 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have launched a strong offensive in the coastal area of Chekiang Province, using 30,000 troops supported by an aircraft carrier with thirty planes in Hangchow Bay and bitter fighting is raging south of the town of Siaoshan, Chinese advices said tonight.
ST. LOUIS, May 14 -- The up-and-down Browns pulled out of a tailspin today to defeat the fourth-place Red Sox, 6 to 3, behind the pitching of Johnny Niggeling.

The ninety-sixth anniversary of the consecration of the present edifice of Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street, was observed yesterday with a special Ascension Day service, including a procession and the singing of Schubert's Mass in B flat by a vested choir of sixty men and boys, accompanied by the organ, and a fifty-piece orchestra.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Headquarters of the Philippine Commonwealth Government in exile was established today.

Arriving in Pennsylvania Station from Boston last night for a five-day visit in New York, President Manuel Prado of Peru was welcomed by Mayor La Guardia and was escorted by a procession of twenty cars to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, to rest up for today's visit to West Point.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The protests, the chiseling and the voiceless despair which have disturbed the land since the queues for gasoline rationing were formed have now been analyzed by some of the rationing officials as traceable to the following causes:

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Hopes for a full agreement guaranteeing the neutrality of Martinique, Guadeloupe and French Guiana were strengthened today when Admiral Georges Robert, French High Commissioner, consented to the immobilization of French warships at Martinique and Guadeloupe.

When warm weather comes to America's largest city small boys dream of swimmin' holes, career girls take to navy blue "sheers" and sensible housekeepers modify their menus. The Sunday roast, for example, often gives way to a molded meat salad or to convenient cook-in-a-whisk broilers.
MOSCOW, May 14 -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

The Supreme Court on Monday handed down two decisions in patent cases. One applied to makers of "hardboard" and the other to manufacturers of bifocal lenses. In both cases the court held that the holder of the patent and his licensees had violated the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 14 -- The police said today that German residents of a house overlooking the Bay of Valparaiso had been tapping a private telephone line between the Ministry of Marine in the Capital and the headquarters of the naval authorities in Valparaiso.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Hopes for a full agreement guaranteeing the neutrality of Martinique, Guadeloupe and French Guiana were strengthened today when Admiral Georges Robert, French High Commissioner, consented to the immobilization of French warships at Martinique and Guadeloupe.

The approval by the Senate Agricultural Committee of a year's extension on Commodity Credit Corporation loans resulted yesterday in a sharp rally in cotton futures here. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 6 to 10 points, with the July leading.

Alfred O'Gara Co. retired on May 8 as a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday by the Exchange, Weingarten Co. have dissolved. Pemberton Berman Co. will dissolve on May 21.

It is far too early to base any forecasts on the opening battles of the new Russian campaign. Like a giant cobra beginning to uncoil, the Winter-slogged front is in motion from one end to the other. The guns are busy again amid the mutilated trees of the Karelian forests.

LONDON, May 15 -- The war is doing some queer things to the London fashion world. Last month the only smart women's clothes to be bad were both expensive and "exclusive," meaning that they were jealously held back for "special customers" in the back rooms of the famous couturiers.

NEWARK, N.J., May 15 -- Operators of parking lots in this area reported today decreases in patronage ranging up to 25 per cent and predicted that a much sharper decline would become evident Monday, when motorists will have exhausted their pre-rationing supplies.

Marketing, usually a familiar and somewhat routine business, will be a new experience for us all Monday, including the clerks who fill our orders. For on that day price ceilings will go into effect on numerous familiar foods that go down on our grocery slips.

LONDON, May 15 -- Dunlop Rubber announced today an 8 per cent dividend for 1941 but last year's 2 per cent bonus was not repeated. The Brazilian Traction dividend of 40 cents a share was the same as last year but was below expectations and the shares eased to 13 7/8d.

A new type of editorial advertisement, in which business leaders report to the public on their war effort, was advocated yesterday by E.R. Grace, president of Grace Bement, Inc., Detroit. Writing in the Adcrafter, official organ of the Adcraft Club of Detroit, Mr. Grace said that manufacturers should figure out budgets which will permit at least a quarterly statement to the public through newspapers.

One hundred and fifty years ago a group of New York merchants met under a buttonwood tree in Wall Street and formed an association which was later to become the New York Stock Exchange. They met, not at the prompting of a bright idea, but simply to facilitate the exchange of securities which was already becoming an essential part of the business of the young and growing country.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Navy Department is pleased with the speed and quality of the work done in rehabilitating the Cramp Shipbuilding Company's yard at Philadelphia, even though it inspired investigations into alleged irregularities in bidding on work there, Representative Michael J.
