Bradley of Pennsylvania, temporary chairman of the House Naval Affairs Committee, asserted today.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 15 -- President Manuel Prado of Peru and his entourage reviewed the cadet corps of the Military Academy today after a luncheon with Major General Francis B. Wilby, Academy Superintendent, and member of his staff.

George Burnside, 36 - year - old Negro, of 117 Bainbridge Street, Brooklyn, was arrested twice yesterday on the same charge -- that of turning on a man who tried to help him. He paid a fine of $5 the first time but was unable to do so the second, and went to jail for two days.

LONDON, May 15 -- A mobile library installed in a truck, presented to the British by the publishers and booksellers of the United States through the British War Relief Society, was handed over to Lord Daryngton, president of the Church Army, today by Bertram de N. Cruger, London representative of the society in the United States.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 15 (AP) -- A United Air Lines official said today the similarity between the red lights of two recently completed commercial radio towers and those of the Salt Lake Airport towers was responsible for the crash of a United Air Lines transcontinental plane May 1 in which seventeen persons died.

Benefits to subscribers to the 3-cents-a-day hospital plan will be increased in value from $6.75 to $7 per day beginning July 1, Dr. S.S. Goldwater, president of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, announced yesterday. The organization, which is observing its seventh anniversary this month, has paid out more than $32,000,000 for subscribers since May, 1935.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 15 -- The Roosevelt Pilgrimage Association, which annually visits the grave of Theodore Roosevelt in Youngs Memorial Cemetery, here, on the anniversary of his death, Jan. 6, made a postponed visit this morning and placed a wreath at the iron paling that surrounds the tomb.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Secretary Stimson announced today that Mrs. Cveta Culp Hobby, wife of the former Governor of Texas and at present a War Department publicity executive on a per diem basis, has been appointed Director of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 15 -- Robert Taylor will co-star with Judy Garland in the screen adaptation of Booth Tarkington's "Presenting Lily Mars," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced today. Joseph Pasternak win produce the film after Miss Garland completes the current "Me and My Gal."

The Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences in the United States, with headquarters at 36 East Thirty-sixth Street, was inaugurated yesterday afternoon at exercises in the Morgan Library, 29 East Thirty-sixth Street. The Polish Ambassador and representatives of leading arts and science societies attended.

William Petersen, 18 years old, of 251 Forty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, arrested recently in connection with a number of robberies in the Bay Ridge district of Brooklyn, was held on a murder charge yesterday after being questioned about the killing of Mrs. Catherine Watson, 63 years old, who was found dead in her apartment, 404 Sixty-first Street, Brooklyn, on Jan. 2, 1941.

Patrolman Thomas Roach of the Kingsbridge station takes a keen interest in the area in Van Cortlandt Park near Mosholu Avenue, the Bronx, which is used by the State Department of Conservation as a breeding ground for wild pheasants.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Roosevelt signed the bill creating a Women's Army Auxiliary Corps and instructed Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, to order local rationing boards to make public lists of persons who obtained gasoline rationing cards.

The use of city cars between homes and offices was again the chief topic of discussion yesterday, when the City Council finance committee resumed hearings on the next budget in City Hall and Councilman Joseph E. Kinsley, chairman of the committee, who clashed on Thursday with Park Commissioner Robert Moses over the home-to-office transportation of Park Department officials, renewed his questioning on the subject.

What is organized baseball doing to strengthen or weaken the democratic spirit in these extraordinary times? It seems to me this is a good question from the mere fact that baseball is regarded as our national sport.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on May 9 amounted to 255,185,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, United States Department of the Interior. This represented a decrease of 3,960,000 barrels in the week, comprising decreases of 3,820,000 and 140,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.

Yesterday was probably the most disgraceful and disheartening day in the history of the Eastern States. For the first time in the history of this war we were called upon to show our patriotism in a real all-out fashion, and the result is a matter of record.

The Barnard School for Boys captured the Metropolitan Athletic Association of Private Schools championship yesterday by beating the Woodmere Academy nine, Southern Division winner, 19 to 4, in a play-off at Fieldston Field. Brainard Rau, Barnard pitcher, yielded four hits and fanned thirteen.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Legislation which would authorize the government to requisition automobiles and tires from private owners and seize the cars of drivers who exceeded a national speed limit has been sent by the Senate Military Committee to the Office of Defense Transportation for review and a report on just how drastic such measures must be to conserve rubber.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- One hundred corporations now hold about 76 per cent of all the war supplies contracts of $50,000 or more, the War Production Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The House Ways and Means Committee decided tentatively today, by a reported vote of 13 to 10, to require joint returns from "husbands and wives living together," but it took a stand against taxing the income of existing or future issues of State and local bonds.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Office of Price Administration today extended from June 1 to July 1 the time within which retail storekeepers must file price lists on cost-of-living items with local War Price and Rationing Boards.
The Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America issued an appeal yesterday "to all Christian citizens" to meet the restrictions of wartime living with "the spirit of self-denial."

VICHY, France, May 15 -- Postponement of the Cabinet meeting scheduled for tomorrow morning until the evening has again delayed the official announcement that was expected regarding French possessions in the Caribbean. In the meantime all information is being withheld both as regards the terms of the American proposals and as regards the measures taken in Martinique.

Writing of new life insurance last month was 5.5 per cent less than in April a year ago, but the total for the first four months of this year was 16.8 per cent ahead of that in the corresponding period last year, according to the Association of Life Insurance Presidents in a report to the United States Department of Commerce.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in a letter made public here yesterday with her permission by Eugene P. Connolly, secretary of the New York County Committee of the American Labor party, contended that one result of the war and ultimate victory by the democracies would be to bring about unity of class, race and creed, a strong labor movement and "equality and freedom of a democracy for which we fight."

BERLIN, May 15 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York and London) -- German planes, swooping down on a United States naval force above Norway on the Arctic supply lane to Russia, sank a Pensacola class heavy cruiser and a destroyer and scored bomb hits on two other destroyers, the High Command asserted today.
LONDON, May 15 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:
JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 15 (AP) -- Jersey City made it two in a row over Baltimore today, winning by 7 to 2. The Little Giants bunched ten hits effectively off a trio of Oriole hurlers.

NEW DELHI, India, May 15 (U.P.) -- Throughout the advance of the Japanese in Burma they interfered as little as possible with the local governments set up by the Burmese as each town fell, apparently letting the natives form independent islands of administration until the entire country was conquered, when taking over the disunited colony would be simple.

TRENTON, May 15 -- Not being counselors-at-law, Frank Hague Jr., son of the Jersey City Mayor, and John J. Rafferty, former Democratic Assemblyman from Middlesex County, are not eligible for appointment to any permanent post on the New Jersey bench under the judiciary set-up proposed by the Commission on Revision of the New Jersey Constitution.

NEW ORLEANS, May 15 -- An enemy submarine, striking near the mouth of the Mississippi River, sank a large American cargo ship on May 12 and killed twenty-seven of its crew, the Eighth Naval District announced today.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 15 -- Two former Governors, a Bishop and two business executives received the award of the Silver Buffalo of the National Council of the Boy Scouts of America for "distinguished service to boyhood" at a dinner tonight during the thirty-second annual meeting of the council.

SUMMIT, N.J., May 15 -- Charley Whitehead of the Plainfield Country Club was the star today as he teamed with Johnny Kinder, Plainfield professional, to win an amateur-pro golf tournament over the Canoe Brook Country Club's south course with a score of 67.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- Holding that conditions resulting from the war program made it more necessary than ever that the corporate recapitalization and death sentence sections of the Public Utility Holding Company act be strictly enforced, the Securities and Exchange Commission rejected today a petition for a rehearing of its one-stock order against the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation.

WHITE PLAINS, May 15 -- Gasoline rationing has reduced traffic so sharply in Westchester that the County Park Commission decided today to extinguish lights on the County parkways. George S. Haight, Commission Superintendent, said that last night's traffic was 20 per cent of normal and automobiles were even scarcer today.

The five-story apartment house at 1075 Bryant Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by the 1075 Bryant Avenue Corporation to an investing client of Nehring Brothers, Inc., brokers. This structure is on a plot 50 by 100 feet and contains ninety-four rooms.

Our commercial air transport system, built by the foresight and courage of private operators into a service unparalleled anywhere else in the world, is now to feel the full effects of total war. To judge from an announcement by the War Department, as yet not fully clarified, the lines will lose half of the planes remaining to them after the recent transfer for war use of 25 per cent of their equipment.

SHEFFIELD, England, May 15 -- Twelve conscientious objectors, who received deferment on religious or humanitarian grounds, have volunteered to endure the torments and sufferings of shipwrecked seamen to help science save life at sea, it was announced here today.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 15 (AP) -- James Harper, 16-year-old Hill Military Academy cadet who joked as rescuers struggled thirteen hours to move a 1,500-pound boulder from his legs, died of his injuries today.
LONDON, May 15 -- The bearded mien of King George V looked down from the walls of Fulham Town Hall today as London's first tribunal to judge women conscientious objectors went into action.

Governor Lehman was asked again yesterday to reopen the Flynn paving blocks case on the basis of an alleged statement by an unidentified member of the Bronx grand jury that Samuel J. Foley, Bronx District Attorney, had given the panel legal advice which "precluded" serious consideration of an indictment.

The municipal bond market took yesterday in stride the good, yet not unexpected, news from Washington that the House Ways and Means Committee had rejected the Treasury's proposal to tax the interest from State and local securities. Activity was stepped up somewhat all along the line, but not spectacularly, according to traders. Prices, however, were generally higher, the best levels being attained right after word of the committee's action reached the market.

I note a letter from Hamilton Fish published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 11 concerning Mr. Hagerty's article in last Sunday's TIMES on Mr. Fish's candidacy for re-election to Congress. In the course of his letter Mr. Fish, referring to Mr. Hagerty's article, said:

The publishers Farrar Rinehart and Collier's Weekly have joined in sponsoring the third Mary Roberts Rinehart mystery novel contest. The prize is $2,000, payable on announcement of the winner (within two months after the close of the contest, Oct. 15).

The Women's Army Auxiliary Corps, authorized by an act passed this week and headed by Mrs. William P. Hobby of Houston, Texas, may make some old-fashioned men wonder what's happened to the country. It seems only yesterday that nice girls didn't show their ankles, and now they're to be soldiers -- 25,000 of them soon, 150,000 ultimately.

Twelve, including Market Wise and Attention, have been named for the $15,000 Metropolitan Handicap, feature this afternoon at Belmont Park on the initial Saturday of a meeting that seems certain to set new highs in attendance, betting and tax payments to the State.

BOSTON, May 15 (AP) -- The Braves moved into second place in the National League today as they rallied in the last two innings to beat the Cardinals, 3 to 2. A walk, a sacrifice, an error and a long fly provided the winning tally in the ninth.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 15 (AP) -- Newark had to go ten innings tonight for a 3-to-2 victory over the Chiefs which gave the International League leaders a sweep of the two-game series.

Suit to restrain Loew's Incorporated, and ten other motion-picture companies allegedly acting "in concert and combination with Loew's," from inducing producers or distributors not to deal with the plaintiffs and from "monopolizing the motion-picture industry in the Borough of Brooklyn," was filed in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday by the Signal Theatre Corporation and Copark Theatres, Inc., owners of three independent theatres in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

For all practical purposes the British occupation of Madagascar is now complete. In this war the effort of the United Nations has often been too little and too late; in Madagascar it was neither. The speedy seizure of Diego Suarez was exactly the type of determined and overwhelming assault needed to offset the feeble attempt to take Dakar.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Details of a plan, effective June 15, whereby men will be transferred to the Enlisted Reserve Corps immediately after induction and may, if they wish, return home at government expense for fourteen days to adjust personal affairs were announced today by National Headquarters of the Selective Service System.

Women of New York and northern New Jersey yesterday acquired a liaison in the Office of Emergency Management with the appointment of Miss Edith R. Brill, for a year a member of the staff in New York, as Information Officer in charge of women's and consumer news.
MOSCOW, May 15 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:

EASTON, Pa., May 15 -- One hundred and eighty baccalaureate degrees and six honorary degrees were conferred today at the Lafayette College commencement exercises, with Lowell Thomas, radio news commentator, giving the principal address.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Mrs. Jacob Strauss, who leased an apartment of eight rooms and three baths at 375 Park Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.

"Cafe Crown," the H.S. Kraft play in which Morris Carnovsky and Sam Jaffe are appearing, will close its Broadway run a week from tonight -- May 23. At that time it will have had 140 performances at the Cort Theatre.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had become a party to fourteen additional proceedings under Chapter X of the Bankruptcy Act as amended.

MOSCOW, Saturday, May 16 -- Taking village after village, blasting its way through Axis barbed-wire defenses and pounding chains of forts with field artillery, Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's drive in the Kharkov sector had its best day yesterday.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., May 15 -- Undaunted by the first day of gasoline rationing, fifty-five women assembled today for the third one-day tournament of the New Jersey Women's Golf Association at the Glen Ridge Country Club.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, May 15 -- Yesterday's aerial warfare over New Britain and New Guinea, in which United States fliers bagged nine Japanese fighters, strafed enemy shipping and broke up a determined attack on the Port Moresby base, was the most active in weeks in that region.

An old estate holding in the Madison Square section passed to new hands yesterday when the heirs of Robert Walton Goelet sold a group of three buildings at the southeast corner of Fourth Avenue and East Twenty-fifth Street to Frederick Brown, the operator.

Salt-water anglers are expected to make today and tomorrow important ones on the year's fishing calendar. It is no secret that weakfish have been caught in substantial quantities at Peconic Bay during the past few days by bottom fishing.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The officers and men of the submarine that the Navy said added "another brilliant saga to the feats of the Navy's underseas vessels in the Pacific war zone" by bringing out a vast amount of gold and securities from the Philippines, who were commended and received War Department decorations, were:

LENOX, Mass., May 15 -- John Matthews, Berkshire sportsman, and his wife, the former Miss Katie Schermerhorn of the old New York family, were found dead of bullet wounds in their home on Cliffwood Street, just off Main Street, here today.

Final arrangements completed last night for the "I Am An American Day" celebration on the Central Park Mall tomorrow afternoon included the provision of thirty-five air raid shelters along the boundary streets of lower Central Park, which will afford protection in case an air raid occurs while the ceremonies are being held.

Joseph Sonsky, 32 years old, was sentenced in General Sessions yesterday to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison for the slaying eight years ago of Detective James Garvey at Broadway and Seventy-fifth Street. Judge Jonah J. Goldstein imposed the sentence. Sonsky recently was convicted of first-degree murder.

BERLIN, May 15 (from German broadcasts) -- Germany declared officially today that the Nazi air force had sunk a United States cruiser of the 9,100-ton Pensacola class and an American destroyer yesterday in attacks on an American squadron between the North Cape of Norway and the Arctic island of Spitsbergen.

MEXICO CITY, May 15 -- While many in Mexico gave every evidence today of being deeply angered by the sinking of a Mexican ship by a submarine off the Florida coast Wednesday, high officials seemed agreed that it would not lead immediately to a declaration of war, though it might lead to drastic measures against Axis subjects and their property in Mexico.
MOSCOW, Saturday, May 16 (U.P.) -- Russian shock troops and mechanized forces are storming ever closer to Kharkov in a mammoth offensive, the Soviet High Command announced today.

Americans have willingly surrendered their trouser cuffs in the interest of conservation, but so far nothing has been said about double cuffs on shirts. Great Britain has just banned the double cuff, and in addition has sliced two inches from the shirt length.

NEW DELHI, India, May 15 (AP) -- British bombers again attacked Japanese barges on the Chindwin River, and United States Army fliers from India bombed the Myitkyina airdrome yesterday for the second day in a row, but the Japanese were busily consolidating their hold on Burma.

John Whitlow Wyatt's return to pitching form was bad news for the Pirates, but good news to a ladies' day crowd of 21,308 at Ebbets Field yesterday as the Dodgers made it two in a row over Frankie Frisch's Buccos. They won by 8 -- 3.

RYE, N.Y., May 15 -- Blackouts, dimouts, rubber shortages and gasoline rationing will not prevent Playland, the $11,000,000 Westchester County amusement center here, from opening tomorrow for its fifteenth Summer season, county officials decided today.

Executives of street railway and bus companies operating in the Middle Atlantic States were told yesterday that the Army has drawn uniform specifications for "blacking out" surface transportation during enemy air raids and plans to promulgate them soon through the medium of the Office of Civilian Defense.

Rome radio and press commentators yesterday appeared to be evincing considerable nervousness over the possibility of a forthcoming United Nations offensive against Axis positions in Libya, according to private advices received by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

President Manuel Prado of Peru will worship tomorrow at the 11 A.M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. A welcome to the Peruvian Chief Executive will be expressed and the sermon preached by the Most Rev. John F. O'Hara, Vicar Delegate of the Catholics in the Armed Forces of the United States, who formerly was president of Notre Dame University.
BERNE, Switzerland, May 15 -- The military situation in Russia today, in the view of competent military observers, is approximately this:

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor declared today that by its voluntary abstention from strikes during the war emergency the labor movement had achieved a pinnacle of performance which could never even be approached by compulsory anti-strike legislation.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 15 -- The thirty-fifth Bach Festival of the Bethlehem Bach Choir opened here today with sessions in the afternoon and evening. Packer Memorial Church, Lehigh University, was the scene. Under the direction of Dr. Ifor Jones, the chorus of 216 voices sang three Bach cantatas at the afternoon session and three in the evening.

MONTPELIER, Vt., May 15 -- Replying to a telegram from Governor William H. Wills of Vermont, President Roosevelt, in a letter made public here tonight with his consent, said that the Governor "complained quite properly about conflicting reports emanating from Washington with reference to the gasoline-rationing program."

MEXICO CITY, May 15 (U.P.) -- A political fight appeared to be developing in Congress tonight over whether Mexico should declare war against the Axis, while public indignation rose over the torpedoing of a Mexican ship and demands increased that the "nation's honor be avenged."

SYOSSET, L.I., May 15 -- Police were notified in an information sent out by the Syosset precinct of the Nassau County police tonight to be on the lookout for a valuable bracelet, lost Sunday by Mrs. William Constable Breed of Cedar Swamp Road, Glen Head, L.I.

The eight-room house on a plot 80 by 100 feet at 35-06 166th Street, Flushing, Queens, has been sold by the Jamaica Savings Bank to Dr. J. Schultz. The property was formerly the home of John Theofel, once a political figure in the borough. The Halleran Agency was the broker.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15 (AP) -- Held to five hits by Tommy Hughes, the Cubs turned back the Phils, 2 -- 1, today, aided by Pitcher Claude Passeau's home run and a Philadelphia error.

THE teams were on the field and the ball game was ready to start. Then the strains of the "Star-Spangled Banner" floated out of the loudspeaker horns, everybody stood up and the flag began its rise to the top of the flagpole. When the national anthem had been played and the flag had been lashed at the peak, the crowd sat down and the game went on.

LONDON, May 15 -- British remnants retreating from Burma were reported today to have reached the Indian frontier after having frustrated Japanese attempts to drive between them and India. New Delhi dispatches said there had been no contact with the Japanese for the past twenty-four hours.

Those fortunate persons owning small sailing craft may be rejoicing that gasoline and tire rationing will not hamper their yachting activities this Summer, but the days of this sport will be short-lived if the desires of some revolutionary-minded individuals are given recognition.

Monogram Pictures Corporation will produce forty-eight feature films on its 1942-43 program, it was announced at the company's tenth anniversary convention in Hollywood, Calif. The four-day meeting will close today. Of the forty-eight pictures, sixteen will be Westerns.

ALBANY, May 15 -- New York State motorists used 18,000,000 fewer gallons of gasoline during the first three months of this year than in the same quarter in 1941. Carroll E. Mealey, president of the Tax Commission, said the principal drop came in March, when there was a decline of nearly 10,000,000 gallons in "taxable sales."

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The abandonment of the Erie Railroad Company's ferry between Jersey City and West Twenty-third Street was recommended to the Interstate Commerce Commission today by Ralph R. Molster, examiner for the commission.

The Rev. Thomas A. Sparks has been appointed cathedral pastor at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Bishop William T. Manning created the office and appointed Mr. Sparks, who has been a member of the cathedral staff for the last five years.

Pearl L. Bergoff, 68 years old, of 105 West Seventy-second Street, who lost his private detective agency license several years ago when he was the country's best known strike-breaker, was found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of conspiring to operate an unlicensed detective agency.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Roosevelt today strongly condemned what he termed loose talk about the war, whether it came from the Far East or from Washington, where, he said, it was more prevalent than anywhere else.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 15 (AP) -- Paul F. Cadman of New York, economist for the American Bankers Association, predicted today that if this country gets through the war without being invaded by land it will enjoy the biggest business boom in history when the war is over.

LONDON, May 15 -- Details of the attack on Madagascar, in which it was confirmed that a British corvette was lost and a destroyer with a force of Marines made a dangerous surprise landing in the rear of the Antsirana defenders, were made known here today in a joint Admiralty and War Office statement.

SEVERAL years ago Tess Slesinger wrote a memorable story of bohemian and radical New York. She called it "The Unpossessed" -- meaning that its characters, unlike those of a Dostoievsky, acted out of an inner sterility. Unanchored and declassed, radical for reasons that could only be understood by a psychoanalyst, their rebellion added up to zero.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., May 15 (AP) -- The Navy's newest cruiser, the Mobile, got her first taste of salt water today in one of the quietest launchings ever staged at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company plant.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 15 (AP) -- Superior Court Judge Ernest A. Inglis issued a bench warrant today charging a 30-year-old volunteer fireman with starting or attempting to start eight fires in Eastern Connecticut, recently the center of a series of blazes which caused $3,000,000 damage in this State and Rhode Island.

The five-story industrial building on a plot 250 by 100 feet at 36-52 Colden Street, Jersey City, has been sold by the Esenbe Building and Loan Association, in liquidation, to the Fifty Colden Realty Corporation of Jersey City, Sam Ogus, president. Revenue stamps attached to the deed show a consideration of $80,000.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Roosevelt said in response to a question at his press conference today that the War Shipping Board should control the loading of ships at American ports.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 15 (AP) -- Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor in 1938, cautioned the public tonight against "bidding against each other for consumer goods."

Recent reports from Washington that restrictive orders affecting rubber thread for use in foundation garments would mean the return of "grandmother corsets" for American women were contradicted yesterday by Harold P. Kurzman, president of the Foundation Garment Institute of America.

Roswell Magill, Professor of Law at Columbia University and a former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, recommended yesterday that the Treasury Department permit an income tax deduction of life insurance premiums "to some limited extent," in an address at the second semi-annual seminar of the New York Chapter, American Society of Chartered Life Underwriters, in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. More than 500 members of the organization attended the sessions.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine discussed night baseball yesterday with President L.S. MacPhail of the Dodgers, and it was understood they probably would meet again today, when President Horace Stoneham of the Giants also may be present.

At the forty-ninth annual dinner of the National Sculpture Society last night at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, Royal Cortissoz, art critic of The New York Herald Tribune, was made an honorary fellow, "in recognition of his great scholarship and his years of devoted service toward a wider understanding of the best in American sculpture."

Considerable fanfare seemed to follow Red Ruffing's achievement last Sunday in notching his 248th victory. That gave him at least two more triumphs than any other active pitcher in the major leagues at the present time.

Two scarves that the State charges were used with adhesive tape to suffocate Mrs. Susie Flora Reich, a refugee, last March 4 when she was robbed of $2,000 in jewels in a suite in the Hotel Sutton in East Fifty-sixth Street, became evidence yesterday in the General Sessions trial of the three alleged slayers.

NEW ORLEANS, May 15 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, while warning of necessary sacrifices during the war, gave assurance tonight at the National Conference of Social Work that there would be an adequate supply of food and other essentials provided they are "equitably distributed."

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company and the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company purchased yesterday $1,100,000 of notes of Rochester, N.Y., at an interest rate of 0.48 per cent plus a premium of $14. The obligations, dated May 20, 1942, will become payable on Jan. 20, 1943.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 15 -- A challenge to politicians and labor leaders to subordinate their interests to the war effort was laid down by L.A. Chambliss, president of the New Jersey Bankers Association, here tonight. Mr. Chambliss, who is vice president of the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark, spoke at the association's thirty-ninth annual dinner in the Hotel Traymore.

LONDON, May 15 -- Despite the huge rebuilding programs for merchant shipping, British circles believe that control of such shipping will probably continue for at least eighteen months after the war. This opinion found expression today during consideration of a White Paper outlining the governmenus scheme for the post-war purchase by British ship owners of new vessels built for the government.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- In the heart of an industrial area that admittedly is accomplishing a remarkable job of heavy ordnance production, an outspoken Army colonel asserted yesterday that the Ordnance Department was not even beginning to tap the resources of small, independent machine shops.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 15 -- For two hours today the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Senate heard Foreign Minister Ernesto Barros Jarpa discuss Chile's position in the world conflict.

Sammy Angott was successful last night in the first defense of his lightweight championship of the world. Fighting Allie Stolz, speedy young Newark challenger, Angott received a split-decision victory in a hard-fought fifteen-round contest that was witnessed by a crowd of 16,099 fans in Madison Square Garden.
BERLIN, May 15 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique today said:

CHUNGKING, China, May 15 (AP) -- Japanese troops from several ships, each carrying more than 1,000 men, attacked on Monday Nanjisu Island, off the central part of Fukien Province, a Chinese communique said tonight. At last reports fighting still raged, it said.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The negotiations in regard to the future status of Martinique, Guadeloupe and French Guiana are moving out of the dramatic into the sphere of details, with the probabilities for ultimate agreement increasing, although this will take some time because of economic questions that require treatment, it was learned here today.
ALBANY, May 15 -- Women's role in the war was the theme of a two-day biennial convention of the State Division of University Women which opened here today.
Leases of quarters for business purposes centered yesterday in the midtown section of Manhattan. A variety of concerns signed for space, including a trade board and an orchestral association.

The unearned-run situation keeps getting worse. It is now the accepted standard alibi for explaining away defeats when the home team loses because of its own errors, while, on the other hand, it goes unmentioned when the home team wins on its opponent's miscues.

CANBERRA, Australia, May 15 -- Treasurer Joseph B. Chifley introduced in the House of Representatives today legislation implementing the Commonwealth Government's decision to enforce a uniform income tax throughout Australia, to which the States expressed unanimous opposition at a recent Premiers' conference.

Warmer weather was a favorable factor affecting retail trade here this week, tending to offset restraining influences such as gasoline rationing and the imminence of the retail price ceiling on Monday. Department store sales were held likely to make a slightly better showing than in recent weeks, with gains ranging between 5 and 10 per cent over the corresponding period last year.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 15 -- Dr. Ramon Castroviejo, New York eye specialist who is in Buenos Aires to investigate the possibility of restoring President Roberto M. Ortiz's sight by surgery called on Senor Ortiz professionally for the first time today and spent about forty-five minutes testing his patient's eyes.

Chemistry and synthetics are the answer to perplexities arising from shortages in food flavorings. Begun long before the war as a means of reducing production costs, development of imitation products has gone forward with greater celerity as foreign sources of supply have been lopped off one by one and ships have ceased to sail with such cargoes.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Office of Price Administration issued today its second question-and-answer bulletin on the general maximum price regulation, containing information on "what every retailer should know" about how the price regulations apply.

Rationing is a form of economic planning. It happens in wartime to be an unavoidable form, but the American public is beginning to discover that, while better than its alternative, it produces no miracles and involves very serious evils of its own. Some forms of rationing are simpler than others. Sugar rationing is a comparatively simple problem, certainly so far as the individual family's direct consumption is concerned.

Police Commissioner Valentine issued orders yesterday for the organization and enrollment of an "Emergency Taxi Corps" as part of the Air Warden Service. This followed the action of the taxicab industry in offering the services of its vehicles and drivers to the city for use in case of "extreme emergency."

ALBANY, May 15 -- Governor Lehman signed today the Johnson bill authorizing the spending of $50,000 for the preparation of plans for a vehicular tunnel under the Narrows from Staten Island to Brooklyn. The bill makes an appropriation out of the new postwar planning fund to the New York City Tunnel Authority, with the money to be repaid later by the Tunnel Authority.

HAMILTON, N.Y., May 15 -- Delegates to the annual convention of the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs moved today toward a strong platform declaration on foreign policy with full recognition of the responsibility of the United States in cooperation with other free nations for establishing and maintaining a stable world order after the present war.

Boating is a sport which has a thrill all its own and which naturally commands many hundreds of devotees. But in line with the current trend toward conservation and prevention of waste, I believe that certain facts concerning this sport and its effect on clothing should be made clear.

A marked decrease in auto traffic in the suburbs was reported yesterday but little if any diminution was noted by bridge and tunnel authorities on the first day of gasoline rationing. Scores of additional filling stations ran dry and cars and trucks with empty tanks were reported stalled in various parts of the city as the thirst for gasoline continued.

As an experiment in the condensation of news, features and departments to meet wartime conditions, the Columbia University School of Journalism issued yesterday a two-page newspaper, giving in brief form foreign and domestic news, editorials, sports events and movie, drama and book reviews.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Roosevelt reported today that American troops were getting into the fighting more and more and in new places all the time, and that American lease-lend aid to friendly foreign powers in April was at the rate of more than $8,000,000,000 a year.

The undaunted will of Holland to fight for the liberation and resurrection of the homeland was pledged last night at a meeting at the Netherlands Club, 10 Rockefeller Plaza, by Dr. Alexander Loudon, Netherlands Ambassador to the United States, in ceremonies commemorating the second anniversary of the fall of Holland.

AN ADVANCED UNITED NATIONS BASE, AUSTRALIA, May 1 (Delayed) -- Here is a typical day on a hillside bordering an airfield in the New Guinea area used by American fliers, an airfield that in the course of the day saw a bombing raid during which your correspondent's right knee was firmly embedded in the back of a Brooklyn boy occupying the same protective trench.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Her acceptance of an appointment as general merchandising consultant to the Office of the Quartermaster General, announced on Thursday by the War Department, will not mean any interruption of her work as first vice president of Lord Taylor, Miss Dorothy Shaver said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Completing a week of conferences in which they have been seeking a solution to the difficulties created for canners by imposition of an over-all price ceiling based on quotations of last March, government officials and canners were still without a definite program here tonight.

"Whispering Ghosts," a Twentieth Century-Fox melodrama, will open this morning at the Rialto. Milton Berle, Brenda Joyce, John Carradine, Willie Best, John Sheldon and Arthur Hohl head the cast of the film.

EVANSTON, Ill., May 15 (AP) -- If there were any doubts of Ohio State's ability to win the Big Ten track championship, they vanished in today's preliminary trials, which the Buckeyes dominated by placing men in thirteen positions.

The stock market continued yesterday to move into higher ground although gains were limited and the air transportation issues were under selling pressure. The losses in the air lines were of major proportions in some cases, fairly heavy selling being induced by the Washington order placing commercial plane travel under Army control as a war measure. Business was again light, with transfers on the Stock Exchange only 257,120 shares against 278,857 shares on Thursday.

Edward L. Shea, president of the North American Company, announced yesterday the declaration of a common stock dividend in the form of shares of capital stock of the Detroit Edison Company, in the same manner as dividends paid by North American in the last four quarters.

At least a partial antidote to the recently issued Polish White Book's official catalogue of German crimes against the Polish nation, which one has good reason to believe have the aim of complete extermination of Poland's national culture, is contained in the announcement of the creation of the Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences in America.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, May 15 (U.P.) -- Three new earth tremors of severe intensity occurred in Ecuador this morning as the toll of Wednesday night's disastrous quakes was estimated at 115 dead in Guayaquil and Portoviejo, capital of the maritime Province of Manabi.

LONDON, May 15 (U.P.) -- The Royal Air Force, swinging back into action after a five-day lull caused by bad weather, joined British light naval forces in a virtual blockade of the French coast today, sinking or damaging three German minesweepers and raising to six the number of German ships smashed in those waters in a few days.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Acting under instructions from President Roosevelt, Price Administrator Leon Henderson tonight ordered gasoline-rationing boards over the country to make the types of ration cards they have issued and the names of persons receiving them a matter of public record.

The Henry Hadley Medal for outstanding services to American music during the year was presented to Mrs. Edward MacDowell at the annual reception of the National Association for American Composers and Conductors last night at the Waldorf-Astoria.

A fifteen months' accumulation of evidence, obtained by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's grand jury investigating possible official corruption in connection with the Staten Island phase of a $50,000,000 city-wide paving racket was forwarded yesterday to District Attorney Farrell M. Kane of Richmond County with the request that it be presented to another grand jury for criminal prosecution.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Roosevelt posed for pictures today with Mahmoud Hassan Bey, Egyptian Minister to the United States, and a photograph was transmitted to Cairo as the first picture to move on a direct radio photo service between the United States and Egypt.

The efficiency with which the Greater New York Fund distributes contributions to benevolent institutions was emphasized by former Mayor James J. Walker in an address at the fund's first borough-wide report luncheon for Queens, held at the Aviation Terrace in the Administration Building of La Guardia Field yesterday.

The wartime expansion of our Army and Navy opens a career of uncertain duration to many thousands of young Americans -- that of the commissioned officer. President James Bryant Conant of Harvard, speaking at one of the public meetings of the Council on Books in Wartime, held in the New York Times Hall, raised a sound objection to present plans for concentrating officer training on students already in college.

Following the call for speeding up coal shipments in the off-season, furniture manufacturers were hopeful yesterday that the War Production Board would take similar steps in recommending the building up of stock piles of their goods, particularly since furniture is so bulky and there is little likelihood that heavy shipments will be possible in the Fall due to expected transportation difficulties.

Provision of $1,475,000 for State income and Federal income and excess profits taxes reduced the net profit of the Universal-Cyclops Steel Corporation to $364,139 in the quarter ended on March 31, according to the report announced yesterday.

Appearance of the first issue of corporate bonds since April swelled the total of new bonds offered this week in this market to $15,698,000, compared with only $9,720,000 in new issues marketed last week. A year ago this week $60,820,000 in bonds were offered for public subscription.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, May 16 -- Reports received here from Moscow this morning indicate that Russian forces on the Kerch Peninsula have stemmed the German advance, at least temporarily. The town of Kerch itself -- despite yesterday's Rumanian claims to the contrary -- is still in Russian hands.
CALCUTTA, India, May 15 -- Two factors shaped the course of the war in Burma that has been so disastrous to the British and Chinese.

PITTSBURGH, May 15 -- The increasing number of mine labor disputes which have been developing in this industrial area in the last ten days and which some observers fear may grow to serious proportions unless checked today was blamed on the delay of the War Labor Board in establishing a wage policy as a result of the negotiations in the "Little Steel" case.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- A large part of the negotiable wealth of the Philippine Islands, including several tons of gold, silver and securities, escaped capture by the Japanese as the result of successful removal of it by a United States submarine in a feat described for the first time today by the Navy Department.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 15 -- Westchester, Putnam and Dutchess Counties had surprise blackouts simultaneously tonight and the test was featured by hundreds of simulated incidents. Also in the zone ordered darkened without advance notice by Thomas W. Darrah, Deputy State Director of Civilian Protection, were four communities in Ulster County -- Highland, New Paltz, Clintondale and Milton -- and two in Columbia County, Ancram and Copake. The blackout lasted an hour.

NEW CITY, N.Y., May 15 -- Sheriff Edward C. Dormann of Rockland County and five others were indicted by the May grand jury here today on charges growing out of an investigation into the numbers racket. The investigation was conducted by State police headed by Lieutenant Charles LaForge of the Monroe, N.Y., barracks on a special order from Governor Lehman.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 15 (AP) -- Senator Charles L. McNary, minority leader, led with 25,834 votes to 6,560 in his race for renomination against Arthur M. Geary, Portland attorney, on the basis of 378 out of 1,770 precincts counted in today's primary election.

Existing information on civil service and industrial jobs for women is entirely "too vague" and "too confusing" for most college officials, Mrs. Chase Going Woodhouse, consultant of the National Roster of Scientific and Specialized Personnel, declared yesterday.

The opening of the Washington Square outdoor art exhibition yesterday revealed that the war had cut heavily into the ranks of artists who have participated in this semi-annual show since its beginning ten years ago.

Workers in the current drive for funds for the work of the Coordinating Council of French Societies reported yesterday contributions amounting to $22,000 toward a $75,000 goal. The amount, gathered in the week following the drive's opening, was announced at a luncheon in the council's headquarters, 451 Madison Avenue.
BOSTON, May 15 (AP) -- Mickey Walsh's Branmintan chalked up his third victory in four starts today as he handily won the Suffolk Downs featured Saugus allowance dash for 3-year-olds.

After handing over five pennies recently to a B.M.T. woman ticket agent, I was quite agreeably surprised to hear her say, graciously, "Thank you." I then countered with: "Madam, during the thirty-seven years that I have lived in America this is the first polite word I have ever heard from any railroad ticket agent."
A total of 1,475 entries, a new record list for open golf competition, was announced yesterday by the United States Golf Association for the Hale America national open tournament.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 15 -- On the spacious grounds of the Garden City Hotel today the American Fox Terrier Club held its sixty-ninth specialty exhibition. In several respects it was a unique event in the history of the noted canine organization.
The Giants seemed to be playing both sides of the board yesterday, but happily they had on their side a young man named Willard Marshall, who moves only with a single-minded purpose.

Discrimination against employing Negroes is "unjust, undemocratic and constitutes a serious threat to our national unity," according to a "statement of principles" made public last night by the National Catholic Committee on Negro Employment at a meeting at the Catholic Club in the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Roosevelt's first move to carry out his proposal to reduce the ceiling on farm products to 100 per cent of parity prices was rejected tonight by Senate farm leaders, after a conference at the White House.

BERLIN, May 15 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The High Command said German and Rumanian troops were at the gates of Kerch tonight after breaking Russian resistance on the heights outside the easternmost town of the Crimea at the end of an eight-day sixty-mile drive through the Kerch Peninsula.

UNTIL recent weeks the story of Bacon's Rebellion had been pretty largely neglected by the historical novelist -- a circumstance which may seem curious in view of the dramatic quality of the material and its obvious significance in the long struggle waged by Americans to secure their political liberties.

OF the major figures in musical history Giuseppe Verdi has been written about with relative infrequency. Compare the outpouring of books and pamphlets about Richard Wagner his contemporary, not forgetting Wagner's own voluminous writings.

DANVILLE, Ky., May 16 -- Centre College of Kentucky is at least partly prepared to meet enrollment problems caused by war conditions because of a successful effort to reduce, the rate of freshman failures at the 123-year-old institution.

A YEAR or two ago few Americans had so much as heard of geopolitics, and probably most of those who had heard of it regarded it is just another crazy dream of Hitler's. Now we know it was not Hitler's idea originally but that he got it from Major Gen. Karl Haushofer and his Institute for Geopolitical Study.

MUCH interest attaches to the announcement made last week by the Whitney Museum to the effect that, a cooperation with other leading American museums, it has established what is to be known as the American Art Research Council, an agency for research in American art, with particular relation to problems of authenticity."
Mr. and Mrs. Kent S. Clow, Kent S. Clow Jr. and William E. Clow 2d have arrived at the St. Regis from Lake Forest, Ill.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 -- Rallying for four runs in the eighth, Temple University defeated the Manhattan nine today, 8 -- 6. The Owls drove Red McNeil to cover, Earl Gotwuls's single being the deciding blow. John Ryan relieved McNeil after Temple had scored one run.

SUMMIT, N.J., May 16 -- The Army team of Vic Ghezzi and Pat Mucci advanced to the semi-finals of the New Jersey pro-amateur golf championship today at Canoe Brook. Ghezzi, a corporal at Fort Monmouth, and Mucci, a Fort du Pont sergeant, eliminated Harold Sanderson, home club pro, and Dr. R.R. Lauckner Jr., 1 up, after finishing second in the qualifying round this morning with a five under par 68 on the south course.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Simultaneously with the swearing in of Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby as director of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps this morning, the War Department announced detailed plans for recruiting members for the first women's army corps ever to be established in this country.

Favorable weather stimulated rei tail trade here last week, althoffgh gasoline rationing and the impending over-all price ceiling were restraining factors. Department store executives estimated the increase over last year at 5 to 10 per cent.

Shipping interests and national agencies concerned with the country's merchant marine in both war and peace are planning to make this year's celebration of National Maritime Day an outstanding one, in keeping with the important role of shipping in the war program.

FRESNO, Calif., May 16 (AP) -- Cornelius Warmerdam, world's greatest pole vaulter, cleared fifteen feet tonight for the twenty-second time -- twenty-two more times than anybody else has done it -- but he failed as the featured attraction at the West Coast Relays to attain his goal of sixteen feet.

THE Naumburg Orchestra will open its annual series on the Mall in Central Park Saturday, May 30, at 8:15 P.M., when the program will be conducted by Max Rudolf, with Cleonice Montvare, soprano, as soloist. Concerts also will be given on the evenings of July 4, July 31 and Sept. 7 (Labor Day) at the same hour.

LONDON, May 16 -- Flight Lieutenant Brendan (Paddy) Finucane, one of Britain's ace fighter pilots, and his friend and former squadron leader, Lieutenant Keith Truscott, who saved Lieutenant Finucane's life during an offensive sweep over France last year, have received a check for 1,000, to be split between them, as the gift of John Wren, a business man and sportsman of Melbourne, Australia, it was made known here tonight.

THE "sound" of snow falling on a velvet collar, condensed milk flowing from a can and the lurch of an airplane in flight have provided a few of the more ridiculous problems actually presented to radio's sound effects engineers. Of course they never solved them -- they didn't try.

AMONG the considerable number of new books on democracy that have come to his notice the present reviewer finds it hard to recall a more straightforward and useful lesson for our times than is contained in the present volume. There is a certain inspirational value in tracing the march of democracy through the ages, as any number of anthologies have done, including one from the hand of the present author.
LONDON, May 16 -- The King and Queen attended their first football game of the war today, visiting Stamford Bridge to watch the Interallied Services Cup final between the British Army and the police.

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, received last night the 1941 award of the New York Society for the City of New York as last year's "outstanding native-born New Yorker" at the society's twenty-eighth anniversary beefsteak dinner in the Grand Street Boys Club House, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The German Crimean offensive against the Kerch peninsula has probably -- but not certainly -- initiated a new phase of the vast Russian campaign. Along 2,000 miles of front the armies that have fought through Summer heat, Winter cold and Spring thaws are now preparing for the gigantic clash of arms that another Summer means.

Queens, with a population of 1,414,000 and an area of 108 square miles, will be blacked out tomorrow night from 9:30 to 9:50 P.M. in the fourth of a series of borough-wide practice blackout drills, Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday.

SEVERAL years ago a novel called "The Grapes of Wrath" was published and became justly famous. It told the story of the refugees of the Dust Bowl, the "Okies" and "Arkies" who traveled westward in endless streams looking for work. Steinbeck, in his excellent portrayal of these people, caught the desperation of their mood, their sense of personal defeat, their poverty and hopelessness.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Following is the text of the Army and Navy report on the progress of war:

CHICAGO, May 16 -- More than one-half million additional engineering man hours, the equivalent of 234 engineering years, are being made available to the nation's war effort through emergency measures taken by Illinois Institute of Technology, the largest school of its kind in the country.

THE chorus of heated dissent which has so often greeted the announcements of the Pulitzer awards in literature will hardly be raised against this year's selections, and that is not merely because our minds are largely occupied with other matters.

Phil Hurt, a fair-to-middling blocking back far Swede Larson who also has been Coach Max Bishop's shining baseball light, did not allow the Columbia nine to get in the way of the Navy's winning streak yesterday at Baker Field. Aiming at ten straight, the Middies succeeded, handing the Lions a 6-1 setback.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- In a joint release issued here today the United States Army and Navy reviewed the military progress of the war from the Japanese surprise attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7 down to the present.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 16 -- Princeton's varsity 150-pound crew reached an end-of-season climax by beating Pennsylvania and Harvard to win the national lightweight crew championship and set a new Henley course record on choppy Lake Carnegie today.

The Metropolitan Division of Bundles for America will benefit from the supper dance to be given tomorrow in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria to mark the opening of that rendezvous for the season. It will be the first benefit entertainment sponsored by the division, which, through its Salvage Sewing Project, operates more than 250 workrooms in this city and its suburban areas under a directive of the War Production Board.

Contemporary styles of furniture are already showing in their design the impact of wartime restrictions in the use of materials and labor. It would seem, however, that these limitations have not hurt the appearance of the furniture; in many cases greater simplicity and unity have resulted.

With the death on May 9 of Mrs. John W. Paris of Flushing, L.I., the garden club movement of America lost one of its most energetic, efficient and best-loved leaders. In 1914 she founded Long Island's first garden club at Flushing, and for ten years served as its president.

IN her first novel Miss Botsford has produced an interesting and precise picture of the peons in an obscure village of Mexico before and during Pancho Villa's revolution. She knows and likes those simple people and ably communicates both her affection and knowledge.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 16 (AP) -- Bob Bensinger of Sidwell Friends School, Baltimore, and Charles Oliver of Perth Amboy High School stroked their way to the final of the twenty-second annual interscholastic invitation tennis tournament today as Hill School clinched its third straight team championship.

The Eastern States mixed team-of-four tournament, for the Wilbur C. Whitehead Memorial Trophy, will be played in two sessions this afternoon and tonight, at 2 and 8:30 o'clock, at the Park Central Hotel. Both are open to the public.

BIRDS come back from their widespread Winter homes in procession synchronized with the opening of blossoms. Feathered fliers began returning to the metropolitan area in March, when robins arrived on lawns sprinkled with crocuses. Forsythia shrubs bloomed in April, and gray phoebes reappeared. Wild brow sparrows with white bibs once again hopped about in Central Park singing prophetic love songs, briefly resting and feeding before journeying on to Canada.

I am an American. I say those words with gratitude, faith and pride. Gratitude to the generations of hard-working and God-fearing men and women who came to this New World to make a home for freedom. Faith that the democracy they built will never die. Pride that my chance has come to show that I can defend their labor worthily.

Limiting the swashbuckling Pirates to two hits, both made by Johnny Barrett, the 22-year-old Ed Head yesterday hurled the Dodgers to an 8-1 triumph and the longest first-place margin they have enjoyed in ten years.

A man who calls himself Joseph Dunn returns to New York after five years in Brazil and is immediately offered a job which lands him in plenty of trouble. With the threat of a charge of murder hanging over his head he is forced for a time to do the bidding of as ruthless a gang of crooks as is seldom encountered even in crime fiction.

A proposal to pledge "complete loyalty" to the Federal Government and the United Nations in the war was modified to eliminate the word "complete" and then adopted by the New York East Methodist Conference at its annual meeting yesterday at Hanson Place Central Methodist Church, at St. Felix Street, Brooklyn. The meeting started Thursday and ends tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Commander Henry E. Eccles, 41, of 5 Bullard Place, Flushing, N.Y., who commanded an American destroyer during the Battle of the Java Sea and in other naval engagements in Eastern waters, told reporters this morning anecdotes which emphasized the initiative and resourcefulness of American sailors under fire.

ON a table in an office high above Times Square there stands an Aladdin's lamp, its once brightly burnished sides now dulled and darkened as if its magic spark had long since flickered out. Surrounded by stacks of papers, it is on the whole a rather unimpressive object.

MARY M. Column, in her review of "New Poems, 1942," an anthology of British and American poetry, makes the statement that the "bulk" of the poets seem to be "engaged in a discourse instead of the writing of a poem";

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 16 -- Harvard engaged in its first formal track meet of the season at the Harvard Stadium today and its talents were pretty much on the unknown side, but the Crimson, scoring heavily all afternoon, upset highly favored Yale to win its third Heptagonal Games championship.

Intensified by the belief that camping, under present war conditions, becomes one of the major solutions to the Summer care of children, the drive for the Johanna M. Lindlof Camp Fund for Public School Children will get under way tomorrow and continue until June 15.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 16 -- Governor Lehman, while giving today his approval to the principle that no person should receive Federal and State pensions at the same time, vetoed as technically unsound the Pillion bill covering that situation.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The sequence of events in the Washington discussions over the amount of the gasoline ration follows:

Donald M. Nelson, war production chief, and Leon Henderson, price administrator, will be the principal speakers at the three-day annual convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, which opens on May 25 at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, the association announced yesterday.

Seven metropolitan women's groups are assisting in the renovation of the Soldiers and Sailors Club at 283 Lexington Avenue, whose new building, clubrooms and garden are being prepared for a Decoration Day opening. The building, a gift of the USO, gives much needed expansion to the club, which was founded during the last war by Mrs. Francis Rogers.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sunday, May 17 -- After more than twelve hours of hotel-room conferences, the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs, at its tenth annual convention early this morning, endorsed the candidacy of Thomas E. Dewey for the Republican nomination for Governor.
Syracuse oarsmen ruled the Harlem yesterday in their two-race regatta with Columbia that marked the close of the campaign for the rival crews.

The development of active liquidation and some hedge selling near the end of trading in yesterday's cotton market reversed an earlier upward trend and brought active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange to final net losses of 7 to 10 points.

MOSCOW, Sunday, May 17 -- Increasing daily in scale and scope, Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's offensive against Kharkov is steadily pushing the strongly resisting Axis troops back from their well-equipped fortified positions. The Red Army has liberated many inhabited places and captured quantities of guns, tanks, trucks, munitions and food.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 16 -- The following is a translation of what was released here this evening by the official Vichy agency as the text of the American note handed on May 9 to the French High Commissioner in the West Indies, Admiral Georges Robert, by Rear Admiral John H. Hoover:

The story of the Marblehead's voyage home described in THE TIMES as an epic of heroism should fill every patriotic American with a sense of pride. In your editorial "The Unsinkable Marblehead" you referred to the fact that there was a Marblehead in the United States Navy during the Civil War and another during our war with Spain.

ANENT your remarks recently concerning permanent casts in radio dramas, you mention that this is not a new thing. Among the earlier examples of this practice was a series given by NBC under the general title of "The Silver Flute" -- notable alike for imaginative treatment and considerable variety in setting.

Tested data on the use of flash with Kodacolor is now available in the Wabash Bulletin No. 301. "Flashing Kodacolor," which lists exposure tables and other information for shooting Kodacolor indoors by artificial light. The Daylight Blue Superflash in the various sizes, said to have the higher 6,000 degree Kelvin temperature required for use with the daylight color film, is used as the basis, of the tables.

THERE'S nothing about Jessica Tandy, the young English actress who walked off with her share of critical praise for "Yesterday's Magic," that even remotely suggests the glamour girl of the theatre. She's an extremely attractive young woman who happens to be playing a leading part opposite Paul Muni, but you'd never guess her professional status, in talking to her, if you hadn't been told.

LONDON, May 16 (U.P.) -- Commando troops ranged far behind the Axis lines in the last big Libyan offensive, ambushed enemy columns, destroyed more than eighty planes, attacked truck columns and damaged airfields, the British announced for the first time today in revealing but a part of the details of the hit-and-run warfare.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 16 -- Fordham shut out the Army nine today, 5 to 0, in a five-inning game.

A NEW-BORN baby wakes up hungry, cries to be fed, but has to wait until the clock moves around to the appointed hour. In his ignorance of the science of nutrition, baby has the old-fashioned idea that eating is intended to relieve a hunger-pang in his stomach; he has to get over that idea.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, May 16 -- An appeal for a broadened basis for the Government has been made by the War Veterans Association to Prime Minister Peter Fraser through Legislative Councillor William Perry.

President Manuel Prado of Peru, on the second full day of his visit to New York, met Governor Lehman yesterday morning, addressed an engineering convention in English and Spanish and spent the afternoon at the Belmont Park races where he sowed some inter-Americaan good-will by presenting a Peruvian silver trophy to the winner of the Metropolitan Handicap.

The proposal before Congress for a joint income tax return for husbands and wives was disapproved yesterday by the majority of a hundred lawyers attending a tax clinic in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street. The informal standing vote was about 3 to 2 on the issue, which on Friday was approved tentatively by the House Ways and Means Committee.

NEW ORLEANS, May 16 -- The profession of social work, in a democratic sense, "must function from now on" as an activity of government, delegates to the National Conference of Social Work were told today at the final session of the organization's sixty-ninth annual meeting.

LEEDS, England, May 16 -- Prime Minister Churchill, speaking here today, paid tribute to the "noble manhood of Russia" and "our kith and kin in Australia who, like ourselves, lie under the menace of an imminent enemy attack and who, like ourselves, are going to strike a heavy and successful blow on all who spring upon us."

Despite the fact that there was no one in the field to offer a serious challenge, Frank Dixon, St. Francis Prep star, yesterday uncorked the fastest mile ever turned in locally by a schoolboy at the twenty-fifth annual Athletic Association of Private Schools track and field championships at Baker Field.

HERE is an exceptionally intelligent treatment of a fundamental and contemporary problem -- the relations of advancing science and technology to broader human values. If this advance continues to a point where science and industry may serve man with maximum efficiency, paradoxically must they not destroy their own worth to him by coming to dominate his culture and enslave his spirit?

"TIME AND THE PHYSICIAN" is the autobiography of a distinguished professor of medicine and medical consultant who was born in an obscure Canadian hamlet and ultimately became Osler's successor at Johns Hopkins.

WHEN and if another Spring blooms, Tim Moore, currently keeping his eyes peeled in all directions as the dusky air raid warden in the graveyard sketch of "Harlem Cavalcade," will pack his battered trunks and mosey back to Rock Island, Ill., where he was born.

Federal authorities in charge of training men for the country's merchant marine, the greatest ever projected by any nation, estimated last week that 120,000 unlicensed seamen and about 26,000 new licensed officers would be required by the end of 1944 if the ship production plans are carried out through that year.

LONDON, May 16 -- Declaring his belief that the beginning of victory was in sight, Prime Minister Churchill told 25,000 war workers and farmers in Leeds, Yorkshire, today, that if the Axis nations decided to "play rough," Britain would play the same game in repaying any tortures that might be inflicted either upon Britain or her allies.
EVANSTON, Ill., May 16 -- Ohio State never had won a Big Ten outdoor track and field championship until today, but when the school finally came through it did so with a bang.

Volume on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was the smallest for a Saturday since August 16, but prices improved fractionally. The market was also the narrowest since the same date, and of the 409 issues traded, 188 rose, eighty-seven fell and 134 were unchanged. Turnover was 122,130 shares.

IT is time to report a controversy that has now been in progress, off and on, for several weeks in various papers that are interested in literary matters. It began with an exposure of the dog-in-the-manger policy of Ireland's most famous seat of learning, and by a devious route it has reached the question of Anglo-American copyright.

Dealers in the Washington Market district, now operating under dimmed-out lights, are working out tentative plans to shift their operations in supplying the metropolitan area with fresh foods to daytime hours if Army officials decide it is necessary to black out the section.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- An arrangement whereby the government will absorb the increased transportation costs involved in keeping New York and New England industries supplied with bituminous coal has been worked out by the Office of Price Administration, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the War Shipping Administration.

War or no war, Spring has come to Crawford Notch, to Tuckerman's Ravine, and to other favorite spots in the White Mountains. And Summer is on the way. To talk of keeping vacationists away from these well-known haunts is like talk of turning the St. Lawrence away from the sea.

IN THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 10 Mr. Lang concerns himself with the question of revising the Baroque opera and comes to the conclusion that performances of Handel's operas might be successful. I believe that the excellent musicologist has too much confidence in stage managers, directors and singers if he believes they might be capable of overcoming by their genius and skill the problems of Baroque opera.

The economic objectives of the Atlantic Charter "will be impossible if we follow policies of narrow economic nationalism, such as our extreme and disastrous tariff policy after the last war," Secretary Hull declared in a statement hailing National Foreign Trade Week, which begins today.

THE very thought that the Fleischer music collection of the Free Library of Philadelphia is in danger of being discontinued is the most alarming news on the musical front. At this moment, when there are so many efforts being made to preserve and to build up the culture of America -- recognizing its importance to defense -- it seems almost inconceivable and inconsistent that such a move as this should be contemplated.

There was a lull in most markets as the trade awaited stabilization of prices pursuant to the ceiling regulations, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

The area of the Army Eastern Defense Command from Maine to Florida inclusive was declared to be a military area, designated as the Eastern Military Area, in a proclamation issued yesterday by Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding general of the Eastern Defense Command and the First Army, in accordance with War Department instructions.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (U.P.) -- A three-man mediation panel of the National War Labor Board will begin hearings Monday on the dispute that led to the recent thirteen-hour strike of 8,000 building service employes in 800 New York apartment houses.

Included in the cast of characters printed at the beginning of this book is the name of Thomas Stearns Eliot, who is described as an expatriate poet. T.S. Eliot does not appear in person in the story, but some of his poems do, and it is in one of them that Fergus O'Breen finds a clue which sets him on the right track.

BAYONNE, N.J., May 16 -- The first of a new type of P-T torpedo boat, an improvement on the type that proved a scourge to Japanese naval and air craft in the Philippines, was launched this afternoon at the yard of the Elco Naval Division of the Elco Boat Company here before 5,000 persons.

DON'T scoff right off, but the demise of the double feature is closer at hand than one could be expected to believe, even with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Twentieth Century-Fox planning to continue delivering their respective films at the rate of one-a-week during the 1942-43 season.

EVER since the first Belgian troops escaped to England in the Summer of 1940 to form the nucleus of the present Belgian Army in Great Britain, that army has been growing steadily. Nearly half the men of the Belgian fighting forces now in Britain have escaped from the occupied countries by one means or another, and new recruits are still arriving from all corners of the earth.

LISBON, Portugal, May 16 -- Italy approaches the end of her second year of war a disheartened underfed and embittered country. It would be difficult to conceive of a government with less popular consent than fascism has today.

The letter of Lawrence Langner, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 9, condemns generally any compulsory licensing of patents and goes so far as to say that "it would be an economic disaster if the patent system were undermined by a compulsory license law."

In the Koshland case (298 U.S. 441) the United States Supreme Court held that a stock dividend is taxable where the stockholder receives an interest in the corporation different from that which his original stock represented.

Among small trees few combine so many desirable qualities as the hawthorns. Varying in form from upright trees to those with a spread twice as great as their height, they present a wide choice to fit various needs. Not only are they lovely ornamentals when in bloom in the Spring and when their highly colored fruits develop later, but at all times they present clean foliage and interesting form.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 16 -- Harvard and Cornell split an Eastern Intercollegiate League doubleheader on Soldiers Field today. Cornell won the first game in two extra innings, 8 -- 5, while Harvard took the second by the same score in the regulation seven innings.

The short, dark man with the jutting jaw, iron-gray hair and piercing eyes merely leaned a little further back in his swivel chair yesterday when told it was his thirty-fifth anniversary as Chief Fire Marshal of New York City. The clips and the city records were the authority,

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The United States Government pointedly ignored today the action of Pierre Laval in making public his version of this country's proposals for neutralization of Martinique and other French New World possessions.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, reported last week to his membership on the agreements signed by sea unions with the War Shipping Administration in Washington, covering conditions applying in the American merchant marine service for the duration of the war.

Americans always were a traipsin' people. They traveled about the East on horseback before there were any roads and, after the roads came, took their covered wagons out beyond road's end, over the plains and mountains to the Western ocean. The arrival of the automobile really set them free.

MAGGIE TEYTE, the English soprano, who has been one of the most distinguished interpreters of French songs, has not been in this country in a good many years. A new generation of listeners have not had the opportunity to see and hear her at first hand.

THE BIBLE keeps on in the face of the pagan revolution. The Gideon Society has distributed 1,000,000 copies of the New Testament to the American armed services and has 2,000,000 more copies on the presses.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 16 -- Private advices from Vichy late tonight indicate that, while comment will not be permitted on what was presented there as the United States note and the French reply to it, diplomatic quarters believe there is still a possibility of settlement.

The major result of the war upon education will be the increased use of films as an educational medium, Professor Robert Gessner, chairman of the motion-picture department of the Washington Square College of Arts and Science of New York University, said yesterday.

Dr. Donald B. Marsh, a university teacher of economics, in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 26, criticizes my proposal of a sales tax to mop up surplus purchasing power, as outlined in my letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 19.

CHUNGKING, China, May 16 -- Reports from Chinese sources here on Japanese treatment of internees in Shanghai, Hong Kong and Singapore say that both British and Americans are being subjected to calculated humiliations, indignities and privations.

WARBLING SIREN -- In a paper presented before the American Physical Society Dr. Grant Hector, Gordon Guernsey and Chester Marcinkowski of the University of Buffalo suggest that air-raid sirens warble like birds.
BERLIN, May 16 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:
The Hudson River Day Line will resume operations for the 1942 season on May 29, Alfred V.S. Olcott, president of the line, announced yesterday.

LION FEUCHTWANGER, the novelist, and Leo Mittler have been turning their hand to the drama and have just finished an original play called "The Brothers Erikson." This is based on the life of Erik Jan Hanussen, one of Europe's best known clairvoyants, who was found murdered near Baireuth in 1933.

THE title of this book leads the reader to expect a wide-sweeping survey of the native stocks and human cultures of South America. On the whole this expectation is well fulfilled, at least as far as the intelligent lay readers to whom it is primarily addressed are concerned.

IN the half dozen books which preceded this one Elizabeth Janet Gray has covered a wide field.
