"Young Walter Scott" with its truth and charm and thoroughly readable quality for young and old set a high standard in biographical writing for boys and girls and was followed some years later by a well-rounded, interesting life of William Penn.

Offenbach's "The Tales of Hoffman," which has not been heard professionally here in five seasons, was presented in English by the San Carlo Opera Company yesterday afternoon at the Center Theatre. Carlo Peroni conducted. The production was often musically charming.

A nation-wide school and community program, designed to utilize all the resources of education in helping to win the war, has been started by the Progressive Education Association. It is planned to establish thousands of "community councils." consisting of school leaders, parents and responsible citizens, to act as a unifying force in this ambitious project.

The universities and colleges in this country are now giving the opportunity of doing musicological work during the Summer vacation to those students who are engaged in other activities during the Winter. Interested students will find such opportunities from the East to the West, from Harvard, Columbia and Cornell to the Universities of California in Berkeley, Los Angeles and Stanford.

Answers to several questions dealing with merchandising under the General Maximum Price Regulation, submitted to the OPA by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, were made public yesterday. They are as follows:

Plants that have been part of the indoor garden during the Winter months come in for their share of Spring treatment in preparation for the Summer ahead. As soon as danger of frost has passed, they may be made part of the outdoor garden -- a benefit not only to the plants, but also a way to make less work on fewer fronts for the ambitious gardener.

The difference between the amateur and the advanced worker in photography lies in the way they take advantage of the lessons our mistakes can teach us, according to Adolph Fassbender, F.R.P.S.,F.P.S.A., New York teacher of photography and champion of the control methods.

To the Ra Edifor; ARE not certain protes that have been appearing in the press about United States broadcasts rather untimely? Exi cept for th diffusions in English I from Tokyo, nothing sent out across the vast expanse of the Pa-' cffic is quite so hilarious as the' F mul.tifarious mispronunciations of l our unitecLStats announcers.

The somewhat sugary opening of this story is easily explained. Catherine Verney is the Cissie Sprague of a radio program aimed at American housewives and the assumed personality is not easily shaken off when she leaves the microphone. But a kidnapping and a murderer are enough to make her forget all about Cissie Sprague; she becomes human and remains so until the end of the story.

How to keep a garden healthy will be taught in a two-day short course on insect and disease control, to be given at the New York Botanical Garden June 2 and 3. The course will consist of two lectures in the mornings and two demonstration and practice periods in the afternoons.
LINCOLN, Neb., May 16 (AP) -- Nebraska made it four straight Big Six track and field championships today, blanketing the field with a display of all-around strength seldom seen in a conference meet.

The war committee of the Bar of the City of New York, representing all the bar associations in the city, made public yesterday an eleven-point program under which the war work of the legal profession here would be coordinated and directed.

Directed to correlate their mathematics courses with other subjects in the aeronautical sciences in order to prepare more high school students for officer training in the Army and Navy, 200 mathematics teachers attended last night, a dinner of the mathematics section of the New York Society for the Experimental Study of Education at the Columbia University Faculty Club to hear specialists describe aviation applications of algebra, geometry and trigonometry.

LONDON, May 16 -- A striking force of 10,000 Japanese with heavy tanks and batteries of field artillery is reported by Chungking at Mong Lin, on the Mekong River, in the Shan States, and fighting is under way there and at Keng Tung and Mong Hai.

The war program of the newly organized salvage committee of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association will be advanced by two benefit events within the next fortnight -the annual flower mart on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral, to be held Wednesday, and the formal opening for the season of the Essex House Casino-on-the-Park the night of May 29.
BOMBAY, India, May 16 (Reuter) -- At a press conference here today Mohandas K. Gandhi, Indian spiritual leader, assailed the United States for its part in the war.

THE odd thing about Pierre Laval is that he believes that he has had a very successful, even a noble, career. He rose from nothing to fortune and high position in his own country. His name has become known throughout the world and his word may sway the course of the war and history.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The start of the sixth month of war participation by the United States finds the shipping problem the major immediate concern of this country. The problem is reflected alike in military and naval action around the world and in the lives of almost every individual.

Freight forwarders in the New York area expressed the hope last week that the War Shipping Administration would yet find means of giving them participation in the tremendous business attending the movement of lease-lend exports.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., May 16 -- Western Hemispheric solidarity is no mere high-sounding phrase at the University of Florida where twenty-two Latin-American students reside not as a group but in an inter-American dormitory section, where the roommate is a Florida born and reared student.

A slight improvement in business conditions in the Detroit and West Coast areas was reported yesterday in the survey of business conditions by purchasing agents' associations. The Purchasing Agents Association of Detroit reported that the change-over in auto plants had been accomplished and payrolls were rising, while the Purchasing Agents Association of Northern California, Inc., also reported that dislocations from defense shifts have been overcome.

Appropriations totaling $1,218,500 were made in 1940 and 1941 by the Spelman Fund of New York, the biennial report disclosed yesterday. In 1941 $787,500 was distributed in seventeen different allocations, an increase of $356,500 over the amount appropriated during the previous year.

A group of broadcasters who have radioed news from overseas will be honor guests of the Women's National Radio Committee at a luncheon on Tuesday, when its nine annual awards will be presented in the field of radio. Mme. Yolando Mero-Irion, who founded the organization eight years ago to encourage higher standards in radio performance and programs, will preside at the gathering in the Hotel Pierre.
NOT one precious grain of the halt pound of sugar a week to which our brand new ration books entitle each of us must be wasted on dishes that "don't turn out."

THIS is very much more than a wartime spy thriller. The events it covers begin on March 19, 1940, with Norway for background and carry on through Hitler's invasion of Holland, Belgium and France, ending only on June 18, 1940, with Winston Churchill's announcement to the world that Britain and the British Empire would fight on till Hitler was defeated.
BOSTON, May 16 (AP) -- Wildness of three Braves pitchers, who gave up eleven bases on balls, today enabled the Cardinals to gain a 7-to-4 victory.

Hunting deer with longbow and arrow in Westchester County will no longer remain in the realm of fantasy or fiction. The State law now provides that from Nov. 15 to Nov. 30 a licensed hunter may take one deer by this method.

THE laughter of children should be encouraged these days, both for the sake of the children and to keep our own perspective a little clearer. Humor is important; laughter is beyond price. Children laugh instinctively, according to Dr. Florence Brumbaugh, principal of the Elementary School at Hunter College.

HAVING helped the cinema to wash out "The Shanghai Gesture" last season, the Hays office showed little hesitation this week in approving the screen adaptation of "White Cargo," another sordid drama of the Nineteen Twenties, which has gone before the cameras at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer with Hedy Lamarr and Walter Pidgeon in the leading roles.

A diversified entertainment program is being devised for the indoor prairie fiesta entitled "The Round-Up," which will be given the night of May 26 at the Park Lane in behalf of the Madison Square Boys' Club. Stars of the theatre, concert stage and radio will contribute their services for the occasion.

THE officer responsible for the farthest-flung outposts of our armed forces is a light-haired naval man who comes from -- no handclaps, please -- deep in the heart of Texas. Admiral Chester W. Nimitz heads the joint defenses of Hawaii, he commands the Pacific Fleet, and his domain, which recently has been crowding uncomfortably on the Japanese homeland, is the northern half of the rolling Pacific.

ANNVILLE, Pa., May 16 -- Under their own leadership, the students of Lebanon Valley College have organized a Sub-Council of Defense. Their head is the captain of the football team, who is also chairman of the Day Students' Council and a member of Phi Delta Epsilon, the honor society of the college.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., May 16 -- Mount Holyoke College will give an engineering, science and management defense training course in industrial supervision this Summer, sponsored by the United States Office of Education and given by this college in cooperation with Northeastern University.

SEVERAL group shows opened in New York galleries last week. Artists represented at the Marie Harriman (which, by the way, announces that it will close at the end of June "for the duration") are Henry Botkin, Thomas Donnelly, Jo Cantine, Fuller Potter, Frank di Gioia, O. A. Renne and Patsy Santo, all of whom have exhibited there in the past.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -Eight officers who served at Wake, Guam and the Philippines and who are presumed to be prisoners of war, were in a list of 100 majors selected by the Marine Corps today for temporary promotion to the rank of lieutenant colonel.

The true English Wallflower is not usually thought of as a good subject for the dry air of a Midwestern Summer, especially when grown in exposed borders with only a meager protection against severe Winters. But even the extreme drought of the past season failed to daunt the ardor of this brave little blossom.

Aviation and shipbuilding, spurred by the unlimited requirements of the United Nations at war, turned in record profits in 1941 in spite of higher costs and tax burdens and in some instances substantial rebates to the government through renegotiated contracts or otherwise.

TEANECK, N.J., May 16 -- Announcement that a new and novel war course for future admirals of the Navy had been added to the "victory" curriculum of Bergen College was made by Dr. Ellwell F. Kimball, dean. The new course in naval history is patterned after the naval history course offered at the Naval Academy at Annapolis.

THE title of this hefty volume suggests that it will not crowd any mystery stories off the market. It is heavy going for the reason that analytical thinking is heavy going. Yet it is in its way almost a decisive document, for here are seventy or more scientists, philosophers, educators and practical men (the terms are not meant to be exclusive) wrestling with the problems of democracy, freedom and human integrity.

One does not expect a government bureau to be funny, but the regulations for women's lingerie issued by the War Production Board read like a joke. Germany might characteristically issue orders about teddy bears, panties, brassieres, hems on nightgowns and details of other intimate feminine attire, but would not the American way be to let women find their own details for economy through an appeal to patriotism?

FARMINGDALE, L.I., May 16 -- A showing of the motion picture "The Land" will be a feature of the eleventh annual luncheon and meeting of the Roadside Committee of the Long Island Association, to be held Thursday at the Institute of Applied Agriculture here.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Compromise of the deadlock between corn and wheat Senators over the proposed disposal of 125,000,000 bushels of the 350,000,000 bushels surplus of wheat for cattle feeding at below-parity prices appeared in sight tonight after the Administration reportedly agreed to the prohibition of the sale of such stocks at less than 85 per cent of the parity prices of corn.

HANS SCHWEIGER, the conductor of the Southern Symphony Orchestra, who was taken into custody shortly after the attack on Pearl Harbor, has been ordered confined to an internment camp for the duration of the war.

IN contrast to "Kings Row" -- which had a richly crowded canvas and a diversity of characters -- "Floods of Spring," Mr. Bellamann's new novel, is a strange, intensive study of one strange and lonely man who withdrew, in so far as possible, from any close or intimate contact with his fellows.

MAXIM LITVINOFF will be remembered, among other things, as the man responsible for putting Soviet Russia and the United States back on speaking terms again, but his English wife. Ivy, may be the one to make it stick. For while the new Soviet Ambassador has continued in Washington to add to his reputation as a shrewd and long-headed statesman, Ivy Litvinoff is the one who is winning the friends and influencing a great many people.

LISBON, Portugal, May 16 -- The last batch of happy Americans arrived in Lisbon tonight from Rome and Berlin to take the liner Drottningholm back to New York along with compatriots from Hungary and the Balkans and many South Americans from the same countries.

BOSTON, May 16 -- The Circle S Ranch's Hysterical and Louis B. Mayer's Sir Jeffrey raced to a thrilling dead heat today in the sixth running of the $5,000 added Governor's Handicap before 23,000 spectators at Suffolk Downs.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 16 -- For its thirty-ninth annual show held today on the tree-shaded lawns of the Garden City Hotel the Ladies Kennel Association of America received an entry of 506 dogs, a total slightly less than last year. It had been feared that gas rationing would have a deterrent effect on exhibitors, but there was an excellent attendance.
A NATION is reflected in its books, and today America at war is publishing an ever-increasing number of volumes dealing directly or indirectly with the technique of war.

A new chapter in the history of retailing in this country starts tomorrow when the nation's 1,900,000 retail establishments, with an annual volume of sales in excess of $53,000,000,000, begin to function at or under the March ceiling prices established under the General Maximum Price Regulation.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission announced yesterday that candidates for the examination for the position of patrolman in the Police Department will receive an extra week, or until 3 P.M. next Saturday, to file applications. The deadline was 3 P.M. yesterday, but the Eccf2nsion wag ordered because not more than 10,000 applications were on hand.

There's many a sad heart today among motorists as that three-gallon ration sloshes emptily in the gasoline tank. Thoughts are nostalgic of the carefree, dust-in-your-eye days that used to be -- when drivers measured their country in 500-mile daily trips, instead of a six-mile daily radius.
On the vacation calendar for the warm months ahead, underscore the Eastern dude ranch.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Treasury is standing firm, against mounting protests from colleges, charities and church organizations, on its proposal to tax bequests to all three groups and certain revenues of the latter two; and the House Ways and Means Committee has kept the proposal among the devices to finance the war which it is seriously considering.

THE fact isn't very well known, but Graham McNamee, dean of big-time radio announcers, who died a week ago last night, actually got his start in the early days of broadcasting by walking on the "wrong" side of the street.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A country which has become accustomed to doing a large part of its traveling and shipping on rubber-wheeled vehicles is being forced back on rail transportation by rationing of gasoline and restrictions on tire buying.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 16 -- General Friederich Karl von Lossberg, well known commander in World War I, died in Luebeck today, aged 75 years, it was reported here today from Berlin. He will receive a state funeral on the orders of Reichsfuehrer Hitler.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 16 -- After three days' discussion of the supply and production problems in this area, delegates of the Middle East Supply Council meeting here have either returned to their respective countries or are taking part in the agricultural section of the conference that is planning ways to increase crops.

BY an odd but convenient coincidence, two new pictures opened in these precincts last week which offer an interesting contrast in the treatment of social problems on the screen. As every one knows, social problems are generally avoided in films, particularly those which involve a real conflict of class interests.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- At the fortieth anniversary meeting of the Monroe County Resort Association, held in Stroudsburg, the sixty members of the organization unanimously re-elected Charles N. Thompson, vice president of The Inn at Buck Hill Falls, as its president for the coming year, while A.F. Everett, newspaper man, was re-elected executive secretary.

A cocktail party will be given tomorrow afternoon at the Stork Club for committee member sponsoring the performance of the new musical comedy, "All's Fair," to be given for the benefit of the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The date for the benefit, originally set for June 1, has been postponed to June 8.
JAMES T. FARRELL works in the living room of the apartment near Columbia where he lives with his wife and their small son.

Three masked robbers, angered when one of eight victims of a poolroom holdup at 1 Pitt Street threw a cue ball at them as they fled with $58, indiscriminately opened fire and wounded two of their victims yesterday. They escaped in a stolen car after a mile chase through the congested lower East Side by detectives whose shots only blasted the windows of the robbers' automobile.

The following statement issued by Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, shows receipts and payments of the City of New York for April, 1942 and 1941, together with receipts and payments from July 1, 1941, to April 30, 1942, and for the similar period of 1941.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 16 -- Addressing the Chamber of Commerce of Danzig and West Prussia, Dr. Walther Funk, the German Minister of Economics, declared that the economic foundations of the eastern provinces would be so constituted as to insure the security of those areas as a granary for the German people.
DERBY, Conn., May 16 -- Howard Odell, Yale's new head football coach, has his staff lined up and will announce the personnel within two weeks.

WHEN this department remarked a month ago that the basic trouble with the theatre is the lack of good scripts, the playwrights did not cringe with shame. An avalanche of protesting letters swept down on this desk.

It is a commonplace which nevertheless cannot be repeated too often, that to grow beautiful, long-stemmed, brilliantly colored and healthy flowers, frequent cultivation of flower beds is as essential as watering or fertilizing, if not more so.
The Ballet Theatre has taken up its residence for a period of four months in Mexico City, at the invitation of the Ministry of Education.

A ship captain and six crew members, including a stewardess, were killed by the explosion of a torpedo that sank a small Norwegian merchant vessel off South America, seven survivors disclosed today. The sinking was announced in Brazil on April 13.

From Mayor La Guardia's office at City Hall there came yesterday the hint that an interesting "surprise'' would feature the observance of "I Am an American Day" on the Central Park Mall this afternoon. Efforts to ascertain the nature of the "surprise" were fruitless.

Their offensive weapons still thundering, the suddenly rampant Giants belted the rather inoffensive Reds at the Polo Grounds yesterday by a 7-2 score, impressively recording a clean sweep of the three-game series.

In selecting a design for the 3-cent purple stamp to be issued on June 1 to commemorate the admittance of Kentucky to the Union a century and a half ago the Post-office Department has once more turned to the archives of canvases produced by noted American artists.

MALCOLM BRINNIN'S first book of poems, "The Garden Is Political," has a title that fits contemporary verse. No longer, like Voltaire's Candide, can a person cultivate his garden with a purely private pleasure.

LONDON, May 16 -- Experience is a great illuminant and in the light thrown on the effects of enemy air raids over Britain it is worth while to look back and see whether the arrangements we made for our homes in anticipation of enemy action from the air were adequate or whether there are any preparations we would have made, had we obtained the knowledge that we now possess.

TORONTO, Ont., May 16 -- For hundreds of miles in the sparsely settled areas of Northern Ontario the only schoolhouse is a railway car fitted as a schoolroom, which pays periodic visits to the small communities on the northern frontier.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 16 (U.P.) -- United Nations and Japanese air and naval forces were believed preparing tonight for a renewal of the Coral Sea battle, but the official silence of a week was maintained on the first phase of the engagement, which ended last Saturday.

Americans must become "community minded" and work together to rebuild a new world after the war ends, Dr. Harry A. Overstreet, formerly Professor of Philosophy at City College, declared yesterday at the "I am an American" luncheon sponsored by the Board of Education's evening elementary division.

TWENTY-FOUR years ago a thin little sergeant who had been drafted sat in his tent between drills at Camp Upton humming tunes and scribbling verses. After some one had put on paper the melodies he plunked out on the camp piano and some one else had typed the unexpected rhymes written in a scrawling hand, "Yip Yip Yaphank" was ready for rehearsal.

Preaching on "I Am an American'' Day, in accordance with the proclamation of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman, rabbis emphasized yesterday that the declaration "I am an American" carries with it not only honor and privileges, but duties and responsibilities.
LISTENING to a story and tucked up for a midday nap, these little boys and girls are in charge of professional and voluntary workers at Hampstead's Wartime Day Nursery in the London area.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- American shipbuilders are breaking all records in the production of merchant vessels, but a shortage will continue "until sinkings throughout the world are brought under better control and the shipbuilding program gets into full production," the White House stated today.

The metropolitan area comprises three States, nineteen counties and more than 200 separate villages, towns, boroughs and municipalities. If any of the important highways that interconnect these communities were bombed, or if a fire broke out in large public markets or in an oil refinery, millions would go without food, fuel and other necessities.
MOSCOW, May 16 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau communique said today:

An exhibition of portraits of patriots of the past will be opened next Wednesday at the Gotham branch of the Grand Central Art Galleries, 2 West Fifty-fifth Street, to inspire patriots of the present. It is being arranged for the benefit of scholarships in American citizenship at Barnard College, Columbia University.

Gas rationing or no gas rationing and even if such members as Mel Hayes, Harry Jackson and A.F. Jenkins are limited to three gallons of fuel a week, which is hardly enough to cruise them out to Execution Light and return, the New York Athletic Club Yachting Department faces the season of 1942 bravely.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 16 (AP) -- Jacques Doriot, ex-Communist who is a leading French pro-Nazi in Paris, is championing the movement to bring France into military cooperation with the Axis, it was reported today, and foreign observers expressed belief he might step into Pierre Laval's place if full collaboration is not accomplished soon.

CLEVELAND, May 16 -- The Indians divided a double-header with the Senators today, taking the first game, 5 to 4, with one run in the ninth inning. Sid Hudson outlasted a parade of Cleveland hurlers in the second game to win, 7 to 1.

PROMINENT in the accomplishment of Greenwich House, the settlement at 27 Barrow Street which is celebrating its fortieth anniversary this month, is the work of its music division. When the Greenwich House Music School started in 1906, four years after the settlement house opened its doors, one room and a single piano were all that was needed to meet its requirements.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it had taken title to about 197,000,000 bushels of 1941 wheat, stored in commercial warehouses by farmers under the government's price-supporting loan program.

UNDER an enigmatic but significant title, the German novelist Alfred Neumann (self-exiled since 1933) has written a powerful and dramatically unusual story of the French defeat in 1870 and of the Paris Commune.

ON the admirable suggestion of Virgil Thomson a Music Critics' Circle was formed in this city over a year ago. Its principal purpose was the encouragement of native talent for composition. The method advocated was that each member of the Circle should report to headquarters when he saw some alarming signs of creativity on the musical front that he covered, and that action then be taken to detect the identity and equipment of the enemy.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 16 -- Dr. William Lloyd Evans, chairman of the Department of Chemistry and Professor Emeritus of Ohio State University, received the annual American Institute of Chemists medal at the institute's twentieth annual meeting tonight.

In line with the latest educational trend of establishing special classes for the bright, the Board of Higher Education has authorized Hunter College to train teachers in methods of educating exceptionally intelligent children, it was announced yesterday by Professor Philip R.V. Curoe, who supervises the teacher-training program at the college.

With drastic gasoline rationing now in effect along the Atlantic seaboard, where normally 40 per cent of the nation's oil consumption is centered, motorists are watching eagerly the outcome of the tug of war now going on between Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator and Secretary of the Interior, and the Texas Railroad Commission relative to a further drastic slash in the output of petroleum in Texas.

Changes in leadership in several women's clubs of Connecticut have resulted from their Spring elections, although many others will continue for their second year of the war under present executives whose terms are still to be completed.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Phil Marchildon, the Athletics' spurting sophomore, was within range of becoming the first big league pitcher to win six games when the White Sox rallied for two runs in the ninth inning today to beat him, 4 to 3.
A part of every street light in the five boroughs will be painted black, it was learned last night as dissatisfaction with dimout effectiveness continued to be voiced by Army and police officials.

HERE is a rattling good yarn of local and State politics down in Florida during the bootleg era. Mr. Wilder calls his city Truro, a name which recalls another political novel published thirty-six years ago -- Winston Churchill's "Coniston," a novel celebrating the elongated Yankee, Jethro Bass, whose little hobby of collecting mortgages combined with a certain native wit and shrewdness resulted in his becoming boss of the State of New Hampshire.
ATLANTA, Ga., May 16 (U.P.) -- Earl Browder was released from the Atlanta Federal Penintentiary at 3:27 P.M. today, his sentence commuted by President Roosevelt.

Norwegian National Day, which occurs on the 128th anniversary of the Norwegian Constitution, will be celebrated today throughout the city by men and women of Norwegian descent and friends of the Nazi-invaded country.

Auctioneers who tried to "muscle in on" the securities business were primarily responsible for the formation of an organized stock market in this city on May 17, 1792. They underlined the need of a central exchange for the bonds of the United States Government and forced the brokers to take action.

GUILFORD, Conn. -- Connecticut's vacationland, from Old Saybrook westward to the New York State line, envisioned new and more promising prospects for the Summer season this week as Army and State defense officials lifted the dimout restrictions which for more than two weeks had held traffic to a snail's pace and prohibited bright lighting after dark.

War costs money * * * Our war program for the coming fiscal year will cost $56,000,000,000, or in other words, more than half of the estimated national income. That means taxes and bonds, bonds and taxes.

OTTAWA, May 16 -- During the United Nations air training conference which will open here formally on Tuesday there will be a truce to what is called the Quebec "crisis" over the man power issue, it was understood today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 16 -- More than 200 outstanding objects of useful and artistic nature, the work of pupils, were shown to parents today at the annual fair of the Westchester Children's Workshop, an activity of the Westchester County Recreation Commission, in the Little Theatre of the Westchester County Center here.

BORDENTOWN, N.J, May 16 -- The first break in the model Bordentown Prison Farm here occurred shortly after last midnight, and today Leroy Jenkins, 31-year-old Philadelphia and Camden gunman, was at large.

M. Laval made that statement as he released the text of what he said was a United States note regarding French possessions in the Caribbean area and also made public the text of a French reply.

Mrs. Charles Parker Stone will give a tea tomorrow at her home, 216 East Seventieth Street, for members of the Judson Health Center volunteer women's committee who are working to advance the center's war program. A series of benefits is now being planned to aid the clinics maintained by the institution, which annually serves more than 30,000 frnlies in the West Side district from the Battery to Twenty-eighth Street.

I read the article recently in the Magazine Section, "Heeded, 50,000 Nurses." In this all-out defense effort there is a large source of nursing knowledge and experience that is almost completely ignored. Why not give the Negro nurses of America a fair chance to serve their country?

New York City's 7,500,000 inhabitants generally are "at home" today. Gasoline rationing, effective since Friday, has reduced to the merest trickle of traffic the outbound week-end motorists, sometimes counted in hundreds of thousands.

A tug of war which has been going on for eighteen years among women's clubs, received fresh impetus last week when the Equal Rights Amendment was placed on the Senate calendar with its first favorable recommendation from the Judiciary Committee.

The systematic disappearance of 6,000 popular books valued at a total of $15,000 from the Book-of-the-Month Club, 385 Madison Avenue, in the past year was believed to have been solved yesterday when detectives from the East Fifty-first Street station arrested four men.

In 1932 the Republican State Convention met at Buffalo. About thirty-five young men came to it fired with the notion of inspiring the young people of New York with the aims and ideas of the G.O.P. They banded together, founded what became the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs, which was affiliated with an older national group, the Young Republican National Federation.

THIS is to express complete approval of the article on the WPA Music Project by Olin Downes in today's TIMES. There particular food for thought in portion dealing with the work the Philadelphia Library, Edwin Fleischer and Arthur Cohn in having American music copied made available for public performance.

HONOLULU, May 7 -- The constitutionality of the operation of martial law in the Territory of Hawaii, which was imposed on Dec. 7, following the Japanese attack, is questioned in an article in the May issue of The California Law Review, by J. Garner Anthony, prominent Honolulu attorney and a graduate of Harvard Law School.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Federal control over retail prices, backed up by a governmental licensing system under which recalcitrant storekeepers can be deprived of the right to do business, becomes effective at midnight tomorrow.

NEWARK, N.J., May 16 -- New Jersey clubwomen, in convention next week, will be asked to decide whether or not they should change from their present universal membership in the General Federation of Women's Clubs, to a status of non-universal affiliation.

ACCORDING to the horoscope of the United States, the war will last approximately four years, with victory coming in sight after January, 1945. But the book to whose interest this prediction forms the general pertinent climax is not at all a book of prophecy.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 16 -- Packer Memorial Church at Lehigh University was thronged with visitors from many States for the thirty-fifth rendition of the Bach Mass in B minor, the composer's great musical achievement, this afternoon. Standing room was at a premium by the time the Moravian trombonists opened the festival from the ivied belfry of the church.
MEXICO CITY, May 16 -- Mexico, it was officially indicated today, will now intensify as far as possible her protective patrols of the Gulf, following the sinking of a Mexican ship off Florida.

BERLIN, May 16 (From German Broadcasts Recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German Army has captured the ancient town of Kerch and its harbor and has over-run virtually the entire Kerch Peninsula after beating down stubborn Soviet resistance in a week-long battle, German authorities reported today.
The effect of the accelerated program to date has not resulted in any evident sacrifice in the standard of performance among students or faculty.

It is apparent that matters have gone very much amiss in the rationing of gasoline. The proportion of A cards issued is far lower than was counted on. The number of X and B cards is far higher. The result is that when the cards are all distributed, holders will have the right to buy more gasoline than is likely to be available.

This spirited, well written book has an especial significance today, for the scene of the story is Holland in the sixteenth century during the siege of Leyden, when the Dutch people were resisting a tyrant and struggling against almost overwhelming odds to win back the right to live in freedom.

The latest in the series of entertainments planned for the late Spring and Summer season to raise funds for the Navy Relief Society is a gala Victory Ball which will be held on the night of June 20 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, May 16 (AP) -- Rounding off a week of intensive day and night attacks on German shipping along the Continental coast, United States-built Hudson bombers blasted last night at two convoys near the Frisian Islands off the Netherlands, leaving three supply ships burning and four others probably damaged from hits.

IN the Southwestern Pacific a veritable ethnological museum is pitted against what Mussolini's radio assures us are "yellow Aryans." Javanese, Dutch, Filipinos, South Sea Islanders, Australians and Americans are being rallied, sorted out, re-equipped and assigned to further extermination jobs. The top man is the knightly MacArthur, who deserves a temporary rest from word portraits.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Assignment of specialists in procedures connected with the War Production Board's production requirements plan will be made to all field offices of WPB, it was announced here today.

Any one with eyes to see can find plenty of evidence these days that the fig is hardy within the limits of New York City. From a train window the unmistakable form of the tree and the character of the foliage are recognized instantly. On the road to Flushing or to Coney Island, fig tree after fig tree may be seen, flourishing in rich dark verdure.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 16 -- Alfred Shriver has been elected an alumnus trustee of the Williams College, it was announced this morning at the annual meeting of the alumni. Mr. Shriver, a member of the class of '15, is a partner of Morgan Stanley Co., and a trustee of the Staten Island Hospital.

As part of the movement for spiritual inter-Americanism, two seminars for graduate study will be held this Summer at the University of Havana, Cuba, and the National University of Mexico under the auspices of The Sign, national Catholic magazine, it was announced yesterday.
AN ADVANCED UNITED NATIONS BASE, Australia, May 16 -- The man best of all people in the world in a position to know had this to say today concerning Sergeant David Lowe of Bristol, Va.:

THERE was a time when an actor, if he was good, could be sure of playing to a crowded theatre; then came a time when he could aspire to an unseen audience of millions over a coast-to-coast network. Now, as a by-product of the war, the world is the limit.

BREWSTER, N.Y., May 16 -- Charles Strang, chairman of the local war council, announced today that Ralph Santorelli, blind high school boy who had written asking for a chance to do his bit, would start work as an active air raid warden here within two weeks.

UNDER a rolling barrage of question and answer explanations, the General Maximum Price Regulation takes over retail prices tomorrow and puts into effect the price tops of March on all except a short list of excepted items.

A man who was booked as Herman Hofer, 52 years old, of Miami, Fla., was charged with grand larceny at police headquarters last night, as a result of what the police described as a $32,000 complaint growing out of a card game in a Manhattan hotel in October, 1940.

A new slate of officers, headed by Miss Frances K. Marlatt, will be presented to the annual convention of the New York State Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, opening Thursday at Utica, and continuing through the week-end. Miss Marlatt, an attorney of Mount Vernon, is now first vice president and program chairman of the organization.

The cutting of the Burma Road is not going to reduce China to impotence. The far-sighted Chinese began moving their essential industries back from the coastal areas before the outbreak of the war, and in the first six months of 1941 the refugee plants produced $110,000,000 worth of goods and ores, compared to $20,000,000 for the corresponding period of the previous year.

At the pilot's cry of "contact!" the propeller spins, the engine roars, the plane taxis down the runway, slowly at first, then faster and faster until finally it leaves the ground. This has always been the customary result from the pilot's cry of contact.

Beginners who are planting Victory gardens this year will be pleased to learn that, despite the widespread supposition to the contrary, sweet potatoes can readily be grown quite far north. They are, in fact, considerably easier to grow than the Irish potato.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 16 -- The year's only intersectional rowing race moved over the mile-and-three-quarter course on the Charles River today and gave to the thousands on the Cambridge and Boston shores one of the greatest competitions the ancient sport has ever produced.

FOR no apparent reason, one December afternoon in 1918, auto owners of Coblenz on the Rhine had a simultaneous desire to go places -- and take their time about doing it. Their organized traffic jam held up American troops who had been foot-slogging in that direction, with some urgent interruptions, since the Argonne drive. The eagle-beaked, stubby Chief of Staff of the outfit inspected the mess, then barked, "Get some baseball bats from the chaplain."

IN his review of the Russian War Relief concert of May Mr. Olin Downes writes, "A bitter and ironical scene written Henry Brandt, with music by Bert Brecht, music which need not entertain us, and did not delay the show was also a good modern thes piece."

We [Privates Henry L. Holbrook and Laurence D. Perrine] had a great deal of fun composing our crossword puzzle and certainly were thrilled to have THE TIMES publish it, especially since both of us are ardent TIMES puzzle-fans.

"TO the memory of the Reverend Pater Ternes," says Barbara Frances Fleury in her dedication, "to three generations beloved as 'Father Pete,'" and it is easy to see that this portrait of a wise and lovable priest in a Michigan village is drawn from life.

Several days ago Dr. Roll Nugent, chief of the Automobile Rationing Section of OPA, proposed a very interesting plan for post-war deliveries. Individuals would place orders for automobiles on an installment payment basis and would receive preferred delivery after the end of the war.

MANITOWOC, Wis., May 15 -- "Uncle needs his boats" is the jubilant battle cry these days at the Manitowoc Shipbuilding Company, where the "local cheese-makers," as the Navy endearingly calls the natives of this district, milk their cows in the morning and then go down to the shipyard to build their famous "upside-down" submarines.

RICHMOND, Va., May 16 -- A process said to increase the amount of plasma which can be obtained from blood by as much as 30 per cent has been developed by the Lederle Laboratories, Inc., of New York City. This is revealed in two patents (No. 2,281,989 and 2,281,990) granted to Ivan A Parfentjev of Nyack, N.Y.

HANOVER, N.H., May 16 -- Evidence that scholastic accomplishment in college is related intimately to psychological factors and that student guidance programs need to attach much greater significance to individual motivational patterns has been presented at Dartmouth College in the recently completed report of a five-year investigation sponsored by the Dartmouth Eye Institute.

The Treasury's experiment with a new type of bond offering designed to appeal to large, long-term investors outside the banking field has proved a success. When subscription books closed last week, it was apparent that considerably more than $750,000,000 of the new twenty-five-year 2 1/2 per cent bonds had been bought.

The steps necessary to establish a system under which buses will space their stops four city blocks apart, instead of two as at present, were being taken yesterday by the Police Department. The new spacing, recommended by the Transit Commission, in conformity qth suggestions from the Office of Defense Transportation, has the approval of the bus companies, the Police Department and the ]Board of Transportation.

Two advertising pools of $1,000,000 each will be set up by the steel and soap industries for nation-wide salvage campaigns under the guidance of the Advertising Council, it was learned here yesterday. Details of the projected drives have not been fully completed yet and they have not been officially announced, but agreement has been obtained from manufacturers on the basic scope of the campaigns, it was reported.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The plane was known variously as the "Red Cap" and the "Gravy Train," but she has traveled 125,000 miles since Dec. 6, has carried nearly every British and American general stationed in the Far East, evacuated about one hundred civilians from Java and rescued two loads of men from the Philippines.

LISBON, Portugal, May 16 -- Adolf Hitler committed the greatest blunder of his career when he took upon himself the odium of declaring war upon the United States. That is the opinion held by those of us who lived in Germany and believe we understand German psychology.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- Charles D. Pack, Justice Department attorney, told the Senate Patents Committee today that E.I. du Pont de Nemours Company had agreed to help a German company regain its share of the South American dye market after the war.

While supporters of Earl Browder, former general secretary of the Communist party, prepared to welcome him on his return to New York this afternoon, officers of veteran organizations denounced President Roosevelt's action in releasing him from Atlanta Penitentiary as "the worst news that patriotic Americans have received since Pearl Harbor."

The world's two mightiest land armies, after months of preparation, moved into renewed action last week on Russia's war-torn fields. In the Crimea, Adolf Hitler's Wehrmacht hurled an offensive toward the Kerch Peninsula, springboard to the Caucasus and oil.

In the article "American History for Americans." appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of May 3. Professor Allan Nevins asks, in effect, why American history has become a negligible subject in the educational curriculum.

ALASKA'S land area is one-fifth of that of the United States proper, its coastline is longer, it is our nearest mainland to Japan, and its official flower is, appropriately, the forget-me-not. It has an alert defense force whose hardy virtues match those of its few civilian neighbors. Last year, confronted with housing problems, some of its commissioned officers built homes for their families with their own hands in off-duty hours.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 16 -- "Everywhere in Berlin these days people are heard discussing poison-gas war. Gas masks are again in evidence in the Reich capital after having been stored away for more than two years. At no previous time during the present war have Berlin political and military circles exhibited more concern over the possibility of poison-gas war."

Congressmen haggling over extra gasoline rations in the East may find their "X" cards extremely useful in this, an election year. No doubt unlimited "honor" rations will come in handy for political tours in the home counties. They will aid in upholding the honor and dignity of incumbents in the national legislature as they visit political workers in out-of-the-way towns to see that the fences are in good repair.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Messages of good wishes and commendation from President Roosevelt and from representatives of the Polish, Czechoslovakian and the Netherlands Governments-in-Exile tonight marked the opening of a war-emergency session of the American Jewish Congress.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 16 -- Over a four-legged course out on Long Island Sound, the first real yacht race of the season was held today. The winner was Joseph L. Merrill's International Class sloop Feather, champion of last Summer and a repeater from last year in this series.

DENVER -- This is one year when the dude ranchers of the West won't get an argument from anybody when they declare that a horse is sure a handy thing to have around. Almost everybody, particularly in the gasoline-rationed States, is agreed on that.

Diego Suarez fell to the British on May 7. Three days later American demands were made upon Admiral Georges Robert for acceptance of the drastic neutralization of Martinique. Admiral Robert is Vichy High Commissioner in the Caribbean Sea. Yet Pierre Laval, who resumed office one month ago on a program of full collaboration with Germany, has not so far taken up the challenge.

LONDON, May 16 (AP) -- A Stockholm dispatch, relayed by the Vichy French news agency and Reuter, said today that the Red Army, flanking Kharkov to the south, had breached the German defenses at Lozovaya in a drive to cut German communications with the entire front south of that point.

Miss Gwen Canfield, 57 years old, of Long Beach, Calif., and Sincoe, Ont., Canada, who arrived at La Guardia Field with fifty-seven other passengers aboard a Clipper Friday night, told her experiences as the only woman among 250 survivors of a torpedoed Canadian ship, in a statement released for publication yesterday by the Navy.

IN the current edition of "Who's Who in America," Major Gen. Charles H. Bonesteel -- he'll like you better if you pronounce it "Bonn-es-steel" -- does not consider his place of residence as his permanent home. Unlike other subjects in the big red book, he does not list his home, merely his "address," which is "Reykjavik, Iceland." Which is tactful evidence to aloof Icelanders that he doesn't intend to stay forever.

An interpretation of new price control regulations and war rationing will be made available to women's groups affiliated with the War Action Center at a forum on Tuesday at 8:30 P.M. at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

From Ecuador last week arrived the first four stamps in the long promised series with portraits of noted citizens. A 10-centavos green presents A. Baquerizo Moreno, lawyer, poet and a former President, now 80 years old. A 10c dark green and 50c brown for regular and 10c violet-brown for airmail use introduce Dr. Remigo Crespo Toral, writer, poet and statesman, who died a few years ago; he was Ecuador's poet laureate.

DETROIT, May 16 -- The Yankees were good and bad by turns today at Briggs Stadium. But, because the Tigers were worse, the world champions triumphed twice in a twin bill that attracted a paid crowd of 6,933.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., May 16 -The war has caused several changes to be made in plans for the annual Tuxedo Horse Show, to be held here June 5 and 6. Taking into consideration the exigencies of the war effort, Mrs. David Wagstaff, president of the show, and her committee are completing arrangements for an exhibition that will be unusual as well as impressive, with the inclusion of several wartime features.

Retail trade continued active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors were busy, casual and fur-trimmed coat departments were active and Summer suits met some demand.

ST. LOUIS, May 16 (AP) -- Ted Williams's homer was the big blow in the Red Sox 4-to-2 victory over the Browns today, while Pitcher Tex Hughson, a tall right-hander, held the Browns to two singles in notching his first victory of the season.

Long, leisurely Summers appear to be another of the war's casualties for a number of women's organizations. Now that their regular programs are drawing to a close, they are laying plans for the coming months when they can devote more time to war relief and civilian defense work.

So far as anything political can be certain in these uncertain times, Thomas E. Dewey will be the next Republican nominee for Governor of New York State. At this moment Mr. Dewey's most probable opponent on the Democratic ticket is Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., but the nomination of Mr. Bennett is not so certain as that of Mr. Dewey.

"MOSCOW Radio," after a silence of over six months, came back on the air recently with more power and zip than ever before. Special English announcers face the Soviet microphone and their voices have such a strong London flavor that they were at first taken for BBC broadcasters.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Those oddly wrought hieroglyphs appearing on the flanks of cattle browsing along the course of the transcontinental streamliner that streaks across the western cow country appear meaningless to those gazing from the car windows.

NEWARK, N.J., May 16 -- The will of Louise R. Pierson of Orange, N.J., filed here today for probate, contained several bequests to Princeton University, including two to honor her father, the late Dr. William Pierson, a physician in Orange.

TOKYO, May 16 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Successful large-scale Japanese Army operations in three Chinese provinces and air assaults on still other areas were reported today in Japanese dispatches.

OF the making of books on the Far East there has been no end since Pearl Harbor; and quality in this field has not always kept pace with quantity. Both the volumes under review, however, although brief in compass, have something original to offer in the interpretation of the complex Far Eastern pattern.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Millions of motorists and gasoline station operators in seventeen Seaboard States this week became participants in the greatest program of patriotic self-denial of their accustomed rights and privileges that this nation probably ever has placed before its civilian population.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, May 17 -- Russian tank formations, supported by infantry and cavalry, are reported from Moscow this morning to be within artillery range of the burning city of Kharkov, where, despite stubborn German resistance, tremendous gains were registered by the Red Army yesterday.

In spite of priorities and a general slowdown in the advancement of public projects, the City Park Department is finding ways and means of pushing ahead, piece by piece, the transformation of the great 1,216-acre tract in the Flushing Meadows of Queens from its one-time aspect as the site of the New York World's Fair of 1939 and 1940 into one of the finest of the city's parks.

THE MAGIC WATER" was lthe name of a sort of American pesion -- the setting of Miss Webster's engaging new novel. "L'Eat Enchantd' was painted on the ornate and bescrolled name-sig hung years ago at the lodge of kiss Peyton's estate and now faded and obscure.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 16 -- A full Hungarian Army division, including a skeleton armored brigade, has been thrown into heavy fighting against Serbian Chetniks in the Batchka district of Yugoslavia, where the Hungarians have massacred more than 5,000 Serbs since the beginning of a violent revolt at Zabalj six weeks ago, it was learned today from the most trusted sources.
Interesting are two cover reflecting territorial change of the second World War. Both come from well-known places in Yugoslavia.

New York University's crack track team registered an expected triumph over Manhattan College at Ohio Field yesterday. The Violets, champions of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A., swept twelve of the fifteen running and field events to bury the Jaspers under a 98-34 count.

A SHORT time ago the news dispatches from Santa Barbara, Calif., carried a strange story -- a bitter dispute between two retired Army majors over the status of the Santa Barbara Home Guard; an exchange of shots; the mortal wounding of one of the disputants.

POZNER'S book about the fall of France comes from the depth of personal experience. The author, French writer of journalism and fiction, went through the fateful weeks of May and June, 1940, as a chauffeur in the army, covering the roads of France as millions of refugees were fleeing in panicky disorder.

DERBY, Conn., May 16 -- In the rowing surprise of the season, a Princeton eight that had taken the wash of its rivals in every previous start scored a well-earned victory over Cornell and Yale today for the Carnegie Cup.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 16 -- The war work of banks and how they do it largely may determine whether in the post-war era free-enterprise banking will survive, Dr. Eugene E. Agger, New Jersey Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, said here today.

NEWTON, Mass., May 16 -- Byron Nelson, winner of this year's Masters' tournament, produced mechanically perfect golf today to put together a five-under-par 67 and a 72 in winning the second annual Massachusetts Big Eight tournament at the Charles River Country Club.

HONOLULU, May 15 (Delayed) -- General Emmons, commander of the Hawaiian Department and Military Governor, said today that "martial law in Hawaii has been purposely designed to meet war conditions of military and vital necessity which were forced upon these islands by a new type of fast long-range invasion warfare."

MEXICO CITY, May 16 (AP) -- A special meeting of the Permanent Congressional Commission was summoned tonight to meet Monday "to discuss Mexico's attitude in the international situation" created by the torpedoing of the Mexican tanker Potrero del Llano this week off the United States East Coast.
JERSEY CITY, May 16 (AP) -- Jersey City made a sweep of its three-game series with Baltimore today by taking the final game of the set, 5 to 1, behind the six-hit pitching of Hugh East.

Continued and increasing resistance to Axis control in Croatia is emphasized in a secret report from Zagreb, capital of the Nazi and Fascisti-created "Independent Croatia," that was smuggled to England recently and was transmitted yesterday by Dr. Juraj Krnjevitch, Vice Premier of Yugoslavia, now in London, to the delegation of the Yugoslav Government in this country.

Members of society from many sections of the East and guests from the South American countries attended the first Saturday program of the Spring meeting of the Westchester Racing Association at Belmont Park yesterday, and despite the rationed gasoline, there was as large a crowd at the Turf and Field Club as has ever witnessed the racing classic, the Metropolitan Handicap.

President Manuel Prado of Peru attended the racing at Belmont Park yesterday to see Attention capture the forty-ninth Metropolitan Handicap and to present a silver trophy, which was his gift to President George D. Widener of the Westchester Racing Association. Mr. Widener promptly made the trophy the perpetual prize for the famous mile run which stretches back through New York's racing history to the old days at Morris Park.

Anybody who has begun to worry about not being able to get household equipment because essential materials are used in war production can be immensely reassured by dropping into a show of substitutes and alternates, new uses of old materials and newly developed materials, arranged by Lewis Conger.

PANAMA CITY -- Panama has surprised collectors with a colorful and picturesque new series of eight stamps for regular and six for airmail postage. Values, colors, quantities and designs are as follows:

SOMETIME around the Autumn of 1940 the writing. editing, cooking, traveling Browns felt, as they say, the "tug of 'escape-to-Utopia.'" So they set off for Brazil, where for ten years they had got out the Brazilian-American Magazine every Saturday, and took an 8-000-mile trip up the Amazon.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- President Roosevelt today ordered Earl Browder, American Communist leader, released from the Federal penitentiary at Atlanta, where he had served one year and two months of a four-year sentence for fraudulent acquisition and use of an American passport.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 17 -- Ann Harding, whose last picture was the 1937 British-made "Love From a Stranger," will return to the screen in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Eyes in the Night," with Edward Arnold and Donna Reed, the studio has announced.

AMHERST, Mass., May 17 -- President Stanley King conferred degrees in course today upon 173 Amherst College seniors at the 121st annual commencement. About twenty-five members of the original class of 240 obtained leaves from the armed services and returned in uniform to receive their diplomas.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 17 -- Secretly planted dynamite charges and firecrackers provided Oslo inhabitants with their traditional May 17 salute this morning, although German orders had distinctly forbidden any celebration of Norwegian Independence Day.

ALBANY, May 17 -- Manufacturing employment in the State shifted to war industries in April, a report of Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller revealed today. Industries producing consumer goods were forced to curtail their employment while those engaged in war production reported further expansion.
CLEVELAND, May 17 (AP) -- The Indians took a double bill from the Athletics today, 4 to 1 and 9 to 3, with Jim Bagby and Al Milnar pitching four-hit games.

A long-range program of the Cowles Commission for Research in Economics of the University of Chicago, directed to analysis of factors determining rates of investment by advanced statistical and mathematical procedure, is another research casualty of the war, a decennial report of the commission disclosed today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 17 -- The tapping of a Navy telephone cable by German residents of a house on a hill overlooking Valparaiso Bay is still being investigated. The Minister of National Defense said yesterday that the Germans used the telephone cable only as an antenna for a radio.

CHUNGKING, China, May 17 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces have inflicted heavy casualties on the Japanese in Chekiang Province, where large concentrations of enemy troops have been reported during the past week, it was announced today.

A repossessed property in the Chelsea section of Manhattan has been added by Miles L. Bleecker, operator, to his holdings through the purchase of the nine-story loft building on a plot 56 by 92 feet at 13-15 West Twentieth Street. It contains a store and eight lofts and was bought from the Harlem Savings Bank.

The same conviction that gripped the Disciples after our Lord's Ascension must now at this hour of opportunity grip all Christians, declared the Rev. Frederic W. Golden-Howes in his sermon yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.

LONDON, May 17 -- British fighters and fast bombers returned to the offensive during daylight today with four major sweeps over the French coast that gave enemy bases there one of the hardest poundings of the air war.

LISBON, Portugal, May 17 -- Germany is a land of irritating shortages but it would be idle to assume that the lack of many things of ordinary living comfort means the nation is on the verge of collapse.

TOKYO, May 17 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Domei said today that a strong United States naval force, consisting of the 19,900-ton aircraft carriers Hornet and Enterprise, some cruisers and destroyers, had been sighted approximately 580 miles east of the Solomon Islands, steaming westward.

WICHITA, Kan., May 17 -- In a brand-new plant that sprang up in thirty days' construction time on the buffalo grass "somewhere in Kansas" the Cessna Aircraft Company will start large-scale production of gliders for the government under a new contract involving "millions of dollars," Dwane Wallace, Cessna's president, announced today.

BOSTON, May 17 (AP) -- A crowd of 25,000 came hoping to see Jim Tobin hit a home run today, but Bucky Walters stole the show from Boston's circuit-clouting pitcher by lifting one over the fence to pace the Reds to a 9-3 victory.

After a week in which financial markets were wholly dominated by war news, last week's markets sank back into the lethargy that had previously prevailed. Day-today developments at the various battle fronts had again become confusing. Even Washington began laying stress on the fact that Japan's naval reverse at the Solomon Islands was not an engagement of the enemy's whole fleet, which still outnumbered ours.

J. Dewey Dorsett, manager of the casualty department of Casualty and Surety Executives, explained in detail the workings of British Government war risk insurance at the semi-annual meeting of the Rhode Island Association of Insurance Agents a few days ago and urged extension of our own government's measures in the light of British experience.

In voting to reduce personal income-tax exemptions to $500 for single persons and $1,200 for married persons the members of the Ways and Means Committee showed courage. There will be no lack of thoughtless people to criticize their action. But such criticism can only come from a failure to look squarely at the hard choice we face.

TOKYO, May 17 -- From a Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Japanese Imperial Headquarters announced today that a British force of 20,000 had been crushed near Kalewa, 150 miles northwest of Mandalay, on Wednesday, and that the British eft 5,935 dead on the field.

A "nutrition for victory" campaign at Hunter College will begin today and continue through Friday, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Gertrude M. Borgeson, director. Aimed primarily at teaching Hunter girls correct diet habits, it is expected that the campaign will eventually cover the college community as well.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is prepared to buy from, or to make loans to, dealers in articles or commodities which have been rationed, according to an announcement today by Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce.

Drastic new regulations for dimming out lights of every kind throughout the city, effective at sunset today, were promulgated yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, as Major Gen. Thomas A. Terry, commanding the Second Corps Area, warned that existing dimout measures were inadequate because the sky glow in the metropolitan area was still strong enough to permit enemy submarines in coastal waters to find their prey silhouetted against the shoreward horizon.

MOSCOW, May 17 -- With the last snows melting in the warmth of Spring, the scene of the gigantic battle for Moscow late last Fall is now full of pathos. The writer has just had a chance to travel along the Moscow-Klin-Kalinin road beyond where the German thrust on the capital was stopped.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Few, if any, complaints are being received from the wheat belt, and in the main they refer to excessive moisture rather than to deterioration in the outlook. Recent reports suggest that the prospective Winter wheat crop is in at least as good condition as it was on May 1, when the Department of Agriculture estimated the yield at 647,000,000 bushels.

Brooklyn Hispano defeated Brookhattan, 5 to 3, and the New York Americans downed St. Mary's Celtic, 7 to 1, in a twin bill of Duffy Cup second round soccer at Starlight Park yesterday before 4,000 fans.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- The market for wheat is being called upon to face the reality that, with virtually all foreign outlets closed, the country is up against the most acute shortage of facilities for storage of grains that it ever has known. This is a result of the piling up of vast reserves of grain, due to yields above normal to the acre in the last few years.

LIMA, Peru, May 7 -- P.K. Norris and H.P. Moffit of the United States Department of Agriculture and E.R. Cook and J.A. Bohart of the United States Commodity Credit Corporation arrived in Lima this week by airplane from Washington to complete details of the agreement whereby the United States Government will purchase Peru's surplus cotton for the duration of the war.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained at the previous week's level of 106.3. Price changes were confined mainly to agricultural commodities. The strongest gains were recorded in meat and livestock prices, while the sharpest declines occurred in eggs, fruits, potatoes, poultry and tomatoes.

God is in great danger of annihilation in America today, for while we cannot actually destroy God, who is an eternal personality, we can destroy the knowledge of Him from the hearts and minds of the people, declared the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer in his sermon yesterday in Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

VICHY, May 17 -- The general assembly of the Credit Lyonnais heard declarations by its president regarded as interesting in relation to the situation of the big banks in general in France. The results last year were satisfactory, thanks to increases in operations and resources.
"Civilization's Debt to Bankers" is the title suggested in Topics of The Times of May 6 for a book or brief in defense of a much-maligned profession.

With many materials banished by priorities, cotton assumes new meaning in the fashion and the interior decorating scene, and its importance will be celebrated by National Cotton Week, which starts today.

HAMILTON, N.Y., May 17 -- After a belated, early morning endorsement of the candidacy of Thomas E. Dewey for the nomination for Governor, the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs ended its three-day session here today with a meeting of its board of governors.

BERLIN, May 17 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Dr. Hans Thomsen, former German Minister to Washington, was quoted in German dispatches from Lisbon today as saying that the United States was bluffing about almost everything about its military production and deliveries of war material. Dr. Thomsen arrived in Lisbon yesterday with the Axis nationals being repatriated in exchange for United States citizens.

Sunday school officials and teachers meeting under the auspices of the board of education of the New York Methodist Conference yesterday afternoon at Hanson Place Central Methodist Church. St. Felix Street, Brooklyn, with several pastors, were urged to work for increased attendance at Sunday school and church preaching services.
LONDON, May 17 (AP) -- The Burma communique stares:

The New York City Symphony Orchestra was conducted by Robert Lawrence of the music staff of The Herald Tribune at the third of the series of War Stamp concerts given last night at the Cosmopolitan Opera House under the joint sponsorship of Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA War Services in cooperation with Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians.

Eight methods of creating additional war jobs for New York City workers are being studied by the regional labor supply committee of the War Production Board, S. Park Harman, acting chairman of the committee and regional representative of the Bureau of Employment Security of the Social Security Board, disclosed yesterday.

BERLIN, May 17 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Sixty-eight thousand prisoners and huge quantities of materiel have been captured in the battle on the Kerch Peninsula, which now can be considered at an end, the Berlin radio announced tonight.

Twenty-eight of the thirty-eight sections of New York City department stores registered decreases in advertising linage in newspapers of the city during April as compared with the like month last year, according to figures made public by Media Records, Inc.

The filing of plans for the construction of a three-story and basement addition to the present premises of Beekman Hospital, at Beekman and Water Streets, was announced jointly yesterday by Elisha Walker, chairman of the hospital's board, and G.H. Niemeyer, chairman of the Emergency Building Fund Campaign recently initiated by the institution.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Business support for a proposed conference of industry and labor to work out the wage-stabilization aspects of the Administration's anti-inflation campaign was voiced today by Eric A. Johnston, new president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

WICHITA, Kan., May 17 -- Ben H. Miller, correspondent for The Baltimore Sun Papers, one of twenty newspaper men on the "production-for-victory" tour of the nation's war plants, was killed late today at Wichita in an airplane crash that also took the lives of the pilot and a local business man.

FRESNO, Calif., May 17 (AP) -- Although West Coast relays officials will seek to have Harold Davis's 9.4 seconds performance in the 100-yard dash recognized as equaling the world record, it appeared today the claim might not be allowed.
LISBON, Portugal, May 17 -- The food and financial situation in Italy is providing for Premier Mussolini his worst headache these days, for it is very grave.

David Diamond, 26-year-old American composer, has received the annual Rome Prize in music, it was announced yesterday by the American Academy in Rome, 101 Park Avenue. The prize consists of $1,000, as the academy has been unable to give its annual fellowships for travel and creative work abroad since the war began.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Research studies of problems of pos-twar economic reconstruction are provided for in grants totaling $130,000 made today by the Maurice and Laura Falk Foundation of Pittsburgh to the Brookings Institution of this city.

LONDON, May 17 -- The story of how photographs taken by a vacationist's camera proved invaluable in the preparation of a British raid on a German radio-location station at Bruneval, France, last month was told here today as the government launched a drive to obtain snapshots from family albums collected during pre-war holidays.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The tempo of the struggle for the world was materially stepped up last week in many different theatres of action.

MEXICO CITY, May 17 -- Leaders of labor and farmers organizations indicated today that they were planning an anti-Axis demonstration upon the arrival in Mexico City of the survivors of the Potrero del Llano, Mexican ship sunk by a submarine Wednesday.

ALBANY, May 17 -- Governor Lehman vetoed today the Halpern bill providing so-called "home rule" for scholastic varsity athletic programs. The measure would have taken control of these programs away from the State Department of Education.

Twelve additional performances of "Candida" will be given the week of May 24 at the Shubert Theatre. There will be no performances this week. The extension of the Shaw revival will start with a matinee and evening performance next Sunday, and there will be nightly showings through Sunday, May 31. In addition to the evening offerings there also will be matinees Wednesday, May 27; Saturday, May 30, and Sunday, May 31.

Harry Gluckin of New York has purchased from Jacob Spitzer the former Shaffer property at Chappaqua, in Westchester County, consisting of a stone residence with sixteen rooms, guest cottage of seven rooms, garage and seven acres of land.

Charging that the Rapp-Coudert committee seeks "to destroy academic freedom in our school system," the committee on constitutional liberties of the New York chapter of the National Lawyers Guild asked Governor Lehman in a letter and report made public yesterday to veto the bill appropriating $50,000 to continue its work.

WYETH, Ore., May 17 -- Lew Ayres, the film actor now in a conscientious objectors' camp, said tonight that he would be assigned to an Army Medical Corps unit tomorrow. The Dr. Kildare of the movies, who for two months has been at Camp Wyeth, a former CCC camp housing about a hundred war objectors, said he would report to the Army at Hood River, Ore., twenty miles east of this community.

American industry already has dealt painful blows to this nation's enemies since Pearl Harbor, but both industry and the consuming public must be prepared for greater efforts and sacrifices to insure ultimate victory, Philip D. Reed, chief of the bureau of industry branches of the War Production Board, told 800 manufacturers and business men last night.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 17 -- Standing in front of the new village hall, flanked by members of the American Legion, village trustees, judges and mayors from nearby towns, Colonel Frederick I. Devereaux, Mayor of Bronxville, after dedicating the civic center with its cluster of municipal buildings costing $250,000, made a surprise announcement that he was resigning as mayor tomorrow.

The San Carlo Opera Company last night ended its fifth local season of popular-priced grand opera at the Center Theatre. The work which closed the eleven-day engagement was Verdi's "Aida." It attracted a capacity audience and was conducted by Carlo Peroni, the company's musical director.
The text of the new dimout regulations as announced by Mayor La Guardia follows:

CHICAGO, May 17 -- An average wage rise of 8 cents an hour, increasing the basic rate for skilled mechanics in the nation's shipyards to a uniform $1.20 an hour, was approved today by labor, management and government representatives at the National Shipbuilding Conference here.

Twenty-seven players representing clubs in Montclair, East Orange, Plainfield, Westfield, Newark, Belleville, Bloomfield, Kearny and Nutley opposed Edward Lasker, international chess master, in an exhibition of simultaneous play at the Masonic Hall at Nutley, N.J., under the auspices of the Nutley Chess Club yesterday.
A brief dispatch in THE TIMES disclosed that syndicates throughout Spain have begun signing up workers for service with labor groups in Germany.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 17 -- The increase in purchases by Nicaragua from the United States in the last three years because of the war has increased the number of American concerns here, Colonel Irving A. Lindberg, Collector General of Customs and High Commissioner, reported today.

DETROIT, May 17 (AP) -- The Tigers used the home run method to subdue the Red Sox in the opener of a three-game series today, Jimmy Bloodworth's four-bagger in the tenth inning resulting in a 4-to-3 victory.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided yesterday morning at a solemn high mass of thanksgiving in the Capuchin Church of Our Lady of Sorrows, Pitt and Stanton Streets, in lower Manhattan. The occasion was the seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of the parish by the Rev. Bonaventure Frey, a Capuchin priest.

Ten Russian vocalists in this city were heard in an elaborate program of excerpts from celebrated operas of their native land at the concert presented by Michel Kachouk yesterday afternoon in Town Hall for the benefit of Russian War Relief.

"All work and no play," as our British cousins discovered when they experimented with the seven-day week, is a hindrance rather than a help. No matter how great your patriotic zeal, you cannot effectively attend first-aid courses every evening.
There is a strong prospect that all one-day betting records in this country will be wiped out at Belmont Park on Decoration Day, according to The Associated Press.

The final link of the East River Drive from Thirty-fourth to Forty-ninth Street will be opened next Monday, Edgar J. Nathan Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, announced yesterday. Special ceremonies will mark the opening, at which Mayor La Guardia, as well as the three Borough Presidents under whose administrations the drive was built, will speak.

Saluted and welcomed by Bishop John F. O'Hara as the first sovereign ruler of "a sister American nation" to worship as "a humble and faithful son of the church in the mother church of the Archdiocese of New York," President Manuel Prado of Peru attended solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Anthony H. Evans, pastor of the West Park Presbyterian Church for forty-seven years, the longest period of service in one church by any living minister in New York, announced his resignation as pastor during the morning service yesterday in the church at Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 17 -- Eight hundred members of the St. George Associations of the Nassau County Police Department and of the firemen of Nassau County attended the association's annual communion service and breakfast here today.

Scheduled in this city for the first time in forty years, the New York State Bankers Association's forty-eighth annual convention, which will be held from May 24 to 26 in the Hotel Astor, will be featured by a discussion of the war's effects on costs, personnel, lending activities and other bank functions, Eugene C. Donovan, president of the association, announced yesterday.
