Three thousand steel helmets, delivered to the city as part of an order for 22,000 and intended for the use of air raid wardens, will be diverted to the Police Department because of Federal regulations, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday in his weekly radio "Talk to the People," delivered from his desk at City Hall via WNYC, the municipal broadcasting station.

NEWARK, N.J., May 17 (AP) -- The Newark Bears, setting a whirlwind pace in the International League, boosted their newest winning streak to six games today by spanking their arch rivals, the Jersey City Giants, 13 -- 3 and 5 -- 4 before a crowd of 9,314.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 17 -- Our current dictator ridden world was compared with that of biblical times by the Rev. Dr. Frank M. Kerr in his address today all the third annual baccalaureate and commencement exercises at Hofstra College here.

A comprehensive program to build up a backlog of peacetime orders for consumers' durable goods through advance purchases on an installment basis, with delivery scheduled when the products are available, is advocated by the marketing research group of the war work committee of the Advertising Club of New York in a plan made public today.

Reflecting growing war needs, the demand for factory space in the New England States has increased so steadily in the last ten months that there has been a decline of 44 per cent in the amount of industrial property available for sale or lease, according to a survey just completed by the New England Industrial Development Conference of the New England Council.

ON THE ASSAM-BURMA FRONTIER, May 17 -- A few minutes after an unidentified Chinese general had committed suicide in front of his troops, who had been pursued across the Salween River, American Volunteer Group fighters roared down on the enemy in a "blitz" of bombing and strafing that so heartened the Chinese that they counter-attacked and inflicted a major defeat on the Japanese.

MOSCOW, Monday, May 18 -- The Red Army forces of Marshal Semyon Timoshenko are still advancing on Kharkov against strong German resistance, while powerful Russian striking formations have left Kharkov behind on their right flank and are pushing toward the heart of the Ukraine in the direction of Krasnograd.

Two Pan American Airways transatlantic clippers arrived yesterday afternoon within two hours of each other at La Guardia Field with 102 passengers, eighteen of whom were from Europe, establishing a passenger record since the entry of the United States into the war.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- In an instead of in 1943, the War Production Board will reorganize around June 1 its system of distributing essential raw materials and expendite the conversion of consumer industries to war production.

Secretary Wickard's proposal that 80,000,000 bushels of surplus wheat be converted into rubber to provide farmers with tires for their automobiles, trucks and tractors is an idea that stirs the imagination. Technically there is no reason why wheat, corn and many other farm products cannot be used to make rubber.

It ought to be far easier to believe in the Bible today than in the days of our ancestors because there have been such amazing confirmations of its truth in our day that doubt is more unreasonable than ever, the Rev. Dr. John H. McComb declared in his sermon yesterday at the Broadway Presbyterian Church, Broadway and 14th Street.

Perhaps it was a former circus press agent who announced the other day the "greatest marshaling of the forces of gardening and horticulture in the history of the world." Yet the words didn't exaggerate the size of one project now under way for the benefit of the Army Emergency and Navy Relief Funds.

The Dodgers swept a double-header with the Cubs, 8-2 and 4-3, yesterday ran their winning streak to six games and increased their lead over the second-place Braves and third-place Pirates to six and one-half games.

The pharmacist is a busy man these days. He hardly knows whether he's coming or going. He's lost his best clerk to the Army, or some manufacturer has taken him away with promise of a better job. He's out of several important items and his jobber tells him he doesn't know when they will be available.

In commuting Earl Browder's imprisonment for perjury from the four years to which he was sentenced to the one year and two months he has served, the President offered two main justifications. The first was that the release of the American Communist leader "will tend to promote national unity."

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- With recruiting for the Officers Training School of the new Women's Army Auxiliary Corps scheduled to get under way within two weeks, the War Department disclosed today further details of the training program designed to furnish leaders for the feminine branch of the Army.

The City Park Department announced yesterday that it had completed arrangements for the free use of public beaches and pools by members of the armed forces during the Summer. At Jacob Riis Park at Rockaway, Orchard Beach in the Bronx and Wolfe's Pond on Staten Island, Army, Navy and Marine Corps vehicles will be parked free, and soldiers, sailors and marines may use the bathhouses without charge.

In two weeks 53,000 children have been immunized against diphtheria and 3,500 have been vaccinated against smallpox, in a campaign by the Health Department to protect all children in the city against the two diseases, Health Commissioner John L. Rice reported yesterday.

Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator; Dr. Grace MacLeod of Teachers College, chairman of the Nutrition Committee of Greater New York, and Dr. Norman L. Jolliffe of the New York Academy of Medicine will be the speakers at a conference on nutrition and health to be held in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, tomorrow at 2:45 o'clock.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 17 (U.P.) -- Yale University's golf team gave Ben Thomson, its coach for fifteen years, the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association championship as a going-away prize by defeating Penn State, Middle Atlantic division winner, 6 to 3, in the finals at the Woodway Country Club today.

VANCOUVER, B.C., May 17 (Canadian Press) -- Adam Smith Johnston of this city, a lawyer, said today that railroad interests in New York and Chicago which he represented were negotiating for purchase of British Columbia's government-owned Pacific Great Eastern Railway and that if they bought it, they intended to extend it to Alaska from its present terminus at Quesnel in Central British Columbia.

Justin R. Whiting, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, said yesterday that the order of the Securities and Exchange Commission denying the company's application for a rehearing apparently did not alter the company's position as stated in the annual report now in the mails.

The American correspondents who have arrived in Lisbon bring out the first direct news we have received from Germany and Italy since the United States entered the war. Until last December, despite censorship and the other handicaps muffling reporters in totalitarian States, dispatches from Rome and Berlin threw considerable extra light on the military communiques and kept us in tenuous touch with conditions in the Axis countries.
VICHY, May 17 -- Economic matters are holding public attention in France much more than are financial matters, which show little change.

In the last few years we have seen a Tammany dissevered, discordant, belligerent. The house has been divided against itself and has had little or no spoils to divide. By its own frowardness it has cut itself off from supplies at Washington and at Albany; and strangers possess its old capital, the City Hall.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 17 -- Observers in the Middle East kept a close watch today on the fighting around Kerch and Kharkov, because they realize that, if the Germans succeed in bridging the Strait of Kerch or find another way to pour into the Caucasus, Britain's Tenth Army in Iran and Iraq may have to act as a backstop.

With Bishop William T. Manning praising the "noble recor of service" already rendered by members of their profession in this war, 3,000 nurses in white uniforms and caps attended last nigh the eighteenth annual Florence Nightingale service for nurses in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

CHUNGKING, China, May 17 -- The Chinese have administered a series of resounding defeats to Japanese columns probing northward of the Burma Road on the west side of the Salween River, it was announced today. Meanwhile, attacks by the American Volunteer Group indicated a new threat might be developing from the south in French Indo-China.

Carmen Amaya returned to Carnegie Hall last night after a sojourn in Hollywood, bringing with her the rest of the populous Amaya tribe of dancers and guitarists, plus Antonio Triana, Lola Montes and the pianist Raymond Sachse, who are non-Amayan, according to the record.

LONDON, May 17 -- Great Britain's post-war export problem is attracting considerable attention following the appointment last Tuesday of a planning commission through the British Board of Trade. Nevertheless, the industry's more immediate concern is with the government's current export policy.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 17 -- With Vichy hoping for a reply from Washington, the controversy regarding West Indian possessions of France is likely to mark time. But private advices from Vichy make it clear that this is but a phase of a wider issue -- the gradual development of the authority of "the Chief of Government" until it approximates supremacy.

With trading restricted by political uncertainties, price movements last week in the cotton market remained within narrow limits. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts declined 12 to 16 points net, in contrast to advances of 17 to 27 points in the previous week.

Striving desperately to respond to the exhortations of a crowd of more than 50,000, largest of the year in the National League, the Giants all but lifted themselves by their own bootstraps at the Polo Grounds yesterday. But then something gave way and Mel Ott's men had to settle for an even break in their double-header with the Cardinals, which left the two teams still tied for fourth place.

In a surprise move veiled in secrecy District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of Bronx County has ordered the March term of the county's grand jury, which recently investigated the Flynn paving case and returned a presentment exonerating every one of guilt, to reassemble this morning at the Bronx County Court House, Grand Concourse and 161st Street.

LISBON, Portugal, May 17 -- Adolf Hitler's firing squads have killed nearly 400,000 Europeans in the process of looting conquered areas of $36,000,000,000 in cash and goods -- equal to the whole cost of Germany's seven years of rearmament, European official and private sources estimate.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- An unsettled feeling has developed in the market for corn and, while the rank and file of traders remain bullish, the threat that large quantities of low-priced wheat will be available for feeding livestock, which might curtail the use of corn, had last week a tendency to induce liberal profit-taking.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- After midnight tonight consumers will not have to pay more than the highest price they paid for goods at retail in March.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 17 -- Getting two second places and a third in the three races sailed, Corny Shields won the James D. Sparkman Trophy, the prize for the opening series of the International Class sloops which was concluded today at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

John L. Pratt, vice president of A.S. Barnes Co., has been elected secretary of the Hundred Year Association of New York, comprising business firms, societies and institutions in existence here for 100 years or longer. Mr. Pratt succeeds Alan N. Mendelson of B.T. Babbitt, Inc.

Dodd, Mead has given its second annual intercollegiate fellowship to Barbara Bentley, a senior at Pomona College in Claremont, Calif., for a novel entitled tentatively "A Hedge Against the Sun." The award is of $1,200. The firm also announced a 1943 contest, open to students and graduate students of American colleges.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- A six weeks' trial of experimental machinery set up by the War Department to re-negotiate contracts and cut governmental costs in ratio to excess profits that are being made by contractors already has saved $160,000,000 in procurement costs and promises to recover many times that sum of money in the near future.
Our friend and neighbor The Sun is a family newspaper and, we have always assumed, full of hospitable instincts. But a one-paragraph footnote on its editorial page the other day has raised doubts.

Eighteen acres of human faces turned toward the speakers' platform at the north end of the Mall in Central Park late yesterday afternoon. Heedless of the drone of pursuit planes in the blue sky overhead, the mighty throng repeated in sonorous rhythm the oath offered to them by Justice Hugo L. Black of the United States Supreme Court:

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Trading in oats and rye on the Board of Trade here was not large last week, but the former showed relative strength, being supported by an active shipping demand for the cash grain and buying by cereal interests. The new crop is reported as in fairly good condition, although not promising a bumper yield.

MOSCOW, Monday, May 18 (AP) -- The Russian offensive on the Kharkov front has resulted in advances of from twenty to sixty kilometers [roughly, twelve to thirty-seven miles] and the recapture of 300 populated places, the government announced in a special communique today.

The fifty-seventh commencement of Wagner Memorial Lutheran College on Staten Island opened last night with the baccalaureate service at Trinity Lutheran Church, Stapleton. The service was conducted by the Rev. Frederic Sutter, pastor of the church and president of the board of trustees of the college.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 17 -- Mother's Day, which was observed throughout Germany today, was made the occasion by the government for the proclamation of at new law governing the health and social status of expectant and nursing mothers.

A young Brooklyn girl, who has never traveled beyond the Catskills or Bayonne, N.J., has won a trip to Latin America as a result of her views on world organization for peace. She is 15-year-old Dorothy Terrace, chosen from students in 1,079 high schools who took part in an annual nation-wide examination conducted by the educational committee of the League of Nations Association.

Six improved models of the new wartime motorcycle ambulance were presented yesterday afternoon to the Royal Norwegian Medical Corps at a Norwegian National Day ceremony held at the doorstep of 40 West Fifty-seventh Street, headquarters of the American Friends of Norway, donors of the vehicles.

ALBANY, May 17 -- The State's entire political calendar, with the exception of registration and election days, was advanced by five weeks today as Governor Lehman signed the Republican-sponsored bill designed to provide for absentee voting by service men in camps in this country, and in the field in foreign lands.

NEW ORLEANS, May 17 -- A new high record for consumption of cotton in April, encouraging news from Russia after the mid-week, more unfavorable crop and weevil reports and a continued tight spot position were in turn virtually overlooked last week in the cotton futures market here. The market drifted aimlessly after opening the week slightly below the preceding week's level.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 17 -- Piloted by Al Homewood to victory in two classes and to third place in another pair, the aged bay mare Play Girl, owned by H.L. Norton of Chatham, N.Y., today captured the jumper championship in the annual Rockwood Hall Horse Show at the Fox Hill Farms.
Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. and Thomas E. Dewey emerged over the week-end as the leading candidates for the Democratic and Republican nominations for Governor in the Fall campaign.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- The War Department announced today the names of 118 additional United States soldiers who were killed in action, or who died of wounds in the Philippine Islands. The list includes fifteen officers and 103 enlisted men.

With retail price regulations becoming effective today, Dr. Merle Fainsod, Chief Federal Price Administrator, expressed confidence yesterday that the 2,000,000 retailers of America would do their duty cheerfully, with a full appreciation of the urgencies involved in the national effort to curb inflation.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- An invitation from President Manuel Avila Camacho to visit Mexico City was accepted today by Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippines, who last week set up his government here temporarily. No date for the visit was announced.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP) -- The Phils split a double-header with the Pirates at Shibe Park today, winning the second game by 5 to 4 in an exciting eleven-inning, struggle. The Pirates easily took the opener, 7 to 2.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The cost of living is due to take a drop of about 1 1/2 per cent tomorrow. Economists figure that retail prices have increased that much in the average since March.

Although rod and reel catches of broadbill are not likely to be recorded for awhile, nevertheless some of the sportsmen who have fought this "smartest" of big game fishes are exchanging notations from their own research on swordfish.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- National Maritime Day next Friday will see the greatest mass launching of merchant ships since American shipyards began construction of the Victory Fleet, the United States Maritime Commission has announced.

Senator Scott Lucas of Illinois, speaking here yesterday, denounced as liars and fifth columnists those who "spread vicious canards that our Jewish citizens in this war are letting others do the fighting for them."
MOSCOW, Monday, May 18 (AP) -- A special Soviet communique said today:

Now comes the time when Summer marshals its potent forces, and wind, sand and sun combine to make a well-tanned leather of our skins, make our hair take on a look of raveled hempen rope, and turn eyes weepy and red. These are only a few of the evils that may befall the imprudent who dare to forget that an ounce of protection is worth a pound of cure.

It seems to me that those doctors who are now giving the physical examinations -- the so-called "screen tests" -- for the various local boards are undergoing a punishment that is due some one else. Not that I disagree with the statement that the present examinations are entirely too cursory.

An "autopsy" on a pinball machine recently seized by the police has revealed the presence of eleven ounces of brass or enough to make seventy-seven buttons for police uniforms, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his radio "Talk to the People."

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, May 17 -- It is now widely recognized that Sergeant Colin Eccles of New Haven, Conn., is a humorist. The sergeant produced two big laughs today while his outfit was being photographed for an American newsreel.

VICHY, May 17 -- Tax receipts of the Government of France in February, as published today, amounted to 6,398,000,000 francs, compared with 5,854,000,000 francs in February, 1941. The returns of all categories of taxes were superior this year to those of a year before.
Marie D. Hilliard, Augusta O. Morla, in 7 Park Ave; Mrs. Joseph S. Ward, in 565 Park Ave; Howard McP. Davis, in 12 E 88th St; Pease Elliman, brokers.

Officials of the Army, the city and the New York Stock Exchange have been preparing over the weekend for the greatest war bond rally in the history of the city. It will be held today on the steps of Federal Memorial Hall, at Wall and Nassau Streets, as the feature of the celebration of the 150th anniversary of the Stock Exchange.

J. Robert Stout, chairman of the National Thrift Committee, issued yesterday a twelve-point program on how an individual may adjust living expenses and increase his savings production to comply with the President's request that he invest 10 per cent of his income in war savings bonds and stamps.

LONDON, May 17 -- In some parts of the world Sunday still may be a day of rest but today the quiet, flowering countryside of Britain is filled with un-Sabbathlike noises and activities. It is the ceaseless, tireless testing of defenses against mock invasion by paratroops of the regular army.

LONDON, May 17 -- The weekend has produced a rich crop of reports from correspondents of British papers in New York and Washington suggesting that the United States is depending less upon the coming year's industrial production to win the war in 1943 and more on hard fighting with the materials at hand to win it this year, in Europe, at least.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., May 17 (AP) -- Philadelphia retained its National Women's Lacrosse Association championship today by beating New York, 11 to 3, then placed six players on the 1942 All-America team selected at the close of the three-day competition.

The Floral Park Corporation has purchased a plot 100 by 246 feet at the southeast corner of Northern Boulevard and 163d Street, in Flushing, L.I., from the Brevoort Savings Bank through Robert Dasey Associates, brokers. It improved the property with a one-story building containing bowling alleys and leased out the structure.

LONDON, May 17 -- As British Imperial forces established new positions in Burma west of the Chindwin River near the frontier of India, General Harold R.L.G. Alexander in a review of the situation from Field Headquarters today said that his men had fought gallantly and their comrades were still fighting.
Bus and railroad transportation systems continued to benefit yesterday as gasoline rationing, effective since Friday, forced additional private passenger cars from public highways.

ST. LOUIS, May 17 -- For a few brief moments at Sportsman's Park today the Yankees were threatened with being toppled from the American League lead. But the world champions sneaked through with half the spoils of their twin bill with Luke Sewell's Browns and are still leading the parade by half a game.

Behind Mayor La Guardia's announcement of more stringent dimout regulations, it became known yesterday, was the Army's feeling, based on first-hand tests, that conditions so far have been unsatisfactory and that the situation has become critical.

MELBOURNE, Monday, May 18 (U.P.) -- United Nations planes and anti-aircraft gunners beat off another Japanese raid on Port Moresby yesterday as Australia rehearsed a mock but realistic "invasion" of Sydney.

Earl Browder, leader of the Communist party in this country, slipped off a train at Newark late yesterday afternoon, disappointing a crowd of 4,000 persons who had gathered in Pennsylvania Station to greet him on his return from a fourteen-month term in Atlanta Penitentiary.

THERE was a little story out of Australia recently to the effect that detachments of American soldiers were ready to tackle the Aussies in games of rugby for fun and exercise. That story brought the distinguished M.P. Greenwood-Adams on the run to this corner.

"Education becomes such a part of our growth and being that it is not easily to be renounced," Governor J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island told 5,000 persons yesterday at the eighty-ninth annual commencement exercises of Manhattan College.

The nation's public utilities, caught in the vise of frozen-rate structures and sharply higher taxes, are petitioning legislatve authorities in Washington for the enactment of special tax proposals designed to afford some relief for the industry from those now pending before the House Ways and Means Committee, it was disclosed yesterday.

Declaring that what he termed the appeal of Pope Plus XII for an immediate negotiated peace was "untimely" and could be "purchased only by a betrayal" of the United Nations cause, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, asserted yesterday in his sermon that the Allies would not cease fighting until the Axis was defeated and overthrown.
BERLIN, May 17 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique issued today follows:

Retailers generally adopted a policy of holding up larger orders, except on fill-in seasonal merchandise, pending further clarification of the general maximum price regulation, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident offices.
The Bank for Savings sold the dwelling at 2857 West Twentieth Street, Brooklyn, to Mrs. Susie Sakara for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $2,800 for five years. Bailey Ferrara were the brokers.

Today the Commission on Revision of the New Jersey Constitution will make a unanimous report, of which partial summaries have appeared. The powers now so feeble of the Governor are greatly enlarged. The sprawling ninety-odd commissions and agencies are to be consolidated into nine departments, whose heads, to be appointed by the Governor subject to confirmation or rejection by the Senate within thirty days, will be his Cabinet.

SUMMIT, N.J., May 17 -- Cutting six strokes from par in seventeen holes, Vic Ghezzi and Pat Mucci of the United States Army today won the New Jersey State pro-amateur golf championship by defeating the Yountakah Country Club pair of Emory Thomas, professional, and George Davidson, 2 and 1.

A statistical survey of health conditions in New York City for the years 1936 through 1940 was issued yesterday by the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association. Its twenty-five pages of tables and diagrams of vital, mortality and morbidity statistics are devised to assist in community health planning, Dr. J. Burns Amberson Jr., president of the association, said in a foreword.

PITTSBURGH, May 17 -- In the steel industry last week accent continued on the all-out production of plates for ships. In addition to a few strip mills which two weeks ago were entirely on plates, with the exception of certain extremely wide sheets which were being produced on the continuous units, more high speed mills were rapidly reaching the point where practical utilization of the units was for plates only.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor issued a formal statement tonight protesting against the Ways and Means Committee's recommendation that personal income tax exemptions be lowered in the pending $8,700,000,000 war revenue bill.
LONDON, May 17 -- Loudspeaker trucks have been touring the cities and villages of Britain during the past week in a widespread recruiting campaign.

LONDON, May 17 (AP) -- Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's air force for the first time in weeks threw its full-scale fighter strength today into attempts to smash back the British daylight attack, reversing sharply the recent German policy of conserving strength while trying to pick off stragglers.

CHICAGO, May 17 (AP) -- Johnny Rigney, pitching his last game before applying for enlistment in the Navy, held the Senators to three hits while the White Sox rallied for their sixth straight victory, 4 to 3, today.

MIAMI, Fla., May 17 (U.P.) -- An Italian submarine "broke the hack" of a small American merchantman with a torpedo and then sank a British vessel that had been standing by six miles away in the "Black Hole" of the Caribbean, survivors reported tonight.
PORTSMOUTH, England, May 17 -- United States Marines met the British Marines in a shooting match here today, but the situation decidedly was not well in hand.

LISBON, Portugal, May 17 -- Three hundred German passengers from America, who intended to have three meals and lodging aboard the liner Drottningholm while waiting for the special train that will take them from Lisbon to Germany, were put off the boat today.

HENRY BELLAMANN, former professor of music, poet and author of several overlooked novels, hit the literary jackpot two years ago with "Kings Row." Overlong and overwritten as it may have been, it was a choice combination of murderous melodrama and psychopathic horrors, no more to be taken seriously perhaps than "Dracula," but enthralling reading just the same.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Although trading in lard futures last week was at the price ceiling established by the Office of Price Administration, which is $12.82 1/2 a 100 pounds, speculative interest on the Board of Trade broadened. A large packing company was a heavy seller of May late in the week, which traders put down as hedging against the cash product.

La Guardia Field, holder of the world's record for the greatest number of scheduled airline arrivals and departures in a single day, prepared yesterday to reduce schedules to conform to the war-operations plan for the nation's airlines as outlined by the War Department last week.

The fear that the farm bloc rift over selling prices for wheat and corn may lead eventually to the inclusion of cotton in Administration designs on agricultural price ceilings at parity was reflected yesterday in a sharp decline in the cotton market.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Recognizing that there will be no more silk or nylon stockings until the end of the war, the Consumer Division of the Office of Price Administration has prepared material to guide women in the buying and care of rayon stockings.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., May 18 -- Concern that freedom of the press might not be restored at the end of the war was expressed here tonight by Arthur Krock, chief of the Washington Bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in the eighth of a series of lectures of the "Lawrenceville Forum" program at the Lawrenceville School.

A seven-point program of "the general principles which will determine the character of future foreign trade" was outlined yesterday by Under-Secretary of Commerce Wayne Chatfield-Taylor, principal speaker at the "World Trade Luncheon," inaugurating National Foreign Trade Week here.

Dusk rolled in last night on a city faintly outlined in haze. Observers looking down from great heights to see the effect of tighter dimming regulations said they noticed only scant difference in sky glow -- the glow that comes from accumulated light and makes ships offshore easy U-boat targets.
The applications of sixty-two policemen for retirement were approved yesterday at the regular monthly meeting of the board of trustees of the Police Pension Fund.

CLEVELAND, May 18 -- Philip Murray, chairman of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, supplementing a report which he will make to the convention tomorrow, reiterated today previous attacks on proposals to freeze the income of wage-earners.

A strong protest against the proposed lowering of income-tax exemptions for married persons to $1,200 and for single persons to $500 was registered yesterday when the New York East Methodist Conference, closing its annual meeting, approved with but little change the "Taxation and War Finance" section of its social service committee's annual report.
KUNMING, China, May 16 (Delayed) -- Tom Jones, a farm boy who became a Flying Tiger and made good in a big way, said yesterday he was going home any time now.

ST. LOUIS, May 18 (AP) -- Ellsworth (Babe) Dahlgren, traveling first baseman recently purchased by the Browns, has been returned to Chicago of the National League, Don Barnes, St. Louis club president, announced tonight.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- Business transacted during the first two days of the Central States Shoe Fair was up to last year's levels despite war disturbances in the industry, while buyer attendance, with the exception of Illinois, ran well ahead, a check of exhibits indicated here today.

TRENTON, May 18 -- Reconvening today after a two weeks' recess, the Legislature received from a special seven-member commission the text of a proposed new State Constitution, together with bills providing for the printing of 100,000 copies and for placing before the voters in September the question whether a referendum on its adoption should be held at the November general election.

The Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria was formally opened for the season last night with a supper dance given under the auspices of the Metropolitan Division of Bundles for America. Mrs. William Astor Chanler was chairman for the event.

LONDON, May 18 -- A big force of British warplanes roared down like a swarm of angry hornets on the Nazi cruiser Prinz Eugen, when they caught her struggling toward Germany around the southern tip of Norway, and put her even more out of battle condition with at least two and probably three torpedo hits, the Air Ministry reported today.

Changes in specifications are becoming the principal relief from a growing shortage of medicinal drugs as about 120 medicinal and pharmaceutical products are now in greatly restricted supply, Dr. E.C. Merrill, director and chief chemist of the department of research and technology of the United Drug Company, said yesterday.

LONDON, May 18 -- Captain Robert Davies, who received the George Cross for removing unexploded bombs that threatened St. Paul's Cathedral in September, 1940, was court-martialed today on eleven charges covering theft, looting and racketeering.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 18 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force issued this communique today:

Wall Street's leaders and Wall Street's rank and file packed into the space before Federal Memorial Hall yesterday noon to help the New York Stock Exchange celebrate its 150th anniversary with a great war bond rally. Postmaster General Frank C. Walker delivered the keynote address.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today $199,740,000 for 164 new airports, almost doubling the House-approved appropriation for the State, Justice and Commerce Departments for the new fiscal year.

Arthur August Backus, vice president in charge of production of the United States Industrial Alcohol Company, 60 East Forty-second Street, jumped or fell to his death yesterday from a New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad train as it neared the Grand Central Terminal, according to police of the East Fifty-first Street station.

TRENTON, N.J., May 18 -- A bill passed by the Legislature to make unlawful the sale by employers to their employes of goods not produced by the former, with the exception of meals, confectionery and tobacco, was vetoed today by Governor Edison.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Disregarding a charge by Senator McKellar that C.B. Baldwin, Farm Security Administrator, was a Communist, the Senate today approved an amendment to the Agriculture Appropriation Bill that will provide $50,319,557 with which to continue the agency's work in rehabilitating poor farm families.

Investment bankers looked upon the sale yesterday of $4,000,000 of Public Service of Indiana 3 3/8 per cent bonds, due in 1972, as bringing forth about the most active and keenest competition yet witnessed in the field of corporate financing.

FORT DIX, N.J., May 18 -- Captain Oliver J. Hart, Episcopal chaplain in the 1,229th reception center, tonight revealed that he had decided to accept the position of Bishop Coadjutor for the Protestant Episcopal diocese of Pennsylvania to which he was elected at a convention in Philadelphia last week.

Manufacturers in their advertising can give considerable help to dealers in the numerous problems now facing them, according to a survey of dealers just completed by the Associated Business Papers and released in two supplements to "A Guide to Effective Wartime Advertising."

BERNE, Switzerland, May 18 (AP) -- The Italian press demanded territory from France tonight in sharp terms and insisted that the transfer be made immediately, regardless of the length and outcome of the war.

Directors of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. declared yesterday an interim dividend of $1 a share on the common stock, payable on June 13. This is a reduction of 25 cents from the previous disbursement on March 14. In 1941 four dividends of $1.75 each were paid.

LONDON, May 18 -- On the West Burma front, as the British continued to withdraw closer to India, a raid was made on Kalewa yesterday by the Royal Air Force, it was announced today. The targets included "important waterfront warehouses," and barges and river craft in the Chindwin River.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The Army has grown extremely cool toward the idea of Joe Louis defending his heavyweight championship this Summer.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Petroleum Coordinator Ickes said in a statement today the action of the Texas Railroad Commission in permitting production of 1,402,038 barrels of crude oil and natural gasoline daily in Texas during the remainder of May, compared with a recommendation of 960,000 barrels by Ickes, was "a serious blow to the war program."

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- If motoring conditions in the rationed areas of the United States are similar to those prevailing in the region surrounding the national capital, and if conservation of automobiles in the rest of the country shall follow, the plan will attain its general objective despite a succession of official blunders, perhaps partly because of them.

BERLIN, May 18 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- German counter-attacks on the Kharkov front precipitated a tank battle in which fifty-six Russian tanks were destroyed, while fifty-four more were put out of action by German planes, the German High Command announced today.

CHUNGKING, China, May 18 (AP) -- The west bank of the turbulent and mountain-walled Salween, barring the eastward advance of the Japanese up the Burma Road, has been cleared of their forces and the enemy columns have been wiped out or driven back to Lungling, the Chinese announced today.

HONOLULU, May 18 -- An eruption of Mauna Loa, which spewed fountains of flaming lava hundreds of feet into the air for two weeks and at one time threatened Hilo and its important harbor, has now subsided. The Army considers the information no longer of value to the enemy and today allowed newspaper men to tell the story for the first time.

Deploring the "light and frivolous attitude with which discussion of the liquor problem is greeted by certain groups of young people," D. Campbell Wyckoff, director of the youth division of the New York Federation of Churches, said this attitude was the result of a "propaganda as insidious as that used in war."

CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) -- Outfielder Wally Moses lifted the White Sox out of the cellar for the first time in more than three weeks today by slamming a homer with one on and two out in the ninth to give the Chicagoans their seventh straight victory and a sweep of the three-game series with the Senators, 7 to 5.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- A program of "price regulation and price support" for canned vegetables of the 1942 pack which will allow canners to increase their prices over 1941 but will preserve the March level as a ceiling for the retailers' prices was announced jointly today by the Office of Price Administration and the Department of Agriculture.
Four-pound weakfish proved large enough to win top prizes in most of the pools on party boats at Peconic Bay on Sunday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 -- Princeton's nine tightened its grip on the Eastern Intercollegiate League lead by taking two close games from the University of Pennsylvania on River Field today, 5 -- 3 and 2 -- 1.

The City Planning Commission went ahead yesterday on its $628,000,000 post-war building program by adopting amendments to the 1942 capital budget that will provide about $22,000,000 for surveys and detailed plans on the individual projects.
LISBON, Portugal, May 18 -- Italians are at war in spite of themselves and they act like it.

CLEVELAND, May 18 (AP) -- The Indians today slammed their way to within 13 percentage points of the league-leading Yankees in a fourteen-hit attack that smothered the Athletics, 7 to 4. The Yanks did not play today.
LONDON, May 18 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique tonight:

ALBANY, May 18 -- All of the ninety-one banks and other financial institutions allotted a share in the $50,000,000 issue of short-term notes notified Controller O'Leary before noon today of their acceptance. Dated May 19, the notes will mature on Oct 19.

Although motor boat racing in seventeen Eastern States has been prohibited by a recent WPB edict, a number of Midwestern States that so far do not have gasoline rationing will continue their regatta plans for 1942.

For the first time since its debut, on Nov. 6, 1928 -- the day Herbert Hoover was elected President -- the electric news sign belting the Times Tower in Times Square was dark last night. It probably will remain dark for the duration, in accordance with the new dimout regulations.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Creation by executive order of President Roosevelt of a board with control over the production and first processing of food products needed in the United Nations' war effort is expected in the near future. It is reported that Claude Wickard, Secretary of Agriculture, will be chairman of the board.

Stopping only long enough to refuel, as it were, the one-time Gas House Gang from St. Louis yesterday dealt the Giants their severest setback of the season. While thousands -- 5,546, to be exact -- yawned, the Cardinals romped to a 16-4 victory at the Polo Grounds.

W.H. Harrison, director of production of the War Production Board, told 1,000 members of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce and their guests yesterday afternoon that American manufacturers had turned out more tanks last month that they did during the whole of World War I. The Federal official was the principal speaker at the luncheon session of the chamber's all-day conference in the Hotel St. George.

The sugar supply situation is not nearly as dismal as it was several months ago, and both current and expected shipments justify looking to the future with more optimism, Ody H. Lamborn, president of Lamborn Co., Inc., sugar brokers, told delegates to the annual convention of the flavoring Extract Manufacturers Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

LONDON, May 18 -- Rear Admiral Sir Henry Harwood, who commanded the British ships at the battle of the River Plate when the Admiral Graf Spee was scuttled by her crew, succeeds Admiral Sir Andrew Browne Cunningham in command of the Mediterranean Fleet in a wide switch of British admirals announced today.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 5 per cent last week over the corresponding week last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The increase was the same as that of the previous week.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 18 -- Al Brosch of Bethpage, metropolital P.G.A. champion, teamed with Ray Marquardt of Bethpage and Mal Galletta of North Hills today to lead a field of twenty-four players in the Long Island Golf Association's weekly pro-amateur bestball tournament at the Lakeville course.

The First Boston Corporation and the Mellon Securities Corporation were the successful bidders yesterday for $4,000,000 of Public Service Company of Indiana 3 3/8 per cent bonds due in 1972, in a sale marked by the keenest competition for a public utility issue since promulgation by the Securities and Exchange Commission of the compulsory competitive bidding rule.

ON THE ASSAM-BURMA FRONTIER, May 18 -- The Japanese have landed 2,400 women radio operators and 600 German shepherd dogs in Indo-China and are bringing them into Burma in an effort to improve their communications.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 18 (AP) -- Lew Ayres, the Dr. Kildare of the films, signed a new contract today, this time to serve with the noncombat troops of the Army.
CHICAGO, May 18 -- John Dungan Rigney, pitching mainstay of the White Sox, starts wearing the blue of Uncle Sam's Navy tomorrow.

CHUNGKING, China, May 18 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces in the eastern maritime province of Chekiang have withdrawn to prepared positions after halting one column of 3,000 Japanese troops and inflicting heavy losses on another column of more than 4,000, an Army communique said today.
Charles Rubenstein expresses the opinion that we are not sending the boys off with glamour, music and cheers. He is complaining that he noticed "sad-looking men and red-eyed women."

A drive to recruit personnel for the government's war savings campaign was launched formally last night at a dinner in the Hotel Astor at which Colonel Richard C. Patterson Jr., New York State chairman of the Treasury's war bond drive, received the annual distinguished service award of the New York Young Democratic Club for his work in promoting sales of government securities.

Wayne Wright and Minee-Mo, a chestnut son of Pompey, won the De Mund Handicap, a seven-furlong event for 4-year-olds and upward that featured yesterday's racing at Belmont Park. Minee-Mo won by three lengths from Mrs. Alice Sherman's Grey Wolf, with the Wheatley Stable's Naval Reserve in third place.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Restoration of old-fashioned night-shirts for men was one of the ideas that haunted a conference today between WPB clothing officials and the Men's Clothing Industry Advisory Committee, looking toward regulation of male pajamas to conserve cloth.

With the disclosure that an actor who had been in New York City had died of smallpox in Portsmouth, N.H., a week ago, medical inspectors of the Health Department visited eighty-five theatrical agencies, three apartment houses, several office buildings and a hospital in the last forty-eight hours and vaccinated 400 persons suspected of having been in contact with the man here.
LONDON, May 18 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler has sent Heinrich Himmler, the Gestapo chief, to the Netherlands to quell a surge of anti-Nazi resistance, the Netherlands Indies News Agency said tonight.

Add to the list of films opening this week "Ships With Wings," which will arrive at the Rivoli on Saturday. The British-made film, the cast of which is headed by John Clements, Leslie Banks, Jane Bax r, Ann Todd and Basil Sydney, was produced by Michael Balcon and deals with the British fleet air arm.

SOMEWHERE IN NORTHERN IRELAND, May 18 -- For several days now United States troops -- the biggest contingent yet to come over in a single movement -- have been pouring into these islands by the thousands. And for the first time in this war they have brought their own tanks.

BERLIN, May 18 (from German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command announced today that a strong British aerial formation attacked the heavy cruiser Prinz Eugen and escort vessels in the northern North Sea last night, but was beaten off with the loss of twenty-nine R.A.F. planes.

The nation's sugar supply situation is improving and in due course of time will reach the point where restrictions on its use will be removed, Ody H. Lamborn, New York sugar importer, said last night.

An application for a court order to compel the Electric Bond and Share Company to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan for divesting itself of control of the American Power and Light Company and Electric Power and Light Company was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by Samuel Okin, holder of 9,000 shares of Electric Bond and Share common stock.

The St. Regis Viennese Roof opened its fashion luncheon season yesterday with a sprightly and topical presentation by the Tailored Woman. Clothes that relate closely to present-day activities were dramatized in six scenes.

MOSCOW, May 18 -- General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock is throwing every ounce of metal he has into the battle for Kharkov. In the first four days of fighting his losses in machines were almost equivalent to the strength of a division.

The report of the Richfield Oil Company and its subsidiaries, announced for publication today, reveals a consolidated net profit for the March quarter of $539,394, equal to 13 1/2 cents a share on 4,010,000 capital shares. The net profit reported for the corresponding three months of last year was $723,442, or 18 cents a share.

THE story of Spain in the Americas is usually told with flourish and glitter, whether it is Prescott reanimating the documents of the libraries or Archibald MacLeish following the trail of Cortez or Samuel Eliot Morison retracing the four voyages of Christopher Columbus, Admiral of the Ocean Sea. But no one, to my rather limited knowledge, has ever done the job in the man ner of German Arciniegas, the Colombian Minister of Education.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 18 -- Several romances and three marriages have resulted from the entertainment of soldiers and sailors in Westchester County homes, Mrs. Richard C. Noel of Scarsdale, chairman of the Westchester Committee for Service Men, said today in announcing that the number of men entertained by the committee had reached 5,000.

The Class I railroads had 985 locomotives ordered from manufacturers or being built or rebuilt in railroad-owned shops on May 1, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday. Of the total, 408 were steam and 577 were electric or Diesel.
Evidence of continuing interest in loft properties in the Chelsea area was seen yesterday in the report that the twelve-story structure at 9 West Twentieth Street had passed into new hands.

Despite the strict new regulations governing lighting in the city and surrounding communities, the sky over the New York metropolitan area still reflects a glow sufficient to aid Axis submarines in their raids on shipping, it appeared last night after an Army inspection.

ISLIP, L.I., May 18 -- After the pilot and co-pilot had parachuted to safety a twin-motored medium Army bomber of the 433d Bomb Squad, Mitchel Field, crashed this morning in Islip Manor, set fire to a dwelling and caused minor injuries to a man working in a garden.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The rationing of the proportion of income that could be spent for consumer goods or travel has been proposed by Treasury economists as an alternative to the over-all rationing of consumer goods. This proposal has not been officially sponsored by the Treasury Department and whether it will be submitted to Congress depends in large extent on the chances for a favorable popular response.

Women in the metropolitan area, both married and single, are losing no time in expressing their desire to enlist in the new Women's Army Auxiliary Corps, created by legislation signed by the President on Friday. The Army recruiting headquarters for Southern New York at 39 Whitehall Street was deluged yesterday with visits and telephone calls from women seeking to serve in the corps.

Funeral service for Morris Gest, producer of "The Miracle" and other stage spectacles, who died at 4 A.M. on Saturday at the Midtown Hospital, was held at 11 A.M. yesterday in Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today set for hearing on May 28 here the application of the Erie Railroad Company to acquire control of the Paterson Hudson River Railroad Company by purchase of capital stock.

A NORTHERN IRELAND PORT, May 18 -- I have just crossed the Atlantic with a huge American convoy that outfoxed enemy submarines all the way. We had to "push the periscopes down" almost all the way of our 2,400-mile voyage of daring and skill. The destroyers and planes delivered thunderous depth-charge attacks.
CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) -- Hog prices eased 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight today, the top quotation sagging to $14.15, as a fairly substantial run arrived.

Drilling of air wardens in city parks will not be permitted, George E. Spargo, executive officer of the Park Department, announced yesterday. He made the ruling after Jerome J. Jacobs, Air Warden Commander, Zone 1, complained that the Park Department had refused to give him a permit to drill 500 of his subordinates in the park at Riverside Drive and 102d Street.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- An agreement covering the use by the armed forces of the United States of numerous defense areas in Panama was signed in Panama today by Edwin C. Wilson, the American Ambassador, and Octavio Fabrega, the Panamanian Foreign Minister.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- An investigation into the possibility of relieving the East Coast's gasoline and oil shortage by the construction of a pipeline, or possible two of them, to bring oil from the Southwest, will be undertaken at once, Congressional leaders stated after a conference with President Roosevelt today.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, May 19 (U.P.) -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's forces were reported early today to be pressing in on Kharkov along a 100-mile arc, storming ahead through scorched fields and burning villages against German defense forces strengthened by the arrival of air and mechanized reserves.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 13: Increases of $82,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $148,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks,$121,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, $387,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $104,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, and a decrease of $101,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

PITTSBURGH, May 18 -- The Carnegie Institute, this community's cultural and educational center, was dark and deserted tonight, and its manifold activities suspended indefinitely, as the result of a strike of stationary engineers at the private plant which supplies the huge building with light, power and heat.
Mrs. Wilhelm Munthe de Morgenstierne, wife of the Norwegian Ambassador, has arrived from Washington and is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

ALBANY, May 18 -- Major Gen. William N. Haskell today assumed his duties as Director of Civilian Protection, operating under the State War Council. He spent his first day conferring with Governor Lehman and other State officials.
A rally and a luncheon yesterday brought the Greater New York Fund $27,500 nearer to its goal of $5,000,000 and swelled the amount donated to $3,000,000.

With a minimum of lights showing, and with no "incidents" to require the attention of wardens or the police, the 118 square miles of Queens went through a practice blackout successfully last night from 9:30 to 9:50 o'clock.

Harry T. Dolan, attorney, as special assistant to the United States Attorney General, filed yesterday in the Queens County Clerk's office at Jamaica a lis pendens on 122 acres of the St. Albans Golf Club at Merrick and Linden Boulevards, St. Albans, Queens.
RING the date, May 31, on the calendar. As a matter of fact, it was a notable day in history just 250 years ago, and Robert Browning, some time later, wrote a poem beginning:

The March Bronx County grand jury reconvened yesterday for the first time since handing up a presentment that exonerated every one in the Flynn paving investigation, and ordered that Professor Herman A Gray and Sidney S. Baron, chairman and secretary, respectively, of the Citizens Committee to Reopen the Flynn Case, be subpoenaed for appearance before them today.

It may have been a shrewd official mind which decreed that the minimum gasoline allowance card should be called A. This is reversing the order of nature and of war priorities. In school the A student is at the top, and quality grades downward through B and C to a doubtful D and a flat failure in F.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The United States has begun to win the war on the production front, with 7,000 industrial concerns already engaged in producing ordnance for the Army, Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, Commanding General of the Services of Supply, said today at exercises commemorating the twentieth anniversary of the Army Ordnance District system.

While sales of New York City department stores increased only 4 per cent in April, their merchandise stocks on hand at the end of that month were 77 per cent higher than a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Fifty-two passengers, 1,661 pounds of mail and 275 pounds of air express were brought to La Guardia Field yesterday by a Pan American Airways Clipper under the command of Captain Charles S. Vaughn.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 18 -- The women's missionary organizations of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., with a membership of 1,500,000, opened today a campaign to prohibit the sale and manufacture of liquor in the United States for the duration of the war.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 18 -- Charges that the New Jersey Licensed Beverage Association had conspired to fix liquor prices were denied here today by Neil F. Deighan of Pennsauken, president of the association.

Reduced to a-four-hour session by a noon hour recess for a combined war bond rally and Stock Exchange anniversary celebration, the share list on the Stock Exchange plodded along yesterday in a colorless performance. On balance, the market managed to lean to the upside at the close, but except for isolated cases the changes were minor.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, May 19 -- Undeterred by enormous tank and gun losses, the German Army continues to hurl counter-attack after counter-attack against Red Army forces still advancing on Kharkov. The frenzy of the battle rises as General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock throws in ever-increasing numbers of German tanks.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 18 (AP) -- Another contingent of the great and near-great in sports converged today on Annapolis, the third class of Navy physical training instructors to report for thirty days' indoctrination training at the United States Naval Academy.

The joint report of the Army and Navy on "the progress of the war" is an interesting and in some respects an illuminating document. One service which it performs is to explain from the point of view of the armed forces why the first few months of battle were bound to find us on the defensive.

Many dinner parties will be given before the premiere showing of the new motion picture, "Ships With Wings," tonight at the Normandie Theatre for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society of America. The benefit is sponsored by the Union Jack Club of the British War Relief Society and the English Speaking Union as an expression of gratitude by officers and men of the British Royal Navy in New York toward American Navy Relief.

Lisbon's streets these days are two-way thoroughfares. From Germany and Italy have come Americans on their way home. From the United States have come citizens of the Axis Powers, also on their way home. Somewhere along the route from dock to airport, or airport to dock, the travelers must have met and passed.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Captain James W. Chapman Jr. of the Army Air Corps was decorated today with the Distinguished Flying Cross for setting a new round-the-world speed record with the Army plane which carried part of the Harriman Mission to Russia last year.

New Utrecht High's athletes rolled up a record total of 76 1/2 points in dethroning Boys High as the team champion in the fourth annual Brooklyn P.S.A.L. track and field games yesterday at Red Hook Stadium. Manual Training was a distant runner-up with 43 points, while Erasmus Hall and Boys High followed with 30 and 28 points, respectively.
From Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine came the definite announcement yesterday that night baseball would not be permitted at the Polo Grounds or Ebbets Field.

Mrs. Alexander Howitt of 62 West 102d Street, six of whose seven sons have been in the armed services of the United Nations, received a six-star American Eagle pin yesterday from Borough President Edgar J. Nathan Jr. of Manhattan to signify her membership in the Emblem of Honor Association.

Ordway Tead was re-elected chairman of the Board of Higher Education for his sixth successive term at the regular monthly meeting of the board last night at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue. Mrs. Carrie K. Medalie was re-named secretary.

ALBANY, May 18 -- The status quo in connection with adolescents' courts in the State was preserved for another year today when Governor Lehman signed the Young bill continuing the present adolescents' courts in Kings and Queens Counties, New York City.
MOSCOW, May 18 (AP) -- A Soviet information bureau communique today said:

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation intends to take the Securities and Exchange Commission to court over the application of the "death sentence" provisions of the Holding Company Act unless the commission is willing to permit the retention of the corporation's southern properties under common ownership, Justin R. Whiting, its president, asserted yesterday in his annual report to stockholders.
CHICAGO, May 18 -- Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States, warned the American people tonight that "the major health problems of the war are still ahead of us."

James Gould Cozzens's new novel "The Just and the Unjust," has been selected by the editorial board of the Book-of-the-Month Club for August distribution. The story is of a murder trial in a rural county seat and the lives of the citizens and lawyers, particularly the latter, are done in a sort of counterpoint, their trial behavior and their private lives.
President Manuel Prado of Peru was guest of honor yesterday at a luncheon in the Federal Reserve Bank. At 3 P.M. the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws was conferred on him at Columbia University.

LISBON, Portugal, May 18 -- German propaganda, thrown on the defensive for the first time by the entrance of the United States into the war, has lost much of its old punch, and its effectiveness on the home front has slumped.

William Reydel, partner of Newell-Emmett Company, was elected chairman of the board of the American Association of Advertising Agencies at the group's twenty-fifth annual meeting at Skytop Lodge, Skytop, Pa., yesterday.

WICHITA, Kan., May 18 -- This may be considered a combination report on production and morale in the Wichita area. After a second day spent here, newspaper correspondents on the "production for victory" tour are able to write that not only is trainer plane production excellent but the spirit of the aviation industry out in Kansas is fine. It is young, vital and decidedly up-and-at-'em. It can do the job.

Last week Secretary Morgenthau made the suggestion of a $5 head tax upon every one who files an income tax return, whether or not his return is taxable. Such a filing tax, he estimated, would bring in $100,000,000 a year. Three days later representatives of labor, management and Government at the National Shipbuilding Conference reached an agreement for a 7 per cent increase in shipyard wages.

The death of Robert Hunter must remind many middle-aged persons of the flaming indignation and the deep pity which he wrote into his famous book on "Poverty," published thirty-eight years ago. As a young man, working with charitable groups and living in settlement houses in Chicago and in England, he had reached the conclusion that the terrible conditions he saw could not be remedied by charity alone.

Mrs. Samuel Rosenman, chairman of the National Committee on the Housing Emergency, has been added to the list of speakers who will discuss price control and rationing under auspices of the War Action Center tonight, at 8:30 o'clock at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- The controversy in the Senate as to whether the Commodity Credit Corporation shall be permitted to sell cash wheat and corn below parity prices continues to rage, but reports today that the farm bloc had split on the question resulted in turning the grain markets downward and the close was near the lowest levels of the day.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Roosevelt signed the bill putting freight forwarders under supervision of the I.C.C. and conferred with Democratic leaders from the Capitol; his visitors included George Harrison, president of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks; Chairman Davis of the Red Cross, Secretary Ickes, Senator Pepper, Representative Melvin J. Maas and Dr. T.V. Soong, Chinese Minister of Finance.

Telephone bills in New York will carry on the reverse side a mathematical formula by which subscribers may determine the amount of taxes included in the bill, under an order issued by the Public Service Commission yesterday.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 18 -- Prime Minister John Curtin, speaking at a Royal Empire Society luncheon today, said that he had no fear of the result if Australia had to meet the shock of war on her own soil.

HONOLULU, May 18 -- From 6,000 feet altitude and 100 miles away as a bomber flies the towering white mass rising above the cloud layer, flashing snow-capped Mauna Kea, appeared on April 29 to be just a part of the thick carpet of vapor that hid sea and islands.

ST. LOUIS, May 18 -- Tuck Stainback, utility outfielder of the Yankees, was sent back to New York today for treatment for his injured right hand. He has been ordered to place himself under the care of Dr. Robert Emmet Walsh.

Your editorial "Ration Card Inflation," and Arthur Krock's recent correspondence, "The Effort to Call the War Program 'Voluntary,'" underscore one of the dangers implicit in the present governmental approach to domestic problems. The apparent fear of the effect on popular psychology and morale of coercive measures is reaping a harvest of resentment and bitterness.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- The war emergency convention of the American Jewish Congress demanded today that "the international status of the Jewish people established in the Covenant of Versailles be recognized by the United Nations and that in the discussion preliminary to peace, the Jewish people be given an opportunity to participate through their credited representatives in all matters affecting Jewish interests."

Old friends and neighbors of Miss Maude Robinson as well as students during her thirty-two years as director of the pottery department of Greenwich House gathered yesterday at the settlement, 27 Barrow Street, to pay tribute to her at a tea signalizing her retirement from that post.

The city of Trenton, N. J., will be in the market on May 28 with an issue of $738,200 of various purpose bonds, for which bidders are asked to name the rate of interest. qne bonds, dated !Iay 1, X942, will nature serially from lIay 1, 1943 to 1967.

DETROIT, May 18 (AP) -- Manager Joe Cronin restored Jimmy Foxx and Pete Fox to the Red Sox line-up today and they batted home three runs for a 4-to-2 victory over the Tigers that squared their series at one game each. It was Charley Wagner's fourth pitching victory against two defeats.
David Kugel, in Hyde Park Hotel, 25 E 77th St; Frances R. Jaffin, broker.

LISBON, Portugal, May 18 -- There is perhaps no better way to demonstrate the manifest deterioration of the German economic position than to enumerate the more important restrictions that we were able to cull from the German press during our internment at Bad Nauheim from the beginning of 1942 to May 7.

Harried from port to port, the entire fighting career of the German heavy cruiser Prinz Eugen has consisted thus far of one escape from disaster after another. But each escape has been at a mounting cost. Caught Sunday night by a British flying squadron off the coast of Norway, she is now limping toward Germany with another torpedo hole in her side.

Antoinette Schulte, who has been quite a stranger here, having spent years abroad and whose one-man show in New York was held in 1936 at the Marie Sterner Gallery, returns now to the local exhibition world with a show that opened yesterday at the Bignou Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, May 18 -- I went out to a hospital today and had a talk with Lieutenant Milton Barnard, aged 23, who was raised in Westfield, N.J., who went to West Point from Buffalo, N.Y., and now has a wife and a ten weeks' old daughter in Troy, Ala.
BOSTON, May 18 (AP) -- Running on top all the way, J.L. Patterson's Shasta Man today won the featured mile for platers of the $2,000-$1,500 class at Suffolk Downs by a length and three-quarters.

Vice President Henry A. Wallace, Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles and high officials of the Latin-American republics will participate tonight in an hour-and-a-half radio program dedicating the Columbia Broadcasting System's new "Network of the Americas."

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, May 18 -- The New Zealand people's army, being trained along the most modern lines, now owns equipment that surpasses all expectations, while other materiel has continued to arrive, Lieut Gen. Edward Puttick, commander of New Zealand's land forces, told the nation in a radio address last evening.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- More than $3,500,000 worth of drugs, medical supplies and clothing have been sent by the American Red Cross to Soviet Russia's war victims in recent months, and this will be nearly doubled within a short time, Norman H. Davis, National Chairman, announced today.

ALBANY, May 18 -- At the opening session of the State Fire Chiefs Association today the Federal government came in for its share of disapproval by Mayor La Guardia for its failure to provide gas masks, protective clothing, supplementary fire-fighting equipment and other essentials to combat enemy air bombing.

Hailing the establishment of retail price levels as "important a war measure as the Selective Service Act," Sylvan L. Joseph, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, warned yesterday that with a national income this year estimated at $117,000,000,000, there would be $21,000,000,000 "running loose" even after $31,000,000,000 was saved or paid to the government in personal taxes.

Greater aid for Russia was urged by Mrs. Winston Churchill in a message read last night at the first organizational dinner of the radio, film, arts and theatre division of Russian War Relief at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The funds raised at the dinner will be used to purchase medical supplies for Russia.

SOMEWHERE IN NORTHERN IRELAND, Tuesday, May 19 (U.P.) -- Thousands upon thousands of United States troops, equipped with tanks, heavy guns and other invasion materiel, have landed in Northern Ireland from the largest convoy of the war, which crossed the Atlantic without the loss of a ship despite sporadic enemy attacks, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Charges of revolting atrocities in Yugoslavia were leveled against Hungary in a note from the Yugoslav Government at London delivered to Secretary of State Cordell Hull today by Constantin Fotitch, the Yugoslav Minister.

BOSTON, May 18 -- Mobilization in the next thirty days of all available school teachers, social workers, psychologists, recreational directors and Scout leaders to protect the mental and physical health of America's youth, now "faced with great and far-reaching danger," was urged tonight by Dr. Arthur H. Ruggles of Providence, R.I., incoming president of the American Psychiatric Association, which opened its annual meeting today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 18 -- "Lucky Number," a screen comedy by Lili Hatvany, has been purchased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a vehicle for Nelson Eddy and Kathryn Grayson, the studio announced today. Eddy will play a dual role in the photoplay, which involves a confusion of identity between a small-time vaudevillian and a film star.

TRENTON, N.J., May 18 -- Asserting the belief that President Roosevelt's nomination of Thomas F. Meaney, Hudson County Democrat to be a judge of the United States District Court in New Jersey was "a mistake which obviously must have been made without the full facts having been presented to him," Governor Charles Edison today urged the Judiciary Committee of the United States Senate not to confirm the appointment.
WITH THE MEDITERRANEAN FLEET, May 18 (Reuter) -- Today in a farewell message to the Mediterranean Fleet, Admiral Sir Andrew Browne Cunningham said:

Conflict with the canceled Giant-Dodger night game having been eliminated as a result of the dimout order, the ten-round heavyweight boxing contest between Bob Pastor and Tami Mauriello will be held Friday night, rather than Thursday night, at Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday by the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- A House Judiciary Sub-committee today approved a measure designed to make labor unions subject to provisions of the Federal Anti-Racketeering Act.

Once more our colored citizens, already deeply aroused over discrimination against them in the armed forces and defense industries, have been presented with a grievance. The United States Supreme Court, on May 4, declined without opinion to review the case of Odell Waller, colored sharecropper, convicted of first degree murder in the shooting of his white farmer landlord during a quarrel induced by Waller's attempt to get his share of their wheat crop.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The House, after tributes had been expressed by Speaker Rayburn, Majority, Leader AIcCormack and colleagues on the Ways and Means Committee, adjourned out of respect to Representative Boland.

JERUSALEM, May 18 -- Another chance discovery -- this time by workers constructing a detour along a highway that leads westward from Jerusalem -- has revealed a remarkable relic of Roman times in Palestine.

This city will witness "the greatest parade in the history of the United States" on June 13, a Saturday, when 500,000 men and women will march up Fifth Avenue from Washington Square to Seventy-ninth Street to demonstrate "the solidarity of the American people back of the war effort," it was announced yesterday.

PATERSON, N.J., May 18 -- This city, by confining celebration of its 150th anniversary to a dinner instead of following original plans for a $77,000 program to last a week, has saved thousands of man hours for the war, Mayor William P. Furrey declared today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The first units of the armored force of the United States Army to be assigned for possible European action have arrived in the British Isles, the War Department announced here tonight.

The Greater New York War Fund drive of the United Service Organizations seeks $4,450,000 as the community's share of the national campaign for $32,000,000 to provide off-duty social and recreational services to the nation's armed forces.

An increase of 5 per cent in Spring prices as a basis for Fall wholesale prices on men's clothing was reported under consideration by the Office of Price Administration yesterday as the solution for the higher costs under which manufacturers are now operating.

William Tiedemann, 22 years old, car washer and night watchman, of 179-16 142d Street, Springfield, Queens, was bound and gagged early yesterday in the garage of the United Parcel Company at 132-05 Merrick Road, Springfield, by burglars who removed a safe containing $14,236 from the company's offices adjoining the garage, according to the police of the Queens Village precinct.

LONDON, May 18 -- Prices on the Stock Exchange were generally firm today but the industrials were buoyant. Imperial Tobacco and British American Tobacco each gained 2s 6d. British Celanese gained 6d and Courtaulds 7 1/2d.

Shoppers and retailers here took Federal control of retail prices in their stride yesterday. The General Maximum Price Regulation, establishing the highest March prices of retailers as the ceiling that will hold for the duration of the war, went into effect smoothly and quietly in the nation's largest retail trading area.

Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. conferred yesterday morning with leaders of the New York War Savings Staff here at an informal session which lasted from 9 A.M. until noon. More than fifty of the "key" men of the Treasury's local war-saving staff attended.

AN EAST COAST CANADIAN PORT, May 18 -- With the Free French tricolor flying sadly but proudly at half mast, one of her crew dead and four injured, a battered freighter has arrived at this port after a stirring battle with a German submarine.

The factory, formerly occupied by the Sklar Surgical Instrument firm at 133 Floyd Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Enos Foundation for Traffic Control, to the Nells Manufacturing Company. Thatcher, Simpson Bartlett were the attorneys for the seller.
BARKSDALE FIELD, La., May 18 (AP) -- Barksdale Field suffered its worst accident today when a four-motored bomber crashed near the field killing the crew of nine.

Cultural anthropology was older than Branislaw Malinowski, yet it was he who raised it above the purely descriptive stage by establishing a scientific basis for the study of primitive and late societies. To him culture was the sum total of all human activities, the vast instrumentality through which man achieved his social purpose.

The Queens campaign of the Greater New York United Service Organizations Joint War Appeal was launched last night at a dinner meeting in the Queens Elks Club, Elmhurst, with more than 200 persons prominent in the activities of the borough attending. The Queens quota is $200,000.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (U.P.) -- Lieutenant John D. Bulkeley, whose torpedo-boat exploits in the Philippines made him one of this country's outstanding naval heroes, told a press conference today these small craft were so effective that the Japanese thought the United States forces were using a new secret weapon.

Breezing along on the impetus of Sunday's twin triumph, the devastating Dodgers yesterday turned back the Cubs again, 4 -- 1, behind the five-hit hurling of the veteran Johnny Allen and achieved their longest winning streak of the campaign, seven games.

An absorption of available residential space during the Fall renting season coupled with the stoppage of apartment house construction should result in a building boom in residential areas after the war, according to Arthur Eckstein, president and treasurer of Arthur Eckstein, Inc.
MOSCOW, May 18 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Soviet information bureau communique today said:

" The Moon Is Down," John Steinbeck's much-discussed drama of a Norwegian town invaded by the Nazis, will close at the Martin Beck this Saturday evening after a run of fifty-five performances. Few plays in recent years have come to Broadway under as exciting circumstances as those which attended the premiere of the Steinbeck play.
MOSCOW, May 18 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Soviet information bureau communique today said:

" The Moon Is Down," John Steinbeck's much-discussed drama of a Norwegian town invaded by the Nazis, will close at the Martin Beck this Saturday evening after a run of fifty-five performances. Few plays in recent years have come to Broadway under as exciting circumstances as those which attended the premiere of the Steinbeck play.

As thousands of motorists rushed to exchange gasoline rationing cards for higher or lower ones in the metropolitan area yesterday, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, announced in Washington that legitimate holders of B gasoline rationing cards who economized on their essential gasoline requirements were free to use saved gasoline for any purpose they desired.

The seven six-story apartment houses containing 230 suites, together with thirty-four garages, at the northwest corner of Burns Street and Stafford Avenue, Forest Hills, L.I., were sold to Forwal Realties, Inc., for cash above a mortgage of $612,500.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 18 -- Tony Tiso, one of the most consistent winners on the Westchester circuit last season, captured his first prize of the new campaign at the Gedney Country Club today.
