He teamed with Mike Tartaglia of Green Valley to post a best-ball score of 35, 32 -- 67 in the opening pro-amateur event of the Westchester County Golf Association.
BERLIN, May 18 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

Charging that he was attempting to "run behind the cloak of retirement," the city opposed yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Ernest E.L. Hammer the application by Maurice E. Rogalin, suspended former principal of the New Utrecht High School, Brooklyn, to compel the Teachers Retirement Board to retire him on a pension.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 20 (U.P.) -- German raiders, reaching the English northeast coast for the first time in eleven nights, bombed a town late last night after Royal Air Force planes had bagged four enemy fighters -- three of which fell to American Eagle pilots -- in daylight sweeps over France.
BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, May 20 -- A communique issued by the Havas OFI Agency today said:

After a week of heavy fighting we still know little about the Battle of Kharkov except its magnitude, which now spreads to include a new German counter-offensive eighty miles to the southeast. There are, however, some revealing items in the news. The Russians report that they are using their cavalry again.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- President Roosevelt, in a telegram today to the convention of the Inland Press Association, said that "the men and women of a nation at war have the right to expect of their newspaper the same loyalty with which they send their men to join our fighting forces."

The National Academy, at 1083 Fifth Avenue, is opening several new exhibitions today. One of these is a small group of early portraits from the academy's permanent collection, installed in what has come to be known as the Walnut Room.

CHUNGKING, China, May 19 -- It would appear that the fateful decision has been taken in Tokyo to try for a knockout blow against China before turning elsewhere for military conquest. The statement from Tokyo that "the war hereafter will be continental" seems to confirm this.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., May 19 -- The automobile industry to date has been a complete "bottleneck" in the plan to have it supply parts and assembled units for war plane production, James H. (Dutch) Kindelberger, president and general manager of the North American Aviation Corporation, declared yesterday, adding that plane production would have been much farther advanced if the automobile makers never had been called into that side of the picture.

Motorists holding X cards for unlimited gasoline will begin receiving letters today directing them to appear before local rationing boards with proof of their claims to the highest rating. This was disclosed yesterday when the first batch of letters went out from rationing offices at 1450 Broadway.

Formal offering to the public will be made today by the First Boston Corporation and Mellon Securities Corporation of a new issue of $4,000,000 of Public Service Company of Indiana first mortgage 3 3/8 per cent bonds, due on March 1, 1972.

Gross revenues of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad in the week ended on May 14 were about $950,000, up 65.2 per cent from the same week last year, Matthew S. Sloan, president, said yesterday. For the first two weeks of May gross was $1,858,000, up 67.4 per cent from the same period last year.

OTTAWA, May 19 -- In a public session that lasted just one hour today and in six committees that are working in private, the United Nations Air Training Conference has in this first day "started so auspiciously that it can already look forward to results with very high hopes," according to Robert A. Lovett, United States Assistant Secretary of War for Air and head of the United States delegation.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Amid charges in the Senate that government agencies were freezing agriculture out of the synthetic rubber and alcohol production program, there emerged today a formula devised by a Pole, alleged to have been "sneaked" into this I country, for the partial conversion, at least, of potatoes, grains and other surplus farm products into these vital commodities of war.
MOSCOW, May 19 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique today said:

FRANKFORT, Ky., May 19 (AP) -- The Kentucky Court of Appeals -- the State's highest tribunal -- declared today for the second time that the State must refuse Federal demands for $1,040,000 collected as jobless benefits from railroad workers before July 1, 1939.

The premiere performance last night at the Normandie Theatre of the British film "Ships With Wings," presented under the auspices of the English-Speaking Union and the Union Jack Club of the British War Relief Society, drew a large attendance of members of society, diplomatic and military circles.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 19 -- Sixty members of the graduating class of the Princeton Theological Seminary received degrees of Bachelor of Theology at the seminary's 130th annual commencement in the Princeton University chapel today. Seventeen advanced students received degrees of Master of Theology from Dr. John A. Mackay, president of the institution.

For about nineteen minutes yesterday many of us were led to believe that an air raid was imminent. There are four kinds of air raid signals: the yellow, which is a confidential warning to civilian defense officials and to essential industrial and transportation services; the blue, which mobilizes civilian defense services; the red or "action" signal, which means that enemy planes are within five minutes' flight; and the white, or all clear.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The House Military Affairs Committee eliminated from the Service Men's Pay Attotment and Allowance bill today a provision that would have permitted the Federal Security Administrator to make supplemental payments to dependents of fighting men.

CHESTER, Pa., May 19 -- The United Nations have at last exceeded the Axis in war production "in nearly every category," Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, declared today. He spoke at Pennsylvania Military College, where he received an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws.

The contribution of members of the American Theatre Wing War Service to the war production program was praised yesterday by Mrs. Anna Rosenberg as regional director of the Social Security Board. She spoke at a luncheon at Sardi's Restaurant, 234 West Forty-fourth Street, attended by members of the committee who are preparing to enroll 27,000 members of the entertainment industry in this area.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Sales of armaments to the Federal Government were excluded from price regulation today by an order issued by Price Administrator Leon Henderson. The exclusion was "to prevent any possibility that sudden wholesale subjection to price control under the General Maximum Price Regulation might interfere with essential war production."

LONDON, May 19 -- Captain Robert Davies, who removed the delayed-action bomb endangering St. Paul's, speaking today in his own defense at a court-martial trial for theft and looting, said his "generosity of heart" had led him into trouble on one of the eleven charges on which he is being tried.

The J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation announced yesterday that 231,100 nominal amount of the sterling issue and $1,025,000 nominal amount of the dollar issue of State of San Paulo 7 per cent coffee realization loan of 1930 have been retired.

The current collegiate trend for discontinuance of competitive athletics may be "disastrous" for the nation, Lieutenant Walter B. Bayless, U.S.N., said yesterday, in discussing the drive to condition 30,000 air cadets for service in the Naval Air Corps, The United Press reported.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Treasury control over the importation of currency, hitherto limited to importations from blocked countries and proclaimed list nationals, was today extended to cover the importation of currency from anywhere.

Women can get a fair idea of how they are going to look under the WPB dress regulation by viewing the midseason "made-to-order originals" now showing at Bergdorf Goodman's. The slim silhouette with its variety of treatments that give it excitement found favor with the fashion critics who were invited to the debut of the collection yesterday afternoon.

Describing a free press as the "Australia of our liberties," Bruce Barton, president of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., said yesterday that in the difficult days to follow the war "we shall need a free press to keep us mindful of the high purposes for which we have fought, to make sure that the ideals of our war-time devotion are not lost in the tough and tedious processes of readjustment."

LONDON, May 19 -- Decrying the "passions of war" but at the same time declaring that the Church of England must do its utmost to help Britain to victory, the new Archbishop of Canterbury, a noted liberal thinker among ecclesiastical circles in this country, asserted today that the Royal Air Force had done "signal" service to the Allied cause by its recent raids on the Baltic ports of Luebeck and Rostock.

The annual report of American Type Founders, Inc., made yesterday by Thomas Roy Jones, president, showed for the fiscal year ended on March 31 a net profit of $810,150 after all charges, including $395,470 provision for Federal income taxes. No provision was made or thought to be required for Federal excess profits taxes.

Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, announced yesterday the membership of the bankers' government bond committee for the Second Federal Reserve District, which will formulate policies and work closely with the United States Treasury in financing the war.

The Committee for the Preservation of Austrian Art and Culture in the U.S.A., which presented two "Masters of Viennese Music" concerts last season at Carnegie Hall, presented another last night at Town Hall. It attracted an audience of 1,500 which received the familiar songs with volleys of applause.

PITTSBURGH, May 19 -- Pickets paraded in front of the Carnegie Institute today as the strike of ten stationary engineers for wage increases forced virtual suspension of activities at the institute for the second day.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Roosevelt has reopened the question of centralizing the government's information services. He has discussed the question with several officials of the government in the last few days, reviving speculation that the nation's official news bureaus will be reorganized soon.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Members of the National Paper Box Manufacturers Association were told today by Walter P. Miller Jr., chairman of the group's advertising committee, that it intends to extend its promotional activity this year because of trade emergencies created by the war.

The rationing of sugar should be developed more thoroughly, more realistically and more justly. At the present time rationing is on a strictly individual basis. It is known that most of the individuals live in families and will consume their sugar at home.

NEW ORLEANS, May 19 -- Enemy submarines in the Gulf of Mexico, after making their boldest show a week ago, when they struck in the very "mouth of the river," killing twenty-seven of a merchantman crew, have intensified their attacks off the Mississippi delta.

All sorts of interesting things are now being told by our American newspaper men in Lisbon, fresh from Hitler's and Mussolini's carefully restricted hospitality. Not all of their observations have to do with the question nearest to our heart, which is the immediate war outlook.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Erie Railroad trustees asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to approve its acquirement of the properties of the Northern Railroad of New Jersey. These would include all the issued and outstanding stock of the Nyack Southern Railroad Company.

IN Europe the Herrenvolk are carving out their New Order from the prostrate States they have destroyed, from the denial of all the human values mankind has learned to cherish throughout its history and from the slaughtered and wasted bodies of men, women and little children. Until we have won our present struggle against the new barbarians it will be well to be reminded of the fate of those they vanquish.
BERLIN, May 19 (From German broadcasts recorded by the Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:
The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company, an important unit in the Bell System, reduced yesterday the dividend on its common stock to $1.50 a share quarterly from $1.75 a share previously.
LONDON, May 19 -- Trading on the Stock Exchange today presented a cheerful tone and despite the small volume the markets remained firm.

Further dividend casualties brought about yesterday another decline in the stock market although the air transportation issues made a strong comeback and enjoyed major additions. Brokers attributed much of the buying to investment demand based on the postwar outlook for the lines.

ALBANY, May 19 -- Legislation signed by Governor Lehman in April to liberalize State unemployment insurance benefits had an immediate stimulative efect on payments, the Department of Labor reported today.

The 635,000 stockholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, none of whom holds as much as one-half of 1 per cent of the outstanding stock, are anxiously awaiting the directors' meeting scheduled for noon today, when action will be taken on the quarterly dividend.

Joseph G. Daher of Morris-Harvey College has been added to Manhattan College's athletic and physical education staff, it was announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics. Though his appointment is principally to coach the varsity basketball team, he also will aid in the administration of the student physical fitness program and serve on the football staff as end coach.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP) -- Scoring all their runs in the eighth, the Phils defeated the Pirates, 5 to 4, in a twilight game today played before 3,366 fans as a benefit for the Army and Navy Relief Funds.
LONDON, May 19 -- A two-day debate opened inauspiciously in the House of Commons today, both for the government and for any definite conclusive result.

CHUNGKING, China, May 19 -- American sailors from the decommissioned gunboat Tutuila have gone into the junk business. They have discovered that there is real money in the pile of junk accumulated in their warehouse because of the high prices of imported materials.

Newtown High's athletes, winner of the City P.S.A.L. title for the last three years, captured the Queens P.S.A.L. track and field championship for the sixteenth time in the last seventeen years by topping a field of ten teams at Jamaica Stadium last night.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 19 -- That Swedish officers in uniform had been seen making the Nazi salute was one of the grievances brought up today in the Swedish Parliament by Socialist Deputy Brandt, who questioned Defense Minister Per Skoeld on the infiltration of nazism into the Swedish corps of officers.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Colorfast and pre-shrunk clothing for civilians can be manufactured without interfering with military production, the Consumer Division of the Office of Price Administration said today in a statement designed to clear up misunderstandings regarding supplies of fast dyes and pre-shrinking machinery.
"This Gun for Hire" will begin a second and final week today at the Paramount... . Also starting a second week today will be "Suicide Squadron," the film attraction at Loew's Criterion.

Intense fighting apparently continued in the Kharkov and Kerch areas yesterday and the arrival of additional American troops in Northern Ireland again concentrated public attention upon the possibility of a "second front."

The wide casement window that stretches across the front of the shop is framed in starched, dotted Swiss curtains, and sprays of bridal wreath trail gracefully from a vase set in the very center of the broad sill. The scrubbed-square room, which is rather like a comfortable country kitchen, is called a "kondis" -- the Swedish word that denotes a delightful compromise between a cafe and a bakery.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Roosevelt today personally awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor to Brig. Gen. James H. Doolittle, noted speed pilot, who led the squadron of Army medium bombers that raided Japan on April 18.

Sky glow, fatal backdrop for ships offshore, was somewhat reduced in New York City last night, but military observers found it still much too bright. The haze ceiling over the city was low and air-suspended moisture intensified "loom," the new term for light sent upward from cities.

MONTREAL, May 19 (AP) -- The Empress of Asia, 16,909-ton Canadian Pacific liner whose safety record as a troopship had given her the reputation of one of the luckiest transports afloat, was destroyed by Japanese dive bombers near Singapore on Feb. 5, an official announcement disclosed today.

To the general public Brig. Gen. James H. Doolittle has always been plain Jimmie Doolittle, an airplane pilot of the "chill 'em and thrill 'em" school, a man who will try anything once. To military aviators and aeronautical engineers he has always been recognized as a gifted "natural" flier and an untiring worker in aviation research and experimentation.

A new early morning train to carry workers from New York to war industries in Connecticut will be added by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad when the Summer timetable goes into effect next Sunday, it was learned last night.

The First of Michigan Corporation and Hornblower Weeks received yesterday the award of $331,000 of various issues held by the sinking funds of the city of Mount Vernon, N.Y., on their bid of 106.7777. The bonds, which bear interest at 3 and 2.80 per cent, mature serially from 1943 to 1962.

Seeking first-base protection in the event that Dolph Camilli is injured, the Dodgers yesterday purchased Ellsworth (Babe) Dahlgren from the Cubs. Larry MacPhail, Brooklyn president, completed the deal by telephone after having learned that the transaction, sending Dahlgren from the Cubs to the Browns, had fallen through.

President Roosevelt himself cannot doubt the sincerity of Governor Edison of New Jersey in urging the Senate Judiciary Committee not to confirm the Presidential nomination of Thomas F. Meaney to be a judge of the United States District Court. Mr. Meaney is a protege of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, who stands for nearly everything, including the suppression of civil liberties, against which the New Deal is supposed to be fighting.

Opposition to the Board of Education's plans for Summer war service by teachers was voiced yesterday by the New York Teachers Guild, Local 2, American Federation of Teachers. The guild charged that the plan to place teachers in Summer play schools or other Summer work would displace "those teachers whose income is eliminated by additions of duties taken on by the regular staff."

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, declared tonight that because the peoples of the Americas were free the United States "has not needed and does not need to engage in propaganda in its dealings with its neighbors in the New World."

Mrs. Jabez Burns, 87 years old, who had written Mayor La Guardia that she had "done a little bit" in the Civil War and wanted to help in this conflict, received a visit from the Mayor yesterday afternoon in her suite at the Hotel Barclay, 111 East Forty-eighth Street.

LOS ANGELES, May 19 -- Instead of reducing the 1,300 memberships of the New York Stock Exchange as advocated by some members, Charles E. Merrill, senior partner of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, would like to see the number of Exchange "seats" boosted to 3,000.

Business, which has neglected its responsibility in helping to mold public opinion for many years, now has its greatest challenge and opportunity to make its contribution by selling through its widespread contacts the idea of individual loyalty and responsibility in the war effort, Samuel Reyburn, chairman of the board of Associated Dry Goods Corporation, said yesterday.
ALBANY, May 19 -- Governor Lehman, before leaving tonight for a one-day trip to Washington, vetoed three bills which had attracted interest at the recent session of the Legislature.

RICHMOND, Va., May 19 (AP) -Although encouraged by the greatly improved financial condition of the company, the directors of the Southern Railway decided today to husband its resources in "this period of uncertainties" and not declare any dividend on either the preferred or common stock.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -Harold V. Hough, chairman of the Newspaper-Radio Committee, told the House Interstate Commerce Committee today that any revision of the communications law should include "in capital letters" a provision "that there shall be no discrimination on account of occupation or class" in the granting of broadcasting permits.

A supper dance was given last night in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre for the New York Diet Kitchen Association. The proceeds will aid the maintenance of the five children's health stations of the association which are operated in various districts of the city for the care of infants and children of pre-school age.

LONDON, May 19 (U.P.) -- The Deputy Prime Minister, Clement R. Attlee, said in the House of Commons today that Britain's strategic position in the Far East was very weak, that "it is perfectly obvious it is impossible for us to provide adequate forces at every point in the Far East."

TRENTON, N.J., May 19 (AP) -- A Chancery Court decree holding that officers and directors of the Breeze Corporations, Inc., of Newark and Elizabeth mismanaged its affairs for their personal benefit was sustained today by New Jersey's highest law tribunal.

Sentences to State prison for minimum terms of two to fifteen years were imposed yesterday by Judge James Garrett Wallace on ten men, one a leader of a labor union and three others former leaders. The men were convicted recently by a jury of a conspiracy in which $2,500,000 was extorted from independent milk dealers and truckers in this and neighboring States, according to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

Eva La Gallienne and Joseph Schildkraut head the cast of "Uncle Harry," a murder melodrama by Thomas Job, which opens tonight at the Broadhurst. In the play, which has a French-Canadian locale, a man commits "the perfect murder," is acquitted, tries to confess and can convince no one of his guilt.

LONDON, May 19 -- There is no confirmation either here or from Chungking of Tokyo reports that Japanese fliers bombed the "new Burma Road" through Assam. The raiders were said by Tokyo to have taken off from bases in Burma and to have demolished the railway stations at Badarpur and Silchar.

After a luncheon of the Federal employes' division of the Greater New York War Fund drive for $4,450,000, conducted by the United Service Organizations, Postmaster Albert Goldman led all those who had attended from the Hotel Pennsylvania to the train concourse of Pennsylvania Station, where a huge victory banner displaying a white "V" on a blue background was unfurled yesterday afternoon.

Many luncheon parties were given yesterday at the formal opening for this season of the outdoor Garden of the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Robert Karsner Stafford entertained with a luncheon there for Mme. Carlos Martins, wife of the Brazilian Ambassador.

LONDON, May 19 -- The theory that Germany had been treated with foolish and purposeless vindictiveness after the last war is one that has been imposed on a foolish world by Germans, Viscount Vansittart said in the House of Lords today.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- General liquidation developed in rye today on the Board of Trade and the September and December futures dropped to new seasonal low levels. There was nothing in the news to account for the selling movement, but brokers said commission-house selling had disclosed a lack of support and when stop-loss orders were uncovered the market gave way quickly.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., May 19 -- War production workers in this area who recently formed an organization known as Soldiers of Industry, pledging themselves to go beyond the call of duty in their production efforts for American fighting forces, were making plans today to have units of the organization established throughout the country.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 19 -- The Netherlands Indies Information Bureau said today that Japanese military authorities in the Netherlands Indies had ordered all foreign men and women, meaning Netherlanders and other Europeans, Chinese and Arabs, who have reached the age of 17 years to vow loyalty to Japan.

Mounting payrolls, more hours of work, declining unemployment and a tremendous backlog of war orders characterize the industrial picture of the nation as reflected in the report of a survey made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Paul Vincent Carroll worked in a rescue squad in Glasgow's Clydeside during the air attacks, and out of that experience came the play called "The Strings, My Lord, Are False." In it he is again stating the case for the little man, his courage and tolerance and charity: the man who has lost his home and possessions, but is continuing undaunted on his way in a tacit understanding of humanity.

It is encouraging that a House Judiciary Sub-Committee has approved the bill sponsored by Representative Hobbs of Alabama to make labor unions subject to the provisions of the Federal Anti-Racketeering Act. William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declares that his organization will oppose the bill because it is "anti-labor" and "there is no necessity for it."

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, May 20 -- Major Gen. Edward Martin, Republican, and Auditor General F. Clair Ross, Democrat, won the Gubernatorial 'nominations of their parties in yesterday's primary election, it became apparent early today on the basis of returns from almost half the 8,124 precincts in Pennsylvania.

President Manuel Prado of Peru, in an hour's visit yesterday afternoon to the campus of Fordham University, received an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, university president, and afterward reviewed the Fordham R.O.T.C. regiment in its fifteenth annual graduation parade.

Unless it could be that somebody surreptitiously kept shoving home plate around at the Polo Grounds yesterday it must be conceded that the aim of Melvin Ott's pitching corps remained atrociously cross-eyed.

One of life's unsung geniuses has just invented a device that will add three full minutes to your morning slumbers. It is called a tipstick, and its price is a mere quarter. It is a modest, black plastic stick, with a smooth plastic cap like the top of a fountain pen, but into the end of it is fitted one of the swiftest and most satisfactory applicators ever encountered.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, May 20 -- On the first day of the second week of the battle for Kharkov the Germans opened a counter-offensive yesterday in a desperate effort to stem Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's drive upon the key Ukrainian city.

PENN YAN, N.Y., May 19 (AP) -- Constance Warren, president of Sarah Lawrence College, said at Keuka commencement today that "the old pattern of family life, dependent on the old pattern of economy, had been disintegrating and a new pattern based on a new economy was evolving.

NEWARK, N.J., May 19 (AP) -- The Newark Bears turned on the lights in Ruppert Stadium tonight for the first time this year, with approval of the Army command, and proceeded to engage the Jersey City Giants in a thirteen-inning thriller before losing a 6-to-5 decision which snapped a six-game winning streak.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (U.P.) -- The War Department announced today the award of Distinguished Service Crosses to the following seventy-nine men, who participated with Brig. Gen. James H. Doolittle in the April 18 raid on Japan:

It is not expected that such well known New York trout streams as the Willowemoc and Beaverkill in ullivan County, for example, will attract any number of metropolitan anglers this season comparable to other years.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 19 -- Gasoline rationing would not interfere with shopping trips in the suburbs if women would band together and ride six in an automobile in making such trips, fifty public officials and women's club leaders of Westchester County said this afternoon at a transportation conference at the Locust Arms restaurant here.

Calling it "folly" to neglect the diet of industrial workers in wartime, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator and Director of the Defense Health and Welfare Service, yesterday afternoon urged this country to adopt the British system of providing nutritious low-cost food for workers as a matter of national policy to increase war production and working efficiency and to decrease accidents and absences from work.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Manuel Quezon of the Philippines disclosed today that he expected to make a visit to various Latin-American countries. Mr. Quezon, who arrived here last week from Australia, said he had received invitations from President Manuel Avila Comacho of Mexico and other American governments.

A general death rate of 9.9 per 1,000 population, a new low for the year so far, was set in New York City last week, it was reported yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records for the city Health Department.

BERLIN, May 19 (From German broadcasts recorded by the United Press in New York) -- German and Rumanian forces have completed occupation of the Kerch Peninsula, the High Command reported tonight in a special communique asserting that nineteen Russian divisions and seven brigades were "annihilated" and sixteen ships sunk in the twelve-day campaign.

POSSIBLY the baseball fans, fight followers and old subscribers interested in sundry other sports are irked by the frequency with which golf has been the topic of discussion in this corner of late. Well, one reason for that is that golfers are going about trying to raise money for the USO, the Red Cross, the Army Emergency Relief, the Navy Relief Society and other such organizations intimately connected with the war effort of this country.

A Stadium Concerts Defense Entertainment Committee has been formed to enable the largest possible number of men in the armed forces to attend the concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra this Summer at the Lewisohn Stadium.

DETROIT, May 19 (AP) -- Behind the six-hit pitching of Southpaw Hal Newhouser, who will be 21 years old tomorrow, the Tigers today tightened their grip on the American League's third place by defeating Boston's challenging Red Sox, 5 to 2, for an edge in their three-game series.
BOSTON, May 19 (AP) -- Charles E. Nelson's Rodin came from behind at Suffolk Downs today to win the featured Beachmont for 4-year-olds and up in Grade C.

Justice Aaron J. Levy in Bronx Supreme Court refused yesterday to disqualify himself from further consideration of a suit brought by the Bronx Savings Bank to foreclose a mortgage on the house at 2184 Parsifal Place where Mrs. Gertrude McMahon, widow of a fireman, lives with eleven of her sixteen children.

The arrival of a third contingent of "thousands and thousands" of American troops in Ireland is proof that we mean business on the other side of the Atlantic. How many troops have been landed the American public doesn't know, and is glad not to know so long as there is hope that the Nazis don't know, either.

While the new dimout regulations which eliminate illuminated outdoor advertising in New York will affect a fairly sizable percentage of billings in this area, plant operators said yesterday that they were anything but discouraged and would continue to promote the medium here for daylight use as vigorously as ever.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 19 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force issued the following communique today:

Although the recent War Production Board order restricting the production of glass containers may mean that only stock molds will be available to industrial users, variations of from 5 to 6 per cent in size and weight from the standard will probably be permitted for private molds, Dr. Julian Toulouse of the Container Branch, WPB, declared yesterday at the thirty-third annual convention of the Flavoring Extract Manufacturers Association.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Members of the Ways and Means Committee said that new surtaxes had been accepted pending last-minute revisions, but Chairman Doughton announced only that the committee had voted on the normal tax rate and had agreed on the goal.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 19 -- The first serious measure against a prominent Axis agent was taken by the Argentine Government today when the Ministry of the Interior ordered the arrest and expulsion of Heinrich Vollberg, who has been mentioned in reports of the Chamber of Deputies investigating committee as a go-between used by the German Embassy to keep in touch with its agents in Argentina.
Set free at last from stifling Fascist censorship, your former Rome correspondent, Herbert Matthews, gave the following impartial synthesis of the Italian situation in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 17:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 19 -- RKO today signed Claudette Colbert to a three-year contract calling for one picture a year under which her first assignment will be the leading role in the screen adaptation of Pearl S. Buck's novel "China Sky," the studio announced today.

OTTAWA, May 19 -- Canada's relation with Vichy will not be changed at the present time, Prime Minister William L. Mackenzie King stated in the House of Commons today in answer to a question put by M.J. Coldwell, leader of the Cooperative Commonwealth Federation.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 19 -- The United States probably will play a major role in opening a second front at a point most-likely to bring a decision, Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts said here yesterday shortly before leaving for South Africa, where he will celebrate his seventy-third birthday Sunday.

Roswell Magill, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, has suggested that income-tax payers be permitted a deduction to some limited extent for life-insurance premiums. Under present conditions, Mr. Magill argues, the middle-class individual will have little income left after payment of living costs and taxes.

Racing luck played a large part in the outcome of the $4,225 Charles L. Appleton Memorial Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, when the Rokeby Stables Redlands scored after Bath had fallen at a backstretch jump.
HAVANA, May 19 -- United States Ambassador Spruille Braden presented his credentials to President Fulgencio Batista today in the newly decorated Salon of Mirrors in the Presidential Palace.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Senate Judiciary subcommittee studying Thomas F. Meaney's nomination to the Federal District Court for New Jersey today invited allies of Governor Charles Edison and a publisher to testify before it.

BOSTON, May 19 (AP) -- The veteran Johnny Cooney's third hit in the ninth inning gave the Braves a 2-to-1 victory over the Reds today after Al Javery and Johnny Vander Meer staged a tight seveninning pitching duel.

A practice alert was ordered yesterday over the air raid warning systems of the metropolitan area and more distant parts of New York and New Jersey by Major Gen. Follett Bradley, commanding officer of the First Interceptor Command.

James D. Meenan and Andrew C. Weiss, inspectors of the Federal Alcohol Tax Unit, pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo, in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to an indictment charging conspiracy to defraud the government of alcohol taxes.

Pointing out that at the April rate of war production unfilled orders are equivalent to a two-and-a half-year load, the National IndustriaL Conference Board, Inc., declared yesterday that the conversion problem that lies ahead this year is as great, if not greater, than the changes introduced in industry from Pearl Harbor to date.

LONDON, May 19 -- As a supplement to the normal egg ration 12,000,000 tins of new egg powder developed under special process in the United States -- the equivalent of 144,000,000 eggs -- will be distributed to the British public shortly, Lord Woolton, Food Minister, announced today.

A.E.F. HEADQUARTERS, Northern Ireland, May 19 (AP) -- United States artillerymen have started an intensive study of British field guns, since the Allied aim is to have the Americans and British function as a team if necessary, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Roosevelt has appointed a committee of key Federal officials to meet tomorrow with the executive committee of the Governors' Conference to discuss elimination of State and local legal restrictions which hamper the war effort.

One of the first United States soldiers to land in Northern Ireland with the last contingent was Sergeant Walter F. Riley of 119 East Eighty-third Street, an Army veteran who, his wife said yesterday, is a poet at heart and a movie actor, too.

The belief that there will be no revision in the Agricultural Adjustment Act to reduce ceiling prices on cotton halted yesterday the liquidation that had depressed the market 80 cents to $1.05 a bale on Monday. With the end of this selling a small amount of price-fixing operations closed active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange at net gains of 1 to 8 points.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the National War Labor Board, indicated today that wage increases granted through his board would be limited to not more than 50 per cent of the increased cost of living since the pay scale was last fixed and would be given to workers in the form of war savings bonds rather than cash to reduce if not eliminate their inflationary effect.

CLEVELAND, May 19 -- Promotion of national unity in an effort to win the war was pledged to President Roosevelt today by Philip Murray, chairman of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, at the opening session of the union's convention today.

John T. Madden, chairman of the Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign opening June 14, announced yesterday "a streamlined system for securing the city's pledge of allegiance" to victory -- New York City's quota of $1,900,000,000 in pledges for the purchase of war bonds and stamps.

If the Dodgers continue their present pace -- and they certainly are showing no signs of letting up -- the National League may find itself without the semblance of a pennant race. For yesterday at Ebbets Field the Brooks hung up their eighth straight victory, leaving nothing to the imagination of 6,877 persons as they romped to a 6-1 triumph over the Cubs.

Norfolk Equities, Inc., and British-American Equities, Inc., have been dissolved and their assets transferred to a Panama corporation called Norfolk International Equities, Inc., Serge Rubinstein declared yesterday at a hearing before Supreme Court Referee Richard P. Lydon.

CHUNGKING, China, May 19 (U.P.) -- Japan has launched major offensives at both ends of the 1,500-mile expanse of South China, from the Burma border in the west to the coastal Province of Chekiang in the east, in an attempt to knock Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek`s armies out of the war this Summer, a government spokesman said today in an urgent appeal for Allied aid.
BERLIN, May 19 (From German broadcast recorded by Reuter) -- The German High Command issued this special communique tonight:

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Navy is ready to enlist 10,000 women in the Naval Reserve to release an equivalent number of men for sea duty, Rear Admiral Randall Jacobs, chief of the Bureau of Naval Personnel, told the Senate Naval Affairs Committee today.
In New York City 43,835 retailers, wholesalers, institutional and industrial users of sugar have registered under sugar rationing, it was announced yesterday by Lee S. Buckingham, State OPA director.

On several occasions Donald Nelson, head of the War Production Board, has indicated that owners of small industrial plants would be brought into the war production program. Surveys of these small plants would be made and their facilities and machines would be catalogued.

CLEVELAND, May 19 (AP) -- The Indians tossed the "kid battery" of Pitcher Charles (Red) Embree and Catcher Jim Hegan at the Athletics today, and the rookie Tribesmen came through with a four-hit, 4-to-1 triumph.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 19 -- Making her first appearance in tournament play this season, Miss Kathleen Byrne of Rye, the Westchester women's open champion, won low gross honors in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day event at the Hudson River Country Club today with a card of 43, 39 -- 82.

Retailers intent on "beating" the War Production Board's order freezing the style silhouette, to conserve material, were condemned yesterday by H. Stanley Marcus, director of the textile division of the WPB.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The President conceded at his press conference today that when he expressed hope that the success of the American troop delivery to Northern Ireland would continue in the future his statement implied that more troops would be sent there.
The Illinois Central Railroad reported yesterday that it was making progress in converting and substituting materials and in employment of scrap for war uses.

Little mention was made yesterday in General Sessions about the murder on March 4 of Mrs. Susie Flora Reich, middle-aged refugee, in the Hotel Sutton in East Fiftysixth Street, as Madeline Webb and her co-defendants, Eli Shonbrun, ex-convict, and John D. Cullen, were being tried in the slaying.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Senate farm bloc split sharply today over the proposal to sell 125,000,000 bushels of government-held wheat at prices below parity.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Ways and Means Committee approved today the raising of an additional $2,750,000,000 from individual taxpayers, and voted tentatively to increase the normal rate from 4 to 6 per cent.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 19 -- How a young Navy enlisted man, wounded in the leg, took the controls of a badly damaged bomber from its dead pilot and flew it back to its Pacific base, saving the lives of five members of the crew, was disclosed here today.

BUFFALO, May 19 (AP) -- Postponement for two years of the government's anti-monopoly suit against the Schine theatre chain was approved today by Federal Judge John Knight, who signed a temporary order providing that the circuit, meanwhile, divest itself of sixteen theatres in thirteen communities.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, May 20 -To the Germans' claim that they had "reached the Strait of Kerch in its entire width," the Russians retorted this morning with the announcement of continued resistance in the neighborhood of the town of Kerch.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Denunciation of John L. Lewis, former president of the C.I.O., was a high point in today's sessions of the annual convention of the United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employees of America.
There is a woman in Brooklyn today who suffers from a unique frustration that sets her up as perhaps the most horrible example to hoarders that the war has produced.

Degrees were conferred upon ninety-three students of ten denominations last night at the graduating exercises concluding the 106th annual commencement at Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street. The election of the Rev. Dr. William Lloyd Imes, Negro pastor of the St. James Presbyterian Church, 409 West 141st Street, to the board of directors of the seminary was announced yesterday afternoon by Thatcher M. Brown, president of the board.

Acclaiming radio's contributions to Democracy, the Women's National Radio Committee awarded certificates of merit yesterday to nine radio programs judged outstanding in a poll conducted by the committee, which represents twenty-four women's organizations.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Roosevelt presented the Congressional Medal of Honor to Brig. Gen. James H. Doolittle for his leadership of the Army's bombing raid on Japan, appointed a committee of Federal officials to work toward elimination of State and local laws hampering the war effort, held his press conference and received Senator Hughes, Rear Admiral Land and Captain McCauley, Jesse Jones, Admiral King and Harry Hopkins.

MILWAUKEE, May 19 -- Red Robert Rolfe, veteran third baseman of the Yankees, made his season's debut here today, and, with Phil Rizzuto's return to duty in short field for the first game on this swing through the West, the champions presented their regular infield array for the first time.

The Bronx grand jury that investigated the use of city paving blocks in the Lake Mahopac estate of Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, returned yesterday a second presentment, upholding its previous failure to bring indictments and defending the conduct of the inquiry by District Attorney Samuel J. Foley.

The earnings of the Plymouth Oil Company in the first quarter of this year were the equivalent of 45 cents a share on the capital stock, compared with 24 cents for the similar period last year, Walter S. Hallanan, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting held yesterday in Pittsburgh.

The possibility of a freezing of wages makes job rating in industrial plants of greater importance than ever before, A.H. Timmerman of the Wagner Electric Company, St. Louis, and retiring president of the National Metal Trades Association, declared yesterday at the opening session of the group's forty-fourth annual convention at the Hotel Biltmore.

New York hospitals responded immediately yesterday to the air raid alert signal. Emergency field medical units were manned, ready for action, nurses and doctors off duty reported back to their places, and in some instances patients were evacuated from upper floors.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yes%erday numbered 594, which compared with 604 in the preceding week and 714 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in l THE NEW YORE TIMES. Yester-i day's arrivals totaled 301, as l against 227 for last Tuesday.

Norman Elson and Captain Stanford Braun, two of the thirty-three New York University entries Coach Emil Won Elling had filed for the Violet's defense of the I.C. 4-A. track meet May 29 and 30 at Triborough Stadium, are now in the armed forces and probably will not compete in the meet, Von Elling disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- To aid the Army's Signal Corps in its drive to recruit women as junior engineers, the Women's Bureau has issued a statement explaining what the work will be and how women high-school graduates can apply for vital civilian jobs in war plants.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Forty-year-old Robert Tyre (Bobby) Jones, noted golfer, has applied for a commission in the air force. At the War Department today it was state "it is likely that his application will be acted upon favorably."

Whether people still read Carlyle or not, his and our old friend, Mr. Devils-dirt, must now be on the job. In this newspaper yesterday a Washington dispatch described a conference of WPB clothing officials and the Men's Clothing Industry Advisory Committee. Regulation of men's pajamas was the topic.

How the Army Air Corps Ferrying Command recently transported a twenty-four-bed hospital to a remote section of Alaska within thirty-six-hours after the hospital there had burned to the ground was told last night by Brig. Gen. Harold L. George, head of that organization, at the Volunteer Land Corps dinner in the Hotel Commodore.

The 10,000 American painters, architects and sculptors who have organized for war work under the title Artists for Victory, Inc., have offered a prize of $1,000 and five additional awards of $100 each in a competition for sculpture to encourage participation in the armed services.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 19 -- Political observers are constantly on the alert to discover national figures who have captured the imagination of the public.

F. Jacobson Sons opened Fall lines of shirts and pajamas yesterday at levels prevailing at the introduction of Spring offerings. The Jason shirt line runs from $18 to $54 a dozen, while the Excello grade starts at $21.50 to $54. Pajamas are priced from $19.50 to $132 for all-silk numbers.

LONDON, May 20 -- Measures taken by the British Government to standarize a minimum fifty-two-hour week for industrial work and one of forty-six hours for clerical work, with a maximum fortnight's holiday each year, from now to the end of the war, were announced by the Ministry of Labor today.

The James boys of Missouri had nothing on the Cooper boys from the same State. In fact, Leo Durocher's league-leading Dodgers might have fared better had the "J" brothers visited Ebbets Field yesterday instead of the St. Louis Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The thousands of varieties of cosmetics, designed by the industry to flatter the individual personalities of every woman in the United States, will soon be standardized for the duration, it was indicated today in a War Production Board announcement that "a study is now being made of the relative essentiality of toiletries and cosmetics and the materials used in their manufacture."
ROME, May 20 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

Carl Sandburg, poet; Lieut. Comdr. Edward Steichen, photographer, and Mrs. Steichen were guests of honor last night at a dinner given in the penthouse of the Museum of Modern Art before the private opening of an exhibition of photographs entitled "Road to Victory -- A Procession of Photographs of the Nation at War."

In the belief that the most effective way of insuring quick victory in the war and a satisfactory peace settlement is to elect capable men to office, the New York City League of Women Voters, at its annual convention yesterday, called upon its members to conduct a pre-election campaign.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The President openly showed the deep enjoyment which was his due when he surprised the country yesterday by informing it that Brig. Gen. Doolittle was the leader of the American air raid on Tokyo, and surprised the hero by pinning on him the Congressional Medal of Honor.

One of the most impressive exhibitions ever put on in New York opened with a preview last evening at the Museum of Modern Art: "Road to Victory," opening to the public today and scheduled to remain current all Summer.

The "roll-back" on pickled sheep -- skins issued Tuesday by OPA failed to clarify the agency's policy on "roll-backs" under the general maximum price regulation, observers here pointed out yesterday, because these skins were exempt from the leather ceilings.

Unless plans are altered, "Harlem Cavalcade," the all-Negro variety program, will give its forty-ninth and final performance at the Ritz Saturday night. No tickets were on hand at the box-office yesterday for next week. The show opened A~ay 1 under the sponsorship of Ed Sullivan, columnist, who occasionally dabbles in show business.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Members of the Pacific War Council discussed today the prospects of renewing aerial attacks on Japan and the probabilities of an early all-out Japanese offensive designed to knock China out of the war. They also countered Japanese propaganda for a "new order" for all of East Asia, coming up with a new United Nations slogan -- "Japan for the Japanese."
BERLIN, May 20 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique today said:

Earnings of the Consolidated Oil Corporation for the first four months of this year were very satisfactory and much greater than in the corresponding period of 1941, H.F. Sinclair, president, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting held here.

The revised war plans of the government cancelling all new factory construction that cannot be completed within twelve months will have no effect whatsoever on the rate of steel output and consumption, it is pointed out in trade circles. Fabricators of structural steel, on the other hand, should begin to notice a difference in their order books and schedules in a fairly near-by future.
LONDON, May 20 (AP) -- Belief that the Nazis were massing 100,000 parachutists on the Kerch Peninsula of the Crimea for a mighty air-borne invasion of the Caucasus was expressed here today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Control of the American Bosch Corporation and of Steel Union, Inc., and five copyrights owned or controlled by German nationals has been taken over by Leo T. Crowley, Alien Property Custodian, it was announced today.

LONDON, May 20 -- The United States Army Air Corps spokesman at New Delhi, India, reported today that daily low-level bombing and strafing raids, plus Chinese resistance, had cost the Japanese so heavily that their advance up the Salween River into Yunnan had been virtually brought to a standstill.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Federal Government is developing plans to prevent prices paid abroad for imported merchandise from disturbing domestic price ceilings, it was announced today by Price Administrator Leon Henderson. Whether this will be done by subsidy, as is done by the Canadian and British Governments in some cases, was not stated.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation has reported that there is not the "slightest foundation" for charges that Senator Walsh, 69-year-old chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee, visited "a house of degradation" in Brooklyn and was seen talking to Nazi agents there, Senator Barkley, the majority leader, announced to the Senate today.

Ludmilla Pitoeff, member of a family whose repertory theatre had won fame in pre-war Europe, made her American debut last night at the Barbizon Plaza Theatre in a benefit performance for the scholarship fund of the Lycee Francais in New York.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 20 -- Yale used its entire pitching staff of four today, but failed to halt the free-hitting Army team which gradually cut down the Elis' first inning three-run lead and won, 6 -- 4.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Major Gen. Levin H. Campbell Jr., a veteran ordnance specialist, was nominated today by President Roosevelt to be Chief of Ordnance, succeeding Major Gen. C.M. Wesson when the latter's term expires on June 2.

BOSTON, May 20 -- America is conducting the war on "an outmoded formula" that gives our enemies a great advantage, it was declared today at the annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association by Professor Edward A. Strecker and Professor Kenneth E. Appel of the University of Pennsylvania Medical School and the Institute of the Pennsylvania Hospital, Philadelphia.

Jerome Hartman of 103-21 116th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, failed yesterday to qualify as a "landlady" so that he could inherit approximately $7,000 from the estate of the late Augustus V. Heartman, who died at Hartman's home, where he had rented a room, on Nov. 19, 1939.

From the looms, potteries and workshops of pre-war Britain has come an exhibition of her arts and crafts, to be shown at the Metropolitan Museum of Art beginning this morning. A preview was held yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Lou Nova, the reformed Yogi, risks his fistic future against Lee Savold of Des Moines tomorrow night in a ten-round battle expected to enrich the Navy Relief Society by about $20,000.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- The nation's railroads put into effect today embargoes on all shipment of grain moving to terminal markets to be stored except when assurance can be given that cars will be unloaded promptly at their destination.

Despite the action of American Telephone and Telegraph Company in maintaining its regular quarterly dividend, the weight of further reductions in payments by other key stocks argued yesterday against any resumption of the recovery movement in stocks.

The Citizens Committee to Reopen the Flynn Case continued yesterday to voice its disapproval over the findings of the Bronx County grand jury which handed up a second presentment Tuesday reiterating their original findings which completely absolved every one in the Flynn paving investigation.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 20 (AP) -- Walter D. Fuller, president of the Curtis Publishing Company and chairman of the board of the National Association of Manufacturers, warned 400 Pennsylvania bankers here today that unless democracy, liberty and free enterprise provided security and happiness for the people of this country, those principles might be abandoned after the war.

Prejudice, social and racial, bears curious fruit. A friend of mine is air warden for a floor in her apartment house. It is a large house built around three sides of a court and pleasantly set in trees in one of the near Long Island suburbs.

Despite a 492 per cent increase in payrolls and $618,676 provision for Federal and State income and excess profits taxes, Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., had a consolidated net profit of $666,366 for the six months ended with March, in contrast to a net loss of $80,556 in the corresponding period of the previous year, according to the statement of Joseph W. Frazer, president, issued for publication today.

VICHY, France, May 20 -- Two British airplanes that flew over French Guinea in West Africa were forced down by anti-aircraft fire, according to reports received here from Konakry tonight. News of the incident follows repeated Royal Air Force flights extending over the unoccupied zone of France and the skirmish that occurred off Algeria in which French and British airplanes clashed yesterday.

E.C. Mauchly, vice president of the F.W. Woolworth Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders in Watertown, N.Y., that officials of the company were optimistic regarding the outlook for sales and that facilities for procurement of merchandise so long as it was available were excellent.

Under a plan to go into effect on June 15 draft registrants accepted for military duty are to receive immediate fortnight furloughs with pay, to afford them time to close out civilian affairs. Furloughs will begin at the induction station. When the fortnight is up, the men will have their parade and farewell and will go to reception camp in groups.

Hermann Goering is said to be putting something by for a rainy day, but not in cash. He is buying up art treasures and jewels in Italy. One story places his investments at a million dollars. It has always been known that Goering likes nice things.

Entitling its annual report this year. "Mental Hygiene: Ally of Victory," the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, Inc., reported yesterday that statistics show a much higher rate of psychiatric disqualification now than during the first World War, but that the rate of rejections should be even higher to prevent mental breakdowns after men are inducted into the armed forces and to keep morale at its maximum under the stress and strain of war.

Some price reductions on government contracts have been made by the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, although they have not been announced by the company, stockholders were told yesterday at their annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., by E.S. Cramer, treasurer and secretary.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Legislation authorizing the seizure of wire or radio communications as evidence in the prevention or prosecution of cases of treason, espionage, sabotage or seditious conspiracies was released today for House consideration by its Committee on Rules.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The United States has made an arrangement with Admiral Georges Robert "to immobilize French warships and merchant vessels at Martinique," Senator Tom Cornally, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said today at a press conference.

LONDON, May 20 -- Reorganization of the Free French governmental establishment, which, if it comes about, will probably mean changes in the National Committee established by General Charles de Gaulle last September, is being widely and heatedly discussed among leaders of the exiled movement in London.

An exhibition on portraits of patriots who helped give to the United States its heritage of freedom was opened yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Gotham Branch of the Grand Central Art Galleries, 2 West Fifty-fifth Street, for the benefit of scholarships in American citizenship at Barnard College, Columbia University.

Retail spokesmen in town yesterday returned to Washington last night to make known their opposition to reported War Production Board plans for limitation of retail and wholesale inventories of consumer goods, it was learned here.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The $680,000,000 Agriculture Appropriation bill, which would authorize sale of 125,000,000 bushels of controlled government wheat at less than parity prices, was passed by the Senate today after one section of the momentarily disunited farm bloc had assailed the provision as a reversal of the entire parity program.

To the surprise of some breeding experts, the fleet chestnut filly, Zaca Rosa, carried her speed for the mile of the $14,800 Acorn Stakes before 15,547 racegoers who bet $1,085,916 at Belmont Park yesterday. Zaca Rosa won handsomely by a length and a half from the heavily-favored Vagrancy.

LONDON, May 20 -- The chief feature in the stock markets today was a revival of interest in the South American rail shares. Central Argentine ordinaries recovered small early losses; Leopoldina debentures rose 1 to 42; United Railways of Havana 1906 debentures moved up l5s to 17 3/4 and Buenos Aires Western advanced 1 to 49.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Sir Walter Citrine, Secretary of the British Trades Union Congress, appealed to the American Federation of Labor Executive Council today to give up its opposition to collaboration with Soviet trade unions and join the British and Russians in an international alliance designed to speed the war effort against the Axis.

A nation-wide "salvage sewing contest," to produce thousands of garments from waste materials, has been organized in forty-six States in preparation for "National Salvage Sewing Week," beginning on Sunday, it was announced yesterday by Bundles for America, Inc., 475 Fifth Avenue.

Lou Novikoff has been a feeble figure at the plate this season. On a hunch, however, Manager Jimmy Wilson again started Lou in left field against the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday and Novikoff drove in the runs which enabled the Cubs to triumph, 6 to 3.
MOSCOW, May 20 (Frown Soviet broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique today said:
PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- Republican and Democratic party machines in Pennsylvania scored impressive triumphs in yesterday's State-wide primary election.

LONDON, May 20 -- The British court martial that is trying Captain Robert Davies, the engineer officer who was decorated for bravery for his bomb-removal feats in London in the Fall of 1940, acquitted him today on three of the counts -- two involving charges of looting and one of extortion -- against him.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The House completed Congressional action today on legislation increasing from $300,000,000 to $800,000,000 the total of loans which may be insured by the Federal Housing Administration and giving special emphasis to the construction of larger rental projects designed primarily for war workers.

To help individuals retain their homes and life insurance and to save business men from defaulting on securities, J. Cheerer Cowdin, chairman of the committee on government finance of the National Association of Manufacturers, endorsed yesterday a proposal of Senator Walter F. George, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.

OTTAWA, May 20 -- Following his announcement yesterday that for the present there would be no change in diplomatic relations between Canada and the Vichy government, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King today told the House of Commons that he had requested the French Minister to Canada, Rene Ristleheuber, to close French consulates and consular agencies.
TAMPA, Fla., May 20 -- A running gun battle between a large American merchant vessel, which eventually was sunk, and "at least three" Axis submarines in the Caribbean was revealed today.

BOSTON, May 20 (AP) -- The Braves clung to second place in the National League today by defeating the Pirates, 4 -- 3, when Paul Waner drew a base on balls from Ken Heintzelman with the sacks loaded in the tenth inning, forcing home the winning tally.

Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes staged his own gasoline conservation campaign yesterday when he drove up to the Hotel Commodore in a horse-drawn cab and in effect warned guests at a luncheon there that they might be forced to similar means of locomotion soon.

Executives of most New York City sight-seeing and charted bus lines were not surprised when informed of the new order of the Office of Defense Transportation. They had hoped, however, that the order would be delayed until after their seasonal Summer rush.

A total of 341 athletes from thirty-five colleges are entered in the sixty-sixth annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. outdoor track and field championships to be held May 29-30 at the Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island, it was announced yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell, executive officer for the meet.

The sustained Russian offensive in the Ukraine, combined with the landing of new contingents of American troops in Great Britain, has precipitated fresh demands in the House of Commons for an invasion of Europe. It is a healthy sign that the periodic waves of criticism that break out in England invariably rise from popular impatience for more audacious military action.

LONDON, May 20 -- A.P. Herbert rose to the defense of Prime Minister Churchill in the House of Commons today, saying that those who spoke in yesterday's debate of "disaster after disaster'' had painted a one-sided picture.

DETROIT, May 20 -- Harry H. Bennett, personnel director of the Ford Motor Company, and spokesman for the management, today announced that the company wished to terminate its contract with the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., on June 20, and negotiate a new contract.
FREEPORT, L.I., May 20 -- Some rather big catches of mackerel have been brought into this port during the past week and these reports of good hauls are well substantiated.

Vice President Henry A. Wallace's widely discussed speech on May 8 at a dinner of the Free World Association here is being rushed into a pamphlet-book by the L.B. Fischer Publishing Corporation for release on Monday. In addition to the text of the speech, which gave a broad view of the war and its relation to history and defined the war aims of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who left this afternoon for New York, told her press conference this morning that she was going "by plane," but that hereafter she would use the air routes, or motor cars, or Pullman accommodations on railroad trains only when traveling "as the President's wife or on some official business."
CHUNGKING, China, May 20 -- "No matter how the situation may deteriorate, Yunnan will be defended," declared General Lung Yun, Governor of the Province, at a memorial meeting at the capital, Kunming.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Roosevelt today ordered the Navy Department to relinquish control of the three plants of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation which were taken over on April 18. The order was issued without explanatory detail.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Lewis W. Douglas has been appointed deputy administrator of the War Shipping Administration, Rear Admiral Land, administrator, announced today.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., May 20 -- Although war industries are providing many jobs in the nation, New York City occupies an unfortunate position and will face increased unemployment at least during 1942, Richard C. Brockway, New York State director of the United States Employment Service, said here today at the annual conference of the United Neighborhood Houses of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Office of Civilian Defense was given authority by President Roosevelt today to develop and execute -- under supervision of the Secretary of War -- protective measures against sabotage of communications systems, air commerce, highways, railways, forests, mines and gas and water utilities, public buildings, storage places and other facilities.

Fordham's baseball team notched its fourteenth victory of the season yesterday, defeating an Army nine from Fort Monmouth, 6 -- 1, on the Rose Hill diamond. The game was completed in an hour and forty minutes, one of the fastest nine-inning contests ever played on Fordham Field.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 20 -- The export of cattle and beef in recent weeks to the United States has caused a shortage in many centers in Canada and the wartime prices control board has been obliged to intervene. It promises immediate relief to the present situation in this country and satisfaction to beef producers who have been benefiting by the higher prices obtainable in the United States.
Mere words cannot adequately express thanks for the splendid work being accomplished by the United Service Organization in help to lift the morale of the Army, Navy, Marines end Coast Guard.
The principal parts of prepared addresses by Herbert Hoover, Robert P. Patterson and Paul V. McNutt last night follow:

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, May 20 (AP) -- A maddening forty-six-day voyage on a raft, during which one companion died and the other fell into the sea and drowned, was described today by Michael Wajda, 28-year-old American seaman brought here by a rescue ship.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Increases in the individual income surtax rates, doubling the rate for the first $2,000 of surtax net and extending throughout the entire range of surtax brackets, were voted tentatively today by the Ways and Means Committee.

DETROIT, May 20 -- A remarkable insight into what the gigantic automobile industry is doing to help America win the war -- an insight convincing enough to drive home to his listeners the feeling that American industry has both the vision and the ability to out-produce the Axis -- was given here yesterday by K.T. Keller, president of the Chrysler Corporation.

THERE was a very bad play in baseball the other day. In fact, it was perfectly ghastly. It happened in Philadelphia. The Pirates were playing the Phils and the gate receipts went to the Army Emergency Relief and the Navy Relief Society. All big league clubs are playing one home game, with balanced partners, for the various war funds.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 20 -- Because armies often feel that their air forces do not understand them and air forces evince similar sentiments about armies, South African bomber crews are learning about South African ground troops by spending short periods on the front line in Cyrenaica.

About 1,400 more X and B gasoline rationing cards were surrendered yesterday to local rationing boards in exchange for cards authorizing fewer gallons, Lee S. Buckingham, State director of the Office of Price Administration, announced yesterday as some local boards in up-State communities began reviewing applications on which X cards had been issued.

The way for a woman to influence male legislators and win votes is to "act quiet like a dumb bunny" and not to "try to act smart," Councilman Rita Casey, Brooklyn Democrat, told forty members of the Women's Natiional Democratic Club at its seminar on "The Voice of Women in Government" last night.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,483,900 barrels daily, a decrease of 60,450 from the 3,544,350 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 9,400 barrels more than the recommendation of 3,474,500 daily by the Office of Petroleum Coordinator for May.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

After registering early gains of 3 to 5 points through price-fixing and commission-house buying in the distant months, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange weakened yesterday under liquidation in late trading and closed 5 to 10 points below Tuesday's final prices.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A war division has been established under which all the Department of Justice war activities will be grouped, Attorney General Diddle announced today.

MOSCOW, May 20 (U.P.) -- Hundreds of miles north of the main Russian fronts, German and Soviet planes were reported today to be locked in a running battle for command of the Allied supply route through Arctic waters to the Soviet Union as the "white nights" of the far north merged into endless day.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 20 -- Lucille Ball was named today by RKO to appear with Victor Mature in "Sweet and Hot," with Mady Cortes, Dinah Shore, Eddie Anderson and the orchestras of Freddy Martin and Les Brown. Tim Whelan will produce the film, which William Bowers, Curtis Kenyon and Kenneth Earle are writing.

Drastic reduction of city street lighting -- as much as 50 to 70 per cent in some districts -- was promised yesterday by engineers for the Bureau of Electricity of the city's Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, following their study of sky glow that endangers Allied ships off our coast.

ST. LOUIS, May 20 (AP) -- The Browns, playing the first game under lights of the major league season, shelled three Washington pitchers for ten hits and a 10-to-1 decision tonight. Southpaw A1 Hollingsworth handcuffed the Senators with six scattered hits.
Park Lane Gowns, Inc., has leased a large store and mezzanine at the southeast corner of Park Avenue and Forty-ninth Street in the Park Lane Hotel through Douglas L. Elliman Co.

BERLIN, May 20 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Reich Marshal Hermann Goering, speaking at a ceremony at which decorations were conferred on workers, declared tonight that "this war is the hardest Germany has had to fight."

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP) -- Ray Lamanno, the rookie catcher who is leading the National League batsmen, fattened his average today with a perfect day at the plate as the Reds whipped the Phils 10 -- 3. His home run with the bases loaded in the third was backed up by a single and a triple.

Tuesday's primary in Pennsylvania showed that there as elsewhere it is hard in these times to whip up excitement about domestic politics. The vote was thin. The contest was among professional politicians. Of the Republican aspirants for Governor, Major Gen. Martin, the winner, was certified by Governor James, the Republican State Committee and those elder statesmen, Joseph Pew and Joseph Grundy.

A syndicate composed of E.F. Hutton Co., Hill Co., the City National Bank and Trust Company of Kansas City, and Soden Co. submitted the high bid for an issue of $505,000 of city of Albuquerque, N.M., various purpose bonds, naming an interest cost basis to the city of 2.19 per cent.

Women make splendid soldiers because they are willing to work, in the opinion of Major Joan B. Kennedy, Officer Administering the Canadian Women's Army Corps, who addresed a luncheon meeting of the Fashion Group's cosmetics section at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday.

Manhattan High School of Aviation Trades ended the three-year domination of the Bronx Vocational teams in the annual city vocational high schools track and field championships by winning the crown yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. Staging a belated rally and tallying 11 1/2 points in the final two events, the high and broad jumps, Manhattan finished with 40 1/2 points.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Temporary promotions in the Marine Corps today included eleven officers who are now believed to be prisoners of war. Among them are Captains Frank C. Tharin of Washington and Herbert C. Freuler or Orinda, Calif.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Motorists applying for supplemental gasoline rationing cards allowing them more than the allotment given them when they registered last week were urged today by the Office of Price Administration to be prepared to submit all essential facts about their driving requirements before going before the local rationing boards to make such applications.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The State Department received a report today of the whereabouts of forty-nine American officials, governmental employes and members of their families who are prisoners of the Japanese of Manila. The information received concerned only their location.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The problem of making the available supply of cargo ships do the biggest possible job of hauling war supplies overseas will be one of the first jobs tackled by Lewis Douglas.

The Better Business Bureau of New York City is cooperating with war agencies and business in six important activities, H. Boardman Spalding, president of the association, reported yesterday at the twentieth anniversary luncheon of the bureau at the Advertising Club of New York.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 20 -- The story of the rescue of troops and seamen from the liner Empress of Asia by the Australian sloop Yarra near Singapore on Feb. 5 was told today by rescued members of the liner's crew. The Yarra was packed with more than 2,000 rescued men, and her commander, Lieut. Comdr. R.W. Rankin, ordered them not to move because of the danger of capsizing.

LONDON, May 20 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill bore the brunt of all the pent-up dissatisfaction in the House of Commons, whose members speak with some authority as the representatives of the British people, when the debate on the conduct of the war continued today.

A triumvirate of New York milliners presented headlines and crowns for this and the coming season at Belmont Park yesterday. The occasion was the first of the season's terrace fashion luncheons. It will be followed by another next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Manuel Prado, President of Peru and first Chief of a South American country to visit the United States while in office, ended a two-weeks' official visit today with expressions of confidence in the United States.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 20 -- Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief declared a mistrial in a divorce suit today because the foreman of the jury, Harry Silver, baldish Mount Vernon real estate operator, arranged a "date" last night with the comely defendant, Mrs. Dorothy Gould of 156 East Thirty-seventh Street, New York City, near here home.

BERLIN, May 20 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Renewed Russian attacks on the Kharkov front were repulsed in heavy fighting yesterday and thirty-four more Soviet tanks were destroyed, the German High Command said today.
It seems to me that THE TIMES'S editorial on the gasoline-rationing situation is unduly hard on Congress.

CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- Anton Christoforidis of Cleveland bounced back as ranking challenger for the world light heavyweight championship tonight by turning back the bid of rugged Johnny Colan of New York in a ten-round battle in the Chicago Stadium.
