Local rationing boards will begin distributing sugar ration books today to those who were out of town at the time of the first registration or who did not apply for other reasons, State headquarters of the Office of Price Administration announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, indicated today that pay disputes would be settled in the future in the light of President Roosevelt's declaration of April 27 outlining to Congress an anti-inflation program which would freeze most wages at "existing levels."

ALBANY, May 20 -- Governor Lehman gave his approval today to seven bills appropriating a total of $50,000 for research work and tests to be carried on in connection with the production of food in the State. He called the legislation necessary to make this country the granary of the world.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Ratification of a convention with Canada with a view to ending double taxation of income by the two nations was recommended today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

The six-story apartment house for eighty-two families at 55 West Broadway, Long Beach, Nassau County, has been sold by the Underwriters Trust Company, as trustee for a group of certificate holders, to the 55 West Broadway Realty Corporation for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $55,000.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York was accused today by James M. Landis, director of the Office of Civilian Defense, of "irresponsibility of utterance," which he characterized as second in wartime "only to giving information to the enemy."

Another murderer is walking these dim old streets, murmuring of poison and of blood, of justice and the pasty-faced hangman's curving noose. Even before the town was darkened because of gentlemen of force residing elsewhere Broadway had its crimes of character -- Boris Karloff and the Sisters Brewster with their neat line of corpses for "Arsenic and Old Lace," and Vincent Price and "Angel Street."

If somebody directed you to make a nourishing cereal by blending certain whole grains with soy bean meal you might not be too appalled by the idea. You would probably think that given the ingredients, a quiet kitchen and a morning to yourself you could somehow successfully arrive at a delicious result.
Operators were the principals in several of the real estate deals on the West Side of Manhattan reported yesterday.

Owners of series E war savings bonds registered in the name of one person, or in the name of one person and a beneficiary, who may desire to have the bond in the name of two individuals as co-owners, are now permitted to make this change, it was announced yesterday by Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in a circular letter sent to all issuing agents yesterday.

MOSCOW, Thursday, May 21 -- Breaking terrific resistance along the Kharkov front, where General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock is being forced to ravel out his tank strength at ever-increasing speed, Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's men are persisting in their advance through the Germans' deep defenses, according to reports available here early today.
Matthias A. Harrington, chief inspector of the Department of Markets since 1927, was suspended yesterday on three charges of misconduct brought by Investigations Commissioner William B. Herlands.

Supreme Court Justice Ernest E.L. Hammer will be asked today by four unsuccessful candidates for positions in the city-wide Sheriff's office to invalidate the appointment of Sheriff John J. McCloskey, Under-Sheriff Meyer Bernstein and Chief Deputy Sheriffs Hyman W. Kehl, James L. Anderson, James P. Brennan Jr. and Theodore H. Malmud.

As the Battle of Russia develops into the tremendous conflict that fate has set for the critical Summer of 1942, it must be increasingly clear to every American that our own fortunes are deeply involved in this test of strength. The Red armies are not fighting in defense of a democracy.

Irene Bordoni, the actress, was one of seven new tenancies in the recently completed apartment house at 40 Central Park South reported yesterday by Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., agents. Other suites were taken by Mrs. Maude K. Sloane, Richard M. Lamb, Mrs. Albertha Wolcott, Mrs. Corinne K. Smith, and, through Frances R. Jaffin, broker, Dr. Sandor Lorand, and, through William A. White Sons, Mrs. Florence Brackett.

BERLIN, May 20 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in London) -- Reich Marshal Hermann Goering announced in an address today that there would be "temporary reductions in the food rations" because the weather made the crop outlook unfavorable.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Treasury announced today that since the beginning of the calendar year government receipts from taxes, borrowings and all other sources had totaled $15,797,000,000, a record for any country at any time in four and one-half months.

Declaring that large numbers of proprietary drug products had withstood legal attacks on their composition and labeling during the past year, James F. Hoge, general counsel of the Proprietary Association of America, advised members yesterday to make certain that their advertising would also stand up under any tests.

LISBON, Portugal, May 20 -- The Italians have been losing the war at a great rate but they certainly have not been losing their sense of humor. They are, after all, one of the most refined and cultured peoples in Europe.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 20 -- Nazi propaganda in Brazil and the rest of Latin America today received a blow by the enforcement of a measure that amounts to the confiscation of dollar currency in the possession of Axis citizens.
NEW DELHI, India, May 20 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force issued the following communique today:

Eli Shonbrun collapsed twice yesterday during his trial in General Sessions on the indictment accusing him of murdering Mrs. Susie Flore Reich, middle-aged refugee, on March 4, in the Hotel Sutton, in East Fifty-sixth Street. Shonbrun's uncle, Murray Hirschl, who is awaiting trial on the same indictment, was continuing his testimony as a State witness against Shonbrun, Madeline Webb and John D. Cullen.
LONDON, May 20 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

LONDON, May 20 -- The great South German inland port of Mannheim, center of large war production factories, including the Badische anilin chemical plant, was bombed last night by the Royal Air Force, which also attacked the U-boat base of St. Nazaire, France, the Air Ministry reported today.

AT UNITED HEADQUARTERS in Australia, Thursday, May 21 (U.P.) -- United Nations bombers, swooping doom on Timor Island, 400 miles northwest of Darwin, yesterday started huge fires in hangars and ground installations at Kupang airdrome and blasted the harbor area of Deli, United Nations Headquarters announced today.

LONDON, May 20 (U.P.) -- Stockholm dispatches tonight said that Heinrich Himmler, head of the Nazi Gestapo, has taken personal command of strengthened occupation forces in the Netherlands in an effort to stamp out growing unrest and prepare the Netherlands against a possible Allied invasion.

NEWARK, N.J., May 20 (AP) -- Making the most of their six hits and profiting from George Washburn's streaks of wildness, the Syracuse Chiefs today administered a 7-to-3 defeat to the league-leading Bears in the opener of a three-game series.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Joe Gordon led the Yankees in one of their favorite pastimes at Comiskey Park today. With two successive home runs, the Rock of the infield, who is also the club's leading slugger, provided the punch for a victory that snapped a seven-game winning streak by the White Sox.

After a stormy discussion over "discrimination" against trained women in the armed forces, the Women's Dental Society of New York unanimously adopted a resolution last night calling upon the Army and Navy to give women dentists "the same status in the armed forces of our country that is enjoyed by the men of the profession."
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 20 -- A serious attempt to smooth out all the wrinkles in the relations between the United States and Chile will be made very soon, well-informed circles predicted this evening.

Three new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall the newcomer will be "Tortilla Flat," Metro's screen transcription of the John Steinbeck book. Spencer Tracy, Hedy Lamarr and John Garfield head the cast of the film, which was directed by Victor Fleming. Frank Morgan, Akim Tamiroff, John Qualen, Connie Gilchrist and Sheldon Leonard appear in supporting roles.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Navy Department tonight set in motion machinery, which, on June 1, will begin the recruiting of Negroes for their first chance at combat service in the Navy and the Marine Corps.

ALBANY, May 20 (AP) -- New York fishermen were assured today of "lenient interpretation" of new amendments to the State Navigation Law, allowing them to fish without United States Coast Guard identification cards in certain waters.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Professional operations were largely responsible for extremely erratic price changes today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade. A small upturn early on scattered buying was followed by a break of more than 1 cent a bushel, but when shorts tried to cover they found little wheat for sale and prices advanced 1 3/4 cents from the low level before the demand let up.
The Navy has announced the sinking of two more ships in the Gulf of Mexico, and elsewhere on the seven seas proud ships loaded with the stuff of war are foundering.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 20 -- Continuing to play fine golf, Mrs. R.M. Torgerson of Lakeville won low gross honors for the third week in succession as she toured the beautifully groomed Meadow Brook Club course in 39, 42 -- 81 today in the weekly tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association.

OTTAWA, May 20 (Canadian Press) -- Registration of men between 16 and 70 years who are not gainfully employed was announced today by Elliott M. Little, Canadian National Selective Service Director, as part of a program "to enable us to put every employable man to work as soon as possible."

From 30 to 40 per cent of retail charge accounts will be in default or "frozen" on July 11 under the terms of Amendment No. 4 to Regulation W of the Federal Reserve Board, James M. Malloy, credit manager of Abraham Straus and president of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, said last night at the meeting of the Metropolitan Controllers Association at the Hotel Martinique.

IT was a brilliant hunch that set Norman Cousins, managing editor of The Saturday Review of Literature, to studying the records of the rise and fall of democracy in Greece of the fifth century B.C. Far from being uninstructive, the story of the fatal pre-machine-age war between Athens and Sparta is full of suggestions that apply to this day of tanks and heavy bombers.

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on April 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $17,809,882 after operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal after preferred dividend charges to $1.44 a share on the corporation's 5,503,193 shares of common stock outstanding.
A Mr. and Mrs. George U. Harris will give a dinner tonight on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
DETROIT, May 20 (AP) -- The Athletics smashed a six-game losing streak today on Lumen Harris's brilliant relief pitching and Lou Blair's ninth-inning triple that beat the Tigers, 5 to 3.

LONDON, May 20 -- Eight London police guards of the Japanese Embassy staff will soon be very happy men, for it is reported today that the Japanese diplomats will shortly be leaving London for Japan. This will mean less hiking for the police guards because during the last six months the Japanese have spent most 'of their time walking round and round Hyde Park -- a distance of eight miles each time.

Sixteen members of the Atlante Soccer Football Club of Mexico City, champions of Mexico, arrived yesterday for the first game of their "good neighbor" tour at Randalls Island Stadium next Sunday against a picked team from local American League clubs.

Former President Herbert Hoover told an audience of 2,000 industrialists, business men and economists last night that President Roosevelt must be vested with dictatorial economic powers to win the total war in which the United States is now engaged, and called for the creation of a more definite national war council composed of the civilian heads of the great war agencies to collaborate directly with the President for a more effective conduct of the struggle.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Army will facilitate by every means the speedy naturalization of non-citizen soldiers, under the terms of the Second War Powers Act of 1942, it was stated today. This law provides for almost immediate grants of citizenship to such soldiers, if they can win the endorsement of their commanding officers.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- British agriculture under the stress of war has become more efficient in the production of food than any other country in the world, Paul H. Appleby, Under-Secretary of Agriculture, reported today on his return from a nine-week visit to Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A conflict between two Free French Governors in New Caledonia has produced such a state of administrative demoralization that the United States has appealed to General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Free French movement, to straighten out affairs in the interest of the common cause. Great Britain is understood to be supporting the plea.

Mayor La Guardia informed the House Ways and Means Committee yesterday that the tapping of municipal sources of revenue by the Federal Government might have disastrous results for cities throughout the country.

Two Greenwich Village artists claimed yesterday the distinction of having sold water-colors to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as she strolled during the afternoon along the south side of Washington Square, near her new apartment at No. 29.

Three hundred fifty women who have been working as volunteers to help New York hospitals run at full efficiency in spite of loss of personnel and other wartime conditions were honored yesterday at a "graduation" held for them at the Academy of Medicine, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

One of the foremost aeronautical engineers engaged in the manufacture of wartime planes delivered a prepared address before 300 dinner guests of the Foreign Commerce Club in the Hotel Astor last night in which he said airplanes must replace ocean-going vessels completely, not only for passenger traffic but also for heavy freight, immediately after the war -- or sooner, if the war lasted many years.
Commercial buildings figured in the leading realty transactions reported on the East Side of Manhattan yesterday.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company maintained yesterday its twenty-two-year dividend record with the declaration of the regular quarterly dividend of $2.25 a capital share. Aggregating some $42,000,000, the quarterly disbursement will be sent to about 635,000 stockholders.

BOSTON, May 20 (AP) -- Phil Bieber's Maechance came on in the stretch at Suffolk Downs today to take the Point of Pines Purse by a length and a half from Watch Over. Rough Time was third in the field of seven.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 20 -- Scarsdale, which has held what amounts to almost a monopoly on the Westchester senior golf title, its representatives winning all but two of the seven championships played thus far, is in a fair way to continue its hold on the crown.

ADELAIDE, South Australia, May 20 -- Sir Howard Lloyd, chairman of the Bank of Adelaide, speaking today at the annual meeting, protested some of the Labor government's wartime restrictions on banking.
A little girl, her short black pigtails tied with lavender ribbon to match her party dress, tugged at the skirt of a supervisor yesterday and poured out her heart.

A broad program of nutritional research, stressing wartime food problems on the battlefield and the home front, will be financed through $125,000 in grants by the Nutrition Foundation, Inc., a public service organization formed last January, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, May 20 -- Governor Lehman struck at the roots of the liquor price war situation today by signing the Hollowell bill eliminating large discounts and rebates from wholesalers to retailers and requiring wholesalers to post their prices with the State Liquor Authority, with the prices remaining fixed at the level posted for at least a month.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Roosevelt issued an executive order authorizing the Office of Civilian Defense, under supervision of the Secretary of War, to develop and execute protective measures against the sabotage of communication and transportation facilities.

Heinrich Himmler has taken a modest pride in his record as Germany's official murderer. He has more corpses to his credit than any man alive except Hitler. Now Hitler has sent him to Holland. The Germans there have just shot ninety-six people and taken 460 others as hostages.

Two more up-State Democratic County Chairmen, Edward B. Frenette of Franklin County and Marion L. Thomas of Essex County, announced yesterday their support of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Tall women got good news today when the War Production Board decreed that women more than 5 feet 8 1/2 inches tall could qualify as being of "unusual height," and, on this basis, are exempt from the size restrictions in the code governing women's clothing.

Because of refusal to become an air raid warden and to attend lectures connected with Brooklyn College's air raid program, Dr. Janet Rankin Aiken, English instructor in the evening semester for twelve years, was informed that she would not be reappointed next semester, she said yesterday in a letter to Harry D. Gidonese, president of the college.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Ways and Means Committee's new income tax program rejected a suggestion by President Roosevelt that no individual be permitted to keep more than $25,000 after payment of taxes. The members also took no action on a coupled recommendation that corporations might well be confined to a more or less fixed percentage of profit.

Testimonials of merit for outstanding service to the city's parks were presented yesterday to Bernard M. Baruch, financier, and Gilmore David Clarke, landscape architect, by the Park Association of the City of New York at a luncheon held by its directors at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

ALBANY, May 20 -- Governor Lehman struck at the roots of the liquor price war situation today by signing the Hollowell bill eliminating large discounts and rebates from wholesalers to retailers and requiring wholesalers to post their prices with the State Liquor Authority, with the prices remaining fixed at the level posted for at least a month.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Roosevelt issued an executive order authorizing the Office of Civilian Defense, under supervision of the Secretary of War, to develop and execute protective measures against the sabotage of communication and transportation facilities.

Heinrich Himmler has taken a modest pride in his record as Germany's official murderer. He has more corpses to his credit than any man alive except Hitler. Now Hitler has sent him to Holland. The Germans there have just shot ninety-six people and taken 460 others as hostages.

Bob Pastor is favored to win the ten-round heavyweight bout in Madison Square Garden tonight with Tami Mauriello of the Bronx, who has outgrown the middleweight and light heavyweight classes in the last year.

LONDON, May 21 (UP) -- The Duke of Bedford, Britain's foremost pacifist rose to Adolf Hitler's defense in the House of Lords today, telling his colleagues that "if you had shared his experience, you would at least understand why he is ruthless in protecting his country."

A Pan American Airways transatlantic clipper arrived yesterday at La Guardia Field with eighteen passengers, nine of whom were transatlantic voyagers, including Margaret L. Holkar, American wife of Sir Yeshwant Rao Holkar, the Maharajah of Indore, who was removed in an ambulance from the marine base to a hospital in Manhattan.

LONDON, May 21 -- The highly prized Vi toria Cross has been awarded for valor in the Commandos' March 27 attack on the German naval base at Saint Nazaire in France to Commander Robert E.D. Ryder, who led the small force of unprotected ships; Lieut. Comdr. S.H. Beattie, who commanded the destroyer Campbeltown, and Seaman W.A. Savage.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Department store sales for the week ended May 16 were tip 5 per cent, compared with the corresponding period last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. For the four-week period ended May 16 and for the year to that date, gains of 8 per cent and 19 per cent, respectively, were reported.

Connecticut shut down on stream fishing a few weeks ago because the seriousness of an existing fire hazard made it necessary to close all woodland areas. When the subsequent lifting of the ban occurred, it indicated that the danger in the State had passed.

An army of American girls is emerging from well-kept houses, shouldering picks and hoes and marching resolutely if inexpertly toward the garden. This is not a Summer for beach beauties, they seem to feel, but one for stakes and twine and seed catalogues. It is a Summer for physical fitness, for farmer's hats and dungarees, for simple, efficient beauty preparations -many of them straight from the family medicine chest.

The New York Yacht Club is ready to carry on in racing this Summer to the extent that skippers wish. That was learned last night after the May meeting of the club, at which in the past the programs have been decided upon, with the exception of America's Cup matches.

ALBANY, May 21 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury returned indictments today charging sixty-one persons with participation in a $10,000,000 lottery ring alleged to have operated in cities from Maine to South Carolina and as far west as St. Louis.

As the Russians in the east widen their assault on Kharkov, the British resume their mass air drive on the Western Front. There is undoubtedly a strategic coordination in this double effort. The present aim of the British is not only to cripple German war production but to keep as many German planes as possible out of the Russian sky.

"Iron Hermann" Goering has played almost as many parts and held almost as many posts as he has uniforms, but Wednesday he appeared in a new role. Tears dripped from his voice as he bewailed the wickedness of the weather. "The Winter campaign was terrible." The Fuehrer suffered "deeply for his troops," but of course he was tougher than the toughest meteorological show.

The overwhelming superiority of the steel industry of the United States in a world at war was the keynote of the fifty-first general meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute, held yesterday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Eight hundred executives and technicians from all parts of the country were present.

President Roosevelt will call Governor Lehman to Washington, probably within a month, to assume a high position in the nation's war machine, it was learned here yesterday after Wednesday's White House conference between the Chief Executives of the nation and State.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 21 -- Following up a two-stroke lead which he gained in the first round, Alfred M. Morris, Scarsdale Golf Club veteran, carded a 44, 39 -- 83 over the heavy Westchester Hills course today and retained his Westchester senior golf title.

Credentials which raise the status of nurses' aides to that of full-fledged members of the city's Emergency Medical Service will be conferred next Tuesday on some hundreds of women who have completed their courses of training. An induction ceremony at Town Hall at 3 P.M. will mark the conferring of the official identification cards and accompanying arm bands on those qualified by Dr. Edward Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals.

Mayor La Guardia vetoed the City Council bill changing the name of East River Drive to MacArthur Drive yesterday with the explanation that it was premature at this time to single out General Douglas MacArthur for special honors among all the country's defenders.

A total of 613,394 gasoline rationing cards was issued last week in New York City, of which 43 per cent were B-3s and 11 per cent Xs, a preliminary report by Lee S. Buckingham, State director of the Office of Price Administration, disclosed last night.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Clear channel broadcasters claiming to serve 50,000,000 radio listeners mostly in rural areas accused the Federal Communications Commission today of having "fallen down" with respect to "insuring a fair distribution of service to the rural population."

HONOLULU, May 21 -- The Army today appealed to dog owners throughout Hawaii to enlist their pets in the Army for "guard and sentry duty at all of the Territory's more important military installations."

"The Cat Screams" will be the Martin Beck's next tenant, opening Tuesday night, June 16, it was announced yesterday. Martha Hodge, actress daughter of the late star, William Hodge, and wife of the actor, Myron McCormick, is entering the managerial ranks with this offering.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 21 -- Frank J. Ryan and Dick Oxley, two home club members, today annexed honors in the Long Island Golf Association's first amateur-amateur best-ball tourney at the Hempstead Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- An eight-point program providing for designation of "critical" war industries in order of importance and for establishment of a modified system of labor priorities to promote "the fullest utilization of the man power of this nation" was announced today by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- If you want to alarm any member of the Administration from the Cabinet level down just whisper in his ear one of two dread sentences: "Sam Rosenman is in town," or "The Chief has an executive order on his desk that affects you."

ALBANY, May 21 -- Governor Lehman signed today the Congressional reapportionment measure passed by the Legislature and at the same time delivered a rebuke to the State's lawmakers for having failed to enact any bill reapportioning the legislative seats.
CLEVELAND, May 21 (AP) -- The Red Sox coasted to an 8-to-3 victory over the Indians today. Rookie Tex Hughson scored his second triumph in two starts, allowing seven hits.

Large crowds of consumers who failed to obtain their copies of War Ration Book No. 1 in the first registration period swamped local rationing boards yesterday. At two locations in Manhattan and one in the Bronx the lines were so long at 3 P.M. that police were summoned to keep applicants in line and the doors were locked against later arrivals.

LONDON, May 21 -- Out of a population of 33,000,000 between the ages of 14 and 64, Britain has mobilized 22,000,000 in the armed forces and civil defense industries, Ernest Bevin, Labor Minister, told the House of Commons today. He estimated that 2,000,000 others, mostly women, were engaged in part-time war work.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- As a step in rubber conservation, the Office of Price Administration announced today an amendment to the tire-rationing regulations which will permit bus transportation companies to enter into new tire and tube leasing contracts with tire manufacturers or wholesalers.
CHICAGO, May 21 -- That man Tiny Bonham was at it again today at Comiskey Park.

DETROIT, May 21 -- There she stood -- one of the seven wonders of the world of war; vast enough to swallow up an entire city; awesome enough to reduce man, her creator, to a lost speck in a jungle of giant machines.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date. Holdings of United States Government securities decreased $39,575,000 during the week.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A resolution increasing by $210,000,000 the marine and war risk insurance fund of the War Shipping Administration passed the House unanimously today, on recommendations from the Appropriations Committee, which estimated that ship sinkings are running at a rate of "a little more than one ship a day."

"A riot of roses" is the poetic report of the New York Department of Agriculture's scout of the flower stalls. Every day this week more than 200,000 rosebuds have arrived from the greenhouses of Long Island and New Jersey, to distribute their petals over polished tables in every corner of the city.

ALBANY, May 21 -- Governor Lehman, in a proclamation today, asked the people of the State to observe tomorrow as National Maritime Day. Noting that the day had been so designated by Congress, the Governor asked for a display of flags to honor our merchant sailors.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, expressed the opinion today that while conditions under which the Navy was combatting submarines "are constantly improving," complete elimination of the menace was not to be expected.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The forthcoming limitation of all inventories to "practicable working minimums" was announced today by the War Production Board. The proposed regulations, it was said, will specifically curb inventories of all types of merchandise to assure quantities on hand are reasonable and that equitable distribution among dealers is provided for.

Morrow says that Harnett T. Kane's fellowship under the Julius Rosenwald Foundation for research of Louisiana history, ultimately to become a book, will follow the completion of Mr. Kane's second volume on Louisiana, on which he is now working.

Perhaps there is no harm in having a second look at this phrase that has captured people's imagination, about the folly of waging war with too little too late. There are circumstances when one can do much worse than arrive on a battlefield with too little too late; and that is to arrive with too little too soon.

The Navy announced yesterday the sinking of two more ships by enemy submarines operating on this side of the Atlantic. One was a medium-sized United States merchant vessel, sent to the bottom off the north coast of South America several weeks ago; the other was a small Norwegian ship sunk off our Atlantic coast on May 17.

After a lively interchange yesterday between Councilmen Walter R. Hart and Stanley M. Isaacs over the merits of several air raid protection bills, the City Council adopted an amended bill designed to provide maximum protection at the least possible expense to home and building owners.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- A proposal that major league games be started earlier or later than at present so that baseball crowds will not add to the rush-hour burden of transportation facilities was placed before Baseball Commissioner K.M. Landis today by the Office of Defense Transportation.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 21 -- For the second time in a row Mrs. Frank J. Holleran of Round Hill led Mrs. Richard Hellmann of Scarsdale by one stroke to capture low gross laurels in the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's weekly tournament at the Tamarack Country Club today.

A request that American Jews, through the United Palestine Appeal, send immediately to the Jewish Agency for Palestine an additional $1,000,000 for urgent war purposes has been received by cable from Eliezer Kaplan, treasurer of the agency, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, national chairman of the Appeal.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Senate voted $50,000 today to build a twenty-five-mile-long barbed-wire fence along the Mexican border west of El Paso, Texas, although Minority Leader McNary of Oregon questioned the wisdom of using essential materials for such a project.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 21 -- The fourth district of the New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs was a casualty of gasoline and tire rationing today when no candidate could be found to run for vice president in that district. Voting for officers was held at the organization's annual convention at the Haddon Hall.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 21 -- An apparently deliberate attempt to wreck trains moving over what is known as the "Fort Dix Line" of the Pennsylvania Railroad was disclosed today by Thomas Thorpe, chief of police of Pennsauken township, who asserted that the act was committed by saboteurs.

Incongruous figures were seen sauntering through the staid corridors and riding the elevators of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. Members of the executive committee of the Hobo Fellowship of America, attending a "convention" in a modest room on the fourteenth floor, mingled with other guests amid stares of shock and amazement.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Navy can and will salvage the liner Normandie, which capsized at its pier following a fire Feb. 9, on the eve of entering service as a troop transport, Secretary Knox reported to President Roosevelt today.

COOK books are indisputably indispensable for the welfare of the human race, and they sell very nicely (Fannie Farmer's "Boston Cook Book" some 2,040,000 copies). So each year publishers proffer new ones of all sizes and varieties, from lordly and expensive tomes invoking the honored names of Escoffier, Vatel and Brillat-Savarin to cute and coy brides' companions designed to aid in holding a husband's love and winning a mother-in-law's respect.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 21 -- Marshal of the Reich Hermann Goering's speech in Berlin, in which he prophesied a long war, with still heavier sacrifices for the civilian population, was the reason why the ban on telephone communication with foreign countries was suddenly and unexpectedly imposed last night.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 -- John Barrymore, noted stage and screen actor, is gravely ill tonight in the Hollywood Hospital.
BERLIN, May 21 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 21 (U.P.) -- United States Army authorities today asked Australian Federal and State authorities to adopt a general wartime policy of relinquishing custody of American soldiers arrested for civil offenses.

The New York Telephone Company announced yesterday that it has asked the Public Service Commission for permission to charge a reduced rate for two or more telephones for the use of civilian defense control centers in most of the State, effective June 15.

MOSCOW, May 21 (AP) -- Along with a swift new Red Army sweep toward Kharkov, prime prize of ten days of the fiercest fighting of the Spring campaign, the army newspaper Red Star outlined these developments on the eve of the twelfth month of the war:

The Rialto's offering, "Grand Central Murder," is the lone film attraction opening today. The cast of the Metro melodrama, directed by S. Sylvan Simon, is headed by Van Heflin, Virginia Grey, Sam Levene, Cecilia Parker, Connie Gilchrist; Tom Conway and Samuel S. Hinds.

BOONTON, N.J., May 21 -- Teaming perfectly, Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont and Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches led a small field by six strokes as the first round of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association best-ball tournament was concluded today at the Knoll Country Club.

One of the basic requirements for a victorious America is child health care, Arthur Huck, executive director of the Children's Aid Society, declared yesterday in making public the eighty-ninth annual report of the organization.

Thurman Arnold's anti-trust division of the Department of Justice, which has deferred prosecution of two court actions against General Electric Company in wartime, moved in a new way yesterday to obtain some of the results sought in the earlier cases.

Welcomes to the sixteen Club Atlante players, who arrived here Wednesday from Mexico City for a "good neighbor" soccer tour in this country, were voiced by Asa S. Bushnell and Dr. G. Randolph Manning at a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Claridge.

When a hotel manager at the General Sessions trial of Madeline Webb, Eli Shonbrun, the ex-convict, and John D. Cullen for the Reich murder, identified Cullen and the woman defendant yesterday as having engaged a room in the Hotel Oxford, at Broadway and 112th Street, on the night after the killing, a noticeably tense situation arose at the defense table.

A Berlin propaganda broadcast of the German Transocean Agency, recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES, indicated yesterday that, despite contradictory earlier stories, Bishop Thomas James Wade, vicar apostolic for the Northern Solomon Islands, had been taken prisoner by the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Statement by Elliot E. Simpson, independent rubber dealer of New York, to the effect that large quantities of scrap rubber, from which military and civilian needs of the country can be met, lie untouched about the country, were challenged today by Representative John F. Hunter of Ohio, member of the Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures.

LONDON, May 21 -- The sharp Nazi air attacks on English cathedral towns in the past month or so, with considerable damage to property and tolls in killed and injured, have caused some misgivings here over the policy of reducing the strength of the civilian defense forces that has been put into effect this Spring.

I have been amazed to notice that very little sentiment is felt here toward Great Britain, who has suffered more in loss of civilian life, women and children, than any other country in the world. I therefore beg to quote from a letter I received from Colonel Norman Graham Thwaites of London, who has many friends here, and who represented his government here during the World War:

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull declared at his press conference today that the whole course of the United States with reference to France was prompted by the central objective of advancing the military progress of the United Nations and winning the war.

An improved technical method for the production of aviation gasoline and butadiene has been developed by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey through which the output of these essential war products will be greatly increased with virtually no change in plants now under way, W.S. Farish, president of the company, announced yesterday.

Steel in the War All pressing requirements for steel were met, despite a concentration late last year of a demand for a few products greater than the tonnages which the mills could supply, Walter S. Tower, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, assured an audience of steel-makers at their general meeting yesterday.

HAVANA, May 21 -- The war effort of the United States is stupendous not only in industrial production but in the fighting spirit of the people, President Manuel Prado of Peru said here this afternoon. He arrived this morning for a one-day visit, coming by plane from the United States, where he had just made an official tour.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Following is the text of the Navy's official report on plans for salvaging the Normandie, known as the U.S.S. La Fayette, and some of the major problems involved:

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Thirteen registration statements, covering fifteen issues of securities for $123,059,000, became effective under the Securities Act of 1933 in April, according to an analysis made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

HARLAN, Ky., May 21 -- Manzo Shepherd, 24, was shot to death in the Harlan Circuit Court room, where he was being tried for slaying a taxicab driver today, and the jury convicted him and recommended the death penalty during the few minutes which elapsed between the time he was shot and the time he was pronounced dead.

CLEVELAND, May 21 -- R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile, Aircraft and Agricultural Implement Workers, attacked John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, today in an address before the convention of the United Steel Workers of America.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 21 -- A national sales tax to help pay the cost of the war is favored by a substantial majority of civic and community leaders interviewed throughout the country by the institute.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, May 22 (AP) -- The following United Nations communique was issued today:
CAIRO, Egypt, May 21 (AP) -- The R.A.F. issued the following communique today:

LONDON, May 21 (AP) -- The statement of condition of the Bank of England disclosed today that note circulation had continued its uninterrupted rise to the high record of 782,470,000, an increase of 2,293,000 in the week ended yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 21 -- Judging by the experience of privately owned mortgage guarantee companies, it is almost inevitable that the United States Government will become owner of thousands of homes within the next few years, Herbert O. Frey told the Pennsylvania Bankers Association here today.

The first quota can on the 36,000 New York City registrants placed in Class 1-B -- physically fit for only limited military service -- will be made on June 8. Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Selective Service director here, announced yesterday.
Led by Federal officials and representatives of the shipping and shipbuilding industries, the entire nation will honor the merchant marine today in observing National Maritime Day.

Following Secretary Knox's announcement six weeks ago that the Navy had decided to enlist Negroes in combat roles, the Navy Department has now disclosed plans to begin forming battalions of colored fighters and specialists on June 1. Thus a longstanding discrimination will be at least partially removed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 -- Universal today scheduled two new pictures, "Off the Beaten Track" and "Sherlock Holmes Fights Back," for production on June 8. Carol Bruce, who has returned to the studio after an engagement in New York, will appear in the former with the Ritz Brothers. Stanley Roberts has written the photoplay, which is a comedy murder mystery with a little-theatre background.

The share of Cornelius Vanderbilt Jr in the estate of his father, the late Brig. Gen. Cornelius Vanderbilt, will not exceed the $910,000 deduction specified in the brigadier general's will, leaving virtually nothing for the younger Vanderbilt out of the estate, it was declared in papers filed in Supreme Court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Members of Congress were advised by the Army and Navy today that they could be of more service to their country by continuing in office than by joining the armed forces.

With yesterday's ball games called off at both the Polo Grounds and Ebbets Field, the Dodgers and Giants will square off against each other in the Coogan's Bluff enclosure this afternoon in the first battle of a three-game series.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 21 (AP) -- Gunter Field counted four British Cadets dead tonight and two missing in the worst tragedy of its history, blamed to a squall encountered by thirty-five training planes last night between Atmore and Evergreen.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 21 -- Inaugurating a new session of Congress today, President Juan Antonio Rios reasserted his faith in democracy, pointed out that "at present Chile is at peace with all nations" and emphasized that Chile's foreign policy represented a loyal fulfillment of all obligations associated with continental solidarity."

CHICAGO, May 21 -- An appropriation of at least $4,000,000 with which to train nurses during 1943 was asked in a telegram sent today to President Roosevelt from a meeting of the National Nursing Council for War Service at the national biennial nurses convention.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Defense housing construction throughout the country is slowing to a standstill as a result of the Army's hold on virtually all supplies of softwood construction lumber, officers of the War Production Board disclosed today.

After two hours of furious oratory yesterday in which virtually every member of the City Council had his say about city finances, the Council adopted the budget -- without changing by as much as one cent the $777,911.70 budget approved by the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Senator Tobey of New Hampshire called today for an investigation of "the motives" for statements recently published about Senator Walsh of Massachusetts, chairman of the Senate Naval Committee.

No loyal American doubts the government's needs for additional taxes to defray the cost of this war for survival. But it occurs to me that some of our lawmakers are seeking to do the impossible -- that is, impossible for many thousands of those who will have to pay.

Replying to James M. Landis, Director of the Office of Civilian Defense, who said on Wednesday that Mayor La Guardia's "irresponsible utterances" were second in wartime only to giving information to the enemy, the Mayor called upon Mr. Landis yesterday for "less chatter, less talk, and more supplies from the Office of Civilian Defense for the American people."

TRENTON, May 21 -- A few minutes after receiving the measure from the Legislature today, Governor Charles Edison signed the much-discussed bill adding $6,600,000 to the $15,000,000 interest waived by the State last year in laws effecting a compromise settlement of the railroad tax controversy dating from 1932.

The House Ways and Means Committee having completed its major decisions on the new tax bill, it is now possible to see what we have to face. It is not an agreeable prospect for any one. The single man with $10 a week and the married couple with $24 a week will, for the first time, pay an income tax.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Total conversion of the liquor distilling industry to production of alcohol for the manufacture of explosives, rubber and other vital materials of war will be effected as rapidly as possible.

MELBOURNE, Friday, May 22 -- United Nations naval forces, presumably submarines, have sunk a Japanese 7,100-ton cruiser and two big supply ships in the Southwest Pacific, General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

It's not much of a place that I've got down in the Village -- one room, bath and a kitchen in the wall. I was sitting in my place one evening, listening to the radio and looking at the door -- an ordinary wooden door with an ordinary lock. And I got to thinking.

BERLIN, May 21 (From German Broadcasts Recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Official German reports said today that 729 Russian tanks had been destroyed in battle on the Southern Front in the last thirteen days, 501 of them in the Kharkov area since May 12 and the others on the Kerch Peninsula.

As a "contribution toward the support of contemporary American art in" this critical war year," the trustees of the Metropolitan Vfuseum of Art have appropriated $52,000 for purchase prizes to be awarded to American' painters, sculptors and graphic artists.

VICHY, France, May 21 -- An interesting development in the internal situation today was the creation of a Bureau of Popular Petitions with the purpose of establishing contacts between the people and the government chiefs, and in this the announcement associated Marshal Petain's name with that of Pierre Laval.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A strong warning against overoptimism concerning the war because of currently good news "about a series of skirmishes" was voiced today by an official who ranks high among those responsible for the war program.

ALBANY, May 21 -- Governor Lehman signed today the Hampton bill rewriting the provisions of the present standard fire insurance policy. He hailed the measure as offering the citizens of the State a more liberal, progressive type of policy. In his message of approval the Governor said:

The contemplated establishment of an over-all requirements committee under the direction of the War Production Board to insure an adequate supply of foods during the war and the "probability" that the body would be headed by Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard were revealed yesterday by Donald M. Nelson, chief of the WPB.

A teacher at New Utrecht High School and his wife, an administrative assistant at William Howard Taft High School, earning $10,188 yearly between them, startled Board of Education officials yesterday by complaining that they did not know what to do with all their money.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Treasury proposed to Congress today collection at the source of 10 per cent of individual incomes, whether these are derived from salaries, wages, interest or dividends. This would be a permanent method of collecting income taxes, not an additional war tax, and would involve refunds or additional payments every March 15 according to whether the amount withheld exceeded total tax liability or was less.

Since the state of affairs in New Caledonia has been publicly referred to, it had better be more fully described. What is the trouble in the South Pacific island now ruled by the Free French and placed under the command of an American general. Major Gen.

A gigantic post-war public housing program, to replace 4,500,000 "tenements, hovels and rural shacks" throughout the nation over a fifteen-year period, was advocated last night by Nathan Straus, former Administrator of the United States Housing Authority.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Agents or subsidiaries of American exporters selling to foreign consumers in Latin America or other foreign countries must abide by the ceiling prices established by OPA's maximum export price regulation under an amendment issued today.

Declaring that public compliance with the new dimout regulations has thus far failed to achieve satisfactory control of the sky glow of the metropolitan area, Major Gen. T.A. Terry, commanding the Second Corps Area, hinted yesterday that new and far more drastic regulations may be issued soon, and enforced by the police.

OTTAWA, May 21 (AP) -- Representatives of fourteen nations attending the Ottawa Air Training Conference appear to be agreed on important phases of the general subject of air-crew training, Air Minister C.G. Power, conference chairman, told the press today.

Five hundred theatre lovers, including Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, sat in straight chairs for two hours yesterday, jogged old-fashioned lunch boxes on their knees and rocked the basement of the Forty-fourth Street Theatre with laughter and applause.

What has come to be known as the Piscator version of "War and Peace" finally has arrived. The Studio Theatre of the New School for Social Research put it on last night down in Twelfth Street after Broadway had toyed with the idea for a year or two and decided against taking a chance.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Because football is, in the words of Lieut. Comdr. Tom Hamilton, the "closest thing to war," the sport will receive a great deal of emphasis in the training of naval and Marine fliers at the four revolutionary pre-flight schools set up by the former Annapolis gridiron star.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President Roosevelt received from Secretary Knox a report on the salvaging of the Normandie and issued a statement clarifying the functions of the State Department and the Board of Economic Warfare in the field of foreign affairs.
Revocation of the charter of a second insurgent local of John L. Lewis's United Mine Workers was threatened yesterday by Lewis aides in this city.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 21 -- About 35,000 men will be mobilized in the Civil Constructional Corps in the next few months, most of them compulsorily, from the 45-to-55 age group, though suitable volunteers will be accepted, it was announced today.

CLEMENTON, N.J., May 21 -George C. Miller, 52 years old, Clementon's only full-time policeman, was shot dead early today outside the home of a woman he had been called upon to protect from a man who had threatened her, and three hours later John P. Lynch, 39, justice of the peace at near-by Stratford, was arrested for the slaying.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President Roosevelt affirmed in unmistakable terms today the supremacy of the State Department over the Board of Economic Warfare in the conduct of foreign policy and negotiations with other nations, and directed the two agencies to work together to aid the war effort of the United Nations on the economic front.

LONDON, May 21 (AP) -- A Free French spokesman said today that the police and natives had clashed briefly at New Caledonia after the departure of Governor Henri Sautot, who is en route to London to report to the Free French Committee.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 21 -- Fifteen Norwegians died today before a German firing squad because they "made an agreement to escape to Great Britain," it is officially reported from Oslo.

City butchers, according to the Consumer's Service Bureau of the Department of Markets, are living up to the letter of the law. Most meats, having declined in cost in the last week, are now selling at March ceiling prices. Lamb, which is exempt from any restriction, is the exception to this downward trend, and all cuts listed by the department are appreciably higher.

Winners of the three literary fellowships of $1,200 each awarded annually by the publishing house of Alfred A. Knopf to assist writers with planned and promising works in history, biography and fiction toward the rounding out of their projects were announced yesterday by Mr. Knopf.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 21 -- A proposal to provide pensions for retired rabbis was made public today by the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Adoption of a rule prohibiting fraud by any person in connection with the purchase of securities was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The Office of Civilian Defense said today that the first gas masks planned for civilians would be of an experimental type, and would be supplied only to members of protective services at first.

Axis and Axis-dominated radios asserted yesterday that United States troops had arrived at Gibraltar, although they differed somewhat on details, according to The Associated Press. There was no confirmation of these reports, all of which were presented as emanating from Algeciras, Spain, near Gibraltar.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- General liquidation developed today in the grain markets and while there was a strong rally at one time, a return of selling pressure came late in the session and prices receded sharply, with oats in the lead. The May delivery of that grain closed off the permissible limit of 5 cents a bushel and the deferred months lost 1 5/8 to 2 1/4 cents.

Rapid action has been taken on the national A.A.U. championships which were returned to Secretary-Treasurer Dan Ferris of the A.A.U. last week by the original sponsors. Yesterday they were awarded again, the decathlon to the Central Association in conjunction with its district championships at Chicago on June 26 and 27, and the three relay title tests to the Pope Pius XII A.A. at Passaic Stadium in conjunction with the invitation meet there on June 22.

William Dean Embree, a former assistant district attorney, was elected president of the New York County Lawyers Association last night at its annual meeting in its building at 14 Vesey Street. Mr. Embree for years has been a member of the law firm of Milbank, Tweed and Hope.

Dr. Edward S. Cowles, operator of the Body and Mind Foundation Inc., a psychiatric clinic at 139 East Sixty-ninth Street, which was raided by Attorney General John J. Bennett a month ago, went on trial yesterday before the State Medical Grievance Committee.

An official nod toward signs of an "early peace" apparently was taken yesterday at full face value by a portion of the investing public, for stocks were bid up 2 points and more in the heaviest trading in two months and a half on the Stock Exchange.

Attempts to get Serge Rubinstein, managing director of the Chosen Corporation, a mining concern, to admit that he had performed the duties of that office in this State made little progress yesterday. Hearings are being held before Supreme Court Referee Richard P. Lydon to determine whether New York courts have jurisdiction over the corporation for the purposes of a $5,900,000 recovery suit against Mr. Rubinstein and others, brought by shareholders.

LONDON, May 21 (U.P.) -- The United Nations are laying the groundwork for an offensive aimed at reconquering the Netherlands Indies and other Japanese-occupied territories, Dr. Hubertus J. van Mook said today following his appointment as Minister of Colonies in a reorganization of the Netherland Government in exile.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Permanent price ceilings at the wholesale level were announced today by Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, for ham, bacon and other pork products in replacement of a temporary 60-day order which expired tonight.

It has often been said that every doctor spends his life trying to work himself out of a job. He tries to prevent illness or injury through education, and through giving appropriate treatment he shortens illness or injury when his patients suffer from either. The sooner they get well the better he likes it.

BOSTON, May 21 -- Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont may assume prominence in a relatively new field, that of supplying mica for expanding war needs, it was revealed here today by the newly organized New England Industrial Research Foundation.

Speeches and ceremonies today will mark National Maritime Day, and there will be stirring words about the great deeds of America's merchant marine in the century since the Savannah set forth to span the Atlantic under steam. There will be proper fanfares in the swarming shipyards from Maine to the Gulf and all up the West Coast, where two new ships a day are being launched to the heart-lifting din of riveters and adzmen.

CHUNGKING, China, May 21 -- While a Chinese military spokesman on Tuesday pointed out that the present Japanese drive in Chekiang aimed to destroy possible springboards for United Nations aerial attacks against Japan, another highly placed military observer points out that it has also the purpose of tightening the coastal blockade to weaken China and open the way for a major offensive.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 21 -- Twelve months after the conclusion of the "first Balkan campaign of the second World War" the Bulgarian people and a certain number of Bulgarian politicians are depicted by a special contributor from Sofia to the Neue Zuericher Zeitung as opposing further encroachments by Germany in the Balkan Peninsula.

A survey of a representative group of grocery manufacurers indicates that 37 per cent has increased 1942 advertising budgets over last year, Taylor Coleman, Penick Ford, Ltd., reported yesterday at the mid-year meeting of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LISBON, Portugal, May 21 -- The leak of a confidential message from Washington to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Vichy Chief of State, making it clear that Pierre Laval was persona non grata hastened the latter's return to office, it is asserted here by qualified observers from France who have joined the diplomatic and newspaper parties awaiting transportation to New York.

Operations of the United Air Lines Transport Corporation in the first three months of this year resulted in net earnings of $143,002, or 9 cents a share on the common stock, in contrast to the net loss of $1,014,272 reported for the comparable quarter last year, according to a statement issued yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (AP) -- Nick Etten and Danny Litwhiler paced the Phils to a 3-2 victory today over Paul Derringer and the Reds. Si Johnson handcuffed Cincinnati with six hits.

With horses spilling or losing riders as things went along, the Spring Maiden Steeplechase was run at Belmont yesterday before the smallest crowd of the meeting, 12,509, as gasoline rationing really began to take its toll. But the betting remained strong, the total being $944,787.

TOKYO, May 21 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded in New York and San Francisco) -- President Roosevelt's announcement that Brig. Gen. James H. Doolittle of the United States Army led the April 18 bombing raid on Japan was "just another trick to switch world attention" from the crushing United Nations naval defeat in the Coral Sea battle the first week of May, Japanese military quarters asserted today.

Straw Hat Season Opens Monday General promotion of straw hats is expected to get under way over the week-end and will officially open Monday, hat manufacturers disclosed yesterday. They pointed out that more effective results are obtained when the opening promotions are governed by climatic conditions rather than a set date which has been the rule in the past.

CHUNGKING, China, May 21 -- The Japanese, apparently intent on knocking China out of the war now or at least seizing forward areas that some day might cradle direct attacks on Japan, have supplemented their broad offensive in Chekiang Province with a landing force near Foochow in Fukien Province, just to the south.

Three and one-half hours after Mrs. William H. Haskell of Bronxville, N.Y., had plunged to her death from the cocktail lounge of the Rainbow Room on the sixty-fifth floor of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center, William Litzrodt, an insurance company instructor employed in the same building, jumped or fell from the thirty-first floor and was killed instantly.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- The market value of sales on all registered exchanges in April amounted to $371,963,673, off 22.2 per cent from March, according to a recapitulation made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The figure also represented a drop of 32.4 per cent from April, 1941.

BOSTON, May 21 -- Declaring that the country's psychiatric resources, its most potent agent for stimulating the will to fight, are being "shockingly unappreciated in spite of the lessons learned from the last World War," the American Psychiatric Association, composed of 3,000 psychiatrists, voted to establish a committee "to present forcefully to the authorities in Washington the need for a greater use of psychiatry in the armed forces and for the maintenance of civilian morale."

ANKARA, Turkey, May 21 -- A revolt of Kurdish tribesmen, Iranian and Azerbaijan, has been virtually crushed by the Red Army and Iranian troops in the troubled areas southeast of Lake Urmia, where the rampaging Kurds raided more than 200 villages and terrorized three provinces, according to advices reaching usually reliable foreign military sources in Ankara tonight.

The only outstanding violator of the coastal dimout in the Broadway sector last night was a large sign on the Criterion Theatre Building on the east side of Broadway between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets. In vari-colored bulbs it glared out an appeal for aid to the Army and Navy Emergency Relief.

LONDON, May 21 (U.P.) -- Ten times George Deckers, 61-year-old Belgium patriot, stood against a wall within an eyelash of death before a German firing squad. And ten times he heard the command, "Lower rifles!" after which he would be taken back to his cell for a grim session with the Nazis trying to wrench from him what he knew about the Belgian underground movement.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- At the request of Senator McNary, the minority leader, the Senate today deferred action on the promotion of Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews to vice admiral until it had an opportunity to study a report by the Senate Naval Affairs Committee on the Normandie disaster.
ST. LOUIS, May 21 (AP) -- Even with the help of six Washington errors and a run-scoring wild pitch, the Browns were futile against Sid Hudson today and lost to the Senators, 5 to 2.
MOSCOW, May 21 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

DETROIT, May 21 (AP) -- The Athletics climbed into the American League's fifth place today by blasting three pitchers for seventeen hits and an 11-to-3 victory over the Tigers that gave them a sweep of the two-game series.

MOSCOW, Friday, May 22 -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's forces are holding their ground against the Axis counter-offensive in the Barvenkova-Izyum sector, while in various other regions of the Kharkov front they have broken clear of the German defense system and, shaking off stubborn and persistent opposition, are continuing to advance in a series of battles of greater mobility.
LONDON, May 21 -- While the British massed forces to defend Calcutta, the Japanese claimed today to have bombed the new Assam Road, supplanting the Burma Road as a supply line to China.

The cotton futures market turned sharply downward yesterday, losing 31 to 36 points. Commission-house liquidation, slackened mill demand and the anticipation of sales soon on the fifth monthly allotment of Commodity Credit Corporation cotton contributed to the decline.

Over the protests of three civic organizations the Board of Estimate approved the service retirement yesterday of Robert L. Moran, Bronx Commissioner of Public Works, who figured in the recent investigation by the Bronx County grand jury of charges that city employes and materials were used to improve the estate of Edward J. Flynn at Lake Mahopac, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The ten-round heavyweight fight between Lou Nova of Alameda, Calif., and Lee Savold of Des Moines, scheduled for Griffith Stadium tonight, was postponed because of the weather. The program, arranged by Promoter Mike Jacobs for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society, will be held tomorrow night.

Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, announced yesterday the completion of work on the Gracie Mansion at Eighty-seventh Street and the East River as a permanent residence for the Mayors of New York as Mayor La Guardia planned to move into the historic building early next week.

More than fifty leaders of American industry, labor and finance attended a dinner held by Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the British War Relief Society, at the Union Club, Park Avenue and Sixty-ninth Street, last night to initiate a campaign of the society to raise $7,500,000 for relief purposes this year.
The enemy's guerre de course, or war of attrition at sea, continued yesterday to take its serious toll.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -Josephine Daniels's clear blue eyes gazed approvingly at Jimmy Doolitte, and she said she would marry him. She did in 1917, a war bride. There followed twenty-five years of high adventure with clouds for a background.

MILWAUKEE, May 21 -- The Rev. Dr. Stuart N. Hutchison of Pittsburgh was elected as Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America today. The election came on the third ballot at the first day's session of the assembly's 154th annual meeting.

Only in New York City could it have happened. Fourteen French boy scouts, most of them over here less than a year, sang a triumphant "La Marseillaise." Portuguese, Italian and Irish children served punch and cookies to 100 visitors.
BOSTON, May 21 (AP) -- The Merry-Ho Stable's Maepeace took command at the top of the stretch at Suffolk Downs today to win the featured Brighton allowance race for 4-year-olds by three lengths.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, expressed to President Roosevelt today his gratification with the "fairness" of the American people as he reported that one-third of the gasoline ration cards issued on the Atlantic Coast had been of the A variety, entitling holders to only three gallons per week.

So far as is generally known, there has been little sabotage in this country since we entered the war, though -- as in the case of the Normandie -- there has been carelessness which was almost as harmful. Perhaps saboteurs are working so subtly that the results have not yet come to light.

Bank clearings this week set a nine-week high and topped the corresponding period of 1941 by 17 1/2 per cent. For the week ended on May 20 clearings in the twenty-four leading cities were $7,532,525,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The Federation of Modern Painters and Sculptors opened its second annual exhibition with a preview yesterday at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. From today until June 10 the assembled paintings and sculpture may be seen by the public.

Although there may be more, at least two biographies of the late Chief Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes are in preparation. One is being done by Mark A. DeWolfe Howe, Dean of the Law School at the University of Buffalo, who edited the "Holmes-Pollock Letters" that were released last year.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- President Roosevelt today personally presented to Admiral Thomas C. Hart, Commander in Chief of the United States Asiatic Fleet, the Gold Star in lieu of a second Distinguished Service Medal and expressed high praise for his "unfailing judgment and sound decision" while he commanded the Allied naval forces in the Southwest Pacific during January and February.

She is the only woman readily admitted to all the prisons of the United States. In the last six weeks she has visited the Federal prison at Leavenworth and the State prison at Lansing, Kan., to say nothing of penal institutions in Virginia, Ohio and Texas. Tomorrow she will be at Sing Sing.

"Pre-Memorial Day" services will be preached tomorrow in preparation for next Saturday, which is Memorial Day. Tribute will be paid to those who have made the supreme sacrifice in this war with heroes of previous wars. Members of the armed forces, military and patriotic societies will attend such services.

Next week Mayor La Guardia will move into the restored Gracie House at Eighty-seventh Street and the East River, henceforth the official residence of our Mayors. No longer will he be a pilgrim of Summer, a transient and a wanderer. It is a goodly house that has been furbished and furnished for him and his successors.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 22 -- While Ray Torgerson and his partner, Wesley Cotterell of the Cherry Valley Club, stood on the sidelines today, more than forty teams attempted to dislodge them as medalists in the Lakeville Club's member-guest golf tournament -- but without success.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Attorney General Biddle said today that the first treason indictment of the war will be sought against Max Stephan of Detroit, who is alleged to have aided Lieutenant Peter Krug when the German air pilot escaped from a Canadian prison camp.

The initial week of retail price ceilings was featured by a somewhat slower pace of retail trade. Department store sales volume was estimated as about even with to 1 per cent higher than in the corresponding week of last year. Specialty shops were smaller than in recent weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Uniforms for the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps will be trim olive drab outfits, closely patterned after the official dress of their brothers in arms but neatly styled for the feminine figure by an expert designer of the Army Quartermaster Corps. The identifying insignia for WAAC members will be a cut-out of the head of Pallas Athene, the Goddess of Victory.

Emmet Everett, 34 years old, faces life imprisonment for stealing an automobile. Everett, a habitual auto thief, was found guilty yesterday by a jury in Bronx County Court on charges of grand larceny and burglary in the third degree.

Thursday's "early peace" theories that stimulated the stock markets then were deflated yesterday by President Roosevelt, and the return to less exaggerated conclusions brought a contraction in trading in shares with a general easing of prices.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 22 -- Simultaneously with a marked multiplication of the contributions of "neutral rumor factories" to the German nerve war, pointing to a forthcoming "probable German offensive" against Turkey from Balkan bases, the Turkish Council of Ministers late this evening after its regular weekly meeting issued the following proclamation to the Turkish people by radio:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 22 -- Gasoline is apt to be found any place these days except at gasoline stations, firemen said today in reporting the discovery of two drums of fifty-five gallons each in a private garage here and a fifty-five-gallon drum and three five-gallon cans in an icebox at Mamaroneck.

The Emergency Revenue Division of the New York City Department of Finance, which has been occupying a part of the former New York Life Insurance Company Building at 346 Broadway into which a portion of the Veterans Administration will be transferred from Washington, beginning today, will move into 350-2 Broadway as the result of a lease for five full floors arranged by the Charles G. Edwards Company.

CLEVELAND, May 22 -- Peace overtures by the American Federation of Labor to the Congress of Industrial Organizations came as a complete surprise tonight to Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O., and to his Associates. So far as they were aware, the A.F.L.'s position with respect to the jurisdictional problems involving rival unions affiliated with the two parent bodies was the same today as in 1939 when peace negotiations were broken off.

The prosecution finished submitting evidence yesterday in the General Sessions murder trial of Madeline Webb, Eli Shonbrun and John D. Cullen. Assistant District Attorney Jacob Grumet had called as his last witness Mrs. Johanna Kordezk, owner of a rooming house at 438 East 147th Street, the Bronx, where Shonbrun and Miss Webb were trapped by detectives last March 10.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, May 23 (AP) -- United Nations bombers crippled two Japanese ships and destroyed seven Japanese planes and badly damaged six others in swift strokes against the enemy's invasion bases at Rabaul, New Britain, and Lae, New Guinea, it was announced officially today.
WELLINGTON, N.Z., May 22 -The government's determination to press war production to the limit is reflected in an order today designed to check industrial absenteeism by the imposition of heavy fines.

MILWAUKEE, May 22 -- Live issues came forward today as the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America got down to business. Noteworthy among them were demands for formal protests against immoral conditions near Army camps, against the sale of liquor to men in the armed services and against the seven-day-a-week schedule in armament factories.

The first official assurance that relief would be granted on an industry-wide basis to "hardship cases" under the recent over-all price ceiling regulation was given yesterday by A.C. Hoffman, price executive of the Food and Food Products Section, Office of Price Administration, principal speaker at the closing sessions of the mid-year meeting of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

TOKYO, May 22 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in San Francisco) -- A Domei [Japanese official news agency] dispatch from a Japanese warship reported today that Japanese marines had landed on Palawan and adjacent islands of the Philippines and had started a "cleanup campaign" against American-Filipino troops.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The rubber situation of the United States is so critical that civilian automobiles may ultimately have to be requisitioned to serve the needs of war workers. This was emphasized today in a statement signed by Donald M. Nelson, chief of the War Production Board; Joseph B. Eastman, Defense Transportation Director; Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, and Arthur B. Newhall, Rubber Coordinator.

ALBANY, May 22 -Governor Lehman approyed today the Republican-sponsored bill creating "a little Byrd 'commission" to investigate State departments and learn where economies could be affected. At the same time he warned against any attempt of the commimsion, which will be. Republican-controlled, to indulge in 'petty politics." ' '

TRENTON, May 22 -- Governor Charles Edison informed the New Jersey Supreme Court today that he would not recognize its authority to interfere with the hearing on removal charges to which he has summoned members of the Hudson County Tax Board.

Price ceilings affecting the cost of food -- now a common subject for conversation -- were yet to be announced in the weeks between the middle of March and the middle of April. Consequently, retail food prices went their own way unrestricted and, proceeding according to recent precedent, rose.

More than 200 oils, water-colors, lithographs, etchings and silkscreen prints, representing 121 artists of all periods from Leonardo da Vinci to Walt Disney, will be employed as part of the treatment of patients in the National Jewish Hospital, Denver, an institution for free care of needy tuberculosis sufferers.

As part of the nation-wide effort to reach the war savings bond sales goal of $600,000,000 set for this month, the F.W. Woolworth Company's chain of stores formally joined the bond campaign with a rally yesterday noon at its leading New York store at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street.

President Roosevelt has again emphasized his opposition to further wage increases as destructive of the national policy of holding down the cost of living. He said yesterday that the Government would do everything it could to prevent "unwarranted" pay increases by private plants, even when the employer was willing and able to grant them.
BOSTON, May 22 (AP) -- Albatross, seemingly enjoying the muddy going, scored a nine and a half length victory today over M. Mac Schwebel's Fritz in the feature race at Suffolk Downs.

Every once in a while somebody quotes "a neutral observer" on some phase or aspect of the war, and no doubt a few citizens of noncombatant countries -- Swedes, Swiss, Spaniards, Turks -- are occasionally to be seen in occupied Europe, may even cross by some long detour the Great Divide between the continent and the British Isles.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The War Production Board today granted the vital chemical war industries further priority assistance in obtaining maintenance and repair materials.
LONDON, May 22 -- There was a great deal of amusement and some masculine snickering when British girls appeared for the first time as conscientious objectors before London tribunals last week.

LONDON, May 22 -- Apart from the new contained in a Chungking communique, which it was stated that a Chinese unit attacked the Japanese at Nawngkio, between Mandalay and Lashio, and inflicted 300 casualties as well as destroying four armored cars, there have been no further details on any contact between the Japanese invaders and the British and Chinese forces in Burma.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 22 -- The Westchester League of Women Voters, in annual convention today at the Hotel Gramatan here, adopted a resolution calling for "adequate public hearings in advance of all proposed changes in the county charter." The move was aimed against the practice by the Board of Supervisors of asking the Legislature for major revisions in the charter without first conducting public hearings.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Steps on the stabilization of wartime wages were disclosed today which made clear that President Roosevelt was carrying forward his policy of raising substandard pay and of leveling off -- with some increases but lower maximum standards -- those wages which fall in the higher brackets.
