It has been a long time since we have witnessed an invasion of our shores by foreign athletes. The days of intercontinental sports competition have been almost obliterated by the war. Yet we haven't done a bad job of maintaining a healthy interest in sports.

OTTAWA, May 22 -- Having in four days "got down to brass tacks and accomplished a great deal," according to Major Gen. Barton K. Yount of the United States delegation, the United Nations Air Training Conference, which opened here on Tuesday, completed its work today and adjourned.

LONDON, May 22 -- The markets continued cheerful today, with prices in most sections going ahead. Public business was small, the movement being mainly professional, due to evening up before the Whitmonday holiday.
Institutional sales of residential realty in White Plains, Scarsdale and Mount Vernon featured transactions reported yesterday by brokers.

Prince George Chavchavadze, concert pianist formerly of Southern France and Bernardsville, N.J., and his wife, the former Elizabeth Ridgway of Philadelphia, have rented an apartment of nine rooms in River House, at 435 East Fifty-second Street, in a deal negotiated by Van Rensselaer Realty, Inc., for Gordon S. Braislin, Inc., managing agent.
NEWARK, N.J., May 22 (AP) -- The Bears, cashing in on five errors, registered a 6-4 victory over Syracuse tonight in an odd game.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The government took the first step today toward rationing seats on railroads and bus lines. The Office of Defense Transportation began a week's check-up on travel originating at 100 key centers throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- The War Production Board prohibited today the sale and delivery of all safety razors now in the hands of manufacturers and jobbers, and ordered them made available to the armed services.

MOSCOW, Saturday, May 23 -- German progress in the Izyum-Barvenkova sector south of Kharkov, after some initial success, has been checked with heavy Axis losses. In three days 15,000 Germans were killed in that sector alone, one division having beaten off eleven German attacks, routing 3,000 men, according to the midnight Soviet communique.

President Manuel Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth arrived here by train from Washington last night and rode in a taxicab to the Hotel Ambassador, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, while the hotel's manager with a private car and a police escort waited at Pennsylvania Station until all three sections of the Congressional Limited had pulled in before learning that they had missed their man in the crowd.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- President Roosevelt issued this statement tonight in connection with the observance of Maritime Day:
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Yankees are billeted tonight on the banks of the Potomac, awaiting the call to their first game of the campaign in the interests of the nations armed forces.

Spurred by President Roosevelt's prediction of a long war, trade buying, which had been absent from the cotton market while rumors of an early peace were rampant recently, returned yesterday and lifted cotton prices 11 to 15 points on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The City Club of New York celebrated its fiftieth birthday last night in its building at 55 West Forty-fourth Street and marked the occasion by awarding its scroll of merit for outstanding public service to John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Although wheat fluctuated in an erratic manner today, there was evidence that liquidation had about run its course. An early dip was followed by a strong rally, prices moving up around 1 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish, only to break around 1 1/2 cents from the early top on a resumption of liquidation and then firm again toward the close.

PATERSON, N.J., May 22 -- Four former Aldermen of Paterson were sentenced to county jail terms and fined today by Judge Robert H. Davidson of Quarter Sessions Court before whom they had been convicted on May 12 or charges of accepting bribes for agreeing to enact, amend and enforce certain municipal ordinances for the benefit of junk yard operators.
Among the Mail-Bag Excerpts in the May 17 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES appeared an interesting paper-saving plan submitted by O.K. Sherwin.

Some of the Treasury economists are reported to favor, as an alternative to the rationing of commodities, a system of rationing the amount of money that individuals may spend for consumer goods and travel. The idea may never get beyond the happy-thought stage, but it's worth looking at.

Two gasoline hoarders, the first brought to court in Manhattan, entered guilty pleas yesterday in the Municipal Term Magistrates Court. Mrs. Clarinne Reavis of 1 Sutton Place, wife of C. Frank Reavis, a lawyer at 70 Pine Street, paid a $100 fine to escape serving a thirty-day workhouse term.

The capital assets of American eleemosynary foundations now exceed $1,400,000,000, according to a survey of 314 leading foundations and family trusts conducted by Raymond Rich Associates of New York. This is an extension of similar surveys comprising 243 foundations published by the firm in 1939 and earlier editions issued by the Twentieth Century Fund.

President Roosevelt paid tribute yesterday to the nation's merchant marine and shipbuilding industry as National Maritime Day was marked by the launching of 270,000 tons of merchant vessels, the greatest mass launching since 1918.

New film offerings will be presented in three theatres this morning. "Ships With Wings," a British-made picture released here through United Artists, will be the new attraction at the Rivoli. John Clements, Leslie Banks, Jane Baxter, Ann Todd and Basil Sydney head the cast of the film, which was produced by Michael Balcon and deals with the British Fleet's air arm.

Today's events: American Recorder Society's Spring Festival, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2:30 P.M.; Victory concert for service men, New York Public Library, 5; concert by Musicians Group of Friendship House, Hotel Sherman, 9; Julia Edna Parker's annual poetry recital and musicale, Philosophy Hall, Columbia University, 8:15.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- In the first week during which wholesale markets were governed by the Office of Price Administration, the average level of wholesale prices showed little change. The Bureau of Labor Statistics's comprehensive index of wholesale prices for the week ended on May 16 stood at 98.5 per cent of its 1926 average.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (U.P.) -- A confidential report prepared for the Senate Naval Affairs Committee asserts that "unreasonable time limitations" which were "dictated in Washington" and placed upon the contractor converting the French liner Normandie into the troopship Lafayette may have been responsible for the fire on the ship in New York Feb. 9.

The emotion called fear is a natural one. For obvious reasons it is especially so in wartime. What is fear? The following is a definition: "Fear is an emotion excited by threatening evil or impending pain, accompanied by a desire to escape them; apprehension; dread." Fear, it must be remembered, is thus a protective emotion.

ALBANY, May 22 (AP) -- Matteo A. De Simone, Sing Sing prison guard, told Governor Lehman today that Joseph "Whitey" Riordan, one of two condemned for murder in a bloody prison escape last year, saved him and a convict from death at the height of the break.

CHUNGKING, China, Saturday, May 23 -- Chinese troops have annihilated more than half of a seaborne Japanese invasion force that landed on Chuanshih Island, at the mouth of the Min River east of Foochow on the Fukien coast, and the rest of the enemy has been driven back to their ships, the Chinese announced today.

KUMMING, China, May 22 (U.P.) -- Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, commander of China's American Volunteer Group, predicted today that the United States would unleash an air offensive against the Japanese in six months. He said that 2,000 United States planes could "wipe out" the Japanese air force.

Two of the largest and best known firms in Wall Street, Paine, Webber Co. and Jackson Curtis, will merge on or about July 1 as Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, it was announced yesterday. Both firms were established in Boston, the former in 1880, the latter in 1879.

BOONTON, N.J., May 22 -- Continuing to team well, Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont and Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches added an 81 to their first-round 77 for a total of 158 to win the Spring two-ball, best-ball tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association over the beautifully groomed Knoll Country Club course today.

Collaboration between pottery workers at Greenwich House and members of classes in flower arrangement resulted this week in an attractive feature of the fortieth anniversary celebration at the settlement house at 27 Barrow Street. Delegates from the two departments merged their efforts in a flower arrangement exhibit.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission gave out this list of the ships launched today and the yards where they were built:
SAN FRANCISCO, May 22 -- West Coast shipyards launched nine cargo ships between dawn and sunset today, delivered three others and laid eight keels as their contribution to Martime Day.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 22 (AP) -- Employment and payrolls in the construction industry in New York State increased 10 and 8.8 per cent, respectively, in April despite the pinch of material shortages.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on May 16 totaled 254,202,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, United States Department of the Interior. This represented a decrease of 983,000 barrels in the week, comprising decreases of 921,000 and 62,000 in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.

LONDON, May 22 -- A federation consisting of India, China, Iran and Afghanistan was proposed today by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, left-wing leader of the All-India Congress party, in a speech made in Lahore, as reported here. Except for Afghanistan, the coalition already has been achieved militarily.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- President Roosevelt today authorized the creation of a National Railway Labor Panel of nine members from which emergency fact-finding boards will be chosen to adjust disputes between railways and airlines and their employes before disputes have reached the stage of a vote to strike.
MOSCOW, Saturday, May 23 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique said:

Means to meet the rising tide of passenger traffic are to be discussed by railroad presidents from all parts of the country in Chicago next Friday, it was disclosed here yesterday. The Office of Defense Transport will be represented, probably by V.V. Boatner, a member of the staff.
CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox opened their night season by pounding out fifteen hits to defeat the Detroit Tigers, 7 to 4, tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The War and Navy Departments renewed their fight today against a provision of the readjusted pay bill, now in conference between Senate and House managers, which would require detailed reporting to the Congress on the qualifications of each civilian receiving a "quickie" commission.

A.E.F. HEADQUARTERS, Northern Ireland, May 22 (AP) -- United States troops in training here were told today by General Sir Alan Brooke, chief of the British Imperial General Staff, that their chance to fight "no doubt will come soon."
Baseball had its crystal ball working the last few months in the matter of transportation, so the minor leagues were ready for the latest ban on chartered bus travel for the most part.

Thomas Walsh, national commander of the Catholic War Veterans, expressed indignation yesterday at the reasons given by President Roosevelt for the freeing of Earl Browder, Communist leader, from Atlanta Penitentiary.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Federal Security Agency, the Office of Civilian Defense and the American Red Cross have agreed upon plans to assist civilian victims of enemy action in case of bombing, President Roosevelt started at his press conference today.

LISBON, Portugal, May 22 (AP) -- The Swedish-American liner Drottningholm sailed tonight with a cheerful group of North and South American diplomats, newspaper correspondents and other civilians. The ship, which arrived here a week ago with Axis diplomats and nationals, carried 875 passengers on the return trip to the United States.

The Kenteis Corporation is the buyer of the sixteen-story store and loft building at 101 East Twentieth Street and 251-55 Fourth Avenue, sold recently by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank through Omnia Properties, Inc. The terms were cash over a purchase money mortgage of $315,000.

AUCKLAND, N.Z., May 22 (U.P.) -- The arrival of Vice Admiral Robert Lee Ghormley of the United States Navy to command the United States-New Zealand naval forces spurred New Zealand today to gear up her preparations to help blast the Japanese out of the Southwest Pacific.

Robert E. Woodruff, president of the Erie Railroad, said yesterday the road's operating revenues in the first fifteen days of May were estimated at $5,652,005, an increase of 33.9 per cent, compared with a year ago. Tax accruals for April were $1,676,289, or $1,005,157 more than in April, 1941.

TOKYO, May 22 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in New York) -- That Japanese and Japanese-American citizens in the United States were lynched or subjected to "indescribable humiliation and shocking treatment" after "the outbreak" of war on Dec. 7 was reported in the newspaper Asahi today.

A fair volume of new security issues is shaping up for offering in the near future. According to the present schedule of underwriters, the $12,000,000 debenture issue of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., should reach the market on Monday. Bearing interest at 2 1/2 per cent and maturing in ten years, the debentures will be priced at par, it was reported yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. L. Wendell Fifield, who has preached from the historic pulpit of the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims at Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, since he came to the church last Oct. 1, was formally installed as pastor last night.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Continued advances in armament production in April and the first half of May were reported today by the Federal Reserve Board.

LONDON, May 22 -- The 10,000-ton German cruiser, Prinz Eugen, which was damaged a few days ago by British torpedo-carrying planes, has arrived at the naval base at Kiel, it was said today by London official circles who also revealed the location of other Nazi warships.

Recently at Belmont a horse broke down during the running of a race. This horse, the public choice, was well-taped and looked poorly, as was noticed by a few improvers of the breed, especially when there was a last-minute play on another horse.

Net sales billed by the American Car and Foundry Company in the year ended on April 30 exceeded $215,000,000, with a carry-over of orders amounting to more than $400,000,000, Charles J. Hardy, president, said yesterday in the notice of the annual meeting to be held in Jersey City on July 9. Mr. Hardy said that this was by far the largest volume of business in the company's history.

An elaborate program of music of the Americas was presented last night in New York Times Hall for the benefit of the Spanish-American Association for the Blind, an organization with headquarters in this city, which aims to arouse interest in the education and care of the blind in all Spanish-speaking countries.

OMAHA, May 22 (AP) -- The Consumers Public Power District of Columbus, Neb., announced today that it had made a formal offer of $40,680,000 to the American Power and Light Company of New York for the Nebraska Power Company of Omaha -- the State's largest privately owned public utility and the last major power concern in Nebraska not under the district's supervision.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- President Roosevelt ordered today the registration on June 30 of every male resident of the United States, Alaska, Hawaii and Puerto Rico who will attain the age of 18 or 19 before June 30, or who has become 20 years old since Dec. 31, 1941.

Public education about cancer has been so effective that the percentage of operable cases of cancer of the breast, among all such cases that reach hospitals in the United States, is now two and one-half times as large as it was years ago, it was reported yesterday at a meeting sponsored by the American Society for the Control of Cancer in the Museum of Modern Art.

In its long history the Children's Aid Society has lived through three wars, and from each of them it has accumulated experience valuable in the present emergency. The society's annual report, with a foreword by William Church Osborn, discusses significant changes which child life is undergoing and the means taken to insure its normal development through a difficult period.
A definite trend has set in toward an intensification rather than a curtailment of college athletics as a contribution toward the war effort.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (U.P.) -- Representative Martin J. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, today asked Governor Lehman to "take official notice of the impasse" existing between Civilian Defense Director Landis and Mayor La Guardia.
Park Tilford, Inc., reported yesterday for the first three months of 1942 estimated consolidated net profit of $204,478 after providing $393,461 for Federal income and excess profits taxes.

Considerable confusion was evident in retail circles here yesterday regarding the actual working out of the proposed War Production Board order limiting retail and wholesale inventories to the 1940 level.

Frank Ciaffone allowed three hits and fanned fifteen as Abraham Lincoln High captured the Brooklyn P.S.A.L. baseball title yesterday by blanking Brooklyn Tech, 3 to 0, at Boy's High Field. It was the seventh loop success in eight starts for Lincoln and it was Ciaffone's fifth shut-out triumph of the campaign.

BERLIN, May 22 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in London and New York) -- A German broadcast in the Russian language said tonight that "even if the Russians succeed at immense cost in taking Kharkov it will neither represent an important break-through nor endanger the German positions nor deprive the Germans of important bases and lines of communication."

The President's wife has set an example for all users of automobiles who have access to more gasoline than an "A" card provides. She is by nature and the range of her interests an active woman who has been constantly going places; now she has carefully examined her conscience and emerged with a code on what her use of the automobile and other war-affected modes of travel shall be.

Two sentences to Sing Sing of three and one-half to seven years each, to run concurrently, were imposed yesterday in General Sessions on Joseph F. Colbert, 40 years old, of Madison, N.J., former chief clerk of the advertising department of the Tidewater Associated Oil Company, Inc., at 17 Battery Place, and George D. Murphy, 43, president of the defunct Phillips Van Brunt Printing Company, formerly at 121 Varick Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 22 -- Paramount and Warner Brothers today closed a deal for an exchange of players whereby Ann Sheridan will star in the former studio's "Texas Guinan" and Fred MacMurray will go to Warners for "Princess O'Rourke," with Loretta Young.

Mayor La Guardia, surrounded by a group of aides, watched the blackout last night from the top of the Municipal Building and, when the period of darkness was over, had words of reproach only for the Board of Transportation.

Mayor La Guardia praised the members of the National Maritime Union at City Hall yesterday as he presented thirteen medals for heroism and 112 silver pins to merchant seamen who had been on torpedoed vessels.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Four-fifths of the jobs in America's key war industries can be done by women, it was reported today by Paul V. McNutt, War Man Power Commissioner.

"Never was informative advertising needed so much as right l now," according to Wilford L. White, head of the regional research unit of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, writing in this week's departmental organ Domestic Commerce.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor appealed today to the Congress of Industrial Organization to resume peace talks immediately with the object of effecting a united labor movement, which, it was declared, would help win the war and advance the economic interests of American workers.

Housewives of brick-and-mortar Manhattan have just had a taste of what was common experience for American wives and mothers in Daniel Boone's time and earlier. Going about their household work with open radios last Tuesday, the women were immediately aware of that 19-minute practice alert when the broadcasters went off the air.

VICHY, May 22 -- Germany has offered to free 70,000 to 80,000 French war prisoners and make other concessions if General Henri Honore Giraud will go back to the Nazi prison from which he escaped and be immediately released, but he demanded instead the freedom of 500,000 prisoners, it was learned tonight.

DERBY, Conn., May 22 -- The oldest intercollegiate sporting event in the nation will be renewed tomorrow afternoon when the Yale and Harvard crews hold their eightieth regatta in a series that began in 1852. Cut down from four to two miles, moved from the highly important Navy harbor of New London to Yale's Housatonic course, the regatta is stripped of most of its fanfare and color.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by twenty-five municipalities aggregates $7,497,084, compared with the revised total of $53,320,000 for this week, the latter including the sale on Monday of $50,000,000 of New York State revenue notes. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at 826,721,776.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 22 -- Police authorities were active throughout today investigating the discovery of bombs, hand grenades and packages of dynamite hidden in the homes of leaders of the Chilean Nazi party, which has been rechristened the Popular Socialist Vanguard.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 22 -- Major Gen. Francis B. Wilby, superintendent of the Military Academy, stated today that James H. Hottenroth of 2728 Henry Hudson Parkway, New York City, was the No. 1 cadet of the class which will graduate from West Point next Friday.

AUGUSTA, Me., May 22 (AP) -- Maine's civilian defense director, Francis. H. Farnum, said today that he had reported in a signed statement to civilian defense agencies that Army authorities and police had "accurate information" that German spies recently had "been landed on the coast of Maine."

CLEVELAND, May 22 -- Philip Murray, head of the Congress of Industrial Organization, was unanimously elected today as the first president of the United Steel Workers of America after a tumultuous twenty-minute demonstration by 1,700 convention delegates.

Thomas E. Dewey, leader of the Republican party in New York State and probable nominee for Governor in the Fall elections, threw the full weight of his position last night against Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. in his attempt to win the Republican nomination in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Intervention by President Roosevelt failed today to settle the longstanding dispute over construction of a gasoline pipeline to supply the Eastern States. A White House conference resulted in the decision that the government should go ahead with construction of gasoline-carrying wooden barges, leaving the pipeline question undetermined for the moment, it was reported.

When the revival of Shaw's "Candida" ends its successful run here on May 31 the play will be given for an additional week at the National Theatre in Washington, D.C., it was announced yesterday. The engagement at the capital will open the next evening, June 1.

Are Larry MacPhail and the Brooklyn Baseball Club so politically powerful as to persuade a draft board to reclassify a draftee from Class 1-A to Class 3-A? Don't they realize that our country is at war for the preservation of our rights and freedom and that we need all the man power available, both for active and non-combat service?

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (AP) -- The Braves put on a four-run rally in the ninth inning tonight to beat the Phils, 10 to 7, in a see-saw game at Shibe Park. A single by Clyde Kluttz with the bases full and the score 7 -- 7 was the deciding blow of the rally.

The Appellate Division rebuked Surrogate James A. Delehanty yesterday by taking out of his hands a will case in which the higher court said the Surrogate had three times failed to comply with instructions to reopen the case.

For twenty minutes last night Manhattan Island huddled in primitive darkness, much as Hendrik Hudson must have seen it 333 years ago. From 9:30 to 9:50 P.M., in the last of the borough blackout drills, the island was a city of wraiths moving through the dark.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Congressional leaders have under consideration a proposal that a bipartisan group of ten Senators and Representatives be chosen to confer in Great Britain with Parliament members on the conduct of the war and plans for the subsequent peace.

The Grand Duchess Charlotte of Luxembourg, accompanied by her consort, Prince Felix, and her Minister of Foreign Affairs, Joseph Bech, arrived in New York yesterday by transatlantic clipper to visit President Roosevelt in Washington tomorrow and to rejoin the Luxembourg Government-in-Exile and her children in Montreal for an indefinite stay.

A scheme to get extra gasoline rations that proved a little too clever was tried yesterday at Manhattan rationing headquarters, 1450 Broadway, and promptly backfired, Joseph Kraeler, Deputy Rationing Administrator, disclosed.

"It is a fact that American aircraft production is nearly twice that of Germany," Glenn L. Martin declared yesterday at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria, "and all this before the automobile companies have begun to roll out airplanes."

The Hudson County Deputy Game Wardens Association is sponsoring a sports show at Sportsmen's Park, North Bergen, N.J., which will open Wednesday and continue on through June 6. In calling attention to this exhibit Commissioner Harry M. Armstrong recalls that President Roosevelt has said "those of us left at home should not let down for a minute on our work of conservation."

Louis Gingold has sold to H. Weinstein, an investor, through the Lewis H. May Company, broker, the property at 1410 Sheridan Boulevard, Far Rockaway, Queens, consisting of a three-family dwelling and an adjoining one-family dwelling on a plot 175 by 110 feet.

Brother Albert Paul of the Department of Classical Languages of Manhattan College announced yesterday the winners of prizes offered by the Catholic Classical Association of New York City. First prizes went to Peter M. Curran of Xavier High School for excellence in Cicero, and to John Long of Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School, Brooklyn, for excellence in Virgil.

IT was over a cup of coffee that Secretary Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick of the Giants dropped a few remarks on the situation in the National League. Strangely enough, he didn't start on the Dodgers and he wasn't swinging for the fences. He rolled out each remark carefully, as though he were bunting down the third-base line.

MEXICO CITY, May 22 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho tonight called for a special session of Congress to declare the existence of a state of war with the Axis. The decision was announced at 10:45 after a session of the Cabinet with the Chief of Staff and leading generals. No time for the meeting of Congress was fixed, but it will be convoked by the Permanent Committee of the two houses.
BERLIN, May 22 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

A small, blue pool symbolizing the Pacific that stretches between Australia and New Zealand reflected the massed colors of the United Nations yesterday afternoon as taps was played in memory of the Anzacs who died in the last war. The ceremony set the serious keynote of a program that officially opened for the season the Anzac Garden atop the British Empire Building at 620 Fifth Avenue.

The Appellate Division, in a unanimous ruling yesterday, granted to opponents of the voting trustees of the Wickwire Spencer Steel Company the right to inspect the list of all voting trust certificate holders and to call a meeting of certificate holders to consider proposals made by the opposition.

The work of the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice is described in its sixty-eighth yearbook, released yesterday, as more necessary during these war years." John S. Sumner, executive secretary, explaining why, had this to say:
So there won't be any yachting after "we get our new order established." Maybe not, if our entire coastline is evacuated and we dry up all our inland lakes, ponds, rivers and creeks.

As one who derives quite a goodly proportion of his living from sales to resort hotels along the New Jersey coast, from Sea Bright to Cape May, I am prompted to write this lettter, in justice to business men along the coast.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

A group of former Western cowpunchers, their patience already tried by talk of "bicycles, foot-runners and roller-skates" as emergency means of transportation, bitterly protested last night a ban by Army officials on the use of horses in "The New York at War" parade on June 13.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, May 22 -- On behalf of President Roosevelt, Rear Admiral David W. Bagley, commandant of the Fourteenth Naval District, presented the Navy Cross here today to Commander Anthony Leo Danis for successfully bringing to port the U.S.S. Kearny after she had been torpedoed by an Axis submarine last Oct. 17.

The Navy announced yesterday the sinking of three more vessels by Axis submarines in the Gulf of Mexico or Atlantic coastal waters. One was a Mexican tanker, attacked in the Gulf, the loss of which was believed to have moved Mexico closer to war with the Axis.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Added protection of service men against actions on obligations contracted in civil life are provided in a bill on which the House Military Affairs Committee began hearings today.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Formation of the Southeast Pacific Command of the United States Navy became known here today with official verification of a report that Rear Admiral J.F. Shafroth Jr. had been assigned as commander of that section of the Pacific Fleet.

The volume of new bonds offered to the public here this week dropped to $4,439,000, the smallest total since the period ended on April 17, when $4,040,000 in new issues was marketed. Last week $15,698,000 in bonds was offered here, and a year ago this week, $23,808,000 was marketed.

HOLLYWOOD, May 22 (U.P.) -- The condition of John Barrymore remained serious today, although physicians reported the stage and screen actor passed a satisfactory day. A bulletin issued by Dr. Hugo M. Kerstsn reported:

CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- A Criminal Court jury convicted Clarence McDonald, 17, today and fixed his punishment at life imprisonment for the movie theatre slaying of his high school sweetheart, Dorothy Broz, also 17.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Raymond H. Geist, chief of the State Department's Division of Commercial Affairs, accused the German people today of responsibility for "the moral collapse" of their nation and predicted that "to lay the foundations for the advent of freedom among them would be a long and arduous task."

PRINCETON, N.J., May 22 -- If this year's income tax bill were written by civic and community leaders throughout the country, many millions of families who have not heretofore had to pay an income tax would start paying one.

A club for service men will be formally opened in the parish house of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, next Friday evening. Members and friends of the congregation will inspect the club quarters on Wednesday following the weekly prayer service.

MOSCOW, May 22 -- Declining efficiency, growing distrust of Reichsfuehrer Hitler and collapse of morale in the German Army's officers' corps as a result of defeats in Soviet Russia and Herr Hitler's Winter purge are said by Colonel Tolchenoff in the Army newspaper Red Star to characterize the German Army today.

A stem new campaign to enforce compliance with the Selective Service Laws was revealed yesterday by United States attorneys in Brooklyn and Manhattan and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. In emphasizing his determination to deal severely with willful offenders, United States Attorney Harold M. Kennedy in Brooklyn called for a law that would deprive of their citizenship all who shirk their military duty -- including native Americans.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 22 -- Cleveland, with its vast resources of trained mechanics, and its manufacturers have hit upon a workable plan to prevent the crippling of their plants by indiscriminate drafting of too great a percentage of irreplaceable skilled workers.

The volume of engineering contract awards continues heavy, with a figure of $216,513,000 for the current week. The Engineering News-Record points out that this is the eighth time this year that the $200,000,000 mark has been exceeded.
Turning on their arch tormentors with a cold fury that must have startled the ladies' day crowd of 18,399, the Giants yesterday made a few things snap at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- General Motors Corporation and two affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, representing 230,000 corporation employes, agreed today on a new overtime pay system which ends the practice of premium payments for Saturday, Sunday and holiday work as such.

In a wild battle that showed each fighter willing to take a punch in order to give one at any time, Bob Pastor and Tami Mauriello. New York heavyweight contenders, fought to a ten-round draw at Madison Square Garden last night.

Ten, including Alsab, have been named for this afternoon's running of the historic Withers mile test, which is expected to gross above $20,000 if all go to the post. The top crowd for New York racing this year is expected to turn out despite gasoline rationing and it surprise none of the officials if as many as 40,000 crowd Belmont Park.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 22 -Closing its forty-eighth annual convention in the Hotel Traymore here today, the Pennsylvania Bankers Association went on record protesting as "inequitable and unjust in operation" proposals by the United States Treasury Department for changes in the capital gains and losses provisions of the Federal income tax law.

Two weeks ago a group of American Eagles assembled in a canteen somewhere in England and in the lulls between bursts of music and singing a recording of messages from the fliers to their families in the United States was made by the British Broadcasting Corporation.
CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- American chemists were accused today of "mental slothfulness" for not having developed rubber from native plants.

BOSTON, May 22 -- Ted Williams, slugging outfielder of the Red Sox, enlisted in the Navy today in the hope of becoming a flier, but there appeared some chance that he would not be called before the end of the baseball season.

Dominick Accobacco, 34 years old, of 517 Titan Street, and James Cummings, 42, of 4049 Chestnut Street, both Philadelphia, were brought here as prisoners last night by detectives of the pickpocket squad for trial on charges of receiving stolen goods.

A "small amount" of business in women's Fall merchandise, particularly coats, is being booked currently at "tentative" prices, but both production and selling operations for the most part continue at a standstill, pending the issuance of the long-awaited supplementary seasonal order by the Office of Price Administration, it was reported here yesterday.

ROME, May 22 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press in New York) -- The Italian High Command said in a special communique today that its submarine Barbarigo sank a United States battleship of the Maryland class with two torpedo hits off the Brazilian coast Wednesday.
ROME, May 22 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

From a visit to London in the Summer of 1937 this writer recalls a small episode in Trafalgar Square more vividly than many scenes rated as more important. Its significance has increased with the portentous historic events through which that city has passed in the intervening five years.
CHUNGKING, China, May 22 (AP) -- The Chinese Command issued this communique tonight:

AKRON, Ohio, May 22 (AP) -- The Beacon Journal says it knows why Mayor La Guardia has not received the 22,100 civilian steel helmets he ordered early this year -- they were made so small they would be just the thing for "a civilian defense force of midgets."

A committee including former Governor Alfred E. Smith, Thomas D. Thacher and C.C. Burlingham yesterday announced plans for national observance on June 22 of the first anniversary of Hitler's invasion of Russia as "a day of tribute to the courage of the Russian Army and people, and as a special occasion for mobilizing new aid for those people."

LONDON, May 22 (U.P.) -- Heavily armed Greek guerrillas, striking 15,000 strong from strongholds in the Rhodope Mountains, have disrupted a German-controlled railroad leading from Greece toward the Russian front and have killed, wounded or captured 225 Germans in attacks on two troop trains, the Greek Government-in-exile announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The taxation of capital gains and losses was revised today by the Ways and Means Committee, which agreed to accept a recommendation of experts of the Treasury and the Joint Committee on Internal Revenue taxation.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, May 23 -- The arrival here of Vice Admiral Robert L. Ghormley to take over the South Pacific command is seen here today as another knot in the net that the United States is casting around Japan so as to transform her early gains into liabilities.

It's likely to turn out a very good thing that we can't get into automobiles this Summer and stream over hot roads in search of a grassy place for a picnic that would turn out to be buggy, or too close to a highway, or highly uncomfortable anyhow.

ALBANY, May 23 -- Governor Lehman today marked the Bronx paving-block controversy involving National Democratic Chairman Edward J. Flynn closed so far as he is concerned. For the third time he rejected a plea by the citizens' group headed by Professor Herman A. Gray of New York University that he reopen the case investigated by the Bronx County grand jury, which failed to indict any one.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, May 24 -- After fifteen days of stubborn resistance against overwhelming odds, Russian troops have withdrawn from their remaining positions on the Kerch Peninsula, it was announced in the midnight Soviet communique, received here early today.

"THE BOOK OF ARIEL" is completely and exclusively a love story, an affaire de coeur after the traditional French pattern. It is written in the first person by the lover (called Stanton Kennedy in the book) and is anonymous -- just to prove, as the blurb says, that "There was an Ariel."

HARD on the heels of the General Maximum Price Regulation under which retail price ceilings became effective last week following the May 11 ceiling for manufacturers and wholesalers, came the announcement that the War Production Board would soon impose a ceiling on inventories.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 23 -- New conditions and problems faced today by the United States will receive a unified and critical treatment in a program of daily lectures opening June 8 at the University of Cincinnati, Dr. L.A. Pechstein, dean of the Teachers College, announced today.
CHUNGKING, China, May 23 (Reuter) -- Today's Chinese comttniqtd said:

Small buying by the cotton trade and New Orleans operators combined yesterday to keep prices of cotton moving within a narrow range near Friday's closing levels. Active months on the New York Cotton Exchange had final net gains of 1 to 3 points after a quiet session.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Pruning out the dead blooms of lilacs as soon as the flowers fade, and an application of plant food worked into the soil over the roots, will benefit next year's flowering. . . . Flea beetles (tiny, hard-shelled, black "hoppers") are already attacking potatoes and tomatoes, peppering the foliage with tiny holes. Dust or spray at once, as they do serious damage.

CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- Baseball's advisory council -- Commissioner K.M. Landis and Presidents Will Harridge of the American League and Ford Frick of the National League -- came face to face today with two new major difficulties tossed up by the war.

Along a land front in Eastern Asia -- some 1,500 miles in length, comparable in its sweep to the Russian battleground -- soldiers of Japan and China were manoeuvring and fighting last week. The Mikado's generals were taking up the initiative again in the "incident" begun at Peiping's Marco Polo Bridge almost five years ago.

The Treasury's consideration of rationed spending, as reported in your columns on May 19, is both timely and welcome. As scarcities are extending to ever-growing numbers of civilian goods and the purchasing power competing for them increases, a method of rationing this variety of articles will have to be devised.

WES TRAYNOR had ridden a long way from Texas on the trail of the escaped convict who had murdered his father. It was away up near Fargo that he hired out to Major Jefferson Calhoun, biggest cattleman in Calhoun County, to track down rustlers who were stealing the major's cattle.

The American liberal arts college, large or small, has been passing through a severe case of jitters. At a time when our way of life was being pared of non-essentials, was the non-technical education to survive? Could the continuance of cultural courses not directly linked with the immediate war effort be justified to the parents, the taxpayers, and the government?

IF Hal Steed were old and retired, he says, there's a point on a plantation near Darien by the Georgia coast where he would go and spend the rest of his days "in contemplating the marshes, the long shadows cast upon them by the live oaks, and the distant wooded islands."

All is ominously quiet on the northeastern dairy front this bountiful May, but the determined forces of John L. Lewis and those of equally determined farmers opposed to the unionization of agriculture seethe beneath the surface.

In the "About" column of May 3 I said, facetiously, that Junior could tame an incendiary bomb by putting salt on its tail. Lest this lead to further confusion, I should like to amplify the serious comment also included in that paragraph: "It (salt) has been found more effective than sand for squelching fire bombs."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 23 (AP) -- St. Michael's High School of Jersey City, defending champion, tallied 53 points to win the senior New Jersey Catholic high schools track championships today at Lincoln Park.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 23 -- According to the newspaper Nacion today the discovery of numerous deposits of arms, explosives, teargas bombs and hand grenades in different sections of the city has revealed the existence of a plan "for a vast campaign of sabotage against all national activities with the idea of avoiding the breaking of relations between Chile and the totalitarian powers."

A star-studded field of 116 professionals are now assembled at the Seaview Country Club, Abse con, N.J., awaiting the start of the twenty-fifth P.G.A. championship which will be the year's only major golfing event now that all U.S.G.A. championships have been called off.

A collection of American art which has been developing gradually for four decades in New Britain, Conn., without much recognition elsewhere, recently has been enlarged by thirty oil paintings, water-colors and prints.

At this time of year the native woodlands of the vicinity bring to mind the breathtaking loveliness of Mountain Laurel (Kalmia latifola) in bloom. Massed in large formations of growth, the laurel, with its pink and white flower clusters, showy against shiny dark evergreen leaves, is one of nature's most spectacular displays.

MEXICO CITY, May 23 (AP) -General Salvador S. Sanchez, head of the General Staff, said today[ that "all measures have been taken" by the army to meet a war crisis, and in other fields measures have been taken or are planned to put the nation on a full war footLug.
With torpedoes and shellfire Axis submarines have attacked three more United States merchantmen in the Gulf of Mexico and destroyed two of them, the Navy announced yesterday.

LONDON, May 23 (U.P.) -- At least ninety-seven more patriots died before firing squads last week as the Germans tried to put down the rising tide of rebellion against Europe's "New Order," official sources said tonight.
CHICAGO, May 23 (U.P.) - War-created problems make it difficult for the National Football League to chart a course for 1942, Commissioner Elmer Layden said today.

Until arrangements are made with local rationing boards for extra fuel for motor cars used for official business, members of the New York City Patrol Corps needing more gasoline in the performance of their duties must request an additional allowance as "individual" motorists, Major Gen. Robert M. Danford, commandant of the corps, explained yesterday.

OTTAWA -- Big game once threatened with extinction because of the settlement of the Western Plains today roams in hundreds of thousands over 12,000 square miles of Canadian Government game preserves. Guns no longer bark at scurrying or resting animals.

MR. SAMUEL JOHNSON once remarked that men seldom think so seriously about anything else as they do about their dinner, and the Quartermaster Corps, which is responsible for feeding upward of 2,000,000 soldiers in our Army three times a day, operates on the theory that this goes double for fighting men.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 23 -- This week has brought fresh news of unrest in German-occupied Europe along with new additions to the ever-lengthening list of victims of Nazi firing squads. The latter is the German "cure-all" remedy for the former, and there is no sign that the prescription will be changed as long as such factors as fear and a desperate need for "collaboration" dictate German policy in the occupied countries.

Retail trade hero slackened last week, the first under the price ceilings of the General Maximum Price Regulation. Department store sales were estimated as running even with to about 1 per cent above the corresponding week last year. At that time, however, a heavy sales increase was noted and hot weather stimulated sales.

The early peas are beginning to reach for something to climb on. Sweet corn is knifing up into the sunlight. Carrots are waving first green leaflets, and hush beans are acting as though Jack had done the planting.

Allen Wardwell, twice head of Red Cross relief missions to Russia, will serve as New York City chairman of the campaign of Russian War Relief, Inc., for $6,000,000, it was announced yesterday by Edward C. Carter, president of the relief agency. Henry C. Alexander, a partner in J.P. Morgan Co. will be vice chairman and twenty-one leaders in industry, finance and law will make up the campaign executive committee.

MILWAUKEE, May 23 -- All Presbyterian churches were urged to liquidate all debts "before the present favorable economic situation disappears" in a report by the general council adopted at today's session of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

Any child who has seen the fascinating unfolding of those Chinese paper flowers which bloom only in water will recognize at once the logic of this nonsense tale for 4 to 6 year olds. Its hero is a homesick father, seized in mythical Amagambia with a fond impatience to see his children.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Martial music, patriotic fervor and the tread of well-drilled feet echoed over Griffith Stadium today as the Yankees struck their first blow in the interests of the nation's armed forces by hammering the Senators into subjection in the game for the Army and Navy relief funds.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The country's leading professional golfers are here for the opening tomorrow of the national championship tournament of the Professional Golfers Association at the Seaview Country Club.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, May 23 -- Port Moresby is the biggest place name in the Southwest Pacific war news these days -- and it's the sort of place nobody in his right mind would pick out to have a war in. For one thing, it's too hot.

Jockey Basil James said: "Alsab never turned a hair; the Belmont will be a cinch for him!" The rider of Albert Sabath's crack colt was talking after the finish of the Sixty-seventh Withers Mile run yesterday at Belmont Park before 30,521 persons who set a new betting record of $1,933,493 for New York.

CHUNGKING, China, May 23 -- The Japanese have occupied Chuanshih Island at the mouth of the Min River below Foochow, in Fukien Province, after the Chinese chased them back to their ships and annihilated more than half their landing force, the Chinese announced tonight.

THEY call it the ad lib, or short for ad libitum, and probably it is as old as the show business. Certainly it is one of the most admired aspects thereof, many and heroic being the tales the veterans tell of its use in the theatre (in vaudeville, especially), of embarrassing situations neatly escaped, of hecklers crushed with the retort devastating.

BOSTON, May 23 -- New England realizes today as never before that our entire social and business fabric is founded on gasoline and rubber. The rationing system now in force affects every family, and the necessary adjustments have produced a good deal of irritation and some bitterness, but there is no ground swell of resistance.

Retail trade continued fairly active in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors were busy; dresses, coats and suits were in demand, and basements were very active.
LONDON, May 23 -- The British Red Cross and the Order of St. John announced today the receipt of unofficial news of conditions among prisoners in Manila, Shanghai, Tientsin and Canton.

On the centenary, June 25, of the birth of Eloy Alfara, regarded by the people of Ecuador as their greatest Liberal leader, that South American republic will release 10-centavos, 20c, 30c and 1-sucre stamps for regular postage and 70c, 1s, 2s, 3s and 5s for air-mail use.

I FEEL that it is very important at present to keep the Edwin A. Fleisher Music Collection of the Free Library of Philadelphia as a going concern. At this moment, when the culture of America must be upheld, I hope that you will lend your efforts to those organizations which are struggling to preserve creative music in America.

Studies made in recent years by Congressional committees and the Treasury, having as their objective the closing of loopholes in tax laws, have given rise to an impression that tax avoidance is a common thing; that in the preparation of a corporation return, for instance, advantages can be obtained for the taxpayer either in an escape from the inclusion of income or in getting the benefit of undue deductions.

MR. DOWNES'S emotional article on the Critics Circle concerts calls for some added comment. I trust that mine -- as a member of the audience -- will be in order. I agree very decidedly with Mr. Downes on the chamber music decision.

Policemen were praised yesterday for their sacrifices since the start of the war by Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, at the annual memorial services sponsored by the Honor Legion in cooperation with American Legion police posts in the rotunda of Police Headquarters.

Nearly seven months ago Patrolman Sidney Turkheimer, who is attached to the warrant squad in downtown Manhattan, gave written permission to a veterinarian to destroy his eight-year-old Scottish terrier, Joey, because he was suffering from what was diagnosed as an incurable disease.

DETROIT, May 23 -- It was bad news for Adolf Hitler and his Axis allies when the United States Army, in a carefully worded statement, announced last week that the huge Ford Motor Company bomber plant at Willow Run was in production.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. -- Boosting home-front morale is aided by the recreational program of outdoor sports and social activities in this midsouth tidewater resort, designed for men in the service as well as for entertainment of visitors here on civilian vacations.

Every intelligent observer of world affairs had to witness with increasing anxiety the rising tide of animosity not only against utopian blueprints for a post-war world but against any concise peace plans and every peace planning in general. The reason for this changing attitude can be found largely in the military reverses after Pearl Harbor.
BOSTON, May 23 -- The Valdina Farms' Viscounty raced to a narrow victory over Phil Bieber's favored Maechance today in the sixth running of the $5,000 added Paul Revere Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

THE short story was recently discussed by one of its most successful modern practitioners, H.E. Bates, in a book which has been generally commended as one of the best critical studies of this variety of literature.

CLEVELAND, May 23 (AP) -- Jim Bagby gave only one hit in the eight innings he pitched against St. Louis tonight, but it was a home run by Harlond Clift and the Browns beat the Indians in the tenth, 2 to 1. Johnny Niggeling held Cleveland to three scattered hits.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 23 -- Yale provided a baseball upset today by defeating Fordham, loser of only two games this year until it met the Blue, 2 to 1. Coaches Joe Wood and Jack Coffey crossed up each other in the choice of pitchers, Wood calling on his sophomore right-hander, Jack Neville, to oppose Dick Fitzgerald of the Rams.

The WPA has been supplying the city with many of the things it has been trying unsuccessfully to get from the Office of Civilian Defense, it was disclosed yesterday at the offices of Major Irving V.A. Huie, local Work Projects Administrator.

NEWARK, N.J., May 23 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal court asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to postpone from June 1 to Oct. 5 the effective date of I.C.C. orders directing interchange of freight cars in seagoing coastwise service.

CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., May 23 -- Acutely conscious of industry's and government's need for the assistance of college-trained women in the war effort, the Wilson College Alumnae Association and the Wilson Placement Office have joined forces in a drive to make Wilson's response to that need both prompt and effective.

Applicants for the Army's glider-pilot training program are now being recruited from qualified male citizens between 18 and 25 years of age, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the Southern New York Recruiting and Induction District, 39 Whitehall Street.

The Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. will stage its sixty-sixth annual track and field championships at Triborough Stadium on Friday and Saturday as three of the really great performers in the long history of the organization make their varsity farewells.
PHILADELPHIA, May 23 (AP) -- The Phils turned back the Braves today, 6 to 5, when Johnny Sain committed a balk in the ninth inning to send Danny Murtaugh home with the winning run.
BERLIN, May 23 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High, Command said in a communique today:

Sharp curtailment by many retailers of wholesale buying activity for an extended period was seen at the week-end as one certainty emerging from the unprecedented and confused merchandising situation created by the impending War Production Board order restricting retail and wholesale inventories.
TO sum it all up in the words of one of the principals involved: "You know something? Now all the agents shave in the morning! It's a fact!"

WITHIN seventy-five miles by highway from Washington -- fifty miles as the crow flies, or as the airliners fly that shuttle between New York and Florida -- is a quiet countryside, very little changed since the Civil War or, for that matter, the War of Independence. The people who live there are the descendants of the people who owned and tilled the same fields in George Washington's boyhood.

LONDON, May 23 -- While big German long-range guns on the hostile side of the English Channel sent shells thundering into some parts of Southeast England today, the Royal Air Force carried out sweeps over occupied France and hammered objectives between Calais and Boulogne.

MOSCOW, May 23 -- The fateful battles raging in the Eastern Ukraine on which the world's anxious attention is now riveted have not distracted the calm and persevering Russian from his daily routine of patient toil. The broad outlines are firmly fixed in his mind.

UNITED STATES NAVAL AIR STATION, at St. Lucia, in the Caribbean, May 23 (AP) -- The concern that the French island of Martinique has caused among the American people, because of fears that it might be used secretly as an Axis submarine base, is not shared by the United States Navy.

HUNTINGTON, W.Va., May 23 (AP) -- William Edwards Jr., a State C.I.O. vice president and general organizer for the United Construction Workers, told today of his discharge from the U.C.W. He declared that "the John L. Lewis faction" was retaliating against West Virginia unionists who refused to support Wendell L. Willkie for the Presidency in 1940.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The War Production Board today ordered that all construction of public amusement projects, such as race tracks, theatres and baseball parks be stopped by June 6, and warned that "other kinds of nonessential construction * * * may be halted by subsequent orders."

NOUMEA, New Caledonia, May 23 -- The American Army men in New Caledonia are now thoroughly established as a working, fighting force, adjusted to its environment and well on the way to making this strategic Free French island an impregnable stronghold of the United Nations in the South Pacific. Already well dug in, the United States forces are in battle position, keen and ready to meet the Japanese.

BURGESS MEREDITH met Eugene Marchbanks when Meredith was 21 1/2 and Marchbanks 18 -- just turned 18, at that. Today Meredith is 33 1/2 and Marchbanks is still 18, thanks to the dramatic fixative sprayed on him by Bernard Shaw.

The Women's Division of the Russian War Relief Society will give a large cocktail party and dance this afternoon and evening in the Viennese Roof and Penthouse Suite of the St. Regis. The fete is one of the largest in a series of benefit events arranged by the women's division in their campaign to raise $500,000 in the $6,000,000 drive now being conducted by Russian War Relief.

A WRITER in The Times Literary Supplement laments that in most modern writing an individual style is steadily becoming rarer. He finds that "the general level of writing has risen, but the high peaks of supreme excellence do not emerge from the range."

Pungent odors of frying fish rising from the basement kitchen window of the Harlem Boys Club at 60 West 134th Street yesterday afternoon at 5 o'clock caused a temporary blackout that had nothing to do with civilian defense.

Rao in memorial services held by the Thomas Jefferson Post, American Legion, at Jefferson Park, 111th Street and East River.

TRENTON, N.J., May 23 (AP) -- Severance of Labor's Non-Partisan League of New Jersey from John L. Lewis, its national chairman, by changing the league's name will be voted at the sixth annual convention of the organization tomorrow, a spokesman for the executive board predicted tonight.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 23 -- Emphasis was placed by officials here today on the provisions for Brazil's development of the Itabira Iron Ore Company that are included in the United States-Brazilian agreements, just approved by President Getulio D. Vargas, for shipment of all exports of strategic materials from this country to the United States.

Growing perennials from seed is not difficult, and yet comparatively few gardeners ever try it. It is true that this takes somewhat longer than purchasing plants, but seed sown now will provide fine specimens of most of the popular garden favorites for transferring to permanent positions late in the Fall or early next Spring.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 23 -- Billy McGuirk pitched Georgetown to a 10-to-2 victory over the Naval Academy nine today. The Hill-toppers' triumph ended the midshipmen's winning streak at ten games.

TORONTO. FOUR governments - in - exile are training soldiers, sailors and airmen in Canada. In Ontario and Quebec the flags of Norway, the Netherlands, Belgium and Poland fly over camps where their young nationals prepare themselves for the fight against the conquerors of their homelands.

Leaders in the shipping industry emphatically reject a prediction made by Grover Loening, aeronautical engineer, that airplanes would replace ocean passenger liners and freighters as a result of aviation developments in the war.

It goes without saying that the Army's motor vehicles must be shod with the best tires that can be made. At the same time, conservation of rubber is good common sense for the Army as well as for civilians. In this connection it is interesting to learn that hereafter all tires used on Army vehicles in the continental United States will have the regular standard tread, formerly used only on administrative vehicles.

A total of 1,800 women volunteers, organized in "hamlets" throughout the city, are working on regular schedule to supply dressings and bandages for the City Cancer Committee. A dozen or more of these units are formed within women's organizations, while others are church guilds, hospital auxiliaries or new groups formed under committee auspices.

The first seven days of surface fishing for weakfish in Peconic Bay ended with the big yellow fins conspicuous by their absence Most salt water anglers have been raising the same question: When are they going to catch some good- sized ones?

Vacation days are here again, but they are vacation days with a new tempo. The old "Hip hip hooray, how far can we go in two weeks?" has been changed to a sober consideration of "How near can we settle to get a fortnight of rest, sports and fun?"

SCHENECTADY, May 23 -- Open support for Owen D. Young as the Democratic candidate for Governor to succeed Herbert H. Lehman developed tonight at a session of the State-wide meeting of the Affiliated Young Democrats when A.A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, announced his personal preference for the former industrialist, now a dairy farmer at Van Hornesville.

Her husband's first wife's best friend is a character with possibilities. Valerie, the serpent in question, makes the most of hers. She had never known Joyce, but Joyce had known Claire, the first wife, who had died after fifteen happy years with Tuck.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Progress in the manufacture of synthetic rubber on a commercial scale was reported by the Goodrich and Goodyear rubber companies in summaries released today by the Senate committee investigating national defense.

My portable flower bed is one of the handiest features of my annual garden. It's very useful, for instance, to tide over those empty spaces which will show up occasionally in the most carefully planned mass plantings. For special occasions I place it in a bare or shady spot on the lawn where nothing bright or showy can be persuaded to grow.

IN an exciting tour of the Army camps, Judy Graves, memorable mischief-maker of "Junior Miss," has met and captivated over 85,000 service men since Jan. 12. Different in every respect from the usual road company tour, the circuit covered by the U.S.O.-Camp Shows "Junior Miss" company has provided countless strange adventures.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 23 (AP) -- Bobby Coombs, veteran right-hander, notched his third straight victory today as he pitched Jersey City to a 4-to-0 triumph over Syracuse. Coombs set the Chiefs down with six hits. Bobby also helped his cause in the fourth inning by driving a single that accounted for two runs.

Strings of shore lights along the Atlantic and the glare of cities once beckoned the sailor from the night sea. Seamen seeing the glare of light were seized by "channel fever," that peculiar disease all sailors catch near port.

LONDON, May 23 -- General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock, German commander on the Kharkov front, was reported in British Government quarters tonight to have sent a message to Adolf Hitler criticizing Herr Hitler's new war powers and saying that a general offensive against Russia was "an utter impossibility."

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Three minor world track records were claimed today in special events as Fordham's powerful team defeated Georgetown, 82-44, in a dual meet dedicating the Hoyas' new athletic field. The gross gate receipts were turned over to the Army relief.

RICHMOND, Va., May 23 -- Alfalfa is the source of a new substance which, when taken internally, is changed by the body into vitamin C, the anti-scurvy vitamin, according to a patent (No. 2,282,969) granted to Dr. Charles G. King, research worker of the University of Pittsburgh, to which are assigned the patent rights.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 23 -- Princeton University clinched the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League championship for the second straight year today by defeating Harvard, 6 to 5, in fourteen innings on Soldiers Field.

With the theme "Bank Operations in Wartime," the New York State Bankers Association will hold its forty-ninth annual meeting tomorrow and Tuesday in the Hotel Astor. It will be the first time in forty years that the association has convened in this city.

Mrs. Skaggs is not meant to be a pathetic case of frustrated ambition.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Senator Brown of Michigan has told Leon Henderson, Administrator of Prices and Civilian Supply, that "indefinite, indistinct and uncertain" reasons for including the Midwest in the gasoline rationing program were insufficient, if full cooperation was to be expected.

Labor stealing among war industries has not reached nearly the proportions it assumed in the last war when it was the accepted method of obtaining men, Richard C. Brockway, New York State director of the United States Employment Service, declared yesterday.

The New York office of the War Production Board's Bureau of Finance has obtained loans and advances to contractors and subcontractors of war equipment amounting to $13,454,455 from Jan. 1 to May 15, Erwin Rankin, chief financial adviser of the bureau, announced yesterday.

YOU were a little rough, it seems to me, in your article of May 10 on John J. Anthony and his "Good-Will Hour." Granted that he must go wrong occasionally on the "snap judgments" he offers to people in search of panaceas for personal problems -- well, what of it?

SAN FRANCISCO -- Commanding a view of the harbor that once sheltered hundreds of windjammers on a single day, ships from every maritime country in the world, San Francisco's new marine museum is answering in the form of models, photos and oldtime shipping posters almost any question that the landsman, possessed of a yen for adventure and travel, could ask.

TO ALEXANDRIA: Sea battles have produced some famous words, like Nelson's "England expects every man to do his duty," and Farragut's "Damn the torpedoes! Go ahead!" In World War II Commodore Henry Harwood of the Royal Navy signaled the start of the dramatic encounter off the River Plate with this message: "My object: destruction."

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Agreement to limit the increased minimum base pay of privates of the Army and Marine Corps and apprentice seamen of the Navy and Coast Guard to the $42 a month approved by the Senate in March, and to reject the $50 voted by the House last week, was reached today by Senate and House conferees on the long-controverted readjusted pay measure.

Appointment of two deputy regional directors, Sydney Hogerton and Phillip M. McCullough, was announced yesterday by John P. Maguire, Regional Director for the War Production Beard for New York and Northern New Jersey. Mr. Hogerton is succeeded as priorities district manager by H. Dudley Swim, formerly vice president of National Investors Corporation and a director of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company, Schick, Inc., and other concerns.

For the benefit of those who have problems to solve in their victory gardens, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden has arranged to have a gardening expert in attendance at the demonstration victory garden. This service is rendered free on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays from 2:30 to 4:30 P.M. and on Wednesdays from 5 to 6:15 P.M., by Montague Free and assistants.

The sixty-seventh running of the historic Withers Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday was the occasion for many luncheon parties before the races and in the Turf and Field Club boxes during the afternoon. The event annually draws a large gathering of members of society from New York, Long Island and other parts of the country.

Formation of an over-all food industry committee to offer a "united front" in the handling of war-time problems with the Government is expected to result from the mid-year meeting of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America held here last week.

There are men in the picture, each. doing his job. They are skillful men who, like Americans, know their business and won't take their hats off to any one.

URBANA-CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 23 -- High School biology teachers should return to the advice of America's pioneer biologist, Louis Agassiz, who said: "Study nature, not books," in the opinion of Dr. H.W. Ward, professor emeritus of Zoology of the University of Illinois.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 23 (AP) -- Lafayette High of Buffalo streaked across the finish line a length and three-quarters ahead of Philadelphia's West Catholic High today to capture the national senior eight-oared rowing championship in the eighth annual regatta of the Schoolboy Rowing Association of America.
