WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The American Army no longer need be considered a potential force; it has matured. It may grow to twice or thrice its current size, and there will be a vastly greater supply of weapons for it to use, but this Army has passed its formative stage.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (U.P.) -- The Navy tonight told for the first time the heroic story of Patrol Wing No. 10 -- Patwing 10 -- which started in the Philippines at the outset of the war with forty big patrol bombers, and ended up in Australia three months later with two.

Nine days after he returned to the Army, in which he had won medals from three nations for bravery in the 1918 smash through the Hindenburg Line, First Lieutenant Thomas G. Dean Jr., 51 years old, shot himself yesterday on Pier 90, North River, where he was on military police duty.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 23 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- Airmen, soldiers and sailors from the Netherlands Indies are much in evidence among the United Nations armed forces in Australia, particularly the native guerrilla bands from Celebes, Borneo and other islands.

FOR an ex-cowpuncher, George Montgomery isn't doing badly at all. Most recently seen hereabout in "Roxie Hart," Mr. Montgomery has just completed "Ten Gentlemen From West Point" and his future schedule already includes "Orchestra Wife," "Down to the Sea in Ships" and "Coney Island," fanfared as one of Darryl Zanuck's most pretentious efforts for this year.

Americans last week had much food for sober thought furnished them by developments in the anti-inflation program. They took the inauguration of price ceilings in their stride. They saw the hand of war reaching deeper and deeper into their pocketbooks.

ONE of the undeniable virtues of the Bay Psalm Book was that it contained not a line that could remind worshipers of the superb cadences of the versions in the Book of Common Prayer used by the Established Church of England.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 23 -- The standardization of freshman and sophomore courses at Hofstra College and Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute so that the two institutions may carry on a joint program of study in engineering, was announced today by officials of the colleges.

IN this day, when the future of opera in America is faced with new developments which may materially alter its course, it is of interest to turn to chapters in Herbert Graf's thoughtful and suggestive book, "The Opera and Its Future in America."

PERSONALITIES are usually irrelevant to a book review, but in the case of Mary McCarthy it seems that the reader should know something of her background and of her familiarity with the world which this first novel depicts.

FRANK GERVASI'S contribution to the ever-growing collection of books by war correspondents possesses two factors of specific interest. First, it is concerned almost entirely with the farther British fronts; and, second, its author was until the fall of France something of an isolationist.

IT should be made clear at the outset that there is little in this thoughtful book about Britain at war. Armageddons, whether ancient or modern, fall as curtains between the acts of a great nation's age-long drama. Bombs may burst where kings were crowned, but gothic -- English gothic -- is imperishable.

A busy doctor has little time for Christmas shopping, and that is especially true of Dr. Westlake, who occasionally doubles as a detective. The doctor's little daughter, Dawn, has hinted -- and her hints are anything but subtle -- that she wants a pair of skis, a bowl of goldfish and a ship-in-bottle.

YEARS ago a New York radio man had an idea -- the day might come, he reasoned, when short-wave circuits would be all-important in the creation and operation of extensive broadcast networks. With such channels a network might become an important agency in international affairs and over them diplomacy might take on new meanings.

WASHINGTON, D.C., May 23 -- State school legislation of 1942, springing directly from war conditions, consists in part of emergency acts giving to State executives broad war powers to utilize schools in the State defense picture, and in part, of finance measures to facilitate accelerated school and college programs.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 23 (U.P.) -- Steadily heavier Japanese raids on the Allies' advance base at Port Moresby, New Guinea, were regarded by military observers today as a possible prelude to a major enemy offensive, supported by planes released from Burma and other Far Eastern battlefronts.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Proposals were advanced today to include representatives of all the United Nations in a projected conference of American and British legislators on war and peace aims. At the same time some opposition developed to the general proposition of such a meeting at this stage of the war.

In a religious pageant of youth in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine 5,000 children of Sunday schools in 300 Episcopal churches gave $25,000 yesterday afternoon as their Lenten missionary offering in the diocese of New York.

The complete housing facilities of the Young Women's Christian Association in this city -- a total of ten buildings -- will be at the service of city relief agencies in the event of enemy action here, Y.W.C.A. officials stated yesterday.

THE author of "Our Library," herself an experienced and successful librarian, tells about the many-sided work of an elementary school library. The result is a volume which should be in the hands of all elementary school teachers and administrators, especially those who have never had an opportunity to see a good school library in action, and so are unaware of the library's practical usefulness and far-reaching influence.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Mickey Cochrane, who piloted the Tigers to the 1935 world championship, today received the job of selecting and managing the All-Star service baseball team which is scheduled to play an All-Star major league team in Cleveland on July 7 for the benefit of the Army and Navy Relief Funds.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Struggling with the problem created by a national income more than twice as great as the value of goods available for consumers to purchase, the government pressed hard this week for favorable consideration from Congress of proposals for sharp advances in income taxes.

ST. LOUIS, May 23 (AP) -- Stan Musial, who hasn't been playing entirely up to expectations, added some weight to his bid for No. 1 Rookie of the Year Honors today by punching the Cardinals into second place in the National League.

NO less than three large works by American composers grace Victor's May list. They are Daniel Gregory Mason's Quartet in G minor on Negro Themes, Op. 19 (M-891, three 12-inch records); Howard Hanson's The Lament for Beowulf, Op. 25 (M-889, three 12-inch records) and Leo Sowerby's Symphony in G for Organ (M-894, four 12-inch records).

THE undersigned composers wish to express their amazement at the irresponsible and offensive tone that Mr. Olin Downes injected into last Sunday's article on the two concerts of American compositions arranged and presented by an organization of which he is an executive member, the Music Critics Circle.

An invitation preview and tea tomorrow at the headquarters of the American Friends of Norway, 40 West Fifty-seventh Street, will serve to open there a benefit exhibition of paintings entitled "Impressions of World Leaders." In addition to the paintings there will be on display a collection of gifts suitable for week-end hostesses.
DERBY, Conn., May 23 -- With almost monotonous precision, four Harvard crews moved over two miles of placid water on the Housatonic today to sweep their regatta with Yale for the fifth straight year.

Perhaps everybody owes everybody else an apology. It now appears that, contrary to first impressions, the number of gasoline ration cards of the unlimited variety asked for and issued was not excessive. On the basis of returns for 1,486,806 car owners, Leon Henderson has reported to the President that 30.8 per cent took A cards entitling them to only three gallons a week.

MR. GUERARD'S volume on Robert Bridges is the first serious and systematic study of the poet. It merits much warm praise. It places significant emphasis upon the poet's critical traditionalism, brings into prominence the position of Spinoza in his thought, stresses (a greatly needed service) his attainment in the two "Nero" plays and presents a greater amount of information and judicious criticism than all other commentaries on Bridges put together.

A one-year literature program designed to make students more international-minded will begin next Fall at Hunter College with fifty-seven professors and instructors cooperating to teach the course. It is planned to present Western literature as a "living unit" so that students will learn to evaluate America's contribution and begin to think in broader and more international terms.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- It appeared the consensus in the capital after a week that gasoline rationing is not too rash and that allotments have been sufficiently generous to preclude in the main only what might be called the more frivolous use of automobiles.

War's advent and the consequent rationing of tires and gasoline have brought into sharp focus New England's development of its back trails during the past decade. The motorist of former years, whizzing over the through roads, was all too often completely unaware that these subsidiary routes existed.

THE Intercollegiate Literary Fellowships, sponsored by the publishers of this novel, have turned up some remarkably fresh and hopeful young talents. Hopeful not only in themselves, but because they seem to suggest a present college generation whose mental honesty and emotional maturity would put to shame undergraduates of the Nineteen Twenties and Nineteen Thirties.

New York tournament players will have their last local opportunity to practice for the Summer national championships when the annual South Shore tournament is held this coming week-end. The South Shore tournament will be played at the Half Moon Hotel at Coney Island.

NEWARK, N. J., May 23 -- Detectives on the staff of Prosecutor William A. Wachenfeld of Essex County, bearing John Doe warrants, sought tonight a counterfeiting ring that has obtained the release of at least seventy-six new automobile tires from dealers in this area through the use of bogus ration orders.

PUTNAMS are quite likely to be interesting folk. The tradition was established by General Israel Putnam, who distinguished himself as an equestrian of parts in 1778 when he escaped from the British by ridding his horse down a steep flight of steps in the vicinity of Greenwich, Conn.

Moved by the growing circulation of Nazi propaganda in Spain, with the approval and connivance of high officials of the Franco Falangist regime, the Most Rev. Fidel Garcia y Martinez, Roman Catholic Bishop of Calahorra in the Province of Burgos, Spain, has issued a pastoral letter attacking Nazi propaganda and reiterating the church's condemnation of Nazism and racism, according to word received here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A total of 8,616 persons have been evacuated from Burma by air in the past several weeks, approximately half of them by the United States Army Ferrying Command, the War Department announced here today.

TORONTO, May 23 -- Harry Giddings's great Ten to Ace ran the King's Plate as if he owned the track, the jockey and the entire seven-horse field today, winning the mile and a furlong event by almost fifty yards from Cossack Post, with Depressor third at Woodbine Park.

A $5,000,000 bathing industry at Long Beach, center of a group of white-sand beaches stretching twelve miles between the Rockaways and Point Lookout on western Long Island's South Shore, stands ready to accommodate the largest influx of Summer vacationists in the resort city's thirty-five-year history.

ANNE BROWN, star of George Gershwin's "Porgy and Bess," is leaving the show to devote herself to a concert career. The present date set for her last performance is May 30, but she may remain a week or so longer if a replacement has not been prepared for her role by that time.

NEWARK, N.J., May 23 -- A group of young, experienced and energetic women are coming to the fore as a result of the New Jersey club elections, and are preparing to guide their organizations through the difficulties of wartime administrations.

FOR the climax of his first, and very interesting, novel Dyson Carter has chosen one of the most appalling of peacetime catastrophes, a fire in an old and overcrowded hospital. The East Wing of the huge General Hospital in an unnamed industrial city is the scene of the story.

THE public mind is, very naturally, much concerned over the economic prospects for the post-war period. The last war was followed by a post-war slump and by a long period of unsettlement. Will the same timetable repeat itself? Will unemployment be one of the blessings of peace?

BERLIN, May 23 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Adolf Hitler's generals declared officially today that Russia's great offensive against Kharkov had been smashed and that the Germans, supported by Rumanians and Hungarians, were counter-attacking along the whole southern front.
Stocks drifted aimlessly yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange with a volume of 131,630 shares. Of the 439 issues traded, 114 rose, 142 fell and 156 made no change.

A Greenwich Village apartment house is the scene of three murders, and every person in the house is more or less under suspicion. The first victim is the landlord, the cause of whose death is inaccurately named by the author as Caisson's Disease.

THERE was nothing in particular to intimate that the season's most moving experience would come so near the season's close. The Museum of Modern Art had already put on its ingeniously staged (still current) "Wartime Housing" show, prepared in collaboration with the National Committee on the Housing Emergency.

"CORPORAL NIP and K.C. Jones is a humorous skit broadcast weekly from the new San Francisco short-wave station which feeds news and entertainment to the Philippines and China. Tuned last Thursday evening to the slapstick of "Jones and Nip," one found Mr. Nip up a tree where he had tied himself so he wouldn't run away.

MONTREAL -- Long a focal point for the United States tourist movement both for its own attractions and as a gateway to the Laurentian Mountains, Montreal this year still has many inducements for the American visitor.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Japanese Government has not yet permitted neutral observers to report upon the condition and treatment of American military and civilian prisoners in the Philippines, parts of occupied China, Hong Kong, the Netherlands Indies and Malaya, the State Department reported today.

A three-day session, opening tomorrow, is being planned for the annual meeting of the American Women's Voluntary Services, with delegates expected from such distant points as California and Alaska. The wartime duties of women generally as well as the specific purposes of the organization will be fully discussed.

Developments during and since the successful completion of the government's major cash borrowing this month disclosed for the first time a sort of general pattern as to the methods by which the Treasury may be expected to raise the huge sums necessary to finance the war.

The annual report of the United Shoe Machinery Corporation, submitted yesterday to stockholders by Sidney W. Winslow Jr., chairman, shows a net income of $9,771.027 for the fiscal year ended on Feb. 28, after all deductions, including $7,650,000 provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes and $1,000,000 reserve for contingencies.
MOSCOW, May 23 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau communique said today:

The lights of New York City could be seen in peacetime from a distance of twenty-five to seventy-five miles. The marquees and signs of the Great White Way, the neon tubing and incandescent bulbs of countless store fronts, the bright windows of tall buildings, the illumination of 150,000 street lamps -- these all combined to create a spectacular glow in the night sky.

Mexico's national champion Atlante team will meet a picked squad from four metropolitan clubs of the American Soccer League at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island today. The kickoff is scheduled for 3 o'clock.
"IT doesn't blow up," the 3-year-old said in a puzzled way, after he had patiently huffed and puffed on a red broom handle; then, thoughtfully, after a long pause, "I have a balloon at home."

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 23 -- Reinhart (Ray) Torgerson of the home club and his partner, Wesley Cotterell of Cherry Valley, reached the semi-final round in the Lakeville club's annual member-guest golf tournament today, thereby justifying their choice as favorites in the Calcutta pool.

Keep away from the ocean! It's a hard restriction for the camera vacationist to swallow, especially for the city dweller, to whom water means escape and relaxation and picture opportunities which in the opinion of many photographers are unexcelled in appeal.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The past Winter, described as the Continent's worst in a century, and an unusually late Spring, were reported by the Agriculture Department today to have seriously affected crop prospects throughout most of Europe.

AKRON, Ohio, May 23 -- While the armed forces are going to have the rubber needed for mechanized warfare, the civilian population should not jump to any overly optimistic conclusions over talk from Washington about 800,000 to 1,000,000 tons of synthetic rubber a year by the end of 1943, and, above all, should not count on driving motor cars cushioned on American ersatz tires.

THE lighted sign outside NBC's studio 8-G said "Rehearsal" in plain red letters, and the page boy insisted his orders were to let no one in. "Besides," he added, "your appointment is with Ezra Stone, and he hasn't come in yet."

Awards for distinguished service in the radio, motion picture and newspaper fields were presented yesterday morning at the annual Youthbuilders Forum, held in Town Hall and attended by 1,000 school children and Board of Education officials.

THERE is a good deal of genuine feeling in this light novel, and most of it is unpleasant. The book also differs agreeably from the pattern of the fiction with which it naturally falls by ending with an unconventional design, happy, but not the regular happy ending.

FOR thirty-five years Helen Mackay lived in the same house in Paris, in that quiet little Place du Palais Bourbon behind the Chamber of Deputies. During that time she wrote books, in French, which were honored by that nation of critics. And for more than twenty years she worked as voluntary aide in the soldiers' hospital of Les Invalides, thus continuing service begun during the first World War.

New York garden lovers who spend their vacations below the Mason-Dixon Line and desire to bring home some plant reminder of Southern gardens might well consider the so-called Confederate Jasmine (Trachelospermum jasminoides).

THE latest volume in the "What the Citizen Should Know" series of wartime handbooks finds its crucial theme in a paradox which by this time is familiar: In the United States today, say the two authorities who are responsible for this excellent book, there are only four forces, the Army, the Navy, the Air Force and the Home Front; "in the ultimate sense there are no civilians."

Coat and suit buying was at a standstill during the past week, awaiting clarification of ceiling prices, and dress business fell off due mostly to unseasonable weather, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Announcement of the planned WPB curb on inventories had a disturbing effect on both wholesale and retail activity, particularly since it came so soon after posting of ceiling prices.

Last week the government permitted the publication of the news that Mauna Loa began to erupt on April 26. On that day the lava poured out of a fissure 3,000 feet below the summit and flowed slowly and irresistibly toward the town of Hilo, exactly as in 1935.

Six newspaper women received certificates of merit yesterday from the Woman's Press Club of New York City, each certificate bearing a citation "for her continuing interest in the activities of organized women, and with grateful appreciation for the space allocated to women by the publishers" of their newspapers.
The Spanish Ambassador, Juan Francisco de Cardenas, is at the Ritz-Carlton.
A tightening censorship brings into relief the issue of what is seditious utterance tending to obstruct or subvert the action of government or bring it into disrepute.

HERE are two Nero Wolfe stories for the price of one, and if that isn't a bargain you never saw one. To be sure, the separate stories are not as long as usual, but that merely proves that Rex Stout is as much at home in the shorter form as he is in the longer.

GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Col. -- Not even a train whistle sounded off the grand adventure. The travelers were mostly business men to whom it was just another train, but for us it was the beginning of a grand holiday, full of the unknown -- two weeks under the stars.
Exploiting an ancient maxim that one good turn deserves another, the Giants gave the Dodgers a couple of more twists at the Polo Grounds yesterday, to the surprise of 21,920 onlookers.

The late Raymond Ditmars rightly succeeded in making millions more snake-conscious. I live at the penultimate of the Doodletown Road, near a sweet-smelling swamp, and an ever-running spring flows out of the ground two rods from my back door, the source of Doodletown Brook.

Two hundred teachers at a testimonial luncheon for Assemblyman Robert J. Crews at the George Washington Hotel yesterday pledged the continuation of their campaign to give tenure to permanent substitutes. The teachers urged that the category "permanent substitute" be abolished and the same status as regular teachers be given to those in it.

BALTIMORE, May 23 (AP) -- Home runs by Ed Robinson, Bob Lemon and George Staller paced Baltimore to a 7-to-2 victory over Newark in the opening game of a series today, although the Bears outhit the Orioles.

EVERY man of fighting rank or rate in the American Navy considers himself eligible and likely to serve on destroyers, those all-or-nothing instruments of war which cannot hide beneath the sea like submarines, or flee in two directions simultaneously at 400 miles an hour like airplanes, or flutter out of gun sights like tiny torpedo boats, or, like heavy cruisers and battleships, fend off shells and bombs with thick armor.

THREE hundred and thirty-six pages of mellow, philosophical and humorous reminiscence belie the implication of Henry Adams's dictum, quoted on the title page, that "nothing is more tiresome than a superannuated pedagogue."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 23 -- A week ago Yale and Harvard turned the Ivy League championships into a private dual track and field meet, which was beating the gun by a full seven days. The Cantabs took that one in something of a surprise, but they were unequal to the task of repeating the operation today in the forty-ninth meeting of these ancient rivals.
BOSTON, May 23 -- Knuckle-Baller Roger Wolff limited the Red Sox to six hits today as the Athletics won, 4 -- 3, before an Army-Navy relief game crowd of 12,216.

A city-bred boy on his first trip to Alaska is ill prepared to face isolation in a snow-bound cabin in the wilderness. This was a situation which Pierre Bernard bad not bargained for when he urged his father, called suddenly away on a short trip, to let him stay on in their hunting camp.

One of the largest benefit afternoon fetes of the season will take place at the Stork Club on Tuesday, when a Spring Tea Dance will be given in behalf of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

Bright, gay accessories in Latin-American styles, daily becoming more evident in the shops, make it easy for the home decorator to employ these exotic fashions. The colorful fabrics, naively painted furniture, unusual pottery and typical Mexican tin decorative objects have the virtue of creating vivid, original effects with the minimum of outlay.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 23 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force headquarters issued this communique today:

The Curies will be honored not only for the importance of their scientific work, but so long as men recognize their individual debts to humanity, for their unswerving devotion to that work in the face of great privation and for their selfless generosity with which they gave its fruits to the world.

It is expected that before another week passes Mexico will be at war With the Axis powers. President Manuel Avila Camacho has declared a state of emergency following the action of the Cabinet, which on Friday night decided that because of the sinking of Mexican ships by German U-boats the Congress should be asked to declare war on Germany. The President has called Congress into session next Thursday for that purpose.
OMAHA, May 23 (AP) -- Leaders of the country's livestock growers went home last night after a conference here, determined to do their best to prevent meatless days in the next six months.

Despite the persistent recurrence of reports that cargoes waiting for shipment are congested in American cities, inquiries disclosed last week that conditions in New York as well as in other important ports on the Atlantic seaboard are excellent.

THIS is the book, Mr. Peattie's publishers tell us, that he "has been promising himself for eight years to write." He conceived it, therefore, in 1934, when Hitler was a miserable little murderer not feared outside Germany, Pearl Harbor was impregnable and Amer ican soldiers visited such places as Australia, China and Northern Ireland only when they were on furlough.

GROUP exhibitions and a sprinkling of one-man shows continued to keep the galleries busy last week and provided a number of attractions of more than ephemeral interest. Among the openings was the "Spring -- 1942," at the Frank Rehn Gallery, which brings together oils, water-colors, prints and drawings by a score of artists associated with the gallery.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- Tanker deaths on the high seas have come home too often to Philadelphians, residents of the principal refinery area on the Eastern seaboard, to make them grumble about gasoline rationing.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Buying by mills and a lack of selling pressure gave the wheat market a firm undertone today on the Board of Trade and closing sales were about the top, with gains of 3/4 to 7/8 cent a bushel.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Back in the Gay Nineties our mother, like thousands of others, used to pack the family trunks, straw suitcases and the other domestic luggage which we four youngsters, with considerable hurry-scurry, would pile on the front piazza.

GRANVILLE, Ohio, May 23 -- Offered for students interested in generalizing in the field of American citizenship as well as for those desirous of specializing in government service as a career, the new major in citizenship and reconstruction to be instituted at Denison University next year will be built around social studies and foreign languages, according to Dean Cyril F. Richards, who prepared the course for advanced registration this week.

Mrs. Junius S. Morgan, wife of Lieut. Comdr. Morgan, U.S.N.R., sponsored a "light destroyer-type sub-chaser" that was launched yesterday afternoon at the Consolidated Shipbuilding Corporation at Morris Heights, the Bronx. A company spokesman said that she was chosen because of her work as vice chairman of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy of the Third Naval District.
The Supreme Court decision of May 11 in line with other recent decisions and the present Senatorial investigation pointedly contrast the differences between patents and monopolies.

The domestic oil and mining industries showed last year the largest combined profits since 1937, which was the best year since 1929. Had it not been for the higher rates of taxation in 1941, however, their profits would have been higher than in either of the former years.

LONDON, May 23 -- The British Government decided this week to solve the difficulties of the nation's supplies of cotton goods. As the first step, 12,000 workers were retransferred to the cotton mills from the munitions industries. Moreover, the government is considering extension of working hours and reopening of several closed mills.

Adolf Hitler, like Iron Chancellor Bismarck, has regarded a two-front war as a "nightmare." "Mein Kampf" criticizes the failure of the Kaiser to avoid a simultaneous clash on Germany's eastern and western frontiers. The Fuehrer's technique has been to move against one victim at a time.

Leaders of industry and education, striving to solve their common problems and create a more effective basis for cooperation, have joined in sponsoring a series of far-reaching regional conferences to be held this year. Through them, it is hoped, many of the existing misunderstandings may disappear.

At the specialty exhibition of the Scottish Terrier Club of America to be held Saturday, June 6, at Brookside, the estate of Mrs. Flagler Matthews in Rye, N.Y., the beneficiary will be Dogs For Defense, Inc. This will be the second show in the metropolitan area -- the first being that today of the Greenwich Kennel Club -- in which 50 cents is added to the entry fee, this money being earmarked for the beneficiary.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Civilian Defense authorities in Eastern seaboard States have been instructed by Washington headquarters to be on the alert for possible attempts to land small, bodies of enemy forces.

Since it was first inaugurated on April 10, 1872, in Nebraska, Arbor Day has become a thoroughly American custom. Now every State in the Union observes an Arbor Day, with dates varying from Feb. 22 in Alabama to December in Georgia. Most States observe the day during April and May, a majority of the Eastern States having their date set by proclamation of the Governor.

The use of mass production methods similar to the automobile and tank assembly lines to speed up the wartime ship construction program will be the subject of discussion at the Spring meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers at Pittsburgh on Tuesday and Wednesday.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 23 -- If Congress were composed of the nation's civic and community leaders -- the heads of church councils, service clubs, boards of education, local labor councils, mayors and other civic figures -- a ceiling would be placed over wages, just as it was placed May 18 over prices.

Operation of air raid report centers in eighty-five police stations throughout the city, manned by small but competent crews of civilian volunteers, has started, James G. Blaine, chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, announced yesterday.

TO meet Mr. Pan will be for a great many readers one of the most delightfully distracting and certainly one of the least political reading experiences of this season. The main figure and theme of twenty-eight charmingly written vignettes, he represents in his own individual manner and mannerisms a very special aspect of China and the Chinese.

WHEN the historians and candidates for Ph.D.'s get to work on The Rise and Fall of Adolf Hitler they will have to go to some of our newspapers for the best contemporary sources. By now it is an old saying that Hitler would never have gotten away with as much as he did if the foreign correspondents in Berlin had been instead the diplomats and political leaders of their native lands.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Private business and industry will provide jobs for America's fighting men when they come back to civilian life, Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, promised in a radio talk tonight.

America's commercial airlines, envy of the peace-time world, have completed their first week of flying under the war-operations plan of the War Department. And the United States can be thankful that so fine and capable a system of air transport was ready to shoulder a heavy burden.

LONDON, May 23 (U.P.) -- An Exchange Telegraph Agency correspondent reported today from Dinapur, Northeastern India, that Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell had arrived there with 400 other persons after a strenuous trek over the mountains from Burma.

The first steps in the establishment of the proposed United Nations Joint Maritime Commission were taken last week when officials of the International Transport Workers Federation met in Washington with officials of the War Shipping Administration.

PROFESSOR VERNADSKY'S latest contribution to the history of Russia is the biography of a man through whose victories the region now called the Ukraine, which in the seventeenth century formed part of Poland, attained the semblance of an independent state.

BARNSTORMING troupers, bouncing sleepily over the one-night-stand route, had a picnic compared with the grueling grind which Dorothy Lamour has gone through since last January, when she placed herself at the disposal of the Treasury Department to promote the sale of war bonds and stamps.

The Joseph J. Windle golf tournament, in memory of the father of Mrs. Josephine Windle Korber, executive secretary and tournament chairman of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, will be held on Tuesday over the famous Ridgewood Country Club course in Ridgewood, N.J.

Here is another galloping yarn about Peter Field's stock trio of rough and ready double-shooters: ingenious Pat Stevens, sharpshooter Sam Sloan and big one-eyed Ezra -- the heroes of Powder Valley, where they have settled to ranching.
LONDON, Sunday, May 24 (AP) -- Conflicting reports concerning Adolf Hitler's whereabouts reached London tonight.

For "distinguished service to the university," five New York University graduates have been selected as recipients of the 1942 Alumni Meritorious Service Awards, Dr. Chester F.S. Whitney, president of the Alumni Federation, announced yesterday. Those honored are:

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Asked for his opinion about the future of advertising under present conditions, Price Administrator Leon Henderson today declared that he had made his views clear to advertising men on many occasions and that they had not changed.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- Converted by a torrential rainfall into maelstroms of death and destruction, the usually picturesque streams of Central and Eastern Pennsylvania boiled over their banks in dozens of communities today to take a toll of at least twenty lives and millions of dollars in property damage.

Veterans of the Civil War, Spanish-American War and of World War I are scheduled to participate with detachments from the Army, Navy, Marine Corps, Coast Guard, Naval Militia and Naval Reserve and the New York Guard in Manhattan's Memorial Day parade next Saturday on Riverside Drive.

Prints by amateur photographers on the staff of WOR will be exhibited in the Grill Room of the Hotel Plaza beginning Tuesday, from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. A special section will be devoted to professional prints by Walter Engel, WOR staff photographer, Victor Keppler, John Muller and Alan Fisher.

The gradual increase in the tempo of the Russian fighting and the arrival of more American troops in Northern Ireland focused attention last week on probable Nazi moves in Europe and possible counter-operations of the United Nations.

Forty-five young Americans of Italian descent from the New York area who have been reported missing in the armed forces were honored last night by an audience of 2,000 at a concert presented at Carnegie Hall by the Grand Lodge of the State of New York of the Order of Sons of Italy in America.

The work of the National Refugee Service "is bearing fruit" in the many-sided refugee participation in the American war program, William Rosenwald, president of the organization, reported yesterday in a statement which was part of the service's third annual report.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- It started Monday, and by Wednesday people in many places in the country reported that you could "feel" it -- the wave of war optimism that rolled over the nation this week.

The importance of shade trees in maintaining property values, as well as general morale, is unquestioned. Recently, on this page, we urged the continued protection of trees which are a legacy from the past to be held in trust for future generations.

NOMINATED: Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania went down to his first political defeat last week. In the Republican race for his State's Gubernatorial nomination he lost by 94,000 votes to Major Gen. Edward Martin. As their candidate the Democrats chose Auditor General F. Clair Ross.

In the 169 days that the United States has been at war the Pan American Airways System has flown under Federal and military control 600 "major overseas flight assignments" throughout the world to average nearly four daily since Pearl Harbor, the airline announced yesterday.

QUEBEC -- Despite gasoline and tire restrictions, a successful season is expected here in so far as the United States Summer colony is concerned. While automobile travel will not be as great as in past years, it is expected that the customary members of the colony here will make their way to Quebec, to occupy their cottages and to spend the Summer far from the hustle and bustle of metropolitan centers.

THERE was considerable hilarity in baseball a couple of seasons ago when Ted Williams remarked carelessly that he would like to be a fireman. Just for that, J.J. Dykes borrowed a fire hose and a helmet and gave Theodore Samuel Williams a three-alarm welcome when the rich Red Sox arrived in Chicago some time later.

CHUNGKING, China, May 23 -- The immediate objective of the Japanese southwestward offensive in Chekiang Province is Kinhwa, a city formerly noted only for its delicious hams. Since the fall of Hangchow. Kinhwa has become a military, economic and communications center, constituting an important defense outpost in Southern Chekiang.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 23 -- More than 400 Cornell alumni registered for the war-curtailed reunion program today, preliminary to the university's seventy-fourth commencement Monday.

Wendell L. Willkie endorsed yesterday the opposition expressed by Thomas E. Dewey, probable Republican nominee for Governor in the Fall elections, to the renomination of Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., long assailed as an "isolationist," in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District up-State.

Details of the plan by which 2,000,000 American boys between the ages of 16 and 18, in 28,000 secondary schools throughout the country, are to be given pre-flight aviation training by the end of 1043 are ready and in the process of being carried out.
DECORATION DAY has long been the official start of the jaunting season, when Americans take to their cars and make for the open spaces -- with a picnic hamper conspicuous amid the luggage.

A Soviet official's call for a Western front against Hitler evoked enthusiastic applause as the Ambijan Committee for Emergency Aid to the Soviet Union yesterday presented a mobile X-ray unit to the Red Army. The ceremony took place in Columbus Circle before several hundred spectators.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, May 24 -- Determined to obtain what Fascist spokesmen call "the rightful fruits of victory" at the expense of Vichy and apparently backed by pronouncements of German officials during the last forty-eight hours, Italy early today -- on the eve of the twenty-seventh anniversary of her declaration of war against Austria and Germany in 1915 -- appeared about to make a desperate play against France.

OTTAWA, May 23 -- The "Quebec problem," which has a great many people in Canada very worried today, is nothing more nor less than the problem of the democratic right of speech and action within the law, according to Rene Chaloult, Liberal member for Lotbiniere in the Quebec Legislative Assembly.

That $1,200,000 has been subscribed in the last ten weeks to the Greater New York-USO-Joint War Appeal, which is seeking $4,500,000 here to carry on its work among the country's armed forces, was announced yesterday. The nation-wide goal is $32,000,000.
Because of the sinkings of Allied Nations' ships by German submarines the railroad manufacturers have embarked recently on a large-scale production of coal cars.

PITTSBURGH, May 23 (AP) -- Rookie Cully Rikard's single in a three-run eighth inning drove in two tallies and enabled the Pittsburgh Pirates to come from behind and eke out a 5-to-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 23 -- Less than forty-eight hours after British fighters shot down a German reconnaissance plane headed in the direction of Cairo, other defensive fighters this morning downed another Junkers 88 attempting to fly into the Nile Delta area.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 23 -- Frank Bedford and Stanley Calder became favorites to capture the Montclair Golf Club's annual member-guest invitation tournament today by winning the medal on a 70, and sweeping through their first match to a 5-and-4 victory.

Conspicuous among war covers for historical interest is one from Czernowitz, capital of Bukovina, formerly a province of Austria, and in a territory which has changed hands several times in recent years.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 23 -- Less than forty-eight hours after British fighters shot down a German reconnaissance plane headed in the direction of Cairo, other defensive fighters this morning downed another Junkers 88 attempting to fly into the Nile Delta area.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 23 -- Frank Bedford and Stanley Calder became favorites to capture the Montclair Golf Club's annual member-guest invitation tournament today by winning the medal on a 70, and sweeping through their first match to a 5-and-4 victory.

Conspicuous among war covers for historical interest is one from Czernowitz, capital of Bukovina, formerly a province of Austria, and in a territory which has changed hands several times in recent years.

The English vegetable marrow, a type of squash, might well be more extensively grown in American gardens. They are superior in many ways to our better known squashes. The squashes and the marrows belong to the same family and are closely allied, but the English marrows have a distinctive flavor and are very prolific.

CLASSICAL mythology has long needed such a popular exposition as Miss Edith Hamilton has given us in this volume, which is at once a reference book and a book which may be read for stimulation and pleasure.

THE "long way" of this Chinese autobiography is of course one of transition from old to new and from East to West, as well as of the young author's round-the-world sojourning. But she started well on the road to modernity; and in the most crucial stage of her progress old and new are in immediate, and somewhat surprising, conflict.

I am not a conscientious objector, nor do I think I could be if I were a man. But Robert van Gelder's article "The Men Who Refuse to Fight," in THE TIMES Magazine of May 10, makes me see red. I do not think it is worthy of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LONDON, May 23 -- With smoothness no one would have believed possible a year and a half ago, the London Stock Exchange carries on, taking each new war menace calmly and keeping a balanced view. Just when they looked most helpless things began to mend.

Topics this morning is glad to yield the floor to what it regards as an authentic voice of American youth today. It is an address delivered by Norman Phillip Ross of the class of '42 at Brown University at the commencement exercises early last week.

In his address last week before the National Industrial Conference Board Herbert Hoover said well, and sometimes eloquently, a number of things that needed to be said. But his speech contained two paragraphs which perhaps already the former President may wish he had omitted, or at least said in somewhat different form:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 23 -- War has added the study of protective concealment to the curriculum of the Department of Agriculture in the College of Fine Arts at Syracuse University, and advanced architecture students have just completed their first project in camouflage of typical military objectives.

THE United States is big -- over 3,000,000 square miles and 132,000,000 people; the United States is rich -- over 100,000,000 working hands and 200,000,000,000 of productive plant. The United States is richly endowed with nature's gifts -- so rich that what mattered waste when there always was more?

IT used to be "Any rags, any bones, any bottles today? It's the same old story in the same old way." But now it is a very different story. For the first time in our history as an industrial nation we are asked to organize our habits of throwing away. The junkman's cry has taken on a new briskness.

AT the sixty-ninth annual assembly, July 5-Aug. 30, at Chautauqua, N.Y., the musical program again will be under the direction of Albert Stoessel, who will lead the Chautauqua Orchestra in thirty-five concerts, at which numerous soloists will appear.

Arthur H. Wadsworth, deputy surveyor of customs attached to the boarding staff, retired last week after nearly forty-four years in the department. He has been one of the service's experts on the handling of baggage examination and for many years was an instructor in a school for inspectors about to enter the baggage division.

Stamps arriving from France afford the major interest among the past week's new issues. One is a semi-postal 2.50-francs plus 75-centimes blue with a portrait of Jean-Francois de Galaup, Comte de La Perouse, eighteenth-century French navigator, against the terrestrial globe as background, with a sailing vessel at either side.

Deliveries every other day and exchange of customers and routes to reduce mileage 25 per cent or more are among the plans of the milk industry in the metropolitan area for conservation of tires, fuel and equipment in compliance with regulations of the Office of Defense Transportation effective on June 1.

A California housewife and grandmother, who "ticked off" her fifty-ninth birthday this month just after crossing the Mexican border at Laredo, has just arrived here on the last lap of a 33,000-mile tour of South and Central America.

SUGAR, even when rationed, is more plentiful than it used to be. In the Englishspeaking world before 1750 it was classed as a medicine and a curiosity. Old-time cookbooks mentioned it not at all; when sweetening was needed, they called for honey.

The narrator of this story is Major Gen. Grady Root, United States Army, retired, a lonely old man who always refers to his wife, May, as being "away," although she has been dead three years. His narrative is addressed to her, and it is a running account of what happened to his neighbors and of the trial of Lieutenant David Kent for the murder of his wife, Hilda Fanshaw Kent.

OTHER New York museums have been active, too, or are about to bring forth major offerings. The Metropolitan opened with a private view on Wednesday (to the public Thursday) its large exhibition of "Modern British Crafts."

IT was in Berlin, in June, 1939. Prince Paul, Regent of Yugoslavia, was paying a state visit with Princess Olga to the German capital. In honor of his Balkan guests -- the first royalty formally to visit Greater Germany -- the Fuehrer was staging a military parade, which served the additional purpose of impressing the Yugoslav ruler and the world with German military might.
An appeal for more adults to be vaccinated against smallpox was broadcast yesterday morning from Station WOR by Dr. Samuel Frant, director of preventable diseases in the City Health Department.
FOUR PLAYS. By Lillian Hellman, 330 pages. New York: Modern Library. 95 cents.

The members of the American Women's Voluntary Services who are working as volunteers assisting the New York War Savings Staff of the United States Treasury Department will give the third and last of their Victory Forum Luncheons tomorrow at the Pierre. Previous luncheons in the series were held May 11 and 18.

BRAIN WAVES AND SIGHT -- That the brain gives off electric waves is now well known. With the waves it is often possible to detect masked epilepsy and even brain tumors. Dr. Frederick Lemere (Seattle) declares in The Journal of the American Medical Association that since certain fundamental waves called "alpha" are broken up when the eyes are open we have here a test for feigned and real blindness.

MOSCOW, May 23 -- Battles in the Izyum-Barvenkova sector south of Kharkov continue to rage, with fortune shifting from side to side, but the Germans, who had some initial success when they struck their shrewd blow, now are being held, it was reported here today.

A midnight ghost hunt in a cemetery ends in murder just as the ghost makes its appearance. The ghost is explained away almost immediately, but not the murder; any one of the ghost-hunting party could have done it. The party consists of Major and Mrs. Beau Richmond of Heron Point and Atlanta and their house guests.

"VENETIAN ADVENTURER" is the first book to offer a full and living re-creation of that legendary yet vitally real and important thirteenth-century hero, Marco Polo. And to appreciation of a work of notable scholarship must at once be added the happiest welcome for a piece of fascinating reading.
We at the Lighthouse were particularly amused by the posters of "The Tokyo Kid" used in the Douglas Aircraft Corporation, which appeared in the Magazine.

AN American tradition in the composition of opera is now in process of formation. This tradition has taken a long time to get started -- there has been lots of talk about how much more opera we should write than we do and how much better it should be than it is.

LONDON, May 23 -- A ban on strong language and abolition of "hate schools" have been ordered by Lieut. Gen. Sir Bernard C. Paget, Commander in Chief of the Home Forces, in a letter circulated to all army commands, and which was read today at the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland in Edinburgh.

ABOARD A WARSHIP With the United States Pacific Fleet (Delayed) -- Striking at Japanese forces that attempted to establish bases in New Guinea, air forces of the United States Fleet halted the move and destroyed or crippled ten enemy vessels on March 10.

The famous stamp collection of the late Colonel E.H.R. Green is to be placed on the auction market by the Chase National Bank, ex ecutors of the estate, it was learned last week. Assembled across many years and containing some of philately's great rarities, the collection is owned by Mrs. Matthew Astor Wilks, Colonel Green's sister and daughter of the late Mrs. Hetty Green.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Explaining that "considerable confusion" has been caused in business circles by speculations about the announcement that WPB is considering action to require stores to reduce their stocks to "practicable working minimums," the War Production Board's Division of Industry Operations today asserted that no definite decisions on the point have been reached.

IT seems to be a matter of philanthropy on the part of John Golden, his bringing "Claudia" back to Broadway tonight at a $1.65 top. He prefers to call it "an extension of democracy." But whatever it is termed, Mr. Golden will hardly grow rich out of the return engagement, even if it goes over the two weeks to which it is "strictly limited.

THE Gay Way is dark, but still White -- indoors. You go down to Billy Rose's Diamond Horseshoe in Forty-sixth Street and lights shine with accustomed brilliance, patrons' hubbub washes up the stairs to engulf you. On the Astor Roof, when you step across the threshold, light is still effulgent, music lively, laughter high as before the dimout. War has driven the Gay Way indoors.

ONCE more -- and now we're getting desperate -- this corner feels compelled to protest against the delay and seeming vagueness of the government and the film industry in setting the cameras to turning on an organized program of war information shorts.

A TRIM little woman from Texas is preparing to pick 400 women from all over America as the first group of officer candidates for the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps. She is Oveta Culp Hobby, Director of the WAAC, and she prefers not to have a photograph taken of her smiling because she fears that a light-hearted appearance might reflect on the seriousness and dignity of her organization.

OTTAWA -- Wartime travel restrictions will give an impetus to fishing, with holiday seekers spending less time on the road and more at resorts, many of them in good fishing areas. Canada has nearly 200,000 square miles of fresh water, not including the Great Lakes.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Anxiety over the impact on the "little fellow" of income-tax coltion at the source, as well as a possible sales tax, was reported today to have created strong sentiment in the House Ways and Means Committee for retention of present personal income-tax exemptions.

BONNEVILLE, Ore., May 23 -- Both friends and foes of the power policy of the Roosevelt Administration expressed approval when the Bonneville Power Administration announced recently that 30 per cent of America's expanded aluminum program will be produced by hydro-electricity generated at the mammoth Federal projects on the Columbia river.

Miss Ruth Ayres and Dr. Persia Campbell, club leaders who are giving their time to direct official programs of consumer strategy for victory, have devised a formula to be followed by women's clubs in this area in winning the contest against inflation.
POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- The Memorial Day week-end is to be celebrated at each of the leading hotels of the Pocono Mountains region with elaborate entertainment programs.

By coincidence, the National Park Service drops an alluring leaflet on newspaper desks just as gasoline rationing shows its teeth, the Government shoos uncalled-for civilians off the airlines, and there are grim whisperings about curtailment of train service. The one on this desk celebrates the charms of the Fort Laramie National Monument in Wyoming.

LONDON, May 23 -- Fortified by lease-lend in terms of mechanized equipment, Britain has plowed up more acres this Spring than ever before. The production of food for this island, which cannot feed itself, is the first line of defense. But there is no hope that it will answer the greater problem of a balanced diet, which is now giving Britain's doctors cause for quietly contained but deeply felt concern.
DURHAM, N.H., May 23 -- A workshop in elementary education is but one of several innovations announced for the 1942 Summer School of the University of New Hampshire.

PORTLAND, Ore. -- The most extraordinary vacation season in the history of the Pacific Northwest is about to begin. It will be a season limited by gasoline rationing and tire shortages, yet resort centers in the uplands and mountains expect more visitors than ever before.

Because the Japanese swarming over Malaya and Java and the German submarines marauding off the Atlantic Coast have shot some of the wheels out from under a motorized America, many United States war plants are threatened with serious disruption of labor supply among employes accustomed to driving to work.

NOW that the season is over, technically speaking, it is time to begin looking backward to see what it has accomplished and whether ground has been gained or lost. That will take some unusually careful doing, for this is the first war year since the dance has come of age in America.

Chsrles Henri Ford, 360 East Fifty-fifth Street, New York City, is editing a special number of his magazine View, under the general heading of "Americana Fantastica." It would be of particular interest to him to publish letters or manuscripts of Edgar Allan Poe and of Herman Melville, in case there are any in museums or private collections which have not been published s.nd which would be suitable to this special number of View.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 23 -- While official dignitaries have been protesting to Washington the rank and file of folks in the Southeast have accepted gasoline rationing with pretty much the mental attitude of the six hundred at Balaklava.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 22 -- Merwin L. Bohan, head of the United States economic mission to Bolivia, left last night for a four-day tour of rubber districts in Northeastern Bolivia before flying for the United States by way of Para, Brazil.

Columbia College class day ceremonies will be held at 10:30 A.M. on Monday, June 1, the day before the university commencement exercises, Dean Herbert E. Hawkes announced yesterday. The recipients of seven prizes, to be awarded on class day, also were announced.

Ignorance of the rule that silver outranks gold in the Army caused a man who described himself as Clarence Mullins, 39 years old, of 28-97 West Eighth Street, Coney Island, to be held in $10,000 bail for trial after he had been arraigned last night in Brooklyn-Queens Night Court on a charge of impersonating an officer of the Air Forces.
ALBANY, May 23 -- Governor Lehman, with the thirty-day bill period ending at midnight tomorrow, vetoed today two of the principal non-defense measures passed by the Legislature.

THE TIMES'S story "'Real Guy' Praised for Work in Raid," a most interesting first-hand story of an American bomber versus Japanese Zeros, tells among other things the vivid recollections Lieutenant Kahle retains of a raid. Among them was the gesticulation with a toothbrush made by his co-pilot, Lieutenant Carl King, who, it appears, carries a toothbrush in his mouth while flying -- but no one, including Lieutenant King, knows why.

LONDON, May 23 -- Fortified by lease-lend in terms of mechanized equipment, Britain has plowed up more acres this Spring than ever before. The production of food for this island, which cannot feed itself, is the first line of defense. But there is no hope that it will answer the greater problem of a balanced diet, which is now giving Britain's doctors cause for quietly contained but deeply felt concern.
DURHAM, N.H., May 23 -- A workshop in elementary education is but one of several innovations announced for the 1942 Summer School of the University of New Hampshire.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (U.P.) -Ralph W. Close, Minister to Washington for the Union of South Africa, said tonight that the United States took a "tremendous step toward winning the war" last week when the Ford Motor Company's new Willow Run plant began turning out bombers on a mass-production basis.

Two New York City fresh water anglers and one from New Rochelle have entries that are leading in the Southern New York Fish and Game Association's contest this month for rainbow, brown and lake trout.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- When applying for sugar for home canning of fruits, housewives should be prepared to supply information on the volume of their preserves last year as well as current plans, the Consumer Division of the Office of Price Administration announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau announced today that the offering of up to $1,151,000,000 of new government securities in exchange for series G bonds of the Home Owners' Loan Corporation of 1942-44 and series S notes of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, due on July 1, would consist of 1 1/2 per cent Treasury notes, series B, due in 1946.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- The united States does not need totalitarianism to concentrate on winning the war, Wendell L. Willkie said today in an address at the annual Founders Day exercises at Eagleville Sanitorium, near Norristown. Hailing the success of the nation's present production-control system, he insisted that civil liberties must not be banished.

NASSAU, Bahamas, May 24 (U.P.) -- The Duke of Windsor, Governor of the Bahamas, told the islanders in an Empire Day radio address today that the economic investigation committee, of which he is chairman, had outlined a plan for a labor training camp on the western end of New Providence Island, where more than 200 persons would be employed on agricultural projects.

Although they were prepared for a partial awakening of the New York City public to the need for darkened windows, department stores hardly foresaw the land-office business that accompanied the city-wide blackout demonstrations of the last months.

ALBANY, May 24 -- New York State embarked today as a war step on a home relief policy of "work or don't eat." The policy became effective when Governor Lehman signed the Moffat bill, which provides, for the first time since public relief was legalized in 1931 under the Wicks law, that persons who refuse work because it is easier to be on home relief face a loss of their allowances.

The French Embassy in Italy was established in the most magnificent of Roman palaces, the splendid pile erected for the Farnese family by Sangallo and Michelangelo in the old square between the flower market and the Tiber. The Academy of France occupied another famous house, built with its lovely green gardens on the finest site in the Eternal City.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The "Spring offensive" staged by nature in the United States this year has been "the most devastating combination of natural disasters" encountered by the American Red Cross in its sixty-one years of relief work and has cost that organization more than $1,000,000 for relief and rehabilitation, Chairman Norman H. Davis stated today.

In accord with an anti-Fascist mass meeting of Russian Jews in Moscow yesterday, the Jewish Council for Russian War Relief here held three meetings to foster solidarity and transmit the greetings of American Jews to their coreligionists in the Soviet Union.

ALBANY, May 24 -- Retail stores in New York State increased workers 0.7 per cent and payrolls 1.0 per cent from the middle of March to the middle of April, according to a report by Frieda S. Miller, Industrial Commissioner, made public today. Wholesale concerns reported further reductions of 1.4 per cent in employment and 0.4 per cent in the payrolls in the same period.

For heroism above and beyond the call of duty, fifteen men and two officers of the Fire Department were cited yesterday by Commissioner Patrick Walsh for the 1941 departmental awards. Another officer was named for an award for having the best disciplined company.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Prices of lard on the Board of Trade here dropped last week below ceiling levels for the first time since last March, scattered liquidation developing on reports that the Office of Price Administration would make a downward revision in the ceiling price on refined lard and that the government had asked that offers for lease-lend purposes be cut by 1 cent a pound.

CHUNGKING, China, May 24 -On one of the last of the big parade of thousands of trucks evacuating lease-lend supplies to cross the Salween bridge before it was dynamited to halt the pursuing Japanese was Carl R. Myers, who has just arrived in Chungking.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, May 25. -- Reports received from Moscow this morning said that a German force had been compelled to withdraw after having struck with tanks at the Russian lines north of Zmiyev, on the Kharkov front.
JERSEY CITY, May 24 (AP) -Jersey City and Syracuse divided a double-header today, the Little Giants winning, 3 to 2, then losing, 2 to 0.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- According to high labor authorities, President Roosevelt must not expect that organic labor unity between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations will be achieved by the six men he named last January to the combined labor victory board.

NOUMEA, New Caledonia, May 24 (U.P.) -- Woolly-haired Melanesian natives of New Caledonia in large numbers have all but formally enlisted in the United States Army that is shaping this 250-mile-long French island into another South Pacific bastion against the Japanese.

The self-contradictions in the Government's censorship and morale policies were never sharper than in the week just passed. The President on Friday warned the country that this was going to be a long war, and deplored the recent "wave of optimism" that had swept over the country, declaring that there was no special reason for it.

It is difficult for an America accustomed to swiftly rolling transportation to find any bright spots in gasoline rationing. But there are some benefits in this enforced conservation that may have a useful long-range effect. We are learning that high speed in spurts, and even sustained speed in the higher brackets, does not save so very much time but does impose a heavy drain from the point of view of cost and wear.

BOSTON, May 24 -- Daniel L. Marsh, president of Boston University, called for more thought of tomorrow's world in his seventeenth consecutive baccalaureate sermon today. He addressed the graduating class of 1,452 members in the Boston Arena.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices advanced from 106.3 to 106.6. Decreases in the price of grains and steers were outweighed by increases in other livestock, poultry, fruits, eggs, and potatoes, raising the raw materials index 0.5 per cent and the farm products index 0.9 per cent.
WASHINGTON, May 23 The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period May 16 to 22 were as follows:

VICHY, May 24 -- The statement of condition of the Bank of France dated April 23 shows that funds supplied to the securities market have not varied greatly. Declines of 52,000,000 francs in bills discounted, of 55,000,000 in advances on securities and of 144,000,000 in short-term advances on bonds were compensated approximately by the increase of 236,000,000 francs in bills purchased on the open market.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Ambassadors, Foreign Ministers and representatives of seventeen of the United Nations will attend the annual dinner here of the American Palestine Committee tomorrow night.

Allen Wardwell, newly elected chairman of the city campaign for Russian War Relief, knows at first hand the terrible impact of war on the Russian people. He was a member of th American Red Cross mission to Russia in 1917 and 1918 and last Fall visited Moscow again as head of the Red Cross delegation with the Harriman mission.
James G. Blaine, chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, emphasized the need for enrollment of volunteers in vital war services yesterday.

BOSTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Red Sox finally broke the spell the Athletics had been holding over them, winning, 6 -- 5, today in a game abbreviated to eight innings by the Sunday law after the Mackmen had overcome a five-run deficit to capture the opener by the same score.

BUFFALO, May 24 (AP) -- Curtiss-Wright Corporation's giant C-46 Army cargo plane, now in mass production, was formally named today "Curtiss-Commando" at ceremonies witnessed by thousands of the company's workers.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 24 (U.P.) -Henry F. Grady, chairman of a United States technical mission to India, revealed today on his arrival here en route home that the United Nations plan to help India increase her war production to the point where she can supply allied forces in the Middle East.

The skills of the thousands of refugees here should be utilized in the nation's war machine, Albert Abrahamson, executive director of the National Refugee Service, declared yesterday at the third annual meeting of the agency at the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 24 -On instructions from Washington the Office of Price Administration's ceiling rules were temporarily reversed in Puerto Rico today following a united protest from organized merchants that the law compelled them "to buy high and sell low."

The twelve-story store and loft building on a plot 85 by 98 feet at 31 East Thirty-first Street has been sold by the Harlem Savings Bank to the 31 East Thirty-first Street Corporation, represented by Moreau Yeomans, attorney, for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $325,000. Bastine Co. were the brokers in the sale, the bank represented by Charles S. Fettretch, attorney.
PITTSBURGH, May 24 (AP) -- The Pirates dismayed 16,746 fans today by dropping a double-header to the Cubs, losing, 7 -- 5, in ten innings and absorbing an 11-4 defeat in the afterpiece.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., May 24 -- Seventy-eight honors and prizes were presented today at exercises of the Peddie School opening the institution's seventy-seventh commencement program. The graduation ceremony will be held on June 1.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- Definite opposition to the rationing of gasoline in the Middle West at this time was announced today by Frank Phillips, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Committee for District 2.

NEW ORLEANS, May 24 -- Selling of contracts for future deliveries of cotton, based largely on the theory that imposition of a general price ceiling had taken the edge off bullish enthusiasm, and also on fears that the farm bloc in Congress might weaken in its defense of parity prices, accounted last week for losses of $2.15 to $2.35 a bale in cotton here by the close of trading on Thursday.

MOSCOW, Monday, May 25 -Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's armies of the Ukraine are waging fierce defensive battles against attacking German tank and infantry forces in the Izyum-Barvenkova sector, south of Kharkov, the Russian High Command announced today.

MORGAN CITY, La., May 24 (AP) -- A brown-eyed, dimpled cheeked gir of 11 sat on the edge of her mother's hospital bed here today and calmly flipped her yo-yo as she told how seamen beat off sharks that tickled her feet while she rode a hatch in the Gulf of Mexico after Axis submarines torpedoed and sank the vessel she was aboard.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP) -The Braves advanced to second place by dividing a double-header with the Phils today. After losing, 3 -- 2, in eleven innings, Boston took the second game, 6 -- 3, in regulation time.

MILWAUIKEE, May 24 -- Racial barriers in American industry were denounced by Dr. Robert W. Searle of New York at a meeting today in connection with the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.

BERLIN, May 24 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The German Army has encircled strong Soviet forces south of Khark0v, thwarted all their efforts to break out and blocked all attempts to relieve them from the outside, the High Command announced today.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, May 24 (U.P.) -- "Lend us a hand -- the front is on fire!" the old manager of a 7,000-acre collective farm in the Volga district exclaimed to visiting American correspondents during a discussion of agricultural conditions.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Blocks of "duration dormitories," temporary in structure but affording essential accommodations, will soon be started in crowded war work areas as an answer to critical building material shortages, the Federal Public Housing Authority disclosed today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, May 25 (AP) -- An Allied ship under attack by Japanese planes several hundred miles off Australia caught fire when an enemy craft, winged by anti-aircraft shells, crashed amidships, General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Roosevelt will be asked this week to create a four-member board to determine Federal policy on wage increases offered voluntarily by employers or negotiated with labor unions without recourse to the National War Labor Board.

The fortunes of war veered sharply to the stronger party yesterday at the Polo Grounds, and when that happens there usually can be only one result. The Dodgers walloped the Giants, 6 to 0, before a gathering of 50,363, including 1,055 service men, and thus, in grabbing the series final, gained some measure of recompense for having dropped the first two encounters to Mel Ott's men.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Yankees had their Sunday pitcher on the mound at Griffith Stadium today without his Sunday pitch. So the world champions' winning streak of four straight was snapped as the Senators clubbed their way to victory before 15,000 fans. The count was 9 to 8.

Six, and possibly seven, new films will reach Broadway during the week. The Capitol was undecided yesterday as to whether it would hold over its current attraction, "The Spoilers," or bring in the new George Raft melodrama, "Broadway," this Thursday. Definitely scheduled are the following:
CAIRO, Egypt, May 24 (AP) -- Today's Middle East R.A.F. communique follows:

"Abide with me! Fast falls the eventide" is one of the most beloved of English hymns. It has been translated into many languages. Its words of sorrow and hope are in the memory of millions. In this time of war they have an added significance. They were written by the Rev. Henry Francis Lyte, a clergyman of the Church of England.

While in England recently on a food mission I had occasion to read dispatches from two of your usually careful and authoritative correspondents which I think tended to give to American people a very erroneous impression of the actual situation with respect to public attitudes concerning wartime regulations in the United Kingdom.
MODESTO, Calif., May 24 (AP) -Cornelius Warmerdam, king of pole vaulters, set a new unofficial world record last night with a mark of 15 feet 7 3/4 inches at the North California Relays.

TOKYO, May 24 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Japanese army planes operating over Eastern Chekiang Province in China have executed more than 100 attacks on Chinese bases, and have staged thirty machine gun and bombing assaults against retreating Chinese forces, Domei said today.

In celebration of its fiftieth anniversary, the Hebrew Free Loan Society of New York, named by the late Jacob H. Schiff "The Poor Man's Bank," yesterday issued a brochure under that title describing its history.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Smooth relations between labor and management, ingenious application of mass production methods, effective use of women workers and a driving zeal for victory have sent war production on the West Coast leaping forward at an "astonishing" rate, William P. Witherow, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, stated today at a press conference.
ALBANY, May 24 -- Governor Lehman took two parting shots at the Republican-controlled Legislature today as he acted on several important measures passed at the recent session.
Nothing is more pleasing to fond parents than to see their characteristics reproduced in their young hopefuls.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 24 -The status quo of Franco-Italian relations continued to hang by a thread, according to information reaching informed diplomatic quarters here late tonight. Last night's expectations of important developments within forty-eight hours persisted.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- About 17,000 employes in eight Midwestern plants of the International Harvester Company today approved overwhelmingly the "maintenance of-union-membership" plan authorized by the War Labor Board in the first such decision of its kind.

The 390 air raid sirens installed by the city will be tested at noon Saturday and the test will be repeated on successive Saturdays at the same hour until further notice, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio "Talk to the People," broadcast from his desk at City Hall via WNYC, the municipal radio station.

KEY WEST, Fla., May 24 (AP) -A submarine crewman waved the Nazi flag and gave the German salute to United States seamen swimming for their lives in the Caribbean Sea after their merchant ship was torpedoed off the tip of Cuba May 18.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 24 -- If Corporal Vic Ghezzi, on leave from Fort Monmouth for the duration of the Professional Golfers Association championship, can maintain the form he displayed playing the last two practice rounds over the Seaview course today, he is apt to make trouble for any one disputing his way to another title.

To the accompaniment of joyous chanting and a six-hour banquet, Father Divine dedicated yesterday his new $60,000 community center at 15 West 128th Street. A five-story brick and stone building, the center will be operated as a combination day nursery, low-cost restaurant, home for the aged and training school.

Most branches of the apparel and dry goods trades were still inactive, with ceiling prices undetermined, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. One of the few exceptions noted was in drapery piece goods, where adoption of ceilings resulted in lowering prices by 5 per cent on the average.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 24 -- "It has been the attitude of many people to sympathize with the present young generation because of the apparently bleak future that lies ahead. Personally, I envy you," Vice Admiral Harry E. Yarnell, U.S.N., retired, told the seniors this afternoon at Clark College's commencement exercises.

The annual memorial services of the United Spanish War Veterans were held yesterday in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Participating in the ceremonies were 150 veteran sailors, soldiers and marine of the Spanish-American War.

LEWISTON, Me., May 24 -- Speaking at commencement exercises today at Bates College, where he received an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws, Jan Masaryk, Foreign Minister and Vice Premier of the Czechoslovak Government-in-Exile, declared that the United Nations must keep on multiplying their material resources and moral efforts until victory was complete and unconditional.

MOSCOW, Monday, May 25 -After two days spent in consolidating captured positions, Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's men on the Kharkov front have resumed their advance, the Russians announced today. A communique says that an important place has been recaptured by Russian troops.

ST. LOUIS, May 24 (AP) -- In one of the finest pitching exhibitions of the year, Johnny Vander Meer and Ray Starr put the skids under the Cardinals today as the Reds won a double-header, 3 to 2 and 2 to 0.
LONDON, May 24 -- A cheerful tone continued last week to characterize the stock markets here, with improvement in the price structure derived less from business expansion than from sentiment.
The first ORT training school for Jewish refugees in North America will be opened on Friday in Canada, George Backer, president of the American ORT Federation, announced yesterday.

As the third title in the American Association for the Advancement of Science series, Doubleday, Doran will publish Friday "Alcohol Explored," by H.W. Haggard and E.M. Jellinek. It deals with the subject's physiological, social and economic aspects.

NORTH HILLS, L.I., May 24 -Fifteen hundred Danes and Norwegians assembled this afternoon at Northcourt, the estate of Frederick Lunning, for a song festival, which was broadcast to the Scandinavian countries through the facilities of NBC.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- An all-star baseball team managed by Dizzy Dean, former Cardinal and Cub hurler, was defeated, 3 -- 1, today by the Kansas City Monarchs, a Negro club, led by Satchel Paige, who pitched seven innings.
George Winthrop Haight, attorney for the Shell Oil Company, has leased a large apartment in the building at 156 East Seventy-ninth Street through N.A. Berwin Co., and Clifford Roberts, brokers.
