BRUNSWICK, Me., May 24 -- Crushed and bewildered peoples who continue to think in terms of liberty after their lands have been invaded are examples for free men everywhere, Dr. Kenneth C.M. Sills, president of Bowdoin College, told the graduating class at baccalaureate exercises in the First Parish Church today.

Sunday motor traffic around New York showed a heavy slump for the second week yesterday as a result of gasoline rationing. An exception was noted in the Bear Mountain and Palisades Interstate Park region.

LONDON, May 24 -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, American commander of the Chinese troops fighting in Burma until virtually all organized resistance there came to an end this month, has arrived in New Delhi, India. Two reasons might account for his being at British Imperial headquarters rather than Chungking:

Dunkerque and Pentecost are "two resembling episodes," the Rev. John T.C. Laughton, British naval chaplain, said in a sermon yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.
LONDON, May 24 -- Even in wartime it is pretty hard to change the eating habits of a nation by propaganda. The British do not give up deep-rooted prejudices easily.

CHICAGO, May 24 -Prices of oats on the Board of Trade here declined last week to the lowest level since last November. Liquidation in the May delivery caused general selling of the deferred months, and at one time the active futures were about 4 cents a bushel below the final quotations of the previous week.
BALTIMORE, May 24 (AP) -Power hitting marked the double-header today in which the Orioles came from behind to beat Newark, 13 to 8, in the opener, while the Bears won the nightcap, 7 to 6.
ST. LOUIS, May 24 -- Another type of experimental rubberless tire, having steel-rimmed wooden wheels, has been found "satisfactory" by the operator of a fleet of St. Louis newspaper delivery trucks.

CHUNGKING, China, May 24 -An estimated 100,000 Japanese battered from three directions today at Chinese defenses in the outskirts of Kinhwa, provisional capital and railway center of Chekiang Province, 185 miles southwest of Shanghai, in the heaviest fighting in East Asia in five years.

A sparkling bit of passing with two minutes remaining averted defeat for the Club Atlante at Randalls Island yesterday and gave Mexico's soccer champions a 3-all tie with a metropolitan All-Star team in the opener of their United States tour.

One thousand persons, among them many civic, communal and religious leaders, paid tribute to Dr. Mordecai M. Kaplan for his forty-year leadership in American Jewish religious and educational life, at a dinner in his honor at the Hotel Commodore last night.

PITTSBURGH, May 24 -- The steelmakers of Pittsburgh, whose furnaces never cease to pour out great clouds of smoke over the valley of the Monongahela these days, say they are confident that the steel industry can overcome obstacles and provide the armed forces with all the steel that is needed.

William Gillette's old farce, "All the Comforts of Home," in which Henry Miller and Maude Adams had the leading roles when it first was produced on Broadway in 1890 and which hasn't been seen hereabouts since 1901, will be presented by Edith C. Ringling of the circus family and Mollie B. Steinberg tonight at the Longacre Theatre.

For the second time in its history of nearly a hundred years, the American Car and Foundry Company is employing women in heavy manufacturing, it disclosed yesterday. These women are helping to produce light combat tanks, which are coming off the line "at an unbelievable rate," according to Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell.

The imminent removal by the Germans of Pierre Laval as Chief of Government at Vichy, as 90 per cent of the people in both unoccupied and occupied France refused to "collaborate" with Adolf Hitler, was predicted in private advices from Europe re ceived yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 24 -"Galveston," a photoplay with the great flood as its climax, will be Dorothy Lamour's next vehicle at Paramount, the studio has announced. Robert Pirosh is preparing the scenario and Sol C. Siegel will produce the film in color.
LONDON, May 24 (AP) -- Londoners felt satisfied that as the first year of clothing rationing drew to a close there had been a more equitable distribution of the things they needed to wear.

LONDON, May 24 -- Two mass meetings today, attended by thousands of persons, urged the British Government to open up a second front in Europe with all possible speed as a way of assuring victory this year.

LONDON, May 24 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 110.7 on May 12. This compares with 110.6 a fortnight before, 110.3 a month before -- at which figure it had stood since March 3 -- 104.6 a year before and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

CHICAGO, May 23 -Liquidation was on last week in the wheat market on the Board of Trade and prices of that grain fell to the lowest levels since late last November. Numerous stop-loss orders were uncovered on the way down. The May future, trading in which ceased on last Thursday, sold down to $1.17 3/4 a bushel at one time, showing a decline of more than 16 cents from the recent high point.

A public offering of $12,000,000 of ten-year 2 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., will be made today by an underwriting group headed by Lehman Brothers at 100 and accrued interest from May 1. Net proceeds of the issue, amounting to $11,750,000 after expenses, will be used to discharge debt of the company to the extent that cash funds and cash requirements will permit.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -The War Department announced tonight an Army plane crashed on a "routine" flight near Houlton, Me., today, killing five officers and a sergeant.

SCHENECTADY, May 24 -- The Affiliated Young Democrats, Inc., of New York State, in the final session of its two-day meeting today, declined to endorse any candidate for the nomination for Governor but instead adopted unanimously a resolution which advanced a list of eight possibilities for Governor, seven for Lieutenant Governor and ten for Attorney General.

SOMETHING may come of the meeting of Lou Nova and Lee Savold in Washington, D.C., tonight. That is, if they do get together in the ring. The affair suffered two postponements on account of something not broadcast at the time because it might have been useful to the enemy. But it's safe to state now that the cause of the postponements of this outdoor bout was not dry rot.

ALL too often the explorers, soldiers, traders and pioneers who led the vanguard of this nation's westward expansion have been represented in literature by lurid adventure stories for boys and the buckskin heroics of crudely competent historical novels. Recently scholarly research has been devoted to the subject, but much of it has been published by the university presses with little popular acclaim.

Taking stock of the effect and position of the Christian religion in the world today, the Rev. Dr. Jesse M. Bader, in a guest sermon yesterday morning in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, admitted that the church was "short on power," but emphasized that "anything is possible" in a church where the presence of the Holy Spirit was dominant.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 24 -- Envisioning "the new world" after the war as a place where all peoples must live in friendly neighborliness, the Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick, minister of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, New York City, declared today in his baccalaureate sermon at Cornell University that a lasting peace must be based on "a genuine sharing of life, people with people."

An exhibition of defense photography by members of the American Women's Voluntary Services will open today and continue through June 1 at the Camera Club of New York, 121 West Sixty-eighth Street, according to an announcement yesterday by George Haas, print director of the club.

Continued uncertainty over pending agricultural legislation caused prices of cotton to decline sharply last week. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts showed net losses of 28 to 33 points. At the low point for the week prices were down 54 to 59 points.
MOSCOW, May 24 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:
CLEVELAND, May 24 (AP) -- The Indians booted away a pair of games to the Browns today, 3 to 2 and 4 to 1.

ALBANY, May 24 -- The double taxation of odd-lot trading on the New York Stock Exchange and other security exchanges will end on July 1. Years of agitation for the abolition of the tax, in so far as it involves double taxation came to an end today as Governor Lehman signed the Coudert bill, effecting that purpose.

The dead of World War I were honored yesterday at Memorial Day exercises throughout the city, the first to be held in wartime in twenty-four years. Memorial Day does not fall until next Saturday, but many organizations observe it on the preceding Sunday.

Detailed plans for the "New York at War" parade, in which 500,000 persons are expected to march up Fifth Avenue on June 13, were announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's Committee for the Mobilization of New York at War.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- The Tigers swept a double-header with the White Sox, 6 to 2 and 14 to 0, before 19,198 today and took third place. Rookie Hal White shut out the Chicagoans for the second time this season. Detroit got twenty-five hits, twenty-one of them singles.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Lou Nova, California boxer, will undertake tomorrow night to fight his way back into the heavyweight championship picture. The husky from Alameda is to battle Lee Savold, rugged young giant from Des Moines, in a ten-round bout arranged by Promoter Mike Jacobs of New York in the interests of the Navy Relief Society.

A WEST RUSSIAN AIRFIELD, May 24 -- "We like the American Airacobras, Kittyhawks and Tomahawks and we would like to have more of them," declared Colonel Nestor Demidoff, slim, dark and smiling commander of an air group that uses American planes.

UTICA, N.Y., May 24 -- Miss Frances K. Marlatt, of Mount Vernon, was elected president of the State Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs at its convention yesterday at the Hotel Utica.

TEANECK, N.J., May 24 -While their pilots parachuted safely to earth, two Army planes fell 10,000 feet here this morning, the wreckage ruining two cars in a garage, setting a house on fire and spattering the neighborhood with fragments of metal.

Today's dictators will be as unsuccessful in their "furious attempts" to destroy the Christian Church as all others who have made similar attempts since the Risen Christ formally established His Church on the first Pentecost, nearly 2,000 years ago, the Rev. Thomas J. McCarty of Philadelphia, Superior of the Mission Band of the Congregation of the Holy Ghost, declared yesterday at pontificial mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 24 -In the final workout of the sailing craft ready for the Yacht Racing Association's championship season, which will open on Saturday, twenty-three sloops competed on Long Island Sound today off the Larchmont Yacht Club. Many others, not completely tuned up, winged along with them, keeping a respectful distance.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 24 -- The State Merchant Fleet said today that the small Argentine steamer Rio Iguazu had picked up fifty-three persons at sea and newspaper reports declared the rescued were sailors from a United States warship of unstated size.

While priorities rear their ugly heads on every side, on one point, at least, we can speak with reassurance -- the woman of 1943 need not appear with hair as straight and stark as nature made it. Curls can still be achieved -- without machinery, without metal, without anything even remotely connected with the conduct of a war. There are, at this writing, two new kinds of non-priority permanent and one revolutionary finger-wave.

Admonishing the public that temporary suspension of radio broadcasting by the Interceptor Command should not be construed as an air raid alert warning, Major Gen. Follett Bradley, commanding the First Air Force, said yesterday that last Tuesday's practice alert showed the air defense system here worked well "except for a few rough spots."

Former Postmaster General James A. Farley said: "We can make it our business to be on God's side in this war," in an address in the Hotel Astor yesterday at the communion breakfast of 1,400 members of the postoffice branch of the St. George Association, a Protestant Episcopal organization.

HONESDALE, Pa., May 24 -The toll of lives taken by the widespread series of flash floods which ravaged large areas of Eastern Pennsylvania yesterday mounted past thirty today as tens of thousands of sufferers, with high spirit, set about restoring order from the chaos left by the receding rivers.

MEXICO CITY, May 24 -- A crowd filling the side of the Central Plaza occupied by the Presidential Palace responded this morning to the invitation of the official political party, the Confederation of Labor and other organizations to demonstrate against the Axis on the occasion of the arrival of survivors of the Potrero del Llano, first Mexican ship to be sunk by an Axis submarine.

LONDON, May 24 -- A survey showed today that there are many coal miners on strike in various parts of Britain demanding higher pay. One unofficial estimate placed the figure of idle miners at 15,000 -- this at a time when the coal shortage is so acute that government authorities are considering coal rationing as well as reorganization of the entire industry.

A mediated peace, with Pope Pius XII umpiring the rival claims in an effort to "establish a peace based on justice," was urged by the Rev. Aloysius McDonough, professor of theology at the Passionist Monastery at Jamaica, Queens, in an address yesterday to 3,200 members of the Department of Sanitation Holy Name Society of Brooklyn and Queens at a communion breakfast in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Secretary Jones said today that he hoped, and expected, the United States could produce 300,000 to 350,000 tons of synthetic rubber during 1943.

WASHINGTON, May 24 Congress enters this week on the first of a series of unofficial Summer "recesses" to allow members to take part in the primary elections which will be held in the next three months.

Likening Japan's successes to a "skyrocket that has reached the top of its flight," Harold A. Sweet, an American aviator who left the Far East last Sunday, declared yesterday that the Japanese would be stopped before they reached either India or Australia.

WATERVILLE, Me., May 2 -- Soon to exchange their academic "mortar-boards" far steel helmets, and nurses' or WAAC caps, 140 Colby seniors afternoon heard Governor Saltonstall of Massachusetts tell them to "Pitch in!"

Bozo, a year-old African chimpanzee that made a perilous three weeks' crossing of the Atlantic last month, gave a two-and-one-halfhour show yesterday to hundreds of persons who happened to be passing the pet shop of Henry Trefflich at 215 Fulton Street.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 24 (AP) -Axis airports, motor transport and shipping in the Cyrenaican area were heavily attacked by British bombers and fighters yesterday in a burst of widespread raiding, the Royal Air Force reported tonight.

TRENTON, N.J., May 24 -- Labor's Nonpartisan League of New Jersey today became the American Labor League of New Jersey when delegates to its sixth annual convention unanimously voted to change the name "so that all organizations can participate in an organization which is independent of John L. Lewis and the organization he represents today."

The influence of air power upon sea power has completely changed the naval program of the United States in six months of war, has hastened the adoption of an aircraft carrier construction program of very great size, and has forced the Navy to shift its emphasis from a traditional dependence upon flying boats to land-based bombers and reconnaissance planes.
HONESDALE, Pa., May 24 -The dead in the Pennsylvania flash floods include the following:

LONDON, May 24 -- Already inroads are being made into the recent increase of 50,000,000 in the fiduciary note issue of the Bank of England. It has been accelerated doubtless by the Whitsun holiday, as note circulation rose 2,293,000 last week, against a rise of only 300,000 a year ago.

William Fellowes Morgan Jr. announced yesterday his resignation as executive director of the Metropolitan Package Store Association, Inc., a post he assumed in January, soon after he resigned as Commissioner of Markets after a dispute with Mayor La Guardia.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 24 -- A swift, sudden invasion attempt was made against New Jersey's shores by an "enemy" task force today as small assault boats, presumably sent from large transports over the horizon, concentrated the strongest of three simultaneous Atlantic "invasions" against this Summer resort following heavy low-flying "bombing", by wave after wave of dark gray planes.

Moscow's admission that the Russians have been driven off the Kerch Peninsula confirms the German claim that the first phase of the offensive on the East Front has ended in a Nazi victory. It is not a major victory, for it cannot be exploited while the great battle around Kharkov still rages.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 24 -- On the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club today Champion Flornell Glamorous paraded to her twelfth best-in-show victory. This beautiful white and tan whippet, owned by the Mardormere Kennels of Mrs. George A. Anderson of Glen Head, L.I., never showed to better advantage for handler Percy Roberts.

At this moment women in America find themselves in a situation both ironic and unjust. From the beginning of this war they have given all-out aid for the survival of democracy. In every town and city you find them serving in every possible way for defense and victory.

KUNMING, China, May 18 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Forty-five Americans, who blew up bridges and supplies throughout the Far East in the path of Japanese invasion, cast about today for new employment. They are members of the American technical group, which has been disbanded after a career in destruction from Borneo to Burma.
VICHY, May 24 -- The statements by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State of the United States, concerning commercial relations after the war have aroused much interest in economic circles here.

Hymns composed by three former organists of Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street, were sung yesterday afternoon at the twentieth annual service of the Trinity Choir Alumni Association at the church.

Reports from retail stores in all sections of the country on National Cotton Week promotions indicate that more than 5,000 full pages of newspaper space were devoted to advertising cottons during the last ten days, according to the Cotton-Textile Institute and National Cotton Council, the sponsors. Total newspaper advertising of cottons was greater than in any corresponding period in many years, it was declared.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The 5,123 active national banks in the United States and possessions on Dec. 31, 1941, reported gross earnings of $925,663,000 for that calendar year, Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, announced today.

There are sharply divided worlds within many individuals, and many of life's confusions result from the fact that persons often are not in either world but between them, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, pastor of the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street, declared in his sermon there yesterday.

The conception of religion of the late Rev. Dr. Minot Simons was reviewed yesterday by Rudolph C. Neuendorffer, president of the board of trustees, at the unveiling of memorial tablets to Dr. Simons, who was the pastor, and his late sexton, Albert Williams, in the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Belmont Stakes Day, June 6, the final day of the Belmont Park meeting, will be Army-Nay Day and the entire receipts of the afternoon, over and above the cost of added money and purses, will be contributed to war relief. This was the essence of a statement issued yesterday by Herbert Bayard Swope on behalf of the Westchester Racing Association, operators of Belmont Park.
Mrs. Cleveland C. Lansing, who has been at the Carlyle since returning from Nassau, B.W.I., will leave today for Salisbury, Conn.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., May 24 -- If the peace is not won "during this war" it will be lost forever, and only "a more destructive war" will be the outcome, James G. McDonald, member of the New York City Board of Education, warned the graduating class at Swarthmore College tonight.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Traders who were free buyers of corn futures recently on the Board of Trade here in the belief that this was the one grain that would be certain to appreciate in price because of the tremendous feeding and industrial demand, liquidated their holdings to some extent last week, and at the inside figures futures showed a loss of about 2 1/2 cents a bushel from the finish of the previous week.

CHICAGO, May 24 -From a moisture standpoint there remains little to be desired in the wheat belt, with the ground saturated in many areas in the Southwest and Northwest. In fact, the latter section has so much moisture that it has hampered the seeding of small grains and it is expected that some acreage originally intended for wheat, oats and barley will go into other grains.

The South American nations are experiencing a great upsurge in trade as a result of the war, and the volume of commerce among the ten South American continent countries undoubtedly will attain record levels in the latter years of the conflict, according to D. Stewart Iglehart, president of W.R. Grace Co. and the Grace Line, which have been active in the South American field for nearly ninety years.

The 100,000 women who are to participate in the ten-day drive of the Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign, starting June 14, represent the largest organization of woman power for a single activity in the city's history, John T. Madden, campaign chairman, declared last night.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, May 24 (AP) -- A story of Japanese brutalities in the Philippines -- including atrocities upon American doctors and nurses -- was related here today by Samuel Roberts, 26-year-old Navy machinist mate.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, May 24 (AP) -- A story of Japanese brutalities in the Philippines -- including atrocities upon American doctors and nurses -- was related here today by Samuel Roberts, 26-year-old Navy machinist mate.

Eli Shonbrun, 34-year-old admitted sneak thief, took the witness stand in his own defense yesterday and with a thief's gallantry completely exonerated his two co-defendants, Madeline Webb and John D. Cullen, of any part in the murder of Mrs. Susie Flora Reich, middle-aged refugee, in a room at the Sutton Hotel on March 4.
Eddie Mead, known to boxing fans throughout the country as the rotund, shrewd, friendly fight manager who brought Henry Armstrong to pugilistic fame, died of a heart attack yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Lieutenant George S. Welch of Wilmington, Del., received at the White House today the congratulations of President Roosevelt for shooting down four Japanese planes in the Pearl Harbor attack Dec. 7.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., May 25 -- Milo Perkins, executive director of the Board of Economic Warfare, declared today that the job of the future would be to build mass consumption great enough to use the mass production potential which will be left when peace is achieved.

Four of the current film attractions in midtown theatres are scheduled to be held over. On Thursday, "Tortilla Flat" will begin a second week at the Radio City Music Hall, while "The Spoilers" will enter its second week at the Capitol. Starting Thursday "My Gal Sal" will go into its fifth week at the Roxy. On Friday, "In This Our Life," the Strand's offering, will enter its fourth week.

RIVERHEAD, N.Y., May 25 -- The Suffolk Board of Supervisors today adopted a resolution authorizing Harry T. Tuthill, County Superintendent of Highways, to prepare maps of large tracts of land for three proposed airports to be established by the Civilian Aeronautics Administration.

Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, heralded yesterday the elimination of the double tax on odd-lot transactions in securities as "naturally gratifying to the Stock Exchange community." The relief came through favorable action by the State Legislature and approval by Governor Lehman.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- A warship will be named in honor of Ensign John Doherty, who gave his life Feb. 1 in a dive-bombing attack on Taros Island, in the Marshall Islands group.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to appropriate or grant contractual authority for $614,445,000 additional for the Navy for construction of 200,000 tons of fighting ships, and an unspecified number of aircraft.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Lou Nova's dream of another crack at Private Joe Louis's world heavyweight title was shattered in the ring at Griffith Stadium tonight. Lee Savold, Des Moines, Iowa, heavyweight, scored a technical knockout over the sturdy Californian in the eighth round of their ten-round battle, staged in the interests of the Navy Relief Society.
CLEVELAND, May 25 (AP) -- The White Sex scored four runs in the last inning today to hand the Indians their fifth straight defeat, 5 to 1. Bill Dietrich held Cleveland to six hits.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A $4,000,000 emergency program for expansion of helium production was recommended today by the Senate Appropriations Committee, paving the way for a corresponding increase in the number of blimps used on coastal patrols.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- With a Senate version of a farm bill scheduled to come up in the House within a few days traders in wheat were inclined to go slow today pending further developments. While there were rather sharp fluctuations at times, the aggregate trade was not large and buying failed to follow the minor bulges.

While the Supreme Court of the United States considers an appeal for a re-hearing of the case of Odell Waller, Negro sharecropper, sentenced to die on June 19 for the shooting of his white landlord, Negro churches in Harlem will join in prayer that the court be "divinely guided and establish democracy for poor folks."

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 25 -- Unusual brilliancy marked the celebration here today of Argentina's one hundred thirty-second anniversary of national independence. Many Chilean organizations, schools, boy and girl scouts, turned out to join in the large-scale celebration.

BOSTON, May 25 -- Curiosity, they say, once killed a cat and today it got the better of Mel Ott's Giants when they opened a two-day investigation of what is holding Professor Casey Stengel's extraordinary Braves in second place in the National League flag race.

Persistent liquidation, particularly in the July position, carried cotton prices progressively lower yesterday. Active months on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 16 to 21 points below Saturday's final quotations.

The musicale and tea to be given by Mrs. Busch Greenough this afternoon in the Viennese Roof of the St Regis for the benefit of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children is expected to attract 400 people. Lanny Ross, radio and screen star, and Roger La Gasse will furnish the program, contributing their services.

WOODBURY, N.J., May 25 -- Lieut. Comdr. James B. Taylor Jr. of 770 Park Avenue, New York, a well-known Navy test pilot, was killed today when his Navy airplane crashed into a thickly wooded section of Colonial Manor, near here. He was 44 years old.

ST. LOUIS, May 25 (AP) -- Detroit pounded two mighty homers in the first two innings, but swung futilely thereafter as the Browns scored a 3-to-2 triumph before 8,496 fans on an error in the ninth inning of their twilight game which netted about $8,500 for the Army and Navy Relief Funds today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- Six hundred WPA workers and thousands of volunteers began today salvaging homes, industrial plants and highways from silt and wreckage borne by flood-swollen rivers in five Northeastern Pennsylvania counties, which counted thirty-two known dead and twenty missing persons among the victims of the disaster.

Nancy Lostutter, 11 years old, from Columbus, Ind., whose suggestion that the young pandas at the Bronx Zoo be named Pandee and Pandah won a contest held by the United China Relief Fund and the New York Zoological Society, found New York a thrilling city a few hours after her arrival here yesterday.

In awarding the annual Avery Hopwood writing prizes at the University of Michigan last week the judges split the first fiction prize three ways. Seven hundred and fifty dollars went to the following three authors of novels: Jay McCormick, Raymond Early and Rosemary Obermeyer, all of Michigan.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Postoffice Department has set up waivers to permit parcel post shipments of books outside the country, primarily to Latin America.

An emphatic denial that Saburo Kurusu, Japanese special envoy, had been sent to this country to lull the United States into a false sense of security before the attack on Pearl Harbor, was made by a Japanese spokesman in a Tokyo short wave broadcast recorded last night by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Activity in most of the wholesale markets here was sharply curtailed yesterday as retailers sought further clarification of the proposed WPB order limiting retail and wholesale inventories, a "second draft" of which was circulated and studied in merchandising circles.

So far as the Red Sox were concerned, it was a matter of too much Hassett yesterday at the Stadium. The Yankee first baseman, who has been doing fine work since Joe McCarthy gave him varsity rating, did enough damage alone to beat Boston. Buddy drove home the first two runs and scored the third in the Yankees' 3-1 triumph, and twice he bobbed up with spectacular plays to snuff out Boston threats.

TRENTON, N.J., May 25 -- Permission was granted the City Affairs Committee of Jersey City today to file with the State Supreme Court clerk a 22-year-old ruling, in which Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Parker declined to allow a review of the late Governor Edward I. Edwards's right to hold a hearing on removal charges against former members of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

Eugene Levine, 6 foot, 240-pound auto wrecker and father of an infant child, was sentenced yesterday in Kings County Court to serve from eighty-two years and six months to 165 years in Sing Sing Prison for various crimes arising from his admitted attacks on nearly 100 women he had trailed at night to Brooklyn apartment houses.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 20: Increases of $540,000,000 in holdings of United States Government bonds, $541,000,000 in United States Government deposits and $155,000,00 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $223,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

An exhibition of twelve paintings, entitled "Impressions of World Leaders," by Eugene Brest, widely known European artist, opened yesterday at the headquarters of the American Friends of Norway, 40 West Fifty-seventh Street.

An accounting suit brought by stockholders of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation was dismissed as against William J. Brown, James H. Ward and the estate of Charles M. Schwab in a unanimous ruling yesterday by the Appellate Division. The court reversed a decision by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer, who had refused to grant the motion of the three defendants for dismissal.

LONDON, May 25 (UP) -- General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Free French forces, told the people of France in a radio broadcast tonight that only their heroic resistance had prevented Pierre Laval and his collaborationist supporters from "mobilizing France in order to assure Hitler's victory."

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 -- Thousands of Italian-Americans in this city were being influenced by a "pro-Fascist element among prominent residents," a State Assembly committee was told today at the opening of San Francisco hearings on un-Americanism.

Except for weakness in the steels the stock market moved yesterday at cross-purposes, with volume the smallest since late March. It was the second lightest five-hour session since May of last year, with sales on the Stock Exchange 233,470 shares, against 329,460 on last Friday.

The Rapp-Coudert legislative committee investigating subversive influences in schools will continue its study of Communist activities in the educational system and "follow up any evidence of Nazi and fascist activity in the schools and colleges," State Senator Frederic R. Coudert, chairman of the subcommittee dealing with the investigation of this city, declared yesterday at the committee's local headquarters, 27 William Street.

Why all the hair-splitting about the new tax bill? The people don't want to be fooled. They can take it straight and standing up. Certainly, tax the lower brackets. By all means collect at the source. We are entitled to know that opportunities for chiseling have been reduced to the minimum.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Division on the subject of patent monopolies was marked in the Supreme Court today when a majority of six, led by Justice Roberts, held that machines used by the Williams Manufacturing Company of Ohio infringed patent claims of the United Shoe Machinery Company of Boston.
MOSCOW, May 25 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast the following communique today:

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, May 25 -- "One hundred per cent cooperation" was promised to Vice Admiral Robert L. Ghormley, supreme commander of the United Nations naval forces in the South Pacific, by Prime Minister Peter Fraser in a welcome to the admiral today.

The New York Federation of Music Clubs held its annual directors' meeting yesterday at its headquarters in the Hotel Great Northern, 118 West Fifty-seventh Street. The directors and representatives of coordinating agencies spent the day discussing effective means of coordinating a "singing-to-victory" campaign.

Edith C. Ringling of the family that runs the Greatest Show on Earth, and her colleague, Mollie B. Steinberg, reached down into the early days of the mauve decade for William Gillette's "All the Comforts of Home." They acquired Helen Jerome to dust the cobwebs off it a little, and Dorothy Sands, Nicholas Joy and Celeste Holm to play the leading roles.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company earned $16,744,222 in the fiscal year ended with February after deducting $11,900,000 for Federal income tax, according to the annual statement of John A. Hartford, president, mailed to stockholders today.
BERLIN, May 25 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:
CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- The major league All-Star game will be played as scheduled at the Polo Grounds, New York, on July 6, with a change made only in the starting time.

In a pointed warning to the American people that waste is treason, Donald M. Nelson, chief of the War Production Board, yesterday called for a campaign to save and salvage every scrap of critical materials. War production is coming along better than was expected, he said, and will be limited only by the scarcity of vital materials.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 5 per cent last week under the comparable week a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Last week was the first of operation under the OPA price ceilings for retailers.
A Russian carnival was staged last evening by Bonwit Teller as a feature of its gala evenings in a special drive for the sale of war stamps and bonds.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Despite shortages of labor, machinery, rubber tires and other equipment, America's food growers and producers are matching heavy industry's production of war tools.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 25 -- Dr. Francis R. Packard of Philadelphia was named as the winner of the Newcomb award for scientific attainment in rhinology and laryngology by the American Laryngological Association at its sixty-fourth annual convention here tonight.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, May 24 (Delayed) -- They endured a hell of shot and shell from Luzon to Bataan to Corregidor. Being women, they were scared. But they held their heads high and perhaps never, since Florence Nightingale created their order, have women tended war wounded more gallantly than did nine United States Army nurses just arrived here from the Philippines.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 25 -- Cornell swept both ends of a doubleheader from Dartmouth, 5 -- 4, in ten innings and 3 -- 0 in seven, today to eliminate the Indians from any mathematical chance of tying Princeton for the Eastern Intercollegiate League diamond title.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The Acting Secretaries of War and Navy and the chairman of the War Production Board have jointly recommended legislation to permit limited suspension of the anti-trust laws when needed as an aid to the war effort.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 25 -- These being days when a leader is supposed to lead, Ed Dudley, president of the Professional Golfers Association today arose to the demands of the occasion by pacing the field in the first eighteen-hole round of the P.G.A. championship at the Seaview Country Club.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 25 (AP) -- American manufacturers and business men must advertise now as never before if they expect to share in post-war sales, Alexander Thomson Jr., of Hamilton, Ohio, a paper and fibre company executive, said today before the Southern Graphic Arts Association convention.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Vallejo and Napa, Calif., with a rise of 47 per cent in department store sales in April, as compared with April of last year, continued to lead all cities, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Twilight baseball as a substitute for the banned arclight game in New York made its debut at Ebbets Field yesterday and, so far as Curt Davis and the Dodgers are concerned, it was an unqualified success, Brooklyn winning by 3 -- 0.

Officials of four municipalities in Kentucky sold yesterday to banking groups a total of $1,930,000 of revenue bonds. A syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., received the award of $1,195,000 of the total, while the Equitable Securities Corporation and associates received the remaining $735,000.
Decision on the Department of Justice's request for leave to intervene in a patent infringement suit now on trial in Federal court was reserved yesterday by Judge Vincent L. Leibell.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 25 -- Mayor Tom Taggart went to the radio tonight to charge that the move by the four other City Commissioners that resulted in stripping him of much of his power was illegal and would not be sanctioned by the courts.

Truth and lasting wisdom are the aims of education, Mgr. Joseph M.A. Fearns, president of St. Joseph's Seminary, told 6,000 Catholic youths from Christian Brothers' schools yesterday afternoon at St. Patrick's Cathedral at the twenty-ninth annual rally of the Archconfraternity of the Divine Child.
LONDON, May 25 -- Widespread arrests by the Gestapo in occupied France as part of a new drive by the German secret police were reported by the Free French here today.

MURMANSK, Russia, May 25 -- We drove along the bay toward Murmansk on a road from which the snow had just been removed. The road is about forty-five miles long and on both sides of it walls of snow rise nearly twenty feet high. The road looks like a trench from the air and the German planes that are over it almost every day can hardly notice it.

A campaign to mobilize 26,000 manufacturers in this city for conservation of materials and salvage of scrap needed for increased war production was launched yesterday under the auspices of the War Production Board through the newly formed Industrial Salvage Committee for Greater New York.

Dr. and 1VKrs. Charles Gilmore Kerley of 10 East Eighty-first Street will open their Summer home, Hilltop, in Sharon, Conn., next week. Their son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Bonner of Pacific Palisades, Calif., will also be in Sharon for the Summer.
Two Army privates yesterday received $5,000 war bonds each had purchased.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Roosevelt today reduced the budget estimate for the Work Projects Administration in the fiscal year 1943 from $465,000,000 to $280,000,000, and told Congress that he was considering new amendments to the Social Security Act which might eliminate entirely the need for WPA after next year.

Welfare Commissioner William Hodson yesterday characterized as "a great misfortune" the assumption that he said underlies the Moffat Law that the jobless will not go to work without a "work or don't eat law." No group of workers in this city is so anxious for work as the jobless, Mr. Hodson contended.

TOKYO, May 25 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in London) -- Japanese Imperial Headquarters asserted today that a United States battleship of the North Carolina class was seriously damaged and that a cruiser of the Portland type was sunk in the battle of the Coral Sea, in addition to losses that the Japanese had previously reported inflicted on the United Nations.

The first issue of railway equipment trust certificates with the indenture modified to meet the situation caused by War Production Board decrees is to be sold by the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway on June 2. Since the rolling stock that will secure the certificates is subject to seizure in whole or in part by the WPB, the indenture will provide that one-half the issue may be retired at the discretion of the company.
MEXICO CITY, May 25 (AP) -- As President Manuel Avila Camacho led Mexico a step nearer war against the Axis powers today preparations for entry into the conflict proceeded swiftly.

We may yet have to ration the English language before we can win the war. Some of the official verbiage now in circulation is enough to make a man pause. He pauses, first, to try and make out what the language means. He pauses in the second place to wonder if the words could not be fewer and shorter.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- On July 1 in every city and hamlet throughout the United States, retail merchants for fifteen minutes will sell no articles but war bonds and stamps.

THE late Rachel Field had many followers. Her Down East stories, which were a peculiarly pleasant blend of antiquarianism, realism and romance, had a charm of their own. This charm is always apparent in her posthumously published "And Now Tomorrow,"* which is recognizable Rachel Field all the way. But simply because there is more than Rachel Field to this novel about a New England textile town in the depth of depression, there are jarring notes.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, May 26 (U.P.) -- United Nations bombers smashed again at Japanese bases on the islands of New Guinea and New Britain yesterday, shooting down four enemy fighters, a communique today said.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- In a sixty-five-page brochure issued here today to refute Congressional and other charges of profiteering in war industries, the National Association of Manufacturers submitted an analysis of groups of naval war contracts showing a median profit of 8 per cent to be the highest, but this was before the deduction of taxes estimated at one-half of the profit.

Groups taking part in the Jeanne d'Arc campaign of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies held a rally last night at the Hotel Plaza to spur the collection of a $75,000 fund in aid of the French homeless and starving. Six hundred persons attended.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 25 -- The Nassau County Republican Committee, meeting here tonight in the Police Auditorium, endorsed unanimously the candidacy of Thomas E. Dewey for the Republican nomination for Governor. In the endorsement resolution, introduced by County Executive J. Russel Sprague, Mr. Dewey, regarded as virtually certain to be the nominee, was praised for his "splendid public record, his patriotism and his uncompromising principles for national unity."

One woman from Juneau, Alaska, joined with contingents from San Francisco, Cleveland, Wichita, and less distant cities as the American Women's Vountary Services, now numbering 250,000 members, yesterday opened its first annual convention here.

Fordham's champion baseball team, having clinched the first Metropolitan Collegiate Conference crown, was honored at an informal luncheon at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. The Ed Barrow Trophy, a beautiful thirty-inch silver statuette, was presented to Captain Manny Gomez of the Rams by Barrow.

Charles J. Marsh, 25 years old, a $27-a-week teller in the Knickerbocker Federal Savings and Loan Association, who was arrested last Thursday, admitted yesterday, the District Attorney's office charged, that he had embezzled $171,000 from the association since April, 1939.

As a result of a heavy movement of gasoline and other petroleum products and a large amount of freight and passenger traffic caused by the war, the gross revenues of the Kansas City Southern Railway have reached high levels, C.P. Couch, chairman, said yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 25 -- Westchester County motorists and filling station proprietors are responsible for widespread violations of gasoline rationing regulations, Leslie V. Bateman, county rationing administrator, charged this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Competitive bidding for workers is doing more than union agitation to drive up wage rates, Marriner Eccles, governor of the Federal Reserve System, told the District of Columbia Bankers Association here today.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- On behalf of President Roosevelt, Secretary Knox presented the Navy Cross today to Lieutenant John D. Bulkeley and the Gold Star in lieu of a second Navy Cross to Lieut. Comdr. Richard E. Hawes.

As armed merchant ships in war gray plied up and down the river, tugs tooted their signals and an occasional Army plane purred high overhead, Mayor La Guardia, Edgar J. Nathan Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, and other officials opened the final link of the East River Drive yesterday with a noon ceremony at Forty-seventh Street, on the crest of an elevated section of the drive.

Free medical, nursing and hospital care for all expectant mothers whose husbands are in military service was urged yesterday by Miss Katharine Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau of the United States Department of Labor.

FALLSBURG, N.Y., May 25 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., speaking tonight at the annual dinner of the Sullivan County Democratic Committee, declared that ultimate victory over the Axis could only be brought about through a unification of all sections of American life behind the President's war policies.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The fight over President Roosevelt's nomination of Thomas F. Meaney for a District Court judgeship in New Jersey was enlivened today, when Senator Barbour, Republican, said he would vote against confirmation and Senator Smathers, Democrat, replied that Mr. Barbour could take no other position and "save face with his party in this Senatorial election year."

Shifts in retail distribution growing out of shortages and other phases of the war effort will increase the importance of both newspapers and transportation media to selective advertising, James B. Lackey, president of the recently organized National Association of Transportation Advertising, declared yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Armand E. Fontaine of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane was nominated yesterday for president of the Association of Customers Brokers to succeed Thomas B. Meek. Allyn C. Donaldson of Francis I. du Pont Co. and Chisholm Chapman was renominated for vice president. Donald C. Blanke of Eastman, Dillon Co. was selected for treasurer and Douglas V. Ellice of Fahnestock Co. for secretary.

MILWAUKEE, May 25 -- Christian educators of all churches face a new and increasing responsibility for recruiting and training young people for Christian leadership in the crisis now existing and in the days which will follow the war, said a report by the standing committee on Christian education, submitted today to the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. and adopted after long discussion.

Instead of going abroad to study art, as was the practice before the war, this year's winners in the American Academy in Rome competitions, announced yesterday, seemed more likely to go abroad to fight. The awards totaled $6,000.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, May 26 -- Russian forces using tanks, planes, guns, rifles, grenades and bottles of flaming gasoline were reported today to be in grim combat against German assault forces making a furious attack in the Izyum-Barvenkova sector of the Kharkov front.

Representative William B. Barry, Queens Democrat, whose Congressional record has been assailed as "isolationist" by opponents, made public yesterday a letter that he had sent to constituents in the Second Congressional District announcing his candidacy for re-election and flatly asserting that he had "no alibis or apologies" to make for his record.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The issue between Elisha M. Friedman and this writer turns on two central questions: (1) "Can income and withholding taxes control consumer spending without help from the sales tax?" and (2) "Will the tax system be more or less equitable if the sales tax is excluded?" (See letters to the THE NEW YORK TIMES, April 26 and May 17.)

UNITED NATIONS OPERATIONAL BASE, in Australia, May 25 -- Lieutenant Charles I. Hitchcock of Winchester, Ind., bomber pilot, has just emerged from his most eerie experience of the war -- an encounter with a Japanese Zero fighter, the pilot of which was dead.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., May 25 -- Asserting that Pearl Harbor was "America's commencement day," Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick told the graduating class of Middlebury College today that "you are the generation which has grown up just as America reaches its maturity."

In peacetime it is at least debatable whether it is best, either for the community or the unfortunate individuals involved, to permit those who refuse work to remain on relief. In wartime, when the need for manpower is so urgent, such a policy becomes impossible. This has now been given formal recognition both in Washington and in Albany.

HOULTON, Me., May 25 (AP) -- A searching party of forty enlisted men and officers from the Houlton Army Airbase slowly made their way out of dense woodlands tonight with the bodies of the six Army airmen who were killed when their twin-motored bomber crashed yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 25 (AP) -- Germany has left Italy free to decide how far she wishes to go in pressing territorial claims upon France, reports reaching Berne said tonight. Pierre Laval, Vichy Chief of Government, to whom both Italy and Germany appear to be cooling fast, presumably was told of the Nazi stand in Paris conferences today.
I claim we got a hell of a beating. We got run out of Burma. I think we ought to find out what caused it, go back and retake it -- Lieut.-Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, interviewed yesterday in New Delhi.

BALTIMORE, May 25 (AP) -- Newark exploded a 7-run, 7-hit ninth inning tonight to come from behind and score a 12-to-7 victory over the Orioles. This gave the Bears an even break in the four-game series.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The fate of the pay-as-you-go income-tax plan hung in the balance today with members of the House Ways and Means Committee temporarily deadlocked on the problem.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 25 -- Addressing the fourth wartime commencement at Cornell, Dr. Edmund Ezra Day, president, defined the present conflict as "a life-and-death struggle against enslavement, a war for freedom. There can be but one outcome," he said.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 25 -- All the planes and tanks and guns in the world will amount to exactly nothing if the United States does not train enough men to use them and to use them properly, Lawrence D. Bell, president and general manager of Bell Aircraft Corporation, makers of the Army's deadly Airacobra, declared last night.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Centralization of authority to move farm labor to areas where extra help is needed was recommended to Congress today by the House Committee investigating defense migration.

Whether the war lasts two or five years, banks will be required to assume even broader responsibilities and to make greater sacrifices than they have so far, William R. White, New York State Superintendent of Banks, told delegates to the forty-ninth annual meeting of the New York State Bankers Association, which began yesterday in the Hotel Astor.
The Virginian Public Service Company asked yesterday for bids on $26,000,000 of first 3 3/4 bonds due in 1972 and $10,500,000 of sinking fund debentures due in 1957.

WASHINGTON, May 25 UP) -- The Office of Defense Transportation sharply restricted today the use of Great Lakes carriers for coal movements, in order to divert more vessels to the hauling of iron ore to meet increasing war needs.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A cloth-conserving order covering women's and children's robes, housecoats, negligees, beachcoats and lounging pajamas was issued today by the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Robert L. Peyton of Waco, Texas, acting as his own lawyer, won a round in the Supreme Court today in a suit against the Railway Express Agency for failing to deliver a manuscript which he sent to Robert Benchley under a trick address for what he termed a "build-up."

COLLINGSWOOD, N.J., May 25 -- The Bible Presbyterian Church congregation will assemble tomorrow night to pray for rain to prevent completion of a race track three miles away before the War Production Board deadline.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 25 -- Reports from Rome to diplomatic quarters here tonight indicated that French-Italian relations were growing worse. Press commentators in Rome today bent their energies to explaining "something new" to their readers, and adopted the theme that "French Empire possessions must now be protected from impudent encroachments of the Anglo-Saxon Powers."

UNION, N.J., May 25 -- Harold Sanderson, Canoe Brook professional, led a field of eighteen contestants in the first New Jersey qualifying round for the Hale America open tournament with two perfect par rounds of 71, 71 -- 142 over the smooth-rolling hills of the suburban Golf Club course today.

The Glen Riddle Farms' War Hazard, coming from behind with a rush that nipped the favored Painted Veil by a nose at the wire, took the Bateau Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park. Paying $39.60 for $2, War Hazard was one of several long shots that came home in front before a crowd of 15,584 that sent $1,032,458 through the pari-mutuel machines.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Efforts to solve the East coast gasoline problem seemed tonight to be heading toward a Presidential request for approval of a pipeline across Florida and construction of wooden and concrete barges to transport petrolum products up the East-coast inland waterway.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals today upheld a lower court ruling which granted a judgment to Mrs. Eleanor M. Patterson, publisher of The Washington Times-Herald, and others, in the $250,000 libel suit filed against them by Representative Martin L. Sweeney of Ohio.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Roosevelt urged the Congress today to prevent commercial use of the Red Cross name and emblem.

TOKYO, May 25 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Yomiuri correspondent reported today that Japanese forces had surged across the upper Salween River in Yunnan Province in the face of heavy Chinese fire and occupied hills to hold the bridgehead in the most difficult operation of an advance upon Yungchang.

Utility circles are awaiting with interest the dividend meeting today of directors of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation. Action is to be taken on the preferred dividend, which is being paid at the reduced rate of $3 a share, and many in Wall Street believe that a further reduction is in prospect in view of the tax problems besetting the corporation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 25 -- The long-standing feud between Joseph Terboven, Reich Commissioner for Norway, and Col. Gen. Nicholaus von Falkenhorst, commander of German troops in Norway, suddenly became acute after the Gestapo executed twenty German soldiers near Bergen without informing the general, it was learned here today.

CINCINNATI, May 25 (AP) -- Playing their first night game of the season before 16,205 fans, the Reds tonight toppled the Pirates, 6 to 1. Paul Derringer, recording his first victory, limited Pittsburgh to six hits.

LONG BEACH, L.I., May 25 -- Pete Cassella, pro from the Sound View Club in Great Neck, paced the Long Island qualifiers for the Hale America golf tournament with a 79, 72 -- 151 over the Lido Country Club course today. Seven qualified in the field of eleven.
Charley (Lulu) Costantino, 129, East Side, knocked out Lou Transperanti, 123, Baltimore, in 1:50 of the fifth round of their scheduled eight-rounder last night at the St. Nicholas Palace.

LONDON, May 25 -- The British Labor party "reaffirmed" today its determination to work for total victory and by overwhelmingly endorsing the role played by the party, which has joined the coalition government to bring about victory, and by overwhelmingly enmovement to end the present political truce and establish a government opposition in Parliament.

LENOX, Mass., May 25 (AP) -- The Berkshire Symphonic Festival and the Boston Symphony Orchestra parted company today for the war's duration and cancellation of the 1942 music festival, scheduled to open July 30 at Tanglewood, was announced amid some confusion.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Thousands of women throughout the country already are seeking to join the new Women's Army Auxiliary Corps, although general recruiting will not start for at least three months.

Arrangement of working hours for employes in war plants in Nassau and Suffolk Counties on Long Island so that buses that take workers to the plants can make the return trip loaded with other workers going home will be discussed at a conference with plant executives and bus operators to be held Friday at the court house in Mineola, the Public Service Commission announced yesterday.
CHUNGKING, China, May 25 (Reuter) -- Tonight's Chinese war communique follows:
The week-end brought a variety of news for the salt-water fisherman who lives in the metropolitan area.

DEVON, Pa., May 25 -- The annual Devon Horse Show opened today and will continue through Saturday for the benefit of the Bryn Mawr Hospital. Isaac H. Clothier Jr. is chairman of the horse show committee.

JERSEY CITY, May 25 (AP) -- Jersey City's Little Giants rallied in the late innings tonight to defeat the Syracuse Chiefs, 5 to 4. Hugh Poland's single to center scored Gibby Brack from second in the tenth frame. The victory gave the Jerseys a 3-to-1 edge in the series.

"A powder for puddings" -- the newest acquisition of a large city store -- is pale cafe-au-lait in color, rich chocolate in flavor. This tantalizing fragrant substance, which is a blend of cocoa and sugar and vanilla, comes in cellophane envelopes, three of which are tidily tucked into a twelve-ounce box costing 29 cents.
The week-end brought a variety of news for the salt-water fisherman who lives in the metropolitan area.

DEVON, Pa., May 25 -- The annual Devon Horse Show opened today and will continue through Saturday for the benefit of the Bryn Mawr Hospital. Isaac H. Clothier Jr. is chairman of the horse show committee.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The policy committee of the United Mine Workers of America today authorized a committee to confer with spokesmen for the bituminous coal operators of the Appalachian area Friday on the request by the operators that the miners forego their vacations in favor of continued production of coal needed in the war program.

The Allied Stores Corporation had an increase of 20 per cent in sales in the three months ended on April 30 over the corresponding period last year, B. Earl Puckett, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The House debated, and arranged to vote tomorrow, on a bill to create a "Smaller War Plants Corporation" to aid small business and to mobilize for war all of the smaller industrial units. It would authorize an appropriation of $200,000,000, or double the amount voted by the Senate.

JERSEY CITY, May 25 (AP) -- Jersey City's Little Giants rallied in the late innings tonight to defeat the Syracuse Chiefs, 5 to 4. Hugh Poland's single to center scored Gibby Brack from second in the tenth frame. The victory gave the Jerseys a 3-to-1 edge in the series.

"A powder for puddings" -- the newest acquisition of a large city store -- is pale cafe-au-lait in color, rich chocolate in flavor. This tantalizing fragrant substance, which is a blend of cocoa and sugar and vanilla, comes in cellophane envelopes, three of which are tidily tucked into a twelve-ounce box costing 29 cents.

BERLIN, May 25 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command announced today that operations against the Russians south of Kharkov had developed into a battle of encirclement.

CHESTERTOWN, Md., May 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told Washington College graduates today that they were entering a new world in which it was more important than ever that they meet the responsibility that goes with the privileges of higher education.

CLINTON, N.Y., May 25 -- A poem written by one of the eighty-nine black-gowned seniors who faced him in the Hamilton College chapel this morning constituted President W.H. Cowley's address to Hamilton's 130th graduating class.

The Federal Government's modified regulations covering rationed sugar for home canning were received here yesterday and transmitted to local ration boards throughout the city by Lee S. Buckingham, New York State OPA director.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 25 -- United States Army bombers battled and sank a German submarine yesterday between Natal and Ceara [Fortaleza], according to advices received from Ceara today.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a New York State court judgment for $228,294,283 against the Bank of France in favor of assignees of the National Bank of Belgium.

Politics in Britain have been suspended during the war by reason of a "truce" between the Conservative party, which has a substantial majority in the House of Commons, and the Labor party, which forms the Opposition. Whenever a vacancy has occurred in the House, a candidate has been nominated to fill this vacancy only by the party that held the seat in question.

A special two-mile run has been added to the program of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships, Asa S. Bushnell, director of the meet, announced yesterday. An all-star field, consisting of Greg Rice, Gilbert Dodds, Earl Mitchell, Jim Rafferty and George De George, has been lined up for the event on Saturday at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.

New York City's Negro residents, like the rest of us, must have come here to better their lot in life. Some of them succeeded. Yet as a group, even in this great free city, they haven't enjoyed equality of opportunity. They have been at a disadvantage in housing, paying higher rent than their white neighbors for worse quarters.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Officials of the Chicago Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission are nearing agreement on revision of Exchange laws to permit corporations to become Exchange members it was learned today in well informed La Salle Street quarters.

While man-made war is raging on three continents, Nature has launched a "Spring offensive" on the American home front. The Red Cross has felt the full force of this drive. Its national director, Norman H. Davis, describes a succession of recent catastrophes as "the most devastating combination of natural disasters" encountered by his organization in sixty-one years of relief work.

A program for the improvement of Negro conditions in New York's Harlem, to be "translated into practical action," was made public yesterday by the City-Wide Citizens Committee on Harlem in opening City-Wide Harlem Week.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 25 -- Jack Sabol, professional at Westchester Hills, added a four-under-69 to a 75 fired in the morning for a 144 and the honor of pacing the field in the Westchester district qualifying round of the Hale America open golf tournament at the Gedney Country Club today.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- Scoring four runs on one hit in the first inning, the Cardinals crushed the Cubs, 10 to 2, today with a total of thirteen hits while five Chicago pitchers paraded. Ernie White, meanwhile, hurled his second victory with an eight-hit performance.

LONDON, May 25 -- Queen Mary, who sometimes is called "Missus" by British Tommies who do not recognize her when she hands them tea and sandwiches at the canteen, laid out her nicest smock tonight and prepared to spend her seventy-fifth birthday tomorrow waiting on Britain's fighting men.

CHUNGKING, China, Tuesday, May 26 (AP) -- Ten thousand Japanese attempted to storm Kinhwa, important military center in the East Coast Province of Chekiang, after a furious artillery barrage yesterday, but stubborn Chinese machine-gunners met them at the walls of the city, killed 1,000 and forced the rest to retire, a Central News Agency dispatch said today.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Bank and credit association spokesmen objected at a House Military Committee hearing today to proposed legislation to relieve secondary endorsers from the obligation of meeting debts contracted by a principal who has been inducted or enlisted in the armed services.

"Comes the Revelation," a comedy described by its author, Louis Vittes, as a satire on the growth of a typical American demagogue, opens tonight at the Jolson, 932 Seventh Avenue. The cast includes Will Geer, Peter Hobbs, Wendell Corey, Richard Karlan, Mary Perry, Lesley Woods, Wendell K. Phillips, G. Swayne Gordon, Grover Burgess, Carroll Hartley, Mitchell Harris, John Thomas, Audra Lindley, Maurice Minnick, Kathryn Cameron, June Stewart and George Leach.

The Medical Society of the County of New York last night unanimously approved a resolution protesting discrimination by the Army and Navy against Negro physicians in the matter of granting commissions. The resolution stated that "duly qualified Negro physicians are being commissioned in the armed forces only in so far as their services are required for Negro troops."

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Postmaster General Walker warned graduating students at Georgetown University this afternoon that all would fight and some would die in the present struggle against tyranny, but asked a pledge that when victory over evil has been won, there should be no succumbing to "the pride of power, the gluttony of tryanny."

CHUNGKING, China, Tuesday, May 26 (AP) -- Ten thousand Japanese attempted to storm Kinhwa, important military center in the East Coast Province of Chekiang, after a furious artillery barrage yesterday, but stubborn Chinese machine-gunners met them at the walls of the city, killed 1,000 and forced the rest to retire, a Central News Agency dispatch said today.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Bank and credit association spokesmen objected at a House Military Committee hearing today to proposed legislation to relieve secondary endorsers from the obligation of meeting debts contracted by a principal who has been inducted or enlisted in the armed services.

"Comes the Revelation," a comedy described by its author, Louis Vittes, as a satire on the growth of a typical American demagogue, opens tonight at the Jolson, 932 Seventh Avenue. The cast includes Will Geer, Peter Hobbs, Wendell Corey, Richard Karlan, Mary Perry, Lesley Woods, Wendell K. Phillips, G. Swayne Gordon, Grover Burgess, Carroll Hartley, Mitchell Harris, John Thomas, Audra Lindley, Maurice Minnick, Kathryn Cameron, June Stewart and George Leach.

Three more United Nations vessels -- a large United States merchant ship and medium-sized craft of Dutch and Norwegian registry -- have been torpedoed and sunk in Caribbean waters, it was announced yesterday by the Navy Department.

ALBANY, May 25 -- Governor Lehman broke official silence today about the reports of his probable departure to Washington to take a prominent war part and made it clear that it was by no means so imminent as had been intimated.

CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- Most hogs sold at steady prices today, although a few types were 5 to 10 cents a hundred pounds under the preceding session. Choice hogs brought a top of $14.45, against $14.50 yesterday.

At another conference at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday representatives of the Milk Drivers Union, an affilate of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L., and of leading milk distributors continued their efforts to find a compromise affecting proposed discharges in the program for the curtailment of deliveries to save tires, fuel and gasoline.

Registration of out-of-town buyers in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 498, as against 594 in the preceding week and 685 in the like period of 1941, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 145, which compared with 301 for last Tuesday.
BERLIN, May 26 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

DEVON, Pa., May 26 -- Hunters predominated at the second day of the Devon Horse Show and the Challenge Trophy, offered by Mr. and Mrs. Alfred G. Wilson, went to Joshua, from the Sunnybrook Stables of Isaac H. Clothier Jr. of Radnor.

Italy has sent to Pierre Laval, Chief of Government at Vichy, a detailed note on territorial demands against France, according to trustworthy advices received from Europe yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

NEWARK, N.J., May 26 -- Operators of filling stations in New Jersey who violate gasoline rationing regulations will be picketed by C.I.O. members, Irving Abramson, president of the State C.I.O. council, announced in a letter he sent this evening to Leon Henderson, director of the Office of Price Administration.

ST. LOUIS, May 26 (AP) -- The Tigers snapped the Browns' winning streak at four games tonight as they took a 3-to-1 decision. Eric McNair's first home run for Detroit this season and a hearty argument over the St. Louis run were the features.

To those who knew the art of Emanuel Feuermann the announcement of his death from a minor operation in yesterday's newspapers must have brought a deep sense of loss. He cannot be replaced. Had he been no more than the consummate virtuoso upon his instrument, Feuermann would have enjoyed his international fame.

The battles that will decide the future history of mankind were slowly growing in scope and magnitude on the Russian front yesterday, and in the Far East Japan continued her grandiose bid for continental power by pushing deeper into China.

BOSTON, May 26 (AP) -- Dr. Frank H. Lahey, president of the American Medical Association, said tonight that the civilian population would have to adjust itself to the rationing of medical care as well as food, clothing and automobiles due to the pressing need for doctors in the nation's armed forces.

MOSCOW, May 26 -- Adolf Hitler has summoned a conference of his leading generals to tell them he is retaining the supreme command of the German Army and will "tolerate no opposition," Tass, the Russian news agency, reported today from Stockholm, Sweden.

LONDON, May 26 (AP) -- Trustworthy reports from the Continent that Adolf Hitler was using Italy's territorial demands on France to wring from Pierre Laval the use of the French fleet appeared tonight to indicate a new threat to the United Nations' precarious mastery of the Mediterranean.

Renewed efforts are to be made by New York State authorities to get securities brokers and dealers to reveal the capacities in which they act for customers and to punish them if they do not. Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. yesterday issued orders to Assistant Attorney General Ambrose V. McCall, who is in charge of the Bureau of Securities, that Article 23-A of the General Business Law must be strictly enforced.

Further details of the nationwide campaign by retail merchants to sell war savings bonds and stamps on July 1 were announced yesterday by G. Ray Schaeffer of Chicago, campaign chairman. He met here yesterday with members of the committee to formulate a general program for a fifteen-minute period at noon on July 1 when 200,000 retailers all over the country will sell nothing but bonds and stamps.

Several large residential properties on the West Side of Manhattan were reported yesterday as having changed hands. A quick resale was listed for a loft building in Thirty-eighth Street and three deals were made in West Thirty-seventh Street. Some of the trading involved properties which are fully occupied.

Men are amused by the way in which their sisters and sweethearts and wives strive for slimness. But we were agreeably surprised the other day to discover that no less an authority than Dr. Morris Fishbein has deemed dieting a matter for his careful consideration.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- New issues of securities offered for cash in March declined to $709,000,000, the lowest amount since November, according to an analysis made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Sounding a note of encouragement in a day marked by reports of progressive rubber shortages and warnings that conservation of tires must extend from the civilian even into the armed forces if war demands were to be met, President Roosevelt told his press conference today that he did not think there was anything in the situation to cause excitement.

TOKYO, May 26 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Japanese forces have broken through enemy pillbox defenses a little more than a mile north and northwest of Kinhwa and now are in the outskirts of that important city in Central Chekiang Province, dispatches from the front asserted today.

LONDON, May 26 -- The stock markets reopened firm today after the holiday. Home rails, because of their high yields, were in urgent demand. London, Midland Scottish 4 per cent preference rose to u55, London North Eastern first preference to 54 and the 3 per cent debentures to u110.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, May 27 (U.P.) -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's Army of the Ukraine is holding fast under an intense battering by German tanks and infantry on its left flank and has made new gains in its drive on Kharkov, it was announced officially today.

The Office of Civilian Defense announced yesterday through its regional headquarters at 111 Eighth Avenue here that 7,286,158 persons had enrolled as volunteers in civilian defense throughout the country up to April 1. This figure was an increase of 1,081,567 over the March 1 total.

MEXICO CITY, May 26 -- While Mexico awaited the meeting of Congress on Thursday and some observers predicted that the vote would be unanimous for a declaration of a state of war, additional guards at airfields and forecasts of extraordinary powers for the President indicated the preparations for the new situation resulting from Axis attacks on Mexican ships.

Actors Equity Association is holding George Jessel responsible for the "stranding" of "High Kickers" in Chicago, where the musical comedy closed its tour last week, the actors' union announced yesterday.

Arrival of the canning and preserving season has started a new procession of New York City housewives to local rationing boards of the five boroughs, seeking supplemental allowances of sugar, it was disclosed yesterday by James W. Danahy, assistant State OPA director, at 535 Fifth Avenue.

CHUNGKING, China, May 26 -The Catholic vernacular paper Iche Pao criticized today the recent clamor for more bombers and pursuits and the attendant hints of dire and unavoidable consequences should this United Nations aid not be forthcoming. The paper said: "

NEWARK, N.J., May 26 (AP) -- Behind seven-hit pitching by Pete Center, Baltimore shaded Newark tonight, 5 to 4. Center had one bad inning -- the fourth -- when homers by Aaron Robinson and Lloyd Christopher sent the Bears into a temporary lead.

ONE of the penalties of literary fame, superior abilities and admirable achievements is the high standard of comparison they automatically erect. If an aspiring unknown writes a sleek, sensational and quite synthetic pot-boiler, congratulations rather than reproaches are in order. But when the author of "Of Human Bondage" writes "Up at the Villa," the author of "Arrowsmith" writes "Bethel Merriday," the author of "So Big" writes "Saratoga Trunk," their sincerest admirers squirm.

PERTH, Australia, May 26 (U.P.) -- The Australia First movement, four members of which await trial here June 2 on treason charges, plotted to set up a regime that would conclude an armistice with Japan and remove all Jews from authority, it was revealed today.
ROME, May 26 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

Members of Mayor La Guardia's family began to move their belongings yesterday from his apartment at 1274 Fifth Avenue to the Gracie Mansion at Eighty-eighth Street and the East River, new official residence for New York's Mayors.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 26 (AP) -- The sinking of a second enemy submarine off the coast of Brazil by a B-18 twin-motored Douglas bomber of the United States Air Patrol was reported today by a high source.

In a new attempt to collect a judgment for $5,949 obtained more than two years ago against Father Divine, Harlem cult leader, but still "wholly unpaid and unsatisfied," Mrs. Verinda Brown, former "angel" in Father Divine's "kingdom," filed an application in Supreme Court yesterday for an order to compel the cult leader to make installment payments on the judgment.

There is still a chance that the Berkshire Symphonic Festival will be held this Summer, according to Gertrude Robinson Smith, president of the festival corporation. She pointed out yesterday that the festival corporation hoped to keep open until June a final decision as to whether the festival should be given.

Out of the tales of religious fervor which bubbled through New York State early in the last century, Louis Vittes has constructed "Comes the Revelation," and last night John Morris Chanin and Richard Karlan put it on at the Jolson, thereby restoring that house to the quasi-legitimate.

LONDON, May 26 -- Harold Laski, Professor of Political Science at the University of London and noted liberal, accused Prime Minister Winston Churchill today of evading the question of a "people's peace" after the war in an address to the Labor party's forty-first annual convention.
