WASHINGTON, May 26 (U.P.) -- The House, by voice vote, passed and sent to the Senate today a bill legalizing wire-tapping by Federal agents in detection of war crimes.

BUFFALO, May 26 -- While three new Curtiss Warhawks, Uncle Sam's latest bolts of lightning on wings, cut dizzy patterns through the sky, Burdette S. Wright, squinting proudly upward, shouted over the roar of the motors that the Curtiss Wright Corporation was breaking all records in its all-out production for war this year.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- James S. Knowlson, director of industry operations of the War Production Board, and William P. Witherow, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, told several hundred middle western manufacturers today that the nation's industry was approaching a production rate which would give the United Nations an overwhelming advantage in the war.

James H. Hand Jr., chairman of the board and president of Remington Rand, Inc., won from Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein yesterday the dismissal of charges in a stockholders' accounting suit involving a stock purchase option given to Mr. Rand in 1932.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -Legislation extending for another two years the 3 1/2 per cent interest rate on farm mortgages made by Federal Land Banks through national farm-loan associations was passed today by the House and sent to the Senate.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Retailers and wholesalers of the United States were advised today by War Production Chief Donald Nelson to reduce their inventories to reasonable working minimums and meanwhile to avoid making panic efforts to anticipate a WPB inventory regulation since it would not become operative for some months.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture today offered technical and financial assistance and an insured market to encourage canners and processors to enlarge vegetable dehydration facilities.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Blakeley, a 1,090-ton World War-type American destroyer, was attacked in the Caribbean Sea by an enemy submarine and damaged by a torpedo, the Navy Department announced today.

A goal of $100,000, to be raised for the Army Emergency Relief through the staging of the fifty-fifth national A.A.U. outdoor track and field championships, carded for Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, June 19 and 20, was established yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the A.E.R. Committee at the Hotel Astor.

An underwriting group headed by Lehman Brothers and Glore, Forgan Co. will offer today to the public 17,609 shares of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., 4 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock at $102 a share. This offering represents the balance of 49,666 shares not subscribed by warrant holders and not sold by the underwriters during the subscription period, which began on May 16 and ended at the close of business on Monday.
MIAMI, Fla., May 26 -- An accusation of piracy was made against the Axis here by the first officer of an unarmed Latvian merchant ship that fell victim to a submarine recently in the Caribbean Sea.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Nation-wide rationing of gasoline cannot be put in effect before July 1, it was indicated tonight by Donald M. Nelson, war production chief.

The double-barreled pressure on Vichy has reached a point where the last dreary rounds of the battle of Francemust divide attention with the stubborn struggle for Kharkov and the arrival in London of a high-powered American military mission. It says something for the power of the defeated that the forces of coercion which Hitler has at his disposal do not suffice to move the dead weight of France.

Remington Rand, Inc., and its subsidiaries announced yesterday in a preliminary statement for the year ended on March 31, a net profit of $6,190,998 after depreciation, interest, Federal and foreign income taxes and other charges.

TRENTON, N.J., May 26 -- Russell J. Eldridge, director of the United States Employment Service for New Jersey, issued a help wanted appeal today for 2,000 strawberry pickers to begin harvesting the State's large strawberry crop within the next week or ten days.

Will you permit me to make my position clear with respect to the Moffat hill, which is so badly called the "Work or Don't Eat Bill"? I have not opposed this legislation because I am in hearty accord with the principle that any person who refuses a decent job should not receive public assistance.

The ballroom suite of the Park Lane was the setting last night for an indoor prairie fiesta entitled "The Round-Up," which was given for the benefit of the Madison Square Boys' Club. The proceeds will be used to provide medical care for more than 200 boys of the club.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, May. 26 --"Dr." John R. Brinkley, gland surgeon and former Kamsas gubernatorial candidate, died here today at the age of 56. He had 'enin poor health since the amputation of a leg several months ago.

BERLIN, May 26 (From German broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- German planes attacked a strongly escorted convoy Monday night between Iceland and Norway's North Cape, and in a two-hour battle sank one merchantman of 8,000 tons and damaged five, the High Command said today.

Bob Anderson pitched Fordham to its fifteenth baseball victory of the season yesterday, the hefty right-hander baffling a Coast Guard nine from Ellis Island, 4 -- 2, on the Rose Hill diamond. It was the eighth straight triumph for Anderson, who is undefeated this year.

Twilight baseball in Brooklyn as a replacement for the banned night baseball is still a bit on the uncertain side following the twilight engagement at Ebbets Field on Monday between the Dodgers and the Phils. President Larry MacPhail of the Brooklyn club said yesterday that the crowd of 9,572 was "about twice what we'd have drawn in the afternoon and about half of what we'd have drawn at night."

Business enterprise of a wide variety were represented in the commercial leasing reported yesterday. Several of the contracts called for large units of space, and one broker listed four rentals in the Twenties.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 26 -- The worm finally turned for Harry Cooper today when the 38-year-old English-born pro led the qualifiers in the silver anniversary championship of the Professional Golfers' Association.

Pearl L. Bergoff, 68 years old, who for thirty-five years conducted one of the most extensive strike-breaking organizations in the country, was fined $500 in Special Sessions yesterday. He paid it to avoid serving a thirty-day workhouse term on his recent conviction of operating a private detective agency without a State license to furnish strike-breakers and guards.
One hundred and fifty crack securities salesmen will launch today in Manhattan an intensified campaign to step up the sales of Series F and G United States Treasury War Savings bonds.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, May 27 -- The great battle in the Izyum-Barvenkova sector on the front south of Kharkov is reaching a climax as Lieut. Gen. Viktor von Schwedler flings his tanks and mechanized infantry against Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's left flank, seeking to establish bridgeheads on a river line, where Russian gunners are taking a heavy toll.

The recent order of the Office of Defense Transportation barring charter bus operation, which becomes effective June 1, will definitely complicate life for the housewife who lives in one of the huge apartment developments in the city or suburbs, for it will deprive her of the special bus service that takes her to subway or train when she goes shopping, window shopping, or to the movies or theatre, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -Government stocks of raw cotton soon will have to be withdrawn from the market unless there is a change in the 1938 Agriculture Adjustment Act, Department of Agriculture officials disclosed today.

MILWAUKEE, May 26 (AP) -- A new world built on fundamentals of Christian brotherhood taught by Christ is "the only kind of a world that will prevent a repetition of the present universal agony," Francis B. Sayre, High Commissioner to the Philippines, asserted today.

THERE came a letter from Dr. Hamilton Holt, president of Rollins College at Winter Park, Fla. Anything that Dr. Holt says is worth hearing and anything he writes is worth some study. Lend an eye to the following:

Dr. Charles Dewey Crandall, 44-year-old deputy medical superintendent of Bellevue Hospital, was arrested on a charge of felonious assault last night as the result of a fracas in which a man was severely beaten with a club in Dr. Crandall's living quarters on the ninth floor of the Bellevue Psychopathic Building at First Avenue and Thirtieth Street.

By changing their accounting periods from the calendar year to the natural business or fiscal year, companies not engaged in all-out war production were told yesterday they would help "clear the decks" for bankers and accountants to serve the increasing requirements of companies giving their full time to war output and not at present in a position to make the change.

CHESTER, Pa., May 26 -- John G. Pew, president of the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, announced today that all the 9,000 workers at a new shipbuilding yard now under construction would be Negroes.

Everything was on its side; the catwalk rimmed the starboard promenade deck like a trail along a mountain ledge. More than sixty feet below a cluster red plush seats protruded soggily above the olive water; that was what was left of the ship's theatre.

The Sinking Fund trustees of Cincinnati, Ohio, awarded yesterday to a group composed of the Union Securities Corporation, Hornblower Weeks and the Equitable Securities Corporation a total of $2,616,000 of various bonds held by the sinking fund.

Declaring that order L-41 had not had the desired effect in curtailing construction work, Colonel Kent J. Owens, assistant chief of the housing priority branch of the War Production Board, announced yesterday that a new and more drastic order was about to be issued which would almost put an end to private building work.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 26 -- The possibility that Chile may modify her international policy, in the light of developments like Mexico's determined attitude and the torpedoing of the Argentine tanker Victoria, is uppermost in the minds of Chileans.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -Customs men at all American ports have been instructed to impound, at least temporarily, all money, either American or foreign, brought into this country.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- The present membership of the Securities and Exchange Commission split by a three-to-two vote for the first time today in an opinion granting the Virginia Public Service Company the right to proceed with the sale of $36,500,000 first mortgage bonds and sinking fund debentures without awaiting the outcome of a recapitalization proceeding.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 26 -- Japanese fliers in the New Britain and New Guinea areas are using a new aerial bomb -- described by United Nations pilots as pear-shaped or cone-shaped -- as an offensive weapon against formations of United Nations planes returning from raids.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Tentative action to revise the exemption for estate taxes and to lower the gift exemption in the tax structure was voted today by the Ways and Means Committee. It deferred action, however, on the rates of probable new taxes to be imposed.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 26 -Tonight's reports from Berlin say the battle of Kharkov is raging with undiminished intensity and military writers in the German capital assert that the encirclement manoeuvres in progress there are destined to go down in military history as the most colossal on the chronology of the Eastern European campaign.

CANBERRA, Australia, May 26 -- As 318,000 more men and women will be needed by December for the fighting forces and war industries, the War Cabinet decided today that these requirements would be met by a further diversion of man power from nonessential industries and by a big increase in the number of women workers.

What seems clearly to be a first tentative move in the direction of a peace offensive by Japan was reported in this newspaper yesterday. It consisted of a short-wave broadcast from Tokyo by Toshi Go, a spokesman of the Foreign Office. Mr. Go's last sojourn in the United States was made in his capacity as commissioner to the New York World's Fair.

Jackie Cooper, 151, Chicago, defeated Wicky Harkins, 149, of Philadelphia in the star bout of ten rounds at the Queensboro Arena last night. A crowd of 4,000 saw the fight. The program was the year's first outdoor boxing promotion in the metropolitan area, and dimout precautions seemed quite satisfactory.

LONDON, May 26 -- The British picture of the battle in the Kharkov sector of the Russian front still is confused and London authorities are not yet ready to draw any conclusions as to what it means. Nevertheless, opinion here does not regard the Kharkov fighting as in any way decisive so far as Russian resistance in its broad outline is concerned.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (U.P.) -- The Office of Censorship asked Congress today to pass legislation closing a loophole which made censoring of international communications difficult to enforce.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 26 -- American Army camps in Australia have welcomed the news that Major William Bradford of Texas, commander of the "Bamboo Fleet" of rickety planes that carried vital medicines and official mail to besieged Bataan and Corregidor, has escaped from the Philippines and joined his comrades in Australia.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 26 -- "The Man From Down Under," a screen story by Mark Kelly and Bogart Rogers, was purchased today by Metro-Goldyn-Mayer as a vehicle for Wallace Beery, who will play the role of an Australian veteran of the first World War in the picture.

NOUMEA, New Caledonia, May 26 -- The American troops in New Caledonia are operating in French territory that is loyally pro-Ally and emphatically Free French. The political differences that exist here are chiefly between Free French factions, the importance of which is minimized by Rear Admiral Georges Thierry d'Argenlieu, High Commissioner of Free French Territories in the Pacific, whose headquarters are in Noumea.

Yesterday Queen Mary was 75. The Princess May was the fitting name by which she used to be called. This is the third war that she has seen. In her private griefs, as in the disasters of her country, she has been patient and brave. What queen has been more loved by her people or more deserving of love?

SAN FRANCISCO, May 26 -- With tears in his eyes and a voice that broke with emotion, Mayor Angelo J. Rossi protested today his "100 per cent" loyalty to America and told a committee of the California Assembly that his presence before it as a witness was "based on the damnable lies of irresponsible people."

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The War Production Board today announced assumption of control over the distribution of many types of general industrial equipment so that they will be directed into war channels. The order affects such machinery as passenger and freight elevators, electric motors of more than one horsepower, industrial fans, industrial compressors and pumps and a number of other classes of machinery used generally in various industrial operations.

This is the uneasy season when women stand sadly before a full-length mirror and consider their silhouettes. Every day the papers print tempting sketches of short little skirts and abbreviated bathing suits -- but the Average Woman regards them despairingly.

The life savings, amounting to $400, of Lieutenant George Barr of 211-49 Ninety-fourth Road, Queens Village, who took part in the bombing of Tokyo on April 18, were invested in war savings bonds yesterday at a ceremony in the office of Borough President James A. Burke of Queens.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 26 (AP) --Ewell Blackwell, rookie Syracuse right-hander, lost his second four-hitter in two starts as Jersey City scored a 1-0 victory over the Chiefs tonight. Bobby Coombs blanked the Chiefs with six hits for the second time in four days.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP) -The rapid expansion of American shipbuilding since the outbreak of the European war was shown today in figures released by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which reported combined sales of five companies alone rose $24,000,000 in 1940.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 26 -- Should the President appoint a unified command over both the Army and the Navy?

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Should the Soviet Government accept the proposal of the American Government today -- that it sign a new lease-lend agreement similar to that which others of the United Nations have signed -- the effects on the post-war world can be tremendous.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 26 -Shipments of flour reaching Greece in the past two months, together with the appearance of seasonal fruits and vegetables, has to some extent relieved the famine that last Winter took a tremendous toll and depressed the birthrate almost to nil.

The advance ticket sale for the "war bond world premiere" on Friday night at the Hollywood Theatre of "Yankee Doodle Dandy" totaled $5,250,000 yesterday afternoon, it was announced by the New York War Savings Staff of the Treasury Department.

Spurred by the success of the advertising and publicity campaign to counteract statements made following Pearl Harbor to the effect that "it was unpatriotic to dress up," a committee representing the entire evening dress group of the New York Dress Institute yesterday signed a petition urging continuation and expansion of the promotional effort.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- A draft proposal of a lease-lend agreement that would align Russia in respect to this form of aid with Britain and others of the United Nations was handed to Maxim Litvinoff, the Soviet Ambassador, today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

Japanese control over Far Eastern areas producing vital materials has been offset at least partially by American ingenuity, which has developed satisfactory substitutes, Colonel George S. Brady, chief of the materials statistics division, Office of Imports, Board of Economic Warfare, declared yesterday at the second day's session of the twenty-seventh annual convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.

When President Roosevelt this week sent congratulations to Argentina on her 132d Independence Day he had to write two messages, one to President Roberto Ortiz and one to Acting President Ramon Castillo. The task was a delicate one. President Ortiz is a moderate liberal, and it is generally supposed that if he were active he would break relations with the Axis Powers and in other ways give outright support to the policy of hemisphere solidarity.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Before approximately 250 members of the policy committee and the executive board of the United Mine Workers today, their president, John L. Lewis, and Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O. and also a vice president of the miners' union, argued the differences between them.

LONDON, May 26 -- Americans in Europe will participate in a great air offensive that Britain and the United States are preparing against Nazi Germany to take some of the sting out of the blow that Adolf Hitler is delivering against Russia.

Federal and State officials joined in a special memorial service for war veterans of the New York Postoffice during the noon hour yesterday in the lobby of the General Postoffice, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-third Street, under the auspices of the Dan Tallon Post, American Legion.

The Charles Hayden Foundation has offered $5,000 toward the continuation of Wiltwyck School for Boys at Esopus, N.Y., it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Eugene C. Carder, chairman of the non-sectarian board recently organized to take over the institution from the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society.
A ten-room furnished apartment in the building at 1000 Park Avenue has been leased for Bing Bing, Inc., agents, by Warren Marks Associates, brokers, to Bertalan Magyar.

Maybe the Yankee hitters have found their batting eyes at last or maybe the Red Sox pitching is merely settling down to its normal gait. Whatever the reason, the New Yorkers fell on three Boston hurlers at the Stadium yesterday for thirteen hits, including three decorative home runs, and whirled off with a 9-to-2 victory.

Six hundred volunteer citizens serving the city's health interests through the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association reached more than 500,000 residents of New York through lectures, exhibits and personal conferences, Dr. J. Burns Amberson Jr., president of the association, announced yesterday in presenting his annual report to the board of directors.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -Legislation making labor unions liable to prosecution under the 1934 Anti-Racketeering Act was sent to the House today by its Judiciary Committee.

A committee raising funds for "scholarships in American citizenship" at Barnard College is currently putting on a "Parade of Patriots" at the Grand Central Art Galleries, Gotham branch. The patriots owe their preservation in this form to such artists as John Singleton Copley, Gilbert Stuart, John Wesley Jarvis, John Trumbull, and others famous and obscure, gifted or merely competent.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Despite the rubber shortages now compelling increasingly stringent rationing, the United States has virtually the only present and potential stockpiles of this vital commodity from which the United Nations may draw, the Senate was told today by the Truman committee, which has been investigating the national defense program.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses does not see the difference between a person in a bathing suit on a beach and in the same attire on a boardwalk.

Thirty-four blind men and women are employed in the Connecticut defense factories. Many of the jobs were secured through the efforts of the placement agent of the State Board of Education for the Blind, who lost his own sight in an industrial accident shortly after graduation from college sixteen years ago.

LONDON, May 26 -- Air power is an "indissoluble ingredient" of sea power in modern warfare, Admiral Sir Andrew Cunningham declared at a press conference today, using his experience as commander in chief in the Mediterranean all through this war to prove his point.

CLEVELAND, May 26 (AP) -- Les Fleming singled home a pair of runs in the ninth to snap the Indians' losing streak at five games and give them a 2-to-1 victory over the White Sox under the Stadium lights tonight. It was Edgar Smith's seventh straight loss.

The program of city-wide Harlem Week was continued last night with a round table discussion of the employment, health, housing and educational needs of the Negro population, broadcast over WEVD under the auspices of the City-Wide Committee on Harlem.

R.J. Marony, fiscal representative here of the trustees of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, announced payment dates yesterday on certain of the carrier's bonds as authorized by the Federal Court in Chicago on April 14.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -America can now celebrate July 4 in the traditional fashion with firecrackers, rockets, roman candles and other fireworks.

That Mexico is on the point of declaring war upon Germany points the sharp contrast which exists between our relations with our neighbors to the south today and in the last war. In 1917 the background of relations between Mexico and ourselves was unfriendly. We had occupied Vera Cruz not long before, and our armed forces, under General Pershing, had invaded Mexican territory in pursuit of the bandit Villa.

The five-story factory building at 31-29 Vernon Boulevard, Long Island City, has been leased by the Harrob Realty Corporation to the Van Portation Corporation and Return Loads, Inc., through Lehr Benes, Inc., brokers.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered today the temporary suspension of scheduled air transport services along important air lines throughout the country, because of the recent transfer of many commercial airplanes to the Army.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -Women's hair can be kept as curly as ever despite War Production Board orders stopping the manufacture of bobbie pins and indications that some chemicals used in permanent wave solutions may fall prey to war priorities.

A demonstration of emergency first aid and the technique of extinguishing incendiary bombs was given last night by wardens of Section D, Zone 1, of the Fifteenth Precinct in a parking lot at Thirty-eighth Street and Madison Avenue. Several hundred residents of the Murray Hill section were present.

ALBANY, May 26 -- Murray L. Watt has been appointed special counsel of the State Insurance Department to have charge of insuring State properties under the new war damage act which becomes effective July 1. He took his oath of office before Lieutenant Governor Poletti in the department's New York office.
TACOMA, May 26 -- Eugene L. Mann, 65-year-old president of four corporations, forsook the golf links and the easy chair today to report for Army duty at $21 a month.

Covering of short positions by local operators and New Orleans interests following the small allotment of cotton for the trade in the fifth monthly disposition of government stock by the Commodity Credit Corporation sent the cotton futures market up yesterday in late trading.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP) -The Senators swept their two-game series with the Athletics, notching an 8-to-3 triumph behind big Steve Sundra's careful pitching today.

CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- The Cubs momentarily snatched a hard-earned victory away from the Cardinals today, but St. Louis scored two runs in the tenth inning to defeat Chicago, 3 to 1, and sweep the two-game series.

As a means of advising fishermen and hunters in this State of various changes in the New York Conservation Law, the Conservation Department has issued a summary of some of the fifty-two conservation bills Governor Lehman recently signed.

Argentinita, the Spanish dancer, who was on the verge of appearing in the first edition of "Keep 'Em Laughing" and then decided not to, is now set for the second edition, opening Friday night at the Forty-fourth Street. Jack Cole and his dancers, members of the present cast, will not be in the revised show.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Richard Earnhart, an 11-year-old pupil in the seventh grade of Coldwell School in El Paso, Texas, won the National Spelling Bee today by knowing "acquiesced" and "sacrilegious."

The Junior Emergency Relief Society distributed 177,996 "articles" to war relief agencies, hospitals and philanthropic institutions during the year ended May 15, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon at the Biltmore Hotel attended by 300 persons.

Robert E. Rew, a Nyack securities broker, and James Henry Ferdon Saier, vice president of Rew's company, were acquitted of fraud in connection with an oil enterprise yesterday by a jury in Federal court. The jury, which deliberated less than two hours after having heard testimony during the last two weeks, also acquitted Rew's concern, Robert E. Rew Co.

The general death rate in New York City set a low record for the year again last week, it was reported yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records in the city Health Department. The rate was 9.2 per 1,000 population. The previous week it was 9.9, a low record then.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Recruiting for officer candidates for the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps will begin throughout the country tomorrow morning at regular army recruiting stations. This was announced by the War Department today at the same time that a new ruling was issued to permit women from 45 to 49 to apply for training with the first group of officer candidates.
Commencement exercises at the Biblical Seminary in New York brought it several thousand dollars nearer the $116,000 sought to avert foreclosure of a mortgage, it was learned yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, May 26 -- A plea for more vigorous church action to protect the community against crime and immorality was made today to the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. by Wilbur La Roe Jr., an attorney of Washington, speaking for the National Committee on Social Education and Action.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 26 -- Mal Galletta, North Hills player who has been faring handsomely this season, was the only one of fifty-four starters to match par at Quaker Ridge today in the year's first one-day tournament of the Metropolitan Golf Association.
Sir Bede Clifford, Governor of Trinidad, and Lady Clifford are at the Ritz Tower.

BERLIN, May 26 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- A German Government spokesman said today that Germany, Italy and Japan were carrying out a naval offensive based on a "joint plan" of operation and that attacks on United Nations merchant vessels and warships would be intensified "on all oceans and from day to day."

Despite Washington's warnings against overconfidence, Major Gen. Hanson Ely admitted last night in an interview at the Officers Club in the Sherry-Netherland that he is an optimist about the chances of the United Nations for early victory.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -The high cost of coffee, coal and wool was advanced by Senators today as a pressing reason for Congressional approval of a bill to increase the RFC's borrowing power by $5,000,000,000, and to authorize the payment of government subsidies to maintain current price ceilings.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -The Senate Military Affairs Committee approved legislation today to provide more liberal allowances for the dependents of fighting men than those in a pending House measure. A priority system for the induction of men with families also was approved.

ST. LUCIA, British West Indies, May 26 -- A submarine lurking in the waters of the French island of Martinique torpedoed the United States destroyer Blakeley yesterday while the continuing negotiations regarding the status of the island were in progress between the United States and the island government.

In the editorial, "Appeal From China," of May 21, you expressed the universal feeling of Americans toward the Chinese as our comrades in arms. I wonder whether this would not be a good time to give thought to our treatment of these comrades under the immigration law.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The United States import balance of trade with the twenty Latin-American republics increased by 46 per cent in the first quarter of this year as compared with the corresponding quarter last year, the Census Bureau announced today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 26 -- The Inter-American Conference on Coordination of Police and Judicial Measures, called to discuss precautions against foreign threats, will meet here tomorrow morning. All American States will be represented.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., May 26 -- Mrs. Arthur J. Sorin of Elmsford won the Joseph J. Windle Memorial Trophy today when she finished 5 down to par over the difficult west and east nines of the Ridgewood Country Club course.

Two new film attractions will open in Broadway theatres this morning. "Take a Letter, Darling," a Paramount comedy starring Rosalind Russell and Fred MacMurray, will have its world premiere at the Paramount. Mac donald Carey, Robert Benchley, Constance Moore and Cecil Kellaway appear in supporting roles.

The constant widening of the "inflationary gap" is one of the most serious domestic concerns of our Government. As the Office of Price Administration has recently estimated, there will be an uncovered difference of 17 billions between buying power and supply of consumer goods for 1942.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Eight concerns in the New York and New Jersey area holding large war contracts have been ordered by the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practice to cease and desist from discriminating against potential workers because of their said today.

Nearly 18,000 bottles of wines, liquors, beers and mineral waters from the stores of the Normandie were sold at auction yesterday at the United States Appraiser's Stores, 201 Varick Street. They brought $20,723.

BOSTON, May 26 -- The Giants' invasion of this metropolis of culture and Stengelese entertainment ended in complete disaster today as the astounding Braves, bent on defying even the law of gravitation, maintained their second-place perch in the National League by again trouncing Mel Ott's Polo Grounders.

CHUNGKING, China, May 26 (U.P.) -- Chinese defenders have hurled the Japanese back from two to nine miles in three directions from the outskirts of Kinhwa, killing another 3,000 to raise Japanese losses in the Chekiang campaign to 8,000 men, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Roosevelt declared in his press conference today that the arrival of top-ranking American air and tank officers in London represented another link in the campaign to win the war. He declined, however, to commit himself on whether a second front in Europe would be established soon.

How to reconcile higher labor and material costs with selling prices in the period July 1 to Sept. 30, 1941, set in the supplementary order of the OPA on seasonal goods, monopolized the attention of the women's garment industry here yesterday, particularly the coat and popular prices dress divisions.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Roosevelt said today that he would take up proposals within the next few days to conscript youths of 18 and 19 for military service. Mr. Roosevelt said that he would discuss the matter with Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of selective service, who has joined the War Department in publicly advocating such a change in the draft law.

LONDON, May 26 -- Queen Marie of Yugoslavia and her lady in waiting, Mrs. R. Cresswell, were badly shaken up but escaped uninjured today when the car in which they were driving through Bedfordshire to London was in collision with a motor truck.

Chief Justice Harlan F. Stone of the Supreme Court came here from Washington last night for three hours to attend the fortieth anniversary reunion dinner of the Columbia Law School class of '02, the first class taught by him as a professor in the law school of which he later became dean.

Shut Out served notice yesterday that the Belmont Stakes would be no cakewalk for Alsab, for the Kentucky Derby winner smashed off a mile and a furlong within two-fifths of a second of the track record and had far behind him such a good horse as Challedon.

The President's reduction in the budget estimate for the Work Projects Administration in the fiscal year 1943 from $465,000,000 to $280,000,000 is an encouraging sign of the beginnings of economy in nondefense expenditures. Even more encouraging is the President's intimation that other forms of relief may in time lead to the "possible elimination" of WPA.

Plans by land, sea and air forces got under way yesterday to provide for the security of the 500,000 persons who will march all day up Fifth Avenue on June 13 to display "New York at War," as well as the equal number of spectators who will occupy the sidewalks of Fifth Avenue from Washington Square to Seventy-second Street.

NEWARK, N.J., May 26 -- Dr. Meta L. Anderson Post, director since 1922 of special education in the Newark public school system, was killed instantly this morning when the automobile in which she was riding was in collision with a truck at the Wilson Avenue ramp of Route 25 here.

Members of the New York Curb Exchange have approved, 177 to 68, an amendment of the constitution raising stock commissions an average of about 25 per cent, effective today. Bond commissions are not changed. At the same balloting, members approved another amendment clarifying the status of a member firm that loses its Curb member by death.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Vigorously opposing confirmation of Thomas F. Meaney of Jersey City as a Federal judge, Governor Edison of New Jersey told a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today that approval of the appointment would be equivalent to "putting Frank Hague on the Federal bench."

Madeline Webb testified yesterday before Judge Jonah J. Goldstein and the jury in General Sessions that she had nothing to do with the murder on March 4 of Mrs. Susie Flora Reich, middle-aged refugee, in the Hotel Sutton in East Fifty-sixth Street.
CHUNGKING, China, May 26 (AP) -- The Chinese Command issued the following communique tonight:
Banks figured as sellers in most of the realty deals reported on the East Side of Manhattan yesterday.
Uniforms of women volunteers are not new fashions but symbols of responsibility and must be worn with that responsibility in mind, Mrs. Carmel Snow, editor of Harper's Bazaar, warned yesterday.

The rumor-mongering and whispering campaign against the Jersey coast about which complaint has been registered in the newspapers has, we find, been extended to the Long Island coast. Reports are being circulated in inland regions that the waters of Long Island are unfit for bathing because they are filled with oil from sunken tankers, and bodies of sailors are said to be washing up on the beach every few minutes.

NEWARK, N.J., May 26 -- As the outcome of a special election held today, Newark will retain its present form of City Commission government. With six districts missing from a total of 248, the administration defeated the proponents of the Council-Manager government plan by a vote of 49,703 to 14,342.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -The House voted 344 to 0 today to pass a $200,000,000 measure designed to utilize the facilities of small business for production of war and essential civilian goods.
With the further revision of air schedules at La Guardia Field practically completed, a survey showed yesterday that the daily volume of traffic is now less than half what it was a year ago.

Directors of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, $1,000,000,000 utility holding company, passed yesterday the dividend on the corporation's preferred stock. The last quarterly dividend on the issue was 75 cents a share on April 1.

DETROIT, May 26 (AP) -- R.L. Vaniman, deputy chief of the War Production Board's automotive branch, told the Detroit Automobile Dealers Association here today that, at the present rate of rationing, supplies of motor trucks will be exhausted by January, 1943.

Five hundred refugees for whom arrangements were made by the Dominican Republic Settlement Association, Inc., are now at the Sousa settlement in that country, Avra W. Warren, newly appointed United States Minister to the Caribbean Republic, said yesterday at a luncheon in his honor at the Lotos Club, 110 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Newtown, the leader in the City P.S.A.L. senior track and field championship meet which had to be abbreviated last Saturday, added six more points to its total when the remaining two events on the program were held at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, gave orders today that housing rents in twenty war production and military training areas should be reduced to levels prevailing in January, April and July, 1941. He gave out maximum rent rules for housing accommodations other than hotels and rooming houses for the control of rent in the areas and reported the appointment of nineteen area rent directors who will administer them.

BOSTON, May 26 -- Harold L. Ickes warned New England tonight to prepare for the worst in the matter of fuel oil supplies for homes and factories next Winter and declared that it was the duty of the petroleum industry here to advise home owners to convert their oil burners to coal heating systems without delay.

The stock market was irregularly higher yesterday but was able to maintain its gains only under the greatest difficulty. Volume on the Stock Exchange was 284,930 shares, against 233,270 on Monday. Only two issues managed to generate trades of 5,000 shares or more.

" Lovely promoters" from Park Avenue, whose primary contribution to the war is seeking "glamorous jobs," drew the scorn yesterday of James G. Blaine, chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office. He said that he would rather have the services of the Tenth Avenue mother who devoted all day to her children but still found time for Red Cross work.

TOKYO, May 26 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Japanese Imperial Headquarters asserted today that Japanese naval forces had sunk or heavily damaged 251 United Nations warships and destroyed or crippled 2,274 planes up to May 20.

With the publication of "Mark Twain at Work," Bernard DeVoto reveals his intention of some day enlarging his "Mark Twain's America." The three essays in the new book show the direction that the expansion would take. For the first time, Mr. DeVoto says of them, here is something on the actual writing of "Tom Sawyer" and "Huckleberry Finn" and a theory regarding the unconscious portion of Mark Twain's mind.

Pledging the enrollment of 50,000 of the 200,000 "minute men and women" needed for the War Bond Pledge Campaign of Greater New York, which will undertake a house-to-house and office-to-office solicitation for war savings bond sales pledges beginning June 14, the 1,250 Boy Scout troops in this city concluded yesterday their arrangements for the drive.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -The P_ NJ Utilities Company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for approval of a proposed exchange of its holdings o5 preferred and common stock of the Keystone Public Service Company with the Associated Electric Company for $1,832,500 [the Metropolitan Edison Corporation's secured consolidated refunding gold bonds, 6 per cent series, due in 1961.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

BERLIN, May 27 (From German broadcast recorded by The United Press) -- Germany is fighting a war for grain and bread, for the conquest of material conditions and for the solution of social problems -- "for a life which is worth the trouble of living by 100,000,000 people," Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels said today.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 27 -- Continuing to monopolize top honors in the weekly one-day tournaments of the Women's Long Island Golf Association, Mrs. R.M. Torgerson of Lakeville today won low gross honors for the fourth time in a row as she toured the long and difficult North Shore Country Club course in 41, 43 -- 84.

Cardboard or fiberboard swords in red, white and blue; detachments on bicycles and roller skates; a float carrying the largest Minute Man ever constructed; and, as poetically described to the reporters by some one in Chairman Grover Whalen's office, 5,000 paraders with torches consisting of.
BERLIN, May 27 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

LONDON, May 27 -- General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Free French, hinted today at a desire for political recognition of the Free French organization and at a desire to enlarge the National Committee formed here last September to include political figures who had proved that they represented the true interests of France.

In your issue of May 5 there appeared an able editorial suggesting proper caution and full consideration before the demolition of the Second Avenue Elevated structure from Chatham Square to Fifty-ninth Street and across the Queens Borough Bridge to the Bridge Plaza in Queens.

More than half of the $106,073,139 spent by food and grocery advertisers in 1941 went to national space in newspapers, with the balance divided among magazines, farm journals and radio, according to the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

The American Superpower Corporation invited yesterday holders of its first preferred stock to exchange their holdings into the $3 cumulative preferred stock of the United Corporation on the basis of three shares for one. The company stated that it owned 130,000 shares of United Corporation preferred stock and was prepared to exchange them for 43,333 shares of its own first preferred stock.

Two books on the Russian war machine are due next month. The first to come out will be "Russia's Fighting Forces," by Captain Sergei N. Kournakoff (June 11, Duell, Sloan Pearce). The author, a writer on Soviet affairs, is a former officer in the Russian Imperial Army.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 27 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A "freezing" of essential workers in critical war industries to their present jobs was decided upon today by the War Manpower Commission to stop "labor pirating," described as a severe interference with war production.

Gas rationing boards must all the time be confronting subtle problems in essentials and nonessentials. To take the suburban automobile owners to the movies once a week will probably be sternly denied as nonessential.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- Farmers, having completed a large percentage of their corn planting, are giving their attention now to the marketing of their surplus grain, and are estimated to have sold in the last three days more than 1,000,000 bushels for shipment here.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress to increase the authorization for public defense housing by $600,000,000, and to appropriate $73,000,000 for the Office of Scientific Research and Development; signed the bill increasing from $300,000,000 to $800,000,000 the amount of private loans for defense housing which the FHA may guarantee, and met with the Pacific War Council.

CHUNGKING, China, May 27 -While Japanese apologists are propagandizing the idea of the "Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere," ronins and adventurers, encouraged and protected by the military, are swarming over occupied China and penetrating trade and agriculture so thoroughly that merchants and .farmers face bankruptcy and slow starvation, according to refugees reaching Free China.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The basis for an effort to oust Philip Murray from his post as vice president of the United Mine Workers was laid before the union's policy committee today by District 50, at a meeting in which for the second day Mr. Murray clashed with John L. Lewis.

Abolition of financial aid to students by the National Youth Administration would be a heavy blow to education and the war, speakers declared yesterday at a "Preserve iNrYA'' rally at Hunter College. Representatives of 7,000 Hunter girls planned a drive to send giant petitions and individual i postcards to the House Appropriations Committee protesting a Change.

Plans have been completed for its first public financing by Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., George A. Henderson, president of the company, announced yesterday. The company is one of the oldest chemical concerns in the United States, having been established in 1849.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- A five-point voluntary plan for compliance with the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Utilities Stock and Bond Corporation, the Empire Southern Gas Company, Robert W. Rea and Floyd W. Woodcock.

Riding the cushion of a five-run Yankee outburst in the fourth, Tiny Bonham moved along to his seventh successive victory of an unbeaten campaign at the Stadium yesterday as he moved down the Athletics. However, the 215-pound Tiny did not get another shut-out, but was content enough to gain a comfortable 8-to-3 triumph.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The number of new passenger automobiles made available for rationing in June will be the same as was allocated monthly in March, April and May this year, plus any unused quota carried over at the end of May, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

Asserting that the profit motive must not be destroyed if war production is to be maintained at full rate, Dr. Julius Hirsch, former head of the German price control board in the years following the World War, declared yesterday that in this wartime period the economic function of profits was changed fundamentally.

The New York City Department of Commerce lent its aid toward relieving the present oil shortage when it expedited the construction of new oil storage tanks in the city as long ago as February, 1941, Commerce Commissioner George A. Sloan reported yesterday.

DEVON, Pa., May 27 -- Miss Deborah G. Rood of Wilmington, Del., rode her 8-year-old brown gelding, Calahan, to victory in the event for ladies' hunters under side saddle at the Devon Horse Show and County Fair today.

LONDON, May 27 -- George Bernard Shaw protested -- moderately for him -- against being roused from his slumbers tonight to answer questions about a matter in which he said he had "no pecuniary interest." It was a question involving royalties on Katharine Cornell's final dozen Broadway performances of "Candida" and her week's engagement in Washington -- all for the benefit of the Army and Navy Relief Funds.

PORT MORESBY, New Guinea, May 26 (Delayed) -- The first night raid since February on the United Nations base here was carried out last night by the Japanese, who thus fulfilled their radioed promise that they would start bombing Port Moresby on May 25.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Roosevelt reviewed general war problems today with members of the Pacific War Council; with Louis Johnson, his personal emissary to India, and with General George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 27 -- Army and Navy teams met in annual competition today in three sports, lacrosse, tennis and golf. The cadets were victorious in lacrosse and tennis but lost by a single point on the links.

MOSCOW, Thursday, May 28 (AP) -- Russian troops battling on the Kharkov and Barvenkova fronts were reported today to have beaten their way forward in both areas after killing 4,500 more Germans and capturing large quantities of equipment.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 -- Harry R. Bridges told a committee of the California Assembly today that Nazi "storm troopers in full regalia" came to San Francisco on German ships in pre-war days, and that Mayor Rossi attended a "German house" meeting in October, 1938, at which the invasion of Czechoslovakia was celebrated.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- An account of the exploits of Lieutenant John D. Bulkeley's squadron of Navy "mosquito" boats in Philippine waters during the siege of those islands by the Japanese was released by the Navy Department today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The submarine menace has been "considerably checked and will be increasingly checked with the new plans now being put into operation," Senator Walsh, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee, said today in the most hopeful pronouncement on the shipping situation that has been made since the new U-boat offensive began.

PITTSBURGH, May 27 (AP) -- Three errors contributed to the Pirates' fourth successive defeat as they lost, 5 -- 3, to the Cardinals today. The Redbirds had two runs handed to them on a platter, yet still needed an eighth-inning drive to break a 3-3 deadlock.

BALTIMORE, May 27 (AP) -- Rolling up a 4-0 advantage in the first half, the North's. All-Star collegiate lacrosse team fought off a second-half rally to defeat the South, 6 to 3, tonight in the third and rubber game of the North-South lacrosse series.

MOSCOW, May 27 -- The Russians have succeeded in consolidating their bridgehead on the river line in the Izyum-Barvenkova sector south of Kharkov, broadening the territory they hold on the right bank and bringing over sufficient tanks and guns to advance, capture the northern hill slopes and attack a village, according to dispatches received here late today.

An 18-year-old boy who had been homeless and friendless since his father, mother and brother died four years ago, found a friend yesterday in Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz, himself a father of two boys and nationally known as a defender of those who have come in conflict with the law.

Two 16-year-old youths and the 13-year-old brother of one were under arrest yesterday charged with attempting to rob two small boys in an isolated part of Bronx Park. The trio let their victims loose after they had disdainfully returned the loot, a pocket knife, an empty wallet and a signet ring.

A repossessed property in the Chelsea section of Manhattan has passed to new control with the sale by the Dry Dock Savings Institution of the six-story elevator building with twenty-five apartments at 254-8 West Twenty-fifth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

BERLIN, May 27 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- A German battle of annihilation has broken the resistance of strong Russian forces trapped in a pocket south of Kharkov, a communique from Adolf Hitler's field headquarters said today.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Army Air Forces will begin training large numbers of glider pilots under an expansion program to be started June 1, the War Department said today.

Axis submarines have sunk six more ships in waters on this side of the Atlantic, it was disclosed yesterday. The loss of four vessels, a medium-sized United States merchant ship, a medium-sized British vessel, a small Greek merchantman and a United States steam fishing trawler, was announced by the Navy Department, while the news of the sinking of a 4,471-ton Swedish steamer and a 1,417-ton Dutch freighter came from other sources.

Announcement that the House Banking and Currency Committee had approved a bill prohibiting the sale of agricultural products below parity prices brought a short-lived flurry of buying into yesterday's cotton market, lifting prices to gains of 11 to 13 points early in the afternoon.

BOSTON, May 27 -- A 44 per cent increase in the volume of orders booked by the textile industry during April, compared with those booked in March, plus smaller increases in other components, has raised the indicated demand for products of Massachusetts manufacturers to a new high level, it was announced today by the Associated Industries of Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Further changes in pending leglislation to create a Women's Reserve Corps in the Navy were indicated today when it became known that President Roosevelt had put pressure on the Navy Department and the Senate Naval Affairs Committee to make the proposed corps an auxiliary civilian group rather than an integral part of the Naval Reserve.

Three hold-up men took over the lobby of the Hotel Bossert at 98 Montague Street in Brooklyn at 4:15 A.M. yesterday, threatened the hotel staff with revolvers and after a forty-minute search for loot left with only $100 in petty cash.

On the milk question we are faced with a condition, not an economic theory. The Federal Government has seen fit through its Surplus Marketing Administration to make milk available to school children at 1c a half pint. The necessity is to provide a quart of milk a day for every child.

BOSTON, May 27 -- The statement of the Ford Motor Company for 1941, filed today with Henry F. Long, Massachusetts Commissioner of Corporations and Taxation, shows an increase of $5,050,142 in surplus during the year and one of $1,865,671 in reserves, or a total increase of $6,915,813.

CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -- About 15,000 head of cattle arrived today on the livestock market, forcing steers and yearlings, down as much as 25 cents a hundred pounds. A few choice and prime offerings held steady. The arrivals were 4,000 more than expected and compared with 9,858 head on last Wednesday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (AP) -- United States District Judge William H. Kirkpatrick approved today a plan for reorganization of the Philadelphia Reading Coal and Iron Company as a climax of a five-year court battle. The plan, reducing the company's capital structure from $61,531,700 to $11,238,229, was proposed by three major bondholders' committees, but four similar groups and the Securities and Exchange Commission argued against it, the SEC declaring it was "not feasible."

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A draft proposal under the lend-lease law for economic collaboration during and after the war was presented by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today to T.V. Soong, the Chinese Foreign Minister. It is similar to the draft given Maxim M. Litvinoff, the Soviet Ambassador, yesterday, and the agreement concluded with the British last February.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A program designed to reclaim 85,000 tons of rubber a year from the country's 800,000 to 1,000,000 ton scrap heap has been undertaken by the government and plans will be announced soon, Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce and Federal Loan Administrator, told the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce today.

One of the last of the season's fashion luncheons on the terrace of Belmont Park was sponsored by Russeks yesterday. It was as gala as the sunny Spring day. Throughout it was keyed to the color sentiment of the day.
The five-story tenement dwelling on a plot 23 by 155 feet at 467 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Ola May Clift to a client of P. Zaccaro Company, Inc., brokers.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Shutdowns in any war plant scheduled for Saturday in observance of Memorial Day should be canceled, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, said today, because the country cannot afford "a lag in war production."
Mrs. Lena Jones Springs, widow of Colonel Leroy Springs, Southern industrialist, who was found dead in her apartment in the Hotel Plaza on May 17, left an estate of $2,500,000 and no will.

CANBERRA, Australia, May 27 -- Prime Minister John Curtin announced today that the Department of War Organization of Industry was drawing up a five-point program for provision of a reservoir of man power from which 269,000 more men and 49,000 women could be diverted to the war effort by the end of 1942.

The Woman's Army whizzed into being with a spectacular start yesterday. Shoving aside prospective masculine soldiers, more than 1,000 women surged through the doors of staid Army Recruiting Headquarters, 39 Whitehall Street, as enlistment in the first officer-candidate school of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps began officially.

A mother and daughter were elected president and vice president respectively of the National Society, Daughters of the British Empire, which met yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel. Mrs. George W. Mercer and her daughter, Mrs. Russell C. Emmel, both of Cleveland, Ohio, are the new officers.

Fifty-seven thousand dairy farmers in the New York metropolitan milkshed collected $14,437,520 for their milk in April, a new high value for the second consecutive month, N.J. Cladakis, Federal State Milk Market Administrator, announced yesterday.

Peter Springman, 20 years old, a captain of bellhops at the Hotel Sutton in East Fifty-sixth Street, called last night as a surprise rebuttal witness at the trial of Madeline Webb, Eli Shonbrun and John D. Cullen in the murder of Mrs. Susie Flora Reich there on last March 4, swore he saw Miss Webb near the entrance to the hotel about the time of the murder.

Executives of leading department stores throughout the city, reporting yesterday on their contributions to the current campaign of the Greater New York Fund, announced that those who had not reached their quotas would strive z to complete them by June 30.

Heydrich "der Henker," Heydrich the Hangman, Heydrich the second-ranking man in Hitler's terrible Gestapo, Heydrich the "Protector" of Czechoslovakia who ordered the death of eighty patriotic Czechs on his first two days in office, has been wounded in an attempt upon his life, and the German Government announces that "severe reprisals" are already under way.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Chairman Walsh of the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs had a good word today for the hard-pressed Navy in its campaign to counter the Axis submarine campaign. Such details of this campaign as are obtainable by inquiry, and even those which are publishable without giving useful information to the enemy, appear to this correspondent to justify what Mr. Walsh said.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 27 (AP) -- Johnny Wittig of Jersey City gave only two hits tonight, but Syracuse used a base on balls, an infield out and Bobby Adams's single to win, 1 to 0. The run came in the first inning.

LONDON, Thursday, May 28 (U.P.) -- The American Eagle Squadron paced a strong Royal Air Force foray over the French, Netherland and Belgian coasts yesterday, shooting down two German fighters while British pilots were believed to have bagged a third.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 27 (AP) -- Agitation for Brazil to engage in active warfare upon Axis submarines operating off the Brazilian coast developed today as continuing and somewhat confused reports of undersea activity reached the capital.

CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -- As the second portion of a double-header played with all receipts going to Army and Navy Relief, the Reds walloped the Cubs, 10 to 1, today before a crowd of 9,966 which paid $10,455.27.

A resolution calling for the dismissal of 125 regularly employed New York City high school teachers was tabled for two weeks by the Board of Education at its meeting yesterday, upon the promise of representatives of teachers' organizations that further attempts would be made to meet the budgetary deficiency faced by the board.

Chester I. Barnard, national president of the United Service Organizations, told a group of women campaign workers yesterday at the Savoy Plaza Hotel that one of the most important tasks of the recreational clubhouses for service men was "to combat the loneliness so often found in military life."

An initial dividend of $1 a share on the 4 per cent preferred stock for the quarter ended on June 30 was declared yesterday by the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation for payment on June 30. International was merged recently with its subsidiary, Union Potash and Chemical Company, on April 6.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The House rejected by more than a ten-to-one vote today the conference agreement which sought to cut back to $42 a month the $50 minimum base pay it approved on May 13 for privates of the Army and Marine Corps and apprentice seamen of the Navy and Coast Guard.

Many gasoline stations in the metropolitan area, particularly those with a predominantly commercial business, already have exhausted their May quotas, it became known last night as Westchester County reported a sharp drop in traffic deaths since rationing went into effect on May 15.

LONDON, May 27 -- Last Tuesday The London Times printed a letter, signed "Septuagenarian," demanding that the government turn its attention to persons over 70 years old, for whom, the writer said, nothing had been done. "Not so much as an extra glass of milk comes their way," the writer asserted, adding that the government "is rightly doing everything for the children."

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- An Administration proposal to bulwark present price ceilings by subsidizing whole trades or industries was temporarily abandoned today after Senator Barkley, majority leader, admitted at the close of two days of debate that if the plan was not eliminated, the bill to which it was attached in the form of amendments would be recommitted to the Banking and Currency Committee.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 27 -- Although the exact positions of the rival forces contending in the Cyrenaican desert cannot be revealed, it is no secret that they are spread southwestward and southeastward from Tmimi and El Gazala.

Edward Mandel, retired associate superintendent of the New York City schools, who died on Monday, at the age of 73, was married the day before he died to Mrs. Agnes Duffy Barrett, 50, an assistant principal at Public School 119, Manhattan, it become known yesterday.

Gasoline stocks in the United States at the close of last week amounted to 97,034,000 barrels, a decline of 2,100,000 from the 99,134,000 reported a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago there were 94,141,000 barrels.

LONDON, May 27 -- A storm blew up today over Baron Wedgwood's broadcast last night to a dinner in New York honoring Dr. Chaim Weizmann, Zionist leader, in which he suggested that America should take over the Palestine mandate from Britain.

ST. PAUL, May 27 (AP) -- Governor Stassen, as a member of the National Civilian Defense Board, recently named by the President, has entered the controversy between Mayor La Guardia and James Landis, Civil Defense Director, and urged that the differences be aired at the next board meeting.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 27 -- Colonel Edward C.O. Thomas, Nassau County director of civilian protection, announced today that he had warned Belmont Park race track that he would take action against it unless its officials "rebut" by Monday criticism made by members of the Nassau County War Council against the track's civilian defense organization.

Greater zeal in plant inspection, hygiene and related industrial conservation problems was urged last night by Ray Murphy, assistant general manager of the Association of Casualty and Surety Executives, as a means to curb sabotage during the war and to keep production in steady flow.

The Florsheim Shoe Company reported yesterday for the six months ended on April 30 net profit of $499,301, equal to $1.25 a share on the Class A common stock and 62 cents a share on the Class B common.

As part of the program of citywide Harlem Week, the problem of Negro housing was discussed last night at an open meeting in the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, by the recently organized city-wide Citizens Committee on Harlem, Cooperating were the Citizens Housing Council of New York, the National Public Housing Conference, the National Committee on Emergency Housing, the United Tenants League of Greater New York and United Neighborhood Houses.

GOSHEN, N.Y., May 27 -- Disregarding the plea made by Thomas E. Dewey, prospective nominee for Governor, to Henry V. Clark, its chairman, the Orange County Republican Committee in a meeting in the Court House tonight, endorsed Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. for renomination in the Twenty-sixth Congressional district.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 27 -- The United States Military Academy began its war-curtailed commencement ceremonies today with the annual baccalaureate services, the Star parade, an athletic review and the presentation of twenty academic award to fifteen cadets among the 374 first classmen who will graduate Friday.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 27 -- Another nation-wide drive for cast-off clothing and discarded textile fabrics similar to that launched in the Summer of 1941 is scheduled for the fortnight beginning June 1 in Germany. Its immediate purpose, it is announced, is to expand the wartime base for raw materials with a view to keeping Germany's fighting front and increasing army of men and women workers employed in war industries comfortably clothed.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer was the guest of honor last night at a farewell dinner tendered by his staff, civil service employes and police officials attached to his office in the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn. Mr. O'Dwyer will enter active service in the United States Army on Monday as a major.

Those with an aversion to sweet, sticky desserts should speedily make their way to one of the most delightful delicacy shops in the city. There they will discover cheese spreads that seem especially designed for their delectation -- extraordinarily smooth and delicately flavored, of the sort that provide a simple yet completely satisfying conclusion to a springtime meal.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 27 -- Army's gain was Navy's loss in the Professional Golfers Association's silver anniversary championship today at the Seaview Club.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- The Missouri Edison Company and the East Missouri Power Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a proposal to sell $854,000 of first mortgage bonds, Series A, 3 3/4 per cent, to the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company.

LONDON, May 27 -- The British Labor party at a stormy session on the third day of its annual convention here today approved the policy of maintaining an electoral truce in furtherance of the coalition government's prosecution of the war.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 27 -- This quiet community was relieved today to learn that the man-eating rooster that had taken over gardens here was behind bars under the custody of Frank Doxey, the local dog catcher.
Intensive courses of study in languages of the Near and Far East will be given in the Columbia University Summer Session beginning July 7 and ending Sept. 4, it was announced yesterday.

The Senate committee hearings on the President's appointment of Thomas F. Meaney to the Federal District Court of New Jersey took a new turn on Tuesday. It seemed to be Mr. Meaney's patron, Mayor Hague of Jersey City, rather than Mr. Meaney himself, who was being looked into.

CLEVELAND, May 27 (AP) -- Pitcher Jim Bagby lost little time clouting a home run for Cleveland today, but Chicago's relief flinger, Joe Haynes, proved the better batter and the White Sox earned a 9-7 triumph over the Indians.
CHUNGKING, China, May 27 (AP) -- A Chinese communique said:

CHUNGKING, China, May 27 (AP) -- The Japanese army of 100,000 that launched the Chekiang offensive has lost 15,300 in casualties, at least 10,000 of them dead and still has not been able to take Kinhwa, the provincial capital, the Chinese reported tonight.
BOSTON, May 27 -- Whit Wyatt's mastery over Casey Stengel's Braves was maintained today, thanks to a a 3-run ninth-inning surge against Jim Tobin that gave the Dodgers the decision, 4 -- 1.

A campaign to make all Americans on the home front more deeply conscious of their individual responsibility to "make any sacrifice, however great, and perform any task, however humble," to aid in winning the war and to safeguard and pass on "our priceless blessing of liberty," was announced yesterday by Bundles for America, Inc., 660 Fifth Avenue.

VICHY, May 27 (U.P.) -- The first detailed reports today reached Vichy of a riot in the Paris Latin Quarter yesterday in which fifty students were arrested after trying to battle their way through a police cordon. All were released after they had been identified as students, reports from the occupied zone said.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 27 -- The huge factories in the Schenectady area have gone to war. At General Electric a million-volt X-ray is searching out "cancers" in giant castings as part of the efficiency in the company's 1942 production program of $1,000,000,000 worth of war goods and at the American Locomotive Company plant tanks and locomotives are being made side by side.

There was an old-time Far Western Senator whose spelling in his private letters was rather free and easy. A friend bet him a fat sum that he couldn't spell a certain word correctly. The Senator won the bet. The exasperated friend said: "Why, you never spelled it that way when you wrote me."

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- James F. Lincoln, president of a company handling millions of dollars of war contracts, testified today that his system of incentive bonuses for employes, ranging as high as $50,000 a year, had saved the government $35,000,000 through increased worker efficiency and reduced costs.

Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School's domination of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association track and field scene continued unchallenged as Coach George Eastment's lads won the sixteenth annual outdoor championship at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

TOKYO, May 27 -- (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Japan's Parliament, in a special session formally opened by Emperor Hirohito, was told today by the Premier, General Hideki Tojo, that Japan would stay in the fight "until the influence of Britain and America and their dreams of world domination" were wiped out.

PORT MORESBY, New Guinea, May 27 -- Forty-five days after setting forth on a bombing mission to Rabaul, New Britain, Lieutenant Louis W. Ford, 22 years old, of Los Angeles, brought his crew safely to this base yesterday. Their plane was lost -- blown up to prevent the Japanese from getting it after a crash landing in the jungle of New Guinea.

DETROIT, May 27 -- Victory for the United Nations in 1944 was forecast tonight by Charles F. Kettering of the General Motors Corporation. He further prophesied that the war would end in the trenches, not in the air, and that it would be won by equipment already in use.

Gaetan de Bourbon, in 325 E 57th St; Dr. Carl Koller, also Mrs. Claudia Johnson, in 24 Central Pk South; Arnold W. Fishel, in 471 Park Ave; Mrs. E.B.H. Bates, through the Fred F. French Co, in 1140 Fifth Ave -- Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, brokers.

The Federal Aircraft Products Corporation, manufacturer of airplane parts and instrument panels, has leased a floor covering 23,000 square feet in 304 East Forty-fifth Street for use in connection with its war contracts. Huberth Huberth arranged the lease.

Declaring that he feared a collapse of private philanthropies in New York, Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, advocated yesterday a community chest drive that would replace the appeals that have been and will be made to support important hospital work.

PHILADELPHIA, Bay 27 -- Manager Mel Ott refurbished his Giants tonight and the result was highly gratifying to all save 5,110 rather disgruntled onlookers. For the Polo Grounders, playing their first game of the season under lights, polished off John Lobert's Phils, 6 to 2, to end a losing streak of three straight.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 27 -- The man in the street breathed a sigh of relief when an official statement, issued late last night, was published today by the Foreign Ministry and spread through the provinces, indicating that "solid friendship and frank cooperation between all nations of the American Continent cannot be altered during the present hour of tragedy."
PEARL HARBOR, May 27 -- Nine officers and men of the Pacific Fleet received medals from Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, aboard a warship here today.

Hailing the war effort to date as "one of the greatest miracles in modern production," Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, declared yesterday that problems of the production line are behind us but that the country now faces shortages of power, fuel reserves, transportation facilities and skilled labor.

TRENTON, May 27 (AP) -- Governor Charles Edison vetoed today a bill to require railroads to continue passenger service on lines operated at a loss, provided the combination of passenger and freight revenues equaled or exceeded operating costs.
ST. LOUIS, May 27 (AP) -- Showing signs of revived power, the Browns gave adequate hitting support to Johnny Niggeling today for a 5-to-2 victory over the Tigers.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Soviet Russia is bringing new pressure in Washington, as well as in London, for the early opening of a second front in Europe, it was reliably reported today. Washington is reported countering with requests for the opportunity to get first-hand information on conditions at the Russian fighting fronts.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Southpaw Oscar Judd let Washington down with six scattered hits as the Red Sox walloped the Senators, 10 to 1, tonight. The first night game of the season in the capital attracted 17,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Demands made at yesterday's meeting in New York of the New York State Bankers Association that the Treasury outline a pattern of financing of deficits for the benefit of the commercial banks which will have to participate in it, and that Federal reserve requirements should be lessened to this end, will not lead to any immediate government action, it was learned today.

The wage increases granted to railroad unions last Autumn will cost the New York Central Railroad $31,500,000 this year on the basis of last year's payroll, F.E. Williamson, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting in Albany. He pointed out that wages would increase with the volume of traffic this year.

Belgian forces in Africa are militarily prepared to meet any thrust, and invasion of the Belgian Congo will be met "with stubborn resistance on a front 2,000 miles away," Albert de Vleeschauer, Minister for Colonies of the Belgian Government-in-Exile in England, declared last night on his arrival from Europe aboard a Pan American Airways clipper at the La Guardia field marine base.
MILWAUKEE, May 27 -- A ban on the manufacture and sale of beer and spirits was urged today by the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.

ANNAPOLIS, May 27 -- West Point baseball and track teams scored a sweep over Navy rivals today, although it took a great rally to clinch the track meet. While the cadet nine was defeating the middies, 10 to 3, the visitors had to take first and third places in the broad jump to triumph, 63 2-3 to 62 1-3, in the track and field tests.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 27 -- Fred Astaire will return to RKO, after an absence of three years from that studio, to star in "Look Out Below," musical film which David Hempstead will produce from a scenario by James Kern and S.K. Lauren, the studio announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Ways and Means Committee voted today to leave estate and gift tax rates as they are, and in a night session discussed excise and sales taxes with the "certainty," according to Representative Doughton, chairman, that the sales levy would be considered.

Two obstreperous baby giant pandas, gifts of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, were "christened" yesterday at the Bronx Zoo in a ceremony that had 300 persons rollicking with laughter. The male was named Pan-Dee and the female, Pan-Dah.

While numerous shortages in consumer merchandise are bound to occur, "we are many, many moons away from a complete, point system type of rationing of all goods," Leon Henderson, price administrator declared yesterday in an address at the annual convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
ROME, May 27 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High, Command communique said today:

It appears to be reasonably certain that the nation-wide sales goal of $600,000,000 of war savings bonds set for May will be reached, with perhaps a small margin to spare. This figure includes Series F and G, as well as the popular Series E bonds.

CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -- Suits in behalf of all policy holders to recover their share of surplus funds totaling $780,750,000 held by seventeen mutual life insurance companies, were filed today in circuit court.

Chekhov's play, "The Three Sisters," has been selected by Katharine Cornell for her vehicle next season. The Broadway presentation, planned for the Fall, will be preceded by an out-of-town tour. Guthrie McClintic will attend to the staging. Miss Cornell will por-i tray Masha, a part last acted here by Anne Revere in the 1939 re- vival-it ran for nine perform- ances-presented ' by the Surry Players and Dwight Deere Wiman.

A suit to compel the NY PA NJ Utilities Company, a subsidiary of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, to transfer to the General Gas and Electric Corporation, another subsidiary of A.G.E., controlling blocks of stock in four operating utilities was filed yesterday in Supreme Court by minority stockholders of General Gas and Electric.
