The Hamburg Savings Bank has sold to Richard Pedone the two-family house at 79-05 Seventy-seventh Avenue, Glendale, Queens. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

The Southern Railway has reached an agreement with banks to meet the situation caused by the War Production Board's seizure of 950 freight cars which the railway had ordered and which it had pledged as collateral against equipment trust certificates it sold.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that the general maximum price regulation does not "require" manufacturers to continue to grant customary advertising allowances to the distributors of their products.

Two Broadway theatres will present new films today. At the Palace the newcomer will be RKO's "Syncopation." Produced and directed by William Dieterle, the film's cast is headed by Jackie Cooper, Bonita Granville, Adolphe Menjou, George Bancroft, Ted North, Todd Duncan, Mona Barrie and Connee Boswell.

According to the prospectus for $12,000,000 of ten-year 2 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., offered publicly on Monday by a syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers, the company last year adopted the "last in-first out" method of inventory valuation, instead of the "cost or market, whichever is lower" method in use in prior years.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to increase the authorization for public defense housing construction by $600,000,000, but specified that most of the low-cost dwellings would be "temporary in nature" so as to conserve critical materials. He urged early consideration of the proposal.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (U.P.) -- The House Rules Committee gave the go-ahead today to legislation designed to relieve the Eastern oil shortage by authorizing construction across Florida of a pipeline and of a barge canal to link existing inland waterways from Texas to Trenton, N.J.

A warning that the Army intends this week to begin "naming names" in reporting violations of the dimout regulations in the metropolitan and contiguous areas was sounded last night by Major Gen. T.A. Terry, commanding the Second Corps Area.

THE mimeograph machines operated by fight promoters or their hirelings are grinding out items of military and naval intelligence rather frequently these days. That's due to the fact that many of the boxers appearing before the public are service men on furlough. Such information probably is of little or no value to the enemy and there is no threat that censorship will be established over the mimeograph machines that roll out the boxing ballyhoo.

Against a news background which suggested no visible alteration in the war picture, the stock market staged yesterday one of its infrequent rallies of major proportions. Strength first centered in the motors and steels, and this gave a breath of confidence to most other sections of the list so that final gains ranged as high as 2 points.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 27 -- Foreign Minister Enrique de Ruiz Guinazu this morning inaugurated the first Inter-American Conference on Coordination of Police and Judicial Measures.

A resolution appealing for relief from the provisions of the supplementary seasonal order of the OPA was adopted yesterday at a special meeting of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Association, held at the Hotel New Yorker. About 250 manufacturers of dresses ranging in price from $1.37 1/2 to $4.87 1/2, wholesale, attended the meeting.

Guided by a small yellow slip of typewritten paper, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spent a busy day yesterday. It was typical of many of the First Lady's schedules, combining an interest in her family, her city and her country.
NEW SUFFOLK, L.I., May 27 -- Weakfish in Peconic Bay still provide the means for a good day's fishing.
LONDON, May 27 -- Developments in the war situation have put a brake on the rise in the stock markets, but there was no selling pressure today and prices showed only trifling declines.

LONDON, May 27 -- Problems of supplying battlefronts -- existing as well as those in the making -- were discussed today with British Army chiefs by Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, Chief of the United States Army's Service of Supply, who is the latest high ranking United States general to arrive here for staff talks.

I have observed with increasing amazement and disgust the campaign against Thomas F. Meaney's appointment to the Federal court. I hope and trust that the President's nomination, which I believe to be an excellent one, will be reviewed more judicially by the Senate than by those who in my opinion have so frivolously attacked Mr. Meaney in the press.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The first copies of the Price Control Pamphlet, designed to tell the consuming public the whys and wherefores of the general price ceiling order, came off the presses of the Government Printing Office today and in about two weeks will begin to find their way into local conferences and meetings.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 27 -- Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City in a statement from his office tonight contradicted Governor Charles Edison's assertion yesterday before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee that he had not sought the aid of the Hague Democratic machine in his campaign for the Governorship in 1940.

LONDON, May 27 -- The Libyan campaign appears to have flared up again, for Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, the German commander in Libya, is striking eastward with considerable air preparation and there is reason to believe that this time he means business.

LONDON, May 27 -- The Libyan campaign appears to have flared up again, for Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, the German commander in Libya, is striking eastward with considerable air preparation and there is reason to believe that this time he means business.

A banking group headed by Lazard Freres Co. has received the award of $1,095,000 of refunding bonds of Montclair, N.J., on a bid of 100.06 for 1.80s. The bonds, dated June 1, 1942, and maturing from June 1, 1947 to 1958, were reoffered at prices to yield from 1.10 to 1.90 per cent, according to maturity.

Ray Robinson, the Harlem welterweight with the imposing record of thirty-one consecutive triumphs in professional competition, will seek to extend his streak at the expense of Marty Servo of the Coast Guard in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Use of lithographed labels for cosmetics has now been approved by the War Production Board, the Toilet Goods Association advised members yesterday. Originally the WPB desired that labels be printed and not lithographed. After discussion with the officials involved, they have withdrawn any objection to the process of lithography, the emergency supplies committee of the association reported.
Standing off three challenges in the long mile and a half, William Woodward's Vagrancy yesterday captured the $20,675 Coaching Club American Oaks, top test at Belmont Park for three-year-old fillies.

Recalling that the city's Common Council passed an ordinance to help hay-fever sufferers as long ago as July 7, 1691, Councilman Joseph E. Kinsley sent a note to Mayor La Guardia yesterday asking him to sign the anti-hay-fever measure that comes before him at a public hearing on Monday.

Thirty-six infants were entered yesterday in the anual Red Hook Gowanus baby health contest in l the Colony House, a settlement at 297 Dean Street, Brooklyn. The event was staged in conjunction i with a program of physical examination of needy children in preparation for camp.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Office of Facts and Figures today quoted a Japanese broadcast, which it said was intended for home consumption, as saying that American prisoners from the cruiser Houston were being forced to do manual labor and, if laggard, were beaten with ropes.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- The grain markets turned downward today on the Board of Trade when many operators who bought yesterday started to liquidate their holdings. Oats showed independent weakness with commission houses persistent sellers, and the close was near the bottom with losses of 1 1/8 cents a bushel, the September selling at a new seasonal low.

PITTSBURGH, May 28 (AP) -- Pinch Hitter Frankie Crespi's Sharp single into left scored George Kurowski from second base in the eleventh inning tonight to give the Cardinals a 3-to-2 triumph over the Pirates. A crowd of 16,577 saw the Buccaneers drop their fifth straight game.

Harley Archie Olson of Portland, Ore., 23-year-old survivor of a torpedoed American freighter, related yesterday one of the most amazing stories yet to come out of the Battle of the Atlantic -- a tale of spending twenty-nine days alone on a liferaft somewhere in the Atlantic and of ending his adventure alive and well enough to clamber aboard a rescue vessel unaided.

BOSTON, May 28 -- The Dodgers hurried happily toward home tonight with a four-game winning streak and a warm feeling toward Professor Stengel's Braves for their hospitality. They took the second game, 6 -- 4, to sweep the short series.

A GOLFER gets plenty of advice, most of it from other golfers. Practically all of it is useless and some of it is definitely bad. It may deal with anything from the proper stance to use on alternate Thursdays in August to the influence of the right wrist on short holes. If the listener pays any attention to the advice poured into his ears, the effect is soon seen.

The night of Sept. 1, 1939, was the first British blackout. So last night made the Thousand Nights and the One Night. By a cruel irony The Thousand and One Nights is the real name of the "Arabian Nights," those stories of the Sultan's wife that have charmed so many centuries and childhoods.

ELMONT, L.I., May 28 -- George D. Widener, president of the Westchester Racing Association, owners of Belmont Park race track here, declared in a statement today that the course had made and would continue to make every effort to cooperate with Nassau County defense officials for the protection of Belmont's patrons.

ROME, May 28 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Today's communique said that British planes bombed Messina, Sicily, last night, the second night in succession. Several houses were damaged, but no civilian casualties were caused, it asserted.

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after expenses and charges of $5,850,772. This is equal, after preferred dividend charges, to 77 cents a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $9,036,690, or $1.34 a common share, in the twelve months to March 31, 1941.

MOSCOW, May 28 -- German and Rumanian reinforcements have arrived in the Izyum-Barvenkova sector, but have been unable to force a crossing of the river line on which much of the fighting is now raging. Many attempts were made, the largest having been entrusted to the 101st German Infantry Division, from Lieut Gen. Viktor von Schwedler's army.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Possible future action on wages stabilization in one type of case was indicated by the National War Labor Board today in a divided ruling on a dispute involving the Chase Brass and Copper Company of Cleveland.

Major branches of the women's garment industry here continued to struggle yesterday with the problems of readjustment of Fall pricing to the supplementary seasonal order issued a few days ago by the Office of Price Administration.
The Browne Sharpe Manufacturing Company announced yesterday an extra dividend declaration of 50 cents a share in addition to the regular quarterly of $1.50.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Immediate deportation of Harry Renton Bridges, Australian-born alien and West Coast leader of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, was ordered by Attorney General Biddle today on grounds of membership in the Communist party, which Mr. Biddle declared to be an organization advocating the overthrow of the United States Government by force and violence.

Ten retiring members of the Columbia University staff, including Dr. James C. Egbert, director of University Extension, and Raymond C. Knox, chaplain of the University, will receive emeritus designations, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, announced yesterday.

A further decline in commercial loans was shown in the combined statement of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City for the week ended on Wednesday, as reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

"Warm with gentle winds," the dulcet voice of Weather-Six-One-Two-One-Two may say. If that should be the forecast, it probably means that the rooftops and gardens and beaches of Manhattan and its environs will be swarming, over the holiday week-end with first-of-the-season sun worshipers. And many of them, it can be foreseen, will sun not wisely but too well.

THE agony of Europe is universal, sparing neither the just nor the unjust, the rich nor the poor. But in a number of cases it has been the rich and privileged in the ravaged nations who have had the friends, the influential connections and the money so that they could escape and tell the story of their country's torment and their own personal adventures.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, May 28 (U.P.) -- The Japanese may resort to unrestricted submarine warfare and hit-run carrier-based bombing raids on New Zealand in a desperate effort to cut United Nations communications between America and Australia, Vice Admiral Robert Lee Ghormley said today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -War Savings Bond quotas totaling $800,000,000 for June were announced today by the Treasury for the 3,070 counties of the nation. They call for contributions one-third greater than those which have been made in the past.

CHUNGKING, China, May 28 (AP) -- A great battle is raging for the Chekiang provincial capital of Kinhwa, but the Japanese invaders, although reinforced and attacking repeatedly, have been repulsed with thousands killed, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

Hugh S. Nesbitt, comparative newcomer to the sport, scored one of his important Eastern victories at Belmont Park yesterday when his Copperman won the Go Between Handicap, mile-and-a-sixteenth test for older horses. Aided by the feather of 103 pounds, plus a powerful ride by Charley Wahler, Copperman scored by a length in 1:43 4-5 at $43 for $2.

LANSING, Mich., May 28 -- The principle of equal pay for equal work by man and woman was upheld here today when Circuit Judge Charles H. Hayden awarded $55,690 to twenty-nine women formerly employed in the Olds Motor Works.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The chartered Swedish liner Drottningholm is due to arrive at New York Sunday or Monday from Lisbon with American officials and civilians from European Axis countries, according to reports received today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Office of Defense Transportation announced today it had "relaxed" an order limiting newspaper deliveries in rubber-tired vehicles to newsdealers to one a day and set up two alternate plans.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 28 -- Mrs. John H. Bartol of the home club won low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association at the Greenwich Country Club today. Her score was 45, 43 -- 88.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- In a precedent-setting opinion, viewed by authorities as of great importance to the whole field of holding and operating utility companies, the Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a voluntary plan of the Jacksonville Gas Company for compliance with the "death sentence" clause of the holding company act.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date. Holdings of United States Government securities increased $43,855,000 during the week.

QUITO, Ecuador, May 28 (U.P.) -- Students stormed and entered the Government Palace in a revolt tonight. One Carabinero was killed and three others were wounded before troops, including cavalry, reestablished order and arrested ten persons.

For eight innings yesterday at the Stadium Jack Knott had the Yankees stopped with only four hits, but in the ninth everything went wrong at once. He gave up his first walk of the game, and then his second one. No one fielded a bunt that was intended as a sacrifice, and finally Joe Gordon lashed a crisp single to left to give the New Yorkers a 3 -- 2 victory over the Athletics.

The loss of two more merchant ships through enemy submarines was announced yesterday by the Navy. One was a medium-sized Panamanian merchantman, sent to the bottom off our Alantic coast with the loss of nine lives, the other a medium-sized ship of United States registry, sunk off the southern tip of Cuba with two of her crew missing and presumed dead.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Closing of all public point-to-point radio circuits within the continentel United States at midnight, June 30, was ordered by the Defense Communications Board today as a war measure.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 28 -- Crowds gathered around bulletin boards and loud speakers this afternoon to follow the Mexican developments, which are causing a stir in all circles as possible consequences in countries in South America are contemplated.
Time out for reflection was taken yesterday by many of the twenty-five officers and enlisted men delegated to look after the women applying for officers' training in the Woman's Auxiliary Army Corps.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- John L. Lewis abandoned today the basis of the charges which were being prepared against Philip Murray, vice president of the United Mine Workers, and summarily removed him from his post on other grounds.

Elimination of nonpatriotic workers in plants working either wholly or partially on war materials is an important phase of plant protection, and can only be accomplished by thorough investigations of those now employed and new applicants, Brig. Gen. Russell B. Putnam, United States Marine Corps, retired, told the insurance conference of the American Management Association concluding its two-day session at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- United States warships now on duty off Martinique are vitally needed to break the "blockade" that enemy submarines have attempted to establish off American coasts, Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia declared today, urging that current negotiations for neutralization of the French West Indian island be completed rapidly.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The War Production Board hesitates to impose a death sentence on jalopies, but it invites them today to commit suicide for the benefit of the country.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Use of metals other than joining hardware, coating, or reinforcing mesh will be prohibited after June 20 for a list of plumbing fixtures common in the home and commercial establishments, the War Production Board announced today.

Bank clearings for twenty-four leading cities of the country for the week ended Wednesday were $6,932,344,000, compared with $6,403,491,000 in the similar period last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Clearings for the latest period were $600,181,000, or 8 per cent below those of the previous week.

LONDON, May 28 (AP) -- The condition statement of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday revealed an increase of more than 6,000,000 in note circulation to the record high of 788,639,000. This marked the fourteenth consecutive increase and compared with 629,515,000 last year.
BERLIN, May 28 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

BRAZZAVILLE, French Equatorial Africa, May 28 -- Free French Africa and the Belgian Congo have lost no time in tackling one of the chief problems created for the United Nations when Malaya and the Netherlands Indies fell -- the loss of their chief source of rubber.

DEVON, Pa., May 28 -- Miss Frances Harrison of Edgemont suffered a recurrence of a shoulder injury when thrown from Isaac H. Clothier Jr.'s hunter in the Dicksfield Farm Challenge Trophy event that was one of the features of the annual Devon horse show and country fair today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., May 28 -- Harry R. Bridges telegraphed his assurance to Donald M. Nelson, War Production Chief, late today that he would do everything in his power to counteract any adverse reaction to the nation's war production that might result from the deportation order against himself.

Representative William B. Barry, who has named the Union for Democratic Action as a defendant in a $100,000 libel action, wrote yesterday to Representative Martin Dies asking him to investigate the union and its financial backing to determine whether it is communistic and "so that the country will know who its enemies are."

BERLIN, May 28 (From German Broadcast Recorded by The United Press in New York) -- German planes and submarines have sunk fourteen ships totaling 96,000 tons in a running attack on an Allied convoy bound through Arctic waters for Russia, a special High Command communique said tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Rookie Early Wynn scattered Boston's seven blows as Washington defeated the Red Sox, 5 to 1, tonight. The victory gave the Senators an even break in the two-game nocturnal series.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 28 -- Posing as an air raid warden, a fast-talking robber gained admittance late this afternoon to the home of Mrs. Jean Crawford at 55 Inverness Road, in Highland Park here, and after binding and gagging Mrs. Crawford escaped with $10 in cash and a $250 diamond ring, according to police.

ST. LOUIS, May 28 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox contributed three walks and the Browns slammed out two hits, one a rousing double by Rick Ferrell, in a big eighth inning in which St. Louis scored four times for a final 6-to-4 triumph tonight.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 28 (AP) -- A British Headquarters communique said today:

Earnings of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., from domestic operations in the first five months of this year were estimated yesterday by John A. Brown, president, at the annual meeting of stockholders held here, at about $15,000,000 before taxes, compared with $13,200,000 before taxes in the similar period in 1941.

The arrival this week of a large United States military and naval mission in London not only emphasizes the growing power of the United States in the European theatre of war but again focuses attention on the strategic problems that arise in a war fought by the Allies.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Among the consequences of the President's offhand remarks at his Tuesday press conference, expressing optimism over the prospect of finding substitutes for private automobile tires fairly soon, some today were inclined to include a Congressional outburst against nationwide gasoline rationing to conserve rubber.

The New York State Economy Commission, which is created by a bill signed by Governor Lehman, has an important job to do. The function of the commission is to investigate the various departments of the State and discover where economies can be made. Wartime conditions will make it imperative for State and local Governments everywhere to seek economies.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (U.P.) -- With the sinking of two more Japanese ships, announced today by the Navy, United States submarines alone are known to have destroyed forty-four enemy vessels in Far Eastern waters -- one-third of the total of all sinkings announced in Washington.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 28 (U.P.) -- The Duke of Windsor, accompanied by the Duchess, arrived here today from Nassau on the way north to confer with Washington officials on the "mutual defense of the United States and the Bahamas in the war effort."

Bertram de N. Cruger, who has just returned from his post in London as distributing agent for the British War Relief Society, declared yesterday that 3,000,000 children and another 2,000,000 adults in Great Britain are urgently in need of all kinds of clothing because of the shortage there of material for making garments and the resultant high prices.

History was made on this continent yesterday when President Avila Camacho, in a strong and spirited appeal to the Mexican Congress, asked for a declaration of war against the Axis Powers. The Mexican Government had broken off diplomatic relations with Germany, Italy and Japan in accord with the decisions of the Pan-American Conference.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, May 29 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur's air forces destroyed four Japanese planes and damaged more than five others in attacks on Rabaul, New Britain, and Lae, Northeast New Guinea, and during a sharp sky fight over Port Moresby, the United Nations base in Papua, it was announced officially today.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Army has taken the first step in developing amphibious forces as a major unit within its ground forces, Secretary Stimson revealed today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 28 -- Edmund O'Brien will appear in the lead, with Deanna Durbin, in Universal's "Forever Yours," which Jean Renoir will direct, the studio announced today. Universal has purchased the actor's contract from RKO, where he had been for the last two years.

BERLIN, May 28 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command announced today that the battle of encirclement south of Kharkov had resulted in an outstanding victory for Germany and her allies.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- "Work or fight" will be the policy of the War Manpower Commission in dealing with men who refuse to accept suitable employment in a war industry without reasonable cause," according to a statement tonight by Chairman Paul V. McNutt.

With a preview from 3 to 6 yesterday afternoon, the Brooklyn Museum opened its Summer show, scheduled to remain open to the public through Sept. 20. Although the material assembled in the special exhibition galleries on the ground floor would be of interest at any time, it proves peculiarly so just now, since it represents the cultures of islands of the Pacific, many of which figure from day to day in war bulletins.

Most enamelware producers, whose order backlogs now average five to six months, are refusing to accept new business, and shipments on old commitments are running slower, distributors reported yesterday. One jobber said he had not yet received complete delivery on an order that was placed for immediate shipment in January.

Murray I. Gurfein, who as assistant district attorney at the head of the Rackets Bureau under District Attorney Thomas Dewey and his successor, Frank S. Hogan, broke up many racketeering combinations in this city, sending many of their leaders to State prison, is to resign on June 1.

The 292d auction sale of the Police Department was held yesterday and proved to be a fairly accurate index of the times. For the tastes of some of the 1,500 persons who attended the sale clearly indicated the influence of gasoline rationing, rubber shortages and the war in general on a once jalopy-conscious America.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Attorney General Biddle urged today prompt passage of legislation exempting concerns from prosecution under the anti-trust laws when they are complying with specific requests from the War Production Board in furtherance of the war effort.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Congressional silver group agreed today to a "friendly truce" with Secretary Morgenthau whereby an additional 53,000 tons of government-owned silver bars, which cost nearly a billion dollars, will be loaned to industry to take the place of copper.

A celebrated controversy which has run through many chapters in the courts, in Congress and before the Federal administrative agencies was ended yesterday -- so far as the administrative agencies are concerned -- when Attorney General Biddle ordered the deportation of Harry Bridges.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, May 29 -- Vengeance executions for the attempt on the life of Reinhard Heydrich began in Bohemia early yesterday morning with the execution of six members of one family, including two women, and another person declared implicated for failing to denounce to the authorities the two men who late Wednesday afternoon attacked the car in which the deputy Gestapo chief was traveling.

With Penn State figured to dethrone N.Y.U. and with Pitt and Yale as the outside dark horses, the sixty-sixth annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships will open today at Triborough Stadium. There will be trials in twelve events this afternoon and finals in sixteen tomorrow.

Representative Michael J. Kennedy, leader of Tammany, is trying to avert a primary contest between State Senator John L. Buckley and Assemblyman Patrick H. Sulivan for the nomination for Senator in the Fifteenth Senatorial District, it was learned yesterday.

The Mayor's Committee for Mobilization of New York at War, touched to the quick yesterday by criticism of the general theme of the parade scheduled for June 13, and by rumors of extravagance in connection with the spectacle, replied with facts and figures intended to ease the public mind.

Further rallying efforts were stalled yesterday in the stock market as the motors and steels failed to continue their leadership, although there were some efforts at pulling up the laggards of the previous day's advance. Traders who had expended their activities on Wednesday were generally content to await the possibilities of consolidating the gains, and thus there was a natural contraction in volume.

Back in the Gay Nineties, according to a well-versed lower East Side clergyman, the scenic value of Second Avenue, from Houston to Seventeenth Street, was so great as to afford it the title of "Lover's Lane." Yesterday, that cleric and his congregation started a movement to restore the beauty if not the legend to the strip of thoroughfare.

Bronx County Court, Part I, resembled a mob scene in a motion picture yesterday when four Negroes, including one woman, and another defendant were arraigned to plead to a charge of first-degree murder. Inside the railing, ready to fight the case, were seventeen defense lawyers, one a woman, all assigned by the court, and two prosecuting attorneys from the District Attorney's office.
NEWARK, N.J., May 28 (AP) -- A four-run assault in the seventh inning by the Bears enabled Southpaw Tommie Byrne to hang up a 5-1 victory over Ken Trinkle and Baltimore today.
Railroad and bus lines were preparing yesterday to take over some of the Memorial Day week-end traffic that would normally have rolled on individually owned rubber and gasoline.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate the nomination of Rear Admiral John H. Hoover to be a vice admiral, and conferred with Senator Maybank, Vice President Wallace and Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O.

Confronted with the seizure by the War Production Board of $5,414,000 of rolling stock which it had financed, the New York Central Railroad asked holders of $15,000,000 of its equipment trust certificates yesterday to consent to wait until a requisite amount of substituted equipment had been delivered to meet the collateral requirements of the issue.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- President Roberto M. Ortiz of Argentina expressed sympathy for the peoples of conquered and occupied countries and declared for "complete solidarity" of the Americas in the face of "any unjust aggression" in a message to President Roosevelt today.

According to the latest information from Florida the metropolitan Miami fishing tournament for this Summer will not be abandoned. The tournament's executive committee has decided to go ahead with plans inasmuch as many service men there will want to go fishing whenever possible.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Senate Finance Committee reported favorably today a House-approved bill which would raise pensions of World War veterans suffering from disabilities not connected with service to $30 or $40 a month.

Predicting that the United Service Organizations would last until "long after the war clouds have faded away," Newbold Morris, City Council President, told 210 representatives of the men's clothing industry yesterday that the United States will be called upon to help police the world when the war is over.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Through the efforts of women volunteers, operating on a "beg and borrow" basis, the housewives of the Chicago metropolitan area are being acquainted in ever-increasing numbers with price ceilings, rationing regulations and many other problems which confront the purchaser of food, clothing and other items.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz Provided a $1 bail bond and a shipyard job yesterday for an 18-year-old father of a baby girl who admitted that he had broken into a gasoline station to get money to buy milk and food for the child.

ST. LUCIA, British West Indies, May 27 (Delayed) -- Surviving a second undersea attack within three days, the crippled United States destroyer Blakeley reached port here tonight after sea and air attacks against a pack of Axis submarines lurking off Martinique.

Labor unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations sent telegrams to President Roosevelt and Attorney General Biddle yesterday, protesting against the proposed deportation of Harry R. Bridges, West Coast C.I.O. leader.

Five waves of expenditures after the present war ends, similar to those that took place in the decade following the conclusion of the first World War, were predicted here yesterday by Arthur R. Upgren, chief of the National Economics Unit of the Department of Commerce, in an address before the monthly luncheon meeting of the New York Chapter of the American Marketing Association.

Harry Benedict, a member of the board of directors and of the executive committee of American Airlines, has been elected a director of the International Utilities Corporation, it was announced yesterday by William B. Yeager, president of the utility holding company.
MEXICO CITY, May 28 -- The text of President Manuel Avila Camacho's address today to the special session of the Mexican Congress follows:

After a long pause the Axis is moving again in Libya. It is too early to tell the extent and purpose of this movement, but London calls it an "offensive." Several tank-led columns, advancing under a curtain of bombardment from the sky, have engaged the British on their main positions.

LONDON, May 28 -- The extent to which the United' States Army has "expanded" over here, to quote the word used by General George C. Marshall, United States Army Chief of Staff, during his visit to Britain, can hardly be appreciated by any one who has not seen it.
Lieut. Comdr. and Mrs. Langhorne Gibson have arrived from Ramsay, Greenwood, Va., and are at the Ritz-Carlton.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 28 -- The cadet corps of the Military Academy was reviewed by the alumni today in the last full dress parade in which the graduating class will march with the three classes remaining at West Point.

President Roosevelt's action in freeing the Communist leader, Earl Browder, was carried one step farther yesterday in the Federal court here. United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa obtained the dismissal of an indictment which had been kept secret since it was returned on April 24, 1940, and thus cleared of all criminal charges the man whose liberation was ordered "for the national unity."

Of all the many things a woman can do with a handful of flowers, among the loveliest and oldest -- and also the newest -- is to wear them in her hair. And it's comforting to know that even if priorities descend upon hats and hair clips and other ornaments, there will always be plenty of blossoms.
ROME, May 28 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command isued this communique today:

There has been no enemy-directed sabotage to date, and the insurance industry has not learned of any incendiary fire in an American industrial plant since the declaration of war, according to the report of the committee on incendiarism and arson presented at the annual meeting of the National Board of Fire Underwriters at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, May 28 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho in person asked a special joint session of the Mexican Congress today to declare that Mexico had been in a state of war with Germany, Italy and Japan since May 22, when his Cabinet took cognizance of the German refusal to receive Mexico's protest against the sinking of a Mexican ship off Florida.

Archbishop Spellman used an almost startling figure of speech in his address to the graduating class at West Point. "Because," he said, "I wish to emphasize the spiritual element in your lives, I speak to you as I would to missionaries departing to their posts in distant lands."

Strong endorsement of the ruling by the Office of Price Administration that advertising allowances do not have to be continued by manufacturers under the general maximum price regulations came from national advertisers yesterday, while retailers, chief beneficiaries in the past of allowances, appeared lukewarm over the prospect of diminishing subsidies.
Madeline Webb and Eli Shonbrun joined late yesterday afternoon in the worst outburst of their trial for the murder of Mrs. Susie Flora Reich.

On May 4 -- sugar rationing day -- I was leaving for the West. I went to the Twenty-first Street registry at 9 o'clock sharp, being first in line, and was told that was the wrong station and that I should have to go to Twenty-eighth Street.
CHICAGO, May 28 (AP) -- Big Bill Lee today limited Cincinnati to six hits and drove in the winning run in the twelfth inning as the Cubs defeated the Reds, 2 to 1.

Thomas E. Dewey advised American business men and industrialists yesterday to begin making plans immediately to solve post-war problems, otherwise "the little collectivist planners will surely be here to take over the job because they're doing it now."

Perhaps those citizens who bemoan the restricted use of their automobiles may derive a measure of satisfaction from the result of their "sacrifice" as revealed by a brief news item appearing in THE NEW YORK: TIMES of May 26. I believe it carries a message more eloquent than reams of comment or preachment.

Survivors of a city-wide elimination series clashed for junior and senior division championships as the New York City Department of Parks conducted its first novice title boxing tournament last night on Randalls Island. Although the Crotona Play Centre of the Bronx carried off the team prize with a total of 743 points, none of its warriors won a championship.

ALBANY, May 28 -- Governor Lehman issued today a call for a conference June 2 at which city, State and Federal officials will consider means to get more war contracts for New York City plants and utilize the surplus labor of the metropolis.

The Transit Commission has given permission to the Third Avenue Railway Company and its affiliates to discontinue operation of their street-car lines in Manhattan and the Bronx, subject to the terms of their contracts with the city for substitution of buses on the same or equivalent routes, it was disclosed yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 28 -- Joe Kirkwood, world-famous for his ability to play trick shots, almost executed one of the neatest tricks of all time in the course of today's second round in the P.G.A.'s silver anniversary championship at the Seaview Club.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The United States must expect to face at any time the "inevitable" possibility of a raid such as the one that Brig. Gen. James H. Doolittle carried out so successfully over Tokyo and other Japanese cities, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson said today.

DETROIT, May 28 -- For the first time this season Rookie Virgil (Fire) Trucks fulfilled expectations by pitching the Tigers to a four-hit, 6-to-2 victory over the Indians today in the first of two games in a fight for the American League's second place.
Under-Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson, in an address at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night, predicted that the United States would produce more than 50,000 airplanes this year.

After an angry interchange in which Chairman John H. Delaney of the Board of Transportation joined former Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs in denying that scrap from the city's demolished elevated lines had been sent to Japan, the Board of Estimate adopted three resolutions yesterday providing for demolition of the Second Avenue "L" from Chatham Square to Fifty-ninth Street.

In "How the Jap Army Fights," to be released by Penguin Books on Tuesday, three United States Army officers review the history and organization of the Japanese Army, its soldiers' weapons and the campaigns in China and Malaya.

"I love a parade" might well be Mayor La Guardia's personal theme song. It is evident that the "New York at War" parade has long been his cherished dream, for the OCD handbooks, published in December, 1941 -- obviously written months before -- contain a fourteen-page section on formation of a Civilian Defense Corps parade and military drill for the participants.

CHICAGO, May 28 (AP) -- Cattle prices declined sharply today as producers, with slaughter material on hand from the heavy run earlier this week, reduced bids as much as 75 cents a hundredweight. Most fed steers and yearlings sold at $12 to $14, off 25 to 50 cents from yesterday, but commission men withdrew a sizable crop from the market in preference to letting them go at buyers' markdowns.

TOKYO, May 28 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Japan has more merchant ships now than when the war started, as tonnage captured from the enemy exceeds what she has lost in sinkings, Parliament was told today before it approved unanimously a bill to expand shipbuilding.

A general strike of 14,000 milk drivers and maintenance men employed by milk distributors in the metropolitan area was threatened yesterday after the breakdown of a conference at the Hotel Commodore between representatives of the Milk Drivers Union and of the New York-New Jersey Metropolitan Milk Industry War Conservation Committee, representing the distributors, when the distributors refused to abandon their plan to reduce home milk deliveries to "every other day."

Elisha M. Friedman and Donald B. Marsh have been debating in your letter columns the virtues and defects of the proposed Federal sales tax. Leaving to these learned gentlemen the statement of their own opinions on this vital subject, we should like to point out what appears to be a mistaken assumption of fact by both.

J.M. Kaplan, president of the National Grape Corporation, has purchased from the estate of Rosalie Slack the five-story modern brick front residence at 53 East Eightieth Street. Occupying a lot 22 by 100 feet and containing an electric elevator and pine paneled library, the house was bought through the William B. May Company, broker.

Four members of the Grand Army of the Republic, whose ages range from 95 to 99, will ride in the annual Memorial Day Parade on Riverside Drive tomorrow morning. Besides these veterans of the Civil War, 26,000 men and women will march in memory of the nation's heroic dead.

Slight losses in yesterday's quiet cotton market were realized through scattered selling by New Orleans interests and spot houses. Buying by the trade was hesitant and mostly on the scale-down as Congressional action on the Agricultural Appropriations Act is awaited.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 (AP) -- Louis B. Mayer, the 57-year-old movie executive who began his career as a Massachusetts theatre operator, topped the field of America's highest paid executives again last year with an income of $704,425.60 as managing director of production for Loew's, Inc.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Four more important Japanese vessels were added today to the official list of enemy ships destroyed or damaged in the Far East by United States submarines.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Office of Price Administration today issued a question-and-answer statement designed to answer questions raised by exporters in connection with its Maximum Export Price Regulation and Amendment No. 1, grouping seventy-five questions and their answers by subject in seven series covering scope, basic price, average premium, allowable expense, records, commissions and licensing.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The text of Attorney General Biddle's decision ordering the deportation of Harry R. Bridges was as follows:

Good news emanates this week-end from the Consumers' Service Bureau of the Department of Markets. Meat prices, which have barely fluctuated in the last seven days, are virtually identical with those that prevailed last Friday. Tub butter and Grade A white eggs show a similar steadiness, and fruits and vegetables, constantly increasing in supply, are significantly cheaper.

"Top-Notchers," a new vaudeville show, displaces "Keep 'em Laughing" tonight at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre. Headliners of the new edition are Gracie Fields, singing comedienne, and Argentinita, dancer. Others who will appear, under the aegis of Clifford C. Fischer and the Messrs.

Albert Safier, a Bronx candy store proprietor, last night won the dubious distinction of being the first person arrested in this city for disobeying dimout regulations. He is accused of refusing three requests by a policeman to darken his store and telling the patrolman to "go to hell."

A syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. received yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,100,000 of various purpose bonds of Albany County, N.Y., on a bid of 100.195 for 1.30s. The bonds, dated June 1, 1942, and maturing June 1, 1943 to 1952, were offered at prices to yield 0.50 to 1.40 per cent, according to maturity.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Secretary Morgenthau told the Joint Congressional Committee on Taxation tonight of six cases of "unpardonable attempts" to escape war-time taxation, and outlined "six considerations that would guide the Treasury in its effort to prevent the avoidance of taxes."

The gasoline rationing system now in effect in the East needs early revision. Although many motorists and gasoline dealers are persons of integrity, there are drivers who concoct fifty-seven, varieties of stories as to their need for Class X and B ration cards and there are filling station proprietors who do not blink an eye at using any one of a dozen hoaxes to sell more gasoline to favored customers than ration cards allow.

Ray Robinson made it thirty-two victories in a row when he received the decision over Marty Servo, chunky Coast Guard welterweight, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.
CHUNGKING, May 28 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command issued this communique tonight:

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The question whether German patents for the manufacture in the United States of atabrine and plasmochin, effective synthetic substitutes for quinine, should be restricted to two firms representing former German and Dutch monopolies or thrown open to United States manufacturers for cheap production of unlimited supplies is causing differences of opinion between government agencies.

Governor Edison denies that he sought Boss Hague's support in 1940. But in any case, if we were Governor Edison and Boss Hague had the goods on us, as the boys in the back room put it, we should not be greatly distressed.

Fifteen thousand veterans of the first World War, the Spanish-American War and the Civil War will honor the war dead of this nation tomorrow in the annual Memorial Day parade and reunion of the Grand Army of the Republic of Kings County through the Bedford and Eastern Parkway sections of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- United States department store sales for the week ended May 23 were down 2 per cent compared with the corresponding period last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. This was the first time in months that the nation's store sales had dropped from the previous year.

Two new entries will be added today to the Broadway film roster. "Yankee Doodle Dandy," Warner Brothers picturization of the career of George M. Cohan with James Cagney portraying the song and dance man, will have its world premiere tonight at the Hollywood Theatre.

LONDON, May 28 -- The war news had a restrictive influence on the Stock Exchange today, and the markets generally were dull. Mexican Government bonds responded to a small speculative demand, with the 5s at 10 1/2, 6s at 10 1/4, and each being 1/4 better.
LOS ANGELES, May 28 -- James M. Landis, Director of the Office of Civilian Defense, said today that the Pacific Coast, especially Southern California, was the No. 1 civilian defense front.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 28 -- In retaliation for the sinking of Brazilian ships by Axis submarines, the Brazilian Air Force has begun to attack such undersea raiders operating near the coast, it was announced today, and has already sunk one of three spotted from the air.

For two successive days news dispatches from the nation's capital have quoted unnamed Federal Reserve officials concerning money rates and the general subject of banks' excess reserves. Thus far, however, there is no indication that a new policy is about to be announced.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 28 (AP) -- Jersey City rallied in the ninth inning for two runs and a 6-to-5 victory in the series finale with Syracuse tonight.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 28 -- Fighting in two columns, German armored forces leading an Axis offensive in Libya attempted yesterday to drive northeastward from Bir Hacheim and in the direction of Tobruk and succeeded in carrying the battle into areas behind British fixed positions.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -The House Naval Committee was told today that the Mine Safety Appliances Company of Pittsburgh had realized "tremendous" profits on millions of dollars of work for the Navy and had doubled the compensation of some of its executives.

The Board of Estimate passed a revised air raid protection bill for the city yesterday and sent it to Mayor La Guardia for signature, although Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick and Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons criticized the measure for containing weaknesses.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A Congressional revolt, threatening to grow into a movement to rescind some of the emergency powers delegated under defense and war stress to the Executive branch of the government, came into the open at the Capitol today.

The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the six months ended with April, net profit of $2,513,629 after provision of $2,865,400 for Federal income and excess profits taxes.

The scrap iron and steel salvage campaign, to be sponsored by the steel industry through Leo Burnett Co., was reported yesterday to be progressing rapidly, with the amount to be spent the only factor still in doubt. Originally three plans were proposed calling for expenditures of $1,500,000, $2,500,000 or $3,500,000.

I think that the critics who are lashing out so unreservedly at the major league sponsors of disappointing service relief games are missing the mark a bit. The point being stressed by the critics is that most of the clubs have assigned unattractive games on unattractive dates for their relief shows.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Norwegian Embassy today gave the following account of the killing of a Gestapo agent on Sotra Island:

The Citizens Union announced yesterday that it had written to District Attorney Willis Ryder of Putnam County, suggesting that he investigate the use of New York City paving blocks on the Lake Mahopac estate of Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee. The estate is in Putnam County.

NORFOLK, Va., May 29 (AP) -- Judge Luther B. Way of the Federal District Court referred today to Tazewell Taylor, special master in the reorganization proceedings of the Seaboard Air Line Railway, in testimony taken at the hearing on two petitions yesterday.
Lefty Vernon Gomez finally had his day yesterday at the Yankee Stadium. And what a day!

SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 -- A telegraphic warrant for the arrest of Harry Bridges, against whom a deportation order was issued yesterday by Attorney General Biddle, was received late today at district immigration offices, but attaches said it would not be served on the C.I.O. longshoremen's leader until Monday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 29 -- An Australian armored division has been equipped with light and medium tanks of the most modern kind, it was announced today. The medium tank, known as the "General Grant," is mainly used for brigade reconnaissance.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- More than fifty civilians have been named by the War Department as field consultants of the new Advisory Board to the Resources Division of the Office of the Army Quartermaster General. They will advise on problems relating to clothing, transport and special equipment for the Army, and the best use of vital materials.

General Marshall's speech yesterday to the West Point graduates of the year was a model of discretion, of clear common sense and of patriotic encouragement. He referred to the grave difficulty of training the Army while there was so sharp a division of opinion about the need of military preparation.

Since last Memorial Day new names have been added to the long list of our war dead. We realize more keenly than we could a year ago how much loss and grief it took to build those old Civil War cemeteries, where trees have been planted and have grown to maturity since the first graves were dug.

BOSTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Braves dropped their third game in a row today as Rube Melton held them to six hits to give the Phils a 2-to-1 victory. Melton struck out nine men. The Braves' only run, in the ninth, was unearned.

Judge Jonah J. Goldstein of the Court of General Sessions will be the guest speaker at the installation exercises and service flag dedication Monday evening at the Sunnyside Jewish Center, 45-46 Forty-third Street, Long Island City.

Twelve, including Whirlaway, have been named for this afternoon's Suburban Handicap, traditional Memorial Day feature at Belmont Park, where the New York season's record race crowd is expected to turn out. Last year more than 50,000 attended on Memorial Day to establish the metropolitan record.

A good grocer is more than just a pleasant person in a starched smock who nimbly fetches you three tins of soup, a quart of milk and a loaf of bread. His functions as an agile automaton are the least of his duties, for his primary purpose is to help you run your household as effortlessly as possible.

About 350 camp or unit papers are now being published by and for American soldiers, and in a few days Yank, a national newspaper for service men, will be added to the list. Some are edited entirely by men in the ranks; others are prepared by Army publicity men or by local publishers working with the Army command.

The Flatbush Congregational Church, at Dorchester Road and East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, will hold tomorrow the final communion service prior to its merger with the Tompkins Avenue Congregational Church at McDonough Street, which is to become effective Oct. 1.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on May 23 totaled 253,423,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines of the Department of the Interior. This represented a decrease of 779,000 barrels in the week, comprising decreases of 509,000 and 270,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.

I have just enjoyed reading John Kieran's column in this morning's TIMES. In Dr. Holt's letter which Mr. Kieran printed, the Mayan predecessor of basketball, played with sometimes as many as 200 men on a side, was presented as one of the largest team games ever played.

The decision of the War Manpower Commission to "freeze" essential workers in critical war industries in their present jobs is of such importance that it needs to be publicly examined from several aspects. The problem of soaring wages and "labor pirating" is real enough and must be solved; but serious questions must be raised about the proposed method of solving it.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 29 -- It will be a long time before any P.G.A. championship produces as many thrills as were packed into today's quarter-final round at the Seaview club.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Despite heavy losses inflicted on American coastal shipping by Nazi submarines, naval experts said today that the United States slowly was winning the main campaign in the Battle of the Atlantic. They emphasized, however, that only steadily increasing production of both war and merchant ships could clinch the ultimate victory.

OTTAWA, May 29 -- Dissatisfaction with the manner in which Canada's share in the war was unknown and misunderstood in the United States turned to heated expressions of dissatisfaction in a debate in the House of Commons this afternoon over the manner in which the Canadian Government is running the war.

VICHY, France, May 29 -- After reviewing before the Ministers Council the principal recent political events, Chief of Government Pierre Laval left tonight for Paris. He was accompanied by Hubert Lagardelle, Secretary of State for Labor.

While Americans of almost all races and religions prepare to fight abroad and on the sea, a quiet campaign is being carried on to support them in an essential way on the home front. Their task will be easier and shorter, and they will return to a happier homeland after the war, if the evils of intolerance and inequality of opportunity are abated.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The general level of farm prices in mid-May averaged parity, the Department of Agriculture reported today. The mean was 152 per cent of the pre-World War figures.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 29 -- On a platform carrying the exhortation "Keep 'Em Flying," workers of the F.H. McGraw, Purdy Henderson Company, constructing the United States naval base at the colony's west end, this afternoon handed over $1,310.10 to the United Services Organization and the American Red Cross to provide clothing and comforts for survivors landed here from torpedoed ships.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 29 -- With persistent reports that Finland and Italy are both tired of war, a substantial number of American civic and community leaders believe the United Nations should offer peace terms to Finland at this time.

The trade's anxiety over the possible implications of the Agricultural Appropriations Bill now pending before Congress, held cotton prices yesterday below the closing levels of the previous session. Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange lost 6 to 8 points.

The Odell Waller case in Virginia has now become a matter of grave national concern, as Dr. John Dewey so convincingly makes clear in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 19. Never have the defects in our democratic system been so dangerously combined -- share-cropping with its attendant poverty, the poll tax, that shocking denial of democracy, and race prejudice.

MOSCOW, Saturday, May 30 -- The Red Army advancing on the Kharkov front has captured a village and several strategic positions, and in the Izyum-Barvenkova area has repulsed two strong German attacks, one of which cost the enemy 1,400 men, front dispatches said today.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Issuance of the "work or fight" statement by the War Manpower Commission will be protested by labor members of the Management-Labor Policy Committee, whose duty it is to pass upon questions of major policy coming before the commission.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Additional lists of officials and civilians on the chartered Swedish liner Drottningholm, now approaching New York, were made public by the State Department today.

The Continental Motors Corporation reported yesterday in a statement covering the six months ended on April 30, net profit of $1,926,178, equal to 64 cents a share on 3,000,000 shares. This compares with $1,224,129 or 41 cents a share earned in the corresponding period of the previous year.

Gracie Fields is in town, and almost everything has become all right again. Last night she took over the Forty-fourth Street Theatre, practically without effort, as part of the vaudeville show called "Top-Notchers" and as the lady who had them whistling up the stairs.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 29 -- Two thousand New Guinea natives who were persuaded to organize a three-night dancing party stamped out a makeshift airfield that enabled seventy refugees to reach Australia by plane.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Some War Department officials, acting as individuals, have promised a small number of women here that they could be assured of commissions in the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 29 -- Discovery of a new motor fuel that can be made of ingredients bought at the neighborhood store was claimed today by John B. Webendorfer, former official of the Webendorfer-Wills Printing Press Company here, and William Yonkers, woodwork manufacturer in this city.

For the third consecutive month a new high record in the value of the milk dairy farmers have produced for the New York metropolitan area will be achieved during May, N.J. Cladakis, Federal-State Market Administrator, forecast yesterday.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 29 -- Sixty-eight teed off today at the Crestmont Club in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association.

Searching for a candidate to block the nomination of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for Governor, the Affiliated Young Democrats have added Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, to its list of available candidates, Harold R. Moskovit, State president, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Check of half a dozen trade groups today suggests that the price ceiling program has stopped the rush of consumer anticipatory buying of most lines, except foodstuffs, and that retailers may have to wait a bit before sales resume their upward trends on goods untouched by priorities.

A new challenger bobbed up yesterday and entered the battle for the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championship at Triborough Stadium. Considered a dark horse before the competition began, Pitt now is a definite threat to both N.Y.U. and Penn State as the athletes whip into the finals today.

Three more merchant ships flying the Stars and Stripes have been torpedoed, the Navy Department announced yesterday. Two were medium-size vessels attacked in the Atlantic, survivors of which have been landed at East Coast ports. The third was a medium-size ship torpedoed in the Caribbean area.

STANTON, Del., May 29 (AP) -- Despite transportation difficulties, a crowd estimated at 12,000 turned out today for the opening-day program of a thirty-day race meeting at Delaware Park and saw Joseph E. Widener's Fair Weather romp to an easy victory in the featured $5,000 added Dover Stakes.

Describing the hardships of wartime air travel from Lashio to New York via Calcutta, a young representative of an American oil company told yesterday of his 17,000-mile flight over war-darkened continents and submarine-infested seas.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Employment reached in April a new high record in the United States with 40,773,000 persons in civil non-agricultural jobs, according to a statement by Secretary of Labor Perkins today.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- A record growth of bank credit, bank deposits and currency, a reverse of the gold inflow into the United States and a 50 per cent decline in excess reserves were reported by the Federal Reserve Board in a review of its activities in 1941 contained in its annual report yesterday.

Where the Nazi scale of human values runs, the life of a creature like Reinhard Heydrich -- a man of diseased personality, a liar, a thief, a butcher -- is considered to be worth the lives or the liberties of whole nations of people. To pay for one Heydrich scores or hundreds may have to die, thousands may be imprisoned and tortured, the Nazi shackles tightened on the limbs of a whole nation.
MOSCOW, May 29 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

The management of "The Strings, My Lord, Are False," the Paul Vincent Carroll play co-starring Walter Hampden and Ruth Gordon, decided yesterday to close the attraction after this evening's performance -- the fifteenth. Add also to the week's list of casualties the Louis Vittes play, "Comes the Revelation."
The Dodgers lost to the Giants, 3 -- 1, at Ebbets Field yesterday in a ball game that the grandstand managers won't stop talking about for the rest of the season.
Within a few days the Army expects to begin reporting violators of the new dim-out regulations to the police, it was learned yesterday.

The new John Jay Diving Pool in John Jay park, at Seventy-eighth Street and the East River Drive, was opened yesterday with ceremonies attended by Mayor La Guardia, Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Irving V.A. Huie, WPA Administrator for the New York area.
Police Commissioner Valentine in an order issued yesterday has directed the 2,100 detectives of the Police Department to equip themselves with halos.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- A Senate-House conference committee was deadlocked tonight on legislation granting pay rises to service men. Further efforts to reach an agreement were put off indefinitely.

More than $70,000,000 of new securities, ranging from municipal revenue bonds to railway equipment trust certificates and public utility mortgage bonds, will be offered for sale in competitive bidding next week. This schedule promises one of the most active periods in the underwriting field in many months -- perhaps the most active, in point of number and types of issues -- since competitive bidding became the fashion.

Art property and rare books of the Bendix Foundation, Chicago, were sold yesterday afternoon at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., for $48,101. A landscape by Claude Monet, "Printemps a Giverny," was bought by an agent for $4,100.

Post-Memorial Day sermons will be preached tomorrow. A number of military and patriotic societies will attend special services. In several churches memorials will be dedicated. The Memorial Day weekend will be used by some organizations for religious pilgrimages.

Foreign traders expressed disappointment yesterday over the list of questions and answers on the export price regulations released by the Office of Price Administration. Although long awaited, the list, it was generally asserted, contained few of the answers which the traders have been awaiting and is principally a restatement of the OPA's own original regulation and amendment.

The Rev. William Van Horn Davies, associate pastor with the Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer, the pastor, for the last seven years at the Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street, has received a call to the pastorate of the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway and Ninety-third Street.

In a premiere unprecedented in motion picture history, "Yankee Doodle Dandy," the Warner Brothers film biography of George M. Cohan, opened last night at the Hollywood Theatre before a distinguished audience that had purchased $5,750,000 worth of war bonds for the privilege of attending.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Attendance at American League war-aid games has been so small thus far that Will Harridge, league president, said today he would take up the matter at once with club presidents "to do something about it."

Tire and gasoline rationing, generally more ample pay envelopes, promise of good weather and generous distribution of week-end passes for men in service last night taxed common carriers in the metropolitan area. Railroads reported from 5 to 50 per cent increase in travel this Memorial Day week-end as against Memorial Day 1941, which was extremely heavy.
The time that the salt water angler has at his disposal will largely determine his selection of a port of debarkation today and tomorrow.

LONDON, May 29 -- The mobility of farm labor is just as important on the agricultural front as the mobility of troops on a battlefront. This is the lesson the British have learned after two years of experimenting with the Women's Land Army.

NEWARK, N.J., May 29 -- Fifteen men were arrested throughout New Jersey today by agents of the Federal Bureau of Invistigation on charges of having violated the Selective Service Act, E.E. Conroy, assistant director of the FBI for New York and New Jersey, announced here tonight.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., May 29 -- Martin Schwarz Jr., 53-year-old former secretary of the Dover Mutual Loan and Building Association of Toms River, was sentenced today to serve thirty to fifty years in the State Prison for embezzling $244,000 from shareholders of the organization in twenty years.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Government orders prohibiting operation of sight-seeing buses and curtailing charter service after May 1 were drawn to halt use of buses "operated primarily to serve places of entertainment," the Office of Defense Transportation said tonight.

In the course of things it was inevitable that, following in the stream of country doctor, editor, lawyer, banker books, there would be one called "Rural Free Delivery: Recollections of a Rural Mailman." It has come from those country publishers the Stephen Daye Press in Brattleboro, Vt., who say "here at last is the most country book of all."

The position of the stock market was not altered yesterday to any appreciable degree as the usual pre-holiday influences restricted trading to a minimum. The session, however, did mark the termination of a month which had witnessed the first over-all advance in ten months on the New York Stock Exchange, although the gain of approximately 3 points for May was accomplished in the face of the smallest business in twenty-four years.

UNION CITY, N.J., May 29 -- Five murders and two shootings were confessed today, according to police officials here, by Vincenzo Piazza, a 58-year-old convicted counterfeiter, who was captured this afternoon in Carlstadt, N.J., through the amateur detective work of a 20-year-old girl.

LONDON, May 29 -- The operations in Libya are going fairly well for the British, it was believed in London tonight, but it was stressed that it was too early to draw any final conclusions, because obviously the Germans must have something in reserve.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Except for sharp increases in certain farm products and foods that are not controlled under the Office of Price Administration's general maximum price regulations, average prices for commodities in primary markets remained comparatively steady during the week ended May 23.

GROTON, Conn., May 29 -- At the plant of the Electric Boat Company, the country's largest private submarine yard, the promised record of one launching a month is being beaten and the company is pushing an expansion program which will practically double present capacity.
ST. LOUIS, May 29 (AP) -- Apparently subdued on one hit in seven innings, the White Sox rallied to score four runs in the eighth and five in the ninth and beat the Browns today, 12 to 8.

L. Bamberger Co. have given thirty days' notice of the payment of $1,000,000 on the mortgage on their store property in Newark, N.J., according to R.H. Macy Co., Inc., parent company. The remaining amount of the mortgage will be $900,000.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- A Congressional drive to speed interstate shipment of war supplies gained impetus today as Representative McCormack, majority leader of the House, made public a complaint from the Navy Department that State barriers to commerce were delaying deliveries.

Borough President Joseph A. Palma of Staten Island answered yesterday three allegations contained in a summary of evidence recently turned over for possible action to District Attorney Farrell M. Kane of Richmond County by the extraordinary grand jury that for fifteen months investigated the Staten Island phase of a citywide paving racket.
BERLIN, May 29 -- (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A German communique said today:
The New York Stock Exchange firms of Gilbert Eliott Co. and Junkin Cooke have dissolved. Francis Bro. Co. has retired as a member firm of the Exchange.

Pleased with the literary efforts of four students of Samuel Gompers High School, Magistrate Anna M. Kross in Bronx Magistrates Court suspended sentence yesterday on them for trampling shrubbery in St. Mary's Park, the Bronx.

We may look forward to profound changes in transportation as a direct result of the war. Aircraft, on missions of destruction, already have made this plain. It is reasonable to suppose that the lessons now being driven home by war will be applied in a more constructive way after the peace.
Teacher got a shiny red apple yesterday from graduates of the first Volunteer Red Cross Nurses' Aide course at St. Vincent's Hospital.

Soldiers, sailors and marines of this war, as well as veterans of the Civil War, the Spanish-American War and the first World War, will be among the 26,000 marchers in the annual Memorial Day parade up Riverside Drive at 9 o'clock this morning from Seventy-second to Ninety-fifth Street.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 29 (U.P.) -- Fires set by Allied bombers have wiped out all buildings around the Japanese-held airdrome at Lae, 200 miles across the waist of New Guinea from Port Moresby, but enemy fighter planes there are offering the stiffest resistance in weeks, war dispatches said tonight.

It is expected that today will be far from a holiday for the officers and enlisted men at Army Recruiting Headquarters, 39 Whitehall Street. The center will be open from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. to provide application blanks for women seeking officers' posts in the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps.

Four men, including three physicians and two women alleged aides, entered not-guilty pleas yesterday in General Sessions in a nine-count indictment accusing them of conspiring to operate an "abortion mill" between June, 1941, and last March at 116 East Sixty-third Street.

LONDON, May 29 -- British bombers of the Coastal Command attacked a Nazi convoy off the Netherland coast last night, setting four of the ships afire, while other Royal Air Force planes raided German airfields and railway lines in Northern France.

Steadiness in the government bond market in the face of the growing volume of Treasury borrowing and consequent gradual shrinkage in banks' excess reserves, together with the general success of the banks in adjusting their reserve position through purchases and sales of government securities, is remarked by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in the June issue of its monthly review of credit and business conditions, released yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- After filling the bases in the eleventh inning today, Joe Beggs walked a pinch-hitter, Dominic Dallessandro, to force in the run that gave the Cubs a 6-5 victory over the Reds.

This is the day when Americans remember the soldiers who died in former wars. It has a peculiar poignancy this year because we are again at war, and on a scale that dwarfs all the conflicts that have punctuated, at pretty regular intervals, the life of this safe and peace-loving nation.

"Red Tanks," a Russian importation, will have its American premiere at the Stanley Theatre on Friday morning. The film, which is a fictional account of Soviet tank raiders behind the Nazi lines, was produced by the Lenfilm Studios, Leningrad, with the cooperation of the Soviet High Command and is released here through Artkino Pictures, Inc.

There appears to be some dissension among members of your editorial staff regarding the permanency of the position of Lew Fields and Joe Weber in the permanent theatrical firmament and the variance of opinion revolves around the viewpoint of the material employed by them.

New bond financing here this week, swelled by industrial loans, rose to $20,932,200 from the $4,439,000 in new issues placed on the market last week. A year ago this week new bonds aggregating $90,803,400 were offered for public subscription.

Madeline Webb escaped the electric chair when at 5:58 o'clock last evening a jury in General Sessions found her guilty of first-degree murder as a participant in the murder of Mrs. Susan Flora Reich, middle-aged Polish refugee, in the Hotel Sutton, but recommended to Judge Jonah J. Goldstein that she be imprisoned for the rest of her life.

In his letter to you of May 26 Francis Hackett, supporting the nomination of Mr. Meaney for United States District Judge in New Jersey, asks on what grounds I charge Meaney with lending himself to Hague's nepotism and whether I rely on Governor Edison's charges without investigation.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 29 -- Speaking as Chief of Staff of the Army to the graduating class of the Military Academy, General George C. Marshall declared today for the first time explicitly that "American soldiers will land in France."

Hopes for modification of the OPA seasonal price order No. 153 rose in the women's garment industry here, following more optimistic reports on the progress made by the group of trade association officials who went to Washington yesterday to confer with officials of the Office of Price Administration.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Arrangements under which Army officers, with the cooperation of retailers, will be able to buy uniforms at much lower prices than now prevail have been worked out in detail by the War Production Board, the Army Exchange Service and the Army Quartermaster Corps, WPB announced today.

The volume of trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in May was the smallest of any month in twenty-four years or since August, 1918, and the second dullest since February, 1915, the second month of the Exchange's reopening after having been closed from July to December in 1914 following the outbreak of the World War.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Declaring that Federal price ceilings are forcing the wholesale meat dealer out of business, with serious consequences for producer and consumer, two Chicago companies today sought relief in petitions filed with the Office of Price Administration.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, May 30 -- Twelve more Czechs were executed yesterday, according to official German announcements, for failing to give information to the authorities concerning the identity of the two assassins responsible for Wednesday's attack on Reinhard Heydrich, deputy Gestapo chief and deputy Reich Protector for Bohemia-Moravia.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Two orders which will make radical changes in the system under which the resources of the United States have been harnessed for the war effort will be issued over the weekend by the War Production Board.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 29 (AP) -- A British Headquarters communique today said:

An international entente cordiale without the usual political overtones was achieved yesterday afternoon at the Park Department's May party for children of the prekindergarten group of the Riverside Drive and Seventy-fourth Street playground.

Large color space in magazines distributed with Sunday newspapers will be used in a Summer advertising campaign for Vimms, vitamin-mineral tablets, by Lever Brothers. This will coincide with extension of distribution nationally, and frequent large space insertions in color and black and white scheduled throughout the Summer for national weeklies.
