BERLIN, May 29 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- German military quarters said today that "the battle of Kharkov has been terminated," with fighting continuing only between German troops and dispersed remnants of the enemy south of the city and that a "final German report" on the battle is expected within twenty-four hours.

LONDON, May 29 -- A firmer tendency developed today on the Stock Exchange, although the week finished quietly. The war declaration of the President of Mexico prompted a general marking up in Mexican securities.

Traffic was stopped on Seventh Avenue between Forty-fifth and Forty-sixth Streets for an hour yesterday as 12,000 persons gathered in Times Square to see and hear a war bond and war stamp rally sponsored jointly by the Treasury Department and the theatre division of the War Activities Committee of the motion-picture industry.

The Philadelphia fans may have missed the game, as Mr. Kieran said, but he himself missed the boat in his article. The blame for the disgraceful showing at the recent Pirate-Philly war relief game should fall smack on the shoulders of the Philadelphia club.
LONDON, May 29 (AP) -- A joint Admiralty and Air Ministry communique said today:

John T. Madden, chairman of the Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign, issued an appeal yesterday for volunteer "minute men and women" to take part in the door-to-door canvass to obtain pledges of systematic purchases of war savings bonds and stamps.

ALBANY, May 29 -- Governor Lehman named five men today as members of the temporary State commission to make a study and investigate the fiscal affairs of the State and recommend economies to bring down the cost of State government.

Thirty-seven young men will be ordained to the priesthood by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman this morning. The ceremony will start at 8 o'clock and continue for more than three hours. Assisting the Archbishop will be members of the faculty of St. Joseph's Theological Seminary, Dunwoodie, N. Y., where all of the candidates have been prepared.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Senate prohibition group today set June 22 for a public hearing on a bill which would severely regulate sales of liquor to the armed forces. Henry Ford and "other big folks" will be invited to speak, said Senator Bilbo, the dry leader.

Fifth Avenue between Thirty-fourth and Fifty-ninth Streets became the "USO Avenue of Heroes" yesterday afternoon when portrait posters of 103 war heroes went on display in shop windows as a tribute of the American people to the members of the nation's armed forces.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 29 (U.P.) -- All three Axis submarines that Brazil announced had been attacked off the east coast probably were sunk, high United States military sources said tonight.

Mollie B. Steinberg, 42-year-old co-producer of "All the Comforts of Home," which ends its Broadway run at the Longacre Theatre tonight after eight performances, was found dead at noon yesterday in her room at the Hotel Piccadilly, 227 West Forty-fifth Street.

LONDON, May 29 -- Dingle M. Foot, Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Economic Warfare, declared in an address at Birmingham today that it was "reasonably certain" that Germany's reserve stocks of her most important commodities were nearly exhausted.

LONDON, May 29 -- The Czechoslovak Government here moved swiftly tonight into the breach it believed had been created by the shooting of Reinhard Heydrich, German Gestapo official. The government's advice to its imprisoned countrymen -- carried by radio -- was to stand firm.

Despite threats of a general strike of 14,000 milk drivers and maintenance workers, spokesmen for the metropolitan milk industry announced late yesterday afternoon that they would go ahead with their plan to curtail deliveries to conserve tires, gasoline and equipment, pursuant to Order 6 of the Office of Defense Transportation.

The St. Ann's Academy baseball team captured the Manhattan-Richmond C.H.S.A.A. championship yesterday as it closed its regular league season with an 11-to-4 success over La Salle Academy. It was the seventh loop victory in eight starts for St. Ann's, which meets St. John's Prep, Brooklyn champion, in a semi-final play-off a week from today.

DETROIT, May 29 (AP) -- The fading Indians dropped their eighth game in nine starts today when the Tigers hammered four hurlers for sixteen hits to give Rookie Hal White his fourth pitching victory, 14 to 3. By sweeping the two-game series the Tigers moved into a virtual tie for the American League's second place, trailing the Tribe by five percentage points.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Alexander Stone of Washington, former $4,600-a-year government employe, who turned salesman late in 1940, testified today that he earned about $600,000 "gross commissions" in fifteen months by obtaining $12,000,000 in naval contracts for several manufacturing companies.

CHUNGKING, China, Saturday, May 30 (AP) -- Chinese soldiers, resisting repeated Japanese onslaughts, are holding grimly to the important Chekiang Province cities of Kinhwa and Lanchi, Central News dispatches from the front reported early today.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- A program to reduce illiteracy among a startling number of Americans who have been rejected for military service although physically fit was discussed by President Roosevelt today.

One thing can be said about the synthetic rubber problem after a thorough study of all the evidence. For a considerable time to come the best substitute for rubber will be no rubber. It is a much cheaper substitute than buna, butyl, butadiene, guayule, golden rod, cactus, petroleum, alcohol, wheat.

Retail trade here this week continued to show a percentage decline under last year. Department store volume was estimated as running 5 to 6 per cent under 1941. The shift of the Memorial Day holiday to Saturday accounted for part of the drop, while another factor was comparison with extremely large sales figures in the closing week of May last year.

Declaring that Mayor La Guardia's arguments against free rides on the rapid transit system for service men "did not hold water," Councilman Peter V. Cacchione, Brooklyn Communist, pressed yesterday for adoption of his bill which would extend the privilege to men in the armed forces.

VICHY, May 29 -- Four French nurses were found guilty of "homicide by imprudence" tonight for killing seven incurable patients unable to join the mass flight from the German invasion army two years ago, but their prison sentences were suspended and they went free.
HOLLYWOOD, May 29 -- John Barrymore, veteran star of the stage, screen and radio, died tonight at 10:20 o'clock Pacific war time. His age was 60.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Secretary Wickard, pointing to shortages in transportation, storage and processing facilities, told farmers today it was their patriotic duty to store as much wheat as possible on farms and to fatten their hogs for early shipment to market.

Declaring the War Production Board does not want to requisition salvage materials in the war effort unless it is absolutely necessary, L.J. Martin, assistant chief of the WPB Bureau of Priorities in Charge of Enforcement, told those attending the priorities training school for electrical manufacturers, conducted by the WPB, that favorable results are being obtained through the conservation program.
Much has been said and hinted with regard to the ability of Yale's varsity crew coach, Ed Leader, since the Eli mentor's varsity lost its seventh straight race to Harvard last Saturday.
JERSEY CITY, May 29 (AP) -- The league-leading Bears captured the opener of a three-game series from Jersey City today, 7 to 0.

Mayor La Guardia accepted a $4,800 ambulance yesterday afternoon on behalf of the City of New York from students, alumnae and faculty of Hunter College, pointing out that the reality of enemy attack was emphasized by the ceremonies.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Liquidation induced by uncertainty in regard to impending farm legislation and the start of harvest in the advanced sections in the Southwest carried wheat prices off 1 3/8 cents a bushel at one time today on the Board of Trade, with the July at a new low since late last November and the deferred deliveries into new seasonal low ground.

VICHY, France, May 29 -- Empire subjects were again to the fore when Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, during his visit to Chateauroux, inspected an empire exposition. He also reviewed the elite of the French Armistice Army, kissing the colors of the regiment he commanded as a colonel.
Speaking of Chichen-Itza, as mentioned by John Kieran in this morning's TIMES, the citizens of Perugia used to play a rousing game called "The Battle of the Stones."

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- A vest-pocket "Servicemen's Manual" containing facts as to the legal civil rights of men in the armed forces is being issued by the National C.I.O. Committee for American and Allied War Relief.

A decline of 60 per cent in the number of families on relief in this city since the peak in August, 1935, was announced yesterday by William Hodson, Commissioner of Welfare, who disclosed that family relief rolls had dropped from 281,097 in August, 1935, to 112,294 last month.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- The National Safety Council reported today that the nation's traffic-death toll, compared with a year ago, dropped 14 per cent in April and 7 per cent in the first four months of 1942.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, May 30 (AP) -- Allied airmen shot down five Japanese planes over the Coral Sea sixty miles southeast of Port Moresby yesterday, while two other air units rained explosives on Japanese bases in Timor and New Britain islands, General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- The National Safety Council reported today that the nation's traffic-death toll, compared with a year ago, dropped 14 per cent in April and 7 per cent in the first four months of 1942.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, May 30 (AP) -- Allied airmen shot down five Japanese planes over the Coral Sea sixty miles southeast of Port Moresby yesterday, while two other air units rained explosives on Japanese bases in Timor and New Britain islands, General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

Four former employes, who looted the branch of the Eagle Star Insurance Company, Ltd., at 90 John Street, of $183,000 since 1936, through filing false claims on policies, were sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday by Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions. All had pleaded guilty.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 (AP) -- Ted Williams hit two home runs tonight -- one in the first with two on and the other in the eighth with the bases full -- to drive in seven runs and pace the Boston Red Sox to a 14-to-2 victory over the Athletics at Shibe Park. The round-trippers were Williams's thirteenth and fourteenth of the season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 29 -- RKO announced today that George Murphy has been borrowed from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to replace Randolph Scott in "The Navy Comes Through," and that Scott will appear instead with Claudette Colbert in "China Sky."

Bonds called before maturity for payment in May were in the smallest volume for any month since last October and for any May since 1938. The total of $57,063,000 compares with $179,888,000 in the preceding month, $172,193,000 in May, 1941, and $25,083,000 in May, 1938.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Answering recent criticism of the Army by the Truman committee investigating the national defense program, which suggested carelessness in its use of rubber while the civilian population was put on rationing, the War Department, through a witness before another committee of inquiry, asserted today that with only one of several of its conservation measures it would save an estimated 50,000 tons of this vital commodity during the next two years.

Something new in high school commencement exercises occurred yesterday afternoon when forty-three seniors of Lincoln School, owned and operated by Teachers College of Columbia University, merged their various experiences and opinions in a simple half-hour ceremony that was partly drama and partly a composite valedictory.
WEST POINT, May 29 -- Following is the text of the address made to the graduating class of the Military Academy today by General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the Army.

LONDON, May 29 -- Owners and miners went to the government hand in hand today to settle a dispute that has disrupted coal production. The miners wanted more wages and the miners wanted greater subsidies with which to pay them. It appeared possible that the demands of both might be granted.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 29 -- The longer the war goes on the more apparent becomes the endeavor in the camp of "our enemies" to bring their war aims into harmony with those of Germany, according to an article by Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister, in this week's magazine Reich.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 29 -- The gag that Acting President Ramon Castillo thrust into the mouth of the Argentine press last December, when he issued his state of siege decree forbidding among other things any public discussion of foreign affairs, was rendered more effective today by a police order prohibiting newspapers from printing or commenting on any speech delivered in Congress "on international questions, on the state of siege or on its application."

With the pardonable pride of a neighbor and former schoolmate, I have glowed with appreciation for the fine job Buddy Hassett is doing at first base for the Yankees. I think, perhaps, he is entitled to a bit more praise than he is receiving generally.

JERUSALEM, May 29 (U.P.) -- The new activity in Libya started an intensified army recruiting campaign here today. Band concerts, parades, speakers, placards in restaurants and propaganda films were used to get civilians into war service.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- A sharp pick-up in the number of applications and in the issuance of rationing certificates for new passenger automobiles in April as compared with March is indicated by returns from thirty-one States that have reported thus far, Price Administrator Henderson said today.
BALTIMORE, May 29 (AP) -- The Club Atlante of Mexico City put on a dazzling exhibition of speed and dexterity tonight in defeating the Baltimore Soccer Club, 6 to 3.

Mike Jacobs, the boxing promoter, confided yesterday that he and Joe Louis, the boxing champion and Army private, were having just a little difficulty with the United States Army. As a result Louis asked yesterday, and received, a thirty-day deferment of a tax payment of $117,000, due June 15.

Boys 18 to 20 are to register June 30. Although I have known this would be necessary, the realization of such a definite date caused me to stop and consider the meaning of this important announcement.

New securities, exclusive of United States Government financing, offered to the public here in May amounted to only $57,102,000, consisting of $54,186,000 in twenty bond issues and $2,916,000 in two stock issues. Flotations of bonds were in the smallest volume for any month since October, 1939, and stock emissions were the smallest since June, 1940.

The trustees of the Chicago North Western Railway are working on a plan to use United States Government bonds as collateral for $3,750,000 of 2 1/2 per cent equipment trust certificates sold last February, it was disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- The country's railroads moved today to tighten their operations to meet the growing war demands. New measures adopted apply especially to passenger service in preparation for the heavy burden expected to be thrown on that department as the use of the private automobile is reduced.

LONDON, May 29 -- The Federation of British Industries today reported on the results of a study of proposals for post-war reconstruction that was frankly based on two conclusions -- first, that the post-war world will need policing by an armed force capable of striking at any point without notice; second, that only through complete British-American cooperation can world economy be restored.

A COUPLE of days ago Al Schacht stopped by to tell a pitiful tale. He-was wearing no hat, a flaring check coat, brown trousers, green socks, white shoes and tears in his eyes. Before he could utter a word -- it takes fast work to cut in before Al gets started -- he was asked whether or not he had seen his old friend, Prof. Moe Berg, lately.

Brother A. Victor, president of Manhattan College, announced yesterday the resignation of the Rev. Brother Alphonsus, dean of the School of Arts and Sciences since 1934. Retiring from his administrative duties, Brother Alphonsus plans to return to his former position as Professor of Philosophy and Education after a brief rest.

DEVON, Pa., May 29 -- Riding her brown gelding hunter Woodfellow, Miss Patricia du Pont of Montchanin, Del., acquired the first leg on the Clarence H. Geist Challenge Trophy in the Corinthian class today at the annual Devon horse show and country fair before a big crowd.

KEARNY, N.J., May 29 -- A new labor relations contract, including the controversial maintenance-of-membership clause, was signed this evening by the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company and Local 16 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of the C.I.O.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that music and song have the highest priorities in war as well as peace, after he listened to 150 singers from six college glee clubs who entertained a noonday crowd of 1,000 from the steps of City Hall.

VINELAND, N.J., May 29 -- The good people of Vineland dug into their savings today, literally turning their pockets inside out to show the rest of the country what a small community can do when it buckles down to the serious business of buying war bonds and stamps.
MEXICO CITY, May 29 -- The Chamber of Deputies unanimously approved tonight a declaration that Mexico had been in a state of war with Germany, Italy and Japan since May 22.
This is a very happy day for me, and that is one of the reasons why I am trying to record it.

DETROIT, May 30 (AP) -- What Jimmy Dykes thought were his powder puff punchers exploded for seven runs in the ninth inning today to give the White Sox a 12-to-5 victory over the Tigers in the second game and a split of a holiday double bill before 31,659 spectators. Four home runs, two by Pinky Higgins, brought Detroit the opener, 9 to 4.

IN the first great national crisis it has known during its short life, is American radio doing a good job? There is a difference of opinion, and, accordingly, a good deal of dangerous confusion. At first glance, all is harmonious.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 30 -- The Summer homes here are being opened, some of them much earlier than usual, and there is every indication that all the villas will be well filled long before the Fourth of July.

IF ever a case could be called definitely closed it is that of the murder which Perry Mason undertakes to investigate in this tale of one of his multifarious exploits. The murder in question has taken place eighteen years before our story opens, and a man has been tried, condemned and executed for it.

THE little girl who came into her first-grade classroom one morning with a story about her difficulties in finding certain wild plants "because they look just like everything around them" started the whole class on a study of camouflage. The children built a toy village there in the classroom, then masked it under a pattern of color and design, and they learned things that many of their elders have not learned yet.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Senate conferees on the deadlocked service pay readjustment bill were challenged today by Representative Rankin of Mississippi to ask the upper House to instruct them as to whether they should yield or stand fast against his amendment which would raise the base pay of the lowest grades of the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard to $50 a month.

This is a time when clever decorative ideas are being called upon to do the work normally accomplished with costly materials and furniture. One device, exemplified in the newly arranged model house at Gimbels, is an adroit contrasting of textures.

LOCAL 47 of Los Angeles, one of the large locals of the American Federation of Musicians, is conducting a detailed and carefully prepared campaign to obtain an appropriation from the Federal Government for a "Music for Victory" program.

The Yankee method of celebrating Memorial Day was to decorate the Senators with a couple of defeats for the entertainment of a gathering of 43,997, 667 of them soldiers and sailors, at the Stadium yesterday.

A greater coordination of effort between the various organizations engaged in the sale of certain types of government war savings bonds is essential to obtain the best results, in the opinion of leading financiers who already are active in the sales program.
MOSCOW, May 30 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau communique said today:

LONDON, May 30 -- An important announcement concerning agricultural production and representing a revision of the British Government's agricultural policy is expected within a few days. Following an intensive plowing-up of permanent grassland in the first two years of the war, the Ministry of Agriculture pursued intensification of cultivation of available acreage for this year.

THE modern aircraft carrier -- "covered wagon" of the Navy -- typifies the new sea war. The great floating hangars are bringing many radical changes to naval combat; their improved successors may even be tomorrow's first-line capital ships, center of all fleets, center of most battles at sea.

MR. HELSETH'S first book, "The Yellow Angels," enjoyed some acclaim as a vivid presentation of genuine characters in an unusual setting. In his second novel he works in a somewhat more ordinary environment than prison, but his people do not for the most part come off with the former touch of life.

WITHIN five days after THE NEW YORK TIMES had published exclusively a digest of the "first draft" of a proposed distributors' inventory limitation order the War Production Board published its regrets.

Ethelbert Smith said that Mayor La Guardia is so frequently out of town on official business it was nothing unusual to read in the morning paper that the Mayor was due back in the evening from a three-day trip to Canada.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., May 30 -- Although it already had a Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps numbering 200 and a student Carolina Volunteer Training Corps numbering 400, the University of North Carolina entered upon the most important and far-reaching phase of its war education program this week when its Naval Aviation Pre-Flight School was formally commissioned at colorful ceremonies.

QUICK FREEZING -- A new machine that freezes foods four times as rapidly as previous methods, keeps the flavor in and provides a protective coating on the food, has been developed at the University of Texas by Professor W.R. Woolrich and Luis H. Bartlett.

In the midst of an oversupply of books for children on Latin America, many of them written and published far too hastily, it is pleasant to find such a gay and friendly little tale for 6 to 9 year-olds as "The Burro That Learned to Dance." Simple, spontaneous and unpretentious, it nevertheless presents a true picture of native life in a small Peruvian town high up in the Andes Mountains.
The text of the Army's statement on a survey of New York's dimout follows:

BRITAIN still believes that the use of offensive weapons in warfare is a man's job and always will be. But in the two and one-half years this nation has been fighting a battle for its existence it has recognized the fact that women don't need to fire guns and carry bayonets in order to perform essential, highly skilled services in the defense of their country.

PEARL HARBOR, May 29 (Delayed) -- The story of "Go Get 'Em" McCluskey was told to the press today by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, commander of the Pacific Fleet, as the admiral's best anecdote of the war.

The war has given rise to a renaissance of interest in geography, according to Johnson E. Fairchild, Who, during the Spring session, has directed a course on "Geography and World Affairs" at Cooper Union.

THE theatre season of 1941-42 comes to an end after tonight's performances, according to the tradition which determines the closing of a season by the expiration of Equity's run-of-the-play contracts. The new Broadway term technically starts tomorrow, but aside from an occasional Summer opening the drama business actually will not get under way until some time in September.

BERLIN, May 30 (from German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command declared in a special communique today that the battle of Kharkov had ended with the annihilation of three Russian armies and that another battle to exterminate encircled units west of Moscow was beginning.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., May 30 -- Valley Stream High retained its title by making 33 5-14 points at the eighth annual South Shore High Schools Athletic League track and field championships today. South Side High was runner-up with 16 and Malverne was third with 15 3-7 points.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. -- Crowds are coming early to this Old Dominion seashore playground on the Atlantic Ocean eighteen miles from Norfolk and available by train, bus, steamboat, motor and plane. The only change in program this year is the dimout of lights at night.

THERE is a curious kind of parallel between this latest Bromfield novel and its immediate predecessor, "Wild Is the River." Both, that is, are tales of suave and lovely cities in the agony of war and invested by an occupying army.
HOUSTON, Texas, May 30 (U.P.) -- A thousand determined Texans swore tonight to avenge the loss of the cruiser Houston and her crew.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- President Roosevelt, standing at attention in the hot sun for more than half an hour, today reviewed a Memorial Day display of our armed strength.
Artists for Victory, Inc., the organization of 10,000 American artists formed last Winter to collaborate in the war, has begun to put its program into effect.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 30 (AP) -- Four bomb hits, two of them "dream shots" from an altitude of only fifty to 100 feet, sent an enemy submarine to the bottom in four minutes of action off the Vichy French island of Martinique early Wednesday, the Tenth United States Naval District announced today.

LONDON, May 30 -- From the beginning of the war the strategy of the Axis powers has necessarily been dictated to a considerable degree by their need for oil and iron ore. With their occupation of the Netherlands Indies Japan tapped a rich source of oil, and Germany, by overrunning Norway and France, gained access to the rich ore deposits of Sweden and Spain.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., May 30 -- Topping an entry of 477 dogs, Champion Broaburn Cherry, the handsome white poodle owned and shown by Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of Stamford, Conn., captured his fourth best-in-show trophy today at the Bucks County Kennel Club's first licensed event.

GREENCASTLE, Ind., May 30 -- DePauw University is conducting an experiment in the nature of a social museum that it believes will deepen the understanding of contemporary society and will help build an intelligent citizenry.

The Army has inspected this city and the metropolitan area from a slow-moving Navy blimp and has found the general compliance with dimout regulations "flagrantly" and "glaringly" insufficient. As a result, Police Commissioner Valentine indicated last night that he was ready to start cracking down on violators, even if it meant summary arrests of merchants and householders.

STANTON, Del., May 30 -- Mrs. T. Christopher's Doublrab, a gray son of Sherab and Double Shamrock, scored a mild upset today when he raced to a nose victory over Mrs. Anthony Pelleteri's Bay View in the fifth running of the $5,000 added six-furlong Wilmington Handicap at Delaware Park.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The pay rates of American workers continued to rise this week as the Federal government sought to create in piecemeal fashion a national wartime wage policy carrying out the objectives of President Roosevelt's anti-inflation program.

Many New Jersey beach resorts got under way this week-end with special programs for the holiday. Others, among them Cape May, which announces its official opening for the last Saturday in June, have been slowly swinging into their stride and have been entertaining early vacationists who prefer the pre-season period.

One of the most notable assemblages in the history of Belmont Park on Long Island is expected there next Saturday when the four-week Spring race meeting of the Westchester Racing Association will close with a gala Army-Navy Day program arranged to benefit various service relief agencies and the United Service Organizations.

THIS is not another of the quaint Irish books in the Donn Byrne tradition of which there has been a surfeit in recent years. The fact that Mary Lavin, American by birth, writes out of Ireland is accidental.

George W. Sutton Jr. appears to be headed for a lifetime job in the presidency of the Marine Trades Association of New York. This veteran motor boating solon, who was formerly national president of the A.P.B.A., was elected to his eighth successive term at last week's annual meeting.

ONE of the most effective devices man ever has contrived to protect his property is the ugly but extremely practical barbed-wire fence. If you stay on your side of it, nothing painful will happen to you. If you try to charge through it, you will be ripped to pieces.

Changing administrations mark the close of the club year in a number of New York women's organizations, bringing new leaders to whom large memberships will look for direction throughout the coming season. Among them are two State-wide groups, the New York division of the American Association of University Women with thirty member clubs, and the State Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, with forty-nine affiliates.

This author's "The Year Round; A Book of the Out of Doors, Arranged According to Season" has been ever since it was published some years ago a useful and popular book with children, parents and teachers. Now Mr. Hylander has given us a volume on the outdoor world in Spring, with the promise of three more books to follow, covering Summer, Autumn and Winter, respectively.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 30 -- Roberto Farinacci, one of fascism's most militant supporters, in a scathing editorial in the newspaper Regime Fascista, puts his finger on a weak link in the chain welding the Italian people and the revolution -- a link that has been considered a bulwark of Premier Mussolini's order.

Transportation difficulties threaten to reduce the attendance at the hundreds of local and sectional bridge tournaments played annually throughout the United States. At most such tournaments all the entrants have been accustomed to travel by automobile.

The Men's Garden Club of New York will meet at 12:15 P.M. on Thursday at the Hotel Lexington. Dr. William Zimmerman of the Boyce Thompson Institute will speak on the subject "Root Promoters and Their Use."

VICHY, France, May 31 -- Pierre Laval, the head of the Vichy government, in an address to the chairmen of 150 professional organizations' committees, whom he called together in Paris today, made an important declaration regarding impending measures concerning labor and production.

Non-defense plants are being closed down due to lack of materials and will remain closed unless converted to war work, according to the monthly business survey of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, released yesterday.

' SEFDL": Congressional Airport is civilian flying field a few miles north of VZashington, D.C. People can hire plane and pilot there for a ride; they can also get flying instruction. For the past month airport officials have been giving lessons to a straight - shouldered, 51-year-old executive who comes up dally from the capital in an _amy car whenever the weather is good.

MOUNT WASHINGTON, N.H. -- They are celebrating this Summer the three hundredth anniversary of the arrival of the first tourist on the summit of New Hampshire's Mount Washington. That, as mountains reckon time, was but a moment ago; mountains are concerned with eons.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 -- Here in the headquarters town of Harry R. Bridges the immediate reaction to Attorney General Biddle's deportation order this week against the longshoremen's leader was one of astonishment, tinged with bewilderment.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Greylock and Mount Everett reservations are being officially opened this week-end. With lessened motoring the commissioners expect many hiking parties, also horseback riders and old-fashioned carryalls. Bascom Lodge on Greylock, so named in 1898 for the first commission's chairman, Professor John Bascom of Williams College, is open with Reservation Superintendent Charles E. Parker and Mrs. Parker in charge.

BOSTON, May 30 (AP) -- Max West slammed out three runs and drove in a total of seven tallies today to give the Braves a sweep of their holiday twin bill with the Phils. The Braves snapped a three-game losing streak by wininng, 10 -- 1 and 4 -- 3.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 30 -- Police measures to curb in this country the "Free" organizations of nationals and former nationals of Axis or Axis-occupied countries were reported imminent today, as Brazilian officials indicated they believed such action necessary to destroy Axis espionage.
HONLULU, May 30 -- At cemeteries in and near Honolulu civilians and service men paid Memorial Day tributes this morning to Americans who died first in this war.
Although this is the worst possible season for aerial operations in North Africa, aircraft will probably play one of the chief roles in what appears to be a new Axis drive across Libya to the Suez.

LONDON, May 30 (AP) -- Production Minister Oliver Lyttelton's forthcoming visit to the United States was regarded by reliable sources tonight as a move in an extensive readjustment of Allied plans in favor of a future decisive offensive in Western Europe.

Thrift House will hold its final luncheon of the year for volunteer workers on Thursday at the Harmonie Club, 10 East Sixtieth Street. The House is a permanent rummage shop at 18 West Fifty-seventh Street, whose entire proceeds go to the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies.

Fordham's best baseball team in several years bade a victorious "au revoir" to Rose Hill yesterday by clouting efficiently behind Dick Fitzgerald's six-hit pitching performance for a 7-to-2 decision over N.Y.U.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- The National Rifle Association announced tonight a 10-man 1942 All-American rifle team of eight Easterners and two Westerners.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 30 -- Young male America, buckling down to the war, is turning strongly to the sciences as it seeks its niche in the great effort.

NEW DELHI, India, May 30 (Reuter) -- "Of course we shall take Burma back; it's part of the British Empire," was the lightning retort made by General Harold Alexander, who commanded the British in Burma, when asked at a press conference here today if there were plans for recapturing the lost territory.

AT A RED ARMY TANK BASE, Russia, May 30 -- A brigade of American medium and light tanks has been completed and it will be ready to go into line with Soviet and British tanks at the front within a week. Several other brigades are in process of formation. Two or three American tanks are already at the front, undergoing real battle tests. This base has not yet had news of them.

THE valiant fight of the Red Army and the Russian people has aroused not only our admiration but a fresh interest in the cultural manifestations of that people. We have had recordings of Red Army songs and Soviet folk songs.

BOOKS of the serious purpose and objectivity of Dr. Segal's strongly reinforce the argument that economic banditry, no matter how refined and subtle in method, cannot in the long run substitute for honest labor.
BERNE, Switzerland, May 30 -- In 1940 the German Army gained success upon success and overcame Denmark, Norway, Holland, Belgium and France to become master of the greater part of Europe.

The Music Education League announced yesterday the winning Soloists and Roman Catholic school groups in its annual auditions. They will receive their awards next Sunday afternoon at a concert in Town Hall at which many of the winners will participate.

The Chungking spokesman revealed the possibility of a Japanese attempt at a knockout blow for China, which grows out of the miserable conduct of the Burma campaign, which again follows the loss of Singapore. Dr. T.F. Tsiang demanded, immediately, bombers and pursuit planes, and more bombers and pursuit planes.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Frank Burke, who in 1915 jumped off a New York elevated train with the brief case of Dr. Heinrich F. Albert, key man of the German subversive organization in the United States, will retire from the Secret Service tomorrow after forty-three years as a top-notch investigator.

China fought back last week, attempting to check drives apparently aimed at knocking her out of the war. Her troopers, veterans of five years of bitter fighting, battled on far-flung fronts: in Chekiang and Fukien near and on China's coastline; in Shansi in China's interior; in Yunnan far in China's southwest.

For the gardener who wants a quick effect from a late start, plenty of color all Summer and Fall until frost, and a foolproof, lusty plant that is free from insects and diseases, the answer can be found in cannas.

IT is certainly true that the young American conductor is confronted with greater competition from his older, more experienced and colorful European betters than any other up-and-coming native musicians were ever faced with in the whole history of music.

ONE week from today this country will have been at war six months. The man on whom the greatest burden of those months has fallen is Franklin D. Roosevelt, President of the United States, the Commander in Chief by virtue of the Constitution. He has been, not only in word but in deed, leader of the nation.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- So far as the records disclose, little attention was paid by the Administration until recently to one of the most available sources of domestic transport, presenting only simple problems for solution -- the inland waterways. Studies of this system for use in wartime were made by the War Resources (Stettinius) Board in 1939 and by its successor, the National Defense Advisory Board, in 1940, but there was no follow-through.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 30 -- That time works against Germany is admitted for the first time in the latest issue of the popular German labor magazine Der Frontarbeiter, received here today, and worried Nazi officials demand that the industrial resources of Germany's allies and satellites should be put at Reichsfuehrer Hitler's disposal more generously.

After a journey over the Red Sea, Indian Ocean, Pacific Ocean and through the Panama Canal, Turkey's late-1941 Barbarossa and Smyrna International Fair series, previously mentioned in these columns, reached New York last week.
PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP) -- The Athletics ended a seven-game losing streak today by whipping the Red Sox, 5 to 4, after dropping the first encounter, 10 to 6.

The shipbuilding industry on all coasts is "reaching its stride" and is beginning to turn out ships at a "surprising rate," according to officials of the American Bureau of Shipping who have completed an inspection of yards on the Atlantic, Gulf and Pacific Coasts.
CHUNGKING, China, May 30 (AP) -- An American Volunteer Group communique said today:

BERNE, Switzerland, May 30 -An official announcement issued early this evening through Berlin confirms the appointment of Col. Gen. Kurt Daluege to succeed Reinhard Heydrich in the post temporarily occupied by K.H. Frank, Czech Sudeten agitator.

THE winners of the Alfred A. Knopf Fellowship Awards for 1942 are: for fiction, Robert F. Gibbons; for history, Dr. Angie Debo; for biography, Russel B. Nye. Each of the winners' receives an outright grant of $1,200 to help in the completion of his work in progress, and Mr. Knopf will publish the prize-winning books when they are completed.

MOSCOW, May 30 -- Across Russia's broad landscape millions of men now are moving forward to their appointed places on an 1,800-mile front. The Red Army's mysterious and incalculable power is being distributed to strike against the German Reichswehr a blow the Russian people are being told can and must be decisive.
A statement issued here yesterday by the National Federation for Constitutional Liberties quoted clergymen, educators and others in denunciation of Attorney General Biddle's deportation order.

A picturesque Yugoslav garden festival, under the sponsorship of the American Friends of Yugoslavia, will be held on the afternoon of June l0 in the twenty Turtle Bay Gardens which form the center of the city block between East Forty-eighth and Forty-ninth Streets, Second to Third Avenue.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 30 -- Fifty newspaper writers from all over the United States are today retiring from a fortnight at Harvard, their heads bursting with information, their hearts bowed down with woe. For the Nieman Foundation for Journalism has been conducting a highly concentrated War Institute in all aspects of current war-making, and the general impression is a somber one.

Once again the United States is to celebrate July 4 in the traditional fashion -- the traditional fashion of allowing the sale of fireworks, as a result of which hundreds of children will be either injured fatally, disfigured or blinded.

RICHMOND, Va., May 30 -- A "bombing camera" intended to facilitate the training of warplane bombardiers without the use of real bombs has been developed by the Bendix Aviation Corporation, South Bend, Ind. This is revealed in a patent (No. 2,283,788) issued to Abrosius Briechle of Brooklyn, N.Y.; Roy T. Hurley of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and George E. Merritt of Lusby, Md.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 30 -- Fifteen more newly commissioned second lieutenants and their brides left the Military Academy today on short wedding trips which will end at various Army stations.
CAIRO, May 30 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:

Rome reports reaching New York last night said that measures had been taken against certain members of the Italian aristocracy. This, it was stated, was an earnest that the Fascist party was to be purged according to Premier Mussolini's indications so that "the minority may face the majority."

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- The third official list of American prisoners of war was issued today by the War Department. It contains the names of 277 soldiers, sailors and marines from forty-two states and Hawaii.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 30 -- Staving off a last-inning rally, Princeton's varsity baseball team downed Fort Monmouth, 7-5, in a twilight game on University Field today. The Tiger victory made up for a 14 -- 4 lacing at the hands of the soldiers three weeks ago.

AND now Mr. Nichols, in no uncertain terms, recants his pacifist creed. In nine dramatic short stories of an autobiographical and semi-autobiographical nature and a foreword outlining a story he would have liked to have written he gives voice to the whys and wherefores of his recantation.

MEXICO CITY, May 30 (U.P.) -- Mgr. Luis M. Martinez, Archbishop of Mexico and Apostolic Delegate in this country, issued tonight the following statement calling on Mexican Catholics to support the government in its war decision:

CAN you remember all the words of "Peas porridge hot, peas porridge cold," and the appropriate clapping motions (with the proper hand) to punctuate each line, up to and including, "Some like it in the pot, nine days old"? And how nimble are your fingers in looping a yard of string into a cat's cradle?

The story of an exhibit of French-Canadian literature that started at Queens College and has since traveled through half the country visiting colleges and universities in the East, New England and the Middle West was told yesterday by Professor Leo Pierre Courtines, who arranged the exhibit.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, May 30 -- To help students understand the important role public relations work is playing in the war effort and the even larger role it seems likely to play in the establishment of a lasting peace, the School of Journalism at the State University of Iowa will add a course in "Public Relations in War and Peace" during the Summer session opening June 8, Dr. Frank Luther Mott, director, announced today.

The first of a series of neighborhood rallies to be staged by the Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign prior to and during the June 14 to 24 drive in which 200,000 Minute Men will call at the 2,000,000 homes of New Yorkers to obtain pledges for war bond purchases, was held at 6:45 o'clock last night at Father Duffy's statue in Times Square.

The parallel between the present reverses for American arms and the early years of the Civil War, coupled with tributes to the dead of this and other wars and assurances of final victory, was the keynote of virtually all the Memorial Day services held in the city yesterday under the auspices of veterans organizations and patriotic societies.
Considering the gasoline and tire restrictions, there will be a good turn-out for the forty-second annual Women's Aetropoiltan Golf l Association championship. Play will begin tomorrow at Lakeville.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- The National Rivers and Harbors Congress ended its two-day annual convention today with the adoption of a series of resolutions, including a recommendation for the construction of an inexpensive pipeline across Northern Florida to provide a continuous flow of 250,000 to 300,000 barrels of oils a day.

A tea for the benefit of Bundles for America will be given Wednesday at the River Club to mark the opening there of an exhibition of old masters and modern paintings presented under the auspices of the club's art committee. Mrs. C. Frank Reavis is chairman of the exhibition and is aided by Mrs. Hugh Bullock, Mrs. William S. Cowles and Mrs. Hugh G.M. Kelleher.

The starving Belgian people are "praying" for an invasion of the continent by the United Nations, although they do not believe an invading force could land successfully on the Belgian coast, because of the country's flat terrain, Albert De Vleeschauwer, Minister for Colonies in the Belgian Government in Exile in London, said yesterday in an interview in the Hotel Saint Regis, Fifty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue.

THERE has been no perceptible slackening in the flood of historical fiction which American novelists have been pouring forth during the last few years. The odds are better than even that any new novel running to more than four hundred pages deals with a section of the American past.

CHUNGKING, China, May 30 (U.P.) -- The Japanese officials held responsible for a breakdown of the air raid precautions system in the surprise raid by American bombers on Tokyo and other centers on April 18 have been imprisoned and punished, Chinese military, intelligence reports said tonight.

HOWEVER much most people may dread and fear illness, they dread and fear it a good deal less than they would were it not for the Dr. Finlays of this world. Many of us have known at one time or another what it means to rely on the skill and trustworthiness of a doctor.

SEEING the funny side of life comes naturally to Ransom Sherman, master of ceremonies on Columbia's Wednesday evening variety show (WABC, 9:30), but one might not guess it to see the maestro at work on a script.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 30 -- The influx of troops from America and the Middle East has greatly increased the number of mouths to be fed by Australia and varied is the kind of food eaten. A survey of the problems that this situation presents shows the need for careful planning.

WHEN Barbara Padowicz and her 6-year-old son fled on a refugee-crowded truck from bombed Warsaw neither of them had the right clothes: Mme. Padowicz's maid had packed Summer suits and filmy underthings and thin-soled sandals; but the little boy's governess-nurse had his calcium ready for him, and gave his mother directions about his care.

THE New York Music Critics Circle originally planned to present a specially designed, engraved plaque to the composer whose work it judged to be the most noteworthy new American composition of the season. But when the Circle examined its finances after presenting two concerts it found itself so much in the hole-that there was a unanimous vote to present "an inexpensive diploma'' instead.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., May 30 -- In September, 1940, President Rufus B. von KleinSmid of the University of Southern California sent the following message to President Franklin D. Roosevelt: "This institution desires to place its facilities, personnel and materials at your disposal for any public service which you believe it can render in this present emergency."

One of those rare occasions when the color prints in a combination color and black-and-white show average higher in quality than the black-and-white prints was opened to the public at the Bronx Zoo yesterday in the exhibition of sixty photographs of birds by Dr. Eliot Porter of Hubbard Woods, Ill., veteran photographer of bird life.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The War Production Board today announced an order which will stop the production of practically all musical instruments in a short time. The provision applies to all instruments containing more than 10 per cent by weight of critical materials, including metals, cork, plastics and rubber, and will affect almost all musical instruments except violins, cellos and some guitars, the agency said.

LAWRENCE, Kan., May 30 -- While the University of Kansas is geared 100 per cent to the war effort, the cultural and educational backgrounds which foster the ideals for which the nation is fighting and which are nurtured especially in the liberal arts and sciences, are not being forgotten, Chancellor Dean W. Malott said today.

" THE poets suspect that I may be a good biographer, and the biographers believe that I may be a good poet," said Carl Sandburg in a rare moment of relaxed talk, as he finished dinner at an Automat on Sixth Avenue.
SELF-RESPECTING musicians must deplore the manner in which the recent "contest" of the Critics Circle was conducted, and especially Mr. Downes's remarks in THE TIMES of Sunday, May 17.

TOMORROW morning 27,000 people of the entertainment industry in New York will find in their mailboxes a large white envelope containing a questionnaire bearing the return address of the War Production Training Committee of the American Theatre Wing War Service.

WE have just had a very active week in the theatre, which, however, has brought us no new plays. Of the three revivals, easily the most interesting is Clifford Odets's "Awake and Sing!" although Daphne Du Maurier's "Rebecca" is likely to make the most money.
The example of our heroic dead should inspire and fortify us today in our fight for the preservation of the democracy for which they gave their lives, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday.

GEORGE S. KAUFMAN has quite a schedule these days, Max Gordon being the cause. Not only will he direct "Franklin Street" for Mr. Gordon but he also will have the same stint for another comedy which Mr. Gordon, who has assumed the mantle of the late Sam H. Harris, will bring forth.

LAST week when I was in New York I saw the revival of "Porgy and Bess" and I find it differs somewhat from the original performance which I saw a number of years ago. I was disappointed that the Buzzard Song had been eliminated, and also the scene where a number of the fishermen are lost in the storm.

Premier Tojo convoked the Diet in extraordinary session last week "to consider the Government's shipbuilding program." This is a strong hint that Japan is feeling the pinch of her losses at sea. Ships are vital to Japan. The empire she is trying to build for herself can be held together only by sea-borne communications.

So when the German invasion of 1940 revolutionized her life and set her to the task of making one franc do the work of twenty -- of somehow, from nothing, keeping her family warm, clothed, fed and sheltered -- she used an old talent bright with use.

Not much room for mystery here, one might say, but one would be wrong, for there are several startling surprises in store for the reader.

IT is never too late for another book on the historic relations of the red man and the white. This work deals mainly with official relations from the formation of the Federal Government to the end of 1850. Only the most patient industry could have amassed so great a store of material on every conceivable aspect of the subject.

There are a surprising number of people who verily believe that in order to see Carolina Hemlocks they must travel to the Great Smokies and Southern hillsides. If they but knew it, this graceful tree will give them year-around beauty in their own gardens at home.

MOSCOW, Sunday, May 31 -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's Soviet Armies in the Ukraine have scored a brilliant success in thwarting a Nazi-planned drive on Rostov, gateway to the Caucasus, the Russians announced in a special communique today declaring that the battle of Kharkov was drawing to a close after nineteen days of violent fighting in which the Germans had lost more than 90,000 killed or captured.

WHEN one contemplates the world in which we live today, one is reminded of that puzzling toy -- I am afraid it was made in Japan -- which came in the form of a wooden egg. When this egg was opened there was another egg inside and when this was opened another and yet another, down to the last center egg.

In a dual launching Uncle Sam's newest submarine chasers, the PC-553 and the PC-555, slid down the ways in the Sullivan Dry Dock and Repair Corporation's yards at Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, while about 2,000 spectators cheered.

ALBANY, May 30 -- The Public Service Commission has taken steps to stagger work shifts and to permit bus companies in war industry areas to run over each other's lines in an effort to get the war workers to and from their homes with the least delay.

In Book I of his "Commentaries" Caesar tells how he destroyed the bridge over the Rhone at the site of the present Geneva to prevent a westward migration by the Helvetii. The year was 58 B.C., and Switzerland is celebrating Geneva's 2,000th anniversary this Summer although as a mathematical proposition the anniversary would be next year).

A TALL steel structure has been erected above the New Jersey Palisades across from Grant's tomb. Tomorrow afternoon at 2 o'clock it will become active with new radio waves as "W63NY," another New York FM broadcaster, the fourth such station to begin commercial operations in this area in a little more than a year.

IT may sometimes appear rather dicouraging, to those of us who have so long sponsored "modern art," that progressive movements should still seem to need earnest, not to say militant, defense. In the Spring many a gardener is stirred to wrath when he discovers bulbs or newly planted seeds disturbed, wilted plants that come out at a touch, or plant roots exposed, or his lawn heaved up in long ridges by the depredations of the lowly mole.

Omer B. Becu, American representative of the International Transport Workers Federation, will leave here early this week to attend the Maritime Conference of the International Labor Office, which will convene in London on June 22.

Delegates from consumer cooperatives in twelve Eastern States from Maine to Maryland met yesterday at the Hotel Edison for the annual convention of the Eastern Cooperative Wholesale and were informed that cooperatives throughout the country had completed another year of record-breaking business.

THE country sets a style all its own in comfortable and becoming clothes. This style is one that ranges from the sophistication of well-cut slacks to the little-girl look of gayly colored cotton dresses. City cares fade away when one puts on these appropriate garments for even a day or two in the open.

A troupe of puppeteers, who have made their own marionettes and sets, will tour the playgrounds of the city Park Department on a trailer stage playing one-day stands free in the open air, according to an announcement by the Park Department yesterday.

It being ever a privilege and a pleasure for the Giants to disrupt things in Brooklyn, Mel Ott's Polo Grounders derived more than a fair measure of satisfaction from their efforts at Ebbets Field yesterday even though they did nothing more than break even in the holiday double-header with the Dodgers.

UNTIL a few days ago the most informative volume upon our national capital, and apparently capital of a world in the making, was "Washington, City and Capital," a monumental guide book (weight, five and a half pounds) of the Federal Writers Project of the Works Progress Administration.

LONDON, MAY 30 -- The battle in Libya for "the gateway to Tobruk" continued to seesaw throughout today in the wake of Lieut. Gen. Neil Methuen Ritchie's action in sending armored and motorized forces of his British Eighth Army in a heavy counter-attack against the wedge that elements of Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Axis army had driven into the area of Acroma and Knightsbridge.
LONDON, May 30 -- The air war between Britain and Germany, that had recently been in a comparative lull because of bad flying weather, has flared fiercely again.

GASOLINE rationing has only just started in the West. But the shortage of tires has given a preview of what the rationing means. In the Rocky Mountain region as well as on the Coast, Western farmers and ranchers already have been using their cars with painstaking care.

Although it is pretty generally realized that investment plays a vital role in the healthy functioning of our economic system, there appears to be the greatest reluctance on the part of those who frame our tax laws to remove the deterrents to investment which some of our taxes impose.

ELIZABETH COATSWORTH knows children well and writes about them with a sure and happy touch. Her latest story tells of a brother and sister's first Summer in Maine, a holiday that is spent delightfully with an uncle and aunt, whose Summer home is a houseboat appropriately christened the Ark and anchored in a cove between pine-covered hills where the dark woods came down to the water's edge.

Barred from sailing coastal waters this Summer due to war conditions, the Mariners, nautical branch of the Girl Scouts, are rapidly switching their planned curriculum into new channels to be carried out on terra firma.
PORTLAND, Me., May 30 (U.P.) -- Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, promised today that Tokyo will receive another visit from American bombers.

WELL, it happened like this: The invitation for my forthcoming adventure into radio fluttered, one day, into my study as if it were one of the doves (not of peace) that mourn in the eaves outside my tower window.

The 188th Commencement Exercises of Columbia University will begin today at 4 P.M. with the baccalaureate service in St. Paul's Chapel and will continue through Tuesday evening, when Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, will confer degrees and certificates upon 5,000 recipients at an outdoor ceremony in front of the Low Memorial Library before an anticipated audience of 20,000 persons.

" Returned to sender by the censor" is now appearing on mail originally addressed from the United States to occupied countries. In some instances where such mail was posted even as early as Nov. 1 last year -- directly to or near the Philippines, for example -- it is only now being sent back to the writers.

Fortunately for inventors, the Supreme Court in a majority decision handed down in an infringement hearing on the originality of a machine for attaching heels to shoes followed the well-established principle that a new combination of well-known mechanical elements is patentable when an improved result is obtained.
CINCINNATI, May 30 -- The Cardinals whipped the Reds, 10-5, in the nightcap of a double-header today before a holiday crowd of 16,017 after losing, 3-2, in the opener to Johnny Vander Meer.

PINOPOLIS, S.C. -- Major new tourist attractions have been built into the center of South Carolina by the Santee-Cooper Power and Navigation Project, which has just started furnishing millions of kilowatts to a big defense plant in Charleston.

THE simplest and most clear-cut picture of the State of Washington, according to Archie Binns, is provided by persons who have never been there. To them the whole State is forested with giant evergreens, rain falls the year round, and radicalism flourishes in the wet shade of the forest.

The former Whitelaw Reid residence at 451 Madison Avenue will be the setting next Saturday night for a benefit ball to be given for junior officers under the auspices of the Committee for American War Work, representing the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies.

JERSEY CITY, May 30 (AP) -- Newark's league-leading Bears made a clean sweep of their 3-game series with Jersey City today by defeating the Little Giants in both ends of a double-header, 4 -- 3 and 10 -- 5, before a crowd of 7,435. The twin triumph ran the latest Bruin winning streak to five in a row.

A SOMEWHAT pessimistic vein runs through a recent Times Literary Supplement article entitled "The Style and the Mass." In most modern writing, it declares, an individual style has become, and is becoming, rarer.

After a tour of the combat training units of our flying forces, Captain Rickenbacker reports that he found morale high among the young airmen and that they were veterans in skill and training compared with the green pilots who, like himself, went into the air over France in 1917. A much more thorough job is being done this time.

A memorial service under the Free French movement in America was held at the Central Commercial High School, 214 East Forty-second Street, at 9 o'clock last night. A priest, a rabbi and a minister addressed a thousand persons.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Senator Tydings of Maryland charged today that Government personnel, funds and office space and machinery required for the war were being diverted and wasted in the production and dissemination of a "daily deluge" of news releases, many of them apparently composed on the assumption that "the entire population of the United States has a mental level of about ten years of age."

THE operator of a powered jigsaw cuts a slot in a small steel part for a marine plane in a Brooklyn factory. The slot must be precisely right and, to inspect it, the workman runs his fingers over it. He is blind.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah -- In the grounds of the Temple Court, under the shadow of the famed Mormon Tabernacle, stands a tall, slender monolith topped by a sea gull with outspread wings, said to be the first monument ever to be erected to a bird.

REMEMBERING the admonition of one observer who said, "The trouble with screen biographies is that the heroes turn to marble too soon," Preston Sturges has begun filming "Great Without Glory" at Paramount with an eye to maintaining the Sturges reputation for slapstick.

THE 1942-43 season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will open Oct. 7 in Carnegie Hall with Berlioz's dramatic symphony, "Romeo and Juliet," which will be conducted in its entirety by Arturo Toscanini. The work will be repeated the afternoons of Oct. 9 and 11.
The first city-wide test of permanently-installed air raid sirens -- of which there are now 407 and will be more -- was held at noon yesterday and in general seemed effective.
LONDON, May 30 (Canadian Press) -- Brentford and Wolverhampton gained England's major wartime soccer trophies today as the season's largest crowds turned out for the finals of the cup competitions.

Mrs. Meadowcroft understands children and knows how to write for them, as she has shown in her "The Gift of the River," Egyptian history for the younger children; her excellent stories "By Wagon and Flatboat" and "Along the Erie Tow -path' and her biography of Benjamin Franklin.

THIS story about a group of people on a palm plantation in the Central American tropics introduces a novelist of distinct individuality and promise. Miss Shedd's writing, highly subjective and often self-possessed, makes one feel her personality almost tangibly behind each phrase.

HOMER CROY writes with humorous and kindly understanding of simple, small-town people. He likes them, and it is easy for the reader to share his feeling. In "Family Honeymoon" the setting is Junction City, a Middle Western town of 5,000. All the pother and to-do is over the marriage of Gram Jordan and Mrs. Hetty Armstrong, both in their early thirties.

War relief work, estimated at a total of $75,000 to date, has been accomplished by the Daughters of the British Empire in the United States, according to annual reports being compiled following their recent convention.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman ordained as priests yesterday thirty-seven deacons who completed their studies at St. Joseph's Seminary, Dunwoodie, N.Y., and four others who received their education in religious communities of the archdiocese.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip Greene Gossler of 14 East Sixty-fifth street, this city, and Belvoir, Montgomery, Ala., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Gossler's daughter, Miss Marion Saffold Oates, to Thomas Leiter of Warrenton, Va., formerly of Chicago, son of Mrs. Joseph Leiter of Washington, D.C., and the late Mr. Leiter.

The long-threatened action by the Army and the Police Department to enforce dimout regulations by arrest if necessary seemed at hand last night, but there still might be time for the public to cooperate voluntarily.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 30 (AP) -- The communique issued by the Royal Air Force here today reported that seven Axis planes had been shot down in dogfights Thursday night and yesterday and acknowledged the loss of twelve planes, but bombing attacks on the airdrome at Catania, Sicily, were included in the operations conducted by the British pilots.

An ambitious plan for illustrating new United States postage stamps with vignettes and wordings promoting the nation's war effort is being prepared by a group of artists, designers, muralists, architects, etchers, art directors, photographers, typographers and writers.

Robert Taylor Merrill, vice president and general manager of the Merchants and Miners Transportation Company, who joined the United States Coast Guard Reserve earlier this year as a lieutenant commander, has been promoted to the rank of captain and placed in charge of the section of merchant marine personnel.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 30 -- Young Jimmy Turnesa of Elmsford, N.Y., now a corporal at Fort Dix, put on another of his acts in the P.G.A. championship today.

With the definite announcement that Joe Louis, the heavyweight boxing champion, and Cornelius Warmerdam, record-breaking pole vaulter, will be among the participants, the program for the all- sports carnival to be held at the Polo Grounds Sunday, June 14, is beginning to take shape.

THE news of the untimely death last Monday of the great 'cellist, Emanuel Feuermann, has been a shock to the whole world of music. To those of us who had the privilege of being his friends, the news has been devastating.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Early on the morning of Jan. 14 a torpedo crashed into the side of the tanker Norness about 200 miles east of New York City. This marked the opening of submarine warfare against American, Allied and friendly shipping in the North American coastal waters of the Atlantic Ocean.

LONDON, May 30 -- It was said here today that Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production, was expected to arrive in Washington shortly for conferences on production and supply. Also arriving is Harold Butler, new Director General of the British Information Service in the United States.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The Miss Atlantic City Ball, highlight of the resort's early Summer social season, will be held in the Traymore on June 20 and already plans are nearing completion for the event.

The general executive board of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, C.I.O., moved at a closed meeting at its headquarters at 261 Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon to have the C.I.O. start an all-labor "win-the-war conference."

"Perhaps a quarter of a million people in many countries," he says, have read that book, and many hundreds, here and abroad, have written to the author.

QUEBEC -- Arriving here by steamer from Montreal, you land in the ancient, Old-World Lower Town. From here an elevator will gladly snatch you up into Upper Town. But not for some folk. They prefer to prowl. They want to see the market place near which in 1608 Samuel Champlain built a combination fort, store and residence, and founded the first permanent French settlement in the New World.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Rear Admiral James Laurence Kauffman, 55 years old, former commandant of the Naval Operating Base, Iceland, has been named commander of the Gulf Sea Frontier, with the additional duty of commandant of the Seventh Naval District, the Navy Department announced today.

OXFORD, Ohio, May 30 -- These students at Western College are studying the college's new lawnmowers. Deciding to save the man power and fuel needed to keep its 200 acres of country campus in order, the college has acquired thirty-seven sheep who quietly, efficiently and picturesquely do the work of several men with mechanical mowers.

Retail trade here last week continued at about the same pace as in the preceding week. Department store volume was estimated as showing a decline of about 5 to 6 per cent under the corresponding week last year. However, retailers said two factors must be considered in appraising the showing.

The first wartime Memorial Day in twenty-four years proved no record-breaker yesterday, but attendance at resorts bettered expectations, admittedly not optimistic, and the volume of visitors to the city compared favorably with peacetime averages.
