Apparel markets are generally inactive, due to confusion over price ceilings and hesitancy created by proposed inventory curbs, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

The New York C.I.O. announced yesterday through its secretary, Saul Mills, that the Department of Parks had accepted its proposals for a program of "mass sports and athletic exercises on the lawns of New York City's parks similar to those common in Europe before the war."

WARTIME honeymoons being definitely on the short side, the first of this year's crop of June brides will find themselves on their own in their brand new kitchens a few days after their marriage. And adding to the natural apprehensions of a novice housewife will be the gloomy tales she has heard about the difficulties of successful cooking for two.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs jumped from seventh place in the National League into a tie for fourth with New York today by taking a double-header from the Pittsburgh Pirates, 10 to 5 and 3 to 2.

Another famous train, the Panama Limited of the Illinois Central, has been streamlined and with complete new equipment is now making its daily run between Chicago and New Orleans on an eighteen-hour schedule, two hours faster than formerly.

So far as the recruiting office of the nation's Women's Army Auxiliary Corps was concerned, yesterday was no holiday. Between early morning and 5 P.M. 450 girls and women filed through the large open doors at 39 Whitehall Street to obtain applications for officers' posts in the new corps.

LONDON, May 30 -- Some Czechs in London said the shooting of Reinhard Heydrich was not the work of Czech patriots but that of Nazis. They stressed that Czechs had never favored murder as part of their campaign of resistance.
DEVON, Pa., May 30 -- More than 5,000 horse lovers enjoyed today's sixth and closing day of the annual Devon horse show and country fair, with Eastern entries gaining most of the major awards.
WEST POINT, May 30 -- There were several "unsung heroes" at the forty weddings which took place at the Military Academy yesterday and today.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 30 -- As field work supplementing lectures, discussion and reading, students taking the nutrition course at Vassar College, chiefly sophomores, have participated throughout the year in the educational program carried on by the Dutchess County Defense Council Nutrition Committee under the leadership of Professor Ruth Wheeler, chairman of the Vassar Department of Physiology.

The outstanding outdoor dog show this year will be that of the North Westchester Kennel Club on Saturday, June 13, on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt in Katonah, N.Y., the beneficiary to be the Navy Relief Society.

KATHARINE CORNELL, who has forfeited many a king's ransom by her steadfast refusal of Hollywood offers, is giving serious consideration to a proposal from Gabriel Pascal to appear in a film version of "Candida," the George Bernard Shaw comedy.

THIS is "the first full-length novel about the Commando forces in England today." Its American author, Elliott Arnold of The New York World-Telegram, tells us that "every single large incident in it is entirely authentic, and the minor details have probably happened a hundred times."

The war work being performed by women in various civilian capacities will be dramatized by the Central Branch of the Y.W.C.A. at an entertainment on Wednesday evening, planned to promote the War Savings Stamp campaign. Admission to the performance in the auditorium at 610 Lexington Avenue will be by stamps of any denomination.

Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow will unveil a portrait of the late Captain Colin P. Kelly Jr., U.S.A., painted for the United States Military Academy by Bradford Lambert, at a private showing of the picture to be held Wednesday afternoon at the Arthur U. Newton Galleries, 11 West Fifty-seventh Street.

THE recorders of the West are having their day, and absorbingly interesting details are being found in recovered diaries and added to the already authenticated history of the settling of the broad lands west of the Rockies.

IF any one wants to write a history of Florida, he can do no better than to go to Providence, R.I. There he will find in the famous John Carter Brown Library collection of North, South and Central America, over 400 titles relating to Florida.

SEATTLE, May 30 (AP) -- Never finishing worse than third in the twelve events in which they scored, the University of Southern California won its seventh consecutive Pacific Coast Conference track and field meet today with 79 points.

Substitution of collateral for equipment trust certificates contrary to the agreements under which the certificates were sold, which some railroads have had to undertake because of decrees of the War Production Board, is an unprecedented step in the history of this form of security.

Since this war is too big for any human imagination to grasp in its entirety, a newspaper and its readers must emphasize one part of it at a time. For instance, most of us have been watching the Russian front during the past two weeks, with a side glance since Wednesday at the flare-up in Libya.

EASTON, Pa., May 30 -- Started as an experiment last September to reduce the living costs of undergraduates, the cooperative house at Lafayette College was operated so successfully during its first year that it is already filled for the next college year, which will start early in September.

Retail trade fell off last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Consumer demand for coats, suits and dresses was fair, with cotton dresses active.

With State Senator John L. Buckley threatened with a primary fight for renomination by Assemblyman Patrick H. Sullivan in the Fifteenth Senatorial District, another supporter of Representative Michael J. Kennedy, Representative Joseph A. Gavagan, also faces a primary contest, it became known yesterday.

Earnings of the steel industry dipped moderately in the first quarter of 1942, compared with the preceding quarter and with the first quarter of 1941, but the decline was due solely to the higher tax provisions for the current year, and earnings before taxes were considerably higher.

UNLESS an editor is prepared to lay down a hard-and-fast formula and bully his authors into accepting it the books in a series like this are nothing like so many peas in a pod. Mr. Thane's High Border Country has little in common with Edwin Corle's Desert Country, Stanley Vestal's Short Grass Country or Haniel Long's Pinon Country -- to mention three excellent predecessors in this serial study of the American background.

HAY FEVER: It's a grim thought to hay-fever sufferers that ragweed xvill soon be in bloom. One seasonal sneezer is New York City Councilman Joseph E. Einsley. Last week Mr, Kinsley urged AIayor La Guardia to sign a bill requiring property owners to destroy ragweed in their lots.

MEXICO CITY, May 30 -- In this revolutionary country nothing has been more revolutionary than the transformation in foreign policy dramatically marked this week by President Manuel Avila Camacho's plea to Congress to place Mexico in the war on the side of the United Nations and thus to make her, for the first time in her history, a belligerent ally of the United States.

Deliveries of milk will be received later in the day throughout the New York metropolitan area, except New York City, beginning tomorrow under the daylight delivery schedule that is part of the program adopted by the milk industry to reduce the wage 25 per cent or more and to conserve tires, gasoline and equipment in compliance with Order No. 6 of the Office of Defense Transportation.

A volunteer "army behind the Army and Navy" that will seek to collect in homes and neighborhood shops $1,000,000 of the city's quota of $4,450,000 in the New York-USO Joint War Appeal will be under the chairmanship of former Governor Alfred E. Smith, it was announced yesterday.

The statement by General George C. Marshall, made at the West Point commencement exercises Friday, that United States troops will land in France is bound to attract a good deal of attention not only among the United Nations but among the Axis nations as well. It will give a definite spur to the idea of a second front in Europe against Germany.

Emphasizing the point that only "total effort" will win the war, Jonathan Daniels, assistant director of the Office of Civilian Defense, warned here yesterday that "a system of day nurseries on a scale never before contemplated" may be established in America to care for children whose mothers are called to work in airplane factories.

Starting with the theme that food will finally win the war and that a pooling of the food resources of the United Nations can both shorten the war and win the post-war future, Bertram B. Fowler, writing in Free America, proposes the formation of an international commission that would use food surpluses as a kind of equivalent to what we intend to do with the arms surplus we are already beginning to manufacture.

The automobile's greatest contribution to sight-seeing -- that ancient recreation of travelers, holiday seekers and Sunday do-littles -- bows out today for the duration under orders from Washington. In force tomorrow, they prohibit the use of buses for "conducted tours" to sights in cities and throughout this wondrous land and for all but a few "essential" charter services.

A world record of $2,176,071 for a day's race-track betting was established at Belmont Park yesterday when a crowd of 51,903, topping all New York figures, saw Market Wise capture the fifty-sixth Suburban Handicap. Many were quick to say that there never had been such a racing day in America, and the assertion was made with full knowledge of memorable days in Kentucky, Illinois, California and New England.

THE papers which have been collected in this volume mostly deal with the year between June 1940 and June 1941, when England seemed to be fighting the war alone. That period has ascended into history, but Mr. Tomlinson's words, for the most part, have not followed.

THE Oliver Mackenzie, carrying a show boat troupe, plied its way up the Mississippi River each Spring from St. Louis to New Orleans and back again in the Fall. In November, 1916, the season was mild and the old boat traveled up the Wisconsin as far as Sac Prairie, where the captain docked to give a performance of "Uncle Tom's Cabin."

The first of the Summer's outdoor concerts in Central Park was presented at the band shell last night. It was the annual Decoration Day concert presented by George W. and Walter W. Naumburg in memory of their father, the late Elkan Naumburg, who founded the annual Naumburg concerts and presented the shell in which they and all the other park concerts are given.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- Dr. Theodore Schmidt, last president of the Australian Olympic Committee, says the war has written "finis" to the Olympic Games as the world knows them.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 30 -- Syracuse's oarsmen were outclassed today as Cornell swept the return regatta with the Orange on Onondaga Lake. The Big Red varsity beat the heavy Orange eight by a little more than a length in
CLEVELAND, May 30 (AP) -- The winning runs crossed the plate with two out in the ninth in both games today as the Indians and Browns divided a twin bill before 13,640 fans.
The new Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission will hold its first session on Friday in this city at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Legislation designed to keep "serviceable" tires on 20,000,000 automobiles for "the duration of the war" with the use of only 3,500 tons of crude rubber annually from the 750,000-ton stockpile was prepared today for introduction in the Senate Monday under the sponsorship of the Small Business Committee.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES CRUISER in the Southwest Pacific, May 30 (U.P.) -New Americin reinforcements have been placed in Melanesia, a 1,600-mile string of islands off Eastern Australia, it can be revealed today.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- With nearly all of the resort hotels of the region officially opening this week-end, early Summer activities are attracting many to the Poconos. Skytop Club is to be host to the National American Boiler Manufacturers Association from tomorrow to Wednesday and the Marketing Executives of New York City and Philadelphia from Friday to June 7.

In a little more than two months some 40,000 plants manufacturing 400 nonessential items which use iron and steel will have to stop the assembly of such products unless they can find suitable substitutes in gold, silver, glass, paper, wood or other noncritical materials.

Money lenders are seldom precisely popular, particularly when they want their money back, and blackmailers are invariably detested, so what can be expected when one man practices both these professions, as does Albert Reeve in this story? The answer is murder.

AS of June 13 the program now known as "Down Mexico Way" (WEAF, Saturdays, 4 P.M.) will have a new name, to wit: "Pan-American Holiday," with the locale shifting first to Cuba and later to the South American countries.
Why should not women render military service to protect America from invasion and conquest? Is not such service a logical development of the doctrine of equal rights between the sexes?

The Children's Theatre of Greenwich House at 27 Barrow Street will present a production entitled "Americana" next Saturday afternoon at Town Hall as a benefit jointly for Greenwich House and the Greenwich Village unit of the American Women's Voluntary Services.

I would like to express my sincere agreement with the views presented in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 24 by Francis S. Campbell on the necessity of a peace plan now, and I would congratulate you on opening your columns to the discussion of this form of political warfare which, I think, is of crucial importance at the present juncture.

I FEEL sure that the audience which attended the orchestral concert at Carnegie Hall sponsored by the Music Critics Circle could not fail to be impressed by the extraordinary manner with which Leon Barzin and members of the National Orchestral Association carried through an evening of extremely difficult and varied contemporary American music.

No need to tell Miss Baldwin's readers that her people seem real, her background authentic and her story interesting. They take all that for granted from one of their favorites, who for her part never lets them down.

Many gardeners find that a tub is better than no pool at all and get lots of fun from such vest-pocket water gardens. The only trouble with a tub "pool" is that planting is limited in quantity and variety.

Three international fellowships to enable women scholars to study in some country other than their own are announced today by the International Federation of University Women, in spite of the war which has involved many of its affiliated members.

GRAND COULEE DAM, out in Washington, the biggest structure man ever made, is about ready to "spill." Within a few days the waters of the Columbia River, backed up into a lake 151 miles long, will pour over the center spillway in a torrent twice as high and half again as long as the American Falls at Niagara.

HERE is another of the now-familiar obituaries of the capitalist system. The pattern is routine: We are in the midst of a social revolution. Capitalism, having long since outlived its revolutionary youth, is moribund.

" HOLLYWOOD has many famous landmarks. But the most interesting of all are the ones most people can't see. Ghost landmarks, I call them. Only the old-timers see them, in memories of days gone forever . . .," reflects Lionel Barrymore as he contemplates the changing scenes he has watched.

The first mass suspension of manufacturing in a varied group of products, chiefly for the home, in the history of American industry took place last night when the deadline ordered by the War Production Board on March 30 was reached.

THE answer of Oscar Williams to my review of his anthology, "New Poems, 1942," is disingenuous, to put it gently. Of the series of questions he puts to me, I shall take the last first, as it is the most pertinent.

Report on Rubber A nation of 32,000,000 motorists -- in pre-war days -- heard last week a discouraging report from Congress on the rubber situation. The Senate committee investigating national defense, headed by Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri, warned that there would be no new tires for civilian cars for at least three years.

At least for the present, the House Ways and Means Committee has decided that the provision for the mandatory joint income tax return of husband and wife will appear in the proposed revenue bill of 1942. This decision was announced in spite of the fact that the House rejected the measure last August by a vote of 242 to 160 just prior to the passage of the Revenue Act of 1941.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., May 30 -- Speaker Rayburn, speaking at the Muhlenburg College bi-centennial celebration tonight, charged that "in some quarters" today there appeared to be "a studied effort to destroy the faith and confidence of the American people in their elected representatives."
ROME, May 30 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

Barney Ewell bowed out of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field picture at Triborough Stadium yesterday, leaving in his wake a few imperishable marks to awe future generations. The Nittany Lion wonder scored the first three-time triple in the sixty-six-year history of the meet as he won the 100, the 220 and the broad jump for the third year in a row.

EDGEWATER, N.J., May 30 -- Thirty collapsible rubber boats, maps of inland waterways, field glasses and arms and ammunition were seized in Edgewater early this morning by FBI agents and local police when they sprang up-on the Edgewater Colony Association and apprehended an undisclosed number of German aliens and nationals.

YOUNG SUSAN BARR started out sweet, simple and gentle, and ended quite otherwise. She looked back on her former self as a thoroughgoing little fool, generally, and even while she told herself contemptuously that her trouble was liking to play God, she refused to give up that pleasure.

In the symphony of protest lifted against the proposed joint income tax by influential women's organizations, a counter-chorus was audible last week from Rochester, where the board of directors of the New York League of Women Voters, in executive session, echoed the conviction of the national unit at its recent convention in Chicago.
LONDON, May 30 -- The heroic dead of the United States were honored today here and at United States Army encampments in Northern Ireland, where four new graves of American soldiers were decorated.

The allium family, cousins of the onion and the lily, are desirable but frequently overlooked garden subjects. The writer passed it by in the catalogues until it was found growing wild; the discovery stimulated an interest in it. The wild allium is about two feet high, with opal-tinted flowers, globe-shaped and with tall, slender linear leaves -- an airy, misty plant with silver sheen to leaf and flower.

HANOVER, N.H., May 30 -- With 82 per cent of its 444 graduates of two weeks ago already in military service or expecting to be in uniform within a month, Dartmouth College this week opened the first regular Summer semester in its history, more convinced than ever that the liberal college can make an immediate and vital contribution to the national war effort without drastic change in its traditional offerings.

The month of June finds the moon waning (it was full on May 30), with last quarter on the fifth and the new moon on the thirteenth. Starting its cycle once more, it will be first quarter on the twenty-first and on Sunday, the twenty-eighth, it will reach full moon.

Two women were killed, a third was injured critically, and a 70-year-old man was slightly hurt at 10 o'clock last night when a seven and one-half ton ice truck ran onto the sidewalk in front of 351-53 East 155th Street, the Bronx, and plowed into them.

The War Shipping Administration has signed a second contract under the authority of the Bland freight forwarding bill, with the New Orleans Foreign Forwarders, Inc., an organization formed by New Orleans forwarding companies to handle lease-lend shipments passing through their port.

IN a nice way, a reader of this column writes in to lodge a gentle complaint against the failure of our comments to "penetrate into acting as deeply as they do into the writing of a picture." Particularly does the gentleman disagree with the harsh things we had to say about the performance of Bette Davis in the Warners' "In This Our Life.

FOLLOWING the fascinating factual drama of "All This, and Heaven Too," Rachel Field's last novel is the tender but searching story of a lovely and sensitive girl who had to find her way to reality. Emily Blair tried to cross the gulf between actual life and her sheltered yet exigent dreams and affections, as she tried to cross the river which flowed between the Blair mills and the home of the mills' owners.

Proof that enormous automobile mileage is being driven in the American war effort originates close to New York City. The Curtiss-Wright Corporation's propeller division, at Caldwell, N.J., reports that an unspecified number of employes drive 250,000 miles a day in going to and from work.

ALTHOUGH exhibitions have markedly declined in number as May comes to a close, the recently opened shows are by no means without interest. Two of the group events of the week, especially, present a diversity of work which would entitle them to stars on the gallery goer's list, even in the middle of the season.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 30 -- Harvard outbatted and outfielded Yale to fashion a 5-3 victory in a fourteen-inning Eastern Intercollegiate League battle before 2,500 spectators today.

WEATHER permitting, there will be a double-header between the Dodgers and Braves at Ebbets Field today and thereby hangs a tale. The way Durocher's Dandies have been mistreating Casey Stengel's Charles River boys this season is perfectly dreadful, almost too horrible to set forth in print.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The military resources of the United Nations are now in effect "in one big pool," Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Lease-Lend Administrator, announced today. He disclosed that the British and Australian Governments were providing food and other essentials to American troops in their territories.

The Swedish-American liner Drottningholm, which will arrive here early tomorrow morning with 908 citizens of the United States and other American republics, will be barred to the press until after the ship has tied up in Jersey City and unloaded her passengers, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The United States will join the other United Nations in disarming all aggressors after the war, and share in an international police power "to insure freedom from fear to peace-loving peoples" until a permanent system of general security, as promised by the Atlantic Charter, is established, Sumner Welles, Under Secretary of State, predicted here today.
BERLIN, May 30 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issues this special announcement today:

EL PASO, Texas -- Many visitors to Texas are discovering that there are some interesting gustatory by-ways to be touched in our great Southwest. In fact, they report rapturously on the unusual dishes served them. Many of these dishes originated over the centuries-old cooking fires of the Mexican and Pueblo Indians.

Along with the Japanese advance in Burma comes the threat on Ceylon with its wealth of tea and rubber. The island of Ceylon, about the size of the State of West Virginia, lies off the southern tip of India in the Indian Ocean.

There are two teachings that are skillfully propagated in our own time and have a wide audience. The first of these is the teaching that convictions do not matter. It is simple-minded, so the argument runs, to suppose that historical events are deliberately planned.

Drop a conventional hardened-steel ball on a hard steel plate and it rebounds in a succession of parabolic loops, diminishing in height and increasing in frequency, as shown on this exposed photograph. Drop simultaneously another ball, this one hollow but filled with grains of tungsten, and it merely rolls along the platform after falling, without bouncing.
ITHACA, May 30 -- Columbia put on one big inning today, scoring five runs, and defeated Cornell, 6 to 2, in closing the Eastern Intercollegiate League season for both teams.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 30 -- Mexico's firm stand in favor of democracy is causing a deep impression among Chileans.

WITH BRITISH FORCES IN THE LIBYAN DESERT, May 30 (AP) -- British concentration on destroying Axis supplies of gasoline and water appeared to be telling on Field Marshal Erwin Rommel today, dictating his battle tactics to such an extent that this factor alone may be enough to defeat his sudden offensive eastward in the desert.

CHUNGKING, China, May 29 -- Dr. Ku Yu-tsuan, director of the National Bureau of Industrial Research, announced today that seventeen laboratories, ten model factories and four extension stations had been established to find new industrial uses for China's agricultural products.

Three hundred bluejackets of the Navy Receiving Barracks, Flushing and Claremont Avenues, Brooklyn, will be guests at a waffle party this afternoon, given by Brooklyn Chapter 100 of the Navy Mothers Clubs of America, a plan which will soon be extended to other points in the borough.

LONDON, May 30 (AP) -- The Germans were reported tonight working on the theory that parachutists dropped from foreign planes had a hand in the attempted assassination of Reinhard Heydrich, Protector of Bohemia and Moravia, as the Gestapo speeded its executions of Czechs to a total of sixty-two, putting to death forty-four during the day.

MARTHA RYTHER, whose one-man show is current, until June 6, at the Ferargil, has taken to painting on glass. There is, of course, precedent for this medium. Some of our nineteenth-century American folk artists, who had a penchant also for velvet, used lots of glass (especially, Mrs. Halpert tells me, folk artists living in Pennsylvania).
College girls have decided tastes of thier own

IN pursuance of their progressive and experimental policy, Martin J. Lewis and H.S. Rosenwald are currently devoting the screen of their Fifth Avenue Playhouse to the first "all-dance film festival" to be presented in New York.

WELLESLEY, Mass., May 30 -- To meet the increased demand for women in radio and electronics, the Department of Physics at Wellesley College during the last year has offered a special course in these fields to seniors who were not necessarily majors in the department.

New York University's Summer program, designed to increase the value of undergraduates, graduate students and other citizens to the nation during the war period, will begin next week in virtually all branches of the university, Harold O. Voorhies, secretary, announced yesterday.

LONDON, May 30 -- Investigation of war-production plants for the period of February and March of this year showed "a very definite increase" in output due to a greater sense of urgency and responsibility on the part of factory hands, but there is still a production lag for which managements are to be blamed, according to a report by the Amalgamated Engineering Union that was issued today.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 30 -- A motion picture cavalcade, "From Peace to Total War," will be shown Tuesday evening at Christ Church parish house here under the auspices of the Oyster Bay Shop of the British War Relief Society.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- President Roosevelt has received a protest from some New Deal Senators that Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, has ignored the wishes of several Administration supporters in filling important posts in the expanding price control agency and, in a few cases, has appointed their political enemies.

BAY HEAD, N.J. -- With all pleasure craft barred from the ocean waters skirting the New Jersey shore and the fate of deep sea pleasure fishing hanging by a thin strand of military favor, there is every indication that the coming Summer season will see great activities on the waters of the rivers and bays that connect with the sea.

Outdoor-loving New Yorkers should get plenty of tan this Summer, for sunshine will be one hot-weather commodity that is certain not to be curtailed, restricted or rationed. The principal problem hereabout will be to get to the sunshine at the beaches and parks minus gasoline and tires.
MOSCOW, Sunday, May 31 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique follows:
I WOULD like to offer my comments on your article in last Sunday's issue of THE TIMES, "Dialing Around."

WITH ingratiating modesty, Channing Pollock begins this little book of homilies with the statement that he is writing about himself: that is, he is writing about what he, as one individual, has "thought, and done, and found true"; and "heaven forbid," he adds, "that I should climb onto a soap-box to interfere with your thoughts or doings."

President Roosevelt's statement last week that the Works Progress Administration might be abolished if Social Security could be expanded into a more generous system of job insurance, has provoked discussions in the financial district. There is a possibility, some feel, that his remarks may foreshadow the use of a much broader insurance scheme to help the nation over the temporary difficulties of war financing.

CHUNGKING, China, May 30 (AP) -- The Chinese officially announced tonight that bomb-ruined Kinhwa had been abandoned to the Japanese after fighting that saw more than 1,000 enemy soldiers killed with hand grenades thrown by tired remnants of the city's defenders in a final close-quarter engagement.

DICTATORSHIP and democracy are fighting an age-old battle, and fighting it on both sides of the line. There are no clean-cut divisions in this second World War, as we can see by looking at the eastern front in Europe. The strain and the stress are eternal. Each country is testing for itself the validity of authoritarianism against representative government, which always has been and always will be one of the basic problems of politics.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 30 -- Parades, speaking and placing of wreaths at memorial monuments and veterans' graves in local cemeteries marked Memorial Day ceremonies in many villages of Nassau County today.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 30 (U.P.) -- Foreign Minister Count Ciano told the Italian Senate in a speech today that Italy's relations with France, which involve Italian claims to Corsica, Nice and Tunisia, were "in harmony with French and German relations."

Rubber is providing one of the most fantastic stories of the war. Were it not for the serious situation into which the United States has been plunged by the Japanese conquest of the great rubber-producing areas in the Far East, the day-by-day record of rubber in the last two years could be enjoyed as a scientific mystery story.

Swift improvement in the critical situation which has developed in the pricing and production of Fall merchandise by major branches of the women's garment industry would follow modification of seasonal order No. 153 issued last week by the Office of Price Administration, according to comment in trade quarters here last week.

Commencement exercises are now in full swing on campuses in every section of the country. Colleges and universities, geared to the war program, are seriously concerned with their future existtence. Despite the drastic readjustments already made, further changes of a far-reaching nature confront the educational world.

Moving upstream over the last mile of the regular course on the Harlem, oarsmen from Philadelphia, Princeton and the metropolitan district shared honors yesterday in the annual Memorial Day regatta of the New York Rowing Association.

THERE is no such thing as the typical American soldier. An American soldier, especially one in the new Army, is merely the boy next door, put into uniform and given a gun. He has been trained to fight, but he has chosen to think and feel as he damned well pleases.

MEXICO CITY, May 30 -- Mexico was virtually at war tonight after the Senate unanimously approved this afternoon a declaration, already adopted by the Chamber of Deputies, that the country had been at war with the Axis since May 22. Fifty-three Senators out of a total of fifty-eight were present.

Although firemen worked for fifty-nine minutes yesterday to put out a fire on the roof of the Apollo Theatre, Clinton and Delancey Streets, the manager, Sam Pearlman, was irate that some one had called for apparatus for a fire "we could have put out ourselves if they had minded their own business."

" CONCERT LIFE IN NEW YORK" is a substantial volume of music criticisms by Richard Aldrich, selected from the multitude written by him in the twenty years from the season of 1902-03 onward when he was most active as reviewer of events of the concert and opera stage for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

NEW HOPE, Pa. -- "Half a cent a mile a mule." Permission has at last been granted for the revival of barge parties on the Pennsylvania State Canal in Bucks County, and one John Winter and his mule are looking forward to a busy season.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 -- Attorney General Biddle's deportation order against Harry Bridges, longshoremen's leader, provided a sharp overtone today to a conference of the C.I.O.'s State Industrial Union Council at Fresno, where Philip M. Connelly, council president, charged that Mr. Biddle was "guilty of contributing to the aid and comfort of the enemy." The statement was cheered.

A doubt that the American people are truly on God's side was expressed in a sermon yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street.
BERLIN, May 31 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I cannot resist the temptation to comment on the article by Arthur Krock, "One Way to Get the Facts About Rubber."

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Litigation involving interpretation of overtime provisions of the Wage-Hour Act awaits Supreme Court action tomorrow at what will be, "unless otherwise ordered," the final session of the term.
CHUNGKING, China, May 31 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Major Gen. Chu Shih-ming, Chinese military attache, pleaded today that the United Nations act quickly to strike at Japan from the Chinese air bases threatened by advances of Japanese troops.
LONDON, May 31 -- A vast battle of tanks continued yesterday over many square miles of desert in Eastern Libya, with neither side able to tell much about results.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- Conflicting influences that tend to restrict operations in the market resulted in wheat prices holding within relatively small limits last week, although the quotations dropped to the lowest marks since last November. Prospective legislative developments in Washington have been losing slowly their effect as a market influence, brokers said, and the shadow of the new crop is beginning to dominate trade sentiment.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 106.6 to 106.8. Price activity still centered Around agricultural commodities, with biggest increases in fruits, eggs, livestock, potatoes and beef. Price decreases occurred in raw cotton, poultry, grains, by-product feeds, flour and lard.

DETROIT, May 31 (AP) --Ted Lyons practiced his art as a switch hitter by setting off a five-run White Sox tenth-inning rally today to defeat the Tigers, 9 to 4, for his third victory. The second game of the double-header was postponed.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- Harvesting of Winter wheat has started in the advanced sections of Texas and Oklahoma. The first wagonload of grain was delivered at a point in the latter State on last Wednesday. The grain tested sixty-three pounds to the bushel, which is regarded as excellent.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 31 (AP) -- The headquarters of the British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

The roar of American planes over Japan, which has now made Brig. Gen. "Jimmy" Doolittle and his seventy-nine companions the newest American heroes of the air, may some day provide an ominous threnody to Japanese hopes of empire.

THIS afternoon at Baker Field, hard by the same Harlem River that rolls by the Yankee Stadium, Columbia and Fordham will play a ball game for the benefit of the Lou Gehrig Memorial Fund. It is hoped that other colleges and professional baseball will help to swell the Lou Gehrig Memorial Fund in the long run. It's set for a long run.

Publishers have arranged fairsized publication schedules for June, putting into them many of their strongest bids for attention in the Summer months. The non-fiction bracket appears particularly strong. The following is a chronological listing of some of the featured titles of the coming weeks:

PITTSBURGH, May 31 -- A drop of 1 1/2 points in output of steel ingots, more concentration of incoming orders in the higher priority brackets and a further step-up in production for certain shipbuilding and Army and Navy programs featured news of the steel industry last week.

With Bob Stuart, freshman sprinter, achieving a double, the Fordham University A.A. retained the metropolitan junior track and field championship at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. Bob Giegengack's Rams triumphed by five-sixths of a point over the Grand Street Boys, 34 5-6 to 34.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 31 -- A National Socialist threat to extend its anti-church campaign to certain of the occupied countries in the immediate future is stated tonight to be the subject of "careful consideration." in Vatican circles. Much attention in this connection is being paid to a report attributed to Mgr. Cesare Orsenigo, Apostolic Nuncio to Berlin, the essence of which is cited from Rome tonight.
Soy beans are all things to all men. Some of us inextricably associate them with the exotic and Oriental, in a blurred setting of joss sticks, gleaming gold buddhas and scarlet mandarin coats.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 31 -- Eighteen more Czechs were executed in Bohemia-Moravia today, charged, according to an announcement broadcast from Prague tonight, with "specifically aiding the assassins [of Reinhard Heydrich, Deputy Reich Protector of Bohemia-Moravia] to escape."

Jascha Horenstein was the conductor and Robert Casadesus, French pianist, the soloist, at the concert given early yesterday evening by the New York City WPA Symphony Orchestra in the Cosmopolitan Opera House. The concert was the fifth and last of the series presented in behalf of the United States Treasury Department by Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA War Services Section in cooperation with Local 802 of the Musicians Union.
CINCINNATI, May 31 (AP) -- The Reds swept a double-header with the Pirates today. Bucky Walters won the opener, 8-2, and Ray Starr blanked Pittsburgh on six hits in the nightcap, 3 -- 0.

LONDON, May 31 (Reuter) -- "The number of incendiary bombs dropped was colossal," said a man who was in Cologne during last night's Royal Air Force raid, in a broadcast on the German wireless (heard by Reuter) tonight. Four citizens of Cologne were brought to the microphone to describe their experiences.

LONDON, May 31 -- Seven-eighths of Cologne, a city the size of Boston, was in flames, an inferno "almost too gigantic to be real," when the history-making raid was over last night, pilots who took part in it said tonight.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 31 (AP) -- Jersey City snapped its three-game losing streak and tied Toronto for third place in the International League standings today by defeating the Buffalo Bisons, 11 -- 5 and 2 -- 0.

One hundred and five City College graduates and students will receive medals, prizes, and graduate fellowships and scholarships at the ninety-sixth commencement exercises of the institution tomorrow evening in Lewisohn Stadium, Amsterdam Avenue and 138th Street, Dr. Harry N. Wright, president, announced yesterday.

Great progress has been made in dimming out the lights of New York City, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast over WNYC, the municipal radio station. He maintained that considering the extent and population of the city and its normal illumination the success of the dimout "borders on the miraculous."

The Memorial Day address of Mr. Sumner Welles is important and timely because it is the most concrete statement of post-war intentions and policy yet made by a spokesman of this Government. Vice President Wallace delivered a speech May 8 before the Free World Association defining the American war objective as the completion and extension of the American Revolution of 1775.

"Relative position of competitors within a single industry has always been shifting, but jockeying for position of leadership has never been more intense than today," Grey Advertising Agency, Inc., 166 West Thirty-second Street, reports in a brochure it has just issued on "War-Tested Answers to Wartime Problems."

New York City had its first glimpse of some of Canada's "air-women" yesterday, when twenty members of the Women's Division of the Royal Canadian Air Force arrived here to study the methods used by American women, volunteers serving with the First Fighter Command.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Sales of 2,860 wholesalers were up 23 per cent in April, 1942, compared with April a year ago, according to figures issued by J.C. Capt, director of the Census. For the first four months of 1942, the average gain amounted to 31 per cent over 1941.

The series of twenty-seven performances of "Candida," at the Shubert, sponsored by the American Theatre Wing War Service in aid of the Army and Navy relief organizations, brought in a total of $90,892, it was learned last night.

Because a large percentage of taxpayers have had no increase in income from the war, but must pay higher taxes because of it and therefore find it difficult to continue the payment of life insurance premious, the New York Chamber of Commerce will act on a report recommending the deduction of these premiums from income tax returns at its monthly meeting on Thursday.

LONDON, Monday, June 1 (U.P.) -- The German Air Force apparently attempting to carry out Berlin's threat to retaliate for Saturday night's destructive Royal Air Force raid on Cologne, heavily attacked a town in Southeast England early today.

Government intervention in the controversy between the Milk Drivers Union, an affiliate of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L., and milk distributors of the New York metropolitan area over the plan of the distributors for every-other-day deliveries to home consumers was expected yesterday in an effort to avert the threatened strike of 14,000 milk drivers and maintenance men.

PITTSBURGH, May 31 -- A last-minute truce was reached shortly before midnight between the A.F.L. Teamsters Union, Local 249, and the Western Pennsylvania Motor Carriers Association, which averted a strike which would have halted motor transport of war materials between New York and Chicago.

"Good things come in small packages" is an aphorism with many exceptions. Notable among these have been the rare and glamorous perfumes of France, which at one time arrived in very big bottles -- with very big price tags. Indeed it is only recently that we non-plutocrats can buy a sniff of these wonderful wares.
CHICAGO, May 31 (AP) -- The Cardinals defeated the Cubs, 3-0, in the first game of a scheduled double-header today, but the second contest was postponed in the last half of the first inning.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A poignant series of radio messages from Corregidor, describing the final hour before the surrender of the Philippine fortress under shelling "too much for guys to take" was made public today by the War Department.

Speaking before the New York State Bankers Association, Adrian M. Massie voiced a well-high universal desire of bankers when he urged that the Treasury outline in general terms some pattern of financing for that part of the deficit which must be financed by the nation's 15,000 commercial banks.
LONDON, Monday, June 1 -- More than 1,000 British bombers dumped 3,000 tons of high explosive bombs Saturday night on Cologne and elsewhere in the Rhineland and in the Ruhr.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- An increase in Social Security payroll taxes would serve to head off Inflation and help put the nation's old-age insurance system on a sounder financial basis, according to deductions of a study, "Social Security Reserves," made by the American Council on Public Affairs.

A Wartime Week-End Pastime This search of the attic and basement that the government wants you to make in the interest of the war effort is going to require more time than you expected, and you will do well to set aside a whole week-end for it.

A four-point war needs program, estimated to cost $500,000 for a sixteen-month period, has been submitted to its own constituency and to the war chests of the country by the National Board of the Young Women's Christian Association, it was announced yesterday.

A spectacular fire that brought out several fireboats, police launches and the Coast Guard cutter Mahoning yesterday afternoon destroyed the floating boathouse of the Waverly Boat Club in the Hudson River off West 157th Street.

The seven-story loft building on a plot 50 by 115 feet at 127-29 West Twenty-fourth Street has been sold by the Harlem Savings Bank to the Collio Realty Corporation, Dr. Leon Lindenbaum, president. It brought cash over a ten-year purchase money mortgage of $42,500 in the deal, which was negotiated by Omnia Properties, Inc., and the M. Morgenthau - Seixas Company, brokers.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Monday, June 1 -- Three Japanese midget submarines penetrated the great harbor at Sydney, Australia's largest city, last night, but they were believed to have been destroyed after they had damaged one small vessel, it was announced today.

Professor Casey Stengel still is seeking a formula that will bring his Braves a victory over the Dodgers. Yesterday the professor and two of his players were given the "heave-ho" by Umpire Al. Barlick, the Brooklyn champions won, 10-2 and 3-1, and 29,104 Flatbush fans had a wonderful time at Ebbets Field.
MEXICO CITY, May 31 -- There were three explosions aboard the American tanker Cacalilao at Tampico early this morning as preparations were being made to load her for a voyage to the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey "covered up" and "distorted facts" in its rebuttal to charges that the company's cartel arrangement with I.G. Farbenindustrie of Germany had hampered the development of synthetic rubber in the United States, Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general, asserted today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 31 -- That the big Royal Air Force raid on Cologne last night caused extraordinary damage is indicated by the official German ire expressed in Berlin's Sunday evening newspapers. Der Montag, which appears during the evening, intimated that the entire center of Cologne was in ruins, chiefly from incendiary bombs.

The real question in war financing is not "Will the government get the money?" but "How will it get the money?" according to the June monthly bank letter of the National City Bank of New York. "Upon the answer to this question," the letter continues, "will depend in large measure our ability to avoid grave currency and credit disorders, disruptive of the war effort and vastly complicating the problem of post-war recovery.
Samuel J. Bloomingdale, chairman of the board of directors of Bloomingdale Brothers, has leased an apartment in 784 Park Avenue through William A. White Sons and Bing Bing, Inc.

It is the duty of every Christian to make a personal effort to check the drift toward paganism that is manifesting itself all over the world today, the Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg, vice chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Members of Congress have condemned the attempt of John L. Lewis to organize the dairy farmers of New York State, Herbert W. Voorhees, president of Free Farmers, Inc., declared yesterday in making public replies of Representatives to a survey made by his organization.

Establishment of a post-war planning commission which would include representatives of cooperative, labor, farm and other groups was urged yesterday at the closing session of the annual meeting of the Eastern Cooperative Wholesale in the Hotel Edison.

LONDON, May 31 (U.P.) -- A second group of American women volunteer fliers will come to England soon to help win the war by ferrying R.A.F. bombers and fighter planes, Jacqueline Cochran, United States flier and commandant of the successful first group, disclosed today.
New York's discarded tin cans have gone to war so effectively that, like the porker in the packing plant, "they use everything but the squeal."

Completed tabulations of the combined net profits for the last five years of 1,087 producing and manufacturing corporations show the undisputable lead taken by 1941 under the impetus of defense preparations and a boom in civilian goods.

Prices on last week's stock market advanced slowly, without activity but holding to the month's earlier gains, so that the rise in the averages between the end of April and last week was nearly 4 points. May was in fact the first month since last July which has not brought about a substantial net decline.

A master plan for a city-wide system of wartime nursery schools has been mapped at meetings of Federal and municipal agencies and citizen groups, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Elinor Gimbel, chairman of the Committee for Care of Young Children in Wartime, 254 West Fifty-fourth Street.

Most apparel markets continued to mark time while attempting to extricate themselves from the tangle of ceiling "interpretations," according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident offices.
LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 31 -- The charmed life that Corporal Jimmy Turnesa of Fort Dix led in the Professional Golfers Association silver anniversary championship at the Seaview club during the past week was ended today.

CHUNGKING, China, May 31 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's armies in Central China have launched a large-scale attack against the Japanese in Anhwei Province, about 200 miles west of Shanghai, the Chinese High Command announced today, and, aided by strong guerrilla forces, already are hammering at the gates of two of the province's largest cities.
ST. LOUIS, May 31 (AP) -- The Browns tumbled Cleveland from second to fourth place today by taking a double-header from the Indians, 5 to 4 and 8 to 3.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The most important personal characteristic of a member of Congress is "intellectual integrity," members of the National League of Women Voters have decided.

The women's auxiliary of the metropolitan army of reserve farm labor supply will begin its march into the country today when the first contingent of 150 women leaves for the berry patches and canneries of New Jersey.

Contributions amounting to more than $5,400,000 had been made to the $32,000,000 USO War Fund campaign up to the close of business Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Prescott S. Bush, national chairman of the campaign, which was launched on May 11.

Jesus told us to "take no thought for the morrow," but He also, in seeming' contradiction taught us to pray for the coming of the Kingdom of God on earth, the Rev. Dr. Frederick May Eliot, president of the American Unitarian Association, said yesterday in the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

The 188th annual commencement exercises at Columbia University began yesterday afternoon with the baccalaureate service in St. Paul's Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 117th Street, where the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox, chaplain of the university, in delivering the baccalaureate sermon, preached for the last time before his retirement on June 30.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- A proposal for a national conference of employers and employes to effect a wage stabilization agreement in war industries came today from Administration circles in Congress, apparently with the unofficial approval of members of the War Labor Board.

WITH BRITISH FORCES in the Western Desert, May 31 -- After four days of miscalculated Blitzkrieg, Field Marshal Erwin Rommel and his Axis armored forces, together with reinforcements that he had rushed through gaps forced in mine fields in a vain effort to solve his supply problem, were making a last attempt today to achieve their original objective -- Tobruk.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Federal rent control will become effective tomorrow in twenty defense-rental areas. Although rent regulations will apply to only the twenty areas, the Office of Price Administration announced today that the basic principles will serve for other areas in which it will move later to order a rigid ceiling over housing rents.

MIAMI, Fla., May 31 (U.P.) -- The gum of the Southern pine can be converted into a synthetic rubber of high quality -- suitable for automobile tires and retreading of worn natural rubber casings -- for less than 32 cents a pound, according to Gustav Weber, an industrial chemist.
VICHY, France, May 31 -- Crowds mobbed a food store in Paris today and in the clash that followed two policemen were killed and three wounded. A considerable number of other persons were injured.
LONDON, May 31 -- The securities markets have been slow to develop since the Whitsun holiday at the beginning of last week, but they made up in cheerfulness for what they lacked in business.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- Activity in the lard market is confined almost exclusively to cash busiaess, operations in futures on the Board of Trade being on a very small scale, although there was last week a moderate increase in the number of uncompleted contracts.

Ernest R. Breech, president of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, says in his report for the six months ended on March 31 that the results clearly show the effectiveness of already existing Federal taxes in "siphoning off" the increased profits of industrial companies under soaring production of war materials.

After having deleted the really objectionable feature of the measure, the Senate Finance Committee has favorably reported one of two World War veterans' pension bills that have been lying on its table for the past five months. The bill reported, HR 4845, as it was put through the House of Representatives last Summer, had two sections.
NEWARK, N.J., May 31 (AP) -- The Newark Bears stretched their winning streak to seven games, a new high for the season, by defeating Rochester today, 6 to 4 and 11 to 2.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 -- The Yankees went in for run-making on a mass-production basis today as they buried the Athletics under an ll-to-7 score to soar to their longest winning streak of the year, eight straight, by taking the first game of a double-header.

The inventive genius of the nation will go on display at noon today for two weeks at the Sachs Auditorium, Thirty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue. The occasion is the 1942 Inventors' Exposition, sponsored by the American Hobby Federation, and there will be no admission charge.
WASHINGTON May 31 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period May 23 to 29 are given in the appended tabulation:

Staging a one-day stand at the Polo Grounds before plunging into the West for their second road jaunt, the Giants yesterday put on a performance, which, if not exactly spectacular, was received enthusiastically enough by 18,072 on-lookers.
The blue and orange of the barker's cap suggested the World of Tomorrow; and like the Fair, was doomed to become part of the World of Yesterday. But the man in the cap was stoical.

Samuel Gilman Ordway, secretary-treasurer of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and a director in that and eight other corporations, was found dead yesterday morning in a partly filled bathtub in his duplex apartment at 25 East End Avenue.

Facilities of railroads and bus companies were taxed to capacity last night as vacationers started for home after the Memorial Day week-end. The task of transporting the thousands to and from the city was not expected to be completed until noon today, when travelers covering long distances will, for the most part, have reached their destination.

Marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding at the Madonna House Settlement, 173 Cherry Street, of the Columbus Volunteers and the local Boy and Girl Scout troops, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman visited the East Side institution yesterday and bestowed medals upon several of its members.

BOSTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Red Sox swept a twin bill with the Senators today, walloping Buck Newsorn in the opener, 11-1, and coming from behind to win, 4-3, in a nightcap cut to seven and one-half innings by the Sunday law.

BERLIN, May 31 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Berlin radio said tonight that 111 civilians were killed in the British raid on Cologne last night and it was stated that "great damage" was done in the central part of the city, but the radio quoted German military quarters as saying that only "about seventy" Royal Air Force planes took part.
WEEK ENDED MAY 29, 1942 A sharp rise in the so-called free Canadian dollar stood out as the most significant development of the trading in the foreign exchange market last week.

A broad program to acquaint the public with, the General Maximum Price Regulation is the objective of a Citizens Advisory Committee on Price Control on which 115 leading citizens of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware and Maryland have consented to serve at the request of Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration.

Amalgamation of one of the oldest members of the New York Stock Exchange, Lawrence Turnure Co., founded in 1832, with Blyth Bonner will become effective today. The combined firm under the name Lawrence Turnure Co.-Blyth Bonner, will have memberships in the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges, the Chicago Board of Trade, the New York Cotton Exchange, the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and the Commodity Exchange, Inc.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- An unusually rapid disappearance of cash corn, estimated by some experts to be between 40,000,000 and 50,000,000 bushels weekly, as the result of record feeding' and processing requirements has tended to maintain the price of that grain, despite the weakness that developed last week . in other grain markets.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEAD-QUARTERS, Australia, May 31 (AP) -- General MacArthur's Head-quarters announced today that a Distinguished Service Cross had been conferred on Colonel Albert C. Searle "for extraordinary heroism in action at Bandung, Java, Feb. 27."

Many of the major first-run houses will change programs during the week, thus bringing to nine the number of new films which will open between Wednesday and Saturday. The schedule follows: Wednesday -- "Remember Pearl Harbor," a fictional drama dealing with the exploits of a group of American soldiers defending the Philippines and featuring Donald (Red) Barry, Alan Curtis, Fay McKenzie, Sig Ruman, lan Keith and Rhys Williams, at Loew's Criterion.

Memorial Day sermons in a number of churches yesterday re-called in various words the theme of Lincoln, "that these dead shall not have died in vain." The day was taken as an inspiration toward the unfinished work to which the honored dead had set their hands.
LONDON, May 31-- The scorched earth has become good earth in the poor districts of London's East End.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There seems to be a good deal of kicking around of public relations going on in current discussion of war news, Walter Lippmann recently took a swing at various techniques of so-called public relations functioning in the government service.

War-created bases of economic cooperation between Canada and the United States may have consequences of a profound and permanent character if the conflict lasts for any length of time, according to a forthcoming conference board report on Canada's role in the American hemisphere.

The problem of giving New forkers adequate warning of hostile air raids is nearing solution, Mayor La Guardia indicated yesterday in his weekly "Talk to the People," delivered from his desk at City Hall via WNYC, the municipal radio station.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- An indication that the Navy soon will ask for a new multimillion dollar program of aircraft carrier construction came today from Representative Vinson, chairman of the Naval Committee.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 31 -- Five of the Fifth Division Handicap Class racers were out today in the first special regatta of the Summer, which was held by the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club.

CLEVELAND, May 31-- A huge wave catapulted shoreward along a sixty-mile stretch of Lake Erie before dawn today, caught holiday fishermen unawares, drowned seven persons, injured at least seven and cast numerous small boats against the beaches.

SAN FRANCISCO. May 31 (U.P.) Police and firemen in three key cities of the West Coast were equipped with gas masks today as j the area prepared to cope with any Japanese raid in retaliation for the bombing of Tokyo by the United States Army Air Force.

Names of the recipients of fourteen honorary degrees and eight university medals for excellence to be awarded tomorrow afternoon at the 188th commencement exercises of Columbia University were announced yesterday at the university.

MOSCOW, May 31 -- While fighting on the Kharkov front subsides, action on other fronts is characterized by reconnaissance in considerable force by both sides. This reconnaissance, when challenged by one side or the other, leads to sharp and bitter fighting.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 31 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has scheduled "Gambler's Choice," a story of two boys who grow up to become a policeman and a gambler, respectively, for John Carroll, William Lundigan, Patricia Dane and Keenan Wynn. Joseph Newman will direct the film, which is reportedly a remake of "Manhattan Melodrama" filmed by Metro in 1934, with Clark Gable and William Powell.

Mayor La Guardia, making his second radio speech of the day over the city's station, WNYC, maintained yesterday afternoon his reputation for vigorous language when he called Hitler "the Oberschwein" (high pig), Mussolini "the yellow cur" and the Mikado "the slimy rat."

Enemy submarines operating off our east coast in the Caribbean and the Gulf of Mexico have sunk four more ships, with a total loss of nine lives, the Navy Department disclosed yesterday. Three of the ships were of United States registry, including one medium-sized and two small craft.

LONDON, May 31 -- American fliers soon will be bombing Germany, the British Broadcasting Corporation warned tonight in a broadcast to the German people that stressed that the huge bombing of Cologne would be followed by others.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Plans for a joint Anglo-American victory production program will be made at the White House this week.

June begins this year with a better military prospect than any one had good reason to hope for three months ago, and certainly far better than any one had dared to hope a year ago. As June opened last year, Germany had been everywhere victorious; organized Yugoslavian resistance had been crushed in an appallingly short time;

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 31 -- Storme Queen, bay mare belonging to J.D. Silberman of Scarsdale and ridden throughout the exhibition by the owner, was awarded the hunter title of the fourth annual horse show of the Secor Farms Riding Club today.

HOLLYWOOD, May 31 (AP) -- A requiem mass for John Barrymore will be celebrated in the secluded little chapel of Calvary Cemetery at 10:30 A. M. on Tuesday by the Rev. John O'Donnell, his long-time friend who ministered the final Catholic rites to Barrymore when he returned to the faith of his childhood shortly before death.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Treasury spokesmen said tonight preliminary statistics indicated the $600,000,000 May quota for war bond sales was surpassed easily.

GREENCASTLE, Ind., May 31 -- Niles Trammell, president of the National Broadcasting Company, suggested today that radio's most dramatic opportunity might come in the writing of the peace after the present war.

The war has caused new defaults on foreign-dollar bonds offered in this country as well as the cessation by some obligors of payments of reduced debt service under temporary or permanent adjustment plans, according to a bulletin entitled "Developments in Publicly Offered Foreign Dollar Bonds Since the Outbreak of the War," issued today by Dean John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance.

The First Baptist Congregation, at Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street, was warned yesterday morning by the Rev. Arthur Franklin Williams, its pastor, of the "progress of apostasy within the Northern Baptist Convention," with, which the church is nominally affiliated.

When one angler believes he has a suggestion that may improve fishing he likes to pass it along to the other fellow for his consideration. Commissioner Harry M. Armstrong of New Jersey has forwarded his comments on various proposals that Hal Paynton has teen making to keep some of our salt water species feeding inshore.

In his youth John Barrymore scorned his heritage in the theatre and hoped to become a painter. One of the few relics of that brief interlude is a poster by him depicting E. H. Sothern as Frangois Villon in "If I Were King." In an acting career of thirty-nine years on and off the stage John Barrymore managed to combine many of the contradictions which distinguished that same Villon.

SOMEWHERE IN SYRIA, May 11 -- There are such things as horse marines and the Free French have them. At present they are formingpart of a growing organization in the Levant for the protection of the long coastline from Palestine to the Turkish border.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Daniel Robbins have left the La Salle for a month's stay in Lenox, Mass., before opening their Summer home in Northeast Harbor, Me.

LONDON, May 31 -- A vast amount of intricate planning and preparation preceded last night's attack on Cologne by more than 1,000 bombers. The operation, the first in which all Royal Air Force commands were concerned in one night's activity, called for perfect timing and perfect coordination.

Forty-three athletic awards, including twenty-one to seniors, who will be graduated this afternoon, have been granted at Columbia, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Edward S. Elliott, director of athletics. The letters went to members of five Winter sports teams.

CHUNGKING, June 1 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces massed in the Canton area of South China have struck out in a drive marking their fourth attempt in four years to open the railway north to Hankow, adding another battle area to China's far-flung war front, it was revealed tonight.

With a slogan "A Hotfoot for Hitler," a city-wide campaign for the collection of scrap rubber will be initiated next week, with the city's 12,000 shoe repair shops designated as the official receiving centers, it was announced yesterday by Clarence H. Low, chairman of the New York City Salvage Committee.

MOSCOW, June 1 -- Encouraged by the success of new weapons and by the stanchness of men called up last Fall and trained during the Winter, the Red Army now stands fully braced for battles as tough and as hard-fought as the Kharkov combat.

The market closed dull and mixed yesterday on the Stock Exchange. There was moderate strength in the first two hours of trading that yielded to pessimistic views of Washington reports that the purchase of war materials abroad, to be admitted duty free to the United States, had been authorized.

BOSTON, June 1 (AP) -- A girl of 18, screaming as she fled before a man brandishing a knife as he pursued her along a parkway path beside the Charles River basin, fell and was slashed to death today within view of horrified Back Bay apartment dwellers.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, June 2 -- Two of the three midget Japanese submarines sunk by gunfire and depth charges when they raided Sydney's harbor Sunday night have been raised from the bottom of the harbor.

The German people are "sorry" the United States entered the war, but they expect to win because they are politically unified, according to Captain Adolf Pickhardt, United States naval attache at Berlin before the war, who returned on the Drottningholm.

Men and women who have been using fertile imaginations in the pursuit of hobbies opened yesterday at the Sachs Auditorium, Thirty-fifth Street and Eigth Avenue, an exhibition of some of their fabrications.

HOBOKEN, N.J., June 1 -- Basil Harris, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, and the nine other members of the board of directors, were re-elected at the annual stockholders' meeting held here today.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- In a 4-to-2 decision, the Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal District Court at South Bend, Ind., had acted correctly in continuing until Jan. 1, 1943, a consent decree restraining the Chrysler Corporation from acquiring an interest in any automobile finance company.
Two years ago this week we were passing through the blackest days of modern history, perhaps the blackest days of all history. It was the week of Dunkerque.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 1 -- A sparkling 31 on the back nine, five under par for the course, enabled George Motz and Willie Klein of the home club to tie Mel Galletta and Gus Norwich, North Hills, at 68 in the weekly amateur-pro tourney of the Long Island P.G.A. at Wheatley Hills today.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- An Administration bill which would safeguard industries engaged in war work against prosecution under the anti-trust laws, provided the Attorney General and the chairman of the War Production Board felt this was "requisite for the war effort," was reported today by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 1 -- Appointment of a service committee in every parish to keep in contact with men in the armed forces was recommended today by Ellsworth C. Miller of Buffalo, president of the Synodical Brotherhood, United Lutheran Synod of New York.

So the sight-seeing buses are no more among the sights of this town. Their room may seem better than their company to economists of space, but tolerant observers mourn their loss. It must be going on forty years since they first showed up in Times Square. If laughs came easier then, that must have been a happier time.
ALBANY, June 1 (AP) -- First reports today on a survey to classify New York prison inmates available for military duty indicated that original estimates of 20 per cent may be exceeded.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 1 -- An Argentine delegation today presented various projects to the Inter-American Conference on the Coordination of Police and Judicial Measures, one of which specifically mentioned communism along with nazism and fascism as a social and political ideology that should be banned from this continent and energetically repressed.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- A petition for a rehearing before Attorney General Biddle on his order to deport Harry Bridges was presented today to the Department of Justice by Mrs. Carol King, attorney for the labor leader.

William F. Strang, Grand Master of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York, announced yesterday the appointment of Edward Vanderlinde of Rochester as Grand Marshal and made public a list of other officials for the organization.

James W. Brown of Florence, S.C., for twenty-one years Rumanian representative of the International Y.M.C.A. Committee, arrived yesterday on the Drottningholf from Lisbon with a story of torture by the Gestapo which he told to The United Press.

Although the Presidential decree authorizing various governmental departments to import war materials duty-free apparently applies only to the long-staple grade with regard to cotton, the futures market yesterday succumbed to liquidation by commission houses and New Orleans interests following the announcement.

BOSTON, June 1 -- Jimmy Foxx, now crowding 35 but up to a year ago one of baseball's greatest right-handed sluggers, today was waived out of the American League by the Red Sox and sold outright to the Cubs, managed by Jimmy Wilson, his old friend and Philadelphia neighbor.

On June 2, 1941, The Associated Press recalls, the German High Command stated the official Nazi verdict on the Crete epilogue of the struggle for Greece: "The fight for Crete is ended." But now, a year later, the fight continues.

On the admission of both sides, the great Battle of Kharkov has ended. Both sides claim the victory. In point of fact, the Russians and Germans seem to have fought each other to a standstill, using up all immediately available reserves and in the end reaching a tactical deadlock.
BERLIN, June 1 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A Supreme Court ruling today broadened the definition, of interstate commerce to bring within the scope of the Wage and Hour Law employes of buildings in which companies doing an interstate business have their offices.
ROME, June 1 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press)-The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

A wild scramble on the part of business organizations, particularly the smaller plants, to get government contracts now that the period for actually stopping production on hundreds of non-essential civilian items has been reached or will be shortly, was predicted yesterday in war agency circles.

TRENTON, June 1 -- John Rogan, identified as a resident of New York and a seaman who has "sailed the Jersey coast," came to Trenton today with seven members of crews of torpedoed ships and told a conference of State and Army ofifcials that he did not consider it was in the best interest of defense to discuss the interference with business at seashore resorts during the simulated invasion staged on Sunday of last week.

Agreeing that New York City, as the "fashion center of the world," also should lead the way in solving problems facing the conscientious consumer who is trying to abide by a pledge of sound buying and home economy, Mayor La Guardia yesterday offered a two-point program to be followed by consumer and merchant.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The Navy Department announced its fourth casualty list of the war today, raising the total of dead wounded and missing to more than 8,500 officers and men.

Ten thousand parents of New York City's school children have been functioning daily as guards to prevent sabotage in the city's schools and to prevent undersirables from entering the buildings, members of the United Parents Association were informed last night at a meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 -- J.F. Deasy, vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, the first defense witness in the anti-trust civil suit brought by the Department of Justice against Pullman, Inc., three of its subsidiaries and thirty-one officers and directors, declared today that the more national the sleeping car business is in scope the better is the public interest served.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Leaselend and commercial exports from the United States during April totaled $681,979,000, continuing the record volume for the first quarter of this year when the highest figures in twenty years were announced, the Department of Commerce reported today.

An underwriting group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., yesterday won the award of an issue of $15,000,000 of Public Service. Electric and Gas Company first mortgage 3 per cent bonds in one of the most keenly contested sales for a public utility issue since the compulsory competitive rule promulgated by the Securities and Exchange Commission became effective in May, last year.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 1 -- Appointment of a bus coordinator for Westchester County to supervise the schedules of interlocking bus companies and to provide bus information to residents by telephone twenty-four hours a day was advocated today by leaders of women's clubs at a transportation conference in the Wykagyl Country Club here.

Miss Camille Anderson, the 1942 Maid of Cotton, from Memphis, Tenn., was received yesterday at City Hall by Mayor La Guardia. The occasion was a ceremonial trade of a miniature bale of cotton on behalf of her sponsors, the National Cotton Council the Cotton Textile Institute and the cotton exchanges of New York, Memphis and New Orleans, for a Lilly Dache hat, a halo of cotton corn flowers, daisies and red and white poppies.

BERLIN, June 1 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in New York) -- The Berlin radio quoted dispatches from Cologne tonight as saying that 139 civilians thus far had died as a result of the British raid, and that "the nightmare of Sunday still is weighing on the Cologne population."
DES MOINES, June 1 -- The Women's Army Auxiliary Corps training center at Fort Des Moines "will be no glamour girls' playhouse," Colonel Don C. Faith, commandant, said upon his arrival today.

LONDON, June 1 -- Disappointment was mingled today with satisfaction at the stations of the British Bomber Command. The reason was that bad weather forced a last-minute cancellation of plans for another big raid on Germany last night.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Duke and Duchess of Windsor had luncheon today at the White House as guests of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt. Stephen T. Early, Presidential secretary, said the luncheon was strictly a "family" affair and that no guest list would be issued.

TRENTON, June 1 -- Members of the Hudson County Tax Board went on trial in absentia before Governor Charles Edison today on charges of dereliction and neglect of duty. After telling the Governor in no uncertain terms why they refused to appear, their counsel also withdrew from the hearing in a small chancery court room in the State House Annex, adjoining the capitol here.

There will be no interruption of work in factories producing war materials as a result of labor's participation in the "New York at War" demonstration on Saturday June 13, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's Committee for Mobilization, New York at War, Inc., at the committee's headquarters, 500 Park Avenue.

LONDON, June 1 -- More than 1,200 miners, out on strike since last Tuesday, returned to work in Durham County today, but for a second time within a month 1,800 employes in the Yorkshire pits walked out.
