A campaign to enlist the support of minority groups for the war was started last night at the first public rally of a new organization, Democracy in Action, at the Heckscher Theatre.

The Navy announced yesterday the sinking of three more ships by Axis submarines, with a total loss of thirty-two lives. A medium-sized United States ship and a small British merchant vessel were sunk in the Atlantic, and a medium-sized Brazilian ship was torpedoed in the Caribbean Sea, south of Haiti.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

THE children in recent literature have been brats. From "February Hill" to "House for the Sparrow," we have had a succession of them, kids with the cunning of animals getting along in spite of aimless; ne'er-do-well parents and homes that come close to being hovels. But the pendulum is swinging back, if Sally Benson's "Meet Me in St. Louis"* is any indication.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 1 -- With the addition of twenty-seven more persons to the growing list of Czech martyrs "implicated in the escape of the two assassins" of Reinhard Heydrich, Deputy Reich Protector of Bohemia-Moravia, today the grand total of those executed now stands at 108 -- with more to come.

Britain's W.A.A.F.'s, the members of the Women's Auxiliary Air Force, did their biggest job on Saturday night, it is reported in a cable received yesterday by the British Press Service, 30 Rockefeller Plaza. They played an important part in the success of the 1,250-plane raid on Cologne.

LONDON, June 1 -- Unless skilled observers have misread the signs, the great striking force that the Royal Air Force demonstrated in its ninety-minute raid with more than 1,000 bombers on Cologne Saturday night, will be doubled this Summer. Except for a few Bostons among the 250 other planes used to disrupt Nazi interceptor stations, not a single aircraft of American manufacture participated in the Cologne attack.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- Saying that there was a prospective critical shortage of doctors, dentists, engineers and other technically trained men, President Roosevelt asked today that Congress appropriate $13,095,000 for Federal loans to needy students in these fields.
Premier Mussolini's son-in-law, Count Ciano, is rapidly becoming one of Italy's richest men.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 1 -- A comparatively small but formidable field of forty-four players teed off in the qualifying round of the forty-second annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today at the Lakeville Club.

MADISON, Wis., June 1 (AP) -- In a military atmosphere, marked by a personal message from General Douglas MacArthur, the University of Wisconsin gave its blessing today to 1,500 members of the 1942 senior class, many of whom will soon be in the armed forces.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 11 -- Westchester County Supervisors balked today at giving a salary to Colonel Frederick L. Devereux as county director of civilian protection, although County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach recommended a $6,000 salary and Colonel Devereux resigned as Mayor of Bronxville a fortnight ago to devote full time to the wartime job.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- While the House devoted most of its session today to consideration of the problem of beating the U-boats, members refused to suspend the House rules to approve the building of a pipe line and a barge canal across Florida.

Unless the government Intervenes, the New York Housewares Manufacturers Association will hold its annual exhibit in Atlantic City during the week of July 12, M.E. Horn, president, announced yesterday. The announcement was made, he said, to clear confusion in the trade as to the practicability of holding the show when there is a shortage of many materials that go into housewares.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 1 -- Parents whose children attend the senior and junior high schools of White Plains voted 891 to 201 against permitting secret societies and fraternities to flourish here, according to a tabulation of ballots tonight by the Board of Education.

A rewarding exhibition of canvases by the celebrated French impressionist Claude Monet opens today at the Paul Rosenberg Gallery, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street, to continue until June 27. Eleven paintings are included, some of them lent -- by the Boston Museum, Harris Whittemore Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Edwin S. Webster and three anonymously.

Expansion of services for men of the A.E.F. now in the British Isles will be considered at a conference of chairmen and field workers from country-wide branches of Bundles for Britain, Inc., opening today at Hotel Pierre and continuing through Thursday.

As the curtailed milk delivery program of more than 100 distributors in the New York metropolitan area, in compliance with the order of the Office of Defense Transportation for a reduction of 25 per cent in mileage to conserve tires, fuel and equipment, went into effect yesterday, the distributors charged in telegrams to the ODT and the War Labor Board, sabotage by the Milk Drivers Union.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Asserting that sales of war bonds are running behind schedule, Senator George, chairman of the Finance Committee, proposed tonight a new plan to stimulate sales by granting corporations and individuals temporary exemption from taxes on that portion of their incomes which they put in a new type of security which would be non-negotiable and non-interest-bearing for the duration of the war.

LONDON, June 1 -- The stock markets continued cheerful today, although business was on a small scale. The outstanding feature was the strength in the Mexican issues. The 6 per cent debenture railway stock rose L2 to L17, but reacted later to L16 on profit-taking.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- In a series of opinions dealing with personal liberties the Supreme Court unanimously invalidated today the Oklahoma law for sterilization of habitual criminals on the ground that it was discriminatory, applying to such offenders as chicken thieves but not embezzlers.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 1 -- Today's graduates face a world which is a wilderness, offering the hardships and the priceless opportunities of pioneering, President Roswell Gray Ham said today at Mount Holyoke College's commencement.

New York City newspapers initiated their wartime schedule of editions and deliveries yesterday. At the same time mercantile, milk and other interests instituted once-daily deliveries. Newspaper publishers asked the indulgence of their readers in the rearrangement of publication time and fused editions and deliveries.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- President Will Harridge of the American League said tonight that three double-headers, all to be played Sunday, Aug. 23, plus a night game in Chicago, had been arranged to bolster the league's drive to raise funds for Army and Navy relief.

A horrifying picture of the plight of the Greek people who are dying of starvation by the tens of thousands as a result of the ruthless policy of the Germans has been revealed to this correspondent by Americans who are returning home after many years of residence in Greece.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 1 -- Five hundred specialists in the treatment of nose, throat and ear disorders met here today at the opening of the forty-eighth annual meeting of the American Laryngological, Rhinological and Otological Society.

The Communist party's financial secretary, Welwel Warszower, or Robert William Wiener as he is better known, will have to go to prison on July 1, unless he changes his attitude and tells the Federal authorities the true story of his faked Atlantic City birth record, Federal Judge John C. Knox decided yesterday.
CANTERBURY, June 1 (U.P.) -- Charred timbers and shattered stained glass littered the entrance to the Kentish War Memorial today and inside near the altar was a plaque bearing the legend:

Governor Lehman and Dr. Frank Aydelotte, president of the Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton University, will be the speakers this evening at the ninety-sixth commencement exercises of City College at Lewisohn Stadium, Amsterdam Avenue and 137th Street.
MOSCOW, June 1 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast the following communique today:
CHUNGKING, China, June 1 (AP) -- The Chinese Command issued this communique today:

Rain yesterday morning forced the main event of the second day of Columbia University's 188th annual commencement activities, Columbia College class day exercises, off the greensward of the Van Amringe quadrangle and into the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway and 116th Street, where 350 seniors and 1,200 visitors heard addresses by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university; Dean Herbert E. Hawkes of Columbia College, Seymour Bthan, class salutatorian, and Herbert A. Deane, class valedictorian.
WITH R.A.F. BOMBER COMMAND, June 1 (AP) -- This is the story of a little Polish pilot hero and his British plane.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- "Don't look for a Cologne-sized raid every night for a while," is a caution against too great expectations by the American public which some military airmen offered as a useful thought here today.

Two brothers battled yesterday in Kings County Court during a hearing to determine which of them should be punished for the hold-up shooting of a police lieutenant. The quarrel ended in a turbulent scene that found freedom promised for the brother facing a thirty-to-sixty-year prison term because the other pleaded guilty.
LONDON, June 1 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique said today:
CAIRO, June 1 (AP) -- The British general headquarters communique said today:

GREENWICH, Conn., June 1 -- Playing in his first tournament since joining the P.G.A., Angelo Mainero of Wee Burn won the weekly pro-amateur best-ball event of the Westchester County Golf Association at Tamarack today with Bill Masilotti of the host club.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 1 -- Sections of the platforms of the extraordinary conference for Zionist affairs and the emergency conference of the American Jewish Congress were attacked today at a meeting here of some sixty non-Zionist reform rabbis.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 1 -- Reporting that reinspection of Belmont Park race track over the week-end indicated a marked improvement in civilian defense protection, Colonel Edward C.O. Thomas, Nassau County director of civilian protection, said today that it would not be necessary to suspend activities at the track.

CANTERBURY, England, June 1 -- About twenty-five German planes swept down last night on this ancient and famous cathedral city in what surely was a reprisal for the Royal Air Force raid on Cologne. But if the Germans fancied that it was an effective reprisal their fancy was ridiculous.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Three flights of heavy United States bombers operating out of India in the past four days carried destructive warfare to the Japanese in Burma, with no loss to the Americans, the War Department announced here tonight.

Private advices from competent neutral observers in Berlin, relayed from Europe to THE NEW YORK TIMES last night, estimated the number killed in the Cologne raid as "in the neighborhood of 20,000." The total population is roughly 800,000.

WITH BRITISH FORCES in Libya, May 31 (Delayed) (AP) -- General Ludwig Cruewell, a commander of the German Africa Corps, who was captured May 26, said tonight that he had been taken prisoner because his pilot had landed in the midst of British desert troops in the mistaken belief that they were Italians.

The Swedish American liner Drottningholm, gaudily painted and marked as a "diplomat ship" entitled to safe passage in the Atlantic, docked in Jersey City yesterday morning with 908 passengers, including the first American diplomatic party to be exchanged since the United States entered the war.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Liquidation of wheat by tired longs carried prices down today to the lowest levels in several months in a session that was marked throughout by lack of any aggressive support. There was some selling on the news that the President had given authority to the Secretary of Agriculture to bring in war supplies from other countries free of duty if the need arises.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., June 1 -- Emory Thomas and George Davidson of Yountakah, with a card of 34, 32 -- 66, tied Maurry O'Connor and Mike Cestone, home club duo, for the honors in the weekly oneday tourney of the New Jersey P.G.A. at Branch Brook today.

Two months and a day after the armistice that ended the last great war, the Supreme Council of the Peace Conference met in Paris for its first session. It seems clear enough now, as we look back through the troubled years, that this meeting came too soon. Two months was not enough time to give either the perspective or the cool judgment that was needed to write the terms of an enduring peace.

As Joseph Alsop and Robert Kintner prepared in 1940 the "American White Paper," the story of diplomacy in the second World War, Forrest Davis and Ernest K. Lindley are working up for Simon Schuster a book to be called "How War Came: American White Paper -- From Sedan to Pearl Harbor."

In the arrest yesterday of eleven men on charges of grand larceny in the first degree, conspiracy, criminally receiving stolen goods and with bringing stolen goods into the State the police say they have cleaned up the wholesale thefts of gasoline and fuel oil at the Staten Island plant of the Socony Vacuum Company, Inc., at Port Socony.

PITTSBURGH, June 1 -- Four strikes, three of them involving carpenters affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, crippled construction work today on two major armament plants and two large housing projects for defense workers.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Senator Van Nuys, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, made known today that "considerable opposition" had developed to the confirmation of Thomas F. Meaney, a member of the Hague organization, as a Federal district judge in New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A major transportation bottleneck appeared broken today with the announcement by Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, that all forty-eight States had agreed to uniform standards and reciprocal license arrangements for interstate motor transport for the duration of the war.

Applicants for supplemental allotments of sugar for home canning who have appeared at public schools where they originally registered, and applicants who have recently changed addresses and who seek certificates from the local rationing board in the district in which they originally registered, were advised yesterday to apply to the local rationing board nearest their homes.

A corporation has been formed to handle the many affairs of "This Is The Army," Irving Berlin's revised revival of "Yip, Yip, Yaphank." One problem is the matter of copyright. To all intents and purposes the Army is producing the show, but the United States Government, it was said, cannot grant itself a copyright.

A patrolman, who is a Phi Beta Kappa member; a Sing Sing Prison guard, who attended evening schools for the last sixteen years in quest of secondary and collegiate degrees, and a 34-year-old pharmacist and his wife will be among the 2,341 men and women to receive degrees this evening at the ninety-sixth commencement exercises of City College in Lewisohn Stadium, Amsterdam Avenue and 137th Street.

LONDON, June 1 -- There are two things that British women will want at the end of the war. One is to get away from the sort of communal living in hotels and camps that the war has forced upon millions doing war work in factories or in the services and return to home life.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Unless 156 striking weavers at New Bedford, Mass., decide to return to work tomorrow, President Roosevelt may be asked by the National War Labor Board to act for the first time to blacklist recalcitrant employes from further employment in war industries for a specified time, it was reported here today.

All windows and skylights in a wide area along the seaboard must be shaded or screened to prevent escape through them of direct rays of light, according to new and more stringent dimout regulations announced last night by the Army. As an alternative, the interior lights of the rooms concerned might be shaded individually to prevent rays from shining through the windows, it was said.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 1 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. George H. Brett, Commander of United Nations' Air Forces in the Southwest Pacific, today announced awards of Silver Crosses to eleven American airmen for action at Java and Bali during the Netherlands Indies campaign.

The highly organized delivery services of milk companies, department stores, laundries, newspapers, bakeries and dozens of other services all suffered drastic wartime curtailment yesterday under the new order of the Office of Defense Transportation diminishing delivery mileage by 25 per cent.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 1 -- Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's battered Axis tank army sought today to fight its way back westward through two gaps in the British mine fields between El Gazala and Bir Hacheim, and his tank commander, General Ludwig Cruewell, was a prisoner in British hands, front reports said tonight.

BOSTON, June 1 (AP) -- The Valdina Farm's Hollywood, making his first start since his disappointing effort in the Kentucky Derby, scored a length and a half victory in the Amesbury, $1,500 mile-and-seventy-yard feature today at Suffolk Downs.

The New York Life Insurance Company has agreed that the Missouri Pacific Railroad may substitute equipment other than was prescribed in the original indenture to secure $4,185,000 of series GG 2 1/4 per cent equipment trust certificates, it was disclosed yesterday.

Belmont Park started the final week of its Spring race meeting yesterday with the sport marred by a serious accident in the steeplechase. Tom Roby, one of the best riders through the field, came a bad cropper with Bayard Sharp's Knight's Quest and was removed in a critical condition to Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, where specialists were called to treat him.

Small, simple wedding parties -- of the kind that are pretty and gay and completely attuned to the times -- are planned, then superbly executed, by a woman with modest manners and a winsome smile. This engaging person, who once attended Paris's most celebrated culinary school, the Cordon Bleu, confesses with captivating candor that she has a special talent for arranging a perfect party.

The Proofroom Front A particular type of innocent fifth columnist or sixth columnist specializes in the dissemination of alarmist news. We refer to the typographical error. It is bound to occur in the best-edited newspaper.

Patrolman Frank Madden, facing a departmental charge of having given false information to a grand jury as a result of disclosures by John Harlan Amen in his investigation of corruption in the Police Department in Kings County, went on trial yesterday at Brooklyn Police Headquarters before Michael A. Lyons, Third Deputy Police Commissioner.
The new regulations issued by Major Gen. T.A. Terry to become effective immediately for the duration of the war or until rescinded or amended, follow:

Columbia University will end a three-day celebration of its 188th annual commencement this afternoon at 5 o'clock, with the conferring' of 4,715 degrees, fourteen honorary degrees, eight University Medals for Excellence and ninety-six diplomas and certificates.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 1 -- The rebellious mood in which Congress received the government order forbidding newspapers to print accounts of speeches delivered in Congress on international questions became vocal today when Deputy Emir E. Mercader of the Radical party opposition announced a petition to address seven questions to the Minister of Internal Affairs.

The basic idea of lease-lend is that the United States, as the Arsenal of Democracy as well as a fighting partner, shall provide its Allies with immense quanties of war materials. But the process is by no means a one-way affair, as Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Lease-Lend Administrator, has reminded us.

"In This Our Life," the current attraction at the Strand, will be held for an additional two weeks, beginning Friday, it was announced yesterday. The film thereby will equal the six-week run mark set in the Summer of 1939 by "The Old Maid," also a Bette Davis vehicle.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, June 2 (AP) -- The Russians' midnight communique:

CARMEL, N.Y., June 1 -- One of the favorite extra-curricular activities of those who fish Lake Gleneida here is to hazard a guess concerning the size of the rainbow trout that may be lurking in its waters.

Sharp criticism of the government for its methods of disseminating news about the war is contained in a report on war morale to be submitted to the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at its monthly meeting to be held on Thursday.

A SENSATION was caused in weight-lifting circles last August when there was presented for probate in Brooklyn the last will and testament of the late Warren Lincoln Travis, professional strong man in his younger days.

Stockholders of the Aluminum Company of America approved yesterday at a special meeting in Pittsburgh an increase of $150,000,000 in the company's authorized indebtedness. Actual creation of additional debt will come from time to time by action of the board of directors.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Income payments to individuals in the United States in April totaled $8,784,000,000, which was almost 25 per cent more than a year ago and amounted to the record annual rate of $109,000,000,000, compared with the annual peaks of $92,100,000,000 in 1941 and $83,600,000,000 in 1929.

WITH BRITISH FORCES, in Libya, June 1 -- The other night as I was lying in my dugout, which is exactly the shape of a tomb but not so deep, and looking up at the bright blue sky glittering with stars and lit by the huge desert moon, which converts the darkness of night into an uncanny semblance of daylight, I was doing some thinking about the battle that is now raging.
CHICAGO, June 1 -- Manager Mel Ott said tonight he would send Hal Schumacher to the mound tomorrow when the Giants open a three-game series with the Cubs. The Bruins are expected to start Bill Lee.
loft building's continued to hole the spotlight in Manhattan trading as the new month opened. A large apartment house on Riverside Drive also was listed in new ownership.

Four of the young people could speak Portuguese. Another could speak both French and Portuguese, but no one could speak English. There was silence in the Travelers Aid Society headquarters, 144 East Forty-fourth Street. The five young men and women, just off the Drottningholm, smiled at each other.

DOVER, N.J., June 1 -- A new "arming fixture" that makes for greater efficiency in machines turning out vane-type bomb fuses at Picatinny Arsenal has been invented by a woman employe, officials at the arsenal announced today.

A week ago Saturday, A.A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, was the scheduled main speaker at the Statewide meeting of the Affiliated Young Democrats in Schenectady, out "missed train connections" and was unable to attend and deliver his speech, which had been expected to open the New Deal attack against Thomas E. Dewey, probable Republican nominee for Governor.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- As a step toward the substitution of allocations for the present priority system of distributing materials to industry, the War Production Board today announced a uniform classification system which will enable the board to trace the flow of materials in terms of their final use and final users.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Columbia Broadcasting System and National Broadcasting Company were entitled to a legal review of 1941 regulations by the Federal Communications aimed at curbing chain broadcasting.
Former out-of-town and suburban residents were reported yesterday by the Live in Manhattan Committee to have taken a number of apartments in Manhattan buildings.
With, no moon to aid the mock raiders and rain helping to keep people at home in many sections, New Jersey staged from 10:10 to 10:40 last night the first State-wide surprise blackout in the East.
CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) -- Buyers wanted heavy "lard hogs" and sows on the livestock market today, advancing these offerings 10 to 15 cents 100 pounds in fairly active trade. Lighter hogs held steady.

"Spring Again" will suspend its engagement at the Playhouse this Saturday night, when it will have completed its 240th New York performance. Grace George and C. Aubrey Smith need a vacation. The play will resume at the same stand on Labor Day for a three-week engagement.

The new Tammany Hall leadership of Representative Michael J. Kennedy faced its first serious primary fight last night when it was learned that Dennis J. Mahon and Assemblyman Patrick H. Sullivan, Democratic leaders of the Ninth and Eleventh Assembly Districts, would contest the candidacy of State Senator John L. Buckley for re-election in the Fifteenth Senatorial District.
LONDON, June 1 -- The Admiralty announced today that the 8,000ton cruiser Trinidad of the new Fiji class, launched in the year that war broke out, has been sunk.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1 -- A screen biography of Helen Morgan, late Broadway torch singer, will be produced by Warner Brothers if current negotiations with Mrs. Lulu Morgan, mother of the singer, are concluded, it was learned today.

Competitive Bidding Competitive bidding "came into its own" in a big way yesterday at the sale of $15,000,000 of Public Service Electric and Gas Company 3 per cent first mortgage bonds, due in 1972. In the first place, the offering was a "natural" for a competitive sale, both in respect to size and rating -- its medium size and top credit rating making the bidding virtually a "money market" proposition.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter K. Byers Sr. of 53 West Eleventh Street, in Greenwich Village, refuse to believe that their sailor son, Walter Jr., reported by the Navy Department as missing, is dead. Mrs. Byers, while quite disturbed at the news, said she feels strongly that her boy is a prisoner of the Japanese.

J. Reid Spencer is 70 years old. He came to Flatbush Court in Brooklyn yesterday to get a summons against the Brooklyn Dodgers' Victory Calliope. Mr. Spencer told Magistrate Thomas H. Cullen Jr. the music played in the Dodgers' ball park breaks in on his afternoon nap.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 1 -- Degrees were conferred this afternoon on 140 seniors of the College of New Rochelle at commencement exercises originally scheduled for the campus but transferred to the sports building because of rain.

CHUNGKING, China, June 2 (UP) -- Japan's offensive in the East China Province of Chekiang has rolled forty-three miles west of fallen Kinhwa to the outskirts of Chuhsien, the site of a large airfield that might be used for Allied bombing raids on the Japanese homeland, an Army communique disclosed today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 -- The Securities and Exchange Commis- sion issued today an order reconvening its proceedings against the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, this time under Section 11 (B) 1 of the holding company act, or the integration phase of the "death sentence" clause.

NEWARK, N.J., June 2 -- Whitney Bowles, 23 years old, of Newfoundland, N.J., a direct descendant of Samuel Bowles, founder of The Springfield Republican newspaper and one of New England's most famous editors, was found guilty by a jury in Federal court here tonight on a charge of violating the Selective Service Act by "willfully refusing to report to his draft board for induction into the Army."

Night Life Shines Night life in New York has lost its second most important feature, and one of the oldest. This is not the spectacular signs on Broadway, or the illuminations at Coney Island, or the sounds and movements in the night club zone.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Representative Vinson, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee, said today that ninety-nine warships and "a large number of converted aircraft carriers" would be commissioned by the end of this year.

DETROIT, June 2 -- Officials at the Dodge Truck Division of the Chrysler Corporation shut down the plant today and sent 3,000 war workers home after 350 employes had protested the employment of Negroes on war jobs at the plant. They were ordered to report back for work for their regular shift on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Harold G. Hoffman, former Governor of New Jersey, has been commissioned a major in the Army and ordered to report on June 15 at Lowry Field, Col., the War Department announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Mexico's declaration of war was widely acclaimed here today.

Irate residents of the neighborhood around Flushing Meadow Park in Queens and members of the Flushing Ridge Civic Association have threatened the Park Department with demolition of the Japanese Pavilion "piece by piece" if the Park Department fails to remove it, it was learned yesterday.

Declaring that their "very existence is dependent upon the maintenance of free competition" in the marketing of motion pictures, the Society of Independent Motion Picture Producers have petitioned the Department of Justice not to consider any substitute sales plan for the consent decree which would include "objectionable features of the present five-picture group plan" or countenance the revival of "licensing feature films in advance of their completion."

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, June 3 -- Albert Clement, managing editor of Jacques Doriot's newspaper, Le Cri du Peuple of Paris, was killed by three revolver bullets as he was leaving his office on the Rue Vivienne at ten minutes to 8 o'clock last evening.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) -- Bob Harris, reporting to the Athletics for the first time, was thrown immediately into action tonight against the Tigers, but was lifted for a pinch hitter in the sixth inning as the Tigers won the night game, 3 -- 0, with Virgil Trucks on the mound.

LIKE the Equator, the line between sentiment and sentimentality is invisible and more or less imaginary, but unlike the geographical abstraction, it has no precise latitude ascertainable by scientific calculation. It shifts with the fluctuating spirit of the times, it is somewhat dependent on the individual and always one man's moving sentiment is another's maudlin sentimentality.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (U.P.) -- The War Department today announced the names of seventy-five additional soldiers who were killed in action or died of wounds in the Philippines. It was the final list of American soldiers reported killed in the islands and brings the total to 513.

Because of the dimout regulations, there will be blue illumination for the coming concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium. The concerts will start at 8 P.M. instead of 8:30 to allow the audience to start home earlier through the partially darkened city and to permit the holding of the greater part of the concerts in daylight.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The United States and its allies have as one objective the liberation of the Italian people from Mussolini and his fascist group, Dean Acheson, Assistant Secretary of State, declared tonight as Count Sforza, former Italian Foreign Minister, said that there are 45,000,000 Italians, virtually the whole population, who comprise a potential "underground movement" in the kingdom.

Members of the City Council voted unanimously yesterday for a resolution asking Mayor La Guardia to rescind his six-day-week order for city employes who can prove that they are spending part of their time on war work.
ROME, June 2 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

An organized appeal will be made by time-pay retailers soon to obtain relief from a situation under which most of them expect to have to pay excess-profits taxes this year on the basis of accelerated collections required by Regulation W, store officials said yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, June 2 (AP) -- Patrick Horgan, FBI agent, read in Federal Court today a document described as a confession by Dr. Hans Helmut Gros that he came to this country from Germany in 1939 with instructions to obtain pictures of harbors and plane factories, incite strikes and organize sabotage.

"By Jupiter," the first musical comedy of the new season, opens at 8:40 tonight at the Shubert Theatre under the joint sponsorship of Dwight Deere Wiman, Richard Rodgers and Richard Kollmar. Based on the three-act comedy, "The Warrior's Husband," by Julian F. Thompson, which was produced on Broadway in 1932, the musical version comes from the pens of Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart.

New York City Omnibus John E. McCarthy, president of the New York City Omnibus Corporation, said at the annual meet- ing here yesterday that revenues last month ran about 10 per cent ahead of May, 1941, and indicated that the gain might be further emphasized as a result of gasoline rationing and other restrictions on the use of private automobiles.
June, the month that ushers in the crucial Summer of the war, has started propitiously for the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A strong attack on the Congress of Industrial Organizations was made today by the Policy Committee of the United Mine Workers of America in a report which set forth the conditions under which the miners would pay their per capita taxes to the C.I.O.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 -- The idea that a reduction of the hours of labor would lead to a greater production of cultural assets for this nation was assailed today by the Rev. Dr. Rex S. Clements, president of the Board of Christian Education of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, who was the principal speaker at the last joint commencement to be held during the war at the University of Pennsylvania.

The latest figures on national income payments of the Department of Commerce throw further light upon the character of our record-breaking rise in national income. In the first four months of this year the total of income payments amounted to $33,888,000,000, of which about 70 per cent consisted of salaries and wages.

Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia reached an agreement yesterday on the need for prompt measures by the Federal Government to make use of labor and plant facilities available here to increase war production and avert a threatened decline in employment because of priorities and other emergency restrictions on civilian production.

"Parents must put no obstacles in the way of daughters who wish to serve their country. They must be willing to send their daughters as well as their sons wherever their country needs them," it was said by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve yesterday at the class day exercises of Barnard College.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Going far beyond the rubber-saving devices disclosed previously in answering Congressional charges that the Army has been careless and wasteful in its use of this vital and rationed commodity, the War Department is studying conservation and substitution measures long "laughed off" by motorists used to speed and comfort.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The question whether Attorney General Biddle or Donald Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, should have the last word on exemption of war industries from prosecution under the anti- trust laws headed tonight for the Senate floor.

A dinner to Dr. Alvin S. Johnson, president of the New School for Social Research, was held last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the League for Fair Play, of which he also is president.

VICHY, France, June 2 -- Summoning of the State Tribunal to try the authors and instigators of the recent riot in a Paris food store was ordered by the Council of Ministers held here on the return of Pierre Laval, chief of government, today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Certain experts here, who have been carefully checking the course of the Axis submarine campaign in the Atlantic, said today that the time is near at hand when Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, will bring up for decision whether he will order a change from the convoy to the patrol system in protecting coastal shipping.

Buyer Registrations Off Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yester- day numbered 336, which compared with 498 in the preceding week and 508 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The ability of the British to raid Essen with more than a thousand planes only two nights after they had launched the greatest air offensive of the war over Cologne is much more portentous for the Germans than the first performance. It shows that Mr. Churchill was uttering no idle threat when he promised that the attack would continue, city by city, on a scale "never experienced by any country in continuity, severity or magnitude."

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt had an opportunity to enjoy some art yesterday. Only a few persons were in an exhibition room at the Gotham branch of the Grand Central Art Galleries, 4 West Fiftyfifth Street, when she walked in to view the "Parade of Patriots."

CINCINNATI, June 2 (AP) -- Young Elmer Riddle and Veteran Si Johnson hurled shut-out ball at each other for nine innings today, but the cellar-dwelling Phils took advantage of a Cincinnati error in the tenth to win, 1 to 0.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 -- The Harry Bridges deportation case finally went to the courts today. The president of the C.I.O. International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union accepted service of a warrant based on Attorney General Biddle's deportation order, and his associates prepared to appeal to the 5,000,000 members of the C.I.O. for moral and financial support in a legal battle to permit him to remain in this country.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 2 -- Prime Minister John Curtin, opening Australia's second uA35,000,000 Liberty War Loan at Melbourne Town Hall, said Japan's program of constant expansion "has at last suffered a stalemate." At the same time Navy Minister Norman J.O. Makin revealed in Canberra that one of three enemy midget submarines was destroyed before it got into Sydney Harbor Sunday and a second before it could fire its torpedoes.

Through the "trial and error" process of having their export license applications rejected because prices are out of line, foreign traders may come to an under- standing of the "average premium" acceptable to the Office of Price Administration, Mrs. Edith Hertz of the agency's staff here declared yesterday at a meeting of the Ex- port Managers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

BERLIN, June 2 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York and London) -- "Strong forces" of British bombers wounded a number of civilians in raiding residential areas at Duisburg, Oberhausen and elsewhere in West Germany last night, competent quarters asserted today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Argentine private interests with Axis outlets are bidding higher than the United States for Ecuadoran supplies of raw rubber, and as a result Equadoran warehouses are filled with rubber that cannot yet be shipped, authoritative sources in Washington disclosed today.

Another action to reopen the Flynn paving case, or at least one phase of it, was started yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court when two attorneys representing the City Club of New York submitted papers to Justice Philip J. McCook which, it is believed, relate to the "misuse" of city materials and labor on the Lake Mahopac estate of Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

BOSTON, June 2 -- After taking four setbacks, the Indians defeated the Red Sox today for the first time this season, and they did it most decisively, for they banged out 14 hits, including two home runs, for a 7-2 triumph.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Payment of overtime to 2,000,000 white-collar and other war workers on the government payroll at the rate of time and one-half after forty hours a week became a firstrank Congressional issue today amid warnings from the Civil Service Commission that a "serious" management problem had developed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: According to an Associated Press dispatch dated May 29, Representative Carl Vinson, chairman of the House Naval Investigating Committee, asked a manufacturer who had paid large fees to a Washington contact man for securing war contracts: "Do you think it was necessary to go to these parasites, who neither toil nor spin, in order to do business with your own government?"

Pointing out that the recent changes by the Office of Defense Transportation in certain of its truck and tire orders, postponing their effective date from June 1 to July 1, 1942, are "merely tem- porary," the National American Wholesale Grocers Association, in a special bulletin to its members yesterday, urged wholesale grocers to prepare immediately a further statement of their transportation needs for presentation to the ODT authorities.

Even Alice, she of the looking-glass, would have been agog yes- terday had she stepped within the portals of the 460 Park Avenue Gallery. There was a Mad Hatter and a tea party in progress to nake her feel at home.

The partnership-to-be of Rubin Rubin, attorneys at law, will be graduated next Wednesday from the New York University School of Law as Mr. and Mrs. Irving Rubin, both 24, of 2899 Kingsbridge Terrace, Bronx.
LONDON, June 2 -- The text of Prime Minister Churchill's statement in the House of Commons today follows:

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Six hundred miscellaneous enemy-owned patents, about 100 of which are owned by the Junkers aircraft company of Germany, and most of which are of great immediate importance to the war effort in the fields of aviation and science, were taken over today from their German and Italian owners by Leo T. Crowley, Alien Property Custodian.

China will never be knocked out of this war, Owen Lattimore, political adviser to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, told 300 United China Relief committee workers last night at a dinner meeting in the Rainbow Room, Radio City. The present war began in Manchuria ten years ago and the Chinese will be in at the finish, he said.

The bombing of Essen with more than a thousand planes is an even more impressive demonstration of British air strength than the bombing of Cologne. It is more impressive because it is cumulative. Coming only two nights after the punishment of Cologne, and followed by huge daylight raids, it demonstrates that the British have the power to sustain this terrific bombardment.

Messages of gratitude for American relief work and of confidence in the ultimate victory of the Allied Nations were brought from France by Miss Eva Dahlgren, field representative for the American Friends of France, who returned to the United States Monday aboard the Drottningholm.

PITTSBURGH, June 2 -- Flouting left and right-handed pitchers alike, the Dodgers today inflicted upon Frank Frisch's hapless Pirates their tenth straight defeat by the National League season's high score of 17 to 2.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Oliver Lyttelton, British Minister of Production, and about twelve other British production experts arrived late today for conversations with Harry L. Hapkins and Donald M. Nelson at which plans will be made for a joint Anglo-American victory production program, it was stated.

After a trial that lasted more than five weeks a jury in United States District Court, Brooklyn, returned a verdict of guilty early yesterday morning against nine inspectors of the Federal Alcohol Tax Unit charged with conspiracy to defraud the government out of more than $5,000,000 in internal revenue taxes.

The destruction of three more ships of the United Nations by enemy submarines operating on the western side of the Atlantic was announced yesterday by the Navy. Nine lives were lost in these sinkings, while the arrival at a Gulf port of survivors of a ship previously acknowledged lost brought the revelation that thirty-nine men went down with that vessel.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, in Libya, June 2 -- American medium tanks -- General Grants and General Lees -- are the pride of the British Eighth Army and a nightmare for the Nazis. The British swear by them and the Nazis swear at them.

A decision of far-reaching impor- tance with respect to the ownership and operation of mining properties in the Republic or Colombia has just been handed down by the Colombia Supreme Court, it was disclosed yesterday. Establishing the rights of private property, including American capital, the court overruled the Colombian Government in its seizure of properties located along the Telembi River and its tributaries which for years had been owned and operated under private management.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 2 -- Nearly sixty rabbis, representing a minority group of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, adjourned today their two-day conference, designed to formulate a statement of principles, without reaching complete accord.

Advertising linage in eight New York newspapers declined 9.5 per cent last month from the like 1941 month, despite the fact that there were five Sundays in the month, as against four in May of last year, according to a compilation based on Media Records figures.

LONDON, June 2 -- After successfully fighting off persistent attacks by a swarm of more than 100 German dive-bombers and torpedo aircraft for five days and facing a constant threat from U-boats in ice-strewn Arctic waters, a large convoy carrying supplies to Russia has reached its destination, the Admiralty announced today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Several weeks ago I received a letter from some business friends in England telling me that they wished to safeguard certain business documents against total destruction by bombing. They informed me of their intention to have photostat copies made of these documents and asked me if I would accept the copies for safekeeping for the duration of the war.

Needy American citizens from Axis prison camps who arrived on the Drottningholm, received prompt aid yesterday from the Federal Social Security Board, the city Department of Welfare, the New York Chapter of the Red Cross and the Travelers Aid, all acting together through a special office at 906 Broadway.

There is no sense in talking peace until the war is won, but the United States must be ready to take the lead in establishing a plan of international cooperation for world prosperity and peace as soon as the war is over, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday in an address at the 188th commencement exercises of that institution.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 2 -- No express trains have arrived in Berlin from Cologne since the night of the British Royal Air Force raid, according to reports from usually reliable German sources. Slower trains and freight trains have arrived from the Cologne district, but up to this evening they had brought no newspapers, from which it may appear that they have stopped publishing.

Need for an additional 1,800 women volunteers to aid Department of Health, doctors and nurses in carrying on health work in New York's public and parochial schools was stressed yesterday in a meeting of a group of women held under the auspices of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office in the assembly room of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service Building, 262 Madison Avenue.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Reports have come to us from China that Japanese are using poisonous gas in attacks on Chinese forces in Kinhwa, capital of Chekiang Province. Poisonous gases, however, have been in constant use by Japanese in many other places in the last four years.
An informal campaign is being considered in New Jersey by which tackle stores would serve as clearing houses for sportsmen who wish to go on occasional fishing trips.

It is said to be a truism on beauty that the age of a woman's face varies directly with the condition of her feet. The relation between an aching metatarsal and those facial traceries known as "fatigue lines" is a direct and disastrous one -- to say nothing of its bearing on one's disposition.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 3 -- Forty-eight hours after the British made their tremendous raid on Cologne they sent another thousand bombers over the Ruhr Monday night, during which Essen was the principal target, the Royal Air Force revealed yesterday.

Reporting many cases of war workers "sleeping eight or ten in a room," using the same beds in eight-hour shifts, or spending their nights in doorways or alleys, the National Committee on the Housing Emergency made public yesterday a list of recommendations to meet the "critical" housing situation in industrial centers.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 2 -- A British counter-assault has shattered Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's main offensive in Libya, but German mechanized forces are making a strong stand on the dust-clouded battlefield twenty-eight miles southwest of Tobruk, front dispatches said tonight.

The decline in the demand for paper and paperboard is beginning to reach serious proportions, with all paper mills now down to 92 per cent of capacity and the paperboard mills to 77 per cent, manufacturers and merchants reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 -- The American Friends Service Committee heard leaders of its relief activities in unoccupied France report today that unless new sources of supply could be found the feeding and other programs probably would have to be abandoned by the end of this year.

Acting: upon the request of the War Labor Board in Washington, the milk distributors of the New York metropolitan area yesterday postponed indefinitely their plan for every-other-day deliveries to home consumers, pending adjustment of the dispute between the distributors and the Milk Drivers Union over the effects which the union feared the plan would have upon employment.

Warnings against any lessening of supervision over food and drugs and the importance of maintaining their purity to promote health and endurance in wartime were impressed upon enforcement officials yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and other speakers at the annual conference of the Association of Food and Drug Officials of the United States in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to recognize existence of a state of war with Rumania, Bulgaria and Hungary. Swift and unanimous approval in the House of Representatives tomorrow and in the Senate Thursday was predicted.

LONDON, June 2 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, beaming as he does when he has good news to impart, strode into the House of Commons this morning, unheralded and unexpected, to report on the course of the war.

An important step in the refi- nancing and recapitalization program of the Virginia Public Service Company, a unit in the Associated Gas and Electric System, was completed yesterday with the sale of $36,500,000 of securities of the utility at competitive bidding.

A young American soldier walked into a USO service club and made a request. He didn't especially want a cup of coffee, a game of chess or a book. He didn't particularly wish to sit down in an easy chair and listen to the radio. He wasn't in the mood for a dance, a floor show or a motion picture.
R.S. McLaughlin's Fairaris and Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's Invader were the stake winners at Belmont Park yesterday, where 11,903 persons bet $896,163.

If some one had predicted two years ago that the three small states of Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania would ever take the initiative in declaring war upon the United States the prediction would have seemed incredible. These little nations had no quarrel with us.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 2 -- A simple ceremony in the presence of a small assemblage of friends and relatives today marked the funeral of John Barrymore, who died here last Friday at the age of 60. Of his four wives, only one -- Elaine Barrie-was present when the Rev.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 2 -- The government denied today that it had intended to forbid the press to publish accounts of Congressional debates on foreign affairs.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, was honored yesterday for his "40-60-80" anniversary at the annual luncheon of the University Alumni Federation in John Jay Hall on the campus. Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding the Eastern Defense Command and First Army, was the principal speaker.
LONDON, June 2 (AP) -- A communique of the Ministries of Air and Home Security said today:

MOSCOW, June 2 -- Although Soviet reports from the Kalinin sector emphasize that the engagements there are of local significance, the dispositions of the opposing forces are so complicated, with salient and counter-salient entangled, that any move there is worthy of close attention.
BERLIN, June 2 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Wheat prices developed a decidedly weak tone in the late trade today, further stop loss selling being a factor. In the early trade there was some mill buying. Traders took a little more optimistic view of Washing- ton reports in regard to possible duty-free imports for war pur- poses.

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Philip Green Gossler, who have arrived from their home in Montgomery, Ala., and Mrs. Gossler's daughter, Miss Marion Saffold Oates, who has come from Washington, are at the Gotham.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, June 2 -- Brazil will not remain passively contemplating the destruction of her shipping by Axis submarines, but will fight back with all her strength, Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Foreign Minister, declared today.

Reacting to President Roosevelt's request for a declaration of war on Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania, commission houses accelerated their liquidation in yesterday's cotton market, tumbling prices to losses of 33 to 41 points, or $1.65 to $2.05 a bale, the lowest levels in more than three months.

The apartment house for twenty-one families with four stores at 239-47 West First Street, Mount Vernon, Westchester County, has been sold by the trustees of Series 6, Lawyers Westchester Mortgage and Title Company, to George Wessell.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (U.P.) -- The Army has all the weapons it can send abroad under present shipping conditions and enough to arm every soldier in the United States, Robert P. Patterson declared today.

The importance of winning the peace as well as the war was emphasized last night by both Governor Lehman and Dr. Frank Aydelotte, president of the Institute, for Advanced Study, Princeton, in addresses at the ninety-sixth commencement exercises of City College, at the Lewisohn Stadium.

Charles Kilpatrick Cook, stock broker and member of the Board of Governors of the Stock Exchange, was found dead last night in his apartment at 655 Park Avenue, of a bullet wound in the heart. The police listed his death as an apparent suicide.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, in Libya, June 2 (AP) -- Under a blazing sun that sent the temperature above 100 degrees, British tankmen fought a furious battle with Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's battered forces yesterday over a ten-mile expanse of desert.

Reserve Act Changes Private advices from the nation's capital received yesterday in banking circles here indicated that proposed legislation is under consideration which would broaden and clarify the Federal Reserve Act. One proposed change would permit the Federal Reserve Board to reclassify member banks of New York City and Chicago for purposes of reserve requirements, instead of including these two money centers with all other reserve cities as at present.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A decision on nationwide rationing of gasoline may be announced within the next seven days, Donald Nelson, War Production chief, said today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The War Production Board announced tonight that it would take control of imports of commodities for civilian use as well as strategic war materials. The order, which is interpreted as one result of sub- marine warfare on the Atlantic Coast, will take effect on July 2.
CHUNGKING, June 2 (AP) -- The Chinese communique said today:

Corporal Jim Turnesa, the soldier-golfer who was the sensation of last week's P.G.A. champion- ship before he finally lost to Sailor-to-Be Sam Snead in the final, was added yesterday to the list of entries for the Hale America open golf tournament.

Beginning with the State-Federal Conference, called by Mr. Roosevelt in the first week of May, a series of negotiations between State and Federal authorities has brought the acceptance by all the Governors of uniform standards and reciprocal licenses as long as the war lasts for interstate motor trucks carrying war materials.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 2 -- Thomas J. Dowling, former circulation director of the Scripps-Howard newspapers, died today in the Mount Vernon Hospital after a four-year illness. He entered the hospital after suffering a heart attack yesterday.

FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, Md., June 2 -- As the curtain rang down tonight on the first Army camp performance of the Maurice Evans-Judith Anderson production of "Macbeth," an ovation came from the 900 soldiers present which Mr. Evans said rivaled anything he had heard on Broadway or the road.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Youthful Early Wynn checked the surging Browns tonight, limiting them to five hits at the Senators pounded Denny Galehouse and Loy Banning for eleven hits and a 4-to-1 victory. George McQuinn blasted a home run over the rightfield fence in the seventh for the St. Louis run.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The House Committee on Rules released today, for scheduled adoption tomorrow, legislation providing financial aid to dependents of enlisted men of the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard.

The twelve-story apartment building at 41 Central Park West, at the northwest corner of Sixty-fourth Street, has been sold by the Bank for Savings to the East Twelfth Street Realty Corporation subject to a ten-year mortgage of $365,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 -- Contrary to previously announced plans, which have been revised on the basis of "the present military situation," persons of Japanese ancestry are to be evacuated from the 60,000 square miles of California lying outside the present evacuation zones which make up Military Area No. 1.
The following is the first of a series of articles by a correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES who was captured in Libya six months ago and has just returned to this country.

Four meet records were broken and two were tied at the Boys High interscholastic track and field games, held on the school's field in Brooklyn yesterday. Bishop Loughlin Memorial High, city C.H.S.A.A. outdoor and national interscholastic indoor high school champion, scored 27 points to take the open team honors for the third year in a row.

In a battle as fluid and as furious as that of the clashing tanks in Libya it would be foolhardy to predict the outcome. It is only possible to tell what has happened thus far. This Premier Churchill did very clearly in his report to the House of Commons yesterday on the first week of operations.

For the third successive week, the general death rate in New York City has established a new low mark for 1942, it was reported yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of records in the Department of Health. The rate for the week ended last Saturday was 9 per 1,000 population, a full point below the "expected" figure.

WASHINGTON, June 2-President Manuel Quezon of the Philippines, addressing the House of Representatives, expressed confidence today that Congress would honor President Roosevelt's pledge to redeem the freedom and establish and protect the independence of the Philippines after the war.

LONDON, June 2 -- The stock markets were cheered today by the air attack on Cologne and Prime Minister Winston Churchill's re- view of the situation in Libya. A good feature was the Anglo-Iranian oil shares, and other oils moved up in sympathy.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., June 2 -- Dr. Marion Edwards Park, retiring as president of Bryn Mawr College, was signally honored by that institution at commencement today when she received the M. Carey Thomas Prize of $5,000 for her contributions to the field of education.

Federal officials here and in Washington declared yesterday that all government departments would continue to guard against the admission to this country of spurious refugees or refugee groups that might act as a cover for the infiltration of enemy agents.

Since last Fall new soldiers in the United States Army have been receiving an orientation course that has had four principal features: a series of military talks reviewing the course of the war from its beginnings; daily portrayals of current developments delivered by company officers to their commands; lectures on correlated subjects by civilian experts and the distribution of maps and literature to places of camp assembly.

The sixteen-room house with a three-car garage on two and one-half acres of land, once owned by the former Mrs. James J. Walk- er (Betty Compton), in Cornwell Beach Road, Sands Point, L.I., has been sold to Eugene Richard, who has occupied the property for the past year.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The national capital experienced its first daylight air raid practice today.

LONDON, June 2 -- In the course of a discussion in the House of Lords today Viscount Cranborne, Secretary of State for the Colonies, announced that the government had opened conferences among the United Nations on the subject of post-war problems.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Master Melvin Ott did not surpass Rogers Hornsby's lifetime National League record for runs batted in today, but he did unfurl three hits. His Giants contributed ten more and the result of all this blasting was to make life miserable for Jimmy Wilson as his Cubs went down to defeat in the opener of a three-game series, 5 to 1.

Formal offering to the public of a new issue of $15,000,000 of Public Service Electric and Gas Company first and refunding mortgage 3 per cent bonds, due May 1, 1972, will be made today by an underwriting group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to compel the recipient of alimony to pay a tax and by this action permitted the payer to deduct the amount in figuring his income tax.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., June 2 -- With only three dissenting voices, the several hundred stockholders of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey at their meeting held here today adopted a resolution ex- pressing complete confidence in the management of the company, which has been under attack for several months by United States Government officials for its rela- tions before the war with the I.G. Farbenindustrie, the German chemical organisation.

No international system of the kind described the other day by Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles can have a real chance to stand the test if it is not supported by the three great nations in the fight against the Axis. Such is the idea that weighed with the British Government and induced it to exchange views with Russia.

MOSCOW, June 2 -- The Memorial Day speech of Stunner Welles, United States Under-Secretary of State, had a favorable reception here and was prominently displayed in all the newspapers. The press gave emphasis to the passage about the United Nations organization of post-war security.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, June 2 (AP) -- Private William E. Brown, 25, of Blackfoot, Idaho, was commended today by his flight captain, Captain E.W. Bleasdale, who said the soldier, a radioman, on two consecutive high Altitude missions above 20,000 feet had discarded his oxygen mask at great risk to help his comrades.

The building containing sixty-seven suits at 1405-15 Palisade Avenue, Union City, N.J., has been sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company, trustee, to the 1405 Palisade Avenue Corporation. The structure, one of the largest multi-family structures in North Hudson, is on a plot 100 by 130 Feet.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- China was brought into the structure of United States-British lease-lend arrangements today through her adherence to the master lease-lend agreement previously concluded with Great Britain.

ST. LOUIS, June 2 (AP) -- Weathering a two-run rally in the ninth inning, the Cardinals opened a fourteen-game home stand with a 4-to-3 victory over the Braves tonight. Johnny Beazley rescued Morton Cooper in the ninth.

Unscrew the black stopper on the jug-like bottle, and consider the contents. First you must sniff the walnut-brown liquid. Its sweet spiciness is reminiscent of the fragrance that goes with pickling and preserving -- the unforgettable odor that fills a country kitchen during the brisk days of late Autumn.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 2 -- Herbert C. Gerlach, County Execu- tive of Westchester, urged the county Board of Supervisors today to reconsider its refusal to grant a $6,000 salary to Colonel Frederick L. Devereux for his work as West- Chester Director of Civilian Pro- tection.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The newspapers have lately been full of articles on the necessity of conserving rubber and gasoline and of new regulations which may mean well but are not always practical, as the one for the return load, which had to be postponed for further study.

A group headed by Blytn Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of $7,062,000 of Buffalo (N.Y.) Municipal Housing Authority, Series A, bonds on an interest-cost basis to the authority of 1.945 per cent. The successful bid was 100.12 for $267,000 as 3s, $1,128,000 as 1.80s, $2,594,000 as 1.90s and $3,073,000 as 2s.

A UNITED NATIONS OPERATIONAL, BASE, in Australia, June 2 -- Of many stories of heroism on the part of American young men who are flying the bombers against the Japanese, few top the tale of Lieutenant John C. O'Donnell, aged 22, of Oakland, Md., and his crew.

The unselfish service rendered the Army Air Forces by hundreds of thousands of ground observers along the Eastern seaboard was praised in a letter from Lieut. Gen. H.H. Arnold, commanding general of the Army Air Forces, to BrigGen. John K. Cannon, commanding the First Fighter Command, which was released for publication yesterday.

Pending the outcome of arbitration affecting the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, an independent organization, and the Publishers Association of New York City, in relation to combination deliveries and other expedients designed to reduce mileage to conserve rubber, gasoline, oil and equipment, the publishers yesterday reported further changes in publication schedules to meet the requirements of the Office of Defense Transportation.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- When a Ferrying Command flyer takes off from Miami for Shangri-La or elsewhere, he knows that the route assigned to him is safe because in Washington, in a section of the Air Corps Ferrying Command, is a group of well-traveled women who watch the earth for him and tell him where the danger lies.
A nine-room apartment with three baths in 470 Park Avenue has been leased to Mrs. Charlotte Pruyn Hyde through Huberth Huberth.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Sales of all retail stores in April for the first time in more than three years were lower than in the same month of the preceding year, the Depart- ment of Commerce reported today. Dollar sales declined more than 3 per cent in contrast to the increase of 23 per cent in income payments for the same period.

Declaring that the war was a conflict between the ideologies of democracy and totalitarianism, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. told graduates of the College of Mount St. Vincent yesterday afternoon that "totalitarianism is the very antithesis of Catholic teaching and practice" and that "it is our duty to do all in our power to destroy it."

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- An outbreak of rioting at Nassau in the Bahamas, which assumed the proportions of a labor revolt and led the Duke of Windsor to fly back to his post, was suppressed as of noon today, according to reports received by the State Departmen.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 3 -- Britain's great army of men and women trained in civil defense were warned today by Herbert Morrison, Home Secretary, that "any day now" the enemy maye strike from the skies in retaliation for the British raids on the Rhineland.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 2 -- Particularly close competition and brilliant exploits under pressure marked the opening round of match play in the forty-second championship tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association today at the Lakeville Club.

A committee of four representing the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers left yesterday for Washington to urge upon OPA officials four alterna- tive modifications of seasonal or- der 153. The committee comprises Stanley Goldstein, Rhea Manufacturing Company; Robert S. Pirie, Carson Pirie Scott Co.; Boris Smoler, Boris Smoler Sons, and J.M. Biberman of J.M. Biberman Brothers, Inc., it was reported yesterday by Erwin Feldman, counsel and director of the organization.

The building, with three apart- ments and a store, on a plot 22 by 100 feet, at 772 Halsey Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Bowery Savings Bank, H.C. Burgess, vice president, to Crest- ville Equities, Inc. Aaron Isaacs was the broker.

(The lot of women in wartime Germany and Italy is a hard one, United Press Correspondents Eleanor Packard and Jack Fleischer, who returned from those countries aboard the Swedish liner Drottningholm, report in two dispatches.)

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 -- "The greatest show on earth" tonight paid off "the best circus band in the world" and pressed into service new-fangled canned music augmented by an ancient steam calliope and the old tinkling chime wagon.

LONDON, June 2 -- The German radio tonight, as quoted by Reuter, described Prime Minister Winston Churchill's statement today in regard to the 1,036 aircraft that raided the Ruhr area as "sheer invention," asserting that he gave this figure only to make the percentage of British losses in these operations appear lower than it was.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Arrangements have been worked out with the fire insurance industry to act as fiduciary agents for the War Damage Corporation in writing policies for protection of property against enemy attack, according to an announcement today by Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, received $68,232 from Sears Roebuck Co. in 1941 before he resigned as its executive vice president, additional reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission revealed today.

Nearly 500 city officials and representatives of civic bodies and realty organizations gathered at a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Commodore to pay tribute to Edward P. Doyle, veteran legislative expert, on his eighty-second birthday.

Mrs. Floyd Kirk Haskell, who has been spending several weeks with her mother-in-law, Mrs. E. Kirk Haskell of Fox Hollow, Morristown, leaves today for Louisville to join her husband, who is at an Officers' Training School.

Share prices drifted irregularly lower yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and closed dull and mixed. Rails and steels were weak. Sales were 316,050 shares, against 308,830 on the previous day, and of the 629 issues traded 269 declined, 174 advanced and 186 were unchanged.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 2 -- "A Thousand Shall Fall," Hans Habe's recently published account of his adventures in the French Army, was purchased today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and assigned to Edwin Knopf for Summer production.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 2 (AP) -- The Connecticut Supreme Court ruled in a 3-to-2 decision today that it was illegal for a physician to prescribe the use of contraceptives even if he believed a married woman's life might be jeopardized by pregnancy.

CHICAGO, June 2 (AP) -- Buying in the hog market was sharply curtailed today and prices closed 10 to 15 cents a hundred pounds lower on all weights and sows. Most livestock men considered the down- turn natural in view of the fact that yes- terday swine had sold at the highest aver- age price since mid-April.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 3 -- Miss Ann Pink of Rye, a rising young player without any previous conquest of consequence to her credit, turned in the finest round of golf to date in the women's metropolitan championship at the Lakeville Club today to eliminate the defending titleholder, Mrs. Charles Leichner of Fresh Meadow, 3 and 1.

The five-story building containing twenty apartments and one store at 503 Jefferson Street, Hoboken, N.J., has been sold by the Chancellor of New Jersey, trustee, to the Ninth Realty Company through the C.B. Snyder Realty Company, broker.

The Yonkers, N.Y., Municipal Housing Authority will receive proposals on June 11 for the refunding of $3,925,000 of outstanding bonds, it was announced yesterday. Each bid must prescribe serial maturities for $3,925,000 of bonds on Nov. 1, each year, beginning on Nov. 1, 1942, and ending not later than Nov. 1, 1997, and shall designate not more than $2,800,000 commencing with the first maturity as Series A bonds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 3 -- Universal announced today that Marlene Dietrich, John Wayne and Randolph Scott will be co-starred in "Pittsburgh," a story about the present Pennsylvania steel boom. Arrangements for the production were made in a "package" deal with Charles K. Feldman, agent.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Office of Price Administration today cut back processors' prices on refined lard to the February, 1942, level, fixed specific ceilings for canned meat and frozen boneless beef sold to government agencies and pronounced "very constructive" a plan to "roll back" the price of men's and boys' work clothing at the wholesale, manufacturing and cloth stages to relieve a price squeeze on retailers.

Champions will defend their titles in sixteen of the twenty-one events at the Metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships at Travers Island on Saturday, it was announced by Chairman Pinky Sober yesterday. In addition, another winner of a year ago will compete in another event.

Certification to the War Labor Board by Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins of the dispute between milk distributors of the New York metropolitan area and the Milk Drivers Union, arising from proposed curtailment of deliveries, appeared probable yesterday.

ALBANY, June 3 -- The downward tendency in formation of new stock companies which has persisted for several months continued in May when only 745 new concerns were formed, Secretary of State Walsh reported today. The total to date this year is 4,437, compared to 6,741 last year in the same period.

Long Island and New Jersey skippers have reported a falling off in the catches of mackerel during the last few days, but they are inclined to regard this as due to weather conditions, rather than to a sudden migration of the fish.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 3 -- Lieutenant William W. Hargrave of Newburg, Ind., and C.S. Nelson, radio operator, survivors of the crew of a Navy patrol bomber, have reached Australia after a remarkable escape from the Netherlands Indies.

LONDON, June 3 -- Denmark, which used to help stock Britain's larder, is now being emptied by Germany at an alarming rate, Christmas Moeller, former Danish Minister of Commerce and now a voluntary exile here, said today. Soon Germany must decide whether to permit Denmark to continue on a self-replenishing basis or put an end to that by decimating dairy herds, he said.
CAIRO, June 3 (AP) -- The British General Headquarters communique said today:

Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Higher Education were rebuked yesterday by the New York Federation of College Teachers, Local 25, for "failure to keep their promises" to get "adequate" teaching posts for fifty-four Townsend Harris High School instructors who will lose their positions when the school is discontinued on Aug. 31.

Jimmy Dykes's self-styled Hitless Wonders, the White Sox, treated Tiny Bonham at the Stadium yesterday as though he were just an ordinary pitcher. They wrested eight safeties from him, his high of the season, but they could not wrench the big fellow loose from his eighth straight victory of an unbeaten campaign.

Asserting that New York City was one of the most vulnerable targets for enemy attack, Mayor La Guardia issued a proclamation yesterday setting aside next week as "Civilian Defense Week" and called for thousands of additional volunteers to join the ranks of the city's defenders.

Death Announced Retired Fireman Patrick F. Slattery, forerly a member of Engine Co. 60, residing at 1227 St. Lawrence Ave., Bronx, died June 1. Funeral will take place from his late residence at 9:30 A.M., Friday, June 5. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. The Deputy Chief of the 7th Division mil detail one captain, one lieutenant and velve firemen as funeral escort. Presentation of Medals

A brown filly named Portable, who had been hard to find in recent races, was a smashing winner at Belmont Park yesterday under the handling of Charley Wahler, who took her to the top in the Belmar Purse and then scored by three lengths at $11.40 for $2.

CINCINNATI, June 3 (AP) -- Frank Melton won his own game for the Phils tonight by pitching six-hit ball and then driving in the winning run with a double in the tenth inning against Paul Derringer and the Reds. The score was 2 to 1.

Having already voted to spend 53,000 to control signals and lighting on the subway and elevated lines of the city's unified transit system during blackouts and dimouts, the Board of Transportation had under consideration yesterday the expenditure of an additional $120,000 for the protection of structures, enclosures, equipment and personnel under such circumstances.

With undue devotion to prosaic accuracy the newspapers speak of Dr. Butler's "thirty-ninth commencement address." It is better to recall that his installation was on April 19, 1902. It was an auspicious date. He has been true to the omen. It is more than forty years since the then Professor of Philosophy went to the presidency.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Familiar household goods that have been disappearing from store shelves, such as girdles, stockings and rubber bands, are fast being transformed into gas masks, parachutes or Army raincoats, according to statistics revealed here today by the industrial conservation division of the War Production Board.
BERLIN, June 3 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique issued today follows:

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The effects of the Axis submarine war on shipping in the Western Atlantic and along the Eastern seaboard of the American continents have been so damaging, and in so many ways, that another report on the campaign of the Navy against them is ventured, even though this makes a half-dozen recently.

Perseverance will be rewarded next Wednesday when Joseph E. Carlin, who has attended New York University continuously for thirty-nine years in quest of a doctorate, will have the degree of Doctor of Philosophy conferred upon him at the university's one hundred and tenth annual commencement exercises.
