Immediately after Pearl Harbor temporary war damage insurance was provided by the setting up (through the Reconstruction Finance Corporation) of the War Insurance Corporation, which provided free insurance up to a total of $100,000,000 against losses resulting from enemy attacks on private property in the continental United States.

The legality of a labor agreement requiring an industry to advertise its products as a means of safeguarding and prolonging the jobs of the workers was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook in a decision giving judicial sanction to the $1,000,000 promotion fund established under the contract between the New York Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A.F. of L., and the dress manufacturers in this city.

The Cuban American Sugar Company cleared up yesterday arrears on its old 7 per cent preferred stock with the declaration of a dividend of $50 a share. The company also declared two regular quarterly dividends of $1.75 each on the preferred and a dividend of 25 cents on the common stock, the first payment on this issue since a similar amount was made in January of 1929.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The American people were warned today that "our civilian economy is fast going on a minimum subsistence standard," that industry must now get ready to "patch and pray," and that even many war materials are now short.

Lewis B. Marks looked back over fifty years yesterday and suddenly realized how close he has come to attaining happiness. He could not help taking stock because earlier in the day he had been guest of honor at a luncheon to celebrate his fiftieth anniversary at work for the New York Telephone Company.

Sales of war savings bonds in May by issuing agents in the Second Federal Reserve District, other than post offices, reached $115,200,000, compared with $102,200,000 in April, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Heavy broadsides fired by two Japanese cruisers and a lighter enemy warship destroyed the seven-ship convoy in which Captain Igner Eklund was sailing as master of the S.S. Exmoor in the Bay of Bengal on April 6 in less than forty minutes, he revealed last night at his home, 43-30 Forty-eighth Street, Sunnyside, Queens.
Several store leases were included in the lists of commercial rentals reported by brokers yesterday. Among the other deals were many calling for expansion of business quarters.

JUST recently the eminent J.J. Dykes, manager of the White Sox, was sitting around with his headquarters staff, the same consisting of Muddy Ruel, one of the few licensed barristers in baseball, and Edmund (Bing) Miller, an old soldier. The White Sox being down where they are, Mr. Dykes wasn't saying much. Barrister Ruel wasn't saying anything at all. Bing Miller had the floor.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The following Navy communique was issued, based on reports received up to 4 P.M.:

Two thousand boys on a sidewalk and several hundred adults at tenement windows yesterday afternoon heard Lieutenant John T. Bulkeley, the naval hero, speak as the Boys Club of New York dedicated its remodeled Tompkins Square building and new sevenstory addition at Avenue A and Tenth Street.

ST. LOUIS, June 3 (AP) -- Behind the masterful relief pitching of Johnny Sain, who stopped three rallies, the Braves scored three runs in the first inning and added one in the fifth to defeat the Cardinals, 4 to 3, in an Army-Navy Relief twilight game before a crowd of 11,477 today.
BERNE, Switzerland, June 2 -- Travelers entering France henceforth, will be allowed to bring with them no more than 200 French francs, but no limit is placed on foreign currency.

The Civil Service Reform Association, in its annual report made public yesterday, warned that wasteful overexpansion of governmental agencies under the pretext of war emergencies must be halted "if the public payrolls are not to swell to burdensome proportions."

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board drew a Congressional rebuke today for what one member of the House Appropriations Committee called a "go-to-hell attitude" toward Congress and another described as a "most outrageous misuse of funds."
LONDON, June 3 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

By a vote of 121 to 85 the House of Representatives has refused to authorize the construction of a pipeline across Northern Florida to relieve the East Coast oil shortage. Apparently, however, the proposal was rejected only because it was linked with a plan for a parallel barge canal.
JERSEY CITY, June 3 (AP) -- Jersey City made a sweep of its fourgame series with Buffalo by winning a double-header today, 7 -- 2 and 4 -- 3, the second an overtime nine-inning battle.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It was my privilege last week to be in the gallery of the House of Representatives when the bill, S. 860, in relation to the sale of alcoholic liquors to the members of the land and naval forces was under discussion.

CHUNGKING, China, June 3 (AP) -- The fate of the important rail line center of Chuhsien hung precariously in the balance tonight as Japanese troops, in some places less than ten miles from the city limits, threw in reinforcements in an attempt to close in from three sides upon a fiercely resisting Chinese garrison.

MOSCOW, Thursday, June 4 (U.P.) -- Russian shock troops, attacking suddenly on the Kalinin front, have driven a salient into tactically important German lines and 5,730 Axis troops have been killed in brisk clashes all along the front, the Red Army reported today.

Since Italy's intervention in the war the relations between the Vatican and the Fascist Government have become increasingly strained as a result of Premier Benito Mussolini's policy of curbing the temporal activity of the Pope.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- While naval spokesmen repeatedly have described the helplessness of the Navy to protect shipping along the Atlantic Coast because of the lack of proper vessels, information has been received in Washington indicating that no effort has been made to convert between fifty and 100 Great Lakes vessels which marine engineers consider readily adaptable to patrol purposes.

BALBOA, C.Z., June 1 -- Jules Souza, 33-year-old seaman of New Bedford, Mass., has told how he kept alive on an open raft on the Atlantic for thirty-two days after the medium-sized American freighter on which he shipped had been shelled and sunk by three Nazi submarines.

Madeline Webb, who is to receive a mandatory life term of imprisonment on June 19 for her part in the robbery-slaying of Mrs. Susan Flora Reich, middle-aged Polish refugee, spent nearly six hours of her twenty-ninth birthday yesterday under examination in the General Sessions Psychiatric Clinic in the Criminal Courts Building.

Formal offering to the public will be made today by a group headed by Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc.; Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.; the First Boston Corporation and Kidder, Peabody Co. of two new issues of the Virginia Public Service Company, aggregating $36,500,000.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Wartime conditions resulted in 1941 in the largest recorded birth rate In the history of the United States, Miss Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor, told Congress in a report released today.

The portrait of Captain Colin P. Kelly Jr. that will hang as his memorial at the United States Military Academy at West Point was unveiled yesterday afternoon at the Arthur U. Newton Galleries, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street. Through June 13 the picture will be on public exhibition here, the proceeds of the 50-cent admission fee going to the USO $32,000,000 War Fund Campaign.

The Japanese raids yesterday upon Dutch Harbor, naval and air base and military station in the Eastern Aleutian Islands, were not unexpected and may prove to be merely the first of several raids against Alaskan and West Coast points.

The New York County grand jury returned a first-degree murder indictment late yesterday after-against Nathaniel L. Ballenberg, 31 years old, an amateur champion tennis player, in the strangling of his wife Ruth, 26, in their home at 42 Thayer Street, Inwood, at noon on May 11.
ROME, June 3 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command, communique said today:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 3 -- According to local newspapers today, Germany delivered a note last Monday acknowledging responsibility for the torpedoing of the Argentine tanker Victoria off the United States coast on April 17 and at the same time offering apologies and volunteering to pay for the damage.

Heavy New Orleans selling, virtually unresisted, moved the cotton futures market sharply downward again yesterday. Losses of 31 to 35 points, or $1.55 to $1.75 a bale, were established before covering operations and a New Orleans switch to the buying side regained some of the lost ground.

Four new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. The Radio City Music Hall will present the world premiere of Metro's pic- turization of the Jan Struther book, "Mrs. Miniver." Greer Garson and Walter Pidgeon are starred in the drama, which is laid in contemporary England and which was directed by William Wyler, Teresa Wright, Richard Ney, Dame May Whitty, Reginald Owen and Henry Travers appear in supporting roles.

BOSTON, June 3 (AP) -- Valdina Orphan, one of the shortest-priced winners in the history of legalized racing in New England, won the Geneva Purse, a mile test for three-year-olds, today at Suffolk Downs.

LONDON, Thursday, June 4 -- Essen, home of the Krupps, and the industrial region around it with homes and factories still smoldering after the raid by 1,036 heavy and medium bombers Monday night, was attacked again Tuesday night by "strong" forces of the Royal Air Force, it was announced yesterday.

Stocks of gasoline in the United States at the end of last week were 95,355,000 barrels, a decline of 1,679,000 from the 97,034,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago these stocks amounted to 93,156,000 barrels.

LEWISBURG, Pa., June 3 (AP) -- M.L. Annenberg, Philadelphia publisher, was released from the Northeastern Federal Penitentiary on parole today because of his health after serving twenty-three months of a three-year sentence in the largest individual income tax case on record.

About 1,000 persons attended last night the fiftieth anniversary dinner of the School of Nursing of Presbyterian Hospital of the Columbia - Presbyterian Medical Center at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. An'hour-long pageant in eighteen scenes, depicting the history of the school, was a feature of the program.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Glenn Russell, who is scheduled to recede into the Cubs' dugout in a few days when Jimmy Foxx takes over at first base, apparently does not intend to vacate without a struggle. He hit his second home run in two days today, and this time he made it quite a shot.

Lieut. Comdr. Hooker Talcott, U.S.N.R., and Mrs. Talcott of 126 East Seventy-ninth Street have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their niece, Miss Katharine Throop Goodwin, to Warren Lombard Wheelwright, son of Mrs. Henry May Wheelwright of Newton Center, Mass., and the late Mr. Wheelwright.

Silverware Lines Withdrawn Unable to get sufficient supplies of silver, a number of silverware manufacturers have withdrawn the promotional weights in sterling that were introduced recently. Shipments against old orders will be made on an allotment basis, it was said.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A warning for the United Nations not to ease up in the fight against Japan was uttered today by Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Minister for External Affairs, at a press conference after his return from four weeks of conferences with Prime Minister Winston Churchill and other officials in London.

They Are Greeted At an early hour on Monday morning Ethelbert Smith might have been observed walking rapidly in the direction of the Jersey City ferry. It had suddenly occurred to Smith that if a citizen should go down to the dock to meet a lot of distinguished incoming reporters it ought to be news.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, New York regional director of the Social Security Board, told a House Appropriations Committee in testimony made public today that although she held three private jobs in addition to Federal office, "I have given 100 per cent of my time to my government work."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a visitor to this country, lost in deep admiration of its vitality, its air of freedom and its constructiveness, nevertheless I tremble when I think of the shattering blows that are being dealt to the future generations.

A campaign to kill the mandatory joint income tax return for husbands and wives in the House Ways and Means Committee was decided on by representatives of women's organizations at a meeting held yesterday at the Women's City Club, 56 West Forty-fourth Street.

Trading in securities here was generally slow yesterday. However, on the New York Stock Exchange stocks dropped their lethargy in the last half hour of business and closed at the best levels of the session, up fractions to 2 points.

This week the Republic of China has been brought into the lease-lend system and under the terms of the Atlantic Charter. So much has been accomplished by the agreement signed by Secretary Hull and Chinese Foreign Minister Soong. Material results in an increased flow of American war goods to China, by whatever routes are open, ought to follow.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The greatest of the nation's new naval building programs, to add 500 fighting ships and 800 patrol, mine-laying and tending craft to the fleet and double its striking power as a completed two-ocean Navy in twenty-four months, was presented to the House today.

Several leases of apartments in Gracie Square Gardens, the new apartment building at East End Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street, to business executives were reported yesterday by Wm. A. White Sons, agents.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Ways and Means Committee announced today recommendations for changes in the tax laws to remove "hardships" and to "adjust" practices under some statutes.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Secretary Morgenthau said over the air tonight that he had been "shocked" at the extravagant salaries and bonuses paid by some war contractors and was determined to make the offending concerns pay. He also asserted that any citizen who went on a buying spree at this time was sabotaging the war effort.

Resales of properties that had been repossessed by banks formed the bulk of realty trading in Manhattan yesterday, the leading transaction involving a theatre in the Times Square area. Most of the buyers were investors.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Customs officials seized "heavy amounts" of currency from passengers on the Drottningholm, which arrived in New York on Monday with many American and Latin-American diplomats and other citizens and refugees from Axis areas.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 -- David A. Crawford, president of Pullman, Inc., testifying today in Federal District Court said that most contracts held by his company and the railroads provide alternative plans for sleeping car service, should it prove impossible to negotiate a satisfactory new contract.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 3 -- Twenty-five new names were added today to the list of Czechs executed for the attack on Reinhard Heydrich, acting Protector of Bohemia-Moravia, and deputy Gestapo chief, who still is critically ill following his third blood transfusion and an operation for removal of his spleen.

OTTAWA, June 3 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian butchers, bakers, grocers -- and even landlords -- have to be pretty smart to beat the price ceiling these days and get away with it, spokesmen for the Wartime Prices and Trade Board said today.

The hanging or guillotining of Hitler "and his colossal fellowmalefactors" was advocated here last night in an address by Senator Claude D. Pepper of Florida, a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

Germans, Italians and Hungarians who are loyal to this country will express their defiance of the Axis with floats that will roll in the same division with those of the United Nations and the Latin-American countries in the "New York at War" all-day parade on June 13, it was announced last night by Dr. Frank Monaghan, administrative assistant to Grover A. Whalen, who heads the Mayor's committee arranging the demonstration.

Associated Press Correspondent It's revolvers down and belts off. for any general or field marshal who wants to see Adolf Hitler at his general headquarters in East Prussia, or in the Berlin Chancellery, or anywhere else.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 3 -- Several first-aid trains of the N.S.V., the Nazi party social welfare organization, have left for Cologne and the Ruhr, according to news from Berlin today. Strong Gestapo detachments have also been dispatched to West Germany, as there appears to be much looting in the bombed area.

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. G. Norman Bacon, who were married here on Friday are now at The Cloister, Sea Island. Ga. Mrs. Bacon is the former Miss Marjorie Knox Goodyear, daughter of Mrs. Edmund Pendleton Rogers and the late Frank H. Goodyear.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (U.P.) -- New and secret aerial weapons, which will deal the Axis some "frightful surprises," have been developed by American warplane manufacturers, it was disclosed today with publication of the Aircraft Year Book for 1942.

Substantial gains in the incomes of 270 industrial incorporations in the first quarter of the year before deductions for Federal income tax and contingency reserves were converted into equally large declines in net after taxes, according to the analysis of the Division of Industrial Economics of the Conference Board announced yesterday.

"Super - heated" residents of Flushing Meadow Park "needn't worry about demolition of the Japanese Pavilion," Park Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday in reply to a threat by the Flushing Ridge Civic Association to tear down that "monument to a treacherous enemy" piece by piece.

Roller skating made its debut at Madison Square Garden last night in the form of an extravaganza entitled "Skating Vanities of 1942." The crowd of 8,000 persons greeted the spectacle enthusiastically, excusing the few spills that occurred.

The new Rodgers and Hart musical show leered its way into the Shubert Theatre last evening, complete with Ray Bolger in tunic and Benay Venuta and Bertha Belmore in tights. It was all right, too. Perhaps in adapting "The Warrior's Husband" of a decade back into "By Jupiter," Broadway's own Gilbert and Sullivan have not written their greatest show, but pending that event it will do.

Three more ships have been torpedoed and sunk in the Atlantic and Caribbean, it was announced yesterday by the Navy. They were a large British ship, attacked in the Caribbean on May 9; a medium-sized United States ship sunk in West Indian waters on May 6, and a medium-sized British vessel sent to the bottom in the Atlantic several hundred miles east of Bermuda on May 20.

CARMEL, N.Y., June 3 -- Following the example of the Orange County Republican organization, the Republican County Committee of Putnam County tonight endorsed Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. for renomination. The vote for Mr. Fish was 41 to 2.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Plans for permanent gasoline rationing in the East were announced tonight and the Office of Price Administration indicated simultaneously that, if nation-wide rationing is ordered, the basic allowance for each motorist might be slightly less than four gallons a week.

American importers of finished manufactured goods expressed satisfaction yesterday over the fact that their products have not been included in the list of imported civilian commodities over which the War Production Board has assumed control.

Government Financing The Treasury Department took occasion yesterday to review what it had accomplished last month in the way of public financing. The figures, which a few months ago would have been staggering and frightening to the market, were taken in stride as merely a sample of what is to come during the fiscal year to start on July 1.

Many used tires that are fit only for junk are being patched and sold to unsuspecting buyers, Clarence H. Low, chairman of the New York City Salvage Committee, declared yesterday on the basis of a survey recently completed at his request.

MOSCOW, June 3 -- Thirteen hundred and sixty-six enemy planes were destroyed in May, against a loss of 479, according to Russian claims released here today. Much of the destruction was on air fields, five raids on the southwestern front having resulted in the loss of ninety-one German planes, the army newspaper Red Star asserts.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Japanese air force today made two daylight raids on the important American Naval and Air Base at Dutch Harbor, Alaska.

As symptomatic of Summer as sidewalk cafes and sunburn lotions are the tender, luscious soft-shell crabs that are now arriving every dawn in the Fulton Fish Market. The crustaceans, which will continue to come from celebrated Chesapeake Bay waters until after Labor Day, are superlatively good at the moment, and, according to the Department of Markets, may be had for as little as a nickel apiece.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The Browns unleashed an eight-run second-inning assault against Sid Hudson tonight and dealt the Senators a 9-5 defeat.

When Tat Terry was a child on his father's cotton plantation in Abbeville, near Eufaula in Alabama, he never, dreamed, he said yesterday, that some day he would be a major general in the United States Army. Completely remote from his thoughts was any notion that one day he would, in a manner of speaking, control New York's night life and the wartime dimming of a great part of the Atlantic seaboard.

William Karlin, city chairman of the Social Democratic Federation, yesterday again requested Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt to "cease lending her moral support and prestige" to the left wing of the American Laboar party. Acknowledging Mrs. Roosevelt's reply to his earlier protest against the wife of the President speaking under the auspices of a left wing Labor party club, Mr. Karlin wrote:
STANTON, Del., June 3 (AP) -- Mrs. Ralph McIlvain's Bright Willie raced to an impressive victory today in the Stanton Handicap at Delaware Park.

A strike of 250 electricians, growing out of a jurisdictional conflict affecting $3,000 worth of work installing telephone cables, has tied up all electrical work on the Navy's $8,120,000 program for the expansion of Floyd Bennett Field since last Friday, it became known yesterday.

BERLIN, June 3 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Russian groups encircled by the Germans on the central front [west of Moscow] have been crushed by the Nazis with a loss of more than 1,500 Russian dead and 2,000 prisoners, the German High Command reported today.
Contributions of $743,610 toward its goal of $1,000,000 have been received by the New York Citizens Committee of the Navy Relief Society, it was announced yesterday by Charles S. McCain, chairman.

Ten thousand persons gathered last night in a dimly lighted Lewisohn Stadium for the Greater New York Inter-Racial War Bond Rally. The great audience, half of whom were Negroes, enthusiastically applauded speakers who stressed the importance of victory over the Axis powers and the need for racial equality at home.

LONDON, June 3 -- A plan for simplifying milk distribution that will cut down the number of small retailers and eliminate the overlapping of delivery routes was given to the House of Commons by the Food Minister today. At the same time Lord Woolton, the Food Minister in the House of Lords pointed out that savings in ton miles of transportation had already been made by enforcing the same type of reorganization in other industries.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- In an announcement foretelling a revolutionary change in naval aircraft design, the Navy Department disclosed today development of a huge new liquid-cooled aviation engine approaching 2,000 horsepower.

VICHY, France, June 3 -- During a declaration here tonight to the French and foreign press, Paul Marion, Secretary of State for Information, protested the British bombings of Paris suburbs as "prompted less on the laws of war than on the practice of private and collective murder."

Fraudulent manufacturing techniques by concerns holding contracts for the supply of cocoa, vanilla flavoring and lemon flavor to the Army and Navy were charged yesterday for the first time during the present war in five indictments handed up in Federal court.

Tuesday night, June 23, has been reserved for the premiere of Andrew Rosenthal's play, "Broken Journey," in the air-conditioned Henry Miller's. The attraction will adhere to a policy of Sunday night performances and omit the Monday night showings.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Arrangements for the closest possible coordination of the Anglo-American victory program in both the military and supply fields were discussed in Washington today by ranking officials of this country and Great Britain.
King Cotton and this year's Maid of Cotton, Miss Camille McLean Anderson, got together yesterday in a fashion show at McCreery's in the Junior Celebrity Shop.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A new and much tighter gasoline rationing scheme for the Eastern Seaboard States, under which X cards will be eliminated and no one, not even dealers, will be able to get gasoline without surrendering coupons for it, was announced tonight by the Office of Price Administration.

Owners of one third of the registered passenger automobiles in New York State failed to apply for any gasoline ration cards for their vehicles, a report made yesterday by Lee S. Buckingham, State director of the Office of Price Administration, disclosed.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 3 -- Schools could solve their fuel oil problems and save considerable money for taxpayers by discontinuing Summer vacations and closing for two and a half months in the Winter, Christian E. Burckel, director of guidance in the schools of Stamford, Conn., said today at the annual conference here of the Metropolitan District Unit of the New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers.

MOSCOW, June 3 -- The Red Army can well afford the losses sustained in the Kharkov battles, and Soviet workers are full of confidence that victory is not far off, in the opinion of British trade union leader John Henry Potts, who has just returned to Moscow after a 4,000-mile tour of Russia, including the Urals and Siberia.

Twelve hundred teachers and parents attended a "victory celebration" yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pennsylvania to mark the signing by Governor Lehman of the Ehrlich bill, which provides State aid for the kindergartens in the schools of this State.

LONDON, June 3 -- The British coal industry has been taken over by the government, which is determined to try to stave off a crisis next Winter through increased production under direct control. A plan for consumer rationing has been drawn up but will not be applied at present, it was explained in a White Paper published today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (AP) -- Jack Knott demonstrated his most effective form of the season for the Athletics today, limiting Detroit to six hits and touching off a batting rally that sewed up a 5-to-1 triumph. The Tigers got their run on a homer by Third Backer Frank Higgins.

NEWARK, N.J., June 3 (AP) -- Last - place Rochester stunned league-leading Newark with a double defeat tonight in the first twilight twin bill tried at Ruppert Stadium. The scores were 4 to 1 and 13 to 5.

LONDON, June 3 --The stock markets were cheerful today and the expansion of public business was an encouraging feature. Giltedge issues were steady. In the industrial section Woolworth advanced to 34 1/2 and Cable and Wire less rose to u60 1/2 from u58 1/2 with the dividend, decision due this week.

The need for some sort of a promotional campaign to spur the use of paper in various divisions of the industry is becoming more acute, as more branches report sharp declines in sales volume. Latest group to complain of the waste-paper campaign and the efforts of stores to economize on packaging is the Folding Paper Box Association of America, which reported a sharp drop in May orders.

Twenty-one metal trophies, won in past years by handball, table tennis and track athletes, were donated to the nation's war effort last night at the Pastime A.C. They were received on behalf of the Bronx Salvage Committee by William A. Stumpp, president of the Bronx Boy Scouts of America.
When something occurs as drastic as capture in battle, one cannot quite grasp it at first. It is one of those things that can happen to other persons, but never to oneself.

Ever since General Doolittle led his squadron of bombers over Tokyo it has seemed certain that Japan would attempt to strike a retaliatory blow somewhere on or near the mainland of this continent. Secretary Stimson warned us only a few days ago to be prepared for news of such an attack, and Vice President Wallace specifically mentioned Alaska as a probable place for it to come.

Maintenance of the steady increase in Argentina's petroleum production is recorded in a dispatch received yesterday by the Argentine Information Bureau here, placing at 326,364,939 gallons the output for the first four months of 1941, against 295,617,871 gallons in the 1941 period, a gain of 10.4 per cent.

Every agle of the price control regulations will be set before the public, by government officials, Mrs. Henry Goddard Leach, chairman of the Price Control Education Campaign of the Consumer Division, OPA, for this region, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Abolition of the Civilian Conservation Corps was voted by the House Committee on Appropriations today when it struck from the Labor Department-Federal Security Agency supply bill for the coming fiscal year the entire $75,818,000 with which the Administration sought to continue the CCC at 350-camp strength.
Two large sales of properties in Queens, one involving apartments and the other a business block front, were reported yesterday.
ALBANY, June 3 -- The adjutant general released the following orders today:

BERNARD DEVOTO'S "Mark Twain at Work,"* which combines scholarship and gusto as only DeVoto can combine them, winds up an ancient quarrel. Long ago, in his lively and pungent "Mark Twain's America," Mr. DeVoto took issue with Van Wyck Brooks's theory that Samuel Clemens's genius had been frustrated from the beginning by the twin environmental factors of Puritanism and commercialism.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Venezuela is on "the side of the United States" and confident of the "triumph of the democracies" over the Axis, Dr. C. Parra Perez, Venezuelan Foreign Minister, declared today.
NEW DELHI, India, June 3 (U.P.) -- British planes have bombed the harbor at Akyab, Burma, an R.A.F. communique announced today as a Chinese expeditionary force from Burma arrived in this country.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Bitterly attacking John L. Lewis, his friend for thirty years, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, today asserted that the president of the United Mine Workers of America was "hell bent on creating national confusion and national disunity."

Henry Torres, whose book on Laval wag published last Fall by Oxford University Press, has been, working on "Campaign of Treachery," an analysis of fifth column methods in Europe and their extension to North and South America. Dodd, Mead plans it for July 14, which is Bastille Day.

Suggesting that it would be better for the government to buy typewriters already made and on dealers' shelves than to direct manufacturers to ''chew up" additional raw material, Nicholas H. Fucci, president of the Office Machine Dealers Association of New York, called upon the government yesterday to discontinue rationing or to buy up retail inventories through some such agency as the RFC.

WASHINGTON, June 3 --The House passed unanimously and sent to the Senate today a formal declaration of war against Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania. There was no debate and no ceremony as the lower chamber, in marked contrast with its enthusiastic declarations of war on Germany and Japan, voted 357 to 0 for war against Bulgaria, 360 to 0 against Hungary and 359 to 0 against Rumania.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 3 -- R.C. Rice of the Plainfield Country Club kept his oneday tournament record among New Jersey Seniors Golf Association members clear today when he carded an 82 to win the organization's Spring tournament at the Upper Montclair Country Club.

An increase of $235,950 over the previously announced total raised yesterday the gifts and pledges by big corporations to the USO War Fund Campaign to $960,750, it was announced yesterday by James A. Farley, chairman of the USO national corporations committee.

Retailers' views on proposed WPB inventory control will be formulated by a committee composed of representatives of seventeen or more national retail trade organizations, according to a resolution adopted yesterday at a special joint meeting held by the American Retail Federation and the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Without attempting to assay the record possibilities in the field events, Chairman Pinky Sober yesterday forecast possible new marks in the 880, the mile and the three miles at the Metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships to be held at Travers Island tomorrow.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, June 5 (U.P.) -- United States Army authorities today for the first time named Private Edward J. Leonski, 24, of New York City, as the American soldier who has been charged with committing three sex murders here.

LONDON, June 4 -- At the end of two days of debate, the Earl of Selborne, Minister of Economic Warfare, today assured the House of Lords on behalf of the government that "Britain will never propose a revenge peace."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The publication of salaries paid, in some cases in excess of a half million dollars a year, appears to be excessive and shocks the conscience of the average thinker.

Bank transactions in the holiday week ended on Wednesday dropped 6.2 per cent under the volume for the preceding full week and 6.8 per cent below the similar holiday period last year. A sharp contraction in New York City accounted chiefly for the decline.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 4 -- "Corvettes in Action," a story of the Canadian convoy-guarding vessels which operate out of Halifax on the North Atlantic lifeline, will be produced by Howard Hawks under his one-picture deal with Universal, the studio announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 (U.P.) -- All Pacific civilian defense agencies exercised redoubled vigilance tonight as a result of the sudden surge of Japanese activity which resulted in air attacks on Dutch Harbor and Midway Island in the last two days.

British Commandos raided the Channel coast near Boulogne again yesterday. As weeks pass by, those landings and the bombing expeditions of the Royal Air Force are bound to increase in number and intensity. And America's air might also will be brought to bear.

Reinhard Heydrich held the title of Deputy Chief of the Gestapo under Hemrich Himmler, but in that unsavory organization he filled the role played by Latzis and Dzerjinsky in the early days of the Russian Cheka -- he was its outstanding expert in terror.

Oil companies supplying the Eastern seaboard are preparing a new appeal to Petroleum Coordinator Harold L. Ickes and Price Administrator Leon Henderson for price increases on gasoline and other petroleum products, it was disclosed yesterday as some smaller units of the industry talked of closing down.

Without pounding a beat alone for a single hour nineteen rookie policemen will start tomorrow on plainclothes duty, replacing the entire present staff of the Chief Inspector's confidential squad and all except two of the veterans assigned to the same work for Commissioner Valentine, the latter announced yesterday.
VICHY, France, June 4 -- Thirteen hundred French factories will be closed under the program for industrial concentration recently pledged by Chief of Government Pierre Laval, it was announced today.

To assist adequate enforcement of the recently enacted wholesale liquor bill, distributors should be required to file monthly statements with the State Liquor Authority showing the salary, commissions and expenses of each salesman or person engaged in sales promotion, the Metropolitan Package Store Association and the Up-State New York Package Stores Association urged yesterday in a joint memorandum to the authority.

LONDON, June 4 -- The government tonight seemed reasonably certain that its plan for nationalization of the coal industry would be approved by Parliament with comparatively few dissents since the issue will be so put that disapproval would be a vote of lack of confidence.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 4 (From Finnish broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Field Marshal Carl Gustav Mannerheim's home in Helsinki was open to the public for well-wishers on his birthday today, but they were received by proxy.

Thousands of independent gasoline dealers will be forced to close by the establishment of a coupon rationing system for gasoline unaccompanied by dealer rationing, the Eastern States Gasoline Dealers Association, representing dealers in seventeen States, predicted yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel New Yorker.

BERLIN, June 4 (From German Broadcasts Recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Reinhard Heydrich of the German Gestapo died from wounds inflicted by two assasisns who attacked his automobile with a British-made bomb "of the type used by the British against German tanks in Africa" and an "automatic pistol," a Prague dispatch said today.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The new drive of the War Production Board for steel scrap needed to meet the steel shortage reported yesterday by William L. Batt, requirements chief, brought warnings today that failure of scrap dealers and owners to cooperate might result in further government action.

Standard Oil The official transcript of the meeting of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, held on Tuesday in Flemington, N.J., is some-what at variance with published reports, particularly in reference to James W. Gerard's remarks.

Seven men and four women of 187 persons seized by raiding police in two gambling establishments late Wednesday night were held in $500 bail each by Magistrate Richard F. McKiniry in West Side yesterday for hearing June 17 on charges of maintaining gambling establishments.

Mayor La Guardia's proclamation of Civilian Defense Week, to run from June 8 to June 13, is opportune. Just now, so far as New York City is concerned, air raids seem a long way off. It is natural to think that the Nazis are too busy in Europe to be able to give us attention, no matter how eager they may be to blow us up or set us on fire.

The revocation by John L. Lewis on March 12 of the charter of a New York local of the United Mine Workers was "without due process of law and therefore illegal," Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag ruled yesterday. The local involved is the Chemical Workers Union, Local 12,165, affiliated with District 50 of the U.M.W.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A Navy Department communique, based on reports received up to noon, said today:
LONDON, June 4 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

Friends of President Roosevelt, faced with the possibility that Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. might be successful in his fight for re-election in the President's home Congressional district, will confer over the week-end with the Chief Executive in an attempt to gain his support in a move to align the Democratic county organizations in the district behind a single "coalition" anti-Fish candidate, it was learned here yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (AP) -- A four-run rally in the ninth gave the Tigers an 8-7 victory over the Athletics today.

The restoration of the Jewish homeland in Palestine must be made one of the peace aims of the United Nations, Lieut. Gov. Charles E. Poletti declared last night at the twenty-fifth anniversary of the formation of the Jewish Legion at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.
Members of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association who assemble in regular session on Wednesday evening at White Plains expressed their determination "to make the striped bass a game fish."

Within three and a half hour yesterday three Pan American Airways clippers arrived at La Guardia Field, bringing to the United States seventy-one persons, 2,85 pounds of mail and more than a ton of air express from various parts of the world.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The executive board of the United Mine Workers of America demanded today that Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organization, retract publicly his "false, malicious and defamatory" charges against John L. Lewis, accusing him of supporting communism and called on him to discharge Communists now on the C.I.O. payroll.
MANHASSET, L.I., June 4 -- "Wedding parties" in a country garden began and ended the Lord Taylor Summer fashion show here this afternoon.

Retailers are being deprived of a "living margin" and are carrying an unfair burden under the new price-freezing regulations, Fred Lazarus Jr., chairman of the Retailers Advisory Committee in Washington, told the graduating class of the Tobe-Cobum School for Fashion Careers at a luncheon at the Hotel Pierre yesterday.

During the war emergency "Brazil represents perhaps the greatest storehouse of vital strategic materials that the United Nations can tap," Joseph C. Rovensky, assistant coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Brazilian Association at the Downtown Athletic Club.

The Port of New York Authority, announced last night the impending retirement of John E. Ramsey, its general manager, and Julius Henry Cohen, its general counsel, as a part of a general personnel reorganization and retrenchment program to meet declining revenues.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 4 (AP) -- British Headquarters said in a communique today:

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation and holding of United States Government securities to be at the highest of the year to date, the latter showing an increase of $43,422,000 for the week.

Sentiment regarding the length of the war crystallized sufficiently yesterday to give the New York Stock Exchange a day of fair volume and strong prices. Stocks registered gains of as much as 2 points and closed at about the best levels of the movement.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The war-caused shortage of qualified medical men should become a concern of the medical profession as it is of the Federal authorities and civilian communities. There are approximately 180,000 licensed physicians today in this country, of whom 80,000 are of the milltary age level of 45 years.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 4 -- The New York Lutheran Synod unanimously endorsed today a recommendation of the New York Conference, one of eight forming the Synod, "that the pastors and congregations of our Synod be encouraged earnestly and continuously during these months to study the principles which must underlie a just and durable peace."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: This is in reply to Mohroe Scharff's letter published May 30. I too am 18. I too am in the stage of undigested ideas and undeveloped interests. I too believe in America and in our victory.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $1,464,518,321 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price per share of all listed stocks on May 29 was $22.40, compared with $21.41 at the end of April.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of June 2 you mentioned the assassination in Prague of Dr. Vladislav Vancura. He was murdered by the Germans in retaliation for the attempt on the life of Heydrich.

WASHINGTON, June 4 --The present situation may not put a ceramic stove into every American kitchen, but It Is likely to sew pottery buttons on women's dresses, put glass casing's around waffle irons or hang drawing-room curtains on glass rods.

Department stores achieved new records for both sales and net taxable income as a result of the heavy consumer buying movement during the latter half of 1941, according to the Conference Board's division of industrial economics. Analysis of the corporate income statements of twenty-five leading stores, it was said, showed an increase of 17 per cent over the preceding year and 5 per cent above the previous peak established in 1929.

Reversing the downward trend of the two previous weeks, which had carried excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Re serve System in New York City and for the entire country as well to the lowest levels in four years, excess reserves of the New York banks rose $45,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $565,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday.

A Frenchman, traveling through the United States for the first time, was asked what impressed him most about the American way of life. "Your civilization is symbolized, he is said to have answered, "by the automobile-and the silk stocking."

Possible candidates for the Democratic nominations for Governor and other State offices have been sent a questionnaire, Harold R. Moskovit, State president of the Affiliated Young Democrats, announced yesterday.

LONDON, June 4 -- Commander R.T. Bower, veteran naval officer and a Conservative member of Parliament, in a speech in Leeds today made a stinging attack on Winston Churchill whom he described as "akin in spirit to the fabled comedian who eats his heart out longing to star in tragic roles."

Archibald MacLeish, on a furlough from poetry, has welcomed to the Library of Congress an exhibition of manuscripts and various other material about Edwin Markham. The collection is lent by Mrs. Ernest Hamilton of this city, long his pupil, secretary and friend. He has been dead a little more than two years, yet no sour critic has fallen upon him.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Processes which will permit the dehydration of meat and reduce the amount of space required for shipment to the armed forces in foreign lands and to lease-lend recipients were reported today by the American Meat Institute.
CHUNGKING, June 4 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command issued this communique tonight:

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 4 -- Prime Minister John Curtin revealed today that four Japanese midget submarines, instead of three, as previously thought, had attempted to enter Sydney Harbor Sunday night. Only one was able to fire its torpedoes, however, before all were destroyed.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, denying a plea that its opinion be with held until after the war, rejected today a plan for consolidation of the Central and South West Utilities Company and the American Public Service Company, directing instead that one or the other be dissolved and that the securities of both be reduced to an all-common stock basis.

There will be concert and opera performances at Tanglewood in the Berkshires this Summer and Dr. Sergei Koussevitzky will direct the symphonic programs, he announced at a press interview here yesterday. The school which he founded and of which he is director also will continue, he declared, and it will carry on under his own financial responsibility.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 4 -- The Battle of the Coral Sea, far from being the Japanese victory claimed by Tokyo, was a signal success for the United Nations and it averted an immediate threat to Australian territory, Prime Minister John Curtin told the House of Representatives today.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Two indications were given today that the government is going to "get tough" in the administration of gasoline rationing, both under the present temporary plan and the permanent one going into effect on July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The House fight over the Appropriation Committee's decision to abolish the Civilian Conservation Corps broadened today into a movement to deny further operating funds to the National Youth Administration also and force the transfer of its war-worker training program, virtually its only remaining activity under present plans, to the Office of Education.

LONDON, June 4 -- Business on the stock markets today was smaller and prices were uneven. Gilt-edge issues remained steady and the industrials saw a further advance in Cable and Wireless 4 per cents which have risen u3 1/2 this week to u61 1/2.

Manufacturers of war goods should prepare a blueprint now of what they intend to do after the war, if the country is to avert a debacle similar to that of 1929, Carroll L. Wilson, director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, Department of Commerce, declared yesterday at the seventh annual convention of the National Federation of Sales Executives at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 4 -- Thomas E. Dewey, aspirant for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination, was among the nine candidates for State or Federal offices endorsed this afternoon by the Westchester County Republican Committee, meeting at the County Center here with 400 delegates attending.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Without mentioning President Roosevelt's surprise at low intelligence ratings among many Army selectees, the Census Bureau reported today that more than half the persons 25 years old or older in the United States had completed at least eight years of school by April 1, 1940.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There is much discussion going on in the press regarding the elimination of ragweed in order to save the victims of subsequent hay fever in the Fall when this plant reaches its devastating stage. It seems to me that volunteers could readily be found to help in the eradication of this pest in the city parks and highways.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 4 (AP) -- Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks criticized today two expense accounts submitted to him in connection with the reorganization of the New Haven Railroad, slashing both of them.

TRENTON, N.J., June 4 -- New Jersey's countryside is about to be invaded by an army of farmerettes as the harvest season for early crops approaches, according to indications in various employment areas. The lady farmers will take the place of young men serving in the armed forces and the transient labor formerly available for seasonal employment which has been siphoned off by the State's tremendous war industries.
NEW YORK Lieut. Comdr. John Jay Ide, U.S.N., and Mrs. Ide have come to the Plaza from Washington.

Level Best, regarded by many as the champion filly last year, gave a very convincing demonstration that she is in the front rank for 1942 when she led from start to finish of yesterday's Top Flight Handicap at Belmont Park and won by three lengths.

Several hundred trained investigators will participate in the first of a series of "flying squadron surveys" of retailer compliance with OPA regulations, beginning on Monday in Philadelphia and later extending to five other major cities in the second OPA region, comprising New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware and the District of Columbia, it was stated yesterday by Sylvan L. Joseph, regional OPA price administrator, at a press conference here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Asserting that Senate conferees on the Soldiers and Sailors Pay Bill were delaying action in order to chisel a "few dollars" from the pockets of the country's defenders. Senator La Follette gave notice today that when the Senate meets again on Monday he will force a roll-call vote on his resolution to discharge the conferees and appoint others with instructions to accept the $50 a month base fixed by the House.

More than 1,500 executives and district leaders of Greater New York's forthcoming War Bond Pledge Campaign received a firsthand demonstration last night of the methods they and 200,000 more Minute Men are to employ in the ten-day campaign starting June 14.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 4 -- A strong finish by Mrs. E.S. Whitman of Hummocks enabled her to win low gross honors today in the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association weekly tournament on the Winged Foot Golf Club's west course.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- In a memorandum to State branches, the Selective Service System, listed the production, transmission, and distribution of electric power as occupations essential to the war effort.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' comparative index of nearly 900 price series in primary markets edged` fractionally upward during the last week of May. With a gain of 0.1 per cent the all-commodity index reached 98.8 per cent of the 1926 average, the highest point in more than fifteen years.

The gigantic role which American air power must play in the war is described realistically in the Aircraft Year Book for 1942, edited by Howard Mingos and published by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America. Men of the aircraft industry, of which the Chamber is the representative, have no illusions about the size of the job that has been undertaken.

Recent heavy liquidation having run its course, replacement buying entered the cotton futures market yesterday and was principally instrumental, under a scarcity of contracts, in working prices moderately higher. On the New York Cotton Exchange active months closed 14 points above Wednesday's final quotations.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- E.I. du Pont de Nemours Company, five other powder manufacturing concerns and ten officials were indicted by the Federal Grand Jury today on a charge of conspiring to fix prices on commercial explosives and blasting supplies.

Group V Savings Banks, an organization of savings institutions in Brooklyn, Queens, Nassau, Suffolk and Richmond Counties, yesterday notified Leon Henderson, OPA Administrator, of their voluntary compliance with the recent rent-freezing plan in their territory.

WITH BRITISH COMMANDOS off Northern France, June 4 (AP) -- The shape of far more fearsome things to come loomed up before the startled Nazi sentries on the French coast early this morning when I saw some of Britain's toughest Commandos wade silently through breast-high surf between Boulogne and Le Touquet, shoot up German strong points and depart safely with useful information and very slight casualties.

Two more important steps to speed up the sale of United States War Savings Bonds will be undertaken immediately by many New York City commercial banks, it was announced yesterday by Bayard F. Pope, chairman of the executive committee of the Treasury's local War Savings Staff.

An intensive drive to enroll "tens of thousands" of additional volunteers "in the defense of New York" will take place next week, it was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (AP) -- The Northern States Power Company, a Delaware corporation, submitted today to the Securities and Exchange Commission a voluntary plan or liquidation that would cut it off from sixteen operating companies in Minnesota and Wisconsin.
ST. LOUIS, June 4 -- The Cardinals settled more firmly in second place in the National League today by taking the rubber game of a series of three with the Braves, 6 to 2.

TRENTON, June 4 -- Under a decision today of the State Board of Tax Appeals, Hillsborough Township in Somerset County is to receive soon a tax windfall of $364,391 from the Duke Power Company unless the company takes an appeal to the courts.

SEIGNIORY CLUB, Que., June 4 (Canadian Press) -- Graham Towers, Governor of the Bank of Canada, said today in an address at the twentieth annual meeting of the United States Bankers Association for Foreign Trade that Canada had decided upon a policy of "pay as you go" in conducting the war, with consequent high taxes and internal borrowings and foreign exchange control regulations.

"Red Tanks," a Soviet importation, will have its local premiere this morning at the Stanley Theatre. The picture was produced at the Lenfilm Studios in Leningrad, with the cooperation of the Soviet High Command, and is released here through Artkino Pictures, Inc.

Soup to start the Sunday dinner this week-end should be hot and savory, clear and colorful, light and stimulating as an aperitif. Soup of this very special sort is a tomato bouillon that has the redness of a ruby and the fragrance of a potpourri.

LONDON, June 4 -- The British made another jab early today at German defenses on the French coast. A small party of Commandos, supported by the Royal Air Force and the Royal Navy, landed on a beach between Boulogne and Le Touquet, tossed grenades at and exchanged rifle fire with the defenders, and retreated under a smoke screen with light casualties.

ALBANY, June 4 -- In a four-to-three decision, the Court of Appeals decided that an injunction, granted by the special term, restraining the picketing of twelve Florsheim shoe stores in New York and Brooklyn, should be reinstated. The Appellate Division was reversed and the court answered in the affirmative a question whether the complaint stated acts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.

BOSTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Indians made it two in a row over the Red Sox today, rallying in a three-run ninth inning to score a 4-2 decision and maintain their slim grip on second place in the American League.

The union Trust Company of Pittsburgh and the National Bank of Detroit yesterday announced that they had arranged a bank credit in the amount of $35,000,000 to be made available to the Standard Steel Spring Company for the period commencing today and expiring Nov. 30, 1942.

BOSTON, June 4 (AP) -- Jockeys Carroll Bierman and Ted Atkinson split the eight-race card between them today at Suffolk Downs, each riding four winners for one of the most unusual sweeps in the last decade of American racing.

HONOLULU, June 4 -- A heavy attack on Midway Island this morning by planes from Japanese carriers accompanied by battleships, cruisers and destroyers has been repulsed with damage to a battleship, a carrier and possibly other enemy vessels, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, announced this evening.

Designating petitions were distributed last night for George W. Thompson as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Representative in the Sixteenth Congressional District against former Representative James H. Fay and for James G. Donovan as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for State Senator against Senator Thomas G. Brennan in the Sixteenth Senatorial District.

STANTON, Del., June 4 (AP) -- The white and black silks of J.B. Belk, Virginia horseman, were borne to an upset victory at Delaware Park today when Blustering was first past the judges in the featured Lewes Purse at a mile and seventy yards.

A musical comedy with melodies by the late George Gershwin, lyrics by his brother, Ira; book by Sam and Bella Spewack, and with the leading roles taken by William Gaxton and Victor Moore is in the offing. At present the show, which would be based on A.J. Lieblihg's hilarious tales of "Jollity Building," that appeared originally hi The New Yorker, has not gone much beyond the talking stage.
STOCKTON, Calif., June 4 (AP) -- Fire, preceded by an explosion, swept through an Army building today and left eleven dead and another nine severely burned.
BERLIN, June 4 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command isued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Air power received new recognition in the War Department today as Brig. Gen. Idwal H. Edwards, a veteran pilot, was named assistant chief of staff in charge of organization and training for the entire Army. The appointment was announced by Secretary Stimson, who noted that the deputy chief of staff, Major Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, likewise was an airman.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Senate approved today by unanimous vote, and without any discussion, three resolutions declaring war on Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania. The House, also by unanimous vote, had adopted the resolutions yesterday, and only President Roosevelt's signature was lacking tonight to add these Axis-dominated nations to the enemies of the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- A nine-hit attack featured by Harlond Clift's two-run homer brought the Browns a 7-2 victory over the Senators today. St. Louis won the series, two games to one.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 4 -- Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, seven times winner of the crown, and Miss Ann Pink of Rye, who eliminated the defending title-holder, Mrs. Charles Leichner of Fresh Meadow, on Wednesday, passed from the women's metropolitan golf championship today at the Lakeville Club.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Buyers regained confidence in the wheat market today, and there was both commission and local absorption as well as some further buying by mill interests, whose support has been a steadying influence for several days.
War flared up in the mid-Pacific again yesterday as British bombers roared over Germany and the furious battle of mechanized man continued across the hot sands of Libya.

MOSCOW, Friday, June 5 (AP) -- The Soviet Command reported early today a resumption of fighting and air force activity in some sectors of the front Actions afield were described as local, however, and there still was no indication of general fighting anywhere.

NEWARK, N.J., June 4 (AP) -- The Seabright invitation tournament, America's oldest tennis classic, probably will be canceled because of war conditions, Holcombe Ward, president of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club, said tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- Despite a monthly low for the year registered in April, new issues of securities offered for cash in the first third of 1942 topped the corresponding volume for 1941 by 51,547,000,000, according to an analysis made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Warning members of his new financial advisory committee that they faced "a long, hard, difficult, thankless job," Mayor La Guardia outlined the scope of the committee's work at its first meeting in City Hall yesterday.
LONDON, June 4 -- War-time Britain is paradise compared with Germany.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 4 -- It Is officially reported from Helsinki that Reichsfuehrer Hitler arrived in Finland today. The reason given for the visit is that Herr Hitler wanted to present personal congratulations to Field Marshal Carl Gustav Mannerheim on the latter's seventy-fifth birthday.

The hunt for rubber in the jungles of Brazil will be matched next week by a rubber hunt through the attics, cellars and closets of this city. It is a hunt that every householder can join. The crop to be garnered will no doubt prove surprising in variety. Let us hope that it will be rich in poundage as well.

THE bombing of Dutch Harbor by the Japs recalls that just a month ago there came with an Alaska postmark a letter from Eskie Clark, the former Harvard football star and later graduate manager of athletics at Lafayette. Eskie wrote in part:

Safe and wholesome food supply for the armed forces must be assured so that the Army of the United States will continue to be "the best fed army in the world," Brig. Gen. R.A. Kelser declared at yesterday's session of the annual conference of Food and Drug Officials of the United States at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Having themselves made all sorts of record streaks in the past the Yankees had no intention yesterday of interfering with the singular pitching string of Edgar Smith. The White Sox left-hander came into the Stadium with eight successive defeats and the cooperative New Yorkers gave him a helpful downhill push with an eight-run second inning for his ninth setback in a row.

The Japanese raid on Dutch Harbor may have been intended as a facesaving operation to impress the bombed population of Tokyo or a reconnoitering prelude to further attacks. Compared to the terrible armadas bombarding the German war forge on the Rhine, or even to the American bombing of Japan, the first stab at the Aleutian Islands was a mere pin-prick.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Senator Wheeler of Montana said today that the last obstacle had been removed to State Department negotiations with the government of Mexico for importation of Mexican laborers to work in the West's sugar beet fields.

Continuation of the strike of 250 A.F. of L. electricians at Floyd Bennett Field will force a shutdown of all construction on the Navy's $8,120,000 program for the expansion of the Brooklyn air has within a week, officials in charge of the project warned yesterday.

Declaring that the Army and Navy "come first" in the need for able-bodied men, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, director of Selective Service for New York City, warned industry yesterday that within six months "tens of thousands" of young, semi-skilled workers would be called for military service.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., estimated yesterday its earnings for the first quarter ended on April 4 at $2,915,000, after interest, and estimated provision for all Federal taxes and other charges, and after including $544,000, representing the company's direct and indirect net interest, as a stockholder, in the combined undistributed earnings, for the quarter, of partially owned non-consolidated subsidiaries, and 5130,000 of non-recurring income.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, June 4 -- A United Nations submarine, presumably American, on cruise somewhere in the Japanese ship lanes, was credited officially tonight with the destruction or damaging of four enemy ships totaling 29,000 tons -- one of them an overloaded troopship that went down with possibly as many as 12,000 Japanese soldiers.

CHUNGKING, China, June 4 (U.P.) -- Chinese defenders of Chekiang, waging fierce battles that cost the Japanese 2,000 casualties yesterday, are closing in on recently captured Kinhwa from three sides and are making a determined stand in the outskirts of Chuhsien, forty-five miles to the southwest, it was reported tonight.
LONDON, Friday, June 5 -- Flying right around the clock, the Royal Air Force kept up an almost incessant attack against the Nazis Wednesday night and all day yesterday.

An arbitration board headed by Raymond P. McNulty, impartial chairman in the administration of the contract between the Publishers Association of New York City and the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, gave blanket approval yesterday to the plans put forward by the various newspapers for conserving gasoline and rubber through combination deliveries but ruled that all such plans must be put into effect without eliminating any jobs.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 4 -- Sandstorms so terrible that they choked men's throats and buried vehicles hub-deep forced a comparative lull yesterday in the great Libyan tank battle that has been raging with only brief let-ups for more than a week, but whenever there was even a slight easing in the blow Royal Air Force planes continued their attacks on the enemy fighting forces and supply columns.

CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- Kenesaw Mountain Landis, commissioner of baseball, cracked down today on commercial promotion of exhibition games that may interfere with, the remaining series of major league contests devoted to Army and Navy relief.

Universal's 1942-43 production schedule will include fifty-five feature pictures, plus seven Western dramas, sixty-five short subjects, two special "featurettes" and 104 issues of the Universal newsreel, it was announced yesterday by William A. Scully, vice president and general sales manager, at the company's annual sales convention in the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 30 totaled 795,756 cars, the Association of Ameriican Railroads announced today. This was 41,992 cars, or 5.0 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week and 6,027 cars, or 0.8 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, but 156,636 cars, or 24.5 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 4 -- Reinhard Heydrich, deputy Gestapo chief and former Reich Deputy Protector of Bohemia-Moravia, died early this morning in Prague Hospital one week and one day after the attack on his automobile by two Czech patriots at Rokitzan last Wednesday afternoon.
CHICAGO, June 4 -- A rousing home run by Willard Marshall into the right field bleachers enabled the Giants to sink the Cubs in eleven innings today, 4 to 3.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Department stores' sales for the week ended May 30 were down 11 per cent compared with the corresponding period last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. It was the second consecutive week that a drop had been reported, a decline of 2 per cent having been recorded for the week ended May 23.

Ezio Pinza, leading basso of the Metropolitan Opera Company, was released from Ellis Island on May 28 after having been held in custody as an enemy alien of possibly dangerous character since March 12, it was revealed yesterday. On the basis of investigations by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and evidence gathered by an Alien Enemy Hearing Board, he has been released to resume his career.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Office of Price Administration today announced a method for pricing textile, leather, fur and rubber fabrics and apparel sold to war procurement agencies which allows the seller to include increases in labor and material costs.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Japanese bombers today struck at Midway Island, lying northwest of Hawaii on the route to Japan, within twenty-four hours after the foray against Dutch Harbor, in the Aleutian Islands, and a later reconnaissance flight over that base.

LONDON, June 4 -- A treaty under which Belgian forces in a vital part of Africa will operate under the orders of the United Nations High Command was signed today in London by Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Britain.
LOS ANGELES, June 4 (AP) -- Dr. Hans Helmut Gros, 34, German-educated native of Minneapolis, and his Kansas-born wife, Frances Goellert Gros, 31, were convicted of espionage today.

A German submarine commanded by an Italian officer sank a medium-sized British merchant ship in the Gulf of Mexico May 27, survivors of the ship told The Associated Press in Key West, Fla., yesterday. The ship was one of three acknowledged lost in a report by the Navy Department.

BOSTON, June 4 -- Some thoroughbreds just naturally can't run in mud and so Suffolk Downs stewards, with applause from the legion of two-buck bettors, have given racing a new wrinkle by ordering the automatic scratching of non-mudders whenever the going becomes heavy at the local race course.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (U.P.) -- Wood, plywood, plastics, steel and fabric are being used in increasing quantities in the manufacture of training planes to save aluminum and other strategic materials for combat types, the War Department said today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission instituted proceedings today against the Southern Union Gas Company to determine what action is necessary against it under the "death sentence" clause of the Holding Company Act.

Changes on No. 153 May Be Due Modifications of the seasonal order No. 153 covering women's and children's outer apparel may make their appearance today or tomorrow, reports in the garment trade here indicated yesterday. Trade association officials continued their conferences in Washington yesterday, but nothing definite was known here as to the scope of the changes.

In five months as a prisoner of war, most of it in the hands of the Italians, I was treated almost with perfect courtesy and often, indeed, with much kindness. This, I believe, is the experience of most British prisoners of the Italians, certainly of British officer prisoners.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Something should be done to improve the bus system going especially toward Broad Channel, Rockaway and Far Rockaway.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Many of the 12,500 idle shipyard and ship repair workers in the Port of New York will be employed on ship repair, maintenance and conversion.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 4 -- The Socialist Party today revealed a definite stand in favor of breaking off relations with the Axis when Julio Barrenechea, a member of the Chamber of Deputies and of the committee appointed by Congress to investigate Nazi activities, recommended in the presence of more than 10,000 supporters, that Chile abandon her neutrality.

The war demands on the home front self-restraint before anything else. As the President has pointed out and as Secretary Morgenthau re-emphasized in the first of his series of talks on the national economic program, we all have a duty to refrain from nonessential spending, to save, and to shoulder heavier taxes.
Organizations that are urging the early opening of a western front in Europe will carry their campaign into the "New York at War" parade up Fifth Avenue on June 13, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Secretary Morgenthau and the Ways and Means Committee made "peace" tonight after the committee had called him to explain his remark in a radio address last night that the war revenue bill as it stands, might prove "too little and too late."

CHUNGKING, China, June 4 (AP) -- The ranking United States commanders in Southeast Asia gathered here tonight for war conferences with China's Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek against a background of press appeals for the United States to take the initiative in an immediate land, sea and air offensive against Japan.

ALBANY, June 4 (AP) -- The Christian Church can back America's war effort without mental reservation, but "coupled with prayer for victory must be a public prayer lifted for the whole human race," the Rev. Simon Blocker of Holland, Mich., retiring president, told the general synod of the Reformed Church in America tonight.
JERSEY CITY, June 4 (AP) -- Rochester snapped Jersey City's winning streak at four straight today by defeating the Little Giants, 4 to 1, in the opener of a four-game series.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- Mr. Lansburgh, whose home was in suburban Swarthmore, was a director of the Philadelphia Committee of the Pennsylvania Economy League and served in the Cabinet of Governor Gifford Pinchot from 1924 until 1927.

While paying high tribute to the leadership of President Roosevelt in the present national and international crisis, Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, took issue last night with those who, like former President Hoover in a recent speech, favor granting dictatorial powers to the President.

Antoine de St. Exupery, author of the best seller, "Flight to Arras," who has been in Canada for the last six weeks because of his confusion over visas (he had gone to Canada to make one lecture in Montreal), was readmitted to the United States yesterday, it has been learned.

How Graduates Operates To introduce a serious theme lightly, there was a brisk little comedy by one of the classic French writers of the nineteenth century which was a favorite text in our high school French classes for a great many years; and may yet be, for aught we know.

A total of $1,421 was raised for the Red Cross and the Treasury yesterday by fifty-seven children of the seventh grade of the Hunter College Elementary School, it was announced by Dr. Florence Brumbaugh, principal. The pupils arranged and directed an "All-out Victory Day" to show how they could play their part in winning the war.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Secretary Morgenthau and the Ways and Means Committee made "peace" tonight after the committee had called him to explain his remark in a radio address last night that the war revenue bill as it stands, might prove "too little and too late."

CHUNGKING, China, June 4 (AP) -- The ranking United States commanders in Southeast Asia gathered here tonight for war conferences with China's Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek against a background of press appeals for the United States to take the initiative in an immediate land, sea and air offensive against Japan.

ALBANY, June 4 (AP) -- The Christian Church can back America's war effort without mental reservation, but "coupled with prayer for victory must be a public prayer lifted for the whole human race," the Rev. Simon Blocker of Holland, Mich., retiring president, told the general synod of the Reformed Church in America tonight.

A "surprise evacuation from the Episcopal Church of the Holy Nativity, Bainbridge Avenue and 204th Street, the Bronx, into its basement auditorium, which has been reinforced as an air raid shelter, will be staged this Summer at several Sunday morning services.

To meet the increasing demands of the Navy in the ship production field, the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, expanded along the East River into Queens territory yesterday, when the former stone-cutting plant of William Bradley Son, 40-20 Vernon Boulevard, Long Island City, was commissioned formally by Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart, commandant of the Third Naval District.

Hope that cancer hospitals may become, in the not-too-distant future, "a haven of hope instead of a place to die" was expressed yesterday by Dr. Ralph I. Lloyd. president of the American Academy of Ophthalmology and Otolaryngology, who spoke at the eighty-second annual commencement exercises of the New York Medical College, Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals, in the auditorium of the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.
OTTAWA, June 5 -- A Royal Commission reported to Parliament today that 212 vehicles intended for the Canadian expeditionary force in Hong Kong had been diverted by United States naval authorities.
LONDON, Saturday, June 6 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique early today:

The first meeting of the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission was held yesterday in this city at the Hotel Roosevelt. It brought together representatives from eight States, with Virginia, although a member, not being represented.

No shipments of United States currency were made to Cuba in May, the first time this has occurred in many months, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York revealed yesterday in its monthly report of currency shipments. Heretofore heavy monthly shipments to Cuba have been made chiefly in large-denomination bills, indicating a hoarding demand, chiefly by foreigners in Cuba.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 5 -- The first Cologne newspapers since the big Royal Air Force raid there last Saturday night reached neutral territory today, carrying the somber statement that the historic Rhineland city, as its people had Known it, was "forever lost."

CHICAGO, June 5 -- After being heavy and sharply lower in the early trading, the wheat market turned strong at the end of the session and closed unchanged to 1/8 cent a bushel lower. Buying by mills on the declines again helped to steady the market and shorts again found offerings light when they tried to cover.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Chairman Somers of New York said today that "shocking revelations" laid before the House Coinage Committee indicated that the "big four" rubber companies were impeding the President's war program.
