WASHINGTON, June 5 -- With creation of the powerful WPB Food Requirements Committee focusing new attention on present and prospective food supplies, Agriculture Department officials emphasized today that it should not be assumed that food shortages or consumer rationing of most foods is in prospect.

NEWARK, N.J., June 5 (AP) -- Night baseball groped through another siege of uncertainty at Ruppert Stadium tonight as the Bears dropped a 9-to-6 decision to Buffalo before 3,684 fans. Its continuance was placed entirely up to Army authorities and local defense officials.
An enormous figure of Death, with the Hitlerian brush of hair across the skull, is taking shape in the backyard of a children's nursery in Greenwich Village.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that Bernard M. Baruch would head a large committee of New Yorkers to make plans for a welcoming parade and rally for a score of British and American heroes on Monday.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, June 5 -- As the climax of a disastrous week for the Japanese in the waters off Australia, United Nations Headquarters announced tonight that aircraft of one Netherland and two Australian squadrons, on reconnaissance off the east coast, discovered three enemy submarines on the surface in widely separated localities and that in the ensuing attacks two of the submarines were certainly destroyed and the third probably sunk.
PITTSBURGH, June 5 (AP) -- The Pirates finally broke their ten-game losing streak today, beating the Phils, 6 -- 5. They had to rally twice.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Quiet strength marked the session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and gains scored early in the day were maintained to the close. Steel, copper, shipbuilding and chemical shares paced trading, which saw a turnover of 486,170 shares and the third upward market in a row.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 5 (AP) -- A British Headquarters communique said today:

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Oliver Lyttelton, Britain's Minister of Production, said today that the object of his visit to this country was the "integration" of British war production with that of the United States through establishment of a joint production agency.

A young woman investigator for the State gave the opening testimony yesterday at the Special Sessions trial of Rudolph Rebold, a chemist, of 116 East Fifty-eighth Street, and Mrs. Eveline Dolin of 379 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, for allegedly unlawfully practicing medicine and operating the clinic of the Body and Mind Foundation, which is in a converted garage in Bast Sixty-ninth Street.

Pre-Flag Day sermons will be preached tomorrow marking the opening of "Flag Week." Clergymen will comment on the bombing this week by the Japanese of Dutch Harbor, Alaska, and Midway Island. In some churches announcement will be made that because of the war usual services will not be curtailed during the Summer, the idea being that there is need for the spiritual uplift that public worship gives.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- An explosion of hundreds of tons of TNT-loaded munitions early this morning at the Elwood Ordnance Plant south of Joliet, Ill., one of several Midwest bomb-loading and storage centers, took a death toll of nearly fifty-five, according to Army estimates.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Establishment of a strong second front in Europe, led by American troops, would result in the world's biggest uprig of "fifth columnists" in occupied and unoccupied France, it was reported in responsible quarters today.

Trade Better Despite Weather While unfavorable weather held back expansion of consumer interest in seasonal merchandise this week, retail trade here probably fared better in comparison with a year ago than in the two preceding weeks.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times:

LONDON, June 5 -- When Summer came to London in the middle of last month, followed by a "heat wave," which means that it was moderately warm, many girls and women overcame the stocking shortage by wearing none.

General Ayres Rated as one of the nation's leading economists-some circles call him the best-Brig. Gen. Leonard P. Ayres, who has been chief of the service of statistics of the War Department since the Autumn of 1940, is to be relieved of his duties on June 30 because he has reached the retirement age of 62 years.

Thurman Arnold, Assistant United States Attorney General, gave an optimistic view yesterday of the post-war situation in this country and predicted a business revival unequaled since the Napoleonic wars.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A nine-man committee was set up by the War Production Board today to exercise full control over the production and allocation of all civilian and military food supplies.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The House voted today to abolish the Civilian Conservation Corps, at least for the duration of the war, and approved a $500,000 fund to effect its liquidation.

HONOLULU, June 5 (AP) -- Mention in Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's communique tonight of the presence of transports among the attacking naval forces added support to the belief that the purpose of the invaders was to seize Midway, removing the last island barrier in the Pacific between Japan and Hawaii.

While the President and high government officials conferred yesterday on the automobile-gasoline-rubber situation, a group of about 100 Congressmen angrily denounced the confusion and lack of "facts" surrounding our rubber shortage and resolved to oppose nation-wide gasoline rationing until the need was made clear to them.

CHUNGKING, China, June 5 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command announced tonight that the Japanese had hurled 100,000 troops in fierce new onslaughts against the walled defenses of Chuhsien, but said the Western Chekiang rail town still held but as a barrier to a broadened scheme of Japanese conquest.

"Here we go again," 17-year-old Victor Haggith of Wembley, England, the "youngest gunner in the British merchant marine," observed with great calmness to his Scottish chum, Frank McMillen, 15, as the torpedo tore into the ship and, sure enough, in a few minutes they were out on the sea again.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 5 -- The executions of thirty more persons today in Czechoslovakia, including nineteen men and three women in Prague and six men and two women in Bruenn, brought the total of "reprisal executions" for the attacks on Reinhard Heydrich to the ratio of 208 to 1, believed to be a new high for any German-occupied country.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- A furious and complicated tenth-inning rally by the Cubs today gave them a 4-3 triumph over the Dodgers and an even break on the day. The Durocher boys took the opener, 6 -- 3, to give Whit Wyatt his fifth victory of the campaign.

OTTAWA, June 5 -- Justifying the title coined by President Roosevelt describing Canada as the "airdrome of democracy," an agreement signed today by representatives of the Canadian, British, Australian and New Zealand Governments provides for still further expansion and improvement of the Commonwealth air training plan that has produced many thousands of the air crews now daily engaged in bombing Germany and fighting Nazi planes in France and Libya.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- High officials, meeting with President Roosevelt today, agreed that nation-wide gasoline rationing to conserve tires should not be undertaken until an inventory of the amount of reclaimable rubber in the country was completed.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Agitation over gasoline rationing to conserve rubber is hastening the search by finance companies for other avenues of employment for their funds, a check of conditions here revealed. Used-car sales, which at one time were relied upon as an offset to the loss of new-car installment paper, are much slower and some softening of prices has resulted.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A national conference aiming at stabilization of the wages of the million employes of the aircraft industry is near, according to reports today at the War Production Board.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- A proposal to manufacture rubber from alcohol produced from grain as a means of solving the rubber and gasoline shortages and the farm problem all at the same time was put forward by Alfred M. Landon, former Governor of Kansas, in an address before the Executive Club today.

A closed court hearing under rarely invoked statutes in which seven principal witnesses refused to give testimony, five even refusing to be sworn, and with an adjournment being taken without public indication as to possible subsequent delopments marked the progress yesterday of a proceeding designed to determine whether Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen of Brooklyn should be examined on charges of willful neglect and omission of duty.

Addition of many more items to the rationing list was forecast by Mayor La Guardia yesterday afternoon when he shared the platform with spokesmen for the OPA at a community conference held by the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office of Greater New York at the Hotel Astor.

Indifferent trade demand and resumption of selling by New Orleans interests were held mainly responsible for a decline in cotton futures yesterday. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange lost early gains of 7 to 10 points and closed 15 to 16 points below Thursday's final prices.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 5 -- Paramount announced today that "Star-Spangled Rhythm," with Victor Moore, Betty Hutton and Eddie Bracken, will take the form of an all-star musical. A service men's show presented on the Paramount lot has been written into the script, and Bob Hope has been cast as the master of ceremonies.

TOKYO, June 5 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in New York) -- Japanese Imperial Headquarters reported today that special submarine units of the Japanese Navy made a surprise attack on Diego Suarez, Madagascar, at dawn May 31, torpedoing and seriously damaging a British battleship of the Queen Elizabeth class and a light cruiser of the Arethusa class.

The week-old strike of 250 A.F. of L. electricians that has retarded work on the Navy's 58,120,000 expansion program at Floyd Bennett Field will be certified to the National War Labor Board by Secretary of Labor Perkins, according to informal advices received here yesterday.

SEIGNIORY CLUB, Que., June 5 (Canadian Press) -- Harry Salinger of New York was re-elected today president of the Banker's Association for Foreign Trade as the association ended its twentieth annual meeting and its first one here.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (AP) -- Walt Judnich's triple and Chet Laabs's long fly gave the Browns a 1-to-0, sixteen-inning victory over the Athletics in an exciting game at Shibe Park tonight before 10,777.
TOKYO, June 5 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- An Imperial Headquarters communique said today:

With rapid-fire precision the Army swung into action yesterday in the first mammoth move to select from 2,000 candidates in this area sixty women to fill officers' posts in the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 5 -- Removal of social bars against women workers in war factories and acceptance of them on the same plane as soldiers and sailors at community functions was urged at today's session of the National Conference of Jewish Social Welfare Workers.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (U.P.) -- A Navy spokesman, denying rumors of air raids on Pearl Harbor, declared at 4:25 P.M. today that "all has been, and is up to this time, quiet there."

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- James M. Carry, assistant to the operating vice president of the Pullman Company, testified today in Federal court that profits from the sleeping-car business today were in some instances only one-fifteenth what they were near the turn of the century.

With next week designated as Civilian Defense Week, James G. Blaine, chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, appealed yesterday for the immediate enrollment of 140,000 additional volunteers to fill gaps in the defense organization.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- The Lone Star Gas Corporation moved today a step nearer compliance with the integration section of the "death-sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company act when the Securities and Exchange Commission approved a plan through which the Northwest Cities Gas Company would be divorced from its parent.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations proposed today that a basis for organic unity with the American Federation of Labor be established by means of a United Labor Council to be created at a joint session of the executive boards of the two labor organizations.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., June 5 -- A formal guard mount and a review of 250 uniformed members of the American Women's Voluntary Services were held here today to mark the opening of a new pass house at the Stewart Avenue Gate.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- President Roosevelt, at a press conference, warned that the United States would retaliate if Japan persisted in using poison gas against China or others in the United Nations. He signed the resolutions recognizing the existence of a state of war between the United States and Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Development of air raid protection plans for industrial plants not owned by the government or engaged on war or Navy contracts through the cooperative action of joint employeremploye committees was urged today by James M. Landis, Director of the Office of Civilian Defense, in a message to regional directors.

In a report which she submitted recently to Congress Miss Katherine F. Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau, called attention to a powder plant in Oklahoma which is being erected in a community of 500 and which will employ 10,000 workers. There is now only one physician in the whole area, and he is 75 years old.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 5 (AP) -- The Federal court today authorized trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, in reorganization, to pay $13,645,605 in bond interest, an increase of $974,000 over the amount named in the original petition filed on May 21.

All deliveries from 375 department stores and specialty shops in the metropolitan district were halted yesterday by a labor dispute involving 1,300 drivers and distribution employes of the United Parcel Service. Efforts by the State Mediation Board to settle the controversy proved fruitless, but the board announced that it would continue its efforts today.

The world's greatest city was blacked out for twenty minutes under a clear, starlit sky last night, in the first practice drill to include all five boroughs. New York's more than 7,000,000 residents and the strangers within the gates together demonstrated they understand the need for cooperation.

LONDON, June 5 -- It was announced today that the biggest convoy ever to reach India and possibly the greatest ever to leave Britain had arrived in India early last month. The long trip around Africa was completed without mishap or loss.

Lefty Al Smith made a serious mistake yesterday at the Stadium. Shouldering the pitching burden for the Indians before a Ladies' Day gathering of 15,247, he tried to spot the Yankees three runs as he swung into action against Lefty Vernon Gomez.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., June 5 -- Forced into the background by the brilliant performance of their brother Jimmy, Fort Dix corporal, in the recent Professional Golfers Association championship at Atlantic City last week, three of the other five pros in the famous Turnesa golf family bore down in today's qualifying test at the Forest Hill Field Club for places in the Hale America open tourney to be held in Chicago two weeks hence.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Proposals of an American technical mission for increasing the war effort in India have encountered objections from the Indian Government on many points, it was disclosed here today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- Another attempt by a public utility holding company to use the war as an excuse for suspending "death sentence" proceedings against it by the Securities and Exchange Commission met with failure today when such a motion was denied the United Corporation.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., June 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. Donald Scott of this place tonight gave a dance, preceded by a small dinner, at the Short Hills Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Dorothy Embree Scott. The clubhouse was decorated for the occasion with greens interspersed with white, peach-pink and yellow blossoms.

The Ruda Realty Corporation has purchased the plant at Waverly Avenue and Somerset Street, in Newark, N.J., from the Uptown Building and Loan Association of Newark, in liquidation, for the manufacture of food products for the Federal Government.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 5 (AP) -- Jersey City defeated Rochester tonight in a double-header, 1 to 0 and 5 to 2.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 5 -- A four-motored Army bomber, flown by a five-man civilian crew and carrying nine Army enlisted men, crashed in a flaming wreckage at Hamilton Field, near here, last night, as an emergency landing was attempted.

There will be two closings on Broadway this evening, "Spring Again" and "The Moon is Down." The former attraction ends its run at the Playhouse after 240 performances and will resume at the same theatre on Labor Day for a three-week stand.

Naval officers of the Eastern sea frontier, a wreck-littered stretch of 1,200 miles extending from Canada to Jacksonville, Fla., said yesterday that the submarine menace in this district was steadily decreasing and that steps were being taken that would insure more gasoline for the drying New England States.

LONDON, Saturday, June 6 -- Soon after daybreak yesterday the Royal Air Force began a series of sweeps across the Channel with hundreds of fighters and fast bombers that developed into what British officials last night indicated was one of the greatest offensives yet carried out against the Nazis in occupied France and the Low Countries.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 5 (U.P.) -- Pacific Coast defense units remained on the alert tonight for the third straight night against the possibility of a Japanese attack following Wednesday's raid on Dutch Harbor.

MEXICO CITY, June 5 -- Mexico completed her alignment with the United Nations tonight when the Foreign Minister, Ezequiel Padilla, announced that she would devote all her resources to winning the war against the Axis and would not make a separate peace.
CHUNGKING, China, June 5 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command said tonight in a communique:

A warning that international cartels will seek a negotiated peace so that they can continue to do business with a powerful Germany was sounded last night by Thurman W. Arnold, assistant Attorney General of the United States, in an address at the annual banquet of the National Federation of Sales Executives at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, June 5 -- Trading in the stock market slackened today, but some bright spots were noted. Gilt-edge issues remained firm, and home rails made a good showing, with junior securities gaining 1/8 to 1-16.

Thomas J. Curran, Republican county chairman, announced yesterday that the Republican party of New York County would not endorse Representative Vito Marcantonio for re-election in the Twentieth Congressional District on the ground that he had followed the Communist party line and voted against every national defense bill before the invasion of Russia by Germany.

ROSCOE, N.Y., June 5 -- Thomas E. Dewey, probable Republican nominee for Governor, declared here tonight that the Republican party Was "unalterably opposed" to partisan politics during the war and would use the full strength of its power "to correct and expose any blunders" by the National Administration which might impair the all-out war effort.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 5 -- Mrs. Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, runner-up a year ago, and Mrs. Ruth Torgerson of the home club will meet tomorrow in the thirty-six-hole final of the women's metropolitan golf championship at the Lakeville Club.

The sharp dip in men's clothing sales during the current quarter is not only due to trading uncertainties created by pending government price and inventory restrictions on Fall goods, but the marked caution shown by the consumer since the latter days of April.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Lord Louis Mountbatten, a cousin of King George VI and head of the Commando units which have made spectacular raids on Nazi-held coastal points, told reporters today that he could not sufficiently impress upon them "the real, mad, keen desire every one I've, come across in Britain has to come to grips with the enemy."

A tall fellow who knows his way around the sports field stopped by for a few minutes. He was pitching for the USO. He threw no curves. All straight stuff. The USO is making a drive to collect $32,000,000 this year. That's a lot of money but it's needed for the work that the USO is doing for the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Senate and House conferees reached a compromise today on the soldiers and sailors pay bill, fixing the minimum base pay at $46 a month, half way between the $42 proposed by the Senate and the $50 on which the House insisted.

The people of both occupied and unoccupied France welcome Britain's bombing of French objectives, and only 1 per cent of them favor the Nazis, according to Professor Robert Le Bidois, who arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday aboard a Pan American Airways Clipper.

DETROIT, June 5 (AP) -- A vast national stockpile of 10,000,000 tons of scrap metal must be attained through salvage to keep steel production at its present level through next Winter, Charles H. McArthur, chief of the industrial salvage section of the Bureau of Industrial Conservation, told a press conference here today.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- President Roosevelt warned the Japanese Government today that the United States would retaliate with the use of poison gas "if Japan persists in this inhuman form of warfare against China or against any other of the United Nations."

Disdaining the light, lyrical themes of youth, Spring or love, New York City high school students, competing for honors at the annual poetry contest yesterday, adopted a realistic, severe motif, reflecting the serious times in which we live.

CINCINNATI, June 5 (AP) -- The Reds, concentrating their batting power in two innings, swept a double-header with the Braves today, 3 to 2 and 6 to 1.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 5 -- The slate of candidates headed by President Richard F. Walsh of Brooklyn was put back into office by an overwhelming vote today at the closing session of the convention of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and Moving Picture Machine Operators (A.F.L.).

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission received today an application by the California-Oregon Power Company and the Standard Gas and Electric Company for the proposed recapitalization of the former through a capital contribution by Standard Gas of $3,215,600 of California-Oregon's outstanding indebtedness for cancellation.

Two midtown theatres will present new films this morning. At the Rivoli the newcomer will be "Miss Annie Rooney," an Edward Small production starring Shirley Temple. Also cast in the film, which is released through United Artists, are William Gargan, Gloria Holden, Guy Kibbee, Dickie Moore and Peggy Ryan.

ST. LOUIS, June 5 -- Johnny Mize gave St. Louis occasion to rue the day it sold the big fellow to New York last Winter by exploding a home run tonight, his sixth of the campaign, to help Mel Ott's Giants defeat the Cardinals in the opening engagement of a four-game series, 3 to 1.

Today marks the end of six months of our active participation in the war. They are not months which we can afford to look back upon with complacency. They have been spent for the most part on the defensive and are marked in the main by defeat and withdrawal.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Rookie Pitcher Hal White issued two bases on balls in the tenth inning to force in the winning run as the Senators defeated the Tigers, 3 to 2, before 10,000 fans tonight.

The Museum of Modern Art will hold a garden party and auction on June 16 to wind up its art sale for the benefit of the armed forces, which began on May 6. Before the garden party and auction the museum will hold at 7 o'clock a buffet supper for service men.

"The Problems of Lasting Peace," by Herbert Hoover and Hugh Gibson, originally due yesterday, will be published June 19 by Doubleday, Doran. The former President and ex-diplomat describe their book as "a sort of preface to peacemaking" that grows out of their fears that the mistakes of the past will be repeated.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 5 -- After two days of searing sandstorms in Libya, which made life almost unbearable in the desert, troops of both sides were suffering today from the heat, but nevertheless they continued to fight sporadically along the southern flank of the British defenses.

New bonds offered here this week aggregated $70,472,000, representing a well-diversified list compared with $20,932,000 marketed last week, and with $36,758,000 placed in this week a year ago. This week's volume was the largest since the period ended on April 24, when $105,550,000 was offered.

Nylon, the fabulous, has stepped out in a new and unexpected role. Its latest appearance is in a fleecy fabric that approximates camel's hair. It is rich, soft to the touch and has a silky hairlike surface. At a distance it might masquerade as wool fleece, but close inspection reveals that it is different in texture and feel.

That retailers have made an Important contribution to the war economy by holding prices down while the costs of raw materials were rising was impressed upon the graduating class of the Laboratory Institute of Fashion Merchandising by Mrs. Sara Pennoyer, vice president of Bonwit Teller, at a luncheon yesterday In the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

In answering a list of questions raised by the General Maximum Price Regulation, OPA disclosed yesterday that, although it has the power to require registration of wholesalers and retailers, there is no requirement at present to register.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by twenty-one municipalities and one public housing agency aggregates $5,253,300, compared with $24,525,735 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $25,951,309.

MOSCOW, Saturday, June 6 (AP) -- The Soviet Air Force was declared today to be pounding at Germany's Arctic airdromes in a major counter-attack on the Nazi air fleet that is trying to cut the midnight sun supply line from Russia's western allies.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Legislation to deprive of citizenship any Navy contractor convicted during wartime of defrauding the government by padding payrolls, or charging for worK done on private orders, was approved today by the Senate Naval Affairs Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The sales tax issue will be forced to a vote when the Ways and Means Committee takes up next week the general proposition of consumer taxes, Representative Robertson said today. He was seconded by Representative Disney, who declared that the $8,700,000,000 goal might even be increased by means of a general sales levy.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Office of Price Administration today established the maximum export premiums that may be charged for finished piece goods for shipment abroad at 6 per cent of the domestic maximum price on sales by a manufacturer or converter and 8 1/2 per cent for other types of sellers.

VICHY, France, June 5 (U.P) -- Young followers of Jacques Doriot, head of the anti-Semitic French Popular party, fought with Jews whom they attacked at prayers in a synagogue at Nice last night and later stoned windows of downtown Jewish-owned shops.

PEARL HARBOR, June 5 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the United States Pacific Fleet, announced in a communique tonight that the Japanese Fleet had been driven from the Midway Island area with heavy losses, including damage to several ships in each of the categories of battleship, carrier, cruise?

Twenty-three members of the Police Department and nineteen members of the Fire Department received medals of valor yesterday from Mayor La Guardia at exercises in City Hall Plaza in the presence of 3,000 persons. The Mayor also decorated the next of kin of five members of the Police Department who lost their lives in the performance of duty under conditions calling for personal bravery.

The Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, announced yesterday that its 2,100 members employed by the New York City Omnibus Corporation, have ratified a new two-year agreement covering wages, hours and working conditions and including an increase of six cents an hour for drivers, bringing their wage to $1 an hour, said to be the highest rate paid for similar work in the United States.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 5 -- Despite a drop in entries and attendance, attributable primarily to gasoline rationing, the Tuxedo horse show as usual had quality as a major characteristic today when this traditional equine fixture got away to a successful start.

BOSTON, June 5 (AP) -- The Red Sox survived a ninth-inning uprising by the White Sox today and won, 4 -- 2, after losing two straight to the Indians.

By an overwhelming vote Phi Delta Kappa, national professional educational fraternity, has approved an amendment to eliminate from its constitution the clause which barred membership to any but white males, Dr. George D. Weeks, chairman, of a Teachers College committee for the elimination of racial discrimination, announced yesterday.

Announcement was made yesterday that the garden apartment project known as Englewood Gardens at 25 Sheffield Avenue, near Grand Avenue, Englewood, N.J., would soon be ready for occupancy. A furnished model suite has been opened for inspection.

Wholesale markets remained inactive last week as retailers were checking over their stocks with a view to keeping in line with expected inventory controls, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

The first national conference of local chairmen and field workers of Bundles for Britain, Inc., which opens on Tuesday, will be concluded with a gala banquet Thursday night on the Pierre Roof. An experiment in high school teaching, in which subjects were made more meaningful to the students, has proved successful, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Morris Meister, principal of the Bronx High School of Science.

ROCHESTER, June 6 -- Solving the problems brought by the dislocation of our normal way of living and preparing the public mind for the problems which the post-war period will bring are the two main obligations resting upon social workers and educators today, Professor Salo W. Baron of Columbia University stated in an address before the National Conference of Jewish Social Welfare tonight.

Police last night broadcast an alarm for the apprehension of three men in a late model sedan who are believed to be responsible for cutting six cables on telephone poles in Queens since last Thursday, interrupting service to hundreds of telephones in the vicinity.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 6 -- The University of Virginia was the first stop on a cross-country tour of a film unit sent out by the Division of Information of the Office of Emergency Management to make a motion picture depicting the important contributions to the war effort being made by the universities and colleges of the nation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 6 -- The past week has brought air raids to Reich territory that official Berlin has, after some initial hesitation, chosen to acknowledge "equal" in intensity and destructiveness to the heaviest raids of the Luftwaffe against Great Britain in the long Battle of Britain, extending from the late Summer of 1940 down to the early Summer of 1941.

It was, of course, a case of immediate and mutual devotion between the little boy and the dog and so he stayed, though Mammy said darkly, "A puppy is always in mischief," and Mammy was right.

LONDON, June 5 -- The Miners Federation today said that the only solution of Britain's fuel problem would be to requisition the mines. Anything short of this step, William Lawther, the miners' chief, said, after a meeting of the mine workers' national executive, would fail to deliver coal.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Charging abuses by some government agencies of their privilege of obtaining draft deferments for essential officials and employes, the Tydings committee, investigating conditions within the executive branch, will call upon the Selective Service System to restudy the cases of about 1,000 Federal workers under 25 years of age who have been excused from call to military duty.

LONDON, June 6 -- All ships under the Netherland flag were requisitioned today for the United States and Britain. The ships will be held under charter to the British War Transport Ministry until six months after the war.

With one week remaining before the staging of the gala All-Sports Carnival for the benefit of the Army Emergency Fund and the Navy Relief Society at the Polo Grounds next Sunday, the program arranged for this blue ribbon event gets more attractive from day to day.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 6 -- What is expected to be a historic meeting in the annals of organized medicine in the United States will get under way here Monday afternoon with the opening of the ninety-third annual convention of the American Medical Association, largest medical organization in the world, with a membership of 120,000 physicians and surgeons.

Asserting that diversion of strategic material to non-essential civilian output "is sabotage of our war effort" Sydney Hogerton, deputy director in charge of operations, announced yesterday that a vigorous program of enforcement of priorities to insure maximum use of such materials is planned by the regional office here of the War Production Board.

Arthur S. Mawhinney, F.R.P.S., received the first award for his "Champion Stingo of Shotten of Greenfair" in the annual Members Salon of the Miniature Camera Club of New York, judged by Dr. D.J. Ruzicka, F.R.P.S., F.P.S.A., Dr. Orrin S. Wightman, F.R.P.S., and John Magee, A.R.P.S. Second award went to Joe Pichler for "Cloister Study"; third to Hans Kaden for "Break of Day."

This is the year to treat exceptionally well any one who invites you to the country for a week-end. Reasons ought to be obvious. For one thing, because they mean extra use of gas and tires, and guests should be duly grateful. For another, a week-end out of town is something special when there are so many obstacles in the way of vacations as usual.

Baccalaureate exercises of New York University's 110th annual commencement program will be held at 4 P.M. today in the chapel of the Gould Memorial Library on University Heights. Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase will preside and the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, minister of Christ Church and member of the university council, will deliver an address, "The Road Leads On."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 6 -- Recognizing the serious lack of trained city and regional planning personnel existing throughout the country, and foreseeing a more acute shortage of such specialists after the war, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today announced a four-year course leading to the degree of Bachelor in City Planning.

The appointment of three assistant deputy administrators of the War Shipping Administration to serve under recently appointed Deputy Administrator Lewis W. Douglas was announced last week by Admiral Emory S. Land, administrator.

With more than 600 speakers enrolled and dozens of special events and demonstrations scheduled, plans for the city-wide recruiting drive to mark observance of Civilian Defense Week, proclaimed by Mayor La Guardia for tomorrow through Saturday this week, were completed yesterday by the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -Ten days ago, and again on last Thursday, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson warned Americans that they must be prepared for the war's being brought directly home to them by enemy bombers at any moment.

With the deadline for voluntary action on the part of landlords to control rents coming nearer and nearer, realty interests in the New York area are keeping their fingers crossed as they await the decision of the Office of Price Administration on rent freezing here.

THE Symphony Orchestra of Mexico, under Carlos Chavez, will open its fifteenth season, Friday night, in the Palace of Fine Arts, Mexico City. This year an enlarged program will embrace a fourteen-week subscription series on Friday nights and Sunday mornings; children's concerts on Saturday afternoons; a popular-priced series on Saturday evenings, and four special concerts, bringing the total to forty concerts.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., June 6 -- Warning that the Middle West and the nation generally face the greatest shortage of school teachers in history, Registrar Harry E. Elder of Indiana State Teachers College said today that steps should be taken immediately to relieve the situation.

MILWAUKEE, June 6 (AP) -- Pittsburgh's Harold Stickel scored a brilliant triple tonight in Marquette Stadium to share honors with Wisconsin, which won the seventeenth annual Central Collegiate Conference track and field title with 27 29-30 points.

TOKYO, June 6 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The capture of the walled city of Chuhsien in Chekiang after a three-day offensive was announced by the Japanese tonight.

ST. LOUIS, June 6 -- The Giants, victors in eight of their last ten games, a spurt that suddenly has catapulted them into the first division again, had to stand idly by today when playing conditions caused postponement of the second game of their series with the second-place Cardinals.

A two-day program of events, held for the benefit of the Army and Navy relief societies, will be the highlight of the annual rose festival at the rose breeding and testing gardens of Jackson Perkins, Newark, N.Y. The festival, "a month of roses," will continue from June 10 to July 5.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Dahlias put in now will start growth vigorously and come along in time for Pall shows..... Annuals for late bloom keep the garden colorful after most perennials are through flowering; among those that can be sown at this time are Sweet Alyssum, babies' breath, mignonette, scabiosa, dwarf zinnias, marigolds and many others.

OTTAWA, June 6 -- During the past week Canadians have come to feel more than ever before that they are really in the war. The long, weary time of preparation and training is over and thousands of Canadian-born and Canadiantrained airmen have shared in the great air offensive against Cologne, the Ruhr and the Nazi-occupied harbors and industries of Northern France.
WASHINGTON. JOSEPH BARTLETT EASTMAN'S idea of being late to work is to get to his office at 8:30 A.M. When he knocks off as early as 10 P.M. he calls it a short day.

THE annual American Folksong Festival will be held June 14 at Traipsin' Woman Cabin on Four Mile Fork of Garner, just off the Mayo Trail in the Kentucky foothills. Jean Thomas will direct the festival, which again will take the form of an old-fashioned "singin' gatherin'" of native mountaineer singers and players of instruments.

RANDOLPH, Vt. -- Tiny sailboats on cool inland waters are going to beckon to gasless customers during the hot vacation weeks, for a sailboat's fuel can't be metered or shut off. Since inland waters are innumerable, only one, Lake Champlain, is selected here for an example.

With Corporal Joe Louis as one of the honor guests and more than 5,000 persons in attendance, the New York-USO-Joint War Appeal yesterday afternoon launched its Harlem-Riverside campaign at a rally outside the USO clubhouse on Seventh Avenue between 137th and 138th Streets.

Intensive training of interpreters in Iranian languages and Russian as part of the nation's total war program has been added to their courses by American universities and educational institutions under a program sponsored by the American Council of Learned Societies.

Undismayed by the assertion of County Chairman Thomas J. Curran that the Republican organization of New York County would not endorse him for re-election in the Twentieth Congressional District, on the ground that he has followed the Communist party line, Representative Vito Marcantonio announced yesterday that he would enter the primaries of all three legal political parties.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6 (AP) -- Despite a seventh-inning rally that netted four runs, the Browns were defeated by the Athletics, 6 -- 5, today and thus were kept from moving into fourth place in the American League.

A new home center known as Broad Ridge at Flower Hill on the North Shore of Long Island in the Port Washington region will be formally opened today, announces Lawrence Carry, developer. Eleven houses, recently completed, will be ready for inspection.

Charley Schroeder gave five hits, three in the opening frame, as St. John's Prep, Brooklyn champion, gained the city C.H.S.A.A. baseball final play-off yesterday by halting St. Ann's Academy, Manhattan-Richmond ruler, 6 to 3, in a seven-inning battle at Fordham Field.

UNLIMITED and uninterrupted production is the challenge that now faces this country. On a score of fronts, millions of men are engaged in battle with the enemy. But mere numbers are not enough. They must have weapons and equipment -- shells, guns, tanks, bombers, ships.
NEW YORK Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador, is expected to arrive at the Waldorf-Astoria today.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 6 -- While the Czech inhabitants of the Bohemian and Moravian Protectorate continued to wait in agonized suspense today for some official inkling as to what the Germans' next move would be in retaliation for the assassination of Reinhard Heydrich, the special tribunal at Prague meted out another thirteen death sentences, which were immediately carried out.

"Atta boy, Admiral!" was shouted by a rail bird at Belmont Park yesterday when Vice Admiral Adolphus Andrews declared that the American fleet in the Pacific would win as Shut Out had just done in the Belmont Stakes, a race that first was run back before two other wars, when our country was recovering from the Civil War.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 6 -- Mr. and Mrs. Clarence J. Hunter of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Dunning Hunter, to Alfred Reynolds Wentworth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip M. Wentworth of New Rochelle, N.Y., formerly of Wellesley Hills.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Senator La Follette will move on Monday that the compromise on the base pay of men in the armed forces reached yesterday be recommitted with specific instructions.

THE name of Bard is a truly great name in the history of the American people, and the reasons for its greatness should be far better known than they have heretofore been." Nicholas Murray Butler introduces with these words the first biography of Dr. Samuel Bard to appear in 120 years.

LONDON, June 6 -- The United Nations must make the same energetic drive after the war to wipe out the social evils of poverty, sickness and unemployment as they are showing in their all-out effort to defeat fascism, United States Ambassador John G. Winant declared today in an address at Durham.

Good Cheer Persists Mark Twain said that his notion of a good library was one that didn't have anything in it by Jane Austen. This column's idea today of a good public speech or a good official statement or interview is one that has nothing to say about complacency.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Senate silver group, having recently reached "a friendly truce" with the Treasury Department for the release of an additional 53,000 tons of government-owned bullion, acquired at about 71 cents an ounce, for the replacement of copper in war industries, discussed today the drafting of legislation to increase the price to $1 an ounce.

There was something very peculiar about my treatment by the Gestapo, which I do not understand to this day. The fact that the Gestapo sent fairly important officials to escort me from the Italian border to Berlin and the fact that I was lodged in the de luxe prison in central Gestapo headquarters would imply that they considered me an important prisoner.

BOSTON. FOR a half hour last Sunday evening the decks of the United States Frigate Constitution, berthed in Boston Navy Yard, were peopled again with men who had yarns to tell, on behalf of "We the People at War," of daring naval exploits.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Establishment of the Foods Requirements Committee to control production and allocation of all civilian and military food supplies will not mean "meatless, wheatless or otherless days," Department of Agriculture officials said today.

NORWALK, Conn., June 6 -- Ruth Mitchell, sister of the late Brig. Gen. William (Billy) Mitchell, American aviator, is in a German concentration camp at Liebenau, Wuerttemberg, it was learned today from Mrs. Albert K. Yohn, her daughter.
Japanese attacks upon Dutch Harbor and Midway last week, and submarine attacks upon Sydney and our Australian supply lines possibly usher in a new phase of the Pacific War.

MAHOPAC, N.Y., June 6 -- Thomas E. Dewey, probable Republican nominee for Governor, carried the fight against the renomination of Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. into the Representative's home district today. He went on record as favoring the candidacy of Augustus W. Bennet of Newburgh, leading opponent of Mr. Fish in the August primaries.

PITTSBURGH, June 6 -- Modern steel-frame buildings offer the best protection against aerial bombs, V.G. Iden, secretary of the American Institute of Steel Construction, told the Building Officials Conference of America, Inc., here recently.

BOSTON, June 6 (AP) -- Dom DiMaggio, the first man Orval Grove faced, banged a home run today, but after that the 22-year-old Chicago right-hander had things pretty much his own way as the White Sox beat the Red Sox, 3 to 1.

Detailed As Inspector The following captain of police is detailed to act as inspector, with the title while so acting of inspector of police, is transferred and assigned as indicated. Designation as acting inspector revoked:

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 6 -- Brownie May, 22-year-old Lackawanna steel worker, scored a three-under-par 69 today to lead a stellar field in the opening eighteen-hole round of the fifty-four-hole Hale America golf sectional qualifying-play.

ONCE again Tecumseh has made his annual safari into the badlands where the drama critics whet their tomahawks to find out what they will be up to during the Summer months. One or two, he found, will hang close to the Broadway underbrush, hopeful of something happening.

WHEN EDWARD SMALL hasn't got at least a half dozen new films on his production schedule, that, in a manner of speaking, is news. Big news, in fact, to a lot of theatre owners, because if Mr. Small doesn't always produce art, with a capital A, his pictures have a nice habit of making money.

IF the jousting knights from the days of King Arthur and the Round Table could know about the exploits of the British and American air forces, they would rest content with the manner in which the canons of chivalry are being perpetuated.

Japan's air raid on Dutch Harbor, Alaska, was the "final shattering blow to the illusionism of those who until recently coddled themselves with the thought that oceans can protect us from air attacks," Rabbi Israel Goldstein declared yesterday in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, near Broadway.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 6 -- Mr. and Mrs. J.T. Gilman Nichols of Cambridge have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Gilman Nichols, to Gerald Burnett O'Grady Jr., son of Lieut, Col. and Mrs. O'Grady of Paterson, N.J.

June is the month of brides, with their retinue of frock-coated, ascottied and high-toppered gentlemen. But it is prooably the last June for the duration of the war in which the sartorial elegance of these bridegrooms, best men and ushers will be allowed to bloom unhampered.

An abrupt halt to virtually all abuse of gasoline rationing will occur next month. The many Eastern motorists who observed the spirit of the ration program will welcome the "coupon collection" system with which the Office of Price Administration Will enforce "permanent" rationing on an annual basis.

MARTHA POLEY has taken over the late Edward O'Brien's job of selecting the so-called "Best Short Stories" of each year. She said that she intended to keep the always rather annoying title for the annual, as it is a trademark by now, "though I do admit, of course, that they are just the stories that seem best to me.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- A new, full-fledged, destructive inter-labor war is on at a most unpropitious moment in American history. With national unity for the war effort at stake, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and its affiliate, the United Mine Workers of America, are engaged in a bitter, "all-out" struggle, whose repercussions may have far-reaching effects on war production.

With their export business reduced to a trickle, or dried up completely, manufacturers of items affected by the war emergency must now decide whether to disband their export staffs for the duration or to undertake the expense of maintaining such organizations in order to be prepared for post-war operations, it was said in the trade last week.

A new technique in coping with wartime have-you-heards was devised recently by sixty delegates from women's organizations on both sides of the Canadian border as they gathered around conference tables in Ottawa. Refraining from passing on wartime gossip is not enough, agreed the women, headed by Mrs. Carolyn Cox, chairman of the Canadian Committee on International Relations, and Mrs. Frederic Beggs, chairman of the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War.

FOR years it has been customary to view With periodic alarm the possible demise of the theatre. We have become so inured to her intermittent illnesses that we have come to accept her as a basically robust hypochondriac.

One of the most notable assemblages ever gathered at Belmont Park attended, yesterday afternoon, the final race program of the Spring meeting of the Westchester Racing Association to celebrate Army-Navy Day, a benefit for service relief agencies and the United Service Organizations.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- A conference committee failed today to agree on an amendment to the $680,000,000 Farm Appropriation Bill permitting the government to sell surplus wheat for livestock feeding at about 8 cents a bushel and decided to return the measure to the House.

A group of air raid wardens feebly concealing pride in their new official uniforms, the first to be delivered to the city, formed yesterday the vanguard of a fleet of "light rescue trucks" and emergency taxicabs that passed in review along the East River Drive at Twenty-second Street before Deputy Police Commissioner John H. Morris, head of the Warden Service.

Urban mortgage recordings of 520,000 or less advanced by about 7 per cent in amount during April over the March total, reports the Federal Home Loan Bank Administration. The aggregate amount of the April recordings was $359,968,000. Compared with April, 1941, there was a loss of 10 per cent, although the total was 6 per cent above the figures for April, 1940.

Often the home orchardist, after having waited two or three years for the first fruits of his labors, is disappointed when his young trees, after blossoming nicely, fail to set any fruit. In the majority of such cases the trouble is that a variety that is not self-fertile -- i.e.: one that must be cross-pollinated by some other variety -- has been planted by itself.

Executives of the United Parcel Service and of Local 804 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced their readiness yesterday to resume negotiations through the State Mediation Board. They said deliveries of 375 retail stores, except Macy's, were "completely shut down" for a second day in a labor dispute involving 1,300 drivers.

The Postoffice Departments at Washington, and Ottawa made available last week advance photographs of stamps which the United States and Canada will issue next month to serve as reminders that the neighbor countries are engaged in the conflict against the common enemy.

BENJAMIN FRANKLIN was first to break ground in so many different fields that their diversity is bewildering. He was the first great man to be born in the New England colonies and to become internationally known, the first to have the breadth of vision, the mental capacity and the generosity of purpose to think and plan for the nation that was coming into being.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Office of Censorship is concentrating at its Chicago station on the examination of mail to and from prisoners of war. It warned that such mail is subject to strict censorship and should include no military, naval or war production information.

FOR its final offerings of the season the National Academy has installed in its ivory tower mazes three exhibitions. One, of recent Diploma Works and Associate Portraits (the capitals seem gravely called for) in galleries A-4 and A-6 on the fourth floor, with fifty selected prints by Canadian artists as a pleasant interlude in Gallery A-5 between.

Held to a 3-all tie in its recent New York appearance, the touring Mexican Atlante soccer team will seek a more decisive outcome to its battle this afternoon when it faces an All-Star squad made up of members of the New York Americans and Brooklyn Hispanos at Starlight Park in the Bronx.

"This is an all-out war. Everything in education that does not bear directly on this effort is irrelevant. Every course must be practical. Any one studying literature, the arts, philosophy, is crawling into an ivory tower and must be dragged out."

Soon after Great Britain and France declared war the statisticians began to figure how long Germany could keep her airplanes, tanks, artillery-tractors and trucks running. The estimates varied from two years to five, and this for the reason that no one knew how much petroleum Germany had stored up.

PERSONS who attend any of the writers' conferences to be held this Summer in various parts of the country will have an opportunity to compete for two literary prizes. Doubleday, Doran Co. and Curtis Brown, Ltd., offer a prize of $400 for the best novel submitted by an accredited student or fellow at a 1942 writers' conference.

SAM BARSKY owned a Summer hotel in the Catskills. The Pinecrest was an establishment of modest size, observing strict dietary laws, and offering to its clientele the quiet enjoyment of a mountain view and a lake, rather muddy after mid-summer.

Hundreds of filling stations throughout the New York City, Newark and Philadelphia metropolitan areas were caught selling gasoline to motorists without ration cards yesterday in the first large-scale enforcement round-up by the Office of Price Administration.

STANTON, Del., June 6 -- Stealing through on the rail at the head of the stretch, Joseph E. Widener's Moscow II raced to an upset triumph in the sixth running of the $5,000 added Brandywine Handicap at Delaware Park today.
ROME, June 6 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:
The fifteen British and American fighting men, who will be honored tomorrow by the city, and their records follow:

At the quarterly meeting of the delegates to the American Kennel Club to be held Tuesday afternoon at the offices of the governing body of canine affairs, a number of important amendments to the rules, which have the approval of the board of directors, will come up for consideration.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 6 -- A Harvard graduate, returning here for a visit, would have difficulty recognizing the scenes that were once so familiar, for Harvard is now geared to modern war, and this is reflected both internally and externally throughout the university.

Special Notice A report from company commanders shall be at the office Chief of the Department on June 9, giving the number of enrollees and graduates of the F.D.E.A.C. that will march with the Corps on June 13.

Soviet Russia's post-war claims to the Baltic republics and to portions of Poland and Rumania as a means of protecting her long, exposed Western frontier are "reasonable -- if not moderate," The Commonweal, a weekly review edited by Roman Catholic laymen, declares in the leading editorial of the issue to be published Tuesday.

As usual at about this time of year, the schedules are shifting around a good deal, what with Summer replacements, vacations, etc. Here, for instance, are a few changes of date and/or time and networks:

HORSE RACING Mrs. Payne Whitney's Shut Out, winner of the Kentucky Derby, again defeated Alsab in the seventy-fourth running of the Belmont Stakes yesterday. The 2-to-5 favorite was beaten by three lengths at the end of the mile and a half.

DALLAS, Texas, June 6 -- Gasoline rationing as a means of conserving tires has encountered opposition in Texas that to the uninformed outsider would appear to indicate that Texans are not willing to make sacrifices for the war effort.
FORT SILL, Okla. NOT long ago they were hitting us again. "Singing, dancing, play-acting -- Humbug. If they put on uniforms, they'd really be doing something." So went the cry. Well, we can take it.

The adoption of a new emergency building code which would stipulate the maximum of materials to be used for any objective rather than the minimum is urged by Lieut. Comdr. John H. Brachts, U.S.N., in a report to the Producers Council, affiliated with the American Institute of Architects.

BRIELLE, N.J. -- There is still plenty of fun at the seashore. It is true that the bright lights that canopied the great centers with white incandescence have been altered to prevent sky-shine. The gaudy, bizarre illuminations of years past, the blendings of red, green, blue and yellow neon, have done with their flashing invitations, but the spirit of pleasure has not been dimmed.
FORT MADISON, Iowa, June 6 (AP) -- Colonel Glenn C. Haynes Iowa State Penitentiary warden since 1933, died at his home here today after several weeks' illness of a heart ailment. His age was 66.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 6 -- For the first time in history an aggressor's missiles have exploded in the North Pacific area of the American continent, and public reaction in this region, the part of the United States proper nearest Alaska, is divided between anger and perplexity.

NEW ENGLAND'S early itinerant artists, all of them self-taught, are presented with authority and enthusiasm in Clara Endicott Sears's "Some American Primitives." For the Wayside Museums, Inc., situated on her estate, Fruitlands, at Harvard, Mass., Miss Sears has gathered together an impressive collection of primitive portraits, and it is with these that her study is mainly concerned.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your recent editorial "Date of a Famous Hymn" throws doubt on a bibliographical fact that I had thought well established.

Fordham University will begin its ninety-seventh annual commencement program with a baccalaureate vesper service and solemn benediction at 5:30 o'clock this afternoon on the terrace of Keating Hall on the campus. The baccalaureate will be celebrated outdoors for the fourth successive year to permit all the graduates of the various schools, about 1,900, to attend.

Vacationists will "stay put" this year for a fortnight at least, in the opinion of many resort men who foresee lucrative business in the longer holiday. Gone are the "rare old, fair old days" when the sky was the limit as far as gasoline was concerned, when weekends to centers hundreds of miles from the home base were habitual, and day trips were as long as drivers had strength to make them.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- An agreement with regard to the New York Governorship race was said to have been reached today by President Roosevelt and James A. Farley, State Democratic chairman and former Postmaster General, at a White House luncheon conference.

Seventeen skippers of the New York Power Squadron who have been applying advanced mathematics and astronomy to their study of boat handling and seamanship have reached the pinnacle and have been rated as navigators, the highest grade offered in the U.S.P.S.
GLOVERSVILLE -- "Can't let you have any gas without a ration card," said the attendant of a service station somewhere west of Oneonta. "How do I know you aren't a spotter for the government?"
AT last the children are in bed; then they want a drink of water, or they want the light left on, or the door left open. If this happens in your family, yours is not the only one.
An exhibition of paintings that shuns the subject of war will help the war program of the American Red Cross.

MADISON, Wis., June 6 -- Courses in various fields bearing on the war, national service and defense have been prepared for the University of Wisconsin's 1942 Summer session. Six, eight and twelve week sessions will include courses relating to the war.

Homes in good condition and well located in Westchester County are reported by brokers in the chief residential areas there to be showing steady activity. During the week several substantial sales were closed in Scarsdale, Bronxville, White Plains, New Rochelle and other suburban areas in the county.

PROFESSOR GUERARD. like many other Americans including the reviewer, is a lover of France. Moreover, the author of "The France of Tomorrow" sees the importance of that delightful and often inspiring country to the world.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 6 -- Describing the present conflict as in one sense "a war of production of ideas," Wendell Lund, director of the Labor Production Division of the War Production Board, said here tonight that management and government must draw increasingly upon the "know how" of American labor.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 6 -- Never relinquishing the lead she took on the fourth green, Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of the Lakeville Club defeated Mrs. Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, 4 and 2, in a beautifully fought thirty-six-hole final over the Lakeville course today to win the women's metropolitan golf championship.
MOSCOW, June 6 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

More than 25,000 young men and women in the twenty-seven schools and colleges affiliated with the Board of Education of the Northern Baptist Convention are being trained not only to help win the war but to "win the peace," it was revealed in a survey just completed.

LONDON, June 6 (AP) -- Three months after the capitulation of Bandung, military capital of the Netherlands Indies, the Japanese invaders still have not achieved full consolidation of their conquest of the far-flung archipelago.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 6 (AP) -- Officer candidates for the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps will be taught everything a soldier needs to know except actual combat.

ONE of the toughest assignments an actor can undertake is thai of portraying a person to whom the public is generally hep. Pretty near any actor, given the proper costume and a beard, could play, let us say, William Gladstone without making the average patron mad.

THE well-known Canadian painter, Emily Carr, became the friend of the West Coast Indians at the age of 15. It was then, when she was visiting at the remote mission station of Ucluelet, that she received her nickname of Klee Wyck -- "Laughing One."

MOSCOW, Sunday, June 7 (AP) -- In a sudden eruption of warfare in the Baltic, Stormovik dive-bombers of the Soviet Fleet Air Arm have sunk ten German vessels, nine of them transports, in assaults on three convoys and a Nazi naval base, the Moscow radio announced today.

Two thousand of the 22,000 members of the Bronx American Women's Voluntary Services participated yesterday in a five-hour first anniversary celebration that began with a drill in front of the Bronx County Court House and closed with a gala luncheon-meeting in the Grand Concourse Hotel.

IT is a pity that Karel Capek died before he was able to complete the novel under consideration here -- a piece of work which is a rare combination of charm and strength, and which promised to be something of a tour de force.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 6 -- Foreign Minister Ernesto Barros Jarpa, tactfully minimized yesterday the criticism of Oscar Schnake, leader of the Socialist party and Minister of Trade, who, in the presence of more than 10,000 supporters on Thursday, attacked the government's foreign policy by stating that "Chile could not and should not remain neutral in the present conflict."

NEWTON, Mass., June 6 (AP) -- Seven meet records were broken today in the New England A.A.U. track and field championships at Boston College. The meet saw the second fastest mile ever run outdoors in New England.

The findings of the 1941 study of tuna as conducted in Long Island waters under the supervision of Nassau County officials cooperating with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service have just been published.

Less than half a century back there was a scarcity of motor cars. In fact, there were no motor cars at all. When people wished to travel -- and generally they did -- they climbed aboard a Josiah Perham excursion train. Perham first organized the cheap excursion.

THE last thing Mickey Mouse could have been thinking of, back in the gilded Twenties, when he was brought to the attention of the American public, was that a book would ever be written about him. To Mickey there would have seemed no material for a book.

MOSCOW, June 6 -- American-built Tomahawk planes have been successful in the defense of Murmansk, vital North Russian port where supplies arriving from Britain and the United States are speedily cleared toward the various fronts.

THE half-year mark from Pearl Harbor was signalized by naval victory off Midway and the leveling of German industrial cities. In a military sense our affairs have taken a better turn except for the inept handling of the submarine menace in the Atlantic, which still bears the label of the Normandie fiasco.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 6 -- A topped infield single by Ed Pope was the decisive blow of a pitching duel today as Yale topped Harvard, 3 to 1, in ten innings to square accounts with the Crimson at Soldiers Field in a setting devoid of the traditional color of Commencement Week.

"Gents around the ladies," sang Teddy Gruber yesterday afternoon from a platform in the Sheep Meadow in Central Park near Sixty-seventh Street. And a hundred "gents" seized their girls and gave them a twirl as thousands of spectators, old and young, clapped their hands and swayed subconsciously to the bewitching rhythm.

THERE is something that Richard Austin Smith is trying to say, to clarify, in his novel, "The Sun Dial," but what it is remains elusive as a shadow. But, in trying to give body to an idea he gives evidence of writing talent that is far above the average.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The War Production Board announced today that tin supplies used in non-critical products will be cut another 10 per cent, effective July 1, in order to provide additional supplies for the urgent needs of military operations and civilian food supply.

Warning that, if normal driving habits are allowed to continue with only "spotty" and "inadequate" regulation, a breakdown in civilian transportation by next year is inevitable, the Brookings Institution in a report just released urges a strict program of reduced automobile mileage that in scope and action exceeds anything yet proposed by Federal officials.

THE faults and even the crimes of the Pizarros, as of most makers of history, are self-evident. Mr. Birney is perhaps right when he affirms that Francisco Pizarro was all physical courage, with nothing on the moral side to uplift his nature.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will deliver the main address of the eighty-second commencement exercises of Hunter College on June 24, it was announced yesterday. The exercises are being held three weeks later than those of any college in the metropolitan area, as Hunter has had no call to forego its peacetime schedule, Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college, explained.

GENEVA, Switzerland, June 6 -- Were this man a Briton his might have been a plain, unvarnished tale. But he is French, and, as he would be the first to acknowledge, rhetoric still holds its sway. But plain or polished, here is his story:

YOUR old records, which have been a nuisance to you and a strain on your storage space, cluttering your closets, cellars and attics, are worth money to you and the recording industry. For they can be broken down and about 90 per cent of their original materials can be reclaimed and put to work into the making of new disks.

With war limitations on photography cutting drastically into available picture-making areas, the zoo is attracting many photographers. Here the subject-matter is so varied that one could probably spend a month and still not exhaust all the possibilities.-

Axis submarine packs operating off the Atlantic Coast of the United States do not spend all of their time stalking and destroying merchant vessels. A large part of their time is spent dodging patrol vessels, blimps and aircraft operated by the Navy and Army.

DETROIT, June 6 (U.P.) -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, completed a whirlwind tour of automotive war plants late today and predicted that American industry could "more than double present production by 1944."

Fighting men right from British and American fronts, heroes of the sweeping raids of the R.A.F. over Germany, of Pearl Harbor, the Philippines, and naval combat in the Java Sea, of Commando raids on Norway and occupied France and air operations over Libya will be hailed by New York City tomorrow.

WILLIAM BERGSMA, senior at the Eastman School of Music; Allen Sapp, senior in the Music Department of Harvard University, and Norman Dello Joio of the Juilliard Graduate School of Music, have been selected as the three candidates for the new Town Hall Composition Award.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., June 6 -- Compulsory courses in occupations for all students in secondary schools were advocated today by Dr. F. Theodore Struck, head of the Department of Industrial Education at the Pensylvania State College, who believes that such courses would help to prevent the potential post-war dangers bred by a body of discontented young people, jobless or in the wrong jobs.

CO-ORDINATOR: The cooperation of Great Britain and America in a combined war effort has not always proceeded smoothly. The war industries of the two nations, working separately, nave overproduced some types of weapons, underproduced others.

William Green, president of the A.F. of L., called upon organized labor "to give without a moment's interruption, so we can win the war at the earliest possible moment," in speaking at a luncheon tendered yesterday to Abraham Cahan, editor of The Jewish Daily Forward, for his contribution to the labor cause.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that the United States was watching closely to ascertain whether the personal visit of Adolf Hitler to Finland would lead to a greater degree of Finnish cooperation against the United Nations.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Early on a recent afternoon the first cargo-laden windjammer to reach San Francisco in well over a decade arrived off The Heads. She was the Chilean naval auxiliary Lautaro, the world's only sail-driven vessel enjoying a full navy status and at the same time on active duty.

ELKINS PARK, Pa., June 6 -- Champion Braegate Model of Bell Haven, a beautiful full-coated white and sable collie owned by Mrs. Florence B. Ilch of Red Bank, N.J., was selected as best in show today at the Huntingdon Valley Kennel Club's annual event held at Lynewood Farms, estate of Joseph E. Widener.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Federal war tax stamps, necessary to legalize the use of automobiles for the fiscal year beginning July 1, will be put on sale Wednesday in all postoffices and offices of Collectors of Internal Revenue.

Victory gardens were started this Spring all over our land. Each gardener, in buying seeds and fertilizer, tacitly enlisted to fight for the balance of the season. But secretly each of us expected most of the pests to be in the other fellow's backyard, not ours; and now when we discover that we have been invaded overnight we wail loudly about fifth columnists.

There was a touch, of humor in the appearance in a single column recently of two items from abroad relating to gold. One was a report from Vichy of discussions provoked by a new book called "Gold Is No Longer King." The other concerned a pronouncement in Berlin by the vice president of the Reichsbank that Germany's currency was not based on gold but upon the "unflinching confidence of the German people in the Fuehrer."
Aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange on May 29 was 534,396 shares, against 530,636 shares at the end of April. Neither total includes short positions of odd-lot dealers.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The outlook in China is critical. Japan has started her knockout blow against China on all fronts: from Burma and Indo-China in the south; Canton and Fukien in the southeast; Chekiang and Kiangsi in the east and Honan in the center.

TWO years before Paul Revere made his famous ride there was born in Salem. Mass., a child destined to become one of the greatest practical mathematicians of all time. The father was Habakkuk Bowditch, a maker of barrels and ship owner in a small way, and he named the babe Nathaniel.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : I liked your recent editorial on the mastodon style in official English. The air raid signs may say that "illumination is required to be extinguished," but of course nobody ever extinguishes illumination. He puts out the lights.

"VIVA PERU! VIVA l'Amerique!" was the cry of President Prado at the conclusion of a special preparedness address on Sunday last from the Lima shortwave rostrum. So fired was the Peruvian President by his own words that he spontaneously burst into song, which, when recognized as the national anthem, was echoed by thousands of followers.

Non-farm real estate foreclosures in April totaled only 3,856, as compared with 3,925 cases for March and 5,445 for April one year ago, reports the Federal Home Loan Bank Administration. The April figures are only slightly above the fifteen-year low record of 3,630 cases reported for February.

STRAWBERRIES, sugar and cream were the fare upon which Curley-locks received an invitation to dine as she sewed a fine seam -- a proposal which must have been made at this time of year, when the luscious, brilliant berries abound.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 6 -- Six records were broken as 584 schoolboy athletes from seventy high schools competed in four divisions of the twenty-fourth annual New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association track and field championships today at Woodman Field.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 6 -- With fifty-one starters, one more than were out in the initial championship a week ago, the Larchmont Yacht Club today held its first regatta of the Summer season. It was the second of the special event series.

STYMIED: A country parson on Briton's Isle of Man applied for a supplementary gasoline ration last week. He worked an appropriate biblical quote into his request. It was: "Remember the commandment 'Go ye into all the world and preach the gospel.' " In an official refusal he got back another quote: "Yea, saddle me an ass."

A demonstration Victory Vegetable Garden will arrive this coming week-end at Rockefeller Center to take the place of the customary seasonal display of flowers. Two thousand plants of tomatoes, cabbage, onions, carrots, beets and a dozen other kinds will be set out as an educational feature for the benefit of New Yorkers and others, enabling them to watch a typical Victory Garden as it matures to harvest.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 6 -- Despite the increased emphasis which war has placed on chemistry, physics, mathematics and geology, the social sciences have replaced the physical sciences as the leading field of concentration for Colgate University sophomores, Dr. John S. Alien, chairman of the institution's preceptorial committee, announced today.

FRANZ WERFEL, author of "The Forty Days of Musa Dagh" and "The Song of Bernadette," writes in The Commonweal about how he came to build a novel round the story of the saint of Lourdes. He goes on to tell why he believes that in telling that story of spiritual experience he was writing "a polemic of this war."

There is something more than wishful thinking in saying that the prospects of the Allied Nations showed an improvement over the week. In the first place, there were no Axis successes and, in the second place, there was more than one evidence of a virility on the part of the anti-Axis forces which lends import to the promises of large offensive action in the months to come.

HERE is a book which possesses a quiet power and a definite distinction. On every page one experiences the impact of a manly, intellectual honesty; but even more, one respects the urbane spirit which, taken with the intellectual vigor, creates the effect of a serene sunrise of enlightenment spreading gradually and powerfully over the mind.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : In THE TIMES of May 31 there was a letter from Professor Ralph Barton Perry which wag of interest to all those who consider the deeper sense of this war.

The prairie dog is an engaging little animal and one that is native to America. Very little has been written about him, however, in spite of the fact that a prairie dog town has the same fascinating suggestion of a planned community life as a beaver village or an ant hill.

CHUNGKING, China,, June 6 (AP) -- Forcing the Japanese to pay a heavy and bitter price for their Chekiang-Kiangsi offensive, the Chinese announced officially tonight that they had thrown back repeated Japanese attacks against the walled city of Chuhsien yesterday.

Cosmos of the early-flowering kind possesses a prolific habit of bloom. During the heat of Summer this is accelerated, resulting in the production of numerous small flowers on short stems, followed later by a general deterioration of the plant.

Archibald MacLeish, Director of the Office of Facts and Figures, denied that his office has attempted to stir up a campaign of hatred against our enemies, in a letter to the Religious News Service, made public yesterday.

LONDON, June 6 -- Flying cameras of the Royal Air Force have brought back indisputable proof that the May 30 raid by more than 1,000 British bombers wrecked at least 5,000 acres, or about eight square miles, of Cologne.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- An estimate that American participation in the air offensive against Germany would mean a United States Army Air Force of at least 400,000 men in the British Isles was made today by the Army and Navy Journal.

ONCE aboard the lugger -- in this case a luxurious yacht -- Miriam Lake is informed that she is not Miriam Lake but Jennifer Murcheson, niece of two of the persons aboard the yacht and cousin of another. What the purpose of this hocuspocus may be Miriam has not the faintest idea.
