WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Congress has become moody under the stress of war, but it has segregated its moods along international and domestic lines and has kept each strictly in its place. Despite these rigid separations of issues the situation has assumed proportions that either may spell out trouble for the war effort as a whole or may have, on the other hand, a cleansing and clarifying effect.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York has received a report from its committee on harbor and shipping, urging the Federal Government to place the New York State Maritime Academy and similar schools in other States on a parity with the country's national maritime academies.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 6 -- The average household furniture manufacturer realized a net profit of 5.8 per cent on sales in 1941, as compared with 2.8 per cent in 1940, according to a study of 1941 operating results issued today by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 6 -- Adolf Hitler's surprise visit with Field Marshal Carl Gustav Mannerheim and the Finnish Government was carried out with the same elements of surprise and precaution that invariably mark the Reichsfuehrer's excursions beyond German frontiers.

Announcing that building operations are being authorized for war housing under the recent amendments approved by Congress to the National Housing Act, Abner H. Ferguson, Federal Housing Commissioner, said yesterday that no work even in defense areas will be started unless shown to be absolutely essential.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., June 6 -- The Turnesa family, which has been in the golfing limelight of late because of Corporal Jimmy Turnesa's great showing in the P.G.A. championship, took most of the honors in the metropolitan qualifying round for the Hale America open tournament at the Forest Hill Field Club today.

With its volume of business about one-fourth larger than in the first quarter of 1941, the chemical industry suffered a set-back in net profits in the first three months of this year, reflecting a 60 per cent increase in provisions for Federal taxes on income and excess profits.

On the eve of the formal constitution of a new Advisory Council on European Jewish Affairs, to be affiliated with the World Jewish Congress office here, representatives of nine Hitler-ravagred countries pledged last night that the freeing of their homelands would carry with it a return of the freedom of their Jewish minorities.

Civilian heroes, the Russian guerrillas, are to be pictured on a 30-kopecs deep blue stamp "in honor of the mass joining of Soviet people in the volunteer armies fighting to protect the Fatherland against the bloody Fascist," according to word received from the Soviet postal authorities by J. H. Stolow last week.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 6 -- For the second time in the forty-four-year history of the Tuxedo Horse Show it was held under war-time conditions. At the sessions both yesterday and today there was a large turnout of local spectators, but few visitors came here due to the gas and tire rationing.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 6 -- Next Tuesday afternoon the 151st birthday of John Howard Payne, author of "Home, Sweet Home," will be observed with simple ceremonies at his birthplace, owned by the village of East Hampton and kept open as a museum, and shrine to his memory.

IF the ever astonishing radio is now recognized as having done away with space -- at least, as far as the human voice and other sounds are concerned -- it would appear also to have played some tricks with time.

With all the enthusiasm shown by women during the first World War, housewives throughout the metropolitan area are reviving a slogan to the effect that food will win the war, especially if it is canned in a time of plenty for use in a day of scarcity.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 6 -- Early arrivals for the Yale commencement events helped crowd the university theatre tonight for the first of two productions of "When in Rome," the best of the comedies of Piautus, the Billy Minsky and George S. Kaufman of his era, set to music.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Revolting against the leadership of John L. Lewis, a group of locals in the United Mine Workers established a National Council of Gas, Coke and Chemical Workers today as an independent union seeking a C.I.O charter.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 6 (AP) -- Jersey City made it three out of four in its series with the tailend Red Wings by taking the final game today, 3 to 2, in ten innings.

MEXICO CITY, June 6 -- Leaders of the five national labor organizations indicated yesterday that a labor-government pact had been drawn up and would be followed by a labor-employer agreement designed to prevent strikes during the war.

FROM morning to night during the past week or so, the local office of the Federal Communications Commission has been swamped with a new tide of mail. Scores of visitors have crowded the aisles. On the desk of Arthur Batcheller, veteran inspector-in-charge of this area, the telephone rings incessantly.

ACURIOUS misconception of the purposes of the Critics' Circle, and a conception still more curious of the individual duties of the music reviewer of New York who constitute it membership, seem to reign in the minds of a certain group of composers whose communications have recently adorned these pages.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 6 -- On one of the most primitive parts of this planet -- the Libyan Desert -- the most modern machines of war are locked in deadly battle. Fourteenton General Stuarts, seventeen-ton Valentines, twenty-ton Crusaders and twenty-eight-ton General Grants and General Lees are moving amid clouds of powdery desert dust.

A copy of the latest pastoral letter of the German bishops of the Roman Catholic Church -- the first since the Fulda Conference last Autumn -- has just reached this country. Dated March 22 and read in the German churches on that day, Passion Sunday, the document reveals that the bishops had recently submitted formal protests to the Nazi Government against oppression of Christianity and the Church, and had demanded its cessation.

BOOK collectors are a hardy lot whose hobby persists in all kinds of weather, through wars and rumors, through fire and flood. Shortness of purse does not stop them, nor does the elusiveness of the quarry. They thrive on discouragement.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Demand for wheat, on the Board of Trade here was sluggish today, and both local and commission-house interests sold that grain. There was a modest rally from the extreme lows, but in the absence of any important buying the market finished 3/4 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel lower than yesterday.

SANTA FE, N.M. -- Advanced Summer reservations for dude ranches in the Southwest indicate that Americans intend to make this year's vacation count toward healthy relaxation and muscle-hardening exercise. They plan to come back to intensive war work hardened and vigorous from long hours in the saddle, browned by the Western sun and refreshed with plenty of sleep.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, June 6 -- French Guiana and Dakar again are attracting attention here, with newspaper commentators and editorial writers expressing the opinion that the recent series of attacks on Brazilian and United Nations shipping between Para and Trinidad have been by submarines probably operating from French Guiana.

Those who like to salt their wartime plain living with high thinking will again find a welcome in the round dozen vacation spots frequented both by well-known writers and those still on their way into print.

Wendell L. Willkie wrote yesterday to Sydney S. Baron, publicity man, expressing appreciation of his suggestion that he be nominated for Governor on a coalition ticket but requesting him to refrain from any further effort in that direction.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 6 -- We are not masters of our fate, James T. Cleland, associate professor of religion at Amherst College, told the graduating class of Vassar College today. "That belief," he said, "is being forced upon us even if we did not have the gumption to recognize it before.

An interesting stampless cover now in a collection here, first mailed in Italy, is addressed to a prisoner of war in Egypt. Instead of going directly to its destination, it was routed, correctly, to headquarters of the International Red Cross at Geneva, Switzerland.

CHUNGKING, China, June 6 -- The panic that seized Kunming with the fall of Lashio and the subsequent Japanese drive up the Burma Road has now somewhat subsided with lack of progress in the invasion, though some apprehension still remains, according to travelers just arrived here from the Yunnan capital.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Children in Summer camps and Army selectees going to and from induction centers have preferred transportation status if they need to roll on rubber, the Office of Price Administration said today.

The people of Norway already are fighting on two fronts, Johan Nygaardsvold, Prime Minister of the Norwegian Government in Exile, asserted last night at a dinner in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. Thousands of Norwegians who have fled their homeland since the Nazi invasion "want to be equipped and prepared to return to Norway and chase the Germans out," he declared.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 6 -- A pair of comparatively unknown 5-year-old thoroughbred hunters shared the spotlight with several noted veteran campaigners today as the curtain descended on the 1942 edition of the Tuxedo Horse Show.

DETROIT, June 6 (AP) -- The weapons of war are roaring, "like a flood, down the assembly lines of America," Alvan Macauley, president of the Automotive Council for War Production, said today in a foreword to a report on what the automotive industry has done since Pearl Harbor.

RICHMOND, Va., June 6 -- A vacuum instead of stitches is used to "sew" together the parts of a shoe in a new method of making cemented shoes which is the subject of a patent (No. 2,283,946) granted to Earle C. Pitman of Red Bank, N.J.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Washington and Detroit divided a baseball twin bill today, the Tigers taking the opener, 9 to 3, behind Tommy Bridges's tight pitching, and the Senators copping the nightcap, 11 to 3.
CINCINNATI, June 6 -- The Reds put on one of their occasional power demonstrations today to defeat the Braves with home runs -- three of them. The score was 8 to 2.

JUST recently there was exposed here the box score of the first game that the Brooklyn club played in the National League. The notable event took place in Boston and "the locals" walloped the invaders from Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Old Dan'l Boone Davis, the calm and collected sharpshooter of the Brooklyn pitching staff, today shot down the Cubs for nine innings and sent the Dodgers winging into a seven-game lead over the second-place Cardinals with a 2-0 triumph over the Bruins.
Approximately 600 golfers pitched and putted their way around eleven courses yesterday in the second stage of qualifying for the Hale America national open tournament.

David R. Carson and George P. Orr have been elected trustees of the Presser Foundation, which provides musical scholarships, assists in the erection of music buildings at colleges and supports a home for retired music teachers in Germantown, Pa. Mr. Carson is vice president of the Central-Penn National Bank and Mr. Orr is a lawyer.

Stocks rose yesterday for the fourth successive day and closed the second successive week of rising prices. Steel, mining and amusement issues on the New York Stock Exchange led a market which did 192,760 shares, the heaviest for a Saturday since May 8.

The burned-out shells of tanks and the blackened bodies of dead soldiers littered the Libyan desert south of Tobruk last week. The first violent phase of Marshal Erwin Rommel's newly launched offensive toward Egypt's border had ended. For nearly a week a confusion of tank battles had raged back and forth, along a line of British defenses extending deep into the desert.
The second test of the 407 permanent air raid sirens in New York City was made yesterday and produced much the same results as the initial tryout of a week previously.

SALLY BENSON"S new book is a collection of frivolously pleasant fragments about the Smith family of St. Louis which adds up to a shrewd and accurate bit of not-too-early Americana. The comfortably above the average family (and there's no doubt that Miss Benson was a member of it) lived well and happily without benefit of automobiles, radios or mechanical refrigerators.

"LAST night a force of considerably more than 1,000 bombers attacked targets in the Ruhr and Rhineland. Cologne was the main objective." So reads a British communique, and judging by events it will not be long before American communiques will tell of bombing raids over the industrial and shipping centers of Germany, with American bombers and pilots taking part.

THOSE who believe in the doctrine of predestination will find in Stuart Chase's "The Road We Are Traveling" a type of analysis suited to their temperament. If you believe in the power of mankind to shape its destiny by the use of intelligence it is easy to find many places where consequences due to economic ignorance are regarded as the results of irresistible forces of change.
Submarine warfare in the Caribbean area in recent weeks claimed three more merchant ships, with ten lives lost and seventy-two survivors landed at Gulf Coast ports, the Navy revealed yesterday.

PELHAM, N.Y., June 6 -- Leslie MacMitchell looked at Don Burnham five scant yards from the beckoning red tape in the mile feature of the fifty-first annual metropolitan A.A.U. championships at picturesque Travers Island today and this sidelong glance caught the 19-year-old Dartmouth sophomore catapulting past him for the victory.

WASHINGTON. AN admiral pounded the table in a New York club to make more emphatic his answer to a question from the audience he had been addressing on the prospects of war for the United States. No, he thundered, there was no chance that the Japanese would sneak up on Pearl Harbor as disastrously as they did on Port Arthur before declaring war on Russia in 1904.

Independent journalists and college professors made by far the best showings as prophets of the outbreak of war in the Pacific last December, with missionaries and isolationist editors turning in the poorest records, according to the results of an investigation just completed by seventy Union College students.

MEXICO CITY. WHEN Mexicans suddenly faced the prospect of being at war with one Asiatic and two European powers, most of them rubbed their eyes in amazement. Such a possibility had entered the minds of only the most imaginative.

DR. Serge Koussevitzky's Summer school, which has been known as the Berkshire Music Center and has functioned in the past under the sponsorship of the trustees of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, will continue its activities this Summer at Tanglewood, near Lenox, Mass., under a new orientation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with Interest the comments of your correspondent Carlton K. Matson in THE TIMES of June 1 and the articles to which he referred on the subject of the public-relations activities of the government.

Broad principles governing wartime construction are designed to bring such work under more rigid conservation control have been set up by top officials of the War Production Board and the Army and Navy.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Temporary gasoline rationing has been in effect in fourteen States for three weeks, and this week the permanent form that will succeed it and possibly be extended throughout the country was announced.

At the moment the Japanese are concentrating the bulk of their offensive power against China. No doubt this drive has long been planned. But it may have been General Doolittle's air raid that precipitated it. Though Japan doubtless hopes to crush China's resistance eventually, her immediate objective is the capture of airfields from which the Japanese islands could be bombed.

HOLLYWOOD, WAR conservation took on a leveling aspect this week in Hollywood with the announcement that limousines for stars and executives will give place to ordinary jitney buses on all studio trips and that the film industry will abandon such luxuries as specially transported hairdressers, cars for distinguished visitors and other speedy niceties to which the glamour folk have become accustomed.

THE Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra is to be allowed to give its annual outdoor concerts this Summer in the Hollywood Bowl. At first permission was withheld because of the problems involved with the blackout, traffic and the gathering of large audiences.

It may be small comfort, but the thousands of Americans who now must forego the pleasures and conveniences of regular airplane travel for the duration ought to know that air transport service after the war will be many times better than ever before.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- A vivid picture of modern warfare, with planes zooming, bombs bursting, the sharp crack of anti-aircraft guns and the rattle of rifle and machine-gun fire, will be given by an "Army War Show" which will tour fourteen major cities for the benefit of the Army Emergency Relief Fund.

LONDON. IT was not on the ground of personal distinction as a classical scholar that T.S. Eliot was chosen as president of this year's meeting of the Classical Association. Indeed, according to his own confession he is among those who have not remembered enough Greek and Latin to read the ancient writers with ease in the original text.

In 1032 B. Jay Becker, now the manager of the Cavendish Club in New York, but then a resident of Philadelphia, showed a double dummy problem to the experts in several New York clubs. He had found it in a monthly bulletin published by the Knickerbocker Whist Club, now (since 1940) defunct.

Preparing for an "intensified campaign for further State government economies to expedite war efforts," the Taxpayers Federation has sent a resolution to Governor Lehman and to members of the State Legislature requesting more time in which to study future budget appropriations.

Definite plans are afoot to relieve the growing tension with respect to the dwindling excess reserves of banks in the nation's two principal money centers: New York and Chicago. Viewed as a whole, excess reserves of the nation's banks are considered to be ample to permit these institutions to play their parts in making loans to industry and in purchasing increasing amounts of government securities.

Most grown-ups talk too much to children, says Eva Knox Evans in "Children and You." "They talk so much that the children just stop listening." The fewer words we use the better, she continues, but we must mean what we say. "You can't get mad at Mary for something one day and not notice it the next.

With the management supplying the necessary space and the tenants contributing the funds for equipment, one of the most elaborate first-aid systems yet set up in a Manhattan apartment group has been completed at the Parc Vendome, in West Fifty-sixth and Fifty-seventh Streets.

LONDON, June 6 -- Artillery preparation for an assault by infantry upon the enemy stronghold has begun. That is the meaning behind the R.A.F.'s mass air attacks upon German industrial centers, just as it was the meaning behind the Battle of Britain nearly two years ago.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The capital received tonight official word that United States forces were scoring a crushing victory over Japanese naval units in the greatest air-sea battle fought thus far in World War II.

To the Music Editor: IN these days of Wagner worship it seems encouraging to see in the pages of the Sunday TIMES an exchange of letters on the subject of the revival of Handel's operas. This is a topic which is rather close to me, since the socalled Handel renaissance saw its origin in my home.

Following many weeks of admitted confusion, military and civil authorities suddenly "clamped down hard" last week with drastic dimout regulations. Army officers and police searched the streets looking for glare, arrested and penalized automobile drivers, shipowners and other persons who persisted in burning bright lights at night.

HOLLYWOOD has mastered the art of being in two places at once. The problem of keeping the familiar faces on the screen while the owners of the faces are in the armed forces has been solved by the stockpile method.

ALTHOUGH other men have put the air-waves to more dangerous uses than did the late Dr. John Romulus Brinkley, the recent demise of that celebrated quack not only recalled a gaudy career but may have reminded you of a truth so obvious that it goes half-forgotten -- i.e., how mighty a force is radio for evil as well as good, even in a democracy.

GENERAL everyday interest in art -- spelled either with a capital A or in small letters -- has been of comparatively recent growth in America. It was retarded by many social and economic factors -- too many to be detailed here in a brief review and perhaps best left to the professional sociologists and historians to thrash out.

ART seasons do not just curl up and go to sleep any more, as they used to do. In fact, for several years now the season has waned and drowsed but kept one eye half open through the dog days. Here it is June, and we had at least fifteen new shows on our list last week, with promise of more to come.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- In view of the fact that a number of thoughtful men, for more than a year at least, have been advocating a long armistice period before the next peace is made, if the United Nations write it, and noting the reception accorded to the recent speech of Under-Secretary of State Welles when he took up this advocacy, it is surprising that the Administration waited so long to make the recommendation.

THE current exhibition at the Paul Rosenberg Gallery is devoted to canvases by Claude Monet. This show interestingly exemplifies work done between 1876 and 1888 -- an early period, during which the long-pondered impressionist theories of Monet and his group crystallized.

SUDDENLY this normally sanguine country goes pessimistic about optimists. Cheerful, confident people who look on the bright side of things constitute, it seems, a sort of Seventh Column and do almost as much harm to the national war effort as the Sixth Columnists, recently discovered, who repeat as true the whispered lies of the Fifth Columnists.

Any one who goes on a buying spree is sabotaging the war, Secretary Morgenthau said recently. Figures released by the War Production Board show why. Practically every article of ordinary household use or of everyday wear competes with the war effort for vital materials.

THE story of the Bataan Peninsula could not be told without inclusion of Douglas MacArthur: the story of Douglas MacArthur could not be told without that of the men of Bataan. Consequently, Mr. Hersey tells the stories of both.

Every household in New York is going to get mail this week. For three days commencing tomorrow postmen will deliver forty-five tons of letters in the city's five boroughs in preparation for the Treasury Department's minute man campaign to sell war bonds.

Declines in two components were more than enough to offset increases in the remaining four components and the New York Times index of business activity dropped to 132.0 for the week ended May 30 from 132.3 in the preceding week. The figure was 129.4 for the week ended May 31, 1941.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: I SHOULD not have made any comment on the review of Dennis Wheatley's "The Black Baroness," by Jane Spence Southron, if she had not stated that "a careful comparison of the war story as given here with actual dates and happenings shows that Mr. Wheatley's account is an exact one."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- This resort will add two more beach playgrounds to its facilities on June 15, bringing the number of such areas on the municipal strand to ten. Supervised play goes on every day except Sunday.

Described as being "super-energetic" about their war work, 4,000 women in settlement house communities are working, conserving, salvaging and studying to be of service on the home front. For these women of many nationalities, united in the League of Mothers' Clubs, the nutrition program holds the spotlight of interest, and one of their projects in keeping with this is reaching constructively into more than forty settlement houses in Greater New York.

VICHY, France, June 6 (U.P.) -- Fresh outbreaks of anti-German disorders were reported in occupied and unoccupied France today as the funeral of the assassinated pro-Nazi editor, Albert Clement, became an angary demonstration against Britain on the boulevards of Paris.

Rooms, quite surprisingly, often take on new gayety when ingenuity replaces money. The question of getting the most out of what one has and making a little expenditure go a long way evidently can be solved smartly. Individuality, for one thing, is bound to result when old pieces out of the attic are combined with colonial heirlooms and a recent purchase or two, perhaps in the English Regency, French provincial or modern fashion.

Restrictions on lumber deliveries contained in limitation order L-121 have been lifted on more than 100,000 of the most essential war housing units now under construction, the War Production Board reports.
CHUNGKING, China, June 6 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command communique issued tonight follows:

In its campaign to equip our rapidly growing military forces, the Army is buying enough personal equipment to cover the equivalent normal peacetime needs of the 50,000,000 men between the ages of sixteen and sixty-four in this country, an analysis of government orders revealed yesterday.
Associated Press Correspondent Will Reich Marshal Hermann Goering, like Rudolf Hess, some day abandon the Hitler burning-ship?

SAN FRANCISCO, June 6 -- "That means we're next" was a typical comment in this area immediately after the Japanese raids on Dutch Harbor. It was not accompanied by any show of excitement. It was a matter-of-fact statement and its collective broadcasters, whether chatting over the backyard fence or conversing with the street car conductor, voiced no evidence of surprise at the presence of enemy craft over Alaska's coast.

Since the Public Utility Holding Company Act was passed in 1935, the primary aim of the Securities and Exchange Commission has been to bring about the break-up of the nation's major utility holding companies through a double-barreled process: (1) corporate simplification, and (2) geographic integration.

The tidewater facilities of the railroads serving New York have become virtually a unit in "New England's fuel life line" as a result of joint action by the railway managements. This means that coal traffic diverted to the railways by the submarine blockade off our shores may be transferred to floating carriers here at any one of various terminals regardless of the route by which it arrives.

Consumer confusion regarding the Federal Reserve Board's recent charge account and installment credit regulations has been a more important factor in the decline in retail trade during the last three weeks than any direct or indirect effects of the General Maximum Price Regulations, retail executives here reported last week.

While camouflage classes are temporarily suspended at Pratt Institute during the Summer months, the camouflage laboratory will remain open and in full operation through the entire vacation period for research work and experimentation, James C. Boudreau, director, announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 6 -- Attacking at night, perhaps to avoid the blistering heat of the desert by day, British and Indian infantry supported by tanks moved forward in Libya late Thursday and early yesterday against the German salient west of Knightsbridge and succeeded in denting the German defenses.

To THE EDITOR or THE NEW YORK TIMES: The statement by Howard Kershner of the American Friends Service Committee which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 3 reveals a tragic condition for which some mitigation must be found if widespread hunger and suffering are not to be increased in France.

NEWARK, N.J., June 6 (AP) -- The Newark Bears suffered a double defeat at the hands of the Buffalo Bisons today, increasing their losing streak to five games, one of the longest in the last few years. The scores were 12 -- 9 and 5 -- 3.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 6 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force communique today said:

The Junior Officers Ball, an event organized for young officers soon to leave for foreign duty by the Committee for American War Work, was held last night in the former Whitelaw Reid residence at 451 Madison Avenue, now headquarters of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies.

LONDON, June 6 -- Rounding out a week of steady, large-scale attacks by the Royal Air Force on Germany and German-occupied territory, a strong force of British bombers unloaded a thunderous weight of explosives on industrial centers of the Ruhr Valley last night. Just after dawn "many squadrons" of R.A.F. fighters and bombers took up great offensive sweeps over Northern France that continued through the day, the Air Ministry reported.

To ease the shortage of rubber caused by the Japanese invasion of the Southwest Pacific, the collection campaign for scrap rubber for reclamation is expected soon to assume renewed vigor. As one incentive, the Rubber Reserve Company last week announced that it would purchase in carload lots anywhere in the United States at $25 a ton "run of mine" scrap and worn out tires.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 6 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force communique today said:

The Junior Officers Ball, an event organized for young officers soon to leave for foreign duty by the Committee for American War Work, was held last night in the former Whitelaw Reid residence at 451 Madison Avenue, now headquarters of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies.

LONDON, June 6 -- Rounding out a week of steady, large-scale attacks by the Royal Air Force on Germany and German-occupied territory, a strong force of British bombers unloaded a thunderous weight of explosives on industrial centers of the Ruhr Valley last night. Just after dawn "many squadrons" of R.A.F. fighters and bombers took up great offensive sweeps over Northern France that continued through the day, the Air Ministry reported.

To ease the shortage of rubber caused by the Japanese invasion of the Southwest Pacific, the collection campaign for scrap rubber for reclamation is expected soon to assume renewed vigor. As one incentive, the Rubber Reserve Company last week announced that it would purchase in carload lots anywhere in the United States at $25 a ton "run of mine" scrap and worn out tires.

To help meet the demand for technicians and other trained workers needed in the war effort, the United States Office of Education is planning an expanded vocational program during the coming year. Three hundred thousand men and women will receive instruction at government expense in 250 colleges and universities throughout the country.

The 520 candidates who took mental tests yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory as part of the "weeding out" process whereby sixty officers will eventually be selected for the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps from 2,000 applicants in this area, learned well their first army lesson -- to keep a secret.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- A series of liberalizing interpretations of the War Production Board order of April 9, which put all construction under rigid control, was issued today.

Faced with a national economic loss, due to accidents, that last year reached a total of $3,750,000,000 -- it is still climbing -- business men and industrial leaders throughout the nation, are cooperating in a drive to raise $5,000,000 needed to promote a broad safety program for the next two years.

ALTHOUGH Washington and Hollywood continue to behave vis-a-vis not unlike a rather uncertain suitor and a skittish lady, a little progress was made recently when as a token of mutual esteem the West Coast patriots agreed to make twenty-six government short subjects for public exhibition.

The Maritime Commission has instituted a new feature in its department of information which is designed to answer all the questions that come flooding into its headquarters in Washington every week from the public.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Henry Coster Emmet of the Plaza are leaving today for Castina, Me., for the Summer.

The battle is barely over. The full extent of losses on both sides has not yet been determined, much less told. Yet it is certain that the great sea battle for Midway Island has been a stunning defeat for Japanese sea power. Just six months after the disaster of Pearl Harbor we have been given just cause, as Admiral Nimitz says, to rejoice over a momentous victory.

AT AN OPERATIONAL BASE, in the Southwest Pacific, June 6 (Delayed) -- A group of American fighter pilots devised a new game today to help pass the time while awaiting orders to take to the air if Japanese bombers and Zeros come over.
MOSCOW, June 7 -- Enthusiastic praise for the Royal Air Force's raids on Germany is heard on all sides these days.

The spirit of St. George is riding abroad today in a world once more threatened by "reptiles," Charles H. Tuttle, former United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, said yesterday in an address before 1,000 members of the St. George Association of the Sanitation Department attending a communion breakfast in the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Representative Robertson said today that the task of drafting wartime legislation was "not made easier by warnings to the American people by distinguished members of the Senate Finance Committee of the undesirability of high taxation on certain tax-paying groups."

ST. LOUIS, June 7 -- Although major league baseball only recently passed what you might call the two-furlong mark, some interesting observations already can be made despite the customary warnings of the cautious Joe McCarthy that "a lot of things still can happen."
CHUNGKING, China, June 1 (Reuter) -- Tonight's communique says:

LONDON, June 7 (AP) -- The body of Reinhard Heydrich, the Gestapo, "executioner" for whose assassination more than 200 Czechs thus far have been slain, was borne through the streets of Prague today in an official mourning ceremony that the whole population was commanded to attend under pain of further reprisals.

Mayor La. Guardia called yesterday upon all New Yorkers to make memorable today's visit of the group of fifteen British, and American Heroes, veterans of combat over Germany, in the Philippines and the Java Sea, at Pearl Harbor, on the coasts of France and Norway and over the deserts of Libya.
BERLIN, June 7 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- In a statement approved by the Navy, Chairman Vinson of the House Naval Committee declared tonight that "the anti-submarine warfare organization has now passed through its period of growing pains, is well established and is functioning efficiently."

PEARL HARBOR, June 7 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the United States Pacific Fleet, announced tonight that quiet again prevailed on the Midway Island sea front, where the enemy apparently was withdrawing after a savage combat with American air and sea forces.

Morale is particularly the problem of our religious leaders, who "must lead the people in devotion to the religious beliefs and principles for which we are fighting," Frank L. Weil, president of the Jewish National Welfare Board and vice president of the United Service Organizations, declared yesterday morning at the seventeenth annual commencement of the Jewish Institute of Religion, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Compared with the $4,500,000,000 that the Nazis now exact annually from occupied Europe, "the $500,000,000 which Germany was finally asked to pay as reparation under the Young Plan is a drop in the bucket," declares a survey of the economic aspects of German military conquests published today by the Foreign Policy Association.

HAVANA, June 4 -- With increasing transportation difficulties seriously handicapping her foreign trade and restriction of sugar production in 1943 appearing inevitable, Cuba faces a severe economic depression.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., June 7 -- Norman C. Armitage of the Fencers Club took all his five matches in the final round robin today to win the Eastern outdoor saber championship at the New York A.C. strips on Travers Island.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 7 (AP) -- Jersey City ran its winning streak to five in a row today by defeating Toronto, 1 to 0 and 2 to 1.

Secular and nonsecular education has failed because it never has appreciated the true nature of man, his origin and his destiny, Mgr. Richard B. McHugh, rector of Cathedral College, Brooklyn, said yesterday morning at the Church of St. John the Baptist, Brooklyn, in a bacca ureate sermon to the students and faculties of St. John's College.

LONDON, June 7 -- Dressed in distinctive American uniforms and with jaunty field service caps on their heads, a small group of young women acting as drivers for United States Army and Navy officers are stationed in London.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Reports in THE NEW YORK TIMES and in New York evening papers of the arrival of the S.S. Drottningholm have included reference to sixty-eight "mystery" passengers described as refugees. The report in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 2 included the following:

LONDON, June 7 -- The explosion that flattened out three five-story apartment houses and killed twenty-eight persons in London yesterday was attributed officialily by the Ministry of Home Security today to the delayed explosion of a bomb dropped at least thirteen months ago by a German bomber and that apparently had tunneled through soft sand to a spot immediately under the buildings' foundations.
If there is any one place better than the battlefield in which to judge the morale of the British soldier, it is a prisoner-of-war camp.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 7 -- Two savage tank attacks by the Germans in the desert at Knightsbridge, Libya, have been repulsed by the British, and tonight the Germans were reeling back south and west of Bir el-Harmat toward a gap that they had made in the British mine fields that extend from El Gazala to Bir Hacheim.

A heavy downpour of rain accompanied by lightning and thunder caused injuries to at least seven persons in the city last night and sent water flooding into the, Grand Avenue-Elmhurst Station of the Independent Subway in Queens, halting service on the line between Roosevelt Avenue, Jackson Heights, and Jamaica from 11 P.M. to 1:30 A.M.

When all is said and done, the most healthful thing that can happen to a woman's complexion is not a fancy facial, not a massage, not a bedaubing or creaming, but a blush! The brisk rush of blood to the face -- whether it comes from modesty or a swift set of tennis -- is an deal, more-than-skin-deep method of improving the tone, texture and clarity of the skin.

PITTSBURGH, June 7 -- Mr. Moffitt, who had been assigned to Pittsburgh since the creation of the Department of Conciliation, was stricken here a few weeks ago at his home in the Roosevelt Hotel. After treatment at Montefiore Hospital he went to Orange, N.J., to recuperate.

Calm people, particularly in times like these, are a godsend, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 122d Street. He spoke on "Being Inwardly Quiet in a Noisy World."

The Music Education League, under its president, Miss Isabel Lowden, brought its nineteenth season to a close yesterday afternoon at Town Hall with a two-hour musical program and the presentation of its annual awards to music students.
Vacation time is in full swing -- in your own back yard.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Stable and amicable relations between labor and management cannot be satisfactorily achieved by dictates of law or government but are dependent upon "the good sense and resourcefulness" of employers and union leaders, according to Professor Frank C. Pierson of Swarthmore College, who has made a study on "Collective Bargaining Systems" for the American Council on Public Affairs.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 7 -- Eighty per cent of the Norwegian hospitals are now requisitioned for German wounded, according to reports today from Oslo sources.

LONDON, June 7 --The stock markets here made an excellent response last week to the war news, prices advancing in nearly all sections. The bond market has done little more than maintain its strength despite the reinvestment demand stimulated by the large government disbursements of June interest, but the more speculative securities have gone steadily ahead, the industrial index rising to the highest point since Jan. 30.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Monday, June 8 -- Sydney and Newcastle were shelled early this morning by Japanese submarines. Large-caliber shells fell in the suburbs of Sydney, where the all-clear was sounded an hour after the attack had started.

Nine hundred and twenty Fordham seniors, representing the eight schools of the University, who participated yesterday in the annual baccalaureate services on the Rose Hill campus, opening Fordham's ninety-seventh commencement week, were advised that nations and individuals in these times of strife must return to realism and fundamental spiritual values in order to survive.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 7 -- Results of animal experiments furnishing a new link in a chain of evidence indicating that the vitamins of the B family play an important role in protecting the body against cancer, and conversely, that a chronic deficiency in these vitamins deprives the body of such protection, are presented in the scientific exhibit of the annual meeting of the American Medical Association, which will open here tomorrow.
Lasting peace after victory must be based on a world understanding of the principles of Christian unity, the Rev. Dr. William F. King declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 7 -- "The Great Big Doorstep," a new play by Albert Hackett and Francis Goodrich., will be filmed by Warner Brothers if negotiations between the studio and Herman Shumlln, who will produce the play on Broadway next Fall, are completed.

Lease-lend assistance to Palestine by the United States as a vital link in the resistance to Axis aggression was urged yesterday by Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan at the annual luncheon of the Pioneer Women's Organization for Palestine at the Hotel Astor.
NEWARK, N.J., June 7 (AP) -- The Newark Bears ended a five-game losing streak today by trimming Buffalo, 3 to 0 and 5 to 1.
WASHINGTON. June 7 (U.P.) -- A more violent rule of terror in German-occupied Europe under the iron fist of Heinrich Himmler, the Gestapo chief, is forecast by the Office of Facts and Figures.

The New York Fire Department baseball team enjoyed a six-run lead over the Police Department nine before their clash at the Polo Grounds yesterday was half completed. Smarting under this indignity, the forces committed to the upholding of law and order rose in their wrath and rallied to knot the count and put themselves back into the struggle.
PITTSBURGH, June 7 -- The total volume of steel orders which reached the industry in May fell short of the volume booked in April. However, it Is reported that May business exceeded actual output.

The rapid change-over in packaging from critical materials to those in plentiful supply was illustrated in the wartime exhibit of packaging held in conjunction with the annual convention of the National Federation of Textiles last week.

At the commissioning of a $27,000 launch for the Police Department's "navy" yesterday morning, Mayor La Guardla said that the 1,200-acre Idlewild airport, now under construction by the city, would be turned over to the armed forces when finished.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., June 7 -- "The problem of adult education for members of our armed forces is one of the most important things to be solved today," said James Marshall, president of the New York City Board of Education, speaking at the Founders Day program of the National Farm School today.

The German people knew Hitler's plans when they voted him into power, and, unless they redeem themselves by a revolt, they must be punished as well as their leaders, James W. Gerard told the national convention of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League here yesterday.
Tiny Bonham lost yesterday before the greatest baseball crowd of the year, one of the largest in the history of the Yankee Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Administration plans to use Treasury silver stocks for war production purposes have struck a snag in refusal of the Senate Silver Committee to approve proposed enabling legislation.
PITTSBURGH, June 7 (AP) -- The Pirates had their longest winning streak of the season today -- four straight -- thanks to the hapless Phils.
CHICAGO, June 7 -- The wheat market, after showing early last week the greatest weakness in some time, became stronger late in the period, although prices still were lower than a week before.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 7 -- Warning against painting too rosy a picture of the post-war world or setting up ideals for that time impossible of fulfillment was given by Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard, today in the baccalaureate sermon opening the commencement program.

The capture early yesterday morning of a giant Negro, grotesquely costumed as the "Black Phantom," ended a wave of terrorism in the wooded sections of Bronx Park where there has been a series of holdups in the past two weeks.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Gross earnings and current operating expenses of the country's insured commercial banks in 1941 were higher than in any other year of deposit insurance, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 7 -- At some time in the future, Ceylon may erect a monument to Squadron Leader Leonard J. Birchall of the Royal Canadian Air Force, the man who saved this island from a disastrous attack by a Japanese battle fleet, which, it can now be disclosed, included five aircraft carriers.

LONDON. June 7 (AP) -- The United States Midway victory in what appears to be the greatest combined sea-air battle ever fought is saluted by the British as indisputable evidence that Japan has lost offensive momentum.

As in months past the trade book clinic of the American Institute of Graphic Arts has singled out another handful of books from the many published and presents to each a compliment for their designers and manufacturers having coordinated imagination with sound execution.
Deals involving properties in the Times Square area featured realty activity reported in Manhattan over the week-end.

Millions are turning wistfully to spiritual things, and many who drifted from the church are coming back, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale said yesterday in his sermon in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street.

The first of the new fluid catalyst refining units which will boost the nation's supply of 100-octane aviation gasoline has been placed in successful operation by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, the company announced yesterday. In the first ten days of operation the new unit exceeded the anticipated capacity by 20 per cent.
PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (AP) -- Driving toward a berth in the first division, the Browns twice defeated the Athletics today, 5 to 2 and 7 to 1.
CHICAGO, June 7 -- The Dodgers made it three in a row over Jimmy Wilson's Cubs today by taking both ends of a double-header and maintained their seven-game lead over the second-place Cardinals.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided yesterday morning at a solemn pontifical mass in the Jesuit Church of the Nativity. Second Avenue and Second Street, marking the 100th anniversary of the founding of that parish on June 5, 1842. After the mass the Archbishop bestowed the Apostolic j blessing on the parish.
LONDON, June 7 - American and British experts here have worked out sweeping plans for an intensified campaign against Axis submarines, it was revealed tonight.

FOREST PARK, Pa., June 7 -- More than 150,000 members of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union in New York and other garment centers throughout the country have been made idle in the last few weeks through the application of an amended order by the Office of Price Administration governing the Fall prices of women's dresses, suits and coats, David Dubinsky, president of the A. F. L. union, disclosed today.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TUIES : While we citizens strip our homes of metals, municipal government continues its waste of materials. For example, little can be more exasperating to those of us who have given even useful pieces from our living rooms than the digging up of stone curbs and the laying of steel ones in their place.

To avert the discharge of 125 high school teachers, scheduled to be dismissed by the Board of Education as a result of a budgetary deficiency, the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations, representing the 35,000 school employes of the city, called upon all teachers yesterday to pledge themselves to a contribution of $5 each, to guarantee $136,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 7 -- The Eastern regional meeting of the National Women's party, closing here today, went on record in support of a movement to grant women physicians rank, pay and privileges in the Medical Reserve Corps of the military services equal to those of men.

There will be more city-wide blackout drills from time to time and they will come on shorter notice than the eight hours given for the test last Friday, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly "Talk to the People," broadcast from his desk at City Hall over WNYC, the municipal radio station.

A courage no less exalted than that of the Christian martyrs in pagan Rome inspires the Passion Sunday letter of the German Bishops read in all Catholic churches of the Reich. A copy of the historic document, dated at Wuerzburg, March 22, has just reached this country.

An All-Star soccer team, featuring players from the New York Americans and the Brooklyn Hispanos, took the measure of Mexico's touring Club Atlante, 2 -- 0, before 5,000 persons, some of whom took part in an impromptu fight on the field at Starlight Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Secretary Wickard said today that the first big task of the government's new Wartime Food Committee would be to determine the quantity of various types of food needed to supply military, civilian, lease-lend and other demands.

A Southern skipper, rescued with twenty-four of his crew after fifty-six and one-half hours adrift on life rafts, told here yesterday of a Nazi submarine commander who torpedoed and sank his ship in less than five minutes, then leisurely dispensed rum, cigarettes and a pair of French military overalls to the victims.

The 1941 annual report of the Electric Power and Light Corporation, issued yesterday by J.H. Gill, president, shows a net income of $1,503,257 after all expenses, taxes and other charges, an increase of 16 per cent over the net of $1,299,075 reported for 1940.

Wholesale markets continued inactive last week, pending further official information on prices and inventories, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
A continuance of the demand for apartments in the city is indicated by lists of latest rentals reported over the week-end by brokers and managing agents.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- Selling of contracts for future deliveries of corn caused several sinking spells last week in prices of that grain on the Board of Trade here. However, following the slump in all grains early in the week there was a good recovery, but this failed to hold and on Friday and yesterday the tone was heavy again.

The so-called Maryland plan was revived at the recent meeting of the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission and no doubt it will receive scrutiny from fishermen, sport and commercial, of our coastal States before long.

"Claudia," which John Golden brought back to Broadway on May 24 for a "strictly limited" engagement of two weeks, again may extend its stay until July 2 and at least until June 27. If it remains until July 2 it will attain its 500th Broadway performance.

NEW HAVEN, June 7 -- Out of the existing international chaos, the United States will see that there emerges an organization able to preserve freedom, President Seymour of Yale University said in his baccalaureate address to seniors today.

CINCINNATI, June 7 (AP) -- A ninth-inning homer by Rookie Ray Lamanno beat the Braves, 3 to 2, in the nightcap of a double-header today after the Reds had won the opener, 6 to 2, on four unearned runs in the eighth.

Dr. Jameg T. Shotwell, Bryce Professor of History of International Law at Columbia University, will retire from his teaching post on June 30, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, announced yesterday. Dr. Shotwell, 68 years old, has taught at Columbia for nearly forty years and is director of the Division of Economics and History of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 7 -- There were seventy craft out today in the second-series regatta of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, which was held by the sixty-eight-year-old Knickerbocker Yacht Club. It was just a score more than in the opening event a week ago, and the number completely refuted the predictions of those who visualized maximum fleets of fifty or sixty this Summer.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- roduction of military airplanes by American industry has increased nearly 85 per cent in the six months since Pearl Harbor, Colonel John H. Jouett, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce, reported today.

LONDON, June 7 -- The Royal Air Force continued last night its program of crippling the German war machine and impeding Nazi preparations for an offensive against Russia by bombing the North Sea port of Emden, one of the most sensitive points in the Reich's industrial and communications system.

Close teamwork between experts of the United States and Great Britain has produced a joint victory production program intended to assure the output of the aircraft and the munitions requested by the combined Chiefs of Staff for the coming offensive against the Axis, it became known last night.

America's wartime speed-up in production will result in a postwar future of "economic plenitude" for the common man, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, minister of Christ Church, forecast yesterday in an address at New York University's 110th annual baccalaureate exercises on University Heights.
MOSCOW, June 7 -- The German Eleventh Army, which drove the Russians out of the Kerch Peninsula, has been pounding at Sevastopol for three days, according to tonight's Soviet communique.

Contributions and pledges or $1,616,671 last week brought the war fund of the United Service Organizations to $7,020,658, or 35 per cent of the $20,000,000 sought this season, it was announced yesterday by Prescott S. Bush, national chairman. The balance of the $32,000,000 goal is to be raised in drives in the Fall.

LONDON, June 7 -- The Economist's Index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 110.9 on May 26. This compares with 110.7 a fortnight before, 110.6 a month before, 104.9 a year before and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Detroit and Washington split a double-header today, the Tigers taking the opener, 6 to 4, and the Senators gaining an 8-0 decision in the nightcap behind Walter Masterson's four-hit hurling.

With his swing as smooth as Dixie molasses. Bob Jones trimmed five strokes off par as he set the pace yesterday for the Hale America national open golf qualifiers it eight courses scattered throughout the United States.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 7 -- The issue of this war is expressed better in terms of women's lives than in abstract generalizations, Archibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress, said in his address at Smith College's commencement exercises this afternoon.

Both wartime and post-war risks up to the amount of excess-profits taxes paid are virtually assumed by the government in Great Britain, while in the United States this risk is borne almost exclusively by business, according to the Conference Board, which adds that both present British taxes and prospective United States taxes on excess profits almost eliminate the profit motive as a basis for increased production.

CHUNGKING, China, June 7 -- Japanese troops have seized the big airfield at Chuhsien, 700 miles from Japan, and have pressed into the walled town itself, where the Chinese are engaging them in violent hand-to-hand fighting, an army communique announced today.

NEW ORLEANS, June 7 -- Long liquidation, including unloading of July contracts on stop-loss orders, more persistent peace rumors and seemingly another concerted effort to get out of cotton on the theory that the government's anti-inflation, price-fixing policy has made any further major uprush highly improbable, combined to put cotton futures prices here down approximately $2 a bale during the last week.

Mayor La Guardia, taking the dual role of director and commentator, has produced a three-minute movie short that will be shown in every moving picture theatre in the city in Civilian Defense Week, beginning today and running through Saturday, it was announced yesterday at the Greater New York Civilian Defense volunteer office in the City Hall.

ST. LOUIS, June 7 -- The gay dash of the Giants to a more advantageous position in the first division of the National League suffered a double disaster today as Mel Ott's Polo Grounders dropped both ends of a twin bill to the Cardinals before 9,391 chortling fans.

A carefully studied picture of the vital need of conserving motor-car operation in America has been issued by the Brookings Institution. Under the title "Automobile Transportation in the War Effort," Charles L. Dearing of the institution staff, now attached to the Office of Defense Transportation, has stripped illusion and confusion from a situation which has been sadly muddled by conflicting and ambiguous statements from many sources.

BOSTON, June 7 -- The Red Sox swept a double bill with the White Sox today by identical scores, 3 -- 2. Home runs by Bobby Doerr and Jim Tabor settled the issue in the last inning of the first game and Lou Finney's long fly drove in the winning tally in the second.

TOKYO, June 7 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Imperial Headquarters asserted today that from Dec. 8 to May 31 the Japanese Army had crushed 505,000 enemy troops in approximately thirty-five and a half divisions in Southeast Asia and had made prisoners of 298,000 of them, including 25,000 Americans.

But that will be one of the involuntary by-products of the order, aimed at saving rubber and gasoline, which is reducing the number of editions some newspapers will publish.

As a result of the conferene between President Roosevelt an State Chairman James A. Farle at the White House on Saturday supporters of Attorney Genera Jonn J. Bennett Jr. expressed confidence yesterday that all obstacles to Mr. Bennett's nomination for Governor on the Democratic ticket had been removed.

VICHY, June 7 -- Interesting details on the concentration of industry projected as early as last December have just been issued. The object is to deal with the situation resulting from the shortage of raw materials. As a matter of fact, total unemployment no longer exists but working hours have been reduced in the extreme and are, for example, as low as twenty-two a week in the textile industry.
"There is going to be less coffee in the country from now to victory."

The greatest miracle of all is the miracle of forgiveness of sin because it gives promise that no matter what mistakes have been made in the past the future can be made glorious "by the grace of' God." the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

While every one wonders when the United Nations forces will invade the European Continent it is, in fact, being invaded. The Commando raids, of which the latest was the one staged between Boulogne and Le Touquet, are invasions with limited objectives, in small force and temporary.

With nine, including Can't Wait and Dit, named for the $6,000 Queens County Handicap, an eighteen-day race meeting will begin at Aqueduct today and end on June 27. With the success of Belmont Park's and Jamaica's Army and Navy Day still fresh in the minds of all racegoers, it is probable Aqueduct and Empire City will provide similar programs to help the boys in the service.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation has reported for the fiscal year ended on March 31 a net income of $4,442,956, including a nonrecurring item of $1,438,400. This was equivalent to $21.67 a share on the common stock. It compared with $2,981,049, or $14.52 a share, for the year ended on March 31, 1941.

After losing ground slightly on the first news of Japan's bombing of an Alaskan port, last week's stock market steadily recovered, reaching the highest average since the first week of March. War news from Europe comprised continued deadlock of the Nazi campaign in Russia and North Africa; also successful bombing of Cologne and Bremen by the Royal Air Force.
CAMDEN, N.J., June 7 -- Seven persons were killed in two highway accidents in South Jersey over the week-end, contrasted with the fatality-free traffic record of the Memorial Day holiday last week.

Golf clubs, particularly in the Eastern gas rationing area, already are seriously feeling the effects of the nation's war effort, according to a survey by The Associated Press. Almost in a body the members of some clubs have stopped paying their dues.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 (AP) -- Evacuation of the Western seaboard's entire Japanese population, a mass movement described officially as without precedent in American history, has been completed.

RYE, N.Y., June 7 -- Champion Flornell Rare Bit of Twin Ponds, a grand Welsh terrier and a rare bit of canine beauty from any angle, was named best in show today at the second all-terrier exhibition of the Rye Kennel Club on the lawns of Brookside, the estate of Mrs. Flagler Matthews.

American book publishers have issued approximately 15 per cent fewer new books and new editions in the first five months of this year than they did in 1941. This is revealed in the latest statistical publishing summary compiled by Publishers Weekly. Totals are 4,118 (1942), against 4,738 (1941).

CHICAGO, June 8 -- A weak tone in wheat was in evidence at the close of the session today, following a brisk upturn shortly after the opening, when there was active buying on a report that Senator Bankhead was to offer a bill in the Senate making loans at full parity prices mandatory on all basic farm crops.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 8 -- Restoration of equality to the individual Jew everywhere and insistence upon an international bill of rights to protect all minorities, are the post-war aims on which Jewish groups throughout the world are agreed, Abraham G. Duker of New York stated tonight at the final general session of the National Conference of Jewish Social Welfare.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Fifty dollars a month as the base pay of buck privates of the Army and Marine Corps and apprentice seamen of the Navy and Coast Guard was established today by a 58-20 vote of the Senate.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Presilent Roosevelt asked Congress today for a new 1943 War Department appropriation of $39,417,827,337, largest in history, and for an additional $137,018,890 for the War Production Board and other war agencies.

Two hundred and fifty-eight members of the senior class of the College of Arts and Sciences, Fordham University, uptown, will receive their degrees at Fordham's ninety-seventh annual commencement exercises this evening at 8 o'clock in the gymnasium on the Rose Hill campus.
STANTON, Del., June 8 (AP) -- Some 6,500 fans at Delaware Park today were afforded an unexpected thrill when two horses fell and another lost his rider during the six-furlong Elsmere Purse.

In and out of trouble like a mischievous child, the Yankees managed to beat the Indians (who did more to beat themselves) in an eleven-inning marathon at the Stadium yesterday. The score was 11-10. Joe DiMaggio, who saved the game in the ninth, carried home the winning point for Johnny Murphy, third Yankee hurler.

There is a nostalgic little scene on the bright label of the brand new cheese spread that has just appeared on the gastronomical horizon. It depicts, in miniature a snug tent, some pointed fir trees and a roaring campfire complete with logs, blaze and smoke.

NEW HAVEN, June 8 -- On the first day of Yale's commencement exercises devoted entirely to undergraduates, President Seymour awarded 607 bachelors' degrees to 378 members of the college, 129 of the Sheffield Scientific School and ninety of the Engineering School and ten incidental degrees in Woolsey Hall with the traditional and historic program.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- A third public hearing on the qualifications of Thomas F. Meaney of Jersey City, President Roosevelt's nominee for a judgeship in the Federal District Court in New Jersey, was under consideration today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 -- The United Light and Power Company system filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan providing for the disposition of its interest in the Point Pleasant Water and Light Company as a step toward compliance with orders already issued for integration under the holding company act.

The East End Surf Fishing Club will hold a meeting on Thursday evening "to talk fishing" at the Hotel Henry Perkins, Riverhead, L.I. Photographs of some of the big striped bass and weakfish taken by club members in other years, as well as the tabulated accounts of season's records that will adorn the hotel's walls, may start the conversation rolling.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Three more United Nations, Belgium, Poland and Greece, were formally invited by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today to become parties to the master lease-lend agreement.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 8 -- New South Wales coastal areas were blacked out tonight after the early-morning shelling of Sydney and Newcastle by Japanese submarines. It is thought that the submarines were of the largest ocean-going type in the Japanese Navy.
CAIRO, June 8 (AP) -- The British Middle East general headquarters communique said today:

Julian Hartridge, retired lawyer, formerly an assistant United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, died yesterday of a heart attack in St. Luke's Hospital, where he had been a patient for a month. He was in his seventy-third year.

Securities on the Stock Exchange responded yesterday In the early trading to the naval successes in the Pacific, but trading was dull and a relapse soon followed. In the final hour, however, buying was resumed at an increased pace, sweeping most of the leaders to the day's best levels with gains of fractions to three points appearing.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- The National Association of Retail Grocers and the National American Wholesale Grocers Association were told today by H.R. Tolley, assistant administrator of the Office of Price Administration, that the supply of food available for distribution among the nation's domestic and civilian population during 1942 and 1943 is likely to be "slightly less" per capita than in 1941.

Despite the limited number of national brands in the produce field, an increase has been noted in war-stimulated advertising of fresh fruit and vegetables by local distributors who have been actively promoting regional products under their own private labels.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The exercise of free speech, a free press and religious freedom may be limited by legislative bodies, the Supreme Court held today, "to times, places and methods not at odds with the preservation of peace and good order."

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate sent the Military Pay Adjustment Bill back to conference today with instructions to its conferees to accept House amendments fixing the minimum pay scale in the armed forces at $50 a month:

The problem of the refugee is bound to assume "vastly greater dimensions" as a result of the crisis the war has created, Myron C. Taylor, President Roosevelt's envoy to the Vatican and vice chairman of the Inter-Governmental Committee on Political Refugees, said yesterday.

Sturdy, alert German shepherd dogs will accompany armed guards patrolling the vital areas of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company's properties in Queens and Brooklyn to prevent sabotage. Announcement of the plan, suggested by the War Department, was made yesterday by officials of the company.
Both the East and West Sides of the midtown section shared in the apartment rental activity reported yesterday by brokers.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 8 -- Reports abroad that a German or German-Finnish offensive on Leningrad is impending are considered in usually reliable Stockholm circles as without foundation. The Germans are said to have no troops left in the south of Finland.

When a prisoner is abruptly transferred from solitary confinement, such as I had for two months in the Gestapo prison in Berlin and in the Rome barracks to the company of congenial associates he feels like a man emerging from a dark cave on a fine Spring morning.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Fighting ships that had been engaged or may still be engaged in the great battle in the Pacific -- a battle divided into two main combats -- moved tonight in the silent reaches of waters far to the west and north of Midway Island.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 -- At the conclusion of an arraignment, during which one of the defendant companies was accused of having sold thousands of loaves of relatively fresh bread in Wilmington at $15 a ton for hog and chicken feed in order to keep up the retail price, two baking concerns and six individuals were fined a total of $20,500 on a price-fixing charge in Federal District Court today by Judge Harry E. Kalodner.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, June 9 -- Soviet troops have beaten off continuing Nazi attacks on Sevastopol for the fourth straight day and have inflicted heavy losses, the Russians announced early today.

Further reports leave no doubt whatever that our forces struck a terrific blow at Japanese sea and air power off Midway Island, and with comparatively little loss to themselves. Our victory has both tactical and strategic importance. We can see its meaning most clearly if we view it in relation both to the past and to the probable future.

MOSCOW, June 8 -- Ivan Benediktoff, the Soviet Union's 39-year-old Commissar of Agriculture, told me today that he was satisfied that the Autumn-sown grain would yield a good crop and that though the Spring had been capricious this year his personal inspection led him to the conclusion so far, that the harvest prospects of Spring-sown grain were good.

An 18-year-old freshman at Hunter College, Liane Brauch, who came to America only a year ago, has won the first prize in a nation-wide essay contest sponsored by the Atlantic Monthly Magazine, it was announced yesterday. Miss Brauch, who competed with 260 other college students, titled her article "Refugee."

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Supreme Court ruled, in a five-to-four decision, today that it was legal for the A.H. Belo Corporation, publisher of The Dallas Morning News and operator of radio station WFAA, to make individual contracts with employes whose hours are irregular, under which the employes receive a fixed sum in pay each week, although they work more than forty hours in some weeks.
MOUNT PLEASANT, Iowa, June 8 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. H.H. Arnold, commander of the Army Air Force, declared today that "for every one of our planes shot down, the Japs have lost four."

Steel output in May failed by 6,000 tons to set a new high monthly record, mainly because of two unpredictable occurrences; the flood of the Lehigh River two weeks ago, hampering operations of the Bethlehem Steel Company, and an explosion of a Jones Laughlin blast furnace early last month, depriving the steel mills of a full supply of pig iron.

DETROIT, June 8 (U.P.) -- America will eventually triple its present output of warplanes, Theodore P. Wright, assistant chief of the War Production board's aircraft branch, disclosed tonight in an address before a group of automotive and aircraft engineers.
The campaign to recruit thousands of additional volunteers for home defense was started yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore formally opening "Civilian Defense Week."

A bill now pending in both houses of Congress forbids the advertising use of the Red Cross symbols or insignia, or any imitations of them, except to "the American National Red Cross and its duly authorized employes and agents, and the Army and Navy sanitary and hospital authorities of the United States."

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 3: Increases of $117,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $262,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, and a decrease of $220,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

Although "the road ahead dark and perilous," the United States and its allied United Nations are determined to fight on until they "shall create a new world in which there is freedom of worship and utterance, freedom from want and from fear, for all peoples everywhere in the world," President Roosevelt declared last night in a letter read at a dinner held under the auspices of The Churchman at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A STRAIGHT line is not necessarily the shortest distance between two points, the laws of geometry to the contrary. From that day some twenty years ago when his father took a wide-eyed youngster of 10 to see Babe Ruth and the Yankees in action, John Aloysius Hassett had only one ambition. He wanted to be a Yankee himself.

The total market value of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange increased $1,333,956,058 last month, according to a compilation issued by the Exchange. The average price of all listed bonds on May 29 was $95.64, compared with $95.63 on April 30.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 8 -- Federal Security Administrator Paul V. McNutt told the American Medical Association tonight that far too few physicians had volunteered for the armed services so far, and that it was "absolutely necessary that there be an immediate and significant increase in the number of volunteers, or else -- ."
CHUNGKING, June 8 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command said in a communique today:

PEARL HARBOR, June 8 -- The first eyewitness account of the Battle of Midway Island, detailing its most violent stages, was related today by a wounded United States naval aviator who told of floating in the sea and watching a line of burning Japanese ships pass by.

HOUSTON, Texas, June 8 (AP) -- Ensign George H. Gay Jr. of Houston, whose experience in the Midway naval engagement was described by the Navy today, is a perfect example of what a grimly determined lad will do when he wants to become an aviator.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- A series of White House conference on the gasoline and rubber situation indicated today that President Roosevelt has not decided definitely in favor of country-wide gasoline rationing.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Man Power Commission, set up today a management-labor policy committee which will be consulted on major questions of policy.
LONDON, June 8 -- French civilians were urged by Britain today to evacuate quickly the Atlantic coastal districts of occupied France.
VICHY, France, June 8 -- Henri Villar, former purser of the Ile de France and Normandie and well known to thousands of American tourists, has become a government official under the Laval regime.

BOSTON, June 8 -- A Federal grand jury, after a six-month investigation, returned a fifty-two-page indictment today against the Procter Gamble Company and ten individuals, charging them with fraudulent use of the mails and conspiracy in a scheme to defraud Lever Brothers Company, Cambridge soap manufacturers.

With the approval of President Roosevelt, leading Democrats of the Twenty-eighth Congressional district were attempting yesterday to make Augustus W. Bennet, Newburgh Republican, the Democratic candidate for Representative as the first step toward getting a coalition candidate against Representative Hamilton Fish, who is seeking re-election.

Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti is likely to be dropped from the Democratic State ticket this Fall, it developed yesterday as it became increasingly certain that Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. of Brooklyn would be the candidate for Governor.
American ships and planes were still searching the broad reaches of the Pacific yesterday for the Japanese task forces that attacked Midway and Dutch Harbor.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Legislation calling for mandatory Federal loans at full parity levels on this year's crops of the basic agricultural commodities was introduced today by Senators Bank-head of Alabama and Russell of Georgia.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 8 -- The German, national debt is increasing by 4,000,000,000 marks a month, according to the Reichsbank balances of last March 31. The balance for the quarter ending June 30 may show an additional increase.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 8 -- Princeton, already assured of its second straight Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League championship, defeated Yale, 2 to 1, in eleven innings today for its tenth triumph in eleven circuit games. Roy Talcott, going the route, hurled his eighth league victory before a Commencement Day crowd of 3,000 representing fifteen Yale reunion classes.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Mrs. Roosevelt pooh-pooed today the idea that the proposal requiring married couples to file a joint income tax return would undermine a working wife's independence. She said she approved the objective of such a return.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Tuesday, June 9 -- Twelve persons, seven of them officers and men of the Navy and five civilian experts, are missing and one naval officer was rescued after two United States Navy training airships, on an experimental mission, were lost in the sea off Manasquan, N.J., late last night.

New York City's supreme accolade, the municipal embrace expressed in tons of paper streamers writhing from skyscraper heights, in confetti blizzards, in shrill whistling and in hoarse acclaim overwhelmed fifteen American and British service men here yesterday.

America now has the power to fulfill the hope of freedom that it gave to the world in 1776, Robert E. Sherwood, deputy coordinator of information, declared last night at the New York University class day exercises on University Heights.
