The curtailment in production of a variety of electrical appliances finally caught up with distributors' sales last month and for the first time since the European war started their volume was below the corresponding month of the previous year, they reported yesterday.

Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis will receive a second gift from the New York Boxing Writers Association in recognition of his philanthropies in behalf of the Army and Navy relief funds before he gives his four-round boxing exhibition at the All Sports Carnival at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.

Miss Elizabeth Newton is among the debutantes aiding in the plans for the Dance Profession Victory Ball to be held on June 20 in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society. Others serving in the group, which is headed by Miss Frederica de Peyster Lawrence, are the Misses Eugenie Tuck, Margaret Whipple, Diana Taylor, Ann Reinicke, Phyllis Adams, Charlotte Whitman, Peggy Keasbey, Jane Thomas and Betty Van Lear.

German troops marched into Kerch two weeks ago. But victory there must remain sterile until Sevastopol is also reduced. This explains the violent renewal of the German assault on the Crimean naval base after 220 days of fruitless siege. To launch his offensive against the Caucasus and loot it of oil, Hitler must have full control of the Crimean peninsula and dominate the Black Sea.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Ways and Means Committee, taking up a study of excises in its drafting of a bill to raise the $8,700,000,000 of additional war revenue requested by the Administration, voted tentatively today to increase the tax on liquor from $4 to $6 a gallon and on beer from $6 to $7 a barrel.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 -- Max Winslow, vice president of Irving Berlin, Inc., music publishers, died today in Cedars of Lebanon Hospital at the age of 59.
Several sales in Yonkers and deals in other sections of Westchester were reported by brokers yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, June 8 -- Mexico swung definitely into the war saddle tonight as important labor confederations signed a "non-aggression pact" before President Manuel Avila Camacho as a first step toward national unity.
ATHENS, Ga., June 8 (AP) -- Four Navy officers clad in trunks emerged dripping from a flame-swept swimming pool, glanced ruefully at the sun, and complained of the blistering heat.

CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -- An excessive supply reflecting the determination of farmers to market their cattle without feeding to a high finish, today broke steer prices as much as 40 cents a hundred pounds. Heifers were weak to 25 cents down, cows off 10 to 15 cents and bulls steady to 25 cents lower.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 8 -- With only comparative lulls and almost continuous fighting, positions around that junction of Cyrenaican desert tracks that is called Knightsbridge continued to change hands so rapidly yesterday that it was never certain where friend and foe were to be found.

More than 1,000,000 retail stores in 3,300 cities and towns of the nation will formally launch the Retailers for Victory Drive on July 1 by concentrating their entire sales efforts for fifteen minutes at noon on the sale of war savings bonds and stamps.

At the Royal Palace at Oslo, Norway, late last Winter, two men faced each other across a conference table. Surrounded by his uniformed aides, the head of Norway's pro-Nazi government, Premier Vidkun Quisling, scrutinized the quiet, impassive features of Eivand Berggrav, Bishop of Oslo and Primate of the Church of Norway, pondering the questions he would ask this man who had dared to defy the new Nazi order.

The earnings statement of the United States Leather Company and its subsidiaries announced yesterday shows a net profit for the six months ended on April 30 of $824,632 after deductions for depreciation, $250,000 provision for Federal and State income taxes and $700,000 for property and equipment rehabilitation, inventories, contingencies and other charges.

Harry Van Arsdale Jr., business manager of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A.F. of L., whose conviction on riot charges under a rarely invoked statute was believed to be without precedent in the history of labor disputes in this State, lost his fight to upset the verdict yesterday when the Appellate Division in Brooklyn sustained the conviction in a three to two decision.

AT AN OPERATIONAL BASE, in the Southwest Pacific, June 5 (Delayed) -- Lieut. Col. Boyd (Buzz) Wagner, the leading American fighter pilot in this area, summed up his opinion of the Japanese Zero fighter plane in these words: "It's not a wonder plane, but it has the respect of all our pilots."
CINCINNATI, June 8 (AP) -- Big Paul Derringer almost pitched a no-hitter today as the Reds beat the Braves, 3 to 1, and swept their six-game series.

MERCERSBURG, Pa., June 8 -- At the forty-ninth annual commencement of Mercersburg Academy held this morning the class of 1932 Alumni Plaque, given annually to an alumnus, was awarded to W. Heber Dithrich, '06, of Coraopolis, Pa., judge of Common Pleas Court of Allegheny County, Pa.

Native intelligence and ability to "take" discipline are qualities most necessary for the successful recruit in the women's auxiliary military services in England and Canada, Wing Officer Lillian Marguerite Crowther of the Women's Auxiliary Air Force in England declared yesterday.

A candy made from sweet potatoes and another from three-day-old bread, were among the wartime exhibits shown yesterday at the fifty-ninth annual convention of the National Confectioners Association, at the Waldorf-Astoria. The meeting, at which the importance of the candy industry as an outlet for American agricultural products and its place in the war effort is being featured, will be continued through Thursday.
The annual election of officers of Chorus Equity Association was held at its headquarters, 701 Seventh Avenue, yesterday afternoon. Paul Dullzell was re-elected chairman of the executive committee.

In the six months since the Japanese struck at Hawaii, the mass-production industry for which America is famous has gone into full speed. On Dec. 7 the accumulated share of the automobile companies in the defense program amounted to orders of about four billion dollars.

After a detachment of twenty patrolmen, two sergeants and Police Captain Francis A. Burns had met the Duchess of Windsor at Pennsylvania Station last night, she said she felt highly complimented but hoped such attention would not be necessary for the duration of her stay of "three or four days."

CANTON, N.Y., June 8 -- For the price America is paying, and will pay, in the coming months of war, anything less than the regeneration of the nations that have attacked us would make the game not worth the candle, Dr. George D. Stoddard, State Commissioner of Education, said today at the commencement exercises of St. Lawrence University.

There is nothing in the rules laid down by the Federal Reserve Bank that limits purchases on regular charge accounts and there has been no intention by the government to end installment purchases, but only to establish certain restrictions, Michael Schaap, president of Bloomingdale's, declared yesterday in a statement intended to cover points about which many of the department store's customers have inquired.

BOSTON, June 8 -- The great task confronting a liberated America, which more than three-quarters of a century ago took its stand for freedom in the world by liberating the slaves, is to work out "freedom from slavery for the whole world," the Christian Science board of directors stated today in its report to the annual meeting of the Mother Church, at the First Church of Christ Scientist here.

JERSEY CITY, June 8 (AP) -- Toronto ended its losing streak at five games and also ended Jersey City's winning skein of five tonight by defeating the Little Giants, 6 to 3, in the third of a four-game series.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 8 -- The Fairfield County race for the Republican Congressional nomination is "wide open," according to local Republican leaders, despite the widespread publicity boom for Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, playwright and author, who lives on King Street here.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Rationing of tea, coffee and cocoa is likely this year, transportation will be restricted, fuel oil will be scarce and there will be priorities on power, said Joseph L. Weiner of the War Preduction Board today in picturing further changes in daily life in America as the nation entered its second half year of war.

BOSTON, June 8 (AP) -- Smart Crack, a 10-to-1 shot from the stable of Daniel J. Sullivan, scored a nose victory over Mrs. Sam Orr's Us today in the feature six-furlong sprint at Suffolk Downs. Mrs. Bettie Garnette's Wake Robin was third, three and one-quarter lengths behind.

LONDON, June 8 -- Hundreds of Royal Air Force planes swarmed over German occupied territory today harassing the Nazis on a 130-mile front from the canal port of Bruges in Belgium to Dieppe and points inland. They engaged Nazi fighters in several aerial battles, in which two American Eagle pilots distinguished themselves. American-built Boston bombers were used in force in the offensive.

KANSAS CITY, June 8 -- It took a minor league team to do what most of the National League clubs have had trouble doing this year -- beat the Dodgers. The Blues triumphed over Brooklyn, 7 to 6, in the ninth inning of an exhibition game tonight.

When the British radio asks civilians in occupied France to get out of the coastal military areas, if they can; when it advises those who cannot get away to confine themselves for the moment to preserving their own lives; and when it refers to coming "operations of capital importance in the struggle for the liberation of France," then we may conclude that something is brewing.
FARMINGDALE, L.I., June 8 (AP) -- At Bethpage Park, as at 5,200 other golf courses in the United States, officials and employes are wondering what the war is going to do to them.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 8 -- Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, expressed confidence today in victory for the United Nations and predicted that as a result the ability of any person to enslave others, physicially or mentally or spiritually, shall be forever impossible.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., June 8 -- "Citizens are no longer mere citizens -- they are the stuff out of which national integrity and effectiveness are made," said President McAfee of Wellesley in a commencement address to the 145 graduates of Northfield Seminary this morning.

A nose on the post decided the $6,425 Queens County Handicap as 13,797 watched the head-and-head duel in which Waller defeated Dit as the thoroughbreds returned yesterday to Aqueduct for an eighteen-day meeting. The John C. Clark color-bearer came from far back, just as he had to win the Excelsior Handicap at Jamaica.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 8 -- A large field of seventy-five started today in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association medal play championship over Rock Spring's well-groomed, well-trapped course. Only three strokes separated the first six players for the first eighteen holes of the three-day, fifty-four-hole tournament.

A Record Marred In all but the final figure of total steel produced and the amount of Bessemer steel the month of May was a record period for the steel industry, and even the decline in Bessemer output would not have mattered had it not been for a flood in one locality and an explosion in another.

In marked contrast to a year ago, when August sales and initial Fall preparations were well advanced at this time, activity for the new season continued at low ebb in major wholesale markets, a survey here yesterday revealed. While an increase over last week was noted in the number of arriving buyers, the arrivals continued well under those of the comparative 1941 period.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Women are forming an increasing proportion of those who are taking special technical war courses at colleges and universities throughout the country. Only four women's colleges are participating in the government-sponsored train ing program.

SYRACUSE, June 8 -- New York State, faced with a shortage of housing facilities in industrial centers, will start an intensive drive next week to obtain living quarters for war workers in private homes, Edward Weinfeld, Commissioner of Housing, revealed here today.

LONDON, June 8 (U.P.) -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler today turned over his new Chancellery for the state funeral tomorrow of Reinhard Heydrich, assassinated Deputy Chief and "hangman" of the Gestapo, whose body arrived in Berlin during the day aboard a special train from Prague.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision delaying final approval of a plan of reorganization of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company.

ALBANY, June 8 -- The General Synod of the Reformed Church in America asked President Roosevelt by resolution today to issue an order to reduce all work on Sunday in the Army and the Navy "to the measure of strict necessity" in accord with similar action of the wartime administrations of Presidents Washington, Lincoln and Wilson.
KALININ, Russia, June 8 (U.P.) -- Kalinin, once a magnificent city, bearing a striking resemblance to Leningrad, is a heap of ruins and ashes, a symbol of total war.
The vanguard of New York's 36,000 men classified in the draft as 1-B because of minor physical defects, voluntarily stepped out of civilian life yesterday and became members of the fighting forces.

Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange met local liquidation and active selling by New Orleans interests yesterday and ended the day with losses of 30 to 33 points. The downward movement which began a week ago has carried futures down 119 to 125 points, or $5.95 to $6.25 a bale, since June 1.

Mamie O'Rourke Sings Why is it when somebody speaks of the little man and the little people that the little man is always suffering and that he is never singing? The humble people of earth have more than their share of the darker hours, but it is not an existence unflecked with sunlight.

The training and organization of 200,000 Minute Men and Minute Women for a gigantic War Bond Pledge Campaign starting next week, will be conducted from today through Friday at grade schools and high schools throughout the five boroughs.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 8 -- Imminence of the turning point of the war toward the momentum leading to the victory of the United Nations was visualized today by Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador to the United States, in his address at the commencement of Syracuse University.

Japanese submarines smashing windows at Sydney and Newcastle are not contributing importantly to the conquest of Australia but they do give the people at home something to talk about. We had a similar visitation of propaganda shelling on our California coast, and Tokyo dressed up some pretty tall tales about it.
NEW YORK Mrs. Henrik de Kauffmann, wife of the Danish Minister, and the Misses Lisa and Tilda de Kauffmann have arrived from Washington and are at the WaldorfAstoria.
Adolf Hitler is convinced that he is not an ordinary mortal.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., June 8 -- Last of a field of twenty-three teams to finish, Ben Roman and C.W. Benedict of the host club turned in a best-ball card of 34, 34 -- 68 to tie the Westchester Hills pair of Jack Sabol and Joseph A. Mitchell for first place in the weekly Westchester P.G.A. proamateur tournament at the Whippoorwill Club today.

LONDON, June 8 -- Oil shares were the strongest feature in a generally bright market today as a result of the naval victory by the United States and more cheerful news from Libya. The Iranians rose 2s 6d to 55s and the Burmahs 103d to 36s 3d.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- When she endorsed the Treasury's proposal of mandatory joint tax returns for married couples, Mrs. Roosevelt was speaking in her dual capacity as the President's wife and private citizen. She has attempted in the past to separate these personalities.

The New York Stock Exchange firms of Evans, Stillman Co. and Maynard, Oakley Lawrence plan to consolidate on July 1 under the name of Stillman, Maynard Co., with offices in 61 Broadway, it was announced yesterday.

BOSTON, June 8 -- Educated women, unafraid of changes, will have an opportunity to take their stand resolutely for "a brave new world" in an after-war crisis which will present greater problems than the actual conflict itself, Dr. Claude M. Fuess, headmaster of Phillips Andover Academy, told a graduating class of 400 Simmons College seniors at the commencement exercises today.

The local regional office of the Office of Price Administration yesterday sent notices to 175 fillingstation proprietors requiring their appearance here on Thursday to answer charges of bootlegging gasoline.

CHUNGKING, China, June 8 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops clung desperately to the outskirts of the shell-ruined town of Chuhsien today under the third day of bombardment from an encircling ring of Japanese who already had captured a suburban air base only 700 miles from Japan.

Suggestions for the bride-to-be as to clothes, flower arrangements and other details of the ceremony were offered yesterday at Arnold Constable's bridal forum. A trio of consultants, whose business it is to assist families bewildered by the many problems connected with weddings, was on hand to give helpful hints.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Men make no war on those whom they trust. The death-dealing antagonisms on both sides in the present war are founded on mutual mistrust. In this lies the ultimate enemy to be fought. Here is the prime evil crying for remedy.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The War Production Board announced today that an order is under discussion which will save another 6,000 tons of tin a year by substituting blackplate and terneplate for it in the manufacture of cans for vegetables and certain other products.

The four-story apartment house at 2012 Sixty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, was purchased by H. Meerbaum, Inc., from P. Walker Morrison, Lazarus Joseph and Leon Leighton, trustees of Series B-K, for cash above a $80,000 purchase money mortgage.

The fourteen-story mercantile building at 300 Fourth Avenue, at the northwest corner of Twenty-second Street, has been sold by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to a syndicate formed by investing clients of Omnia Properties, Inc., with the Wood, Dolson Company acting as brokers and George M. Jaffin acting as attorney for the purchasing corporation.

A witness at the Special Sessions trial of two aides of Dr. Edward S. Cowles, the psychiatrist, for allegedly practicing medicine without licenses in Dr. Cowles's Body and Mind Foundation in East Sixty-ninth Street, testified yesterday that he had heard the psychiatrist tell a large gathering in his clinic recently that "most of those present" had obtained help from him "because they could obtain no help from the medical profession."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 8 -- Despite the successes of United States forces in the Midway battle, the Pacific Coast was cautioned today against falling into the belief that it had been relieved of all danger of attack.
The Frick Collection at 1 East Seventieth Street has placed on display several works of art recently acquired, it was announced yesterday.

SKYTOP, Pa., June 8 -- While war-accelerated research by industry will result in many new products after the war, the general public will not turn to them until two or three years after peace has come, by which time demand for things which people are now doing without will have been met.

Twenty-thousand New Yorkers jammed Madison Square Garden last night to give a roaring, tumultuous ovation to the fifteen thorns in the Axis side. The fifteen British and American heroes, for their part, were "completely dazed" by the magnitude of their reception and viewed it as "something you dream about but can't believe is real."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 -- "Kismet," Edward Knobloch's 1911 play about a Baghdad beggar, will be filmed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer this season with William Powell playing the beggar, Hajj, the character which the late Otis Skinner created on the New York stage.

The Army and Navy relief groups will split approximately $72,280 as a result of Katharine Cornell's revival of George Bernard Shaw's "Candida," under the auspices of the American Theatre Wing War Service, Inc. This was disclosed yesterday by Gertrude Macy, Miss Cornell's general manager, who handled the business arrangements.

The set-up and plan of operation of the State War Transportation Committee was released here yesterday at the same time that the program was made public in Albany by the committee's chairman, Carroll E. Mealey, president of the State Tax Commission.

CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -- Within a few weeks the country is expected to be almost 100 per cent on a wartime body and nerve building diet of enriched, vitamin-packed flour and bakery foods, milling trade authorities said today.

Department Store Sales Off 3% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 3 per cent for the week ended June 6, in comparison with the corresponding week of last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

LAKEHURST, N.J., June 9 -- The bodies of four of the twelve men who died late last night when two blimps came together in mid-air and fell into the ocean about four miles off Manasquan Inlet were recovered today, but the Navy, Coast Guard and private searchers continued a vigilant hunt for the eight who were still missing.
RYE, N.Y., June 9 -- The Eastern invitation interscholastic tennis tournament started today on the courts of the Manursing Island Club with an entry of fifty-four players representing eleven schools.

A statement calling for the establishment of Palestine as a post-war refuge for Jews of Central and Eastern Europe was issued yesterday under the signatures of seventy-five Christian clergymen and laymen.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 9 -- The Commander in Chief of the German Navy, Grand Admiral Erich Raeder, spent last week in Norway inspecting defenses, it was reported today from Oslo.

Greater use of arbitration methods among nations will have to be made after this war if future wars are to be avoided, Frederick E. Hasler, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, declared yesterday. Speaking before more than 250 leading business men, Mr. Hasler accepted, on behalf of the chamber, the annual Importers Guide Award, sponsored jointly by that publication and the American Arbitration Association.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 9 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued the following communique:

Illegal price-fixing activities and production restraints were charged in two Federal indictments yesterday to seven corporations, an association and ten individuals engaged in the flexible metal hose and tubing industry. The defendants included the American Brass Company and other concerns which, according to the indictment, dominate 60 per cent of their field.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Mrs. Oveta Gulp Hobby has hung up her linen daytime frock and donned her new khaki uniform, with a colonel's silver eagles, as head of the Women's Auxiliary Army Corps.

Pere Marquette Issue Equipment trust certificate dealers awaited with interest yesterday to learn whether the $680,000 issue of these securities contemplated by the Pere Marquette Railway in part would be callable. The Interstate Commerce Commission has received an application for approval of the financing, but Washington advices did not touch on the callable aspect.

Police Commissioner Valentine made public yesterday the report of his department for 1941. It showed decreases as compared with 1940 in the number of felony complaints received and major crimes reported, but an increase in the number of arrests.
CHUNGKING, China, June 9 -- "The situation remains grave," declared T.F. Tsiang, director of the Political Affairs Department of the Executive Yuan, at a press conference today.

After Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick had warned yesterday that the city could accomplish its post-war construction program costing $628,000,000 only if the Federal Government contributed $272,700,000 toward it, the Board of Estimate unanimously adopted the program as a step toward taking up the slack in employment after the war ends.
ST. LOUIS, June 9 -- The Cardinal drive to whittle down the seven-game Brooklyn lead was halted before it got started tonight when the scheduled arc-light contest was called off.
CHUNGKING, June 9 (AP) -- The Chinese Command issued this communique tonight:

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Army and Navy drains on personnel have made it necessary for large numbers of women to enter the nursing profession or become Red Cross nursing volunteers to maintain civilian health, officials said today.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Roosevelt today called upon Americans in those areas wheve there is enough gasoline to cut nonessential driving in half, and to drive slowly in the hope that the resultant conservation of rubber will make unnecessary further compulsory action by the government.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Mill buying of moderate proportions early in the session and again on a later setback caused a stronger tone today in wheat. There also was some buying induced by the announcement the government would provide storage room for 60,000,000 bushels of grain in wooden bins.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 9 -- Although sporadic fighting continues around Knightsbridge, the focus of the Libyan battle moved south-ward yesterday to Bir Hacheim, where Axis tanks, infantry, artillery and dive-bombers joined for their tenth attack on the Free French position.

The sister ships Kaga and Akagi are no more. Tossing in his rubber boat in the waters off Midway, our wounded Ensign Gay watched the two great Japanese carriers blasted into flame from stem to stern as their planes circled helplessly above them, unable to land on the blazing furnaces which had been their nests.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. of Brooklyn was virtually assured yesterday of the Democratic nomination for Governor when Frank V. Kelly, Brooklyn Democratic leader, predicted that he would get the unanimous support of the Kings County delegation to the State convention.
As time went on in the British prisoner of war camp at Poppi, Italy, where I spent my last two months of imprisonment by the Axis, our life steadily improved from a very barren beginning.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Bobby Jones, the Atlanta golfer, and Arthur M. Loew of Glen Cove, N.Y., a motion-picture executive, have been commissioned in the Army and ordered to active duty.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Intercity bus companies were ordered by the Office of Defense Transportation today to discontinue all express services, services to golf clubs, race tracks and other amusement places, as well as thinly patronized schedules, and to freeze present routes and pool or stagger competitive services.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- John F. Lane, secretary-treasurer of Pullman, Inc., describing present conditions as a "windfall," declared in Federal District Court today that competition on an unprecedented scale would confront the Pullman interests after the war.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Ways and Means Committee declined today to change the rate of tax on gasoline, but raised the tax on lubricating oil and on still wines.

RYE, N.Y., June 9 -- After what he accomplished today in the first round of the thirty-eighth annual United States Seniors Golf Association championship, it would not be at all surprising to find Ellis Knowles crowned champion by the time it's all over Friday night.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 9 -- China's war aims are political freedom and economic justice for Asia, T.V. Soong, Chinese Minister of Foreign Affairs, declared today at the alumni luncheon, final event of Yale University's commencement.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Roosevelt has appointed the nine members of the National Railway Labor panel which was authorized by Executive order on May 22.

PENSACOLA, Fla., June 9 (AP) -- A Navy patrol plane with ten men aboard has been unreported since it took off on a routine training flight Friday and is presumed lost in the Gulf, officers at the naval air station here announced today.

Expenditures anticipated by up-State industrial building plans filed with the State Labor Department for approval thus far this year are running almost two to one ahead of last year's record-breaking figures. Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The cruiser Houston, sunk by Japanese bombs in the Battle of Java, at an earlier date fought off waves of Japanese bombers and saved intact a merchant convoy entrusted to her care, the Navy Department revealed today.

New York University, largest in the nation, will celebrate its 110th annual commencement exercises today at 10:30 A.M. on Ohio Field of the University Heights campus, 181st Street and University Avenue, the Bronx. About 20,000 persons are expected to attend.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter to THE TIMES of June 6 Milton M. Hermanson rightly cites the inadequately realized investment merit of our war bonds; but his analogy, "there is no difference between investing in a bond and placing money in a savings bank," still understates their advantages.

Selected as outstanding examples of students who, through their own effort and determination, have overcome physical handicaps, two young women received the first Alfred E. Smith scholarships yesterday at a luncheon of the Men's League in Aid of Crippled Children at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

CINCINNATI, June 9 -- A persistent band of athletes, if nothing else, the Giants resumed their climb back toward third place in the National League today by tripping the Reds, 3 to 1, in the first of a two-game series.

In response to a call by the American Association of Advertising Agencies, more than 200 agencies have already volunteered their services or the services of individuals within the agencies for work on government war-aid advertising in cooperation with the Advertising Council, the association announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today that hearings begin here on July 8 on a voluntary plan for dissolution and liquidation filed last Thursday by the Northern States Power Company (Delaware).

DETROIT, June 9 -- An "emergency" or "interim" automobile tire, designed to keep most of America's motor cars in operation until the government's rubber substitute program bears fruit, is being sought by the combined technological resources of the automotive and tire industries.

Members of the New York Curb Exchange held their final election of a nominating committee yesterday, choosing Harry A. Tracy, Joseph F. Crowley, O.F. Browning Jr. and Edward C. Werle as Class A members and Robert J. Lewis, James C. Warren and Mathew Dean Hall as Class B members.

The Ed Wynn show, "Laugh, Town, Laugh!" has been postponed for a week, Mr. Wynn having broken four fingers of his right hand during a rehearsal. Originally scheduled for next Monday, the variety show will not arrive at the Alvin until June 22.

RED HOOK, N.Y., June 9 -- Youthful fighting legions hit the fields of Hudson Valley lands today only to come up with hands blood-red. But the stain was of strawberries, the battle one of farmers against a critical labor shortage.

IN recent years the press and medicine have shared the greatest literary popularity of any professions in the world. The doctor books have been legion, but newspaper books have been a deluge. Although country editors, tabloid editors and veterans who knew Pulitzer, Hearst or Scripps "when" have all had their say in what they may have fondly hoped was the greater permanency of book form, the foreign correspondents have ruled the roost.

COLUMBIA, Mo., June 9 -- Speaking at the commencement exercises of the University of Missouri, from which he was graduated as a Bachelor of Science thirty-one years ago, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, today asserted that the total production of war goods now was "higher than we had any reason to suppose it could be" when the munitions blueprints were drawn.

SYRACUSE, June 9 -- Successful functioning of the nation-wide program of civilian protection depends almost entirely upon the ability of municipal officials to enlist "the loyalties and activities of the ordinary people," said James M. Landis, Federal Civilian Defense Director, tonight at a dinner meeting of the convention of the New York State Conference of Mayors and Other Municipal Officials.
BERLIN, June 9 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique issued today follows:
The Fordham University College of Arts and Sciences, uptown, held its ninety-seventh annual commencement exercises last night in the gymnasium on the Rose Hill campus, graduating 258 seniors.

A committee representing fifteen national retail trade associations will confer tomorrow morning in Washington with Joseph L. Weiner, deputy director of the division of civilian supply of the War Production Board, to obtain the government's views on the necessity for retail and wholesale inventory limitation, it was stated yesterday following a closed meeting of retail executives at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Twelve FBI operatives and a detail of Union City, N.J., policemen under Deputy Chief Edward Mescall surrounded Dr. Leopold William A. Brandenburg's home at 2802 Hudson Boulevard in Union City at 7 o'clock yesterday morning.

AT AN OPERATIONAL BASE, in the Southwest Pacific, June 8 (Delayed) -- An American fighter pilot who was missing after a recent combat has returned to this base after harrowing jungle experiences. His worst moment came when a crocodile attacked him as he was swimming a river.

There is nothing new in the story of the Nazi campaign to stamp out religion, or in the heroic resistance of the church leaders to the systematic attempt to destroy the last vestiges of religious freedom. When the history of this new Reign of Terror is written, it will appear that the strongest centers of opposition to the claims of the God-State were not universities, trades unions, political parties, courts or organized business.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Admiral William D. Leahy, Ambassador to France, declared at a press conference today that the United States should continue in its purpose of defeating the Axis but should give every practicable assistance to the French people, short of interference with that effort.

Never before have the American people been called upon to pay anything approaching the cost of the present war, yet never have the American people seemed less concerned about the cost of a national objective. The President has asked Congress for a new 1943 War Department appropriation of $39,400,000,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Why do we persist in the folly of permitting our valuable tankers and cargo vessels to brave the submarine-infested coastal voyages alone? What do we gain thereby except mounting losses of vessels and cargoes and sailors? Since February, on the basis of official statements, approximately 250 of our freighters and tankers have been lost on this side of the Atlantic.

BOSTON, June 9 -- The body of a man identified as Benjamin Pierce Cheney of 50 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, was found today beside a lonely desert road fortynine miles south of Kingman, Ariz. He was a victim of thirst. An empty canteen lay beside the body.

President Theodore J. Knapp of the Queens County Jockey Club announced yesterday that Aqueduct would make its contribution to war relief on Saturday, June 27. With Whirlaway and Market Wise scheduled to meet again in the Brooklyn Handicap, that day should be the best of the meeting and the track will donate its entire proceeds, minus the purses and added money for stakes, to Army and Navy relief and the United Service Organizations.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- The adoption of a rule under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, designed to clarify and to make more specific the procedure for withdrawal from registration by a broker or dealer, was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Reversing a decision of Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday that city employes who volunteered before April 1, 1942, as members of the reserve forces of the United States and were later called to active service were entitled to receive from the city the differential between their service pay and their city salaries.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The coming Congressional elections have produced a great furor about the pre-Pearl Harbor voting record of certain Senators and Representatives. The purpose, of course, is to return to Congress or to elect only those who will prosecute the war with all their energies.

NEWARK, June 9 (AP) -- Four thousand fans who turned out tonight to see the last nocturnal game at Ruppert Stadium for the duration were treated to a sparkling show as Montreal vanquished Newark, 7 to 6, in ten innings.

With the decks tilting under them as their ship listed, a gaping torpedo hole torn in her port side, the gun crew of a medium-sized Norwegian merchant vessel fired half a dozen shots at the Nazi submarine that had attacked them and broke into cheers when it appeared that one of their shells had hit its target, a mile and a half distant.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The breach between the C.I.O. and the United Mine Workers of America widened today with the announcement by the United Construction Workers Organizing Committee that it was severing its direct affiliation with the C.I.O. to become a division in District 50 of the U.M.W.

CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- Jimmy, Dykes, fiery manager of the White Sox, must dig into his bank account for $250 to pay a limit fine imposed upon him today by President Will Harridge of the American League for his "conduct and deliberate stalling tactics" in the second game of a double-header at Boston last Sunday.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 9 -- The Inter-American Conference on Coordination of Police and Judicial Measures, in session here since May 27, with nineteen republics participating, closed today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- A registration statement covering 90,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the G. C. Murphy Company, a chain-store organization with headquarters in McKeesport, Pa.

Americans returning to the United States from Scandinavia on the Swedish-American liner Gripsholm were cautioned not to talk about anything they had observed abroad, they disclosed when the liner arrived here yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (AP) -- The Athletics made only two hits off Southpaw Edgar Smith tonight, but capitalized on both to beat the White Sox, 2 to 0, behind the seven-hit twirling of Bob Harris.

Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding general of the First Army and the Eastern Defense Area, and Vice Admiral Adolphus Andrews, commandant of the Eastern Sea Frontier, were named yesterday as grand marshal and deputy grand marshal, respectively, of the all-day "New York At War" parade to be held on Fifth Avenue on Saturday.

He Showed Them Two victims of early miseducation somehow managed to surmount their poor start in life sufficiently to figure in the day's news. One is Torpedo Plane Pilot Ensign George H. Gay Jr., who fought in the Battle of Midway Island and has sent us the first eyewitness account.

RKO's "The Mayor of Forty-fourth Street," a medodrama with music, which arrives at Loew's Criterion, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Featured in the picture are George Murphy, Anne Shirley, William Gargan, Richard Barthelmess, Joan Merrill and Freddy Martin and his orchestra.

CLEVELAND, June 9 (U.P.) -- Joseph B. Eastman, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, praising the role of the railroads in transporting war materials, said today that he saw "nothing to be gained" in the government taking over the roads.

Denmark will arise despite the war, Mrs. Ruth Bryan Rohde, former United States Minister to that country, declared yesterday at the annual luncheon meeting of the Danish-American Women's Association, Inc., in The Cottage of the Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South.
The apartment house for seventeen families at 71-73 Elliott Avenue, Yonkers, was sold by Elsie N. Block to I. Cohen through Victor Cantor, broker.

The Greeks threw their lives and everything they had into their fight for freedom. It is a fight in which we have joined. But they are conquered and stripped to their last crusts of bread so that Germany may still fight on stolen food. Unless help reaches them quickly the whole nation will starve.

In a 5-to-4 decision handed down on Monday the Supreme Court declared that "courts are competent to adjudge the acts men do under color of a constitutional right, such as that of freedom of speech or of the press or the free exercise of religion, and to determine whether the claimed right is limited by other recognized powers, equally precious to mankind."

While the war risk insurance losses of the two large American pools covering ocean shipping reach an unprecedented total of $46,486,068 in the first five months of 1942, due mainly to numerous sinkings off the Atlantic Coast, the unfavorable balance of the insurance organizations since the outbreak of war in Europe has been only $1,453,690.

The varied activities of the USO not only contribute to morale in the armed forces but serve to relieve commanding officers of welfare duties so that they can devote more time to the job of winning battles, Major Gen. Thomas A. Terry, commanding the Second Corps Area, said yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 9 -- Funeral services for Reinhard Heydrich, late Reich Protector for Bohemia-Moravia, were held today in Berlin in the new Reich Chancellery in the presence of Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Heinrich Himmler, Gestapo chief, both of whom made brief addresses.

With the heavy liquidation which had plunged futures prices to losses of more than $6 a bale in a week apparently spent, the cotton market, in turning upward yesterday, was susceptible to moderate demand in the face of a paucity of contracts.

The war in the desert apparently continued without decisive advantage to either side yesterday, as tank crews sweltered in temperatures of 110 degrees and the hot wind of North Africa blew over the Libyan sands.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 9 -- Finishing with a 38, only three over men's par, after faulty putting resulted in a 45 for the outgoing nine, Miss Ann Pink of the Rye Golf Club topped the largest field of the season in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tourney at the Century Country Club today.

Long Island Sound fishermen have been forwarding reports of rather good fishing for that area. In the New Haven sector black-fish have been taken in good numbers and near Branford at New Reef one of 10 pounds 14 ounces was caught by Bert Crosby.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 9 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. George H. Brett, commander of United Nations' Air Forces in the Southwestern Pacific, today announced awards of silver stars to twenty United States fliers for action in the Philippine and Australian war zones.

CHUNGKING, China, June 9 (AP) -- Chinese forces still in possession of the walled town of Chuhsien have killed or wounded 7,000 Japanese in three days, raising enemy casualties to more than 18,000 in furious but thus far futile Japanese assaults upon the key rail town in Western Chekiang Province, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

All of the proposed amendments to the rules of the American Kennel Club which had been previously approved by the board of directors were adopted yesterday at the quarterly meeting of the delegates of the organization. The officials met at the club's quarters.

A new solution to the problem caused by the War Production Board's seizure of rolling stock was offered by the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad yesterday in the form of a proposal that it buy back from the public about $5,000,000 of equipment trust certificates it sold last July.

A number of leases for quarters in buildings on Park Avenue were included in the contracts for residential space reported yesterday by brokers. The balance of the rentals were about equally distributed in building's on the East and West Sides of Manhattan.

LONDON, June 9 -- The Admiralty announced tonight that a severe blow had been struck at Axis communications to Libya by a single British submarine. An Italian destroyer of the Navigatori class, three supply ships bound for Bengazi and a small merchant vessel loaded with explosives were sent to the bottom, it was announced.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- A Burmese monsoon struck down four heavy United States bombers from Indian bases after they had delivered an attack on vital Japanese operations at Lashio, Burma, on June 3, the War Department announced here tonight on the basis of delayed reports from Major Gen. Lewis H. Brereton.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 9 -- Warner Brothers is planning a remake of George M. Cohan's "Little Johnny Jones," which was first filmed in 1923 and again in 1929 by the studio. The earlier screen versions were produced under licensing contracts from Cohan, and negotiations are now in progress for the rights to make a third film edition.

Youthful after-school gardeners exhibited their practical application of the victory garden plan yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the New York Plant and Flower Guild, held at the Children's Garden, Sixty-fifth Street and York Avenue.

The plump, pleasant person we describe now has a preference for parties of a very special sort. She likes them a bit on the smallish side -- gatherings that are friendly and informal, spontaneous and gay. Her chief care, she asserts, is for the hostess, and her primary function is to perform all those odd culinary tasks that complicate the career of a party-giving house-keeper.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 9 -- Major Gen. Walter C. Sweeney was called out of retirement today to take command of the State Guard, which has been the center of sharp controversy in the six months since the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor made this coast a potential battle front.

Delegates from twenty-three States and the British West Indies registered yesterday in the Hotel Pierre for the first National Conference of Bundles for Britain, Inc., held to present reports on the progress of this organization which was founded in December, 1939.

Despite wartime restrictions, candy makers will probably be able to produce enough of the "low cost food item" to meet public needs during 1942, manufacturers were assured yesterday by government spokesmen and industry leaders at the fifty-ninth annual convention of the National Confectioners Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, June 9 -- Carrying out heavy raids on the Ruhr for the fourth time since 1,000 bombers were used to destroy a large part of the Old City of Cologne, the Royal Air Force lost eighteen aircraft last night. Bad weather was believed to have taken as heavy a toll as the German defenses. Under the circumstances it is folly to try to guess the size of the force involved on a percentage basis.

Axis radio broadcasts yesterday indicated that the Japanese naval authorities were preparing the Japanese people by guarded and roundabout means for the news of a naval defeat in the Midway Island battle.

The results of increased military and civilian travel and of higher fares were shown yesterday in a report of the Pullman Company, car-operating subsidiary of Pullman, Inc. The report disclosed that gross revenues of the Pullman Company in April were the highest for that month in any year and the highest for any month since the Summer of 1930.

When Brenda Frazier Kelly, New York City's glamour girl of the debutante class of '39, was 8 years old she was allowed $2 a week pocket money to spend on herself. Yesterday, on her twenty-first birthday, she inherited a fortune of more than $3,500,000.

LONDON, June 9 -- The home rails again provided one of the main features of the trading on the Stock Exchange today. London Midland Scottish ordinary rose 206d to u20 1/4, Southern deferred 5s to u17, London North Eastern second preference 7s 6d to u22 1/4 and Great Western 5s to u46 1/2.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 9 -- The Foreign Ministry stated officially this evening that an Argentine note protesting the torpedoing of the Argentine tanker Victoria was delivered in Berlin today. No confirmation has yet been received that a similar note of protest has been delivered to the Italian Government.
LONDON, June 9 -- The arming of Jews in Palestine was debated in the House of Lords today at a stormy session, in which Lord Wedgwood defended his opinion that they should be permitted to mobilize.

TRENTON, N.J., June 9 -- Warning local authorities that regulations "must be carried out to the letter," Leonard Dreyfuss, State Director of Civilian Defense, made public today orders formally imposing the new Army restrictions on illumination in the metropolitan and coastal areas of New Jersey.

Although he is not a defendant, Dr. Edward S. Cowles's tactics as head of the Body and Mind Foundation, in East Sixty-ninth Street, became the principal subject yesterday in the Special Sessions trial of his aides, Rudolph Rebold, a chemist, and Mrs. Eveline Dolin Schulman, for allegedly practicing medicine in the foundation's clinic without State licenses.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 9 -- Following are the citations of President Seymour and the Public Orator, Professor Frederick A. Pottle, in awarding honorary degrees at the Yale commencement exercises today, the recipients being listed in the order in which the degrees were conferred:

Hank Borowy required only 1 hour 36 minutes to beat the Tigers yesterday at the Stadium. The former Fordham right-hander, whom Paul Krichell signed to a Yankee contract with a borrowed pen, pitched by far his best game of the season while setting down Detroit with four hits, 4--1.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- A program for drastic reductions in the Work Projects Administration was presented to the House today by its Appropriations Committee for consideration tomorrow. It will be used to sound out Congressional sentiment on whether the agency shall continue through the war period or shall be closed down.

Mrs. Samuel Levin, mother of Corporal Meyer Levin who was Captain Colin Kelly's bombardier in the successful attack on the Japanese battleship Haruna, appealed at City Hall yesterday to everyone in the city to buy war bonds and stamps.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Indians pushed over a run in the tenth inning to edge out Washington, 7--6, in a three-hour game tonight.

Special Notice Members of the Uniformed Force are notified that permission has been granted to the Army and Navy Union, Garrison No. 4100. of the New York City Fire Department, to hold its Second Annual Picnic and Games at Adelphi Athletic Field. Queens, on June 21, and to sell tickets to members of the department.

VICHY, France, June 9 -- Absence of news from Vichy and the fact that the copy baskets on the censors' tables have never been so empty cannot be taken as evidence that nothing is happening here. It merely means a marked reduction of the number of people "in the know."

BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- Bobby Doerr collected four hits, including a homer and a double, out of four tries today when the Red Sox regained second place Toy drubbing the fast-traveling Browns, 7--4, in the series opener.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 9 (AP) -- Gibby Brack's left field single, which scored Nap Reyes from second base, broke up an 11-inning pitching duel between Bobby Coombs and Nick Strincevich today and gave Jersey City a 4-to-3 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in the final game of a four-game series.

Creation of a small stockpile of critical materials for this area to meet emergencies and prevent stoppage of production is now under consideration by the War Production Board, John P. Maguire, WPB regional director, reported yesterday, at his first press conference.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The prediction of Senator Murray, after conferring with the President today, that, on the basis of government studies now under way, a means will be found to keep in service 20,000,000 of the 30,000,000 American private cars, is supported by statistics which some industrial students of the problem have compiled.

NEWARK, N.J., June 9 -- After three postponements last week, the Essex County Symphony Society tonight opened its seventh season of outdoor concerts at the City Schools Stadium. There was an audience of 13,000, Dimitri Mitropoulos was the conductor and Vitya Vronsky and Victor Babin, duo-pianists, were the soloists.

Industrial stocks on the New York Stock Exchange advanced yesterday, several to new high levels for the year, but in the final hours the market eased and the close was mixed. THE NEW YORK TIMES industrial average rose 0.24 to 126.69, the rail average fell 0.10 to 17.17 and the combined average gained 0.07 to 71.93.

The six-story apartment house on a plot 135 by 100 feet at 43-34 Forty-ninth Street, Sunnyside, L.I., was sold to an investing client of James C. McCormick, Inc., brokers. Sale of the property, which contains seventy-one apartments, was for cash above mortgages totaling $189,200.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., formerly the Merchants Association, announced yesterday that its board of directors had adopted a report opposing the 8 P.M. curfew for retail stores proposed by the City Department of Commerce, of which George A. Sloan is commissioner.

BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Valdina Farm's Valdina Orphan qualified handily for Saturday's Constitution Handicap at Suffolk Downs by romping to a six and three-quarters lengths victory over Phil Reuter's Curious Roman and three other rivals in today's mile feature.

Although production of pianos will stop on July 31, the National Piano Manufacturers Association plans to intensify its publicity and consumer education programs to insure maintenance of consumer acceptance at its present high level. Lawrence H. Selz, secretary, announced yesterday at the group's annual meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
LONDON, June 9 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

Women like to potter. But they also like to look pretty. Often the two clash, for it is difficult to decide between an irresistible desire to paint the porch furniture and a commendable wish to keep a manicure.

After three successive weeks of record low death rates, the index of general health conditions rose toward more "expected" levels in New York City last week, it was reported yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records in the city Health Department.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, June 10 -- Red Army men and marines continued to stand firm today against the onslaught of the Eleventh German Army's ten divisions on Sevastopol. The midnight Soviet communique reported that the Nazi forces had been hurled back with heavy losses.

HANNIBAL, Mo., June 9 (AP) -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, came back today to the scenes of his boyhood and baseball-playing days in Hannibal, the Mississippi River city which claims him and Mark Twain as its two most distinguished sons.

In the Roman Catholic churches of the Netherlands, on the morning of Sunday, Aug. 3, 1940, parishioners settled back in their pews as the priest slowly mounted the pulpit to read a pastoral letter bearing the signatures of Dr. J. de Jong, Archbishop of Utrecht, and the Bishops of Breda, Bois le Due, Roermund and Haarlem.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Henry F. Grady, head of a recently returned United States technical mission to India, reported to President Roosevelt today that the groundwork had been laid so that war production in India could be increased within a year to a point where it would sustain the Burma-China-India front with materiel, aside from tanks and planes.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Delegates to the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers voted overwhelmingly at a lively session today to table indefinitely a resolution urging a national sales tax. The measure represented a reversal of the association's stand against sales taxes as "unsound and undesirable."

Mayor La Guardia's pension plan for staggering police retirements received yesterday indirect support from the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, representing 19,000 members of the Police Department, at the association's monthly meeting and annual election of officers in the Hotel Commodore.

HOLLYWOOD, June 9 -- The will of John Barrymore, filed for probate today in Superior Court, while observing all the legal formalities, went on to pick from his life as a stage and film star three objects inanimate and one living, a dog, for specific mention.
Trading in Manhattan yesterday was confined largely to smaller loft and residential buildings. A large downtown garage was taken under lease.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Administration lost another round of its fight with the Congressional farm group today when the House instructed its conferees on the 1943 Appropriation Bill of the Department of Agriculture to insist that government-owned wheat surpluses be sold at parity.

LONDON, June 9 -- The award of Victoria Crosses to a naval officer and a naval petty officer for throwing two unexploded bombs off a submarine that might have had to crash dive any moment was announced today. They were the fortieth and forty-first V.C.'s of the war.
NEW YORK Mrs. Philip G. Gossler and her daughter, Miss Marion Saffold Gates, are staying at the Ritz-Carlton.

Four correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES recently returned from various theatres of the war told an audience in The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, last night, that so far as they could see since their arrival in this country the American people were not yet fully aware of what total war meant and of the task confronting them before achieving victory.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill announced jointly today the creation of a Combined Production and Resources Board and a Combined Food Board, with Broad powers to coordinate the military materiel and food stocks of the United Nations.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 9 -- Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont added an 80 to her first-round 82 for a total of 162 to hold her slim lead of one stroke as the second round was completed in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association medal play championship over the Rock Spring course today.
Trading in Manhattan yesterday was confined largely to smaller loft and residential buildings. A large downtown garage was taken under lease.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Administration lost another round of its fight with the Congressional farm group today when the House instructed its conferees on the 1943 Appropriation Bill of the Department of Agriculture to insist that government-owned wheat surpluses be sold at parity.

LONDON, June 9 -- The award of Victoria Crosses to a naval officer and a naval petty officer for throwing two unexploded bombs off a submarine that might have had to crash dive any moment was announced today. They were the fortieth and forty-first V.C.'s of the war.

MADISON, N.J., June 9 -- Dr. Arlo Ayres Brown, president of Drew University, conferred seventy-three degrees and announced awards today at Drew's seventyfifth commencement exercises. Dr. Franklyn Bliss Snyder, president of Northwestern University, delivered an address entitled "An Incident in the History of Fort Ticonderoga."

While the literature of the Battle of Britain has been plentiful, Flight Lieutenant John Strachey describes the forthcoming "Arise to Conquer" as one of the few accounts written by a pilot who took part in that engagement. The author is Wing Commander lan Gleed, D.F.C., under whom Lieutenant Strachey served in 1941.

NEW ORLEANS, June 9 (AP) -- The United States should be able to absorb a $200,000,000,000 debt after the war, because its government is sound and the lenders have unlimited faith in the contract under which the money was lent to finance the war, the American Institute of Banking was told here today at its annual convention.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill announced jointly today the creation of a Combined Production and Resources Board and a Combined Food Board, with Broad powers to coordinate the military materiel and food stocks of the United Nations.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 9 -- Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont added an 80 to her first-round 82 for a total of 162 to hold her slim lead of one stroke as the second round was completed in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association medal play championship over the Rock Spring course today.

Final figures for the "Candida" revival, which was presented here and in Washington for the benefit of Army and Navy relief, were made public yesterday by Gertrude Macy, general manager for Katharine Cornell, who appeared in the play under the auspices of the American Theatre Wing War Service, Inc.

From the late Victorians and the days of the matter-of-fact romance through A.J. Cronin, Phyllis Bottome, Storm Jameson, Phyllis Bentley and other contemporary British novelists, William C. Frierson of the University of Alabama, has traced the upheavals and drifts of English fiction-writing in "The English Novel in Transition," just released by the University of Oklahoma Press.

Gasoline stocks in the United States declined last week for the twelfth consecutive week, according to figures issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. The total at the close of last week dropped 2,050,000 barrels to 93,305,000 from 95,355,000 barrels the week before.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 -- The pool of sleeping cars maintained by the Pullman Company is both the basis of the existence of the concern and the real reason why railroads almost unanimously have shied away from providing such traveling facilities themselves, David A. Crawford, president of the company, testified today in Federal District Court.

TRENTON, N.J., June 10 -- Denunciation of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City by John Warren, counsel for the City Affairs Committee in its effort to oust five members of the Hudson County Tax Board, brought a rebuke today from Governor Charles Edison at his inquiry into the committee's charges.

The fifteenth running of the $6,800 Shevlin Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday brought the upset of the heaviest choice of the afternoon when, the Milky Way Farm's Dogpatch, an 11-to-1 shot, came through on the rail to defeat R.S. McLaughlin's Fairaris, a 3-to-10 favorite, by three lengths.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A Republican economy group asked the House today to discontinue the Works Progress Administration on the ground that "any man or woman who is able to work can now find work in the United States."

CAMDEN, N.J., June 10 -- Six months ahead of schedule and only one year and three days after the keel was laid, the light cruiser Sante Fe, of the Cleveland class, was launched at 12:03 P.M. today at the yard of the New York Ship Building Corporation.

Internal difficulties in the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation were said yesterday in financial circles to be in part responsible for the second adjournment of the company's annual meeting of stockholders, at Dover, Del., to next Wednesday.

LONDON, June 10 (AP) -- Yesterday, during Reinhard Heydrich's funeral rites in Berlin, Gestapo Chief Heinrich Himmler vowed complete revenge on the Czechoslovak patriots who slew Herr Heydrich. The assassins, who leaped upon his car with automatic pistol and bomb, have not been caught.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies showed an increase of 3.2 per cent in May the smallest monthly rise sine January, 1939, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Losses were reported for the mail order, men's wear and automotive groups, reflecting curtailment of business in consumer durable goods, gasoline rationing, and a reaction in the buying of men's wear following the marked gains early this year.

The formal entry of Joseph Gregory Rice yesterday reached the desk of Dan Ferris for the National A.A.U. track and field championships at Triborough Stadium June 19 and 20. The Mighty Mite will be after his fifth straight 5,000-meter title and, as good as the field is, there is no one in sight to stop him.

SYRACUSE, June 10 -- An appeal by Governor Lehman for all-out participation by "every loyal and physically fit citizen" in the State's war effort and a warning from Major Gen. William N. Haskell, civilian protection director, that the possibility of enemy air attacks on State industrial centers was "a real threat" were features of the final session today of the State's conference of Mayors and other municipal officials.
CHUNGKING, June 10 (AP) -- Following is an addition to yesterday's communique:

Bathers and sun-seekers from New York City probably will continue this Summer to have regular bus service to Jones Beach on Long Island, in the opinion expressed yesterday by an official of the Bee Line, Inc.

The Prospect Park Y.M.C.A. canceled a meeting tomorrow night that it was about to permit in its assembly hall, 357 Ninth Street, Brooklyn, on discovering yesterday that it was to be the first membership meeting of a new organization, Americans for Peace, urging "immediate peace without victory."

The sinking of two Gloucester fishing boats by shell fire from a submarine off the New England coast and the torpedoing of a medium-sized British freighter in the Atlantic were announced yesterday by the Navy. In all, eighty-five survivors of the three ships reached shore.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 10 -- Having temporarily given up his drive in the Knightsbridge area in Libya, Field Marshal Erwin Rommel yesterday continued to throw considerable forces of tanks and infantry, supported by artillery and dive bombers, against the Allied positions at Bir Hacheim.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE.NE-W YORK TIMES : I have reference to a news story which appeared one day last week in your columns and an editorial which appeared on the same day relative to the agreement by the forty-eight Governors on the removal of interstate trade barriers to motor transportation.

Men's Clothing Sales Improve Men's clothing manufacturers and retailers reported that there has been an improvement in retail sales in the Northeast territory the past three days. This has created a note of optimism in the market because June is considered the key month in the movement of seasonal goods.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Rejection by the House of Senate amendments to the Farm Supply Bill providing for the sale of government-owned stocks of grain at less than parity prices was the signal today for fairly general buying of wheat futures on the Board of Trade.

CHUNGKING, China, June 10 -- Chinese troops besieged at Chuhsien hurled back fresh assaults today by Japanese forces, who have had nearly 20,000 casualties in the last five days, but other enemy units were reported to have raced twenty miles farther along the Hangchow-Nanchang railroad to Changshan near the border of Kiangsi.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 10 -- Sixteen newspaper men from thirteen States received Nieman Fellowship awards today for a year's study at Harvard.

Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., manufacturing chemists, reported yesterday the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission of a registration statement covering 240,000 shares of common stock. F. Eberstadt Co. were named as head of an underwriting group which plans to offer the shares to the public.

LOUISVILLE, Ky. June 10 (AP) -- The directors of the nineteen-year-old Kentucky-Tennessee Light and Power Company voted today dissolution of the company after the transfer of most of its properties to the Tennessee Valley Authority.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Indians pushed over three runs in the ninth and added one in the twelfth inning to defeat Washington, 4 to 3, tonight. It was the second consecutive extra-inning victory for Cleveland over the Senators.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- During the first legal tests of New Deal legislation, certain dissents of one member of the Supreme Court, Harlan F. Stone, were so powerful that, aided by the advancing public thought of the times, they became the majority view of the court more quickly than dissents ever have before.

MOSCOW, June 10 -- The German campaign against the guerrillas is continuing and severe battles are progressing behind the lines. About ten regions of considerable size are under the sole control of guerrillas in the German rear.

The large apartment building at the southeast corner of Riverside Drive and West 116th Street, near Columbia University, which was purchased recently by Frederick Brown, the operator, has been resold to an investing client of Marks Marks, attorneys.

A cornfield, thriving in the midst of the activities of New York's night-club block, on Fifty-second Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, gives a rural touch to this sophisticated corner of the city.

LONDON, June 10 -- John Maynard Keynes, famous economist who has advised both the British and the United States Governments and is a wartime advocate of "forced savings," was made a baron in the King's birthday honors list announced tonight.

Twin boys, Kurt and Manfried Amsterdam, who had not seen their parents since 1939, were among eighty-seven passengers and one stowaway who arrived here yesterday morning on the Chilean liner Aconcagua. The 14-year-old refugees, accompanied by a representative of the National Council of Jewish Women, were taken to Ellis Island for medical clearance.

LONDON, June 10 -- Derby fever, an ailment that becomes epidemic in the week preceding the English racing classic, is raging here again. Everywhere people are scheming against gasoline rationing and restricted rail traffic in the hope of getting to Newmarket this weekend where the King's horses -- owned, incidentally, by the taxpayers -- it is predicted, will likely hoist the royal racing colors to new heights.

Mayor La Guardia got a slight surprise at La Guardia Field yesterday morning when an airline employe failed to recognize him as he was about to leave for Washington to urge a fairer distribution of oil and gasoline rationing.

HARTFORD, June 10 -- Gerhard Wilhelm Kunze, former head of the German-American Bund, whose whereabouts is unknown, and Anastase Vonsiatsky of Thompson, Conn., world leader of the National Russian Revolutionary Fascist party, and three others were indicted today by a Federal Grand Jury which charged them with membership in a spy ring furnishing military information to Germany and Japan.

WHITE PLAINS, June 10 -- A housing survey to determine whether White Plains has suffered from an exodus of residents to defense centers elsewhere was completed today by the local realty board with the aid of policemen and postmen.

A newspaper wouldn't assign a reporter to be nearly killed by a tank, captured by the enemy, held in solitary confinement and cross-examined by the Gestapo. These things did happen, however, to Harold Denny of THE TIMES, who went into a section of the Libyan desert last Fall, with seven other correspondents, to see a tank battle.

CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- Prices of hogs turned upward today, advancing 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight from three-week lows which had carried the average price below $14. The top price was $14.25 and most offerings sold at $14 to $14.25.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Reports of continuing naval action in the Aleutian Islands, including enemy statements that Japanese troops had landed on parts of that northern Pacific archipelago, brought tonight only the laconic statement by a naval spokesman that "none of our inhabited islands or rocks are troubled with uninvited visitors up to this time."

A weary investigator who had made more than a dozen telephone calls to four different numbers and had talked to at least a score of executives, clerks, telephone operators, publicity men and stenographers in the War Production Board's office yesterday finally got from an official of the Federal agency an interpretation of the recent order virtually ending private construction.

MOSCOW, Thursday, June 11 -- General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock struck at the Red Army yesterday in the Kharkov sector. The midnight Soviet communique tersely announced a German initiative in an offensive action. It is too early, with the scant information available, to hazard a guess as to whether this is an attempt on the Germans' part to readjust the lines disarranged by Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's May offensive or whether it is more serious.

An apartment consisting of twelve rooms and five baths in the building at 215 East Seventy-second Street has been leased by Theodore Pearson through Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers, who also rented an apartment in 785 Park Avenue to Dr. Augustine L. Walsh and a suite in 530 Park Avenue to W.B. Reynolds through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc.
Yesterday's air attacks upon Germany continued what is now obviously destined to be a Summer-long offensive, an offensive that will probably grow in scope and magnitude.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 (AP) -- The Athletics and the White Sox swapped cellar positions today, Philadelphia going back to the bottom by virtue of the 4-1 Sox triumph. Just 6 percentage points separate the clubs.
The Catholic Church has not only a religious mission but a social one, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman told 538 graduates yesterday at the Fordham University commencement exercises.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 10 -- Total assets of all savings and loan associations in this State increased $28,570,978 in 1941 to a new peak at $476,058,641, Zebulon V. Woodward, executive vicepresident of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Association told delegates to the fifty-fifth annual convention of the association today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 10 -- A resolution calling for the rupture of relations with Germany, Italy and Japan, as required by the undertaking that Argentina signed in Rio de Janeiro, was submitted to the Chamber of Deputies today by Raul Damonte Taborda, chairman of the chamber investigating committee.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 10 -- The National Federation of Catholic Physicians Guilds held its bi-annual meeting here today. The following officers were elected:

Officials of the city and County of San Francisco, Calif., are expected to issue a formal invitation soon for bids on an issue of $4,250,000 of bonds which was authorized By voters on Tuesday. Controller Harold J. Boyd said yesterday that authorization and appropriation formalities would be presented to the finance committee of the Board of Supervisors immediately, and if approved, bids for the bonds might be considered on June 22.

TOKYO, June 10 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Japanese Imperial Headquarters, making its first report on the battles in the Midway Island and Dutch Harbor areas, acknowledged today the sinking of one Japanese aircraft carrier, severe damage to another carrier, damage to a cruiser and the loss of thirty-five planes.

Eliminating the squeeze on manufacturers of women's and children's outer apparel which would have resulted from application of the original Fall seasonal order, the Office of Price Administration issued in Washington yesterday amendments to Maximum Price Regulation No. 153.

The Board of Education, viewing the diamond piles in this city that have grown since Hitler's European conquests to a size that would make Sinbad's eyes pop, is preparing to institute the first diamond-cutting course in any public school in the country at the High School of Industrial Arts, 211 East Seventy-ninth Street, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Associate Justice Frank Murphy took a leave of absence from the Supreme Court bench today and took the oath of a lieutenant colonel in the Army. He said he planned to report at once for at least four months of duty.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Specialization by the United States in the production of bombers, and by Great Britain in the manufacture of fighters will be one of the principal results of the new Combined Production and Resources Board, and combined Food Board, the creation of which was announced yesterday by President Roosevelt.

OTTAWA, June 10 -- Defining his government's policy as "not necessarily conscription but conscription if necessary," Prime Minister William L. Mackenzie King in a two-hour speech this afternoon presented to Parliament the bill amending the present National Mobilization Act so as to permit the sending of drafted men on service abroad.

A set of nine advertising standards, designed to establish competitive equality among retailers selling goods covered by the credit restrictions of Regulation W, was subscribed to yesterday by representatives of more than fifty associations and individual companies, at a meeting sponsored by the National Better Business Bureau in the Hotel Lexington.

MELBOURNE, June 10 -- The unsuccessful gunfire attack on a United Nations vessel by a Japanese submarine off the southeast coast of Australia was understood here today to have occurred some time after the shelling of the shores of Sydney and Newcastle Monday.

In a special letter to its members and other restaurant owners, the Society of Restaurateurs urged yesterday that they join in opposition to the Sheppard bill, now before the United States Senate, to regulate the sales of liquor to members of the armed forces.

Provincetown's last town crier has lost his job. His office was merely commercial and theatrical. Its discontinuance will sadden only those antiquarians who spell shop with two p's and a final or finial e. For a long time and in the days when the crier wore no imitative ancient rig he was a necessity.

In an effort to increase its supply of crowns for bottles, the Pepsi-Cola Company will attempt to stamp them out of old tin cans, Don G. Mitchell, vice president of the company, revealed yesterday. The company has already started the collection of old tin cans, chiefly the No. 10 size, and has acquired about 10,000 to 15,000 for experimental purposes, he said.

DENVER, Col., June 10 (AP) -- Declaring excessive inflation more dangerous than war, Louis H. Pink, New York State Superintendent of Insurance, predicted today that America's hour of "greatest trial" will come "with peace and the demobilization of our armies and war industries."

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Sixty-five of the first group of officer candidates for the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps will be especially selected from among those volunteers already working for the Aircraft Warning Service, the War Department announced today.
