CHUNGKING, China, June 10 -- In a signed article in the Communist newspaper Sin Hwa Jih Pao, written by Naoki, a Japanese seaman who is a prisoner in Chungking, the Japanese naval reverse at Midway and the recent defeat in the Coral Sea are laid to the seamen's lack of endurance because of poor living conditions aboard ships.

As three ex-convicts were about to be sentenced in General Sessions yesterday to long State prison terms for a recent Greenwich Village taproom hold-up, their lawyer, Joseph C. Thomson, quoted Jean Valjean, the ex-convict in Victor Hugo's "Les Miserables," in his protest to the Bishop that society offers no encouragement to felons on their liberation from the galleys.
PHILADELPHIA, June 10 -- The Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn received news of his indictment in Hartford today with a protestation of his innocence and a declaration that he was "dumbfounded" by the charge.

Still another means to circumvent the situation caused by the seizure of railway rolling stock by the War Production Board was outlined yesterday when the Pere Marquette Railway announced it would ask for bids on June 17 for $680,000 of equipment trust certificates on the condition that the proceeds might be invested in United States Government securities.

William Gerald Bishop, who was a principal defendant among the seventeen tried in Federal Court, Brooklyn, in the "Christian Front" sedition case two years ago, took action yesterday to obtain his release from Ellis Island, where he is detained as an enemy alien.

When final victory comes to the United Nations this country "must assume responsibilities" in creating a world order based not on a balance of power between Britain and the United States but on the guarantee of freedom and security for al mankind, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University asserted yesterday at the 110th commencement of the university.

A BRITISH PORT, Thursday, June 11 (AP) -- For the first time in the war King George has visited United States warships in British waters. He was received with the old-time nautical ceremony of the world's greatest naval powers blended with the easy democracy of the nations these ships defend.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Civilians who must fly on essential war business will have equal rights with members of the armed forces in allocation of priorities for airline passage under regulations made public today by the War Department, but "an individual of the armed forces or a civilian engaged in the war effort is not entitled to priorities unless his mission justifies it," the announcement said.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Roosevelt will address the country Sunday afternoon in an unprecedented Flag Day ceremony formally welcoming Mexico into the family of nations fighting the Axis.

Appearing before the City Council yesterday as a member of the City Planning Commission, Park Commissioner Robert Moses stressed the need for immediate establishment of the city's $628,000,000 post-war building program and received a pledge that the Council would act within ten days.

New York racing reached a total of $261,560.38 in its contributions to war relief yesterday when Dr. Edward P. Kilroe, president of Jamaica, turned over checks totaling $125,000, more than matching the total realized from Belmont Park's Army-Navy Day program last Saturday.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 10 -- Richard Behrens, 35 years old, a transport pilot, power-dived to his death in a trimotored ten-year-old Ford plane on the edge of Pleasantdale Cemetery here at 1:40 P.M. today. He was alone in the ship.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 10 (UP) -- United Nations forces in Australia are "prepared for offensive action whenever it is deemed advisable," Army Minister Francis M. Forde announced tonight, and there was renewed speculation that General Douglas MacArthur's campaign to oust the Japanese from the Southwest Pacific might be unleashed soon.

Double Guarantee The indenture of the $680,000 of equipment trust certificates that the Pere Marquette Railway proposes to sell contains the provision that moneys derived from the financing not used for the purchase of equipment may be invested in United States Government obligations.

KEARNY, N.J., June 10 -- The Club Atlante of Mexico City defeated the Scots-Americans, five times champions of the American Soccer League, on Scots Field tonight, 4 to 2. A crowd of 3,000 saw the Mexican stars, who have been making a good-will tour of the United States, triumph.

Fragrant coffee -- at once soothing and stimulating -- is undoubtedly America's favorite beverage. The nation-wide predilection for this aromatic liquid may account, we think, for the minor flurry that is taking place in a mid-city store.

Advertising in Canada is "keeping healthy" under price control, with the Dominion Government playing an important role in extensive use of newspaper space bought at regular rates, Mrs. Doreen Day, fashion director of T. Eaton Co., Montreal, said yesterday in an address at the luncheon meeting of the sales promotion division of the Fashion Group at the Murray Hill Hotel.

CINCINNATI, June 10 -- Continuing our observations along the western fringe of the National League, it should make interesting reading for home consumption to learn that New York's likable Melvin Ott and his ponderous Giants are doing a pretty good job these days, both for themselves and their circuit.

What is probably a unique combination in the fashion world was formed recently by three of New York's leading milliners. Lilly Dache, Sally Victor and John-Frederics have pooled their efforts to make this a great season for millinery.

Government subsidies and low interest loans to thousands of small industrial plants that may be forced to close because of priorities were proposed last night by Philip D. Reed, chairman of the General Electric Company and chief of the bureau of industry branches of the War Production Board.

NEWARK, N.J., June 10 -- A C.I.O. union at the Titeflex Metal Hose Company, a war-production plant here, demanded today that the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practices reverse its recent findings that the company had discriminated against Jews in hiring help.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 10 -- "Tarzan Triumphs," a story of the ape-man's defense of the British Empire against the Nazis in Deepest Africa, will be Sol Lesser's first Tarzan production for RKO, it was learned today. Johnny Weissmuller and Maureen O'Sullivan, who have appeared in Tarzan films at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the last eight years, have been engaged by Lesser for the RKO picture, and William Thiele has been signed as director.

LONDON, June 10 -- The stock markets provided today numerous good features. Gilt-edge issues were stimulated by Chancellor of the Exchequer's reaffirmation of the government's cheap money policy. The 3 1/2 per cent war loan rose to u105 1/4 and the old Consols to u82 5/8.

Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew rebuked Daniel P. Woolley, Commissioner of Markets, and Joseph M. Aimee, director of the Bureau of Weights and Measures in the Department of Markets, in a decision yesterday in which he accused them of conducting a "pre-judged, pre-determined lynching" in revoking the coal dealer's license of the New York Southern Coal Terminal Corporation, West 145th Street and Harlem River.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Talk of a United Nations offensive against Japan to recapture some of the territory she has taken in her march southward received impetus today from Pacific War Council discussions of the American victories in the Naval-Air battles off Midway and in the Coral Sea.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Reporting that crop prospects have rarely averaged better at this season of the year, the Department of Agriculture said today that if weather conditions continued favorable the country would be assured of a record output of farm commodities.
ROME, June 10 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

LONDON, June 10 -- The Polish National Council in London -- the Polish Parliament in exile -- issued today an appeal to the Parliaments of all free nations for moral help to the Polish nation in this its darkest hour, when hundreds of thousands of Poles are being forcibly impressed into the German Army and into labor gangs on the Eastern Front.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The War Department has awarded the Soldier's Medal for Heroism to fourteen enlisted men of the Army.
PARADE ORDER The "New York at War" demonstration (parade) will be held on Saturday, June 13.
TOKYO, June 10 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press ) -- Imperial Headquarters issued the following communique today:

The War Production Board is working on an over-all order designed to ration electricity throughout the country to assure an ample supply for war industries, J. A. Krug, chief of the power branch, of the WPB, declared yesterday at a meeting of the nation's leading utility executives.

The Duchess of Windsor, whose husband as Prince of Wales was frequently characterized as a supersalesman of the British Empire, has gone in for salesmanship herself in a small way, it was learned yesterday.

The vague Japanese claims that they have made landings on or "occupied" some of the Western Aleutian Islands are contradicted by a spokesman for our Navy, who declares that "We have no information about any Japanese on Alaskan soil. Certainly, none of our inhabited areas, islands or rocks are troubled with uninvited visitors up to this time."
BOSTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox maintained their newly won grip on second place today by downing the St. Louis Browns, 10-3, behind the eight-hit pitching of Cecil (Tex) Hughson.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 10 -- What was described as an "apparently successful attempt" at immunizing babies against whooping cough by vaccinating the expectant mother three months before the infant's birth, was reported here today at the annual meeting of the American Medical Association by Drs. Philip Cohen and Samuel J. Scadron of Beth Israel Hospital, New York City.

Bundles for Britain received a grand total of $6,546,153 in cash, contributed articles, revenues from entertainments and profits from the sale of merchandise between its foundation on Dec. 17, 1939, and May 29, 1942, according to a financial statement issued yesterday at its national conference at the Hotel Pierre.

There are a dozen bitter feuds among Nazi leaders marking the lines of cleavage for a crack-up when Adolf Hitler dies or the going gets too tough. The most celebrated quarrel is between Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop and Reichsmarshal Hermann Goering.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The hardest part of the war still lies ahead, Robert Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, declared tonight.
JACKSON, Miss., June 10 (U.P.) -- Several hundred Dutchmen are training 10 hours daily at United States air bases here and at Fort Leavenworth, Kan.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- American production of weapons and munitions recently overtook, that of Britain and soon will be far ahead, Oliver Lyttelton, British Minister of Production, told the people of the United States tonight in a radio address.

BERLIN, June 10 (From German broadcasts recorded in New York) -- All men in the Czechoslovak town of Lidice have been shot, the women sent to concentration camps, the children placed in "educational institutions" and the town itself "leveled to the ground" on the charge that the population gave shelter and assistance to the slayers of the Nazi leader Reinhard Heydrich, the Berlin radio announced tonight.

The American Gold Star Mothers, holding their eighth annual meeting in a year of strife and sacrifice that evokes vivid reminders of 1917 yesterday received the first application for membership from a mother who lost her son in the present seruggle.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 10 -- In their attempt to take Sevastopol at all costs, the Germans now say they are using their previously much-publicized 25-centimeter mortars, whose projectiles are alleged to produce insanity and paralyze every living thing within a radius of 400 yards.

Dr. Chaim Weizmann, who besides having been for years an outstanding Zionist leader has been recognized as one of the world's greatest chemists, was honored last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria attended by 2,100 persons, including many well known in many fields.

The "New York at War" parade, in which 500,000 men and women are expected to march up Fifth Avenue, will he held on Saturday, "rain or shine," it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's committee in charge.

Next Saturday Governor Darden of Virginia will hold a commutation hearing in the case of Odell Waller, Negro sharecropper condemned to death for killing his white landlord. This will be Waller's last chance. The Supreme Court of the United States, to which Waller's attorneys appealed on the ground that he was not tried by a jury of his peers, has refused to intervene.

Thursday night, June 18, has been set for the opening of "Star and Garter," Michael Todd's glorified burlesque show, at the Music Box. Several previews for service men and officers will precede the opening. The show, which is being directed by Hassard Short, stars Bobby Clark and Gypsy Rose Lee.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The War Production Board today approved immediate construction of a 24-inch steel pipeline from Long-view, Texas, to Salem, Ill., which, it said, would provide "an increased supply of oil to the East Coast area within six months."

Although new Army restrictions on the illumination in the metropolitan and coastal areas of New Jersey went into effect officially on Tuesday, Jersey City embellished with fireworks a parade staged last night to spur the sale of war bonds and stamps.

LONDON, Thursday, June 11 -- A strong United States Navy task force has joined the British Home Fleet for a share in the job of keeping Adolf Hitler's high seas fleet from smashing at Allied shipping lanes and maintaining a blockade of German-held Europe.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy approved yesterday a settlement offer of $1,000,000 made by the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company in an accounting suit brought by stockholders of the Radio Corporation of America against General Electric, Westinghouse and certain present and former directors of R.C.A. Justice Levy said that "in all the circumstances the offer of settlement is fair and should be accepted."

It isn't often that the Yankees lose an overtime decision, but yesterday at the Stadium they ran into Alton Benton, and the biggest man on the Detroit squad proceeded to subject the McCarthymen to their first extra-inning setback of the year.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 10 -- Civil war has broken out in Norway in the Trondelag district, with inhabitants of Rissa and Selbu villages fighting the National Samling Hird [Quisling] units. Many persons have been killed or wounded in these encounters, according to reports tonight from Oslo.

Reaction ruled the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and shares sacrifices some of their recent gains. American Telephone and Telegraph and electric equipment issues led the decline. Trading was the smallest of the week and the second smallest of the month.

Part of women's fight in the war can be waged with scissors, needle and thread, it was demonstrated yesterday. The second annual national sewing contest at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria revealed that feminine ingenuity can conserve material by wearing home-sewn, home-designed clothes.

LONDON, June 10 -- The War Office's general staff will be split into two sections, both under the direction of General Sir Alan Brooke as chief of the Imperial General Staff, it was announced today by War Secretary Sir Edward Grigg in the House of Commons.
PEARL HARBOR, June 10 (AP) -- The Japanese force that Americans defeated at Midway Island was an armada of more than thirty

Death benefits received by American families on life insurance policies during April were $92,409,000, the largest monthly total since last October, and the first month in 1942 to show an increase over a year ago, according to the Institute of Life Insurance.

Prominent attorneys, including many long active in international affairs, joined yesterday in support of the current campaign for Russian War Relief at a luncheon held under the auspices of the Lawyers Division of the campaign in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

The Turtle Bay Gardens, cultivated backyards of twenty New York families, resembled a revolving stage yesterday as their overhanging trees and trim flower plots provided scenery for a four-hour festival of continuous entertainment.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- To the astonishment of Senators, who had just been told that the B.F. Goodrich Company planned ultimately to produce 165,000 tons of synthetic rubber annually, an executive of the company compounded some in ten seconds today and bounced it on the floor.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- King George II of Greece was greeted with full military honors and a handshake by the President and Mrs. Roosevelt today when he and his party arrived at the White House after their trip from Cairo, Egypt, part of the way by air.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 10 -- Mr. and Mrs. Archie C. McLave of Westchester Hills scored an 80 at the Century Country Club today to dethrone Mr. and Mrs. James M. Robbing of Mount Kisco as Westchester husband-and-wife golf champions.

PITTSBURGH, June 10 (AP) -- With Rip Sewell permitting only four singles and letting only one man get to second base, the Pirates tonight gained their sixth straight triumph by beating Boston, 3 to 0. It was the Braves' ninth straight setback.
CAIRO, June 10 (AP) -- A British General Headquarters communique said today:

Thirty-nine students will be initiated today into the Hunter College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, national honor society, at a special scholarship assembly in the college auditorium. Dr. Elizabeth Lynskey of the social science department will speak on "Homo Sapiens and the Great Community."

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Members of the National Association of Retail Grocers listened to speeches by government spokesmen today urging cooperation with the OPA in its price-control campaign and then went on record by an overwhelming voice vote as believing the program to be "unsound and fallacious" and recommending that Congress refuse to appropriate funds for "an army of snoopers" to be hired for an enforcement drive.

From Chungking, via London, comes the cheering word that units of British and American air squadrons have reached China. As this news follows the recent meeting of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and Generals Brereton and Chennault, at which the urgent need of air support was emphasized, it must represent a belated effort to remedy a situation which is rapidly becoming critical.

"I Was Framed," a Warner Brothers melodrama, will be the film newcomer opening today at the Palace. Regis Toomey, Julie Bishop, Michael Ames and Patty Hale are featured. The second run, "My Gal Sal," is the associate picture on the double feature program.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Declaring that the recent proposals by the executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations suggesting an approach to peace with the American Federation of Labor were "fantastic counterproposals which were wholly unworthy of serious consideration," the weekly news letter of the American Federation of Labor today assailed the C.I.O.

Checks totaling $120,000 for British war relief were presented yesterday to Sir Walter Citrine, general secretary of the British Trades Union Congress, at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore given in his honor by the American Labor Committee to Aid British Labor, of which Matthew Woll, vice president of the A.F. of L., is chairman.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Enemy submarines are no longer able to operate closer than fifty miles off our coasts as a result of counter-measures taken by the Navy, members of a sub-group of the Truman committee indicated today after a two-hour conference with Secretary Knox.

ST. LOUIS, June 10 -- The first game of the important series between the Dodgers and the Cardinals has yet to be played. Today's contest was called off by President Sam Breadon of the St. Louis club after an early morning exploratory tour of Sportsman's Park.

One Who Knows How the British people behave about their Constitution or how they behave about Nazi bombs over their cities is common knowledge. How the British behave about their tea is something much harder to understand.

The Virginia Public Service Company will redeem on Aug. 1 all of its outstanding first mortgage refunding twenty-year 5 1/2 per cent bonds, Series A, due Feb. 1, 1946, and all of its first mortgage and refunding twenty-year 5 per cent bonds, series B, due Dec. 1, 1950, and all of its first mortgage and refunding twenty-year 6 per cent bonds, series C, due March 1, 1952.
NEW YORK Lieut. Gen. and Mrs. William S. Knudsen have arrived from Washington and are at the WaldorfAstoria.

LONDON, June 10 -- The coal scheme fostered by the government was today assured safe passage through the House of Commons. During the debate Sir John Anderson announced for the government that rationing of coal would not be introduced for the present because inquiries had shown a conviction among the public that it was not now necessary.

Support by the trade at the opening and the close and in spurts throughout the session held the cotton futures market at gains yesterday, with the exception of a brief early period when the rising market attracted profit-taking. Final net gains of 10 to 14 points were made by active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York and other witnesses declared today before a Senate Commerce subcommittee that the Midwest must accept some gasoline rationing and that every available form of transportation, including wooden and concrete barges on inland waterways must be used immediately if New York City and the Eastern seaboard were not to be critically short of fuel oil for heating homes and offices next Winter.
New Jersey's Fish and Game Commission is confident that the bass season, which opens in the Garden State on Monday and lasts until Nov. 30, will be a good one.

For the first time in its history, the Board of Education at its regular meeting yesterday voted to dismiss 125 regularly appointed teachers from the New York City school system, to take effect on Aug. 31. This was made necessary, board members, explained, as a result of a budgetary deficiency.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 10 -- Defying all competition, Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Cresmont, today added a one-under-women's-par 78 to previous scores of 82, 80, for a fifty-four-hole total of 240, and became the Women's New Jersey Golf Association champion as the tourney was completed over the Rock Spring course.

CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- Usually a Cub nemesis, Johnny Podgajny was just that for six innings while he pitched no-hit baseball today, but something happened in the seventh and Chicago got five runs to beat the Phils, 5 to 2. During the uprising the Cubs bunched four hits -- three off Podgajny and another off Ike Pearson.

CINCINNATI, June 10 -- The bat of Big Johnny Mize boomed long and loud along the banks of the Ohio tonight and the result was a 6-to-1 victory for the Giants over the Reds in a game witnessed by 14,183 sorely distressed spectators.

FIFTEEN months ago, in the town of Hattiesburg, Miss., which is only a few miles from Camp Shelby, you could sense a curious thing: the townsfolk were far more sold on the idea of war against Hitler than were the Shelby soldiers, most of whom came from Indiana and Ohio.

The importance of the medical profession in the current conflict and afterwards was stressed by speakers yesterday at the forty-fourth commencement exercises of the Cornell University Medical College held in the auditorium of that institution at 1300 York Avenue.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today added details which will govern the amount of gasoline to be rationed after July 1.

RYE, N.Y., June 10 -- To the general consternation of all those nursing hopes of winning the championship of the United States Seniors Golf Association for some years to come, Ellis Knowles, New York shipping executive, today celebrated his initiation into that venerable but never aged body of linksmen by smashing all existing records as the first half of the field completed play in the tournament.

NEWARK, June 10 (AP) -- Newark maintained a lead of two and a half games over Montreal today by dividing a double-header with the Royals. The Bears were soundly thrashed in the opener, 15 -- 2, but came back with a 3-2 decision in the overtime eight-inning nightcap.

Yugoslavia is a subdued nation that refuses to be subdued. In its rugged hills an army under the leadership of General Draja Mikhailovitch, is carrying on active warfare against the occupying legions of Hitler. The fearless general is continuing a tradition of courage and love of freedom which have, for centuries, been characteristics of the South Slavs -- the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes -- who make up the population of the Yugoslav kingdom.

Luigi Antonini, State chairman of the American Labor party; Alex Rose, State secretary, and Jacob S. Potofsky, representing the right wing group in control of its State organization, conferred yesterday with James A. Farley, Democratic State chairman, and decided to refer the question of whether they should endorse Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., prospective Democratic nominee for Governor, to the entire leadership of the State organization after learning the wishes of the rank-and-file membership.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A half-cent increase was involved in the Federal tax on a pack of cigarettes, which was approved tentatively today by the Ways and Means Committee. The additional $65,500,000 represents about one-third of the additional cigarette revenue requested by the Treasury.

The impact of the Treasury's heavy withdrawals of funds this week from commercial bank depositaries in this city, amounting to about $400,000,000, was minimized by the inflow of funds from out-of-town banks, deposits of government checks here by war materials contractors, and by purchases of government securities by the Federal Reserve Bank, thus putting money into the market.

LONDON, June 11 -- Amid the gayety of a cocktail party in celebration of the Russian pact, the envoys representing Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania solemnly turned their thoughts tonight across the ocean to the United States in reaffirming their faith in the Atlantic Charter.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 11 -- Harvard University closed tis 306th year today and in a stately ritual almost three centuries old awarded 1,825 degrees to students in the college, graduate schools and special departments of the university.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A 69-0 vote of the Senate today completed Congressional action on the readjusted service pay bill and sent it to the White House carrying a minimum base pay of $50 a month for buck privates of the Army and Marine Corps, and apprentice seamen of the Navy and Coast Guard, and $54 for first class privates and seamen, second, class.
The warm weather has been viewed as a prelude to the bass season and many are planning vacations near lakes or ponds this year for more than one reason.

Council President Newbold Morris was the target for a few good-humored jests yesterday as members of the Board of Estimate assumed a spirit of levity at one of their last meetings before Summer recess.

LONDON, June 11 -- A treaty has been signed binding Russia and Great Britain in close alliance in the war against Nazi Germany and the countries "associated with her in acts of aggression in Europe" and pledging cooperation and mutual assistance for twenty years on the principles of the Atlantic Charter.

Stocks did little yesterday. The market on the New York Stock Exchange driifted without direction in a narrow range and closed irregular. What trend there was was accidental. Of the 584 issues traded 199 advanced, 198 declined and the others were unchanged.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 11 -- "Best Foot Forward," George Abbott's current Broadway musical comedy, has been, bought by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for $150,000, it was learned today Of the purchase price, Abbott and the authors. John Cecil Holm, Hugh Martin and Ralph Blane, received "more than 100,000," but a substantial sum was paid to Lester Cowan, Columbia producer, because of a prior deal he had made with Abbott for screen rights to the show.

LONDON, June 11 -- Polish spokesmen here are particularly pleased with the British-Soviet treaty announced today, since it allays apprehensions that such an agreement might contain provisions for territorial changes in Russia's western boundaries.

Strong opposition to the candidacy of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for Governor on the ground that he had shown antilabor bias was expressed last evening by Representative Vito Marcantonio, chairman, and Eugene P. Connolly, secretary of the New York County Committee of the American Labor party.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation and holdings of United States Government securities to be at the highest of the year to date, the latter showing an increase of $35,456,000 for the week.
Those Elusive Facts Despite the confusion surrounding this problem of providing official information for the American people, this column believes it is beginning to get the hang of the thing.

NEWARK, N. J., June 11 -- "Man failure" and faulty supervision of personnel were censured today by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners as mainly responsible for the wreck of a Hudson and Manhattan train April 26 in Jersey City, in which five persons were killed and more than 200 injured.

DUBLIN, June 11 -- The drastic Clothes rationing order promulgated here by Minister of Supplies Sean Lemass early this week has brought the administration up against something like a major internal crisis.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Several hundred persons are dying daily in Athens alone as a result of hardships, and the amount of food thus far sent to Greece has relieved "only slightly" the suffering in Axis-occupied territory, King George II told a gathering in the Red Cross garden this afternoon.

Right now the petroleum shortage in the Eastern States means, as a practical matter, eliminating unnecessary automobile driving. Next Winter it will mean cold houses, schools, offices and factories-a much more serious problem. The extent of the problem has been concisely summarized by Dr. Robert L. Wilson, chairman of the Committee on Petroleum Economics and president of the Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company.

Two hundred and fifty-four officers, comprising the sixth and largest class to complete the intensive officer-training course at the Naval Training School of Indoctrination at Fort Schuyler, Throgs Neck, the Bronx, will be graduated at 10:45 A.M. today as the Navy, stepping up its war training program here, announced plans for expanding present quarters to accommodate the 1,600 young men that are to be assigned to the school in October.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 11 -- Mrs. Beatrice Schepps, 38-year-old wife of a tailor in Fairlawn, N.J., was held here tonight for the murder of her stepdaughter, Beverly, 8, by drowning in a bathtub in the Schepps home at 1001 Fourth Street, Fairlawn.

The Nazis have learned that the people of Belgium, a land "saturated with Catholicism," cannot easily be wooed into joining the "new order." They have found in Cardinal van Roey, Archbishop of Mechelen (Malines), a spiritual opponent deaf alike to blandishments and threats.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 11 -- Although the gallant Free French defenders of Bir Hacheim had repulsed for sixteen days constant attacks by German tanks, guns, infantry and dive-bombers, they were finally forced to withdraw from that outpost in the Libyan defense line last night, it was announced today.

LONDON, June 11 -- The coal proposal for government control of the coal mines was adopted by the House of Commons without a division today. Before the House accepted the Government motion indorsing the coal proposals as set forth in a White Paper it had beaten down a motion by James Maxton, calling for outright nationalization of the Coal mines, by a vote of 329 to 8.

Bail was denied to five Negroes in the Felony Court yesterday when they were arraigned before Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in the hold-up Wednesday night at Lenox Avenue and 134th Street of two sons of prominent residents of the city.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The text of the official White House statement on the Roosevelt-Molotoff conversations follows:

The Most Rev: Stephen J. Donahue, senior anxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, presided last night at the annual commencement of Cathedral College, preparatory department of St. Joseph's seminary, in the Dunwoodie section of Yonkers.
AT ARMY AIR FORCES HEAD-QUARTERS, Hawaii, June 11 (AP) -- "A better show than the World Series," was the way crew members of one of the Army's big B-17 bombers described the battle of Midway.

LONDON, June 11 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden made his announcement of the signing of the British-Russian treaty to a crowded but not a packed House of Commons. The house had been reasonably full all day because of the coal debate.

The announcement that the Senate is holding out for retention in the Agricultural Appropriations Bill of the provision permitting the sale of surplus wheat at subparity levels excited general liquidation in the cotton futures market yesterday near the end of trading.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- The Rev. Kurt E. B. Molzahn, pastor of Old Zion Lutheran Church and one of five men indicted by a Federal grand jury at Hartford yesterday on a charge of conspiracy to violate the Espionage Act of 1917, was arrested today at the parsonage which the government alleges was used as a mail address by German and Japanese spies.

LONDON, June 11 -- The loudest cheers -- or rather a loud but gentlemanly "Hear, hear!" -- greeted Secretary Anthony Eden's announcement in the House of Commons today that there were no secrets in the British-Russian treaty and no commitments not made public.

A program to assure adequate housing for war workers by utilizing existing structures was urged for the United States yesterday by Captain Richard L. Reiss, British housing expert, who has been in this country since April 21 touring the principal war industry areas and conferring with officials of the National Public Housing Agency.

Mayor La Guardia, on a tour of Bellevue Hospital yesterday, held out to a group of volunteer nurses' aides the possibility of salaried employment for them, to replace regular nurses called into war service.

Further declines in bankers' dollar acceptances and in commercial paper outstanding in the United States were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly survey of these markets. The report, which covers May, discloses that bankers acceptances outstanding declined $3,387,000 in the month to $173,906,000, lowest level-in twenty-five years.

Brokers reported yesterday additional lists of names for tenant rosters in apartment houses in the East and West Side areas of Manhattan. Several of the new tenants signed for suites in the Gracie Square Gardens development at Eighty-ninth Street and East End Avenue.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and Petroleum Coordinator, asserted here tonight that restrictions on the ordinary use of petroleum products would continue indefinitely in States of the Eastern seaboard, which depend on ocean shipping for normal supplies.

CHUNGKING, China, June 11 -- Thousands of factory workers are deserting their jobs in occupied North China areas to join the Chinese guerrillas as a result of oppressive labor conditions, according to information received by the Chinese Association of Labor in Chungking.
LONDON, June 6 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

Teachers and parent organizations, aroused at the dismissal of 125 regularly appointed teachers by the Board of Education on Wednesday, started a campaign yesterday to win back the jobs of their colleagues who are to be ousted on Aug. 31, and announced plans for a long Summer fight to prevent further dismissals.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- In a sharp debate during which a bipartisan economy group sought vainly to abolish the Work Projects Administration and turn over to the States the administration of unemployment relief, the House passed and sent to the Senate today legislation authorizing the government to spend $336,000,000 on work relief in the next twelve months.

An exhibition of sculpture by Malvina Hoffman entitled "Men of the World" will open with a preview and cocktail party on Monday afternoon at the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, Inc., 451 Madison Avenue. The exhibition will open to the public on Tuesday and remain current through Sept. 15.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Office of Price Administration has issued a question-and-answer explanation of the registration by landlords of houses, apartments flats, tenements and all other similar housing accommodations which will begin next Monday in the first twenty defense-rental areas brought under Federal jurisdiction June 1 by OPA.

LONDON, June 11 (AP) -- Note circulation reported by the Bank of England for the week ended June 10 showed an increase of u787,000 to a high record. That was the sixteenth consecutive weekly increase and the second smallest in that period.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- There are few, if any, obvious weaknesses in the ball club picked by Lieutenant Mickey Cochrane of the Navy to represent the Army and Navy in the benefit game at Cleveland on July 7 against the winner of the National-American League AllStar contest on the previous day.

The German radio, barely mentioning the British-Russian mutual assistance pact itself, went to lengths yesterday to argue that informed quarters in Berlin had known for several days about Vyacheslav M. Molotoff's visit to the United States and Britain, The Associated Press here reported.

RYE, N.Y., June 11 -- Undaunted by the realization that they were shooting at the moon, the second squad competitors in the United States seniors' golf championship teed off at Apawamis today, their gun sights set on the amazing new record score of 143 made by Ellis Knowles in the first two days of play.

LONDON, June 11 -- The stock markets ceased today their upward trend on less favorable war news. Reports of the German offensive in the Ukraine was a signal for profit-taking in the more speculative groups.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., June 11 -- The Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation in Federal District Court today denied point by point virtually every charge listed in a suit filed against It last April 20 by the War Production Board, for alleged violation of priority ratings.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 11 -- Speakers at the annual convention of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations here emphasized today the soundness of savings and loan institutions, but stressed the need for conservative management policies as a wartime measure.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The sailing of the chartered Swedish liner Gripsholm from New York, scheduled for today, with approximately 1,000 Japanese diplomats and nationals on board for repatri ation was put off today until about June 16.

An injunction to halt picketing of department store and specialty shops as an outgrowth of the labor dispute between the United Parcel Service and its employes will be sought in Supreme Court today, it was announced last night by Frank L. Weil, counsel for a group of the stores.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 11 -- Prague's "horror broadcast" at 10 o'clock tonight announced the execution of thirty-four more persons during today. These, with the thirty-one yesterday, bring the total of executions officially announced in connection with the killing of Reinhard Heydrich, Gestapo official, to 326.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- A House Military Affairs subcommittee was told today that War Production Board officials were risking possible power shortages in some areas to meet constantly growing demands for copper for munitions.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, June 11 -- The American naval victory at Midway has caused a marked increase in confidence and feeling of security in the South Pacific. It is considered that the possibility of a successful Japanese attack on New Zealand or the islands north and northeast is now appreciably lessened.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (U.P.) -- The Senate voted today to revoke the citizenship of government contractors who commit fraud in connection with the performance of government war contracts.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McJLaughlin signed a condemnation order yesterday permitting the city to demolish, after midnight tomorrow night, the Second Avenue elevated line from Division Street to the Queensborough Bridge.

ST. LOUIS, June 11 -- For the third successive day the Dodgers and Cardinals, scheduled to meet in a three-game series that might have renewed the hope of the Red-birds to overtake the high-flying Brooks, were forced into idleness tonight.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers and Phelps, Fenn Co. won yesterday the award of $2,396,000 city of Yonkers, N.Y., Municipal Housing Authority series A refunding bonds, naming a combination of interest rates equivalent to a net interest cost basis of 2.0606 per cent.

Accessories Meet Active Call Summer accessories continue to be in fairly active demand in the wholesale markets here. Plastic and fabric handbags are selling well, and reorders have been coming through for straw styles. White handbags in practically all price ranges are in short supply.
ROME, June 11 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

George J. Schaefer has resigned as president and a director of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, the resignation to take effect at the pleasure of the board of directors, it was learned yesterday. It is expected the resignation will be acted upon at the twice adjourned annual meeting of stockholders, to be held on next Wednesday in Dover, Del.
BERLIN, June 11 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique issued today follows:

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- After a luncheon conference with President Roosevelt today Governor Lehman of New York said that he believed Lieutenant Governor Poletti was not only the strongest candidate but also the best fitted man to succeed him as Governor.

BERLIN, June 11 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German attacks southeast of Kharkov and against Sevastopol are necessary preliminaries to "the coming great offensive" against the Red Army, the military correspondent of the German news agency D. N. B. declared.

Fairleigh Dickinaon Junior College, recently organized by a group of fifteen high school principals in the neighborhood of Rutherford, N.J., with Dr. Peter Sammartino as president, has taken title to the old Rutherford estate known as Iviswold, with a thirty-six-room residence and seven acres of land.

It is difficult to read the full text of the Supreme Court's majority decisions in the Belo case and the Missel case -- both concerned with interpretations of the Wage-Hour Act -- without feeling that these two decisions are inconsistent, or at least that the distinction drawn by the Court between the two cases is a finely technical one.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Department store sales for the week ended June 6 were up 7 per cent compared with the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. This came after two consecutive weeks of decline.
NEW YORK Sir Ronald lan Campbell, British Minister, has arrived from Washington and is at the Ambassador.

The Didier Publishing Company is preparing for publication next Wednesday a book by Edouard Herriot, former French Premier, entitled "Message to the Free Countries." It will include both the original French text and a translation.

MOSCOW, June 11 -- The battle for Sevastopol reached a pitch of unparalleled ferocity yesterday as Col. Gen. Fritz Erich von Mannstein continued to pour troops into what one dispatch from the front calls a "meat-grinder." It is against this defense system -- sweating, grimy marine gunners, stubborn riflemen and grenadiers -- that the German Air Force is striking.

WITH UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES, Hawaii, June 11 -- Officers of the United States Army Air Forces disclosed today some of the carnage spread by their high altitude bombers in conjunction with the Navy among the Japanese invasion fleet that massed off Midway last week in futile effort to take this vital island in the American Pacific defense chain.

TOKYO, June 11 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Japan's leading civilian naval expert, Masanori Ito, said today that "in view of the great success" of the Japanese in the Battle of the Pacific, "we should not be disappointed at the loss of two aircraft carriers, for the gain is far greater than the loss."

Miss Ruth Ayres, economist and president of the New York State League of Women Voters, has been appointed to take charge of a new branch in the consumer division of the Office of Price Administration, dealing with women's activities, it was learned here yesterday.

MOSCOW, Friday, June 12 -- The Germans have thrown strong tank and infantry forces against Russian defense positions on the Kharkov front, and fierce battles have developed, the government announced today.

Six men who labored to counterfeit 25-cent War Savings Stamps but failed to find any one to help them market their product received yesterday prison terms aggregating fifty-eight years. Five of them were sentenced to ten years each, and the sixth, who had aided the prosecution, got an eight-year term.

AT AN ARMY AIR FIELD, Hawaii, June 11 -- A lumber salesman and a truck driver who won Army wings less than two years ago told today how it felt to take a B-17 Flying Fortress bomber over a Japanese invasion fleet and drop bombs on the enemy.
Paul Revere rode again yesterday for the sale of War Bonds, but only briefly. After the first few sales the rain sent the Minute Man to shelter and his horse to the stable.

IT was at the Metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships last week that a huge conference took place at Travers Island. The conferees were Al Blozis, Frank Berst, Henry Dreyer and Shorty Folwartshny, a picture of beefy symmetry.

In the great air raids upon Germany, which continued on a very much reduced scale yesterday, replacement of aircraft losses is only one of the many problems that must be met if the raids are to be continued on a four-figure scale.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The White House announced that President Roosevelt and V. M. Molotoff, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs, had reached an agreement for creation of a second front in Europe. The President signed the Smaller War Plants Corporation bill, sent to the Senate the nomination of Dwight F. Davis to be Director General of a new Army Specialists Corps and of seven assistants, and conferred with Governor Lehman on New York State politics.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Certainly, the great majority of the French, people have put their hope and trust in their American friends. Friendship has a very real and deep meaning in French. I always believed there has been a great psychological misunderstanding in the relations between France and America.

LONDON, June 11 -- The following White Paper, "Russia Number One (1942)," was issued by the British Government today immediately after the announcement of the British-Russian treaty in the House of Commons:

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Anti-trust prosecutions of leading dyestuff manufacturers, including Allied Chemical, E. I. du Pont de Nemours and American Cyanamid and their affiliates, have been indefinitely postponed because the trials would interfere with conduct of the war, Attorney General Biddie said today.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- President Roosevelt formally established the Army Specialists Corps today by submitting to the Senate the names of eight men who will organize and direct the recruiting of thousands of civilians for supplementary work for the Army, with semi-military rank.

While linage of monthly magazines for this month is down about 15 per cent from last year, the showing is slightly better than in April and May and it is now regarded as possible that forthcoming issues may begin to reduce the gap between this and last year.

LONDON, June 11 -- The secrecy surrounding the visit here of Soviet Foreign Commissar Vyaeheslaff M. Molotoff, which was imposed at the request of the Russians on the grounds of security, was lifted today and the general public was at last told the details.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 11 -- The announcement of the Anglo-Soviet alliance has made a "great impression" in Swedish official circles, where the probable effect of the pact on Finland and on the Baltic States is of particular interest.

Women must be represented at the peace conference, but if their representation is to mean anything, they must earn it by giving "magnificent war service," Mrs. Linda Littlejohn, Australian feminist and lecturer, declared yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 11 -- After conferences between Prime Minister John Curtin and General Douglas MacArthur and between Australian Army Minister Francis M. Forde and Lieut. Gen. Sir Thomas Blarney, commander of the United Nations land forces in the Southwest Pacific, the Advisory War Council sat for three hours today to survey the Pacific situation in the light of recent developments, especially the Battle of Midway Island.

William D. Rawlins was designated last evening by the Queens County Republican executive committee as the candidate for Representative in the Second Congressional District to oppose Representative William B. Barry, Democratic incumbent, who is under attack as having been an "isolationist" before the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

"Nazi Agent," a Metro melodrama, which opens at the Rialto, is today's only new film arrival. Conrad Veidt appears in a dual role in the picture and Ann Ayars, Frank Reicher, Dorothy Tree, Martin Kosleck, Marc Lawrence and Sidney Blacloner are featured in support.

MOSCOW, June 11 -- Throughout this warm Summer evening street amplifiers in Moscow have read the terms of the Anglo-Soviet treaty and accompanying documents, and Moscovites, of whom a vast proportion are now uniformed, have paused to listen.

GEORGE WASHINGTON was the richest man in America, a Virginia aristocrat, fox hunter, farmer. He was tall and thin and strong, although sickly. He swore prodigiously, drank heroically and all his life fought with a monstrous temper. His red hair, pale gray eyes and rocky features were appropriate outer symbols of his iron pride, but less appropriate for his simple humility of character and torturing lack of assurance and self-confidence.

With Mayor La Guardia making the principal speech, officials of the Army Emergency Relief Society yesterday gave a luncheon in the Park Lane at which they outlined plans for staging the national track and field championships at Randalls Island on June 19 and 20.
Loft building's and tenement houses comprised the bulk or the properties that figured in realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.

HAVANA, June 11 -- The gun crew of an American merchant ship, most of them youths of 20 or less, has sunk an Axis submarine after a brief running gun fight, thus raising the total of enemy U-boats sunk in recent weeks in waters of the Greater Antilles to three -- and possibly five -- authoritative but unofficial sources said tonight.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 11 -- The Japanese military attaches from Berlin and Rome met with the Japanese military attache here today in the first of a series of conferences, as foreign diplomatic pircles hummed with rumors of a new Axis-peace offensive, fostered by the pro-Nazi editor of the Istanbul French-language newspaper Republique.

American industry is winning on the production front because it has the industrial "know how" and the determination to win, Alvin E. Dodd, president of the American Management Association, declared yesterday at the group's annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

TRENTON, N. J., June 11 -- Setting aside franchise tax assessments against the Public Service Electric and Gas Company and three other utilities for 1940, the State Board of Tax Appeals today ordered a recomputation.

Bank clearings in twenty-three leading cities in the country in the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $6,382,502,000, a gain of 7.5 per cent from the $5,935,376,000 total for the corresponding week last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Thomas Hitchcock, a figure in steeplechasing for more than a generation, was memorialized at Aqueduct yesterday by the running of a stake race which called sharply to mind the veteran sportsman who passed away about a year ago.

SALEM, Ill., June 11 -- Oil men were somewhat perplexed over the choice of Salem as the terminus of the new 550-mile pipe line to be built from Longview, Texas, to assist in relieving the shortage in the East. Pipe lines out of here are now running to their full capacity.

OUTSIDE BIR HACHEIM, Libya, June 10 (Delayed) -- From the top of the cannon-riddled wreck of a Stuka dive-bomber today I watched the thunderous climax of the Axis offensive against the tiny, desolate outpost of Bir Hacheim.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The realistic and high-minded diplomacy by means of which the political post-war autonomy of the little Baltic States was preserved during the recent treaty negotiations between Great Britain and Soviet Russia reflects great credit on those two governments and that of the United States.

The Yankees and Tigers tried yesterday to squeeze in the final game of their series at the Stadium. They were delayed almost an hour in starting, then had to quit after playing only two and a half innings with Detroit ahead, 2 to 1.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on June 6 totaled 854,689 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 58,933 cars or 7.4 per cent more than in the preceding week, 1,749 cars or 0.2 per cent more than in the corresponding week last year, and 151,797 cars or 21.6 per cent more than the corresponding week two years ago.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The flying visit of Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff from Moscow to London, then to Washington and back to London and Moscow, was one of the best kept secrets of the war.

Excess Reserves Figures available yesterday showed that excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City dropped $50,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $515,000,000, lowest since March 2, 1938.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Ways and Means Committee voted today to double the present 5 per cent transportation tax, voted increases in cigar, tobacco and cigarette levies and postponed until tomorrow final action on other excise tax changes recommended by the Treasury.

NEWMARKET, England, June 11 -- The King's horses and the King's men -- his trainer and his jockey -- were one-sided betting choices tonight to make British racing history by winning both the Oaks tomorrow and the Derby Saturday.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Edwin C. Witte, Professor of Economics of the University of Wisconsin, was named today as the arbiter in the dispute that led to the recent strike of members of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Federal Reserve Board revealed today that by the end of May it had Continued on Page Thirty-one Continued From Page Twenty-nine supported the market for government securities by increasing its holdings of taxable bonds in the previous two months $60,000,000 and by buying $160,000,000 of Treasury bills and $30,000,000 of Treasury certificates of indebtedness in May.

CHUNGKING, China, June 11 (UP) -- Three Japanese columns driving east along the Nanchang-Hanchow Railway from Nanchang have covered eighty miles or more and threaten a juncture with a westbound Japanese force that has been delayed six days by a fiercely fighting garrison at Chuhsien, it was announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Senate asked the House today to agree to the enactment of legislation which would permit the deferment of married men from draft call regardless of whether their wives and children were financially dependent on them.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 11 (AP) -- British headquarters said in a communique today:

James G. Blaine, chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, issued another warning yesterday to New Yorkers who "are not doing enough" about the protection of their city, which, he said, "is lying wide open to destruction."
ALBANY, N.Y., June 11 -- The Adjutant General released the following orders today:
CHUNGKING, China, June 11 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command said today in a communique:

WASHINGTON, June 11-- The War Production Board today announced extension of wool conservation order M-73 for a month to Aug. 2 to allocate new wool for July on substantially the same basis as the allocation for the second quarter this year.

Opposition to admitting mothers of fighting men who die in this war to membership in the American Gold Star Mothers developed yesterday when a resolution providing for such action was Introduced at the eighth annual convention at the Hotel New Yorker.

The Pan-American Society and the Venezuelan Chamber of Commerce of the United States gave a dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for Dr. C. Parra Perez, Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Senor Rodolfo Rojas, Minister of Agriculture, on the eve of their return to Venezuela after an official visit to the United States.

LONDON, June 11 (AP) -- Soviet Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff in a 1,200-word diplomatic note accused the German High Command tonight of introducing the "universal practice of physical extermination" of war prisoners.

With 500,000 men and women marching up Fifth Avenue, and more than 2,000,000 watching from the sidelines if the weather is clear, tomorrow's all-day "rain or shine" parade to demonstrate "New York at War," is expected to be the biggest spectacle of its kind ever held.
VICHY, France, June 11 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, today took occasion In a public declaration to affirm his confidence in Pierre Laval as Chief of Government.
LONDON, June 11 -- The text of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's statement in the House of Commons today follows:
CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- Claude Passeau pitched a five-hitter today and scored his ninth victory of the season as the Cubs beat the Phils, 7 to 1.

Representative Michael J. Kennedy, leader of 'Tammany, succeeded yesterday in averting a threatened primary fight which has been causing concern. At his request, Neil J. Cohalan, son of former Surrogate John P. Cohalan, withdrew as a candidate against Representative Joseph A. Gavagan in the Twenty-first Congressional District.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- A four-run uprising in the ninth inning brought the Indians an 8-6 victory over the Senators today and a sweep of the three-game series.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- President Roosevelt today signed a bill setting up a Smaller War Plants Corporation with a 5150,000,000 revolving fund which will function under a deputy administrator of the War Production Board. The objective is to bring smaller business more extensively into the war production program.

Dispensing With the usual procedure of a closed ballot election, members of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A. F. of L., voted by acclamation last night to re-elect their business manager, Harry Van Arsdale Jr., whose conviction on riot charges was upheld last Monday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.

T Bohemian town of Lidice has been "leveled to the ground and the name of the community extinguished." This action was taken after all the men in the town had been shot, all the women placed in concentration camps, all the children sent to "educational institutions" -- which is the Nazi term for propaganda schools, where an effort will be made to teach them to admire those who murdered their fathers and abused their mothers.
BOSTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Red Sox pushed across a run in the ninth inning today to win, 8-7, for three straight over the Browns.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In my opinion, the authorities have a wrong conception of what steps to take in blackouts.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The gasoline ration unit of "A" and "B" cards in the seventeen East Coast rationed States was increased by the Office of Price Administration today from three to six gallons, effective after midnight Sunday, to tide drivers over a two-week extension of the temporary rationing plan which was originally set to expire June 30.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (AP) -- The Central Maine Power Company and the Cumberland County Power Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposal to merge. Central Maine would continue as the surviving company.
The spotlight swings to the vegetable counter this week-end, where bargains abound and excellent quality is the order of the day.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 11 -- Charles Dalton, veteran actor who played many classic and modern roles on the English and American stages, died today of a heart ailment in his home on Riverbank Road, here. He was 77 years old.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Can one fight an effective war without hatred? That is a question which must have occurred to many of your readers a few days ago when you reported that a civic association in Queens threatened to tear down the Japanese Pavilion in Flushing Meadow Park unless it was promptly razed by the Park Department.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 11 Miss Jane Evans of Vernon Hills won low gross honors from a large field in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association today when, after a mediocre first nine of 43, she came back in 39 for 82 over the Siwanoy Country Club course.

The personnel of the Army baseball team which will oppose the Navy nine in the All-Sports Carnival at the Polo Grounds on Sunday was announced yesterday by Colonel H. Clay Supplee. Heading the list is Corporal Hugh Mulcahy, former pitching star for the Phils, who will hold down the mound assignment for the soldiers.

The four grand juries that for more than two years have been investigating under Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen the ramifications of a city-wide $50,000,000 paving racket submitted jointly yesterday a comprehensive final report designed to protect the city from future construction conspiracies and to permit action against public officials who accept the graft and retire on pensions when detection appears imminent.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- With another year of record food production in sight, the United States should be able to feed her Allies and herself with rationing in only a few exceptional cases, Secretary Wickard said today after the first meeting of the new Food Requirements Committee.

Spokesmen for both the Federal Government and the private power and light industry gave assurances yesterday that the nation has an ample supply of electricity to meet war production demands. Power rationing for civilian use in certain highly industrialized areas, however, probably will be necessary as war output accelerates, it was said.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I thank you for your admirable editorial this morning on the Supreme Court five-to-four decision affirming the right of a community to interfere with and thus limit the distribution of literature, i. e., the dissemination of ideas, by imposing "prohibitive taxation" in the form of licenses.
The Summer sun sometimes la a false friend. While we attain a suntan, it bleaches our hair and inflicts on us that painful vacation ailment -- sunburned lips.

Paul Robeson will appear in "Othello" the week of Aug. 10, at Brattle Hall, Cambridge, Mass., and the next week at the McCarter Theatre, Princeton, N. J. Margaret Webster, who is now making her own acting version of the tragedy, will direct and also play the role of Emilia.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Spurred to action by recent declines in market prices for some major farm crops, the Senate Agriculture Committee demanded today that the government put a floor under prices of basic agricultural commodities at levels well above the present average.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 11 (AP) -- Lawson Little's putter was the best club wielded today as the "grand slam" amateur king of 1934-35 scored seven birdies in the opening round of the Inverness invitation best-ball golf matches.

With market sentiment greatly improved and uncertainty ended through the OPA amendments to Maximum Price Order No. 153, the women's and children's outer apparel industries here began to get back to normal yesterday. Nummerous trade meetings were again held at which technical phases of the amendments were discussed.

Present contemplated purchases of food items by wartime agencies will not be sufficient to keep the food industry completely occupied and conversion of plants to emergency needs will have to be for the production of unrelated items, A. Rush Watkins, chief of the conversion section, Food Supply Branch, WPB, declared yesterday.
CHICAGO. June 11 (AP) -- Prices of hogs and steers eased today, but those for lambs rose. The report of the livestock markets by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Friday, June 12 -- The United States and Russia have reached a full understanding on the "urgent tasks of creating a second front in Europe in 1942," and have signed a master lease-lend agreement providing reciprocal defense aid and designed to create "a new and better world" after victory is won, it was announced officially yesterday.

STANTON, Del., June 11 (AP) -- In one of the greatest stretch duels ever witnessed at Delaware Park, Belair Stud's Vagrancy drove to a nose victory over Joseph E. Widener's Waygal in the sixth running of the $7,500 added mile and a furlong Delaware Oaks today.

Thirty thousand men's clothing workers in the metropolitan area face unemployment for the duration of the war unless the government allocates an increased share of work on Army and Navy uniforms and other textile products to New York shops, Louis Hollander, manager of the joint board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C.I.O., warned yesterday.

Paul Robeson will appear in "Othello" the week of Aug. 10, at Brattle Hall, Cambridge, Mass., and the next week at the McCarter Theatre, Princeton, N. J. Margaret Webster, who is now making her own acting version of the tragedy, will direct and also play the role of Emilia.

Thirty thousand men's clothing workers in the metropolitan area face unemployment for the duration of the war unless the government allocates an increased share of work on Army and Navy uniforms and other textile products to New York shops, Louis Hollander, manager of the joint board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C.I.O., warned yesterday.

Twenty-six gasoline station operators in the metropolitan district conceded yesterday at hearings before trial commissioners of the Office of Price Administration in the Empire State Building that their stations had sold gasoline in violation of rationing regulations to volunteer investigators of the OPA.

The three-day conference of Bundles for "Britain closed last night with a dinner at the Hotel Pierre attended by 300 leading workers of the organization, who came from twenty-four States in the Bast, the Middle West and from the British West Indies.

In the dullest full session since Aug. 26, 1940, stocks on the New York Stock Exchange eased irregularly yesterday and closed mixed to moderately lower on the day. Deals were 220,220 shares, compared with 281,914 shares on Thursday and 216,620 shares in the four-hour session of May 18, when the Exchange was closed for an hour for a war-bond rally.
CHUNGKING, China, June 12 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command issued this communique today:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 12 -- The Anglo-Soviet pact has unmistakably provided immediate relief for both Sweden and Finland, judging from Stockholm editorial comment today, in that it has allayed recent fears of a Ruaslan-German separate peace, which has been the bugaboo of the atateamen of 'both countries since the rumor campaign first started last January.

Asserting his expectation that production of war materials by General Motors Corporation will accelerate to the point where sales in dollar value should equal the $2,436,800,000 volume of 1941, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the company, warned stockholders yesterday that they cannot expect earnings and dividends to show a corresponding result.

Foreseeing an end of isolation among the Americas, Rodolfo Rojas, Venezuelan Minister of Agriculture, at a luncheon in the Union Club yesterday called for a policy of "absolute equality" in this country's relations with Venezuela after the war.

Axis countries, strange though it seem, will contribute gold, silver and bronze 'for statuettes to be awarded to the first "United States Navy crew that drops a live shell into Tokyo and either to Brig. Gen. James Doolittle, who already has left his calling card in that city, or to the first Army unit to plant its battle flag on Japanese soil.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Ways and Means Committee recommended today substantial rises in the tax rates for telephone, telegraph and radio messages and for photographic equipment.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Senate and House conferees agreed today on revisions of the Selective Service Law which would permit the deferment, as a national policy although not en bloc, of married men without regard to financial dependency and notwithstanding the fact that the same legislation would provide family allowances.

Two of the city's boldest robbers, who had ambitions to organize an expansive extortion racket, with business men mainly as their victims, were sentenced by Judge Saul S. Streit in General Sessions yesterday to long prison terms for three robberies committed last Winter in a few weeks.

The new order in "night" baseball will be introduced at Ebbets Field Monday. President Larry MacPhail of the Dodgers yesterday announced a schedule of dusk games to supplant the nocturnal contests originally provided for Flatbush on the National League schedule.

BINGHAMTON, June 12 -- The most immediate problem facing credit men is the huge adjustment that will be necessary following the war, Harry J. Delaney, president of the New York Credit Men's Association, declared here tonight in addressing the annual meeting of the Triple Cities Association of Credit Men.

If the increase In the excise tax on cigarettes as voted by the House Ways and Means Committee stands in the final revenue bill, this will mean a rise of 1 cent per package in retail prices, bringing standard brands now sold at 16 cents to 17 cents, it was estimates yesterday by Eric Calamla, president of the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America.

CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- Vern Olsen pitched his first victory of the season for the Cubs today, 3 to 2, with a six-hit performance against the Braves in the opener of a four-game series. He had suffered four defeats.

THE Russian revolutionists, from Lenin to Stalin, were educated in Siberian exile; Cervantes wrote "Don Quixote" in jail to laugh the age of chivalry out of existence; Hitler composed part of the gelatinous mass of "Mein Kampf" while under nominal duress in a cell at Landsberg-am-Lech. The story of enforced confinement or rustication is a major part of the dynamic history of the world.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 12 -- A beautiful puppy, just nineteen days less than a year old, today was adjudged best dog in the Summer specialty show of the Welsh Terrier Club of America on the lawns of Strathglass Farm, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh J. Chisholm.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 12 (AP) -- Jersey City's initial effort to complete a twilight-night baseball game before the lights were turned off by defense decree backfired tonight, but the Giants took a 3-2 decision over the Montreal Royals in eight official innings.
A warning against "some Quislings and the clergy" of the United States was sounded in a statement released yesterday over the signatures of seventeen prominent Protestant clergymen.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 12 -- Ferdinand A. Hoyt, former City Judge of Beacon, announced today his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Representative in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District.

The latest round-up by the New Jersey Council regarding the leaders in the Governor's New Jersey fishing tournament shows Merritt Budd of Chatham in first place in the rainbow trout division with a 4-pound-8-ounce fish which he caught in the Pequest River.
LONDON, June 12 -- The Anglo-Russian treaty steadied the stock markets today.

Walter Gellhorn, chief regional attorney for the Office of Price Administration, defended yesterday the procedure followed in using volunteers, most of them women, to check on observance of gasoline rationing regulations as service station and garage owners protested that they had been entrapped into violating the plan by appeals to their chivalry or sympathy.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 12 (U.P.) -- Axis tanks have driven fifteen miles north of fallen Bir Hacheim and British forces are battling them fiercely, while another enemy column has struck out twenty miles east of the desert outpost, apparently intending to circle back against the Imperial defenses before Tobruk, it was revealed tonight.

The outlook for retail adversing is improving slightly as a result of the recent letdown in trade, according to store advertising managers. Since the start of the year the demand for goods has been such that advertising was not antirely needed to push volume but low public lethargy is requiring more vigorous promotion.

The Navy's belated communique on the Battle of the Coral Sea, issued yesterday, and the available facts about the Battle of Midway Island indicate that the carrier strength of the Japanese Fleet has been seriously impaired.

Mr. Molotoff's chief purpose in coming to Washington was to press for a second front. This was the subject of at least nine-tenths of his conversations with the President, Mr. Hopkins and the military leaders and officials he met during his six-day stay in the capital.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is with dismay and disdain that I read in THE NEW YORK TIMES various remarks made by Federal Security Administrator Paul V. McNutt at the annual meeting of the American Medical Association in Atlantic City.

A broader list of exemptions from Priorities Regulation No. 1, which limits inventories to a practicable working minimum, will be sought by some industries, with the twofold purpose of getting more business on the books now and preventing a transportation jam in the Fall months, it was learned here yesterday.

Armed with a three-page brief and a map of the street on which she had parked her car, Miss Emily Marx, former judge of Domestic Relations Court, appeared yesterday in Downtown Traffic Court to plead innocent to an overtime-parking charge.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Fifteen Japanese warships, including an up-to-date aircraft carrier and four cruisers, were destroyed in the Battle of the Coral Sea at a cost of one United States aircraft carrier, the Lexington; one destroyer, the Sims, and one tanker, the Neosho, the Navy Department revealed today.

BALTIMORE, June 12 -- An indication, in miniature, of what the Axis may expect from the United States Army was demonstrated here tonight by 1,200 officers and soldiers schooled in the principle that "attack is the American thesis of war."

LAKEHURST, N.J. -- Memorial services were held here today for the twelve victims of last Monday's collision of two Navy blimps off Manasquan. Over 800 civilians and Navy personnel attended the services in the huge dirigible hangar of the United States Naval Air Station.

PEARL HARBOR, June 12 -- The United States Marine Corps officer who commanded a shore battery on Midway Island during the unsuccessful Japanese attempt to invade the mid-Pacific base told newspaper men here today the story of the part played by his forces.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Your editorial entitled "Relics of a Poet," on the subject of the Edwin Markham Exhibition in the Library of Congress, concludes with the suggestion "Won't some one else, and why not Mrs, Hamilton, write an adequate account of an interesting life?"

Maurice E. Rogalin, suspended former principal of New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn, won from Supreme Court Justice Ernest E.L. Hammer yesterday the right to retire on a pension despite the charges pending against him that he accepted gifts and loans from teachers in return for assignments on which the teachers could earn extra money.
NEW YORK Mrs. Norman Armour, wife of the United States Ambassador to Argentina, has arrived from Buenos Aires and is at the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Yugoslavia has been officially invited to sign the master lease-lend agreement now being concluded by the United States with members of the United Nations.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, June 13 -- Indications that after eight days' furious resistance at Sevastopol the Russian garrison there has reached its maximum effort and has been driven back from an important position northeast of the" city were "contained in reports received here this morning from both Berlin, and Moscow.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: John Kieran's comment on the Travis diamond-jeweled gold and silver belt put me in good humor is his columns usually do.

Twenty - seven basic training planes for 1,000 pilots are only a drop in this war's bucket, but an important one in that the planes are for Norwegian fighting men training in Canada and the money for them is being raised by Wings for Norway, Inc., a Swedish-American drive.

The Mount St. Michael High School baseball team of the Bronx ivon the City C.H.S.A.A. championship yesterday by defeating the St. John's Prep nine of Brooklyn, 6 to 4. The game, a seven-inning affair, was played at Fordham Field.

To permit theatregoers the opportunity of viewing the "New York at War" parade, which starts at 10 o'clock this morning from Washington Square, all Broadway's attractions, numbering sixteen, will begin their afternoon performances today at 3 o'clock, or fifteen minutes later than the usual time.

This year's meeting of the American Medical Association is of extraordinary importance, since the time has come to take stock of our medical resources and to consider how they can be most effectively distributed to meet the needs created by the war. Paul V. McNutt appeared twice before the meeting to express the Government's dissatisfaction with what has been done thus far.
