ASHLAND, Ky., June 12-- Probably it would be unwise to underestimate the intelligence that people in odd corners of the country have about the war.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 12 -- A special transcontinental trip was crowned with success today for Mr. and Mrs. S.F. Heckert Jr., as the pride of their Villa Marina Kennels, Ch. Odin Vom Busecker Schloss, captured the premier prize in the Shepherd Dog Club of New England specialty show at the Round Hill Club stables.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 12 -- Paul Engels and Mal Galletta of North Hills cut three strokes from, par with a 35, 35-70 to take the medal in the second annual member-guest tourney at the Hempstead Golf Club today. Fifty-five teams competed.

North of Boston in a modest cottage near the sea, a spinster schoolmistress, distinguished alike for her wit and culinary talents, spends the Summers. Her guests, who invariably make lengthy visits, depart with all kinds of pleasant gustatory memories.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Proposed wholesale rate schedules to increase the price of natural gas bought and sold between three New York State companies were rejected today by the Federal Power Commission.
ST. LOUIS, June 12 (AP) -- With Mort Cooper hurling five-hit ball, the Cardinals downed the Phils, 2 to 1, tonight on the basis of a two-run first-inning uprising.

Mrs. Lucille Byrne, in 535 Park Ave; Mrs. Albert Reinthal, in 983 Park Ave; Mrs. S.S. Wolfson, in 969 Park Ave; Miss Frieda Marcus, Victor E. Johns and Miss Dorothy Zell, in 223 E 61st St; Pease Elliman, brokers.

PEARL HARBOR, June 12 -- Ensign Milton Tootle 4th, banker's son from St. Joseph, Mo., has had his Navy wings for only six months and he was in the battle of Midway' for just five minutes, but those were about the most actioncrammed five minutes a young pilot ever had.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- President Roosevelt created by Executive Order today an eight-member Alaska War Council, headed by Governor Ernest Gruening.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The United States will resume shipments of low-grade fuel oil, milk and other foods and clothing to North Africa immediately under a decision announced today by Secretary of State Cordell, Hull.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 12 -- A new drug, known as dicoumarin, originally isolated from spoiled sweet clover and recently synthesized at the University of Wisconsin, promises to become an important new agent in the treatment and prevention of the formation of blood clots, one of the serious risks of surgery, it was reported here today before the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American Medical Association by three groups of investigators.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Persons interested in the sound administration of municipal and State services cannot accept with equanimity the fact that our public school system is to be deprived of 125 regularly employed teachers. It is clear that such action does not further the effective prosecution of the war.

LONDON, June 12 -- There has been, such a rush to the altar by British girls and soldiers of the United Nations during the past year or so that the authorities have become concerned and are beginning to show some anxiety over these marriages that usually result from lightning courtships.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, June 11 -- Corporal Louis E. Murphy, 26, from Bridgeport, Conn., but whose family is now living in Portland, Me., where his father is in a shipbuilding plant, returned to this operational base today after a three-week absence with a strange lot of fellow-travelers.

Washington, June 12 -- The new V-Mail for United States overseas forces, patterned after the British microfilm postal system, was started when letters were delivered to President Roosevelt today from Ambassador John G. Winant and Major Gen. James E. Chaney, commanding officer of American forces in the United Kingdom.

Mothers of sons or daughters killed in military or naval service during this war are eligible for membership in the American Gold Star Mothers, Inc., as the result of the amendment of the organization's constitution at the closing session of its national convention yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 12 -- Political as well as celestial navigation was discussed here today by America's leading astronomers at the meeting of the American Astronomical Society.

In voting to dismiss 125 regularly employed high-school teachers the Board of Education has taken an unprecedented step in local educational history. Never before has it been necessary in this city to oust members of the permanent teaching staff. The board is trying to meet a financial crisis, brought about when Mayor La Guardia, pruned the school budget by $3,093,161.

A national campaign to wipe out discrimination against Negroes in the Army, Navy, government agencies, war industries and labor unions will open Tuesday night with a mass meeting in Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday by A. Philip Randolph, president of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, A.F. of L.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on June 6 were 254,316,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, United States Department of the Interior. This represented a decrease of 707,000 barrels in the week, comprising a decline of 788,000 barrels in domestic stocks and an increase of 82,000 in foreign stocks.

A test air raid drill will be held by the ushers of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, at 10:15 A.M. tomorrow in the church auditorium, preceding the morning worship. A similar drill will take place on the first Sunday of each month throughout the Summer as a new slate of ushers takes over.

The volume of new bonds offered here this week dropped to $3,150,000 and consisted exclusively of State and municipal issues, compared with $70,472,000, comprising a well-diversified list of new issues, marketed last week. During this period last year $25,311,403 in new bonds were offered for public subscription.

The North American Company, one of the nation's largest utility holding companies, petitioned yesterday the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for a review of an order issued against it by the Securities and Exchange Commission requiring it to break up in conformance with the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The text of President Roosevelt's radio address on the scrap rubber collection campaign was as follows:

In celebration tomorrow of Flag Day, or "United Nations' Day" as President Roosevelt has named it, clergymen will preach sermons advocating that at the same time the Stars and Stripes are honored as the emblem of our country's freedom, strength and unity, a tribute also be paid to the flags of all the nations fighting together for the cause of freedom.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Eastern oil industries were advised today by Jesse Jones, Secretary of Cortimerce, that they might proceed immediately with the construction of the proposed 24-inch pipeline which will carry oil from Longview, Texas, to Salem, Ill., to relieve the petroleum shortage along the Atlantic seaboard.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The value of department store Inventories increased considerably during the first four months of the year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. On April 30 it was nearly 60 per cent higher than a year earlier.

RYE, N.Y., June 12 -- For a time today it appeared as if all the encomiums heaped on Ellis Knowles for his brilliant performance on the first two days of the United States seniors' golf championship would have to be retracted.

The nine-story apartment house at 119 East Eighty-fourth Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues, has been sold by the 51 East Ninetieth Street Corporation to the Sejoe Syndicate, Inc., represented by David Kugel, attorney. It was sold for cash over a mortgage of $267,300, held by the Bowery Savings Bank, which extended the loan for five years at 3 per cent interest.

While New York City swelters the fur manufacturers are showing the luxury coats that will keep women warm come the Winter with its frosty days. Furs have not fallen under the restraining hand of priorities.

TOLEDO, June 12 -- Dapper Lloyd Mangrum and husky Lawson Little went out in front today in quest of the $2,150 top prize in the eighth annual $7,650 Inverness four-ball golf matches, chalking up an aggregate plus 7 count with two impressive victories.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12 -- The first of a series of short-wave broadcasts, sponsored by Harvard University and the World Wide Broadcasting Company over Station, WRUL, was beamed tonight throughout the entire world. The broadcasts are to be known as "the fight for a free world" series and will be conducted by the newly created Harvard Radio Board.

Rents and housing conditions in the New York area have become so satisfactorily stabilized that it will not be necessary for the Office of Price Administration to establish a price ceiling on living quarters here on July 1, as had been threatened, A.E. Casgrain, regional rent administrator of the OPA, announced yesterday.

Without prejudice to the question of a second front in Europe, the time has come to consider formal substantial aid to China. For political as well as military reasons something must be done for China. It is necessary to give more than moral support, money credits and tokens like the American Volunteer Group flying corps.

LONDON, June 12 -- American officials and private citizens and representatives of all the United Nations in Britain, as well as the empire, joined today in preliminary gestures in a salute to the United Nations Day which will be officially observed on Sunday in accordance with the proclamation by President Roosevelt.
BERLIN, June 12 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique issued today follows:
MELBOURNE, Australia, June 12 -- Rationing of clothing and footwear begins throughout Australia on Tuesday. Meanwhile there will be no sales tomorrow or Monday.

The long delay in making public American losses in last month's Battle of the Coral Sea is defended on strategic grounds in the Navy Department communique" which is published in this morning's paper. It is argued here that "holding up this information gave to our Navy security which was a cornerstone in building for the Midway victory."

HOLLYWOOD, June 12 -- Elimination of all billing and credit footage except the main title from future motion pictures was expected today following the urgent recommendation of the Film Conservation Committee that studios abandon the use of credits for the duration.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 12 -- Staging a blazing finish with a best-ball 65, six under par, the Plainfield Country Club entry of John Kinder, pro, and Charles Whitehead won the second annual metropolitan pro-amateur golf championship with a thirty-six-hole card of 133 at Metropolis today.

BERLIN, June 12 (From German Broadcast Recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbes said tonight that Germany would carry out a mass "extermination" of Jews in reprisal for the Allied air bombings of German cities which, he acknowledged, have caused heavy damage.

Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in his capacity as chairman of the Victory Fund Committee of the Second Federal Reserve District, formally called yesterday on all banks in the State "to expand their already considerable efforts" to promote the war-financing program.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Legislation designed to suspend the operations of existing selection boards and make more flexible the system of officer promotion in the Navy and Marine Corps was approved today by the House Naval Affairs Committee and reported to Congress for early action.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 12 -- When Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles declared that no element in any enemy nation should be forced to suffer after the war for the crimes of its leaders, he was expressing a viewpoint widely held by the American people.

Prices of cotton moved indecisively yesterday in relatively thin trading. The most noteworthy element in the market was continued support by the trade, which neutralized early losses and established final net gains of 2 to 5 points for active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Ex-change.
PHILADELPHIA, June 12 (AP) -- The Athletics tonight beat the Indians for the first time this season, scoring a 5-to-4 victory behind the five-hit pitching of Dick Fowler and Russ Christopher.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 12 (AP) -- Southern California, the defending champion in the N.C.A.A. track championships, virtually had an eighth consecutive trophy wrapped up for shipping home when the trials of the twilight meet were over tonight.

To Sports Editor at The New York Times: In one of his recent columns in THE TIMES, John Kieran mentioned the report by Dr. Hamilton Holt of a game similar in some respects to basketball way down in Yucatan.

Whirlaway and Market Wise, arch rivals in the handicap division, are slated to meet, rather to the surprise of everybody, in the seven-furlong Carter Handicap, big feature of Aqueduct's eight-race program today. The test will gross $10,000, but it is at a distance far shorter than, the long routes over which Whirlaway and Market Wise have done so well.

CHUNGKING, China, June 12 (UP) -- Japanese advancing west-ward into East China's Kiangsi Province today neared Yushan, site of an airfield within bombing range of Japan, an army communique said after announcing evacuation on Wednesday of Chuhsien, about thirty-five miles to the northeast.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- From the deck of an aircraft carrier that was bombed, machine-gunned and torpedoed I witnessed the Battle of the Coral Sea. For five full, never-to-be-forgotten days I lived with the American heroes -- airmen and seamen alike -- who there won a magnificent victory.

PITTSBURGH, June 12 -- A crowd of 19,307 fans was sorely disappointed and the Giants were deeply distressed tonight when playing conditions prevented the nocturnal game between Mel Ott's Polo Grounders and Frankie Frisch's Pirates from going beyond one out in the second half of the fourth inning.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "Mr. Meaney Meets Opposition" is unworthy of a newspaper which many of us have liked to believe is fair-minded.

In memory of the late Felix M. Warburg, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has received three paintings and three drawings as a gift from Mrs. Warburg and their children. These are in addition to the important collection of prints given last year which was especially rich in etchings and drypoints by Rembrandt.

TRENTON, June 12 -- Governor Charles Edison rebuked Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City by inference today for the fireworks display there Wednesday night in connection with a war bond sale campaign rally.
ALBANY, June 12 -- The adjutant general released the following orders today:

MOSCOW, June 12 -- Amid widespread popular expressions of approval of the Soviet Union's new agreements with Britain and the United States, Pravda, official organ of the Communist party, today editorially stressed the point that the agreements are in the people's interests because they envisage the acceleration of the process of defeating Adolf Hitler.
LONDON, June 12 -- Two enemy vessels were hit by Hudson bombers of a Canadian Coastal Command squadron off the Netherland coast last night, the Air Ministry said tonight.

MEXICO CITY, June 12 -- Formal confiscation of all properties belonging to subjects of Axis powers was made possible tonight through a Presidential decree putting into effect tomorrow the "law of properties and businesses of the enemy."

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- King George II of Greece told the press today that he had come to the United States to renew his country's pledge "to continue the battle until a new world is established where the desire for peace shall be synonymous with the will to achieve peace and the determination to preserve peace."

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Coincident with today's communique describing the Coral Sea engagement, the Navy issued two tables which by comparison indicated that Japanese losses in the Coral Sea were greater in tonnage than all the losses suffered by the United States Navy, including Pearl Harbor, and announced to this date.

IT is a little tit warm for football talk, but not nearly as hot as Lieut. Comdr. James H. Crowley and Lieut. Col. Bernie Bierman, U.S.M.C., will shortly be making it for their squads in the Navy Pre-Flight Schools.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Wage-stabilization "cannot be accomplished by freezing existing rates," according to a unanimous opinion of the National War Labor Board, which today granted an upward adjustment of 10 cents an hour to employes of the Ranger Aircraft Engines, Farmingdale, L.I.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: John Kieran's articles on baseball are always interesting to me. As a reader of THE TIMES for more than forty years I found especially entertaining his recent column concerning the first National League game for the New Tork Giants that was played on May 1, 1883.

The State administrative committee of the American Labor party, representing its right wing group, decided yesterday not to support the candidacy of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., who seems certain to be the Democratic nominee for Governor.

CHUNGKING, China, June 12 -- While the press and officials in Chungking today enthusiastically greeted the news of the Russian-British military alliance and the Russian-American agreement with regard to the urgent tasks for the creation of a second front in Europe in 1942 there was some disappointment because China and the Asiatic front did not receive equal attention.

PEARL HARBOR, June 12 -- How United States Navy air power, in conjunction with Army and Marine bombers, met a big Japanese fleet off Midway and gave the enemy invasion forces a surprise from which they never recovered, was related today by the commanding officer of an American carrier air group.

NEWARK, N.J., June 12 (AP) -- Shut-out pitching by George Washburn in the last eight innings after he replaced Milo Candini carried Newark to a 3-2 victory today over Toronto. All runs came in the first inning. Gene Corbett wiped out Toronto's lead by rapping a homer off Jack Hallett with two on base.

PITTSBURGH, June 12 -- The United Steel Workers of America, C.I.O., won a sweeping victory in elections held by the National Labor Relations Board at twenty-three plants of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation.

PEARL, HARBOR, June 12 -- With torpedoes slung under their belliesi, four big United States Army bombers took off to meet the Japanese fleet June 4. They twisted through a curtain of anti-aircraft fire that was four miles thick. Their gunners matched lead with, scores of Japanese Zero fighters.

A new variation of the callable provision is included in the indenture for about $3,000,000 of equipment trust certificates which the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad proposes to sell, it was disclosed yesterday. Under this indenture all the certificates will be callable, but not after Sept. 1, 1943.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Major Gen. Clarence L. Tinker, commander of the Hawaiian Air Force and one of the most brilliant air officers in the American Army, was lost during the battle of the Mid-Pacific, the War Department announced today.

VICHY, France, June 12 -- The life of the French Parliament expired legally at the beginning of this month and the newspaper Figaro points out today that there is small chance of its term being extended further.

LONDON, June 12 -- Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, the Russian Foreign Commissar, and his party left here convinced that practical considerations rather than ideological differences provided the only limitations on British aid to Russia. Presumably he gained the same impression in Washington.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that three large manufacturers, producing the bulk of the nation's soap, have agreed jointly and voluntarily to rescind price rises averaging 3 1/4 per cent which were posted in February and March.

VICHY, France, June 12 -- Pierre Laval, Chief of Government, has met a challenge for power from Jacques Doriot, head of the pro-Axis French Popular party, by forbidding him to organize political rallies in unoccupied France, it was learned today.
ROME, June 12 (From, Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- A competent estimate that the spear-head of Japan's naval and naval-air striking power has been broken by the loss of possibly half of her best aircraft carriers came from well-informed quarters today in the wake of the newest reports on the Coral Sea and Midway triumphs.
"True to the Army," which arrives at the Central Theatre, will be this morning's sole film opening. Featured in the Paramount comedy are Allan Jones, Judy Canova, Jerry Colonna and Ann Miller.

A German Messerschmitt 109-E will fly over the city on Tuesday, but the United States Treasury Department war savings staff is hopeful that there will be only the one, because its appearance has been arranged for and its pilot will be a United Nations pilot.

LONDON, June 12 -- Momentarily laying aside all thoughts of the war, racing enthusiasts wracked their brains tonight to devise some means of wending their way to Newmarket tomorrow in hope of seeing the King's horse Big Game complete the second half of a two-day meet by winning the Derby.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Japanese have made small landings on islands of the western tip of the Aleutian Islands and naval and air operations against them are in progress, the Navy Department announced tonight.

With Army planes flying overhead and Army, Navy, Marine Corps, Coast Guard and New York Guard units marching up Fifth Avenue with the latest equipment of modern warfare, today's eleven-hour rain-or-shine parade to demonstrate the power of "New York at War" and stimulate the sale of War Bonds is expected to give a realistic picture of what the Amercan armed forces and their machines of destruction look like.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Fallowing is the text of the mutual aid agreement signed yesterday by the United States and Russia:

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- It is not smart to go to the bootlegger in wartime, and violating price and ration controls is close to treason, Donald M. Nelson, War Production chief said tonight in a broadcast warning against inflation. He admonished American manufacturers to avoid panic buying and said that those who found themselves making more than a fair profit out of war contracts should seek voluntary downward adjustments from the government.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- President Roosevelt confessed today to the 425 soldiers comprising the Army guard assigned to duty at the White House that he, in common with many of them, would prefer "duty a little nearer the front," but added that some part of the population had to do the less exciting jobs which he and the White House guard were performing in time of war.

By extending the life of temporary gasoline rationing cards for two weeks and doubling the value of uncancelled units, the Office of Price Administration has deprived some A card holders of the possibility of buying additional fuel before July 15 and provided substantial "bonus" gallonage for others, it was disclosed yesterday as preparations went forward for institution of the permanent system.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 12 -- The New World's oldest democracy today moved nearer a formal state of war with the Axis, as Indian chiefs of the Iroquois Confederacy voted to join the United Nations in battle.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: While reading the story of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field meet in the TIMES, I was impressed by the many fine marks and times made in the events. Nevertheless, I am sure the Trojans of the University of Southern California would easily have won the meet just as they did the last time they competed -- in 1939, I believe.
Trios by Brahms and Tchaikovsky will form the program of the Kraeuter Trio at the Victory concert for service men at 5 P.M. today, in the New York Public Library.

WITH BRITISH FORCES, in the Western Desert, Libya, June 11 (Delayed) (AP) -- Four members of an American Field Service detachment on ambulance duty with the defenders of Bir Hacheim were among the missing when that stronghold was yielded to the Axis last night, it was learned today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 12 -- "Labor hoarding" by California farm operators in the face of a shortage of seasonal help and some resultant crop losses posed a new problem today for Federal and State agricultural experts.

Herbert C. Lanks, who with Harry A. Franck wrote the picture guide book "The Pan-American Highway -- From the Rio Grande to the Canal Zone" several seasons back, has done a new volume, this time without Mr. Franck's collaboration.

Delivery Dispute Hits Trade The delivery dispute and extremely humid weather took toll of retail trade here this week. Estimates indicated department stores had decreases ranging to 10 per cent or more under the comparative 1941 week.
SARASOTA, Fla., June 12 (AP) -- Eight Army fliers were killed and two injured early today when a four-engined bomber crashed into Sarasota Bay.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Sir Walter Citrine, secretary of the British Trade Union Congress, spent an hour and a half today with John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America. The visit led to reports that it might have been connected with British labor's proposal for an America-British-Soviet Labor Alliance.

DAYTON, Ohio, June 12 -- About 50,000 persons have viewed this week an exhibit and stage show demonstrating the conversion of factories to war production totaling a daily output of $6,000,000. The exhibit was prepared by General Motors Corporation.
CHICAGO, June 18 (A.P.) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department or Agriculture follows:

A voluntary program of conversion to war production involving spinners of wool carpet yarns, now idle, and weavers of upholstery fabrics, In which approximately 1,000,000 bales of' cotton waste will be used for manufacturing much-needed bagging materials, was announced yesterday by the Eastern Textile Association for War Conversion.

While the United States Government holds up the sailing of 1,000 Japanese diplomats and nationals on the Swedish liner Gripsholm, immigration officials on Ellis Island were collecting a third contingent of Axis nationals bound for Lisbon.

Below the Surface Bristol Basin is a section of the new East River Drive near Twenty-fifth Street where part of the fill used in building the road consists of the shattered bricks, stones and rubble of the bombed English city of Bristol, brought here as ballast in British ships.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 12 -- Within a few hours after the Axis occupation of Bir Hacheim, Field Marshal Erwin Rommel launched an attack yesterday toward the north. It appeared today to be developing into the third big Nazi drive of the present Libyan campaign.

While the United States Government holds up the sailing of 1,000 Japanese diplomats and nationals on the Swedish liner Gripsholm, immigration officials on Ellis Island were collecting a third contingent of Axis nationals bound for Lisbon.

Below the Surface Bristol Basin is a section of the new East River Drive near Twenty-fifth Street where part of the fill used in building the road consists of the shattered bricks, stones and rubble of the bombed English city of Bristol, brought here as ballast in British ships.
CHICAGO, June 18 (A.P.) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department or Agriculture follows:

OMAHA, Neb., June 13 -- Middle-western farmers are saving money and paying debts. Those are two plainly visible results of increased farm income about a year after the increase in prices began to be really felt in the farm belt.

HARRISBURG, Pa. -- Despite the war Pennsylvania is all set to entertain big crowds of visitors this Summer. For many years people from all over -- from Kalamazoo and Paducah and Flagstaff, from Indiana, Michigan, California and near-by New York -- have shown an inclination to explore Pennsylvania.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 13 -- A fleet of United States four-motor bombers manned by American crews has carried out a destructive bombing of Rumania's oil fields, it was reported reliably tonight after six or possibly seven of the big raiders were forced down in Turkey en route home to their secret bases.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the Chinese Generalissimo, in a message broadcast yesterday from China to a luncheon marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of her graduation from Wellesley College, declared that America's freedom and belief in the equality of all races had inspired China in her war against Japan.

An all-sports carnival will be held at the Polo Grounds this afternoon, with top-ranking athletes from a half-dozen sports contributing to the activities, while a crowd, which may reach 40,000, will contribute to the Army Emergency Relief Fund and the Navy Relief Society, joint beneficiaries of the show.

Home-grown herbs are so much more fragrant and tasty than the boxed product to be found in stores that it is profitable to include a small bed of them in the garden. Most herbs will thrive almost anywhere on a dry slope, as ground cover, under shrubs, in a rock garden, or as a flower-bed border.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 13 -- The "women only" sign is being placed on an increasing number of special courses of study at Ohio State University, as traditional curricula are being streamlined to meet war needs.

The parade was the greatest and the most significant in the city's history and will be surpassed only by the parade that will mark the victory of the United Nations over the Axis powers, Mayor La Guardia declared last night, just after the last contingent of the day-long procession had passed the reviewing stand at the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Stewart McDonald, as chairman of the board of the Maryland Casualty Company, announced yesterday the appointment of Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., as managing agents for twenty-one properties owned by a subsidiary of the casualty company, the Gedex Realty Corporation, and other affiliated companies.

LONDON. THE first public performance of a violin concerto of Sir George Dyson has been by far the most interesting event of the last few weeks. Sir George is better known to the public of the Three Choirs Festivals than to our concert audiences.

TO THE EDITOR: Robert van Gelder's article on conscientious objectors in THE TIMES Magazine of May 10 had the necessary shortcomings of a rather brief survey. The implications of that article are evidently causing more than momentary damage, however, and in the interest of fairness some better informed authorities should be quoted.

TO THE EDITOR: As one who has spent his life in four continents in fighting race prejudice and resisting the doctrine of race superiority, I hope not to be misunderstood if, for reasons of space, I confine my comments upon Miss Pearl Buck's otherwise admirable article to her overstrained and onesided contrast between the peoples of the East and of the West.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The American people heard a good deal more from various government authorities this week about rationing, which is quickly becoming an integral part of their wartime life and bulks large in public and private discussion.

A sharply stepped up educational campaign is planned among retailers on the regulations governing the posting of prices as a result of the recent survey in Philadelphia by a flying squadron of OPA investigators, which showed proper compliance by only 11.1 per cent, Sylvan L. Joseph, regional OPA administrator, said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- President Roosevelt, seated beside Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, and Mrs. Roosevelt on the east portico of the Executive Offices, today received the fourteen British and American war heroes who are on a tour of the nation's principal cities for the Treasury's war-bond sales drive.

MOSCOW, June 13 -- The German advance in the Kharkov sector is being successfully held despite very heavy pressure on a narrow front, involving the use of large tank and air forces supporting waves of infantry, according to the latest reports here tonight.

Joseph P. Day, New York realty operator and auctioneer, will open the third annual conference of the New York State Society of Real Estate Appraisers at Lake George in June, to be held in connection with the annual convention of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York, June 24 to 27.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Manuela Hudson Vanderbilt received a divorce today from Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt of New York on the ground of mental cruelty. Records were sealed after the brief hearing, at which Mr. Vanderbilt was represented by counsel.

HOLLYWOOD. THERE is nothing quite so evident out here as a view. Whether you look to the north or south, upside down or downside up, you can't escape it. It is the most concrete fact about this arbitrary place.

The wartime motorist finds himself faced with some interesting problems in his driving. Both his fuel and his tires will, of course, stretch much farther if he stays under the 40-mile-an-hour limit on the open road. They will also be conserved, as will oil consumption and maintenance costs, if he will keep a sharp eye on stopping and starting.

CHEYENNE, Wyo. -- Bigger and better than ever is the prediction this year for the forty-sixth successive Cheyenne Frontier Days celebration, one of the spectacles of the Old West, which is planned for the five-day period from July 21-25.

RUTLAND, Vt. -- For vacationists looking for something different in the way of a trip, the Long Trail has much to offer. Approaches to its 260 miles of well-blazed route may be easily reached by train and bus, leaving the hiker practically at the foot of the mountain he may wish to climb.

William B. Wheeler, passenger traffic manager of the Grace Line, retired last week at his own request after twelve years of service with the line and twenty-eight years in the shipping business. Before joining the Grace Line in 1931 Mr. Wheeler was passenger traffic manager of the United Fruit Company, with which he became associated in 1914.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 13 -- The nature of the Netherlands' expected contribution to the postwar "new order in Europe" is coming more actively within the purview of inspired German press discussion, and comment now released in German and Netherland quarters suggests that she is to be reimbursed in Eastern Central Europe for her lost colonial empire in the Netherlands Indies.

Because of the urgent need for war contracts to prevent numerous shutdowns in New York City industries, THE NEW YORK TIMES asked George A. Sloan, chairman of the Mayor's Business Advisory Committee, for a statement as to what is being done to solve the problem. Following is his statement:

The trees are full of song these days -- song of the birds that stay with us all year round and of those that visit us in Summer. Dominating this symphony is the robin's merry roulade. Suburbanites who are light sleepers can be awakened by this red-breasted backyard habitue.

In its efforts to conquer the sub marine menace off the Atlantic Coast, the Navy has gone through the yachting and small-boat field of the Third Naval District with a "fine-tooth comb" and already-possesses virtually every suitable craft in the district, officers of the department said here last week.

A violent outbreak in New York harbor a week ago among seamen of a United Nations ship who had just completed a harrowing four and one-half month voyage was disclosed yesterday by shipping men who said such incidents might be expected on a larger scale unless something was done to alter the treatment of seamen serving on dangerous war routes.
LONDON, June 13 -- Czechoslovak President Eduard Benes tonight delivered a radio warning to the Nazis that the day of reckoning for their cruelties in his country was drawing nearer.

CAMDEN, Me. -- A half dozen two-masted schooners sail the sheltered waters of Maine's bays this Summer, giving vacationing landlubbers the thrill of sailing under canvas. The Coast Guard and Navy have approved a course through the inlets of Penobscot, Blue Hill, Jericho and Frenchman Bays, where hundreds of square miles of blue water and steady winds assure pleasant cruising.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- American Army and Navy aviation, striking whenever the dirty weather of the Far North permitted, was believed to be at work today to drive the Japanese from their fingertip hold on the outermost end of the Aleutian Island chain stretching westward from Alaska.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- A new slogan, "less light but more life." has been introduced here, and in keeping with it many new recreation and sports features have been put into effect for the influx of Summer visitors who are already beginning to arrive.
In the Missel case, decided last week, all but one member of the Supreme Court declared:

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Savings to the government of $673,946,103 in recaptured excessive profits on war contracts have resulted thus far from investigations and disclosures made by the House Committee on Naval Affairs in its role of a special body of inquiry, its chairman, Representative Vinson of Georgia, asserted today.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 13 -- Half way through this blazing June of the Anatolian Summer and midway through the potential crisis period when it is commonly conceded, the Near East must face the menace of the Axis now-or-never attempt to smash through the United Nations back door in this vital war theatre, Allied diplomacy in Turkey suddenly has switched from the defensive to the offensive.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Navy Department announced today that many of the nation's headline athletes now stationed at its Norfolk (Va.) school for physical instructors had been ordered to training in gunnery and fire control in preparation for assignment to battle stations at sea.

THERE is a style to literature from New England which is as plain, ordinary and worldly as can be and yet is far more distinguished than writing that gets more talked about. Robert Frost gets the accent perfectly.

The subject now uppermost in the discussions of local philatelists is the coming auction of the collection of the late Colonel E.H.R Green, estimated to be worth between one and two million dollars Professionals are posing the question as to whether income from the public sales will exceed the appraisal figure, $1,200,000, and how much beyond that figure the realization may be.

WITH the exception of the hard - working singers who are going to South America the Summer plans of most concert artists consist of one or two outdoor appearances, a few broadcasts, and for the rest rusticating in Summer homes variously located in Connecticut, New England, Long Island and California.

Rooms that appeal to youth have a prominent place in home decoration -- rooms with freshness, simplicity and an elasticity that allows for economies and changes. And such rooms appeal not only to couples just starting out but to those who are moving to smaller quarters or, who, for one reason or another, want a different effect from last year's.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Philippine Commonwealth, with its territory now occupied by Japan, and Mexico, the latest nation to declare war on the Axis, will formally Join the United Nations in a White House ceremony tomorrow afternoon.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We emigres from the invaded countries are frequently told that American public opinion would fee more stirred by the reports of atrocities if only we could give the names of some of the victims -- names known to Americans who have visited our several countries.

Because or the war, the Home Owners Loan Corporation, which yesterday marked its ninth anniversary, is being deluged with payments from persons who borrowed money several years ago to halt foreclosures on their homes, John H. Fahey, Commissioner of the Federal Home Loan Bank Administration, reported yesterday.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, June 13 -- A twenty-mile column of uniformed men parading through the capital today marked United Nations Day and gave New Zealanders their first glimpse of the degree of military mobilization they have now achieved as part of the Pacific defense plan:

The board of governors of the New York Building Congress, of which J. Andre Fouilhoux of the architectural firm of Harrison, Fouilhoux Abramovitz, was recently elected president, has approved in principle the proposed Post-War Works Program for the City of New York.

CAPE MAY, N.J -- More Navy and Army uniforms are appearing on the boardwalk and in the treelined streets of this resort town. Silver blimps are seen out where sea meets sky and black patrol craft bob at docks among the fishing boats.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter by Gabor de Bessenyey in THE NEW YORK TIMES was interesting in that it revealed the peculiar position of Hungary in the present war. No real pacification of Central Europe is possible without a friendly cooperation between Hungary and its neighbors, the Czechoslovaks, Rumanians and Yugoslavs.

Changes in the constitution of the New York Stock Exchange to allow corporations to become members are taking shape gradually in discussions by the governors. The principle appears to have received wide approval and to be backed by sentiment of the general membership, but details for effecting the change are proving to be troublesome.

The key to America's grave rubber shortage may be hidden under its unknown quantity of leaky hot water bottles, old garden hose, torn bathmats, worn girdles, galoshes and shoe heels, unwanted shower caps, toys and baby teething rings. Such commonplace articles, plus other things like decrepit tires and tubes lying around the family garage, constitute the national stock pile of scrap rubber.

LONDON, June 13 -- London began dressing up late today with flags and bunting in preparation for its share in tomorrow's observance of United Nations Day in which Britain and the British Empire will join with the United States and all the other nations with which the Axis powers are at war.

Elmer Davis is widely known as a writer, author, and commentator on domestic and foreign politics. He was born in Aurora, Ind., on Jan. 3, 1890, the son of Elam H. and Louise Severin Davis, is married and has two children, Robert Lloyd and Carolyn Anne Davis. He lives at 423 West 120th Street, New York City, and spends his Summers at Mystic, Conn.

NEW HOPE, Pa. -- Walking the Canal -- an expression used by men when they ran the boats on the Pennsylvania State Canal-suggests at once an unusual way of taking a vacation. Any one with a yearning for still waters and luxuriant green will find the answer here.

From the seacoasts to the farmlands, drivers can aid in lessening the tire shortage. They can collect, list, report and keep their eyes open for old rubber lying about at roadsides, in creek beds and on junk piles. It all must be gathered under the nation's new program to find and use every piece of rubber scrap.

GLADSTONE, Mich. -- While many traditional celebrations have been canceled for the duration, this one-time booming lumbering community is going ahead with its plans for the National Roleo and Forest Festival to be held on the shores of Little Bay de Noquet from July 3 to 5.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 13 -- By taking the stand that tutoring "is injurious to the best interests of Princeton education," and directing the university committee on examinations and standings to consider measures by which tutoring can be avoided, the Princeton faculty, led by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the college, has opened the way for complete abolition of unjustifiable commercial tutoring here.

A rolling stone gathers no moss, nor does the meandering photographer gather any pictures who does not stay long enough in one place to realize its full camera possibilities, warns J. Ghislain Lootens, P.R.P.S., New York teacher of photography.

STUART, Fla. -- When they are not out hunting submarines in the Gulf Stream, Navy officers stationed in Florida take a sort of busman's holiday and go sailfishing. Together with Army officers and business men and officials from the North, down here on government work, they are keeping alive Florida's $20,000,000 industry.

NEWARK, N.J., June 13 (AP) -- Randy Gumpert, rookie right-hander who was given his start in professional baseball by Connie Mack, pitched his first complete game of the year for the Newark Bears today and made it a shutout performance.

Collectors have reason to believe that President Roosevelt suggested the 5-cent stamp which Postmaster General Walker last week announced would be issued on July 7 "in recognition of the five years' resistance of the Chinese people to Japanese aggression," and that the President had a hand in preparing the design.

Torpedoing of a medium-size United States merchant ship and a medium-size British freighter in the Atlantic was announced yesterday by the Navy. One of the crew of thirty-five on the American ship was killed when the torpedo exploded.

CHUNGKING, China, June 13 -- Approaching the eve of her sixth year of resistance against Japanese aggression, Free China today is making elaborate preparations to celebrate United Nations Day tomorrow.

FRANCONIA NOTCH, N.H. -- All the popular Summer attractions of the Franconia Notch area will operate this season. The tramway, which carries twenty-seven passengers in a cable car to the 4,000-foot summit of Cannon Mountain, opened on Memorial Day for its fifth season.

THAT Hitler has met with opposition on the "home front" is obvious and inevitable. He had, as a matter of fact, prepared carefully to deal with resistance and sabotage, as the record of the SS organizations and the secret police amply prove. How strong are his enemies, and our friends, inside the Fatherland?
DETROIT -- Solution to the civilian-tire shortage isn't "just around the corner," but it's gradually approaching that point, recent events show.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Onota Lake, at Pittsfield, may be opened to fishing and other recreation this week. It is well stocked with rainbow trout through the combined activities of Pittsfield Sportsmen's Club, Onota Lake Trout Rearing Association and Pittsfield Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- President Roosevelt today named Elmer Davis, nationally known radio news commentator, author and former newspaper reporter, as director of a new Office of War Information, with authority over dissemination of all official news and propaganda within the United States and, except for Latin America, abroad.

BOTH the Stadium Concerts and the Daniel Guggenheim Memorial Concerts by the Goldman Band will celebrate their Silver Jubilee season this Summer. The concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium and in Central Park will begin Wednesday night, the former starting at 8 P.M., and the latter at 8:30 P.M.

A radio script writer from New York accepts the job of organizing a radio department in a South Carolina college and arrives just in time for a murder, of which he is promptly accused. Mike Leiter has no alibi for the time of the murder, and every one else who might possibly have done it seems to have an unassailable one.
LONDON. THE chief theatrical event of the past week was the production of a new play by Laurence Housman; but because the Old Vic company now is on tour, I had to go to Birmingham to see it.

SCHROON LAKE -- Resorts here expect that there will be ample railroad and bus facilities to take care of this Summer's sojourners who will not be arriving by automobile. Judging by the more than adequate supply of gasoline in this region, moreover, motorists who are saving their ration stubs for vacation trips to Schroon will not be entirely deprived of their cars, once they are here.

"TWO ON A TOW" has a fresh and interesting background of life on the New York State Barge Canal and an unhackneyed, well worked out plot which is full of surprises for the reader. The plot is concerned with identical twins -- only one of whom is supposed to be on board the barge Araminta.

The American Flag today is not merely a national emblem but a symbol of hope for all the oppressed peoples of the world, rabbis declared in sermons nere yesterday. The "New York at War" parade, the danger of overconfidence and the future of the Jews were other sermon topics.

THIRTEEN New York galleries specializing in American art have already opened or will open tomorrow group shows of work by artists associated with the galleries, in connection with the Federal war bond campaign. The directors of the galleries and the artists represented have agreed that the entire proceeds from sales made during the two weeks of the campaign concluding on June 27 shall be devoted to the purchase of War Bonds.

FORT WORTH, Texas, June 13 -- More students on the campus of Texas Christian University write poetry than play football, which may be hard to believe in view of the reputation of the famous Horned Frogs for prowess on the gridiron.

There are many duplicate games, especially in New York City, which give cash prizes to their winners. This has never been permitted, however, in championship play. Winners of tournaments conducted by the American Contract Bridge League are permitted to receive only trophies or other prizes which, however costly they may be, have little resale value.
CHUNGKING, China, June 13 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command communique issued today follows:

PRINCETON, N.J., June 13 -- Bob Peters made Princeton baseball history by pounding two home runs to bring in seven tallies as the Tigers overpowered Yale, 12 to 8, at University Field today before a cheering crowd of 2,500 Nassau alumni here for commencement festivities.

DOCKED: An 18,134-ton ship, with the word "diplomat" in large letters on her side, steamed into New York Harbor last week. She was the Swedish liner Gripsholm, chartered by the United States Government as an official exchange vessel. She had carried 194 passengers, mostly American citizens, on her trip from Gothenburg, where she had been lying since the outbreak of war.

Mort Starobin, one-time football player coach and in recent years a member of the fur-dyeing firm of Starobin Miskowitz, died yesterday at his home, 356 Buckingham Road, Cedarhurst. He was 40 years old.

LONDON, June 13 -- Increased shipments of goods to Russia are likely to be the most important early tangible results of the recent negotiations of Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, Russia's Foreign Commissar, here and in Washington. Russia's territorial losses last Fall included her most fertile agricultural areas, and replacement of the losses by intensified production elsewhere was hampered by the military training of millions of Russian farm workers.

LONDON (By Wireless). GENERALIZATIONS about individuals are dangerous enough. Those regarding a whole nation are infinitely more so. Yet within limits certain observations of a general nature can be made.

CHUNGKING, China, June 13 (UP) -- Japanese columns, led by strong bomber squadrons, smashed at unyielding Chinese defenses in Kiangsi and Chekiang today, according to Chungking reports that also said the Chinese were striking back along the Kan River and near Nanchang.

Trade buying, balking selling pressure by New Orleans interests, moved cotton futures to moderate gains yesterday. This support was particularly strong in the last hour of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, giving active months rises of 21 to 24 points.

PITTSBURGH, June 13 -- Some years ago a husky, broad-shouldered pitcher named Johnny Broaca, who wore spectacles and a studious look, because he was also a Yale man, gained distinction of a sort by hopping himself off the Yankees at the very moment the Yankees were hopping into the homestretch and heading straight for a pennant.

LAKE PLACID -- Located within 300 miles of New York City, encircled by railroads and penetrated by various motor bus lines, the Adirondacks seem comparatively well adapted to these trying days of rationed routine and "victory vacations."

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumed during May was 957,015 bales of lint and 132,390 bales of linters, compared with 998,754 of lint and 132,106 of linters during April this year, and 923,518 of lint and 129,562 of linters during May last year.

A number of Westchester women will spend the Summer learning how to be as adept as their Girl Scout daughters at building a fire without matches, cooking in the wind and the rain and improvising shelter in the open.

Since the United States entered the war a wholly unexpected situation has developed in the canine world and quite the reverse of what would normally seem probable. This is the remarkable increase in the number of dogs registered with the American Kennel Club, the total for the first five months of 1942 having reached 40,575, against 36,650 for the same period last year.

MR. HUBNER'S casual description of this book as "a novel about a lot of crazy people he knew in Tokyo" is quite accurate but doesn't go far enough. His novel is immensely amusing and casually instructive.
LONDON, June 13 (AP) -- Royal Air Force Spitfires shot up several trains and illuminating-gas tanks and a factory today in a sweep over Northern France.

The significance of the design on the pfennige-denomination stamps in Germany's 1934 air-mail series is the subject of an article by John de Pool, a Panama philatelist, in the current issue of La Estrella de Panama.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Small Business Committees of the Senate and the House, having obtained the enactment of legislation creating the Smaller War Plants Corporation to assure war contracts for a large number of the companies previously frozen out of the production program, set out today for a new objective, relief for thousands of concerns which still cannot get war orders or essential civilian work.

BUENOS AIRES, June 13 -- The announcement from Berlin of the German blockade of the United States reached Buenos Aires too late for official comment, but it is obvious to every one that it will create problems of the utmost gravity for Argentina.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Steadily mounting, but undisclosed, war production figures and employment statistics testified this week to the slow but steady success of efforts to lick the problem of the "week-end blackout" and put the United States on an all-out basis in its effort to turn back the challenge of the Axis powers and turn early reverses into victory.

Miss Jean Barrett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Conklin Barrett of Hempstead, L.I., was married to Captain Maurice Joseph Fitzgerald, United States Army Air Force, son of Mrs. Maurice Fitzgerald of Fort Smith, Ark., and the late Mr. Fitzgerald, yesterday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York will appeal to the Federal authorities to allot more war contracts here in an effort to avoid serious local economic dislocation, Neal Dow Becker, newly elected president of the association, declared in a statement yesterday.
ROCHESTER. THE outstanding feature of this year's Eastman School Festival of American Music was, I believe, the discovery of an important new name among young American composers, William Bergsma.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 13 -- At the Gross Lichterfelde Barracks in the western suburbs of Berlin 258 Jews were put to death by the S.S. on May 28, and their families deported, in retaliation for an alleged Jewish plot to blow up the anti-Bolshevist "Soviet Paradise" exhibition at the Lustgarten.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (AP) -- Handcuffed for seven innings by Mel Harder, the Athletics finally solved the Cleveland hurler's curves today and scored a 4-1 victory, their second in two days over the Indians.

IT is too plain for repetition that the most effective "special pleading" possible is that which stimulates the emotions and quickens a response from the heart. Let a man's sympathy be enjoined and he is definitely on your side.
LONDON, June 13 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique today said:

Ebbets Field and vicinity will be placarded tomorrow with notices announcing that the Dodgers will refuse admission to all who acquire tickets from brokers or speculators. Larry MacPhail, president of the club, made the declaration to that effect yesterday.

SIX months ago Japan's war against China merged with Japan's war against the West. The lines which illequipped Chinese soldiers had been holding with courage and tenacity for more than four years became a part of America's worldwide front.

FRANK MANDEL of the happily recalled Schwab-Mandel partnership is about to return to Broadway production, having been absent from these parts for a matter of about ten years. He has acquired the rights to "V for Vickie," by the Siegfried M. Herzig who less formally is known as Sig Herzig.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 13 -- Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Charlotte Hernandez, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton N. Hernandez of 54 Fairfield Road, this city, and Ticonderoga, N.Y., to Donald S. Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher W. Wilson of Brooklyn and Ticonderoga.

Whirlaway failed yesterday at Aqueduct, where the crowd of 25,2.89 made him the favorite for the $9,875 Carter Handicap, but it took the greatest race Doublrab ever flashed -- seven furlongs in time equaling the track recordto turn the trick on the long-tailed chestnut who tried to give ten pounds to the flying winner.

RUTH HARKNESS is the lady of the panda -- the young American woman who a few years ago found a baby giant panda in the fastnesses of the China-Tibet border and was the first to bring such a rare creature to America.

IN the last war we spoke of "the Allied and Associated Powers" -- and the United States was but an associate. In this war we speak of the "United Nations." The change is significant, and so is the fact that our Flag Day has this year been designated United Nations Day. Out of association came division and isolation.

UNIVERSITY, Ala., June 13 -- The University of Alabama, first school in the South to introduce aeronautical engineering and one of the first to offer civilian pilot training instruction, is again taking the lead in aviation education with a course in aeronautical instruction for high school teachers at its Summer quarter, which started this week.

Stories of how this or that Florida hotel has been taken over by our armed forces are not stopping vacationists intent on seeing something of the South during annual holidays. In fact, though Miami is full of men in uniform going about their training and other business, there is plenty of room for civilians, and plenty for them to do.

HAVE you ever heard the tale of Francois Benjamin Courvoisier, valet to the 75-year-old Lord William Russell residing in London? Courvoisier back in 1840 took to robbing his master's house and topped this habit off one night in May by cutting his lordship's throat ear to ear, as they say.

City doorbells will be rung on a scale not matched since census takers were around, beginning tomorrow, as the campaign opens to bring to householders a new slant on wartime thrift -- the wisdom of buying War Bonds and Stamps to fight inflation and to arm the men at the front.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- President Roosevelt's Executive Order creating the Office of War Information was as follows:

Horsey-minded vacationists may be interested in haunting the comparatively new dude ranch region in the foothills of the Canadian Rockies, where a new frontier is opening up for those who want to rough it and at the same time have soft mattresses, plumbing, and electric lights.

WITH THE A.E.F. IN NORTHERN IRELAND, June 13 -- Thousands of heavily armed United States troops, equipped with twenty-eight-ton tanks and other offensive weapons, moved into camps in Northern Ireland tonight from the "greatest American convoy which ever crossed the Atlantic."

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- The Empire Gas and Fuel Company and the Cities Service Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an answer to the commission's proceedings pending against them and certain other subsidiaries and incorporating an amended plan of recapitalization of Empire Gas and Fuel.

LONDON. IT is always risky for a novelist to stray into unfamiliar territory. The classic example of such an escapade is Ouida's description of the exploits of a college eight, in which she told how they all rowed fast, but her hero, stroke, rowed faster than any other member of the crew.

The turnover of shares on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was the smallest in more than a year -- since May 31, 1941. Stocks drifted idly and closed moderately firmer on a volume of 108,740 shares, against 192,760 on the previous Saturday.

Summer displays at the New York Botanical Garden include many groups of plants that will be of interest to gardeners. In addition to the thousands of roses, there are perennial borders planned to be a "living catalogue," borders of annuals being tested for AllAmerica selections, and a patriotic planting of red, white and blue flowers dominating the scene.

Fierce fighting flared up along a considerable section of the Russian front last week as the anticipated "deadline" for Hitler's renewed "Drang nach Osten" approached. The assault upon Sevastopol and the drive in the Kharkov sector may be preliminary to or a part of the big German push to the East, so long expected, but not yet fully launched.

AT AN OPERATIONAL BASE, in the Southwest Pacific, June 12 (Delayed) -- One of the best things about this place is the coconut. Native hoys climb trees to get them. The best part is the milk, which is very tasty when the coconut is still green.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 13 -- Sir Samuel and Lady Salvage will open the gardens of Rynwood, their estate on Cedar Swamp Road, next Saturday for an English garden party sponsored by, the British Schools and Universities Club of New York for the Eagle Squadron Fund and the Royal Air Force Benevolent Fund of the U.S.A., Inc.

THE men in our armed services represent every phase of American life, and their interests are as diverse as the nation itself. Among the millions of men wearing the uniforms of the various services, there are many who like good music.

A censored letter received from neutral Sweden last week brings hints of what has been going on postally behind the German lines in the U.S.S.R. Early in the Nazi onslaught the three Baltic States, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, were overrun, together with some Soviet terrain.

LONDON, June 13 -- While Labor Leader Arthur Greenwood was calling on the workers of Britain today to redouble their energies in order to speed the time when a second front can be opened in Western Europe, several exiled governments reported the receipt of underground information indicating rising anxiety among the Nazis all along the occupied coast.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- President Roosevelt this week termed rubber the principal problem of national scope and every one in Washington agreed that no problem existed about which there had been more confusion, both as to the extent of the shortage and as to what further means should be employed to meet it.
OKLAHOMA CITY, June 13 (AP) -- Rescue crews counted twenty-nine dead today after the tornado which struck a residential district near the city's southwest corner last night.

Attempting to focus attention on the need for the use of schools as neighborhood centers, the Committee on Education of the Women's City Club has just completed a study of the custodial management of New York City schools, with particular reference to the effect of the system on the functioning of the schools in wartime.

EVERY now and then, in this vertiginous age, a newspaper or periodical digs into its files and publishes what finds there which is reflective of the doings of the world ten or twenty or fifty or a hundred years go.

The ten-day War Bond Pledge campaign in Greater New York will be started tomorrow as 200,000 "minute men" call on every family in the city to obtain pledges for purchases of War Bonds and War Savings Stamps.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- The Most Rev. Joseph M. Corrigan titular Bishop of Bilta and rector of the Catholic University of America, was buried this afternoon alongside the hall which bears his name at St. Joseph's-in-the-Hills, headquarters of the retreat of the Men of Malvern.

OTTAWA, June 13 -- During the debate on the bill to make it possible to send conscripted men overseas -- presented on Wednesday for second reading in the House of Commons by Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King-only two speakers dealt in any way with the fundamental reasons that lie behind the opposition of the Canadians of French descent.

CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) -- Ceilings on prices of dressed beef and pork continued this week to restrict price movements in the live stock markets, but sheep and lambs worked up to around the best figures since 1929. Little was done today because of the usual small Saturday supply, but prices were steady.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 13 (AP) -- The sinking of the aircraft carrier Lexington, burned out below decks and rocked by explosions of burning ammunition and gasoline after her part in the Coral Sea Battle was described today by Rear Admiral Frederick C. Sherman, her commander.

Government-built war housing, points out Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, is tending more and more toward merely temporary construction. Among the projects under construction at present, he says, are dormitories with sleeping wings having central lavatories and showers, and with one large dining hall for each dormitory block.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As the war progresses it is not difficult to visualize unflinching, decisive action which must be carried out by all able-bodied civilians in coordination with competent government and local administrative bodies. The hour of regimentation is here, regardless of whether we like it or not.

The fifty-fifth annual National A.A.U. track and field championships will be held at Triborough Stadium on Friday and Saturday with no adjective carrying less weight than a full-fledged superlative worthy to describe any part of the meet.

Praise Not Stinted From unexpected quarters come kind words for the capitalist system. Secretary Ickes expresses admiration for what the oil companies, the railroads and the truck operators have done in the oil emergency.

Next Sunday being Father's Day, wives and offspring had better begin right now to notice whether Father's wallet is getting frayed at the edges, whether Father has run out of books to read, or whether ho needs some little thing he'd never bother buying for himself.

THE Federation of Music Clubs is extending its activities to South America. It now has cooperating groups in Rio de Janeiro, Buenos Aires and Montevideo. Mrs. Helen Harrison Mills of Peoria, Ill., is the federation's chairman of music in international relations and this is what she reports about Latin-American activity:

PORTLAND, Me. -- Summer tourists will find the same warm welcome awaiting them upon their arrival in Maine this year as in previous years. The lakes and rivers, forests and shores that make Maine a leading vacation State will be here for their enjoyment as before.

THIS annual period of selecting the best this and that in various fields of art has brought grief in several worlds of creative endeavor, but certainly not in the dance. The Drama Critic's Circle decided to forego any award in the theatre, and the Pulitzer committee followed suit.

AUGUSTA, Me. -- In Maine are 2,500 lakes and ponds, 5,000 rivers and streams, and they contain millions of fish. Many of these fish are game and they provide sport for thousands of anglers each year. In the Dennys River and the Penobscot and Atlantic salmon should be striking now; his landlocked kin are putting up a fight in hundreds of inland waters.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- There is no priority on bathing beauties and despite the war they are still very much in evidence here at the shore. Beaches are already doing a heavy business as visitors seek the Summer combination of salt surf and sunshine.
A great array of football stars will go into action at the Polo Grounds on Saturday afternoon, Sept 12, when the All-Army football team will play the New York Giants in a benefit game.

"HEY, mister, got an extra ticket to the show?" pleads a ragamuffin in front of a radio station or playhouse. And if your girl friend doesn't show up or your chum couldn't make it that night, you give the youngster a ticket and tell him to have a good time.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. -- Flag Day is being observed in this resort today with flags displayed on all public buildings, as well as cottages and hotels. At the Sunday tea and night dances on the Show Boat Deck at the Cavalier Beach Club, the program will be marked by patriotic music.

There is no single season of applied effort for members of the subscription committee of the New Opera Company, the lyric theatre organization established last year under the leadership of Mrs. Lytle Hull. This is a fact manifest in the time and coordinated work being devoted to the company's interests through the late Spring and early Summer by many women of prominence in society and artistic circles who compose the special committee on subscriptions.

GRANTS, N.M. -- Adding one more to the contradictions of nature found in the Southwest are the perpetual ice caves of New Mexico, formed by the flow of molten lava spewed forth by the now long extinct Bandora Crater.

No general rise in the rent levels for apartments and homes in the New York area is anticipated despite the fact that the OPA has decided not to invoke the rent-control law here, according to those who have their fingers on the pulse of the real estate market.

HALF a world has changed since, half a year ago, Japanese bombs fell on Pearl Harbor. On the one side Japan has overrun some 800,000 square miles and planted her flag on Hong Kong, the Philippines, Thailand, Malaya, the Netherlands East Indies, Burma and a ring of outposts overshadowing Australia; she has carried the attack across the Pacific.

LONDON, June 13 -- Military experts estimate that it would take about 400 ships of 10,000 tons each to transport a modern army of 100.000 overseas with equipment. Ninety or a hundred destroyers would be needed to protect the convoy, not to speak of the necessity of establishing air superiority as an umbrella over the bridgehead to be established.

MELBOURNE. THIS year there will be none of the visits by overseas musicians on whom Australia largely relies to furnish its musical season. The United States' entry into the war cut off the last source of supply.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The following Foreign Service change's since May 30 were annpunced today by the State Department:

MURRAY BAY, Quebec -- The Manoir Richelieu and the colony at Murray Bay is expected to get off to an auspicious start when the hotel officially opens June 22. The hotel and cottages can be reached by rail, boat, air and motor. Trains leaving New York nightly arrive in Montreal in the morning, connecting with a Canadian Steamship Line vessel that cruises up the St. Lawrence River to Murray Bay.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 13 -- Southern California gained its eighth, consecutive National Collegiate A.A. track and field championship tonight, assembling 85% points through a grand display of team strength.

IT was a bit of rare good fortune for the world that Walter de la Mare while exploring a box of old papers and letters should come upon a "commonplace book" containing twenty pages of verses written thirty-five years ago, laid aside and forgotten.

Eight guests, six of them uninvited, descend upon Mrs. Sally Dudley at her Summer cabin on Lone Island. Sally's stepson Joel and fiancee are already there when the guests arrive. The problem of finding food and beds for so large a crowd is bad enough, but there is worse to come.

As an R.A.F. plane flies it is 1,840 miles from Knightsbridge in London to its namesake, Knightsbridge in Libya. The place in the British capital is not a bridge, but a busy half mile of thoroughfare running from Hyde Park Corner at the end of Piccadilly to a point a bit beyond Brompton Road.
The story of the man who built a boat in his cellar and had to move the house to extricate his handiwork was re-enacted yesterday a few minutes after the great parade began.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 13 (AP) -- Bobby Coombs, veteran right-hander, limited Montreal to 5 hits as Jersey City wound up a successful home stand with a 3-to-1 victory over the Royals today.

Vacations taken at any time should be safe, but now, with the country at war and in need of man power, it is more important than ever that each individual should use the utmost care to guard his health and general well-being. And this can be accomplished if the vacationist will exercise a reasonable amount of discretion.

CHUNGKING, China, June 13 -- China, Dai Nippon's No. 1 headache, begins the sixth year of her struggle against Japanese aggression, easily the longest major war in modern history, with increasing confidence.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, today sent a message of congratulation to General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the United States Army, for the splendid work accomplished by Army airplanes in repulsing the Japanese raid on Midway Island.

A nation-wide drive to enlist the country's savings in the war effort begins today. Minute Men and Minute Women will ring their neighbors' doorbells to bring the message that America needs every dollar and every dime that its people can save. This is no ordinary "drive" for funds.

When I took office as chairman of the Board of Higher Education in New York City, I stated my hope that it would be increasingly possible to extend into the colleges where so-called mass education has to prevail, some of the qualitative values which the small New England college has always stood for.

DETROIT, Mich., June 13 -- The measure of Detroit's war production effort, which may not be revealed in terms of bombers, tanks, guns, shells and other equipment actually built, was indirectly shown this week through a survey of employment.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 13 -- A nation-wide educational program dedicated to the care and protection of children during the war is in full swing, it was announced today by Dr. Leonard Mayo, chairman of the United States Children's Bureau Commission on Children in Wartime and dean of the School of Applied Social Secience of Western Reserve University.

HOLLYWOOD. OF all the Hollywood stand-ins, Jim Fleming is perhaps the best known and highest paid of this craft since Slim Talbot, who acted for many years in this capacity for Gary Cooper, retired to an Oregon ranch, and Miss Sally Sage, who was for so long Miss Bette Davis's stand-in, went home to have a baby, as even stand-ins do.

The National Ski Patrol System announced yesterday that its trophy for the "outstanding patrolman of the 1941-42 Winter campaign had gone to Robert Livermore Jr. of the Ski Club Hochgebirge of Boston. The former Harvard ace has long been associated with the ski sport, both from competitive and recreational phases.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- Chester Waters Larner, a pioneer in the design of hydraulic machinery for water power plants, died Thursday at his home in the Kenilworth apartments in Germantown. He was 61 years old.

KINGSTON -- The Summer season in the Ulster-Greene vacationland in the Catskills began for resort officials on Memorial Day. At that time heavily taxed facilities indicated that, no matter what restrictions motorists might experience, mountain visitors will continue to come somehow, to give the region one of its biggest seasons.
Women's place in this war was brought home as never before yesterday in the parade. And their ability to "take it on the chin" was proved beyond doubt.

JERUSALEM, June 13 -- In an article published Thursday in the Jerusalem periodical. Problems of Today, Dr. Judah L. Magnes, president of Hebrew University, discusses further the question "Palestine and Arab Union.

NEWMARKET, England, June 13 -- The crowd of hitch hikers and pedestrians far outnumbered the carriage trade today when King George and Queen Elizabeth saw their handsome colt, Big Game, beaten in the historic Derby by Lord Derby's Watting Street and four other plebeian animals.

There has been a marked change in the tenor of popular discussions of post-war prospects in recent months. In contrast with the dire predictions of collapse that were current not long ago, we now hear and read almost daily forecasts of a great new era of unparalleled prosperity to follow the end of the war.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -- The White Mountains of New Hampshire already are welcoming guests to several resorts. At Spring meetings attended by hotel proprietors discussions were held concern- ing transportation and more comprehensive programs for the entertainment of Summer guests, who, deprived of their usual pleasure of motoring through the mountains, will need new diversions.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass. -- Six miles off the south coast of Massachusetts, this scenic little Island is busy polishing up its colonial traditions and historic spots preparatory to the observance of its tercentennial. The first permanent white colony on the islands "near unto Cape Cod" was established three hundred years ago at what is now known as Edgartown, by one Thomas Mayhew of Watertown, Mass.; his son, Thomas Jr., and several associates.

PITTSBURGH, June 13 -- To help students continue in college, the A.W. Mellon Educational and Charitable Trust has established annual grants of $10,000 each to the University of Pittsburgh and Carnegie Institute of Technology.

IF it were any other year but this, the radio would now be about to enter upon a comfortable Summer doze, not to awaken fully until Autumn and the return of the big programs; for even the radio is given in normal times to seasonal lulls, though, by comparison with the theatre, say, it is a study in perpetual motion.

SPRING LAKE, N.J. -- Into the pattern of Summer play and social gayety along the length of the New Jersey seafront will be woven, this season, a motif of work for victory. Relief agencies, service organizations, and war bond campaigns will all benefit from the programs of social and sports programs being arranged.

The Maritime Commission is not ready to embark upon a program of building wooden ships because the size of wooden vessels is limited, and as there is a shortage of propulsion engines the entire output of ship engines must be totalled in steel ships.

ROME, N.Y., June 13 (AP) -- Dr. Charles Bernstein, superintendent of the Rome State School for Mental Defectives for thirty-eight years and an originator of progressive rehabilitation programs for asylum inmates, died today. His age was 69.
