SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 -- An over-all proclamation this week finally excluding all Japanese from their homes anywhere in the Far West's Military Area No. 1 focused attention on the "speed tempered with humanity" with which the Army has handled the Japanese evacuation on this coast and almost involuntarily raised the question, "What of the German and Italian aliens?"
CAIRO, June 33 (AP) -- The British Middle East Headquarters com- munique said today:

NANTUCKET, Mass. -- For years Nantucket has been a mecca for Summer visitors who want to escape the hustle and bustle of everyday America, and this year more than ever the quiet charm of this famous island will have an appeal for vacationists.

MEXICO CITY -- Although Mexico has taken her place beside the United States in the war, she has no intention of closing her doors to legitimate tourist business from the north. Quite to the contrary, Mexico will give a cordial welcome to those travelers who are able to snatch a few weeks of respite from the tension of war work in the United States.

THE NBC String Symphony Orchestra, under Frank Black, will be heard for the first time outside of the radio realm, when it appears in a subscription series of three concerts next season in Carnegie Hall. The events are scheduled for Oct. 23, Nov. 27 and Jan. 15.

With the loss of only three bouts, the Fencers Club successfully defended its women's national fencing championship on its home strips last night. The Misses Ruth Maxwell, Helena Mroczkowska and Dorothy Wahl, with Miss Dorothy Lancaster as an alternate, retained the crown by defeating the Salle Santelli representatives, 5 -- 1, in the final match.
HITCH-HIKER: A slight, dark, bespectacled Briton stood stranded last week on the highway between Ogdensburg and Canton in up-State New York. He was Malcolm MacDonald, High Commissioner for Canada.

Thousands of doctors went to Atlantic City last week to attend the annual meeting of the American Medical Association, always the major medical event of the year. Largely because so many doctors are in the Army or Navy, this year's meeting was of less scientific interest than usual.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 13 -- For the first time in the history of higher education in America, a course dealing exclusively with the social and economic activities of women will be offered when Syracuse University introduces next Fall a new course in the Department of Sociology entitled "The Status and Responsibilities of Women in the Social Order."

Most gardeners are familiar with the Oriental Poppy, with its brilliant scarlet flowers and the bit of black at the base of each petal. Of recent years many new varieties have been developed. In Snow Flame the upper part is a flame orange, shading down to a snow white, contrasting vividly with the black at the base.

ELAINE had "a divine disposition." So at least her ex-mother-in-law declared, and it really wouldn't seem reasonable to expect that lady to be unduly prejudiced in favor of the woman her son had married and divorced at an extremely early age.

Parades, meetings, broadcasts and religious services in the countries fighting the Axis will mark today an international observance of Flag Day. President Roosevelt, who designated the day as one for honoring the twenty-seven United Nations, will broadcast at 5:50 o'clock this afternoon a message of welcome to Mexico, the newest ally.

A neat edging, which precisely marks the line of a bed or border, is considered the indispensable finishing touch by many self-respecting gardeners who spend tedious hours keeping, these edgings straight and even. Permanent materials, such as bricks, cypress blocks or metal strips, are a greater investment than many gardeners wish to undertake.
HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., June 13 -- Paul Engels and Mal Galletta of North Hills, the medalists, led the way into the semi-finals of the second annual member-guest tournament at the Hempstead Golf Club today.

A DAYLIGHT patrol of fourteen infantrymen, including a corporal and the only old "regular" among them, a sergeant. Two trucks and a Bren carrier. Three guns, a Lewis and two Brens. Mills grenades. Iron rations.
Funds to start art projects in at least twenty Army camps will be provided by the Museum of Modern Art's sale of paintings and prints, which, ends on Tuesday night with a garden party and auction.

OKMULGEE, Okla. -- Visitors to Eastern Oklahoma this Summer need not be alarmed by the sound of midnight tomtoms and the sight of Indiana dancing around a secluded fire. The green corn ceremony or "busk" is a completely peaceful affair which ushers in the Creek Indian New Year.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 13 -- On the question of the Berlin Government's view of the decision of Chief of State Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's regime at Vichy virtually outlawing all the Free French forces, apparently hung tonight the fate of the de Gaullist officers and men captured by the Axis forces at Bir Hacheim in Libya.

Tall, husky Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. of New York was born forty-eight years ago of Irish Catholic parents in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn. He left school for work at the age of 15, but managed to finish his studies, mostly at night. While he was preparing for the law, he clerked for J.P. Morgan Co., eventually becoming secretary to a partner.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 13 -- W.S. Wasserman, leader of the United States lease-lend mission to Australia, who is returning to Washington primarily to expedite the supply of materials for this country's needs in the war effort, said today that he was taking home the message that the Australians were doing a splendid job of production.

FLAG DAY means more to Americans this year than at any other time since 1877, when the government issued the first call for its observance. An executive of one of the half-dozen companies that manufacture flags for the country says: "The custom of displaying the flag has been growing for a long while; the timing of Flag Day close to Memorial Day and Independence Day has something to do with that.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Tire shortages, gas rationing and the inability to get new cars or replacements for the old ones have combined to allow the motorist today to cross the nation's highways in almost solitary grandeur.

DOWN at his Summer retreat and workshop in Bucks County, Pa., George S. Kaufman is getting into shape the scenario of his first film under the writer-director-profiucer contract which he signed with Warner Brothers last March.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Motorists in the seventeen East Coast gasoline rationed States will register at public schools on July 1, 2 and 3 for the new gasoline ration books under the "permanent" rationing plan which becomes effective July 15, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

A sizzling sun and wilting humidity sent hundreds of marchers and spectators to the ten first-aid stations along the route of the parade yesterday, and dozens of accidents ranging from an Army tank that caught fire after the parade to a police inspector who was bitten by a horse added to the day's casualty list.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 13 -- Long Island Sound reverted to type today in the special regatta of the New Rochelle Yacht Club. After two week-ends of reliable breezes, there was one of those windless sessions for which it has been famous.

LAKE WINNEPESAUKEE, N. H. -- Transportation, this year's vacation bugaboo, is a problem already half solved in this area, which is served by two railroad lines, bus routes and water-borne carriers. Along the western shore of the lake the Boston Maine has stops at Laconia, Lakeport, the Weirs and Meredith.

THE logger who worked around the ranch knocked a table together the day after the bride reached the Montana shack, so that she wouldn't have to serve dinner on the lid of a cowboy's chuck-box. She covered the top with white oil cloth and set it with her grandmother's silver, rescued twenty years before from the Civil War's depredations and now brought from her West Virginia home.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 13 -- "Exploding" stars don't really explode after all. Evidence presented to the American Astronomical Society here today indicates that the greatest cataclysm in the universe occurs when some over-energetic star merely "lets off a little steam."

WINTON, Minn. -- Even the tiny Minnesota town from which we leave -- our last link with civilization -- is itself worth the trip up North. It is the last stop on the Duluth Iron Range Railroad of mine and lumber fame, and, spread ever the top of a hill, it suns itself in the brief northern Summer on the shores of Fall Lake.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At a time when our nation as a whole is urged to make every sacrifice in order to bolster our war effort it is decidedly not intelligible why subsidized silver interests should remain immune to our national program.

Yachtsmen already in the Army, and especially those with marine motor experience, are being sought for motor boat service. Those who are still civilians but whose call to arms looms in the near future, are also registering their names with Captain James W. Orme Jr. at Room 3112, New War Department Building, Washington.

A statement broadcast from Berlin and recorded here yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting Company described a submrine "zone of operations" extending to the American coast," indicating a new threat of undersea warfare.

A message from the Archbishop of Canterbury will be read at the special United Nations service to be held in Washington Cathedral in the National Capital next Sunday afternoon. The services will begin at 3:30 o'clock, and will be broadcast by the Columbia network to the United Nations, and by shortwave to the occupied countries.

HOLLYWOOD. "MY SISTER EILEEN," the Jerome Chodorov-Joseph Fields play of two seasons ago, has gone before the cameras at Columbia with plot and most of the dialogue intact, despite a number of changes demanded by the mores of the cinema.
NEW YORK Vice President and Mrs. Henry A. Wallace are at the Towers of the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The War Production Board today ordered manufacturers of cans for several vegetables, fats and a score of other products to substitute wherever possible electrolytic tin plate and chemically treated black plate for tin plate so as to conserve further the nation's supplies of war-essential tin.
Following is a detailed description of the Prologue and the various divisions of the parade:

A veteran trio from the New York A.C. thrust its way to the National epee team championship at the Salle Santelli yesterday. Leo Nunes, a duelist for twentyfive years; Nicholas Muray, fifteen years a blade-wielder, and Henrique Santos, some ten years in the sport, combined to sweep the Winged Footers to victory.

WITH smaller gains last year to beat, retail sales have managed to move out of the minus column, although general merchandise volume still fails to match, that of 1941, when the difference in prices is considered.

IF John Addington Symonds had not sent Whitman a certain letter a few years before the poet's death in which he demanded specific answers to embarrassingly specific queries the problem of Whitman biography would have been much simpler than it is.

HOUSTON, Texas, June 13 -- As part solution of a traffic problem that is made acute by the daily influx of 50,000 war-plant employes, this city has turned to the voluntary "staggering" of working and shopping hours.

Headed by J. Donald Budge, former world's amateur and professional-champion, the foremost professional tennis players of the country will gather, at the West Side Tennis Club-Stadium, Forest Hills, on Saturday for the national championship.

IN point of chronology the twenty-six pieces by Mark Twain written for the Alta California during the first half of 1867 come between his Sandwich Island letters and the European ones that eventually became "The Innocents Abroad."

EAST HAMPTON, June 13 -- The Devon Yacht Club's opening dinner dance on June 27 will be a benefit to aid in the United Service Organizations campaign, which is now well under way here under the chairmanship of Kenneth E. Davis, with Mrs. Edward Ewen Anderson as vice chairman.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Pennsylvania's vast area of forest land, lakes, streams and waterfalls -- the Pocono Mountain region, little changed from its natural state -- will be discovered this Summer by many who have known of its wealth of beauty only by hearsay.

TORONTO -- The Lions, Kiwanis and Rotary Clubs will hold their annual gatherings in this Canada's second largest city, this Summer. In recent years, because of its proximity to the American border, Toronto has become an important international convention center.

LONDON, June 13 -- The extensive and severe battle that has raged in the Libyan Desert for weeks is perhaps unique in tank battles of modern warfare in that it has brought the British and Germans together on more or less equal terms with more or less equal equipment.

While the profits of automobile manufacturers were more than halved in the first quarter of 1942, compared with those a year before, because of the termination of production for civilian customers early in the year, only a moderate set-back was sustained by the automotive equipment industry.

Various inquiries have been received concerning the newly formed Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission. The chief question raised is about the representation of sportsmen or the generally interested public beyond the commissioners from each State.

The new appeals committee of the North American Yacht Racing Union, ruling body of yacht racing in this country and Canada, consists of seven members. The union decided that appeals from decisions of the racing rules by member yacht clubs and associations that before were put to its executive committee should be handled by a separate body, which should give a final ruling.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- Paralleling the action taken yesterday by the North American Company in the Circuit Court of Appeals in New York, the United Gas Improvement Company filed today in the Third Circuit Court here appeals from two separate orders directed against it by the Securities and Exchange Commission under the integration section of the "death sentence" clause of the Holding Company Act.

Main floor departments were active in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Consumer demand for dresses, coats and suits was generally fair.

WE all realize that the arts have a stake in the present world crisis. Just what is that stake? The question is thoughtfully discussed by George Boas, Professor of Philosophy at Johns Hopkins University, in a paper which he contributed to the Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion in Their Relation to the Democratic Way of Life, held at Columbia University last September.

Admitting that it is somewhat too early to gauge the effect of gasoline rationing upon residential real estate as a hole, Newell J. Nessen, president of the Quaker City Federal Savings and Loan Association, of Philadelphia, says that present trends seem to indicate a strengthening and increased demand, rather than a decline, for urban and suburban properties close to transportaion facilities.

A fog four miles deep, so to speak, blankets the East and West Coasts for 150 miles inland as far as private flying is concerned. If anything, the visibility is even less in the Pacific area. The flier who is not in CAP, CPT or commercial work might as well get used to the zero ceiling.

Filling in for the men who are called to war is more a matter of mechanical skill than muscle, as rural women are learning along with their city sisters. On farms, where the war problem is resolved largely to a maximum production of food supplies for the allied armies, harvest bounties will be garnered on more lavish scales where the land army is as mechanized as its counterpart at the front.

THOMAS HARDY'S awareness that he was writing for two distinct audiences is acutely shown in "The Return of the Native," in a footnote that appeared for the first time in the British Wessex Edition in 1912.

In an effort to encourage needed war housing through remodeling and conversion of existing structures, remodeling loans on the FHA plan have been converted to a strictly wartime basis, Federal Housing Commissioner Abner H. Ferguson announced yesterday.

Declines in three components more than offset gain in the other three series and THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity dropped a full point for the week ended June 6. The figure was 131.0 as against 132.0 for the previous week and 127.4 (revised) for the week ended June 7, 1941.
THE big event of the week is, of course, the Dance Profession-Victory Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria on Saturday and the all-day exposition of dance methods which precedes it.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 13 -- Lawson Little, former grand slam amateur' champion, and Lloyd Mangrum won two matches today in the Inverness invitation fourball golf 'tourney, jumping far ahead of the field at the end of five of the seven rounds in the $7,650 competition.

TO the question "What has fascism contributed to Italian literature?" I often answer "Count Sforza", and, indeed, some of the bright spots in the Italian writing of these last twenty years have been essays, speeches and meditations by this liberal Italian statesman now turned man of letters in exile.

THIS is the sixteenth volume of a series of books on American rivers, but it is only incidentally about a river. Something more than water puts the Sangamon on an equality with the Mississippi, the Kennebec, the Hudson and the Delaware.

IF there is light before dusk one may look for light again after darkness. Such is the significance of the title of this book of recollections from France by a Russian woman whose father was Ambassador to Paris in days preceding the first World War.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman headed a group of Roman Catholic dignitaries who reviewed the "New York at War" parade yesterday as it swung up Fifth Avenue past. Fiftieth Street. The Archbishop arrived at 4:30 P.M. at a special stand on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral and watched the marchers until the end.

Determined that the United States shall not lose the peace this time, a committee of nationally recognized educators is engaged in an extensive program to help clarify the many serious issues that will need to be solved after the war ends.

HONOLULU, June 12 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons, Hawaiian Army Commander, today issued a statement mourning the loss of Major Gen. Clarence L. Tinker, commander of the Air Force here, who, General Emmons said, had died "knowing we had an important part in winning a great air victory."

A two-day Fashion Fair, presenting the first national exhibition of salvage sewing in America, will be held from 2 P.M. to midnight Tuesday and Wednesday in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor to demonstrate the progress made in Bundles for America's national project of salvaging and reconstructing discarded clothing.

Home ownership interest is showing no diminution in Long Island residential centers and brokers state that the market for wellconditioned older houses is steadily improving. Among the active selling centers during the past week were Forest Hills, Jackson Heights, Jamaica, Flushing and Manhasset.
BOSTON. MOVING officially for the first time into the field of radio broadcasting, Harvard University has just begun a series of programs over WRUL, Boston's world-wide shortwave station.

Despite gasoline rationing, the rubber shortage and other travel difficulties, one of the greatest fields in the game's history is now assured for the Hale America Golf Tournament, which is to be staged at Chicago from Thursday through next Sunday.

Department store sales, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table of percentage comparisons with a year ago for the Reserve districts, for the last two weeks and the latest four-week period:

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- There is every indication that resorts in this vicinity will have a greater appeal this season than ever before, and already Southampton, East Hampton and adjacent watering places at this end of Long Island have made plans to meet the emergency of transportation in these days of gasoline and tire rationing.

The confectionery industry, because of its highly diversified equipment and processes, has been able to convert whole sections of its plants to war work and the average candy manufacturer already has at least two departments of his factory given over to the production of war supplies, according to A. Rush Watkins, chief of the Conversion Section, Food Supply Branch, WPB, who yesterday made public recognition of the industry's efforts.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 13 -- Economically, politically and militarily, the situation of Finland has not become substantially worse in the last few weeks, but gnawing fear for the future -- fear of a breach with the United States that would cut their last link with the democratic world -- is today the silent companion of every Finn.

The nation's colleges could play a tremendous part in building up American morale if they made students more aware of the value of music as a socializing force, Dr. George Dana Weeks, who has completed a two-year doctoral study of students at Hunter College, asserted yesterday.

IN the Civil War's darkest days The Atlantic Monthly published Edward Everett Hale's "The Man Without a Country," a realistic story that electrified the war-weary nation with its message of patriotism, grim fiction for grim times.

NORTH CREEK -- During Summer months many persons who have formerly spent vacations touring in automobiles will perforce leave the highway far behind and seek recreation hiking and camping along woodland trails. Unless properly prepared and equipped, initiation into the much-touted joys of camping and hiking may be a dismal disappointment.

PITTSBURGH, June 13 -- Being apparently an outfit that knows no happy medium, Frankie Frisch's Pirates, who recently took to reversing their field after blowing ten. engagements in a row, bagged their seventh straight victory today by sinking the Giants, 8 to 2.

WESTPORT, Conn., June. 13 -- Piloted by Miss Elizabeth Hyland, the imported thoroughbred Bally Bohill, registered two sparkling successes in full-count hunter classes today to highlight the opening sessions of the nineteenth annual Fairfield County Hunt Club Horse Show.

LONDON, June 13 -- A detailed study of photographs taken at Cologne, district by district, soon after the R.A.F. attack by 1,000 bombers two weeks ago, shows even more extensive destruction and damage than earlier reconnaissance suggested, the Air Ministry announced today.

Vacations are "out" for the duration. Furloughs are "in." A furlough, of course, is also a brief time off for rest, relaxation and change of scene. But it is granted as a reward for work well done. And its purpose is to prepare for more hard work.

THERE are irony and human kindness and excellent reporting in these twoscore or so of sketches about New York. The city has had most of its polygoned aspects thoroughly illuminated before, of course, but Mr. Berger has selected some new viewpoints and shifted his lighting equipment to good effect, so that the results are always fresh and sometimes dramatic.

Window Boxes Last Summer I was very successful with my two window boxes. I had on hand, wintered over, begonias and miniature ivy. Since my supply of loam was not sufficient (I was at the shore), I gathered wood and coal ashes I had been saving, in addition to a pail of peatmoss which I had-on hand.

Most manufacturers of women's apparel seemed satisfied with the amendment to OPA Regulation No. 153 and anticipate an active season, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

SHELTER ISLAND -- Two of the largest hotels here, the New Prospect and Peconic Lodge, will open June 25. Others, including the Pridwin Hotel, Oxford Hall, Shelter Island House and Cheqfuit Inn, are already open. Dance orchestras enliven several of the hotels, with dancing nightly, except Sunday, at the New Prospect, where a team of dancers offer special exhibitions on Saturday, competition and group dancing on Friday, and children's night on Wednesday.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 13 -- While a large-scale air battle raged overhead German armored divisions yesterday continued their drive toward the sea and after a day of intense fighting reached the area between Knightsbridge and Acroma by dusk.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Wheat was extremely dull today on the Board of Trade, but the tone was firm. Commission buying was of small proportions, as was mill buying. Local professional operations were light and of little significance. Continued uncertainty about the final form of the Farm Bill in Congress tends to restrict the trade.

Few weeds are as vicious as the poison ivy, which, left to grow without check, soon becomes a menace. Contact with the leaves or stems results in painful skin poisoning to most people. Children are particularly susceptible, as they are apt to walk among the leaves of the poisonous plant without knowledge of the risk.

SAVE the water in which vegetables are cooked, admonish the nutritionists, and never, never throw away the liquid from canned food. But while obliging salvage committees take away the waste paper, tin cans and odds and ends of rubber which a good housekeeper has patriotically collected, what to do with the carefully conserved fluids remains strictly her own problem.

Allie Feldman spun, a neat two-hitter yesterday as Abraham Lincoln High won the city P.S. A.L. Senior High School baseball championship by walloping George Washington High, Manhattan-Bronx ruler, 8 to 1, in the final-round play-off at Lincoln Field, Brooklyn.

ST. LOUIS -- The lordly Mississippi, as patriotic as it is famous, is furnishing a share of recreation to the motor-saving public this Summer. A venerable packet steamer chugs away from the levee at least once weekly with her decks of passengers, and a shiny big excursion boat plies forth twice daily with several thousand folk aboard.

EVEN in this mechanized world many children take a very real and lively interest in horses, and though their personal experience may be largely confined to motoring, they get a vicarious thrill out of tales of fine horses and able horsemanship.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, June 13 -- Brazilians are debating whether Spanish merchantmen are mother ships for Axis submarines or are being forced to deliver fuel and provisions. Brazilian interest was increased after the arrival here of the Spanish steamer Aldeco last week to get fuel to replace that taken by a submarine.

E.B. WHITE lives on a farm on the Maine coast; he raises sheep and chickens, he has a wife and son; he writes. It sounds like a good life and, judging from "One Man's Meat," a collection of pieces which have been published in The New Yorker and in Harpers Magazine, it is.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., June 13 -- Wendell L. Willkie demanded here today that "all aspirants" for nomination on the Republican State ticket in the coming Fall election "forthrightly and directly, without evasion or confusion," publicly give their stand on all major issues, particularly that of isolationism.

Home movies can be made to pay dividends for the benefit of various patriotic organizations in a plan proposed by Official Films, Inc. Give a show for friends and neighbors, charge a nominal admission fee, and donate the proceeds to the USO, the Red Cross, the Army and Navy Relief Societies, or any similar body, is the gist of the plan.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Senators bunched their hits in two innings to defeat the White Sox, 4 to 3, tonight. The first Saturday night major league baseball game in the capital attracted 7,500 spectators.

THE normal child during the years from 8 to 11 is likely to have an insatiable appetite for fairy stories of one kind or another, and South American Indian folk-tales, with their unfamiliar setting, their sense of mighty mountains, impenetrable jungles and limitless pampas in the background, when chosen wisely and well presented, will pleasantly increase the available supply of legendary literature.

As a substitute for any form of wage freezing, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, favors a wartime wage policy under which organized workers would retain the right to bargain collectively for wage increases based on their employers' "ability to pay."

THE cautious cat-and-mouse game which Hollywood regularly plays with millions of moviegoers, coaxing them gently into the theatres with studied lures, has been considerably upset since Pearl Harbor and the entrance of this country into the war by the incertitude of the studios as to current public tastes.

DID you know -- we didn't -- that there were isolationists in the South during the Civil War? It seems that several groups of them actually seceded from the Confederacy and in some instances formed their own republics.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I. -- The French invaded this tiny island twelve miles off the New England shore in 1689, the British landed here during the Revolutionary War, German U-boats preyed in the neighborhood during the first World War, and they are now back again.

THE making of motion pictures in China today is a drama in itself. Raw film is arduously transported by camel or elephant over the tortuous passes of the ancient IndiaSinkiang caravan road -- a journey of several months.
LONDON, June 13 (U.P) -- Commenting that "the Nazi reign of terror in Czechoslovakia, shows no sign of abating," the British radio said today:

As more and more manufacturers of civilian goods abandon their production of such items for war work, surpluses of various materials are beginning to pile up and some items that were formerly scarce are now plentiful, purchasing agents reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Leslie (Bill) Fleming, Cubs' rookie righthander, missed a niche in the nohit hall of fame today by the margin of a pop fly that dropped in center field for a base hit. He pitched a one-hit, l-to-0 victory over the Braves to give the Cubs their fourth victory in a row.

IN 1643 the first Governor's wife in what was later to be Pennsylvania set up her housekeeping at Tinicum Island, in the Delaware. Her husband was Johan Bjornsson Printz, and he was sent by Queen Christina of Sweden to establish a colony in America.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I. -- Sailing, bathing, golfing and tennis, horseback riding, bicycling and gardening, these interests have continued to bring visitors to Westhampton Beach for over a half century. The proximity of this resort to New York together with the variety of wholesome activities to be found here are of extreme importance this year to those who cannot take long vacations because of the war.
BOSTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Red Sox won their sixth straight game today by pushing across a run in the ninth to beat the Tigers, 6 to 5, in the opener of a three-game series.

MOSCOW, June 13 (AP) -- Around the campfires of the Eastern Front Red Army troops today were informed of Russia's new alliance with Britain and of the mutual aid agreement with the United States, and pledged themselves to seal the pacts with new blows at the Germans.

RICHMOND, Va., June 13 -- A crude oil pipe line in which power is generated from the oil passing through the conduit to drive the pump which, in turn, forces the oil toward its destination is described in a patent (No. 2.284,809), awarded to Joseph G. Dyer and Archie C. Wilkinson of Ponea City, Okla., and assigned to the Continental Oil Company, of the same city.

This week is devoid of real activity in women's sports, only one important championship being at stake, but the following week finds the schedule top-heavy, with two district golf tournaments and one State tennis title up for contention. These will be held in Westchester, Long Island and New Jersey.

LITCHFIELD, Conn. -- Only a few miles from the busy industrial areas of Connecticut, and about 100 miles from Times Square, the Litchfield Hills of Connecticut call to the vacationist who seeks to spend his Summer in an unspoiled rural section, often compared to the Sussex countryside of England.

"THE MAN WHO KILLED THE DEER" is a short and outwardly a simple novel -- simple as the title itself is simple, in that it is stripped of ornamentation and reduced to its essential elements. Underneath it is no such matter.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 12 (Delayed) -- Four American Air Force Liberator bombers were forced down in Turkey his morning, three of the four-engined giants landing at the Ankara civil airdrome. The fourth was forced down at Arisiye airdrome, near Izmit, on the North-western Turkish coast, according to a communique issued by the official Anatolia news agency tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- If Dr. Gordon S. Seagrave, the Rangoon-born American Baptist missionary in Burma, had not been a fighting doctor at heart, he might very easily have decided to sit the war out in his own Harper Memorial Hospital at Namkhan.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- In a little more than six months the folding paper box industry has undergone a reversal from an excess of business to an excess of supplies and is now cooperating with the armed forces in a quest for a new sales outlet -- containers for dehydrated foods for shipment abroad.

Retail executives are watching consumer credit developments closely to determine if Canadian experience will be repeated here to the extent that the charge account trade will tend to stabilize at about the basis to be set between now and July 10.
Tommy Henrich saved the day for the Yankees before 11,193 of the faithful at the Stadium yesterday.

Of the many entertainments arranged for the late. Spring and early Summer to raise funds for welfare and relief agencies coordinating in the war effort, one that has received an encouragingly large advance subscription is the tea dance for the benefit of the United Service Organizations, which will be given June 24 at the Stork Club.

WATCH HILL, R.I. -- War restrictions, the rubber shortage and gasoline rationing have thrown a pall of uncertainty over the outlook for Rhode Island's Summer resorts. But there are some compensating factors, and by and large the hotel owners and the chambers of commerce in this section believe their business will suffer less this season than it will in some of the other sections that are more difficult to reach.

VICHY, France, June 13 -- Fierce Laval, Chief of Government, addressed a luncheon here today for a group of French newspaper men who will soon make a tour of German centers where French workers are employed. M. Laval's remarks were not made public.

IN 1942, remarks Margaret L. Macpherson, "the Americans discovered Australia. I beat them to it," she adds, "by nearly ten years." And she is now aiding that "discovery" for stay-at-home Americans through the delightfully personal agency of a most inviting book.

"THE UNVANQUISHED" concerns itself chiefly with the retreat of the Continental armies of the Thirteen Colonies through Manhattan and Westchester and with the Revolutionary generals and patriots who played a part, in it, but, above all, it gives us a fair, living and handsome portrait of George Washington, not as a statuesque Commander in Chief but as a fallible and noble human being.

Tear after year in the complacent period before the war spokesman after spokesman used to say that the United States possessed "the best naval air arm in the world." In the battles of the Coral Sea and Midway the Navy proved it.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Literally making Illinois Institute of Technology the electrical war-training headquarters of the Midwest, 1,140 men -- the largest such group in the nation -- are studying electronics, radio, fundamentals of electricity and micro-wave techniques in a special defense-training program.

KATONAH, N.Y., June 13 -- For the tenth time, Chafpion Flornell Rare Bit of Twin Ponds was named best in show today. The occasion was the annual all-breed dog show of the North Westchester Kennel Club on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt.

A new canvas of the far-flung Battle of the Pacific, painted by dramatic air-and-sea encounters over the past three months, unfolded last week. The details of the picture were supplied by reports from America's armed forces. They spanned 5,000 miles of the world's largest ocean, from the fog-shrouded rim of the Bering Sea to the tropic islands off Australia's shore.

OTTAWA -- There were no automobiles or roads or railways when Canada was first explored, and yet it was explored from east to west, from north to south, on foot, on horseback and by canoe. And that, it seems, is what we are coming back to -- for pleasure.

The words "after the war," or their equivalent, occur at least a dozen times in the British White Paper announcing the Anglo-Russian Treaty. The words are used once in the White House statement on the Russo-American mutual aid agreement, and are implicit in the agreement itself -- particularly in the reference in Article VII to "the betterment of world-wide economic relations."

An extensive garden apartment project by Sam Minskoff Sons, New York builders, called Suitland Manor is nearing completion in suburban Washington, on Suitland Road, Prince George's County, Md., for occupancy August 1.

Despite heavier taxes and the war bond sales campaign, the volme of money in circulation continues to mount rapidly and now has reached the unprecedented level of more than $12,000,000,000. The outlook is for this potentially langerous inflation factor to expand further rather than contract.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Asserting that the no-strike agreement in war production plants "cannot be flouted by a small group of selfish and willful workers," the War Labor Board today ordered 125 strikers at the Arkwright Corporation's textile mills in Fall River, Mass., to return Monday morning or lose their jobs.

Distress conveyances of Manhattan real estate during the first five months of this year, including completed foreclosures and surrenders of deeds in lieu of foreclosure, were greater in number but lower in dollar volume than during the same period of 1941, according to the monthly survey of the Real Estate Board of New York.

Governors of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms and of the New York Stock Exchange will meet in Philadelphia on Tuesday as a feature of the third out-oftown meeting of the former body on Monday and Tuesday. On Tuesday evening Ganson Purcell, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will be the main speaker at a dinner.

WE think we are being good parents when we do everything for a child, Mrs. Lili E. Peller of the Child Education Foundation said in a recent interview, but children want a chance to do things themselves. "The all-important feeling of security for little children comes mainly from being loved and accepted, but the feeling of being needed is almost as important."

TAHOE CITY, Calif. -- Restored to strictly civilian pleasure uses by governmental discovery that there is not enough level land around Lake Tahoe for its projected development as a great naval training station, this famous "highest big lake" or "biggest high lake" in the United States is prepared for a season on which war's impacts are expected to cancel themselves out.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Gleanings from the new State school statutes of 1942 reveal that progress toward modern tenure and retirement laws for teachers was continued. Notable are Kentucky's new tenure act, and Virginia's retirement system for teachers and State employes which supersedes an older pension plan.

THE Treasury Star Parade, whose fifteen-minute recorded shows have been among the better war programs, advises that it is facing a shortage of scripts -- this despite the generosity of sundry well-known authors who have contributed their services.

THIS page has not offered a previous round-up of art books since early last September. In more settled years the publishers were often so active in this field that in order to keep the accumulating mass of inpouring volumes manageable it seemed wise to take inventory twice a year.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Atlantic Charter has survived its first great crisis, and the totalitarian government of Soviet Russia has placed its trust in the democratic governments of the United States and Great Britain in so far as aid during the war and security afterward are concerned. These are the outstanding implications of the treaty just signed between London and Moscow and the coeval understandings between the governments of the United States and Russia.

A woman who expressed her contempt for Hitler by laughing at a caricature of the German dictator in the parade yesterday and carrying a sign that read "Stop Hitler" was hit and kicked by Patrick Gill, 46 years old, of 344 East Twentyfirst Street, a hotel runner, about 6:30 o'clock last night in the IRT subway station at Park Avenue and Thirty-third Street.

Almost every one with a plot of workable ground has planted a Victory garden this year, and housewives have stocked up with glass jars in order that they may provide their families with Winter stores of home-canned goods from vegetables grown in the garden.

STANTON, Del., June 13 -- Joseph M. Roebling's Lochinvar loped home five lengths ahead of the field today to take the $10,000 added Kent Handicap for 3-year-olds, Delaware Park's mile-and-a-sixteenth feature race.

IN the graduating class at New York University, a decade ago, the man who was voted most popular and best allaround student left college with an original ambition. He didn't want to make a million. He didn't want to be president of a company. He didn't want to go to Hollywood.

American bombers and fighter planes roared overhead in the clear blue skies. American tanks with funny names and ugly looking snouts and guns rumbled up Fifth Avenue. Hundreds of thousands of American men, women and children, sweltering in the heat and humidity, marched for hours -- soldiers, sailors, marines, industrial workers, air raid wardens and others, including just plain "little people" of the home front.

Almost every one with a plot of workable ground has planted a Victory garden this year, and housewives have stocked up with glass jars in order that they may provide their families with Winter stores of home-canned goods from vegetables grown in the garden.

IN the graduating class at New York University, a decade ago, the man who was voted most popular and best allaround student left college with an original ambition. He didn't want to make a million. He didn't want to be president of a company. He didn't want to go to Hollywood.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMESL: An article in THE NEW YORK TIMES recently reported the action of Phi Delta Kappa, national professional fraternity in education, in approving an amendment to eliminate from its constitution a clause restricting membership to white males.

If the ingredients of the salad bowl are going to be as hard to get during the coming year as the authorities seem to think, it will pay home gardeners to make careful plans to produce the maximum quantity in their own gardens. Greens, being mostly quick to reach the edible stage, are what gardeners know as short-season crops, and may therefore be worked into successional plantings.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMESL: An article in THE NEW YORK TIMES recently reported the action of Phi Delta Kappa, national professional fraternity in education, in approving an amendment to eliminate from its constitution a clause restricting membership to white males.

James W. Egan Jr., who has been in the newspaper advertising business many years, has been appointed advertising manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, it was announced yesterday by Harold Hall, business manager.

PROFESSOR ALFRED N. WHITEHEAD once remarked that science has brought about the most intimate change in human outlook that the human race has ever experienced. That change is concerned largely with man's place in the universe.

Ventnor City, popular chess center, is all primed for the fourth invitation masters' tournament scheduled to begin at 2 o'clock Saturday afternoon and extending until the afternoon of June 28. Nine daily rounds will be contested by the ten experts invited from New York, Philadelphia, Washington, Providence and Esmont, Va.
BERLIN, June 13 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The High Command said in its regular communique today:

Refugees who have come to this country since the Nazis rose to power in 1933 have not displaced American workers, but rather, through the exercise of their "transplanted skills," have been employing American citizens in new trades, according to a study, Refugees at Work, issued today by the Kings Crown Press of Columbia University.

NEWARK, N.J., June 14 (AP) -- The Newark Bears, ending a long home stand, divided a doubleheader with the Toronto Maple Leafs today, winning the opener, 9 to 5, and losing the seven-inning nightcap, 6 -- 5.

ST. LOUIS, June 14 (AP) -- The Cardinals nosed out the Phils, 6 to 5, in the nightcap of a double-header today after walking away with the first, 9 to 1. The net re- sult was a gain of one game on the league-leading Dodgers.

A world association of free people, to be founded by the United Nations in the post-war period, was visioned yesterday by Governor Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota, who declared that "the walls of isolationism and narrow separation" between nations were gone.

Atlante, Mexico's champion soccer team, here on a good-will tour sines May 20, brought its schedule of six games to a close yesterday at Starlight Park in the Bronx, playing a 1-1 tie with a combination team from the four local members of the American Soccer League.

Many students of the Bible feel that this war may end in a celestial invasion of the earth, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared in his sermon there yesterday.

CALCUTTA, India, June 14 -- When the American Volunteer Group pilots are incorporated into regular United States Army air units next July 4 each of them will have about $10,000 accumulated. That is the average nest egg saved by the Flying Tigers while they terrorized the Japanese during a year of fighting in the skies over Burma and China.

MOSCOW, June 14 -- United Nations Day was observed here with the flags of Russia's Allies flying alongside the Red Flag, while the significance of the occasion was stressed by the press. British documentary films were showing in fifteen Moscow cinemas, and there were exhibitions of British and American books in the Russian language.
ROME, June 14 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

ANNAPOLIS, June 14 -- The annual June Week at the Naval Academy opened today when King George II of Greece made an informal visit and sat with the members of the graduating class during their baccaulaureate sermon in the chapel.

The signing by King John on June 12, 1215, of Magna Charta, symbol of man's fight for liberty and freedom, was observed yesterday in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The participants in the ceremony included Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, Bishop William T. Manning and Sir Gerald Campbell, British Minister to the United States.

Emlyn Williams's sentimental and melodramatic play about wartime London, "The Morning Star," which has been running there for the last six months, will be introduced to Broadway by Guthrie McClintic early this Autumn. Mr. Williams will be recalled as the prolific playwright, author among others of "The Corn Is Green" and, more recently, "Yesterday's Magic."

If the Allies' mass air raids upon Germany are to have the desired effect, they must be extended far beyond the cities of the Ruhr and Western Germany to the central and eastern portion of the coun- try.
New Deal Democrats opposed to nominating Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for Governor turned yesterday to Senator James M. Mead as a candidate in the hope of blocking Mr. Bennett.

SYDNEY, Australia, June 14 (UP) -- The United States naval tanker Neosho survived three attacks by Japanese planes, one of which crashed in flames on her deck behind the funnel, during the Coral Sea battle, but the Neosho was wrecked so badly that a rescue warship had to sink her the next day.

WESTFORT, Conn., June 14 -- In the tenth annual all-breed exhibition of the Longshore Kennel Club at the Longshore Beach and Country Club today for the benefit of Dogs for Defense, Inc., the immaculate white standard poodle Champion Broadrun Cherry, owned by the Blakeen kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of Stamford. Conn., and handled by Mrs. Hoyt, was named best in show.

KITTRELL, N.C., June 14 (AP) -- A freight train rammed the Silver Meteor, fast New York-to-Florida train of the Seaboard Air Line, here early today, killing eight passengers. An hour and a half later the district superintendent of the railroad was mysteriously shot to death at Raleigh, thirty miles away

During the First World War thousands of German, shepherd dogs served with the armies of the Allies as well as with those of Imperial Germany and her partners. They were able to perform a variety of services, not merely as keen sentries, but as couriers, as wire carriers and as searchers for wounded, especially in forested terrain.

Apropos of the Presidential use of Shangri-La (when Mr. Roosevelt explained to inquirers the take-off point of the bombers that raided Tokyo), James Hilton, who created the imaginary locale in his "Lost Horizon," says that La means mountain in Tibetan dislect and Shangri just "popped into his head" in the course of writing the book.

Fifteen thousand sons and daughters of the Gael, representing the thirty-two counties of Ireland, thronged the campus of Fordham University yesterday to take part in the tenth annual Irish Feis. Delegations from Chicago, Detroit, St. Louis, Denver and near-by cities augmented the local turnout.

VICHY, June 13 -- Results of the government's recent big conversion and consolidation bond operation have been published by the National Sinking Fund. The report shows that 80 per cent of the securities called for conversion were exchanged for the new 4 per cent bonds.
On Being More Neighborly If the War Production Board says that we must become more friendly with our neighbors, as was reported in this newspaper the other day, good Americans will do so.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- I had long believed the aircraft carrier was superior to any other craft afloat as a naval weapon, but not until I had seen the two carriers in our task force in action in the developing stages of the epic Battle of the Coral Sea did I understand how deadly a modern aircraft carrier can be, and how much superior to any other type of vessel it has become.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Germany's threat to destroy any ship, belligerent or neutral, that attempts to enter any port on the east coast of the United States was being studied today in Washington in relation to its possible effect on the future foreign policy of Argentina and Chile.

Officials of Bellevue Hospital have relaxed their rules to permit Sally, a Seeing-Eye shepherd dog, to remain by the bedside of her blind master, Robert J. Loach, a 41-year-old business man who is a surgical patient, it was learned yesterday.

There is no reason why the scientific method should not be applied to religion, according to the Rev. Laurance I. Neale, pastor, in his sermon yesterday in the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Although it's a bit too early to estimate how many hunters will be back at their old haunts when the duck season is here again, nevertheless the United States Fish and Wildlife Service has assembled some essential data relative to any revisions which may be made concerning Federal regulations on hunting migratory birds.

LONDON, June 14 -- More British girls will soon be moving into the Royal Observer Corps to take over the duties of "spotting" for enemy planes from male members of the corps who are being called to more active duties in other branches of the fighting services.

Mrs. Eliot Lee Johnson, director of emergency telephone service for the American Women's Voluntary Services, has been appointed director of all Fire Department telephone volunteers in the five borough control centers, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Edgar Leonard, AWVS chairman for Greater New York.
NEW YORK Crown Princess Martha of Norway, accompanied by her lady-in-waiting, Countess Ragni Ostgaard, is at the Towers of the Waldorf- Astoria.

BERLIN, June 14 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- German forces have penetrated "deeper and deeper" into the dense fortified belt of Sevastopol, and "the modern, strong Fort of Stalin" has been captured in hand-to-hand combat, the German High Command announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Office of Price Administration warned motorists today that those who had used all the units on their gasoline rationing cards would not be able to get any gasoline for the next thirty days without showing need before a rationing board.
SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, June 12 (Delayed) -- Here are some details, hitherto unrevealed, of last month's Allied-Japanese naval action in the Southwest Pacific.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 14 (U.P) -- A German bomber had landed in Turkey and its crew been interned a short time before the internment of the crews of four United States heavy bombers that were forced down in this neutral country Friday while reportedly returning to Syrian bases from a destructive raid on Rumanian oil centers, it was learned tonight.
MOSCOW, Monday, June 15 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midnight communique:

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices dropped from 106.7 to 106.6. Prices fell off considerably in livestock and poultry, but were sufficiently offset by gains in oranges, grains and potatoes to raise the raw materials index by 0.1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Members of the Senate Military Committee expressed the opinion that most men having dependent wives and children could feel fairly certain of not being drafted for military duty this year.
LONDON, June 14 -- Prime Minister Churchill joined with President Roosevelt in honoring the forces of the United Nations today in the following message:

NEW DELHI, India, June 14 (AP) -- Six American airmen and a Royal Air Force sergeant, missing since June 7 when their heavy United States bomber was forced to land in the sea after being damaged in a raid on the Japaneseheld Burmese port of Akyab, sailed their rubber rafts up the Bay of Bengal to a tiny Indian village and returned to their base today in a rescue plane.

Two-thirds of all the physicians under 45 must join the armed forces. Already gaps yawn in our civilian medical defense, partly because many doctors have become officers, partly because little towns have skyrocketed in population. Bremerton, Wash., which once had 30,000 inhabitants, will soon have 40,000, to which another 30,000 in the surrounding area must be added for medical purposes.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 14 -- A detailed report depicting what he termed the "phenomenal growth" of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and of the union movement generally was presented today to the general executive board of the union by David Dubinsky, president, covering the ten years during which he has headed the organization.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 -- On the day when the gallant but starving and shattered American Army in the Philippines capitulated to the Japanese after its matchless "death watch" of five months, an American Colonel was sent to the enemy lines with a flag of truce.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 14 (AP) -- Lawson Little, 1934-35 grand slam amateur king and former national open champion, and his partner, Lloyd Mangrum, walked away with the eighth annual $7,650 Inverness four-ball golf matches today.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 14 -- Relatives of Thomas E. Carley Jr., aged 27, and Private John Service, 25, who were killed today in a train wreck at Kittrell, N.C., said they were friends traveling together by chance one bound on vacation, the other returning to an Army camp.

MOSCOW, Monday, June 15 (AP) -- Soviet forces in the south, pounded by two major German offensives, held firmly to their positions yesterday in continued bloody and indecisive fighting about Kharkov and Sevastopol, it was announced early today.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Prices of corn on the Board of Trade here followed last week the general, upturn in grains, but there was a sharp setback from the top. For the week the market was up 1/8 to 3/8 cent a bushel, with July at 86 1/8 to 86 1/4 cents, September at 88 3/4 to 88 7/8 and December at 91 1/4.

PITTSBURGH, June 14 -- The Giants had the eminent satisfaction of causing their ancient foe, Frankie Frisch, considerable an- guish today by winning the first game of a double-header, 4 to 3, to snap a Pirate winning streak that had been painstakingly built up to seven games in a row.

Beginning with a further advance, financial markets lost ground later in the week. Last Tuesday stock market averages had risen to the highest since March 5 -- an advance of 4 points this month and of 8 1/2 since April. This was the market's response to the full particulars published regarding the defeat of two Japanese fleets at Midway Island.

VICHY, France, June 14 -- Dis- cussions on the subject of collabo- ration are likely to dwell largely upon its political aspect but for practical purposes the realm in which the greatest progress is being made is economic. This has been developing regularly.

With the war giving thrift an especial importance, there is increasingly much to be said for the home treatment of hairdresses -- providing one's fingers possess that indispensable knack of making a wave swirl in the direction it is intended to go, and to stay where it is put.
TO THE EDITOR or THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a resident of New Jersey, I wish to compliment New Yorkers for the cooperation they have shown in dimming their lights at nightfall.
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- The largest galleries in golf history are expected to stream over the Ridgemoor course this week during the Hale America tournament.
CHICAGO, Jun 14 (AP) -- The Braves ended a twelve-game losing streak today when they defeated the Cubs, 10 to 1, after bowing 8 to 6.

"The values in our democracy all center on the word freedom, and the way to freedom can be secured by reasonable thinking," the Rev. Dr. Hughell E.W. Fosbroke, dean of the General Episcopal Theological Seminary, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Whole-hearted adoption by advertisers of voluntary standards for the advertising of consumer credit, consistent with Regulation W of the Federal Reserve System, will eliminate the need for the establishment of any regulations governing advertising by the government, according to the Better Business Bureau of New York.

ROCKLEIGH, N.J., June 14 -- This tiny hamlet, one of the slowest growing communities in the United States and proud of its size and rustic atmosphere, may be forced by the War Department to surrender to the march of progress by accepting an airplane parts factory.

NOW the Minute Men are riding -- or walking -- the highways and byways of New York, getting in the pledges of the citizens to buy war bonds. The sports field is being covered in the drive, which makes it fair game for comment in this corner.

One of the first steps in a plan to decentralize the headquarters of the Bureau of Old-Age and Survivors Insurance of the Society Security Board in Washington, D.C., was taken when the bureau leased large space here in the Commerce Building, 155 East Forty-fourth Street, for a regional office.
BERLIN, June 14 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Today's German High Command communique follows:

CAIRO, Egypt, June 14 -- Having thus far failed to equal the high tide mark reached on the second day of their offensive, the Germans yesterday appeared to be halted between Knightsbridge and Acroma. The united armored forces of the Axis and Allies remained locked in battle southwest of Tobruk and although the Germans are still attacking they are unable to gain further ground.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Wholesale prices in Great Britain rose 61 per cent from the outbreak of the war to February, 1942, and the cost of living1 increased 29 per cent, according to the publication titled "Economic Series No. 18 -- Effects of the War on British Marketing," released today by the Department of Commerce.
LONDON, June 14 -- The stock markets ended last week with a subdued tone following what promised to be another highly profitable period.

An influx of trade buying after heavy liquidation had been halted stabilized prices of cotton futures last week on the New York Cotton Exchange, and active contracts closed the week with net gains of 15 to 19 points, following net declines of 108 to 112 points in the preceding week and of 10 to 17 points in the week before that.

MEXICO CITY, Mexico, June 14 -- Bruce Vickers, a United States citizen representing the Russian Military Commission headed by Colonel Ilia Savaev, Russian mili- tary attache to the United States, said today that the Soviet Union was anxious to enter a commercial agreement with Mexico regarding products needed by both countries.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday, in his weekly radio talk, that he and Governor Lehman would attend a conference in Washington Friday morning in the office of Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the Federal Manpower Commission, in an effort to convince the heads of Federal agencies that more war contracts should be allocated to New York City industries so that unemployment due to priorities, price ceiling and rationing may be absorbed.

MOSCOW, June 14 -- In the five-day-old battle on the Kharkov front the Germans have failed to accomplish their first objective -- to force a break-through in a narrow sector and establish positions within the Russian lines from which the Russian flanks could be rolled back and the whole defensive front ripped apart.

VICHY, June 13 -- The advent of Pierre Laval as Chief of Government has resulted in appreciable changes in the economic policies of France. Mistakes committed by the Supply Administration were admitted openly and measures have been ordered to punish severely frauds or negligence in these services in the future.

Sale of war bonds through payroll deductions has now become the most important medium for encouraging employe thrift in American industry as a result of vigorous promotion campaigns by many companies with the United States Treasury, according to a study just completed by the Conference Board.

L. Metcalfe Walling, Federal Wage-Hour Administrator, warned employers yesterday that his office took a limited view of the applicability of the Supreme Court decision authorizing the A.H. Belo Corporation, publisher of The Dallas Morning News and operator of radio station WFAA, to make individual contracts with employes whose hours were irregular.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The White Sox won both ends of a double-header from the Senators today, 9 to 3 and 11 to 4. Ted Lyons chalked up the 249th victory of his career in the opener while Edgar Smith scored his first vic- tory of the season in the nightcap.
CHUNGKING, June 14 (AP) -- The text of the Chinese communique today follows:

LONDON, June 14 -- The complete agreement between Britain and the Soviet Union comes at a time when it can be coupled with the mounting strength of the United Nations in the Far East to spread a wave of confidence and hope around the world, Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal, said today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 14 (U.P.) -- If Germany makes effective her newly announced blockade against the United States and Canada, it will interrupt commerce between Argentina and those countries, Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu said today.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 14 (AP) -- Representative Hamilton Fish accused Wendell L. Willkie today of the "disservice" of impeding America's all-out war effort by "trying to resurrect" pre-Pearl Harbor interventionist and noninterventionist issues.
PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP) -- Luman Harris's three-hit pitching gave the Athletics an even break with the Indians today. The Tribe won the first game, 8 to 3, and dropped the second, 5 to 1.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday that he had submitted to the City Council a final estimate of $184,700,000 as the total revenues that would be available for the city's general fund -- which is exclusive of taxes -- for the 1942-43 fiscal year, which begins July 1.

Sir Gerald Campbell, British Minister in Washington, asserted yesterday before an audience gathered in Rockefeller Plaza to observe a United Nations Flag Day ceremony that the enemies of the Axis must cooperate with each other or die.

Wholesale activity improved slightly last week and a further gain is expected this week following the setting of ceilings on seasonal goods, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 14 -- Mary Beth Hughes has been as- signed to co-star with Don Ameche in Twentieth-Century Fox's "The Oxbow Incident," which will go be- fore the cameras June 29 with William Wellman directing. Other additions to the cast were Dana Andrews, Sara Allgood, Harry Davenport, Paul Hurst, Victor Killian and Matt Briggs.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- The course of prices of wheat was influenced frequently last week by the various, often conflicting, reports from Washington anent the farm appropriations bill. In general the market on the Board of Trade showed considerable price improvement for a time because of the temporarily oversold state of the pit.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 14 -- The third championship series regatta of the season was held on Long Island Sound today by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club with forty-two starters. Only eleven Internationals went to the line, and of these Arthur Knapp and Corny Shields turned back.

BIRMINGHAM, England, June 14 -- Throughout the Midlands, the heart of England's production area, voices were raised today in singing the "Battle Hymn of the Republic" as the people observed United Nations Day.

Senators Bankhead of Alabama and Russell of Georgia have introduced and the Senate Agriculture Committee has approved legislation calling for mandatory Federal crop loans at full "parity" levels on this year's crops. In view of the "low and constantly declining" prices of basic crops, says Senator Bankhead, a higher Government "floor" under farm prices is needed.

MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa, June 14 -- Calling for a "reasonable clarification of war aims as a part of the preparedness for peace," Alfred M. London said here today that the first approach to post-war problems should not be "through the fetid and unhealthy swamps of hate bred by blood lust.

PITTSBURGH, June 14 -- Steel ingot output in the country last week was unchanged from the week before at 98 per cent of rated capacity. Indications are that little or no change in the level of output will occur this week.

Scores of New York war factories, faced with a critical shortage of skilled workers, have been able to cut the breaking-in period for new employes by 40 to 75 per cent through the aid of the training-within-industry division of the War Manpower Commission, D.J. Hoose, State representative of the training program, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- A reform in the system of awarding honorary college and university degrees was recommended today by Dean Stephen Epler of the Southern Oregon College of Education, who asserted that in many cases such degrees were now granted in the hope of financial remuneration.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 14 -- How to meet ever-increasing demands for food with ever-decreasing sup- plies of vital materials is the prob- lem which confronts members of the Institute of Food Technologists as they gather here for their annual meeting to begin tomorrow.

The Paderewski Memorial Hospital in Edinburgh, Scotland, whose training school for physicians and surgeons is said to be the only Polish center of learning now existing, will be transplanted to Poland after the war, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, June 14 -- The reported bombing of Rumanian oil centers or German bases on the Black Sea by huge United States Army bombers caused military experts to suggest tonight that America's multi-front air power had been brought to bear against German preparations for a Caucasus-Middle East offensive.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Deflation, which follows inflation, is a nightmare to be avoided. Renouncing advantages from inflation, however attractive they may be temporarily, we should support aggressively by example and self-discipline the development and execution of an effective anti-inflation program.
ARMONK, N.Y., June 14 -- No longer are Sundays sleepy in this part of Westchester County. At the airport here military commands cut through the murky air early this morning.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Charles W. Eliot, director of the National Resources Planning Board, predicted tonight that it would be necessary, when peace comes, to continue many of the economic controls made necessary by the war so as "to prevent runaway prices and to assist in orderly demobilization of the war machine."

AN EASTERN PORT, June 14 (UP) -- Twenty-nine survivors of thirty-five crew members of a small United Nations cargo ship have reached safety after losing a gun duel with a submarine and drifting in lifeboats four days off the Atlantic Coast, the Third Naval District revealed tonight.
LONDON, June 14 -- Since I have returned from Moscow I have had so many people say to me, "Sssssh! You mustn't say a word against Russia -- people simply won't have it," that I am inclined to revolt.
When warm weather comes to the city, consider the food habits of a native of the tropics. His diet, largely one of fruits and vegetables, is suited to life in torrid temperatures.

NEW ORLEANS, June 14 -- Cotton showed a stout heart last week after an early sell-off that apparently was the continuation of "peace" rumor selling of the previous week, recovering losses of about $1.50 a bale made on Monday.

A service flag with two gold stars and 221 blue stars, denoting the number of members of the parish serving with the armed forces, was dedicated yesterday at the morning service at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

It has taken the United States just eight days to carry the war to Rumania. On June 5 Congress without even the formality of debate declared war on the Nazis puppet states of Bulgaria, Rumania and Hungary. On June 13 a fleet of American heavy bombers was ranging over Bulgaria and Rumania, unloading tons of bombs on the Ploesti oil fields, coastal refineries and enemy-held Black Sea ports in Russia.

The Yankees capitalized on un- earned runs yesterday at the Sta- dium as they won a double-header with the Browns before 21,861 fans. But the thrill of victory was dulled somewhat by the fact that budding hitting streaks were swept into the discard.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Following are the texts of the address by President Roosevelt and excerpts from the remarks of representatives of sixteen of the United Nations as they spoke to their own peoples, and to those of all their Allies as a part of Flag Day here:

As thousands of pledge solicitors "jumped the gun'' on the official schedule and began their rounds a day ahead, Mrs. Colin Kelly, Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, and Bill Robinson, the "Mayor of Harlem," broke the tape yesterday afternoon on New York City's campaign to sell $1,900,000,000 in war bonds before Wednesday of next week.

An entertainment potpourri with sports as its main ingredient amused a gathering of 12,648 spectators at the Polo Grounds yesterday for five and a half hours. The gathering contributed an undisclosed sum to Army and Navy relief and apparently enjoyed itself to the full.

CHUNGKING, China, June 14 -- The western units of the Japanese forces in Kiangsi have captured Nancheng, 100 miles southeast of Nanchang, it was acknowledged here today, but the Central News Agency said the Chinese had recaptured Tsungjen, roughly half way between Nanchang and Nancheng.

CINCINNATI, June 14 -- Playing National League baseball for the first time since last Sunday, the Dodgers found themselves a bit off stride today and could do no better than divide a double-header with the Reds, taking the opener, 4 -- 1, and losing the nightcap, 2 -- 1.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 14 -- "If the war purges our souls through suffering and work for a common cause, as it undoubtedly will, success in the years of peaceful reconstruction to follow will come to those who worry less about prosperity and more about the satisfactions of self-expression, not for one's self but for others," Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, said today in his baccalaureate sermon in the university chapel.

The American bombers reported forced down in Turkey were returning, the pilots said, from a mission in the Black Sea. That's about all we know about them. The Turks believe they carried out a raid on the Ploesti oil fields in Rumania. Some reports mention the German occupied cities of Odessa and Nikolaev as the targets of attack, others describe the expedition as a reconnaissance flight only.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As an engineer who has made traffic studies for transportation interests and one of New York City trucking for a commercial body, perhaps you will allow me to comment on your editorial of June 8 which discusses a Brookings Institution report on the conservation of rubber tires in motor transport.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 14 -- A keen battle for the hunter championship, resulting in victory for Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Hale's thoroughbred brown gelding Heman, featured the nineteenth annual Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show today.

ASHLAND, Ky., June 14 -- On the second Sunday in June a number of people from the Kentucky mountains come every year to the singing gathering at the Traipsin' Woman Cabin, eighteen miles south of Ashland.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- While representatives of twenty-six nations stood before their national flag's forming a huge "V for Victory" in the White House, President Roosevelt appealed today to the people of Germany, Japan and the conquered nations of Europe and Asia to revolt against their Axis masters for "freedom of speech and religion, freedom from want and from fear."

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- A five-year study of the Civilian Conservation Corps prepared by the American Youth Commission of the American Council on Education asserts that "whatever may be the future of the CCC, its past will be long remembered in America."

A minimum capital requirement for admission to, and maintenance of, membership in the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., has been proposed by the board of governors of the association and submitted to the membership for approval, it was disclosed in a letter sent today to all members by Wallace H. Fulton, executive director.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Following are the texts of communications from Mexico and the Philippines to Secretary Hull, stating their adherence to the Atlantic Charter, and Secretary Hull's replies, all being preliminary to the Flag Day ceremonies today:
CAIRO, Egypt, June 14 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:

Congress has shown good judgment in increasing the appropriation for lighter-than-air craft, in view of the excellent work that blimps have done in anti-submarine patrol. The special characteristics of the airship, and particularly its ability to move slowly, to hover, and even to anchor at sea, make it an effective weapon against raiders on coastal shipping.

LONDON, June 14 -- Marking the greatest patriotic turnout this country has seen since the war began, the British people, led by their King and Queen, observed United Nations Day today by attending church services at which they prayed for victory in freedom's cause and by holding military parades in flag-draped cities, towns and hamlets throughout the land.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Donald M. Nelson said today that America was "over the hump" in war production, but he warned that "as for the inconveniences, discomforts and hardships that you and I will have to endure -- why, we haven't even got to the foothills yet."

WARDHA, India, June 15 (AP) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi declared today that he soon would launch a movement against British rule in India that "will be felt by the whole world." He made the state- ment in an interview in this Southern India town near which he lives.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- "Chatterbugging" is the Australian term, "gossiping" is the old English word for it and "loose talk" is the phrase with which President Roosevelt has condemned it, but, whatever the name may be, the business of expanding and repeating a war story which has no provable grounding in fact must be stopped.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 15 -- Frank Strazza, the Round Hill professional, and Jack Shaw, young amateur from the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club, took top honors in the Westchester County Golf Association's pro-amateur best-ball competition a Sleepy Hollow today.

"The Cat Screams," a mystery melodrama set in a Mexican locale, opens tonight at the Martin Beck. This marks the debut as a producer of Martha Hodge, daughter of the late William Hodge and Helen Hale, and herself well known as an actress.

The combination of twilight and night baseball, making its debut at Ebbets Field last evening, was a reasonable financial success, with 15,159 Flatbush fans paying to see the oddity. The total attendance at the game was 16,549. The contest started at 7 P.M.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Distribution of gauges, precision measuring tools, testing instruments and chucks was brought under strict control today with the issuance of General Preference Order No. 5.

BOSTON, June 15 -- The first horsemen's strike in the 10-year-old history of New England parimutuel racing -- a strike over demands for increases in all purses -- today resulted in the cancellation of tomorrow's eight-race program at Suffolk Downs.

Freed by the amendments to Maximum Price Order No. 153 from the uncertainties which delayed pricing of their seasonal garments by two to three weeks as compared with last year, many manufacturers of coats, suits, dresses and sports wear began showing their Fall lines yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- War construction is proceeding at a rate of about $12,500,000,000 a year and by the end of the year should be $13,500,000,000, the War Produc- tion Board said today. This would be 20 per cent greater than the previous record of 1941.
