CAIRO, Egypt, June 15 -- The battle between German and British armored forces in Libya continued yesterday between Knightsbridge and Acroma with an intensity considered almost incredible in view of the duration of the action, British reports indicated today.

Following a study of substitutes for materials that are or may become critical, the scientific advisory committee of the Toilet Goods Association, Inc., yesterday recommended to members a list of substitutes for menthol, quince seed, spermaceti, thymol and tragacanth.

Completing a double which he had started in the fourth aboard the Greentree Stable's Tierce, Eddie Arcaro came through with a stretch run to get home first on the Barrington Stable's Scotland Light in the Bohemian Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Conviction of the American Medical Association and the Medical Society of the District of Columbia by the Federal District Court last year on charges of conspiracy to violate the Sherman anti-trust law, was upheld by the Court of Appeals of the District of Columbia today.

The odor of frying fish and lemon permeated the grand ballroom of the Hotel New Yorker yesterday as five boys, winners of district championships, matched their skill, under the watchful eyes of three judges, for the grand prize as the best fish fryer among New York City's Boy Scouts.

A week of festivities combined with a nation-wide drive for $6,000,000 for medical aid to civilians and soldiers of Russia will be held from Saturday through June 27 under the auspices of the Russian War Relief organization to mark the anniversary of the German invasion of the Soviet Union.

Every plant in the city capable of manufacturing gun parts and other equipment used by the ordnance branch of the Army will receive war orders soon, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday after a conference in City Hall with Maj. Gen. Levin B. Campbell Jr., Chief of the Ordnance Department, and Brig. Gen. Walter P. Boatwright.

LONDON, June 15 (U.P.) -- Unconfirmed reports from the Continent tonight said that Switzerland was preparing for full mobilization, partially in expectation of internal trouble in Germany; that Italian soldiers were not being paid and were underfed, and that traffic on the underground railway by which refugees and deserters from the German military forces escaped into Switzerland had increased so that Switzerland was enlarging her border guard.

Representative Michael J. Kennedy, declaring that he would devote his "full time" to being leader of Tammany Hall and would not seek renomination to his Congressional seat this Fall, announced last night that all but one of the serious primary fights within the local Democratic organization that had threatened his leadership had been called off.

LENOX, Mass., June 15 (AP) -- Serge Koussevitzky, Boston sym- phony conductor, received word today that the rights had been granted him for the first concert performance in the Western Hemisphere of Dimitri Shostakovich's Seventh symphony.

With all classifications showing declines, newspaper linage for May in fifty-two cities measured by Media Records registered a drop of 12.6 per cent from the corresponding month of last year. The decline brought the loss for the year to date to 8.3 per cent.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The text of President Roosevelt's letter to Congress accompanying the fifth report on lend-lease operations was as follows:

DUBLIN, June 15 -- Dublin has seen many strange parades through its streets, but the one staged to- day, when hundreds of the city's drapery employes demonstrated against Eire's recent clothes rationing order, was unique. Every drapery store, tailoring establish- ment, shoe shop and even the Woolworth multiple stores had to shut down for the day as part of the State-wide organized protest against the government's edict.

The United Service Organizations for National Defense, Inc., spent $1,765,328 in May to provide off-duty social and recreational services for men in the armed forces, according to a report yesterday by Chester I. Barnard, president of USO, to its board of directors.
ROME, June 15 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

Freedom Bell, 800-pound bronze sister of Liberty Bell, clangorously called New York's millions to the war bond pledge campaign at 5 o'clock yesterday evening in front of the Capitol Theatre in Broadway, but hours before eager Minute Men and Minute Women had started their door-todoor rounds and were garnering pledges running from a child's promise of 10 cents weekly to a rich man's pledge of $100,000 in one year.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 -- Immediate importation of thousands of Mexican farm workers to help California agriculture avert a "disastrous" situation was urged today by Governor Olson in telegrams to Paul V. McNutt, director of the War Manpower Commission, and Secretaries Perkins, Hull and Wickard.

The Bronx had its own one-horse rodeo last night with a cast that included ten radio patrol cars, at least forty policemen and as many more civilians. All were engaged at one time or another in a fifteen-mile chase after a runaway saddle horse that refused to be captured until his legs were about to give way.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 15 -- Americans must work, not with financial gain as their objective but with life itself and the freedom of this country and of the world for centuries to come as their goals, Colonel Paul P. Logan, assistant chief of the subsistence division, office of the Quartermaster General, said today.
The instruments of air warfare that Britain has so far used against Germany are largely British-designed and manufactured; the American "lightning" has yet to strike the Reich.

On Sunday at Atlantic City President David Dubinsky of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union turned in a progress report which covered the ten years from the depth of the depression to the height of a world war. Mr. Dubinsky took over a labor organization which his predecessor, the late Benjamin Schlesinger, had worked long and valiantly to build up.

Department Store Sales Off 16% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed a decrease of 16 per cent under the corresponding week last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 15 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

Secretary of Labor Frances Parkins, declaring that the nation's war production was "away ahead of schedule," asserted here yesterday that experience to date had shown that a forty-eight-hour week for industrial workers and a 160-hour week for production plants had become the "optimum" -- best working average -- for labor and management for the duration of the war.

Taking issue with published versions of an extemporaneous speech he made ten days ago at a luncheon of the Women's Republican Club of Putnam County in Mahopac, N.Y., Thomas E. Dewey, leading Republican candidate for Governor, put himself on record last night as opposing the renomination of Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., because of his views as well as because of his associates in office.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 15 -- Colonel John M. McDowell, commandant of the Princeton Field Artillery unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps, presented ninety-nine members of the university's graduating class to Dr. Harold W. Dodds, Princeton president, for commissions as second lieutenants in the Army, in the feature event of Class Day exercises on Cannon Green here this morning.

Entertainment for Russian soldiers falls far below that provided by the USO for American men in service, Cyrus L. Sulzberger, NEW YORK TIMES foreign correspondent who recently returned to this country, said yesterday. He spoke at the dedication of a sky terrace at 1 East Sixty-fifth Street, where a USO clubhouse is maintained by the Jewish Welfare Board under the chairmanship of his mother, Mrs. Ely Jacques Kahn.

Harry Waltzer, 42-year-old business agent of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, an independent organization, and William Walsh, 42, a delegate of the union, were arrested on charges of attempted extortion last night after detectives said they accepted $5,000 to "settle" a threatened "strike" against Racing Publications, Inc., of 350 West Thirty-fourth Street.

J. Donald Budge, former world champion; Robert L. Riggs, winner of the national amateur crown last year; Frank Kovacs, whom Riggs met in the final, and Wayne Sabin were among the thirty-two players drawn yesterday for the sixteenth annual national professional tennis championship.

The Norfolk Naval Training Station will be represented by a sixteen-man squad in the fifty-fifth annual National A.A.U. track and field championships, which will be staged at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island Friday and Saturday for the benefit of the Army Emergency Relief.

LONDON, June 15 -- The mar- kets began the week in a subdued vein with gilt-edge issues, foreign bonds and home railways showing little change. In the industrial section the stores declined. Imperial and British-American Tobacco each lost 7 1/2d.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, N.Y., June 15 -- Chris Weber and Gus Norwich, North Hills assistant pro, produced a 63, the lowest score of the season, in leading a strong array in the weekly Long Island P.G.A. amateur-pro best-ball competition today on the 6,455-yard Rockville Country Club course.
NEW HAVEN, June 15 -- The problem of transportation, acute throughout the country, was taken up today by more than 100 delegates to the fifth National Institue for Traffic Training at Yale.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Some form of balance in the retail inventory picture will have to be achieved soon to insure an equitable distribution of remaining consumer goods among all retail stores and civilians, Joseph L. Weiner, deputy director of the division of civilian supply of the War Production Board, informed those attending the mid-year convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association here today.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons, who holds the rank temporarily as commander of the Hawaiian Department, won extraordinary promotion on the permanent list today when President Roosevelt recommended that he be jumped from colonel to major general.

Answers to a series of questions on the recent amendment to the War Production Board General Imports Order M-63, submitted to the board by importers, was released yesterday by the Priorities Section of the Regional Office here. The questions had been compiled and presented through the Commerce and Industry Association.

Outside on the city pavement the midmorning sunshine is hot and almost blindingly bright. But within the square shop, behind the broad-paned window with its pale green awning, there is coolness and shadow. It is 10:30 and still too early for the bustle of business.

LONDON, June 15 -- The death at sea of Captain Arthur Tillotson Brown, who had command of the old Mauretania when she left Rosyth, Scotland, to be broken up and who was skipper of the new Mauretania on her maiden voyage to the United States in 1939, was announced today.

One of the largest deals in Har- lem in some time was announced yesterday by Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., broker, who reported the sale for cash by the New York Telephone Company of the entire blockfront on the west side of Lenox Avenue, between 122d and 123d Streets, together with 103 West 122d Street.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Duke of Windsor, Governor of the Bahamas, took luncheon with President, Roosevelt today and talked with him for three hours about "the world in general" and, in particular, about adjusting wages of Bahaman natives whose dissatisfaction over their low pay on an American project led recently to rioting in which there were fatalities.

Formation of a national association in the dress industry which would separate the problems of labor from those of management and confine its activities to the latter, particularly those created by wartime regulations, was approved at a meeting held last night at the Hotel Astor.

The current rate of dividend is not in jeopardy unless something unforeseen develops or the government takes action that frustrates or eliminates the company's present plans wholly or in part, J.P. Bickell, president of McIntyre Porcupine Mines, Ltd., said yesterday at the annual stockholders' meeting held in Toronto.

MELBOURNE, June 15 -- Twenty-seven Japanese bombers supported by fighters made an extensive raid on Darwin shortly after noon today. The Japanese dropped their bombs more carefully than usual and some residential buildings, most of which were empty, were damaged.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today an application by the National Power and Light Company for permission to engage the services of three investment banking companies to facilitate an exchange of stock to terminate the status of the Houston Power and Light Company as a subsidiary to National Power and Light.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Japanese forces that attempted a surprise raid on the fog-bound and shoal-surrounded Aleutian Islands have paid thus far the penalty of damage to "at least" three cruisers, a destroyer, a gunboat and a transport, the Navy Department announced tonight.
The two-week drive to collect all the scrap rubber lurking in discarded footwear, underwear, waterproofing, toys, inner tubes et al, began in the city yesterday -- but slowly.

The editorial board of the Book-of-the-Month Club decided yesterday on a dual selection for September composed of Gertrude Diamant's book about Mexico, "The Days of Ofelia" (Houghton Mifflin) and "The Raft," by Robert Trumbull (Holt).

ROME, June 15 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES in New York) -- The present air-sea battle in the Mediterranean began after an Italian patrol plane had spotted a British naval squadron consisting of one battleship, the aircraft carriers Argus and Eagle, some cruisers and twenty destroyers off Algeria on Saturday, it was reported tonight by Stefani, Italian official news agency.
NEW YORK Mrs. Donald Carr has arrived from her home in Ventnor, N.J., and is at the Colony Club.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Is there still among Americans one who is dissolute? Are there still Americans who dream of appeasement? Are there still among us those who would make peace with nazism or fascism? If there be such, let them read your editorial in this morning's paper, titled "Lidice the Immortal."

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Fine shades of sentiment can be expressed in inexpensive fixed-text cable and radio messages which may now be exchanged between United States troops serving overseas and the people at home.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Senate speedily approved today legislation to aid the families of service men through a system of pay allotments and government grants.

Mayor La Guardia, styling himself a "son of the steerage," declared yesterday afternoon before 2,000 persons in City Hall Park that the world could not hold both a Nazi form of government and an American democracy.

Mlle. Eve Curie, who recently completed a 40,828-mile trip through the battlefields of Africa, Europe and Asia, told more than 4,000 persons in the Manhattan Center last night that this was not merely a war of defense against aggression, but a war of liberation for those living under the yoke of aggression and those "half-free" under Allied rule.

The new plan whereby selectees reporting for induction into the Army may have fourteen days to adjust personal affairs immediately after passing their physical examinations became effective yesterday, but Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, draft director here, announced last night that 20 per cent of the men called by the city's local boards expressed a desire to begin their military service at once.

ALBANY, June 15 (AP) -- Immediate action by the Republican-sponsored commission to investigate State financing and recommend economies was indicated today with appointment of nine members by Republican legislative leaders.

They Inform Him One man at the present moment is in receipt of more information than any ten other American citizens. It is not hard to guess who. It is Elmer Davis, the new director of the new Office of War Information.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The country-wide drive for scrap rubber got off to a flying start, according to William R. Boyd, chairman of the Petroleum Industry War Council, who predicted today that it would be "an outstanding success."

ATLANTIC CITY, June 15 -- Sharp criticism of the refusal of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to accept the recent proposal of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor for resumption of peace negotiations was voiced here today by Daniel J. Tobin, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, largest single labor union in the country, with a membeship that is said to total 650,000.

The National City Bank will observe today its 130th birthday and also the active participation of the bank in financing six major wars of the United States. The bank began business on June 16, 1812, two days before the beginning of the War of 1812 and one week before Napoleon invaded Russia.

What the nature of the United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament will be this year is still a matter of conjecture, but the majority of club representatives attending the meeting yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker voiced their approval of attempting" to hold one.
TRENTON, N.J., June 15 -- The Republican-controlled Senate failed today to take advantage of an opportunity to help Governor Charles Edison in his fight against Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City.

The sinking of three more ships -- two United States vessels, one small and one medium-sized, and a large Panamanian merchant ship -- was announced yesterday by the Navy, while a dispatch to The United Press from New Orleans reported that a fourth ship, the 2,158-ton freighter Miraflores, has been overdue for four months and is presumed lost.

Government leases continue to help building owners in the downtown district of Manhattan to fill up vacant space. The latest lease reported is one to the United States Army Air Force, which has taken an entire floor in the building at 225 Broadway for immediate occu- pancy, through Schlang Brothers Co.

When Army bombers raided Tokyo two months ago they dropped, attached to a 500-pound bomb, two Japanese medals given to American sailors by the Emperor of Japan when the United States battle fleet visited Yokohama in 1908 on its trip around the world.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The condition statement of weekly re- porting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 10: Increases of $611,000,000 in holdings of Treasury notes and $107,000,000 in Treasury bills and a decrease of $610,000,000 in holdings of obligations guaranteed by the United States Government; a decrease of $477,000,000 in United States Government deposits and an increase of $539,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Charges that the Office of Price Administration is holding returns on agricultural commodities below those permitted by law are under study by a special Senate committee appointed to investigate reports that a "program" is afoot to depress farm prices, Senator Thomas, of Oklahoma, its chairman, said today.

CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) -- Hogs gained 10 to 15 cents a hundred pounds today, touching a high of $14.35, as salable receipts at 13,000 head were considered com- paratively small for a Monday. The gov- ernment discontinued reporting the number of hogs held over.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Donald Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, declared here tonight that cooperation by labor and management in the WPB's drive to speed up the national output of materiel had resulted in deliveries of weapons and war implements as much as fourteen months ahead of schedule.

LONDON, June 15 -- Italy claimed today that a great sea and air action that already had cost the British seven ships sunk and nine damaged, including damage to a battleship and an aircraft carrier, was raging in the Central Mediterranean. Despite official silence here, there was speculation that some great United Nations fleet movement might be underway.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma declared tonight that an organized bear raid upon cotton prices had caused a decline of $10 a bale and a loss or $100,000,000 on the 10,000,000 bales in storage.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 15 -- Thirteen Princeton athletes were rewarded with trophies in various sports today as part of the exercises of the graduating class. Heading the list was Robert H. Baldwin, '42, of East Orange, N.J., who received the William W. Roper Trophy for general proficiency in athletics.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 -- Fines aggregating $122,075 were imposed in Federal District Court today by Judge Guy K. Bard upon the American Waxed Paper Association, thirty-four member companies and seventy of their executives when they entered pleas of nolo contendere to a charge that they had engaged in a conspiracy to fix prices for waxed paper.

The Special Sessions trial of the Body and Mind Foundation, Inc., and two of its attaches, Rudolph Rebold, a chemist, and Mrs. Eveline Dolin Schulman, neared a close yesterday with defense testimony by Rebold and the refusal of Mrs. Schulman to testify, after which her lawyer rested her case.
ALBANY, June 15 -- New York started today a "Junior Commando" course designed to harden high school boys by means of obstacle races.

The apartment house for forty families at 155 Union Avenue, Rutherford, N.J., was purchased by an investing client of Paul Weisbart, Inc., broker. This structure is on the entire blockfront on Union Avenue from Irving Place to Wood Street.

Despite a large increase in taxes, the Charles F. Noyes Company, in reports received at the annual meeting of stockholders and directors of the firm yesterday, showed a rise in gross business and in income.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was the guest of honor yesterday afternoon at the joint meeting of the National Council of Women and the Women's Society for a Free and Democratic Europe, in the Amsterdam Room of Holland House.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 15 (AP) -- Short on numerical strength, but heavy in power, the Pacific Coast Conference's track stars are expected to score by a solid margin over the Big Ten's best in tomorrow's sixth annual dual meet between the two college leagues, in Northwestern University's Dyche Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Ways and Means Committee received from the Treasury today a proposal for a "supertax" to put into effect President Roosevelt's suggestions of April 27 that "no American citizen ought to have a net income after he had paid his taxes of more than $25,000 a year."

BALTIMORE, June 15 (AP) -- United States torpedo planes sank a Japanese cruiser and scored a direct hit on an aircraft carrier of the main Japanese task force off the Aleutian Islands, a telegram from Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, Chief of the Army Air Forces, to Glenn L. Martin, aircraft manufacturer, disclosed today.

A cheering crowd of 2,000 persons in Wall Street, standing in front of the Subtreasury Building at noon yesterday, heard political and business leaders plead for continued support of the United Service Organizations. The speakers emphasized the sacrifices being made on all fronts and the contribution by the USO toward maintaining morale.

There is no name in American history more cherished than Lexington. It was near by that the shot heard round the world was fired Twenty-four American counties, cities and towns carried the name of the little Massachusetts village westward. American ships carried it into every ocean.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "Man does not live by bread alone," nor is a war won by bullets alone. Your editorial in the June 12 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES, which so effectively describes "Lidice the Immortal," inspired me to make a suggestion which, if carried out, would truly establish Lidice as an immortal village throughout history.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15 -- Irving Berlin's forthcoming Broadway show, "This Is the Army," will be brought to the screen by Paramount if current negotiations among the studio, Berlin and the War Department are completed. It is understood that a deal whereby Paramount will produce the film at cost, distribute it on a percentage basis, and turn the remaining proceeds over to Army relief, tentatively has been arranged.

Twenty - two teachers were dropped from the staffs of the four city colleges as a means of meeting the cut in the budgets of the institutions, it became known last night at a meeting of the Board of Higher Education at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue.

ROCHESTER, June 15 (AP) -- Newark's league-leading Bears opened a four-game series with the Red Wings tonight by spoiling the debut of Rochester's new manager, Ray Hayworth. The Bears won, 5 to 4, scoring the deciding run in the ninth when Pitcher Tom Byrne doubled over third to send Boyd Perry home.

The fifth quarterly report on leaselend operations provides new and heartening proof that the flow of war materials from the Arsenal of Democracy to the Fighting Fronts of Democracy is at length moving in powerful force. The total of lease-lend aid since the start of the program in March, 1941, now amounts to $4,497,000,000, of which $1,927,000,000, or better than 40 per cent, was supplied in the three months ended May 31, last.

Warm Winter suits for some 5,000,000 migrant workers in the United States will be the objective of a nation-wide pilgrimage to 25,000 automobile graveyards soon to be undertaken by Bundles For America, Mrs. Wales Latham, national president of the organization, announced yesterday.

DETROIT, June 15 -- Walter Hagen, whose golfing exploits of the last fifteen years are pretty much wrapped up in the American Ryder Cup team, announced tonight that eleven golfers had been invited to play on a team that will meet the cup squad here July 18 and 19 in matches for the Red Cross.

LONDON, June 15 -- President Roosevelt's report noting that lease-lend was working in two ways now, today served to call attention to a new trend in the relations developing between the United States and Britain so far as war supplies are concerned.

TORONTO, June 15 (Canadian Press) -- Jersey City teed off on five pitchers for thirteen hits tonight to trim Toronto, 9 -- 5. The defeat ended a thirteen-game winning streak at home for the Maple Leafs.

Dr. George W. Carver of Tuskegee Institute has been selected by The Progressive Farmer as its "man of the year in service to Southern agriculture." This is an annual honor given by that journal "for outstanding contributions to agricultural progress." Dr. Carver has been at Tuskegee for forty-six years.

The technical position of the stock market was helped slightly yesterday by late strength in the air transportation issues and concentrated buying in the gold group. Elsewhere, there was only scattered semblance of power, and the list as a whole drifted narrowly with the close irregularly higher.

The British radio reports that on Sunday, United Nations Day, Prime Minister Churchill stood in a crowd with no policeman "within dozens of yards." There was some risk in this. Just as occupied Europe has many sane people who would like nothing better than a shot at Hitler, Himmler, Goebbels or Goering, so a free country may have a few insane people who will commit senseless acts of violence.

Tax Day Money Turnover Although yesterday was quarterly payment day for Federal taxes and also for New York State income taxes, ripples in the money market were hardly noticeable. Most of the larger tax checks will be put through for collection today and it may take about ten days to complete the entire job.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 15 -- Dr. Hu Shih was the commencement orator at Wellesley today and in the course of the ceremonies an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws was conferred on Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, Wellesley '17. The citation, read by President McAfee, was as follows:
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A system of awards, certificates and citations for American workers who devise means for more and better war production was announced today by the War Production Board.

LONDON, June 15 -- With British production reaching the limits of manpower available, Jack Tanner, president of the Amalgamated Engineering Union, summarized at Blackpool today an extraordinary study of factors retarding maximum production.

Plans have been completed for the three-day Federation Fete, the Spring festival sponsored annually by the Women's Division of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities, which will open tomorrow at the Inwood Country Club on Long Island.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (U.P.) -- The Navy gave out a story today of a Pearl Harbor hero who had a Japanese machine-gun bullet in his heart for two months before it was discovered and successfully removed.
BERLIN, June 15 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The text of today's German communique follows:

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- By unanimous consent the Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill to create a new grade -- flight officer -- in the Army Air Forces. The post will carry the rank, pay and allowances of a warrant officer, junior grade.

Democratic leaders of the three counties composing the Congressional district now represented by Hamilton Fish Jr. tentatively agreed yesterday at a meeting in the Biltmore Hotel to back Ferdinand A. Hoyt, former Beacon City judge, as Mr. Fish's opponent.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, June 16 -- Russian defenders destroyed or damaged 180 German tanks and repelled several enemy assaults in a continuing battle on the Kharkov front yesterday, the Russians reported today, while Sevastopol's stalwart defense stiffened appreciably with the help of the guns of the Black Sea Fleet.

TRENTON, N.J., June 15 -- Appointed three months ago by Governor Charles Edison to serve as Hudson County Register until the November election, James F. Murray, a political foe of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, reported to the Governor today that since taking office he had been subjected to "Hague-inspired personal abuse and attempted sabotage" and that he had found the department overloaded with "payroll drones."

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Federal Employment Service, for the first time during the war, is seeking to fill places of strikers as a result of the unauthorized walkout of 125 loom fixers and changers in the mill of the Arkwright Corporation, Fall River, a week ago today.

The movement to prevent Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. from getting the Democratic nomination for Governor received a setback yesterday when the Erie County Democratic Executive Committee adopted a resolution pledging him its support in the event that Senator James M. Mead continued his refusal to become a candidate.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 15 -- Political circles in Rome were inclined tonight to attach more than passing importance to the "unofficial" visit by Ramon Serrano Suner, the Spanish Foreign Minister, to Count Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, "for purposes of informal discussions."

The large loan exhibition entitled "Happier Days in the United Nations" will open officially today with a reception from 3 to 5 P.M. at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street. It is being held as a benefit for the American Red Cross.

BERLIN, June 15 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- German military spokesmen said today that the battle east of Kharkov had ended, with the objective of the German offensive achieved. The operations were described as "a major German offensive action carried out to remove the northern pincer of Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's forces, which had remained in the battle area of Kharkov."

Good news that American planes are hammering Japanese ships off the Aleutians comes from the Pacific. In these continuing air attacks on the enemy forces that risked a landing on the western islands the most noteworthy fact is the close and highly successful collaboration of the Army and the Navy.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The dollar has friends everywhere. Just now the dollar has more friends abroad than ever before, and there is reason to suspect that some influential coin-collectors among the Axis personages -- hedging against a growing certainty of the success of the United Nations in the war -- are among them.

Arthur W. Wallander, Deputy Chief Police Inspector, was sworn in by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday as chief of staff of the city's defense forces and was empowered to issue directives for the Mayor.

CHUNGKING, China, June 15 (AP) -- Two powerful Japanese columns, applying a nutcracker squeeze on the ill-equipped Chinese troops in Chekiang and Kiangsi Provinces, had driven tonight within 75 or 100 miles of a junction on the vital Nanchang-Hangchow Railway.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Not only is the lease-lend program serving as a major factor in the war but it is emerging as a major influence "in the combined effort of the United Nations to weave a pattern of peace," President Roosevelt told Congress today in his fifth report on lease-lend operations.

The seven justices of the Appellate Division, First Department, and nearly 100-present and former attaches of the court and friends took part yesterday in a ceremony honoring fifty years of court service by Benjamin H. Doane, confidential clerk of the Appellate Division, who was described by Presiding Justice Francis Martin as responsible "more than any other man" for the success of the court since its establishment in 1896.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP) -- General Motors Corporation paid Charles E. Wilson $149,803 as president and director in 1941, and added as a bonus 4,500 shares of common stock to be paid in four equal annual installments, addi- tional reports filed with the Se- curities and Exchange Commission showed today.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- King George II of Greece addressed the Senate and House today, visited Princess Martha of Norway and took time out from a busy schedule to receive Steve Vasilakos, Greek peanut vendor at the White House.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Aluminum, the war production program's oldest bottleneck, was "corporation - created" with the Aluminum Company of America in control and with government officials in key posts serving either as "innocent dupes" or conscious aides of "a perfect monopoly," Senator La Follette of Wisconsin asserted in the Senate today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 15 -- A plan to provide work for 150,000 garment workers throughout the country made idle by priorities and other war dislocations was adopted by the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers, in session here today, after receipt of information from Washington indicating that 20 per cent of all orders for Army and Navy uniforms may be alloted to shops in New York employing I.L.G.W.U. members.
BOSTON, June 15 -- Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, urged today a cessation of public criticism of Congress.
ALBANY, June 15 -- The Adjutant General released the following orders today:

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Our task force had drawn away southward after the victory on May 4 at Tu- lagi harbor in the Solomon Islands. Although we had not recognized it as such, total destruction of the occupation force -- cruisers, de- stroyers and the all-important transports in Tulagi harbor -- had been only the opening wedge of the desperate fight in which we now found ourselves.

Lee S. Buckingham, State Director of the Office of Price Administration, announced yesterday that only 250 public schools would be needed for the registration of motorists for permanent gasoline rationing. The Regional OPA office here disclosed that it had held hearings in the cases of nineteen additional filling station owners accused of gasoline bootlegging.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 15 -- The elimination of the German Boerse as a free clearing house for deals in industrial stocks, shares and bonds was forecast in a sweeping ordinance of the Reich Ministry of Economy, effective today, according to information received here.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 15 -- Sixty thousand Jews of Vilna were put to death between May 7 and May 20 by the German-controlled Lithuanian police, according to reports brought here by a Pole, who said he was in Vilna until May 24.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Our task force had drawn away southward after the victory on May 4 at Tu- lagi harbor in the Solomon Islands. Although we had not recognized it as such, total destruction of the occupation force -- cruisers, de- stroyers and the all-important transports in Tulagi harbor -- had been only the opening wedge of the desperate fight in which we now found ourselves.

Lee S. Buckingham, State Director of the Office of Price Administration, announced yesterday that only 250 public schools would be needed for the registration of motorists for permanent gasoline rationing. The Regional OPA office here disclosed that it had held hearings in the cases of nineteen additional filling station owners accused of gasoline bootlegging.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 15 -- The elimination of the German Boerse as a free clearing house for deals in industrial stocks, shares and bonds was forecast in a sweeping ordinance of the Reich Ministry of Economy, effective today, according to information received here.

Testimony of Serge Rubinstein in the Chosen Corporation hearing yesterday concerned itself largely with an attempt by him to dispose of 150,000 partly paid Chosen shares on which he still has a liability of $722,700.

BOSTON, June 16 (AP) -- Although given seven hits and as many bases on balls because of Johnny Vander Meer's wildness, the luckless Braves suffered a 5-0 shut-out today when they opened a three-game series with the Reds.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 16 -- The names of fifty-one honor men in the graduating class of the Naval Academy were announced today.

STANTON, Del., June 16 (AP) -- Mrs. C.S. Bromley's In Question, second to the consistent Firebrom in his last start, came into his own at Delaware Park today when he was a driving winner of the mile and a sixteenth Powder House purse.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Definite collaboration between the War Production Board and the Office of Price Administration to check the quality of consumer goods as "a necessary adjunct" of price control is under way and will soon take shape in the form of a new unit in OPA.

Buyers' Registrations Jump Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 810, which compared with 488 in the preceding week and 967 in the similar period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The thirteen Ordnance Districts of the Army have doubled their operations since the beginning of the war. As of the end of May, the War Department stated production was reported under way on 12,000 prime contracts and 70,000 subcontracts.

A heel-clicking, fully uniformed member of the German Bund was arrested in Brooklyn early yesterday morning, and when the Federal Bureau of Investigation had finished questioning him it was found that a grim loyalty to a dead friend had led him to appear in the unpopular regalia.

A long investigation by an official of the New York Public Library led yesterday to an order by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan for the arrest of Benjamin M. Harris. 46 years old, in his second-hand book store at 84 Fourth Avenue in connection with thefts of more than 200 rare books and pamphlets, roughly valued at more than $5,000, from the libraries of the Harvard-Andover Theological Seminary, Princeton University, Princeton Seminary and Rutgers University.

The appointment of Frank R. Crosswaith, Negro organizer for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, as a member of the New York City Housing Authority, was announced by Mayor La Guardia last night in a telegram read at a mass meeting at Madison Square Garden attended by 18,000 Negroes.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- In the earlier two phases of the historic Coral Sea Battle our American air squadrons had surprised, trapped and annihilated Japanese warships with a swiftness and efficiency that was horrible to contemplate -- even by the victorious air fighters and bombers themselves.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Immediate steps to place the civilian population of Alaska on a war footing, for complete collaboration with military and naval authorities there were ordered today by Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, who holds legal control over Territories of the United States.

LONDON, June 16 -- United States Army Liberator bombers and, according to German sources, at least one American battleship have helped two large British convoys to fight their way through opposition from lurking Axis submarines, German and Italian planes and Italian warships in the Mediterranean and deliver supplies to beleaguered Malta and Tobruk.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Scoring promises to run extremely low in the Hale America national open golf tournament starting a fourday run at the Ridgemoor Country Club Thursday. The 107 stars gathering for a shot at the $1,100 first prize figure to whisk around the compact course with a minimum of exercise.

NEWARK, N.J., June 16 -- Four New Jersey residents, among the sixty-three indicted in Detroit for allegedly using the mails to defraud in connection with the operation of the Republica de Cuba Hospital Funds Lottery, were arraigned here today before United States Commissioner Joseph F. Holland and released in $2,500 bond each.

If the War Production Board finally rules that a production-limitation order is necessary for the cosmetic industry, it should be on the basis of dollar volume for a recent base period instead of a limitation on every product produced by the industry, H.L. Brooks, president of the Toilet Goods Association, suggested yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Foreign Trade Zones Board reported today to Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, that the New York foreign zone had become so vital in the promotion of international trade that not even war could interefere with its continuance.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 16 -- Chile will sever relations with the Axis sooner than most persons believe, "definitely linking her destiny to the destiny of America," and taking up arms, if necessary, In defense of democracy, according to Senator Eduardo Cruz-Coke, a prominent Rightist leader, in an exclusive interview today.

Tomorrow night's scheduled premiere of Michael Todd's revue, "Star and Garter," featuring Bobby Clark and Gypsy Rose Lee, has been shifted to next Wednesday night at the Music Box. On Sunday Mr. Todd expressed no hesitancy in saying his attraction, which is foregoing an out-of-town tryout, would open on schedule.

Scrap rubber in increasing volume began flowing yesterday into gasoline service stations that are acting as collection agencies in the nation-wide salvage campaign as officials mapped plans for mobilizing volunteers to assist in the drive.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- No solutions have been announced of two arguments in connection with the anti-submarine campaign which have been going on for some time between the Navy and a combination of War Shipping Administration officials and yachtsmen.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The House passed by voice vote and sent to the Senate today a $53,548,099 second deficiency appropriations bill. It carried $8,235,000 for the development of guayule and other rubber-bearing plants.

CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- Orval Grove, White Sox freshman righthander, won a 2-1 hurlers' duel from Bob Harris of the Athletics before 9,180 fans tonight. Bob Kennedy doubled to drive in Joe Kuhel, who had walked, in the ninth inning, to win the game.

Contributions to the American way of life made by the late Justice Louis D. Brandeis, of the United States Supreme Court, and United States Senator Robert F. Wagner are contrasted with the designs of Axis leaders by President Roosevelt in a message prompted by a tribute to be paid to Senator Wagner tonight at a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Commodore.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 16 -- In accordance with its established policy of making public all income and expenditures, the International Ladies Garment Workers issued today a detailed report of its finances for the fiscal year 1941, covering the accounts of the national office as well as of 325 affiliated locals, twenty-three joint boards and fifteen regional departments.

The estate of Mrs. Daniel Guggenheim near Port Washington, L.I., has been given to the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences for the establishment of a research center as a memorial to her husband, it was announced yesterday by Major Lester D. Gardner, executive vice president of the institute.

If the top showings of the current outdoor season were any barometer of championship rating, then the following athletes would take senior titles at the fifty-fifth annual National A.A.U. track and field games, from which the Army Emergency Relief will benefit, at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island Saturday:

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. received yesterday the award of an issue of $1,792,000 of Albany, N.Y., various purpose bonds on a bid of 100.16 for 1.80s. Dated June 1, 1942, and maturing serially on June 1, 1943 to 1962, the bonds were immediately reoffered at prices to yield from 0.50 to 1.85 per cent, according to maturity.

ALBANY, June 16 -- The major points of a new transportation conservation program were stated tonight in a broadcast by Governor Lehman and Carroll E. Mealey, State Tax Commissioner. The program is designed, they said, to assure the people adequate and comfortable transportation for the duration of the war.

ROME, June 16 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command declared today that Axis forces had "reached and passed" Britain's El Gazala positions on the Libyan front and claimed Axis mastery of the skies over the North African battle area.

Believing that the United States will have to accept "the heavy responsibility of world affairs" after the war, Walter Hoving proposed yesterday that this country's great universities and foundations be converted into "reconstruction research institutes" to make the "instruments for peace."

Two principal leaders of the American Labor party conferred by appointment with President Roosevelt at the White House yesterday, and asked the President to take a direct hand in the selection of a candidate for Governor of New York State who is more closely identified with the New Deal than is Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., who has already received pledges of support sufficient to nominate him as the Democratic candidate.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Changes in specifications for certain grades of iron and steel scrap, together with the addition of several new grades to those already in revised price schedule No. 4, were provided for in an amendment announced today by Price Administrator Leon Henderson.
The City Council adopted a local law yesterday which prohibits the wearing of bathing suits or other scanty attire on streets or boardwalks at a distance of more than 200 feet from a bathing beach.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- Francis B. Sayre, Philippines High Commissioner, and John J. Dempsey, Under-Secretary of the Interior, have submitted their resignations to President Roosevelt, it was disclosed tonight.

Jose Basora, 155, Puerto Rico, outpunched Jacob La Motta, 158, Bronx, to earn a decision in the feature ten-round contest at the Bronx Coliseum last night before a crowd of 7,500. The rivals battled to a draw over the same distance three weeks ago.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. L. Stuart Wing, who had been at the Plaza, left yesterday for their home in Santa Barbara, Calif.

CHUNGKING, China, June 16 -- Calling for a "unified" strategy now, in which the launching of an immediate and big offensive in the Pacific would receive equal importance with other theatres of war, Dr. P.S. Foo, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, at a press conference today maintained:

Plaidish-looking suits made from mill ends, a dress sewn of a silk tie and a shantung curtain, and a little boy's suit made from two sugar sacks at a cost of 12 1/2 cents were among costumes selected yesterday by outstanding designers and fashion writers for submission next Tuesday to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and executives of the War Production Board for final judging in a nation-wide salvage design contest.

NOT so long ago Barrister Muddy Ruel of the White Sox, when asked what he thought of how the pennant races were shaping up, said he never looked at the standings until the Fourth of July. On the other hand there are those cold statisticians who say flatly that a game won in April counts as much as a game won in September.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 16 (AP) -- A Royal Air Force special communique said:

LONDON, June 16 -- A frank admission that the British school system is not what it should be came in the House of Commons today from Richard Austen Butler, president of the Board of Education, reporting on the occasion of the submission of education estimates to the House.
ROME, June 16 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

LONDON, June 16 -- Complaints that the industrial production of this country is suffering from a lack of effective planning and that "vested interests at the top" were allocating raw materials to their friends at the expense of other factory owners came today from the Amalgamated Engineering Union at its convention at Black-pool, England.

TRENTON, June 16 (AP) -- Nettled by the State Senate's failure to go along with a pair of nominations designed to weaken the Statewide influence of Mayor Frank Hague, Governor Charles Edison said today he felt "the majority of the Republican Senators have demonstrated the utter insincerity of their repeated outcries against Hague domination."

WATERLOO, Ind., June 16 (U.P.) -- George Froboese, 42 years old, of Milwaukee, trustee of the German-American Bund Committee, who was on his way to New York in answer to a Federal subpoena, committed suicide by throwing himself before a New York Central passenger train at the depot here, the Federal Bureau of Investigation made known tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Navy stated today that another Lexington would be launched soon to replace the carrier destroyed in the battle of the Coral Sea.

NEWARK, N.J., June 16 -- An audience of 16,000 attended the performance of Rossini's "The Barber of Seville," which was presented tonight at the City Schools Stadium as the second event in the Essex County Symphony Society's seventh season of outdoor concerts.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Roosevelt reminded Congress today that every hour that passes without enactment of tax legislation means the loss of vitally needed revenue for war purposes, but Congressional leaders declined to accept his suggestion that the tax bill be split and the excise levies enacted immediately.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the National War Labor Board's fact-finding panel in the "Little Steel" wage dispute, has formulated a preliminary report which, according to report, points the way to a substantial wage increase if the board concurs.

ALBANY, June 16 -- A Federal grand jury indicted four Albany labor union representatives today, the government charging that they had exacted more than $50,000 from workers who were hired at the new Voorheesville Army depot.

The disbarment of State Senator Joseph A. Esquirol, Brooklyn Democrat, was recommended yesterday by one of Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's extraordinary grand juries on the ground that he had been guilty of fraud, deceit and unprofessional conduct in matters involving the operations of the pinball racket, and had benefited financially from obtaining legislative appointments and had misused clients' funds.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Congressional action on legislation providing financial aid for dependents of men in the armed services and also for permitting deferments of married draft registrants, regardless of their financial dependency status, was completed by the House today.

SPRINGFIELD, N,J., June 16 -- Charles P. Burgess of Baltusrol exhibited a fondness for his home course today and relieved August F. Kammer Sr., a club-mate, of the metropolitan seniors' golf title when he scored a 75, three over par for the difficult upper course.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 16 -- The science of nutrition can be used to increase employer-employe understanding, N.W. Shefferman, head of the industrial relations department of Sears, Roebuck Co., said today.

LONDON, June 16 -- It has taken a long time, but today the people of London finally received permission to fish in the Serpentine, the lake in Hyde Park created under the guidance of Queen Caroline, consort of George II, in 1730.

"Don't write about me. Tell about the people on the home front in Norway who are just waiting for the day when they can overthrow the Germans. Tell about my boys who are learning to fly in Canada so that they can take the shortest way back to assist our countrymen.
Continued good health in New York City was reflected in the vital statistics for the week ended Saturday, Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records in the Health Department, reported yesterday.

How far may organized physicians control the practice of medicine ? That they alone are competent to decide what diagnostic and therapeutic procedures are right or wrong no one will deny. But have they the right to prevent lay groups from setting up their own medical organizations and devising methods to reduce the cost of good medical care?

Americans fortunate enough to be able to leave their desks and business offices long enough for some salmon and trout fishing in New Brunswick are enjoying their excursions, judging from reports emanating from several regions in that Canadian province.
HONOLULU, June 16 -- The Navy's newest outfit, the seagoing engineers, made their report today on the first six months of the war. Pearl Harbor was the first big job.

Councilman Peter V. Cacchione, Brooklyn Communist, ran into a legislative Blitzkrieg in the City Council yesterday over his proposal that 10 per cent of every Councilman's salary of $5,000 be deducted for the purchase of war bonds.

The crime club took over the Martin Beck last evening to watch Basil Beyea stir up a most astounding witches' brew called "The Cat Screams." There were five scenes, with a murder per scene being par for the course, and at the end of it all the crime club went trailing down Eighth Avenue, gleefully quoting fragments of dialogue and meowing to one another like contented cats.
CHUNGKING, June 16 (AP) -- The text of today's Chinese communique follows:

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A reorganization of the functions of the War Production Board is under way which will transfer the duties of purchase and production of finished goods to the War and Navy Departments and coordinate its operations with those of the British Ministry of Supply in a general pooling of Anglo-American resources.

Confidence Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said last night that the financial industry in this country may expect an early revival. He spoke at a time when firms are merging to save expenses, members are dropping out and gloom is almost unbroken.

LONDON, June 16 -- Eating in the West End of London must now come close to the ultimate in confusion, for it was marked yesterday by the introduction of the Food Ministry's idely heralded 5-shilling -- roughly $1 -- maximum price for meals in a campaign austerity that has left customers and restaurants dazed.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Suspension of gasoline deliveries for periods of fifteen and thirty days were Imposed today by Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, on fourteen service station operators in the New York and Philadelphia metropolitan areas "for flagrant violation" of gasoline rationing regulations.

The nine-story apartment house containing fifty-four suites of three and four rooms at 150 West Fifty-fifth Street was sold by the 150 West Fifty-fifth Street Corporation to a client of Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc., brokers. The structure is on a plot 100 by 100 feet and the entire property is assessed for $500,000.

The House Ways and Means Committee has rejected the Treasury's recommendations to carry out President Roosevelt's recent suggestion that "no American citizen ought to have a net income after he had paid his taxes of more than $25,000 a year." They provide for a supertax of 100 per cent on all income after taxes above $25,000 for a single person or $50,000 for a married couple.

American-manned bombers, cooperating with R.A.F. fliers in a great four-day air and naval battle, have sunk a 10,000-ton Italian cruiser, set fire to two Italian battleships and damaged or sunk other warships in one of the sharpest defeats the Axis has suffered in the Mediterranean.

HONOLULU, June 16 -- The men who fly the big patrol boats, the lumbering Albatrosses that are the eyes of the Navy and at the same time the most vulnerable of all Navy aircraft, sat in the small office of their commander today and told the stories of the days and nights west and north of Midway on and after June 3, when first contact was made with the invading Japanese fleet.

Isadore Goldstein, 23 years old, who for the last year and a half has been working' as a Department of Sanitation man, Class B, better known as a street cleaner, last night was graduated magna cum laude from Brooklyn College. He had attended the institution at night for seven years.

The Body and Mind Foundation, Inc., which is in a converted garage at 139 East Sixty-ninth Street, and Rudolph Rebold, a Swiss chemist who was "research observer" in its clinic for its head, Dr. Edward S. Cowles, the psychiatrist, were found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of unlawfully practicing medicine there up to the police raid on the place last April 22.
EVANSTON, Ill., June 16 -- The Big Ten's All-Stars won their dual track meet with the Pacific Coast's best tonight for the first time in the six-year history of the event.
Two years ago today American radio listeners heard a faraway band playing the Marseillaise hymn. It died away at last, into echoes, some thought into history:

CHUNGKING, China, June 16 -- About 150,000 Japanese troops in two armies closing in from the east and west threatened today to capture the last Chinese-held stretch -- eighty miles long -- of the Hangchow-Nanchang Railway.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (AP) -- After dropping nine straight and thirteen out of their last sixteen games, the Phils slammed out a dozen base hits and got some top-notch pitching from Johnny Podgajny today to defeat the Pirates, 5 to 1.

The Summer dancing season in the city's parks opened last night on the mall in Central Park as 8,000 young jitterbugs and several elderly ones danced and listened to Raymond Scott and his orchestra. It was the first in a series of fifty-four dance-concerts arranged by the Park Department in cooperation with the Consolidated Edison Company.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 16 -- A jury was chosen in Westchester County Surrogate's Court today to determine whether the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest at Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, New York, carried on an "illicit love affair" with Mrs. Anna H. Paton and influenced her unduly into leaving part of her $1,300,000 estate to him, his children and his church.

American industries have pledged $1,500,000 in a $5,000,000 program of the National Safety Council to combat worker accidents slowing war production, Colonel John Stilwell, council president, said yesterday.
TORONTO, June 16 (AP) -- Jack Hallett restricted Jersey City to three hits and pounded a two-run homer to pace Toronto to a 7-2 triumph in a twilight game tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The plan to establish food wardens in every block of every community has passed into the experimental stage and a large Eastern city will soon be called on to show the effect of neighborly conversation in coping with food shortages and surpluses.

Those tired and worn cars of the Second Avenue elevated line that rattled and banged up and down that structure for twenty to forty years and more are being drafted by government and private agencies for the all-out drive on the Nazis and the Japanese, it was learned yesterday.
A number of leases for living quarters on Park Avenue were among the contracts for residential space reported yesterday by brokers and agents.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (U.P.) -- The favorite meal of Brig. Gen. "Jimmy" H. Doolittle, leader of the bombing expedition against Japan, is a thick, rare steak, two vegetables, mashed potatoes, gravy, salad and cake with a lot of chocolate sauce, his wife told a group of women leaders here today.

HARRODSBURG, Ky., June 16 -- Kinsmen of Kentucky's modern heroes of Bataan mingled with descendants of pioneer heroes today as Harrodsburg celebrated the State's sesquicentennial and its own 168th anniversary.

LONDON, June 16 -- The news from Libya caused prices to decline today on the Stock Exchange, with gilt-edged issues falling as much as 2s 6d. There was little selling, with prices steadier at the lower levels.
ST. LOUIS, June 16 (AP) -- Stretching their winning string to nine games, the Red Sox tonight downed the faltering Browns, 4 to 2. It was the seventh consecutive defeat for St. Louis.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 -- ThE broad outlines of a plan for collaboration between stock exchanges, securities dealers and the Securities and Exchange Commission with the purpose of maintaining a sound national economy during and after the war were suggested tonight by Ganson Purcell, chairman of the SEC, and endorsed by Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, in addresses before the governors of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms.

Frank Crosswaith, named last night by Mayor La Guardia as a member of the New York City Housing Authority, worked as an elevator operator while attending night schools and eventually was graduated from the Rand School of Social Science, remaining there to teach for several years.

More than 300,000 pledges were counted at the Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign headquarters at 521 Fifth Avenue last night, within twenty-four hours after 200,000 Minute Men had started their door-to-door and shop-to-shop canvassing.

Spring is giving way to Summer, and the shift in seasons brings a change in the mood of diners. Those who were eating brimming bowls of Swedish pea soup not long ago may be heard to ask for chilly cups of jellied tomato bouillon. And the appetites that used to be satisfied with a piping hot beef ragout now demand thinly sliced cold cuts.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 16 -- The Senate, which the government has a firm majority, voted fifteen to three late tonight to keep the state of siege in force for another sixty days.

BOSTON, June 16 -- A warning that "the short-sighted policy" prevailing after the last war must not be allowed to influence Congress when peace is planned this time, was sounded today by Representative Mary T. Norton of New Jersey before the first regional conference on women and the war, sponsored by the women's division of the Democratic National Committee.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, June 17 (UP) -- This communique was issued today:

The Same Place One hears the name pronounced in four different ways: Sevastopol, with a v, accent on second or third syllable, and Sebastopol, with a b, accent on second or third syllable. Presumably there is some authority for all, but this column votes for only two.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Secretary Ickes urged again today that householders in the East Coast States provide for heating their homes with coal because the supply of heating oils would be "entirely inadequate to take care of the sharply increased Winter requirements."
General Douglas MacArthur was designated yesterday "the outstanding American father of 1942" by the National Father's Day Committee.

Wholesale grocers have petitioned the Office of Defense Transportation to abolish the ban on "back-hauls" and "circuitous routes" as stated in its General Orders Nos. 4 and 5, it was learned yesterday. The National-American Wholesale Grocers Association, representing a membership which distributes approximately 75 per cent of the groceries wholesaled by independent merchants, in a formal petition to the ODT has requested relief in connection with the orders.
American air power struck on a new front yesterday as four-engined B-24 Consolidated bombers, apparently based in Egypt and the Middle East, attacked the Italian Fleet in the Mediterranean.
LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- A joint Admiralty and Air Ministry communique said:

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Forecasts of a substantial decline in retail store volume and earnings were revealed today at the mid-year convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association here. Speaking before the Controller's Congress session of the convention, D.J. Duncan, Professor of Marketing of the School of Commerce, North-western University, Chicago, estimated that the total retail sales volume would decline three billions in 1942 to approximately fifty billions.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- A house Military Affairs Subcommittee gave a clean bill to the nation's dollar-a-year men today in a report of an investigation of circumstances surrounding the resignation last March of Robert R. Guthrie of Paducah, Ky.

BOSTON, June 16 -- Dissatisfied horsemen at Suffolk Downs ended their one-day strike today by submitting their demands for a 20 per cent increase in minimum purses to the three-man Massachusetts Racing Commission for arbitration.

DETROIT, June 16 -- Sixty-three persons, alleged operators of a $7,500,000 lottery of national scope, were charged with fraud in an indictment returned June 1 before Federal District Judge Ernest A. O'Brien, it was made known today by John C. Lehr, Federal District Attorney.

FALL RIVER, Mass., June 16 (AP) -- A war-busy textile plant, crippled by an eight-day strike of 125 changers and loom fixers, slowed to a virtual standstill today as strikers steadfastly refused to return to work until union representatives conferred with officials of the War Labor Board in Washington.

Sevastopol has become the pivot of a vast are extending from Murmansk to Gibraltar and connecting the two remaining open gates of Europe. Whether the fighting is active or dormant, this are is not only a continuous battle line but the same battle line. Within it lies the world's central continent, and whenever it is breached decisively at any point the iron ring will be broken and the war for Europe won.

Mrs. Henry Goddard Leach, chairman of the Educational Price Control Campaign of the OPA, told a noon-day rally at the Civilian Defense Information Center in Pershing Square yesterday that "when any article consumed in quantity by the public becomes scarce it will be rationed."

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The House Naval Affairs Committee voted unanimously today for an $8,550,000,000 fleet, doubling the naval expansion program, and by its action approved High Command emphasis upon the aircraft carrier and smaller, speedier fighting ships rather than the superdreadnaught type of war craft.

The regional headquarters of the Office of Price Administration is planning a new drive against gasoline dealers who refuse to sell to any but regular customers, it became known last night as trial calendars were cleared of cases involving sales of gasoline without cancellation of ration card units.

Enos (Country) Slaughter drove a ball into the top tier of the right-Field stands in the tenth inning and the bottom fell out of the game between the Cardinals and Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds. For this homer, Slaughter's fifth of the campaign, gave the Red-birds a 4-3 victory over the home-coming New Yorkers, with Carl Hubbell the victim.

Cooperating with the United States Government War Bond Drive, thirteen New York galleries which specialize in American art have put on group shows, all proeeds from sales until June 27 to be put into bonds by the artists and galleries.

Columbia Pictures announced yesterday that its 1942-43 production schedule, which it described as "an ambitious effort to meet the unprecedented entertainment demands of the nation," would be composed of forty-eight features, sixteen Westerns, four serials and 130 short subjects.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 16 -- Greer Garson's next vehicle at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will be "Mrs. Parkington," a new novel by Louis Bromfield, according to the studio's plan, it was learned today. The story was purchased by Metro last October before publication and deals with the effect of wealth on four generations of an American family.
TOKYO, June 16 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in New Tork) -- Attacking from the west, Japanese
James G. Blaine, chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, again stressed the need for enrollment of volunteers in vital war services.
Trade buying in the face of limited offering's sent cotton futures higher yesterday. On the New York Cotton Exchange actrve contracts closed 13 to 15 points above Monday's final prices.
DETROIT, June 16 -- The Yankees accumulated two four - run leads in as many experimental contests against the Tigers at Briggs Stadium today, tout could capitalize on only one.

As a result of a rise in taxes, the Pennsylvania Railroad reported yesterday for the first four months of the year a net income only slightly larger than the total net income for April. The company changed its bookkeeping in March to provide for an increase of $1,500,000 in sums set aside to pay taxes in the first two months of the year.
in a thrilling tournament, Dr. Norman C. Armitage of the Fencers Club retained his national saber championship on the strips of the Salle Santelli last night.

A FEW days ago a talented American woman writer who is also a book reviewer expressed In my hearing the idea that in times of world crisis, calamity and suffering like these, there should be no place for books that seek merely to entertain.
Two more American merchant ships have been sunk and a third has been damaged by torpedoes off the Atlantic and Gulf coasts, the Navy announced yesterday.

After expressing his "deepest gratitude" for American relief sent to the Greek people, King George II pledged his country to stand beside its Allies "in the formation of a new world society founded on the ideal of the four freedoms," at a dinner in his honor given last night by Harold S. Vanderbilt, honorary chairman of the Greek War Relief Association, in the Ritz Carlton Hotel.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 16 (AP) -- Rochester's Red Wings swept both ends of a double-header from the league-leading Newark Bears tonight.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Soy beans and wheat paced the grain markets to higher levels today on the Board of Trade, the former moving up 4 cents a bushel at one time on buying induced by a belief that something constructive would come out of a meeting between the Commodity Credit Corporation and processors.
MOSCOW, June 16 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau communique said today:

TRENTON, N.J., June 16 (AP) -- Federal District Court Judge Phillip Forman, denying an application by a Union City draftee to get out of the Army, rejected today the government's contention that soldiers in such a spot had no right to take advantage of habeas corpus proceedings.

A special board of Navy officers held a hearing at 90 Church Street yesterday on an appeal by O.M. Salisbury, vice president of the American Communications Association, C.I.O., and a member of the Defense Communications Board and one of the eighty - seven radio operators put on a "blacklist" by Secretary of the Navy Knox last March for alleged un-American activities.

Edward (Paving Block) Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, wishes a cessation of public criticism of Congress. "If present criticism continues," he fears, "our whole structure of government may fall." "How can we expect other nations to respect our government," he asks, "if our own people are continually criticizing, ridiculing and belittling'' Congress?
BERLIN, June 16 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The degree to which retailers improve their bad record of compliance with the price posting regulations of the over-all price control order will have "a decisive bearing" on the Office of Price Administration policy for enforcing the price ceilings.

On the face of it, Mayor La Guardia has at last taken the step which many of us have long urged upon him. He has named Deputy Chief Police Inspector Arthur W. Wallander to be not merely "Chief of Staff" of the city's defense forces but deputy Mayor. "Orders coming from the Chief of Staff," Mr. La Guardia states, "are orders coming from the Mayor."

The good luck of Mrs, Tilyou Christopher, who saw her Doublrab topple Whirlaway in the Carter Handicap last Saturday, continued yesterday at Aqueduct when Doubt Not, carrying the same blue and gold silks, led from end to end of the Previous Handicap to score decisively at even money.

Film inventory of Paramount Pictures, Inc., has increased by about $9,000,000 in the last seventeen months, mainly due to the provisions of the consent decree that requires trade showings before the release of feature pictures, Barney Balaban, president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday.

FORT DES MOINES, Iowa, June 16 -- There will be little excuse for the uniforms of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps bulging in the wrong places, for the Army, it is announced, is going to issue two girdles each to members of the unit.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Oliver Lyttelton, British Minister of Production, said today after a conference with President Roosevelt that one American concern would be turning out war weapons at the rate of $4,000,000,000 a year at the end of 1942.

No older than this morning's headlines -- if somewhat less momentous -- are two new versions of a woman's chosen weapon, her lipstick. Necessity, or her step-sister Priority, has been the mother of twin inventions.

All Investment firms in the Second Federal Reserve District were requested yesterday by the Victory Fund Committee of this district, which is headed by Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, to furnish the committee with the names, addresses and territory covered by their sales personnel.

A new form of entertainment for children during blackouts was presented yesterday at the opening of a new library at the Boys Club of New York, Tenth Street and Avenue A. A series of musical radio script records were developed by Mrs. Molly Donaldson, composer and organist, and by Miss Madge Tucker of the National Broadcasting Company.

LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- Axis claims concerning the air-sea battle in the Mediterranean reached a crescendo today. A special communique issued by the Germans covered damage reported inflicted on a westbound British convoy from Saturday to yesterday.

Minor gains were scored again yesterday in the stock market but the volume continued too light to give an over-all appearance of sincere strength. War news from the Mediterranean, where American airmen were operating with British flyers for the first time, and also from the Aleutians, was highly encouraging.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Just when the House of Representatives had decided that the labor situation was not so bad after all twenty-eight of the thirty-four Negro waiters in the main House dining room struck for higher wages today in the middle of the noon rush hour.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- With reports from all parts of the country indicating hearty cooperation In the scrap rubber collection, President Roosevelt declared today with gratification that the campaign was off to a good start.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 16 -- On the steps of Nassau Hall, only a few feet from the office where Woodrow Wilson labored during the nine years he was president of Princeton University, Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, and Dr. Hu Shin, the Ambassador from China, proclaimed today that the United Nations would have to return to the principles of Wilsonian idealism to insure a just and lasting peace.

General instructions, account summaries and other data pertaining to government insurance on real property against war damage are now expected to be placed in the hands of companies, brokers and agents who will handle the placing of insurance for the War Damage Corporation on Saturday.

Republic's "In Old California," which opens at Loew's Criterion, will be this morning's sole film newcomer. The Western drama stars John Wayne and includes Binnie Barnes, Albert Dekker, Helen Parrish, Dick Purcell, Edgar Kennedy and Patsy Kelly among its supporting players.

STANTON, Del., June 17 -- Delaware Park ushered in its steeplechase season today and Miss Ella Widener's Iron Shot, a gray son of Chance Shot and Prevencheres, won the two-mile Spring" Maiden Steeplechase.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- Phil Marchildon, the Athletics' right-hander who had his five-game winning streak stopped here by a 4-3 score on May 16, broke a five-game losing streak by the same count today as Philadelphia beat the White Sox to move into sixth place.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 17 -- Prime Minister John Curtin, in a nationwide broadcast today, warned Australians of the gravity of the war situation in Russia and Libya. He appealed for subscriptions of u3,000,000 (Australian) a day in the final days of the second war loan campaign.

If manufacturers of plastics salvaged only 15 to 20 per cent of the available scrap in their plants, they would add 1,000,000 pounds of material yearly to their output, S. Donald Perlman, WPB salvage director in charge of textiles, plastics and solvents, declared yesterday at a panel discussion at the one-day salvage conference sponsored by the American Management Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

Rubber thimbles, diving suits, heels, old tires, hot-water bottles and hundreds of other articles containing rubber income form were accumulating yesterday in evermounting scrap piles at gasoline service stations throughout the city.

Falling another 1,311,000 barrels last week, gasoline stocks in the United States declined for the thirteenth consecutive week, bringing the total to 91,994,000 barrels, as compared with 93,305,000 in the preceding week, according to figures announced yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

CLEVELAND, June 17 (AP) -- Ken Keltner's single in the seventh inning tonight drove in the tying and winning runs as Cleveland beat the Senators, 5 to 4. It was the Indians' seventh victory over Washington in eight meetings.

NEW ORLEANS, June 17 (AP) -- A frustrated submarine commander fruitlessly fired six torpedoes at a medium-sized cargo vessel in the central Gulf of Mexico early May 12, but Captain Peter Joseph Sigona and his crew of thirty-seven kept the vessel from being hit.
