Members of the New York Curb Exchange voted yesterday approval of three amendments to its constitution intended to overcome the effects of declining revenues, at least in part, and to facilitate the acquisition of memberships to replace the losses of recent months.

BOSTON, June 17 (AP) -- Left at the gate, John L. Sullivan's Transfigure came from last place today at Suffolk Downs to win the eighth running of the $5,000 added Bunker Hill Handicap before a holiday throng of 14,000.

Gordon Auchincloss, attorney, has leased an apartment of nine rooms in 950 Park Avenue through Douglas Gibbons and the Payson McL. Merrill Company. The latter, in conjunction with Culver, Hollyday Co., rented an apartment of twelve rooms and four baths in 1067 Fifth Avenue to John Stone Willim.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW TORK TIMES: I feel grateful to THE TIMES for the editorial of June 13, "Too Many Teachers?" It should help clarify the situation which induced our Board of Education to vote a lay-off of 125 high school teachers. The outcries of the teachers are likely to spread an impression that their welfare was the primary issue to be considered.

George D. Widener's Stefanita, a daughter of Questionnaire, who has been favored in every one of her five starts, fought her way through along the rail at Aqueduct yesterday to capture the $7,475 Astoria Stakes in 1:05 4-5, only two-fifths of a second slower than the track record for five and a half furlongs.

In the delicacy shops of this city there is evidence of change. Imports that once helped to make life pleasant-tiny terrines of French pate de foie gras, flat tins of British kippered herrings and square canisters of Chinese tea -- are disappearing.

Commercial Loans Survey The survey undertaken by the Federal Reserve Board and the twelve Federal Reserve central banks of the commercial and industrial loans made by member banks of the Reserve System covering the period from April 16 to May 15, inclusive, has been virtually completed.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The House Naval Affairs Committee disclosed tonight that this country has in service 1,009,245 tons of fighting ships built since 1934 and 2,646,606 tons under construction.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 17 (AP) -- Sixteen of the twenty-one members of the American Field Service Ambulance Unit at Bir Hacheim got out safely when that desert outpost was abandoned last week, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Representative Samuel Dickstein, New York Democrat, today accused Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and other medical schools of barring students not socially acceptable to them and asserted that if this became a fixed policy the government would find it necessary to maintain an institution similar in design to West Point or Annapolis to fill its need for physicians.

Because his business has been affected by the war, Daniel A. Daly, foreman of the March Bronx County grand jury that handed up two presentments exonerating every one in the Flynn paving block investigation, revealed yesterday that he has sent two applications to Washington for a government position.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Treasury announced today the offering tomorrow of another issue of certificates of indebtedness with a few new features which were not present when the previous offering was made some months ago. The issue will be $1,500,000,000 of five-eighths of 1 per cent Treasury certificates of indeotedness of Series A, 1943.
After a separation of fifteen days, the Duke and Duchess of Windsor were reunited at 2:30 P.M. yesterday at La Guardia Field, where he landed in a bimotored Navy plane after a flight from Washington.

Reaching a new high figure, inventories of New York and Brooklyn department stores at the end of May showed an increase of 86 per cent over the corresponding date a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

BOSTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Reds ran their string of victories over the Braves to nine today by capturing the front game of the Bunker Hill Day double-header, 4 -- 2, and then coming from behind to gain a 4-3 decision in the eleventh inning nightcap.

Charles Silverstein, formerly sales manager of Rhinecraft Company, has formed a novelty jewelry company under his own name at 1239 Broadway. The Rhinecraft company suspended operations for the duration of the war.

ROME, June 17 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) The High Command said today that the presence of a strong Italian naval formation in waters near Crete had forced a fifty-ship British convoy to turn back to Alexandria in one phase of the battles along the Mediterran can supply lanes.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Howard Phipps are at the Pierre.

BERYL MARKHAM'S "West With the Night"* is the sort of book that makes you think human beings can do anything. The author grew up on a farm in East Africa, a straw-haired girl with long, coltish legs who played with native children, rode horses and learned very little from school teachers.

LONDON, June 17 -- Announcement that the United States was moving rapidly to expand aircraftcarrier construction was hailed in naval circles here as one of the most realistic developments of this war.
There were almost as many generals as enlisted men present yesterday afternoon at the Soldiers and Sailors Club when it dedicated its enlarged and renovated quarters at 283-85 Lexington Ave.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 17 -- Although German armored forces in Libya continued to attack the British positions near Rezegh, British mixed forces preserved the front, which at most points is based on Tobruk.

Warning that unemployment in this city would pass the half-million mark by the end of the year unless additional war contracts were forthcoming, the New York C.I.O. Council put forward yesterday a ten-point program intended to create a minimu mof 200,000 new jobs here.

While critics of the measure adopted by the City Council restricting the wearing of scanty attire near beaches said yesterday that it was meaningless because Park Department beaches were excluded from its provisions, Councilman William N. Conrad, who sponsored the bill, predicted that it would succeed in clearing the city streets of persons in abbreviated costumes.

MOSCOW, Thursday, June 18 (AP) -- The fortifications of Sevastopol and historic, battered Balaclava presented an unbending defense today to the repeated attacks of Germany's greatest offensive against the last Russian ports to stand guard on the western Black Sea.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Stamps bearing the numbers 5 and 6 in the country's sugar ration books will be valid each for a period of four weeks instead of two as were the first four stamps, but the individual sugar ration will remain at half a pound a week, the Office of Price Administration said today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of June 12 you published the highly interesting information Frederick C. Oechsner gives on the private life of Hitler. He writes that "in the great hall of his quarters in the Chancellery there are fourteen gorgeous Gobelin, tapestries selected by him (Hitler) personally."

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Marking one of the few occasions on which the Treasury has refused to honor genuine American currency, Secretary Morgenthau announced today that some $300,000 of $50, $100, $500 and $1,000 bills which had been shipped from Axis-occupied countries to the Dominican Republic would not be allowed to enter the United States.

Wendell L. Willkie declared last night that he doubted he would ever again seek public office, since to do so might attach a "taint of self-interest" to the causes he is advocating that this nation pursue. He made it clear that the principal cause at present is the preservation of democracy in this country, with particular reference to rights of minorities.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 17 -- The Foreign Ministry announced today the receipt of a note delivered to the Argentine Embassy in Berlin yesterday in which the German Government acknowledged responsibility for the torpedoing of the Argentine tanker Victoria off the United States coast just two months ago.

The City Planning Commission approved plans yesterday for the post-war construction of a low-rent housing project to be called Lillian Wald Houses. The houses will be built on a site bounded by East River Drive, East Houston Street, Avenue D and Sixth Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 17 -- Rosalind Russell will be starred in "Portrait of a Lady," an unproduced stage comedy by Alexander King and Chester Erskin, which was purchased the other day by RKO. The plot deals with a husband's efforts to win his wife away from a business career.
CHUNGKING, June 17 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command issued this communique today:

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., June 17 -- Golfers of the New York Stock Exchange today swept the semi-annual tournament of the Wall Street Golf Association, at the Rockville Country Club, winning not only the Charles R. Gay Cup for team play but most of the individual prizes.

The $1,000 prize offered by Artists for Victory, Inc., for a statue to symbolize "Wings for Victory -- The Spirit of Aviation," was awarded yesterday to Thomas Lo Medico, 134 West Twenty-third Street.

VICHY, June 17 -- A decree issued today imposes penalties of extreme severity for persons responsible, willfully or through negligence, for the loss of food supplies. Government employes will be held strictly responsible and will be liable to loss of their positions and to prison terms.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Roosevelt may remain neutral in the contest for the New York Democratic Gubernatorial nomination, it was indicated today by Edward J. Flynn, Democratic national chairman, who held two conferences with the Chief Executive.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The White House contributed nearly 400 pounds of scrap rubber today to the national collection campaign, its gifts including several sections of old garden hose, rubber floor runners and sponge rubber floor pads used under rugs, old and discarded overshoes and one rubber ball.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Abuse of the right of free Americans to criticize their government was assailed tonight by Archibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress and director of the Office of Facts and Figures, as a force which may destroy that very right.

An American born on Flag Day, 1915, yesterday told how when the order came to abandon the torpedo-torn aircraft carrier Lexington the men converging on the escape ropes performed virtually an Alphonse-Gaston act.

Price Administrator Leon Henderson is being asked by the Gasoline Merchants of Brooklyn and Queens, Inc., to reconsider penalties imposed on eight gasoline dealers in the New York and six in the Philadelphia areas for selling gasoline without punching ration cards, Louis Kimmel, business manager of the association, announced yesterday.

VICHY, France, June 17 (AP) -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, 86-year-old Chief of State, acknowledged on this second anniversary of his suit for the armistice with Germany that "discontent is growing" and "anger is rumbling" in France.

The New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad issued yesterday a report which, showed that because of taxes it had a smaller net income in the first five months of this year than in the same period last year, although its gross revenues for the period had increased $10,000,000.

IT'S a little early to be looking for punts soaring over the gridiron, but hundreds of fast-stepping backs and husky linemen will be in camp early this season. In fact, some of them are there now. With famous coaches to train them, too. It's on account of Hitler and Hirohito, not to mention Mussolini.

It rained at the start, it sprinkled during the intermission and it rained again during the second part of the program, nevertheless Edwin Franko Goldman and his band opened their twenty-fifth season of outdoor concerts last night on the Mall in Central Park and a loyal but small audience remained to the end to enjoy and applaud.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Army Air Force has side-tracked civilian facilities, capable of giving, preliminary pilot training to an estimated 180,000 youths a year, While it is spending $312,000,000 to build its own facilities, according to a survey to be published tomorrow by the American Aviation Daily.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 17 -- Midshipmen of the first class at the Naval Academy, who were rushed through the usual four years of academic work in three years because of the need for them in, the fleet, continued today their last round of social activity before becoming fighting men.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I thank you for the editorial in your issue of June 10, "A Test of Freedona." The 5-4 decision of the Supreme Court which you criticize so soundly puts it within the power of local authorities to ban any active church or sect, by license fees or other forms of taxation.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Pacific War Council received from President Roosevelt today an encouraging report on the general war situation and a prediction of possible good news in the future in the shipping situation, which is the most important bottleneck in the war effort of all the United Nations.

With offerings scarce, substantial demand by New Orleans interests and trade support lifted cotton prices 26 to 34 points yesterday. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active contracts were 27 to 29 points, or $1.35 to $1.45 a bale, above those of the preceding day.

Postmaster General Frank S. Walker announced yesterday that the Postoffice Department, in cooperation with the War and Navy Departments, had begun the new V-Mail service for the handling of mail to and from our armed forces outside the Continental United States.
BERLIN, June 17 (from German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

The proposal that the larger industrial plants of the country share the technique of their successful safety programs with smaller plants to aid the war program was made in the winning essay selected yesterday by the American Museum of Safety.

Beginning today, women volunteers of the New York Red Cross chapter's motor corps will do all the daytime driving of all ambulances at Knickerbocker Hospital, Major Gen. Robert C. Davis, executive director of me chapter, announced yesterday.

HONOLULU, June 17 -- Speaking from the deck of a combat ship just before he awarded medals for acts of bravery in air and sea actions against the Japanese, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, today lauded the fighting qualities of the men who spearheaded the American attacks in the Pacific.

The cosmetics industry was urged yesterday to continue the "good job" it has been doing in conservation and use of substitute materials, by C. A. Willard, chief of the toiletries and cosmetics branch of the War Production Board, in an address at the closing session of the annual convention of the Toilet Goods Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The index is based on spot market prices. Moat of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

The bitter joke about the place of "the old school tie" in British life will lose some of its point if action reported this week to the House of Commons is followed up. The "old school," by an inversion which seems strange to us but natural to the British, is the "public school" of the Eton, Harrow and Rugby type, or what we should call a private school.

The United States will be asked to turn over some of its new merchant ships to the Norwegians, who have experienced, idle seamen ready to man any type of tonnage, according to Arne Sunde, Minister of Supply and Shipping of the Norwegian Government in London, who arrived yesterday by air at La Guardia Field after crossing the North Atlantic in an unconvoyed freighter flying his country's flag.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Further piecing out the pattern of wage stabilization which it is seeking to frame, the National War Labor Board ruled today that a company's assertion of inability to pay a wage increase could not be given controlling weight "in the absence of a showing that all possible economies in other cost divisions of the industry have been made."

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill authorizing the construction of a barge canal across Northern Florida and at least two pipe lines designed to transport 90,000 to 250,000 barrels of oil a day from the oil fields of Texas and Mississippi to the Eastern seaboard.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 17 -- The four United States bombers forced down in Turkey last Friday were part of a force of fifteen planes that raided storage tanks and oil refineries at Ploesti, Rumania, setting enormous fires and causing damage that will take the Germans months to repair, it was revealed tonight.

Too Much Beauty? Possibly this column is not alone in thinking that the pictures of people buying bonds could do with fewer Broadway beauties and with more coal miners and truck drivers and factory operatives.

MELBOURNE, Thursday, June 18 (U.P.) -- Eighteen Japanese heavy bombers, escorted by nine Zero fighters, yesterday attacked the harbor area of Port Moreshy, United Nations outpost In Southeastern New Guinea, but two of the raiders, were shot down, a United Nations communique announced today.

Bespectacled Bobby Ginn, the Nebraska junior, who last Saturday came from behind with a tremendous finishing kick to Win the N.C.A.A. mile championship, defeating Leroy Weed and Leslie MacMitchell, and a number of other outstanding track and field stars, arrived yesterday for tomorrow's and Saturday's national junior and senior championships to be held at Randalls Island for the benefit of Army Emergency Relief.

To protect holders of equipment trust certificates of the Chicago North Western Railway in the event that the War Production Board interfere in the rolling stock to be bought with proceeds of the certificates, Guy A. Thomson, trustee in bankruptcy of that road, proposed yesterday to insurance companies and banks here optional changes in the terms of the loan.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the Segal Lock and Hardware Company, Inc., its subsidiary, Norwalk Lock Company, and Louis Segal, president of both corporations, to cease and desist from misrepresentations in the sale of a lock cylinder designated the "Segal pick-proof," and from unfairly disparaging competing products.
CHICAGO, June 17 -- This is the story of the aircraft carrier Lexington's last hours.

Commonwealth Edison Directors of the Commonwealth Edison Company announced yesterday a quarterly dividend of 35 cents a share, against 45 cents paid in all previous quarters since November, 1939. The board, in a statement, called attention to the fact that in April it stated that subsequent dividends would have to be reasonably related to the year's earnings.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Elmer Davis was sworn in today as director of the new Office of War Information about the same time that announcement was made at the White House that President Roosevelt had appointed Milton S. Eisenhower, former press chief of the Department of Agriculture, as Mr. Davis's deputy director in charge of administrative matters.

TORONTO, June 17 (AP) -- Toronto climbed back Into the first division tonight as Joe Sullivan and Nick Strincevich hurled four-hit games to beat the Jersey City Giants, 2 -- 1 and 4 -- 0. It was Strincevich's fourth shutout.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The long-awaited campaign to induce housewives to save and sell excess kitchen fats to augment the nation's glycerine supply will get under way early in July.

Existence of a Federal grand jury investigation of the supposedly defunct German-American Bund, indicated by the suicide in Indiana of a former high official of that organization, was confirmed here yesterday by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa.

More than 400,000 war bond pledges, or better than one-fifth of the 2,000,000 set as their ten-day goal, had been garnered last night by Greater New York's 200,000 Minute Men. This average of 200,000 pledges for each of the two days of' canvassing indicates the Minute Men will achieve their ultimate objective of $1,900,000,000, or drive beyond it.

UNITED NATIONS AIRDROME, in North Africa, June 17 (AP) -- Veteran Royal Air Force pilots today told how they had flown through the heaviest anti-aircraft barrage they had ever experienced to score direct hits on an Italian battleship, a cruiser and a destroyer already crippled by United States bombers.

A census of underworld informers was being taken last night by the police on the chance that the victim of a trunk murder, discovered early yesterday morning in Brooklyn, was a stool-pigeon who had fallen into the hands of gangster executioners.
BALTIMORE, June 17 -- Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, advocated tonight a cooling-off period after the war before final peace terms are made.

LONDON, June 17 -- The war is costing Britain about u9,750,000 daily in the fighting and supply forces alone, Sir Kingsley Wood, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today. The total expenditure of the British Government now is running about u12,000,000 daily, he said.

The formation by Mayor La Guardia of a special committee for wartime care of children in New York City was announced last night by Welfare Commissioner William Hodson at a conference of the Committee for the Care of Young Children in Wartime at the Hotel Edison, 228 West Forty-seventh Street.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 17 -- Emphasizing that the war confronts the German people with the "problem of the complete solution of its destiny." Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the Reich Propaganda Minister, addressing a gathering of party functionaries in Berlin late last night asserted that the prospects for the United Nations since Japan's entry into the war have "materially worsened."

BERLIN, June 17 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German and Rumanian siege armies around Sevastopol have "largely extended" their breaches in the Russian defense system and thrust deep new wedges into the fortified lines, but are meeting "bitter resistance and difficulties of terrain," the German High Command asserted today.
CAIRO, June 17 (AP) -- The British Headquarters communique said today:

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Eleven more persons, including Dr. Edward C. Elliott, president of Purdue University, and Raymond Rubicam, New York advertising executive, have been appointed to the War Manpower Commission by Paul V. McNutt.

Harold Campbell's death in the full strength of his powers and his usefulness is a memorable public loss. Such a post as his, as he filled it, is of far higher moment and longer influence than most political offices. His first teaching was at 19. Aside from the time given to his own education, he was for all his adult life a teacher or an administrator in the public schools.

We are fighting in the Mediterranean. The full story of the four-day fight is not yet told, but it is plain that a great naval battle has taken place. Cargo ships have been sunk in two convoys making a daring race under Axis guns to reinforce the hard-pressed garrisons of Malta and TobruK.

UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE, in Egypt, June 17 -- Happy as high school boys after a successful football game, American Army air officers -- youngsters and veterans together -- described today the bombing attack in the Mediterranean in which they seriously damaged two Italian battleships, helped to sink a cruiser and played a material part in getting two British convoys to their destinations.
LONDON, June 17 (U.P.) -- It is understood that if the improved
LONDON, June 17 -- Further evidence of Nazi nervousness over the prospect of an Allied invasion in the west reached Free French headquarters in London today.

The Cardinals, moving along under a full head of steam at long last, will chug into Ebbets Field today with a seven-game winning streak. The Redbirds supplied the last portion of that string at the Polo Grounds yesterday when Mort Cooper blanked the Giants, 3 to 0.

ST. LOUIS, June 17 (AP) -- The national clay court tennis championship became the national asphalt court tennis tournament temporarily today as the event finally began on hard-playing surfaces after two postponements because of the weather.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 17 (AP) -- Nazi desert forces, now superior in tank and anti-tank strength, smashed southeast of Tobruk today in an attempt to isolate that British garrison from land supplies, but the shock of their initial assault broke against the resistance of the British Eighth Army and its R.A.F. support.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 17 -- Concrete Signs of internal opposition to Reichsfuehrer Hitler are contained in supplementary reports received at the Adolf Hitler Leibstandarte S.S. Barracks at the Berlin suburb of Gross Lichterfelde to the effect that the 258 persons executed there a few days ago for an alleged bomb plot at an anti-Soviet exhibit included twenty-five "Communists."

The Dodgers used only an hour and forty-three minutes to beat the Cuba, 5 -- 1, at Ebbets Field yesterday and even the short series. Their lead over the second-place Cardinals remains at four and a half games.
BALTIMORE, June 17 -- Following is the text of the address made here tonight by Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State:
Purchases by Irving Maidman of three properties on the West Side from the North River Savings Bank were announced yesterday. Mr. Maidman also reported that he had sold a garage on Tenth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, today lowered prices of woolen and worsted fabrics for men's and women's suits and overcoats in many instances at the manufacturing and jobbing levels through a special seasonal pricing formula and announced there was no further reason for delaying their flow to garment makers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Arthur Livingston writes about my new book, "The Real Italians," In THE TIMES of June 14, for which I am grateful to him even when he disagrees with some of my interpretations: "Count Sforza * * * recommends that Italians here preserve their original cultural background.

CHUNGKING, China, June 17 (U.P.) -- Chinese and other Allied intelligence reports of Japanese planes streaming northward in large numbers from invaded areas in Southeast Asia to Japan and Manchukuo strengthen the belief that a Japanese attack on Russia is imminent.

One of the reasons that national advertisers have approved the OPA ruling that advertising allowances need not be continued lies in the fact that they are anxious to eliminate all of the so-called marginal media which have developed in recent years and which have begun to take larger proportions of the advertising budgets.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The War Shipping Administration formed a division of maritime labor relations today to implement its recently announced policy of dealing with unions in the maritime field.

LONDON, June 17 (U.P.) -- General Draja Mikhailovitch's Yugoslav patriot armies, the leading force in the revolt in occupied Europe, have captured 1,500 Axis troops and an artillery battery in a new-outbreak of heavy fighting in the mountainous provinces of Bosnia, Hercegovia and Montenegro, the Yugoslav Government in London reported tonight.
The enemy's war of attrition in our coastal waters is continuing to make serious inroads upon our offensive capacity.

Yesterday, on the second anniversary of his surrender to Hitler, Petain spoke to the French people. It was a strange little speech, filled with abject confessions of loss of confidence in his own regime and of the complete failure of the armistice he sought to bring real peace to France.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Roosevelt signed today legislation which gives the buck private in the American Army and an apprentice seaman in the Navy a basic salary of $50 per month, making them the highest paid soldiers and sailors in the world.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 17 -- To facilitate conversion of New York City garment shops for the production of war garments and accessories to provide work for thousands of workers made idle by priorities and other dislocations arising from war conditions, the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union voted today to cooperate with the employers in any steps taken to achieve the desired objective.

WITH BRITISH MERITERRANEAN FLEET, June 16 (Delayed) -- Every available Axis war machine has been turned loose in these last few days of blazing hostilities in the Mediterranean and they have been out for bigger game than a couple of British convoys.

AN EAST COAST PORT, June 17 (U.P.) -- Forty-one seamen died in the Caribbean sinking by Axis submarines of two United States merchantmen flying Central American flags, and seven others still are missing on a raft somewhere south of Cuba, survivors reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Roosevelt has written a letter to Paul V. McNutt, Director of the Office of Defense Health and Welfare Services, calling on all public and private agencies to aid in the establishment of total physical and moral fitness.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 17 (AP) -- The Newark Bears gained an even break in their four-game series with the Rochester Red Wings by pounding out an 8-5 victory tonight.

Entertaining as well as educational, the new 16 mm. motion picture, "The Making of a Shooter," now available to sportsmen's, boys' and other interested groups through, the Sporting Arms and Ammunition Manufacturers Institute, likely will have a wide appeal.
CHICAGO, June 17 -- Golf, which has been doing its bit by sniping away at the Axis here and there, now is ready to launch its major attack on the foes of democracy.
LONDON, June 17 -- It was acknowledged tonight that the British had suffered a considerable loss in getting supplies through to Malta and Tobruk during the recent air-sea battle in the Mediterranean.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Soy beans continued today to set the pace in the grain markets, the July moved up 2 3/4 cents a bushel, an upturn of 12 cents from the low of last week. Final trades were at the top. Distant months gained 1 1/4. to 1 1/2 cents.
ROME, June 17 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

There has just been published in England a symposium volume based on the seventeenth international congress of the P.E.N., which was held in London last September. The bitterness expressed at the sessions of the international writers' group is reflected in the volume, which is titled "Writers in Freedom."

LONDON, June 17 --The stock markets were quiet but firm today at yesterday's lower levels except the oils which continued to weaken on the news from Libya. There was a rally, however, toward the close.

LONDON, June 17 -- The Royal Air Force took to its wings again last night to bomb industrial targets of the Ruhr and Rhineland after a week of inactivity. Eight aircraft failed to return, indicating that the attack might have been fairly heavy. In these operations one German fighter was shot down.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Ways and Means Committee voted tentatively today to tax freight and express, parimutuel wagering, extend the levy on coin-operated devices, and raise the second-class postage rates for newspapers and periodicals, except county weeklies.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY, in Libya, June 16 (delayed) (U.P.) -- Batteries of new 3 1/2-inch anti-tank guns, rushed across the Mediterranean during the Axis air bombings of Malta, enabled Field Marshal Erwin Rommel to break the British desert line and drive to within sight of Tobruk.
PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (AP) -- Pittsburgh's Pirates shelled two pitchers at will tonight to lambast the Phils, 6-1, before a crowd of 3,804.

CHUNGKING, China, June 17 -- The Chinese acknowledged tonight the loss of Shangjao, an important station on the 450-mile Hangchow-Nanchang Railway, but declared heavy fighting was in progress. Two Japanese columns, one moving westward and the other eastward, lack only about fifty miles of capturing the entire railroad.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Recent charges made by retailers that an "army of snoopers" was proposed by the Office of Price Administration to enforce its orders are false and misleading, David Ginsburg, general council of OP A, declared tonight at the convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Palmer House.
ST. LOUIS, June 17 (AP) -- Three streaks ended today as the Browns defeated the Red Sox, 6 -- 3.

DETROIT, June 17 -- The strange, unwelcome experience of a shut-out came to the Yankees today at Briggs Stadium for the first time since the 1942 campaign got under way. The Tigers did it, 1 to 0, scoring the lone run on a ninth-inning hit by Ned Harris.

"The Cat Screams," Martha Hodge's first attempt as a theatrical producer, will vacate the Martin Beck after Saturday night's performance. According to a spokesman for the management, the production represents an investment of about $15,000.
Henrique Santos of the New York Athletic Club became the new national epee fencing champion when he won eight bouts and lost three on the strips of the Salle Santelli last night.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, the largest operating utility in the country, joined yesterday the list of corporations seeking relief from what they consider the "drastic provisions" of pending tax legislation.
The city government and Columbia University combined yesterday to do honor to New York's royal visitor, King George II of Greece.

Net sales of Remington Rand, Inc., rose to $77,282,536 in the fiscal year ended on March 31, from $49,173,969 in the previous year, according to the fifteenth annual pamphlet report issued for publication today.
Pershing Square Information Center for Civilian Defense was nearly as busy as Grand Central Station yesterday noon.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Elmer Davis, the head of the new Office of War Information, continued today to stress news as the product expected of him by the public and the press. Repeating what he said when informed of his appointment, Mr. Davis committed himself to "get as much news as possible, as speedily as possible and as accurately as possible."

In an effort to save the jobs of 125 high school teachers whose positions were voted out of the Board of Education budget on June 10 as an economy measure, it was learned last night, Mayor La Guardia has suggested to members of the board that "superannuated and physically disabled teachers" should be the first to go.
BERLIN, June 18 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique today said:

DETROIT, June 18 -- The Yankees made the acquaintance of Virgil Trucks today at Briggs Stadium, and they were agreed tonight that if the introduction had been delayed indefinitely it would have been just as well.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 18 (AP) -- British Headquarters issued this communique today:
CLEVELAND, June 18 (AP) -- The battery of Catcher Jake Early and Pitcher Early Wynn led the Senators to a 7-to-1 victory over the Indians today, giving Washington an even split in a two-game series.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On June 1 the commander of this corps area issued a strict order for the dimming of lights in our city and adjacent areas. This order replaced an order issued on April 27. The full text of the order was published by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Albert H. Gordon of Kidder, Peabody Co. was elected yesterday president of the Bond Club of New York at its annual meeting at the Bankers Club. He succeeds J. Taylor Foster of Spencer Trask Co.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 18 -- The emergency landing of American bombers on Turkish territory was coming more actively within the range of German official and editorial comment today, and the incident was being exploited as an American attempt to force Turkey into the war through "extortion and pressure."

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Average prices for most industrial commodities in primary markets during the week ended on June 13 continued with little change for the fifth consecutive week since the effective date of the General Maximum Price Regulation.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 18 -- The 611 midshipmen who will receive their diplomas tomorrow, exceeding by thirty the Naval Academy's record class of 1939, participated today in the traditional "Presentation of the Colors."

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 13 -- Heretofore impenetrable reaches of the Southern Venezuelan jungle and the vast Amazon basin will be brought to within easy distance of civilization this year if the Venezuelan Government adopts a transportation plan so revolutionary it might have been considered fantastic four years ago.

The Giants filled an off day in their schedule yesterday by journeying to Brooklyn and defeating a soldier team from Fort Hamilton, 17 to 6. Festivities were called off by agreement after seven innings.

There will be sixteen weeks of performances by the Metropolitan Opera Association next season, and the price scale will be reduced, according to an announcement made yesterday by Edward Johnson, general manager. The season will open on Nov. 23.

In eleven minutes yesterday afternoon a General Sessions jury found Frank Castellano, 25 years old, an ex-convict, guilty of murder in the first degree for shooting Patrolman Thomas J. Casey at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-second Street last Dec. 6.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- An amendment to the government's labor transfer policy for the auto- mobile industry, designed to facili- tate employment of trained work- ers at their top skills, was announced jointly today by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, and Don- ald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Prices of grains and soy beans turned downward today on the Board of Trade on selling induced by Secretary of Agriculture Wickard's radio ad- dress last night in which he ex- pressed opposition to proposed legislation in Congress seeking 100 per cent of parity loans on major agricultural products.

BUFFALO, June 18 (AP) -- Frankie Kelleher's thirteenth home run of the season, with a mate aboard in the seventh inning, provided the margin by which the league-leading Newark Bears were able to down the Bisons tonight, 9 to 7, after the locals staged a rally good for seven runs to force a deadlock in the fourth inning.

In an interview at Bombay Pandit Nehru echoes the cry of Gandhi that Britain "withdraw from India." Unhappily, recent experience has shown how much easier it is to give this advice than to create the conditions in which it would become possible to act on it.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The State Department announced tonight the following list of American diplomats and newspapermen whose names have been received through Swiss authorities from Japanese officials to be repatriated from Japanese controlled territory in the Far East, excepting the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Ques- tions and answers, giving interpre- tations of the effect of the General Maximum Price Regulation on different commodities and services, were released today by the OPA. The Q. and A. covers milk, dis- counts, Army and Navy uniforms, premiums and other topics.

From the welter of lotions, powders and potions devised in the last few months for the benefit of feminine pulchritude a gallery of favorites has been culled from the scrap book during a leisurely hour. Our choice fell upon the coolest cosmetics in town -- the sort that will make you feel like a frosted icicle while the rest of the world melts.

Check exchanges in twentythree major cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $7,170,990,000, an increase of 12.4 per cent over the volume reported for the previous week and 1.4 per cent ahead of the corresponding week in 1941 when the total was $7,069,600,000, according to figures announced yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Robert B. Irwin, executive director of the American Foundation for the Blind, proposed yesterday that the Federal Government finance a program of training men blinded in the war, working through private agencies already in existence.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The battle of the North pacific, which began with the smashing United States air victory over the Japanese Navy near Midway Island and has flared tip in sparsely reported contacts off the Aleutian Islands, may still be continuing in the open ocean where ships have been out of contact with land-based planes, Secretary of War Stimson indicated today.

PITTSBURGH, June 18 -- Eight hundred members of the United Electrical Radio and Machine Workers (C.I.O.) caused suspension of defense work at two plants of the Pittsburgh Equitable Meter Company today by failure to report to work.

Mike M. Masoka, national secretary of the Japanese-American Citizens, declared yesterday at a meeting of the Post War World Council called to discuss the question of Japanese evacuation that "we are a test of democracy." Referring to the Japanese evacuation on the West Coast, he said, "If they do that to one group, they can do that to other groups."
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Harold D. Smith, budget director, revealed today that America's arms factories were so busy now that government war expenditures had climbed to about $1,000,000,000 a week.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The War Production Board's textile, clothing and leather branch made known today that it is considering a plan submitted by its woolen and worsted industry advisory committee under which manufacturers who blend new wool with cotton, rayon or reprocessed woolen fibers will receive "bonuses" by getting more new wool for civilian uses.

United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, chairman of the policy committee appointed to advise Representative Michael J. Kennedy, leader of Tammany, said yesterday that he expected to call a meeting of the committee the week after next.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Legislation designed to plug loopholes in pre-war laws protecting the civilian rights of men serving in the armed forces was passed by the House today and sent to the Senate.

Every once in a while we feel a pleasant compulsion to take notice of that typically American Institution, the Sunday night supper. In our opinion it is a meal that is best served in casual, help-yourself fashion. And when we have our way about it, there are candles and flowers and, above all, a menu that is simplicity itself to prepare.

CHUNGKING, China, July 18 -- The China Transport Corporation, which is authorized to handle all non-military passenger and freight traffic in Southwest China, recently purchased five hundred charcoal burners and two hundred gas cylinders to convert trucks from gasoline.

Officials of Paramount Pictures, Inc., who made payments out of company funds to Willie Bioff, former Hollywood representative of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, A. F. of L., acted in the best interest of the company, to forestall any labor difficulties, despite the fact that many directors were ignorant of the payments during a five-year period, Adolph Zukor, chairman of the board of Paramount, testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Defense Transportation Director, Joseph B. Eastman, appealed tonight for voluntary deferment for the duration of all meetings, conventions, group tours, country fairs and kindred events not related to the war efforts.

LONDON, June 18 (AP) -- The British Broadcasting Corporation told the Czechs in a broadcast from London tonight that the Nazis had "decided to discover" the assailants of Reinhard Heydrich after realizing that their threats of heavy reprisals were "in vain."

Activity by New Orleans operators directly swayed the cotton futures market yesterday, with their buying reflected in early gains of as much as 8 points and their late selling almost completely instrumental in posting losses of 17 to 22 points for active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The first day of a three-day Conference on Education of the Exceptional in the War and the Posf-War Emergency, the main purpose of which is to draft proposals which the Federal Government may act upon to use "exceptional" persons in the war effort, was held yesterday at Teachers College, Columbia University.

TRENTON, June 18 -- The State Board of Tax Appeals ruled today that the Woman's Club of Little Falls and the Forum Club of Madison were tax exempt under a recent State Supreme Court decision exempting college fraternities from taxation.

CHUNGKING, China, June 18 (U.P.) -- United States bombers will fly to China and, under the command of Colonel C.V. Haynes, will take up permanent stations within striking distance of Japan as soon as United Nations air strength in India is considered adequate, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (U.P.) -- The Swedish motor ship Gripsholm, bearing Japanese officials and nationals who will be exchanged for Americans who have been interned in the Far East, sailed tonight from New York, it was announced by the State Department.

Since about 75 per cent of the Fall woolen and worsted requirements of the larger clothing houses have been delivered, these clothing manufacturers will benefit very little from the rollback provided in Maximum Price Regulation No. 163, covering woolen and worsted civilian apparel fabrics, they said, yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 18 -- The Chamber of Deputies, at a brief secret session today, decided to forego the exposition of Argentina's foreign policy it had requested of Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu. The Deputies took the stand that no explanation was worth listening to that could not be made available to the Argentine public.

OTTAWA, June 18 -- Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands arrived in Ottawa today by plane from Great Britain. She will remain only a few days before going to Lee, Mass., where her daughter, Princess Juliana, has rented a home for the Summer.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A decision to send the largest tax bill in history to the floor of the House by July 6 was reached today by the Ways and Means Committee. It was indicated that the measure will provide for an increase of about $6,640,100,000 in revenue, which would be $2,060,000,000 less than the Treasury requested.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Secretary Ickes said today that everything possible was being done to expedite building of the twentyfour-inch Texas-Illinois pipeline completion of which by Dec. 1 is relied on to relieve somewhat the fuel-oil shortage in the Eastern States.

Ellsworth B. Buck, vice president of the Board of Education, declared yesterday that the suggestions offered by Mayor La Guardia for saving the jobs of the 125 high school teachers slated for dismissal had been considered carefully but it seemed unlikely the dismissals could be averted.

MOSCOW, Friday, June 19 -- Russian armies fighting from recaptured trenches repulsed fresh attacks at Sevastopol and inflicted new heavy losses in German ranks yesterday, it was announced today as the city's besieged people flashed word to the outside world that they would "die to the last soul" before surrendering.

A total of 248 tons of scrap rubber has been collected in the metropolitan area since the start of the nation-wide rubber salvage campaign on Monday, Eugene F. McCabe, chairman of the oil industry's scrap committee, announced last night.

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 18 -- Ensign John J. Tidmarsh, scouting plane pilot, and Raymond G. Green, radioman, who were down twelve hours on a stormy sea when their plane fell about two weeks ago, have arrived here on the Argentine steamer Rio Segundo, which went five days out of her course to land the rescued men on United States soil.

If Army nurses are not the "best dressed" of their calling, the Army Quartermaster Corps will be genuinely disappointed, for its officials have really racked their brains to provide a complete outfit for the front-line Florence Nightingales.

Summer sessions will be held at private high schools this year from July 6 to Aug. 21, according to an announcement yesterday by Ernest Greenwood, president of the Association of Private Summer High Schools.

ALBANY, June 18 -- Modifying an order of the Appellate Division, first department, the Court of Appeals ruled today that the New York City Board of Education had the right to assign out-of-license teachers to conduct junior high school classes.

LONDON, June 18 (U.P.) -- Two weeks ago the British Imperial Army in Libya was on the verge of smashing the German Africa Corps of Field Marshal Erwin Rommel in a narrow desert pocket southwest of Tobruk. Today Marshal Rommel is laying siege to Tobruk and the bulk of the British Eighth Army faces a flight to Egypt to avoid destruction.

CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- With receipts smaller than expected, prices rose today about 10 cents a hundredweight. The top was $14.45, highest in two weeks. In the dressed pork market prices were at cellings. Shipments of cattle also were down and the market was active and firm. A top of $14.65 was paid for choice yearlings, Lambs eased.
LONDON, June 18 -- The markets today maintained a firm tone. Inasmuch as most sections are still short of stock, it is easier to sell than to buy and the list hardened before the close.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 18 -- The German Gestapo vigilantes announced tonight that they had succeeded "in the early hours of this morning" in capturing and killing the authors of the fatal attack upon Deputy Reich Protector Reinhard Heydrich.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- In the new Navy bill which the House committee has approved there are provisions for building 1,000 small craft to fight the Axis submarines. This is good news, as it is also good news that the current production rate of the P.C. patrol vessels for submarine lanes is mounting.

Defense Area Retailers Active Retailers located in defense areas have been actively placing orders for Fall coats and suits during the past week, resident buyers here re- ported yesterday. These stores were said to be already selling a substantial volume of this mer- chandise.

They Mount Up Some of the war bond campaign advertisements in the press are more effective than others. An extremely effective full-page display was the one in yesterday's paper. It showed the nickels, dimes, quarters and dollars of the plain American people drip, drip, dripping down on the unattractive skulls of the Fuehrer, II Duce and the Mikado.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in two addresses here yesterday pleaded for unity in the ranks of labor and again appealed to members of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to return to the fold of the A.F. of L. parent.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 18 -- Warning that the split in organized labor would seriously jeopardize its gains and its entire position in the emergency that might be expected to arise after the war, the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers' Union urged today the immediate resumption of peace negotiations between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of industrial Organizations.

RICHMOND, Va., June 18 (AP) -- Governor Darden granted a thirteen-day reprieve today to Odell Waller, 25-year-old Negro who is under sentence of death for the slaying of his white landlord. This will allow a hearing on a plea for commutation of the sentence.

LONDON, June 18 -- The fact that the situation in Libya is extremely grave and that the war at sea is going badly for the United Nations came up in the House of Commons today in such a way as to reflect growing impatience with the government's policy of shielding the public from the grim facts of the war.

"EVEN with victory, after the dreadful degenerations of these thirty years of war, revolution and disorder, if Western Civilization is to be saved from another relapse into the Dark Ages, it must be saved at the peace table. Never will humanity need more objectivity, more tolerance and more vision, more open and more prayerful minds. * * * But we will not win lasting peace unless we prepare for it.
The tide of men and machines ebbed and flowed along the vast Russian front yesterday without material change in position or major action by either side.

A REMARKABLE record is in the making and will go on the books as soon as the accountants have checked up on the total receipts in connection with the holding of the National A.A.U. track and field championships at the Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island today and tomorrow. It's an entrancing story for those who love sports in general and have a fancy for track and field athletics in particular.

MOSCOW, June 18 -- The Supreme Soviet, Russia's Parliament, at its first meeting since the war began, tonight formalized the people's acceptance of the treaty with Britain and, linked with it, the agreements documented in the Washington and London pronouncements.
CHUNGKING, China, June 18 (AP) -- A Chinese communique said today:

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (AP) -- Edgar Bergen, whose "dummy" friend, Charlie McCarthy, has been asking for an increase in his allowance of 75 cents a week, received $282,000 for his radio work in 1941 from Standard Brands, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The War Department said today that the number of regular Army officers on desk duty in Washington would be sharply reduced. Many officers would be sent to the field and their work would be taken over by qualified persons chosen by the Army Specialist Corps.

The helicopter will bear the same relationship to the airliner in post-war transportation that the automobile has borne to the railroad, Igor Sikorsky, aircraft designer, said last night in picturing a future in which suburban and rural dwellers would keep the odd-shape flying machines behind their homes and city residents would go aloft from handy parking lots or roof-tops.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The American heavy bombers that attacked the Italian fleet in the Mediterranean on June 15 in cooperation with Royal Air Force units scored repeated direct hits on the Italian battleships Littorio and Conte di Cavour, the War Department reported here tonight.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, reserve note circulation and holdings of United States Government securities to be at the highest of the year to date, the latter showing an increase of $11,000,000 for the week.

LONDON, June 18 -- The Battle of Libya has narrowed now to a battle for Tobruk. If that goes against the British, it will become a battle for Egypt. That is the plain meaning that expert observers read into tonight's news from the Middle East.
BOSTON, June 18 Off)-Mrs. William R. Fleming's Loveday beat five horses at Suffolk Downs today to win the $1,500 Priority Purse at a mile and seventy yards.

Preparations are being made to accommodate a throng of deep-sea anglers in Nova Scotia starting early next month. The first run of giant tuna generally appears off the province's many miles of shoreline about the first week in July and that annually is the signal for a big influx of visitors.

A search for a mink coat and jewelry valued at more than $10,000 and their recovery under mysterious circumstances from a parcel safe in the Grand Central Terminal on information given in anonymous letters were disclosed yesterday in papers on file in Surrogate's Court.

A group of 50,000 volunteers is being recruited by the Office of Price Administration to explain the posting requirements of the price ceiling order to retail merchants in the five States covered by the New York regional office, Sylvan L. Joseph, regional director, announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 18 -- Lester Cowan, Columbia unit producer, today signed Merle Oberon to star in the screen version of "Heart of a City," Broadway play of last season by Lesley Storm, which Cowan has bought for $40,000.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The hitherto united front of employers on the National War Labor Board against union security clauses cracked today when two employers joined the public and labor members and for the first time voted for maintenance of union member- ship as a condition of employment.

Presidents and other top executives of forty-five of the principal business organizations of Illinois who make up the directorate of the Illinois Manufacturers Association, in a statement issued in Chicago yesterday, urged business nation- ally to continue advertising "for the duration" as a means of maintaining a free press, free enterprise and "fundamental rights of the public."

Wendell L. Willkie urged the Republican party in New York State yesterday to maintain an open mind in its selection of a State ticket in the Fall elections and to study the records of all available candidates to choose the strongest possible slate.

LONDON, June 18 (AP) -- The Bank of England's statement showed today a decrease of u543,000 in note circulation, the first drop in seventeen weeks. Other items increased, however, with public and private deposits improving.

STANTON, Del., June 18 -- Running right back to her excellent effort in the recent Delaware Oaka when she was a bang-up second to the crack filly Vagrancy, Joseph E. Widener's Waygal led all the way in the three-quarter-mile Corner Ketch Purse, feature race at Delaware Park today.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of June 11 you have an editorial entitled "Odell Waller: A Test Case."
With their financial and athletic success assured, the fifty-fifth annual National A.A.U. track and field championships will be staged at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island today and tomorrow.

MOSCOW, June 18 (AP) -- Thundering a vote of complete confidence, the Supreme Soviet, at its first wartime session, tonight ceremonially approved the British-Russian treaty after hearing Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff express the deep hope that the "common enemy soon will feel on his skin the mighty blows" of Russia, Britain and the United States.

Sinclair Lewis will resume teaching writing this Fall when he conducts a course at the University of Minnesota. In 1940 Mr. Lewis joined the faculty of the University of Wisconsin but after thirty-nine days his theatre preoccupations won out and he left Madison for New York.

General Douglas MacArthur, who numbers among his other honors the title of "outstanding American father of 1942," has sent a message to the National Father's Day Committee expressing the hope that his 4-year-old son, Arthur, will remember him not as a soldier but as a father saying daily prayers with his son.
A quartet made up of four baritones were an added attraction to the eighth annual American ballad contest for barber shop quartets held last night on the Mall in Central Park.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Crowded warehouses in some sections have forced the Office of Price Administration to consider a plan under which housewives could buy a year's allotment of sugar at one time, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The War Department issued this communique today:

The formal offering yesterday of $1,500,000,000 of Treasury fiveeighths of 1 per cent certificates of indebtedness, due on Feb. 1, 1943, coincided so closely with expectations that the market and the financial community generally took the announcement in stride and with a minimum of excitement.

OTTAWA, June 18 (Aneta) -- Queen Wilhelmina, who arrived here by plane from Great Britain today, will some time next week accompany Crown Princess Juliana and the latter's young daughters, Princesses Beatrix and Irene, to Lee, Mass., it was learned this afternoon.

Twenty-one consecutive years of fencing effort were rewarded last night when Warren Dow swept through fourteen straight bouts to win his first national foils championship on the strips of the Salle Santelli. In 1922, when he still was in high school, Dow began his quest of the crown.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 18 -- Mrs. Frank J. Holleran of Round Hill won low gross honors by the slim margin of one stroke in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association today. After a great outward nine of 38, she faltered and carded a 43 for an 81 over the Bonnie Briar course.

DETROIT, June 18 -- Because eight Negro employes, in accord- ance with their union seniority rights, had been assigned to ma- chines formerly operated by white workers, several thousand mem- bers of the United Automobile Workers-C.I.O. went out on a "wildcat strike" today, shutting down 60 per cent of the Hudson Naval Ordnance Arsenal.

Earning assets of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City fell $108,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

CHUNGKING, China, June 18 (UP) -- Japanese spearheads have reached Kweiki, at the western end of the still unoccupied fiftymile stretch of the strategic Hangchow-Nanchang Railroad, but Chinese forces have driven back into the outer defenses of Nanchang, Kiangsi terminus of the line, it was announced today.

Permission for Roman Catholics in the armed forces to attend masses afternoons and evenings, when prevented by military duties from doing so morning's, was announced yesterday by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman military vicar. The grant came in a decree from the Sacred Congregation of the Sacraments in the Vatican.

A miracle of scientific detection seemed to have been achieved last night when police announced they had obtained prints from seven of the fingers of the trunk murder victim whose charred body was found Wednesday morning in a lot near Fourth Avenue and Thirty-third Street, Brooklyn.

Three gunmen who interspersed hold-ups in the city last Winter with several burglaries of homes in Miami, Fla., entered guilty pleas yesterday before Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in General Sessions to a specific second-degree robbery charge.

With the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, urging widespread support of the USO, the Women's Division of the New York-USO-Joint War Appeal reported yesterday that it had raised 67 per cent of its $750,000 quota.

Price regulations made by the Office of Price Administration under the Emergency Price Control Act make a contract with the United States Government a "scrap of paper," it was charged yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers in a memorandum to members of Congress.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 18 -- Dried-up lake formations mined and processed by the British Tenth Army's engineers in Iraq are saving the Allied war effort many thousands of dollars and tens of thousands of tons of transport.

SYRACUSE, June 18 -- The State Industrial Union Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, torn by factional strife since the left-wing delegation walked out of its Rochester convention two years ago, found a new "middle-of-the-road" group holding the balance of power tonight as union representatives from all parts of the State gathered here for the opening of a two-day convention tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Four months of intensive war-time field manoeuvres, stressing desert and jungle fighting and joint operations by air and ground forces, will open for a large part of the expanding Army July 13.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- The legend of the remarkable Turnesas, golf's royal family, was kept alive today when Mike, pro at the Elmsford Club in White Plains, came in with a sensational 65, seven under par for the Ridgemoor course, to tie for the lead at the end of the first eighteen-hole round of the Hale America tournament, wartime substitute for the national open.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 18 -- Mrs. Anna H. Paton arranged as early as 1933 to reduce her relatives' share in her $1,300,000 estate and to leave substantial legacies to the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington and the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, witnesses testified today before Surrogate Charles D. Millard and a jury.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 13 totaled 832,726 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 21,963 cars or 2.6 per cent less than for the preceding week, and 30,248 cars or 3.5 per cent less than for the corresponding week last year, but 119,805 cars or 16.8 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Colliding head-on at Ebbets Field last evening, the runner-up Cardinals and league-leading Dodgers regaled a crowd of 23,643 fans with a bit of every sort of entertainment, the piece de resistance being a free-for-all fight on the field in the sixth inning and the joyous climax a 5-2 Brooklyn triumph in the ball game.

LONDON, June 18 -- Lewis Crommelin Masefield, 32-year-old son of the British poet laureate, John Masefield, was "killed in action far from home in recent fighting," while serving as a private in the British Army Medical Corps, officials announced today.

TRENTON, June 18 -- The last barrier to the opening of the track of the Garden State Racing Association near Camden was removed today when the State Supreme Court declined to review the constitutionality of the statute under which the State Racing Commission licensed the track for pari-mutuel betting.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today, after less than an hour's debate and with a 316-0 vote, an $8,550,000,000 naval expansion program giving emphasis to the aircraft carrier as the backbone of the modern fleet, and promising to put upon the seas by the end of 1946 a Navy that will surpass in ships and striking power "any combination of foes."

American European Securities The American European Securities Company voted yesterday a dividend of 25 cents a common share. The previous payment, an initial of 40 cents, was distributed in December, 1941.

LONDON, June 18 -- Dr. V.K. Wellington Koo, the Chinese Ambassador, declared emphatically today that the Chinese people would not lay down their arms, but instead would continue to fight on, even though they have had "nearly five years of trial and tribulation."

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission invoked death sentence proceedings today against the voting trustees of the common stock of the Central Public Utility Corporation, simultaneously with the announcement that the trustees had filed a voluntary plan for compliance with the clause.

Marking a significant change occasioned by wartime conditions, several Fifth Avenue stores will remain open Thursday evenings, beginning next week, it was announced yesterday. The new plan will bring night shopping into the upper Fifth Avenue area for the first time, except for brief holiday trade periods.

Diverse results from the Federal tax burden were reported by the Kansas City Southern and Pere Marquette railways yesterday. The Southwestern line showed record revenues and net operating income for May and the first five months of the year, although it accrued $425,000 income taxes in May against $16,000 in May, 1941.

Change of Heart The Securities and Exchange Commission has exhibited a change of heart in respect to the potential effectiveness, or usefulness, of securities dealers in carrying out some of the dissolution orders under the Holding Company Act that may open up a new and profitable field to the investment banking industry.

The practice of "cloaking," by which Latin-American consignees, often acting through third parties, seek to avoid the effects of blacklists, is one of the most difficult problems now facing the Board of Economic Warfare, Colonel F.R. Kerr, chief of the export control branch, Office of Exports, declared yesterday.

Betting swung to its two extremes at Aqueduct yesterday when 13,626 racegoers saw the longest and shortest priced winners of the New York season at well as the biggest daily double pay-off in this State since the inauguration of the mutuel form of betting in 1940.

The Theatre Authority has just distributed $20,000 among various theatrical charities, making a total of $150,000 disbursed in such a manner since its formation seven years ago, according to Alan Corelli, head of the T.A. The money went to Actors Equity, Chorus Equity, Screen Actors Guild, American Guild of Musical Artists, American Federation of Radio Artists, American Guild of Variety Artists, League of New York Theatres and the Authors League, each receiving $1,875.

Predictions that the United Nations would win the war against the Axis powers and that a new Greece would rise from the ashes of the old marked a formal city dinner given last night in honor of King George II of Greece at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The sea-air battle in and over the Mediterranean, following close upon the battles of Midway Island and of the Coral Sea, must still further modify opinion concerning the respective merits and role of the ship and the airplane as weapons of war. It was not so long ago that some of our admirals were still complacently believing that airplanes could not sink battleships.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- In a special report which Donald M. Nelson regarded as a reflection on his policy and which some Senators declared should not be published, the Truman committee charged today that the War Production Board had not fully measured up to its responsibility of converting the nation's industry to war production, and called on Mr. Nelson to demote some dollar-a-year men and promote labor and small business in the battle of production.

It was in 1936 that we first heard of a canal across Northern Florida. A ship canal was then proposed, to cost a probable $250,000,000 and to be constructed in ten to fifteen years. Largely because of the opposition of the Geological Survey, the Board of Engineers of Rivers and Harbors and PWA Congress took no action.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Leon Henderson said today that for the first time since November, 1940, the steady increase in living costs had been checked. This he declared, was a direct result of the general retail price ceiling which became effective May 18 and the accompanying measure to reduce rents in defense areas.

There is one group of women whom the war has made particularly unhappy. It has taken away from them their jobs. While they have obtained others, it is not the same. Formerly, as they worked, they watched the scenery change under their noses.

War bond pledges had bee signed by more than 500,000 residents of Greater New York by noon yesterday. This was reported by John T. Madden, chairman of the War Bond Pledge Campaign. He estimated the count would pass 600,000 today.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill of Great Britain arrived in the United States today for conferences with President Roosevelt on "the war, the conduct of the war and the winning of the war," the White House announced shortly after 8 o'clock tonight.

At the 171st charter day meeting of the Society of the New York Hospital it was announced yesterday that the Army unit of fifty-five doctors and 120 nurses of the New York Hospital and Cornell Medical College had been called into service and its personnel would report for active duty on July 15.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- De- partment store sales for the week ended June 13 were down 3 per cent from a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. For the four weeks ended June 13, there was a drop of 2 per cent.

The Stadium Concerts opened last night their twenty-fifth season. The program was conducted by Artur Rodzinski, and Arthur Rubinstein gave a masterly performance of Rachmaninoff's Second Piano Concerto with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

DURHAM, N.H., June 18 -- The General Council of the Congregational-Christian Churches at its biennial meeting here today revived the ancient custom of "owning the covenant" at a special service of communion.
ATLANTA, June 18 (AP) -- Governor Talmadge reckoned today that New York was "the most illiterate" State in the nation.

An exhibition made up of 149 entries submitted by sculptors living in many States is now open at the Whitney Museum, where the work will remain on view until the end of the month. During this period the museum will be open daily except Sundays and Mondays.

Elbridge Manning, 25-year-old Negro who saved the lives of two policemen after a holdup last March, was praised for his action by Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions Court yesterday after District Attorney Frank S. Hogan spoke of his "magnificent public service."

Governor Darden of Virginia added to his fine reputation for fair-mindedness yesterday when he granted a fifth reprieve to Odell Waller, this time until July 2. Waller, it may be recalled, was a Negro sharecropper, who shot and killed his white landlord, Oscar Davis.

CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- The White Sox and Athletics traded places in the American League standing for the third time in three days today when the combined five-hit pitching of BucK Ross and Joe Haynes put the Chicagoans back in sixth place with a 7-to-2 victory.

DURHAM, N.H., June 18 -- The General Council of the Congregational-Christian Churches at its biennial meeting here today revived the ancient custom of "owning the covenant" at a special service of communion.
ATLANTA, June 18 (AP) -- Governor Talmadge reckoned today that New York was "the most illiterate" State in the nation.

An exhibition made up of 149 entries submitted by sculptors living in many States is now open at the Whitney Museum, where the work will remain on view until the end of the month. During this period the museum will be open daily except Sundays and Mondays.

Elbridge Manning, 25-year-old Negro who saved the lives of two policemen after a holdup last March, was praised for his action by Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions Court yesterday after District Attorney Frank S. Hogan spoke of his "magnificent public service."

Governor Darden of Virginia added to his fine reputation for fair-mindedness yesterday when he granted a fifth reprieve to Odell Waller, this time until July 2. Waller, it may be recalled, was a Negro sharecropper, who shot and killed his white landlord, Oscar Davis.

A trustworthy diplomatic source reported recently that Pierre Laval, in his negotiations with Berlin, had reached the point where he could hope to obtain the release of French war prisoners. He has always regarded such a step as a prerequisite to further advance along the line of close collaboration with Germany and the only means to win French opinion, at least partially, to his policy.

LONDON, June 18 -- The British Council of Churches, an interdenominational organization, was formed in London today, uniting the Council on Christian Faith and Common Life, the Commission of Churches for International Friendship and Social Responsibility and the British Section of the World Conference on Faith and Order.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, June 19 -- A further account of last month's Coral Sea battle was told today by American land-based fliers who delivered the first of a series of blows that sank fifteen Japanese ships, set more than twenty afire and sent the scattered remnants of a great armada fleeing northward.

Reserve Requirements Belief is fairly general in banking circles that Congress will pass without undue delay proposed legislation amending the Federal Reserve Act, giving the Reserve Board, among other things, power to cut reserve requirements on demand deposits of New York City and Chicago banks, placing such requirements on a parity with those of banks in other large cities.
All the attributes of an Edgar Allan Poe thriller centered yesterday about the building at 513 East Eighty-third Street, but the affair wound up as just another case for the A.S.P.C.A.

Madeline Webb was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to spend the rest of her life in the Westfield Farms State Prison for Women at Bedford Hills, for her part in the hold-up murder of Mrs. Susan Flora Reich, 52-year-old Polish refugee, in the Hotel Sutton on March 4.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 19 -- Improving their score on the incoming nine, on which most of the contestants had trouble, Ray M. Torgerson of Lakeville and Wesley Cotterell of the home club shot a 66 today to win the medal in the sixth annual best-ball invitation tourney of the Cherry Valley Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Leon Henderson informed retailers today that there would be no extension of the July 1 deadline for filing ceiling prices on 200 or so groups of cost-of-living commodities and gave them further instructions on how to make such filings.

IF you follow H.I. Phillips in the newspapers, you probably know all about the war-born vicissitudes of Private Oscar Purkey, the perennial rookie. Oscar is made up of a dash of Ring Lardner's busher, a suggestion of World War I doughboy, a bit of the Arkansas Traveler, and large gobs of H.I. Phillips, the kindliest of columnists.

Hundreds of insurance agents gathered yesterday at the New York Fire Insurance Exchange at 85 John Street to obtain an initial supply of applications for War Damage Corporation insurance, which is to become available to property owners in the United States, Alaska and the insular possessions on July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Surrounded by ranking military aides at a secret rendezvous, President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill were in conference today, discussing, it was understood, the Pacific situation in the light of the Midway victory, China's desperate position, the Russian campaign and matters related to a second front in Europe.

Appeals for support of Russian war relief will be made at synagogues and churches today and tomorrow, according to Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary and vice president of Russian War Relief, Inc.

John T. Madden, chairman of the Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign, estimated last night, on the basis of results to date, that city residents will have signed in excess of 1,500,000 pledges when the final count is taken next Wednesday.

Former Mayor James J. Walker found that he was not forgotten yesterday when he returned to City Hall to stimulate the sale of war bonds and received a cordial welcome both inside and outside the building.

BOSTON, June 19 (AP) -- Pittsburgh and Boston today picked the day Paul Waner made his 3,000th major league hit to stage an eleven-inning thriller that went to the Pirates, 7 to 6, on the strength of big Bob Elliott's second home run of the game.

These are dark days for the elevated lines that have darkened the streets so long. The Second Avenue El, long threatened and dying piecemeal, has run its last train. The wreckers began their attack on it this week. It had been losing money right along. Yet it has had its friends, especially in Queens, and some in Manhattan.

Steps have been taken by the Long Island Railroad to aid metropolitan salt-water anglers who have found transportation to distant Long Island points difficult since the Fishermen's Special was discontinued last month for the duration of the war.

Rumors that the war may end shortly have not been as responsible for market movements as the public has believed, according to The Exchange, monthly publication of the New York Stock Exchange.
