The magazine points out that peace talk started twenty-five weeks after Pearl Harbor, providing a complete parallel with the peace talk which affected Wall Street twenty-five weeks after the United States entered the war in 1917.
Years and years ago, two wars ago, an English poet consecrated himself to:

Business houses began making substantial contributions to New York's scrap rubber pile yesterday as the salvage campaign neared the end of its first week and about 50,000 Boy Scouts and Cub Scouts under the jurisdiction of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York prepared to launch their scrap rubber treasure hunt today.

CHICAGO, June 19-- Although the wheat market showed a firm undertone in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, the buying was not aggressive, and when cotton failed to maintain an early upturn offerings of wheat futures increased and disclosed a lack of support.

The announcement of Metropolitan opera next season at a five-dollar top to subscribers is one of the most important decisions that the institution has made in years, and one that is certain to be of benefit not only to the local public but that of the national and indeed of the artistic world.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 19 -- After three weeks of gallant but unsuccessful fighting against Axis armored divisions, Lieut. Gen. Neil M. Ritchie's Eighth Army completed today its withdrawal to fortified positions along the Egyptian-Libyan border, but it continued to hold the Tobruk area on the Germans' northern flank.

Edward Lynch, WPA laborer foreman, set the marker in its place. It read "Buster -- Long and Devoted Friend." He gazed pensively at the fresh grave he had just dug by searchlight in the yard back of the two-story house in which he lives in the East Bronx, at an address that Lynch requested be not revealed.

LONDON, June 19 (U.P.) -- The Premier and the Minister of Commerce of the Netherland Government-in-Exile soon will follow Queen Wilhelmina to the United States to set up a post-war plan of economic cooperation and discuss Allied peace objectives, it was announced today.

Robert H. Hinckley, Assistan Secretary of Commerce for Air warned yesterday that "a government agency" concerned with aviation should not become "so strong that its primary interest is itself" and not with private enterprise that has flying" facilities to offer particularly in time of war.

WASHNGTON, June 19 -- The Ways and Means Committee indicated today that it favored a withholding tax to insure collection of the higher rates on individual income taxes and in order to ease the taxpayer's method of payment.

The Giant craft came close to upending itself and plunging into the second division yesterday when, with a ladies' day crowd of 17,678 looking helplessly on, Mel Ott's men dropped the opener of a double-header to the Cubs at the Polo Grounds, 7 to 4.
For several days no news has been forthcoming of operations against the Japanese in the Western Aleutian Islands. The inference to be drawn is that bad weather has hampered reconnaissance and attack.
BERLIN, June 19 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

OTTAWA, June 19 -- Information gathered from official sources indicated today that Canadians will have to get along indefinitely on a sugar supply that represents approximately one-half the normal peace-time consumption.

LONDON, June 19 -- A feature of the trading today on the stock exchange was a sharp fall in diamond shares on the announcement that De Beers Consolidated would not make an interim distribution on the deferred and ordinary shares.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 19 -- Westchester County's airport in the estate area of this community began to become a reality this afternoon when steam shovels and bulldozers started leveling the 503acre timbered site. Two years of bickering, feuding and litigating preceded the construction work.

ALBANY, June 19 -- The State Banking Department announced today the appointment of Elmer W. Poole, 317 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, as a junior bank examiner effective on July 1. He will receive $10 per diem.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on June 13 totaled 253,386,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, United States Department of the Interior. This represented a decrease of 930,000 barrels in the week, comprising decreases of 887,000 and 43,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 19 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's visit with President Roosevelt causes German editorial writers to comment caustically, and the captions in the afternoon papers stress their obvious enjoyment.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, June 19 -- Lieutenant Paul G. Brown, aged 25 years, of Oak Park, Ill., has found his own way of downing Japanese Zeros. He got one the other day by the simple method of running into it in the air.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 19 -- The political spat between Wendell Willkie and Thomas E. Dewey is being watched by political observers as a preliminary round for the 1944 Presidential fight.

The second concert of the Lewisohn Stadium golden jubilee season last night was a tribute to the Soviet Union, whose composers filled the program. Artur Rodzinski, conducting the New York Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, began with Reinhold Gliere's "Marche Heroique."
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I wish to register a very strenuous protest against a grave injustice too often perpetrated against that hard-toiling clan of ball players -- the pitchers.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, June 19 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. George H. Brett, commander of United States Air Forces in Australia, has decorated Brig. Gen. Martin F. Scanlon and twenty-one other officers and men for gallantry in action against the Japanese, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (U.P.) -- Leon Henderson, who has been criticized by some members of Congress over appointments of aides to his Office of Price Administration, told local rationing boards today that he would continue "the democratic method" of selecting board members from nominations made by local defense councils.

First Lieutenant Mary Lohr, an Army nurse who served at Corregidor, arrived here yesterday, none the worse for her experiences, and told of her flight with eight other nurses who escaped from the island fortress under orders from Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright five days before it fell.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The results of last year's campaign for the collection of old aluminum were disappointing, the War Production Board's Bureau of Industrial Conservation reported today. The chief reason for this, the bureau said, was that the Office of Civilian Defense left junk dealers entirely out of the program.

Rear Admiral Stanley V. Parker, who assumed command this week as district officer of the Coast Guard In the Third Naval District, said yesterday after his preliminary survey of security measures in the Port that he would concentrate his attention in the Immediate future on protecting the port and its environs against any danger.
The second visit of Prime Minister Winston Churchill to the United States comes, like the first, on the eve of military crisis.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Legislation designed to equalize the pay of soldiers of the Philippine Commonwealth Army with that of the Philippine Scouts, while both organizations are pursuing guerrilla warfare with the enemy alongside United States troops, has struck a snag in the House Rules Committee.

Reports that gasoline shortages were interfering with the transportation, of war plant employes in New Jersey were being investigated last night by officials of the Marketing Division of the Office of Petroleum Coordinator as State gasoline tax administrators, meeting at the Hotel Lexington, considered the possibility that more drastic rationing may become necessary so that transportation facilities can be used to bring in essential heating oils.

The ninth annual $2,000 prize of the Julia Ellsworth Ford Foundation for Children's Literature was awarded yesterday to Isabel McLennan McMeekin of Louisville, Ky. Her winning book manuscript for children entitled "Journey Cake" is a frontier story of the late eighteenth century.
The Index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The National Wool Growers Association defended today the stand of Kenneth W. Marriner, member of the textile division of the War Production Board, in opposition to the mandatory blending of wool fibers. Mr. Marriner's position was criticized by the Truman committee in its report on hearings resulting from the resignation of R.W. Guthrie, former director of WPB's textile section.

Statisticians and economists will find material for many cozy academic chats in a bulletin on the cost of food just off the government printing presses. Budgetwatchers will discover good and bad news balancing with almost perfect equilibrium.

Sugar refiners and producers are urging the Office of Price Administration and the War Production Board to increase domestic and industrial sugar rations so that some of the surplus now glutting their warehouses can be moved out and storage space provided for fresh supplies from this year's production, it was learned yesterday.

That ancient mariner, Lieutenant Joe McCluskey of the United States Naval Reserve, made good use of part of a week-end furlough to win his twenty-second national championship at Triborough Stadium yesterday as the fifty-fifth annual A.A.U. show began with two senior crowns decided and the full twenty-one junior titles awarded.
ST. LOUIS, June 19 (AP) -- In a game featured by five double plays and the four-hit pitching of Johnny Niggeling, the Browns shut out the Athletics tonight, 4 to 0.

In a prefatory note to his latest novel, "The Copper Pot," Oliver La Farge has a few words to say about the novelist's blending of real life with imagination to achieve the desired fictional synthesis.
CHUNGKING, China, June 19 (AP) -- A Chinese High Command communique said today:

MOSCOW, Saturday, June 20 -- Russian infantry, marines and artillery men are repulsing the heaviest German attacks on Sevastopol since the all-out assault began fifteen days ago and are hurling heavy counter-blows at Col. Gen. Fritz Erich von Mannstein's siege army, the Soviet High Command reported today.

LONDON, June 19 -- Officially the real purpose of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's visit to the United States remained a mystery tonight. With that unanimity which usually suggests direction, British newspapers abandoned the field in the guessing game to their American representatives, who had it all figured out that the Prime Minister and the President were studying maps and selecting the points at which Anglo-American expeditionary forces would invade Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Leo T. Crowley, Alien Property Custodian, has ordered all persons claiming any interest in patents or patent applications now or formerly owned by nationals of "designated" foreign countries to report their interest, including any license agreement or claims of ownership, by Aug. 15.
ALBANY, June 19 -- Republican leaders who will control a large majority of delegates to the State convention reaffirmed today their intention to nominate Thomas E. Dewey for Governor.
The nine-room dwelling on a plot 75 by 257 feet at 144-71 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, was sold by Howard Springsteen to Dr. Elliott J. Sossei through the Halleran Agency.
The national professional tennis championships return to Forest Hills today for the first time since 1930.

Senator James M. Mead reiterated yesterday that he was not a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor. He addressed 1,800 members and guests of the Federal Business Association, who were honoring him and Representative Robert Ramspeck of Georgia at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore.

To Sports Editor of The New Fork Times: It was very interesting to observe that in the recent North Westminster Kennel Club dog show at Katonah the dachshund led all classes in number of entries benched. There were 158 dachshunds exhibited against 136 cocker spaniels, figures that are especially surprising when it is considered that cockers have dominated most of the major shows in recent years.

LONDON, June 19 -- The German-controlled Oslo radio quoted Ankara reports tonight as saying thirteen to fifteen United States planes flew over Turkish territory and headed for the northern coast of the Black Sea in the second appearance of American bombers over Turkey.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 19 -- Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States fleet, told the 611 midshipmen who were graduated from the Naval Academy today that the United States could be fully confident of winning "the greatest war in history" only at the cost of "unremitting labor and a multitude of heartaches and sacrifices such as this country has never before known."
CAIRO, Egypt, June 19 (AP) -- British Headquarters issued this communique today:
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Permit me to make a slight amendment to your article last week about Elmer Davis, who was a contemporary of mine at Oxford from 1911 to 1913.

Only five or six of the ninetyone women who left the city several weeks ago to pack vegetables on a farm in Southern New Jersey have returned here dissatisfied with farm life, It was learned yesterday.

Price restrictions and rationing cannot succeed without the aid of advertising, according to Dr. Kenneth Dameron, director of the Committee on Consumer Relations in Advertising, Inc., who yesterday urged individual advertisers to assume part of the job of overcoming consumer ignorance and unpredictable prejudices which might, arise from adverse consumer mass opinion.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : In its opposition to the sales tax measure now pending before Congress, the Administration is once again demonstrating its tendency to sacrifice good economics to what it considers good politics, when it feels the two are in conflict.

A word picture of gambling in political clubs in the Williamsburg and Greenpoint sections of Brooklyn, and of attempts by police officers to persuade a fellow-officer to collect and distribute bribes for the protection of the city-wide gambling racket bared recently by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen, was drawn yesterday by Captain Louis Goldberg, in charge of the Elmhurst, Queens, precinct, in the trial room at Brooklyn Police Headquarters.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (AP) -- The Reds won their fifth straight game tonight, beating the last-place Phils, 6 to 4, at Shibe Park.

Following, as furnished by the official Soviet Tass news agency, is the text of the report made on June 18 by Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, Russian Commissar for Foreign Affairs, to the Supreme Soviet of U.S.S.R. on the treaty between the Soviet Union and Great Britain, signed May 26.

There is some discussion of the advisability of combining the roll-call of the American Red Cross with the fundraising appeals of the Community Chests and the United Service Organizations. It is urged that this would lead to harmony and efficiency of collection.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 19 -- The Japanese are using a new bomber as well as a new fighter in the air war over North Australia. The new bomber is more heavily armed than the earlier types, is fitted with a cannon and has a speed of 270 miles an hour.

New bond financing virtually dried up this week, formal offerings to the public being restricted to a single tax-exempt issue of $1,792,000. This is the smallest weekly total since early last December, when less than $1,000,000 was offered.

State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by twenty-six municipalities and six local public housing agencies aggregates $9,507,444, compared with $26,240,094, for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $25,134,940.

Allan (The Turk) Williams, 33 years old, of Washington, leader of a $2,000,000 narcotics and prostitution ring, who was one of five persons charged with, the murder of Eugene Epps, Federal Government witness against the ring, pleaded guilty yesterday in Bronx County Court as an accessory after the fact.

Permission to "sell' typewriters under the so-called lease-lend system, a plan that was announced by two department stores here this week, may be withdrawn by the Office of Price Administration, it was learned at the regional office here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The serious unemployment situation in New York City will be re-examined by various Federal agencies, according co a decision made today at a conference held at President Roosevelt's direction and attended by Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia, Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, and representatives of Federal agencies concerned "with war production.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 19 -- The masters and officers of sixteen Swedish cargo steamers in the Netherland trade have protested to the Swedish Shipowners Association against "the reckless and inconsiderate employment of Swedish tonnage in the iron ore and local traffic to Rotterdam," the Netherlands, and have served notice that out of regard for their own security and the welfare of their families they henceforth will refuse to participate in any more voyages to Rotterdam.

Eighteen hundred girls at Hunter College, the largest single unit to be recruited voluntarily for war work, are ready to serve as emergency telephonists in the Central Control Unit for East Manhattan, it was revealed yesterday in a report issued by the Hunter Committee on Defense.
LONDON, June 19 -- The sinking of the old British destroyer Wild Swan-but not before she had shot down six of the twelve German planes that attacked her -- was announced by the Admiralty today.

DURHAM, N.H., June 19 (UP) -- Intolerance between faiths is being overcome by the nation's military chaplains, the biennial meeting of the General Council of Congregational-Christian Churches was told today.

MONTREAL, June 19 (Canadian Press) -- Jersey City climbed to within a half game of the second-place Montreal club tonight by beating the Royals, 5-3. Rube Fischer, Jersey right-hander, allowed nine hits, but struck out ten men and was effective in the pinches, the Royals leaving twelve men on the bases.

CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) -- An inside-the-park homer by Dom DiMaggio -- normally good for two bases-added to Hard-Luck Edgar Smith's misfortunes tonight as the Red Sox beat the White Sox, 1 to 0, before 12,938 fans. Outfielder Wally Moses couldn't retrieve the tricky ball beneath the Boston bullpen bench.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES has given generously of its support in news columns and editorials to the Red Cross appeal for urgently needed pints of blood and the announced intention of storing thousands of such pints in civilian and military blood banks.

BOSTON, June 19 -- Increase in business mortality in the Northeast, noted within the last two months, is not an alarming symptom, it was declared today by Walter Mitchell Jr., research director of Dun Bradstreet, New York.

LONDON, June 19 -- British coal miners gained a notable victory today through government approval of their demand for a minimum, wage that is the equivalent of $16.60 weekly for underground workers. Private owners of this important British resource obtained an even more significant decision, for it was decreed that the new wage schedule would not cost the owners anything, but would be passed on to the consuming public in higher prices.
Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. They are:

CLEVELAND, June 19 -- The Yankees' surprising dash in reverse continued tonight as the Indians submerged the champions, 5 to 4, thanks to the efforts of an old Dodger named Oris Hockett. This was the Yanks' third straight setback.
DETROIT, June 19 (AP) -- Rookie Hal White just missed his fourth shut-out of the season today as the Tigers defeated the Senators, 5 to 1. The Detroit right-hander scattered six hits.
NEW YORK Mme. Wilhelm Munthe de Morgensierne, wife of the Norwegian Ambassador, has arrived from Washington and is at the Waldorf-Astoria.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: It's time some one took up the cudgels for baseball's greatest outfield, namely the Brooklyn Dodger picket line of Joe Medwick, Pete Reiser and Dixie Walker.

Overcoming the selling pressure exerted earlier on the market by increased liquidation in the July position because of the proximity of first-notice day for that month, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday found enough strength in late covering operations of locals to close mixed, 1 point lower to 2 points higher than Thursday's final prices.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- To nip any chiseling under the permanent Eastern gasoline rationing system starting July 15 every automobile will have to carry a colored sticker showing the type of rationing book held by its driver, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- Dissolution of the Standard Power and Light Corporation under the "death sentence" clause of the Holding Company Act was ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which called the concern, top holding company of a system including forty-two other companies, a useless "corporate shell."

Orders related closely to sales expectancy rather than stocking up for inventory featured most of the wholesale markets here this week. The inventory fever, according to close market observers, appears to have burned itself out and was replaced by a degree of conservatism greater than that noted at any other time this year.
The miracle that Wall Street never expected came to pass yesterday -- the Erie Railroad declared a common stock dividend.
The prepared address of King George II before the Council of Foreign Relations last night follows:
LONDON, June 19 (AP) -- A communique of the Air and Home Security Ministries said today:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 19 -- Hopes that President Roberto M. Ortiz might return to power and remove Acting President Ramon S. Castillo from effective management of Argentine affairs collapsed almost completely this morning when Dr. Ramon Castroviejo, eye specialist of the Columbia - Presbyterian Medical Center in New York left by air for home.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- A House subcommittee investigating the government's rubber programs has voted to demand of the War Production Board that it grant a rehearing to applicants for machinery priorities for a projected reclaiming plant in Texas, after having received testimony that a WPB official pronounced their engineer-drafted plans "child's stuff" and suggested that new ones be drawn by a recommended expert at a cost of $50,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 19 -- Franchot Tone, Marsha Hunt and Gene Kelly will play the leads in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Skyway to Glory," formerly "The Story of Number Five," which will go before the cameras Monday, the studio announced today.
CHICAGO, June 19 -- One of the sparks from yesterday's scoring conflagration in the Hale America open tournament fell on little Ben Hogan, golf's mighty atom, and burst into flame today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 18 (AP) (Delayed) -- A Bucharest resident, who saw United States bombers over the Rumanian capital in broad daylight last week, said today it was reported in Bucharest that they had raided Constanta. Rumania's chief Black Sea port, as well as the oil center of Ploesti.
The destruction of nine Allied merchant vessels by Axis subma- rines in the Atlantic was disclosed yesterday by the Navy and Caribbean sources.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 19 -- That Reichsfuehrer Hitler will make a speech either Sunday or Monday, on the occasion of the anniversary of his invasion of Russia, was strongly rumored in Berlin political circles this afternoon. By that time he hopes to announce a concrete success, such as the capture of Sevastopol, and in any event he is expected to announce up-to-date casualty figures, for which the German people are clamoring.

CHUNGKING, China, June 19 (AP) -- The Chinese reported local successes tonight in operations against Japanese bases in Kiangsi and Hunan, offsetting somewhat enemy gains on the coast of Chekiang and in the drive toward still unoccupied areas of Fukien.

With "a little surer acceptance" of President Wilson's ideals of twenty years ago, the world may attain at the end of this war the peace it missed before, King George II of Greece suggested last night. He spoke at a dinner in his honor given by the Council on Foreign Relations at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

COATESVILLE, Pa., June 19 -- The sit-down strike of open hearth workers at the Lukens Steel Company plant has spread to 225 men from seventy-five and threatens to force a shut down affecting 5,000 workers on war production within a week, it was declared today by a spokesman for the company.

Inevitably there will be much, speculation concerning the precise reasons why Mr. Churchill has come again to America to confer with President Roosevelt. Each of these two men bears a tremendous responsibility -- a responsibility greater, indeed, when one considers what is at stake, than that ever borne before by any statesman in history.

NORWALK, Conn., June 19 -- Thomas B. Clarke Jr., retired banker and former husband of Elsie Ferguson, actress, shot himself in the temple this afternoon in his home on Morehouse Lane here, according to State police. He was taken to the Norwalk Hospital, where his condition was reported critical.

The Bank for Savings has sold the twelve-story apartment house on a plot 100.5 by 150 feet at 41 Central Park West to the 41 Central Park West Corporation for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $365,000 for ten years. The property is assessed at $965,000, of which 5550,000 is land value.

NOBODY seems to know who will win the 1,500-meter race in the national championships on Randalls Island this afternoon. That makes it all the better. Last year the insiders went all out for Leslie MacMitchell and Les didn't let them down. Last Winter the N.Y.U. miler looked like a sure shot to stay in front at his favorite distance and its nearest metrical equivalent, 1,500 meters.
Winston Churchill arrived in the United States just as Foreign Commissar Molotoff was reporting to the Supreme Soviet in Moscow the results of his recent visits to London and Washington.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 19 -- Nineteen newspaper men magazine writers and radio commentators were named today to the "Headliners Hall of Fame" in recognition of outstanding journalistic achievements during the past year, the National Headliners Club announced in making public its annual list of awards.
SYRACUSE, June 19 -- A plea for the election of Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti as Governor was cheered today by delegates representing C.I.O. unions from all parts of the State.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- To obviate delay in the production of textiles, clothing and related articles for the armed services, Price Administrator Leon Henderson today announced a method by which war procurement agencies of the government may contract for and receive deliveries of these commodities pending OPA action on applications for adjustment of ceiling prices.
Just say Nothing There is still another way to deal with public bewilderment produced by conflicting official utterances in Washington. Just cut down the volume of such utterances -- with an axe.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 19 -- Prime Minister John Curtin warned today that the war situation was bad. He was speaking to 300 representatives of eighty-four unions, asking their assistance in expediting the transfer of 300,000 more men and women to war industries.

The Laclede Gas Light Company's certificates of deposit for refunding and extension mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds extended to April 1, 1942, have been stricken from New York Stock Exchange listing. The same bonds extended to 1945 are listed.

Several thousand persons crowded around the steps of Brooklyn Borough Hall yesterday at noon for the formal presentation of sevan ambulances and four mobile canteens to the Brooklyn chapter of the American Red Cross. The presentations were made by representatives of various schools and other organizations and the gifts were accepted by Clifford R. Beardsley, Brooklyn chapter chairman.

DUBLIN, June 19 -- A sturdily built gray-haired man in his late thirties, Stephen Hayes, who admitted that he was chief of staff of the outlawed Irish Republican Army, was sentenced to five years penal servitude by a special military court here today for usurping the function of the government by obtaining an illegal force known as the I.R.A.

CHICAGO, June 19 (A.P.) -- Prices of hogs rose today to a top of $14.50 a hundred-weight, highest in three weeks, spurred by a light supply, good wholesale demand for pork and expected continued heavy buying of pork and lard by the government. Steads-prices were paid for the limited amount of cattle.

Archbishop Athenagoras of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America will conduct a special service at noon tomorrow at Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral, 319 East Seventy-fourth Street, to be attended by King George II of Greece.
TOKYO, June 19 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in New York) -- Domei, Japanese news agency, issued the following statement today:
Leaving fisticuffs to those who get paid for that sort of thing, the Cards and Dodgers yesterday devoted themselves wholeheartedly to baseball before a ladies' day throng of 28,729 at Ebbets Field.

Directors of the California Oregon Power Company voted yesterday to clear arrears of dividends on its preferred stocks with the declaration of two full quarterly dividends of $1.75 each on the 7 per cent preferred, two full quarterly dividends of $1.50 each on the 6 per cent preferred and two full quarterly dividends of $1.50 each on the 6 per cent preferred series of 1927.

Two attractions will terminate their Broadway engagements this evening, "Top-Notchers" and "The Cat Screams." The Clifford C. Fischer-Shuberts variety show will have been seen at the Forty-fourth Street for forty-eight performances. The Basil Beyea-John Patrick mystery melodrama vacates the Martin Beck Theatre after seven performances.

CAIRO, June 19 (AP) -- British mobile forces, fanning out northward from their new line along the Egyptian border, jostled German preparations for an all-out assault on Tobruk today and gave that isolated British stronghold time to perfect its defenses.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have completed a first aid course of the American Red Cross and I fully appreciate the practical and efficient method of the program supplied by the textbook as well as by the instructors.

Johan Strauss's operetta, "The Gypsy Baron," was presented by Gustave Kotanyi last night at the Cosmopolitan Opera House, under "the auspices of the Committee for the Preservation of Austrian Art and Culture in the U.S.A. The performance, an excellent one in every regard, attracted an enthusiastic capacity audience, containing many celebrities of the Central European musical and theatrical world now resident in this city.
BUFFALO, June 19 (AP) -- The Bisons and the league-leading Bears played almost six hours of baseball tonight before breaking even in a double-header that ended long after midnight.

Johan Strauss's operetta, "The Gypsy Baron," was presented by Gustave Kotanyi last night at the Cosmopolitan Opera House, under "the auspices of the Committee for the Preservation of Austrian Art and Culture in the U.S.A. The performance, an excellent one in every regard, attracted an enthusiastic capacity audience, containing many celebrities of the Central European musical and theatrical world now resident in this city.
BUFFALO, June 19 (AP) -- The Bisons and the league-leading Bears played almost six hours of baseball tonight before breaking even in a double-header that ended long after midnight.

LONDON, June 19 -- The Empire's highest decoration, the Victoria Cross, has been, awarded posthumously to Lieut. Col. Geoffrey C.T. Keyes, 24-year-old son of Admiral Roger Keyes, who was hilled in a daring Commando raid on Marshal Erwin Rommel's headquarters in Libya one night last November in an unsuccessful attempt to capture him, it was announced today.

From Chungking comes what has the appearance of an official announcement that American bombers will fly to China and take up permanent stations there as soon as the air strength of the United Nations in India is considered adequate. Every friend of China, which means every last one of us, will hope that the arrival of these bombers is not long deferred.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- The names of sixty-six firms which will underwrite an offering of 240,000 shares of $1 par value common stock of Charles Pfizer Co., Inc., were supplied today in an amendment to the registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
A continuance of the demand for apartments in the city was indicated yesterday by lists of new names that have been added to tenant rosters. Houses on Park Avenue attracted many of the new tenants.

Now that the burst of dainty Spring bloom, has faded away, gardeners are looking forward to the more massive growths of Summer and Fall -- the groups of phlox, the tall delphiniums and lilies, and finally the huge clumps of chrysanthemums in the Autumn.

President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill are in conference again on United States soil. It is but natural that secrecy surrounds their meeting. It may not be stated where it is taking place and there is no statement of the subjects being considered. Of course, it is safe to say that they are weighing the many problems confronting the United Nations in their many fields of action against the Axis powers.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Machinery for operating the wartime plan for close collaboration between the financial industry and the Securities and Exchange Commission, as suggested here on Tuesday by Ganson Purcell, chairman of the commission, already is being assembled.

NORMAL, Ill., June 20 -- An organized cooperative program between State-supported institutions of higher education in Illinois the past two years has proved advantageous, President R.W. Fairchild announced here today. As a result, the plan will be continued.

The Giants, a compact body of large men who are not easily checked once they start rolling into action, picked up yesterday where they left off in the second game of Friday's double-header with the Cubs and by reason of the added momentum, gained an even more impressive triumph before a gathering at 7,420 highly pleased onlookers at the Polo Grounds.

A properly planted garden pool is an eternal joy, with its constant mirroring of the sky and its enchanting succession of exotic blooms. Yet, unknowingly stocked, it is a disaster, a disintegration from beauty to confusion, its reflective value lost in rank growth and its flowering possibilities crowded out by urgent water weeds.

Canning and storing of vegetables will be demonstrated at the Festival of Roses for the benefit of the Army and Navy Relief Organizations today, at the Jackson Perkins Rose Gardens at Newark, N.Y. Canning methods will be explained by Miss Orilla Wright of the Home Economics College at Cornell.

AS of July 5, half of the Sunday night hour that Fred Allen is now occupying -- the second half, 9:30 P.M. to 10 -- will be taken by a concert program comprising Al Goodman, the man who never rests; Jane Froman, who rings; a chorus of twelve, and Jimmy Wallington, m.c. and announcer....

Calling attention to the fact that while wartime restrictions are presenting trying problems to the home-financing and construction industries, the prediction is made in the current issue of the Federal Home Loan Bank Review that American home seekers of the future will reap benefits from the trend toward lower-cost homes resulting from those restrictions.

Those who work in the city and have only evenings in which to enjoy their flower gardens will find a "twilight garden" most enjoyable. There are a number of flowers that suddenly and wonderfully revive when night comes on. While many of the evening bloomers are white they give forth delicious odors.

LONDON, June 20 -- Following formal acceptance of terms for dissolution of the international tin buffer pool, steps are being taken to distribute the available funds. Since the pool sold its tin reserve early in the war, dissolution was solely a financial transaction without influence on the supply of that metal.

MR. MAUGHAM has written a quietly interesting novel of the war in England in his mildest manner. He has not attempted to make capital out of the hysteria, dramatics, whimsy or heroics that accompany most war novels.
CAIRO, June 20 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters said today:

Camp Nyda at Wallkill, N.Y., the unique institution that during the past six years has provided a happy Summer vacation for underprivileged diabetic children of the tenements, will open again this year on July 1 under the sponsorship of the New York Diabetes Association, a group of leading specialists on diabetes.

ALFRED SWAN of the Music Department of Swarthmore College believes that the one way to make amateurs really acquainted with the quality of the art is to have them perform the music of which they read in the histories or hear discussed by a lecturer.

New York Although warm weather spurred the sale of seasonal merchandise, retail trade here held unchanged last week. Department store sales were estimated as about equal to those of the corresponding week a year ago.

THERE it stands for all the world to puzzle over, says Philip Ainsworth Means in introducing the subject of his new book: the most enigmatic and provocative building in the United States, argued about for more than a century.

As the country's farms go on a war basis with higher quotas from, the Agricultural War Board and fewer hands with which to produce them, the burden on the farm woman is being doubled beyond her capacity. Help must come, many of them believe, not from raw recruits of farmerettes, but from townswomen who will take over their household work.

TUCSON, Ariz., June 20 -- In an effort aligned to the nation-wide plan to better Pan-American relations, the University of Arizona has taken steps in the direction of educational encouragement, adjustment and assistance to scholars of the Latin-American republics.

CHUNGKING, China. June 20 -- "China is experiencing a crisis similar to that following the loss of the political capital at Nanking and the economic capital at Hankow," said Dr. T.F. Tsiang, American-educated Minister without portfolio, in an interview today.
Problems facing the real estate and building industries and the architectural profession under war conditions will be the chief topics of discussion at three large conventions to be held this week.

A series of spectacular achievements marked the fifty-fifth annual A.A.U. track and field championships before the enraptured graze of a gathering of 12,000 in sun - baked Triborough Stadium yesterday. But the half-century-plus history of this meet has made mark-shattering an extremely difficult task and hence only two records were broken despite the awesome efficiency of a great cast.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 20 -- The shadowy events occurring in the stony and volcanic Aleutian Islands have aroused genuine alarm and apprehension along the North Pacific Coast. Newspapers, public officials and rank and file citizens have sharply criticized Navy suggestions that Japanese footholds at Kiska harbor and Attu island are not of great importance.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- By an amendment to the tire rationing regulations, war workers are made eligible for third, fourth and fifth line new tires under restrictive conditions.

HONOLULU, June 20 -- Two of the United States Navy carrier pilots who took part in the Battle of Midway told today of the hectic hours of June 4 off the mid-Pacific island when American planes struck the invading Japanese Fleet, and in a matter of hours smashed it so that it turned tail and ran.

A proposal to use in the war and afterwward the services of 600,000 physically or mentally handicapped persons was drafted yesterday by the Conference on Education of the Exceptional During the War and the Post-War Emergency on the last day of its three-day session in Teachers College, Columbia University.

IN the case of radio, as in the theatre, the cinema and the arts in general, it is the recognized privilege of a critic, or kibitzer, to offer his opinion without being obliged to do anything more about it, an arrangement which frequently annoys the party of the second part but is highly satisfactory to the party of the first.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Northward the mountain laurel display makes its way, with the peak this week in the Mount Everett State Reservation, town of Mount Washington. The laurel grows in profusion for three miles along the hard-surfaced Mount Everett Highway, which leads off the main turnpike near the civic center.

BANFF, Alberta -- The iniskim, or buffalo stone, a joint of fossilized sea plant, found in the country between the Saskatchewan and the Missouri Rivers, is sacred to the Blackfoot Indians of Western Canada, who tell in their tribal legends how it saved the race from starvation.

BOSTON, June 20 (AP) -- Despite a slow start, Anthony Pelleteri's La Reigh closed fast today to win the $7,500 added Betsy Ross Stakes for juvenile fillies at Suffolk Downs by a head. Hal Price Headley's entry of Tellmenow and Askmenow ran second and third, respectively, in the seven-horse field.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- David C. Prince, president of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, said today that in the last two years the nation's electrical manufacturers had "more than doubled their volume of shipments and the number of people they employ."

BROADCASTERS, like every one else, are keen to do their bit, not only for winning the war, but also for the establishment of a just and enduring peace. To these ends, in addition to its many other wartime broadcasts, the National Broadcasting Company is founding the Inter-American University of the Air which at expects to develop as a permanent agency for the promotion of mutual understanding and good-will among the nations of the Western Hemisphere.

Forecasts by Sumner Towne that Maine waters would yield an abundant supply of striped bass this year are proving correct. In fact these fish are so plentiful that veteran anglers of the Pine Tree State consider the current run the largest on record.

The Maritime Commission has set up a new organization to bolster industrial morale and increase industrial production by introducing workers on the "home front" to men who have come back from active duty with the scars of battle.

The volunteer movement by leading artists, muralists, architects, etchers, typographers and art directors in preparing designs for United States war stamps has become national in scope, it was learned last week. Paul F. Berdanier, director, announced that the Society of Typographic Arts in Chicago and art societies in other cities had joined with the American Institute of Graphic Arts and the Society of Illustrators here in support of the idea.

LONDON, June 20 -- With afternoon and evening meetings, London today launched its week-end observance of Russia's entry into the war against Germany last June 22. Seven thousand persons gathered in Empress Hall cheered for ten minutes when Sir Stafford Cripps, Deputy Prime Minister, said: "When we strike, let us strike hard with a determination to march through to Berlin before we call a final halt."

The advance guard of America s armed might was spread around the world last week. Strong ground units were in Ireland in the Atlantic, Australia in the Pacific. United States airmen were guarding the nation's coasts and the coasts of the nations to the south, they were fighting in the Aleutian Islands, China, the Southwestern Pacific, the Black Sea and the Mediterranean.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, June 20 (AP) -- Six Allied airmen clung to a rubber raft in sharkinfested waters of the Coral Sea for two and a half hours before being rescued by natives in canoes, Captain Albert J. Moye of Ashton, Ill., said today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 20 -- The week's developments on Germany's "occupied front" have brought fresh evidence of German nervousness and preoccupation over the obstinacy and dogged determination of the peoples of conquered Europe to resist the new order.

DETROIT, June 20 (AP) -- The Tigers piled up a five-run lead in the first inning for Tommy Bridges today, but the Senators whittled away at the margin, tied the count at 6 -- all in the ninth and chased Bridges to the showers before Detroit came back with the winning run in the last half of the ninth for a 7-to-6 decision.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- When Prime Minister Winston Churchill landed again on American soil to confer with President Roosevelt, his unheralded visit raised again the always current question: Which way will the war turn now ?
BOSTON, June 20 -- Al Javery shut out the Pirates, 4 to 0, with three hits today -- the first time the Braves have registered a nine-inning shut-out this season.

The holder of a basic gasoline pittance of fuel gallonage or the business man with a card in an extra allowance group who has expended his quota and finds it necessary to make an unexpected business trip can still get behind the steering wheel of an automobile and drive off with the comfortable feeling of security that comes when the fuel indicator on the dashboard reads "Full."

TRADE activity was reported somewhat steadier in the week and may have gained against last year in dollar volume, although the closing weeks of June, 1941, brought soaring increases. Insistent urging from Washington that stocks must be brought to working minimums has led to greater promotional effort, particularly by larger concerns which do not relish sharing their warehoused goods with smaller stores, as war agency spokesmen have declared may be necessary.

The resources of the Metropolitan Museum of Art as a storehouse for the art of the past and a depository for information about those arts have been increased lately by its designation as custodian of the WPA Index of American Design.

WHAT was once just a simple New England farm nine miles east of Lee, Mass., will blossom out next month with, what is probably the largest crop of dancing to be found anywhere in the country this Summer.

A warning that the public schools of this country, faced by reduced revenues, may suffer lowered educational standards and curtailed classroom programs, is contained in a survey prepared by the research division of the National Education Association, made public last week.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The United Press dispatch published in THE TIMES recently and recording that two Japanese have been shot on Madagascar brings to mind an interesting bit about that island and the Japanese.
DORCHESTER HIGH SCHOOL had a senior prom in 1920 and one of the seniors was a 16-year-old stringbean who had been taught to waltz by his mother because she thought it was something he ought to know.

The Kee family, which has several branches down in Chinatown, is getting to be a definite problem to aspiring parents in the neighborhood. Yesterday, three members of the clan walked off with honors in an annual play day, held in Columbus Park, between Mulberry and Baxter Streets, under the auspices of the New York Council of Chinese Youth.
HAMMONTON, N.J., June 20 (AP) -- There'll be plenty of raspberries for New Jersey housewives this Summer -- thanks to young and eager hands who will combine work with, play on their Summer vacations.

RICHMOND, Va., June 20 -- The process of producing hats, gloves, girdles, foundation garments and brassieres from nylon fabric would be speeded and cheapened by a new way of cold-drawing these products, or stamping them out of flat pieces of nylon fabric, according to a patent (No. 2,285,967) granted to Vernal R. Hardy of Wilmington, Del. The patent is assigned to the E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co.

AMHERST, June 20 -- Massachusetts State College became a partner with civilian defense agencies and with the Army this week in an opening move to train specialized civilian personnel in methods of protecting the home front against bacteriological or chemical contamination of water or food supplies which might be caused by enemy gas or bombing attack or by saboteurs.

IN her adjacent article. Miss Anne T. Eaton, whose work as librarian of the Lincoln School has given her long and close acquaintance with the reading needs and preferences of children, emphasizes the importance of imaginative literature in the child's development.
PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad Company paid its president, M.W. Clement, a salary of $100,685 last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Another ten days should show whether the United States will pledge 10 per cent of the national income for buying war savings bonds and stamps, and present indications are that the voluntary purchase method sponsored by the Treasury is attaining its objectives.

OLIVER LA FARGE is rare among contemporary novelists for the disposition he has shown never to repeat himself. "The Copper Pot" is the courth novel he has published since "Laughing Boy," his beautiful and memorable study of the Navajo Indians, won the Pulitzer Prize more than a decade ago.

DANVILLE, Va. -- The war is about to stage a comeback for the old-fashioned "Summer hotel" in the South -- an establishment which remained annually popular but languished with the era of broad roads and purring cars. Such hotels are found scattered about, still enjoying a quiet dignity.

King George II of Greece, busy as he is with affairs of state and ceremonies attendant on his visit here, has given his royal sanction to a new war relief project designed to aid his countrymen who are suffering dire privation. Tomorrow a shop specializing in Grecian novelties will be opened under the sponsorship of Friends of Greece, Inc., at that organization's headquarters, 52 East Fifty-seventh Street.

MONTREAL, June 20 (AP) -- With the already strained rivalry between the clubs tautened by the beaning of Jack Graham, Montreal slugger, the Royals and Jersey City Giants split a double-header today. Montreal won the opener with a 17-hit barrage, 11 -- 5, and the Jerseys took the nightcap, 6 -- 5.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Prices of wheat held today within a range of 1/2 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade and fluctuated in an erratic manner, but the undertone was relatively firm and sufficient mill buying and commission-house support developed to hold the market above yesterday's closing level during most of the session.

Immediate coordination of "the four primary elements of national defense" -- the Army, Navy, Air Force and industrial mobilization -- with a civilian Cabinet officer at the head, was advocated yesterday at the close of the annual meeting of the Aeronautic Association at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Herman Hornig, former city entomologist here and in recent years entomologist of the Public Museum and Art Gallery, Reading, Pa., died of a heart attack today while waiting in line to pay taxes at the Reading City Hall.

LEWISBURG, Pa., June 20 -- Bucknell University will organize the talents of the college's various departments in presenting during the Fall term an honor seminar devoted to the general subject of Principles and Problems of Post-War Planning, it was announced today by Dr. William A. Shimier, dean of the faculty.

POINT PLEASANT, W.Va., June 20 -- A group of about twenty men attempted tonight to prevent distribution of an extra edition of The Point Pleasant Register reporting developments in a strike of Marietta Manufacturing Company employes.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- Stirred by reports of conditions of twelve to fifteen thousand Americans who are prisoners of the Japanese in or near Manila, newspaper men of San Francisco telegraphed a plea today to President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull to arrange "proper and adequate" means for sending relief.

THE President hag named as "directive" head of his newly created Office of War Information one of the most trenchant critics of the government's previous machinery for keeping the sovereign people of this country in vital touch with the progress and significance of the war's developments.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- With a single crisp order, the War Department undertook today to solve the problem of hasty marriages by members of American expeditionary forces in Australia, Northern Ireland and other overseas posts.
CHUNGKING, June 20 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command issued the following communique tonight:

Led by Muscles Medwick and Mickey Owen, former Redbirds, the Dodgers yesterday pounded four pitchers for fifteen hits, gave the Cardinal pennant aspirants a 10-4 beating and stretched their first-place margin to seven and a half games, their longest of the campaign.

A nation-wide campaign "to promote the physical fitness, health and morale of American war workers and civilans through recreational exercise" was begun by members of the dance profession with an all-day demonstration yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, followed in the evening by a "Dance Profession Victory Ball" for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 20 -- The war in which the United Nations are opposed to the Axis, its impact on life in the United States, its war aims and peace objectives, will be discussed during the sixteenth Institute of Public Affairs which the University of Virginia will sponsor for one week beginning July 5.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- A warning that California farm, production might fall below last year's level unless an adequate supply of agricultural labor was assured was sent today to Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, by James Mussatti, general manager of the California State Chamber of Commerce.

With three components registering gains, as against two losses and one series unchanged, THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity moved fractionally higher for the week ended June 13, The figure was 131.4 as against 131.0 in the preceding week and 130.0 for the week ended June 14, 1941.

As the war effort increases, it is imperative that every waste of manpower be stopped. One important waste is that caused by accidents, both on and off the job. Last year accidents meant the death or injury of 9,401,500 persons and the loss of hundreds of millions of man-days of labor.

ADIRONDACK MOUNTAINS -- With the approaching Fourth of July week-end, resort communities in the eastern Adirondack range are all set to begin another season of vacation activities. Most of the sports and social events slated for July and August will be tied in with the victory effort; Independence Day, especially, will be marked by appropriate celebrations at every resort from Saratoga Springs to the northernmost Adirondack points.
"Will your mother let you?" one child asks another. "Ask your mother," says the grownup. Nobody asks father.

Glenn L. Martin, Baltimore aircraft manufacturer, has agreed to give the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences during the next five years a science research endowment valued today at $500,000, the institute announced yesterday. The donor asked that studies be made of means to make high-altitude flight safer for war pilots.

BUFFALO, June 20 (AP) -- Pounding Floyd Giebell, the league-leading Bears scored eight runs in the second inning and gained an 18-to-4 decision over the Bisons tonight. The victory gave Newark three out four in the series.

GREENSBORO, N.C., June 20 -- Entering upon the second half century of its history, the Woman's College of the University of North Carolina faces as its biggest immediate problem an intensive survey of the curriculum, with the view of revamping it to meet present-day needs.

That there were 433,000 young men refused active service in the Army because of illiteracy was no surprise to school teachers; but it burst like a bombshell in the news. People at once began to calculate. Here were at least 150,000 physically fit -- probably 100,000 more which a little medical, dental, or nutritional treatment could make into good fighting men.

Approximately 6,000 brokers and dealers in securities engaged in interstate transactions who are registered now with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 may be required to meet somewhat stiffer qualification requirements in order to continue in business if the trend of thought in commission circles is transcribed into official action.

FRENCH dressing is standard in the salad bowl, but, like almost every other good thing, it may become tiresome unless changes are rung upon it now and then. A variation still possible in spite of war conditions is the rich and biting roquefort dressing which may be made with the many excellent "blue" cheeses now being produced in this country.

Entertainment for the WAAC's is the newest concern of the USO and Mrs. Maurice T. Moore, vivacious director of the women's division, has plans humming in their behalf. She confides that it looks like a great boon to the USO program.

Considerable ingenuity must be exercised by the Army building industry in developing new materials or new uses for existing materials in order to insure continued production of war housing in the face of growing shortages of many basic building materials, points out Federal Housing Commissioner Abner H. Ferguson.

PEDESTRIANS in major American cities soon may carry about on their backs a new war-emergency service -- two-way radio sets sprung, literally, from the "junk boxes" of amateur operators and radio repairmen of the nation.

NEW acquaintances, when they hear that I am an actress, have an annoying habit of saying to me, "Are you playing in anything at present?" I can never bear to answer this awkward question completely in the negative.

Buyers able to pay "all cash" for Manhattan properties always have paid lower prices than those who carry out negotiations with small down payments, and this favorable position of the investor with ready money has been particularly evident in recent months.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Closing of the schools in the metropolitan areas is usually the signal for families with children to start taking vacations, so Vermont Summer resort areas are prepared for an influx of guests during the remainder of June and early July.

QUENTIN REYNOLDS is one of those foreign correspondents who are called by their first names by First Lords of the Admiralty, and who like every one except vegetarians and total abstainers. The present book was written during a period of comparative quiet and enforced leisure -- namely, during a twenty-three-day voyage in convoy from Cardiff to Halifax between Dec. 26, 1941, and Jan. 18, 1942.
Important golf fixtures, as well as a top tennis tourney, are on the schedule for women this week.

SOMETIME this week interested Washington officials will get their first look at the feature-length film document of events leading up to Pearl Harbor and America's participation in the war on which Sam Spewack, playwright, has been working since last January.

Hospitals are hanging out the welcome sign to women physicians these days. Fledgling women doctors, once excluded from the hospital fraternity, are being snapped up as fast as the ink dries on their medical diplomas to fill vacancies left by men internes going into the Army and Navy Medical Reserve Corps.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., June 20 -- Scoring a three-under par 68, G. Foster Brown Jr. of Tedesco, Mass., and J.W. Reynolds, home club star, tied T. Desmond Sullivan, unattached, and G.K. Brown today in the first round of the tenth annual John F. Roche memorial golf tournament at the Maplewood Club.

A patrolman seated in a radio car parked on West 140th Street near Amsterdam Avenue was fatally shot at 10:25 o'clock last night after a bitter quarrel with his police partner, who later was found to be too intoxicated to be questioned and was suspended and held at the West 152nd Street Station.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 30 (AP) -- War and its problems affecting the States will dominate the discussion at the annual Governors' conference, which opens here tomorrow. Thirty-nine States have sent their Governors here and others have named high officials to represent them.

Cape Cod has gone in for civilian defense in a big way, and the busiest person on the entire Cape appears to be Asey Mayo's Cousin Jennie. Asey knows nothing of her various activities because he, too, has been busy helping Bill Porter build tanks.

At the twentieth annual conference of the Milbank Memorial Fund in New York Dr. John H. Foulger, director of du Pont's Haskell Laboratory of Industrial Technology, rose to tell his audience that vitamin C is a boon to war workers in these hot Summer days. Like salt, vitamin C is drained from the perspiring body.

How dwellings of eighty or more apartments should be organized as air-raid defense units and how tenants and building employes are to divide the necessary tasks is explained in an Office of Civilian Defense pamphlet received yesterday at the Second Regional Office, 111 Eighth Avenue, for distribution to State and local War Councils in New York, New Jersey and Delaware.

Which New York? As a friend of the common people what could the Governor of Georgia have been doing in the best New York hotels on his visit here? His most loyal followers at home must have been troubled by that inadvertent confession.

The Coast Guard's identification card system, which was placed in effect more than a year ago by Captain John S. Baylis, United States Coast Guard, Captain of the Port, already has grown beyond the peak volume of the identification system in effect in the last war, it was announced last week.

NORTH CREEK -- Because forests are vital to the war effort, many conservationists have expressed grave concern over the fire hazard that will readily mount during Summer months when vacationists enter the half-billion acres of forest land in the United States.

The cotton futures market advanced moderately yesterday and closed 13 to 15 points higher than Friday's final quotations, the trade becoming a good buyer in the last half hour on the New York Cotton Exchange. Active months rose easily on buying by mills because of a dearth of contracts, although earlier in the session dealings had lagged while traders concentrated on liquidating and switching the July position.

Revision of the New York City high school curriculum in keeping with contemporary needs, was recommended in a survey made public yesterday by Professor Harold H. Abelson, director of the City College Education Clinic. The study was conducted to determine how well the present science instruction is training students to meet war emergencies.

Carl J. Broadland, 40 years old, a Salvation Army worker for thirteen years, was found stabbed to death early yesterday in a room at the Times Square Hotel. He had been here on a two-week vacation from Grand Rapids. Mich., where he was district welfare finance officer.

"As we look back * * * and realize the alterations in our point of view I prophesy that the changes a year from now will make those of the past year appear small in comparison." The words are those of Dr. Frank H. Lahey and they come from the address that he made to the American Medical Association as its outgoing president.

FOR years we have been hearing cries of "Wolf!" on the subject of inflation. Like the men in the fable, some of us stopped paying attention long ago. But in the fable the wolf came. Now inflation has come.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The appointment of Elmer Davis, radio commentator, author and former reporter, as director of government news and propaganda was taken as a concession by the Administration of the need for a better information service and as an expression of its hope that the most glaring faults of the prevailing system can be corrected.

CLEVELAND, June 20 -- Yankee operations dipped to a new low at Municipal Stadium today when the world champions were shut out with one hit. Lefty Al Smith, the Giant cast-off who recently had snapped Tiny Bonham's winning streak, performed the feat as the Indians toppled the California giant again, this time by 1 to 0.

THIS is a typically Katharine Brush story about Hobey Hadley, a boy from Maine, and Rosalie Hastings, the beautiful gray-eyed blonde, who was the one love of his life. It is so typical that practically all the titles of her other books fit patly into a casual description of it.

THE thirteenth season of Summer concerts at Robin Hood Dell will open tomorrow night. Eugene Ormandy will conduct the first program and Lawrence Tibbett, the Metropolitan baritone, will be the soloist. The purely orchestral offerings to be played by the Robin Hood Dell Symphony, which is composed largely of members of the Philadelphia Orchestra, will include Beethoven's Fifth symphony, the prelude to Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" and Strauss' "Death and Transfiguration."

Impelled by an immediate demand for more engineers for the war effort, but with a view toward long-range needs for professional engineering training in the rapidly growing Long Island region, a new development in engineering education has been inaugurated by New York University's College of Engineering and Adelphi College.

These surveys are made by a system of highly selective samplings in each of the forty-eight States in proportion to voting populations; thereby, the American Institute of Public Opinion holds, is obtained a result which would, not vary from that of a much larger canvass.

If the medical societies fail to provide adequate medical and maternity care, "there is undoubtedly more than a threat of state medicine," Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, warned yesterday in a talk at the New York Academy of Medicine.
LONDON. RECENTLY the A.D.C. (Amateur Dramatic Club) of Cambridge University wrote a line or two of theatrical history by giving the first performance in England of Maxwell Anderson's "Key Largo."
When we left the Simplon Express at Istanbul, Lalezar Sadri, the furniture manufacturer from Teheran, who furnished the Shah's palace, said to me:

Details have been completed for the distribution of the Herman E. Mellenthin Memorial Fund, which is being accumulated to honor the memory of the foremost breeder and exhibitor of cocker spaniels in the United States. This fund will be disbursed to exhibitors in the form of cash prizes and trophies at five leading shows over a period of five years, beginning with the Westminster Kennel Club's sixty-seventh annual fixture in Madison Square Garden next February.
A PROGRAM of American folk music, "Folk Songs on the Firing Line," presented under the auspices of the Negro Publication Society, will be heard Friday night at Town Hall.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 20 -- Finnish-American relations were the subject today of an editorial in the organ of the Finnish Social Democrats, the Suomen Sosialdemokraatti.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 20 (AP) -- A high government source said today that Argentina, one of two American nations that still "maintain diplomatic relations with the Axis, would not seek shipping immunity under the extended German submarine blockade that becomes effective June 26.

A nation-wide survey, conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES, shows that 82 per cent of the institutions of higher learning in the United States do not require the study of United States history for the undergraduate degree. Eighteen per cent of the colleges and universities require such history courses before a degree is awarded.
CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady today after a week of advances in hogs and declines in cattle and sheep. Not enough animals were on sale to test the market.

PROMOTION: An honor believed unprecedented in the recent history of the United States Army came last week to a 53-year-old veteran of the Air Corps. In a list of promotions submitted to the Senate for confirmation, President Roosevelt recommended the advancement of Delos C. Emmons, commander of the Hawaiian Department, from colonel to major general on the permanent list, skipping the rank of brigadier general.

SHELTER ISLAND -- While Shelter Island, along with all resorts, has been dependent on automobiles, it can do without them. The island is easily reached by Long Island Railroad, and automobile and train passengers must join at the same point, Greenport, for the eight-minute ferry ride to the island.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (U.P.) -- The $25,000 yearly limitation on salaries proposed by President Roosevelt but turned down by Congress, will apply generally to per- WASHINGTON, June 20 sons working on war contracts, officials declared today.

EDDIE DOWLING'S plans for the new season apparently are all set. He is going to revive Gilbert Keith Chesterton's "Magic." This "fantastic Comedy," as G.K.C. called it, has only once been seen on Broadway and only twice in New York.

The bugbear of a possible Federal system of compulsory saving as a means of closing the "inflationary gap" between the incomes of consumers and the quantity of goods left for them to buy still is interfering with sales of war savings bonds and is cutting the normal rate of increase in savings bank deposits.
On a desk in Washington today lies a sheaf of pages that provide for the mental and material salvation of a tragic army of Americans -- the newly blinded.

LONDON, Sunday, June 21 -- Taking advantage of the first spell of favorable flying weather that has prevailed for several days, the Royal Air Force pressed its offensive again Friday night, a "strong force" of the biggest planes bombing points in Northwest Germany, especially the port of Emden.

Funds to purchase sulfa-compound drug's will be raised by the women's division of Russian War Relief from proceeds of a luncheon to be held on Tuesday at the Hotel Astor. The event will be this group's main campaign effort during Russian War Relief Week, closing next Sunday.

A plan has been formulated by the Urban Land Institute with the object of enabling the private building industry to engage in slum clearance on a large scale at the close of the war. It suggests Federal loans for acquiring large tracts of land in blighted areas to be redeveloped by private builders in accordance with a city plan for the entire metropolitan district, after approval by the citizens of the area.

Although furniture manufacturers are generally pessimistic about buying activity during the market week which opens in the New York Furniture Exchange tomorrow, it was hoped yesterday that a warning on transportation problems in the Fall, which was distributed among 10,000 retailers earlier in the week by the exchange, would bring about a last-minute change in buying plans.

STANTON, Del., June 20 -- Setting a new track record of 2:03 for a mile and a quarter, the Greentree Stable's Corydon settled an old score with Arnold Hanger's Dit when he defeated that racer by a head in the $10,000 added Sussex Handicap at Delaware Park today.

LONDON, June 20 -- Streams of refugees have poured into India in recent weeks from Burma. The Japanese have moved their air fields within striking distance of Chittagong and Calcutta, the latter a vital center for the supply of Indian-manufactured arms to the soldiers defending the border.

IT is impossible to withhold admiration from the energy the aging H.G. Wells exhibits in the writing of books. This one, a novel, is something of a surprise, for Mr. Wells has returned, in some measure, to the genre he made famous with the "History of Mr. Polly."
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 20 -- With the beginning of the vacation season, society folk from communities throughout the East are returning to their Summer homes and camps in the Adirondacks.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- The name of the Rabbit Club bids fair to be inscribed in the annals of the history of the financial industry in the United States as the place where brokers and members of the Securities and Exchange Commission looked this week upon one another and found that neither wore horns.

GENEVA, N.Y., June 20 -- Selected undergraduate students from all departments of Hobart and William Smith Colleges are serving as research assistants in a survey which will cover the social and economic history of this community from its founding down to the present time.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 20 -- Next week-end will be marked by three benefits for United Service Organizations here. On Saturday afternoon a bicycle scavenger hunt being organized by Mrs. Thomas Aquin Kelly, Mrs. Lee Bouvier and Mrs. S. Kip Farrington Jr. will start from the flagpole on the Village Green.

Because of a shortage of radio operators, two merchant vessels under the United States flag were delayed in sailing from American ports last week, and union officials warned yesterday that the shortage would become more acute in the next few weeks.

Ten new war training courses will be started July 6 at New York University. Eight of the courses will be for both men and women, and two will be restricted to women, it was announced yesterday by Dr. John T. Madden, dean of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance.

The New York State office of the Federal Housing Administration, which last week completed its eighth, year in the mortgage-insurance business, has since its inception insured mortgages on 56,473 single-family homes representing a monetary value of $285,769,208, Thomas G. Grace, State director, reported yesterday.

THE new Alec Hudson (he is Lieutenant W.J. Holmes now back in the Navy) is the first of his tales in which no submarine plays an important role. It is a story of the part played by a destroyer in a naval engagement at night and of her skipper, Lieut. Comdr. Shears.
ST. LOUIS, June 20 (AP) -- Today was Roger Wolff Day but the Athletics' pitcher couldn't produce a victory for a group of visitors from his home town of Chester, Ill.

FIRST FLIGHT: For the first time in her life a 62-year-old lady climbed into an airplane last week. She settled down for the long trip from, England to Canada, her first Atlantic crossing. She was Wilhelmina, Queen of the Netherlands. At the airport outside Ottawa she was met by her daughter, Princess Juliana, whom she will visit this week.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -- The 300th anniversary of the first ascent of Mount Washington by Darby Field, who climbed to the summit in 1642, will be observed this month, and the cog railway, which has carried thousands of passengers to the summit since 1869, already is operating on a limited schedule this month, to be increased as the season warrants.

Lord BYRON was never one of those mean little men who did their worst to corrupt the relations between the English and the Americans. He said so himself, adding, "to America only can I look for anything like justice in the appreciation of my real sentiments on the rights of mankind."

LONDON, June 20 (AP) -- All persons within the German Reich who are deemed irresponsible, lazy, quarrelsome, immoral or in any way disinclined toward wholehearted support of the war effort were marked down by the Nazi party today for a ruthless purge which already has gotten under way in Vienna and the Austrian Province of the Lower Danube.

MOSCOW, Sunday, June 21 -- The Germans continued last night to batter Sevastopol with some 150,000 men and hundreds of planes and tanks and at the same time registered a new advance in a revival of fighting on the Kharkov front, the Russians announced early today.

LOURENCO MARQUES, in Portuguese East Africa, is the point chosen for exchanging home-coming American nationals from Japan and homegoing Japanese from here. The place, though half the world away from either end of the route, seems to be about the only available neutral spot, short of the South Pole, at the present moment in history.

In Vichy last week Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, one-time defender of Verdun, now 86-year-old chief of a conquered State, spoke to Frenchmen on the second anniversary of the armistice with Hitler's Germany. Nearly 2,000,000 of his countrymen were still prisoners of war, three-fifths of France was occupied by the Invader.

The Princeton baseball team's superiority in the Eastern Intercollegiate League race is emphasized by the final statistics, which were released yesterday. The Tigers, who won the championship by the margin of five games, took fourteen and tied for another of the thirty individual or team titles at stake.

NEARLY all of the recordings of full operas have been made abroad. The reasons are obvious. Costs have been cheaper, especially the costs of the orchestra. But the war has cut off this source of supply, and if there are to be further recordings of operas, they will have to be made here.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 20 -- At the end of nine miles of racing out on Long Island Sound today Corny Shields's International sloop Aileen defeated Albert Marx's Alberta in a nose finish by a fraction of a second. It was in the special regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- The Skytop Club will hold its twelfth annual women's invitation golf tournament, fifty-four holes of medal play, on June 29, 30 and July 1. Miss Dorothy Germain of Philadelphia was low gross winner in this event last year.

The new German ordinance requiring holders of corporation stocks and bonds to surrender them to the Government in exchange for treasury bonds is an extraordinary measure. Its primary purpose must be to close the one important remaining avenue through which inflation could be registered.

THE murder victim is Courtney Barnes, and a right good victim too. He is a war correspondent, widely read and widely detested because of his acid comments on everything and everybody with the sole exception of Adolf Hitler.

ST. LOUIS, June 20 (AP) -- In mild upsets, two of the four top favorites were defeated in the national clay court tennis championship today as Seymour Greenberg and Gardner Larned, both of Chicago, William Talbert of Cincinnati and Harris W. Everett of Jacksonville, Fla., advanced to the semi-final round.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 20 -- That the execution of General Alois Elias, former Premier of Czechoslovakia, was but an earnest of Gestapo determination to put down a situation characterized by a semi-official Berlin spokesman today as "revolt" in the protectorate was borne out by indications throughout today of at least forty-five more executions in Prague and Bruenn.
LISBON, Portugal, June 20 (AP) -- Nine hundred and forty-nine North and South Americans evacuated from Axis countries boarded the Swedish liner Drottningholm tonight for back home.
