Stocks did little yesterday. After drifting in narrow ranges on a volume of 127,060 shares, they closed irregularly easier on the New York Stock Exchange. On the Curb Exchange the volume of 18,120 shares was the smallest since Saturday, Aug. 24, 1940.

GUILFORD, Conn. -- The Connecticut shore is now adapting itself to a dimmed-out Summer which already shows more promise than even the most hopeful had anticipated. Already numbers of families have arrived at their Summer homes and real estate men, hotel operators and local officials report that season leases and the number of permanent Summer residents have surpassed any recent year.

With their supply of fuel oil reduced by government orders to 50 per cent of normal requirements, owners of homes and apartment buildings in the New York district already are casting about for means of keeping their buildings adequately heated next Winter.

Valdina Orphan toppled Shut Out from his recently gained pedestal as 3-year-old champion by leading from start to flnish of the $29,650 Dwyer Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday as 23,833 gasped at new track record figures. It is true that Valdina Orphan, with only 116, had a ten-pound pull over Shut Out, but none was disposed to take any credit from the Valdina Farm star when the time was flashed on the board.

CHUNGKING, China, June 20 (AP) -- Toiling over some of the most difficult terrain in the world, two groups of surveyors are mapping a new supply line from India to China, which the Chinese hope may be in operation before the end of the year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "Psychological weapon," "psychological warfare" and "morale" are frequently used terms. As yet they mean nothing precise, because the actual techniques are not described and because there is no conception of how psychological defense and morale can be built up.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Under-Secretary of State, Mr. Welles, has made a second speech urging that a long armistice precede the making of peace after victory; the plan has received full support in the important book by Herbert Hoover and Hugh Gibson, just published; and still no responsible American voice has been raised in dissent.

SYRACUSE, June 20 -- Governor Lehman called upon both major parties today to set aside considerations of self-interest and political expediency and to nominate Gubernatorial candidates who had demonstrated "by their character and their acts that they are against isolationism, against compromise, against any yielding to reaction."

A program to train all 26,000 physicians in New York State to diagnose and treat persons suffering from poison gas will be undertaken in a few weeks, it was announced yesterday by Dr. David D. Rutstein, recently appointed consultant on medical aspects of chemical warfare for the medical division of the Office of Civilian Defense.

THE unconventional daughter of an Englishman who "came out of Sandhurst with such a ponderous knowledge of Greek and Latin that it would have submerged a lesser man" has dedicated to him, here, the story of the highlights of a career as untrammeled and forthright as his own.

Rooms can be practically made over by clever little touches, as every home decorator knows. One recipe for relieving that feeling of stereotyped monotony which may come over almost any interior is to put in a set of wall shelves or pair of brackets.

Richard D. Chapman, former national amateur champion, and Ray Billows, holder of the New York State amateur title, share the honor spot on the first list of Metropolitan Golf Association handicaps for the current year.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- A proposal to make every warship of the fleet (from destroyer to battleship) a carrier of fighting planes was advanced today by members of a Senate committee considering a House - approved $8.500,000,000 Naval Expansion Bill.
LONDON. THE increasing vogue of autobiography is regarded by Gilbert Thomas as a healthy sign of the times. In his opinion, it marks a definite advance in a right sense of values.

TODAY, embattled Russia is producing war films almost as fast as America is turning out Jeeps. Like the defense plants, the film studios in all parts of Russia are operating full blast, twenty-four hours a day -- even the exiled Ukrainian cinema now in far-off Tashkent, in Central Asia, near the border of India.

By far the most widely distributed and most provoking of lawn pests is crabgrass, a fifth-columnist type of weed that sneaks in in the innocent-looking garb of just another item in the lawn grass mixture, to begin one of the slickest subversive operations in the plant world.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Time now to order pot-grown Strawberries if a full crop of berries is desired next year. . . . Many plants in the rock garden, now through flowering, look better if trimmed back to new growth, and will be more likely to produce some flowers in the Fall. . . . Last call for giving the lawn a pre-Summer application of a complete plant food; water in thoroughly at once.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Leon Henderson told a press conference today that he would be willing to resign as Federal Price Administrator if Congress imposed his retirement as a condition for authorizing subsidies to be used to keep consumer prices stabilized.

To the Drama Editor: AS the director of the current revival of "Porgy and Bess," I feel called upon to answer Glenn Flickenger of Buffalo who discussed the show in his letter to you in a recent Sunday's Drama Mailbag.

WE have reaped during the past year a bumper crop of vocational books covering a wide field of subjects. Although the majority of them were written before the present situation had altered the immediate outlook for many young people as well as certain aspects of the professions and vocations, young readers who must find their places in a postwar world wall find in them pertinent suggestions and basic information which are still valid and stimulating.

Some persons fortunate enough to travel for business or pleasure have returned to the East in recent weeks with eyewitness stories of general disregard in the Midwest for wartime conservation by motorists.

CHESTER -- Near New York City there are many charming old towns and villages worthy of a visit. The main arteries of travel have by-passed them, and much of the old-time atmosphere remains to delight the eye of the casual passer-by and lover of the historic.
The annual list of committees of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York for 1942-43 was made public yesterday.

Aboard a ferry to the Palisades a dozen members of an uptown camera club were heading across the river for a Saturday afternoon field day. Several of the group were old hands, as festooned with equipment as any paratrooper. Ruthie had only a lot of enthusiasm and a small box camera.

King George II of Greece, in greeting 2,000 Greek-Americans attending a dinner in his honor last night at the Hotel Astor, said the war was certain to end with victory for the United Nations and "out of it will come the complete liberation of the world."

MANY drafted men and volunteers in the service must be wondering what to do about the rent at home, the payments on car or furniture, the note at the bank, insurance premiums, taxes, and getting their old jobs back when the war is over.

The Canal Zone Philatelic Agency in Balboa Heights on July 1 will begin selling canceled-to-order Canal Zone official stamps bearing the overprint "Official Panama Canal." Behind this development is the fact, not set forth in the postal administration's formal announcement last week, that this series, fourteen varieties, has been bringing prices ranging from $400 upward in the United States.

"I, JAMES BLUNT" is a diary of the German occupation of England, and it is dedicated to all complacent optimists who think that "it can't happen here." The time is the six-month period from September, 1944, to March, 1945.
Answers of OPA officials to rent control questions raised by property managers in recent conferences are reported in the current issue of The Journal of Property Management.

In the first week of the rubber-scrap campaign New York State has collected 1,108 tons, including 391 in the New York City metropolitan area, according to preliminary figures made public yesterday by Eugene F. McCable, local chairman of the Petroleum Industry's Rubber Salvage Committee, cooperating with the War Production Board.
Flames roaring through a paper loft in southwest Greenwich Village yesterday crumpled its walls and virtually wrecked the block bounded by Washington, Clarkson Greenwich and Leroy Streets.

With the State party conventions barely two months away, little chance remains of stopping Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for the Democratic nomination for Governor and no chance at all for stopping Thomas E. Dewey for the Republican nomination.

New York filling stations reported a record drought yesterday. Dealers who had no gas did not trouble to unlock their pumps. Those who opened for business with a small supply were dry in most instances by 11 A.M.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The ordinance of the Reich Ministry of Economy concerning the trading of stocks and bonds may be interpreted as the first step in Germany's economic system toward very important changes.

Moscow. IT is a long time since the fables to the effect that musical culture of the Slavonic nations represents a secondary branch of European music has been utterly confuted. In the course of many centuries, particularly the eighteenth and nineteenth, Slavonic musicians proved the right of their art to claim permanent historic significance.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., June 20 -- Ten picked chess experts started play today in the fourth annual invitation tournament at the new casino at the Municipal Pier. Mayor Harry S. Hodson, Councilman E. Lynas Wood, Richard W. Wayne, tournament director, and I.F. Daily addressed the gathering at the opening session.

SHOSTAKOVICH'S Seventh Symphony was flown to this country in a small circular tin. The score and parts were printed on a 100-foot roll of 35-millimeter microfilm. It is probably the first time a major symphonic work has been transported in this fashion.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Office of Price Administration today announced the granting of permission to importers to sell imported commodities, under certain conditions, to industrial and commercial users at prices above those paid in March.

WHEN Adolf Hitler promised his armies they would be better prepared for the next Winter's campaign his words must have been greeted with mixed sentiments by the German troops now fighting in the Soviet Union -- mixed, in that the troops dreaded the thought of still another campaign in the endless snows of Russia, but at the same time hoped to Valhalla they would be out-fitted more warmly and established in better bases.

To the dangers besetting shipping of the United Nations off the East Coast of America from shellfire and torpedoing by Axis submarines, which have accounted for nearly 300 cargo vessels since last December, there was added yesterday the certainty of submarineplanted enemy mines, which have already taken a toll of at least two merchantmen.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 20 -- A.H. (Bud) Kroeger was distinctly on his game today as match play started in the sixth annual best-ball invitation golf tournament of the Cherry Valley Club, and he moved into the semi-final round without the aid of a single hole from his partner, George Wagner of the host club.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- Plans are well under way here and in adjacent resorts for furthering the work of war relief agencies and in arranging entertainments to be held during the coming weeks. Daily work at the local chapters of the American Red Cross is needed more than ever and this work is expected to be forthcoming.

Gasoline and tire rationing and war demands on the railroads, airlines and bus companies will make it necessary for many a New Yorker to look to his own back yard this Summer for the relaxation that he has previously found at his favorite mountain or seaside resort.

ONE way of defining any river valley is by function, the uses men have put it to. The Allegheny River is a natural link between the Lake Erie country and the Ohio River, a waterway which early served as an emigrant route to the West.

An interesting picture of the simplicity that marked the founding of the New York Polyclinic Medical School and Hospital sixty years ago is presented by Dr. W. Morgan Hartshorn in his history of that institution that just has been privately printed.

CHUNKING, China, June 20 (U.P.) -- Heavy fighting in Kiangsi was reported in today's war com- munique, which said that "numerous" casualties had been inflicted on the Japanese and that the town of Wutu had been recaptured by Chinese forces.

IN announcing the forthcoming publication of "Prophets and Portents" by Rolfe Boswell, author of "Nostrodamus Speaks," the Thomas Y. Crowell Company informs us that there have been seven seers besides Nostrodamus who have foretold the doom of Hitler.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- Governor Olson's appeal to Washington this week for the immediate importation of thousands of Mexican farm workers to save California's crop emphasized a situation which all informed quarters are ready to term "serious" and which the Governor himself views as potentially "disastrous."

While even the poorest shrub is bound to have its good points, few of them really give the all-around satisfaction provided by the viburnums. Not particular as to soil, and natives of our own country as well as Europe and Asia, they may be found growing north and south, east and west, with most of the deciduous species being hardy as far north as New England.

"Haiti in Photographs," an exhibition of thirty-two pictures made by Albert Greenfield, traveler and amateur photographer of New York City, in the course of several visits to Haiti, opens tomorrow at the Brooklyn Museum, following a preview at 2 P.M. today.

PETOSKEY, Mich., June 20 -- In a factory being established here processing of 1,000,000 pounds of milkweed floss will start in August to furnish the Navy a substitute for kapok in life jackets and in lining of flying suits.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (U.P.) -- Brig. Gen. Harold L. George, chief of the Army air ferrying command, said tonight that the United States was not far behind Germany in technical development of gliders. He foresaw tremendous possibilities in their use as transports but emphasized that the use of gliders for long-distance overseas hauls was hardly feasible at this time.

The annual Pocono tournament, held at Buckwood Inn, at Shawnee, Pa., will be played over the coming week-end. This tournament customarily attracts the strongest field of any minor tournament, perhaps because the ranking players of New York and Philadelphia use it to practice for the national championships, which will begin on Aug. 3 at Asbury Park, N.J.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 20 -- Widespread violations of gasoline selling regulations and a growing contempt among gasoline station operators for the emergency rubber collections in this city were reported today to the OPA in Newark by William J. Culver, secretary of the local rationing board.
BERliN, June 20 (from German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

PHILADELPHIA, Juns 20 (AP) -- Elmer Riddle retired the first twenty men to face him today, then went on to chalk up a two-hit shut-out against the Phils as the Reds won their sixth straight game, 7 to 0.

The Nazi slaughter of hostages was denounced by rabbis in sermons here yesterday. The anniversary of Russia's entry into the war against the Axis tomorrow and the importance of buying war bonds were other sermon topics.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The military talks between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill continued in extreme secrecy, but on this third day of their conferences evidence has accumulated indicating there is some divergence between the British and American views, not with regard to fundamentals but with relation to the timing of action.

The presence of a large group of officers of high rank in the United States Army and Navy gave the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Artur Rodzinski, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium a distinctly wartime atmosphere.

The Eighth Annual Children's Dance Exhibition, sponsored by the Department of Parks, was held at 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon on the Sheep Meadow in Central Park. In a presentation of thirteen costume dances 500 girls and four boys, representing the parks of the five boroughs, participated.

When credit for final victory in this war is handed out much will go to China for her stout resistance to Japan, beginning in 1937; much to Britain for standing fast after the evacuation of Dunkerque; a very great deal to Russia for slugging it out with the Nazis after June 22, 1941.

Silvery "dural airliners of America's great commercial transport fleets may be seen daily winging along the airways. The planes are speeding both the war effort and the nation's essential civilian activity. Though split in operation the combined task is bigger than it was when domestic airlines reached their peacetime peak and led the world in efficiency, speed, safety and traffic volume.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 20 -- Best-in-show at the twenty-sixth annual exhibition of the Ladies Kennel Club today went to the American-bred white standard poodle Ch. Knight Errant of Salmagundi, owned by Justin W Griess of Hamilton, Mass., and shown in splendid condition by Walter Johnson.

A scream in the night, followed by four shots, awakens Jill Trent and her elderly cousin, Miss Julia Buchanan, who live next door to a house occupied toy a Mrs. Warner and her mother. The sounds appear to have come from the Warner house or grounds.

A huge hand-colored mural map of the world, fifteen feet, four inches high and thirty-two feet, six inches wide, will be displayed in the windows of the National Cash Register Company in the Associated Press Building facing Fiftieth Street beginning Wednesday or Thursday.

One of life's little disappointments is to put in good time in the kitchen preparing a picnic or a buffet lunch only to have the sandwiches get limp, the hot dishes cool off and the cold ones turn an uninteresting air temperature by the time people get around to eating them.

As against the millions of miles of frontiers and boundaries which land and water borne vehicles must face and cross, the air has no frontier, no fixed roads, no physical barriers. The barriers are only in men's minds. American technical genius and manufacturing skill already assure air vehicles capable of leadership on all the skyways when peace returns again.

ALTHOUGH the annual round-up of art books was begun confidently enough, space ran out on us last Sunday, with much ground still uncovered, thus necessitating a second, and final, installment today. Remaining to be noticed, however briefly, are books of a learned, critical, analytical or primarily instructive nature; books that deal with American art, especially our "primitives," a group of catalogues, and some books that are included solely or chiefly because of the illustrations.
A new shipbuilding yard for the construction of a special type of vessel described only as "a modified cargo ship" is being prepared in the New York harbor area, it was announced yesterday.

No. 1 Warship The House Naval Affairs Committee voted last week to double the naval expansion program and spend $8,550,000,000 on a ship construction list different from any other ever to come before Congress. The program called for 400 long-range combatant vessels, 1,000 smaller, speedier craft.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Brewster Jennings gave a dinner dance last night at the River Club to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary Brewster Jennings.

One of the most important electrie power conservation programs to be evolved out of the war production program has just been developed in connection with the construction of aircraft engines. Airplane motors, a vital product of the nation's war industry, are now playing the dual role of powering the fighting forces and helping to supply electric power to reproduce themselves.
The campaign of the Mediterranean and Middle East opened a new chapter last week.

France has postally honored another of her citizens who won renown in the arts -- Alexis Emmanuel Chabrier (1841-94), composer. A 2-francs plus 3fr olive-gray semi-postal commemorates the centenary of his birth at Ambert on Jan. 18, 1841.

SWEATERS, sneakers and raincoats have been checked on the lists, name tapes sewn on blankets and bath towels. Tennis rackets, fishing tackle, cameras and flashlights have been collected. Mothers are getting the children ready for another Summer at camp. By July 1 the annual trek win be under way, and the children can hardly wait.

ATLANTA, June 20 -- At this blooming season of the year it is hard to visualize a war for survival. Amid the tobacco fields of Kentucky and the cotton fields of Georgia it is hard to remember that every ship sunk along the stricken Atlantic Coast drags down a particle of democracy with her or that every thrust at the Russians at Sevastopol draws the blood of freedom here.

Substantial increase in the volume of sales was shown by principal electrical manufacturing, office equipment and construction companies in the first quarter of 1942, compared with the same period in 1941, but net profits in the aggregate were slightly lower owing to the much heavier burden of taxes this year.

MOSCOW, June 20 -- Soviet Russia ends the first year of war profoundly and, many would say, permanently changed. In the long run it may be that the moat important of these changes has been in the minds and hearts of the Russian people, who have come to regard in a new light their country's past, their fellow-citizens and the lands with which they are now firmly bound in alliance.

HOLLYWOOD. WITH more than 80 per cent of his current film output consisting of government projects made on a cost-only basis, Walt Disney's cartoon production has become the most ambitious single part of Hollywood's contribution to the war effort.

Renewed activity was evident in wholesale apparel lines last week, but since market stringencies have moderated there was little inclination to speculate, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- With one round in the Hale America open tournament to go, Ben Hogan, Hershey, Pa., pro who yesterday set a new world record for major golf with a 62 on the Ridgemoor course, and Mike Turnesa of Elmsford, N.Y., are tied for the lead with fifty-four-hole totals of 203.

The girls of the first class at Hunter College to be graduated under the impact of all-out war in America admit that they are "a bit confused" on what their country is fighting for, it was revealed yesterday in a cross-section survey of 142 graduating seniors at the college.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- As a result of studies which show that the average college graduate does not participate in politics, and has cultural attitudes which in practice are little different from those who have not attended college, a new program, designed to prepare Students to face problems constructively, will be introduced next September in the College of Arts and Sciences of the American University.

Renewed activity was evident in wholesale apparel lines last week, but since market stringencies have moderated there was little inclination to speculate, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- With one round in the Hale America open tournament to go, Ben Hogan, Hershey, Pa., pro who yesterday set a new world record for major golf with a 62 on the Ridgemoor course, and Mike Turnesa of Elmsford, N.Y., are tied for the lead with fifty-four-hole totals of 203.

The girls of the first class at Hunter College to be graduated under the impact of all-out war in America admit that they are "a bit confused" on what their country is fighting for, it was revealed yesterday in a cross-section survey of 142 graduating seniors at the college.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- As a result of studies which show that the average college graduate does not participate in politics, and has cultural attitudes which in practice are little different from those who have not attended college, a new program, designed to prepare Students to face problems constructively, will be introduced next September in the College of Arts and Sciences of the American University.

The food trade, one of the most vocal in protesting the effects of the general maximum price regulation, has put new impetus into its campaign with the realization that, although no full-scale relief has been granted to meet its most pressing problems industry generally has only until Saturday to file protests against current difficulties.

LAKE PLACID - Saturday marks the opening of Lake Placid's eleventh annual Summer ice season. There will be patch skating, public skating and ice dance sessions daily until Labor Day on the 20,000-square-foot ice surface of the Olympic Arena.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided yesterday afternoon at the graduation exercises of Cathedral High School for Girls, attended by 2,000 persons in St. Patrick's Cathedral. A class of 407 girls, the largest number in the school's history, was graduated.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Army Air Force, from the commander, Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, to the specialists in charge of the various divisions, has given to the Aviation Writers Association a clean-cut picture of a great air force.

JAPANESE CULTURE -- The Japanese race and Japanese culture are hybrids derived from three major sources, according to Carl Whiting Bishop, Smithsonian Institution archaeologist, an authority on Far Eastern races. Mongoloids invaded the Japanese islands and gradually conquered the original inhabitants, the Ainus, of whom 20,000 are still alive.

LONDON. THE present popularity of the ballet has induced choreographers to make a wide search for new subjects, and apparently after the romantic type like "Les Sylphides"; the classical, like "The Good-Humored Ladies," and the fantastic, they are now opening up an era of ballets inspired by literary subjects.

DURHAM, N.H., June 20 -- A sharp clash, between pacifists and interventionists marked discussion of a proposed resolution on the church's relation to the war at a ministers' round-table discussion today as the biennial session of the General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches entered its third day.

TORONTO -- Canada's thousands of lakes and rivers Within overnight rail distance of the international boundary are expected to see more canoe travel this Summer than ever before. With motor travel restricted because of gasoline rationing vacationists who like to be on the move will take to the water in large numbers, and with gasoline for outboard motors and motor boats rationed the canoe paddle will come into its own again.

Harold W. Ross, editor of The New Yorker, became the target for the official wrath of the Bronx yesterday because of published comments that the residents of that proud borough and of Harlem were "an alarming bunch of people' whose incursions into the Connecticut countryside near his home had driven him into "panic, alarm and sheer terror."

Throughout the land, from, the greatest industrial plant to the smallest shop, from the most palatial mansion to the dingiest hovel, a new and embracing treasure hunt is on -- the frantic scramble for scrap and waste materials to feed the giant arsenal of democracy.

Aside from the work on the Fort Greene housing development in the Navy Yard section, and the apartment houses under construction by the Equitable Life Assurance Society in the Clinton Hill area, new residential construction work is almost at a standstill in Brooklyn, the Brooklyn Real Estate Board reported yesterday.

Executive Director. Board of Economic Warfare OUR country is settling down to the grim business of smashing the Axis powers. We are beginning to realize that the national problem is an individual problem. There is a growing sense of personal responsibility for winning this war.

The conversion of vacant stores into temporary housing units, points out Harold A. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, is a possibility that owners of such property may well investigate, and that should be explored quite thoroughly by local officials and civic groups concerned with the inventory and planning of space for housing war workers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: This letter is prompted by your editorial of June 5 "Relics of a Poet," and by the letter which appeared on June 13 over the name of Joseph Auslander relating to my late father, the poet Edwin Markham. Both refer to a much misunderstood subject, namely, the "My Biography," to which my father alluded a thousand times.

MOSCOW, June 20 -- The end of a year of Russia's war with Germany, coinciding with the end of the Spring, in which the threatened Hitler offensives failed to materialize, finds the Soviet Union's international relations firmer and more sincere than at any time since the revolution.

OTTAWA, June 20 -- Fifty-five Members of Parliament, including seven members of the Cabinet, took part during the past ten days in the debate on the extension of conscription to overseas service, and apparently the list of speakers is far from being finished.

Nation-wide business interest in the numerous plans now coming out to spur advance sales of consumer durable goods for delivery after the war has been stimulated to the point where at least one large trade association expects to introduce such a plan soon, it was learned last week.

More than 500 teachers met yesterday in the Central High School of Needle Trades, Twenty-fourth Street, near Eighth Avenue, to protest against the action of the Board of Estimate, which voted June 10 to eliminate the positions of 125 high schools teachers from the Board of Education budget.

MAY DAY morning in England -- only a few weeks ago, although in this environment it seems many years past in point of time and half the world away in matter of distance. An ancient city of Georgian houses amid the rolling hills of Somersetshire. Normally, peaceful sleeping city; certainly a place of no military importance.
NASHUA, N.H., June 20 -- Former Governor Francis P. Murphy set forth today his reasons for changing his party enrollment from Republican to Democrat.

While the question of policing OPA price ceilings has stirred up considerable controversy, the important problem of how to make price checking effective has been largely overlooked thus far, Roger Wolcott, executive secretary of the National Consumer-Retailer Council, said here last week.

It is rather disconcerting to read in this morning's TIMES that the colleges and universities of our country are slighting the study of United States history. When only 18 per cent of the institutions of higher learning deem American history essential to undergraduate students and when only 28 per cent require it of applicants for admission a problem arises that demands the careful attention of all serious-minded citizens and educators.

MARIE STERNER, impresario extraordinary, has enlivened the fag end of our art season with a big benefit show that proves both entertaining and, in its collective stature, impressive. It is being held at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, to aid the American Red Cross-admission 50 cents, students 25 cents.

CONGERS -- Now that the flow of gasoline seems to be at about its lowest ebb and such heretofore commonplace items as automobile tires and bicycles are to be valued above rubies, this long-time city dweller and pavement-pounder would like to get on the records his reactions to the pioneer life -- Summer of 1942 style.

Miracle of the Erie The Erie Railroad's prospects ninety-odd years ago were bright. Its main line had reached Buffalo, making the first rail link between seaboard and Great Lakes. In Wall Street quick minds, seeing other possibilities in the road, made it one of the first victims of the "bet 'em high" era of financial banditry and stock manipulation that lasted for fifty years.

Compensation in some measure for the fewer opportunities New Yorkers will have for motoring this Summer are the special paths for bicyclists which have been set aside in all five boroughs of the city, some in parks and others along scenic roads.

NORTH CREEK -- Forest rangers of the New York State Conservation Department have been tidying up the Adirondacks and Cats-kills for the arrival of the Summer public. The number of persons who will utilize the vast outdoor recreational resources of the up-State mountains is expected to be large because of their accessibility.

THE position and experience of the authors would make this a book of the first importance even if the subject and the ideas advanced in its pages were not of supreme interest to the American people as they harden their wills and fuse their energies to win the most decisive struggle in their history.

THE real stir in the Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday came when the clerk of the course summoned the competitors to the starting mark for the 1,500-meter event. That was the race that brought Leslie MacMitchell, Don Burnham, Leroy Weed, Bobby Ginn, Earl Mitchell, Gil Dodds, Prank Dixon, Ed Gulp and a few more to the mark and all the spectators to the edge of their seats.
Tomorrow there convenes in New York the sixtieth annual convention, of the American Seed Trade Association, and advance registrations indicate a record-breaking attendance.

Maxim Litvinoff, Russian Ambassador to the United States, and Harry Hopkins, Federal Lease-Lend Administrator, will be the principal speakers at a mass meeting to be held in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night in tribute to the armed forces of Russia for their year of fierce resistance to the Nazi armies, Allen Wardwell, chairman of the Greater New York Campaign of the Russian War Relief, Inc., announced yesterday.

"No Bass Fishing," a sign that makes good anglers see red, has been hauled down at Lake Vermillion, Ont. For in both the big and little lake (known by the same name) young fingerlings planted several years ago have grown and multiplied, multiplied until, according to informed sources, there are millions of small mouth black bass waiting for worms.
SEATTLE, June 20 (AP) -- Japanese invaders of isolated Aleutian Islands are "getting smacked whenever there is a rift in the fog banks," a Thirteenth Naval District spokesman said today.

LONDON, June 1. FOR the first time since the government took over Pinewood and renamed it the Joint Services Film Studios the press was conducted on an official tour of the pre-war glamour plant the other day.

The eleventh annual conference of the National Association of Seamen's Welfare Agencies opens in Portland, Me. next Saturday and will continue through the following Tuesday. The general theme of the conference, according to R. L. McAll, executive secretary of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, will be wartime service to merchant seamen.

THE urgent request that Hollywood and the motion-picture industry as a whole cut down on its use of raw film stock in order to release materials for the war can be -- if the boys apply it wisely -- a blessing in disguise.

COOPERATING with the current war bond drive, thirteen galleries identified with the promotion of American art have arranged to have the proceeds of all sales from shows put on for this purpose for the period of the drive, both for the artists and for the galleries, go into the purchase of bonds.

PACIFIC GROVE, Calif. -- Travelers who specialize in "collecting" lighthouses, this Summer will find that most of them are on a wartime routine. Now warfare is no new experience to lighthouses. They are born for battle. For the challenge of heavy seas and roaring weather never knows an armistice.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A Negro manpower service to work for full use of Negroes in the training and employment phases of the war production program has been set up by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission. Dr. Robert C. Weaver is director of the new division.

COOPERATING with the current war bond drive, thirteen galleries identified with the promotion of American art have arranged to have the proceeds of all sales from shows put on for this purpose for the period of the drive, both for the artists and for the galleries, go into the purchase of bonds.

PACIFIC GROVE, Calif. -- Travelers who specialize in "collecting" lighthouses, this Summer will find that most of them are on a wartime routine. Now warfare is no new experience to lighthouses. They are born for battle. For the challenge of heavy seas and roaring weather never knows an armistice.

Members of the Bayside Y.C. are largely manning not one but two flotillas of the Coast Guard Auxiliary on Long Island Sound. Flotilla 1201 was the first to be organized, and the recent promotion of its commander, George B. Dermody, to become junior captain of the Long Island North Shore Western Division of the Auxiliary was followed by the election of Edward Levanion to replace him.

John T. Madden, chairman of the Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign, reporting yesterday on the first week of the local drive, declared that the army of volunteer Minute Men had called on nearly 1,000,000 families in the city and had received pledges from 98 per cent of those visited.

John T. Madden, chairman of the Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign, reporting yesterday on the first week of the local drive, declared that the army of volunteer Minute Men had called on nearly 1,000,000 families in the city and had received pledges from 98 per cent of those visited.

Although the past week was confused, both in its war news and in taxation plans proposed, the stock market slowly recovered, regaining most of the previous week's losses. War news was not unfavorable so far as concerned our own participation, but the advance by the Nazis in North Africa and by the Japanese in China did much to offset the somewhat belated American bulletins from the Pacific.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., June 21 -- Abe Yanofsky, Canadian title-holder, beat Jeremiah F. Donovan, former Brooklyn College player, in the annaul invitation chess masters' tournament on the Ventnor Municipal Pier this afternoon for his second straight victory.

LONDON, June 21 -- A large number of British bombers hammered Emden, Germany, last night for the second night in succession and also other objectives in North-west Germany and air bases in the Netherlands.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP) -- Errors cost the Phils a chance to take both ends of a double-header with the Reds today. The Phils captured the first game, 3-2, but Cincinnati made a ninth-inning run to take the afterpiece, 2-1. Ray Starr held the Phils to five hits in this one.

Coleman Cheney, Professor of Economics at Skidmore College, Saratoga Springs, was nominated for Governor yesterday by the State Convention of the Socialist party at its local headquarters at 303 Fourth Avenue. The rest of the ticket follows:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 21 -- The famous imported Pekingese, Champion Che Le of Matson's Catawba, owned by Mrs. James M. Austin of Old Westbury, L.I., and handled by Mrs. Henry Sayres, today was awarded the top honors in the fourteenth annual all-breed fixture of the Monmouth County Kennel Club.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 21 -- On the second anniversary tomorrow of the armistice between Germany and France, Pierre Laval, Chief of Government, will broadcast from Vichy, France, and German Professor Grimm will lecture on "French-German Reconciliation."

The lower East Side, whose narrow, crowded streets are overhung with scores of banners honoring its sons in the armed forces, echoed with simultaneous ceremonies yesterday afternoon marking the close of United Nations Week.

The turn in legislative developments and sentiment in Washington, especially with regard to loans on major crops at full parity, faced fluctuations in the cotton futures market last wreek. The trade alternately bought and shied from purchases as conflicting reports on the Administration's views on the legislation emerged from the Capitol.

OSSINING, N.Y., June 21 -- Auxiliary Bishop J. Francis A. McIntyre of New York officiated at the ordination mass celebrated here today for twenty-five young men ordained to the Catholic priesthood at the Maryknoll Seminary of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America.

LONDON, June 21 -- A smashing blow delivered yesterday by waves of German tanks, heavily supported from the air, crushed the defenses of Tobruk in Libya. The War Office tonight confirmed the loss of the town, already claimed by the enemy who said 25,000 prisoners, including "several generals" had been captured.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 15 -- The Iron Mines Company of Venezuela has just completed the first year of a five-year program to prepare for exploitation the iron deposits in the State of Bolivar on the southern side of the Orinoco River.

TWO stories that may be of interest to sports followers came out of Washington, D.C., recently. One was the announcement that, beginning at midnight, June 30, the War Department was putting all soldiers in the field on a twenty-four-hour watch, so to speak. For the military men there will be no more mention in orders of such times as 5:30 A.M. or 7:22 P.M. after June 30.
A summary of recent War Production Board regulations and orders which directly concern the printing and publishing industry indicate the status of critical materials to be as follows:

PITTSBURGH, June 21 -- Dr. John R. Steelman, chief of the Conciliation Division of the Department of Labor, has taken over direction of mediation in the deadlocked wage controversy involving the Western Pennsylvania Motor Carriers Association and the local A.F.L. Teamsters Union, it was learned tonight.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 21 (AP) -- H. Lutcher Brown, San Antonio, Texas, oil executive, shot a perfect 100 and then racked up another 75 straight birds today to shake off three rivals and win the all-bore individual championship in the Great Eastern skeet championships.

Today, when men are asking for certainties, the church should enunciate the thing's we can live and die by, declared the Rev. Dr. Jesse M. Bader, executive secretary of the Department of Evangelism of the Federal Council of the Churches , of Christ in America, in his sermon yesterday morning'.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Special sectional, industrial and commercial interests, and also government agencies, still compete for relative advantage in carrying forward our raw materials program and thereby tend to thwart a total national war effort, according to a survey of measures being taken to replace United States strategic materials lost in Asia.

LONDON, June 20 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi has conditioned his opinion that the British should withdraw from India with a statement appearing in his weekly paper Harijan to the effect that military necessity made their presence desirable, according to reports from Bombay today.
NEW YORK Commander D.H. Harries, naval attache of the Australian Legation, and Mrs. Harries are at the Ritz-Carlton.

Hamilton Basso is doing for Reynal Hitchcock a book of social history in terms of biography that employs a somewhat unconventional technique. It works something like this: The book, entitled "Mainstream," has a hero, "the American himself" whom the author has named John Applegate.

Wholesale activity showed a marked improvement last week, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Last-minute commitments in preparation for Father's Day increased volume in the men's wear field, and establishment of ceiling prices on seasonal apparel enabled coat and suit manufacturers to introduce Fall lines.

THE vast armaments, the fighting skill and magnificent courage of the Red Army may prove to have been the decisive factors in the salvation of the human race from Nazi slavery. Our debt of gratitude to the millions of Russian soldiers who have fought and died in this war and who will continue to do so is beyond estimation or expression.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Monday, June 22 -- The Australian Minister of External Affairs, Dr. H. V. Evatt, returned home today after completing a special mission, to Washington and London. He was accompanied by his wife and was welcomed by a large number of relatives, friends and officials, including Army Minister F. M, Forde.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 21 -- Walt Disney, film cartoon producer, has bought the screen rights to Alexander de Seversky's new book, "Victory Through Air Power," and win use it as the basis of a feature-length cartoon which he expects to release next Fall.

CAIRO, Egypt, Monday, June 22 -- The capture of Tobruk gives the Germans their first objective of the present offensive. In twenty-six days they have pushed the British back into positions that are certainly no better, and perhaps are worse, than those held before the British offensive of last November.

Tankermen and other men of the American merchant marine literally go through fire to carry supplies to our armed forces in remote lands. Each week they are pulled or washed up out of the sea, after incredible hardships, or after death amid vast stretches of flaming oil.

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Ted Lyons pitched his 250th victory for the White Sox today by defeating the Red Sox, 6 to 5, in the first game of a double-header before 18,777. Boston won the second, 7 to 0, behind Tex Hughson's three-hit hurling.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Roosevelt was asked today by representatives of farm organizations, church groups and organized labor to carry to the people his fight against the farm bloc in Congress, which opposes his plan to sell government-owned wheat and corn below parity prices and his proposals for farm security.

American aeronautics is the richer today by reason of two generous gifts. Last week Mrs. Daniel Guggenheim, in memory of her husband, gave to the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences her estate of more than 160 acres near Port Washington, L.I. This will enable the Institute to make a direct contribution to the war effort by providing facilities for experimental aeronautical investigation.

The executive committee of the Federal Council of Churches, which embraces twenty-four denominations, appealed to churches yesterday to set their own houses in order in the matter of race discrimination, asserting that "men and women of all races should be warmly welcomed among their members."
Herewith, in order of their arrival, are the five new films coming to Broadway theatres this week:

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Little business in lard futures was transacted last week on the Board of Trade here and prices changed little. July closed yesterday at $12.62 1/2 and December at $12.82 1/2 a hundred pounds, or the same as a week before.

Business has been "virtually drafted" into partnership with the government, Miss Vivien Kellems, industrialist, declared yesterday. Addressing the opening session of the thirty-eighth annual convention and exposition of the Advertising Federation of America, in the Hotel Commodore, she said busines and industry must take increasing responsibility in government now and after the war.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices declined 0.1 per cent to 106.5. This decline resulted principally from sizable decreases in butter, beef and poultry prices, which caused a 0.9 per cent decline in foodstuffs index.

Five local representatives of the United Nations joined yesterday with several prominent Jewish laymen in calling for support of the United Jewish Appeal drive at the fourth annual luncheon of the Council of Organizations at the Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street.
DETROIT, Mich., June 21 -- Marygrove College has published a monograph, "A Spiritual Conquest: The Jesuit Reductions in Paraguay, 1610-1767."

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Japanese forces that have been operating in the western Aleutian Islands since June 3 have succeeded in occupying Kiska, 650 miles west of Dutch Harbor, strategic American operations base, the Navy Department announced today.

Wartime conditions have thrust new problems upon fishing devotees in this State, but apparently they are determined to continue participation in their favorite sport as much as possible, regardless of the accelerated pace in industrial production and the inconveniences caused in some areas by gasoline and tire rationing.

The worst gasoline drought in the history of the New York City area sad the Atlantic seaboard yesterday reduced motoring to a small fraction of the normal Sunday traffic. The police and other traffic observers estimated that Sunday motoring was cut 40 to 70 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Profits of American corporations during the first quarter of 1942, after reported tax deductions, were about 8 per cent less than in the last quarter of 1941 on a seasonally adjusted basis, the Department of Commerce estimated in an article to appear in the forthcoming issue of the Survey of Current Business.

PITTSBURGH, June 21 -- The output of steel ingots moved up 1 point last week in the nation to 99 per cent of rated capacity, but the fear was growing that shortages in scrap might prevail in the Winter unless extra efforts were made to build up supplies.

Determination of Americans of Slavic descent to go and remain "all out" for victory was emphasized yesterday at an all-day conference at the Manhattan Center, under the auspices of the American Slav Committee of Greater New York.

New Yorkers, afflicted with the first sweltering Sunday of the season under the gasoline shortage, stayed at home yesterday, sitting on the sidewalks or in penthouse or roof gardens, or went to near-by parks and beaches. Pleasure driving was only half of normal, by and large, and the resorts, particularly the distant ones, bore the brunt of the decline.
BERLIN, June 21 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The text of today's German communique:
CHUNGKING, June 21 (AP) -- The text of the Chinese communique today:

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 21 -- In an east-northeast breeze, full of life and on the nose as they went their way, forty-four craft competed today in the seventieth annual regatta of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club and the fourth one of the Long Island Sound championship series.

Stressing the difficulties charitable institutions are experiencing regarding earnings on invested assets, the Church Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church, in its twenty-fourth annual report just issued, reports assets of $35,650,000 and current pensions of 1,390,000 a year.
MELBOURNE, Australia, June 21 -- United States recognition of full Philippine independence was noted by President Manuel Quezon in a message received here today by General Douglas MacArthur.
This is a story for Summer -- about a new cold cream that's really cold, and also about the coolest bottle of cologne we've ever encountered.

Merchant ships of the United Nations, harried by German submarines which have sunk nearly 300 of them this year, are now exposed to the additional hazard of German mines. This revelation by the Navy Department, disturbing as it is, was to be expected. The Germans laid mines here in the last war.

LONDON, Monday, June 22 -- "Incontestable disaster" is the phrase applied by military observers in their discussions of the fall of Tobruk. In one swoop the Axis captured the excellent harbor before it could be wrecked as well as a quantity of stores that doubtlessly was large and may have been very big.

The Forest View and the Mountain View, two four-story apartment buildings at 14 and 16 Forest Street, Montclair, N.J., have been sold by Bud A. Lipnian to Ann Harrison for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $255,725. They occupy a plot 190 by 200 feet and contain fifty-four apartments of two to five rooms each.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 20 (Delayed) -- Lieutenant Virgil D. Anderson, co-pilot of one of the four American bombers forced down in Turkey after a bombing raid over Rumania, described today a dramatic fight for oxygen while flying five miles above the objective.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Washington Cathedral was the scene this afternoon of the American portion of an international broadcast in which the new Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Reverend William Temple outlined the role of the church and the victory responsibilities of the United States and Britain.
ST. LOUIS, June 21 (AP) -- The Athletics stopped the Browns' three-game winning streak today by sweeping a double-header, 4 to 2 and 4 to 3.

Charges that Mayor La Guardia has failed to give the Police Department orders to enforce the Army's dimout regulations, but has endeavored unsuccessfully to get the Army to modify its specifications, were advanced yesterday by two members of the executive board of the Lower West Side Defense Council, acting as a special committee in behalf of the council.

LONDON, June 21 -- A militant call for the immediate opening of a second front, coupled with the claim that the army is now adequately equipped to carry out a continental invasion, was voiced in Birmingham today by Lord Beaverbrook.

LONDON, June 21 (Reuter) -- A congregation in the Washington Cathedral, Washington, D.C., was addressed today by the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. William Temple, who spoke to them from the British Broadcasting Corporation studio here upon the use the two nations must make of the "almost unlimited economic power" they will wield after the war.

"Laugh, Town, Laugh," a "United Nations vaudeville show," with Ed Wynn as producer and master of ceremonies, opens tonight at the Alvin. Featured in the show will be Jane Froman, Carmen Amaya, Joe Smith and Charles Dale, Senor Wences, Red Donahue and his mule (Uno), Hermanos Williams trio, Ken Davidson and Hugh Forgie, and Emil Coleman, orchestra leader.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A series of amendments designed for the most part to simplify the application of the General Maximum Price Regulation have been announced by Price Administrator Leon Henderson. Price ceilings are not affected.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- A strong Congressional group was reported authoritatively today to be lining up for an effort to curb the appointive powers of Price Administrator Leon Henderson when his request for OPA appropriations of about $161,000,000 reaches the House floor.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The largest contract for the manufacture of American airplanes in South America was announced tonight by the Brazilian Embassy and by Richard S. Boutelle, vice president and general manager of the Fairchild Aircraft Division of Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation at Hagerstown, Md.
Big John Mize touched off two gaudy homers at the Polo Grounds yesterday, to the delight of 26,251 onlookers. But only one of these brought the Giants any lasting good.

BOSTON, June 21 (AP) --Pinch-hitter Eddie Stewart's tenth-inning triple with the bases loaded, plus the wildness of Boston pitchers and an error, gave the Pirates a 7-to-3 victory over the Braves today. A scheduled second game was postponed because of the weather.

Barges along the East River waterfront from the Battery to 125th Street and householders of that area yielded 1,944 pounds of rubber scrap to members of the Kips Bay Boys Club Boy Scout Troop 472 who toured the district yesterday and the day before in automobiles.

Father's Day was celebrated here yesterday by the Lexington Post of the American Legion in a program on the Mall in Central Park, at which a National Father's Day Medal was presented to Arthur S. Ash as "the outstanding father of the nation's industrial war front."

LONDON, June 21 -- The stock markets received a sharp check last week. This certainly was overdue, having regard to the indiscriminate buying reported recently in many directions, and technically it has improved considerably the position of the markets.

The Cardinals started the double-header at Ebbets Field yesterday seven and one-half games behind the first-place Dodgers, and when the crestfallen Redbirds walked off Ebbets Field with the doleful strains of "St. Louis Blues" from the pipe organ following them they still were that distance in arrears.

BERLIN, June 21 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Admiral Alberto di Zara, commander of the Seventh Division of the Italian Navy, told a German correspondent in an interview today that the Italian, light cruisers Eugenio di Savoia and Raimondo Montecuccoli received hits in the battle with a British convoy last Monday off Pantelleria Island in the Mediterranean.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Unfavorable weather conditions prevailed last week in parts of the main corn-producing belt and brought in a little buying on the Board of Trade here, but in the main the market was inclined to follow wheat, although having a range of only 1 cent a bushel.
JERSEY CITY, June 21 (AP) -- Jersey City climbed into second place, within three and a half games of first place, by defeating league-leading Newark today, 6 -- 3 and 5 --2.

Three hundred investment banking firms and dealers in securities throughout the country, armed with a 107-page prospectus similar to those employed in the marketing of new issues, will begin today solicitation of exchanges of National Power and Light Company $6 preferred stock for the common stock of the Houston Lighting and Power Company.

Defense Transportation Director Eastman has so impressed the country by his moderation that when he asks the people to abstain from unnecessary travel it seems reasonable to expect that they will do it. There will be vacations as usual except that travel for that purpose should be staggered, and start and return should be on week-days.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 21 -- On the anniversary of the outbreak of the Russo-German war many meetings were held today in Australia to pay tribute to the Soviet's gallant resistance. In a statement issued at Canberra Prime Minister John Curtin said:

NEW ORLEANS, June 21 -- Cotton futures here made small net gains last week despite a sudden dampening of spirits for those of the industry who long had held favorable prospects for loans at 100 per cent of parity.
DETROIT, June 21 (AP) -- The Tigers evened the score with Bobo Newsom today, but failed to gain ground in the league race by dividing with the Senators before 31,097 fans.

MADISON, Wis., June 21 (AP) -- Winning the war is going to make the capitalistic system work "because it will revive it with the new blood of full production," Thurman W. Arnold, assistant attorney general, said here today.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Washington was in a sober and realistic mood tonight. The fall of Tobruk and the situation of the Russians at Sevastopol have put a damper on the unrestrained second-front speculation that has surrounded the Roosevelt-Churchill talks.

John T. Madden, chairman of the Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign, announced yesterday that he had called a special meeting of borough leaders of the local drive for today to consider the advisability of extending it a few days.

WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET, at Sea, June 4 (Delayed) -- Today is the day. Mark it on your calendar in red ink, Thursday, June 4. It may be the one on which the tide definitely turned in the battle of the Pacific.

MOSCOW, Monday, June 22 -- The Russian High Command acknowledges in its communique this morning that the Germans have succeeded, at a high cost in lives lost, in driving a wedge into the defenses of Sevastopol. But the bulletin also reports the repulse of numerous severe German assaults on the Sevastopol front.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- On the first anniversary of the Nazi invasion of the Soviet Union, the United Nations find themselves in a position to exploit a major propaganda victory as a result of German embarrassment over the phrase "Spring offensive," according to a special report from official sources analyzing Nazi propaganda with relation to the Russian campaign during the past year.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 21 -- Premier Winston Churchill's third visit to President Roosevelt in less than a year constitutes the outstanding topic of German political comment and the conclusion reached is that the Allied statesmen are confronted with insoluble problems.

The American Bankers Association will mail today to the 15,000 banks of the nation a forty-page manual on war-production loans, generally known as Federal Reserve Board Regulation V loans, which are guaranteed by the Reserve Banks in whole or in part where the commercial bank feels it cannot assume all of the risk.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Jaunty Jimmy Demaret, colorful Texan now located in Detroit, today added his name to the list of Roland Hancocks, Sam Sneads and others who have tossed major golf honors over their left shoulders.

Gifts totaling $1,243,196 were received last week by the USO War-Fund Campaign, increasing the total raised so far to $10,280,713. The USO is endeavoring to get $20,000,000 at this time and will seek $12,000,000 more in the Fall. Last week's contributions included a gift of $35,000 from the Commonwealth Fund, the largest gift of the week.

Improvement in the supply situation on a number of the important raw materials used in the paint industry is reported by the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association in a bulletin issued for publication today. Among developments reported by the association are the following:

The church has a definite contribution to make toward the reconciliation of individual freedom and community fellowship, which is the basic moral problem underlying all democratic aspiration, the Very Rev. Hughell B.W. Fosbrooke, dean of the General Theological Seminary, declared yesterday in a sermon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Last Spring -- the pleasant season that officially ceased to be yesterday at 9:17 P. M. -- an appealing array of good things appeared for the first time in city groceries. Some of them were so completely in tune with the times -- economical and easy to prepare -- that we cannot resist the temptation to review a few of them here.

LONDON, June 21 -- The British Board of Trade's index of commodity prices in May, based on 1930 as 100, was 160.7 as compared with 159.6 for April, 151.3 for May of 1941, and 98.1 for August of 1939. The aggregate increase since the outbreak of war now is 64 per cent, food being 80 and industrial materials 56 per cent higher.

The Treasury proposal that corporations be permitted to set up what may be called "inflation reserves" to protect themselves against wide price fluctuations is a wise suggestion. In a period of rising prices taxable profits inevitably include a considerable amount of paper profits that are locked up in higher inventories.

NEWARK, N.J., June 21 -- Postmaster John F. Sinnott of Newark today broke the silence he has maintained through months of controversy over the question of his reappointment. Postoffice clerks, backed by various labor groups, have campaigned vigorously against Mr. Sinnott's retention, charging that he is "tyrannical in his treatment of employes."

CLEVELAND, June 21 -- Joe Gordon snapped out of a hitless streak and pulled the Yankees out of their headlong dive today at Municipal Stadium before a gathering of 44,278. The Old Rock of the infield likewise helped Hank Borowy, the major leagues' leading unbeaten pitcher, gain his sixth straight victory.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., June 21 -- Four intrepid men set out on a safari in the uncharted tangle of Owl Swamp, Bear Mountain-Harriman State Park, early today. Four men returned.

Arriving at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon by transatlantic clipper, Harold Beresford Butler, new Director General of the British Information Services in the United States, said that the "pending fall of Tobruk had no effect on the morale of the British people" at the time he left England.

The war will inject new life into the United States and create again the "spirit of neighborliness" that once helped to build the nation, Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, told the 917 seniors yesterday at the college's eighty-second baccalaureate service, held in the Hunter assembly hall.

Owen D. Young has removed himself as a possible candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor in a letter to Harold R. Moskovit, State president of the Affiliated Young Democrats, made public yesterday by Mr. Moskovit.

OTTAWA, June 21 -- Estevan Point on Vancouver Island was shelled by an enemy submarine at 10:35 o'clock, Pacific time, last night (1:35 A. M., Sunday, Eastern war time), Colonel J. L. Ralston, the Defense Minister, announced here today. The submarine was presumed to be Japanese.

BERLIN, June 21 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- German troops have captured Fort Lenin, in the northern segment of the Sevastopol defense system, and all other Russian strongholds in that area except one coastal fort, the High Command reported today.

LONDON, June 21 (U.P.) -- A joint pastoral letter read in all Roman Catholic churches in England and Wales today suggested the following ten points as the "minimum conditions for a Christian way of life":

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., June 21 -- Henrique S. Santos of the New York A.C., who won the national epee open championship on Wednesday, triumphed in the annual outdoor epee competition of the Amateur Fencers League of America on the N.Y.A.C. grounds at Travers Island today.
CHICAGO, June 21 -- Forty years of accomplishment by the Jewish National Fund were acclaimed tonight by 1,500 civic, religious and educational leaders.

MOSCOW, June 21 -- A year of war has seen important developments in Soviet culture. There are few if any painters, composers, dramatists and writers who have not devoted themselves to themes connected with the war, and sometimes this preoccupation has taken them into study of Russia's heroic past.

LONDON, June 21 -- One development of this war that the British Foreign Office is considering seriously is the possibility that by the time it is ended all distinction between Ministers and Ambassadors will be abolished for good and that all diplomatic representatives throughout the world will have the rank of Ambassador.

MOSCOW, June 21 (AP) -- President Mikhail Kahnin, reviewing the first year of the war in Russia, declared today that Reichsfuehrer Hitler has lost his power to launch a general offensive and cited American-British, aid as a powerful factor that would help the Red Army to defeat the Germans.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 21 -- The thirty-fourth annual meeting of the Governors' Conference formally opened here today as Governors of many States in the union began to gather at the Grove Park Inn, but the first business session will be held tomorrow.

The Joint Maritime Commission of the International Labor Office opens its conference today in London. Delegations from at least twelve countries will attend. Among those to be represented are the United States, Great Britain, Canada, Australia, India, Belgium, China, Free France, Greece, Netherlands, Norway and Sweden.

King George II of Greece, whose stay in the United States has been a round of formality, will exchange his khaki marshal's unform for a sack suit tomorrow and visit several cities incognito to see for himself the war factories at work and do some personal shopping.

Repainting and redecorating, when they are necessary to "maintain" or "repair" an apartment, home or office, are permitted under the War Production Board's program for reducing nonessential construction to a minimum, it was explained in a statement issued here yesterday by the Office for Emergency Management.

Connecticut's unemployment tax rate for the coming year will be at the minimum of 1.5 per cent for 2,616 employers in that State, it was announced yesterday by State Labor Commissioner Cornelius J. Danaher. Only 1,857 employers qualified for that rate last year.
LONDON, Monday, June 22 (AP) -- The fall of Tobruk is a setback that imperils Allied plans for a second front and leaves Egypt and Suez seriously threatened by Axis forces.

VTCHY, June 21 -- It was announced last week that the maximum sum in French currency that may be exported or imported without special permission of the Exchange Office had been limited to 200 francs. It should be added that this restriction not only applies to imports and exports from and to foreign countries but it also concerns French colonies.

MOSCOW, June 21 -- Anglo-Soviet relations are discussed in a Pravda article by Ilya Ehrenburg that probably is the friendliest article ever written for the Soviet press about a foreign people. It is all the more remarkable because Mr. Ehrenburg has been the Soviet press's sharpest critic of Britain during the last year.
CHUNGKING, China, June 21 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops have killed or wounded 1,300 Japanese in Honan and stalled a strong column on the Kiangsi railway front, a communique said tonight.

In the seven months that it stood last year, surrounded by Axis forces, and hurled back every assault, Tobruk became a symbol of courage and resistance. Its sudden fall, coupled with the almost simultaneous loss of Bardia and Bir el-Gobi, is a hard blow. The explanation of Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's success repeats the weaknesses which have beset the British forces in Libya from the start.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : In justice to the many Negro nurses who do not qualify for employment in the Department of Hospitals and in order that the department may not be misunderstood, may I clarify the statement which appeared in the June 18 issue of your paper?

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 21 -- A birdie 3 on the nineteenth, hole toy Wesley Cotterell of the home club enabled him and Ray Torger-son of Lakeville to defeat Bobby Andrews and Eddie Neu of the Hempstead Golf Club in the final of the sixth annual invitation tournament at the Cherry Valley Club today.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., June 21 -- C. Foster Brown of Tedesco, Mass., who will enter the United States Navy this week as an ensign, and J.W. Reynolds, home club star, today won the tenth annual John F. Roche memorial golf tournament when they added a best-ball 69 to the 68 they scored yesterday for a total of 137 at the Maplewood Club.

The day is here when scraps can be made to qount. A gay bit of color used here and there in a patch contributes considerable amusement to a frock. Girls can go into the attic and pull out some of grandmother's old finery in the way of cottons and calico, cut it into bits, and put it together with ingenuity to make all kinds of accessories to their costumes.

Deploring the spiritual defeatism now prevalent, particularly among intelligent and high-minded people, because of the fury and destructiveness of the war, Dean Charles W. Gilkey of the University of Chicago Chapel told the congregation of the Riverside Church yesterday that such defeatism is not justified by past events, however natural it may seem now.

The big four of the national professional tennis championship -- J. Donald Budge, Robert L. Riggs, Frank Kovacs and Wayne Sabin -- moved into the quarter-finals yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

In the presence of 150 guests, including leaders in the city's welfare work, the new $500,000 wing of the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews, 120 West 106th Street, was dedicated yesterday afternoon. The structure, which is four stories high and equipped to care for fiftytwo bed-ridden patients, will be open to the public next Sunday.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull, in a message to Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs, predicted tonight that "before the end of another year the instigators of this war will have been given to understand how seriously they underestimated the determination and the ability for effective action of the peace-loving nations."

PITTSBURGH, June 21 -- Asserting that "we will not make the same mistake twice," Secretary Ickes promised a gathering of 35,000 American Slavs today that peace after victory would be enforced so that the next century would be "the people's century."

Obeying the mandate of the New York State War Emergency Act, which became effective May 1, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the appointment of a City War Council, with Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, as its chairman.

Destroyers, sub-chasers, patrol ships and other anti-submarine vessels by the hundreds, now being launched with increasing swiftness from American ways, will soon begin to play an increasingly important role in the Battle of the Atlantic.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Appointment of Elmer Davis to head the new Office of War Information raises hope that a disease which is sapping American morale will now be remedied.

Furniture buying was spotty yesterday at the opening of the midsummer market week in the New York Furniture Exchange, but reports by manufacturers at the close of the day indicated that total volume was much better than had been hoped for by local representatives last week.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Unfavorable war news from the Middle East was responsible today for a break of around 1 1/4 cents a bushel in wheat futures on the Board of Trade in the early trading, but as soon as the selling movement spent its force prices rallied and at one time most of the loss had been wiped out.

With the publication of the fifteenth section of "A Dictionary of American English, on Historical Principles" the enormous research undertaking at the University of Chicago reaches the end of its third volume. The new addition carries the work from Pole to Record.

DURHAM, N.H., June 22 -- Interventionists, hitherto unorganized, are massing to defeat a pacifist resolution on the church's relation to the war which is due to be brought up on the floor at tomorrow's session of the national convention of the General Council of Congregational Christian Churches.

TRENTON, N.J., June 22 -- After two postponements for efforts to effect a settlement out of court, trial of the government's suit against eleven concerns manufacturing electric light bulbs began before Federal Judge Phillip Forman here today.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 22 -- Perhaps because the Axis forces of Field Marshal Erwin Rommel had smashed into Tobruk more quickly than they had believed possible, they appeared today to be catching their breath, and no large-scale fighting was reported.

With even the lowly, much-maligned weed playing a role in the war, American seed growers were called upon yesterday to produce this year three times as much seed of all kinds as they did during any single twelve-month period in the last five years.

Major Frank E. McKinney will represent the Army Procurement Division as liaison officer between the credit department of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the Army in approving contracts to suppliers who finance themselves by means of Federal Reserve Board Regulation V guaranteed loans, it was announced yesterday as he opened offices in the bank.
The following article was written after the Battle of Midway by a correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES who was aboard one of the United States warships.

Only a Laval and a Hitler, brothers in the art of blackmail, could strike such a bargain as that which the head of the French Government announced yesterday, appropriately on the second anniversary of the Compiegne Armistice that marks the most humiliating day in French history.
LONDON, June 22 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Senator Brewster of Maine intimated today that regular production of the "Sea Otter" type of cargo vessel might be started soon, but officials who must make the final decision said that such discussion was premature.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- Miss Eleanor Dudley of Chicago, a broad-shouldered lass whose hobby is physical education, pounded the golf ball today as Babe Ruth used to hammer a baseball and recorded the only par score at the Elmhurst Country Club.

Mothers with sons at Fort Wadsworth need no longer worry about their drilling in torn or buttonless uniforms or in undarned socks. Clothes will be neatly mended and any soldier who wishes to darn his own socks or sew on buttons may learn to do so under expert tutelage.

A nation-wide underwriting group headed by Eberstadt Co. will offer today to the public 240,000 shares of common stock of Charles Pfizer Co., Inc., manufacturing chemists. The stock will be priced at $24.75 a share, involving a total market value of $5,940,000.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today it had reached an understanding with Price Administrator Leon Henderson that maximum charges prescribed by him for interstate contract carrier service would not be less than the minimum rate set by the I.C.C.

OTTAWA, June 22 -- About thirty shells were fired at the Dominion radio telegraph station at Estevan Point on Vancouver Island on Saturday night and the probability was that two enemy craft were involved in the attack, Defence Minister J.L. Ralston told the House of Commons today.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, June 23 (AP) -- The Russian High Command reported today that hard fighting continued at Sevastopol. Earlier reports had said that the defenders had been thrust back north and south of the city, despite stubborn resistance that took thousands of German lives.

PASSAIC, N.J., June 22 (AP) -- Some of the nation's topnotch track and field athletes, out to break a bunch of little-sought-after world records, wiped three of them off the books and tied another tonight.

Reporting on operations in the fiscal year ended with March, O.H. Chalkley, president of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., informed stockholders that wider distribution of its tobacco products, resulting in a 29 per cent increase in sales to a new all-time high, enabled the company to make a record profit and maintain dividends in its fiscal year despite higher taxes and many operating cost items.

LAUGH, TOWN, LAUGH! a vaudeville show. Cast includes Ed Wynn, Jane Froman, Carmen Amaya, Joe Smith and Charles Dale, Senor Wences, Hermanos Williams Trio, Ken Davidson and Hugh Forgie, and Emil Coleman. Presented by Mr. Wynn. At the Alvin Theatre every evening, including Sunday; matinees Wednesday through Sunday; extra 5:30 P.M. show on Sunday.

According to a London dispatch in this newspaper yesterday, the British Foreign Office is pondering seriously the bringing up in the peace conference of a proposal to end the distinction between Ministers and Ambassadors and to give to the chief diplomatic representatives of all nations the latter title.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Senate adopted and sent to the House as a separate measure today Sections 3, 4 and 5 of the Civilian War Benefits and War Relief Bill and another bill containing the first two sections was reintroduced and referred to the Senate Finance Committee.
