WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The United States Treasury's Foreign Funds Control has found cached in New York banks $10,000,000 of securities and cash owned by Henry M. Blackmer, who fled to Paris in 1924 when sought as a witness in the Teapot Dome oil frauds.

Findings and recommendations regarding Africa, the war and peace aims, with special emphasis on the interests and duties of the United States in "the Dark Continent," were made public yesterday after six months of study by a national committee headed by Dr. Anson Phelps Stokes, president of the Phelps-Stokes Fund.

VAN HORNESVILLE, N. Y., June 22 (AP) -- The sixteen-year development of New York's 296 central schools is "the most outstanding accomplishment in education for rural people ever to occur in this or any other State," Dr. Ernest E. Cole, State Education Commissioner, said today.

A good housekeeper who aspires to become a better housekeeper may realize her ambition without extraordinary effort. Ways and means of accomplishing this transformation are to be found in a series of shrewdly written pamphlets, which are descriptively entitled "Wise Buying in Wartime."

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 22 -- Alex Watson of Hudson River and Richard W. Woolworth of Mount Kisco paced the field of eighteen pro-amateur golf pairs in the Westchester P.G.A. one-day tournament at the Mount Kisco Country Club today with a best-ball 32, 33 -- 65.

The Chemical Bank Trust Company and Harvey Fisk Sons, Inc., were the successful bidders yesterday for an issue of $490,000 State of Tennessee defense and consolidated bonds, naming an interest cost basis to the State of 1.7149 per cent.
NEW YORK Sir Harry Oakes of Nassau, British West Indies, left the Plaza yesterday to join Lady Oakes in Bar Harbor, Me.

HONOLULU, June 22 (AP) -- Warning that the United States victory over the Japanese in the Battle of Midway "has given many people a false sense of security," Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons today urged non-essential civilians to leave the Hawaiian Islands as soon as possible.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Ways and Means Committee refused today to tax bank checks, and approved eight classes of relief to corporations which would be hard pressed under the present and proposed law. The committee expects to complete its work by Wednesday, and to turn over its tax proposals to the drafting experts.

Reports that the rubber scrap salvage campaign had proved a failure here were denied last night by George Sutherland, regional salvage manager of the Bureau of Industrial Conservation, War Production Board.

Standard Power and Light In furtherance of the "death sentence" program for utility holding companies, the Securities and Exchange Commission, in an order issued a few days ago, called for the dissolution of the Standard Power and Light Corporation on the ground that the concern was merely a "corporate shell."
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 22 -- It Tyler Edwards of Elmore County is not passionately absorbed in the war this correspondent is not prepared to blame him much.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 22 -- Wide-ranging problems of family and child care caused by the impact of war on homes were taken up today by delegates to the Vassar College Summer Institute for Family and Child Care Services in war time.

"Broken Journey," a play by Andrew Rosenthal, will open tonight at Henry Miller's Theatre under the auspices of Martin Burton, a former stage and screen actor, who is making his debut as a producer. The play deals with a war correspondent-radio commentator, his feminine associate, and the correspondent's former sweetheart, all of whom meet in his home town, where he is making his first visit in many years.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 22 -- Terming President Roosevelt "the champion of the rights of minority peoples throughout the world," the independent order of B'rith Sholom today adopted a resolution pledging its members and resources to his guidance in the nation's crisis.

Wartime conditions have brought increasing difficulties in field research on a national scale, according to the consensus at the luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association at the Advertising Club, attended by advertising agency, media and manufacturing executives.
The sixth Libyan campaign had obviously resulted yesterday in the worst defeat the British have yet received in North Africa.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 22 -- Governor Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota, young liberal who made the keynote speech at the 1940 Republican National Convention, urged today that the United States take the leadership in the "winning of the peace" as well as the war.

First Lieutenant H. Mayhew Lancaster of the Army Air Forces, who was attached to Mitchel Field, L.I., was found dead yesterday morning in the gas-filled kitchen of the apartment in which he lived with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Lancaster, at 324 West 108th Street.

Maxim Litvinoff, the Russian Ambassador, declared in a speech here last night at Madison Square Garden that Hitler was now flinging all his forces into the Soviet front "in his final throw of the dice on which he is staking his all." He asked again for a second front and added "there is now every ground to hope for it in the near future."

BERLIN, June 22 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A German motor torpedo boat flotilla attacked a formation of small British coastal craft and freighters fleeing from Tobruk yesterday morning and completely destroyed it, the German High Command declared today.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Martin Wagner, chairman of the newly formed National Council of Gas, Coke and Chemical Workers, an organization evolved from locals which broke away from District 50 of the United Mine Workers of America, said today that his organization already had 18,750 of the 40,000 gas and chemical workers originally affiliated with District 50.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today that the Treasury would borrow between $2,750,000,000 and $4,500,000,000 of new money in July and August. The financing is expected to conform to precedent but Mr. Morgenthau said he would not rule out new types of securities if "somebody had a brilliant idea."

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 22 -- The Riverhead Town Board, after conducting a public hearing, refused today by a vote of three to two to approve the establishment of a Federal Farm Security Administration migratory labor camp two miles northwest of Riverhead village.

Holding that no advantage would accrue to the city from a new inquiry into the use of city labor and materials on the Lake Mahopac estate of Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Justice Philip J. McCook denied yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court an application of the City Club of New York to reopen the case.
Coastwise convoys of tankers to help keep New Yorkers from freezing next Winter were visualized here yesterday by Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation.
ALBANY, June 22 (AP) -- Roy S. Smith, 66 years old, district Federal housing director, was found dead in his apartment tonight, victim of a bullet wound in the heart.

It is romantic nonsense, and as such not popular in any sane army, that a soldier is attracted by the thought of dying at the moment of victory. Soldiers, like the rest of us, prefer to live. But soldiers and civilians alike will agree that it is sad to die at the moment of defeat.

A second German-American Bund member has committed suicide within a week while under subpoena in the Federal grand jury investigation of that supposedly extinct organization, United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa revealed yesterday.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Your editorial on the Odell Waller case is a great encouragement to every one who wants to see the administration of our laws brought into greater harmony with the social needs and trends of our time.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 22 -- A parlor maid once employed by Mrs. Anna Hollingsworth Paton was called as a witness in Westchester Surrogate's Court today by three relatives seeking to upset the disposition of the $1.300,000 Paton estate, but insisted under cross-examination that she had never witnessed anything "wrong or immoral" between Mrs. Paton and the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 22 -- Anastase A. Vonsiatsky, 42-year-old White Russian "fuehrer," pleaded guilty in Federal court here this afternoon to conspiracy to send defense and military secrets to Germany and Japan and was sentenced to five years in prison and fined $5,000.

Predicting that the battle of the Coral Sea would go down as a turning point in naval history comparable to that between the Monitor and the Merrimac, Rear Admiral Frederick C. Sherman, who commanded the aircraft carrier Lexington during the struggle, said on his arrival here yesterday that two Japanese carriers were definitely sunk and a third was badly damaged in the battle.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Office of Price Administration postponed today until July 22 the date on which it will put into effect its new coupon plan for permanent gasoline rationing in the East. The date previously fixed was July 15.

LONDON, June 22 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi replied today to criticism in the London press of his demand for the withdrawal of the British from India, according to a Reuter dispatch from Wardha, India. Mr. Gandhi said that every time Indian Nationalists had suggested solutions, however sound intrinsically, there were distortions of their speeches and writings, followed by "persecution."

As manager of the National League champions, Leo Durocher of the Dodgers automatically becomes the pilot of the senior circuit's All-Star aggregation which is to face an American League aggregation at the Polo Grounds on July 6.
LONDON, June 23 -- Parliament will meet in its next session in a mood to demand reasons instead of excuses for the defeat that British arms have just suffered in Libya.

Nine American Institutional benefactors of Greece, including relief, welfare and hospital organizations as well as colleges, were thanked warmly by the ruler of that war-stricken country, on behalf of his people, at a dinner last night in the Colony Club.

The twelve-story loft and store building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 22-24 West Thirty-eighth Street has been purchased by David W. Frankel, operator, from Arthur Frankenstein through the Cross Brown Company, brokers.

A convoy system to protect merchant shipping along our Atlantic coast from Maine to Florida has been in operation for the last month, it was disclosed by the Navy yesterday. That period has witnessed a marked decrease in sinkings in that area, as enemy submarines shifted most of their activities to the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean Sea.

WASHINGTON, June 22 - A committee of eighteen women will convene here on Saturday to select the final 375 officer candidates for the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps. Meetings are expected to continue at least a week while the director, Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, and committee members choose from among those recommended by the nine Army Corps Areas.

Tauchnitz, name of the Leipzig publishing house that started in the last years of the eighteenth century, used to be familiar in this country. The colleges, at least the college book stores, knew if only on the outside the Tauchnitz unbound editions of the classics. And perhaps most Americans who had "been to Europe" were acquainted with some volumes of the Tauchnitz Library of British and American Authors.

LONDON, June 22 -- General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Free French forces, has been conferring by secret methods with underground organizations in both French zones and has reached with them an agreement on a manifesto of Free French policy in the future, it was disclosed today.

Shells from Japanese submarines bursting over beaches in Canada and Oregon are presumably some of the first fruits of our failure to protect the Western Aleutians. Apparently these enemy craft crept down the Alaskan coast from the Japanese naval base at Paramoshiri by way of Attu Island.

It was announced yesterday afternoon at a final meeting of the executive committee that more than 200 tickets have been purchased for the tea dance in behalf of the United Service Organizations to be given tomorrow at the Stork Club under the auspices of the Officers Service Committee, a subdivision of the New York City Defense Council.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill announced jointly today that their objective was "the earliest maximum concentration of Allied war power upon the enemy."

Nathan Straus, former United States Housing Administrator, was being mentioned last night as a likely Democratic candidate for the Congressional seat now held by Representative Joseph Clark Baldwin, following a conference yesterday between Mr. Straus and Representative Michael J. Kennedy, leader of Tammany Hall.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- American production engineers can and will give the country's fighting forces superior equipment "in time and plenty," Dr. D.D. Ewing, head of the Purdue University School of Electrical Engineering, said today in an address before the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, which opened its five-day annual convention.

Leon Henderson is in trouble with Congress. The members of that body are disposed to "discipline" him by refusing him authority to hold down prices by subsidies and by cutting down on the appropriation for his office. There is much talk of curbing "bureaucracy," but the nubbin of the quarrel seems to be just old-fashioned patronage.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 22 -- Most of the evening newspapers today announce that President Roberto M. Ortiz, having lost all hope of regaining his eyesight after an unfavorable report on the possibility of operating by the American ophthalmologist, Dr. Ramon Castroviejo of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, New York, has decided to resign, yielding the reins of power definitely to Acting President Ramon S. Castillo.

NEW DELHI, India, June 22 -- Major Gen. Lewis H. Brereton, United States Air Force Chief in India, lost in zero-zero weather which prevented landing his Flying Fortress bomber in China, recently flew back over Japanese-held Burma and reached an Indian airfield with only enough gasoline for ten minutes of flying, air headquarters here revealed today.

Retreating under the pressure of the news from the Libyan campaign, the stock market suffered yesterday its worst set-back in more than a month. Although prices declined more than 2 points in the early trading on the Stock Exchange, the list was more orderly in the afternoon when it was realized that the declines had not prompted any sizable liquidation.

DENVER, June 22 (AP) -- Labor's part in the prosecution of the war and in the reconstruction period afterward was emphasized today at the opening session of the American Newspaper Guild's ninth annual convention.

News of the fighting in the Near East and Russia was interpreted yesterday by the cotton trade as indicative of a prolonged war and buying was continued in futures on the New York Cotton Exchange. The close was at gains of 8 to 14 points compared with Saturday.

Ten school children in this city received yesterday checks for $100 as prizes in an essay contest conducted by Gimbel Brothers to commemorate the one-hundredth anniversaries of the Board of Education in New York and of Gimbel Brothers.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- An enemy vessel, presumably a Japanese submarine, haunting the shipping lanes linking West Coast ports with Alaska, fired nine high-explosive shells in the general direction of Fort Stevens on the Northern Oregon coast late last night, Army sources disclosed today.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 22 -- Tobruk fell after twenty-six hours of the grimmest fighting ever known in the Libyan desert, and it fell because the outmanoeuvred defenders had delayed too long in making the moves that might have saved them.

SYDNEY, Australia, June 22 -- William Morris Hughes, leader of the United Australia party, addressing the Institute of Sales and Business Management, contrasted the difficulties confronting the United Nations with the reassuring tone of official statements.
ALL the big league ball clubs held still yesterday, giving the fans as well as the players a breathing space and a chance to think things over. They had a big week behind them.

An exhibition illustrating the history of the American Red Cross and showing the vital role of women in war will be opened to the public tomorrow by the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Senator Tydings is doing a grand job in exposing our $27,000,000 waste in "publicity" and "press releases" and he should have every encouragement. But one sometimes wonders why, in spite of this elaborate, wasteful machinery, it is so often impossible to obtain really needed information.
The texts of the addresses of Maxim M. Litvinoff and Harry Hopkins and excerpts from that of William Green at the Russian War Relief meeting last night in Madison Square Garden follow:

Citing with approval several recent editorials in The Watertown (N. Y.) Times, W. Kingsland Macy, Suffolk County Republican leader and former stormy petrol of Republican State politics, yesterday inferentially rebuked Wendell L. Willkie for the latter's reported opposition to nominating Thomas E. Dewey for Governor.

The new ruling of the Office of Price Administration which permits importers to recover their extra costs of landing merchandise, despite the existing March price levels, is unique in that it provides the first "roll-forward" allowed to any industrial group, importers asserted yesterday.

The little horse with a big tail had just far enough to go at Aqueduct yesterday. Warren Wright's champion, Whirlaway, needed every inch of the mile and a furlong he raced to nose out Mrs. Parker Corning's Attention and take the Celt Purse, an overnight special that furnished a crowd of 14,924 with a preview of the Brooklyn Handicap, in which these two are due to meet again on Aqueduct's Army-Navy benefit program next Saturday.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Millicent Hirsh Lang of New York swept through her first and second round matches as the women's New Jersey State tennis championship opened today at the Oritani Field Club. Mrs. Lang, twice winner of the tournament, can retire the trophy with a third straight triumph.

LONDON, June 20 -- Fighting in the North Sea and Channel waters during the past three nights, in which Allied naval patrols clashed with German convoys and patrols and caused "loss and damage" to the enemy, was announced by the Admiralty today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22 -- "Wherever the Grass Grows, a magazine story of the post-Civil War period by Allan Bosworth, was purchased today by Paramount as a vehicle for Richard Dix. The yarn deals with a soldier who goes west after the Civil War and becomes a cowboy.

Salt-water anglers who dropped baited hooks in New Jersey coastal waters during the past week-end were well rewarded, judging from the reports of fine catches of bass and porgies that have been received from several points.

After Mayor La Guardia had ignored an inquiry yesterday on the date when the first meeting of his newly appointed War Council would be held. Councilman Joseph E. Kinsley said he would introduce a resolution in the City Council today asking an immediate meeting of the War Council so it could adopt the blackout and dimout regulations authorized by the State War Emergency Act.

DETROIT, June 22 -- The impact of war on building activity has made a major casualty out of the profession of architecture and the large number of those in the profession who cannot be absorbed in defense work should be employed now in planning post-war construction, in the opinion of the committee on architectural services of the American Institute of Architects.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Without a record vote the Senate passed today and sent to the House a bill amending the Communications Act of 1934 to permit a merger of all domestic telegraph operations.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, protested to Senator Truman today that the Truman committee's report that "the role of the woolen industry in our war economy is not defined six months after Pearl Harbor" was "ridiculous and patently untrue."

The first step by officials of the Board of Education to weed out unfit teachers, in accordance with a suggestion of Mayor La Guardia to save the jobs of 125 high school teachers whose positions were eliminated because of a budget reduction, was announced yesterday by Ellsworth B. Buck, president of the board.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- By a vote of 2 to 1 a Senate judiciary subcommittee recommended today confirmation of Thomas F. Meaney as a Federal judge in the New Jersey District Court, but the full Judiciary Committee deferred action until Wednesday.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 22 -- Robert McHale of Wheatley Hills and Jack Mallon of the Garden City Country Club won the amateur-pro best-ball golf tournament today at Wheatley Hills. They carded a 66, going out in 35 but returning in 31.
Every time the word spreads that a century plant is blooming or about to bloom, it has to be emphasized for the record that the plant is not necessarily 100 years old.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, June 23 -- Following is the text of the more important sections of the Soviet Information Bureau's official review of the first year of the war with Germany:

LONDN, June 22 -- Disappointment at the fall of Tobruk was reflected today in dullness in the stock markets. Dealers marked down prices as a precautionary measure but little or no stock came out. Apart from the oils and the Egyptian loan there was very little selling.

VICHY, June 22 -- Pierre Laval, broadcasting tonight after two months as the Vichy Chief of Government, asked French workers to leave their families and volunteer en masse to help German factories produce for "victory over bolshevism."

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A native revolt occurred in Northern Korea from Feb. 2 to Feb. 6 in which, more them 1,000 Japanese were killed and extensive damage done to Japanese military installations, according to a report received today by Kilsoo Haan, secretary of the Sino-Korean People's League.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill of Great Britain issued a joint statement on the objectives of their current conferences.

With Federal insurance of property against war damage due to be put in effect at noon on July 1, property owners in this and other areas began to criticize rates and conditions, depending on the nature and location of their property. Certain classes of property owners found the government rates most suitable.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 22 -- "Laval's swan song" was the way private advices from unoccupied France tonight described the Vichy Chief of Government Pierre Laval's broadcast, the theme of which was a panegyric of German might and a hope for a German triumph.

MILWAUKEE, June 22 -- Some 2,000 librarians from all over the country, gathered here today for the annual convention of the American Library Association, discussed the sharp changes in methods which the war has brought about in their work.
LOS ANGELES. June 22 -- Julia Bracken Wendt, nationally known sculptor, died here today at the age of 72 at her home in Laguna Beach.

LONDON, June 22 -- The National Executive Committee of the Mine Workers Federation decided at a closed meeting today to recommend that the federation accept, with certain reservations, the miners' wage increases proposed in the recently published report by Lord Greene's investigation board.
CAIRO, June 22 (AP) -- A British General Headquarters communique said today:

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 22 -- Mrs. Harry McNaughton, Eastern titleholder, repeated her sterling performance of last year in leading the qualifiers in the fifteenth annual Women's Long Island Golf Association championship for the Howard F. Whitney Trophy today.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, June 22 -- The nine "hot" phonograph records sent Private F.E. Miller of Scotch Plains, N.J., by his girl, Laura Childs, a law student at New York University, have arrived safe, it was disclosed today.

TOKYO, June 22 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The official Japanese Domei news agency reported today that the entire American Pacific Coast from Alaska to Mexico was "panic stricken by the latest bombardment" of the Oregon coast.
CHUNGKING, June 22 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command issued the following communique today:

This city's war bond pledge campaign, originally scheduled to end officially tomorrow, will be extended through Sunday to permit the army of volunteer Minute Men to canvass thousands of families not yet reached, John T. Madden, chairman of the campaign, announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, June 23 -- A communique issued this morning by the Red Army High Command announces that fierce fighting continued yesterday on the Sevastopol front, where the German attackers have succeeded in driving a wedge into the Russian defenses in the northern sector.
BERLIN, June 22 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The text of today's German communique:

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Ceiling prices which apply to service industries beginning July 1, will be covered by a separate price regulation designed to embrace the special conditions existing in that division of business, it was announced here today.

Iron Horse Returns American railroads have been making history. In the process they have been making a good many prophets' faces red. In people's minds these last twenty-five years the railroad has been a chronic invalid, a bankrupt, a derelict, an anachronism. Its doom was seen written in the form of the automobile.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 23 (Reuter) -- Alexander Clifford, correspondent of The Daily Mail with the British forces in Libya, writes that the defeat there was due to the fact that "our Army was not rightly handled."

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- With the government taking large quantities of pork and lard for lease-lend purposes. meat processors bought live hogs today at the highest prices since permanent pork ceilings went into effect.

NEW ORLEANS, June 22 -- Ted Schroeder of Stanford tonight moved into the second round of the fifty-eighth national intercollegiate tennis championship as officials disclosed that Charles Olewine of Southern California, his chief rival for the singles title, had not reported.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., June 22 -- Albert S. Pinkus of the Manhattan Chess Club, winner of the Hall-garten tournament sponsored by that club, today forged into the lead in the invitation chess masters' tournament at the casino on the Municipal Pier.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 22 -- Dick Haskell, bespectacled North-western University golfer from Seattle, Wash., today led a field of 131 players in the first eighteen-hole qualifying round of the national intercollegiate tournament.

Angered by a union leader's statement that he could not dissuade the members of his organization from going out on strike this morning at two big New Jersey propeller plants of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, went over the leader's head last night and telegraphed a personal appeal to each of the 1,134 members not to quit work.

The Democratic leaders of the Eighth Senatorial District in Brooklyn yesterday agreed to designate Samuel L. Greenberg as the party's candidate for State Senate. The position now is held by Joseph A. Esquiro, who was charged with unprofessional conduct in a presentment handed up last week by John Harlan Amen's additional extraordinary grand jury.

CHUNGKING, June 22 (U.P.) -- Chinese fighter planes downed one and damaged two of thirteen Japanese raiders in a two-hour battle today that broke four years of unchallenged bombing of Hengyang, major Hunan Province railway city between Canton and Changsha, the official Chinese Central News Agency reported.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 22 -- Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu and the Ministry of Navy announced officially tonight that the merchantman Rio Tercero, belonging to the Argentine State Mercantile Marine, was sunk off the United States Atlantic coast this morning.

JAMES B. RESTON, known to his colleagues on THE NEW YORK TIMES as Scotty, is fighting mad. The fact that Tobruk has fallen almost on the very eve of the publication of his "Prelude to Victory"* gives special point to his passionate anger.

Thirteen, sections of New York City department stores recorded increases in advertising linage in newspapers in the city in May, while twenty-one registered declines, according to figures made public yesterday by Media Records, Inc. The main store total for the month was 2,751,442 lines, compared with 2,847,586 lines for the 1941 month, while the basement total was 236,329 lines compared with 222,129 lines.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 22 -- Mrs. Richard Hellmann of the home club won the qualifying medal in the twentieth annual Women's Westchester and Fairfield golf championship with 38, 42 -- 80 over the Scarsdale G.C. course today.
ABOARD A SUBMARINE CHASER WITH AN ATLANTIC PATROL (Delayed) -- "This," said the Navy public relations officer, "will be only an indoctrination cruise and you'll probably find it rather boring."

Four officers and a former director of Paramount Pictures, Inc., testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter that their first knowledge of the payment of $100,000 by Paramount to Willie Bioff and George E. Browne, former labor leaders, came as a result of reading newspaper accounts of the arrest and indictment of Bioff and Browne on extortion charges.

BERLIN, June 22 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Bloody hand-to-hand fighting is raging through the streets along Syevernaya Harbor in the northern defense sector of Sevastopol, with German forces storming house after house in that shipbuilding section, High Command informants reported tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 22 -- Two lieutenants of the former Czechoslovak Army, Jan Kubis of Willomitz and Josef Gabcik of Poluvsie, were identified in a communique received from Berlin today as the authors of the attack on May 27 on the Deputy Reich Protector of Bohemia-Moravia, Reinhard Heydrich.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve System announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 17: Increases of $234,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and $124,000,000 in balances with domestic banks and a decrease of $216,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 22 -- Reviving a project that proved to be of economic value in the first World War, a Princeton committee will open a community canning kitchen on Wednesday with a view to enlisting as many women as possible in a food conservation campaign.

LONDON, June 21 -- To a country that has had little fresh fruit for nearly a year and that hasn't seen a tomato in eight months the advent of Summer has not been heralded by any change in the weather -- fur coats are still seen in the streets of London -- but by the arrival of long-forgotten delicacies in stores and markets.

On the north side of the Bay of Sevastopol is an inlet which ia called, or used to be called, Syevernaya Harbor. On its shores are buried 100,000 Russian soldiers who fell during the siege of 1854-55. A little to the east is the site of the "soldiers' battle" of Inkerman, where French, British and Russian infantrymen butchered each other all one bloody day, with bayonets and clubbed muskets.

LONDON, June 23 -- Eric Lloyd Williams, Reuter correspondent at battle headquarters of the Eighth Army in Egypt, sends details to London today on how Tobruk fell and records how some of the garrison escaped. He lays the fall of Tobruk to mass Stuka raids on the garrison's anti-aircraft defenses, followed by "a terrible artillery barrage."

CHUNGKING, China, June 23 (AP) -- The Japanese drive to open an all-rail route from Shanghai to Singapore and thus obtain communications immune to sea attack has been stalled, at least temporarily, on two of the vital fronts, and the Chinese are counter-attacking successfully at some places, government sources announced today.

DETROIT, June 23 -- Henry Ford has not only denied a government request to permit surveyors to enter his property near the Ford Willow Run bomber plant but he has also ejected government engineers and pulled up surveyors' stakes, Harry H. Bennett, the Ford company's personnel manager, disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill called in British and American shipping experts today to outline the maritime requirements of their "offensive strategy of the war." For one hour and twenty-five minutes the President and the Prime Minister discussed with the experts shipping needs in the light of these indicated strategical decisions:

CHICAGO, June 23 -- In place of sapphires, once used almost exclusively as bearings in electrical indicating instruments, tiny drops of fused hard glass are being used, the American Institute of Electrical Engineers was told today by F.K. McCune and J.H. Goss of the General Electric Company.

The Celanese Corporation or America filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Philadelphia a registration statement covering a new issue of $35,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent debentures, due July 1, 1962, it was announced here by the company.

QUEBEC, June 23 (AP) -- President Roosevelt, joining Prime Minister Churchill in greetings today to the convention of the National Editorial Association, expressed "deep appreciation" for the part its editor and publisher members have played in the war effort.

That Whitlow Wyatt wasn't right was apparent from the outset, but the veteran right-hander didn't have to be told. He realized it himself as he saw his fireball coming up to the plate as big and as inviting as the proverbial balloon in the Dodgers' twilight-night game against the Pirates at Ebbets Field last evening.

VICHY, France, June 23 (AP) -- Blaring headlines in the collaborationist French press trumpeted today the formation of a Laval government sponsored "Tricolor Legion," which "will fight Russian barbarism and also against American imperialism or Anglo-Saxon greed."

DETROIT, June 23 (AP) -- Lanky Ted Williams returned today to his favorite park, Briggs Stadium, and belted a two-run homer, his sixteenth of the season and first since Memorial Day, to help the Red Sox to a 6-2 victory over the Tigers.

MILWAUKEE, June 23 -- Two authors of children's books were honored by the American Library Association here tonight. Walter D. Edmonds received the Newberry Medal for "the most distinguished contribution to American literature for children." The award was based on his novel "The Matchlock Gun."

Mayor La Guardia told the graduating class of 361 students of Manhattan High School of Aviation Trades last night that their training as aviation mechanics was of great importance to the country now and will be of distinct advantage to them after the war.

Emphasizing the challenge to women in total war, Clare Boothe declared yesterday that American women do not yet measure up to the women of China, Russia and Great Britain -- "not because they have not the stuff but because they have not been challenged."

The expenditure of $11,143,767 by the American Car and Foundry Company out of its own resources and for its own account to increase capacity for the production of munitions is disclosed in the annual report of Charles J. Hardy, president, issued yesterday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 23 -- Chile will declare war on the Axis without the preliminary of severing diplomatic relations if any ship of any of the American republics should be sunk in the Pacific between Panama and the Antarctic, Chile's sphere of interest, according to informed circles.

The general council of, the Lower West Side Defense Council at a meeting at Greenwich House last night adopted a resolution repudiating the "unauthorized wording and critical sentiments" expressed in a letter sent by two members of the council to Mayor La Guardia on Sunday and published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Monday.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Navy women would take over the desk work of shore officers and enlisted personnel at the same fate of pay and with the same respective ranks as men in the Navy under terms of the Walsh bill to establish a Women's Reserve in the Navy.

A $59,000,000 field vegetable and fruit crop, the biggest in the history of this State, may perish this year because of a shortage of migratory and other farm labor, due to war conditions, unless New Yorkers come forward to help harvest it, the United States Employment Service announced yesterday from its office at 342 Madison Avenue in an "S O S call" for workers.

The rally for Russian War Relief held Monday in Madison Square Garden netted $750,000 for that organization, it was announced yesterday during a luncheon at the Hotel Astor sponsored by the women's division. Proceeds of the luncheon, $6,500, will be used to purchase "sulfa" drugs for the treatment of the Russian wounded, according to Mrs. William Morris Jr., chairman of the women's division.

Probably Andrew Rosenthal has been listening overmuch to the radio. Likely he has wondered a bit about the personality and character of the owners of those far-off voices, speaking breathless from the battlefield, and he has gone on to imagine them set down temporarily in a small Ohio town of pre-Pearl Harbor.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 23 -- Heavy Axis mechanized formations, bringing with them the threat of impending attack, rumbled today toward hastily consolidated British outposts near the Libyan-Egyptian frontier after American bombers had joined in the war in the desert with a devastating raid on the Axis supply base at Bengazi.

Charges that a former high-ranking public official of Queens County accepted "a substantial sum of money" to insure the use of a certain type of paving brick for streets adjacent to the new General Court House in Jamaica were made yesterday in a court action designed to bring the matter within the jurisdiction of the Federal Government for possible criminal prosecution.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The proposed reorganization of the War Production Board on the basis of agreements made by its chairman, Donald Nelson, with the Army and Navy to transfer the board's functions of production and purchase of war equipment to them has met with opposition in some administration circles as well as within the board itself.

Selective recovery of limited range was enjoyed yesterday in some sections of the stock market, but the lack of volume prevented any spread to a major portion of the list. Traders apparently had lost some of the intense pessimism evidenced on Monday, but the shock of the loss of Tobruk still stayed the activity of any support other than that which came from Wall Street.

MOSCOW, June 22 (delayed) -- Bidding the people steel their hearts against new hardship, difficulties and sacrifices that lie ahead on the way to victory, Pravda declared in an editorial today marking the first anniversary of the war with Germany that never before has assurance in that victory been so strong.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will deliver the main address tonight at the eighty-second commencement exercises of Hunter College in its assembly hall at 695 Park Avenue. Nine hundred and ten students will receive academic degrees.

ST. LOUIS, June 23 -- Buddy Rosar limped into home plate ahead of an attempted triple play tonight and carried the Yankees to their first victory of the campaign under floodlights. Before 17,501, the season's largest American League crowd at Sportsman's Park, the world champions nosed out the Browns, 6 to 5.
LONDON, June 23 (Reuter) -- General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel is still receiving French North African products in Libya and Axis ships are using French territorial waters.

Spokesmen of occupied countries and European underground movements, speaking at a meeting in Town Hall, last night told of the resistance of their peoples against the Nazi oppressors and called for the organization of concerted action by all underground elements in Europe as a means of speeding the defeat of the Axis powers.

The postponed premiere of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Lewisohn Stadium took place last night before a crowd that numbered approximately 10,000. The first of three consecutive evenings, it offered nothing in any way novel by way of program, but confined itself to the tried and true -- Balanchine's "Serenade" (much the newest work on the schedule), Alexandra Fedorova's version of "The Nutcracker," and Fokine's apparently wearproof classic, "Prince Igor."

The beginnings of a "draft Willkie" movement on the part of Republicans opposed to the nomination of Thomas E. Dewey for Governor were discernible yesterday. Events of the next few days are scheduled to indicate whether supporters of Wendell L. Willkie will attempt a State-wide primary fight for delegates to the Republican State convention.

Declaring that industry should set aside adequate reserves to prepare for economic "shocks" that lie ahead, Harry J. Delaney, president of the New York Credit Men's Association, urged yesterday that corporations withhold 10 per cent of their normal dividends to invest in war bonds.

MAJOR GENERAL PROFESSOR DOKTOR KARL HAUSHOFER has enjoyed such sensational publicity in the last two years that the average United Nations citizen probably thinks of him as a sort of satanic septuagenarian sitting in his Geopolitical Institute in Munich, like a spider in its web, putting all the resources of modern science to the perverse ends of the Nazi war lords.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., June 23 -- Mrs. Richard Hellmann of the home club, yesterday's medalist, had little difficulty winning by 8 and 7 from Mrs. H.W. Herrick of Bonnie Briar as the first round of match play was completed in the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's twentieth annual championship over the hilly Scarsdale Club course today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The House Military Affairs Committee voted by 12 to 9 today to submit a report on the War Production Program which asserted that "unbelievable red tape, topheavy organization and lack of orientation to a state of war still lead the parade in wartime Washington."

The war has inevitably brought great changes to the advertising business. At a time when there are growing shortages of consumer goods it would be neither necessary nor desirable to seek to stimulate increased consumer demands for the products that are scarce.

HEWLETT, L.I., June 23 -- Three debutantes were honored tonight at the first of the parties of the "Little Season" on Long-Island and, although the entertainments were kept to simple proportions, there were about 200 of the younger set, including young men home from college, a few junior officers in the armed forces and house guests in the neighborhood.

These surveys are made by a system of highly selective samplings in each of-the forty-eight States in proportion to voting populations; thereby, the American Institute of Public Opinion holds, is obtained a result which would, not vary from, that of a much larger canvass.

JERSET CITY, N.J., June 23 (AP) -- Jersey City made a clean sweep of its three-game series with the Bears tonight to move to within two and one-half games of the league leaders before a paid attendance of 38,704. The entire proceeds of the game were turned over to Army-Navy relief.

A joint movement to convert garment factories from civilian to war goods production to meet growing military requirements and to avert the threat of widespread unemployment arising from fabric shortages and priority restrictions was launched yesterday at a meeting of representatives of employers and labor of this city's largest single industry -- the women's and children's apparel trades representing 4,000 firms employing more than 200,000 workers.

Late selling instigated by testimony before a House Appropriations subcommittee, disavowing any necessity for rationing cotton because the current supply for military and civilian uses apparently was adequate, forfeited early gains of 14 to 16 points in yesterday's cotton market. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts closed unchanged to 3 points higher than on Monday.

Away back in those simple days when George Bernard Shaw was a young man somewhat under 40 -- it was, as a matter of fact, the year 1894 -- that red-haired Irishman wrote a pleasantly humorous play called "Arms and the Man." Not long thereafter that estimable Viennese music master, Oscar Straus, turned it into an opera bouffe, an act calling for not too much ingenuity on his part.
The Navy made public the following list covering the New York area of missing passengers and members of the crew of the ship sunk off the New England coast:
CAIRO, Egypt, June 23 (AP) -- A British Headquarters communique said today:

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Details of the salvage campaign to retrieve annually an estimated 500,000,000 pounds of fats from kitchen waste, which is to be undertaken early next month in a cooperative drive by industry and the War Production Board were made known today.

In conjunction with the elaborate plans of the General Electric Company to establish training schools throughout the country to instruct dealers in repair work and to set up service centers in numerous cities, an informative campaign to the consumer is now under consideration, it was learned yesterday.

Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands, who arrived in Ottawa last week, went yesterday to Lee in Western Massachusetts to visit her daughter, Princess Juliana, and her grandchildren. In time she will be a guest at the White House. It is to be hoped that the people of this city, founded by Netherlanders, will have the pleasure of seeing a woman and a ruler whom they have learned to admire and respect.

If the Giants could play the Reds every day, they probably would have the pennant clinched already. The New Yorkers blithely bowled over the Cincinnati troupe at the Polo Grounds yesterday for the sixth straight time and for the seventh time in nine tries this season.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., June 23 -- Jacob Abraham Voice, president of the Consolidated Lithographing Corporation of Brooklyn, was drowned while swimming off Atlantic Beach near his home early this morning.

Bobby Ruffin, Long Island City lightweight, defeated Terry Young of the East Side in the star bout of ten rounds at the Queensboro Arena last night. The fight was waged at a brisk clip, and the crowd of 5,123 fans followed the action closely.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 23 -- Attorneys for relatives seeking to break the will of Mrs. Anna H. Paton said tonight they probably would call the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington as a witness in their efforts to prove that, by exerting "undue influence," he persuaded her to bequeath 40 per cent of her $1,300,000 estate to him and to the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, of which he is rector.

Treasury Financing Having taken the $1,500,000,000 Treasury certificates of indebtedness offering in stride with a minimum of disturbance to the bond or money markets, dealers are now speculating upon the types of issues likely to be offered to raise the $4,000,000,000 or so to be borrowed in the market in July and August.

LONDON, June 23 -- War news continued today to make itself fell in operations on the Stock Exchange. In most cases business was too small to test prices and by the close most sections had become dull again.

Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Selective Service director here, estimated that between 150,000 and 175,000 young men between 18 and 20 years old would register in New York City next Tuesday in the fifth registration. He explained the spread between the two figures by pointing out that the number of youths between 18 and 20 who are already in service could not easily be estimated.

TRENTON, June 23 -- Although Governor Charles Edison, Democrat, who is chairman of the State House Commission, was known to be opposed, the other members, all Republicans, voted in his absence today to take bids on July 7 for the rental or purchase of 850 voting machines for compulsory use in Hudson County.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Ways and Means Committee voted today a post-war credit for corporations which, pay excess profits taxes. The credit would be in the form of non-negotiable, non-interest-bearing bonds to be redeemable after the "cessation of hostilities."

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 23 -- A Navy Ministry communique today announced that it was a torpedo from the German submarine Innsbruck that sank the Argentine freighter Rio Tercero 120 miles off New York yesterday.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., June 23 -- As part of the program in which more than 1,000 high school students already have put in periods of fifteen days and longer working on New Jersey farms, Peddie School here has seven youngsters out at farm labor this Summer.
LONDON, June 23 -- Following is the text of Deputy Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee's statement today to the House of Commons on the Libyan situation:
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Francis Rogers will leave on Friday for Honey-suckle Cottage, their Summer place in Southampton, L.I.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters were Moss Hart, playwright, who leased an apartment in 4 East Sixty-fifth Street through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., brokers; and Nikol Schattenstein, painter, who leased a suite in 58 West Fifty-seventh Street through Huberth Huberth, brokers.

The Senate Judiciary Committee plans to vote today on the President's nomination of Thomas F. Meaney to be a Federal District Judge in New Jersey. A subcommittee on Monday approved the nomination. Senators Smathers of New Jersey and Hughes of Delaware, Democrats, with terms expiring in December, voted for it.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 23 -- Protesting against "head hunting" because of the Libyan reverses, Prime Minister John Curtin today issued a warning against "armchair critics who don't take into account the heroism of those doing the actual fighting."

NEW ORLEANS, June 23 (AP) -- Two Stanford University teams -- one breezing, the other struggling -- won initial matches in the doubles of the fifty-eighth national intercollegiate tennis championships today, placing the West in position to continue dominance in the event.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 23 -- Axis occupation of Tobruk does not mean a thing. The fact that the British Eighth Army lost the battle for Tobruk means everything. It means more than the loss of Greece or Crete. It means more because it shouts to high heaven that nothing has been learned.

We still do not know enough facts to draw all the lessons of the British defeat in Libya. But one or two lessons -- and they are very important ones -- are already clear. The British learned early in the war, as the Polish, Dutch, Belgians and French had learned before them, that courage is not enough.
CHUNGKING, June 23 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command communique:

Scrap rubber receipts at bulk collection depots yesterday were substantially in excess of the daily average since the start of the rubber salvage campaign as officials spurred volunteer and professional collectors to greater efforts.

The Museum of Modern Art is opening to the public today several small exhibitions, one of which consists of acquisitions of works by contemporary German artists who are "not approved by the Nazi Government."

"There Were Giants in the Land" is the title that has been given to a book of portraits of Americans, the preparation of which was undertaken at the Treasury Department's suggestion. This will be a Farrar Rhinehart item for Fall with an introduction by Henry Morgenthau Jr.

PERHAPS some psychologist will explain why the inhabitants of a town like Boston or New York will rush to an indoor track meet in the Winter and remain placidly aloof when a similar spectacle is offered outdoors in Spring or Summer.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Dies Committee charged today that Communist front organizations had started a campaign to "discredit" and "obliterate" Congress and thus alter the American form of government.

TRENTON, N.J., June 23 (AP) As a precaution against enemy air raids military authorities are considering a dimout along some sections of the Atlantic Coast which would extend seventy miles inland, Acting Governor I. Grant Scott declared today.

Mrs. Jessie Matthews, 56 years old, who the government says is the operator of "the most luxurious brothel in New York City," was in Federal custody yesterday. She was accused of having defrauded the creditors who had helped her to furnish her resorts.

Before leaving for Nassau yesterday, via Washington and Miami, the Duke of Windsor summed up his accomplishments on his interrupted twenty-five day trip here at a press conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Three housing authorities awarded yesterday a total of $2,951,000 of Series A bonds to various banking groups. A syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. was the high bidder for an issue of 52,267,000 of housing bonds of the New Haven, Conn., Housing Authority on an interest cost basis of 1.8298 per cent.
ALBANY, June 23 -- The Adjutant General released the following orders today:

An Axis propaganda campaign, either preparing advance excuses for a Japanese attack on Russia or signifying ardent German desires for such an attack, was launched yesterday on the German radio, according to The Associated Press.

NEW DEL.HI, India, June 23 (AP) -- The flying freighters of the United States Ferry Command, United States Army bombers and fighters are giving the implements of war to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Chinese armies, despite the increasing fury of the monsoon season and the growing watchfulness of Japanese fighter squadrons in Burma.

The Transit Commission rejected yesterday a 10 per cent increase in commutation rates within the city by the New York Central Railroad, which it ordered suspended last February pending hearings. As hearings on similar applications by the Long Island Railroad and the Staten Island Rapid Transit Company have not been completed, the commission extended for six months its suspension of the increases asked by those roads.

CLEVELAND, June 23 (AP) -- Getting up from the floor after two savage left hooks had floored him for a count of nine in the fifth round, Melio Bettina battered his heavyweight rival, Harry Bobo, to take a ten-round decision tonight in a feature bout of the Cleveland News' Bomber-for-MacArthur card before 23,574 fans.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Navy Department released tonight its fifth casualty list of 2,207 dead, wounded and missing, reported to next of kin from May 11 to June 6 inclusive. The latest list includes 98 dead, 8 wounded and 2,101 missing, of which New York State has 8 dead, 1 wounded and 63 missing, or a total of 72 casualties.

Fourteen of New York's top-flight designers sent some of the best of their models, created for this season, to the fashion show staged by the women's division of Russian War Relief and held at the luncheon hour on the Hotel Astor Roof yesterday.

CLEVELAND, June 23 (AP) -- A flurry of home runs from the bats of Oris Hockett, Les Fleming and Ken Keltner today gave the Indians a 7-to-5 victory over the Athletics. The fourth circuit smash of the contest, by Bob Johnson in the fifth, accounted for three Philadelphia tallies.

LONDON, June 23 -- As reports from Cairo seemed to indicate that Marshal Erwin Rommel was massing troops for a renewed offensive against Great Britain's Eighth Army's defensive positions outside the Egyptian frontier, Deputy Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee told the House of Commons today that substantial British reinforcements were arriving both by land and by air and more were on the way.

DETROIT, June 23 -- The new character and broadened scope of modern warfare, loosing destruction on civilian centers far from the scenes of actual conflict, have brought a new concept of the functions and responsibilities of democratic government, with the result that for the first time American property owners have available to them reasonable protection against war losses, Charles Smith of Chicago told the convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers today.

Lieutenant Charles O. Dannhauser of 104-24 193d Street, Hollis, Queens, on trial at Brooklyn Police Headquarters on charges growing out of his alleged attempts to persuade a fellow-officer to collect and distribute bribes for the protection of a city-wide gambling ring, testified yesterday in his own defense.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP) -- Lou Novikoff's homer with two on in the fifth inning today paved the way for the Cubs to beat the Phils, 8 to 4. Novikoff's round-tripper gave the Cubs a 5-0 lead and a big enough margin to withstand a four-run uprising by the Phils in the seventh inning off Southpaw Vern Olsen.

Sir Andrew Cunningham, British admiral who formerly commanded the Mediterranean Fleet and who is to head the British admiralty delegation to the United States, arrived at the marine terminal at La Guardia Field yesterday. Sir Andrew was one of seventeen passengers who made the maiden passenger voyage aboard an American Export Lines Flying Ace from Europe.

BOSTON, June 23 -- The monthly index of the Associated Industries of Massachusetts for May, at 200.2, compared with 235.1 for April, indicated a general decline in the volume of orders for the products of Bay State manufacturers. However, considerable strength was given to the index for May by even greater demands for cutting tools, gauges and instruments.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Petroleum Coordinator Ickes said today that ground surveys have been started to determine the exact route of the twenty-four-inch Texas-to-Blinois oil pipe line "which will provide partial relief for the East Coast shortage area next Winter."

The British are a far more patient people than Americans. They are less given to emotional ups and downs. The psychological climate of England, like the damped-down weather, is more equable than ours. Yet it is only on the surface, a surface smoothed down by a long habit of self-restraint, that the English are phlegmatic.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, June 24 -- Reinforced but still heavily outnumbered, the defenders of Sevastopol repulsed fierce German attacks yesterday after the partial evacuation of civilians, but on the Kharkov front the Red Army fell back to new positions under sustained assaults, the Russians reported today.

Military reverses, officials of the Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign noticed yesterday, have spurred the populace. The average pledge, since the news took a dark tinge, has gone from $175 to $197, much more than the 10 per cent of earnings sought in the drive.

BUENOS AIRES, June 23 (U.P.) -- Rumors that President Roberto M. Ortiz was about to resign apparently were confirmed tonight when Senate Secretary Ezequiel Fernandez Guerrico visited the Presidential mansion. The Argentine Constitution stipulates that such a decision by the Chief Executive must be communicated in person to the President of the Senate.

On an average of once every three months a woman is likely to decide that she doesn't like the way she looks. Whatever the cause -- a sudden, unexpected meeting with herself in a full-length mirror or a vain attempt to fit into last Summer's bathing suit -- something must be done immediately

YONKERS, N.Y., June 23 -- The Common Council of this city voted unanimously tonight to approve both the Republican and Democratic referenda on the abolition of proportional representation for election to the Council.

The alertness of a postal clerk, combined with the scientific sleuthing of a stamp detective, resulted yesterday in the conviction of a dealer in "washed" and "pieced" stamps. The clerk, Benjamin Goldberg of the postoffice at 103 Prince Street, noticed almost imperceptible irregularities in stamps on packages he was handling and started the hunt that led to George Pappas in his stamp shop at 40 West Eighteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Dissolution of the Vindicators Association, Inc., was asked of the Federal District Court today by Senator Reynolds of North Carolina, who is president of the organization. He made the request on the ground that the war made it "undesirable and impracticable" to carry out all of the objectives of the association.

For two days Yank, the new Army newspaper for men overseas, has been broadcasting bright bits of soldier news to the armed forces in the camps and outposts wherever the American flag waves in other parts of the world.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Comment in New York and some other cities that government "bombing" insurance rates were higher than those for ordinary fire insurance, although the chances of large-scale air raids against the United States seemed slim, were answered today by Frank Christensen, executive vice president of the War Damage Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Consumer services, for which the American public spends upward of 55,000,000,000 annually, today were ordered under price ceilings in a ruling from the Office of Price Administration effective July 1.

Axis submarines have sunk fifteen more ships of the United Nations, with the probable loss of 231 lives, in waters on this side of the Atlantic, it was announced yesterday by the Navy Department. This was by far the heaviest toll of our shipping that has been announced on any single day since the submarine attacks off our coast begun last January.

MOSCOW, June 23 -- Though Col. Gen. Fritz Erich von Mannstein has succeeded at great cost in driving wedges at several points into the defensive system of Sevastopol, Russian reports give no indication that there has been anything like a break-through or a disorganization of this system.

Buyers' Registrations Up Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,070, which compared with 810 in the preceding week and 1,031 in the similar period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your nation-wide survey which shows that 82 per cent of our colleges today, do not require study of United States history is a most valuable and timely service.

At a final informal gathering before suspending activities for the Summer, members of the Women's Council of the Greater New York Fund heard yesterday from John W. Hanes, 1942 campaign chairman of the fund, that cash donations have already reached $4,000,000.

Puzzled Share Cropper The case of Tyler Edwards of Elmore County, Alabama, is not so peculiar as his interviewer, Brooks Atkinson, would seem to think. In the course of his eager rediscovery of America by day coach and bus Mr. Atkinson found Tyler Edwards under the chinaberry tree on his rented farm, blessed with nine children, but rather skeptical about the war.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 23 -- "Dishonored Lady," Katharine Cornell vehicle of the 1930 Broadway season by Margaret Ayer Barnes and Edward Sheldon, was purchased today by Hunt Stromberg, United Artists producer, for a reported $25,000.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The continued Japanese occupation of Attu said Kiska islands In the outer Aleutians probably prefaces a protracted struggle for domination of those wind-swept, desolate, fog-shrouded islands.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 23 -- It was officially announced today by the Swedish Foreign Office that the 4,000-ton Swedish steamer Ada Gorthon, the torpedoing of which was reported yesterday, was sunk in territorial waters.

Richard A. Knight, the disbarred lawyer, whose eccentricities in recent years, including standing on his head and doing handsprings in evening dress between acts at an opening performance at the Metropolitan Opera House, brought him country-wide attention, was being-sought as a fugitive last night on two "informations" filed against him in Special Sessions.

The "crucial test" of sales management and of all business will come during the latter phase of the post-war adjustment period when foreign customers become competitors and industry begins to supply current needs, Donald K. David, newly appointed dean of the Graduate School of Business Administration, Harvard University, asserted yesterday at a meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The eruptions in the House of Commons that have welled upward from deep underground dissatisfaction with the British conduct of the war are not likely to be matched in volume or display by members of the Congress of the United States very soon.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The article and the editorial in the Sunday TIMES on American history as a college requirement imply that our colleges are remiss at this point. A correspondent in that same issue says that "if Wilson and Lloyd George had read history" their post-war ideas would have been more sound.

Delay by the OPA in issuing the long-awaited supplementary seasonal order on furs continues to retard operations in the fur industry to a serious extent, reports here yesterday indicated. Ordinarily at this time the industry is well advanced on both orders and production for August sales and the early Fall, but lack of the seasonal order, together with the possibility of inventory control, has left both producers and retailers unable to determine where they stand.

The corner store in the new taxpayer at Sixth Avenue and Waverly Place recently completed by the Madison Construction Company, Inc., has been leased to the Manufacturers Trust Company for fifteen years at an aggregate rental of $175,000, it was announced yesterday by John J. Reynolds, broker.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Testimony by Admiral Home giving "considerable information about the actions in the Coral Sea, at Midway and in the Aleutians in connection with the airplane carrier, our naval vessel that proved the most serviceable," was the first official intimation that one or more American carriers might be involved in the Aleutians action.

Mayor La Guardia, in an address at the commencement exercises of the High School of Music and Art yesterday, took a prize winning graduate's written work as an example of the clarity and simplicity he said was needed today in international relations.

The East Brooklyn Savings Bank has sold the eight-family dwelling at 858 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, to J. Lawrence Ernstoff through Bernard Seltezer, broker. The size of the plot is 25 by 100 feet, with an assessed valuation of land and improvements of $8,500.

DURHAM, N.H., June 23 -- An agreement to disagree on the relation of the church to the war was made today at the biennial session of the General Council of Congregational Christian Churches with the unanimous adoption of a statement that presented, but did not endorse, the views of both interventionists and pacifists.

The development of intolerance and oppression in America will weaken our fighting arm immeasurably, Wendell L. Willkie warns in an article in the current issue of The Saturday Evening Post. A preface to the article, signed by the editors of the magazine, says Mr. Willkie was invited to write his views after the publication of an article by Milton Mayer on the Jewish people in the same magazine earlier this year.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., June 23 -- Another of the ten competitors in the fourth annual invitation chess masters tournament on Ventnor's municipal pier went down to defeat for the first time today. Albert S. Pinkus of the Manhattan Chess Club, leading at the opening of the fifth session, was defeated by Louis Levy, who first made his mark in intercollegiate chess as a representative of New York University.

George Biddle, painter, and his wife, Helene Sardeau, sculptor, have been jointly commissioned to decorate the walls of the National Library of Brazil, in Rio de Janeiro, with murals, bas-relief and sculpture. The Biddles spent last Winter in Brazil and received the commission from Dr. Gustavo Capanema, Minister of Education.

OTTAWA, June 23 -- Sticking doggedly to the "pay-as-you-go" policy inaugurated at the outbreak of the war and ever since adhered to "as far as it is practicable," Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley presented in the Canadian Parliament this evening a budget that calls for the meeting of an expenditure of nearly four billion dollars.

George Biddle, painter, and his wife, Helene Sardeau, sculptor, have been jointly commissioned to decorate the walls of the National Library of Brazil, in Rio de Janeiro, with murals, bas-relief and sculpture. The Biddles spent last Winter in Brazil and received the commission from Dr. Gustavo Capanema, Minister of Education.

OTTAWA, June 23 -- Sticking doggedly to the "pay-as-you-go" policy inaugurated at the outbreak of the war and ever since adhered to "as far as it is practicable," Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley presented in the Canadian Parliament this evening a budget that calls for the meeting of an expenditure of nearly four billion dollars.

If you used to visit your grandfather's farm long ago, you probably remember Summer evenings when you perched on the back stoop and watched the hired man carry the milk pails into the house. The fresh, foaming fluid was warm and satisfying and flavorful, and you greedily drank two and three mugs of it at the supper that was always served at precisely six o'clock.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Vallejo and Napa, California, with a 40 per cent rise, continued to lead all cities in department store sales in May, compared with May of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Next came Charleston, S.C., with an increase of 30 per cent.

Johnny Longden, a veteran of many years in the saddle, scored a triple at Aqueduct yesterday, which saw him get home aboard Miquelon at $125.50 for $2, Best Irish at $3.60 in the featured Buck Horn Purse and Bright Gray in the nightcap at $19.60.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Miss Marjorie Row, 20-year-old Michigan State College co-ed from Detroit, jolted the medalist, Miss Eleanor Dudley, out of the women's Western open golf tournament today with a stinging 1-up victory in the first round of match play.

LONDON, June 23 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill faces a critical House of Commons and a vote on a motion of non-confidence when he returns from Washington, but he will weather the storm as he has before, it was clear today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Leo T. Crowley, alien property custodian, has seized another 750 enemy-owned patents and taken control of four New York corporations, one of them a holding company administering German-owned real estate. The concerns are the J.M. Lehmann Company, Inc., the Adlanco X-ray Corporation, Ergen Corporation and the Avonzel Corporation.
Indianapolis, Ind. The city of Indianapolis, Ind., will be in the market on July 7 with an issue of $990,000 of temporary-loan notes. The obligations will become payable on Nov. 15.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The House Military Affairs Committee's report criticized virtually every branch, of the War Department, including the Air Corps, and likewise voiced displeasure with the Maritime Commission.
LONDON, June 23 -- The German port of Emden was subjected to heavy bombing in the concentrated period of less than one hour last night, the Air Ministry announced today.

Three new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. "Beyond the Blue Horizon," a Paramount production in Technicolor starring Dorothy Lamour, will be the new tenant at the Paramount. Featured in the romantic comedy are Richard Denning, Jack Haley, Patricia Morison, Walter Abel and Helen Gilbert....

DETROIT, June 23 -- Developments in the new world war give evidence that the white man's domination over the great masses of population in the so-called "backward" nations has been broken and when peace comes there will emerge a new world of free nations and greater racial independence, Senator Elbert D. Thomas of Utah predicted in a speech before the American Institute of Architects today.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Wheat prices were on the downgrade today, reflecting better harvesting weather in the Southwest and a little hedging pressure. At one time the market showed a loss of around 1 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 23 -- A brilliant finish by Mrs. J.B. Balding of the Cedar Creek Club gave her a surprising 1-up victory over Mrs. Harry McNaughton of Plandome, the medalist, in the opening round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association's fifteenth annual championship at the North Hempstead Country Club today.
BERLIN, June 23 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command said in a communique today:

Magistrate Edgar Bromberger fined a Bronx couple $4 yesterday for walking on the grass at Orchard Beach last Sunday and in the same session of the Bronx Magistrate's Court put two 16-year-old youths on a year's probation for throwing stones at three other boys in a rowboat near the same beach.

The advertising profession yesterday pledged itself to the achievement of "unquestioned national unity and understanding and an invincible morale," in resolutions passed at the business session of the thirty-eighth annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America at the Hotel Commodore.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The article which appeared in THE TIMES describing the failure of our colleges and schools to offer courses in American history is a condition which every thinking American must personally regret.

George Murnane, chairman of American Bosch Corporation, announced at the adjourned annual meeting of the company that 535,000 shares, representing 77 per cent of the outstanding stock, which he had held in voting trust for foreign interests, was deposited with Leo C. Crowley, Alien Property Custodian, on May 19, 1942.
MOSCOW, June 23 (U.P.) -- This is a story of Russian dogs that attack German tanks and destroy them.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- So many royal roads have been leading to Washington of late that Mrs. Roosevelt was asked at her press conference today if the entertainment of royalty at the White House presented any special problems or, as one reporter put it, if these guests were "any more trouble" than others week-ending under its roof.
The following Finnish communique was broadcast by the German Transocean Agency and recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

The Pullman Company yesterday advised civilians to keep their vacation plans flexible this Summer. George A. Kelly, vice president, pointed out that the company had carried nearly 2,500,000 troops in the first five months of 1942 and that this figure was 525,000 for May, or 13 per cent above the averages for the four preceding months.

In one of the largest realty deals consummated thus far this year Charles F. Noyes has purchased for his daughter, Mrs. Duncan M. Findlay, the seventeen business buildings comprising the entire block bounded by Beekman, Pearl, Ferry and Cliff Streets, it was announced yesterday.

The general death rate in this city struck a new low for the year again last week, Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of records in the Department of Health, reported yesterday. New low marks have been set four times recently.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The following table shows how the amount approved by Congress for defense and war for the fiscal years 1941-42-43 has grown to $205,311,233,542:

Encouraging evidence that the New York Conservation Department's efforts to improve the supply of muskalonge are meeting with success is contained in latest reports concerning the spawn-taking operations for the Bemus Point hatchery.

Council President Newborn Morris and Councilman Joseph E. Kinsley, Finance Committee chairman, engaged in a heated row yesterday as the Council adopted a new basic tax rate of $2.79 per $100 of assessed valuation at its meeting in City Hall.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 23 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board; Leon Henderson, administrator of the Office of Price Administration, and Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, joined today in emphasizing the urgent nature of the rubber shortage in addresses this afternoon at the annual meeting of the Governors' conference.

Magistrate Edgar Bromberger, who fined a Bronx couple $4 Tuesday for walking on the grass at Orchard Beach to retrieve their 2 1/2-year-old son who had run onto the lawn, yesterday in Bronx Magistrate Court dismissed a summons against Mrs. Celia Feldman, a school teacher, of 1314 Seneca Avenue, the Bronx, who was accused of sitting on a newspaper on Orchard Beach.

LONDON, June 24 -- While the country generally is seething with indignation over the Libyan defeat, Parliament appeared today in calmer mood and less inclined to find a scapegoat, but intent on ascertaining the real reasons for the recurrent military reversals and correcting them.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- If a passenger car driver and a truck driver want gasoline from a dealer and he has not enough for both he may give preference to the truck driver. An amendment to the emergency gasoline rationing regulations issued today by the Office of Price Administration included defense workers and ambulance drivers in the preferred class.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 25 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Tokyo newspapers today published the first pictures of Japanese landings on a sparsely populated Aleutian island outpost and printed with them the first detailed Japanese version of the attack, written by a Domei naval correspondent.

Many of the American citizens scheduled to return from Japanese-held territories are priests and sisters who were trained for foreign missionary service in the Far East at the seminaries of the Maryknoll Brothers and Maryknoll Sisters near Ossining, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Norman H. Davis, national chairman of the American Red Cross, made it known today that with the approval of President Roosevelt the November roll-call would be deferred and combined with the next war fund appeal, scheduled for March.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 24 -- Advance columns of the Axis desert army were advancing southeastward from Gambut yesterday as it they meant to flank the Halfaya-Sblum area and enter Egypt by pushing through British border defenses in the vicinity of the two Omars -- Libyan Omar and Sidi Omar.

LOS ANGELES, June 24 -- Stanley Johnston, Chicago newspaper man who reported the battle of the Coral Sea and the sinking of the carrier Lexington, did not tell the whole story. He did not relate his own heroism on board the carrier.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A national food industry advisory committee to work with the Office of Price Administration in the solution of problems and adjustments under the General Maximum Price Regulation was appointed today by Price Administrator Leon Henderson.
