WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Draft headquarters announced tonight that, generally speaking, married men with children would be the Last to be called into service, but emphasized that they could count upon no permanent deferment.

There is no doubt a connection between two events reported from Buenos Aires yesterday: the resignation of President Roberto M. Ortiz and a strong protest sent to the Nazis, on behalf of Acting President Ramon S. Castillo, over the torpedoing of an Argentine freighter.

Mink Brings $13.25 Top Ranch mink of the American National Fur Breeders Association met a good demand at the sale conducted yesterday by Lampson, Fraser Huth. The skins brought prevailing market prices. The top was $13.25.
LONDON, June 24 -- The text of General Charles de Gaulle's Free French political declaration, issued tonight, follows:

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- An estimate of $161,000,000 to finance the Office of Price Administration in the next twelve months, approved by the Bureau of the Budget, was cut today to $95,000,000 by the House Appropriations Committee which acted on the theory that the Price Control Act would be "self-enforcing."

The annual Housewares Show, which was to have been held in Atlantic City during the week of July 12, has been called off at the request of the Office of Defense Transportation, Maurice E. Horn, president of the New York Housewares Manufacturers Association, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The war production program is being held back by three bottlenecks in steel production, according to Philip Murray, president of the United Steel Workers of America, C.I.O.
VALLETTA, Malta, June 24 (AP) -- An R.A.F. communique said:

ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 24 -- In a demonstration of national unity the final session of the annual Governors Conference, attended by the Chief Executives of thirty-six States, unanimously adopted resolutions today paying tribute to President Roosevelt's leadership and wisdom and pledging him full cooperation in support of his war program.

Richard B. Scandrett Jr., co-chairman of "Vote for Freedom," made formal announcement yesterday of the start of a movement to draft Wendell L. Willkie for the Republican nomination for Governor on the ground that the records of Thomas E. Dewey and Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., prospective Republican and Democratic nominees for that office, unfitted them "for this position of leadership in time of war."

As the Navy announced yesterday another sinking of a merchant ship in American waters by an enemy submarine, Senator Brewster of Maine, a member of the Senate Naval Affairs Committee, declared that the convoying of coastal shipping is "not a satisfactory solution" for the submarine problem.
Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that any one who changed into bathing attire on the front lawn of a private home should be "fanned" by the police all the way to the station house.

Commenting yesterday on the new city basic tax rate of $2.79 on every $100 of assessed valuation, the Citizens Budget Commission said that the saving of $1,600,000 was made possible only by a "makeshift balancing of the budget."

A cloud of dust rising from the Libyan desert warned the Egyptians yesterday that Marshal Rommel's forces were swinging southward with the evident aim of flanking and encircling the border defenses. Once pillars of cloud and fire appeared in the Egyptian skies to guide Moses across the neighboring wastes of sea and sky.

MOSCOW, Thursday, June 25 (U.P.) -- Russian armies fighting from new positions after forced withdrawals hurled back heavy German tank and infantry attacks on the Kharkov front yesterday and battled stubbornly against numerically overwhelming besiegers of Sevastopol, the Soviet High Command reported today.

With a small group of newspaper reporters for an audience, several staff employes of the State Office of Price Administration and a group of volunteer assistants supplied by the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office began yesterday a name-reading marathon that will continue until the names, addresses and occupations of the 70,000-odd holders of X gasoline rationing cards living in New York City have been disclosed.

LONDON, June 24 -- At a press conference today Oliver Lyttelton, British Minister of Production, was most optimistic about United States production. He said it had already passed British production forty-five to fifty days ahead of time and that the peak of United States production was not in sight.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- President Roosevelt was informed today by Secretary Ickes that the first six days of the scrap-rubber collection campaign had yielded 100,438 tons. The Eastern States, where gasoline rationing is in effect, were reported to be lagging far behind their Western neighbors, who hope to avoid curtailment of gasoline sales as a tire conservation measure.
After a three-day interlude, play will be resumed today in the national professional championships at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.
Abraham Straus, Inc. Abraham Straus, Inc., yesterday declared a 50-cent dividend payable July 25 on the common stock. A similar amount was paid on April 25.

The American Bankers Association has canceled its annual convention that had been scheduled for Sept. 25 to 30 in Detroit, it was announced yesterday by Henry W. Koeneke, president of the organization. This action, he said, was in recognition of the growing wartime transportation needs of the nation and the national policy of discouraging conventions by associations with large memberships.

Likely it was the sight of those dark and shuttered houses along Forty-second Street that stirred in Mike Todd some dim, nostalgic memory of a far happier day. Being a demoniac fellow from away back, he swung instantly into action, and the burlesque which License Commissioner Moss lately tore asunder he quietly restored, like humpty-dumpty to the wall.

In a closing rally in the Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign to be held tomorrow evening in Times Square, pledge signers and bond purchasers will have the privilege of signing their names to bombs destined for Berlin and Tokyo, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Japan is systematically looting occupied regions and forcing her "culture" and economic controls on the peoples of the areas, the Office of War Information stated today in quoting material from foreign broadcasts monitored' by the Federal Communications Commission.
France fell because its leaders feared the common people and the ideas abroad in the world that "they were not sure they could combat," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday.

Still unable to generate any public activity because of the continuing effects of the Libyan disaster the stock market rambled along yesterday within a restricted range. Price changes were confined to fractions although major retreats cropped up in isolated spots.

The country's largest manufacturer of air filters, another corporation in that field and eleven individuals were fined a total of $88,000 by Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard yesterday on charges of violating the anti-trust laws. The defendants, who were named in an information filed by a Federal grand jury shortly before the fines were imposed, pleaded nolo contendere.

A grand jury indicted yesterday Harry Waltzer. business agent of the Newspaper and Mail Deliveries Independent Union, and its delegate, William Walsh. The indictment accused them of attempting to extort $5,000 from William Armstrong, president and treasurer of the Armstrong Racing Publications, 350 West Twenty-fourth Street, on June 16 in a restaurant in Greenwich Village.

LONDON, June 24 -- The heavy losses of raw materials suffered by Britain through Japanese conquest of some of her colonies, and the steps being taken to make good the shortages, were revealed to the House of Commons today by Under-Secretary for Colonies Harold MacMillan.

BOSTON, June 24 (AP) -- Taking command at the sixteenth pole, Colonel Edward Riley Bradley's Bless Me pulled away to a length and a half victory over Arnold Hanger's Harvard Square today in the feature at Suffolk Downs.

A 26-year-old wounded Czechoslovak soldier was one of fifty-one passengers who arrived yesterday aboard a Pan America Airways transatlantic clipper at La Guardia Field. Behind him a story of fighting in France h his compatriots after the evacuation of the British Army at Dunkerque; his escape from occupied France to Africa and other perils, until his journey's end here.

Of the thousands of children who will be graduated from public schools this month, few, if any, will cherish their diplomas as much as the two girls who composed the graduating class at commencement exercises of Public School 401, yesterday at Bellevue Hospital.

Aided by Patricia, a young beagle, and a nameless stray kitten, doctors at the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals, 350 Lafayette Street, demonstrated yesterday proper first-aid treatment for pets in the event of air raids.

LEE, Mass., June 24 -- A gray-haired American woman who when she was a tiny girl was told by her mother that she was the same age as "little Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands" welcomed that same Queen this morning to her country, home.

Stocks of gasoline in the United States at the close of last week amounted to 89,847,000 barrels, a decline of 2,147,000 from the 91,994,000 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago these stocks amounted to 90,874,000 barrels.

STANTON, Del., June 24 (AP) -- Taking the lead from the tiring Ossabaw just after clearing the ninth fence, Mrs. Esther du Pont Weir's Deanslaw raced to a convincing triumph today in the $6,000 added Georgetown Steeplechase Handicap at Delaware Park.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- For the second time this administration has entrusted an account of the inner operations of its foreign policy to writers in private life instead of assembling these matters in a White Book. For the second time official information, withheld from Congress and the general press and public, has been authorized for publication at commercial profit to a few persons.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You have recently published a communication regarding the waste of water in park drinking fountains.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24 -- "Flesh and Fantasy," a photoplay in four episodes, will be Charles Boyer's first production for Universal, and Edward G. Robinson will appear with Boyer in the film, it was learned today. Each actor will star in one episode, and negotiations are under way for players to head the casts of the other two sequences.

Alice, the 50-year-old dowager queen of the Bronx Zoo elephant herd, who had a slight mis-adventure Friday when she fell over on her side and had to be lifted to her feet with a six-ton crane, was in excellent fettle yesterday when she took part in ceremonies officially opening the new moated elephant enclosure.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 24 -- Twenty-one women here, sharing six uniforms of the local women's volunteer defense office, took a large part in the city's salvage campaign which ended today. The corps originally numbered thirty-two, but had to be reduced owing" to certain problems of feminine fitting.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Secretary Knox, acting on behalf of President Roosevelt, presented a Congressional Medal of Honor in absentia today to Captain Albert H. Rooks, commander of the cruiser Houston, which disappeared in the Java Sea Feb. 28 after three weeks of almost constant engagement with the enemy.
CHICAGO. June 24 -- Chicago today started a two-week campaign to salvage household grease. Results of the drive will be used as the basis on which a nation-wide campaign will be planned.

DETROIT, June 24-Decentralization, of government agencies, started just after the attack on Pearl Harbor, to provide more room in crowded Washington for essential war activities, is likely to continue for some time and offers one of the chief hopes of land-lords and their agents for absorbing vacant office space, the National Association of Building Owners and Managers was informed today.

CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- Miss Betty Jameson hit her old-time golfing form today, and as word spread around the Elmhurst course the other seven survivors in the women's Western open agreed the Texas girl had become the "one to beat."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 24 -- William T. Chalkley, butler to Mrs. Anna H. Paton from 1917 until her death last year, spent three hours on the witness stand today before Surrogate Charles D. Millard and a jury explaining why he believed the friendship between Mrs. Paton and the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington was "religious affecion," although fellow-servants considered the clergyman "Mrs. Paton's gigolo."

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The State Department announced tonight the names of 629 Americans scheduled to return from Japanese-held territory in the Pacific under exchange arrangements made through Swiss authorities.

Buyers of industrial products, anxious to be assured that the prices they pay are not in excess of ceilings, have been advised by Harold Leventhal, assistant general counsel of the OPA, to seek written certification to that effect from sellers, the National Association of Purchasing Agents announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- King Peter n of Yugoslavia was officially welcomed to the United States by President Roosevelt today, and entertained at a state dinner in the White House tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The House Banking Committee unanimously approved today a bill to amend the Federal Reserve Act by providing, among other things, for a regrouping of Federal Reserve banks for the purpose of electing their five representatives on the Federal Open Market Committee.

President Roosevelt's former New York City home and the adjoining building that belonged to his late mother at 47 and 49 East Sixty-fifth Street have been purchased by a committee of thirty-three citizens and will be opened in the Fall as a community house for Hunter College students.

DETROIT, June 24 (AP) -- Ted Williams's seventh-inning homer, his seventeenth of the season, produced the only run Broadway Charley Wagner needed today to pitch the Red Sox to a 1-to-0 victory over the Tigers in a twilight game before 13,193 spectators.

Claude Passeau chalked up his eleventh victory tonight as he pitched the Cubs to a 3-to-1 victory over the last-place Phils. Rookie Earl Naylor gave the Cubs only eight hits, but Passeau yielded only four.
BERLIN, June 24 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this special announcement today:

LONDON, June 24 -- The weakest features in dull trading on the Stock Exchange today were the Egyptian securities, the oils and the chain stores. Egyptian unified 4 per cent bonds lost u2 more to u81 and other loans were marked down several points.

Complaining that inability to buy gasoline was interfering with work on war contracts at several plants in Queens, the Chamber of Commerce of Queens appealed yesterday to Mayor La Guardia for assistance in remedying the situation. The appeal was made before the Office of Price Administration in Washington announced revision of regulations to permit operators of gasoline stations to discriminate in favor of workers in war factories.

HUNTINGTON PARK, Calif., June 24 -- The efforts of Darwin Lyons, 46, to protect his family from a possible gas attack led to the deaths of his wife and three children in an explosion and fire which followed "a rehearsal" in a specially fitted room at their home, he told physicians today.
CAIRO, June 24 (AP) -- A British headquarters communique said today:

Yesterday the Board of Education elected as Superintendent of Schools in place of the deeply mourned Dr. Harold Campbell the long-trusted associate whom he called his "strong right arm." There could be no higher testimony of Dr. Wade's qualifications. Educated in our public schools and at two of our urban universities, he began teaching, forty-four years ago.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., last month borrowed $5,000,000 for working capital from two banks and paid off a balance of $1,300,000 on a five-year serial loan, making the net increase in working capital $3,700,000, it was said yesterday.

BOSTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Cardinals' pennant hopes suffered a rude jolt today when the Braves pulled out of a prolonged losing streak by sweeping a double-header with second-place St. Louis, 6 -- 2 and 3 -- 1.

A tea dance was given yesterday at the Stork Club by members of the Officers Service Committee for the benefit of the United Service Organizations. A feature of the afternoon's divertissements was a shower of multi-colored balloons containing orders for many donated gifts.

TO THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES: In an editorial in THE TIMES of June 18 you refer to the passage of the bill by the House for the construction of the Florida barge canal and say that "the Florida project can no more be regarded as a war measure than a St. Lawrence power plant."

CHUNGKING, China, Thursday, June 25 -- American Volunteer Group fighters converted into bombers raided Hankow on Tuesday, sinking a Japanese warship and three river transports, probably damaging others and blowing up military establishments, it was announced today.

Receipts of scrap rubber at the metropolitan district bulk collection depots of the petroleum industry spurted sharply yesterday, the day's total amounting to 364 tons, or 43 per cent of the previous receipts for the entire rubber salvage campaign.

CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- Johnny Humphries, White Sox right-hander who pitched four shut-outs in six 1941 starts, reverted to his best form today to blank Washington on eight hits while his battery mate, Tom Turner, helped out with a homer with the bases loaded.

Mayor La Guardia extended a broad invitation yesterday to Conrado Traverso, Consul General of Argentina, to place his country on the side of the United Nations, but the Argentine official by-passed the opportunity in discreet fashion.

Abandonment of the present method of choosing jurors in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York was recommended yesterday in a resolution adopted by the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut at a meeting held in the Federal Court House in Foley Square.

Gambling and Speculation When Elisha M. Friedman appeared before the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce to urge amendment of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, little attention was paid to his remarks on gambling.

NEW ORLEANS, June 24 (AP) -- It was a great day for Stanford University's entries today in the national intercollegiate tennis tournament, as that school's four-man team, paced by top-seeded Ted Schroeder, won three singles and two doubles matches without a loss.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: First we were told there was a serious shortage of sugar because it was to be used for something connected with the war. Propaganda got busy telling the long-suffering citizen that practically everything that kills people could be traced to the demon sugar.

ST. LOUIS, June 24 -- The Yankees, with a rush of extra-base hits against Johnny Niggeling, again beat the Browns at Sportsman's Park today. The count was 6 to 4. But it required the calm relief hurling of Johnny Murphy, for the second time within twenty-four hours, to protect this latest victory, the third in a row for the world champions.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 24 -- At least 100 new airdromes have been built for United Nations air forces over a wide area of Australia in the last few months, and the Allied Works Council has 1,500 large-scale and 10,000 smaller projects on its program.

Mayor La Guardia has sent letters to business leaders in the city criticizing the lack of action in Washington in planning for the post-war period and asking business men to join him in a local study of plans to meet the afterwar period, it became known yesterday.

The names of several new tenants have been added to the tenant roster of London Terrace, large housing development on West Twenty-third Street. The latest rentals were announced by William A. White Sons, agents, as follows: H. Rawlins Overton, Andrew Costa, James J. French, Lieutenant William E. Lowe, Bernice Seaver, Alfred J. Peterson, Nicholas G. Demy, Eric Johnson, Mrs. Janna W. Cruikshank, Lieut. Col. Paul C. Ashworth, Robert S. Ward and G. Wilber Read.

The Giants apparently look much less formidable to the Reds under floodlights than they do in the sunshine. At any rate Cincinnati turned on its New York tormentor yesterday in the first twilight-night ever held at the Polo Grounds and beat Mel Ott's operatives, 4 to 3, to the complete chagrin of a gathering of 13,967.

CHICAGO. June 24 -- Wheat reversed its action in the late trading on the Board of Trade today and an early loss of about 1/2 cent a bushel was followed by a good rally. A little buying was credited to mills, presumably against prospective sales of flour to the Navy, and caused shorts to cover.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 24 -- With stout hearts but quavering voices, thirty Confederate veterans, including two Negro bodyguards, have gathered here for their fifty-second annual convention. The average age of these gallant old soldiers is about 96, their years ranging from a youthful 91 to a more sedate 103.

The annual report of the Thompson-Starrett Company, Inc., issued yesterday, disclosed a net income of $1,385 for the year ended on April 30, equal to 2 cents a share on 63,896 shares of $3.50 preference stock, on which unpaid cumulative dividends to and including April 1 amounted to $2,348,178.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Congratulations on your editorial entitled "Tankermen" which appeared today. You put it mildly when you say "the cop on the beat, gentle with the tipsy soldier or the unsteady gob, is apt to put his nightstick to the britches of a merchant sailor who has tippled heavily in the town's bars to celebrate his rescue from the sea."

Persistent liquidation, exerted almost completely in the July position, outweighed spasmodic trade buying in the cotton futures market yesterday, causing active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange to close 5 to 12 points under the previous day's final prices.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., June 24 -- Sidney Bernstein and Albert S. Pinkus of the Manhattan Chess Club of New York were tied for the lead in the invitation masters tournament in progress on the Municipal Pier when play was stopped tonight.
MOSCOW, Thursday, June 25 (AP) -- The midnight Soviet communique follows:
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Eight directives to promote "effective mobilization and utilization of the nation's manpower," were sent out today by Paul V. McNutt, head of the War Manpower Commission.

LONDON, Thursday, June 25 (AP) -- German raiders smashed at two West Midlands towns with heavy explosive and incendiary bombs early today in the first such attack for more than a year, causing a number of casualties and some damage.

The New York Young Republican Club, by a vote of 104 to 1 endorsed last night the candidacy of Thomas E. Dewey for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination The lone dissent came from Henry G. Van Veen.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company has sold for cash to Thomas Friedman, an investor, the five-story dwelling on a lot 20 by 102.2 feet at 59 East Seventy-second Street. The house, which adjoins the twelve-story apartment building at the northwest corner of Park Avenue, formerly was owned by Joseph D. Stein, an official of the Latham Lithographing Company, and was acquired by the insurance company at foreclosure.

Allocation of domestic hides by WPB may be delayed another two to three weeks, according to reports circulating in the market yesterday. It is believed that postponement of the order is due to the fact that WPB officials want to have it in such form that it will not temporarily halt the flow of hides from packers to tanners and through to leather goods manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Ways and Means Committee sent to its drafting experts today its decisions on the largest tax bill in history, providing a gross increase in revenue estimated tentatively by Treasury experts at $5,924,000,000.

CLEVELAND, June 24 (AP) -- The veteran southpaw Al Milnar gave five safeties in three innings, then held the Athletics hitless for the last six innings as the Indians registered a 9-to-0 victory with fifteen hits including homers by Milnar and Les Fleming today.

By unanimous vote, the Board of Education elected Dr. John E. Wade, deputy superintendent of schools, yesterday as Superintendent of Schools for a six-year term at $25,000 a year. He will fill the vacancy caused by the death of Dr. Harold G. Campbell a week ago.
LONDON, June 24 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:
CHUNGKING, June 24 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command communique said:

This morning in the ventilated coolness of a local store a prospective hostess may determine, leisurely, the pattern for her future party. There against a pink-and-white background in a sequestered section of this shop she will find settings and suggestions for Summer-time suppers.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, June 25 -- Lieut. Gen. D.T. Kozloff, under Marshal Semyon Timoshenko, in charge of operations to relieve the beleaguered garrison at Sevastopol, has launched another surprise operation on the southern coast of the Crimea with landings by Russian marines, according to information received here early today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Representative Voorhis of California dissented from the majority of the Dies Committee today, accusing it of undignified "name-calling" in its criticism, of the Union for Democratic Action.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 24r -- Two snake trainers in a carnival show, bitten yesterday by a diamond-back rattlesnake, died today in the West Jersey Homeopathic Hospital, despite blood transfusions from other persons in the show.

Inspector Martin J. Brown, commander of the Seventh Inspection Division, the Bronx, testified yesterday at the departmental trial of Lieutenant Charles O. Danhauser in Brooklyn police headquarters that his examination of the arrest records in the Fourteenth Inspection Division in Brooklyn, to which Danhauser was assigned as clerical officer during the latter part of 1938, showed that no arrests of consequence had been made by the plainclothes men assigned to the division.

The refining plant and warehouse consisting of six buildings, formerly owned by the American Sugar Refining Company, on the south-east corner of Essex and Washington Streets, Jersey City, N.J., have been purchased by the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company, soap manufacturers of Jersey City.

DURHAM, N.H., June 24 -- Conscientious objectors were praised at the convention of the General Congregational Christian Churches today as high-minded and devoted young men who have the courage of their convictions.

An audience of some 14,000 people saw the second performance of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Lewisohn Stadium last night. Leonide Massine made his first appearance of the Summer season as the gay hussar of "Beau Danube," Mia Slavenska made her Summer bow in the chief role of "The Magic Swan," and "Scheherazade" had a new Zobeide in the person of Tatiana Orlova.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., June 24 -- The importance of enlisting the aid of thousands of men capable of mastering the intricate mechanics necessary to the communications branch of the United States Army was urgently stressed by Major Gen.

An official referee's report exonerating C. Ernest Smith, Staten Island political leader and twice president of the Richmond County Bar Association, of all charges contained in a presentment requesting his disbarment has been filed with the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, it was disclosed yesterday.

NEW YORK Mrs. Edgerton Parsons has gone to her Summer home in Hadlyme, Conn. Her daughter, Miss Patricia Parsons, and Christopher Layton, son of Sir Walter and Lady Layton, are with her to stay for the season.

STORRS, Conn., June 24 (AP) -- Carl J (Dutch) Weese of Newark, N.J., today finished the first York round with a lead of 5 points over his nearest rival and a 38-point edge over the present titleholder, E. Harold Potts of Moorestown, N.J., as the Eastern Archery Association's 1942 championship tournament opened at the University of Connecticut.

Advertising men are getting such diversified experience at the present time that, if they return to the profession when the war has ended, their abilities as creative advertising men should have been considerably improved, it was suggested yesterday by an agency executive.

A representative of Cuba's distilleries said yesterday, according to The Associated Press, that the United States was permitting to lie unused in the island's storage tanks enough molasses to make 125,000,000 gallons of alcohol, a major necessity for smokeless powder, synthetic rubber and other war materials.

Two midtown theatres will present new films this morning. At the Capitol the attraction will be Metro's "Ship Ahoy!" Eleanor Powell, Bert Lahr, Red Skelton, Virginia O'Brien and Tommy Dorsey and his orchestra head the cast of the musical. . . . At the Palace the newcomer is "Mexican Spitfire at Sea," the latest comedy in that series at RKO.

DETROIT, June 24 -- The building industry faces its greatest challenge and greatest opportunity in immediate organization of all its branches for conversion, to peace after the war, leaders in the field of building design assured the American Institute of Architects today.

With the growing trend toward night shopping, several stores that have never before remained open after 5 or 6 o'clock, except in some cases just before Christmas, will launch new late houru this evening. In addition, two fashion shows geared to the city's wartime life will be staged at Fifth Avenue shops.

BALTIMORE, June 24 (AP) -- An order filed in Circuit Court today disclosed settlement of Federal tax claims against the Chesapeake Corporation receivership for $1,200,000, leaving large assets of the former Van Sweringen Holding Company for distribution to stockholders.

In this Summer of Axis aggressiveness China, as well as North Africa, Russia and the Western Atlantic, is a field of battle. It is harder for an American newspaper reader to follow events in China, because the place names and the nature of the country are alike unfamiliar to most of us.

In voting a post-war refund to corporations paying excess profits taxes the House Ways and Means Committee has followed the recommendation of its own experts, the Treasury, the War Production Board and most outside economists. Under the plan tentatively approved, excess profits will be taxed at 94 per cent, but corporations will receive non-negotiable, noninterest-bearing bonds in an amount equal to 14 per cent of their excess profits.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 24 -- Unable to match, the consistency of her rival, Mrs. Charles Leichner of Fresh Meadow, defending women's Long Island golf champion, was eliminated in the quarter-final round of the title test at the North Hempstead C.C. today by Mrs. Thomas Rudel of Cedar Creek.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 24 -- The capture of Tobruk, combined with the progress of the Axis forces in the Sevastopol sector, has given fresh impetus to popular speculation in Germany over the prospect of an early offensive against Russia on a wider front.

DANVILLE, Va., June 24 -- Governor Colgate W. Darden Jr. was back in the Executive Mansion at Richmond tonight after making a visit incognito to Pennsylvania County to study the case of Odell Waller the Negro sharecropper under death sentence for the killing of Oscar Davis.

A Twin City banking group headed by the Wells-Dickey Company of Minneapolis won yesterday the award of $2,025,000 of State of Minnesota rural credit deficiency fund certificates of indebtedness. The bankers bid 100.38, naming the interest rate as 1.70 per cent.

Vagrancy chalked up her fourth stake victory of the season in the $6,675 Gazelle Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday to establish more than ever her supremacy among 3-year-old fillies. If there is as good a thoroughbred of the sex and age he does not come readily to mind, and admirers of Vagrancy declare there is none such.

Metropolitan fresh-water anglers are eagerly awaiting next Wednesday, when the curtain will be lifted on the black bass season in this area, even though their activity may not be as extensive as in former years because of various restrictions.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., June 24 -- Playing the beat golf she has displayed so far in this tournament, Miss Margaret Nichols of Hudson River today eliminated the medalist, Mrs. Richard Hellmann of the home club, 5 and 3, in the second round of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association championship over the hilly Scarsdale Country Club course.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 24 -- The field in the national intercollegiate golf tournament was whittled down from sixty-four to sixteen players today by two eighteen-hole rounds of match play and was jammed with dark horses after many of the favorites had been eliminated.

Jay Northam Whipple, a partner in Bacon, Whipple Co. of Chicago, an investment securities firm, has been nominated for the presidency of the Investment Bankers Association of America, it was announced yesterday by John S. Fleek of Hayden, Miller Co., Cleveland, president of the association.
THE tennis fan was in no mood for trifling. He was irked, annoyed, indignant and distressed. He sounded off with, vigor.

Ray Brock, NEW YORK TIMES correspondent in Turkey, cabled to Reynal Hitchcock yesterday that the manuscript of his promised book had at last been shipped off by a safe and fast method. There is more or less speculation about what the book will be, since negotiations were carried on with the author by short cablegrams.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, June 24 (AP) -- A. United States fighter pilot forced down after a battle with a Japanese bomber came out of the crocodile-infested swamps of Northern Australia today to tell of a three-day ordeal during which he ate a grasshopper and raw owl meat.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 24 -- Argentina's efforts to avoid a break with the Axis resulted today in a demand by Congress that Foreign Minister Enrique de Ruiz Guinazu appear before it July 2 to explain what action had been taken following the sinking of the Argentine merchantman Rio Tercero off New York.

Evidence multiplied this week that retailers are now committed to a policy of confinings current buying to fill-ins and balancing of stocks until the government's policy with respect to inventory control becomes clearer, with the result that conditions in several wholesale markets became softer than they have been at any time thus far this year.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Motor transport units to move troops or evacuate civilians in the case of an attack on the United States are to be organized in various parts of the country jointly by the Office of Civilian Defense and the Office of Defense Transportation.

Five to Four One major secret of American peace and well-being is that at heart we are one for all and all for one, but on the United States Supreme Court we are five to four. Chief Justice Stone the other day himself took cognizance of this point, which has been in many people's minds in recent months.

The two-and-a-half-week-old strike of members of Local 804 of the Teamsters Union, A. F. of L., that disrupted deliveries to 100,000 customers of 375 departments and specialty stores in the metropolitan area ended yesterday as a result of intervention by Mayor La Guardia, The 1,600 drivers and helpers returned to work shortly after announcement of tie settlement by Mrs. Ethel Epstein, the Mayor's industrial secretary, at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- By a vote of 11 to 5, the Senate Judiciary Committee approved today for a New Jersey Federal District judgeship the nomination of Thomas F. Meaney, who had the sponsorship of the political machine of Mayor Hague of Jersey City, and was actively opposed by Governor Edison.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., June 24 -- A woman who lives in an ancient, unpainted cabin on the edge of the woods discharged a phrase last February that has stimulated a lot of people.

Richard A. Knight, the disbarred lawyer who has been described as a "thorn in the side of the legal profession of the city," walked into District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office at noon yesterday and surrendered on two Special Sessions "informations," accusing him of having sent annoying letters in the last eight months to a judge and numerous prominent lawyers.

Within two months some of the 20-year-old registrants due to enroll next Tuesday in the fifth selective service registration may be called for Induction into the Army, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, draft director here, revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Methods by which the volume and weight of beef, pork and mutton can be reduced at least one-half for shipment overseas are being developed by scientists of the Department of Agriculture. They are working in close cooperation with the technical departments of the larger packing companies and the scientific laboratory of the American Meat Institute.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- President Roosevelt today summoned a special meeting of the Pacific War Council tomorrow to receive a report from himself and Prime Minister Winston Churchill "on the offensive strategy of the war." The President and Mr. Churchill also invited a bipartisan Congressional delegation to meet with them to review the war planning.

When P.A. Green of the finance committee of The Lambs Servicemen's Morale Corps solicited members for fluids for its weekly dinners for soldiers and sailors he did not neglect William S. Hart, the two-gun movie actor now living on his California ranch.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 24 -- Emil (Bus) Mosbacher, Dartmouth skipper, and his crew of three sailed to victory in the final race of the fifteenth annual Intercollegiate Y.R.A. championship series off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today to give his college the McMillan Cup for another year.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Federal taxes other than those imposed by the new bill are expected by the Treasury to yield $16,500,000,000 for the next fiscal year. On top of this $22,424,000,000 total, the taxpayers would be assessed another $2,000,000,000 in increased social security levies if Administration recommendations are adopted.

The State Liquor Authority is "determined" to enforce the recently enacted Hollowell act covering wholesalers' discounts and any operator found in violation of its provisions "won't be in business," Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the authority, warned the industry yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- America's genius for organizing large-scale engineering work will determine the future freedom of the world, M.R. Sullivan, vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said today before the convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' Weekly Composite Index of Primary Market Prices of 889 series for the week ended June 20 registered the third consecutive decline. Seasonally lower prices for fruits and certain vegetables together with declining quotations for livestock and meats brought the index down 0.3 per cent to the lowest level since mid-April.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill outlined today their new strategy for offensive warfare to the Pacific War Council and Congressional leaders, who expressed the belief that the plan "will ultimately give us the results we want."

DETROIT, June 25 -- Members of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers pledged the resources of their industry today to aid the war program, voted to comply willingly with the various emergency restrictions which have virtually disrupted their business, and offered their service and experience in providing promptly any additional space needed for expanding government agencies and defense work.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Department store sales for the week ended June 20 were up 9 per cent compared with the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This came after a 3 per cent decline during the previous week.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Donald Nelson, War Production chief, told the Truman committee today that the United Nations are now outstripping the Axis in production, but still have a seven to eight year time-lag to overcome. American production, he said, had achieved such epic and heart-warming performances that the supply of raw materials had become the chief problem.

New York Stock Exchange memberships have been transferred from Arthur D. Weekes to Raymond H. Sigesmund, from Oliver F. Church to Lewis E. Tifft of Tifft Brothers, Springfield, Mass., from Philip W. Wrenn to George F. Hackl Jr. of Laird, Bissell Meeds, from the late Miles E. Browne to George A. Winsor and from Richard B.W. Hall to Milton Dorland Doyle of M.D. Doyle Co.

LONDON, June 25 -- The first non-confidence motion against Winston Churchill since he became Prime Minister two years ago was laid on the table in the House of Commons today by Sir John Wardlaw-Milne with, twenty other signatures, mostly of constant critics of the government.

Aviation Corporation Directors of the Aviation Corporation inspected yesterday a new plant in Toledo, but delayed dividend action until a meeting in New York next month. The earnings report was approved by the directors, but was ordered withheld

MILWAUKEE, June 25 -- Awards for distinguished publicity were made to sixty-nine libraries all over the country tonight at a special meeting of the annual conference of the American Library Association.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., June 25 -- A 77-year-old retired manufacturer is hard at work these days in a converted garage and chicken coop here, turning out "howlers" and switch boxes for the United States Navy under A-1-A government priorities for aluminum and glad of the opportunity to do "something to help win the war."
Selective Service Order The following notification was issued yesterday by the local Selective Service Board:

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Battle of Libya becamo the Battle of Egypt today as the clanking Axis legions of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel drove strongly eastward on the long trail to victory or to death.

Characterizing as "corny" the movement to draft Wendell L. Willkie for the Republican nomination for Governor started by Vote for Freedom, Roger W. Straus in a letter to Richard B. Scandrett Jr., co-chairman of that organization, declared yesterday that the latter's attack on Thomas E. Dewey as unfitted for the Governship in time of war was completely unjustified.

CHUNGKING, China, June 25 (U.P.) -- Chinese bombers have joined the Kiangsi battle for the first time, supporting troops who have retaken twelve miles of the Hangchow-Nanchang Railway and stalled the whole Japanese offensive southeast of Nanchang, it was reported here today.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- In a series of record votes today the Senate instructed its conferees to insist upon, its amendments to the 1942-43 appropriation bill for the Department of Agriculture.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 25 -- The reputation of another professional man came under attack in Westchester Surrogate's Court today in the contest over the will of the late Mrs. Anna H. Paton when proponents of the will undertook to prove that the New York widow cut off her brother, the late Dr. Elijah H. Siter of Philadelphia, with only $25,000 from her $1,300,000 estate because she considered him a heavy drinker and a wife-deserter.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have just read with greatest interest "Problems of Lasting Peace," by Herbert Hoover and Hugh Gibson. I hope it will be read by thousands of Americans.

Paul Shields of Shields Co. announced yesterday that the investment banking house had purchased 100 per cent control of La Consolidada, Mexican steel company, for a group of American financial and business men. There will be no public offering in this country but Mexican interests may join in the undertaking.

DETROIT, June 25 -- In keeping with the Federal Government's ain of closer cultural and trade ties with South and Central American countries, the American Institute of Architects has created a division of Pan-American affairs, it was announced today at the institute's convention.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday were 4.3 per cent below those in the preceding week but 13.7 per cent above the corresponding week of last year. The volume for the twenty-three cities for the last week, as reported yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $6,930,829,000, compared with $6,097,166,000 for the week in 1941.
WASHINGTON, June 25--The text of the new code of wartime practices for the American press, issued by the Office of Censorship today, follows:

TOKYO, June 25 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A communique reporting that Japanese naval and military forces in the Aleutian Islands had occupied Kiska June 7 and Attu a day later said today that "they are at present consolidating their position in neighboring islands."

Ten suits by stockholders of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey for recovery of losses allegedly suffered by the company through its pre-war agreements with I.G. Farbenindustrio, the German chemical trust, were disclosed in Supreme Court yesterday when the defendants moved to consolidate all the actions into one.

The German General Rommel, who is now threatening Egypt, seems to be one of those soldier's soldiers who win respect even from their enemies. If the man responsible for the handling of Russia's unconquerable millions is left out of the picture Erwin Rommel is the first military genius who has appeared in this war.
The Portuguese liner Serpa Pinto docked at a Staten Island pier just before noon yesterday with 677 refugees from Nazi-dominated countries of Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Sharp criticism of the war leadership of the United Nations was made on the floor of the Senate today, coupled with a defense of Winston Churchill against an attack on Britain's effort.

Ned E. Depinet has been elected president of RKO Radio Pictures, Inc., succeeding George J. Schaefer, who resigned on June 17, it was announced yesterday by Richard C. Patterson Jr., chairman of the board of Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, after an executive board meeting held at the corporation's offices at 1270 Sixth Avenue.

BERLIN, June 25 (from German broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The High Command said today that German and Rumanian troops attacking Sevastopol had gained further ground after bitter fighting house-to-house and in the forests.

Supervisory officials of the Pennsylvania Railroad were charged yesterday by Walter F. Brown, chairman of the board of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company with "sole responsibility" for examination of the motorman who drove the train that was wrecked in the Hudson Manhattan tubes in Jersey City on April 26.

A curious dilemma in which a spokesman for eighteen live poultry commission merchants declared they could keep the city's new $550,000 Live Poultry Terminal in Long Island City closed indefinitely because of their refusal to lease space in it was presented to the Board of Estimate yesterday afternoon.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., June 25 -- A youthful defense worker recently released from an Eastern Army camp, where he risked his life saving campmates from injury or death by an aircraft gun out of control, and two young girls were drowned tonight in the Delaware River opposite Fieldsboro when the motorboat in which the three were riding upset.

A nation-wide "Keep Well Crusade" will be started today by the Institute of Life Insurance, representing life insurance companies and agents throughout the country, with five rules for conserving man-hours of work for war production and to relieve a possible shortage of medical aid caused by doctors and nurses joining the armed forces.

The House Ways and Means Committee at the last minute has eliminated from the 1942 Revenue Act the provision requiring mandatory joint returns of husband and wife. In this action the committee has established for itself a consistent record of rejecting unfair and arbitrary provisions which would have complicated the progress of the bill through Congress.

Scrap rubber isn't the only treasure to be found in the attic since the Japanese took the East Indies, surprised scientists at the Museum of Natural History admitted yesterday as they surveyed the skull of Rhinoceros sondaicus.

Miss Barbara Gonzales, top ranking honor student of the Hunter High School graduating class, placed second in the nation and first in the city in a competition testing intelligence and achievement sponsored by the Phi Delta Kappa Society.

The United States is "barely holding its own" in the shipping race against Axis attacks, Rear Admiral George H. Rock, U.S.N., retired, declared last night. He was the main speaker at a presentation dinner of the Navy "E" for excellence in production to Gibbs Cox, Inc., naval engineers, of 1 Broadway and 21 West Street, held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The first vocational training school for refugees in the United States was opened by the ORT last night at 480 Canal Street with an enrollment of 160 students. Most of the students were professional men and artisans in the countries from which they come and are seeking to train themselves for jobs in war industries.

Democratic organizations of fifty-two of the sixty-two counties of New York State, either by formal election, or by statement of the county chairman after a canvass, have endorsed Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for the nomination for Governor.

MOSCOW, Friday, June 26 -- The Russian High Command announced early today that Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's forces in the Ukraine had abandoned Kupyansk, a railway junction about sixty miles southeast of Kharkov and well east of the northern Donets River.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 25 (AP) -- A British Headquarters communique said today:

Experts of the Office of Petroleum Coordinator are experimenting with several new plans to insure adequate supplies of gasoline for war plant employes and operators of trucks working on war contracts, it was disclosed yesterday as the Interstate Movers Tariff Bureau, Inc., representing 400 moving companies, complained that many of its members are unable to get gasoline for their trucks.

DENVER, June 25 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Guild attacked tonight what it termed "a vermin press'' which it described as being guilty of "such newspaper practices as tend to breed disunity and defeatism."

CAIRO, Egypt, June 25 (AP) -- General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, leading the Axis forces that have entered Egypt, was reported today to be using recently captured British and American tanks. The invading Axis column also includes a number of French tanks.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I. June 25 -- Mrs. Thomas Rudel of Cedar Creek and Mrs. Ruth Torgerson of Lakeville will meet tomorrow in the thirty-six-hole final round of the women's Long Island golf championship at the North Hempstead Country Club course.

Currently in the preparation stage but lacking as yet the funds necessary to carry it through, is a program for a nation-wide campaign to promote the printing industry. It would embrace all divisions of the industry, including the suppliers of paper, ink and other materials.

BALTIMORE, June 25 (AP) -- With two out in the ninth, George Staller and Sherry Robertson clouted successive homers, giving the Orioles a 2-to-1 triumph over Jersey City tonight. Until Staller batted, Frank Coombs had yielded only six scattered hits.
CHUNGKING, China, June 25 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command communique said today:

BOSTON, June 25 (AP) -- An Army-Navy relief game crowd of 25,093 saw the fireballing Mort Cooper score his tenth victory of the season and pitch his sixth shutout when the Cardinals blanked the Braves today, 4 -- 0, on his two-hit performance.

May Collections Off 0.31% Credit collections during May showed a decline of 0.31 per cent, according to the twenty local store index of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, issued yesterday. Nine stores had increases for the month.

Transfer and liquidation of the July position was the pivotal factor yesterday in a slight decline in the cotton futures market. Final prices for active months on the New York Cotton Exchange were 3 to 7 points under Wednesday's closing levels.

LONDON, June 25 (U.P.) -- Reliable reports from the Continent said tonight that Nazi-dominated Slovakia had deported half of its estimated 100,000 Jews to ghettos in occupied Poland and Russia and was attempting to become Europe's first "Jew-free country" by Autumn.

DETROIT, June 25 -- The Tigers exploded six runs in the eighth inning today to defeat the Red Sox, 7 to 3, for the first time in six starts. Detroit ended Rookie Cecil (Tex) Hughson's winning streak at four games.

Sheepskin importers disclosed yesterday that a shortage of these skins, which are used in a wide range of civilian uses, may develop in the near future because of the import regulations which become effective July 1. As only a small proportion of these skins are used for military purposes, it is believed that priorities on shipping space will relegate them to a low classification.

The field in the national professional championship was narrowed to the seeded group at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday, and the decks were cleared for heavy action from here in through Sunday.

New York City will have to be satisfied with an "extra Jap" casualty and a pledge of "protection" in lieu of a $4 traffic fine from a soldier whose Army duties made it impossible for him to appear in Traffic Court yesterday.

DUNRHAM, N.H., June 25 -- A call for unity among the Protestant, Catholic and Jewish churches on the settlement of post-war issues was sounded today as the biennial session of the General Council of Congregational Christian Churches came to a close.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 25 -- The renomination of Representative Hamilton Fish, who is under attack as a pre-war isolationist, would jeopardize the Republican ticket not only in Mr. Fish's district but in the State, Augustus W. Bennet, a leading opponent of the incumbent in the Republican primaries, declared tonight before the Young Men's Republican Club here.

After a lengthy hearing in which Park Commissioner Robert Moses scoffed at efforts to restore old Fort Clinton in the Aquarium Building in Battery Park and said the fort had "never fired a shot," the Board of Estimate adopted a resolution by a vote of 11 to 5 providing for demolition of the Aquarium.

The E.H. Harriman Memorial awards for railroad safety -- distinctions for which the railroads vie annually -- were apportioned yesterday by the American Museum of Safety in the Yale Club after speakers had emphasized that demands of war upon the railroads had made the task of maintaining their safeguards on life more arduous.

Statements by Congressional leaders after a conference with President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill, which could be interpreted as encouraging, helped the stock market yesterday to attempt to pierce the welter of gloom.

Legislative representatives of both, the State and city governments advocated yesterday the implementation of existing laws and the enactment of new ones to prevent subversive activities during the war and the "undermining of American democracy by discriminations based upon race, color or creeds."

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- All retailers were designated as "Class II" purchasers when buying finished piece goods of cotton, rayon or their mixtures covered by Maximum Price Regulation No. 127, under an amendment to the regulation issued by the Office of Price Administration today.

A.T. T. Action yesterday by two important subsidiaries of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in reducing dividend payments illustrated further the problem besetting the Bell System because of higher taxes and increased operating costs.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 25 -- A demonstration of trailing has just been given by an aboriginal tracker in the service of the Australian Army in the north, who traced a missing American pilot, forced down far from his base, as the flier wandered for several days through dense scrubland and swamps, according to a report reaching here today.
The colorful moving picture embodied in New York City's pedestrian traffic has experienced two important changes in the transformation period from peace to war.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Manufacturers of most types of cosmetics will be limited to two or three varieties for each line of products, the Toiletries and Cosmetics Division of the War Production Board revealed today.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Officials of the transportation division of the War and Navy Departments, and representatives of the War Production Board, Office of Defense Transportation and other interested agencies today heard Colonel E.S. Evans, Detroit industrialist, outline the advantages of the utility loader, a device for the general loading of freight in box cars.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 20 were 844,913 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 12,187 cars, or 1.5 per cent more than, for the preceding week; 40,626 cars, or 4.6 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 116,420 cars, or 16 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Mayor La Guardia extended his control over local defense activities in several directions yesterday, as the Board of Estimate received a report from Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick listing defense expenses that have absorbed $2,000,000, and asking for an additional $500,000.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- A War Department communique said today:

LONDON, June 25 -- Fresh from conferences with President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill earlier this week, Major Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived here today as commander of the United States forces in the "European theatre."

CAMP TAMIMENT, Pa., June 25 -- Herbert Agar, president of Freedom House, New York City, and editor of The Louisville Courier-Journal, urged tonight the drafting of Wendell L. Willkie for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination in New York, declaring that the politicians' plan to nominate "a hack in one party and a trimmer in the other."

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., June 25 -- Leaders in the invitation chess masters' tournament being conducted on the Municipal Pier shifted in and out of the higher places in the standing today as four adjourned games from the sixth round were completed and three in the seventh were decided.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman approved yesterday an offer of settlement, involving an immediate saving to the company of $653,744, made by defendants in an accounting suit brought by minority stockholders of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation.

Countess Mercati of the St. Regis gave a luncheon yesterday in the Viennese Roof of the hotel for King George II of Greece. Others in the party were Princess Rene de Bourbon Parme, Mr. and Mrs. Michael Arlen, Mrs. Henry Martyn Alexander, Mrs. Robert Woods Bliss, Princess Marthe de Bourbon, Princess Xenia, Prince Serge Obolensky and Algara de Terreros.
CLEVELAND, June 25 (AP) -- Al Smith, holding the opposition to five hits, scored his fourth straight victory today as the Indians beat the Athletics, 4 to 1, and swept the three-game series.
ROME, June 25 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today: ...

Minute Men and Minute Women collecting pledges for the Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign were exhorted last night to draw on reserve power for an intensive week-end effort to dedicate the city to go beyond the $1,900,000,000 in pledges originally set as the goal.

What Japan really means by the much publicized slogan "Asia for the Asiatics" is now being demonstrated in the territories which the Japanese armies have overrun. Quoting material from foreign broadcasts recorded in Washington, the Office of War Information reports that Japan is already looting the occupied areas systematically and forcing her "culture" and her economic controls on the people of those territories.

A German who had almost succeeded in obtaining work at one of this country's foreign military bases was faced yesterday with Federal charges carrying maximum penalties of fifteen years in prison. The man, George Calvin Mains, 39 years old, had been transported in a convoy to the vicinity of the unnamed base before his false statements were discovered, Federal Attorney Mathias F. Correa said.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) -- The Cubs swept their three-game series with the Phils today as Bill Lee limited the cellar-occupants to five hits to gain a 7 to 1 victory.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Roosevelt expressed gratification today that the New York town houses of his mother and himself in East Sixty-fifth Street had been acquired by Hunter College as "the Sarah Delano Roosevelt Inter-faith House."
STANTON, Del., June 25 -- Hal Price Headley's Anticlimax romped to an easy victory today in the fifth running of the mile and a furlong Diamond State Stakes at Delaware Park.

The first group of 101 under-privileged boys from the streets of the city's five boroughs left Grand Central Station at 9:15 o'clock yesterday morning for Fox Lair, Baker's Mills, N.Y., for a twenty-two-day rural vacation.

Of all the specialists in the fine art of keeping cool the most successful is the polar bear. And so it happens that his aquatic activities have inspired the newest beauty note of the sultry season --

LORAIN, Ohio, June 25 -- A strike involving 3,500 C.I.O. steel workers seeking wage adjustments closed the pipe mills of the National Tube Company today and threatened to involve the remainder of the concern's 10,000 employes.

A new hurdles record for a mile and three-quarters was set yesterday at Aqueduct when Lovely Night, owned and bred by Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark, won in the easiest sort of fashion by ten lengths in 3:12 3/5. This time is three seconds faster than the old mark, set by Arms of War, who was in yesterday's race and who was made the favorite by a crowd of 13,985.

After three physicians and their ''runner" in an East Sixty-third Street "abortion mill" had been found guilty in General Sessions late yesterday afternoon, a woman who was said to be the wife of one of the convicted men, struck one of the jurors in the face in the corridor outside the court room.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Revised codes of war practices for newspapers and radio broadcasters, extending or limiting the rules laid down Jan. 15, were issued by the Office of Censorship today. The changes were made necessary by various incidents and rulings which have come about since the newspapers and radio began their voluntary censorship as a contribution to winning the war.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Ten Democratic members of the House Military Affairs Committee filed a minority report today charging that the committee's recent criticism of the War Department was "biased and intemperate."

As a result of economic difficulties arising out of the war, education in China is deteriorating in quality, if not disintegrating, Dr. Marshall C. Balfour of the Rockefeller Foundation, who returned from the Far East a few weeks ago, told a United China Relief luncheon gathering yesterday in the Hotel Biltmore.

The National Association of Dress Manufacturers staged an official welcome for WPB limitation order L-85 yesterday with a fashion show in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Plaza. Accenting their genial acceptance of the order by individual war-bond pledges from the floor totaling $275,000, exhibitors even went the WPB restrictions one better.

A plea to Hollywood to produce pictures that provide an "honest interpretation of the war" and that will serve to promote a better understanding between the people of the United States and Great Britain as well as among our other Allies was made here yesterday by Sidney L. Bernstein, film adviser to the British Ministry of Information.

CHUNGKING, China, June 25 (U.P.) -- General Lo Cho-ying, commander of the Chinese troops who fought in Burma, said today that the Allies were massing strength to force the Japanese out of all Burma as soon as possible.

The forest fire observation towers that anglers and hunters have spotted during their trips through the Adirondacks or Catskills are going to serve another useful purpose after Wednesday. They will become lookout stations and form a cog in the Army's vast system of observation posts, it has been announced.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Dr. William J. Hale, president of the National Agrol Company and consultant to the Dow Chemical Company, told a House mining subcommittee today that he could produce in a year all the rubber the nation needed if $100,000,000, the men and priorities were allowed to him.

Members of the food trades, while welcoming the announcement of the formation of a national food industry advisory committee to work with the Office of Price Administration, were generally inclined to withhold comment yesterday pending some definite action by the new group.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 25 -- A joint committee that has been working four years on a plan to unite the Protestant Episcopal Church and the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. ended its semi-annual meeting today at the Hotel Dennis, here, in "complete accord" on basic principles, according to the Rev. Dr. William B. Pugh, Stated Clerk of the General Assembly of the Presbyterians and secretary of the committee.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- Lee (Buck) Ross, White Box right-hander, sent the Senators out of town without a run in their two games here by shutting them out, 2 to 0, on six hits today to avoid Sid Hudson's five-hit opposition. Johnny Humphries blanked the Senators on eight hits yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA., June 25 (AP) -- Bing Crosby, crooner, received $300,000 from Paramount Pictures last year to rank among the highest paid persons in the United States. His radio earnings were not shown.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., June 25 -- With a magic putting touch enabling her to defeat her opponent by 6 and 5, Miss Margaret Nichols of Hudson River, today sent Mrs. John F. Degener 3d of Apawamis to the sidelines as she went on to the final of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's twentieth annual championship at the Scarsdale Club today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 25 -- Edward A. Golden, independent producer, will film "Education for Death" by Gregor Ziemer for RKO release, the company announced today. Ziemer's work is based on his twelve years' experience in Nazi Germany.
CHICAGO, June 25 -- The world champion Yankees dominate the American League's All-Stars picked for the annual game with the National League All-Stars at New York's Polo Grounds on July 6.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night concluded the first of its two scheduled three-day seasons at the Lewisohn Stadium, presenting those old favorites, "Sylphides," the inevitable "Scheherazade" and "Gaite Parisienne."

AT UNITED NATIONS HEAD-QUARTERS, Australia, Friday, June 26 (AP) -- Allied planes swept both, northwest and northeast of Australia yesterday, attacking Japanese positions on Timor, New Britain and New Guinea, General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

NEWARK, June 25 (AP) -- A long fly by Gene Corbett with the bases loaded and one out in the ninth, scored Pitcher Tommy Byrne and gave the league-leading Bears a 4-to-3 victory over Syracuse today in the opener or a five-game series. The victory ended a three-game losing streak for the Bears.

Excess reserves of the thirty-three member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City fell $95,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $485,000,000, lowest level since March 2, 1938, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
LONDON, June 25 (AP) -- Note circulation, as reported by the Bank of England today, increased in the week ended on Wednesday L2,857,000 to a record high of L796,040,000.

A mystery man among National League pitchers this year with ten victories, the veteran Ray Starr was no mystery to the Dodgers last night. The Brooks hammered him for five straight hits and four runs in the third inning of the twilight-night game at Ebbets Field and this delighted a crowd of 24,020.

MOSCOW, June 25 -- Lieut. Col. Joseph A. Michela of Duluth, Minn., United States military attache in Moscow, accompanied by his assistant, Major Richard Park Jr. of Washington, returned today from, a visit to a sector of the front, where they were guests of Lieut. Gen. Ivan Fediuninsky, the victor of last Winter's battle for Tikhvin.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Spreading operations furnished much of the trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade today, especially in corn and rye. Cash interests bought July corn and sold the September at 2 5/8 to 2 3/4 cents a bushel difference, while the spread between the same deliveries of rye was 3 cents a bushel.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 25 -- It is understood on good authority the Argentine note to Germany protesting the torpedoing of the freighter Rio Tercero warns in polite but unmistakable language that future relations between Argentina and Germany depend on the satisfaction of three demands.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 25 -- James B. Schafer, 41 years old, self-styled "master-metaphysician," appeared here this morning before Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis in a habeas corpus proceeding and sought to be released from Sing Sing to which he was sentenced seven weeks ago to a term of from two and a half to five years for grand larcency.

BOSTON, June 25 (AP) -- Coming from far back in the last sixteenth, Arnold Hanger's Ubiquitious, a 13-1 outsider, just got up to win the featured $1,500 Patriot allowance mile for 3-year-olds today at Suffolk Downs.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, June 26 -- In preparation for bad news, Moscow spokesmen late last night began announcing that after five days of feeling out the Russian lines in the Kharkov sector the Germans had launched a major offensive along its entire length.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation and holdings of United States Government securities to be at the highest of the year to date, the latter showing an increase of $4,189,000 for the week.

PEARL HARBOR, June 25 (AP) -- The story of an American submarine that played a deadly game of hide-and-seek with segments of the Japanese fleet that attempted to invade Midway Island was disclosed today by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- King Peter II of Yugoslavia, prevented by the war from addressing his own Parliament, told Congress today that he was confident the United States would win the war and the peace after the war.

John J. Reddan, former police inspector, who has been a pivotal figure in the departmental trial of Lieutenant Charles O. Dannhauser, denied in the trial room at Brooklyn Police Headquarters yesterday that corruption had existed in the Fourteenth Division while he was in charge of the area.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Office of Price Administration has taken under control charges for rooms in hotels, boarding and rooming houses in twenty defense areas and set the levels at the charges prevailing in those communities for the thirty-day period ending April 1 for the majority of the areas.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Senate and return to the House today a $282,584,000 appropriation bill providing funds for work relief for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

Three works by American composers will be featured on the program of tonight's concert at the Lewisohn Stadium under the direction of Alexander Smallens, who will make his initial appearance of the Summer at the amphitheatre. These compositions comprise Copland's "Outdoor Overture," Schuman's "News Reel," which will receive its first performance in its new symphonic form, and Creston's "Pastorale and Tarantella."

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today a petition of the North American Company that the hearings which led to the commission's integration order of April 14 be reopened, but gave qualified approval to the plea made by two subsidiaries in the $2,300,000,000 system that new evidence be heard in their cases.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- Meat packers, needing slaughter material to supply the heavy lease-lend demands for pork and lard, kept prices of hogs firm today at levels only slightly under the sixteen-year peaks touched in mid-April. Best swine brought $14.55 a hundredweight, with buyers paying this price freely.

Once more John Golden finds himself compelled to extend the limited return engagement of "Claudia" at the St. James. First brought back here on May 24 for two weeks only at bargain prices, there has been a series of extensions, the most recent of which specified July 4 as the closing date.
The Commonwealth, of Massachusetts will offer for sale on next Monday an issue of $2,500,000 of notes. The obligations, dated July 14, 1942, will mature on July 13, 1943.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The difficulties of unifying the military conduct of the war by the United Nations are many and obvious. This conflict is global and the allies are fighting on the perimeter. One ally, Russia, is a belligerent in Europe but a neutral in the Far East.

A substantial group of individually owned luxury-type automobiles are being rented as taxicabs or used for towing and hauling purposes, an inspection yesterday of applications for X gasoline rationing cards indicated.

That a part of Arthur Koestler's "Spanish Testament" -- never published here -- that deals with his incarceration and sentencing to death during the Spanish civil war will be published by Macmillan Tuesday as "Dialogue With Death."

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 25 -- Harvey Lewis and son, Dick, of North Hempstead and Dr. John A. McCabe and son, John, Jr., of North Hills today tied for the Long Island father-and-son golf championship, each pair producing a net 71 on the Cherry Valley course.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- Miss Phyllis Otto, 17, of Atlantic, Iowa, and Miss Jeanne Cline, 18, of Bloomington, Ill., won their quarter-final matches in the women's Western open golf tournament today and qualified to meet Miss Marjorie Row, 20, of Detroit, and Miss Betty Jameson, 24, of San Antonio, Texas, tomorrow.

SEATTLE, June 25 (AP) -- First eye-witness accounts of the Japanese bombing of Dutch Harbor in the Aleutians, made public today, disclosed how heavy anti-aircraft fire, and even rifle fire, drove off the attackers and that the enemy machine-gunners strafed fleeing civilians.
NEW YORK Mrs. Willing Spencer of Newport is visiting Mrs. John R. Bradley at the Waldorf-Astoria.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 25 -- Chief of Government Fierce Laval, back at Vichy from Paris, which he seems to consider his headquarters, has struck a snag, according to private advices reaching here tonight. It is a German snag and it follows fast upon M. Laval's broadcast on Monday committing official France to Axis policies.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- A textile company which reduced wage rates 15 per cent while a demand for a wage increase was pending before the War Labor Board today promised to restore the former rate upon demand by the board. This was the first time that a wage cut was put into effect while the board was considering a dispute which threatened a strike in a war industry.
LONDON, June 25 -- The stock market today was quiet with most issues lower where changed. Egyptian unified bonds dropped to L80. Oil shares closed a shade lower.

Officers of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, submitted to a group of section leaders last night a "four-point victory program" approved by Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O., and designed to promote sound labor relations between the Board of Transportation and the 35,000 civil service employes of the city's unified transit lines.
It is not weather alone that shrouds the Aleutian Islands in a fog. An obscurity of official comment also veils them.
